title: TUDOR CITY ACCORD GIVES TENANTS TWO PARKS
description: Tenants at Tudor City, the classic complex of buildings near the United Nations, now own two small parks that were once threatened with development. The action ends a conflict that dragged on 15 years.

title: U.N. PARLEY AGREES TO PROTECT OZONE
description: A conference on protection of the earth's protective ozone layer has reached an agreement in principle to freeze and ultimately to reduce production and consumption of chemicals thought to deplete the ozone.

title: No Euphemisms: Call Them 'Orphans'
description: The word ''orphan'' to describe children who have lost one or both parents early has an old-fashioned ring. It seems as out of date as the black stockings and high shoes worn by inmates of asylums that used to take up city blocks and loom large in the countryside. As adult mortality caused by infectious diseases declined, and parents lived long enough to raise their children, the number of orphans dropped so sharply (from 16.3 percent of the total population in 1920 to 5.4 percent in 1953) that they became what one statistician called ''a vanishing phenomenon.''

title: 'Postscript,' on Channel 13, Looks at Refugees in U.S.
description: In the wake of war and disaster, more than 700,000 Southeast Asians have immigrated to the United States. ''Postscript to a War: The Indo-Chinese in America'' looks at a few. The 30-minute film, on Channel 13 at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow, has a skeptical intelligence and a barbed point of view.

title: Ready for the World
description: Ready for the World and the System, two funk bands, will perform at 8 P.M. Sunday at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street (496-7070). Tickets are $20.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (ARKANSAS) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after extraordinary charges of $2,123,000 for the quarter and $367,000 for the 6 months. The company converted to stock form in April 1986. The company also said that during the second quarter of fiscal 1987, First Federal realized a gain from the sale of loans and mortgage-backed securities of $4.8 million.

title: TRADE BILL IS PASSED BY HOUSE
description: Despite the opposition of the Reagan Administration, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a sweeping trade bill that demands America's trading partners open their markets to American products and requires retaliation if they refuse.

title: A WALK IN THE PARK ATTRACTS TOP FIELD
description: Vyacheslav Ivanenko had a sore back. Watching television one day, he learned that walking would be good physical therapy. So he tried it, walking to and from his job as a textile worker in Siberia, a distance of about two and half miles.

title: SoHo Festival
description: More than 100 exhibitors will offer food, clothing, pottery, records and other items tomorrow at the 10th SoHo Festival on Prince Street, from West Broadway to Avenue of the Americas. The festival, sponsored by the SoHo Center for Arts and Education, runs from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. If it rains, it will take place on Sunday. Information: 228-2882.

title: 717 Jews Left Soviet In April, Group Reports
description: The National Conference on Soviet Jewry announced today that 717 Jews had emigrated from the Soviet Union in April, making the total the highest for any month since July 1981, when 779 Jews were allowed to leave.

title: Early to Rise
description: Tom Trebelhorn of the Milwaukee Brewers is 18-3 in his first full season managing a major league team. The best records by rookie managers since 1900 (minimum of 100 games for the season):

title: Field of 17 Suggests a Wide-Open Race
description: Seventeen 3-year-olds were entered today for the 113th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs Saturday, a race so close on paper that nearly half the entrants appear to have a reasonable chance of victory.

title: The Scandal Becomes a Conspiracy
description: Suddenly, after five months of maneuver and study, someone has admitted criminal guilt for arming the Nicaraguan rebels at a time when Congress prohibited it. Carl Channell, a flourishing fund-raiser for conservative causes, has confessed to misusing a tax-exempt organization as a conduit for arms and has identified Oliver North, formerly of the National Security Council staff, as a fellow conspirator.

title: Pollock-Krasner Home Donated to Stony Brook
description: The Long Island home of Jackson Pollock and his wife, Lee Krasner, has been donated by Ms. Krasner's estate to the Stony Brook Foundation of Stony Brook, L.I., for preservation as a museum, library and study center. The house and a studio, on two acres of land, is in the Springs, a small village at the eastern end of Long Island, where the two painters settled in 1945. Jackson Pollock died in 1956.

title: In a South Seas Eden, a First Taste of Race Strife
description: This South Pacific island group is often described as a paradise, not only for its beautiful beaches but also for the harmony of its ethnically divided population.

title: Market Place; Money Center Banks Favored
description: MONEY center bank stocks have been relatively unpopular investments this year.

title: DOMINICAN ASKS POLITICAL REFUGE
description: Salvador Jorge Blanco, a former President of the Dominican Republic, asked for asylum today at the Venezuelan Embassy here, where he took refuge after a court issued a warrant for his arrest, officials said.

title: STAGE: 'JERKER,' ON AIDS
description: ROBERT CHESLEY'S two-character drama, ''Jerker, or the Helping Hand,'' is a cry of anguished solidarity from the heart of San Francisco's homosexual world, a segment of society where the AIDS epidemic has taken an especially devastating toll.

title: OGDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,638,000.

title: MAGNA CARTA GOES ON DISPLAY IN PHILADELPHIA
description: It is a single sheet of parchment, bigger than an average-size business letter but smaller than a wide-measure computer printout. Its Latin script, so arcane to modern eyes that it might as well be cuneiform, is blotted out here and there by water marks. But it established the rule of law in England and was a direct precursor of the United States Constitution.

title: NUCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: The shares outstanding were restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split in June 1986.

title: BROWN TRANSPORT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOETZ LAWYER TRIES COMPLEX LEGAL TACTIC BY ATTACKING SHOOTING VICTIM'S CREDIBILITY
description: The issue was whether a tan down-filled vest with a bullet hole in the back and three screwdrivers - all found on a downtown IRT train shortly after Bernhard H. Goetz shot four young men - would be allowed into evidence in Mr. Goetz's trial.

title: Next U.N. Official From U.S.: Political Flair
description: Joseph V. Reed, who is soon to become the top-ranking American in the United Nations Secretariat, knows the value of popularity here.

title: NEW ENGLAND CRITICAL CARE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $251,000.

title: SCRIPPS HOWARD BROADCASTNG reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $21,974,000 from the sale of the company's investment in Fairfield and Bridgeport, Conn., CATV systems and the Tulare, Cal., CATV system. c-Net loss

title: Black Mountain Music
description: A concert of music composed at Black Mountain College, which had a brief existence neaeAsAsvivie,e.C.C between 1933 and 1957, is to be held tomorrow at 8 P.M. on the campus of Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., in Dutchess County. The concert includes works by John Cage, Lou Harrison and Stefan Wolpe. Admission is free. Information: (914) 758-6822. To get there, take the Taconic State Parkway north, Route 199 east through the village of Red Hook and Route 9G north to the campus.

title: COHERENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Net income

title: Dutch, but Not German
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH GIVES PLAN TO CUT INCOME TAX
description: A combination of Federal tax changes and a small city tax cut will save New Yorkers a total of $305 million on personal income taxes next year, city officials said yesterday.

title: GOODY PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net of $101,000 from discontinued operations. Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 1, 1986. The company said the 1987 results reflects a charge of $486,000 (pre-tax) for early retirement program. The company also said the 1986 results are restated to reflect J. & P. B. Meyers as a discontinued operation as well as adoption, in December 1986, of FAS 87 accounting for pension benefits.

title: LAND VALUES STARTING TO RISE AS BUYERS EMERGE FOR FARMS
description: The country's major agricultural lenders are beginning to sell much of the vast acreage they have been taking over from troubled farmers for the last few years.

title: A SENSE OF RELIEF AND ANTICIPATION
description: Denis Potvin and most of the Islanders reacted to another narrow escape as if it was an everyday event.

title: ARROW ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain on the sale of property of $7,584,000 and equity in the earnings of affiliated company of $1,177,000. c-Net loss and after equity in earnings of affiliated company of $742,000.

title: U.S. AND JAPANESE TAKE JOINT ACTION ON INTEREST RATES
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, seeking to steady the dollar, told President Reagan today that the Bank of Japan would guide interest rates lower.

title: Rep. McKinney Hospitalized
description: Representative Stewart B. McKinney was listed in very serious condition on a respirator in the intensive care unit of the Washington Hospital Center today, a week after he was admitted to the hospital for tests after suffering gastroenteritis. His spokeswoman, Diane Brockett, said Mr. McKinney's doctors thought his respiratory tract infection was clearing up when he began having difficulty breathing on Wednesday and was returned to a respirator. Mr. McKinney, a nine-term Congressman, represents southern Fairfield County.

title: STUDY HINTS AT BLOOD AS A CLUE TO THE RISK OF BABY CRIB DEATH
description: Doctors may be able to identify some babies who are at high risk of sudden infant death syndrome by testing their blood, according to a report published today.

title: JURY HEARS TAPE OF 2 POLICEMEN TAKING MONEY
description: Shortly after he and his partner took $204 from two Brooklyn drug sellers, a New York City police officer remarked: ''It's so nice. I like this kind of day,'' according to a secretly recorded tape played yesterday for the jury in his corruption trial.

title: WISCONSIN ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that latest quarter earnings were affected by lower gas deliveries and a 2.8 percent electric rate reduction that went into effect Jan. 1.

title: CONVICTION UPHELD AGAINST U.S. JUDGE
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the perjury conviction of Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr., the second sitting Federal judge ever convicted.

title: COTTON STATES LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $249,465. c-After a capital loss of $17,569. Year-ago results are restated to correct an error in computation of future benefits.

title: MINISCRIBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
South Africa Disperses Protesters
description: Riot police officers used tear gas today to break up a student protest in Johannesburg, and an ABC News crew was seized while filming at a campus near Cape Town.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After gains on investments of $46,774,000 for the latest quarter and $7,954,000 for the year-ago period.

title: INHERITANCE OF 'INSIDER'S PRICE' UNDER RENT CONTROL IS BARRED
description: When a tenant in a rent-controlled apartment dies, so do all legal rights to the ''insider's price'' offered during a cooperative conversion, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

title: PESTICIDES CALLED MANAGEABLE EVIL
description: The head of the Food and Drug Administration told a House subcommittee today that imported fruits and vegetables adulterated with pesticides were a problem but that ''the U.S. food supply is safe.''

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''I do hope Baryshnikov gets a good home,'' a worried Austine Hearst said Monday evening at Christie's, where the New York City Opera spring auction party was in progress. This particular Baryshnikov, it should be explained, is a 6-year-old Arabian gelding that Mrs. Hearst contributed to the auction. Bidding was as spirited as the horse appeared to be - it did not attend but was viewed on video, eliciting oohs and aahs. The final bid, $4,000, was made by John Pomerantz, president of Leslie Fay Inc.

title: AGS COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WASHINGTON TALK: The Trade Bill; Speaking of Imports, What's That Sitting In Your Parking Spot?
description: Not only does Richard A. Gephardt not own a foreign car. He prefers not even to set foot in one.

title: TALK TO REPUBLICANS BY JUSTICE O'CONNOR TO BE RECONSIDERED
description: Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor is scheduled to give a talk in late May at the Supreme Court to a group of visiting Republican contributors, but has decided to ''reexamine'' the appointment after learning that the visitors represent a political organization, the Court's press officer said today.

title: Bid for Taft Is Sweetened
description: The limited partnership that is bidding for the Taft Broadcasting Company has sweetened its offer to $157 a share, from $155, and the company's board has authorized negotiations to complete a merger.

title: AUCTIONS
description: HUGH M. HEFNER is selling two major Abstract Expressionist paintings -Willem de Kooning's ''Woman'' from 1953 and Jackson Pollock's ''Number 26, 1950,'' a large drip painting from the artist's most prolific period - in a contemporary-art sale at 7 P.M. Monday at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. These paintings and works by Arshile Gorky, Hans Hofmann, Franz Kline, Jasper Johns, Roy Lichtenstein and David Smith are among the most important of the 84 offerings in a sale that is expected to bring in $14.2 million to $19 million.

title: IN 'ALL MY SONS' ROLE, A CHANCE TO PAY A DEBT: JAMEY SHERIDAN
description: AS a boy Chris Keller was an Eagle Scout, as a soldier a courageous and selfless leader and now, as a young man learning the family business, he is an honorable worker, a compassionate son and a loyal friend. ''You're the only one I know who loves their parents,'' observes his fiancee.

title: A Spring House Tour
description: Some residents of Greenwich Village, SoHo and Chelsea will open their doors on Sunday starting at 11 A.M. for visitors taking part in the Village Community School Spring House Tour. The tour, which is self-guided, includes stops at two houses, three lofts and one apartment; interiors range from folk and country decors to Victorian designs. The tour costs $25; proceeds will benefit a scholarship fund at the Village Community School. Information: 691-5146.

title: MONITERM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $233,412. c-Net loss

title: N.B.A. Playoffs; Mavericks Eliminated By Sonics
description: Tom Chambers scored 31 points and Xavier McDaniel had 29, leading the Seattle SuperSonics to a 124-98 victory over the Dallas Mavericks tonight to take the Western Conference semifinal series, three games to one.

title: QUIXOTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: AFFILIATES OPPOSING NEW PLAN FOR LONGER CBS NEWS
description: CBS News plans to unveil a proposed hourlong version of its evening news broadcast to its affiliated stations later this month, but the proposal is already meeting strong resistance from the stations and some network executives, according to CBS officials.

title: GOODEN RETURNS TO SHEA BUT SAYS LITTLE
description: Dwight Gooden, four weeks of treatment for cocaine abuse behind him and a lifelong recovery ahead, returned to the Mets and Shea Stadium yesterday and acknowledged that he had ''made a mistake.'' However, under the advice of his doctor, the Mets would not let Gooden talk about his cocaine problems. General Manager Frank Cashen and the doctor also declined to discuss the matter.

title: APPROACH MADE TO THORNBURGH TO DIRECT F.B.I.
description: Former Gov. Dick Thornburgh of Pennsylvania has been approached by the Reagan Administration to become Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, White House officials said today.

title: Toshiba, Norway Concern Assailed in Soviet Sale
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has told members of Congress that a Japanese corporation and a state-owned Norwegian company have violated Western export controls by selling technology to the Soviet Union that makes submarines run more quietly.

title: ROBINS, A H CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ACME-CLEVELAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $209,000 and $8,682,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $5,015,532 for the quarter and $5,204,770 for the 6 months.

title: Texaco Lawyers Bungled Pennzoil Case; Ridiculous Award
description: To the Editor:

title: Pinetop Perkins
description: Pinetop Perkins, a blues pianist, will perform at midnight Sunday at the Limelight, 660 Avenue of the Americas, at 20th Street (807-7850). Admission is $12.

title: MORGAN PRODUCTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects a change in accounting methods for certain inventory costs at distribution centers, resulting in a cumulative increase in net income of $571,000.

title: Letter: On Alaska; Rigging Destruction of an Arctic Refuge
description: To the Editor:

title: NORDIQUES RALLY TO TIE SERIES AT 3-3
description: Normand Rochefort, a defenseman, capped a three-goal comeback in the third period with a 20-foot wrist shot with 4 minutes 37 seconds to play and the Quebec Nordiques defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 3-2, tonight.

title: Peddler On the Roof
description: Joel Schiavone, a wealthy real estate developer who serves as chairman of the New Haven Nighthawks' advisory board, is not one of your more reserved businessmen. In an effort to bolster season ticket sales, Schiavone, who owned the Amercan Hockey League club for four years and retained his devotion to it after selling it to the Los Angeles Kings in 1983, went so far as to dress up as the Easter Bunny at a playoff game last month.

title: BAKER CUTS LATIN-LENDING REQUEST
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has ordered a severe reduction in planned American contributions to a major multinational lender to Latin America, according to Administration officials and officials of the lender.

title: METS REGAIN LOOK OF TITLE WINNERS
description: Often the sports world is criticized for not having enough to do with sports and too much to do with financial, legal and other peripheral matters. And for most of yesterday, that was the case at Shea Stadium.

title: Knight Questionable
description: Ray Knight, the Baltimore Orioles third baseman, is listed as questionable for the weekend series with Chicago White Sox. Knight is scheduled to be examined today by doctors in Baltimore following his release yestrerday afternoon from a Kansas City hospital, said Rick Vaughn, an Orioles spokesman. Knight suffered a mild concussion Tuesday night after being accidentally tagged in the head at second base during a game with the Royals.

title: ATLANTIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $188,000 for the latest quarter and $110,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: U.S. ISSUES RULES MAKING IT EASIER FOR ALIENS TO OBTAIN LEGAL STATUS
description: The Reagan Administration, in a reversal, today announced policy changes that will make it easier for thousands of illegal aliens to obtain legal status under the new immigration law.

title: PHILIPS SEES OIL PRICE RISE
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company's chairman, C.J. Silas, said that oil prices, which fell sharply last year, should gradually increase in 1987. ''We expect oil prices to continue an upward trend, but the improvement will be gradual - and will probably be somewhat erratic during the second and third quarters,'' Mr. Silas told the annual meeting.

title: AT THE NEW GARBAGE DUMPS, TECHNOLOGY AND STRICT RULES
description: It was not long ago that the town dump was nothing more than a convenient hollow where trash was indiscriminately discarded. Modern environmental rules and waste-management technology have changed that.

title: Albany Weighs Urging Garbage Scow's Return
description: The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation - which regulates landfills and incineration plants throughout the state - is studying whether it has the legal authority to invite a barge full of commercial garbage from Islip, L.I., to return to New York, according to a spokesman, R. W. Groneman.

title: WYNN'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $113,000, or 3 cents a share. The company said its sales of air- conditioning kits to Mazda will be reduced by some $20 million during the second half of 1987 as Mazda begins to package its own air-conditioning kit for its imported 626 model vehicle.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The idea for a dog hairdressing salon did not surprise me. I must admit, I did not anticipate the idea of creating a cafe inside a tour bus.'' - Valery Andreyev, chief of the Cooperative Department in Riga, Latvia. [ A8:2. ]

title: GLITTERING PREMIERES AND DARING REVIVALS WOO DANCEGOERS
description: BREAKFAST tables throughout the city would be centers of pleasurable dither this morning if dance audiences were the heroines of 18th-century romantic novels. The fare on this first weekend of the spring dance season amounts to the fullest of ballroom dance-cards crammed with the names of handsome strangers and familiar friends.

title: ST PAUL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $14,747,000 and a tax credit of $10,519,000. c-Includes losses on investments of $2,988,000 and a tax credit of $1,159,000.

title: RJR NAVISCO PROMOTION
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said yesterday that Robert J. Carbonell, senior executive vice president, had been named to the additional post of chief administrative officer. Mr. Carbonell is also chairman of RJR Nabisco's Del Monte Corporation.

title: Folk Music and Dance Of Ethiopia at 2 Sites
description: The folk music and dance of Ethiopia will be presented by the Adei Abeba Folklore Ensemble this weekend. Tonight at 8, the group will be at Avery Fisher Hall; tickets are $15, $20 and $25. Information: 874-2424.

title: NORTH-WEST TELCOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AIDS-Free Is Easier To Say Than to Prove
description: To the Editor:

BAKER, MICHAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend payable at a date to be determined to shareholders of record April 22.

American Slain by Guerrillas Is Buried in Nicaragua Town
description: Benjamin Ernest Linder, an American volunteer killed in an attack by the Nicaraguan insurgents, was buried with honors here today among the people he was trying to help.

title: ATHLONE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $578,000, or 25 cents a share.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Brazil Devalues Its Currency
description: Just two days after the appointment of a new Finance Minister, Brazil tonight devalued its currency as part of an austerity program aimed at controlling inflation, stimulating exports and ''re-establishing a dialogue'' with the country's foreign creditors.

title: IN SOVIET, CAPITALISM (BUT DON'T CALL IT THAT)
description: It struck Leonid Melamed several years ago, as he read the desperate personal advertisements in Riga's evening newspaper, that loneliness was a serious problem in the Soviet Union. More recently, it came to him that it might also be a business.

title: Jeans Maker Shifts
description: Guess? Inc. said that its board had voted to oust the three founders of Jordache Enterprises Inc. from its board effective June 14. Guess?, which is involved in a complicated legal battle against Jordache, said that Maurice Marciano would replace Avi Nakash as chairman of the sportswear company, while Armand Marciano would assume the titles of executive vice president and secretary from Ralph Nakash and Joe Nakash, respectively.

title: BROWN HOLDS LEAD IN LAS VEGAS GOLF
description: Ken Brown of England maintained his first-round, single-stroke lead in the Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational tournament today without swinging a club.

title: Wendy's Posts Loss in Quarter
description: Wendy's International Inc., battered by a costly retreat from its ill-fated breakfast program, today reported a loss in the first quarter.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $462,000 for the quarter and $707,000 for the 6 months.

title: Reagan Backs Unions in Court Over Use of Fees
description: The Reagan Administration, angering some of its supporters, sided with labor unions today in a major court battle over the legality of unions' use of compulsory fees paid by nonunion employees.

title: BIG SOVIET WHEAT DEAL SET AT SUBSIDIZED RATES
description: After months of urging by the Reagan Administration, the Soviet Union has agreed to buy four million metric tons of American wheat at subsidized rates.

title: TENNECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $71,000,000. The company said that latest quarter earnings were adversely affected by lower energy prices, resulting in a decline in the operating income of its energy businesses to $169 million, compared with $218 million a year earlier.

title: Prices to Farmers Rise
description: The average prices received by farmers for raw products rose 1.6 percent in April from a revised March index and were above the level a year earlier for the second consecutive month, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: BREWERS SUFFER 3D LOSS
description: Reggie Jackson hit a two-run homer, and Dave Stewart and Jay Howell combined on a three-hitter today as the A's beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 4-1, handing the Brewers just their third loss in April.

title: Crew Saved Off Canada
description: All 24 crewmen from a sinking merchant vessel were safely aboard a Canadian research ship today after a harrowing night in high seas, officials said. The 558-foot Skipper One, registered in Panama, radioed a distress call Wednesday from about 350 miles southeast of Newfoundland, The research vessel Hudson, 45 miles away at the time, met the Skipper One crew late Wednesday, the search and rescue center at St. John's reported.

title: LOYOLA CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Loyola converted to stock form in December.

title: MODULAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: AT SOTHEBY'S, MANAGING THE BUSINESS OF ART
description: Most auction devotees would not recognize Diana D. Brooks. She has never stood behind an auction room lectern, has never been heard rattling off numbers to a room full of bidders. Nor has she spent her days examining paintings or furniture. Indeed, Ms. Brooks - the president of Sotheby's and the first woman to head a major auction house - is neither an auctioneer nor an art expert. Not yet.

title: With Guidry Comes Change
description: The clubhouse conversations have slowly begun to turn toward Ron Guidry, the free-agent pitcher who could officially become a Yankee again as early as Friday. But the rising anticipation among the players is mixed with a certain degree of apprehension, because Guidry's eventual arrival will likely mean a roster move on a pitching staff that has been generally exceptional.

title: Suns Plead Not Guilty
description: Nine people, including three current members of the Phoenix Suns and one former player, pleaded not guilty today to charges stemming from a drug investigation by Phoenix police.

title: FREE AGENTS CAN HEAD HOME
description: As if the Mets haven't had enough complications in their effort to duplicate last season's torrid start, they may very well encounter another before the weekend is over. They are in the middle of a series with Montreal, and before they are done, they may see Tim Raines in the Expos' lineup for the first time this season.

title: 'SHOPPING' FOR JUDGES IS CURBED
description: The judges of Federal District Court in Manhattan decided yesterday to end a longtime system of ''judge shopping'' that allowed some defendants to select lenient judges for sentencing.

title: U.S. Microchip Industry Needs Reconfiguring; Value of Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Shaheed Parvez, Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street (206-1050). This young Indian musician, making his first New York appearance, plays the sitar in a style that has little to do with the bravura pyrotechnics of Ravi Shankar. All Indian instrumental music is rooted in the ancient traditions of Indian vocal music, but the school of players to which Mr. Parvez belongs particularly emphasizes voice-like phrasing and lyricism. He will be accompanied by Vijay Ghate, a tabla drummer. The concert begins tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $10 at the door. Wayne Shorter Quintet and Jack DeJohnette's Special Edition with Lester Bowie, Beacon Theater, 74th and Broadway (496-7070). Some people like Wayne Shorter's recent recorded music, a commingling of computer-assisted synthesizer systems with the saxophonist-composer's characteristically oblique lyricism. Some people don't. But on his recent visits to New York, Mr. Shorter was playing with such inventive intensity that listeners forgot all about those recent records. The drummer Jack DeJohnette's band, with the ferocious Greg Osby on alto saxophone and Lester Bowie's thrust-and-jab trumpet, should get things off to a rousing start tomorrow night at 8. Reserved seat tickets are $18.50 at the Beacon Theater box office, at all Ticketron outlets (399-4444), and through Teletron (947-5850).

title: BROADWAY
description: NOTHING tickles Joseph Papp more than unexpected choices and odd marriages. Well, he's done it again. For the 1987 New York Shakespeare Festival season in Central Park, he has captured Charles Ludlam, the comic genius of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, to direct ''Titus Andronicus,'' Shakespeare's grisliest melodrama. And to portray Richard II, Shakespeare's poet-king, he has chosen Peter MacNicol, best remembered as the naive writer Stingo in the film ''Sophie's Choice,'' and the molasses-mouthed lawyer in Beth Henley's stage comedy ''Crimes of the Heart.''

title: FILM: 'MY LIFE AS A DOG,' FROM SWEDEN
description: ''My Life as a Dog'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 24. The film opens today at Lincoln Plaza 2, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: MEDALIST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $230,000.

title: Ford-Nissan Study
description: The Ford Motor Company and Japan's Nissan Motor Company said they are planning for the first time to study the feasibility of developing and producing a vehicle together in North America. The two auto makers said that if such a vehicle were developed, it would not compete with any of the companies' existing models. The companies will investigate a range of issues - including product details, possible plant sites in the United States and Canada, and possible parts suppliers - to determine if the vehicle could be built and marketed profitably in North America. The study could take up to one year to complete.

title: Cases of Tuberculosis Rise; Possible Tie to AIDS Is Cited
description: Cases of tuberculosis in the United States are up significantly for the first time since 1953 and the spread of AIDS may be partly to blame, the Federal Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: Speed Up the Deportation of Ex-Nazis
description: Karl Linnas illegally entered the United States in 1951. It took 36 years to deport him to face possible execution in the Soviet Union as a Nazi war criminal. Why did it take so long to deport a man whose crimes a Federal court called ''horrific'' and ''monstrous''? What can be done to prevent similar delays in the 25 other Justice Department cases pending against accused Nazis as well as 520 other open cases?

title: Soviet Business: New View
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has authorized new types of nongovernmental business to increase the supply of goods and services. Here are some of the new activities.

title: BARRY WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects a gain of about $800,000 from the sale of a building and an increase of about $390,000 from adoption of new accounting rules for pension costs. c-Included non-recurring income of about $400,000 from an insurance settlement.

title: MICROSEMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-After an after-tax gain on the sale of an interest in an unaffiliated electronics company of $213,000.

title: WRITER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Avalanche Starts
description: Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, wrote a letter last Oct. 17 to Carl R. (Spitz) Channell, fund-raiser for the Nicaraguan contras. ''Dear Spitz,'' he wrote, ''. . . You have set both a standard and a challenge to which we must all aspire if we are to be successful in Central America.''

title: INTERNATIONAL GAME TECHOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and the quarter includes $9.5 million in special pre-tax charges to reduce inventory and fixed assets carrying values. The company said that excluding its equity in the earnings of Syntech International Inc., its net for the latest quarter was $716,000, or 13 cents a share, and its year-ago second quarter loss was $6,902,000.

title: AMERICAN HEALTH COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $204,000 for the quarter and $415,000 for the year.

title: MUSIC: PERAHIA PLAYS AND CONDUCTS MOZART
description: THERE was a time, fortunately long past, when most pianists approached Mozart as if he were a porcelain figurine, handling him delicately so as not to crack the vitreous surface. Murray Perahia attacked two Mozart piano concertos at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday evening as if intent on making sure he could not be accused of that ancient crime. His performances of the concertos in G (K. 453) and C minor (K. 491) consistently stressed a muscular, at times almost violent, style of pianism that threw into prominence the bony structures of these works, though often at the expense of beautiful tone and gallant charm.

title: HERTZ NAMES PRESIDENT
description: The Hertz Corporation, a unit of the Allegis Corporation, said yesterday that Craig R. Koch, general manager of the domestic rent-a-car division, had been named president and chief operating officer of Hertz. The polition of president had been vacant since 1983. Frank A. Olson continues as chairman and chief executive of the New York-based company.

title: Texaco Lawyers Bungled Pennzoil Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank Morgan Quartet
description: The saxophonist Frank Morgan is leading a quartet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN FILTRONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split in August 1986.

title: INFINITY BROADCASTING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $549,000 from early retirement of debt.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WHEN the Stanhope Hotel on Fifth Avenue completed its yearlong renovation last December, much of the publicity focused on its revamped dining room and its new chef, Michel Fitoussi, who was recruited from 24 Fifth Avenue. Those with good memories and deep pockets may remember Mr. Fitoussi as the chef at the celebrated but short-lived Palace, on East 58th Street, the priciest restaurant in New York in the early 1980's.

title: ZEHNTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $13,000 and $137,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Hannelore Baron, Artist, 61; Known for Symbolic Collages
description: Hannelore Baron, an artist known for her collages and box assemblages, died of cancer Tuesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 61 years old and lived in Riverdale.

title: Contel's Chief Quits Over 'Differences'
description: The Contel Corporation, which recently moved to cancel a merger with the Communications Satellite Corporation, said yesterday that its president and chief executive, John N. Lemasters, had resigned after ''differences in both management philosophy and operating policy.''

title: NEW YORK SEEKS TO LURE PROJECT STUDYING ATOMS
description: The State Urban Development Corporation yesterday approved spending up to $3 million to prepare proposals to persuade the Federal Government to build a major atomic research project in New York State.

title: Two of Zion's Doctors Accused in Her Death
description: Two physicians at New York Hospital were accused by the state yesterday of incompetence or gross neglect at the opening hearing into the death of an 18-year-old woman at the hospital two years ago.

title: GIANTS' TOP PICK LEARNED LESSON IN JAIL
description: Mark Ingram was a model youth from a model family.

title: POPE, IN GERMANY, ASSAILS ABORTION AND MERCY KILLING
description: Pope John Paul II, arriving for the start of a five-day tour of West Germany, called on the nation's bishops today to step up their efforts to halt the spread of abortions and mercy killings, comparing such actions to the killing of invalids and the terminally ill under the Nazi regime.

title: COMDIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $115,000. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Firestone to Move
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it would relocate its corporate headquarters to Chicago from Akron beginning in the second half of the year. A company spokesman said Chicago offers better transportation facilities and as a major center for finance and retail activities the city is of increasing importance to the company's operations.

title: LENGTHY TALKS PRECEDED U.S. - JAPAN RATE MOVES
description: The complementary interest-rate moves disclosed today by the United States and Japan followed long discussions between the two nations' central banks during the last month, Federal Reserve and other monetary officials said today.

title: ACME ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in March.

title: Mother's Day Crafts
description: Crafts fans can choose from an array of items the next two weekends and help benefit a restoration fund at the same time, at the eighth annual Mother's Day Crafts Festival on Columbus Avenue, between 77th and 81st Streets (behind the American Museum of Natural History). The festival, sponsored by the American Arts and Crafts Alliance, goes on tomorrow and Sunday, from 10 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. Some of the proceeds will benefit a fund for the maintenance of Margaret Mead Park. In addition to the crafts, there will be musical entertainment. Admission is free. Information: 866-2239.

title: A HOUSE SUBPOENA BARRED BY SHULTZ
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today rejected a Congressional subpoena seeking documents said to have been withheld from an investigation of the Marine espionage scandal in Moscow.

title: ART: ALEXEJ JAWLENSKY AND HIS SON, ANDREAS
description: THE son of an army officer, Alexej Jawlensky (1864-1941) was all set to become one himself when he saw an art exhibition at the 1880 World's Fair in Moscow. As a result, he resolved to become an artist as well as an army officer, which required some maneuvering. Thanks to his good social connections, however, the young officer managed to get himself posted to St. Petersburg and, from 1889 to 1896, studied at the art academy there, while also discharging his military duties.

title: Clay-Price Pact On 4 TV Stations
description: Clay Communications Investors Inc. said that it had agreed to sell its four television stations to the Price Communications Corporation for $60 million. The stations to be sold are WAPT-TV in Jackson, Miss.; KJAC-TV in Beaumont-Port Arthur, Tex.; KFDX-TV in Wichita Falls, Tex., and WWAY-TV in Wilmington, N.C. The sale is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2 million from a tax loss carryforward. c-Net loss and after a loss of $129.6 million from discontinued operations.

title: COLLAPSE INQUIRY STUDIES BRACING FOR KEY COLUMN
description: A possible failure to brace steel columns as required by engineering plans may have contributed to the collapse of a 13-story Bridgeport, Conn., apartment building that killed as many as 28 construction workers last week, experts close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: STRUTHERS WELLS CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $6,201,895, a loss from disposal of discontinued segments of $8,556,965, and an extraordinary credit of $131,345. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,884,639 and an extraordinary credit of $3,548,277.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about a bronze Egyptian cat at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, now believed to be a forgery, carried an incorrect description issued by the museum for a $975 copy sold in its gift shop and a cat picture in a book called ''Metropolitan Cats.'' The museum now says the copy and the picture depict authentic sculptures in its collection, not the discredited one. The developments are reported today on page C36.

title: Testimony by Volcker Helps to Bolster Dollar
description: The dollar firmed on world currency markets yesterday, bolstered by strong statements from the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, and the news that Japanese interest rates would be lowered again soon.

title: SOUTHLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $23.3 million from the sale of a half-interest in Citgo. c-Net loss and includes an operating loss and inventory write-down totaling $151.9 million.

title: BERKLEY, W R CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $422,000 and $319,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively; and tax credits of $4,181,000 for the latest quarter and $1,321,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said the latest quarter figures include results of two subsidiaries acquired after March 1986. The company also said 1987 operating results include a $600,000 income tax benefit from the ''fresh start'' provisions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: JEW'S ROLE AT A NAZI CAMP IS INVESTIGATED
description: The Justice Department is ''seriously contemplating'' denaturalization proceedings against a 75-year-old Jewish man from Brooklyn in connection with allegations that he brutalized Jewish prisoners in a Nazi camp, people familiar with the investigation said yesterday.

title: STAGE: CARNAL ABANDON IN 'LIAISONS DANGEREUSES'
description: FOR the Royal Shakespeare Company production of ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' the stage at the Music Box Theater has been remodeled into a sex-drenched boudoir of late 18th-century France. Signs of reckless carnal abandon are everywhere. Huge linen sheets, rumpled from hectic use, drape the proscenium and boxes. Lacy silk underthings tumble in messy profusion from the hastily slammed drawers of a towering chiffonnier. Tall slatted screens, the better for servants to peep through, cast distorted shadows. All that's missing is a proper regal bed. Instead, there's a constellation of settees and chaise longues: this is an arena for men and women who copulate on the run.

title: ROBIN WILLIAMS IN 'SEIZE THE DAY'
description: SNARING Robin Williams for the lead role of Tommy Wilhelm in Saul Bellow's novella ''Seize the Day'' must have given the producers cause for celebration. Mr. Williams is a singularly gifted comic actor and comedian, a master of dizzying improvisation. Unfortunately, his performance in ''Seize the Day'' - a ''Great Performances'' presentation on Channel 13 at 9 this evening - is a miscasting fiasco, all the more regrettable because so much intense care has been so obviously spent on the production. The lineup of established talent is impressive. Robert Geller, whose credits include public television's ''American Short Story'' series, is the executive producer. Fielder Cook is the director, and Ronald Ribman did the adaptation. A promising roster, indeed.

title: CAR JUMPS CURB AND INJURES 10 ON EAST 40TH ST.
description: A car with a jammed accelerator ran out of control at a busy midtown intersection yesterday and struck 10 people as it mounted sidewalks, demolished a telephone booth, overturned food-vending stands and cut a swath through crowds of pedestrians on crosswalks.

title: Shearing Sheep
description: The Museum Village in Orange County, New York, opens for the year tomorrow at noon with its annual sheep-shearing demonstration to celebrate the arrival of the lambing season. The village is to be open tomorrow and Sunday from noon until 5 P.M. Admission is $4.75 for adults, $3.50 for the elderly and $2.50 for children. Information: (914) 782-8247. To get there, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway north, Route 17 west, and Route 210 south to Monroe.

title: David Murray Octet
description: David Murray, a saxophonist, is leading his octet - with Hugh Ragin and Rasul Siddik on trumpets, James Spaulding on saxophone, Craig Harris on trombone, Dave Burrell on piano, Wilber Morris on bass and Ralph Peterson Jr. on drums - tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.

title: WHERE TO SEE THE NEWEST OF THE AMERICAN ART
description: FOR those who want to be up to date on the subject of the new American art that is being both welcomed and criticized these days, this is the weekend to hit the street, or at least those streets with certain art galleries on them. A tour of said galleries, most of them in SoHo and the East Village, can tell you a lot about the shifts in esthetic taste and fashion that have been in the works for the last 12 to 18 months.

title: USF&G CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a capital loss of $94,635,000 and a tax credit of $3,431,000. c-Includes capital gains of $50,253,000 and a tax credit of $42,758,000.

title: MET ASSERTS CAT COPIES BASED ON AUTHENTIC WORK
description: Officials at the Metropolitan Museum of Art said yesterday that bronze replicas of an Egyptian cat that are sold in the museum's gift shop for $975 each are copies of an authentic Egyptian sculpture in the museum's collection, and not of an Egyptian cat now thought to be a fake.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Bear Market in Dead Souls
description: The funniest of classic Russian authors is Nikolai Gogol, whose masterpiece was ''Dead Souls,'' acclaimed from the moment it appeared in 1842. To today's reader, his mordant tale could as well be about a new kind of unperson - the Soviet Jews, barred from normal life, who have been turned into a form of merchandise in Russian diplomacy.

title: EDUCATION CHIEF PRESSES AIDS TESTS
description: William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, today urged making testing for AIDS mandatory in some situations, and said that the right to confidentiality should not block health officials from notifying the sexual partners of those infected with the deadly virus.

description: Richard J. Ferris, chairman and chief executive of the holding company that owns United Airlines, offered employees some form of financial participation in the company yesterday to improve relations with employees.

description: b-Net loss The NVHomes went public last June and the latest share earnings adjusted for a previously declared 2-for- 1 unit split payable April 30. The latest first quarter results include all the sales and 55 percent of the earnings of Ryan Homes Inc., reflecting the acquisition of a 55 percent stake in Ryan last December.

title: EXPLORING INWOOD HILL'S URBAN WILDERNESS
description: SEVERAL months ago, the northern Manhattan community of Inwood was abuzz about one of the city's more bizarre acts of thievery in recent memory. Four large trees known as Paulownia tomentosa mysteriously vanished one night from Inwood Hill Park.

title: Remember Mr. Marshall
description: The Latin American historian was waxing eloquent about the heartless, mindless neglect of Latin America. ''You made a Marshall Plan for Europe, for Asia, for Africa, even for Israel, for everybody but Latin America,'' he said. ''Why?''

title: Nicaraguans Seize Leaflets at a Suspended Paper
description: Security agents occupied the plant of the suspended opposition newspaper, La Prensa, for four hours today, confiscating copies of a leaflet printed Monday.

description: A popular challenge among analytically minded players is ''Play or Defend?''

title: Advertising; JWT Fills U.S. Unit's Top Posts
description: DON JOHNSTON, chairman and chief executive of the JWT Group, who of late has been beleaguered by Wall Street and the trade press, announced yesterday that the administrative and creative heads of J. Walter Thompson's New York office would additionally run J. Walter Thompson U.S.A.

title: LAWMAKERS ASK NUCLEAR AIDE TO QUIT
description: Five House Democrats joined Senator John Glenn today in demanding the resignation of Thomas M. Roberts, a two-term member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. They charged that he had given conflicting accounts about the disappearance of official documents and that by doing so he had tried to ''thwart'' a Senate committee's investigation of him.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE De Laurentiis Entertainment Group is taking marketing strategy one step further than anyone has before: Instead of finding something in the film's concept that it can market, it is making the marketing itself the concept of the film.

title: USE FOR SCHOOLS IS URGED
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday projected that it would produce a new surplus of nearly $600 million by 1995, and its chairman, Felix G. Rohatyn, urged that the money be spent on the city's public schools.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ANNE FRANK REMEMBERED: The Story of the Woman Who Helped to Hide the Frank Family. By Miep Gies, with Alison Leslie Gold. Illustrated. 252 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: A MISSILE-FREE EUROPE: LITTLE IMPACT ON A WAR
description: A United States-Soviet agreement to eliminate medium- and short-range nuclear missiles in Europe would have little battlefield effect on a war between NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

title: DEMOCRATS LOOK FOR WINNER AS THEY STUDY '88 HOPEFULS
description: Democrats have spent much of their time since the 1984 elections telling one another that their party had to make a fresh start. If Democrats are going to win the White House in 1988, went the party line, they had to change their message and send forth a new generation of political leaders.

title: NEW LANDFILL IS GUARDED LIKE A JEWEL
description: Far away from the congestion of northern New Jersey, the political maneuvers of the state's mounting garbage crisis are being played out over the new Gloucester County landfill here.

title: CUOMO TO NAME CHIEF OF M.T.A. TO A NEW TERM
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he would name Robert R. Kiley to a new six-year term as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority when his current appointment expires June 30.

description: To the Editor:

title: Factory Orders Up 2.3%
description: Orders to factories, strengthened by another big jump in demand for military equipment, rose 2.3 percent in March, the Commerce Department said today.

title: WIDER AIDS DEFINITION PROPOSED IN MOVE TO EXPAND U.S. BENEFITS
description: Federal officials have proposed an expanded definition of AIDS in a move that will increase the recorded number of cases by 20 percent and make important social benefits available to thousands of additional patients.

title: LAWMAKERS TAILOR ETHICS BILL TO APPEASE CUOMO
description: Leading Senate Republicans said today that they were drafting a new ethics code that meets several of the conditions set by Governor Cuomo when he vetoed an earlier version as too weak.

title: M.A.C. Retiring Its 1992 Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York announced plans yesterday to repay about $285 million of its outstanding Series 7 obligations this July 1 at a price of 100.

title: FILM: 'ROSA LUXEMBURG,' NEW LIGHT ON EARLY LEFTIST
description: WHEN she was murdered in Berlin on the night of Jan. 15, 1919, Rosa Luxemburg - flippantly referred to as Red Rosa by both friends and enemies - had been one of the leading figures of the European left for over 20 years. She was 49. Two weeks earlier, the woman who preached unity in the ranks (though she'd angrily broken away from the German Social Democrats five years before), joined with the members of her splinter group, the Spartacists, to found the German Communist Party.

title: Umpire Calls Foul
description: Tom Mosser, who dresses up as the Pittsburgh Pirates Parrot mascot, has been suspended for one game after he was involved in a incident with Umpire Fred Brocklander Wednesday night in Three Rivers Stadium. It came just after Brocklander made a disputed call that went against the home team during the Dodgers' 10-2 victory over the Pirates. Mosser rode his motor scooter onto the field and acted as if he were going to throw a bucket of water on Brocklander, but instead heaved a plastic ball at the umpire before leaving the field. Billy Williams, the crew chief, said he would notify the National League office about Mosser's behavior, which led to the suspension. ''Was I angry? Very much so,'' said Williams. ''If the crowd had been bigger he could have started a riot.'' Mosser, an artist who has drawn covers for Pirates programs, said he didn't know that Brocklander had just been involved in a controversial call and apologized. ''I shouldn't have done it,'' he said. ''It was dumb.''

title: CCX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,669,000 for the quarter and $1,419,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes a tax credit of $168,000 for the quarter and a $197,000 loss from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward for the 9 months. The company said the latest quarter and 9-month include a one-time charge of $1,576,000 related to a writedown of investments in technology and corporate officer separation pay as the result of a corporate restructuring.

title: NAVY UPHELD ON ATOMIC ARMS
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn has ruled that the Navy is under no obligation to disclose whether ships based at a planned port on Staten Island will carry nuclear weapons.

title: Inflation in Australia
description: Australia's declining rate of inflation is encouraging for the country's ailing economy but is still high in relation to other countries, economists and industry leaders said today. The Bureau of Statistics said that the Australian consumer price index for the whole of 1986 rose 9.8 percent on an annual basis, which compares with the calculations of economists that prices rose 9.4 percent for the first quarter of 1987.

title: ART: MEYER SCHAPIRO IN SHOW AT COLUMBIA U.
description: PERHAPS the most surprising show of the season is ''Works of Art 1919-1979'' by Meyer Schapiro, which can be seen in the Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery on the eighth floor of Schermerhorn Hall at Columbia University. Professor Schapiro has rightly received every possible academic honor for his work on art-historical terrain that begins with late antique and early Christian art and ends with the abstract painting of our own day. As to that, we have only to turn to the three volumes of his collected papers that were published in the 1970's by George Braziller.

title: CAPITAL WIRE & CABLE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Diner's Journal
description: THE constant inquiries I receive from readers and friends seeking worthy dining spots in the Broadway theater district prompted me to revisit some old standbys recently, and a pleasant surprise was the improved cast at Nicole, a handsome French brasserie in the Omni Park Central Hotel at Seventh Avenue and 56th Street. This cheerful spot with its marble cafe tables, tulip light sconces and burgundy banquettes has always been a favorite for a glass of wine and oysters on the half shell, but when it came to full meals I was usually disappointed.

title: SUNWEST FINANCIAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $3.1 million gain from the sale of securities.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tonight's scheduled 15-round World Boxing Association lightweight title bout between champion Edwin Rosario and Juan Nazario in San Juan has been postponed because Rosario is suffering from a stomach virus, according to Eulalio Medina, his trainer. No date has been set for the match. . . . Tyronne Stowe, the Rutgers linebacker who set school records for tackles, announced that he has agreed to sign with the San Diego Chargers as a free agent. The 6-foot-2-inch, 225-pound native of Passaic, N.J., was bypassed in Tuesday's N.F.L. draft. ''I want to show them how good I realy am,'' he said.

description: The New York City Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday more than $1.9 million in contracts for asphalt to be used for road repairs.

title: Our Towns; Gumshoe Stalks Housing Hidden By Developers
description: Since February, Jodie Manasevit has been paid by the City of Hoboken to track down illegal vacant apartments. She keeps her eyes peeled for empty mailboxes, peeks under doors but more than anything, she watches windows. ''They have a certain look,'' she said. ''Even if they have shades, you can tell by the way the shades are pulled, they look too uniform.''

title: THE FILM: 'ELEMENT OF CRIME'
description: ''THE ELEMENT OF CRIME,'' opening today at the Metro 2, is a film noir that's murky without being terribly mysterious.

title: HISTORIC LOOK IS STRESSED IN A PARK SLOPE RENEWAL
description: Developers frequently complain that the restrictions imposed by preservation agencies on rehabilitations of properties in historic districts are expensive and meddlesome.

title: FASTBALLS, A HUG AND A RING
description: When the bullpen gate in right field opened around 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Dwight Gooden was wearing his white Mets uniform for the first time in a month. But only the Shea Stadium grounds crew and two television cameramen were there to see him. The 22-year-old pitcher loped toward center field on the red-clay warning track, around left field and past the visiting team's dugout. As he neared the Mets' dugout, one of the television cameramen, Joe Mirandi, called to him.

title: FOODMAKER INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 12
CONCERT: HAROLD ARLEN, THE COMPOSER, HONORED
description: HAROLD ARLEN, who died just over a year ago at the age of 81, maintained that his entire songwriting output contained only one true blues song, ''Blues in the Night.'' The many other blues-flavored ballads that the public thought of as blues tunes, he insisted, were really torch songs.

title: Stability Seen From Japan Cuts
description: Japan's decision to guide short-term interest rates lower may help to stabilize exchange rates and to restore Japanese confidence in investing in the United States, economists said today.

title: Dining Out Guide: Latin American and Spanish Cuisine
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BRAZILIAN PAVILION, #316 East 53d Street (758-8129) - **(June 24, 1983) The cuisine of Brazil combines simply prepared stews and grilled meats and fish, black beans, and rice dishes with native South American ingredients and spices from West Africa. The Pavilion offers up examples of it in a bright modern setting. Appetizers include clams steamed in garlic broth, fried slices of linguica sausage, and caldo verde, a potato soup. Main-course choices are feijoada, the national dish of pork, beef and sausage added to black beans, simmered for hours with onions, green pepper, bay leaves and spices; broiled shrimp with garlic, and roast leg of pork. Dinner entrees average $13. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to midnight; closed Sundays. CAFE MARIMBA, 1115 Third Avenue, entrance on 65th Street (935-1161) -

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: TREASURIES SURGE AS YEN FALLS
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday, along with the dollar, after traders learned that Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan had instructed officials in that country to ''start operations to lower interest rates.''

title: Banks Speechless
description: When it came to words, Chip Banks, the Cleveland Browns' all-pro linebacker, was thrown for a loss after he was traded to San Diego for a higher postion in Tuesday's N.F.L. draft. during the N.F.L. draft Tuesday. When asked if he would honor the deal, Banks told The San Diego Union, ''I don't know. I'm busy talking with my agent. If I come, I'll have a comment.'' Two years ago the Browns sent him to Buffalo as part of the deal for Bernie Kosar, the quarterback, and when Banks refused to report to the Bills, the the Browns were forced to give Buffalo a first round pick.

title: THE DANCE: 'THEME AND VARIATIONS'
description: THE younger generation is coming to the fore during American Ballet Theater's season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Wednesday afternoon's performance introduced Ricardo Bustamante in a major role and marked the first time that Deirdre Carberry and Robert Hill were seen leading the cast of ''Theme and Variations.''

title: NEW LUTHERAN CHURCH FORMED FROM 3 ROOTS
description: A new major Protestant church with 5.3 million members was born here today with the merger of three Lutheran denominations that have diverse ethnic and geographical roots.

title: Parental Leave Bill Passed
description: The State Senate today approved a bill granting state employees up to 24 weeks of unpaid leave in any two-year period for personal illness or to care for a sick child, spouse or parent. The bill, which was passed, 33 to 1, and sent to the House, allows a state employee to take a 24-week unpaid leave because of personal illness and 24 weeks to care for a sick family member in a two-year period. The employee would be guaranteed the job back upon return to work.

title: Toots and the Maytals
description: Toots and the Maytals, a reggae band, will perform Sunday at Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street (242-1664). Shows are scheduled for 9:15 and 11:30 P.M., with Pacific Orchestra opening; tickets are $12.

title: Group to Buy Thrift Unit
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it has approved the acquisition of the Southern California Federal Savings and Loan Association by an investment group led by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary.

title: JWT GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The loss in 1987 first quarter pre-tax income included costs of $2.7 million for termination allowances and for closing certain facilities.

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $377,000 for the latest quarter and $172,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said in the latest quarter it absorbed $300,000 of losses in Brazil, including currency translation losses.

title: Nixon, Kissinger and a Super-Chernobyl
description: Richard Nixon and Henry A. Kissinger celebrated the first anniversary of the Chernobyl disaster by unveiling a new nuclear nightmare in a column in The Los Angeles Times. Their mischief-making purpose was to throw another monkey wrench into the prospects for a summit meeting that could lead to an agreement on intermediate-range missiles in Europe. They'd rather ruin a new global photo opportunity than see themselves out of the picture.

title: BODY IS FOUND AFTER ATTEMPT ON GOTTI'S LIFE
description: Detectives are investigating a link between an apparent attempt to assassinate John Gotti, the reputed Mafia leader, outside his headquarters in Queens on Wednesday and the discovery yesterday of the body of a mauled and bullet-riddled man on Staten Island, police officials said.

title: NETWORK HEADS DEFEND CUTBACKS
description: In the third and final day of House hearings on the impact of mergers on the television networks' news operations, the chief executive officers of the three major commercial networks testified that recent cutbacks had not affected the quality of their companies' news operations.

title: SENATE PANEL BLOCKS FUNDS FOR WEAPON REACTOR
description: The Armed Services Committee of the United States Senate has voted to bar funds for reopening a troubled nuclear reactor in Washington State that is a key source of the nation's plutonium fuel for nuclear weapons.

title: EG&G INC reports earnings for 14wks to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of 2 cents for the latest quarter and 20 cents for the year-earlier period. Year-ago results are adjusted to reflect the 1987 first quarter acuisition of KT Aerofab Inc., accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Devils Name Lamoriello
description: The search by the Devils for an experienced hockey man to be the president of the team ended yesterday when they signed Lou Lamoriello, who has resigned as director of athletics at Providence College.

title: AUSTRALIANS BUY BONWIT TELLER
description: Bonwit Teller, the century-old fashion chain whose flagship store is a mainstay in Trump Tower on 57th Street, has been sold by the Allied Stores Corporation to Hooker Corporation Ltd. for $101 million in cash, top executives of both companies said yesterday.

title: Chairman of Cullinet Is Giving Up Position
description: John J. Cullinane, founder of Cullinet Software Inc., announced yesterday that he would step down as chairman in September.

title: INTERNATIONAL HOLDING CAPIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $8,000 for the quarter and $86,000 for the 9 months.

title: On Rowny's Dissent
description: The walls of Edward L. Rowny's office are decorated with prints by M. C. Escher, the master illusionist. Mr. Escher's trompe l'oeil prints portraying waterfalls that run uphill and stairways that appear to turn on themselves seem an apt metaphor for the paradoxical debate over eliminating missiles from Europe.

title: Pennzoil Calls For Settlement
description: J.

title: Big Audio Dynamite
description: The rock band Big Audio Dynamite will perform tonight and tomorrow about 11:30 at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at East 15th Street (249-8870). Tickets are $12.50.

title: The U.N. Today: May 1, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Study of U.N. Intergovernmental Structure and Functions in Economic and Social Fields - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NALCO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN SHIP BUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,917,000 on the disposition of a shipyard. c-Net income d-Restated due to a restatement of the provision for income taxes.

title: FILM: 'SWEET LORRAINE'
description: CAN anyone love the Borscht Belt better than Steve Gomer? According to his biography, Mr. Gomer, who makes his directing debut with ''Sweet Lorraine,'' had a grandfather who worked at the Heiden Hotel in South Fallsburg, N.Y., and spent the summers there; he grew up to marry the granddaughter of the hotel's original owners. So Mr. Gomer's film was shot at the Heiden just before it was torn down. It's a friendly, agreeably aimless portrait of the Heiden, which is here called the Lorraine.

title: Fugitive Racist Leader Is Captured in Missouri
description: A fugitive white supremacist who reportedly threatened a war against blacks, Jews and the Federal Government and violated the terms of his bond, was captured today by agents who fired tear gas into a mobile home, the authorities said.

title: NO REAGAN FRAUD, WHITE HOUSE SAYS
description: The White House asserted today that President Reagan did not take part in the criminal conspiracy to defraud the Government and support the Nicaraguan rebels that was headed by Carl R. Channell, a conservative fund-raiser who pleaded guilty to a felony count on Wednesday.

title: Short-Covering Pushes Precious Metals Higher
description: All precious metals futures closed higher yesterday, largely because of a late burst of buying by traders who were covering contracts they had sold short only hours before.

title: HANNA, M A CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $2,650,000. c-After a loss of $409,000 from discontinued operations. In the latest quarter the company had preferred stock dividends of $1,588,000, compared to none a year- earlier.

title: IN NIGERIA, POLO AND POLITICS MEET AT THE CLUB
description: Saturday afternoon at the Lagos Polo Club is a scene painted in vaguely colonial hues.

title: CROWN CRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
ACUSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $944,000.

title: TALK OF A PEACE CONFERENCE STRAINS ISRAELI COALITION
description: Israel's coalition Government came under new strain today because of tensions over a proposed international peace conference and the Israeli investigation into the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case.

title: KEY RATES
MINE SAFETY APPLIANCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $2,143,799 related to the sale of the company's controlling interest in MSA Africa Pty Ltd.
