PHILIP CROSBY ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INDIANA ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE DANCE: PARSON'S 'EDGE' ON TAYLOR PROGRAM
description: ONE of Paul Taylor's most wide-ranging programs framed the final solo in a series choreographed by dancers in the company. Thursday night's bill at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, featured the premiere of ''The Edge,'' the solo by David Parsons, and four works by Mr. Taylor - ''Cloven Kingdom,'' ''Snow White.'' ''Junction'' and ''Sunset.''

title: Blinded by Limelight
description: Tony Woods, the first-round draft choice of the Seattle Seahawks out of the University of Pittsburgh, has admitted that he signed with an agent before his senior year, in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. Woods, a defensive end, said he signed early because Pittsburgh was between coaching staffs and the agent, Norby Walters of New York, dazzled him by taking him to parties, where he met entertainment stars including Eddie Murphy. ''It was something I used to dream about, to be face to face with superstars,'' said Woods. ''He gave me that opportunity. I was glassy-eyed.'' Woods said he had broken off his relationship with Walters.

title: GENERAL RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $6,100,000 for the latest quarter and $6,800,000 for the year-earlier period; and the latest quarter also includes a tax credit of $11,700,000.

title: Envoy in Moscow Wary
description: Ambassador Jack F. Matlock Jr. said today that the evidence ''is not in yet'' to justify demolishing the new building.

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in pension accounting.

title: Marine Prosecutors Outline Spying Case Against Guard
description: Military prosecutors began outlining their case today as pretrial hearings opened for a Marine guard charged with espionage while assigned to the United States Embassy in Moscow.

title: GUTIERREZ SEEKS BALANCE IN PIANISTIC REPERTORY
description: FOR Horacio Gutierrez, a concert pianist is not unlike a tightrope walker: Juggling artistic needs with career goals can be a constant balancing act.

title: Rise Sought In Debt Limit
description: The Treasury Department asked Congress today to swiftly raise the limit on Federal borrowing by $500 billion, to $2.8 trillion, to prevent the Government from running out of cash next month.

title: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Jackson's Job Search
description: Tom Jackson of the Denver Broncos, the oldest active linebacker in the National Football League, announced his retirement yesterday after playing a franchise-record 14 seasons. Six years ago, the Broncos instituted a Most Inspirational Player award, and Jackson won it six times. Jackson, age 36, has been invited to join the Denver coaching staff, an option he said he was considering along with a possible broadcasting career. ''At the moment, I'm unemployed,'' he said. ''If anybody knows of something out there that pays $300,000 a year. . . .''

title: Sixth Nuclear Test in 1987
description: An underground nuclear weapon test rocked the Nevada desert today. The test, the sixth announced at the Nevada Test Site this year, was listed by the Department of Energy as having an explosive force equal to that of 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT. A department spokesman said the test appeared to have gone off normally.

title: Extel Is Sought
description: Britain's big United Newspapers group began a $:259 million ($427 million) takeover bid for Extel, a printing and information services concern. A merger of the two companies would create a major new British-based media conglomerate with American interests, including the money-making PR Newswire. But Extel directors said in a statement that they rejected the bid, in which United is offering shareholders 103 of its shares for every 100 Extel shares. United's investment banker, Samuel Montagu, on Wednesday bought 26.3 percent of Extel put up for sale by Robert Maxwell's Mirror publishing group.

title: SPS TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $500,000 and $300,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: ANTHONY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $166,000.

title: ONCE AGAIN, THE ISLANDERS REUTRN FROM THE BRINK
description: The Islanders returned tonight to their much-traveled comeback trail and won again.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Suzanne Vega, Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street (239-6200). There are still some tickets available for Suzanne Vega's two Broadway concert performances on Sunday, at which she and her band will present all the songs from her second album, ''Solitude Standing,'' and most of the material from her first. In concert, Miss Vega's clear deadpan delivery of her original folk-pop songs is matched by a dry, perspicacious sense of humor. The songs - finely drawn personal reflections infused with a low-keyed obsesssive poetry - wear exceptionally well. ''Small Blue Thing,'' ''Marlene on the Wall,'' ''Cracking,'' ''Tom's Diner,'' ''Night Vision'' and ''Luka'' are especially wonderful. The 7 P.M. show is sold out; tickets still remain, at $20 and $22.50, for the 10 P.M. show.

title: KOGER COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Company Is Fined $50,000
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission fined the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation $50,000 today for maintenance shortcomings identified at the Nine Mile Point 1 nuclear power plant near Oswego. The agency cited such violations as the failure to alert management of problems and failure to adequately analyze problems to determine their underlying causes.

title: Home for Robbie
description: Joe Robbie, the team's owner, has directed the planning for the new 74,835-seat stadium the Miami Dolphins will move into this season, 15 miles north of the Orange Bowl. He even put up his franchise as collateral for the loans needed to finance the $100 million project. Now he can truly call it his own because the park will be named Joe Robbie Stadium. According to his son, ''If he had flunked the marketing test or the private financing test, the project would have been 'Joe Robbie's folly.' So why not 'Joe Robbie Stadium'?''

title: BURNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 1, 1987
description: The Economy

title: USLICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $2,900,000 and $450,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively, and the latest quarter includes a tax credit of $1,000,000.

title: Billy Joel Plans Tour Of Two Soviet Cities
description: Billy Joel, the rock singer and songwriter, is scheduled to bring his current world tour show to the Soviet Union in late July, said a spokesman for Mr. Joel, Michael Jensen.

title: METROPOLITAN FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4,269,000 from early repayment of debt.

title: GREINER ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ANCHOR HOCKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2,183,000 from disposition of a subordinated promissory note. c-Restated to reflect an increase of $1,000,000, or 10 cents a share, from pension accounting changes.

title: Pip of a Pick
description: While it's the major colleges that naturally produce the sweetest cream of the N.B.A.'s rookie crop, every so often a first-round pick emerges from a Virginia Union (Charles Oakley), a Wisconsin-Stevens Point (Terry Porter) or an Illinois Wesleyan (Jack Sikma). Now comes word that a player to look for on the opening round of the June 22 draft is a 6-foot-7-inch swing man from Central Arkansas named Tony Pippin.

title: Banshees of Blue
description: Buster Poindexter and the Banshees of Blue will perform tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street (228-6300). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $11.

title: POLYSAR LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Add More Cops. Then What?
description: Two cheers for Mayor Koch's plan to add 1,931 officers to the New York Police Department. There is comfort in a department fully restored after the fiscal crisis decimations. Then why not three cheers? Because more cops mean more work for courts and jails already near collapse. Yes, expand the force, but with an eye to the rest of the system.

title: NEW YORK STATE BIAS PANEL BEGINS HEARINGS
description: A special New York State panel on bias-related violence opened hearings yesterday and heard calls for stronger penalties for crimes related to prejudice and the creation of a special prosecutor to investigate them.

title: MARINE TRANSPORT LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The major causes of the latest quarter loss were a foreign currency loss of $299,000 from the balance sheet translation of Spanish Peseta debt into U.S. dollars and the operation of Marine Regent at voyage rates that continue to be insufficient to cover its charter-in costs.

title: MERIDIAN INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After investment gains of $552,000 for the latest quarter and $172,000 for the year-ago period. The latest first quarter net includes a 44 percent pooling participation with Meridian Mutual Insurance Co., the majority owner of Meridian Insurance Co., compared with an 8 percent participation in the year-ago first quarter.

title: Love That Science
description: The Reagan Administration's determination to improve the country's economic competitiveness has prompted the National Science Foundation to declare that virtually its entire array of programs is directly geared toward that end.

title: 2 MAKERS OF CHIPS TO MERGE
description: Two Silicon Valley semiconductor companies today announced a merger that could be the start of a broader consolidation in the chip industry.

title: Economic Scene; A Trade Truce With Japan?
description: THE atmosphere surrounding the talks between President Reagan and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone has been highly charged - particularly in the financial markets. Yet the situation looks manageable, if the emotions do not win out over pragmatism. Indeed, the two national leaders are seeking to calm the atmosphere to preserve the close economic, political and national security relationship between Japan and the United States.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN SINGERS
description: TEN male voices - nothing more - create the unforgettable sound of Ladysmith Black Mambazo, the South African group that will perform tonight at Sounds of Brazil. The voices, seven of them basses, share deep, resonant chords, hummed or shouted or swooped, in joyous crescendos or a velvety hush; they answer gentle exhortations from Ladysmith's leader, Joseph Shabalala, or propel his solos with rhythmic riffs, or sing along behind him with rich unanimity. Onstage, the group matches its harmonies with dance steps, kicking and soft-shoeing as Mr. Shabalala strolls in the foreground.

title: Fred Howser, 82, Dies; Lawyer in California
description: Fred N. Howser, a fiery District Attorney of Los Angeles and Attorney General of California who sparred with politicians, journalists and celebrities in the 1940's, died Sunday. He was 82 years old.

title: UNION SPECIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $304,000.

title: KAY JEWELERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Listen, Here's Clinton's Plan for the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Jazz Quintet
description: The New York Free Jazz Quintet -with William Parker on bass, Raphe Malik on trumpet, Glenn Spearman on tenor saxophone, Karen Borca on bassoon and Paul Murphy on percussion - will perform at 10 P.M. tonight and tomorrow at the Kraine Club Theater, 85 East Fourth Street (254-7706). Admission is $7.

title: 3 SEIZED IN ARSON OF FOSTER HOME
description: Three longtime homeowners on a quiet middle-class street in Queens were charged yesterday with setting fire to an unoccupied house on their block that New York City wants to use to shelter six foster-care infants.

title: Money Fund Assets Dip
description: Assets of the nation's 380 money market mutual funds decreased $523.5 million, to $238.27 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 93 institutional funds were down $341.6 million, to $64.98 billion. Assets of the 198 general-purpose funds were up $860.9 million, to $67.26 billion. The 89 broker-dealer funds fell $1.04 billion, to $106.02 billion.

title: Dow Up 32.10 for Third Gain in Row
description: The stock market rallied yesterday for its third gain in a row amid encouraging news about trade, the dollar and interest rates.

title: Susan Brooks Is Wed To Bradley I. Ruskin
description: Susan Beth Brooks, the daughter of Mrs. Milton M. Brooks of Rockville Centre, L.I., and the late Mr. Brooks, was married yesterday to Bradley I. Ruskin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. M.Ronald Ruskin of New York, Menands, N.Y., and Burrville, Conn. Rabbis Stanley Davids and Michael Monson performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue in New York.

title: Hudson Valley Concert
description: The first performance of a new work, ''Kaaterskill Quartet,'' composed by Robert Starer of Woodstock, N.Y., is to be played on Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Ulster County Community College in Stone Ridge, N.Y., by members of the Hudson Valley Philharmonic. Tickets are $8. Information: (914) 454-1222. To get there, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to exit 19 and Route 209 south to the college campus.

title: The Koop Testimonial
description: Republican Presidential hopefuls are scrambling to disengage themselves from a testimonial dinner honoring Dr. C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, who was once a favorite of conservatives and anti-abortion groups but has come under criticism in such circles.

title: UGI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $422,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,554,000 and a gain of $3,387,000 on an accounting change for unbilled utility revenue.

title: SOVIET COMMERCIAL SPACE BID SUFFERS IN NEW ROCKET FAILURE
description: Soviet efforts to enter the commercial space transportation business suffered another setback last week with the second failure in three months involving the Proton rocket, American space experts reported yesterday.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES $4.5 BILLION 'STAR WARS' PLAN
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee has approved a $4.5 billion budget for a space-based defense against nuclear missiles while trying to write its version of a military budget, Congressional officials said today.

title: JAPAN'S PUSH INTO AUTO PARTS
description: The Nippondenso Company's plant in Battle Creek, Mich., may soon begin supplying air-conditioners to the Chrysler Corporation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MAY 1, 1987
description: International A3-11 2,,q>U.S.-Japanese efforts to ease tension over trade were announced. Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said he had ordered the Bank of Japan to lower interest rates, in an effort to spur Japanese consumption, especially of foreign goods. Page A1 News analysis: An accord to remove medium- and short-range nuclear missiles in Europe would have little battlefield impact on a war between NATO and the Warsaw Pact countries. A1 Efforts to protect the ozone layer advanced as officials said a 31-country meeting had agreed in principle to freeze and ultimately reduce production and consumption of chloroflourocarbon chemicals. A1 Israel's coalition was under strain over proposals for an international peace conference and the Israeli investigation into the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case. A3 Russians are opening businesses under new laws designed to improve services. Moscow officials say 2,000people have established such opera-tions as cooperative cafes, taxi services and recycling centers. A1 Pope starts German visit

title: NOBLE AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ORION PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

title: PATTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BARRETT WENDELL
description: Barrett Wendell, a former executive director of the Ellis Memorial and Eldredge House of Boston, a social services agency that was originally one of the oldest settlement houses in the country, died April 8 at Coral Reef Hospital in Miami after a short illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Key Largo, Fla., and Beverly Farms, Mass. He was a former member of the board of the National Council on Alcoholism.

title: Americans Win In World Hockey
description: The United States continued its improved play at the world hockey championships with a 6-3 victory today over West Germany.

title: IRANIAN REPORTED SEIZED IN BEIRUT
description: An Iranian diplomat has been kidnapped in predominantly Moslem West Beirut and his captors have offered to exchange him for the missing Anglican Church envoy, Terry Waite, according to a magazine here that is usually well informed on Iranian affairs.

title: F.B.I. QUESTIONED NORTH 2 YEARS AGO
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation questioned Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North in 1985 about money he was trying to raise for the Nicaraguan rebels from an Iranian who described himself as a Saudi prince, it was disclosed today.

title:
PATENTS;
An Implant to Support An Artificial Tooth
description: LEAD: Patent 4,661,066 was granted to Dr. Leonard I. Linkow, an oral surgeon, and Leo Hoffman, a mechanical engineer, this week for a dental implant that is permanently installed in a jawbone to support an artificial tooth or a bridge.

title: GUIDELINES ON ARMS READIED
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff are drafting a report for President Reagan on what could constitute ''military sufficiency'' if an agreement to reduce nuclear missiles in Europe is reached with the Soviet Union, a senior Pentagon official said today.

title: PLEXUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a loss of $26,000 for the quarter and income of $35,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations.

PENTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss All share earnings and shares outstanding are on a fully diluted basis.

title: NEW BUDGET PLAN WOULD RAISE TAXES
description: Senate Democrats reached a tentative agreement today on a revised budget that would increase military spending and raise taxes to pay for it in the fiscal year 1988.

title: CARMIKE CINEMAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said this year's first quarter results include the operations of Essantee Theatres which were acquired in late 1986.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 2, 1987
description: Markets

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures restated to reflect a change in accounting method. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Sale of Mitchell-Lamas for Profit Endangers Subsidized Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: TM COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BIRMINGHAM STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRAZIL'S PRESIDENT, ALREADY SLIPPING, IS FURTHER WEAKENED IN FIGHT WITH PARTY CHIEFS
description: President Jose Sarney, seriously weakened by angry clashes with Brazil's dominant political party this week over the choice of a new Finance Minister, is now struggling to prevent his term in office from being cut short.

title: THE DANCE: 'PILLAR OF FIRE'
description: ''Pillar of Fire'' was the first ballet Antony Tudor created in the United States after arriving from his native London. Its premiere in 1942 with Ballet Theater, later American Ballet Theater, made a star of Nora Kaye, a dancer in the corps and, in fact, confirmed Mr. Tudor's own stardom as a choreographer.

title: Howard Beach Driver Is Subject of an Inquiry
description: A Queens grand jury is expected to hear evidence next week in an effort to determine whether any crime was committed by the driver of the car that struck and killed one of the victims of the Howard Beach racial attack, according to people familiar with the investigation.

title: Kaisertech Ltd.
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said that it had completed its reorganization into a holding company called Kaisertech Ltd., with its largest stockholder, the British investor Alan Clore, as chairman. Holders of Kaiser Aluminum stock automatically have become holders of the new company, and Kaiser Aluminum will continue as the operating company with current management in place. In return for a 31 percent stake in Kaisertech, Mr. Clore invested $140 million. The company has had five years of losses totaling $504 million.

title: Bally Shows Loss; Trump Deal Cited
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, the nation's biggest gaming concern, said its first-quarter earnings were cut $23.8 million by its repurchase of stock from investor Donald J. Trump. The hotel, casino and gambling company reported a 1987 first-quarter loss of $26 million, in contrast to a profit of $4.5 million, or 17 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues were $389.8 million, up 59.1 percent from $245 million a year ago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: High Spot Manhattan has its Times Square and Brooklyn has its Times Plaza. The plaza, named for the long-gone Brooklyn Daily Times, is formed by the intersection of Atlantic, Flatbush and Fourth Avenues, and of Hanson and Ashland Places. Nearby is the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and overlooking all is Brooklyn's tallest building, its only skyscraper, the 512-foot Williamsburgh Savings Bank.

title: GARBAGE BARGE PRODS OFFICIALS
description: As it floats aimlessly around the Gulf of Mexico, the garbage barge to nowhere from Islip, L.I., has drawn anger from politicians, chuckles from Johnny Carson and chagrin from the very red-faced community from which it came.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Reached agreement with Rich Gedman, catcher, on a two-year contract.

description: Federal regulators moved today against the nation's largest Medicare-certified prepaid health plan, ending the right of the concern, International Medical Centers Inc., to serve its 135,000 clients.

title: ENERGY FACTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCIENCE DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.N. Chief to See Waldheim
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who is scheduled to visit Vienna next month for a narcotics conference, has accepted an invitation to dine with President Kurt Waldheim there on June 16, a United Nations official said today. The Secretary General has refused to comment on reports that Mr. Waldheim, his predecessor as Secretary General, took part in Nazi war crimes in World War II.

title: DIGILOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in March.

title: SOVIET WHEAT DEAL
description: Farmers and grain traders here in the Middle West, like the Washington agricultural advisers whom many of them heed, were reacting with restrained enthusiasm today to the Soviet Union's agreement on Thursday to buy four million metric tons of American wheat.

title: CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Abigail Adams Meets Sally Hem(m)ings
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AMR Corp., Dallas, said it had completed the acquisition of ACI Holdings Inc., the parent company of AirCal Inc., for $15 a share. AMR said it would integrate AirCal into its American Airlines system on July 1.

title:
PATENTS;
New Method to Collect Fares Automatically
description: LEAD: A plastic memory token is the heart of a data transfer system patented this week for Paperless Accounting Inc. of Washington. Patent 4,661,691 was awarded to John W. Halpern, chairman of the company's board.

title: ALLIS-CHALMERS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinuing operations of $1,397,000.

title: FRANCHISING CHIEF QUITS IN NEW YORK
description: The New York City Franchise Director submitted his resignation yesterday, ending more than 21 years in the job and 32 years in city government. The director, Morris Tarshis, said he did so because recent news accounts had attacked his integrity.

title: A 22% INCREASE FOR TAXI FARES IS READY TO START
description: New York City's 11,787 yellow medallion cabs will charge higher fares starting tomorrow as new rates - averaging 22 percent higher and weighted to encourage drivers to serve areas outside central Manhattan - take effect.

title: Korea Pledge to Europe
description: Foreign Minister Choi Kwang Soo of South Korea has pledged to open his country to European imports as part of his Government's plan to ''liberalize and diversify'' trade relations. But he warned the European Community on Thursday against applying anti-dumping rules to the imports of product parts, saying that such a measure would violate world trade rules and discourage South Korea's investment in Europe.

title: 3 Sought in Connection With S.I. Body
description: Two organized-crime figures and a relative were being sought for questioning yesterday in connection with the slaying of a man who apparently tried to assassinate John Gotti, the reputed head of the Gambino crime family.

title: Texas Utility Contract Fight
description: A Federal regulatory agency is backing the Southern Company in its fight to force a Texas utility to honor a contract worth $900 million.

title: TAPIOCA PUDDING: COMFORT FOOD FIT FOR A PRESIDENT
description: ''Tapioca is the teddy bear of desserts, an edible security blanket,'' wrote Jane and Michael Stern in ''Square Meals,'' their compendium of all the wonderful and terrible things we ate as children. My sentiments exactly.

title: EXPERTS FIND FEW PLANS FOR RESCUES
description: For the disaster and rescue experts here, there are comparisons to Mexico City, San Salvador, Kansas City and Palm Bay, Fla.

description: b-Net income

title: ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Atari Profits Rise Sharply
description: The Atari Corporation, a personal computer and video game manufacturer based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said today that it earned $15.3 million, or 53 cents a share, in the first quarter, up sharply from $2.7 million, or 11 cents a share, a year ago. Sales for the quarter rose 45 percent, to $65.1 million, from $44.9 million a year ago.

title: QUEBEC ACCEPTING A ROLE IN CANADA IN A CONSTITUTION
description: After 20 years of uncertainty about its place in the Canadian confederation, Quebec has agreed to end its holdout and sign the Canadian Constitution.

title: CODE SIGNALED POLICE THEFTS, WITNESS SAYS
description: Plainclothes officers at Brooklyn's 77th Precinct used a secret code on the police radio to signal each other when they were ready to rob drug dealers, a witness in a police corruption trial testified yesterday.

title: Al Campanis Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: STANLEY INTERIORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Slayer Is Acquitted of Civil Rights Violation
description: A jury found a Detroit automobile worker not guilty today of Federal civil rights charges stemming from the 1982 beating death of a Chinese-American.

title: Thomas To Take Over London Symphony Post
description: Michael Tilson Thomas will become principal conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra when Claudio Abbado relinquishes the post at the end of the 1987-88 season. Mr. Thomas joins the handful of American-born, American-trained conductors - including James Conlon and Dennis Russell Davies - to head major musical organizations in Europe.

title: PIECES FIT FOR ISLANDERS
description: They are blocking the Flyers' paths, on the ice and in the series, just as they did to the Capitals two weeks ago. Resilience is the Islanders' forte, and an unassuming game plan has been their best weapon.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What we have now is a whole country.'' - Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada. [ 1:4. ]

title: Nikko Studies Bid For Toronto Seat
description: TORONTO, May 1 (Reuters) -

title: METS LAST SHOT IS THEIR BEST SHOT
description: The Mets of last season did not just survive. They dominated. So there is something unusual in this year's Mets playing such pained, uneven baseball. But any way it appears, one thing is certain: The Mets are winning again.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MEETING OF DEMOCRATS SUCCEEDS BY BEING DULL
description: The thin air of Santa Fe, which is 7,000 feet above sea level, did not seem to have any noticeable effect on the behavior of Democratic Party officials who met here this week. The two-day meeting of the Democratic National Committee was uneventful, some would say dull, and therefore, by Democratic standards, successful.

title: BRINKMANN INSTRUMENTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Derwent Award to Stars Of 'Coastal' and 'Fences'
description: Annette Bening, a member of the cast of ''Coastal Disturbances,'' and Courtney B. Vance, who is appearing in ''Fences,'' were named the winners of the 1986-87 Clarence Derwent Award yesterday. The award, which is named for the actor and former president of the Actors' Equity Association, has been made each year since 1944 to ''the most promising male and female actors on the metropolitan scene.''

description: Policemen with rifles and riot sticks guarded the spacious ranch-style home of the Venezuelan Ambassador here today where a former President of the Dominican Republic is seeking political asylum.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Long Shots Win: Buryyourbelief and Queen Alexandra, a pair of long-shot New York-breds, won major stakes races at Churchill Downs yesterday, and Manila, last year's grass champion, came through as the heavy favorite in another.

title: SOME MINOR GAINS ON TRADE CONFLICTS
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan today offered concessions in particular areas of the trade dispute with the United States. American representatives, while welcoming the remarks, said they would wait to see what actually comes of them.

title: GOETZ SHOOTING VICTIM SAYS YOUTHS WEREN'T THREATENING
description: One of the four young men shot by Bernhard H. Goetz, facing his assailant for the first time since the shooting more than two years ago, testified yesterday that Mr. Goetz was not being robbed or threatened but that he had pulled a revolver and fired after simply being asked for money in a ''normal tone'' of voice.

description: b-Net loss

title: They Might Be Giants
description: They Might Be Giants will perform at Darinka, 118 East First Street, near Avenue A (598-0157), at 10 P.M. and midnight tonight. Admission is $5 for members, $10 for nonmembers.

title: P.L.O., REUNITED BUT ISOLATED, WILL MOVE TO ALGERIA AND IRAQ
description: A largely reunited Palestine Liberation Organization has decided to relocate most of its political and military functions in Algeria and Iraq because of its growing isolation in the rest of the Arab world, according to P.L.O. officials here.

description: The year-ago figures are not comparable; Hako went public in March.

description: LEAD: When people ask why I've been edgy, I tell them it's all because of a 7-year-old boy in San Carlos, Calif. Actually, it's not his fault that I'm edgy. But then maybe it is. That's the problem.

Dallas Museum Chief To Quit After 13 Years
description: The director of the Dallas Museum of Art, Harry S. Parker 3d, has announced that he will resign his post June 1, after serving 13 years. The museum's deputy director and chief curator, Steven A. Nash, is to become acting director until a permanent successor is found.

title: British Trade Deficit Widens
description: Britain's merchandise trade deficit widened in March from the previous month but remained considerably narrower than a year ago, the Government said today.

title: OSHKOSH B'GOSH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TEXAS ARCHITECT AND AUTHOR
description: Howard Barnstone, a Houston architect whose teaching and buildings had an impact on this city's development, was found dead in his apartment here Wednesday in an apparent suicide. He was 64 years old.

title: FFB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: FFB converted to stock form last June 27.

title: NEWCOMERS SEEK STAR ROLE
description: The 113th Kentucky Derby is filled with veterans who have stormed down the long stretch at Churchill Downs before. Among such trainers and riders as Leroy Jolley, Woody Stephens, Angel Cordero and Jacinto Vasquez, who among them have won eight Derbies, the race is a rather routine rite of spring.

title: Becker Leads Tourney Field
description: Boris Becker, the top-seeded player in the Shearson-Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions, is one of two drawing cards in the tournament on the clay courts at Forest Hills.

Dow Falls 5.96 Points, To 2,280.40
description: Except for the surging automobile sector, the stock market ended the week on a desultory note yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average losing 5.96 points to close at 2,280.40.

title: PREJUDICE VICTIMS TELL TASK FORCE ABOUT CONFLICTS IN NEW YORK CITY
description: A Bronx woman testifying yesterday before a special New York State panel on bias-motivated violence surprised members when she said she was roughed up by the Port Authority police even as she protested that she was a transit police officer on maternity leave.

description: The New York City Department of Transportation has listed the following trouble spots for weekend traffic:

description: Following is the text of a joint statement on economic issues released today after President Reagan and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan ended two days of meetings:

title: BARFIELD HELPS JAYS TAKE FIFTH IN ROW
description: Jesse Barfield's second home run of the game, leading off the bottom of the 10th inning, gave the Blue Jays a 3-2 victory over Texas tonight, ending the Rangers' six-game winning streak. Barfield hit a 3-2 pitch from Mitch Williams (2-2) over the right-field fence to give Toronto its fifth straight victory.

title: New Bridge Over Tampa Bay
description: The new $240 million Sunshine Skyway bridge opened Thursday with a procession of cars, yellow balloons and a memorial bouquet of 35 white carnations dropped into the bay, one for each person killed when part of an adjacent span was knocked down.

description: b-Net income

The year-ago fourth quarter figures adjusted for certain intra-period adjustments. The company did not elaborate.

description: A meeting between two groups planning to form a consortium to rival Japan's international telecommunications monopoly fell apart today after sharp disagreement over a trans-Pacific undersea cable, an official said.

CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of the art dealer Xavier Fourcade on Wednesday misstated the occupation of Mr. Fourcade's father, Jean. He was a banker in Paris, not a baker.

description: Latest quarter results reflect a change in method of accounting for certain pension costs as a result of adopting SFAS No. 87.

title: STAGE: NEW WORK BY ROBERT WILSON
description: Although he remains the most important figure of the American theatrical avant-garde, Robert Wilson does more work in West Germany now than anywhere else. Publicly supported opera companies and spoken theaters in this country offer him a more lavish forum both for the staging of the classics (Gluck's ''Alceste'' in Stuttgart last December; Shakespeare's ''King Lear'' in Hamburg next fall) and for his own work.

title: No Second Thoughts
description: Rick Pitino, who had been considered for the Knicks' coaching vacancy, confirmed yesterday that he would return as coach at Providence College. The Knicks have also reportedly considered hiring Don Nelson, the Milwaukee Bucks' coach and director of player personnel. Pitino said he might have been the Knicks' second choice, getting the job if Nelson were not available.

title: VERMONT RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
DOWNWARD SPIRAL FOR U.S.-CUBA TIES
description: In the last few months, the United States and Cuba have traded a flurry of diplomatic jabs that have brought relations between the two mutually antagonistic countries to the lowest point in at least a decade.

title: TWO SEXUAL DISEASES ARE FOUND REDUCED BY VAGINAL SPONGES
description: Women who use contraceptive sponges significantly reduce their risk of contracting gonorrhea and chlamydia, sexually transmitted diseases that can cause infertility, a study has concluded.

title: Florida Bank Indictments
description: Federal prosecutors said today that 21 former employees of south Florida banks and savings and loan associations have been indicted on charges of embezzling a total of $1.2 million.

title: Wickes Cites Test In Carpet Problem
description: The Wickes Companies' sale of up to $360 million in carpeting that failed to meet density and flammability standards stemmed from employees giving false test results to customers, the company said. Wickes also said it had dismissed four employees, including two executives of the carpeting division of the Collins & Aikman Corporation, a New York-based textile maker that Wickes acquired in January for $1.16 billion.

title: DATAREX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JEWISH-BORN NUN BEATIFIED BY POPE
description: Pope John Paul II today beatified a Jewish-born Carmelite nun killed in Auschwitz, saying she ''offered herself to God as a sacrifice for genuine peace, and above all for her threatened and humiliated Jewish people.''

title: CHINA PLANS BOND ISSUE
description: China plans to issue construction bonds this year and to expand its bond and stock exchange markets later, a Chinese official told Japanese business leaders at the Federation of Economic Organizations in Tokyo Thursday.

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $210,000. The latest revenue decline resulted from the sale of the company's hospital products division in October 1986.

title: METAL'S LINK TO ALZHEIMER'S STUDIED
description: Researchers have reported finding a means by which aluminum, thought by a number of researchers to play a role in Alzheimer's disease, can reach the brain. Experiments with rabbits, they say, indicate that aluminum inhaled through the nose can penetrate the brain through the olfactory nerves.

title: CANTERBURY PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter results include Empire Career Center Inc., acquired Feb. 12.

title: Film Library Sale
description: Weintraub Entertainment Group said it had completed the purchase of the Screen Entertainment film library from the Cannon Group for $84.8 million. The library includes more than 2,000 motion pictures and nearly 900 episodes of 28 television series.

title: RECITAL: EDWARD ALDWELL PLAYS BACH 'GOLDBERG' VARIATIONS
description: In recent seasons a cult has developed around the pianist Edward Aldwell, who gave another of his Bach recitals on Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. The cult deserves to be much bigger, and no doubt will be. Mr. Aldwell, a teacher of theory and musical analysis at the Curtis Institute and at Mannes College, is an unusual artist who knows how to transmute scholarship into passionate performance. His journey through the ''Goldberg'' Variations on this occasion suffered little or nothing in comparison with remembered performances by such Bach specialists as Ralph Kirkpatrick, Rosalyn Tureck and Glenn Gould.

title: LUTHERAN CONCILIATOR: Herbert Walfred Chilstrom
description: After an election that required nine ballots over two days, the newly formed Evangelical Lutheran Church in America today chose as its first Bishop a man with a reputation for openness and reconciliation, the Rev. Herbert Walfred Chilstrom of Minneapolis.

title: ERVING'S CAREER EXTENDED BY SIXERS
description: Admirers of one of professional basketball's most accomplished performers received a reprieve tonight.

title: JAPANESE - U.S. IMPASSE
description: The news on Thursday that the Federal Reserve and the central bank of Japan had put together an interest rate deal to stabilize the weak dollar was a sign that countries without much in common can tackle a common problem. The markets, which had been urging such action for a couple of months, duly cheered.

title: VERNITRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $585,000 gain from the sale of real estate. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $448,000. Year-ago quarter results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY BARRIERS REMAIN ON PATH TO A MIDEAST CONFERENCE
description: American officials say that although intensive diplomatic efforts in recent weeks among Jordan, Israel and the United States have made some progress toward agreement on a format for an international peace conference, major differences remain on how the Palestinians would be represented and how much authority such a conference would have.

title: A REBOUNDING PAN AM SEES BREAK-EVEN YEAR
description: Executives at Pan American World Airways expect the airline to break even this year and the overall holding company to make a small profit.

title: CUOMO LISTS POSSIBLE RISES IN SOME TAXES
description: The Cuomo administration yesterday proposed almost $1 billion a year in new fees and taxes on a variety of goods and services to pay for road and bridge improvements statewide. The fees would be phased in over the next eight years.

title:
PATENTS;
New Phone Service
description: LEAD: A new system has been developed for telephone subscribers who receive a signal when a third party calls during a conversation. Sergio M. Brecher of Bell Communications Research Inc., in Livingston, N.J., was granted patent 4,661,975 this week for a system that enables subscribers to avoid interruption of the call.

DURAMED PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $57,000 and a tax benefit of $63,000. c-After a tax credit of $99,000.

title: LAKELAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $15,000.

title: Six Killed When Small Plane Crashes Off Coast of Antigua
description: A small plane crashed in the Atlantic Ocean today shortly after takeoff from the island of Antigua, killing all six people aboard, the police said.

title: WOLVERINE WORLD WIDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: GRENADA SUNBURST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $1.3 million. The latest quarter results include gains of $800,000 from the sale of securities, compared with $1.7 million for the year-ago period.

title: The Wild Blue Squalor
description: Hawaii's newspapers recently ran front-page headlines announcing one of the few victories that frequent travelers have scored recently, over the airlines on which they have no choice but to suffer and fly.

title: NISSAN DROPS ESTY AD AGENCY
description: The William Esty Company, which has suffered a steady erosion of its account roster since becoming a part of Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi Company, has now lost the Nissan Motor Corporation. The Nissan account's annual billings of approximately $140 million represent about a quarter of the agency's total.

title: TV:'Police Story' Revived as Special
description: From ''Perry Mason'' to ''Mayberry R.F.D.,'' old television shows and casts are being resurrected in periodic specials. Worse, they are getting hefty ratings. As far as broadcasters are concerned, that's the cue for a nostalgia binge.

title: Frog Dissection Compromise
description: Jenifer Graham should be allowed to finish her biology class but her transcript should show that she refused to dissect frogs, school district officials say. Miss Graham, a 15-year-old sophomore at Victor Valley High School, asked for alternative anatomy lessons because of her vegetarian beliefs. The school's board of trustees is scheduled to vote on the case May 12.

title: TV MINISTRY SCANDALS LAMPOONED IN SOUTH
description: All across the South's Bible Belt, country music radio stations these days are freely lampooning the troubles of television evangelists. On many stations the most requested song is ''Would Jesus Wear a Rolex on His Television Show?''

title: THOMSON NEWSPAPERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: A TOBACCONIST'S SWEET SCENT
description: For a cigar store, J.R. Tobacco is smelling awfully sweet these days.

title: SELECTIVE INSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $9,629,000 and $250,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: The Cabaret Law, Out of Tune
description: New York City's cabaret licensing law allows a club to offer a trio of piano, bass and drums. But to add a saxophone, creating a quartet, without also investing in safety devices risks discipline by the Department of Consumer Affairs. Safety is important, but the law is badly out of tune.

title: Construction Spending Declined 1.3% in March
description: Commercial and business construction fell sharply in March, pulling down overall construction spending by 1.3 percent, to its lowest level since December, the Government reported today.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE APPROVES WEBSTER
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee unanimously approved the nomination of William H. Webster as Director of Central Intelligence today despite questions about his knowledge of the Iran-contra affair.

title: INQUIRY ASKED ON MEESE AND HIS TIE TO WEDTECH
description: The chairman of a Congressional panel that oversees ethics in Government today asked the General Accounting Office to examine the financial relationships between Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the Wedtech Corporation.

title: Beth Gersh Becomes Bride
description: Beth Susan Gersh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Gersh of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Sunrise, Fla., was married yesterday to Dusan Nesic, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kosta Nesic of Knicanin, Yugoslavia. Mayor Gisella Knight of Dobbs Ferry performed the ceremony at the Gersh home there. Mrs. Gersh-Nesic is an assistant to the director of the Grey Art Gallery at New York University, where Mr. Nesic is an associate research scientist in the high-energy physics group. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: PRIMAGES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
O'CONNOR CANCELS ADDRESS TO REPUBLICAN CONTRIBUTORS
description: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court said today that she had canceled a talk to a Republican group that had advertised her scheduled appearance in a letter soliciting $10,000 political contributions.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 35. 1. This X-ray was very revealing, according to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Why? 2. He called the action ''dismaying and incomprehensible,'' and said, ''I have a clear conscience.'' Who was speaking? To what was he referring? 3. Lawrence E. Walsh, special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, made the first criminal charge in his inquiry. Who was charged? What were the charges? What did he plead? 4. Mayor Koch's announcement that the city will add 1,931 police officers by June 1988 brought widely shared cheer to city officials. What is particularly noteworthy about the additions? 5. A major Wall Street concern said that it lost $250 million in April, apparently in little more than a week. Wall Street executives could not recall an occasion when a securities company lost so much in so short a time. What is the company and how did it sustain such a loss? 6. A Hall of Fame member will return to the National Basketball Association next year as a coach. Who is he and what team will he join? 7. Moves by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan and Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in the United States, represented a concerted approach by the two countries to reduce tension and steady the dollar. What were the moves? 8. Because too few states responded to his request to impose their own standards, Labor Secretary Bill Brock issued rules that will apply to nearly 500,000 migrant farm workers. What are the rules? 9. A British newspaper published details of a book, ''Spycatcher,'' by Peter Wright. Why was this noteworthy? 10. The City of Dallas, the Reagan Administration, a Federal district judge and a group of poor blacks approve of a proposal to destroy the city's most infamous slum. Why? 11. As expected, Vinny Testaverde, the quarterback from Miami, was the first pick of the National Football League college draft, taken by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Other first round choices were more of a surprise. Why? 12. The Interior Department announced its final five-year plan for opening millions of acres of the outer continental shelf to oil and gas exploration. How does the plan differ from the proposal James G. Watt made in 1981 that was widely criticized? 13. New optimism about the nation's farm economy has become evident after years of recession. Why? 14. Benjamin Ernest Linder, an American volunteer working on a rural development project in Nicaragua, was apparently the first American civilian to be killed in the fighting in Nicaragua. Who was blamed for his death? 15. The Supreme Court upheld a law classifying as ''political propaganda'' all foreign government films that might influence public opinion on United States foreign policies. What were the subjects of the three Canadian films that led to the suit? 16. The United Nations Environmental Program announced a step toward ''a meaningful international agreement to protect the ozone layer.'' What was the step?

title: TV Ministry Lists '85 Income
description: The Jimmy Swaggart Ministries had revenue of nearly $128.5 million in 1985, according to the auditor of the evangelical organization.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $124,000, or 5 cents a share, for the latest year and $77,000, or 6 cents a share, for the earlier year.

title: PASTOR WITH WIFE IN COMA SAID TO ATTEMPT SUICIDE
description: DALLAS, May 1 - The senior pastor of a large Methodist church here, whose wife has been in a coma and in critical condition since an attack by an unidentified assailant last week, apparently attempted to kill himself with a drug overdose early today, the police said.

title: BOND PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Capping off a turbulent week, bond prices fell sharply yesterday, giving back roughly two-thirds of Thursday's strong gains.

title: CONVEX COMPUTERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $781,000. c-After an extraordinary credit of $250,000.

title: Trade Surplus Hits $101 Billion in Japan

title: Moon Sounds Off

title: MUSIC: 'KO WO KIKU'
description: ''Ko Wo Kiku,'' a new work by the Canadian composer R. Murray Schafer, tries hard to evoke the spirit of the Japanese incense ceremony from which its title is drawn. Translated as ''listen to the incense,'' ''Ko Wo Kiku'' is a coloristic piece, filled with the kind of simple, repetitive phrases, whistling flutes and glissando strummings from the harp that have become a cliche of Western composers trying to evoke an Eastern flavor. The piece, commissioned by a Kyoto bank, was completed two years ago and received its New York premiere Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall in a performance by the Boston Symphony.

title: Protectionism Wins, Barely
description: Encouragingly, the Gephardt amendment to the House trade bill squeaked by on a margin of only four votes, thanks to a band of enlightened Democrats who broke with their leaders. Not encouragingly, the completed bill, including that obnoxious amendment, then won a resounding two-thirds majority.

title: Marcia Meighan Wed To Gregory B. Abbott
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church Chapel yesterday Marcia Meighan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hunter Meighan of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married to Gregory Booth Abbott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Abbott of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Wilson Foods
description: Texas Partners, an investment group with ties to the wealthy Bass family of Fort Worth, has purchased a 5.4 percent stake in the Wilson Foods Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said that it had bought the shares of the Oklahoma City-based meatpacker for investment purposes only. The investment group includes David Bonderman, a vice president of the Robert M. Bass Group. Between March 5 and April 20, the investment group bought its entire 523,000 shares of Wilson for prices ranging from $10.38 to $10.63 a share.

title: 4 Die as 2 Small Planes Collide Over Orlando
description: A private twin-engine Cessna 340 aircraft and a single-engine SNJ collided in midair and crashed about five miles northwest of Orlando, Fla., yesterday afternoon, Government officials said.

title: New York City Disables the Disabled
description: LEAD: For one day - May 7, National Barrier Awareness Day - more than half a million disabled people in New York City will become the focus of civic concern. How easy is it for these people to get around and participate in all that New York has to offer? Do Federal, state and city laws and programs actually result in a barrier-free environment?

title: KENNEDY CENTER HEAD TO STEP DOWN IN '88
description: Roger L. Stevens, head of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts since 1961, said today that he expected to step down early next year and be succeeded by Ralph P. Davidson, chairman of the executive committee of Time Inc.

title: HONDURAS ARMY LINKED TO DEATH OF 200 CIVILIANS
description: The Honduran Army high command maintained a network of secret jails, special interrogators and kidnapping teams who detained and killed nearly 200 suspected leftists between 1980 and 1984, according to a former Honduran Army interrogator who says he was part of the network.

title: EX-RADICAL ADMITS PLANTING BOMB IN '70 AT UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON
description: Terrence Peter Jackson, a Vietnam-era antiwar protester formerly known as Silas Trim Bissell, pleaded guilty today to a Federal charge stemming from an attempt to blow up an Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps building in 1970.

title: One Person, and One Borough, One Vote

Queens has been part of New York City for 88 years, yet its people think of themselves as distinct from Manhattan's vague menace.

title: Lease Radar Planes to Pakistan
description: Count the Pakistanis among the many victims of the war in Afghanistan. Pakistan's help for the Afghan rebels has brought it heroin trafficking, guns galore, millions of refugees - and now two air raids a day by Afghan planes. As the Afghan downing of an F-16 yesterday dramatized, Pakistanis need help with air defense. They have the necessary fighter aircraft. What they don't have is surveillance aircraft, and only special action by Congress can provide them.

title: REAGAN'S SON TELLS OF ABUSE AS A YOUTH BY MAN AT CAMP
description: Michael Reagan, President Reagan's adopted son, disclosed in an outline for an autobiography that he was sexually molested and photographed in the nude by a day-camp official when he was 7 years old.

Mr. Williams, a member of the staff for 23 years, is an internationally known teacher of classical ballet whose students have included Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: POLAND AND CHINA REPORTEDLY SENT ARMS TO CONTRAS
description: The Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair have uncovered detailed evidence that the Reagan Administration solicited aid for Nicaraguan rebels from Poland and China, a Congressional official said today.

title: CHESAPEAKE TOWN FACES A PARTING WITH ITS PAST
description: For most of its 280 years, the residents of this bayside town have proudly proclaimed it the ''Pearl of the Chesapeake.'' They made a good, if hard, living catching oysters, clams and crabs, and what they couldn't eat or sell, they used, paving the roads with the shells.

description: At the turn of the century, commercial traffic in New York Harbor forced most yacht racing to develop in Long Island Sound. Now there is a move to bring sailboats back into the city through a novel idea for yacht club competition.

title: FATE OF ROBINS I. IN QUESTION AGAIN
description: LEAD: MARTHA JANE PAUL of Cutchogue remembers the day clearly. It was April 2, 1982. As president of the Save Robins Island Committee, she had organized a luncheon for Suffolk County legislators before they were to vote on an appraisal before acquisition of the 445-acre island The meal featured wines, vegetables and apple cider, all locally produced, and clams that her husband had dug almost outside the door of their home on Nassau Point, which overlooks the island.

title:
ART;
HOLOGRAPHY: TESTING THE BOUNDARIES OF PERCEPTION
description: LEAD: THE development of holography, the most convincing method yet discovered for creating three-dimensional photographic imagery, is hardly two decades old, yet already scores of artists have produced a significant body of work in this nascent medium. However, the mechanistic technology that called into question the camera's role in creative expression is magnified in holography, where the technical aspects of picture-making assume a disproportionately dominant role.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANTING ALTERNATIVES FOR SHADED AREAS
description: LEAD: WHEN a house is first built, more than likely the trees will be small and the garden sunny, but in 10, 15 or 20 years, the trees will have grown, and the garden may well be shady. This can play havoc with the planting schemes for both woody and herbaceous plantings.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: I am the same age as Bruce Weber, and I find this ''unromantic'' generation to be more honest and up front about who they are and what they want than my own generation, especially those 30- to 40-year-olds working in corporate America. Many pseudo-rebels of the 60's have become everything they once despised. At least the ''unromantic'' generation is honest - ''the best things in life aren't free, they want money!'' SANDY WEXLER New York City

title: AMERICAN WHO LOBBY FOR JAPAN

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Galveston, Tex.;
Replicating An 1861 Hotel
description: LEAD: THE WASHINGTON, a $4 million reconstruction of a small 1861 hotel destroyed by fire four years ago, is scheduled to open here this month on the its original site in the Strand, where $75 million has been privately invested to restore the landmark commercial district dating from the 1850's.

title: Lisa Ann Fiedler To Marry June 20
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Walter Gustafson of Pasadena, Calif., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gustafson's daughter Lisa Ann Fiedler to Virgil Thomas Fryman Jr., the son of Mr. Fryman of Washington, Ky., and the late Elizabeth Louis Marshall Fryman. A June 20 wedding is planned.

title: Sports of The Times; SHOOTING FOR PENSION PLAN FROM UNDER N.B.A. RUG
description: HE's 59 years old now, a retired Wall Street institutional broker living in Stuart, Fla., in a condo on a golf course. Every so often he puts on a sweat suit and sneakers and goes over to the Martin County High School gym where the coach, Don Wallen, lets him shoot baskets. One day not long ago when the high school players were shooting free throws, one of the kids asked him if he wanted to shoot, too. He went to the free-throw line, took a few warm-up shots, then began shooting. And counting.

title: FEEDING AND PLANTING TO BE CONTINUED
description: ANY dead stems and leaves left over from last fall should be carefully pulled or cut off perennials now and composted. Be careful not to disturb new growth and shoots. Last call to apply general garden fertilizer to established shrubs and perennials; be sure to use acid-type fertilizer for azaleas, rhododendrons and pieris. When planting new rosebushes, they will become established better if removed from boxes; loosen the root mass, especially if it is in a twining circle. Apply water-soluble fertilizer at half-rate to indoor seedlings; pinch back spindly snapdragons, petunias, marigolds and zinnias to encourage branching. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS FICUS

title: A QUIET HARMONY: PITCHER AND CATCHER
description: LEAD: LYDIA SHAFFER expected her second varsity softball season to be quite different from the first. Her team at Roger Ludlowe High School was consolidating with that of Fairfield's other public high school, Andrew Warde, which did little to ease her doubts about earning the starting job at her favorite position, third base.

title: Diverging Views Found on Donating Organs
description: Americans are more likely to donate the organs of a loved one for transplant than to donate their own, according to a new survey of public opinion.

description: SINCE early this year, a Soviet frigate has been steaming outside the Strait of Hormuz at the entrance to the Persian Gulf.

description: Dr. Deborah Geraldine Ruiz, an ophthalmologist, and Anthony Blenk, a director of equity investments at MONY Financial Services, were married yesterday at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in New York. Msgr. Myles M. Bourke performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Robert A. Nunn of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: FICTION
description: COD STREUTH. By Bamber Gascoigne. (Available Press/Ballantine, $4.95.) When Jacques le Balleur, the Calvinist monk at the center of this bizarre short novel, is captured by Tupinili cannibals in the Brazilian jungle in 1560, his primary concern is that he will become the pagan tribe's next meal. In his pocket, however, the Tupinili find 10 pages from the complete works of Rabelais, and they mistakenly identify that ribald 16th-century French text as the Bible they were promised by a previous missionary. To their great delight, they discover that the much-anticipated Good Book is remarkably in tune with their own customs and inclinations, which (as Jacques himself soon learns) are not exactly of a character that Maitre Calvin would approve of. To reward the bringer of such an agreeable ''holy'' text, therefore, the grateful natives decide that Jacques, rather than becoming their dinner, should become their king. He naturally accepts the position, and with it the responsibilities (which include keeping a harem and engaging in all sorts of libidinous rituals), but this conscientious man of God is careful at the same time to instruct his new subjects in true Christian principle. ''Thus are we slowly becoming a Christian community,'' Jacques writes in his monthly reports to the outside world, ''though a visitor newly arrived from Geneva might detect unorthodoxy.'' Unorthodoxy, perhaps, but certainly no lack of hilarity. Bamber Gascoigne, the author of two other novels and several nonfiction works, has concocted this wonderful little fiction with just the right balance of ironic restraint and unbuttoned vulgarity. One of the most unusual books to appear in a long time, ''Cod Streuth'' (''God's Truth'') is literary entertainment of a high order.

title: PUTTING A PINCH ON MANAGEMENT PERKS
description: SHOULD companies take from the rich or give to the poor?

title: A June Wedding For Susan Sands
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. William Sands of Malibu, Calif., of the engagement of her daughter, Susan Elizabeth Sands, to Edward Wesley Harbert 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harbert 2d of Westport, Conn. The couple plan to marry June 13. Ms. Sands, the daughter also of the late Mr. Sands, an actor, graduated from the University of California at San Diego. She is director of dramatic series development for ABC Television in Los Angeles; her fiance is vice president of motion pictures at ABC-TV. Her mother, Marsha Sands, owns Camelions restaurant in Los Angeles.

title: THE DANCE: FENLEY'S 'MOMENTS'
description: ''GEOLOGIC MOMENTS'' was the mysteriously evocative name Molissa Fenley gave to the full-evening piece she and her company presented on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater. Set to music by Philip Glass and Julius Eastman, the dance had muted subtextual elements. But there were times when wondering about the context and extra-dance content of the work proved more absorbing than the dance itself.

title: AMERICAN KILLED IN CONTRA ATTACK
description: Thousands of foreign volunteers have gone to Nicaragua, trying to help the Sandinista Government improve living conditions. They include an estimated 1,500 to 2,000 Americans in the country at any given time. For, while the Reagan Administration supports the insurgents who want to overthrow the Sandinistas, the United States also recognizes the Sandinista Government and has diplomatic relations with it. Last week, one of the Americans, Benjamin Ernest Linder, a 27-year-old engineer from Portland, Ore., was killed in an attack by United States-supported anti-Government guerrillas in an ambush in a remote northeast part of the country. It was unclear whether Mr. Linder and his co-workers had been armed.

title: Sarah P. Conners Is Wed in Albany To an Executive
description: At St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Albany yesterday Sarah Parker Conners, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Conners of New York and Loudonville, N.Y., was married to William Moran Schaefer Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Schaefer of Loudonville. The Rev. Dr. Laman Bruner performed the ceremony.

description: Those who heard the joyous, yet melancholy music late Friday night and followed it found six young musicians - the drummer was small and looked no more than 14 years old. The sound, not heard often in New York City, brought back memories of the venerable Jimmy Ryan's, recently deceased, of 54th Street.

description: A highway engineer has come up with a way to quantify the severity of traffic jams. As might be expected, they are bad in New York City and likely to get worse. Perhaps surprisingly, they will get worst elsewhere.

title: NO LONGER IN HIDING
description: THESE DAYS, IF A WOMAN LEANS FORWARD and a bit of an essential underpinning shows, it is not considered a fashion faux pas. Quite the opposite. Today's teddies, brassieres, bustiers, camisoles and corselettes are designed to be seen, and not just in the boudoir. The best do the things they have always been intended to do - help support or shape up a comely figure. But they can also serve as an integral part of a fashion statement. Such underpinnings are as stylishly designed nowadays as what is intended to go over them. Very often, necklines are cut to deliberately reveal a hint of what used to be hidden. And even working women who dress in a rather tailored manner on the outside will confess to the pleasure of knowing they have on something redolent of femininity on the inside. Young women, emulating the attire of pop stars, have inspired the return of the boned corselette. They wear this strapless contraption as the top of their get-up - or over their T-shirts. Older fashionable women, however, have taken up the corselette as the right thing to wear under low-fastening or clinging evening wear. Many name designers, including Italy's Valentino, are now producing feminine underthings. Some, like Parisian Jean-Paul Gaultier, are even designing cocktail dresses of old-time corset materials styled to spoof the original item. But these are advanced - a fashion advisable only for the very special woman and, then, for a very special occasion. -

title: ARE VIEWERS ENTITLED TO GAMES ON FREE TV?
description: The real issue facing us is not whether viewers should have to spend a few extra bucks a month to see games on cable as opposed to free television; it's whether they should be able to see games at all. People are finally getting awfully mad about the unavailability of cable television for most New York homes. Now if only all that anger could be focused directly on the two public officials, Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch (a notorious nonsports fan), who have the regulatory power to do something about the problem. JOSEPH J. KENNEDY New York

title: WHEN THE DIFFERENCE REALLY MATTERS
description: NOT knowing what a piece of software really can do is one of the greatest stumbling blocks to putting it to use. Ten years ago, for instance, few writers had any idea of the value of moving blocks of text or of searching and replacing words or phrases. Today these functions are standard on most word processing packages. They are office tools that not only save time and sometimes frustration, but generally make our work easier and more productive. Their advantages are obvious.

Grieg at his best -which is usually when his music is at its simplest - invents such a tradition out of thin air. And it is a world of such charm and fascination that even an entire evening of his songs - like the one Norma French and Richard Gordon offered at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night - never palls.

A pupil of Nicolo Amati, whose exquisitely crafted instruments were the most sought after, was Antonio Stradivari. This month, 250 years after his death, Cremona will inaugurate the Stradivari Festival.

description: UNTIL a short while ago, sport fishermen in New Jersey and New York faced the possibility that striped bass would be off limits to them this season, but the species may now be caught in both states save for New York's marine waters when the season opens Friday.

But Americans are often slow to adopt new ideas that have originated elsewhere. A minor example is the bidding box, which was invented in Sweden a quarter of a century ago and is used automatically in every small Scandinavian club.

That was the year he led demonstrations in the county against the Vietnam War, organized a rally featuring a man described in fliers as ''Defense Captain, Black Panther Party, Westchester County'' and baked an ''integrated peace cake'' with chocolate and vanilla icing and a peace sign decoration.

Tied for the lead with three more experienced golfers -Hal Sutton, Dan Pohl and Ken Brown -Perry will be going after the top prize of $225,000 in Sunday's final round of the $1.2 million Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational.

title: NONFICTION
description: BOGANIS: Letters From the Hunt - A Field Journal. By Wilhelm Dinesen. Translated by Lise Lange Striar and Myles Striar. (Rowan Tree Press, 124 Chestnut Street, Boston, Mass. 02108, $13.95.) ''This is living,'' wrote Wilhelm Dinesen in 1886, summing up a description of long days of hunting (''you hunt alone'') and nights of dining (''white tie and tails) on fresh game. ''Boganis: Letters From the Hunt'' details the joys and demands of a way of life that Dinesen's daughter Karen would celebrate 50 years later in ''Out of Africa.'' Born in 1845 into the Danish nobility, Dinesen spent a restless youth wandering and soldiering, and lived for two contented years in Wisconsin, hunting and trapping with the Indians whose ways he assumed. The Chippewas gave him the name he would latter use as a pseudonym, Boganis, meaning hazelnut. He returned to Denmark, married and fathered five children, the second of whom, Karen, was to inherit his passion for nature; he committed suicide when she was 10 years old. Written during hunting expeditions in Scandinavia and appearing now for the first time in English, ''Letters From the Hunt'' displays heightened powers of observation and insight into the complex systems of seasons, climates and migrations. Despite his enthusiasm for hunting, Dinesen believed that man has a responsibility to manage and preserve wildlife, and repeatedly urged the restriction of ''hunting to some extent through protective wildlife legislation.'' The hunter and his prose aspire to the same virtues: restraint, discipline, precision. (Ocassional lapses into verse disavow this ideal.) Dispersed throughout the letters are bits of homely wisdom and advice on topics both practical and genteel: fishing lures, dogs, menu planning, love, duck farming, haberdashery, taxidermy, conoe making and woman's place in the hunt (at home). The letters conjure the image of an independent, well-fed, expert sportsman of a particular time and place - a Natty Bumppo in spats.

title: BARGAINING PROPOSALS REFLECT WIDE GAP ON KEY ISSUES
description: When the chief labor negotiators for the National Football League players and owners exchanged opening proposals for a new collective bargaining agreement two weeks ago, they gave each other documents that reflected vast differences in how they think professional football's economic system should operate.

title: Roommates
description: I CAME RATHER LATE to understanding myself in the cycle of life. Until three years ago, I was a boy in relation to my grandfather. He lived to 107 and remained mentally and physically capable until the end of his life. A generation after the last of his friends died, he could still mow the lawn on a hot summer afternoon, and he insisted on doing so. I usually wrestled the mower from his grip, but his extraordinary energy I took for granted. I had seen it all my life; he was my roommate.

title: GLAMOUR AWARDS
description: IT didn't quite have the celebrity quotient of the Academy Awards ceremony, but last week's International Center of Photography Awards Dinner in New York managed to bestow some Hollywood-style glamour on the field. The I.C.P. awards were the third installment of a program to honor outstanding talents in the field.

title: VIOLINIST PLANS CONCERT IN MEMORY OF A FRIEND
description: MOST people don't deliberate over Schonberg's ''Phantasy'' on their Stradavarius. But when the violin virtuoso Stephanie Chase saw that score on Herbert L. Cohen's music stand in his home a few years ago, during one of the musical evenings hosted by the Cohens in Westport, she knew he was more than an amateur.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Newcomer to the Seafood Scene

title: A VERBAL ASSIST
description: For three long hours they faced each other across a desk, the animated speech consultant and the sober scientist from Taiwan.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: Bruce Weber's perceptive article ''Alone Together: The Unromantic Generation'' (April 5), did not go far enough. It should have been entitled ''The Unromantic Age.'' Though yuppies in their mid-20's may reflect most obviously a loss of human values, the trend is much more pervasive. Consider the longstanding success of ''Dallas,'' Madonna's hit song ''Material Girl,'' the beer commercial ''You Can Have It All'' and the recent scandals originating in greed. One can only conclude that there is a national obsession, among people of all ages, with money, status and power. CHARLES KLEIN New York City

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
Why Teachers Should Serve On School Boards
description: LEAD: WHEN I ran for the Board of Education in 1983, I had already been a high school teacher for 19 years. Throughout the 1970's, a time of strife, strikes and cutbacks in education, some teachers vaguely alluded to the need for friends of education, even teachers, on local school boards. Having toyed with this idea for a number of years,

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
Atlantic County's Beginning
description: LEAD: RE-ENACTING an event that took place 150 years ago, the Atlantic County Board of Chosen Freeholders will meet in Mays Landing at noon next Sunday to adopt resolutions creating the county and making Mays Landing the county seat. The board, dressed in period costumes, will then adjourn at the call of its chairman, John F.

title: Goodwill Games Get 1990 Dates
description: With an eye to the weather, the 1990 Goodwill Games will be July 20 through Aug. 5, organizers have decided.

title: Piquet Out of Race
description: ONE Brazilian, Nelson Piquet, will skip today's San Marino Grand Prix auto race in Imola, Italy, and another, Ayrton Senna, will leave from the pole position. Piquet, who suffered a concussion and a left ankle injury when he went off a curve shortly after clocking the fastest qualifying time in Friday's official practice, was discharged from a Bologna hospital yesterday. Ready to compete in the Formula One event, Piquet flew to the race site, but doctors found him physically unfit for racing.

title: JAILED EX-OFFICIAL PRESSES FOR RELEASE
description: LEAD: ENTERING a visiting room at the minimum-security facility in Yaphank, Richard Ignatow carried with him a dog-eared paperback copy of ''Les Miserables.'' A bookmark showed that halfway through a six-month sentence for contempt of court, he's also halfway through Victor Hugo's story of a hounded prisoner, a tale that he sees as an analogy to his present circumstances.

title: OLD LINEN AND LACE RETURNS IN LONDON
description: Stephen Lunn, a London antiques dealer, holds up a big linen sheet, old and worn. Not long ago it might have wound up in a trash heap. But for a small, ardent following, this old sheet is a treasure. Its appeal lies in the soft, smooth feel that crisp new linen lacks. Renewed interest in antique textiles has further burnished its popularity - and its price. In Britain, antique linens are being snapped up by a new generation of sybarites, among them the so-called New Georgians, history-minded collectors who outfit their vintage homes with vintage objects. And some Americans are starting to collect old linens as well.

title: DANCE: 'VARIATIONS' BY BALANCHINE
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Theme and Variations'' is more than a set of choreographic patterns to music by Tchaikovsky. When well danced, this ballet can have the elegance of a fancy party. Its variations can seem like sparkling repartee and its duets can resemble the sonnets two sophisticated lovers might send each other.

title: Audience of One For a Daughter
description: MY daughter turns this way and that, striking professional model-like poses as best she knows how. I regard her with mixed feelings, my mouth perhaps too tight, lips more pursed (as my own mother might say) than smiling openly and appreciatively: an independent, willful tear sneaks warily down my cheek.

title: Marion M. Shackford Wed to Gary Muldoon
description: At the First Unitarian Church in Rochester yesterday Marion March Shackford was married to Gary Muldoon by the Rev. Robert M. Lindberg, an Episcopal priest. The bride's daughters, Laura and Sarah Chazan, were bridesmaids, and Arthur W. Muldoon was his brother's best man.

title: FOLK ARTS ARE REBORN IN THE OZARKS
description: Throughout the 1960's, Mountain View, Ark., was cut off from the world. There were no paved roads, no railroad tracks and no bus lines into this remote Ozark community.

title: Q & A
description: SALES TAX ON CO-OPS Question: I read recently that apartment houses are among the kind of investment properties that are automatically reassessed at 45 percent of market value when sold.
