Does this mean that the apartment building in which I live would be reassessed at 45 percent of value if sold to a converter or a co-op corporation?. . . . H. P., Manhattan Answer: David Goldstein, a tax specialist with the city Department of Finance, said that for assessment purposes, the law distingushes between sales of residential buildings to investors and sales to their residents through co-op corporations. Section 581 of the Real Property law says that tax assessment on sales to co-op corporations are based not on the actual sale price but on comparable value as a rental.

title: GARRY HART THE ELUSIVE FRONT-RUNNER
description: PLEASE,'' SAID THE frustrated politician on the other side of the Formica breakfast table in a New Hampshire hotel, ''keep your mind open to the possibility that I'm not weird.''

title: Charter Panel Told of Need for Local Power
description: In the sometimes conflicting testimony on many issues at the New York City Charter Revision Commission hearings so far, a common complaint has emerged. Private citizens and elected and appointed officials are saying that municipal government needs greater decentralization so that officials at every level can be held more accountable.

title: GLASS FIT FOR AN EMPEROR
description: CRAFTSMEN OF THE Roman empire spun, cut, engraved, painted and blew works of stunning virtuosity in glass, as can be seen in ''Glass of the Caesars,'' an exhibition described by the Corning Museum of Glass as the most important presentation of Roman glass ever assembled. The assessment is shared by the British Museum in London and the Romisch-Germanisches Museum in Cologne, West Germany, organizers with Corning of this show.

title: TRASH, AGE 140, IS A TREASURE TO ARCHEOLOGISTS IN THE VILLAGE
description: Perhaps somebody in Jacob Shute's house at 25 Barrow Street thought it was a fine day for spring cleaning. Out into an abandoned cistern went all kinds of junk: pottery, plates, medicine bottles, a tobacco pipe, fish and mutton bones, teacups, buttons and at least one bullet.

title: TWO SHOWS IN NEW HAVEN
description: IN New Haven, the Yale University Art Gallery is offering ''Charles Sheeler:

title: STAGE: COMICAL BENEFIT FOR THE HOMELESS
description: SOME 30 comedians, most from the New York area, donated their talents Wednesday evening to Comedy Cares, a benefit for several organizations serving the city's homeless. The two shows, each featuring a different lineup of talent, were taped at the Eisner and Lubin Auditorium of New York University. for a home-video and a possible cable-television special.

title: DELAYED WEDDING, HOPEFUL MOTHER
description: Tall, handsome and hard-working, Alejandrino Arriaga is the apple of Imelda Vega Cruze's dark eyes, although, with little English, they wouldn't have put it quite that way.

title: RIPPING CLIO'S BODICE - THE CHRONCILE OF A SWEET SAVAGE HACK
description: ON the first day of school, my junior high English teacher used to make us write essays called ''What I Did on My Vacation.'' I always invented healthy, normal activities like sailing and swimming to conceal the fact that I had spent the summer in our beach cottage pantry soaking up the fiction of Frank Yerby. I was the happiest girl in the world, drunk on historical novels.

title: SCHOOL BOARDS LOSING YOUTH
description: FAME may be ''the thirst of youth,'' according to Lord Byron, but not for some local school officials. Two of Long Island's youngest school board members have decided not to seek re-election this month.

title: Paris Museums
description: To the Editor: As a long-time francophile and museum lover, I took special interest in your article on the small museums of Paris (Travel, Feb. 8). I would like to add two personal favorites.

title: Prominent Georgia Dissident Reported Released in Soviet
description: A prominent Georgian dissident, Merab Kostava, was freed from labor camp this week, another newly released political dissenter said today.

title: What Ails Musicals; Upbeat Rock?
description: To the Editor:

title: Conner's Way
description: To the Sports Editor

title:
WESCHESTER JOURNAL;
Helping Hands
description: LEAD: If you are in high school, have some spare time, and think you could work with the retarded, Youth-ARC wants you. The program, which has branches nationwide, is affiliated with the Westchester Assocation for Retarded Citizens. Volunteers meet once a week after school to engage the retarded recreational activities.

title: BENEFIT AUCTION
description: The Hudson River Keeper Fund will be the beneficiary of an auction at 3 P.M. today in the Garrison Union Free School on Route 9D. Ron DeSilva, a former vice president of Christie's, will wield the gavel as some unusual items go on the block.

title: HOW AMERICA IS LOSING ITS EDGES
description: WETLANDS are places rich with life. Swamps, bogs and estuaries, tidal flats, prairie potholes and shallow lakes, are breeding grounds and habitats for insects and amphibians, fish and mollusks, waterfowl and mammals. They are are keys to the food chain.

title: WEARING MEN'S SHIRTS, OFF THE CUFF
description: THERE is something different in men's dress shirts these days - women. They've worn them before, but generally not to the office. Now they have discovered that the roominess these shirts afford looks both chic and professional. What's more, men's shirts are usually more reasonably priced than standard women's styles, and who's willing to turn her back on a bargain?

title: HIGH FLYING HORSEMAN
description: He strode through the flower-draped paddock at Hialeah Park in Florida, an intense man in a navy blazer. A shock of silver-streaked hair spilled down his forehead; his craggy features were deeply tanned. As he stopped next to one of the horses being saddled for the afternoon's featured race, a woman nearby tugged at her husband's sleeve. ''Who's that?'' she asked. ''Henry de Kowalski,'' he replied. ''You know, the Polish guy who wins the Belmont Stakes every year. Everybody calls him Mr. Lucky.''

title: IRAN-CONTRA INQUIRY NETS ITS FIRST OFFENDER
description: EVEN as Congress made final preparations for the opening this week of its public hearings on the Iran-contra scandals, a central question was resolved. There is no longer any doubt that Federal criminal laws were broken.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: In this era of social, political and economic flux, romance is not dead. It has simply been scaled down to a more manageable size. RUSSELL RIGGS Trenton

title: 'ADOPT-A-FAMILY' BEGUM TO AID HOMELESS
description: CONCERN for a homeless population that is rapidly surpassing the county's ability to house and service it has brought together churches, synagogues and community groups in a new initiative to help the homeless.

title: HOME VIDEO: THEATER
description: KEYSTONE An original musical composed by Lance Mulcahy. Lyrics by John McKellar. Book by Dion McGregor. Starring Ann Leslie Morrison and Wayne Bryan. 1983. Sony Video Software. 90 minutes. $59.95.

title: WAR IN AN ALTERNATE UNIVERSE
description: IN THE FIELD OF FIRE Edited by Jeanne Van Buren Dann and Jack Dann. 415 pp. New York: Tor/St. Martin's Press. Paper, $8.95.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Mayhem, anyone? Try ''Murder on the Orient Express'' or ''Malice Aforethought.'' The two classy British-based suspense puzzles are back on TV this week. Novices should pounce. Those who know whodunit can savor the expertise.

title: Helena ten Bos Plans To Be Married in June
description: Mrs. Alastair Campbell of Bernardsville, N.J., and Frans H. ten Bos of London have announced the engagement of their daughter Helena ten Bos to Count Frederic de Belloy de Saint-Lienard, the son of Count and Countess Henri de Belloy de Saint-Lienard of Notre Dame de Gravenchon, France. A June 27 wedding is planned.

title: DANCE: THE HAIM COMPANY
description: WALTER TERRY once suggested that dance critics ought to try writing reviews without adjectives. There were adjectives all over the place in a program presented by Mark Haim and Dancers on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. There were also ideas. But one longed at times to get Mr. Haim into a room without a single striking lighting or scenic effect, antic bit of soundscore, rubber face or funny walk at his disposal and see what the results would be.

title: FINDING A PLACE TO LIVE ISN'T EASY
description: LEAD: LEIGH CURTIN, a single mother with a 12-year-old son, did not think she would have trouble finding an apartment when, to be closer to her public-relations job, she tried a year ago to move from Toms River to Secaucus. She was white, earning more than $25,000 a year and had references from landlords.

title: AMBASSADOR OF TRUE LUST
description: BURNING PATIENCE By Antonio Skarmeta. Translated by Katherine Silver. 118 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Paper, $6.95. Cloth, $10.95.

title: Joan Fisher Is Married
description: Joan Catharine Fisher and Christopher M. Fox, art teachers at the Haverford School, were married yesterday at White's Chapel in Milton, Del. The Rev. John W. Sonnenday, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Michael McGarry, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Fisher of McLean, Va., and Milton, is a graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design. Mr. Fox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Fox Jr. of Philadelphia, graduated from the Tyler School of Art at Temple University.

title: AN EXQUISITE NOVEL, A CLOUDY DRAMATIZATION
description: ELIZABETH BOWEN'S ''DEATH OF the Heart,'' published in 1938, remains an exquisite exploration of adolescence. Even today, when teen-ager anxieties seem centered on whether or not Molly Ringwald will get a date for the school prom, the novel can whisk readers back a mere 50 years to a time when a sensitive 16-year-old girl named Portia might still have to confront the profoundly unsettling specter of Innocence Betrayed. This takes place, admittedly, in a very special and insulated world of social privilege, dominated by those possessing what Ms. Bowen chose to call ''a natural grace.'' But, sharply perceived, the story is almost breathtakingly illuminating about the human condition.

title: LAURIE METCALF, STEPPING OUT FROM STEPPEN WOLF
description: LAST WINTER, WHEN THE STEPPEN-wolf Theater Company's production of ''Educating Rita'' was closing in Chicago, a New York producer, checkbook in hand, offered to bring it all to Manhattan - the director, the two stars, even the set. It was the summons most regional and nonprofit theaters await, and one that most actors dream of.

title: Byars Hurt Again
description: THE PHILADELPHIA EAGLES announced that Keith Byars, who required surgery last year for a broken bone in his right foot, had broken the corresponding bone in his left foot yesterday during practice. Byars injured the fifth metatarsal bone in his left foot making a cut on a pass-pattern drill at Veterans Stadium during the Eagles' fourth minicamp practice, a team spokesman said, adding that surgery would be necessary.

title: FEW WELCOME MATS OUT FOR WALDHEIM IN EUROPE
description: THERE are too many living ghosts of the Nazi past around for any European nation to feel that the case of Kurt Waldheim is simply an isolated Austrian matter. This month France warily confronts the trial of Klaus Barbie, the erstwhile Gestapo chief in Lyons; his lawyer has vowed to expose alleged betrayals by the French resistance and even of the French Jewish community during World War II. And the ailing Rudolf Hess, once Hitler's deputy, just passed his 93d birthday in Berlin's Spandau prison with the Soviet officials turning a deaf ear to West German pleas that he be freed.

title: Roebling Revival On the Delaware
description: IN the days when coal was king, mules on a narrow towpath pulled canal boats along an elevated aqueduct near Lackawaxen, Pa., spanning the Delaware River from coal-rich Pennsylvania into New York.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: GOING DUTCH There may not be many descendants of New York's early Dutch settlers still around on Long Island, but you wouldn't know that on Hofstra's Hempstead campus. The university goes out of its way to emphasize its roots since it is, after all, named after William Hofstra, whose ancestors came from the Netherlands.

title: 'THE MIDDLE AGES': GLIB SOCIAL CRTIQUE
description: WHAT may be most heartening about the emergence of an ongoing professional theater - even if only twice a season - at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck is the concentration on plays of intelligence and substance by the producing director, Norman Kline.

title: Return From the Dustbin of History
description: I appeal to you, a future generation of Party leaders, whose historical mission will include the obligation to take apart the monstrous cloud of crimes that is growing ever more huge in these frightful times. . . . -Nikolai Bukharin, a few days before his arrest in 1937 Will Mikhail S. Gorbachev give Leon Trotsky, Bukharin and other Bolshevik revolutionaries their rightful place in the history of the Soviet Union? This has been a subject of speculation since February, when the Soviet leader vowed that ''there must be no forgotten names, no blank spaces, either in history or in literature.''

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article April 19 profiling the community of Hoboken, N.J., incorrectly charactrized house prices. Detached single-family houses sell for up to $700,000; brownstones range in price from $200,000 to $500,000.

title: West Berlin Police Seize 51 In Riot After May Day Fete
description: Hundreds of youths looted shops and burned vehicles during an overnight riot described by the police as the worst violence in the city in several years. At least 51 people were arrested.

title: VAGUELY LIBERAL, FULL OF DOUBT
description: THE OLD LEFT By Daniel Menaker. 132 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: Bruce Weber does offer hope, though, when he states that ''young people are older than they used to be.'' I suspect that by the time they are 30 they will be sufficiently bored by their own constrictions to go through ''mid-life crisis.'' Fortunately, they will be young enough to start over, or to start, period. JEANNE ST. REMY New York City

title: AN OMINOUS TREND TO GREATER INEQUALITY
description: THE United States is fast becoming a nation of two classes, with the haves growing richer, the have-nots growing poorer, and the middle class slowly sinking into oblivion. We should resist this trend, not just to preserve a more equitable society, but also to avert disaster.

title: THREE INVASIVE PLANTS
description: LEAD: SOME plants, newly introduced to the flower garden, may be loved for their beauty or novelty the first year. But when they've had a few seasons to show their habits, they can easily get out of hand by appearing where they are not wanted.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: After reading Bruce Weber's article, I am struck by two conflicting impulses: the urge to ask the author how he got his job at The New York Times and the desire to ask him out for a romantic dinner. LYNN ARDITI Washington

title: NED ROREM DELIVERS A SOLO ON THE STATE OF MUSIC
description: ''I AM AS INSECURE AS I EVER was,'' says Ned Rorem, the 63-year-old Pulitzer Prize-winning composer. ''If I don't have tangible proof every day of the week that I am appreciated - a commission, a letter from a stranger, a performance by someone somewhere - I suffer.''

title: Cuban Team Visit To U.S. Canceled
description: Baseball games between Johns Hopkins University and a visiting team of Cuban all-stars have been canceled because the Cuban players were unable to receive American visas in time for their scheduled trip here next week.

title: ARE VIEWERS ENTITLED TO GAMES ON FREE TV?
description: The matter of ''entitlement'' to view free games at home may be debatable, but to baseball teams concerned about increasing the ranks of their fans there can be but one answer. Make it as easy (especially for those without access to cable) and as inexpensive as possible to follow what players are accomplishing.

title: What Ails Musicals; Flexible Fig Leaf
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Fairstein Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Linda A. Fairstein to Justin N. Feldman took place yesterday at the home of Alice Fairstein, the bride's mother, in Mount Vernon, N.Y. Judge Pierre N. Leval of the Federal District Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: Ms. Peckinpaugh, TV Anchor, Weds
description: Janet S. Peckinpaugh, a news anchor for WTNH-TV in New Haven, and Elliott Francis Gerson, vice president of government and public affairs of the Travelers Companies in Hartford, were married yesterday at the Polytechnic Club in Hartford. Judge Anthony V. DeMayo of the Connecticut Superior Court performed the ceremony.

title: REAGAN RESHPAING CONTRA AID DEBATE
description: President Reagan will seek to redefine the legislative debate over United States aid to the contras by muting a desire for military aid to overthrow the Sandinistas, White House officials said today.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE National State Bank in Elizabeth will exhibit for the rest of the year artifacts commemorating its 175-year history. A similar exhibit is on display at the bank's Trenton office.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: It is not that we are ''self-preoccupied'' or overly calculating. Rather, we are in love with equally old virtues such as hard work, patience and sacrifice. To say that we are unromantic is to discount our dedication to equally passionate affairs, such as writing a book or building a financial success.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
DETERRING YOUTHFUL BIGOTRY
description: LEAD: A COMMON denominator in the racial assaults in Howard Beach, the University of Massachusetts, Forsyth County and elsewhere is the youth of the attackers. Most are male adolescents. This was true both of the white attackers and later of the black retaliators.

title: Headliners; Sincere Actors
description: In a refreshing departure from the usual vein of such events, none of the actors who paid tribute to Sir Alec Guinness last week appeared to be practicing his or her craft. Instead, the ''Tribute to Alec Guinness'' by the Film Society of Lincoln Center was marked by unabashed admiration of his mastery. Irene Worth said that while appearing with Sir Alec in T.S. Eliot's ''Cocktail Party,'' she stationed herself offstage one night to discover what technique he used to provoke roars of laughter with a one-word line. ''It was extraordinary, because he wasn't doing anything, that I could see,'' she said. ''And that, of course, is his genius and his secret.''

title:
ART;
Wallace Putnam Works At the Somerstown Gallery
description: LEAD: AT 88, Wallace Putnam is a year older than this century, but like the man, the painting shows no signs of flagging. It might be said that Mr. Putnam ''draws'' with paint in clear colors. Recent pure white seagulls tipped in yellow are as vigorous as paintings from the 1930's that comment on the Depression.

title: THE FINE ART OF COLLECTING COLLECTORS
description: ON THE HOT TURF OF CONTEMPORARY art, museums are beginning to look like corporate raiders. In today's market, where seven-figure prices for major 20th-century works are increasingly evident, institutions can no longer come up with the money to buy them. So they are making more aggressive pitches than ever for donations of single works and whole collections, and boldly invading the ''territory'' of other institutions to do so.

title: Starting Over to House Newark's Poor
description: OF all the grim images that have ruled Newark, overshadowing small signs of hope whenever they arose, none has been more severe than that of its high-rise housing projects. Ravaged, worn, largely vacant and looming over their crumbling neighborhoods, they have become towering reminders of the city's failure to care for its own.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: I disagree that ambition or even a moderate amount of consumerism, per se, creates an emotional void. Is a winter sunset any less brilliant when viewed through an office window? Is ''West Side Story'' less memorable on a VCR?

title: SHIPWRECKS POSE A PROBLEM FOR STATE
description: THE crew of the Japanese commercial vessel Sindia got good and drunk one night in 1901, so the story goes, and she sank in the Atlantic off Ocean City.

title: LIFE STYLES OF THE RICH AND PAGAN
description: A HISTORY OF PRIVATE LIFE Philippe Aries and Georges Duby, general editors. Volume One: From Pagan Rome to Byzantium. Edited by Paul Veyne. Translated by Arthur Goldhammer. Illustrated. 670 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $29.50.

title: PRESIDENT OF HUNTER IN SPOTLIGHT AT 3D WOMEN'S ROAST
description: Feminists and their friends roasted and toasted one of their own, Dr. Donna E. Shalala, the president of Hunter College, last week at a champagne-and-stuffed-chicken dinner atop the World Trade Center.

title: REMEMBER THE FUTURE
description: THE NATURE OF TIME Edited by Raymond Flood and Michael Lockwood. Illustrated. 187 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. $19.95.

title: CAPITAL MARCHES: PROTESTS AT C.I.A. ECHO 60'S, 70'S
description: IN counterpoint to an anti-Administration protest Monday that ended with more than 550 arrests, one man carried a sign reading: ''Go Home Amy - You Too Abby.''

title: Perri Klass's Enemies
description: To the Editor

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: I think what Bruce Weber is trying to say is that romantic love is a luxury, that America is growing old and tight-pocketed and that we, the ''unromantic generation,'' are the necessary result. He is correct.

title: HIGH C'S AT LOW PRICES IN GERMANY
description: THIS IS BEING WRITTEN IN THE MIDST OF A new production here of ''Der Ring des Nibelungen.'' The subject, however, is neither the performance of Wagner's music nor Ruth Berghaus's avant-garde staging. My concern here is with the sociology of opera - how the very experience of going to opera in Frankfurt seems so different from that in New York. My intention is not to point fingers but to elucidate differences, in the hope of suggesting not that Frankfurt is perfect - it is by no means so - but that New Yorkers should hesitate before defining norms for the art of opera based on their own, distinctly parochial viewpoint.

title: Talking: Admissions; A Job Can No Longer Be an Issue
description: PROSPECTIVE renters, condominium and co-op buyers, landlords and co-op board members are beginning tolearn how to accommodate to a recent amendment to New York City's human-rights law barring discrimination in housing because of occupation . The measure, signed into law Nov. 25, 1986, resulted from dozens of complaints by people who were turned down for an apartment because their jobs were considered a potential nuisance.

title: WEIGEL LEADS 1-2-3 PARADE OF EAST GERMANS
description: Ronald Weigel of East Germany won the 50-kilometer event in the World Cup of race walking yesterday in Central Park, and that's not too surprising. Weigel has walked the two fastest times in history in the distance and yesterday's finish, 3 hours 42 minutes 26 seconds, was a World Cup record.

title: BLUES: COPELAND'S AFRICAN INSPIRATION
description: JOHNNY COPELAND, the Texas bluesman who was at S.O.B.'s on Wednesday and Thursday, has never written a scholarly study on the West African roots of the blues. But while the scholars have been theorizing, Mr. Copeland has been busy putting theory into practice. On a recent album, and now on his Afro-Blues '87 Tour, he has been working with a mixed group of African musicians and American blues players, hammering out a common musical language.

title: OPERA: COPELAND'S 'TENDER LAND'
description: ''THE TENDER LAND,'' Aaron Copland's second opera, was produced in 1954, revised and revived the next year, and has been seen occasionally - mostly on college campuses - since then. It has never really caught on, but the manifest merits evident in excerpts, workshop performances and an abbreviated recording have placed it high on the list of American works deserving re-evaluation. The new production that opened at the Long Wharf Theater here Friday night provides an opportunity: it is caringly conceived, sensitively and skillfully carried.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Rebuked for Rise in Trade With Hanoi
description: As the United States and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations prepare for new rounds of talks with Vietnam on missing Americans and the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia, the Japanese are being criticized in this region for steadily expanding Hanoi trade.

title: VOLUNTEER ORGANIZATION MARKS A CENTENNIAL
description: THE latest United States Postal Service commemorative honors the United Way concept which was conceived 100 years ago in Denver, Colo. The stamp was released in Washington, D.C., and is on sale now.

title: Florida
description: To the Editor: ''A Florida Shore Where Solitude Rules'' by Melvin Mencher (Travel, March 8) must have brought a smile to many ex-G.I.'s.

title: HELPING WORKERS LEARN ENGLISH
description: LEAD: IT was noon on a recent Wednesday and workers streamed out of the warehouse at the SID Tool Company in Plainview for the silver lunch wagon parked outside. Melvin Navas did not follow along.

title: Classical Music
description: Well-tuned by the religious observances of April, choral groups now propel themselves into a busy May. Sunday afternoon at 4:45, the Manhattan Choral Festival sings Vivaldi, Vaughan Williams and Samuel Adler at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and 50th Street, in a Christian sabbath celebration, and Sunday evening at 7, the Merkin Concert Hall at the Abraham Goodman House (129 West 67th Street) offers ''A Time for Freedom,'' a concert in support of Russian Jewry. London's Zemel Choir and students and faculty from the Peabody Conservatory of Music will perform Cotel's ''Night of the Murdered Poets,'' Stuchefsky's Klesmer Trio, Russian Jewish choral music and violin compositions.

title: Data Update
description: HOUSING COSTS: N.Y.-Northeast N.J. area*

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: DR. SPOCK IN PLAINFIELD

title: Discouragement Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: PIPELINE MAPPING SEEN AS PERIL TO ANCIENT SITES
description: ALL the archeological sites along the proposed gas pipeline from Canada through upstate New York and Connecticut to Long Island were carefully identified and mapped, so that they could be properly protected. Now, an archeologist, in a view becoming increasingly widely shared, says the attempt at protecting the sites has endangered them.

title:
TO START WITH...;
WHEN C.E.O.'S BID A FOND GOOD BUY
description: LEAD: Who says you can't take it with you?

title: Brooklyn Man, 92, Shoots His Daughter and Himself
description: A Brooklyn man, apparently afraid of being sent to a nursing home, shot and seriously wounded one of his daughters and shot himself in the head yesterday, the police said.

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
New Sabbath Service
description: LEAD: Eleven women who set out to ''demasculinize'' the traditional Friday night sabbath service of their Reform congregation found that the project involved more than removing the many male nouns and pronouns.

title: WOMEN AND CAREERS
description: As a professional team with expertise in women's career development, we wish to respond to an article by Mary Jane Genova called ''Training Women for False Hopes'' [ Opinion page, April 5 ] . Wherever a need presents itself, resourceful people are likely to hang out a shingle and solicit business; and as in most businesses, service providers include competent professionals, shysters and also-rans. Career counseling is no exception. Helping women to enter the marketplace - either for the first time or after a long absence - requires comprehensive assessment and thoughtful planning as well as the assertive behavior that Ms. Genova describes. And all job-search activities should be part of an appropriately targeted self-marketing campaign.

title: Anne Stires Is Married
description: Anne Carroll Stires and John Henry Carter Jr. were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. John G. B. Andrew, assisted by his vicar, the Rev. Gary P. Fertig. Martha S. Perry attended her sister, and Jamie Campbell Fagan was best man.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MAY 3, 1987
description: International 3-23 2,3.6,q>An ambassador helped the contras on orders from senior officials in Washington who are now denying their involvement. ''It's insane,'' said Lewis A. Tambs, the former Ambassador to Costa Rica. Page 1 The U.S. role in the contra war has been marked by contradictions and questions since President Reagan approved support for the rebel forces six years ago, officials said. 14 Reagan shifting contra debate 15 Canada wants nuclear submarines to enforce its claim to sovereignty in Arctic waters and protect the coastline, an official said. The Government has concluded that it needs as many as 10 nuclear-powered vessels. 1 An Israeli disk jockey is beloved in his country, although few Israeli Jews have heard of him. Shafik Salman has become known across the Arab world, reaching out to it with jazzed-up Arabic music with Hebrew lyrics. 1 Moscow has a listening system used for eavesdropping on sensitive United States Government communications from a network of East bloc embassies in the Washington area, according to intelligence authorities. 1 A new effort in South Africa to convince whites not to vote in an upcoming election as a protest against apartheid is drawing anger from some liberal politicians. ''We are having to tell people why to vote,'' one said. 11 A Brazilian Government ombudsman has been appointed to combat the country's bureaucratic dragon. The ombudsman's office has handled 5,000 complaints over three months. 18 Thai cabinet pressured by farmers 3 Talks founder in Zimbabwe 3 Filipino rebel runs for Senate 4 Japan rebuked on Hanoi trade 6 U.S. bars a prize-winning pianist 21 Risks growing in A-war systems 23 National 26-39, 50-53, 60-62 2,3.9,q>Amnesty for illegal aliens will begin to be claimed under the new immigration law on Tuesday. Aliens across the country are expected to emerge from the legal and social shadows they have lived under for years. 1 Candidacies often die in Iowa, where the state's party caucuses begin the process of weeding out a crowded field of Presidential aspirants. The candidates are keeping in close touch with Iowans who can help. 1 Albert Einstein's love affair with the woman who would become his first wife is detailed in newly disclosed correspondence between the couple. The letters tell the story of an their anguished relationship. 1 Carl Channell's donors were upset by contras. They have tried to understand how a man they regarded as a patriot had become a self-confessed criminal. 18 Channell solicited contractors 19 A challenge to a board at Harvard has been organized by some alumni who want the university endowment purged of companies doing business in South Africa. The alumni have a slate of candidates for the Board of Overseers. 35 Uproar in a small Vermont town 26 Montana grapples with workers' compensation 26 Volcker urges tax increase 27 Views vary on organ donation 28 Study finds pollution in harbors 38 Boston's elevated Orange Line goes underground 52 Regional 40-48, 54-58 2,3.3,q>A prison ferry is 60 percent empty because its operation is being changed to prevent $3 million in unexpected staffing costs. The ferry, run by New York City, opened three months late and $3 million over budget. 40 The cause of a building's collapse in Bridgeport, Conn., is still unknown, and engineers and investigators have reported little progress after a week of preliminary investigations. 40 Sex bias has been reduced in courts in New York State through sensitivity training and other programs, a committee reported. Court employees no longer deny that such bias exists, the committee's chairwoman said. 48 Opposition to a special high school for gifted students is coming from the New York State Education Department and education groups. The prospects for the proposal are in doubt, according to legislative aides. 46 In a crucial zoning-bias case, judges expressed doubts about whether the plaintiffs have a right to sue. A Long Island town is accused in the case of using its zoning powers to discriminate against poor people. 47 Archeologists see gold in garbage that was thrown into a cistern in Greenwich Village 140 years ago and discovered last week. ''Garbage can tell you all kinds of things,'' said one of the archeologists examining the find. 40 A homosexual rights group has won acceptance outside the homosexual community. The Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund Inc. is the nation's largest organization working for civil rights of homosexuals. 43 Central Park terrace to reopen 40 Need for local power is stressed 41 State backs care in New York hospitals 54

title: COLLAPSE INQUIRY YIELDS FEW ANSWERS
description: After a week of preliminary investigations into the collapse of the L'Ambiance Plaza apartment complex here, engineers and investigators have reported little progress in determining what caused the building to fail, killing 28 people.

title: WORLD-CLASS PERFORMERS
description: EUROPEANS HAVE ALWAYS DONE IT. The Japanese, bolstered by theirmighty yen, have een doint it adroitly over the last decade. And now global investing has come of age in the Unites States, too.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: MY TIRADE AGAINST MYSELF At 71, Jorge Luis Borges had had such a copious literary career that he even grew a bit tired of himself. At least this is what he says in ''Critical Essays on Jorge Luis Borges'' (G. K. Hall), edited by Jaime Alazraki.

title: FIGHTING BACK IN FOUR LANGUAGES
description: THE DEFIANT MUSE Hispanic Feminist Poems from the Middle Ages to the Present. Edited by Angel Flores and Kate Flores. 145 pp. New York: The Feminist Press. Paper, $11.95. Cloth, $29.95. THE DEFIANT MUSE German Feminist Poems from the Middle Ages to the Present. Edited by Susan L. Cocalis. 163 pp. New York: The Feminist Press. Paper, $11.95. Cloth, $29.95. THE DEFIANT MUSE French Feminist Poems From the Middle Ages to the Present. Edited by Domna C. Stanton. 207 pp. New York: The Feminist Press. Paper, $11.95. Cloth, $29.95. THE DEFIANT MUSE Italian Feminist Poems from the Middle Ages to the Present. Edited by Beverly Allen, Muriel Kittel and Keala Jane Jewell. 150 pp. New York: The Feminist Press. Paper, $11.95. Cloth, $29.95.

title: Company With Union Trouble Gets Contract from the Navy
description: The Navy has awarded a $4.1 million contract to a New Hampshire company that has been embroiled in a labor dispute for the past nine months and has become the object of a Congressional inquiry. A Navy spokesman said Friday that the contract, awarded to the Simplex Wire and Cable Company in Newington, N.H., did not alter the service's policy of labor neutrality.

title: Demand for Yew Tree Concerns Environmentalists
description: The Pacific yew tree, which up to now has had so little going for it that it has been left to rot when cut in logging operations, has suddenly become so much in demand that environmentalists are expressing fear about its survival.

title: SORTING THE STOCKPILE
description: NUCLEAR FALLACY Dispelling the Myth of Nuclear Strategy. By Morton H. Halperin. 173 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Ballinger Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: Taxing the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: ACTUALLY, WE ARE ALL GETTING POORER
description: FOR nearly a decade now, analysts have been saying that American income inequality is growing and that the middle class is declining. Yet, while casual observations - widespread layoffs, large numbers of families headed by single women - support their point, Census statistics paint a different picture.

title: Mary Ellen McCabe Wed to Robert D. Kirschner
description: Mary Ellen McCabe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. McCabe of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert D. Kirschner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton I. Kirschner of Brooklyn and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Shimon Berris performed the ceremony at the Monmouth Hills Club in Highlands, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. James McCabe, a Roman Catholic priest who is a cousin of the bride.

title: PRINTS THAT GO BEYOND THE BORDER OF THE MEDIUM
description: SUDDENLY, IT IS NO LONGER enough for a photograph to be a picture of something. For a photograph to succeed in the art world, all the signs this spring suggest, it needs to be an object. And the more elaborate, the better.

title:
TO START WITH...;
NOBLESSE OBLIGE
description: LEAD: Charity may begin at home, but for many a wealthy, socially aspiring American, it can end most pleasantly abroad, courtesy of a tax loophole that has remained intact despite last year's sweeping reform measures.

title: 4 NEW YORK BATHHOUSES STILL OPERATE UNDER CITY'S PROGRAM OF INSPECTIONS
description: More than a year after New York City closed several homosexual bathhouses because of ''unsafe'' sexual practices that it said occurred in them, four others remain open, and health officials say they have found no violations to warrant their closing.

title: OVERSEER IS NAMED FOR V.A. ON PAYMENTS AND PENSIONS
description: A Federal district judge has appointed an outside overseer to supervise the Veterans Administration's compensation and pension division for an indefinite period.

title: UNCERTAINTY AT RENT BOARD
description: THE Rent Guidelines Board faces uncertainty about its membership and jurisdiction as it prepares to hold public hearings on setting new rent levels for tenants in 18 Westchester communities.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report last Sunday about the engagement of Lisa Ann Fiedler to Virgil Thomas Fryman Jr. misidentified the bride-to-be. A corrected version appears today on page 72.

title: SMITHSONIAN SHOW DEPICTS WAR CAMPS
description: The plans of the National Museum of American History for an exhibit on the forced relocation and detention of Japanese-Americans in World War II are arousing new debate over that period. The exhibit is part of the museum's observance of the 200th anniversary of the Constitution.

title: HOUSE TAKES A CHANCE ON A TOUGH TRADE BILL
description: A strong trade bill was passed by the House with enough votes to override the Presidential vet that is certain to come if the bill makes it to the White House included in the omnibus legislation was an amendment sponsored by Richard A. Gephardt, a Missouri Democrat, that requires the President to retaliate against nations with the biggest trade surpluses with the United States, if it is determined that the surplus was a result of unfair trade practices. Mr. Gephardt had tried repeatedly in the past to get his amendment attached to the trade bill. Its success is probably shortlived, however, since the Senate is not likely to enact such tough legislation and the House would probably agree to modify its bill in a compromise.

title: North, on Television, Asserts His Innocence
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North today firmly asserted his innocence of wrongdoing in his role assisting the Nicaraguan rebels and insisted his actions were taken to help the United States.

title: MALE AND FEMALE, MEN AND WOMEN
description: ICE AND FIRE By Andrea Dworkin. 181 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $14.95. INTERCOURSE By Andrea Dworkin. 257 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: Article 612487 -- No Title
description: A steamboat captain trying to save his sidewheeler a few miles made a little improvement to the Mississippi River 156 years ago. Over the decades, it has cost United States taxpayers nearly $500 million for repairs.

title: Antonio Won Pat, 73, Dies; Guam Delegate to Congress
description: Antonio Borja Won Pat, former delegate to Congress from Guam, died of a heart attack Friday at Holy Cross Hospital, hospital officials said. He was 78 years old.

title: STUDENTS AND ACCOMPANISTS FORM TIGHT MUSICAL BOND
description: FOR months, student musicians have been practicing scales and solos, shaping their interpretations and sharpening their technique. ''Nyssma'' is coming. That is short for the yearly New York State School Music Association Evaluation Festival, which is to be held next Friday and Saturday at Manhattanville College in Purchase.

title: Bluebirds, With Help, Are Returning
description: FIFTY years ago, a flock of a hundred or more bluebirds was not an unusual sight.

title:
PAPERBACKS;
FICTION
description: LEAD: ARCHIMEDES AND THE SEAGLE. By David Ireland. (Penguin, $6.95.) Here's a dog who thinks he's the cat's meow. He also thinks he's the only dog author. But, no; in 1950 there was a Jean Dutourd de force, ''A Dog's Head.'' Our dog in question is variously named Archimedes, Happy and, officially, Spangler Red Brian Boru.

title: SECRETS OF HIS SUCCESS
description: GEORGE HAD BEEN ONE OF my best students when I came to Harvard in 1981. I hadn't seen him since graduation.

title: POP AND FOLK ROCKS A QUIET VILLAGE
description: Eleven months of the year Roskilde is a peaceful town. At midday church bells sound, as they have since medieval times. Through the crisp air comes the call of a gull or a mockingbird. And then, July rolls around. Church bells are drowned out by the sound of applause. The occasional sound of a strident guitar is heard across the town, as are the voices of a sing-a-long. For three days in July - this year they will be July 3, 4 and 5 - the Roskilde Festival becomes a magnet for lovers of pop, rock and folk music.

title: THE HUMBLING OF BANKAMERICA
description: The building dominates the San Francisco skyline, not only by its 52-story height but also by its bulk: a monolith rising without setbacks from most of a city block. And the institution that occupies the building, Bank of America, was also until recently a dominator - the biggest bank in the world. Ninety percent of the population of California lived within a mile and a half of one of the bank's 1,100 branches, and from that broad base grew an institution of towering eminence on four continents. At its peak five years ago, BankAmerica, the holding company for Bank of America, had 83,000 employees and assets of $120 billion, about the size of the gross national product of the Netherlands.

title: COPING WITH LIFE AFTER TAX SHELTERS
description: ''NO ONE ever expected to get wealthy on a salary, but they did expect to get wealthy on tax shelters,'' said David N. Swinford, a vice president at Towers Perrin Forster & Crosby. ''These really got gored.''

title: More Nonexistent Classics
description: To the Editor:

title: Diane Schindler to Be Bride
description: Diane Carol Schindler and Grant David Werner plan to be married June 7, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Peter H. Schindler of Manhattan, have announced. Miss Schindler, a graduate of the University of Rochester, is a member of the credit portfolio management department of Credit Lyonnais in Manhattan. Mr. Werner, the son of Ernest M. Werner of Manhattan and the late Mrs. Werner, graduated from Lehigh University. He is a business development officer of the Daiwa Bank Trust Company in Manhattan.

title: Plan to Poison Cape Cod Gulls
description: The Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, which usually defends wildlife vigorously, was in the uncomfortable position of proposing to poison some sea gulls in the Cape Cod area.

title: Businesses Capitalize on the Luxury Car
description: JUDGING from the crowds at the 1987 New York International Auto Show in Manhattan before it closed last week, Americans are still enamored of cars.

title: Fresh Air for Real Kids
description: ''Dear Daddy, I really did it.'' What 9-year-old Felix had done was to climb a tree in Connecticut. ''Dear Mommy, I'm not afraid anymore.'' What 10-year-old Lanette no longer feared was the water in a lake in Vermont. ''I feel like a real kid,'' said 10-year-old James, who suffers from sickle cell anemia. He felt like a real kid after learning to play softball with other youngsters, some of whom were in wheelchairs.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: D.O.A. Hal Roach Studios. 83 minutes. $29.95.

title: EVENTS LISTED TO MARK CONSTITUTION'S BIRTHDAY
description: New York City will celebrate the nation's 200-year-old Constitution, and the city's role in its creation, with various activities over the next two years.

title: BRINGING LIGHT AND SPACE TO A TENEMENT
description: THERE WOULD SEEM, AT FIRST glance, no common ground whatsoever between serious architectural intentions and a tenement on Mott Street. The tenement is harsh, cramped, a pile of tiny warrens that barely meets any rational standard of decent housing. Its problems would not seem to be those that can be solved by a dose of high art.

title: MORE COMPANIES OFFER CHILD-CARE AS JOB INDUCEMENT
description: LEAD: BETWEEN 8 and 8:30 A.M., Sandra Weiner Sosinski of the Monmouth County community of Cream Ridge and her year-old daughter, Mallory, arrive at the Carnegie Family Center here. After seeing Mallory settled, Mrs. Sosinski, a vice president of United Jersey Banks, walks to her nearby office.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: ALL SORTS OF GIFTS AND FUNCTIONAL DESIGNS Modern Classics, a miniature ''design center,'' opened one month ago in Larchmont with unusual functional designs for table, kitchen, household and bath. The celebration of the opening is Saturday, with music from 1:30 to 3:30 P.M.

title: MIXING OFFICE WORKERS AND STORES UNDER ONE ROOF
description: LEAD: IN Uniondale, a European American Bank employee, John McKenna, daydreamed one recent lunch hour about sun-drenched beaches as he flipped through a Hawaiian travel brochure he had just picked up from the travel agency in his building's lobby.

title: 2 AGENCIES OF STATE AT ODDS ON CLEAN AIR
description: LEAD: TWO departments of the state government are involved in a lengthy debate over how to balance the goals of clean air and energy conservation.

title: Writer Says Khomeini Doesn't Seem Very Ill
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini appears to be in better health than Western intelligence officials generally believe, according to a magazine editor who saw the Iranian leader earlier this year.

title: Smoking Advocate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rowny Time Bomb
description: The chorus of doubts that has greeted the Reagan Administration's proposal to eliminate nuclear missiles from Europe includes some surprising voices. But the White House need not have been surprised to find Edward Rowny, one of the President's own arms control advisers, among the critics. He criticized the negotiations and indicated that the missile pact would be a profound mistake unless linked to relieving the Soviet advantage in conventional arms.

title: PROTECTIONIST MOOD OVERSHADOWS REAGAN'S MEETING WITH NAKASONE
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN stood in the White House Rose Garden Friday and said he was optimistic about reducing economic tensions between Japan and the United States, but there were not many people in Washington who shared his characteristically rosy outlook.

title: WHEN ARTHUR KOPIT TACKLES A COP-THRILLER
description: THE PHRASES COME LATE IN the first paragraph of Robert Daley's police thriller ''Hands of a Stranger,'' but they are the ones that gave Arthur Kopit a chilling central image for the two-part mini-series that will begin next Sunday evening at 9 on NBC. A young assistant district attorney is arguing in court against the release of an accused rapist. She turns to look at the suspect, standing just a few feet away. ''If a man is a rapist, she thought, studying him,'' Mr. Daley wrote, ''it ought to be obvious. You ought to be able to tell by looking at him. But nothing shows. Rapists look no different from anybody else. Same with murderers. Evil cannot be recognized at a glance.''

title: GEOGRAPHY TEXT MIXES 'PHYSICAL' AND 'HUMAN'
description: LEAD: IT is not enough to know that Connecticut is the third smallest state and the fourth most densely populated and has a hilly topography, three major river systems, five regions and three metropolitan areas.

title: WHY OUR MEN OF POWER FAILED TO INSPIRE POWERFUL PORTRAITS
description: JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES once wrote that England didn't produce Shakespeare until she could afford to. The comment is a forceful reminder of the extent to which art is sustained by money and power, but it would be a mistake to push its implications too far. If we did, we would be left puzzling over such conundrums as why it is that 19th-century Norway could afford Ibsen and late 20th-century America can only afford - fill in the dramatist of your choice.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
IN SEARCH OF HER OWN CONCERT
description: LEAD: WHEN Eve Queler takes the podium at the John Cranford Adams Playhouse of Hofstra University Saturday night to conduct the Nassau Symphony, the orchestra's yearlong search for a music director will be nearing an end. Ms. Queler, the pioneering female conductor whose Opera Orchestra of New York is a major international showcase for rarely heard operas, is the fifth and final contestant for the position.

title: Streetscapes: The Samuel R. Smith Infirmary; 'Pride of the Island' Facing an Uncertain Future
description: DESPITE its size and prominence, the Samuel R. Smith Infirmary - a great red-brick Victorian castle in New Brighton, S.I. - is a building that has fallen through the cracks.

title: DEVELOPERS HALT PLAN TO BUILD DAM ON NEW HAMPSHIRE RIVER
description: A six-year effort to build a small hydroelectric dam on the Merrimack River here has been abandoned.

title: STRATEGIES FOR TALKING WITH ELDERLY RELATIVES
description: LEAD: FAMILY members provide 80 percent of the care for their elderly relatives, including helping them with chores and finances and providing emotional support. That factor adds importance to improving communication with the elderly, according to the director of the Center for the Study of Aging at the University of

title: Help Gorbachev, but Not Too Much
description: LEAD: Interesting and potentially crucial changes are taking place in the Soviet Union. That Mikhail S. Gorbachev is sincere about transforming his stagnant society is no longer in doubt. Yet, his proposals to the United States - whether on arms control or on trade - should be treated strictly on their merits.

title: GONE OFF FLY-FISHING
description: ''The greatest strategic error of my adult life,'' Paul A. Volcker says - and I feel sure, listening to his deep, booming voice, that the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board is going to talk about something momentous, like the decline of the dollar against the pfennig - ''was to take my wife to Maine on our honeymoon on a fly-fishing trip.'' It cost him dearly, a lost decade of fishing.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
TRADE POLICY SHOULDN'T IGNORE SMALL BUSINESS
description: LEAD: AS THE debate on trade legislation advances in the House of Representatives, we must put people at the center of our trade policy. Specifically, our trade policy has overlooked the small-business community, with its untapped potential for increased exporting of goods and services.

title: ARE VIEWERS ENTITLED TO GAMES ON FREE TV?
description: It seems everyone is making a big fuss about the paucity of games being broadcast on free television these days. Others may welcome the opportunity to experience a season of baseball in a new way. Actually an old way, the way it was before picture tubes, slow-motion replays and remote controls evolved to render the fan an unthinking, lifeless lump, slouched six times a week in a recliner.

title: Bargain Fares In the Skies Over France
description: Air fare cutting has come to France.

title: BIDDING ADIEU TO THE FEMININE MYSTIQUE
description: THERE WAS A TIME WHEN GOING TO THE movies let us sink into solitude, when the archetypes of ideal women were before us in all their vast simplicity, as aloof as goddesses, nine feet high. They represented what we wished we were or thought we were, would like to be, ought to be, ought not to be.

title: INSURERS START TO TOUGHEN THEIR RULES
description: SINCE the 1970's, health and life insurance for people labeled high risk - either because they have medical problems like hypertension or because they engage in hazardous activities like sky diving - has become more and more affordable. The reason: Medical and technological advances have enabled the industry to assess more accurately the underwriting risks, and more insurers began competing to cover risky applicants. ''Almost anyone can get insurance, if they shop hard enough,'' said J. Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization.

title: A June Wedding For Nancy Kase
description: Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Kase of Manhattan and Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Anne Kase to James Henry O'Brasky, a son of Elizabeth H. Barnston of New Haven and Harris O'Brasky of Medway, Mass. The couple plan to be married June 21.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
New Castle, N.H.: Trying to Save A Victorian
description: LEAD: WENTWORTH-BY-THE-SEA, the last Victorian resort hotel to grace the coast of northern New England, stands forlorn and empty, a major piece that remains to be fitted into a large development puzzle on this island community hard by Portsmouth.

title: Andrea Lee Berg, Student, To Wed Juvenal A. daSilva
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Carl Berg of Floral Park, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Lee Berg, to Juvenal A. daSilva, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonardo daSilva of Sao Paolo, Brazil.

title: Moscow Moves in the Mideast
description: As Israeli leaders lunge for each other's throats and Reagan policymakers dabble, the Soviet Union has moved swiftly and deftly to reestablish itself in the Middle East.

title: AN ARTIST TEACHES THE HANDICAPPED
description: LEAD: PETER BARBARA and Patrcia Edwards, bound to wheelchairs as a result of disabilities, credit Betty Merriss with teaching them how to get beyond their problems to succeed at sculpture.

title: PROM BARS GIRLS' TUXEDOS
description: Four teen-age girls who spent $93 each on outfits for their senior prom may have to sit at home unless they exchange the tuxedos for more conventional wear, their high school principal says.

title: Punjab Legislators Ousted
description: Eleven members of the Punjab state legislature who deserted the ruling Akali Dal Party were dismissed by the legislature's speaker Friday night after a court judgment upholding an anti-defection law. The Punjab High Court rejected petitions from the 11 members challenging the validity of a law that disqualifies legislators from the house if they defect from the party for which they were elected.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: Mr. Weber's student Alex de Gramont stumbled on the answer. These are very unromantic times. We didn't write the music. We're just dancing to the tune. JANET C. TAMARO New York City

title: A LA CARTE
description: THE dining room at the Culinary Arts Center of the New York Institute of Technology in Central Islip is breathtaking: soaring 20-foot ceilings, tall multipaned windows, fresh flowers and an elegant pink, rose and burgundy color scheme. If this were a commercial enterprise rather than a university restaurant, it would be the talk of Long Island. As would the prices: a seven-course dinner for $30.

title: BLUE JAYS, DOWN TO LAST OUT, RALLY TO WIN 5TH STRAIGHT
description: Tony Fernandez's two-run double in the bottom of the ninth inning gave the Toronto Blue Jays a 9-8 victory over the Texas Rangers today. It was the fifth straight triumph for Toronto.

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
Cook College Land
description: LEAD: A controversy over the potential development of land now used by the state's Agricultural Experiment Station and Cook College has ended with a rejection by Rutgers University's board of trustees of a developer's proposal. The land is on the east side of Route 1 adjacent to the Cook College campus in New

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: LEAD: PEPE LE PEW'S SKUNK TAILS. Directed by Chuck Jones, Arthur Davis and Abe Levitow. Warner Home Video. 60 minutes. $14.98.

title: CHANNELL BACKERS SAD AND DISMAYED
description: The sight of Carl R. (Spitz) Channell after he pleaded guilty this week to felony charges for raising money for the Nicarguan rebels brought out strong emotions in Mary J. Adamkiewicz, who contributed $60,000 to his organization last year. She wanted to give him more.

title: Update on Jets
description: THE JETS may be light a few cornerbacks when the veterans' minicamp begins Tuesday. Jerry Holmes, the starting left cornerback, and Bobby Humphery and Carl Howard, backups, are unsigned. Meanwhile, Johnny Lynn, the senior defensive back, has been asked to retire because of medical reasons. He is scheduled to take another physical after the camp, which ends Friday.

title: A FIRM FOUNDATION
description: FOUNDATION - THE NAME ALONE SAYS this is serious business, the critical part of makeup. It also happens to be the most confusing. With the growing number of foundation shades and the dizzying variety of formulations - from moisturizing to oil-absorbing, from heavyweight to almost sheer - finding the right foundation can be a challenge.

title:
BASEBALL;
SCOUTS BLOOM FOR FORDHAM PITCHER
description: LEAD: There were more baseball scouts than fans at Jack Coffey Field yesterday to watch a right-handed pitcher, Pete Harnisch of Fordham, at work. Harnisch pitched the opening game of a doubleheader against La Salle -and lost, 6-0.

title: A CELEBRATION OF ARTISTS' BOOKS
description: WHILE the State Museum here pays homage to Victorian gardens in its main galleries, another show as fresh as this year's tulips has been installed in the South Gallery.

title: ILL VETERANS FACING TRAVEL CUTBACK
description: A MAJOR cut in transportation reimbursements may force thousands of New Jersey veterans to pay their own way when seeking treatment at Veterans Administration medical centers.

title: Proposals for Talks On Middle East Advanced Anew
description: Serious talk about a new Middle East peace conference accelerated last week. It began in Israel, where the coalition Likud-Labor Government seemed to have two competing policies on the issue. In Washington, Reagan Adminstration officials reported some progress toward such a conference but cautioned that many obstacles remained.

title:
HOLLYBUSH FESTIVAL;
SOVIETS AND AMEICANS TO MAKE MUSIC
description: LEAD: THE Hollybush Festival, extended this season - its fifth - to include a greater number and variety of performances, will offer American and Russian music, dance and visual arts.

title: CAMACHO OUTPOINTS DAVIS
description: Hector Camacho, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion, came into the ring today at the Convention Center to the sound of boos - a reaction to his performance in recent fights.

title: HOME VIDEO: GARDENING
description: YARDENING WITH JEFF BALL: HOW TO GROW ROSES Kartes Video Communications. 7225 Woodland Drive Indianapolis, Ind. 46278 (800) 586-2000. 48 minutes. $17.95.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Livingston $300,000 39 Shrewsbury Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, older colonial; kitchen with breakfast area, deck, dining room, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes, $4,004. Maplewood $143,000 22 Manley Terrace 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; fireplace, wood stove, den, 1-car garage; taxes $2,961. Millburn $195,000 449 Wyoming Avenue 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 52-year-old colonial; porch, basement, fireplace; taxes, $2,692. South Orange $302,000 186 Glenview Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 43-year-old colonial; central A/C, family room, fireplace, 2-car ga rage; taxes, $7,419. Sparta $189,900 111 Warren Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old split-level; deck, eat-in kitchen; taxes, $1,882. Washington Township $125,000 2 Schindler Square 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 2-year-old town- house condo; fireplace, central A/C, 1-car garage; maintenance, $100, taxes $1,664. OTHER AREAS East Islip, L.I. $170,000 167 Keswick Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old high ranch; family room, dining room, deck, 2-car ga rage; taxes $3,500. Madison, Conn. $329,000 21 Thames Way 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; screened porch, 1.1 acres; taxes not yet available. Pleasantville, N.Y. $282,000 22 Hillside Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old raised ranch; deck, den, cathedral ceilings; taxes $4,318.

title: A COMMON-SENSE GUIDE TO HEALTH INSURANCE
description: TO JUDGE BY THE JUNK MAIL, TELEVISION commercials and print advertisements, a great many people are worried that you, whoever you are - corporate employee or self-employed, old or young, white collar or blue collar - do not have the right kind of health insurance.

title: CANADIENS TOPPLE NORDIQUES
description: After six games of provincial passion, the Montreal Canadiens relentlessly established themselves as the dominant team in Quebec, if only for one night. On the evening that the Stanley Cup series against the Quebec Nordiques reached its climax, tonight was enough.

title: Superpower Missiles in Europe Are Redundant
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESSMEN BEMOAN LOSSES TO 'GRAY MARKET'
description: LOOKING to save $10 on a favorite perfume, $80 on a Seiko watch or perhaps $10,000 on a Mercedes-Benz?

title: Sonics Take Opener in Overtime
description: Even with their Twin Towers intact, the Houston Rockets cannot seem to figure out how to beat the Seattle SuperSonics. The Sonics beat Houston in four of their five regular-season meetings when the Rockets' Twin Towers - Ralph Sampson and Akeem Olajuwon - were hobbled with injuries.

title: Educating for Freedom
description: Normally we don't pay much attention to teachers. We expect them to educate our children and practically to raise them by protecting them from drugs, crime and sexual disease, all for a lot less than we pay plumbers. From time to time, when they slip a bit in their police functions, we yell at them but we don't actually try to find out what is on their minds.

title: Hastings Riverfront A Treasure to Preserve
description: The waterfront in Hastings-on-Hudson and that of Irvington have both come into sharp focus recently [ ''Development Along the Hudson: Two Villages, Two Approaches,'' April 5 ] . The approaches to the problem are in direct contrast.

title: TWO CLEVER LADS FROM LONDON
description: METROLAND By Julian Barnes. 176 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. Paper, $4.95.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
VETERINARIAN
description: LEAD: AMONG the animals at the Rye-Harrison Veterinary Hospital one recent day are a Portuguese water dog, an Irish setter and a huge gray cat. Among their owners are a young woman who works in marketing, a television producer and a man retired from a moving company. Coming and going all day, from early morning to nearly sunset, are dozens of pets and people.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; GARDEN CITY
description: THERE are no walls or gates surrounding this serene residential enclave in the heart of Nassau County, but travelers know when they have entered Garden City.

title: ARGUMENTS ARE PRESENTED IN L.I. ZONING-BIAS SUIT
description: Judges of the New York State Court of Appeals, hearing oral arguments in a lawsuit in which a Long Island town is accused of using its zoning powers to discriminate in housing against poor people, expressed strong doubts this week about whether the plaintiffs have a right to sue.

title: GOTHAM SPELLS TROUBLE FOR CARDIN AND PARTNER
description: The wind whistled through a broken window and neon light bounced harshly off a cracked mirror. On the 15th floor of Manhattan's Gotham hotel on Fifth Avenue, last December, four men were assembled around a large table. Three were real estate investors, representing the new ownership of the hotel, and they were directing their fury at the fourth - 59-year-old Jack Pratt, an ambitious hotel developer from Dallas. (IS THIS TRUE OF FRIEDMAN, THAT HE WAS FURIOUS AT PRATT?) In the summer((??)) of 1984, Pratt had struck a Maxim's licensing deal with Pierre Cardin. Having built the Pratt Hotel Corporation into a $200 million company over the past three decades, the developer was itching to move up out of his world of hotel-casinos. He planned a chain of super-luxury hotels, tapping into a still-flourishing area of the over-built hotel business. The Maxim's name, he thought, would be his ticket to glory.

title: Verbatim; Distributional Equity
description: 'If one district has more access to funds than another district, the wealthier one will have the best ability to fulfill the needs of its students.'

title: Park Greets Special Visitor
description: Walt Disney World greeted visitor No. 242,831,300 at 11:14 A.M. Friday, a number officials said matched the population of the United States at that time. The visitor, Kent Robertson, a 27-year-old mechanic from Collinsville, Ill., clicked the turnstiles at Epcot Center, making him and his family instant celebrities. They received a special tour and a lifetime pass to the park, which opened Oct. 1, 1971.

title: TAKING A STAND IN PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: AS the Presidential race begins, Long Island's two Republican Congressmen, like most of their New York Republican House colleagues, have endorsed Vice President Bush at an early stage of the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Pine Tree Lane Wins Easily: Pine Tree Lane continued her dominance over male rivals when she raced to a front-running 2 1/2-length victory in the $284,000 Carter Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct. Carrying 119 pounds, including Randy Romero, the 5-year-old daughter of Apalachee posted sizzling quarter-mile fractions of 0:21 3/5 and 0:44 on her way to a time of 1:21 1/5 for seven furlongs. The time was only fourth-fifths of a second slower than the stakes record set by King's Bishop in 1973. The track record is 1:20 1/5 by Dr. Fager in 1968. Pine Tree Lane earned $170,400 for her owner, Leonard D. Mathis, and paid $4.20 for $2 to win as the favorite. King's Swan was runner-up in the field of six, 1 1/2 lengths ahead of Zany Tactics. Love That Mac, Cutlass Reality and Purple Mountain completed the order of finish. Pine Tree Lane survived two claims of foul. Chris Antley, the rider of King's Swan, and Eddie Maple, on Love That Mac, said they had been interfered with by the mare on leaving the starting gate. But the stewards disagreed. Pine Tree Lane scored her fifth victory in six starts this year. Don't Forget Me Newmarket Winner: Don't Forget Me upset the favored Ajdal to win the 2,000 Guineas yesterday at Newmarket, England. The 3-year-old colt, ridden by Willie Carson, never trailed in winning at odds of 9-1. Bellotto, ridden by Pat Eddery, was second at 7-1. Most Welcome crossed the finish line in third place, but after a steward's inquiry the horse was disqualified for interfering with Ajdal two furlongs from home. Midyan, ridden by Steve Cauthen, was moved up from fourth to third. Ajdal was fifth. (AP) HOCKEY U.S. Finishes in Seventh Place: The United States wound up seventh in the World Hockey Championships yesterday with a 7-4 victory over Switzerland, which did not have a victory, while West Germany played a 2-2 tie with Finland in the final game of the relegation pool. The Americans finished with four victories and six losses. But the point West Germany gained from its tie with Finland meant the West Germans finished with 9 points compared to the Americans' 8. As a result, the West Germans wound up sixth and the United States seventh. Bob Brooke of the Minnesota North Stars and Ed Olzcyk of the Chicago Blackhawks scored two goals each.(AP) GOLF Baldwin Captures Richardson Title: John Baldwin, the current amateur stroke-play champion of the Metropolitan Golf Association, captured the William D. Richardson Memorial Tournament yesterday. He defeated Bob Keller, a two-time champion from the Garden City Golf Club, 3 and 2, at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor, L.I. In the competition, named after the late golf writer of The New York Times, Baldwin, who plays out of Meadow Brook, ran up a four-hole lead in the first five holes and never was caught. In the morning semifinals Baldwin eliminated Howard Aal of Middle Bay, 3 and 2, and Keller eliminated Ed Sallie of I.B.M., 2 and 1. TENNIS Lendl Holds Off Carlsson: Ivan Lendl came within 2 points of a shocking defeat by Kent Carlsson of Sweden in the German Open yesterday at Hamburg, West Germany, but came back in devastating style to earn a place in the final against Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia. Carlsson was serving for the match at 6-3, 5-4 and led by 30-15 before Lendl won the next 3 points and squared the set at 5-5. The top-seeded Lendl then overpowered the third-seeded Swede and won the next eight games to wrap up the semifinal match, 3-6, 7-5, 6-0. In the other semifinal, second-seeded Mecir eliminated Eduardo Bengoechea of Argentina, 7-6, 6-1.(AP) Laver and Rosewall Advance: Rod Laver and Ken Rosewall, the top-seeded team, advanced to the semifinal round of the Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions Grand Masters doubles by defeating Ramanthan Krishnan and Marty Mulligan, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens. In other matches, Neale Fraser and Andres Gimeno defeated Alex Omedo and Whitney Reed, 7-6, 6-3; Mal Anderson and Roy Emerson defeated Frank Froehling and Ron Holmberg, 7-5, 3-6, 6-1, and Cliff Drysdale and Owen Davidson defeated Frank Sedgeman and Gene Scott, 6-4, 7-5. TRACK AND FIELD Tilden and Bishop Loughlin Win 2: Tilden and Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn and Truman of the Bronx won two high school events each yesterday on the second day of the New York Relays at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. Tilden captured the girls' 800-meter and sprint-medley relays following a victory on Friday in the 1,600-meter event. Lavern Linton and Keisha Demas earned watches as prizes on all three winning Tilden teams. Loughlin won the boys' distance medley and 3,200-meter relays. Lance Smith, Jason Williams and Kenny Lewis ran on both quartets. Truman's triumphs were scored in the girls' 400 and 3,200 relays. Joe Galeano of Centereach (L.I.) High School was the most impressive male performer. Friday he won the high jump and anchored the winning shuttle hurdles team and yesterday he finished first in the 400-meter intermediate hurdles. SOCCER Everton Held to Scoreless Tie: Everton was held to a scoreless tie at home by last-place Manchester City yesterday but moved to within 2 points of clinching the English League soccer title as Liverpool, the defending champion, was upset by 1-0 at Coventry. Nick Pickering scored in the 50th minute for Liverpool.(AP)

title: MEDICARE, TREATMENT AND CONSCIENCE
description: An elderly man suffering from widespread colon cancer was recently admitted to the hospital with severe abdominal pain, fever and shortness of breath. The admitting physician was told by a Medicare reviewer that the patient did not really need hospitalization. Less than two months later, the patient was dead.

title: 75 Arrested at Protest
description: Scores of anti-abortion protesters demonstrated this morning at a women's clinic that performs abortions, and 75 to 80 people were arrested, the police said. The demonstration at the Northside Women's Clinic in this Atlanta suburb was part of a day of protests planned in the region by anti-abortion advocates. The demonstrators blocked the clinic's driveway and lay down in front of and under cars trying to get into the clinic. Ann Wiley, a police dispatcher, said most of those arrested would be charged with trespassing.

title: SOFT COVERS FOR CHILDREN
description: NOW that publishers are printing their best children's books in their own paperback editions, brows are knitting as serious trend watchers ask what it all means. Will paying one-third the hardback price deprive a child of two-thirds of the book's literary experience? Is the only real book a hard-cover book? Will standard-sized paperbacks be the children's literature equivalent of video cassettes? If the lushly embossed Caldecott award medallion is printed flat, will it lose that tactile quality that draws buyers to the cash register?

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
SPAIN'S TENDER SUCKLING LAMB
description: LEAD: When weekends and holidays come around, the roads from Madrid choke with the cars of city dwellers making their exodus to the countryside. Many are off to second homes, but just as many may be on their way to feast on one of the great delicacies of Spain's Castilian heartland: roast suckling lamb.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: CONSTITUTION IN LEXINGTON

title: U.S. Rebukes an Arms Control Aide
description: As the United States and the Soviet Union seemed to be moving cautiously toward an agreement to remove their medium-range missiles from Europe, there was more contentious talk last week among officials concerned with arms control.

title: Defining What We Mean by AIDS
description: Determining who has AIDS is partly a matter of semantics. According to the current definition, people infected with the virus are diagnosed as having acquired immune deficiency syndrome only if they have at least one of the cancers or infections that take advantage of the body's weakened immune system.

title: Network Officials At the Microphone
description: Executives from ABC, CBS and NBC politely answered a House committee's questions about their operations last week, while some members of the panel complained that the answers were none of Congress's business.

title: IN TODAY'S ISSUE: THE BUSINESS WORLD
description: Part 2 of The Times Magazine today is The Business World, including these special reports:

title: BEST SELLERS: MAY 3, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 7 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 2 13 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 3 6 4 TEXASVILLE, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) From the 50's to the 80's in Thalia, Tex. - a sequel to ''The Last Picture Show.'' 4 4 8 BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) The jockey-hero of ''Break In'' has to contend with a romantic crisis and an arms-selling intrigue. 5 3 14 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A chronicle of one season spent with the Indiana University basketball team. 2 2 10 COMMUNION, by Whitley Strieber. (Beech Tree/ Morrow, $17.95.) A professional writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his home. 3 7 22 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists. 4 5 3 THIS 'N THAT, by Bette Davis with Michael Herskowitz. (Putnam, $17.95.) The actress's memories and opinions. 5 6 4 HOLD ON, MR. PRESIDENT! by Sam Donaldson. (Random House, $17.95.) Changing patterns in love and marriage. 11 1 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) (Golden Press/Western Publishing, $19.95.) New, revised ring-bound edition. 5 1 SUPERIMMUNITY, by Paul Pearsall. (McGraw- Hill, $17.95.) Ways to control your emotions in order to improve your health. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) TRUST ME, by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) Twenty-two stories by a master of private vernacular experience, the best of them full of the humor and compassion demanded by even the saddest tales about us frail humans in a mysterious world. NIXON: The Education of a Politician 1913-1962, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) This detached, objective and thick (752 pages) biography by a professional historian shows Mr. Nixon as both more accomplished and complicated than either his friends or his enemies usually suppose. FIERCE ATTACHMENTS: A Memoir, by Vivian Gornick. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15.95.) The major characters in this disturbing, unflinchingly honest book about love and conflict are the author, a Berkeley-educated urban intellectual, and her mother, a sort of 19th-century villager from the Bronx. ON GLORY ROADS: A Pilgrim's Book About Pilgrimage, by Eleanor Munro. (Thames & Hudson, $17.95.) Some time-hallowed pilgrimages of Hinduism, Buddhism, Judaism and Christianity as experienced by a thoughtful writer who adheres to none of them but has a penetrating sense for the cosmic language of all. MUMMY, by Daniel Curley. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) A stylish comic novel, honestly, about a man smuggling his mother's corpse in a suit of armor on top of a stolen automobile through a surreal and sinister Mexico; other strange things happen as well. THIS FAR AND NO MORE: A True Story, by Andrew H. Malcolm. (Times Books, $17.95.) Interviews and the victim's journal inform this unsettling account, by The Times's Chicago bureau chief, of a woman's day-to-day decay from an incurable and fatal disease that wastes the body utterly while leaving the mind unscathed. THAT NIGHT, by Alice McDermott. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) A brief, elegiac, lyrical, morally complex novel centered on a teen-age love affair some time ago on Long Island.

title: Spring Parties and Causes
description: SEAPORT PARTY May 4 - The South Street Seaport will provide the background, Peter Allen the entertainment and a host of Broadway performers some of the cooking at a benefit for the Association for the Help of Retarded Children. Cocktails at 7:30 P.M. at Caroline's on Pier 17 start the evening, followed by dinner in the atrium and dancing under the stars. Tickets for the black-tie event are $200. Call 212-988-1036. ACTING BENEFIT May 4 - The Acting Company is a professional repertory company that brings stage performances to out-of-the-way places around the country, providing theater for audiences and acting experience for actors. The company will hold its 15th annual spring dinner-dance at the Plaza, starting with 6:30 P.M. cocktails. Uta Hagen will receive an award and Steve Allen and Jayne Meadows will guide the ceremonies. Black tie. Tickets are $300 and $500. Call 212-564-3510. SONGS FOR MUSIC SCHOOL May 4 - The Gregg Smith Singers, winner of three Grammy Awards, will perform at an 8:30 P.M. benefit for the Turtle Bay Music School at St. Peter's Lutheran Church at the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. A cocktail reception follows. Tickets are $60 for those age 30 and over, $30 for those under. Call 212-753-8811. BRIEFLY NOTED: May 4 - The New York Theater Ballet will hold an 8 P.M. benefit performance, with works from the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries, followed by a champagne reception at the Roundabout Theater, 100 East 17th Street. Tickets are $35 to $250. Call 212-679-0401.
