May 6 - The Victorian Society Scholarship Fund, which provides money for American and British students in the fields of art, architecture and preservation, is holding a 5:30 to 8 P.M. tea at the Fletcher-Sinclair House, 2 East 79th Street. Tickets are $125, $225 for two. Call 212-206-5549. May 6 - The Salvation Army Greater New York Division will hold a black-tie dinner, with entertainment by Anthony Newley, at the Marriott Marquis, 44th Street and Broadway, starting with 6:30 P.M. cocktails. Tickets are $400. Call 212-807-4262. May 6 - The black-tie Mayfair Ball of the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center will be held at the Plaza starting with 7:30 P.M. cocktails followed by a dinner-dance in the Grand Ballroom. Tickets are $250, or $150 for those 35 and under. There will also be dancing and a light buffet for those 35 and under in the Terrace Room. Tickets are $50, or $60 at the door. Call 212-554-6361. May 6 - The Concert Artists Guild, which has sponsored more than 500 young musicians since 1951, will honor Rudolf Serkin at a black-tie dinner-dance at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof. Cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets are $200. Call 212-333-5200. MUSEUM CELEBRATION May 6 - As it prepares for its 50th anniversary next year, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum will hold a 1930's-style benefit sponsored by the museum's associates' committee. From 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. there will be cocktails, hors d'oeuvres, desserts (including a chocolate tree), coffee and music throughout the museum. White or black tie. Tickets are $75. Call 212-360-3554. FOR ASPIRING MUSICIANS May 7 - Simone Dinnerstein, a 14-year-old pianist, and the violinist Michael Shih, 16, are winners of the annual competition of the Bloomingdale House of Music, the nonprofit community school that has nurtured young talent for 21 years. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. at the Trinity School, 101 West 91st Street, start the benefit evening, followed by a concert by the winners and dinner. Tickets are $50. Call 212-663-6021. DANCE AT '21' May 7 - The junior committee of the Irvington House Institute for Medical Research will hold a dance at the newly refurbished ''21'' Club. Champagne and hors d'oeuvres will be served from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. Tickets are $65 or $70 at the door. Call 212-758-8250. THREE-SCENE BENEFIT May 8 - To mark its first year of programs at its present location, the Kitchen, a center for video, music, dance and film, will hold a benefit at three addresses. The highlight will be a concert by Philip Glass and his ensemble at the Triplex, 199 Chambers Street, at West Street. Cocktails there at 6 P.M. will precede the 7:30 P.M. concert. Guests will then head over to the Kitchen at 512 West 19th Street for dinner. The evening ends with dancing at Tunnel, 220 12th Avenue, at 27th Street. Tickets for the whole evening are $250, or $125 for the reception, concert and dancing alone; for just the concert and dancing, $25. Call 212-255-5793. DAYLONG TRIP May 9 - A ''Day in the Hudson River Valley'' begins at 9:30 A.M., when guests board buses at the office of the American-Italian Foundation for Cancer Research, 872 Madison Avenue, at 71st Street. There will be a tour of Washington Irving's home and one of the Boscobel Restoration, an 18th-century mansion in Garrison-on-Hudson, and a cruise aboard the yacht Commander with entertainment by Pete Seeger. In addition to aiding the foundation, the excursion, which ends in Manhattan at 5:30 P.M., will benefit Progetto Uomo, a drug rehabilitation program in Italy. Tickets are $150, $75 for those under 21. Call 212-628-9090. VINTAGE EVENING May 10 - The New Amsterdam Theater Company, which presents concert productions of vintage American musicals, will present its spring benefit and an 8 P.M. concert at Alice Tully Hall, followed by a reception. Tickets are $100. Call 212-757-0189. Tickets for the performance alone are $25 and $35. Call 212-362-1914. CRYSTAL BALL BENEFIT May 12 - In addition to being a highlight of last year's social scene, the Mount Sinai Crystal Ball raised over $1 million for medical research. The goal of the second Crystal Ball is $1.25 million, as 1,100 guests are due to fill the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria starting with 7 P.M. cocktails. Dinner, dancing and the songs of Dionne Warwick complete the black-tie evening. Tickets are $500 and $1,000. Call 212-650-6976 or 212-650-8257.

title:
ANTIQUES;
'WISTERIA HEIGHTS' BLOOMS IN MONTCLAIR
description: LEAD: WITH considerable daring and few caveats - aside from a strict injunction to preserve the integrity of the exceptional paneling and other architectural elements - Dr. and Mrs. John Sudol of Montclair and their family packed their personal possessions a few weeks ago, had their furnishings placed in storage and left for the comfortable surroundings of their summer house at the

title: Italy Calls Elections
description: Amintore Fanfani lost a confidence vote and was forced out last week, after only 10 days as Prime Minister of Italy. President Francesco Cossiga ordered elections for June 14. Bettino Craxi, the Socialist leader and a former Prime Minister, wanted to keep the weak Fanfani Government in office. But Mr. Fanfani's Christian Democrats were eager for elections in which they hope to gain strength at the expense of Mr. Craxi's party.

title: ART INC.
description: It happened last year: Seijiro Matsuoka, a Japanese realty magnate, paid .3 million for a Ming dynasty dish at an auction in Hong Kong, a record price for a single piece of Chinese porcelain. . . . Nobutaka Shikanai, former chairman of the Fujisankei Communications Group, a major media company in Japan, purchased 16 Henry Moore sculptures for more than $10 million from a collector in Wichita, Kan. . . . Kanichiro Ishibashi, honorary chairman of the Bridgestone Corporation, the largest Japanese tire manufacturer, bought a Renoir painting for $10 million from a dealer in Tokyo.

title: MAINE DEBATES BIG PLAN TO BUY LAND FOR PUBLIC
description: With its 3,500 miles of coastline, 6,000 lakes and rugged northern mountains, Maine has become known as a paradise for outdoor pursuits. But the beauty and solitude that have made Maine so popular among tourists in the last five years are now threatened by overcrowding and development, say a group of naturalists, sports enthusiasts, developers and legislators.

title: 'Metroland'
description: Julian Barnes dazzled American readers with his third novel, ''Flaubert's Parrot,'' which arrived from across the Atlantic with all its brilliant plumage in 1985. That novel - an exquisite blend of criticism, fiction and imaginary autobiography -promised even better things to come. It has also been reason enough for publishers to move backward to his second novel, ''Before She Met Me,'' and now to ''Metroland,'' his first, published in Britain in 1980.

title: College Declares Bankruptcy
description: Million-dollar lawsuits and other financial woes have forced 106-year-old Bishop College here to file for bankruptcy, according to attorneys for the school. Bishop's filing Thursday under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws came five months after the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools revoked its accreditation because of the college's financial instability. The loss means students may have trouble transferring credits to accredited schools and will lose Federal financial aid.

title: Melissa Stern, Gallery Director, Wed To Peter K. Lourie, Graduate Student
description: The wedding of Melissa Stern and Peter King Lourie took place yesterday at the Chapel of Our Lady in Cold Spring, N.Y., with the Rev. Donald S. Harrington, a Unitarian minister, officiating.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A TRANS-ATLANTIC VOYAGE ABOARD THE ILL-FATED HINDENBURG
description: LEAD: MAY 6, 1937: Driving across the George Washington Bridge in midafternoon, headed home to Passaic after a visit on Long Island, I looked up and saw the looming, cigar-like shape of the airship Hindenburg, easing its way down the Hudson toward a 6 P.M. arrival at the Naval Air Station in Lakehurst. The great zeppelin, I knew, was coming from Germany on its inaugural crossing of the 1937 season, its second in North Atlantic service.

title: USING SONGS, ISRAELIS TOUCH ARAB FEELINGS
description: To hear Shafik Salman tell it, if the Arab-Israeli conflict could only be put to music it would be settled in no time at all.

title:
TO START WITH...;
DINOSAUR DAYS
description: LEAD: The operators of mom-and-pop gift shops were rubbernecking down the aisle, shoulder to shoulder with buyers from major department stores, and not a few paused to chat with Frances Meyer, a cheerful 40-year-old paper-products manufacturer from Savannah - one of 2,200 exhibitors crammed into the mammoth Jacob K.

title: CHOOSING THE RIGHT PAINT FOR THOSE OUTSIDE JOBS
description: THE homeowner who decides to repaint the outside of his house often finds that shopping for exterior paints or finishes can be confusing, because there are quite a few types from which to choose. This is particularly true when manufacturers make conflicting or exaggerated claims, or when you are dealing with a salesman who may not be as knowledgeable as he should be.

title: PHILIPPINE REBEL SEEKS SENATE SEAT
description: Eighteen years ago, when he was a young laborer on a sugar plantation owned by the family of Corazon C. Aquino, Bernabe Buscayno founded the New People's Army, a Communist fighting force, with 35 men and a handful of rusty weapons.

title: DECORATIVE WORKS TO J.P. MORGAN'S TASTE
description: J. PIERPONT MORGAN, COLLEC-tor'' at the Morgan Library is something quite new for the Library. By definition, a library is concerned with two-dimensional objects -books, manuscripts, autograph letters, musical scores, drawings, prints and stage designs. Almost all of the Morgan Library's exhibitions have had that character. But the present one, which can be seen through Aug. 1 and moves later to the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, is concerned with the decorative arts in Europe. Everything in it belonged to Morgan himself and was given in 1917 to the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford.

title: IN YONKERS, POLITICS AS UNUSUAL
description: LEAD: TWO years ago, Nicholas C. Wasicsko, a 26-year-old law student who had never sought elective office, made political history in Yonkers when he defeated a six-term incumbent, Stephen J. Kubasek Jr., in a City Council election.

title: RECITAL: NORMA FRENCH SINGS GRIEG PROGRAM
description: AS the creator of ''Keeping Up With the 80's,'' a mild-mannered performance piece dealing with computer technology in everyday life, Michael Smith deserves the label ''user friendly.'' Co-author of the script (with Howard Mandel) as well as the show's principal performer, Mr. Smith has an amiability that might earn him an open invitation to ''Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood.'' Actually, the apartment that is the setting for this mini-musical could also be just around the corner from Sesame Street.

title: A SOVIET EMIGRE TAKES THE 'A' TRAIN
description: CAN WE DO WITHOUT AN enemy? Can the United States do without the Soviet Union as its archfoe, and vice versa? What kind of world would we see without this habitual animosity and confrontation?

title: NONFICTION
description: SOUTH AFRICA: A Different Kind of War - From Soweto to Pretoria. By Julie Frederikse. (Beacon, $12.95.) This collection of interviews, government statements, opposition leaflets and posters and photographs is as vivid a slice of life as can be found since the South African Government clamped down on press coverage, especially photographic, of this tormented country. Julie Frederikse, a National Public Radio correspondent, has written a text weaving together this reporter's scrapbook of the years 1980-84, during which the antiapartheid movement gathered steam and declared what amounts to war on the Government and its supporters. ''South Africa: A Different Kind of War'' does not pretend to be analysis; it simply puts before the reader the stark images of apartheid and protest. In doing so, it becomes a valuable primary resource. The author could have been more helpful in guiding the reader through the chronicle and its accompanying images (there are no captions; all materials are identified at the back of the book). Yet the voices are authentic, the story unrelievedly grim. When we reach the conclusion, it seems self-evident: ''If the government and its opponents agree on nothing else, it is that South Africa's future will be resolved through war.''

title: Saving Sacred Sites: Matching Grants
description: The Sacred Sites and Properties Fund, a matching-grant program for the preservation of architecturally significant religious sites in New York City, is a year old this month and once again is looking for beneficiaries of its largesse.

title: Diane McWhorter Is Married to Richard Rosen
description: Rebecca Diane McWhorter, the daughter of Elizabeth Gore Biggs and Martin Westgate McWhorter, both of Birmingham, Ala., was married there yesterday to Richard Dean Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Abraham Rosen of Highland Park, Ill. Judge Charles M. Nice of the Alabama Circuit Court in Birmingham performed the ceremony at the home of Marie Stokes Jemison.

title: Emily Ward Engaged To John F. Neilson Jr.
description: The engagement of Emily Tatnall Ward to John Fullerton Neilson Jr. has been announced her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Rodman Ward Jr. of Wilmington, Del. Mr. Neilson is the son of Mrs. William C. Sellars of Litchfield, Conn., and Mr. Neilson of Badenweiler, West Germany. The couple plan to be married June 27.

title:
PAPERBACKS;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SARABAND. By Eliot Bliss. (Penguin/ Virago, $6.95.) Reprinting neglected novels can be risky: there is always the chance the neglect was deserved. But that is not the case with Eliot Bliss's 1931 ''Saraband,'' the first of this writer's two novels, written when she was 28 years old. A wonderfully impressionistic account of a young English girl's struggle to grow up in World War I England, ''Saraband'' captures not only the dreamy world of adolescence, but also the shift and slide of the

title: LETTER TO THE EDITORS
description: MAKING NEWS By Martin Mayer. 348 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $18.95.

title: U.S. MEETS IMMIGRANTS ON UNEASY TERMS
description: ONE of the great experiments in American history begins Tuesday, when the Immigration and Naturalization Service will offer legal status to millions of illegal aliens. No one is sure what to expect, and perhaps the only thing certain is that, like much social policy legislation, the new law will have unforeseen, unintended consequences.

title: Cooperman as Tutor
description: Following 18 hours of training by the Manville-based New Jersey Literacy Volunteers of America, the state branch of a national organization based in Syracuse, N.Y., Dr. Saul Cooperman, the Commissioner of Education, is teaching a 30-year-old Trenton man to read, tutoring him in his office once a week for a year.

title: V.A. Hospitals' Deaths Are Traced to Mistakes
description: Patients may have died needlessly in Veterans Administration hospitals because of doctors' mistakes, according to a report made public today by a Congressional panel.

title: A GALLERY OF OWNERS AND THEIR TROVES
description: EVERY MUSEUM HAS A shopping list, not only of the works it wants, but of the collectors who might be persuaded to provide them. The following roster, assembled by informal consultation with curators throughout the country, notes some major contemporary collectors -and their collections, at present uncommitted - who are watched by museums.

title: Record Payout For Gator Bowl
description: Stanford and Clemson received a record payout of $900,000 for playing in the Gator Bowl football game last December, bowl officials announced Friday. The previous high payout was in 1984 when Oklahoma State and South Carolina received $831,020 each.

title: FACING $3 MILLION OVERRUN, JAIL FERRY PLAN IS MODIFIED
description: New York City's prison ferry, which opened three months late and $3 million over budget, is 60 percent empty because its operation is being changed to prevent $3 million in unexpected staffing costs.

title: Generous Act
description: John W. Kluge, who was graduated from Columbia University 50 years ago with the aid of a scholarship grant, will be footing tuition bills for hundreds of others in years to come. The university announced last week that Mr. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Company, would donate $25 million to create an aid program for minority-group students. His gift, the largest in Columbia's history, comes at a time of heightened racial tension on the campus, exemplified by a recent brawl between black and white students, but Columbia officials said it had been under discussion for several years. They said the gift would enable the university to provide about $10,000 a year in aid to each of 60 to 75 students.

title: KEEPING THE SHOW GOING ON
description: MY favorite character in ''42d Street'' isn't Sawyer, who goes out there a kid and comes back a star; it's Marsh, the director, who turns a collapsing musical comedy into a hit. But Maryellen Barnes of Bayside keeps Long Island musicals from any danger of collapse.

title: TRYING TO SELL WITHOUT SALES
description: A STRANGE paradox has developed in retailing lately. When department stores increased the initial prices of the merchandise, their profits ebbed. Now that they are reducing some of the list prices, their profits have picked up.

title: Statewide High School Faces Stiff Opposition
description: A proposal to build a special residential high school for gifted students in New York State continues to face stiff opposition, even though the Legislature recently approved $1 million for the project.

title: ARE VIEWERS ENTITLED TO GAMES ON FREE TV?
description: Sports and cable-TV executives should remember that over-the-air broadcasts were powerful marketing tools used to build the huge audience and interest they now command. By shutting out sizable portions of the market (especially in the case of the Yankees and SportsChannel) who are they serving? The issue is not necessarily entitlement, but more a question of access for the non-cabled viewing market.

title: Sandra Bond Tregellas Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Sandra Bond Tregellas and Michael A. McManus Jr. took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Thomas J. Joyce.

title: Kit Tobin Planning to Marry George C. Whipple 3d in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Henry deYoung Tobin of Hillsborough, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Oliver Tobin to George Carroll Whipple 3d, the son of Mrs. Whipple Jr. of New York and the late Mr. Whipple. A July wedding is planned.

title: Susan Nathalie Smith Weds James M. Stiles
description: The marriage of Susan Nathalie Smith to James Mark Stiles took place yesterday at St. Peter and Paul Russian Orthodox Church in Meriden, Conn. The Rev. Raphael Rodiliski performed the ceremony.

title: FRESH AIR FUND OPENING 11TH DRIVE
description: In 1877, the Rev. Willard Parsons conceived a simple, direct way to help children living in squalid New York City tenements. He asked members of his small country Presbyterian congregation in Sherman, Pa., to open their homes to city children for the summer.

title: Commercial Property: The Clerical Flight; Competition and Costs Moving Jobs to the Suburbs
description: EARLIER this year, Mayor Koch lashed out at the American Telephone & Telegraph Company after learning of its plans to transfer hundreds of executive jobs from Manhattan to Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: ARISE! YOU CAN'T SLEEP ANYWAY
description: I AM an insomniac. ''Me too! Me too!'' cry 30 million bleary-eyed bedfellows from apartments, Cape Cods, bungalows, condos, mansions, igloos and lanais all over the United States. From China, using the same population ratio, 120 million voices would be elegible to join the ''Me too!'' chorale. Or is insomnia strictly a capitalist phenomenon?

title: Nora L. Ryan Is Engaged To Howard P. Johnson Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Ryan Jr. of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nora Louise Ryan to Howard Pratt Johnson Jr., the son of Katherine Addison Johnson of Washington and Mr. Johnson of Montclair, N.J. The wedding is to be next month.

title: CANDIDATES ALREADY DRIVING HARD IN IOWA FOR FIRST BIG TEST OF 1988
description: ''Ruth, this is Congressman Gephardt calling. How are you? Hot? How are you doing on the farm? The hogs are helping a little, aren't they? So you're breaking even?''

title: 24 Political Prisoners To Be Freed by Seoul
description: The Justice Ministry said today that it would release 24 political prisoners on Monday in an amnesty marking the birthday of Buddha, an official holiday. In addition, it said, 1,082 others in jail for other crimes will be released.

title: Intruders Don't Discriminate
description: To the Editor:

title: Name Changes
description: To the Editor:

title: HOMOSEXUALS CITE RISE IN HARASSMENT
description: LEAD: HOMOSEXUALS in the state say they are encountering a rising intolerance directed against them by heterosexuals because of fears and anger over AIDS. Antihomosexual acts cited have ranged from verbal slurs to physical assaults.

title: TWO-DECADE PATH OF EINSTEIN PAPERS
description: A chance remark in Zurich in 1985 and the subsequent discovery in Berkeley, Calif., of six manuscript pages in the plastic cover of a notebook led to the discovery of about 50 letters between Albert Einstein and his first wife. The letters are to be published this month by Princeton University Press.

title: HARVARD IS FACING AN ELECTION ISSUE
description: Harvard alumni who want the university to purge its endowment of holdings in companies doing business in South Africa have put together a slate of candidates for the Board of Overseers, one of the university's two governing bodies.

title: NOT ALL ERRORS ARE RUN-OF-THE-MILL
description: MOST errors are banal and need no explanation; they are made by grandmaster and amateur alike. Yet every once in a while there is something intriguing about an error. We are prompted to ask why. Consider, for example, the game between Grandmasters Alonso Zapata of Colombia and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland in the ninth round of the Hoogoven International Tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands.

title: ON FIRST DAY BACK, RAINES SLAMS METS
description: When his name was announced as he went to the plate in the 10th inning with the bases loaded, many of the 37,235 spectators tried to boo him. It came out more like a groan. What they were thinking could practically be heard across Shea Stadium: ''Oh no, it's Raines again.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: TEL AVIV
description: In an increasingly polarized Israel, Jerusalem rightly remains the hilly bastion of spirituality, while Tel Aviv, only 50 minutes away by car, is fiercely secular, Mediterranean and dedicated to fun. Mount Zion may fulminate about the cities of the plain, but as the country's largest urban center (1.2 million with the suburbs), Tel Aviv revels in being Israel's hub of music, theater, dance, sculpture, seaside recreation and discotheques.

title:
INVESTING;
NEOAX EMERGES FROM OBSCURITY
description: LEAD: The name Neoax Inc. is not well known, except to students of bankruptcies. For almost 70 years, the company called itself the White Motor Corporation and then, after a stint in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, was reorganized in late 1983 as Northeast Ohio Axle Inc. That was condensed in May 1986 to Neoax. Its stock, which trades over-the-counter, sagged to $2.75 in

title: FICTION
description: STORIES. By Cesare Pavese. Translated by A. E. Murch. (Ecco, $12.95.) In 1950 the Italian novelist and poet Cesare Pavese committed suicide at the age of 41, just three months after receiving his country's highest literary prize, the Premio Strega, for his novel ''Among Women Only.'' Numerous short works of fiction were found among his papers; the present collection includes 22 examples, of varying length and quality, rather ploddingly translated by A. E. Murch. Pavese, like certain hostile and forbidding landscapes, inspires a kind of unwilling fascination. His outlook on the human condition is unremittingly bleak; man is lonely, alienated and unable to communicate with his fellow creatures. Character never changes, it merely reveals itself, generally in unhappy love affairs that underscore the impossibility of understanding between men and women. The ruling emotion for Pavese is a deep longing for solitude, which he sees alternately as delicious freedom or incarceration. Not surprisingly, the figure of the prisoner looms large in these stories (Pavese himself was jailed and sentenced to internal exile under the Fascists). In ''The Intruder,'' a young man shares a cell with an old jailbird. There he learns two lessons: that life teaches one to be alone, and that every man has a congenital fault line along which he breaks, given enough pressure. Poised midway between fable and naturalistic slice of life, Pavese's tales intertwine the day-to-day routine of ordinary folk with the mythic power of rivers and fields - which often engage his characters' emotions more profoundly than any human being. Pavese's stories rely on a limited number of humble props: sometimes no more than a table, a cigarette and a glass of wine. At his best, the author masterfully blends character and setting, unabashedly placing the pathetic fallacy at the service of high art.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: HANSEL AND GRETEL Opera by Humperdinck. Starring Judith Blegen, Frederica von Stade, Rosalind Elias, Jean Kraft. Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and Chorus, conducted by Thomas Fulton. Bel Canto: Paramount Home Video. 104 minutes. $39.95.

title: WHO KILLED MAJOR CASTRO?
description: BALLAD OF DOGS' BEACH Dossier of a Crime. By Jose Cardoso Pires. Translated by Mary Fitton. 181 pp. New York: Beaufort Books. $15.95.

title: FACING BRAZIL'S BUREAUCRACY AND THE 'DEAR JOSE' LETTERS
description: Of the 262,808 letters received by President Jose Sarney last year, one came from a 55-year-old woman who appealed for help in finding a husband, and another was signed by a beggar who asked to be given a 1975 taxi to take him to ''work'' each day.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: CLEAN WATER WEEK, an annual public-education effort by the state's Department of Environmental Protection, begins today, and the focus again is on nonpoint sources of pollution: everything that does not come out of a pipe, from storm-water runoff to deposition from the atmosphere, such as acid rain.

title: CHAOS WAITING IN THE WINGS
description: WHEN THINGS GET BACK TO NORMAL And Other Stories. By Constance Pierce. 255 pp. Normal: An Illinois State University/ Fiction Collective Book/Sun & Moon Press. Paper, $7.95. Cloth, $15.95.

title: THEIR HEADS BELONG TO DADDY
description: THE LAUGHING CRY An African Cock and Bull Story. By Henri Lopes. Translated by Gerald Moore. 259 pp. New York: Readers International/Persea Books. Paper, $8.95. Cloth, $16.95.

title: A NEW STYLE FOR OLD INN
description: WHAT a change new ownership can mean for an inn or restaurant. While sometimes it can be for the worse, in the case of the Mayflower Inn in Washington it is decidedly for the better.

title: 99 Demonstrators Are Seized At Seabrook Nuclear Reactor
description: About 300 demonstrators converged on the Seabrook nuclear power plant today to protest attempts to reduce its evacuation zone, and 99 were arrested when they refused to leave.

title: Economic Affairs Dept.
description: To the Editor:

title: RE-CREATIONS OF SWEDISH COLONIAL LIFE BEGIN IN JERSEY FOR 1988 CELEBRATION
description: The newest building in town, a one-room Swedish log cabin held together with notching rather than nails, will resemble those of 350 years ago as soon as the logs weather a bit and shingles are cut for a roof.

title: The Laziest Gal in Town
description: With pandas few and far between in New York, the city's residents - who can safely be said to have seen just about everything else - are journeying north to the Bronx Zoo. There Ling Ling and Yong Yong, loans from the Beijing Zoo, are doing what pandas always do, which is to say not much, while cameras click and voices urge ''Look over this way.''

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Damming Up the Flood of Development
description: OVERWHELMED by the demand for land and a blizzard of applications for building permits, communities in the remote reaches of Connecticut are suspending development while they review and adjust their zoning regulations.

title: Bonn Church Is Set Afire
description: A Lutheran church was set afire today in a Bonn suburb, the police said, but they were not sure whether the arson was related to the visit of Pope John Paul II. It was the second church fire reported since the Pope began a West German tour on Thursday. The police said the latest fire destroyed $55,000 worth of furniture in the St. Thomas Church.

title: U.S. Barring a Prize-Winning Vietnamese Pianist
description: Not all those in Moscow who are being denied the right to travel abroad are victims of Soviet restrictions. At least one, a pianist, has failed to get permission from the United States to accept American concert engagements booked for him since he won the Chopin piano competition in Warsaw in 1980.

title: DR. HERBERT L. VOLCHOK
description: Dr. Herbert L. Volchok, the director of the Federal Department of Energy's environmental measurements laboratory in lower Manhattan, died Thursday after suffering a heart attack at Wayne (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Wayne.

title: AN AEGEAN ARISTOCRAT
description: Places that have seen their days of glory but still bear themselves with the dignity of a dowager are often among the most rewarding for travelers. However prim and staid, they offer an adventure in time, a plunge into the not-quite-past, a stroll through a present that no longer looks toward a future. They are a melancholy reminder of life's transitoriness but offer the consolation of enduring grace.

title: TROUBLE IN RIVER CITY
description: THE NATIONAL DEBT By Lawrence Malkin. 309 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

title:
PAPERBACKS;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BEYOND EINSTEIN: The Cosmic Quest for the Theory of the Universe. By Michio Kaku and Jennifer Trainer. (Bantam, $9.95.) Michio Kaku is among the numerous physicists who believe that something called ''superstrings'' will be the basis for the long-sought unified field theory, which would show all physical forces to be different aspects of a single, ultimate force.

title: EINSTEIN LETTERS TELL OF ANGUISHED LOVE AFFAIR
description: The story of an anguished love affair between Albert Einstein and the woman who would later become his first wife has emerged in newly disclosed correspondence between them.

title: New York Company Indicted In Asbestos Removal Project
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted a New York company, accusing it of using untrained workers and falsifying safety tests on an asbestos removal project.

title: Ellen McCurdy Is Wed
description: Ellen Steele McCurdy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert McCurdy 3d of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Jackson Burchenal Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burchenal of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Riley E. Jensen officiated at the Central Presbyterian Church. The bride is an assistant trader in the municipal bond department at Wertheim & Company in New York. Mr. Burchenal is an associate in the management training program at the Citicorp Investment Bank in New York.

title: U.S. CAN DO BETTER IN TENNIS, AND NEEDS TO START TRYING
description: LEAD: I DO not count myself as being among the doomsayers who say that America's impact in the tennis world, specifically on the international circuit, has faded, with no sign of returning. However, one must concede that things are not exactly rosy for United States tennis fortunes. Just look at the draw for this week's Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions at the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills.

title: Ann Whitney Smith Wed
description: Ann Whitney Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Conner Smith of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Christopher Erb Campbell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Forrester Campbell of Summit, N.J. The Rev. David Earnest performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church. The bride is on the administrative staff of the Unette Corporation in Parsippany, N.J., a contract packager of which her father is president. Mr. Campbell is a sales representative for the Campbell Foundry Company in Harrison, N.J., of which his father is president.

title: FOES OF APARTHEID DIVIDED OVER VOTE
description: Helen Suzman, a human-rights campaigner and South Africa's longest-serving Member of Parliament, has always reserved her anger for the apartheid policies of the National Party Government.

title: ETHICS PANEL IS TREADING QUIETLY
description: THE first meeting of Governor Cuomo's Commission on Government Integrity took place in New York City last week almost unnoticed. In part this may have reflected the unassuming personality of its new chairman, John D. Feerick, the dean of the Fordham University School of Law. Certainly the retired nature of the proceedings was in sharp contrast to the public buffetings the commission received after its formation in January, under the leadership of Joseph A. Califano Jr., a prominent Washington Democrat who served as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Carter Administration.

title: TEACHING ONE OF LIFE'S LESSONS: HOW TO DEAL WITH DEATH
description: IT was a warm afternoon, but Lynne Arico said she felt a chill as she watched the caretakers throw dirt on the coffin, slowly burying it. Aaron Brown stared at the hole; he said he was wondering how deep it went and whether the man inside had led a happy life.

title: COURT ACTIONS ARE BLUNTING BOTHA'S TOOLS OF REPRESSION
description: THE South African courts provided the cutting edge last week for renewed anti-apartheid resistance, overshadowing the final campaigning for the election of the controlling white branch of Parliament this Wednesday. The state has responded with tear gas and bullets to a strong challenge by black labor unions. But the anti-apartheid groups were scoring victories in the courts, which have shown a growing willingness to rule against the Government in recent years.

title: Air Deregulation Raises The Cost of Misfortune
description: To the Editor:

title: GILMAN'S ROLE IN DRUG BATTLE
description: HE is a quiet man who seems painfully shy when forced to speak in public, but get him started on the nation's drug problem and he's hard to stop.

title: EDUCATOR HAD ROLE IN U.N.'S FOUNDING
description: Charles E. Rothwell, a former president of Mills College and a onetime State Department official who played a key role in the conference that founded the United Nations in 1945, died Friday in Point Reyes, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: I'm 10 years older than Bruce Weber, having graduated from Smith College in 1965. My generation began what his ended.

title: JULES FEIFFER'S WEST SIDE STORY
description: DURING THE FIRST SCENE change of ''Little Murders,'' which opens Wednesday at the Second Stage, the sound of ''Abbey Road'' fills the theater. The Beatles music, like the Jimi Hendrix and Sly Stone songs used for breaks later in the play, provides one of the few obvious clues that Jules Feiffer's tragicomedy itself arose from the cultural and political ferment of the late 1960's.

title: SAUCES ADD A SPICY TOUCH TO FISH DISHES
description: WHILE nothing beats fresh seafood served plain, I like to experiment with different sauces. For example, a green peppercorn and brandy sauce is superb with fish steaks such as shark, swordfish or tuna or fillets of red snapper. A piquant ancho chili sauce is wonderful with sauteed shrimp. And, for shad roe, which are now at the height of their season, an old-fashioned beurre noisette with capers - a sauce normally served with skate in French bistros - is a perfect foil for the richness of the roe.

title: ARE VIEWERS ENTITLED TO GAMES ON FREE TV?
description: Sports fans are not guaranteed the right to have free television coverage of games. But it is to the ball clubs' advantage to let the fans view the games on broadcast television. By encouraging fan interest and hence loyalty, people will want to go to the ball park. A professional team has to balance the need to increase revenues with cable television and the need to encourage fan loyalty. With that in mind I have a proposal. Negotiate a contract with the cable outlet and the broadcast company so that the previous year's attendance dictates the present year's quantity of games on free television. An example would be: Attendance of 3 million gives 120 free games, 2.5 million gives 100 free games, 2 million gives 90 free games, and 1.5 million gives 70 free games. This would put the free television coverage in the hands of the fans. JOHN GRIFFIN Carmel, N.Y.

title: Recent Sales
description: New Rochelle,N.Y. $173,000 54 Clove Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 66-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, fenced yard, walk to schools; taxes $2,144. North Salem, N.Y. $255,000 Hilltop Drive 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, new clapboard coloni al; deck, family room, sitting room, 1.5 acre; taxes not yet assessed. Pleasantville, N.Y. $282,000 22 Hillside Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old raised ranch; deck, den, cathedral ceilings; taxes $4,318. Guilford, Conn. $361,000 Sugarloaf Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; views of historic area, adjacent nature preserve, 2 acres; taxes not yet available. Madison, Conn. $329,000 21 Thames Way 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; screened porch, 1.1 acres; taxes not yet available. Stratford, Conn. $170,000 198 Fairview Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial, kitchen skylight, wood stove; taxes $1,170. OTHER AREAS Maplewood, N.J. $143,000 22 Manley Terrace 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; fireplace, wood stove, den, 1-car garage; taxes $2,961. Millburn, N.J. $195,000 449 Wyoming Avenue 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 52-year-old colonial; porch, basement, fireplace, entrance hall; taxes, $2,692. Patchogue, L.I. $95,000 119 Clark Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 80-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $1,400.

title: Eileen T. Burke Is Bride of Thomas A. S. Bucaria
description: The marriage of Eileen Theresa Burke and Thomas Andrew Sheridan Bucaria took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Plainfield, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's brother, the Rev. James A. Bucaria. who was assisted by the Revs. Joseph Mirandi, Dennis Corado and Charles Guarino.

title: Alison Collier Is Engaged
description: Alison Collier, a daughter of John D. Collier of New York and Mrs. Robert Woodruff of Atlanta, plans to be married June 20 to Robert Bajek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bajek of Clifton, N.J. Miss Collier is an executive assistant at the New York real estate company S.K.S. Associates. Mr. Bajek, a graduate of Colorado State University, is a sales manager for Nozaki America, a New York import company.

title: BUYNG BERTHS FOR THEIR BOATS
description: THIS spring, while most property owners on Long Island have been seeding and fertilizing lawns, washing windows and propping up their fences, property owners at the Anchorage Aquaminium in Lindenhurst have been gazing out to sea in anticipation of one of the Island's most popular recreational pursuits - boating on the Great South Bay.

title: GUILT-EDGED
description: In the 1950's, I hired a nanny for my daughter, Alison, and got a job writing copy for J. Walter Thompson.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: THE Jersey Devil has come a long way in the last couple of hundred years. For a long time, he was generally known as the fiendish son born ''one stormy and gusty night'' to a Mrs. Leeds, a Burlington County woman ''suspected of a little amateur witchcraft.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
THE WAY TO PREVENT TEEN-AGE SUICIDE: LISTEN
description: LEAD: A DEPRESSED 14-year-old girl, after telling her guidance counselor that she could not stop thinking about killing herself, sat in a psychologist's office, sobbing. ''Doctor, how would you feel if you can't ever please anyone,'' she said. ''All I seem to do is cause my parents disappointment. So I figured I'd do everyone a favor....Besides, it hurts too much when no one understands me and I feel all alone.

title: SYNAGOGUE BECOMES AN ARTS CENTER
description: WHEN he was 13 years old, Melvin Title had his bar mitzvah at the Charter Oak Temple in Hartford. Now, 76 years later, he will be among those who gather to celebrate the transformation of Connecticut's first synagogue into an arts and cultural center.

title: A TIME TO TINKER WITH OPTIONS PLANS
description: STOCK options have always come in a variety of shapes and sizes. There are qualified options, so-called because they ''qualified'' for tax-favored status. There are non-qualified options, on which corporations get a tax break but employees do not. And there are incentive stock options, particularly beloved by executives because they incur no tax when exercised and until recently were taxed at low capital gains rates when the stock was sold.

title: Janet Smith Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. Herbert Smith Jr. of Clover, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janet McArthur Smith to William Edwards Hunt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Hunt of Cambridge, Mass. The wedding is to be June 27.

title: LEFT-HANDERS THROW TIGERS FOR LOSSES
description: LEFT-handed starting pitchers havethrown a shutout at the Detroit Tigers, but their irrepressible manager remains undaunted and as orally outrageous as ever. The Tigers, in games played in April, lost all six started against them by left-handed pitchers, making them the only team in the major leagues without a victory in such games.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Mahwah Feeling the Strains of Recovery
description: LEAD: IN the seven years since Mahwah lost its position as a thriving industrial center, the township has faced trying economic times. Gone are the huge Ford assembly plant and the Abex Corporation foundry where generations of local residents once worked.

title: Q AND A
description: Paris Hotels

title: Melissa Chassin Marries
description: Melissa Chassin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Joel Chassin of Roslyn, L.I., was married last night to Jeffrey Weiller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Weiller 3d of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Great Neck, L.I. The bride is a sales representative for the Cone Mills Corporation in New York. Her husband is a real-estate broker for Joseph Hilton & Associates in New York.

title: Leslie J. Shecter Wed To Todd A. Hammer
description: Leslie Joy Shecter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Shecter of New City, N.Y., was married there last night to Todd Andrew Hammer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Hammer of New York. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Dellwood Country Club.

title: FEDERAL STUDY FINDS POLLUTANTS IN HARBORS AROUND THE NATION
description: Pesticides, industrial chemicals and sewage flow into the harbors along America's coasts, often collecting and concentrating to pollute the sediment, according to a Government study.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
In Great Neck, Luxury Hugs the Tracks
description: LEAD: CUTTER MILL Road and Great Neck Road in the Village of Great Neck Plaza are unlikely sites for expensive condominiums because they border the Long Island Rail Road tracks. But such is the lure of the Great Neck area that three such developments are under construction along the two thoroughfares, another is planned and village officials expect more in the future.

title: Not All of the Wildlife Lives in the Rockies
description: To the Editor:

title: Shooting Mystery In Gangland
description: If it was an attempt to assassinate John Gotti, it didn't work. The reputed Mafia chief was still alive, outside his Queens headquarters with several companions, after the noise that could have been a gunshot startled the neighborhood Wednesday afternoon. Mr. Gotti denied that he had been shot at, and there was no suspect for the police to arrest.

title: Outstanding Young Woman
description: Dr. Cooperman is not the only state aide to have been honored recently. Hope A. Arvanitis of Lawrenceville, a media consultant at the Department of Human Services in Trenton and a former reporter and anchor newscaster for WMGM - the NBC-TV affiliate in Atlantic City - has been named an Outstanding Young Woman of America by Outstanding Americans, a Montgomery, Ala., biographical publisher. She was cited for career achievements in television and social services that have benefited society. Winners are selected by an advisory board of women who head national organizations, such as the American Association of University Women, and government officials.

title: Ann B. Bierbower Marries John Lally in Washington
description: Ann Butler Bierbower, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Joseph Bierbower of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to John Patrick Lally, a son of Mrs. John James Lally of Newark and the late Mr. Lally. Msgr. W.Louis Quinn performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington.

title: LYME DISEASE SPREADS NORTH
description: THIS month marks the start of the Lyme disease season, and because there are indications that the disease is spreading rapidly, health agencies are devoting increasing efforts at prevention.

title: HAROLD SHAPIRO ON PRINCETON, PLURALISM AND DEBTS TO PAY
description: FOR the last eight years, Harold T. Shapiro has served as president of the University of Michigan, one of the country's best public research universities. Now the 51-year-old economist will be switching to the private sector. On Tuesday the trustees of Princeton University announced that by January he will succeed William G. Bowen, becoming the 18th president of the country's fourth oldest university. Mr. Shapiro, a native of Montreal who received his Ph.D. from Princeton in 1964, spoke to Edward B. Fiske of The New York Times. Excerpts of the interview follow: Question. Do you expect it to be difficult moving from a large public university to a small private one? Answer. I don't think so. My style of management has always been fairly personal, and I'm very much attracted by the chance to focus on undergraduate education at a place that maintains a commitment to high-level scholarship. Princeton has three times as many undergraduates as graduates. Q. Do you have any mandates from the trustees? A. It's always a struggle to sustain high quality, but no, I don't have any special mandates. I see my job at the beginning as one of listening, not making announcements about what Princeton needs. Q. A lot of people are concerned about soaring tuitions. Is there anything colleges can do about it? A. We have two responsibilities. The first is to be efficient. Even though we have no ''bottom line'' in a traditional sense, we have to have internal discipline. At Michigan I required every vice-president to send me a memo every six months with some sort of proposal for eliminating a procedure or cutting the flow of paper. Sometimes I accepted the recommendation, sometimes I didn't. Q. And what is the second responsibility? A. We have to care about quality. Q. That's fine, but a lot of people are concerned about the amount of debt that students are having to accumulate in order to get high-quality education. A. In relation to total household debt in this country, you'd hardly notice if all the higher education debt went away. Every society has to decide how much quality education it wants and for how much. It's really not a matter for universities to decide. It's a much broader question. I, of course, have my own answer. Q. What is that? A. The answer that I hear is that people want quality education. When people choose where to go to college, they always choose quality irrespective of cost. People were always willing to pay more for the University of Michigan if that was the best quality option they had. Q. Are you concerned about the declining presence of blacks and some other minorities on campuses? A. It is an extraordinarily dangerous situation. . . . If the trend continues, it will undermine public support for colleges and universities among minorities, who constitute an important segment of the population. Moreover, the country's future depends on educating all parts of American society. Q. At Michigan you've recently dealt with racial incidents. What did you learn? A. I came away from the situation with a greater sense of urgency and a recognition that the simple solutions of the 60's are no longer adequate. In the past, many minority students were coming from high schools where the student population was mixed. Now they are coming from schools that are mainly black.

title: THIS WAY TO THE MEANING OF THE COSMOS
description: LEAD: AEGYPT By John Crowley. 390 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $17.95.

title: 3 LG. RMS, 3D FLR WLKUP, NR PARK (NO CHILDREN)
description: LEAD: FOR several years, state advocacy groups have been seeking legislation to prohibit discrimination in rental housing against families with children, but not until a shortage of affordable housing caused a public outcry did legislation begin to move.

title: NEW DRUG LAWS POSE PRISON PROBLEM
description: GOVERNOR KEAN signed into law last month bills that give New Jersey some of the toughest drug legislation in the nation. However, they will not take effect until something is done to provide prison space to house the drug dealers that the laws are designed to convict.

title: CANADA CONSIDERS 10 NUCLEAR SUBS TO PATROL ARCTIC
description: The Canadian Government has concluded that it needs as many as 10 nuclear-powered submarines to enforce its claim to sovereignty in Arctic waters.

title: NONFICTION
description: I USED TO BE AN ANIMAL, BUT I'M ALL RIGHT NOW. By Eric Burdon. (Faber & Faber, $9.95.) Eric Burdon's autobiography should dispel any illusions readers may have about the romance of being a rock star in the 1960's. Mr. Burdon, leader of the now-defunct band the Animals, begins this cautionary tale with upbeat memories of his working-class roots in Newcastle, England, and his first exposure to American blues at the Newcastle College of Art and the Liverpool and London club scenes. But his story is mostly one of disappointments. While the success of the band's first big single, ''House of the Rising Sun,'' secured the Animals an American tour, they had not bargained for the hordes of intrusive fans and the disorientation of living on the road. Mr. Burdon reminisces about his first visits to the Apollo Theater in Harlem, where he saw his heroes James Brown and B. B. King; the Animals' tour through the American South in the summer of 1965; and his encounters with Ronald Kirk, Chuck Berry and Otis Redding. However, he spends as much time describing nights of anonymous sex, confused acid trips and the tax dodge his manager set up that cost the band their millions. By 1966, when Mr. Burdon left the Animals and moved to California, he recalls not the peace and love of Haight-Ashbury, but Hell's Angels beating up people at the Fillmore and the death of his friend Jimi Hendrix in London. Though one can't help feeling that much of Mr. Burdon's insight into the era is unconscious, it hardly matters. Taken as social history, his autobiography stands as a vivid record of what has now become pop mythology.

title: A Billion Bottles a Year Defy India Liquor Ban
description: During India's independence struggle against Britain, Mohandas K. Gandhi identified the consumption of alcohol as a major social evil and urged a ban on drinking.

title: A Pillar of the Piano
description: JAZZ: EARL HINES AND COLEMAN HAWKINS Earl Hines, Coleman Hawkins, George Tucker, Oliver Jackson. Produced by Stephen Schmidt. Directed by Karl Genus. Rhapsody Films. 28 minutes. $29.95.

title: THANK YOU, MRS. GILPATRICK
description: AN APPLE FOR MY TEACHER Twelve Authors Tell About Teachers Who Made the Difference. Edited by Louis D. Rubin Jr. Illustrated. 186 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. Paper, $10.95. Cloth, $19.95.

title: What Ails Musicals; Paradise in Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING IT SAFE WITH A CAR RENTAL
description: One New Yorker who does not own an automobile and needs to rent a car whenever she leaves town on business has express-service reservation numbers with major rental companies and can reserve a car without spending time dictating information.

title: MADISON AVE. ROCKERS
description: MIDNIGHT AT THE SAINT. A THOUsand dancers flail about the cavernous club in lower Manhattan, once home to the legendary Fillmore East. Suddenly, the 120-decibel dance music breaks, and an electric panel on one wall rises to reveal a small stage. A spotlight pins Steve Gold, the club's director of marketing. ''Ladies and gentlemen,'' he shouts. ''Continuing in the Fillmore's tradition of featuring the greatest of the greats, let's hear it for...the VPs!''

title: CROSSFIRE AT THE BAR
description: Study this scene and spot the one false note.

title: PORT AUTHORITY: TOO BIG FOR THE PUBLIC?
description: LEAD: SUPER government agencies like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey get things done. But I am just wondering if they can be a bit less super once in a while; maybe this could result in better public acceptance of their proposals.

title: THE IDEA MERCHANT
description: STANDING RESOLUTE IN THE WEEL OF THE House of Representatives last January for his seventh State of the Union Message, President Reagan warned that America was indanger of losing the race for the global market. He was planning, he said, a set of ''comprehensive proposals to enhance our competitiveness.''

title: Young Andretti Has Fast Practice
description: Michael Andretti bettered his father's unofficial record for the fastest lap on opening day of Indianapolis 500 practice today, and the defending champion, Bobby Rahal, predicted speeds of more than 220 miles per hour were possible before or during qualifications for the May 24 race.

title: Act of Recognition
description: Pope John Paul II tread some fine theological and political lines in Cologne, West Germany, last week in beatifying Edith Stein, a Jewish-born nun who was murdered in Auschwitz. Some Jews criticized the beatification, apparently the first of a Jewish-born Catholic, saying Edith Stein was not martyred as a Christian but as a Jew. The Pope, appearing aware of such differences, said the church was ''honoring a daughter of Israel who remained faithful to the Jewish people and, as a Catholic, to our crucified Lord Jesus Christ.'' In the presence of a Jewish delegation, he refrained from using Edith Stein's Catholic name, Sister Teresia Benedicta a Cruce.

title: ALYSHEBA, 8-1, IS FIRST IN KENTUCY DERBY
description: Alysheba, a roguish colt whose misbehavior had cost him victories in the past, was almost knocked over by Bet Twice in midstretch but recovered courageously and won the 113th Kentucky Derby today at Churchill Downs.

title: BASEBALL;
description: He will turn 44 years of age in less than three weeks, but Tommy John is proving that he can still pitch effectively and win in the big leagues. Tonight, he also became the Yankees' stopper, beating the Minnesota Twins, 6-4, in the Metrodome and putting an end to a losing streak that had reached three games.

title: What Ails Musicals; Coward's Comedies
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN THE DOLLAR FINALLY HITS BOTTOM
description: THE dollar has fallen more than 40 percent over the last two years, and some investment strategists think it could soon hit bottom. If so, investors should consider changing the strategies they used while the dollar was heading down.

title: Not Ready For Prime Time?
description: Geraldine Fabrikant's article ''Not Ready for Prime Time?'' (April 12), echoes the runaway excesses of all three networks and the protests from their operating managements.

title: PLAZA OF TEARS
description: MY first response was ''poor old Bridgeport.'' She's a wonderful town and would never ask for my condolences. I should have known that before I saw what was left of L'Ambiance Plaza. The huge slabs of concrete jutting into the spring sunshine and the crumbled cookie bits of the stuff looking so harmless on the muddy ground; before I heard the reporters with their endless questions - some of them humane, some astute, some just plain repetitive and dumb. And listened to Tom Bucci, the Mayor, and Jonathan Best, the director of Emergency Services, give their calm, articulate answers. And before I watched the volunteers unpack the garbage bags filled with carefully pressed shirts, folded towels, blankets, socks -whatever would help, if it could help, the dead construction workers and their families and, more particularly, the brotherhood of union men who were the true reporters this time, uncovering the tragic story in a kind of nightmare archeological dig.

title:
PAPERBACKS;
BEWARE THE CHILDREN OF MAO
description: LEAD: BORN RED A Chronicle of the Cultural Revolution. By Gao Yuan. 380 pp. California: Stanford University Press. Paper, $7.95. Cloth, $39.50.

title: FOR ARTISTS, A CAUSE WORTH THEIR WORK
description: LEAD: FIVE galleries, 33 artists, two citizens' groups and the estate of the sculptor Alexander Calder have joined forces in a fund-raising effort to block construction of a proposed natural gas pipeline through western Connecticut.

title: OVER THERE
description: LEAD: It was 6:30 A.M., and Paige Meili was off on an energizing walk to the health club and then to the office. As usual, the venture capitalist was wearing a gray, man-tailored business suit, a no-nonsense tie and her Nikes - the New York executive look of the 1980's. Ah, but this was not New York. This was a business trip to Paris, and the verdict on Ms.

title: HOME VIDEO: DANCE
description: LEAD: ROMANTIC ERA Starring Alicia Alonso, Carla Fracci, Eva Evdokimova. Kultur. 89 minutes. $39.95.

title: MONTANA GRAPPLES WITH HIGH WORKER INSURANCE
description: When his best logger quit for a better-paying job cutting timber in California, Bruce A. Vincent felt cheated - not by the employee but by the Montana Division of Workers' Compensation. ''There was nothing we could do,'' said Mr. Vincent, business manager for Vincent Logging Inc. here. ''With the cost of workers' compensation insurance so high, we can't compete with neighboring states. We are losing our competent people.'' Other States Affected

title: Roosevelt Meeting Opens Tomorrow
description: Harness racing returns to Roosevelt Raceway with the opening of the spring meeting Monday. The meet will offer 48 programs, concluding Sunday, June 14.

title: HOUSING DESIGN ARGUED IN YONKERS BIAS CASE
description: THE struggle over placement of public housing in predominantly white Yonkers neighborhoods as part of a court-ordered desegregation plan reached a critical stage last week with allegations of delay and conflicts over sites and the type of housing to be built.

title: TEACHING LURES PRINCIPAL TO CLASS
description: BECOMING the principal of a school is the ultimate goal for many teachers, because of the position's status and authority and the higher pay. And few who become principals return to teaching on a full-time basis.

title: 'A Sport of Nature'
description: ''A Sport of Nature'' opens with a girl called Kim discarding her name. On a train coming home from Rhodesia to South Africa, ''she threw Kim up to the rack with her school panama and took on Hillela.'' This is the first stir within the chrysalis of the seemingly ordinary child who will become an African legend, a mythic figure of Nadine Gordimer's Promised Land. The names are carefully chosen. Kim is Ms. Gordimer's witty reference to Kipling's famous tale of colonial life. Her family has also called the child Hillela, a name she has never used, a name meant to honor her great grandfather, a Zionist, who came steerage to Cape Town fleeing the Cossacks in a forgotten pogrom, but the girl Hillela, with no mind for history, simply wants to be different. The change of name is a beautifully observed adolescent gesture, but it is also the first move in a powerful novel of awakening, emergence, and, in so far as fiction can make it possible, a call for a new order.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Amityville $293,000 Meadow Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath new contemporary; fire place, 2-car garage, 60-foot waterfront; esti mated taxes $5,000. East Islip $170,000 167 Keswick Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old high ranch; family room, dining room, deck, 2-car ga rage; taxes $3,500. Elmont $167,000 35 Emily Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 34-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,200. Great River $420,000 123 Widgeon Court 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; fireplace, solar heat, pool, cabana, tennis court; taxes $7,000. Lindenhurst $205,000 209 47th Street 6-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old high-ranch 2-family house; two 3-bedroom units, 1-car garage; taxes $4,000. Patchogue$95,000 119 Clark Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 80-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $1,400. OTHER AREAS Madison, Conn. $329,000 21 Thames Way 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; screened porch, 1.1 acres; taxes not yet available. Pleasantville, N.Y. $282,000 22 Hillside Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old raised ranch; deck, den, cathedral ceilings; taxes $4,318. Millburn, N.J. $195,000 449 Wyoming Avenue 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 52-year-old colonial; porch, basement, fireplace; taxes, $2,692.

title: CONCERN OVER AIDS HELPS RIGHTS UNIT
description: It took a ruling by New York's highest court before a group of homosexuals was permitted to incorporate as the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund Inc. in 1973. Even as recently as 1980 Lambda was, in the words of its executive director, ''still a bit too fringe'' to be taken seriously by many people outside the homosexual community.

title: THE RISKS OF AN UNCHECKED TRADE DEFICIT
description: WHY should the average American care about the record trade deficits? Because, many economists say, they may lead to lost jobs, fewer products at higher prices and general austerity. The recession in the farm belt, which was deepened by contracting overseas markets for American food, may spread across the economy if the imbalances are not redressed. Steelworkers in Pittsburgh have also been squeezed as lower-priced foreign steel replaced their products and many of them were pushed into lower-paying service jobs.

title: IN THE BALDWIN TRADITION
description: BILLY BALDWIN'S IN-teriors - those crisp-lined rooms that epitomized elegance and sophistication from the 1950's through the early 70's - had such a powerful effect on design that his name became synonymous with American style. Popularly referred to as the dean of decorators, Baldwin, who died in 1983, has been an inspiration to old-guard designers for as long as anyone can remember. Trendier decorators, however, tiring of the recent craze for 19th-century clutter, are only now taking a look at Baldwin's style. His luxurious brand of simplicity, evident in the overall spirit of his rooms as well as in his furniture designs, have a broader appeal now than they have for some years.

title: Miss Douglas Has Wedding
description: Grace Episcopal Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Christine Sanders Douglas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Douglas of New York, to Charles Dennis Tansey, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard G. Tansey of San Jose, Calif. The Rev. Kenneth B. Swanson performed the ceremony.

title: Not Ready For Prime Time?
description: Describing the low-rated but superb ''Our World'' as a ''cheap news show'' does a disservice both to the intestinal fortitude it must require of ABC honchos to keep it on the air and the intelligence of the people who produce it. ''Our World'' teaches and entertains; if it is not ready for prime time, then it really doesn't matter who runs the networks. After all, anyone can heap garbage. CHRISTOPHER POLICANO Brooklyn

title: GROWING UP IN L.A.
description: KIDDO By David Handler. 200 pp. New York: Available Press/ Ballantine Books. Paper, $4.95.

title: TURNTABLES RISE TO THE CHALLENGE OF THE CD ERA
description: WITH ATTENTION concentrated on the ascendant CD, developments in conventional phonography are easily overlooked. Yet millions of LP's, accreted over nearly four decades, still make up the bulk of the world's recorded music, and the audio industry continues to provide conventional turntables to serve the needs of listeners loyal to their older disks.

title: Iran Marines Board 14 Ships In Search for Iraq War Goods
description: Iranian marines looking for goods bound for Iraq intercepted and boarded 14 foreign oil tankers and other ships Friday at the Strait of Hormuz, the Iranian press agency reported today.

title: A PLAN TO STAVE OFF THE SEA
description: IN flights over the Louisiana marshes, Dave Hall, a Federal fish and wildlife agent as familiar with the territory as with his own backyard, now becomes disoriented, he says, ''because it's changing so quickly.''

title: CITY BALLET: 'LA SOURCE'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE did more than specialize in the kind of plotless dance works that have come to be known as abstract ballets. He made certain that all his abstractions were different in character. Just how different his ballets could be was demonstrated Thursday night when the New York City Ballet offered ''La Source'' and ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto'' at the New York State Theater.

title: SAVORING PAUL TAYLOR'S EXUBERANT CREATIVITY
description: EVERY SEASON BY THE PAUL Taylor Dance Company brings into focus a different and rich aspect of Mr. Taylor's choreography. In the past, both the sense of ambiguity and the theme of duality common to his work have been highly noticeable. More recently, some of his pieces have demonstrated an uncanny use of abstract form to evoke realism in character and locale.

title: CHILDREN'S CLOTHES FOR LESS
description: MANY women are reluctant to splurge on expensive maternity and baby clothes. But a stylish pregnancy is possible without breaking the bank, and children can be outfitted without taking out a second mortgage.

title: Kristine Kachlein Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Kristine Kachlein and David Rome Ehrlich took place yesterday at the Ione (Calif.) Community United Methodist Church. The Rev. Faith Whitmore performed the ceremony.

title: THE BEAST ABOVE THE SURFACE
description: REPUBLICAN PARTY REPTILE Essays And Outrages. By P. J. O'Rourke. 220 pp. New York: Morgan Entrekin/The Atlantic Monthly Press. Paper, $6.95. THE BACHELOR HOME COMPANION A Practical Guide to Keeping House Like a Pig. By P. J. O'Rourke. Illustrated. 127 pp. New York: Pocket Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: HOUSE CLASH: CULTURE VS. PAST
description: LEAD: PERCHED atop a small hill, the Mercator Cooper house dominates Southampton Village just as it did in the 1840's, when a whaler captain, Mercator Cooper - great-grandfather of the present town justice, Mercator Kendrick - became the first American to visit feudal Japan.

title: HOW BALLET THEATER FOUND 'GISELLE' AT THE MOVIES
description: BALLET COMPANIES dream regularly of new productions. But American Ballet Theater went about acquiring its latest production of ''Giselle,'' which will be seen for the first time in New York at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday, in a novel way. The fresh new sets and costumes that will be unveiled this week are actually glamorously secondhand. By agreement with Cannon Groups Inc., the film producers, the sets and costumes were created for a movie in which the ballet characters come to life and live out the ballet's story of the doomed love of a young peasant girl for a faithless nobleman.

title: Suspended Between a Huff And a Puff
description: Smokers and nonsmokers were united in uncertainty last week as the Appellate Division of New York's State Supreme Court said it would not decide until the last minute whether the state's new smoking restrictions should go into effect Thursday as planned.

title: SAY HEY! IS ERIC DAVIS THE NEXT...
description: LEAD: EVERY WINTER, ERIC DAVIS, the 24-year-old center fielder of the Cincinnati Reds, gets together with some of his friends for batting practice. Each week, from December until the start of spring training in February, Davis, the New York Mets' outfielder Darryl Strawberry and Chris Brown, third baseman for the San Francisco Giants, meet at Harvard Park in the inner-city slum of south central Los

title: Accord in Canada
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney announced that Quebec had finally agreed to sign the Canadian Constitution last week, after holding out for 20 years. Under a widely applauded agreement with Mr. Mulroney and the premiers of the nine other provinces, French-speaking Quebec will be recognized as a ''distinct society.'' All the provinces will get more of a say on immigration policy and Supreme Court appointments. The accord must be ratified at a formal conference, then by the Parliament and 10 provincial legislatures. Approval is expected.

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: I have difficulty accepting that the people described in Bruce Weber's article are representative of the ''emotional temperature of a generation.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm ready. This is home for me. I've lived here a long time, and the condition of life is much better here. I want to get this taken care of so I can visit my family in Mexico.'' - Melesio Sidon of San Antonio, Tex., an illegal alien who will seek amnesty. [ 1:4. ]

title: FAVORITE RUNS OUT OF LUCK
description: PAT DAY recalled in the jockeys' quarters immediately afterward that when he and Demons Begone, the favorite at 2-1, broke from the starting gate in the 113th running of the Kentucky Derby Saturday, ''we broke excellent, broke clean.''

title: Ministry Blocks Bakker's Return
description: When he resigned in March from the PTL television ministry, the Rev. Jim Bakker hoped his exile would be brief. But last week the board of PTL (which stands for Praise the Lord and People That Love) unanimously agreed that he would not be reinstated. They voted to stop paying him and his wife, Tammy Faye, who together made $1.6 million last year in salaries and bonuses.

title: Virginia Wedding For Beth Tanner And Peter Burrus
description: Mary Elizabeth Tanner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Clarence Tanner of Newport News, Va., was married there yesterday to Peter Michael Burrus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Preston Burrus Jr. of Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. J.Wayne Yawn performed the ceremony at the Hilton Baptist Church. He was assisted by the Rev. John M. Lord, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Panel Says Sex Bias Is Declining in the Courts
description: Sensitivity training for judges and other programs have helped reduce sex bias in the New York State court system, a state committee reported last week.

title: FROM TRADITIONAL TO ZOOMOOSOPHONE
description: THE first half of May is traditionally a busy musical fortnight in Westchester: the universities and conservatories are presenting final programs before the semester ends, choirs are ready to display the works they have been rehearsing all spring, and many other performing and presenting organizations are wrapping up their seasons.

title: NOT FOR RED SOX FANS
description: KINER'S KORNER At Bat and on the Air - My 40 Years in Baseball. By Ralph Kiner with Joe Gergen. Illustrated. 239 pp. New York: An Associated Features Book/Arbor House. $16.95. NAILS The Inside Story of an Amazin' Season. By Lenny Dykstra with Marty Noble. Illustrated. 215 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $15.95. A DREAM SEASON By Gary Carter and John Hough Jr. Illustrated. 210 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: Peru Curfew Violators Slain
description: Troops shot to death a doctor and another civilian who were violating the nightly curfew intended to curb violence by leftist rebels in Lima, newspapers reported today. The shootings Friday raised to at least 18 the number of people slain by security forces during curfew hours. The restrictions, in effect from 1 A.M. to 5 A.M., were imposed 14 months ago.

title: Miss Rogers, Reporter, Marries Robert Simko
description: The Harkness Chapel at Connecticut College in New London was the setting for the wedding yesterday of Alison V. Rogers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brian Rogers of Mystic, Conn., to Robert Simko, the son of Mrs. Morris Schapiro of Bayonne, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., and John R. Simko of Bayonne. The Rev. David J. Robb, a Congregational minister who is chaplain of Connecticut College, performed the ceremony.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: The discussion of the Swiss countryside (Travel, April 5), jarred some personal memories. More than a score of years ago, my family toured Switzerland, staying for a few days in Interlaken. My father and I walked up into the hills. As Judith Mandelbaum-Schmid implied in ''Where Heidi Belongs,'' the Swiss mountains, even where they are not Alpine, are always Heidi-esque.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
What Do You Think?
description: LEAD: ''Do you think spending for national defense should be increased, decreased or remain the same?'' ''Do you think spending by the Federal Government for social programs should be increased, decreased or remain the same?'' ''Do you think that welfare benefits are too low, too high or about right?''

title: NATIVES BATTLE NEWCOMERS IN VERMONT TOWN IN ROW OVER RUDE POLICE CHIEF
description: With local government in turmoil in this small Vermont town, only one thing is certain: Job openings abound.

title: Susan Gail Santon Weds a Physician
description: Susan Gail Santon was married yesterday to Dr. Athleo Louis Cambre at the Helen Hills Hills Chapel at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., by the Rev. James Sipikowski, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: ENTERING FROM THE RIGHT, LAXALT IS IN
description: PAUL LAXALT is a well-known politician in two relatively small jurisdictions: his home state of Nevada, which he has served as Lieutenant Governor, Governor and Senator off and on since the early 1960's, and Washington, where he became President Reagan's unofficial agent in the Senate and the official head of the Republican Party with the title of general chairman.

title: Yachts of Luck
description: THE AMERICA'S CUP Narrated by Christopher Reeve. LCA, a division of New World Video 48 minutes. $19.95.

title: Rediscovering A Queens Jewel
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH HAS, SOUTH WANTS
description: TOWARD WORLD PROSPERITY Reshaping the Global Money System. By Irving S. Friedman. 317 pp. Lexington, Mass.: Lexington Books/D. C. Heath & Company. $24.95. THE GLOBAL STRUGGLE FOR MORE Third World Conflicts With Rich Nations. By Bernard D. Nossiter. 254 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $20.

title: JAZZ: THE ALTO SAX OF FRANK MORGAN
description: FRANK MORGAN'S alto saxophone improvisations proceed with the relaxed pacing and solicitous empathy of a conversation between old friends. Just as a complex phrase is winding down, he thinks of something else, another angle, and so he adds an aside. Sometimes the asides take such an unexpected turn that the fabric of the conversation threatens to unravel. That's when Mr. Morgan pauses, smiles and gives the music the chance to reorient itself. Like all good conversationalists, Mr. Morgan is listening even when he's talking.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 30 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 30 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Hard Times
description: THE WICHITA WINGS not only lost their final regular-season game Friday night, but their shirts as well. Following their 6-4 loss to Tacoma in the Major Indoor Soccer League finale, the Wings auctioned off their jerseys in a fund-raising move to help cope with a deficit that threatens the future of the franchise. A team spokesman said the auction raised $20,375. The top price of $2,025 was paid for the jersey of Kim Roentved, a defender, while the dress shirt worn by Roy Turner, the team's president and former coach, brought in $500. Turner has projected a loss of between $500,000 and $600,000 for the Wings.

title: OFFICIALS SPEND A DAY ON THE SOUND TO LEARN OF ITS PROBLEMS
description: AS brisk winds whipped the waves rocking the boat in the choppy waters of Long Island Sound, several people grabbed the lines of an otter trawl and carefully lowered the big net over the bow into the water. These weren't seasoned fishermen, however, they were local officials and residents learning about the problems of the Sound.

title: TEAM EFFORT RESULTS IN SHOWY ROCK GARDEN
description: WHEN Sam and Beverly Ryburn were planning their home on the site of an abandoned Massachusetts farm, they faced a dense tangle of scrub and brush gone wild. The 12-acre site had become a rough woodland of second-growth oak, maple and birch with giant oaks and pines that dated back a hundred years and more. Underneath the trees were blueberries, cat briers and poison ivy. An imposing rock outcrop stood where they had hoped their house would be.

title: Swedes Impose Tax On Sinatra Concert
description: Frank Sinatra will have to pay tax on earnings from a Swedish concert he is planning because he has performed in South Africa, the Swedish Finance Ministry has ruled.

title: Golf; FOCUS ON BLACKWELDER, EXPECTING CHILD IN JUNE
description: Jan Stephenson and Cindy Hill both birdied the 18th hole to take a one-shot lead today after three rounds of the S&H Classic. But the player capturing the most attention was Myra Blackwelder, seven and a half months pregnant, who is among four players right behind the leaders.

title: A BIT OF THE WEST IN EASTERN CONNECTICUT
description: ''HERE lies Les Moore,'' reads the headstone on Boot Hill. ''Shot down by a .44. No Les, no more.''

title: Miss Barone Wed To Mark Schultz
description: At St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Charleston, S.C., yesterday, Caroline G. Barone, a daughter of Mrs. Oliver Rhett Talbert and Dr. Bartolo M. Barone, both of Charleston, was married to Mark Dana Schultz, the son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Carl F. Schultz Jr. of Glastonbury, Conn., and Craigville, Mass. The Rev. John A. Simonin, pastor of the church, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the bridegroom's father, who is senior minister of the First Church of Christ Congregational in Glastonbury.

title:
PAPERBACKS;
MAN SHOT BY APE
description: LEAD: THE INNER GARDEN By Sam Eisenstein. 248 pp. Los Angeles: Sun & Moon Press. Paper, $10.95. Cloth, $15.95.

title: Using Donkeys As Shepherds
description: The use of female ''guard donkeys'' to protect sheep and goats from coyotes and other predators was reported catching on in Texas.

title: 'Judge Shopping' Made Harder
