description: The search for an edge will be a little more difficult for criminal defendants in Federal District Court in Manhattan after July 1, when defendants who plead guilty will no longer be able to ''judge shop'' in search of a lighter sentence. The judges of the court voted unanimously last week to have all cases assigned on a random basis.

title: East Is East, West Is West, but Midwest?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Grocery Store Worker Fatally Shot by Holdup Man
description: A 30-year-old Bronx man working in a grocery store in the Tremont section was shot and killed by a holdup man last night, the police reported.

title: TAKE THESE JOBS AND SAVE THEM
description: SHARP debates have erupted in the General Assembly over legislation on housing, English as an ''official'' language, the death penalty, homosexual rights and plant closings - to name a few issues. A singular bill - H.B.7607: An Act Creating a Task Force on Manufacturing in Connecticut - that could have elicited an equal amount of polemics has surprisingly brought together quite diverse interests.

title: FOR THE STATES, A STARRING ROLE IN THE TAKEOVER GAME
description: THE ink had hardly dried on the Supreme Court's decision last month to uphold an Indiana law regulating mergers before state lawmakers throughout the country began grappling with ways to tighten their controls on takeovers.

title: Dance
description: Who but the madcap Mark Morris would rent the grand ballroom of the Manhattan Center for a striptease - and two other dances based on the essays of Roland Barthes? The Mark Morris Dance Group moves into the ballroom on Wednesday for five performances of ''Mythologies,'' which includes ''Soap-powders and Detergents,'' ''Striptease'' and ''Championship Wrestling.'' The wrestling piece has been performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music; the other two dances come here after premieres in Boston that are still being talked about. The performances will occur in a setting that is part cabaret, part conventional theater, with pre-show entertainment provided by Julie Cascioppo and Linda Dowdell. The company will perform evenings at 8 through Saturday, and next Sunday at 3 P.M. at the center, 311 West 34th Street.

title: BIG ART MUSEUM PLANNED FOR RURAL MASSACHUSETTS
description: This decaying industrial city in the northwest corner of Massachusetts may soon become the site of the largest contemporary art museum in the world.

title: CAIN AND ABEL IN CALIFORNIA
description: IN ''True West,'' Sam Shepard's riveting play now at the Long Island Stage, two brothers play out a modern Cain and Abel story.

title: Doing Jet Maneuvers, Flier Is Killed in Crash
description: The pilot of a military jet who was performing aerial maneuvers was killed when his plane crashed and exploded Friday night, the authorities said.

title: Angola Rebels Report Victory In Diamond-Producing Area
description: Angolan rebels said today that they had killed 108 Government troops and 4 Cubans in a battle in the northeastern diamond-producing province of Lunda.

title: Paris Museums
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed your article on the little museums of Paris. Not only are their collections unique, but they are often in areas that travelers might not otherwise visit. One such museum (not included in the article) that fascinated my family and me on a rainy afternoon last year was the Musee de Neuilly.

title: Postings; Circa 1959 Prefab: $1.1 Million Asked for a Wright House
description: The only Frank Lloyd Wright-designed residence in New York City is up for sale and the asking price is $1.1 million.

title: Trading 24 Hours a Day?
description: The Chicago Board of Trade started night-time trading last week, partly to get more trans-Pacific business. With its added 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. schedule, the Board is the first financial market to cater explicitly to foreign clients by being open during hours convenient to them, says Richard L. Sandor, senior vice president at Drexel Burnham Lambert in Chicago.

title: U.S. AND THE NICARAGUAN REBELS: SIX YEARS OF QUESTIONS AND CONTRADICTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration's support for the Nicaraguan rebels has been marked by contradictions - and the potential for misleading Congress - ever since President Reagan approved support for the rebel forces nearly six years ago, according to present and former Administration officials.

title: MALE AND FEMALE, MEN AND WOMEN
description: LEAD: FEMINISM UNMODIFIED Discourses on Life and Law. By Catharine A. MacKinnon. 315 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: DECADENT DESSERTS
description: I AM NOT A DESSERT FANATIC. NOR do I suffer withdrawal in the absence of chocolate. However, when the mood strikes me -and it happens often enough - then I seek pure, unrestrained decadent pleasure. For the seduction to be complete, the object of my affections will be a combination of caramel with nuts, or fruit with chocolate. The texture must be at least partially crunchy or crisp, and the dessert must be beautiful to behold. Like love, temptation is often sparked at first sight.

title: A LESSON FROM PAPA
description: In their book, ''The Classic Touch: Lessons in Leadership from Homer to Hemingway,'' to be published this month by Dow Jones-Irwin, John K. Clemens and Douglas F. Mayer reconsider the great works of literature in search of lessons for modern executives. The following is adapted from their discussion of Ernest Hemingway's famous novel about the Spanish Civil War.

title: CRIME
description: The search for really good original crime novels in paperback can have its rewards, and one of them is HE DIED WITH HIS EYES OPEN by Derek Raymond (Available Press/Ballantine, $4.95). Mr. Raymond, a British author, writes about an unnamed Scotland Yard sergeant who works in what is called the Factory. In the Factory uninteresting murders are investigated; that is, murders of derelicts or hopheads, or anything that does not interest the Serious Crimes Division.

title: National Parks
description: To the Editor: As Irvin Molotsky reports in ''Pay As You Go at National Parks'' (Travel, March 29), this is just another tax. It's repulsive in the extreme to be charged a fee to enjoy the great outdoors. Let's hope a more enlightened administration will rescind these revolting fees. BEN CALDERONE Levittown, L.I.

title: North Providence, R.I.: Texas Builder Moseys North
description: DEMAND for housing in Rhode Island has brought a Texas-based developer to this growing town next to the state's capital and about an hour's drive from Boston.

title: WHY THE SUN NEVER SETS ON A GEOCHRON CLOCK
description: JAMES M. KILBURG'S big day in the sun was Nov. 19, 1985. It was on that day, at the summit meeting in Geneva, that President Reagan presented one of Mr. Kilburg's products to Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev as a gift.

title: TICKET STRATEGIES FOR CONCERTGOERS
description: You like music and you like to travel. It follows that you would probably like to travel to Europe to attend one or more music festivals, but one consideration may be holding you back: how to get tickets to performances.

title: PATRIOTS IN SMOKE-FILLED ROOMS
description: ARE WE TO BE A NATION? The Making of the Constitution. By Richard B. Bernstein with Kym S. Rice. Illustrated. 342 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Paper, $14.95. Cloth, $35.

title:
PAPERBACKS;
FICTION
description: LEAD: HE RAU AROHA: A Hundred Leaves of Love. By Apirana Taylor. (Penguin, $4.95.) Just when you thought you were broadening your reading list by picking up Milan Kundera and the other Eastern Europeans, here comes a slim volume of parablelike mini-stories and poems by the New Zealand writer Apirana Taylor.

title: Former Taxi Chief Indicted Again
description: Jay L. Turoff, the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, already facing a prison term after having been found guilty three weeks ago of tax evasion, was indicted on new Federal and state charges last week in a case that prosecutors said involved illegal medallions.

title: Dr. Judith Smith Weds D. E. Fairbank
description: The marriage of Dr. Judith Wilson Smith and David Ezekiel Fairbank took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Alice Farquhar-Mayes performed the ceremony.

title: POLITICIANS AND POWER SHORTAGES
description: I wish to protest negative reporting re the shortage of electric power on Long Island [ ''Lilco Sounds Sharp Alarm on Power,'' April 12 ] . Demand for electricity has increased 50 percent in the last 15 years and Lilco, anticipating the increase, built the Shoreham nuclear power plant with the approval of Suffolk County, New York State, the New York State Public Service Commission, the New York State Power Authority, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the United States Government.

title: OBSERVATION AT FULL THROTTLE
description: NOBODY BETTER, BETTER THAN NOBODY By Ian Frazier. 181 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: PLEASE GIVE $25. GIVE $25. GIVE $25.
description: IN March 1986, while scrutinizing every deduction that could possibly lower my 1985 Internal Revenue Service bill, I found I had given more money to a number of charitable organizations than I had intended to.

title: MUSIC: BOSTON SYMPATHY
description: THE Boston Symphony's program of Liszt and Bruckner at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night was already rich in irony before the first note was played. It ended with Bruckner's Second Symphony, a work offered in dedication to Liszt but offered in vain. Liszt found Bruckner a pest and seems to have lost the manuscript in transit from Vienna.

title: RAUSCHENBERG'S TOUR DE FORCE
description: FOR ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG all the world's a canvas - and a palette. Up to his elbows in paper pulp in China, in mud-manure straw clay in India, in red-brown tribal facepaint in a Venezuelan village on the Amazon or a mixture of sands from Israel, Mr. Rauschenberg takes materials and images, techniques and information from cultures around the globe and uses them in his art.

title: RACIAL DRAMA CLOSES SEASON AT CROSSROADS
description: FOR ITS last play of the season, the Crossroads Theatre Company is presenting, through May 17, an incendiary work: ''Split Second,'' a 1984 Off-Broadway production.

title: Vamping Till Ready
description: It ALL BEGAN WITH AN innocent parenthetical remark. A couple of months ago, in a piece about the language of self-involvement, I quoted a girlfriend of Woody Allen as having described the actor as ''very much of a womanizer, very self-involved.'' Then this afterthought: ''(If anyone knows the noun for the feminine counterpart to womanizer, send it in).''

title: Protests On Navyport
description: To the Editor:

title: ARE VIEWERS ENTITLED TO GAMES ON FREE TV?
description: If you need to watch a ball game, go to the ball park. Support your home team. Otherwise, we may find ourselves watching a free broadcast originating from New Jersey. SALVATORE MESSANO Brooklyn

title: THAI CABINET BESIEGED, NOW BY FARMERS
description: Thailand's Government, shaken last month by a show of disapproval from the powerful military, came under attack again this week from a new and apparently well-organized movement advocating a populist revolution.

title: June Wedding Planned By Lisa R. Weinstock
description: The engagement of Lisa R. Weinstock to Dr. Richard I. Finkel, a son of Dr. Martin Finkel of Manhattan and the late Dr. Elaine R. Finkel, has been announced by her parents, Esther Weinstock and Israel Weinstock, both Weinstock and Israel Weinstock, both of Forest Hills, Queens. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: EATING THE COMPETITION FOR LUNCH
description: A TRIP to the Corporate bookshelf usually provides some food for thought,and my latest excursion was no exception. In ''Managing Your Mind and Mood Through Food,'' Judith J. Wurtman, a nutrition expert, says the overriding, undeniable reason many people feel listless at conferences and seminars - wait, don't nod off yet -is that they eat incorrectly. Ms. Wurtman would like to see a nutritional revolution in corporate America and, evidently, she is not alone.

title: ON TOUR WITH ROCK HUDSON
description: LEAD: DO WE NEED TO KNOW the truth about Rock Hudson? Would he have wanted it known?''

title: A TIMES POLL OF M.B.A.'S
description: While they single out a few companies and top executives for plaudits, the graduates of six leading schools of management are generally critical of American management as shortsighted and preoccupied by merger mania. They also disdain members of corporate boards as inattentive, ill-informed and too slow to fire inept chief executives. There is one business development, however, they wholeheartedly endorse: the recent drastic cuts in the ranks of middle management.

title: BATMAN AT MIDLIFE: OR THE FUNNIES GROW UP
description: I NEVER got to read ''Alice in Wonderland'' until I was an adult, and I was spared ''Peter Pan'' until we had children of our own, one of whom, bless her, stuck out her tongue when she was invited to clap hands if she believed in fairies. I come from Canadian law-and-order country, where even jaywalking is a punishable offense in some cities, and we were brought up to believe in Superman, the Batman, Dick Tracy and others, who made short work of villains (the Joker, the Penguin, Flattop, Pruneface), never mind sissy stuff like reading them their rights or taking into account their deprived childhoods. I was reared on the comics, or the funnies, as we used to call them -Tarzan, Li'l Abner, Joe Palooka, Alley Oop, the Gumps, all of whom came my way when my father returned from his junkyard in the evenings, remembering to bring home The New York Mirror and The Daily News. I abhor latter-day, modishly camp takeoffs of my cherished boyhood heroes and heroines (Little Orphan Annie, Wonder Woman, Invisible Scarlet O'Neil). Say, the Batman series on television or, more recently, Superman on the wide screen, with their irritating wink wink style. This sort of desecration will bury the form as surely as good Indians and then slapstick did in the western.

title: 'SILVER CITY' PLANS A MUSEUM OF THE METAL
description: JOE PISTILLI, a Meriden silversmith, likes to talk about the Connecticut silver industry of yesteryear. Meriden, he noted, was known as the Silver City of the World, producing the largest volumes of silver and silver-plated wares in the world.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Fitness, Then
description: LEAD: YOU can't get Benjamin Brandreth's purgative pills anymore. But for 90 years, from 1837 until 1927, the tiny capsules, manufactured by the millions in his Ossining factory and designed to cure ailments by purifying the blood, were a staple of the nation's medicine chests.

title: Americans Need a Few Good Reasons to Save; Thrift, Thrift, Horatio!
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS ARE LEVELED BY FLYERS, 5-1
description: For the first time in these playoffs, the Islanders could not scramble their way into a comeback. Finally, faced with a sixth glimpse of elimination and the unrelenting force of the Flyers, the combination proved too much for the Islanders.

title: Residential Resales

Chelsea $490,000 346 West 22d Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. condo in prewar brownstone; open kitchen, fireplace, large master bedroom suite; common charges $758, taxes $2,496 (Broker: King man Associates) Turtle Bay $271,000 255 East 49th Street (Sterling Plaza) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 4-year-old condo; dining alcove, 24-hr. door man, concierge, common charges $525, taxes $600 (Broker: Dwelling Sales) Upper East Side$375,000 333 East 69th Street 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft postwar duplex co-op; den, 24-hr. doorman, attended garage, solari um; maintenance $1,382, 50% tax- deductible (Broker: Olshan Realty) Upper West Side $436,000 251 West 89th Street 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft. condo in recently renovated prewar building; formal dining room, maid's room, 24-hr. doorman; common charges $597, taxes $151 (Broker: Alpha Equities) BRONX Parkchester $205,000 1410 Croes Avenue 4-family brick detached house; 2 bedrooms and dining room in two units, 1 bedroom in other two, 1 bath in each; finished basement, private driveway, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,100 (Broker: Marland Real Estate) Throgs Neck $186,000 27-18 Schurz Avenue (White Beach Condominiums & Marina) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old 1,029-sq.-ft. condo; fireplace, on- site parking, eat-in kitchen; com mon charges $171, taxes $720 (Broker: Tryax Realty) Williamsbridge $105,000 815 East 217th Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, detached wood-frame single-family house; dining room, front porch, stand-up attic, full basement, garage, 33- by 114-ft. lot; taxes $700 (Broker: J.A.V. Walsh Realty)

title: Strikers Vote to Quit Union
description: Striking employees at a missile electronics plant here have voted to decertify the United Automobile Workers as their bargaining agent, a company spokesman said. The union, which has been on strike against the LTV Aerospace plant since June, called off the strike Friday night and recalled its pickets, according to Tommy Wilson of LTV Aerospace in Dallas. The vote was 615-419 in favor of decertification, Mr. Wilson said. Union representatives could not be reached for comment.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HARTFORD SHOW HOUSE

title: 2 'TRAVIATAS' COMING
description: LEAD: FOR the first time in its 21 years, the New Jersey State Opera, conducted by Alfredo Silipigni, will give two performances of a production at Symphony Hall here.

title: LIFEGUARD SHORTAGE SEEN
description: A LIFEGUARD shortage is expected this summer and, as a result, swimming hours may be curtailed and some pools and beaches could be closed, officials say.

title: ARE VIEWERS ENTITLED TO GAMES ON FREE TV?
description: George Steinbrenner must think all Yankee fans are fools, after he ''sold out'' on us once again. Well, I will never go to the Stadium again, and I feel the only recourse we fans have is to pool together and boycott games. When Mr. Steinbrenner sees those picket lines, maybe, just maybe he'll get the message. The Yankees are our team, and we can do something about it! ROB ILARIA Brooklyn

title: U.S. Schools Are Said to Fail in Reducing Bias
description: America's schools have failed in their task of educating children about the country's racial heritage and teaching them constructive ways of confronting prejudice and fear, a group of mental-health and education experts agreed last week.

title: DESPITE SCRUTINY, STATE BACKS CARE IN NEW YORK HOSPITALS
description: Although intensive governmental surveillance is uncovering troubling numbers of fatal medical errors at many New York hospitals, Dr. David Axelrod, the State Health Commissioner, said recently that ''the quality of hospital care in New York has never been better.''

title: The Unromantic Generation
description: I wish you had interviewed me. After all, I fit the mold. I am 27, an honors graduate of Stanford who worked on Madison Avenue. I had my own income, my own apartment, a great social life and no intention of marrying before 30.

title: A Prison Is Boon to Building
description: LEAD: GROUND was broken last month for the $59 million, 500-bed maximum-security Chemung Correctional Facility in Southport, N.Y., stirring hopes that the upstate community's real-estate market will pull out of a 20-year-slump.

title: DRIVING HARD ON WALL STREET
description: HOWARD SILVERMAN drives a Porsche 928. He used to race Jaguar XKE's. He runs his powerboat at speeds of 60 miles an hour. He likes to use the word ''aggressive'' when describing himself. And when he goes to work each day at 14 Wall Street, he pushes the Gruntal Financial Corporation toward an expanded future as a brokerage house.

title: Watching the Ball
description: DICK WAGNER, the Houston Astros' president, said yesterday that A. Bartlett Giamatti, the National League president, had told him that umpires would continue to check balls for scuff marks when Mike Scott pitches for the Astros. ''We told him the Astros objected to Mike Scott being singled out and hassled,'' Wagner said at a news conference before a night game against the Braves in Atlanta.

title: THE WOMAN WHO BEAUTIFIED BAYREUTH
description: She was always short of money but managed to build herself a sumptuous opera house and a couple of palaces; she was married to the ruler of a tiny, previously obscure German state, but managed to make her village-like capital one of Europe's great cultural centers. In the mid-18th century, Wilhelmina, Margravine of Bayreuth, corresponded with Voltaire, set a new fashion in gardens and so embellished her surroundings that, today still, they make her city one of the most fascinating in Central Europe.

title: MALE AND FEMALE, MEN AND WOMEN
description: LEAD: THE SECRET MUSEUM Pornography in Modern Culture. By Walter Kendrick. 288 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Reagan's Name Used to Solicit Contractor Funds
description: Carl R. (Spitz) Channell, a fund-raiser who pleaded guilty this week to illegally raising money for the Nicaraguan rebels, tried unsuccessfully last spring to involve President Reagan in soliciting contributions from military contractors for promoting the Administration plan for a defense against missiles.

title: Dietzel Retires
description: PAUL DIETZEL, former national football coach of the year with Louisiana State University, has decided to retire and will leave as athletic director at Samford University in Birmingham, Ala., June 1. Dietzel, 62 years old, said in a statement that he and his wife, Anne, wanted to return to their home in North Carolina. ''We do not know how many golden moments each of us has,'' Dietzel said.

title: Miss Mac Donald Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Armstrong MacDonald of Albany of the engagement of their daughter Heidi Beth MacDonald to Louis Robert Bergesch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis William Bergesch of Mamaroneck, N.Y. A June 29 wedding is planned.

title: PAPERBACK BESTSELLERS: MAY 3, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 9 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.95.) A plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 2 1 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter becomes a consuming passion. 3 6 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 4 4 THE GREAT ALONE, by Janet Dailey. (Pocket, $4.95.) Women's role in seven generations of Alaskan history. 5 * 5 STONE 588, by Gerald A. Browne. (Berkley, $4.50.) The pursuit of a stolen crystal with curative powers. 6 9 PRIVATE AFFAIRS, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $4.95.) title: Two Defrocked Clergymen Arrested at Lutheran Session
description: Two defrocked Lutheran ministers were arrested today when they and about 30 supporters tried to force their way onto the convention floor of the newly formed Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.

title: LOST ON THE OPEN ROAD
description: FAST LANES By Jayne Anne Phillips. 148 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/E. P. Dutton. $15.95.

title: THE RISE OF HILLELA, THE FALL OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: A SPORT OF NATURE By Nadine Gordimer. 341 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: COPPOLA RETURNS TO THE VIETNAM ERA, MINUS APOCALYPSE
description: ON THE EDGE OF NORTHERN California's wine country, a huge turn-of-the-century Victorian manor has been transformed by Hollywood magic into a home in Ypsilanti, Mich., circa 1945. Beside it, in a sooted brick factory building that seems nearly as old as the mansion but was erected only a few weeks ago, Francis Coppola is directing the actor Jeff Bridges as he portrays a man - the postwar auto maker Preston Tucker - pursuing a dream.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN COMPENSATION
description: AS 1986 drew to a close, there was a flurry of activity in many corporate payroll departments. Computers were reprogrammed to withhold paychecks from senior executives who felt they could ride out November and December without their salaries. They would get the money in 1987 or 1988, when it would be taxed at the lower rates mandated by the Tax Reform Act.

title: The Bronx River Is Wonderful - Really
description: EACH spring walking tours that highlight the metropolitan area's architectural wonders, historical sites or cultural treasures become the vogue, as people look for opportunities to get outside and enjoy the improving weather.

title: SMITHSONIAN TO OFFER LECTURE SERIES AT PACE
description: BEGINNING Wednesday night, Pace University will be the site of an ambitious five-day series of educational programs that showcase the Smithsonian Institution's collections and research materials.

title: ALL FOR ONE? ZIMBABWE PARTIES RESIST
description: The political party of Joshua Nkomo designed an emblem not long ago intended to reflect an anticipated merger with the ruling party of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe.

title: PEE-WEE HERMAN'S MAD, MAD WORLD
description: THE multicolored hibiscus that blooms in the garden of the Selby Gardens Museum of Botany and the Arts in Sarasota, Fla., is now called the Pee-wee Herman. The parents of the television comedian arranged to have it named for him.

title: Forums of Anti-Communism
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET MONITORING OF PHONES IS CITED
description: The Soviet Union maintains an elaborate system for eavesdropping on sensitive United States Government communications from Soviet-bloc embassies here, according to intelligence authorities.

title: Science Academy Rejects Harvard Political Scientist
description: Since it was founded in 1863, the National Academy of Sciences has been dominated by practitioners of physics, chemistry and other sciences whose subject matter is particularly amenable to the rigors of mathematical analysis. Human behavior is more difficult to quantify, however, and members of the so-called soft sciences - which include sociology, political science and economics - have had trouble penetrating American science's most prestigious club. About 12 percent of the Academy's members are social and behavioral scientists.

title: GARBAGE ODYSSEY PROVES EMBARRASSING
description: LONG ISLAND'S pariah garbage barge gathered more than just flies last week as it meandered through the southern seas.

title: Jane Elizabeth Blinder To Wed Robert Barocas
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seton Laurence Blinder of Hewlett, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Elizabeth Blinder to Robert Barocas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Barocas of Great Neck, L.I.

title: CARLY SIMON'S EMOTION-LADEN SELF-PORTRAIT
description: ''COMING AROUND AGAIN,'' the title song of Carly Simon's latest album, embodies everything that the 41-year-old singer-songwriter does best. This deceptively simple song, written for the movie ''Heartburn,'' distills the film's themes and atmosphere in broad, blunt strokes. Depicting a high-powered, high-strung woman struggling miserably through the rituals of daily life while her marriage is coming apart, its verses paint a concise picture of domestic desperation: ''You pay the grocer/ Fix the toaster/ Kiss the host goodbye/ Then you break a window/ Burn the souffle/ Scream the lullaby.''

title: BLAKE EDWARDS: LAUGHS AMID THE BRICKBATS
description: THE TOMATOES ARE AGAIN flying, as they always do with the advent of a new Blake Edwards film. For a director who specializes in light farce, Mr. Edwards certainly can generate a lot of ill humor. ''Ever been steered by a critic to a movie you ended up actively despising?'' asks Amram Whiteman of New York City, one of numerous annoyed readers. ''Enjoy it I didn't. . .a car crashes into a store twice or even three times (I don't remember which). Funny? I don't think so. A waiter is tossed in a swimming pool. Funny? Not on your life. Pocket ripping also leaves me quite cold.''

title: THE STATE AS EXECUTIONER, THE STATE AS ADVOCATE
description: IN matters of institutionalized life and death, Florida and Texas share some bleak statistics.

title: SUGGESTIONS FOR DINING ON MOTHER'S DAY
description: LEAD: GATHERING the family together while giving mother a day off from the stove is the thoughtful motive that, according to Harper's Index, puts Mother's Day at the top among holidays in the number of Americans who dine out to mark the occasion.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: HIGGLETY PIGGLETY POP! Fantasy opera by Maurice Sendak and Oliver Knussen, with Cynthia Buchan, Andrew Gallacher, Rosemary Hardy, Neil Jenkins. London Sonfonietta conducted by Nona Liddell. Home Vision 8339261. Color. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: INSIDE
description: Floating Jail Proves Costly New York City is modifying the operation of its new prison ferry to avoid $3 million in unexpected staffing costs. Page 40. Watchdog for V.A. Unit A Federal judge has appointed an outside overseer to supervise the Veterans Administration's compensation and pension division. Page 26. Islanders Out of Playoffs Philadelphia eliminated the New York Islanders from the National Hockey League playoffs, winning the final game of the series, 5-1. Section 5. Vote Splits Apartheid Foes Some liberals in South Africa are angered by a campaign by anti-apartheid groups to boycott the whites-only election set for Wednesday. Page 11.

title: PLAYLAND TO OPEN AMID POLITICAL CALM
description: LEAD: PLAYLAND, the county-owned amusement area in Rye, opens for its 59th season on Saturday, this time without any of the political pyrotechnics that once accompanied the event.

title: GROUPS TO OFFER HELP FOR ALIENS
description: Following is a list of religious, civic and community groups in the New York metropolitan region that will help process the applications of aliens for legal status under the new immigration laws: MANHATTAN Lutheran Immigration and Refugee Services, 360 Park Ave. South. Episcopal Mission Society, 14 E. 109th St. Presiding Bishop's Fund, 815 Second Ave. Private Immigration Agency Inc., 601 W. 156th St. International Ladies Garment Workers Union, 1710 Broadway. United States Catholic Conference, Migration and Refugee Services, 902 Broadway. Polish and Slavic Center Inc., 119 E. 15th St. Japanese American Social Service, Inc., 275 Seventh Ave., 12th floor. Ethiopian Community Mutual Assistance Association, 225 Park Ave. South. BROOKLYN St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, 1227 Pacific St. South Side Community Mission, 280 Marcy Ave. Catholic Migration Services Inc., 75 Greene Ave. America's Grateful Immigrants Inc. 281 Classon Ave. Congress of Racial Equality, 1463 Flatbush Ave. Congress of Racial Equality, 304-A Utica Ave. Polish and Slavic Center, 176 Java St. Polish and Slavic Center, 119 Greenpoint Ave. Caribbean/American Media Studies Inc., 968 49th St. QUEENS St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 89-16 168th St. Concerned Citizens of Queens, 82-14 Roosevelt Ave. Hellenic American Neighborhood Action Committee Inc., 31-14 30th Ave. NASSAU COUNTY St. George's Episcopal Church, 319 Front St.,Hempstead. Congress of Racial Equality, 125 Botsford St., Hempstead. SUFFOLK COUNTY Catholic Charities, 143 Schliegel Blvd., Amityville. Christ Episcopal Church, 155 Third Ave., Brentwood. Rural Opportunity, 145 Griffine Ave., Riverhead. WESTCHESTER COUNTY Westchester Hispanic Coalition Inc., 200 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains United Slavonian American League Inc., 240 McLean Ave., Yonkers Spanish Community Progress Foundation, Inc., 201 Palisade Ave., Yonkers ROCKLAND COUNTY World Relief, 201 Route 9W North, Nyack. UPSTATE Albany - International Center of the Capital Region, West Mall Office Plaza, 875 Central Ave., Albany Albion - Rural Opportunity Inc., P.O. Box 24. Binghamton - American Civic Association, 131 Front St. Buffalo - Catholic Charities, 531 Virginia St.; International Institute of Buffalo, 864 Delaware Ave. Corona - Concerned Citizens of Queens, 40-03 National St. Highland - Rural Opportunity Inc., 74 Vineyard Ave. Newburgh - Rural Opportunity Inc., 346 Broadway. New Hampton - Rural Opportunity Inc., Rd.

title: THE THORNY AND MAGNIFICENT MAX REGER
description: RECORDINGS THAT EXPLORE byways of the classical repertory can often prove more stimulating and satisfying than repeated versions of the familiar. There is always a possibility, however unlikely, of discovering unaccountably ignored major works. Furthermore, this is an area in which performing groups that cannot quite compete with the world's finest in the standard repertory can make real discographic contributions.

title: Rail Engineer in Traffic Court
description: The engineer of a freight train that collided with an Amtrak train in January, killing 16 people, pleaded guilty Friday to driving an automobile while under the influence of alcohol and passing a red light and a stop sign. The engineer, Ricky Gates, 32 years old, was fined $1,000, given a two-month suspended sentence and put on two years' supervised probation by Judge Joseph Murphy of Baltimore County Circuit Court. Mr. Gates resigned from the railroad earlier this week. He had been suspended without pay since the accident.

title: Robert Moravek Wed To Rebecca Campbell
description: Rebecca Mary Campbell and Robert Anthony Moravek were married yesterday at St. Anastasia's Roman Catholic Church in Douglaston, Queens. The Rev. Thomas Murtagh performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. William Smith, pastor emeritus, and the Rev. John H. Meyer, a minister of the Reformed Church in America.

title: TELESCOPE BUILT WITH DEDICATION
description: LEAD: USING a 26 1/2-inch reflecting telescope - a legacy from a determined band of men who believed they could build their own observatory - amateur astronomers can peer into the skies over 515-acre Voorhees State Park and the surrounding Hunterdon County countryside.

title: 48 for Elmhurst: Parking Lot Is Yielding To Condos
description: Turning parking lots into housing is old hat to George Greene, whose most recent project along those lines is a condominium development in the heart of Queens called White Oak at Elmhurst. The difficulty is finding and buying the parking lots.

title: Elizabeth Henderson Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Warwick Henderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Warwick Henderson of Locust Valley, L.I., and Robert John Andrew Coleman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Coleman of Manhattan and Fishers Island, L.I., were married yesterday at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Stanley O'Konsky performed the ceremony.

title: Didier Devynck, Executive, Married To Mary Sue McCarthy in Baltimore
description: Mary Sue McCarthy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Jordon McCarthy of Baltimore, was married there yesterday to Didier Devynck, the son of Odette Devynck of Lille, France, and the late Antoine Devynck. The Rev. Blair Newcomb performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: KINJI MORIYAMA
description: Kinji Moriyama, a Member of Parliament and a former Japanese Cabinet minister, died today of heart failure after suddenly becoming ill at a resort hotel west of Tokyo. He was 70 years old. Mr. Moriyama, a member since 1949 of the House of Representatives, the decision-making body of Parliament, served in the 1970's as Transport Minister and as director general of the Science and Technology Agency. For a while, he also was acting secretary general of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party.

title: Children Dining
description: To the Editor: Most of what Paul Hofmann had to say in ''The Instant Seasoned Traveler'' (Travel, March 1) is sound. But in offering blanket advice to spare children culinary adventures, he is wrong.

title: FICTION
description: ASA, AS I KNEW HIM. By Susanna Kaysen. (Vintage Contemporaries, $4.95.) Susanna Kaysen's first novel is a fascinating story of the powers of invention: how most lovers half create the object of their affections, and how artists elevate ordinary persons, objects and events to a kind of mythology. The book begins with the romantic species of invention, as Dinah Sachs, a 30-year-old copy editor at a semi-scholarly magazine in Cambridge, Mass., falls madly in love with Asa Thayer, a married editor of old New England stock, some dozen years her senior. But midway into the history of their doomed affair, Dinah points out that such a story is ''old and boring,'' and the novel changes its course. It becomes Dinah's semi-fictional rendering of Asa's adolescent admiration for and quasi-sexual attraction toward Reuben Sola, a charismatic Jewish youth who is the son of a Harvard professor and art collector. Ms. Kaysen vividly describes Asa's Cambridge boyhood, and especially the emotional tenor of his love for Reuben -whose passion for adventure leads ultimately to tragedy. Art, in the form of a painting evocative of Reuben, acts as a minor solace for Asa. In the same way, the creative process comforts the disillusioned Dinah when she begins writing her story of Asa. Occasionally, this multilayered narrative wobbles on vague sociological underpinnings - the ''soulless'' WASP Asa loving Jews for their ''access to passion'' smacks of stereotyping. But it is a tribute to Ms. Kaysen's considerable talent that when she leaves ethnic generalities for the particularities of character, we easily believe in all her inventions.

title: EVERYBODY IS EDGY AS GOETZ TRIAL OPENS
description: THE trial of Bernhard H. Goetz opened last week with the same mixture of sharp contrasts in opinion and subtle legal distinction that have characterized the case since the day on the subway in December 1984 when Mr. Goetz pulled out an unlicensed pistol and shot four people he said were menacing him.

title: 'COTTON CANDY' FOR THE GIFTED
description: What is happening to our priorities when we train 800 children to make clowns of themselves in a ludicruous extravaganza masquerading as ''creativity for the gifted''? [ ''Olympics of the Mind,'' Long Island Journal, March 15 ] . This is pure entertainment and, as one official said, ''mass insanity.'' (A teacher for 23 years, I was invited to the event.) The time and energy invested in these annual events is cotton candy. Teachers have a mistaken belief that merely being sent to a gifted group, ipso facto, makes children superior. These children need legitimate study and fewer distractions to prepare for their future.

title: WHAT, NEW YORK CITY WORRY?
description: THE J.C. Penney Company, a retailer long known for its budget-priced apparel, decided last week it was no longer comfortable in the high-rent district of Manhattan. The company announced it would move its headquarters to Dallas next year, emptying its 45-story tower on the Avenue of the Americas at 52d Street of the 3,800 employees working there.

title: THEATER: KOREAN DRAMA
description: During its 10 seasons, the Pan Asian Repertory Theater has introduced audiences to plays of Chinese, Japanese, Indian, Filipino and other Asian - and Asian-American - derivation. The current show, Che Inhoon's ''Wha . . . i, Whai, a Long Long Time Ago,'' is the first from Korea. In common with many of the previous plays given by this resourceful company, it demonstrates both a universal application and a cultural specificity. However, in contrast to other Pan Asian work, its theatricality is limited. The play, a contemporary work on a classic theme, was found by Tisa Chang, the Pan Asian artistic director, on a recent trip to Korea. As translated by Hui-jin Pak, ''Wha . . . i, Whai'' is running at Playhouse 46, 423 West 46th Street.

title: PORT AUTHORITY: TOO BIG FOR THE PUBLIC?
description: LEAD: TOM KEAN has done much to earn his popularity as New Jersey's Governor. He started emphasizing education before it was fashionable, and he courageously fought for the reappointment of Chief Justice David Wilentz, a man he would not have selected if there had been a vacancy.

title: IN CENTRAL PARK, A TERRACE IS SAVED FROM DECAY
description: Trampled by the be-ins of the 60's, invaded by the drug dealers of the 70's and defaced by the graffiti of the 80's, Bethesda Terrace deteriorated into a sad, sinister mess.

title: TONS OF RUBBLE, DAYS OF GRIEF: BRIDGEPORT ENDURES
description: AS the death toll rose in Bridgeport last week, weary investigators from Federal, state and local agencies continued their search for clues in the collapse 10 days ago of an apartment building under construction there.

title: How to Lose in '88
description: The way things are going, it will be hard for the Democrats to lose the Presidential election of 1988, but they might just do it.

title: CONFLICT AT LYNDHURST AS DIRECTOR DEPARTS
description: ALMOST four years ago, John L. Frisbee left his job as senior vice president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation to become director of Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, one of the 17 historic homes and museums across the country owned and managed by the trust.

title: THE NEW TAXI FARE: HOW FAIR AND WHO FOR?
description: STARTING today, New Yorkers will pay more to take a taxi. The initial ''drop of the flag'' charge is now $1.15, up 5 cents.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Wheaton, Ill.; Sharing the Du Page Boom
description: AFTER almost a decade of delay, final approval for the development of the 600-acre former Rice family estate on this city's southern edge promises to bring to Wheaton a share of the boom which has been enlivening the rest of Du Page County.

title:
PAPERBACKS;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: READING THE NEWS: A Pantheon Guide to Popular Culture. Edited by Robert Karl Manoff and Michael Schudson. (Pantheon, Paper, $9.95, Cloth, $19.95.) Should we believe what we read in the papers? The six contributors to this lively little book of essays agree - as they do on most points - that while journalists usually get the facts straight, the way they write them up leaves objective truth beyond the average reader's grasp.

title: MOLECULAR INSTITE ADDS STAFF
description: ENCOURAGED by recent Federal grants toward its new $36.4 million center for the diagnosis and treatment of cancer, the Center for Molecular Medicine and Immunology in Newark has begun adding to its staff.

title: THE CONVICTION OF HER COURAGE
description: CORAZON AQUINO The Story of a Revolution. By Lucy Komisar. 290 pp. New York: George Braziller. $16.95.

title: Art
description: As the number of first-rate Jewish sculptors grows, the small sculpture court of the Jewish Museum becomes increasingly important. It gives individual sculptors a chance to respond directly to Jewish culture or history. It also provides a challenging space. The court is open on one side to Central Park; on the other three sides, it is enclosed. It is a difficult mix of styles. The museum and apartment building adjoining it are extremely different in texture and height.

title: Kimberly Ann Steel To Wed J. T. Morley
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. John F. Steel 3d of La Jolla, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Ann Steel, to J.Todd Morley, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Morley of Lloyd Neck, L.I. A June 27 wedding is planned.

title: Volcker Urges Tax Increase to Reduce Deficit
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, said today that the Government must raise taxes or cut spending, or do both, to reduce the huge Federal budget deficit.

title: RISKS ARE GROWING IN A-WAR SYSTEMS
description: The complex systems that keep the world's 50,000 nuclear warheads in check are increasingly vulnerable to false alarms, computer failure and human error, according to a group of Soviet and American researchers.

title: MAXIM'S NAME IS THE GAME
description: AT 8 A.M., PIERRE CARDIN AWAKENS TO TRUMPETS. Across the street from his four-story Paris town house, reveille is sounding at the Elysee Palace, the residence of the President of France.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: New Castle, N.H.;
Trying to Save A Victorian
description: LEAD: WENTWORTH-BY-THE-SEA, the last Victorian resort hotel to grace the coast of northern New England, stands forlorn and empty, the last piece that remains to be fitted into a major development puzzle on this island community hard by Portsmouth.

title: THE VICTIMS USUALLY AGREED
description: DIVINE HUNGER Cannibalism as a Cultural System. By Peggy Reeves Sanday. 266 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. Paper, $12.95. Cloth, $37.50.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Can a Town Set a Minimum House Size?
description: A DENSE hilltop thicket of beech trees and red oaks in a pastoral corner of East Hampton, Conn., seems an unusually tranquil location for a major legal dispute. But the fate of this three-acre parcel is expected to determine the right of any Connecticut town to regulate the minimum size of a house.

title: What Ails Musicals
description: To the Editor:

title: 'A LEGACY OF MISTRUST OF FOREIGNERS'
description: AFTER a lively campaign, the Swiss voted overwhelmingly in a nationwide referendum last month for Government proposals that will restrict the entry of people seeking asylum here.

title: A NEW TAKE ON TYPE A
description: I DROVE ALL THE WAY IN THE RIGHT-HAND lane this morning,'' says one of the senior executives proudly. His five colleagues sitting around a conference-room tabel nod approval. They are part of the fast track, at the San Francisco headquarters of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, but they are also determined to sample life in the slow lane.

title: FUGITIVES IN MONTANA WILDERNESS SAID TO PERISH AS HIDEAWAY BURNS
description: Snipers inside a trailer opened fire today on police officers searching a rugged mountain wilderness for three heavily armed fugitives, then were killed when a fire destroyed the mobile home, the authorities said.

title: KIROV BALLET JOINS CELEBRATION
description: LEAD: TWENTY years ago, ''Glassboro'' and ''Hollybush'' joined the international political lexicon when President Lyndon B. Johnson and Soviet Premier Alexei N. Kosygin met for a summit conference at Hollybush, the campus home of the president of Glassboro State College.

title: A FIGHT TO BUILD ON THE BEACH
description: FROM the southernmost tip of Texas to way down East in Maine, battle lines are being drawn in the sand over the fate of the nation's remaining undeveloped beaches, marshes and wetlands. The tug-of-war is between environmental and economic exigencies, and the outcome will shape the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts for generations.

title: SRI LANK PRESIDENT VOWS TO RECAPTURE TAMILS' STRONGHOLD
description: President J. R. Jayewardene said today that troops must recapture the Jaffna Peninsula, a Tamil rebel stronghold. But he did not say when the northern peninsula should be retaken and did not announce a military offensive.

title: WILMINGTON SAVINGS FUND reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company converted to stock form in November.

title: AMERICAN PASSAGE MARKETNG reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
MYRON L. CHASE
description: Myron L. Chase, president of the Witte Chase Corporation and past president of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, died of a heart attack Friday en route to St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: John E. Kerrigan Dies; Former Boston Official
description: John E. Kerrigan, a longtime City Councilman and former Mayor of Boston, died Saturday of cardiac arrest. He was 79 years old.

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $363,548 and $80,689 from life insurance investments for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, and tax credits of $927,158 and $361,288 for the same periods, respectively.

title: HEAR THE BEAT OF DANCING FEET: A WALKER'S GRIEF
description: When a tap dancer named Charles B. Lawlor and a hat salesman named James W. Blake composed ''The Sidewalks of New York,'' they immortalized the city's pedestrians in waltz tempo. That was in 1894. Try waltzing along the sidewalks today.

title: UNIFORCE TEMPORARY PERONNEL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FILM: PETER USTINOV IN 'MEMED, MY HAWK'
description: PETER USTINOV has a style like no other. Blustery, with eyes rolling and voice rumbling, his characters may have a political edge but they are conceived in the broad strokes of a vaudevillian. That farcical manner may be the one least suited to the story of a young man who rebels against the feudal lord of his Turkish village in 1923, yet the style pervades ''Memed, My Hawk,'' written and directed by Mr. Ustinov and starring him.

title: Business and the Law; Fiery Response To Robins Plan
description: THE avalanche of claims filed against the A. H. Robins Company by 330,000 users of its Dalkon Shield birth-control device has made the company the target of one of the biggest mass-injury cases in history. So there are no good precedents on how to resolve the competing claims from women who say they were injured, women who come forward with claims in the future, creditors, the Internal Revenue Service and others.

title: Andrew Ferguson Wed to Tracy Gill
description: Tracy Gill, promotion director for the Hearst Magazines Special Publications Group in New York, was married at the Prospect Park picnic house in Brooklyn yesterday to Andrew Charles Ferguson, a vice president and government securities trader in the New York office of Hill Samuel & Company, a London merchant bank. M.Michael Grupp, a leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, elected as senior vice presidents: Damaris Ames, Nader F. Darehshori and John P. Schram.

title: MISSING PLANE AND 4 BODIES FOUND IN UPSTATE MOUNTAINS
description: Four bodies were recovered today from the wreckage of a private plane carrying a Virginia family headed for a ski vacation in February.

title: FILM: 'CREEPSHOW 2' OF STEPHEN KING
description: THE ghoulish campfire-tale premises of Stephen King's stories are often a lot more memorable than their particulars, but Mr. King almost always provides more follow-through than ''Creepshow 2,'' a three-section omnibus film based on his writing. As directed by Michael Gornick, with a screenplay by George A. Romero, ''Creepshow 2,'' which opened Friday at the Embassy 1 and other theaters, has three suitably grisly ideas that are only glancingly developed. The episodes are marginally interesting, but each is a little too long. And each could be fully explained in a one-sentence synopsis.

title: GUIDRY STARTS WORKOUTS ON WARY NOTE
description: Ron Guidry said today he would be willing to start the season in the bullpen rather than interrupt the cohesion in the team's pitching rotation.

title: In Jerusalem, a Kibbutz With an Urban Style
description: Ensconced in one of this city's poorest neighborhoods, in a one-story stone house built around a courtyard garden of plants potted in rusty tin cans, is Israel's first urban kibbutz.

title: LAND IN CRISIS LOOKS ANEW AT BATTLES OF YEARS AGO
description: Their faces appear on the national currency, their names adorn countless streets and plazas. But 77 years after the eruption of the Mexican Revolution, the leaders of that cataclysmic period are little more than vague and fading images to millions of their countrymen.

title: FEARS ARE RAISED OVER LEPROSY PLAN
description: A plan to treat leprosy patients at a community health clinic has stirred fear and anger in a tiny community 45 miles south of here.

title: HILL WINS BY THREE IN L.P.G.A. EVENT
description: Cindy Hill, who took sole possession of the lead when Jan Stephenson withdrew because of injuries suffered in an automobile accident Saturday evening, shot a six-under-par 66 today to win the S&H Classic by three strokes over Jane Crafter.

title: Brooklyn Mugging Suspect Dies in Police Station House
description: A 33-year-old mugging suspect died early today while being questioned at the 71st Precinct police station in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, a police spokesman said.

title: INTELLICORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $280,000 for the quarter and $621,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STORMING THE MAGIC KINGDOM:

title: CAUTION AT THE PENTAGON
description: A Pentagon spokesman, Robert Sims, found himself trying to mollify reporters who had gotten wind the other day of the Defense Department's plan to run background checks on journalists applying for credentials to cover the enormous military headquarters building.

title: AA IMPORTING CO reports earnings for Year to Feb 1
WASHINGTON STILL PINES FOR A BIG LEAGUE TEAM By IRVIN MOLOTSKY
description: The signs around Washington say ''Baseball in '87.'' They can take them down.

title: Laughter at Stable 32
description: IT was a gray day, but a day filled with jokes and bright laughter around stable 32 on the backstretch of Churchill Downs, where Alysheba stood in his stall.

title: SHAKE-UP AT MERRILL EXPANDS
description: Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday a high-level shake-up in the management of its securities trading in an effort to recover from last month's loss of $250 million in its mortgage-bond trading.

title: Bank Centers For Canada
description: The Canadian Finance Minister, Michael Wilson, said the Government intends to establish two international banking centers despite a report that is sharply critical of the plan.

title: MANY BENEFIT AS THE SPOTLIGHT TURNS
description: Harry S. Truman was a relatively obscure senator from Missouri in 1941, when he started an investigation into profiteering by military contractors. Three years later he was elected Vice President, and within months he was President, one of many politicians over the years who used a Congressional investigation as a springboard to prominence.

title: A Painful Story of Japanese-Jewish Marriage; The Akutagawa Prize
description: To the Editor:

title: TOMATO GROWERS HURT BY SUCCESS
description: The tomato growers of California's Central Valley say they did everything right to increase productivity, improve quality and cut costs, expecting, with Yankee self-confidence, ''to feed the world.'' Now, in a microcosm of the problems facing much of American agriculture, many of the growers are worrying about feeding themselves and wondering what went wrong.

title: They Won't Be Coming Back
description: ONE of the many fascinating aspects of the National Hockey League is its exotic awards. Among my personal favorites are the Lady Byng Memorial Trophy (I have always thought of her as a character in Hemingway, sipping Rioja from a goatskin and watching the hockey players run in Pamplona), the Calder Memorial Trophy (for the best mobile fashioned from broken hockey sticks) and the Hart Memorial Trophy (formerly known as the Hartpence Memorial Trophy, but nobody knows what the trophy really stands for).

title: 2 Bodies Found in Rubble in Montana Manhunt
description: Two bodies that the authorities believe are those of fugitives sought for nearly a week after an ambush on the police were removed today from the burned-out rubble of a mobile home, officials said.

title: CHINESE BANK IS AN ANOMALY
description: To foreign business executives, the Chinese banking giant Citic sometimes seems to be everything that the country is not: capitalist, bold, efficient, profitable.

title: Dole's Three Vulnerabilities
description: Bob Dole is the Democrats' favorite Republican. He is reasonable, pragmatic and witty. He is too politically savvy to say ''I am not a kook'' but his non-kookiness is plain to see.

title: A Painful Story of Japanese-Jewish Marriage; Shanghai Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: Lehman Rein's End Lets Dillon Fill Post
description: For a select group of Wall Street investment bankers, May 12 will provide their first chance to scratch a three-year itch.

title: MAYOTTE LEARNS OFF-THE-COURT GAME
description: THE photo studio was located in a dimly lighted, unfurnished basement, far removed from the glamour usually associated with a high-profile modeling career. After four tedious hours of primping for the camera -being poked and tugged at by a photographer's assistant, having water sprayed on him to simulate sweat, being asked to smile on cue -Tim Mayotte had a new appreciation for the preparation he puts into a tennis workout, when at least the emotions and sweat are real.

title: QE2 Passengers Get Rebate for Problems
description: Passengers on the Queen Elizabeth 2, which arrives in New York Monday, will receive cash refunds to compensate for a disastrous start to their luxury five-day transatlantic cruise, the operators said.

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago period.

title: Maura F. Smotrich Wed To Mark Jeffrey Shapiro
description: At Temple Beth-El in Chappaqua, N.Y., yesterday Maura Faye Smotrich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David I. Smotrich of Chappaqua, was married to Mark Jeffrey Shapiro, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Shapiro of Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Robert Fine performed the ceremony.

title: DAVIS'S BARRAGE FLATTENS PHILLIES
description: Eric Davis hit three home runs, including a grand slam, and drove in six runs today, powering the Cincinnati Reds to a 9-6 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: RACIAL REMARKS FORCE RECALL OF STATE MANUAL
description: An affirmative-action manual used to train 100 New York State employees has been recalled because it characterized all white Americans as racist.

title: ONE ISSUE THAT'S SAFE
description: New York's House delegation of 19 Democrats and 15 Republicans rarely finds itself united on any legislative action, but one of those unusual moments of unanimity occurred Thursday when Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of the Bronx, Nassau and Queens, persuaded all the other 33 New Yorkers to co-sponsor his resolution for official House participation in a 1989 New York City ceremony that will celebrate the 200th anniversary of the First Congress and the inauguration of President George Washington in that city.

title: DANCE: TWO DEBUTS ON PROGRAM OF CITY BALLET
description: THE New York City Ballet kept both the audience and the dancers on their toes in a program of notable variety on Friday night at the New York State Theater. There was a little celestial light and romantic chiaroscuro from George Balanchine, as well as a knock-'em-dead pas de deux. And a ballet by Paul Mejia added a dose of melodrama to the proceedings.

title: TSENG LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization Subcommittee on Small Territories - 3 P.M. Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Plenary - 10:30 A.M. Social Committee - 3 P.M. Economic Committee - 3 P.M.

title: BLUE JAYS WIN, 3-1, FOR SIXTH IN ROW
description: Jim Clancy held Texas to two hits for eight and one-third innings today, and the Toronto Blue Jays extended their winning streak to six games by beating the Texas Rangers, 3-1.

title: REECE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $22,000.

title: FEAR ON PROTECTIONISM SOFTENS TRADE BILL PUSH
description: Not long before last week's vote on the House trade bill, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca, told Democratic leaders here, ''A member of Congress would rather be called a pervert than a protectionist.''

title: NEW ALIEN LAW PUTS PRESSURE ON AGENCIES
description: Churches, neighborhood groups and government agencies in the New York region are scrambling to set up counseling networks that will guide aliens through the amnesty program established under the nation's new immigration law, which takes effect tomorrow.

title: MANY QUESTIONS TO ANSWER, MANY TRAILS TO FOLLOW OVER WEEKS OF SESSIONS
description: After months of preparation, what promises to be the main political drama of the spring and summer will open Tuesday morning. For the next three months or more, four days a week, Congress will be holding broadcast public hearings into the Reagan Administration's dealings with Iran and the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: CHICAGO CARDINAL SANCTIONS DISSENT
description: Choosing careful but conciliatory words, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago said last week that couples who have been unable to have children ''must make their own decisions'' after prayer and reflection on the new Vatican doctrine opposing artificial fertilization.

title: AFTER A DECADE, POITIER RETURNS AS AN ACTOR TO A CHANGING HOLLYWOOD
description: Sidney Poitier was, for a long time, the only black man in a rarefied white world: he was Hollywood's one black movie star. Now, at the age of 60, after a self-imposed 10-year absence from the screen, he is once again acting in a movie. It is a measure of how things have changed that the role he is playing in ''Little Nikita'' was written for a white man.

title: THE IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS: LIKELY MEMBERS OF THE CAST
description: A parade of witnesses will go to Capitol Hill beginning tomorrow and continuing into the summer to testify in public hearings on the Iran-contra affair. The Senate and House investigating committees have not announced a witness list, except to say that Richard V. Secord will be the opening witness, to be followed by Robert C. McFarlane. Here is a list of some of the people likely to testify. The Congressional committees have given some potential witnesses limited immunity, or immunity from prosecution based on their testimony. Elliott Abrams Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs.

title: CENTER FOR AIDS CARE IS OPENING IN ALBANY
description: The State Health Department has approved the Albany Medical Center's plan to open the state's first AIDS center outside the New York City area, officials said.

title: CROWN AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $220,692 and $204,910 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Son-in-Law Is Held in Florida In Nipons' Slaying in January
description: The fashion executive Edward Nipon was killed to keep him from testifying against his son-in-law about a New York loan-sharking scheme, according to police and court documents.

title: Time Bomb in the Debt Ceiling
description: There is a time bomb in the national debt ceiling, set to go off at midnight May 15. If a new and higher ceiling has not been set, or the current ceiling extended, Government borrowing must stop and the United States will slide quickly into default.

title: Tunisia Arrests Seen as Aimed At Islamic Fundamentalists
description: Businessmen accused of giving money to Islamic fundamentalists loyal to Iran have been arrested in a continuing crackdown against suspected extremists, Government sources said.

title: Steven Belasco Wed To Frances Schwartz
description: At the Temple Israel Center in White Plains yesterday Frances Schwartz, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herman Schwartz of Brooklyn, and Steven R. Belasco, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Belasco of Englishtown, N.J., were married by Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky.

title: INSIDE
description: Push Is On to Help Aliens Officials and private groups are hurrying to help illegal aliens comply with the Federal immigration law taking effect tomorrow. Page B1. Foster-Care Rise Proposed Mayor Koch proposed a 25 percent increase in spending for children in New York City's troubled foster-care system. Page B1. Too Many Tomatoes California growers redesigned the tomato to increase processing efficiency, but they still suffer from overproduction and imports. Page A16.

title: U.S. Mint Assignment For Saatchi's Ted Bates
description: The British-owned Ted Bates Worldwide has won the competition to handle the promotion for the United States Mint's Bicentennial Constitution Coin Program. The assignment is scheduled for 20 months and the budget is $27 million.

title: AMERICAN WESTERN SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VAN STUDY SET BY FORD AND NISSAN
description: The Nissan Motor Company and the Ford Motor Company have agreed to study a joint venture to develop and produce in North America a version of the popular mini-van.

title: Lebanon Bomb Kills One
description: Islamic guerrillas said they exploded a roadside bomb in southern Lebanon today, killing a member of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army. The South Lebanon Army's radio station said the bomb killed the militiaman and wounded three others near Kafr Falous, six miles east of Sidon.

title: Harsh Election Campaign Is Predicted in Italy
description: When representatives of Italy's 11 political parties gathered one afternoon last week for a televised question-and-answer session, the discussion repeatedly degenerated into shouting matches punctuated with table-pounding.

title: Probe Albany's Padded Commissions
description: Prosecutors are looking into a dark corner of New York government: legislative commissions believed to be hidden preserves of no-show and seldom-show jobs. Governor Cuomo boldly questioned the value of several commissions before he signed off on the state budget last week. But he stopped short of singling them out for a veto, apparently to avoid further inflaming his battle over ethics with the Legislature. Taxpayers still need to be reassured they are getting their money's worth.

title: SCIMED LIFE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $36,000 and $87,000 for the latest quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Dirt Under the U.S. Rug
description: The trial of Klaus Barbie, known as the ''butcher of Lyon'' for his wartime Gestapo activities, finally starts next week. It will be something of an ordeal for France, which never really faced up to the extent of collaboration in Nazi atrocities during the German occupation. It should be for the U.S. as well. Jacques Verges, the enigmatic lawyer who is defending Mr. Barbie, says that ''France lives on an official truth that is still not real, it is a lie.'' He plans to make the most of Mr. Barbie's incriminating knowledge about wartime France in his arguments.

title: 3 SUE AN ARGENTINE GENERAL HELD IN U.S.
description: Three people who say they were among the thousands of Argentines abducted and tortured under military rule have filed civil lawsuits against a former general who is awaiting extradition proceedings.

title: IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS: WHAT TO LOOK FOR
description: The hearings open tomorrow at 10 A.M. Witnesses will be heard four days a week, probably until August. A page of explanatory material with diagrams and photographs tells whom to watch and what to listen for. Who will ask the questions: The legislators and their aides, with a chart of the seating plan.

title: WORLD COMPETITION IS FULL OF SURPRISES
description: The World Cup of race walking ended yesterday with two world bests, two team titles for the Soviet Union, a happy Mexican celebrating his 20th birthday and an unhappy Chinese woman whose apparent victory was nullified when she was disqualified.

title: Article 685087 -- No Title
description: The Treasury's May refunding, in which $29 billion of new notes and bonds will be auctioned, is the dominant financing in the credit markets this week. After paying for about $12.5 billion of maturing issues, the financing will raise $16.5 billion in cash to finance the Federal budget deficit.

title: Warming to Task
description: Having never been on skis until last Jan. 24, Fred Winkel was fairly ambitious. Less than two months later, he and a Long Island neighbor, Ray Hagan, who himself hadn't skied in 30 years, headed for Sweden to join 10,000 other competitors in a 60-mile cross-country race called the Vasaloppet, which marks the first leg of that nation's four-season sports extravaganza. The Vasaloppet is followed by a 200-mile bicycle race in the spring, a 3-mile river swim in the summer, and an 18.6-mile run in the fall, and anyone who finishes all four events in a row within established times receives acclaim as a ''classic athlete'' of Sweden.

title: Ms. White Weds John Edmondson
description: Susan McDonald White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Boyette White of Charlotte, N.C., and John Huber Edmondson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Joseph Edmondson of New York, were married yesterday at the Chapel of Our Lady in Cold Spring, N.Y. The Rev. Leonard A. Rust, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Robert Springer, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

Mattiaccio, a partner in the law firm Pavia & Harcourt. Judge Daniel M. Friedman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal District officiated in his chambers in Washington.

title: FILM: BURT REYNOLDS IN 'MALONE'
description: WHAT is it about a Burt Reynolds movie these days that gives you the feeling of having seen it before, once or a dozen times? Maybe it's the role into which Mr. Reynolds seems to have settled - a master of mayhem in midlife crisis. The big guy has grown weary of killing, but no matter where he goes, there are baddies who require it.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER PERFORMS BALANCHINE
description: NEW talent with respect to dancers and choreographers has come to the fore at American Ballet Theater this season. On Saturday night, the ever-impressive Julio Bocca made a role debut at the Metropolitan Opera House in George Balanchine's ''Donizetti Variations,'' and on Friday, the company presented the local premiere of Clark Tippet's ballet, ''Enough Said.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MAY 4, 1987
description: COMPANIES Merrill Lynch announced a high-level shake-up in the management of its securities trading activities. In the wake of a $250 million loss last month in mortgage securities trading, the firm also asked for an independent review of its trading operations. [ Page D1. ] Ford and Nissan have agreed to study a joint venture that could produce a mini-van by the early 1990's. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY The push for strong trade legislation has been tempered in Congress by legislators' fear of being labeled protectionist. Democratic leaders say that the tough retaliatory amendment sponsored by Representative Gephardt is sure to be modified before a trade bill gets through Congress this year. [ D1. ] Commodity prices have been rising steadily this year, not because of shortages of food or raw materials, but because of the market's belief that inflation is once again on the rise. [ D1. ] The economy continued to expand in April, with industrial companies reporting increases in employment and production, according to the nation's purchasing managers. [ D12. ] Commercial bank earnings were mediocre in the first quarter and continue to be threatened by a plunging dollar, rising interest rates and Brazil's suspension of interest payments. [ D5. ] INTERNATIONAL Brazil's Finance Minister has announced an austerity program as he continues to distance himself from the policies - and the popularity - of his predecessor. [ D10. ] India's Reliance Industries is enmeshed in a scandal that has affected everyone from the Prime Minister to its stockholders. The Indian Government has accused it of smuggling in textile manufacturing equipment. [ D10. ] The aggressive Chinese bank Citic has aroused tensions and rivalries with more staid institutions, while it has won praise from U.S. executives as the best-run company China has ever had. [ D1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A. H. Robins has enraged some attorneys for its creditors with its proposal on Dalkon Shield claims. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Retail jewelry companies have acquired a new luster as studies show sales growing into the 1990's. Market Place. [ D8. ] This week's Treasury borrowing faces pessimism, with bond prices down 10 percent in the last month. Credit Markets. [ D1. ]

description: Hell hath no fury like a frequent flier unwarned. Airlines' cutbacks on popular ''frequent flier'' prizes, like trips to Hawaii, anger business travelers who had come to count on them.

description: BARBARA KOLB'S ''Yet That Things Go Round,'' which received its premiere Saturday evening in a performance by the New York Chamber Symphony at the 92d Street Y, is a taut, edgy piece of music, smartly conceived. Written in three nearly continuous movements, the 15-minute work builds to an early and stirring climax and then explores in moody fashion some of the jagged melodies laid down in the opening section.

FOR 'AIDA,' A PREMIERE IN THEBES
description: ''Aida,'' Giuseppe Verdi's opera about ancient Egypt, which had its premiere in Cairo in 1871, played in one of its original settings, ancient Thebes, for the first time Saturday night. An international gathering of 5,000, including Queen Sofia of Spain and Princess Caroline of Monaco, paid up to $750 each to attend the gala first night in the 3,000-year-old temple of Amenhotep III in this small town 350 miles south of Cairo.

title: FILM: SUSANNA HOFFS STARS IN 'ALLNIGHTER' BY HER MOTHER
description: WATCH enough exploitation films about sun-loving, fun-loving teens and you become accustomed to a certain level of benign idiocy. But even by that standard, ''The Allnighter'' is outstandingly dim. It concerns graduation eve at a California college, though none of the students seems clever enough to graduate from driving school. The principals are three bubble-headed women who room together, and the film could be accused of sexism if their male counterparts were not equally dumb.

description: Commodity prices have been steadily rising this year, even though there are no shortages of food or industrial raw materials.

description: Salomon Brothers Inc. has named Michael J. Zimmerman, a 36-year-old mergers and acquisitions expert, to head the firm's merchant banking activities.

title: Pittsburgh's Ketchum Buys Hicks & Greist
description: As rumored, the Pittsburgh-based Ketchum Communications has acquired Hicks & Greist of New York for a combination of cash and stock.

title: A CHILD'S CHOICE OF FRIENDS
description: LAST summer Peggy Daley was upset when her 15-year-old son Patrick brought home a new friend, a punk rocker, for dinner.

title: Bridge: A Queens Couple Produces A Sampler of Favored Deals
description: One way to produce an entertaining bridge book is to ask a group of stars to provide a favored deal, preferably with humor, psychology and technique. That the recipe works has been proved by Matthew and Pamela Granovetter with ''Tops and Bottoms,'' obtainable by sending $11.95 to them at 80-85 Dumfries Place, Jamaica, N.Y. 11432.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When Roger Clemens set the major league record for strikeouts in a game last season against the Seattle Mariners, were his current teammates, Spike Owen and Dave Henderson, among the 20 batters he struck out? Certainly, and they accounted for 25 percent of Clemens's strikeout total on April 29, 1986. Henderson, the center fielder, went down all three times he batted - in the third, sixth and eighth innings - and Owen, the shortstop and leadoff batter, struck out in the first and last innings. Owen's strikeout leading off the ninth inning gave Clemens 19, tying the major league mark. But the fly to center Owen hit his previous time up in the sixth inning ended a string of eight straight batters struck out by Clemens, and prevented Clemens from breaking an American League mark. In a six-player deal nearly four months after the 3-1 Boston victory, Henderson and Owen were sent to the Red Sox, where Henderson struck out 15 more times and Owen 9 more while playing the last six weeks of the season on Clemens's side. QUESTION: How successful was Don Mattingly, runner-up in the American League most valuable player voting, when he batted last year against Roger Clemens, winner of the award? Just a bit less successful than he was against the other pitchers in the league. The Yankee first baseman batted .352 in 1986 and hit .333 against Clemens in their 12 confrontations, getting four of his league-leading total of 238 hits against the Boston right-hander. Clemens got one of his league-leading total of 238 strikeouts against Mattingly. All the hits were singles and none drove in any runs. QUESTION: Why is Roy Campanella, who never hit more than 41 homers in a season, listed in the record books as the catcher with the most home runs in a season? Didn't Johnny Bench hit 45 one year? Bench's home run total for Cincinnati in 1970 does indeed exceed the amount hit by Campanella with the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1953, but not all the homers by Bench came when his position was catcher during that season, nor did all of Campanella's. There were 38 homers in Bench's 140 games behind the plate in 1970, 6 in his 23 appearances as an outfielder and 1 in the 12 games he performed at first base (some of the positions overlapped in games). Campanella's total is not pure because he hit 40 homers in his 140 games as catcher in 1953 and hit another homer as a pinch-hitter.

title: Red Wings Cap A Rare Comeback
description: Glen Hanlon turned in his second shutout in three games tonight as the Detroit Red Wings, completing a three-game comeback, beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3-0, to win the Norris Division final in seven games.

description: Rikers Island is a mean, violent place. And of its six jails, C-76 has long been the meanest and most violent.

Hortense Calisher, the president of PEN, and A. E. Hotchner, the biographer, are to take part.

title: Jennifer L. Stevenson Marries S. M. Kessler

description: Over the next two years, the Iowa Libel Research Project will try to settle about 30 libel cases without costly litigation or damage awards.

title: MUSIC: LAWTELL PLAYBOYS
description: FRIDAY'S concert by the Lawtell Playboys, a Creole band from Louisiana, had something every New York zydeco show ought to have: a dance floor. With some pews out of the way at the Washington Square Church, listeners turned into waltzers and two-steppers, and the band revved up the tunes to keep them moving. While they watched the dancers, the band members played almost as if they were at a bayou dance hall.
