FIDELTY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rosemary C. Mancuso Wed to Peter Parthenis
description: Rosemary Christine Mancuso and Peter Parthenis were married yesterday at SS. Catherine and George Greek Orthodox Church in Astoria, Queens, by the Rev. Anthimos Panagiotopoulos, Bishop-elect of Troas, Turkey.

title: Czyz Retains Title With a Knockout
description: Bobby Czyz, the International Boxing Federation light-heavyweight champion, retained his title today when he stopped Jim MacDonald in 37 seconds of the sixth round of a scheduled 15-round fight at the Convention Center.

title: FOR TRASH BARGE CREW, EMPTY DAYS AND FLIES
description: The quarters are relatively spacious, the television a color RCA. But the weeks at sea with outcast garbage from Long Island have clearly taken a toll on the crew of this 96-foot tugboat.

title: BOARD OF EDUCATION TO TRANSFER 200 FROM HEADQUARTERS TO SCHOOLS
description: In a drive by the New York City Board of Education to reduce its central bureaucracy, more than 200 employees will be transferred from the board's Brooklyn headquarters and into schools by July 1, according to the board president, Robert F. Wagner Jr. Many of these employees will use their professional skills as assistant principals, teachers, guidance counselors and speech therapists. Others will continue as administrators but under the direction of a school principal rather than as remote officials in the board's main offices at 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn, Mr. Wagner said.

title: A Tribute Scheduled For Luther Henderson
description: Luther Henderson, the arranger and conductor of more than 50 Broadway musicals, is to be honored for his contributions to music by Broadcast Music Inc., a music licensing organization, Thursday at 4:30 P.M. in the Tower Suite of the Time & Life Building, 1271 Avenue of the Americas, at 50th Street.

title: THERMO INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Theodore Charles Savaglio Weds Amy Jo Rosenblum
description: Amy Jo Rosenblum and Theodore Charles Savaglio were married yesterday at the Water Club in Manhattan by Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. John Riordan, a Roman Catholic priest. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rosenblum of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Charles Savaglio of Simi Valley, Calif.

title: Savings Bond Rate Cut
description: The Treasury Department said Friday that savings bonds sold in the next six months would pay interest of 5.84 percent, down from the 6.06 percent rate on bonds sold in the last six months. The rates are payable on bonds held for five years or longer.

title: Two Sonic Players Jailed in Houston
description: Two Seattle SuperSonics players were arrested and jailed early today after a scuffle at a night club, the police said.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S SPEECH TO NEWSPAPER PUBLISHERS
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech yesterday to the American Newspaper Publishers Association, as recorded by The Associated Press: ...

title: CHEMICAL FABRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I just feel blessed in a special way, so there's nothing to be sad about. For me this will be a very, very long off season, the longest one I've ever had.'' - Julius Erving, after his last game. [ C3:4. ]

title: VOTRAX INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Player's Death Still a Mystery
description: A medical examiner said today that he had been unable to determine the cause of death of Hernell (Jeep) Jackson, a Texas-El Paso basketball star, and was awaiting the results of further tests.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING Allison Takes Talladega: Davey Allison raced away to a dominating victory yesterday at the Winston 500 in Talladega, Ala., earning his first Nascar stock car victory in an event stalled for more than two and a half hours after Bobby Allison, his father, walked away from a frightening crash. Allison, 26 years old, took control after the restart of the 500-mile race. His Ford Thunderbird crossed the finish line 65-hundredths of a second ahead of Terry Labonte. But the race wasn't as close as the margin appeared. Allison, who led for 101 of 178 laps, earned $71,250. (AP) Mansell Moves Into Lead: Nigel Mansell drove his Williams-Honda to an unchallenged victory in the San Marino Grand Prix and took the lead in the world Formula-one championship with 10 points. His victory gave the Briton a 1-point edge over Alain Prost of France, who was stopped by engine problems in the first stages of the race. Mansell defeated Ayrton Senna, driving a Lotus-Honda, by 27.5 seconds. (AP) Ludwig First at Monterey: Klaus Ludwig took the lead with 11 laps to go yesterday and won the 300-kilometer Camel Grand Prix at Laguna Seca Raceway in Monterey, Calif. Driving a Porsche 962, Ludwig averaged 108.923 m.p.h. In second was Sarel van der Merwe in a Chevrolet Corvette GTP. Chip Robinson was third in a Porsche. (AP) TENNIS All-Australian Final: Rod Laver and his partner, Ken Rosewall, will play in an all-Australian final tonight for the Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions Grand Masters at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. They defeated another Australian, Neale Fraser, and his partner, Andres Gimeno of Spain, in the semifinals yesterday, 6-4, 6-3. They will face two countrymen, Mal Anderson and Roy Emerson, who defeated Owen Davidson of Australia and Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 6-4, 6-3. Evert Wins in Houston: Top-seeded Chris Evert battled past Kate Gompert, 6-3, 6-2, to win the $150,000 Eckerd Open women's tournament in Largo, Fla. It was Evert's second consecutive tournament championship. The 24-year-old Gompert was competing in her first championship match on the women's tour. She is ranked 25th in the world. (AP) Lendl Takes German Open: Ivan Lendl, the world's No. 1 player, captured his first tournament of the year with a 6-1, 6-3, 6-3 victory over Miloslav Mecir. (AP) ROAD RACING Bishop Takes L.I. Marathon: Mark Bishop of Dallas won the Long Island Marathon in 2 hours 24 minutes 46 seconds yesterday. Andy Whitney of Stony Brook, L.I., finished second in 2:26:02 and Peter Boni of Coram, L.I., was third in 2:31:16. The women's winner was Christine Gibbons of Elmwood Park, N.J., in 2:55:03. Donna Chacalos of Hanover, N.H., was the runner-up in 2:59:50. Runaway Winners in Pittsburgh: Rodolfo Gomez, a 36-year-old from Mexico, ignored a steady rain to sprint away from two other runners at the 24-mile mark and win the third annual Pittsburgh Marathon in 2:13:07. The women's winner was Silva Ruegger of Canada, in 2:31:53. (AP) HOCKEY Title Goes to Sweden: Sweden won the world championship yesterday in Vienna on goal difference by beating Canada, 9-0, while the defending champion Soviet Union edged Czechoslovakia, 2-1, in the second game. Both Sweden and the Soviet Union finished the medal round tied for first place with 4 points each on one victory and two ties. But Sweden scored 14 goals and allowed 5 in the three games, while the Soviet Union scored 4 and and gave up 3. (AP) HORSE RACING Devil's Bride Takes Comely: Devil's Bride, a gray filly by Caro from the Crimson Satan mare, Satan's Pride, carried her formidable speed in front from wire to wire for a four-length victory in Aqueduct's $87,150 Comely Stakes for 3-year-old fillies yesterday. Oh So Precious was runner-up, two lengths ahead of Valid Line. For Devil's Bride, shipped in from California for this engagement, the victory was the third in four starts this year. All have been for added money. Carrying 116 pounds, she sped seven furlongs on the fast track in 1:23 3/5 under the ride of Rafael Meza to earn $52,290 for Oak Cliff Stable. TRACK AND FIELD Double Winners: Janu Williams and Clive Wright won two events each yesterday at the conclusion of the New York Relays, a three-day program on Randalls Island. Williams, a graduate of South Shore High School in Brooklyn, was first in the women's 200 meters (25:42 seconds) and 400 (55:26) while Wright, a Jamaican, was the winner of the men's 100 and 200 dashes in 10.79 seconds and 21 seconds.

title: METHODIST CHURCH IN DALLAS PRAYS FOR STRENGTH IN ITS MINISTER'S CRISIS
description: Members of a large Methodist church here sang and prayed today both for the recovery of their minister and his wife and for strength to face the details of the events as they unfold.

title: RAINES DOES IT AGAIN
description: This is probably the way it is when a star goes to the minors to play himself back into shape. Tim Raines is the star, and the Expos are probably the closest thing to a Class AAA team in the majors.

title: LISTLESS YANKEES LOSE, 4-3
description: The frustration in Lou Piniella's voice rose quickly as he leaned back and replayed the game in his mind. He could not dismiss the failure to hit in critical situations, the inability to convert runners into runs. The day was done, and the Yankees had lost another game. Then the frustration turned into a mini-tirade.

description: When a former Methodist minister decided to run for county superintendent, court papers charge, he tried to add special ingredients to the campaign.

title: Robert DiClemente Weds Judy Ann Lewis in Jersey
description: The marriage of Judy Ann Lewis to Robert V. DiClemente took place yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Mayor Joseph Parisi of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., performed the ceremony.

description: Despite the noise from renovators converting a hotel into its headquarters, the Bank of Communications is open for business and offering services that promise to shake up banking in China.

description: The share earnings are in units and the company went public in October 1986.

title: OFFSHORE PLANS RAISING AN ONSHORE STORM
description: Among the brick carcasses and rusty relics of an Army post off the coast of this city, Gordon Marshall tramps through the underbrush and dreams of a new world.

title: Yevtushenko Reading
description: The Russian poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko is to read from his new book of poetry, ''Almost at the End,'' at 8 P.M. next Monday at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The reading is the second of three this month sponsored by the Poetry Center. The last, on May 18, is to feature May Swenson and Henri Cole. Tickets to the Yevtushenko reading are $10. Information: 427-4410.

title: Advertising Federation To Protest Florida Tax
description: The board of directors of the American Advertising Federation met Thursday night in New York to decide whether to follow the actions of other advertising organizations that have canceled planned gatherings in Florida in protest of the recently approved state sales tax on adertising. They decided to go ahead with the meeting.

title: Lorna Stokes, a Photographer, Is Wed
description: Lorna Douglass Johnson Stokes, a daughter of Mrs. Bertram R. Firestone of Waterford, Va., and Kilcullen, County Kildare, Ireland, and Richard G. Stokes of Leesburg, Va., was married yesterday to Daniel Mark Wyner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin L. Wyner of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The Rev. Roger Paine, a Congregational minister who is executive director of the Interface Foundation, an educational center in Watertown, Mass., performed the nonsectarian ceremony at the Mountain Top Inn in Chittenden, Vt.

title: A SENATOR ASSERTS THAT REAGAN KNEW OF ARMING CONTRAS
description: Daniel K. Inouye, chairman of the Senate committee investigating the Iran-contra affair, said today that he believed President Reagan knew money was being raised to buy weapons for the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: GIANTS' PROSPECT KNOWS THE SCORE
description: Dave Walter knows his chances to make the Giants are slim.

title: USX: NEW OPTIMISM ON STEEL
description: The USX Corporation's largest steel plant, in Gary, Ind., houses the company's most modern piece of steelmaking equipment: a year-old continuous caster that has resulted in plummeting energy costs and soaring productivity.

title: Merger at Union Pacific
description: The Union Pacific Corporation will combine two subsidiaries, Champlin Petroleum and the Rocky Mountain Energy Company, into a single operating concern called the Union Pacific Resources Company, Union Pacific announced on Thursday. It said the change would permit further cost and productivity improvements in the natural resource businesses.

description: Su Yufeng dangled his left arm from a window of the baby-blue bus without wheels planted on a scruffy patch of dirt at the Baiwanzhuan free market. ''Watches Repaired,'' a gaudy sign on the bus announced.

description: Mayor Harold Washington begins his second term Monday as the most powerful political leader here since the longtime Mayor Richard J. Daley.

title: IN CUBA, THE CALL GOES OUT FOR LESS SMOKE, MORE ACTION
description: A THREE-RUN home run had just increased the home team's lead to 5-0, and the fans were going wild. Adding to the celebration was a makeshift salsa band of indeterminate number high above the third-base dugout that grew whenever someone appeared with an instrument, the only requirement for joining. In any case, after Antonio Arduy of Cuidad Habana returned from his trip around the bases to a wave of high fives from his teammates, the noise in Estadio Latinoamericano was deafening.

title: 200,000 AT RALLY FOR SOVIET JEWRY
description: More than 200,000 people demonstrated in Manhattan yesterday, waving banners, stars of David and pictures of dissidents to push for the release of Jews barred from leaving the Soviet Union.

description: New methods of detecting and matching fingerprints have substantially increased the effectiveness of law enforcement, an agency of the Justice Department said in a report today.

description: The nation's newspaper publishers get down to the business of their 100th anniversary convention today, the beginning of three days of addresses, panel discussions and assessments of their industry's future.

description: In a decisive shift away from institutional care, nearly twice as many elderly patients in New York City are receiving publicly financed health care at home as in nursing homes, according to state and Federal statistics and a hospital study.

Under terms of the new accord, Consumers Power will not be required to make principal payments until 1990.

Message From a Met
description: From his locker in the Mets' clubhouse, Mookie Wilson has watched, in his usual quiet, contemplative way, the tempest surrounding Dwight Gooden. He has considered the question of whether ballplayers are responsible to the public for their actions. It is an old question, one that baseball and most athletes constantly confront. It's one that Wilson said he has to address when he delivers talks in schools.

title: FIGHT FOR 2 PARKS WON BY TUDOR CITY 'KINGPIN'
description: John F. McKean had barely stepped out his door yesterday afternoon when he was surrounded by a group of elderly women leaning on canes, bundled in woolen coats and chirping congratulations.

description: For the third time in as many years, Patrick Murphy traveled from his home in Kildare, Ireland, to this city near the Idaho border to run in a race named after the literary creation of a fellow Irishman, James Joyce.

description: The economy continued to expand in April, with industrial companies reporting advances in employment and production, the National Association of Purchasing Managers said in its monthly report to be released today.

description: Argentina's recent military crisis set off a conflict between the Government of President Raul Alfonsin and the privately owned press over coverage and the way the Government used television to rally support.

description: To the Editor:

title: East African Meeting Set
description: Ministers from Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania will meet in Arusha, a town in north Tanzania, on Wednesday to discuss future areas of cooperation among the three East African states, a foreign ministry spokesman said today. The three countries, former members of the dissolved East African community, are sending high-ranking delegations. No details of the agenda were given. Before the East African community broke up in 1978 over political differences, the three former British colonial possessions shared transport, communications and other public services.

title: Must We Torpedo Our Banks?
description: Negotiations between the world's major banks and less developed countries, mostly in Latin America, have become a more or less constant feature of our economic landscape. Countries like Brazil, which seemed in good shape a year or two ago, may now be struggling to put their house in order; equally, countries like Mexico, struggling a year or two ago, now seem in much better shape.

title: U.S. Cautioned On Trade Bars
description: West German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher urged the United States today not to erect trade barriers.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Near-Nuclear Club
description: For decades, the effort to contain the spread of nuclear weapons has depended on several assumptions. There were five nuclear-weapons nations, the rest were nonnuclear-weapons nations, and the best way to maintain that status was to control nuclear technologies and materials. But in the meantime, other countries have become nuclear powers in all but name, and a viable nonproliferation policy requires acknowledging reality and responding to it.

title: FILM: 'CAMPUS MAN'
description: THE look and sound of ''Campus Man,'' which has found its way into the United Artists Twin and other theaters, mark it as a production done on the cheap, which is appropriate to this little anecdote about a business major at Arizona State who produces a jock calendar featuring his best friend, a champion diver, and so jeopardizes the friend's amateur standing. Also splashing around here are a tough moneylender and, yes, a couple of pretty girls. As the hustling entrepreneur, John Dye is indistinguishable from the other cutely coiffed young fellows who find their way into such movies. Steve Lyon, as the athlete, has plenty of opportunity to show off his biceps and pecs. Except for a few diving scenes, Ron Casden's direction offers no distractions. It took three people to patch together the made-for-music-video screenplay.

title: WHEN TO SCRAMBLE
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, has recommended that long distance telephone companies ''scramble,'' or put into code, telephone calls that now are commonly transmitted via satellite. The Soviet Union can intercept the calls and sift through them for potentially valuable intelligence information, Mr. Moynihan said.

title: Assistant District Attorneys Should Get Raises

title: Market Place; Better Outlook For Jewelers
description: THE once-dull retail jewelry industry has acquired a new luster through a wave of consolidations, a rise in disposable consumer income, more competitive pricing and the emergence of several new publicly held companies.

title: RECITAL: MUSIC OF NORTH INDIA
description: SHAHEED Pervez and Vijay Ghate brought what was billed as ''Music of North India'' to the Washington Square Church on Saturday night. Mr. Pervez, a young virtuoso of the sitar, plays in the ''gayaki'' style, described in the program as more vocal than the quieter, more melodic instrumental music of other Indian traditions. Judging by Saturday's event, gayaki is an art fueled by dramatic contrasts and vivid surges of excitement. These were underlined on this occasion by the use of amplification.

description: Paul Azinger rammed home a 30-foot eagle putt on the final hole today for the richest prize so far in PGA Tour history, the $225,000 winner's share of the $1.25 million Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational.

description: Why did the 113th Kentucky Derby, which drew what had looked like the most talented field in this decade, turn out to be an astonishingly slow race despite a very fast track at Churchill Downs?

description: Auto workers here and in Hagerstown, Md., overwhelmingly approved a five-and-a-half-year contract with Mack Trucks Inc. that trades wage and benefit cuts for job security.

description: The State Department's top lawyer has completed a study of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972 that keeps the Reagan Administration on a potential collision course with Senate supporters of a stricter interpretation of the agreement, according to Administration officials.

title: Saturday in the Glassed-In Park
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, I went with several fellow photographers to shoot pictures of various examples of indoor atriums that major corporations have built in their lobbies. We went to the gardens in the I.B.M. building, the Citicorp Center and the Park Avenue Plaza. For the urban stroller, they offer a delightful bit of country greenery. Many have kiosks for coffee and cake, which can be enjoyed at tables set among the bamboo or ficus trees. An air of quiet civility permeates the scene.

title: BEAR AUTOMOTIVE SERVICE EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $67,000 for the latest quarter and $316,000 for the year-earlier; and the year-ago quarter also included a loss from an accounting change of $67,000.

title: HOW EFFECTIVE IS BREAST SELF-EXAMINATION?
description: Every month, she conscientiously examines her breasts, searching for minuscule lumps and scrutinizing herself in the mirror to see if there are any changes. Could she someday save her own life by finding a tumor in its earliest, most treatable, stage?

title: ROSE MANAGES HEADFIRST, TOO
description: THE SCENE in 1986 was a dark bus splashing through soggy streets in fetid Houston. The Reds had been making a kind of semi-run toward the first-place Astros and earlier this day in Cincinnati had thrown their ace, Bill Gullickson, against the Chicago Cubs and a novice pitcher named Greg Maddux.

title: INDIAN COMPANY'S TACTICS CHALLENGED
description: In the early 1980's, Reliance Industries was one of the fastest-growing industrial concerns in India, hailed as ''the finest investment proposition ever seen by the Indian investor'' in one magazine report.

title: Outdoors: Time to Fish for Shad
description: AMONG the natural rituals that delight angler and gourmet alike are the annual spring spawning runs of the American shad, which even now are ascending the Connecticut, Hudson and Delaware rivers.

title: U.S. SUSPICIOUS OF CANADA'S PLAN FOR NUCLEAR SUBS
description: Defense Department officials suggested today that a Canadian plan to acquire nuclear-powered submarines to patrol Arctic waters was aimed more at closing important sea passages to the United States and the Soviet Union than at increasing allied naval power in the Arctic.

title: DANCE: WINDEMERE
description: THE Windemere Ballet Theater, a company of young dancers from Jackson Heights, Queens, celebrated its 20th anniversary with a performance Friday night at Symphony Space that featured works choreographed by its director, Sally Hammond. Unfortunately, the occasion was not as jubilant as it ought to have been.

title: REGAN CRITICIZES TRANSIT OVERTIME
description: The New York State Comptroller has asserted that weak controls on overtime worked by employees of the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority in the year before they retire is costing taxpayers millions of dollars in extra pension benefits.

title: OPTICAL SPECIALTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
A PATIENT WHO CHOSE TO STAY HOME
description: When Lecynth Sinckler was discharged from St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx two years ago, she was 81 years old and suffered from a number of illnesses and infirmities that kept her in a wheelchair. She was virtually alone in the world, had no one to help her and she seemed destined to spend the rest of her life in a nursing home.

title: JOHN L. RIEGEL
description: John L. Riegel, retired chairman of the Riegel Paper Corporation and the Riegel Textile Corporation, died of pneumonia Friday at White Plains Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: WILL 'STAR WARS' WORK, OR BREAK US?
description: WHETHER it will work is one thing; how it will effect the economy is another. '' 'Star Wars': The Bottom Line'' is concerned mostly with the economy. As Hodding Carter asks as the program opens, will the Strategic Defense Initiative usher in ''a new age of technology for America or will it make us poor?'' That's not a bad question. But the program, on Channel 13 at 10:30 tonight, never really answers it.

title: ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $4.7 million realized during the first quarter on sale of 250,000 shares of Exxon Corp. common stock. The company said the latest quarter includes an after-tax non-cash charge for a loss on the disposition of drilling vessels of $5.1 million. The company is in the process of disposing of its two tender-support rigs, Williamsburg and Bull Run.

title: MEDIOCRE QUARTER FOR BANKS
description: As the year began, the nation's leading commercial bankers hoped to put the problems of 1986 behind them. Instead, loan losses continued to mount, profits on good loans narrowed further, and overhead costs rose at rates well above the level of revenue growth or the pace of inflation.

title: REAGAN, IN SPEECH ON ELLIS ISLAND, MAKES A NEW PLEA FOR CONTRA AID
description: President Reagan said yesterday that the goal of his policy in Nicaragua was to establish democracy there and that continued United States support for the anti-Sandinista rebels was essential to achieve that goal.

title: BOND VOLATILITY IS COOLING DEMAND
description: Pessimism is widespread as the credit markets face this week's Treasury borrowing program with a long list of reasons why foreign and domestic investors will require higher interest rates before adding to their holdings of notes and bonds.

title: FASTER TURNS CANDIDATE
description: Charles Hyder, a scientist who has been fasting for nuclear disarmament in Lafayette Park, across the street from the White House, for more than seven months, has ended his hunger strike to run for the presidency.

title: ARCHITECTS' WATCHES

The Italian jewelry manufacturer Cleto Munari is about to release four watches, each designed by a leading architect: Michael Graves, Ettore Sottsass, Hans Hollein and Arata Isozaki. Ranging from $5,000 to $8,000, they will be available in stores within two months, according to Lorry Parks of Grace Designs in Dallas, Mr. Munari's United States representative.

title: THEATER: PIELMEIER'S 'SLEIGHT OF HAND,' A THRILLER
description: ACT II of ''Sleight of Hand,'' the new John Pielmeier play at the Cort, is set in ''an empty Broadway theater.'' No one can accuse Act I of failing to do its part to make that description come literally true. Mr. Pielmeier's would-be thriller opens with 50 minutes of rambling, numbing exposition -much of it accompanied, if not enlivened, by the sort of canned magic tricks so memorably mocked by the comic illusionists Penn and Teller. Then comes what the Playbill conservatively describes as a ''20-minute intermission,'' followed by a denouement that runs slightly longer than the intermission but proves not nearly so action packed.

title: KNICKS GIVING BROWN ANOTHER LOOK

But as the team continued to lose, and even following the sudden dismissal of Scotty Stirling and Bob Hill two weeks ago, everyone involved said there were no plans to hire basketball's nomadic coach.

title: TALKING TO THE BABY: SOME EXPERT ADVICE

title: Surgery for Byars
description: Keith Byars, the Philadelphia Eagles' leading runner last season, underwent a bone graft yesterday to repair a broken bone in his left foot. A bone from Byars's hip was grafted onto his foott in a procedure in Columbus, Ga., a spokesman for the club said. The same type of surgery was performed on Byars's right foot in January 1986. As for when Byars could play, Ed Wisneski, a spokesman for the Eagles, said, ''We're hoping early September, possibly for the last preseason game Sept. 3.'' Byars needed almost seven months to recover fully from his first foot operation. He broke the fifth metatarsal bone in his left foot Saturday afternoon making a cut on a pass-pattern drill at Veterans Stadium during the Eagles' minicamp.Byars ran for up 577 yards last season, a club record for a rookie.

title: FAMOUS FOR 15 MINUTES?
description: The 13 faces of Andy Warhol - that's what they're calling the newest success in message T-shirts. Silk-screened in black on white cotton, the shirt, designed by an Irish artist who calls himself Seamus, costs $16.95. Seamus moved to New York in February and never got to meet Warhol, so he designed the T-shirt as a tribute. The shirt is popular with young people in the East Village and SoHo and is sold through Alada NY at 2 Astor Place, a shop near Broadway that is devoted to T-shirts on the cutting edge of the news. Yesterday at Alada, Seamus said, ''I think Warhol would have liked the idea of my making money'' from his image.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why do birds molt? A.Molting is determined by a combination of physiological and environmental changes, such as breeding, light and temperature. Most birds shed their feathers once a year just after breeding, but some species molt while breeding, and still others molt after breeding and before migration. Some birds even molt while on their winter grounds. Birds that have a very bright plumage during breeding and dull feathers in the off season molt twice a year. In the molting process, old feathers are replaced by new ones that grow in the same follicle. Q.How is prestressed concrete made? A.Most concrete that is used in the construction of buildings, highways and bridges contains steel reinforcing to increase its strength. Concrete is about 10 times as strong in compression as it is in tension, so steel rods or cables are placed within to carry the tensile stresses, according to Dalton Hamilton, vice president of the Trinity Engineering Testing Corporation. The steel reinforcement has defaced edges that allow it to bond to the concrete as it dries. Tensile loads placed on the structure are then transferred through the concrete to the reinforcing bars, Mr. Hamilton said. In prestressed concrete, the steel reinforcement is stretched between abutments and concrete is poured on top and allowed to harden. This is called pretensioning because the steel is stretched before the concrete matures. The other method of prestressing concrete is post-tensioning, in which ducts are left in the concrete for steel cables. Once the concrete has cured, the cables are threaded through the ducts, stretched and attached to anchorages.

title: Ship Rams Georgia Bridge
description: A Polish freighter struck a tower of a bridge at this Atlantic Coast city Sunday, causing an estimated $3 million in damage and closing the structure for up to 21 weeks, the authorities said. Federal Judge Anthony Alaimo issued an order allowing the authorities to hold the ship, the Ziemia Bialostocka, to force its owners to post a bond big enough to pay for the damage, a state Transportation Department spokesman said. There were no reports of injury on the bridge or on the 608-foot ship. In November 1972 a ship struck the same bridge, killing 10 people in cars sent plunging into the river.

title: New York Does Nothing About Reckless Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: Freedom Day - and Year
description: By coincidence, today in Mexico is Cinco de Mayo, a holiday commemorating the 1862 victory of outnumbered Mexican forces over Napoleon III's invading armies. Today in the United States brings another kind of holiday, for millions of illegal aliens, many from Mexico. Freedom Day, it might be called, because starting today aliens who have lived here furtively since 1982 can claim legality. Today, 180 days after it was enacted, the delicate bargain called the Immigration Reform and Control Act begins to operate.

title: ZENNTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $13,000 and $137,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. ouf92c-Net loss

title: NOT AWARE OF AIDE'S LINK TO FUND-RAISER, REGAN SAYS
description: Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, said yesterday in New York that he was unaware that a former aide had been paid to arrange photo sessions with President Reagan for contributors who made donations to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: It All Came to Nothing
description: LEAD: As the dust settles from Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's trip to Washington, this latest summit meeting can be appraised for what it was - a sad demonstration of the impotence of political leadership on both sides of the Pacific.

title: Lists of Women
description: The Women's Foreign Policy Council, a New York-based group, has published a Women's Foreign Policy Directory of women who work as foreign policy specialists and women and groups working in international affairs.

Chess: Shifting Direction of Attack, Belyavsky Rolls Up Bareyev
description: In a tournament almost totally dominated by the generation of players in their twenties and thirties, grandmasters Aleksandr Belyavsky and Valery Salov tied for first place in the 54th running of the Soviet Championship, in Minsk.

title: SECORD IS LEADOFF WITNESS IN IRAN SESSION TODAY
description: With Richard V. Secord as the leadoff witness when Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair begin on Tuesday, the public can expect the first detailed inside account of both the secret arms sales to Iran and the covert operation to supply the Nicaraguan rebels, investigators say.

title: Calvin Wasn't Swiss
description: To the Editor:

title: BMW Prices Rise
description: BMW of North America Inc. said it would increase suggested retail car prices by an average of 3.8 percent, or $1,028. The increase is effective with the introduction of the 1988 5-series models this month and shipments to dealers of other models after June 1. Increases range from 1.2 percent, or $310, for the 325IS sedans, which will be priced at $27,300, to 7.7 percent, or $2,170, for the 1988 528e sedan priced at $30,500. The M3, to be introduced June 1, was set at $34,000.

title: BATUS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $150,000,000 for restructuring.

title: HAIGHT VOWS HARD WORK, LONG SEASON
description: The Jets are not willing to give up on last year's famous fizzle. Mike Haight - the Jets' forgotten No. 1 draft pick of a year ago - finally has it figured out.

title: EMERGENCY MEASURES BY COMEX
description: The board of the Commodity Exchange has taken several extraordinary measures to settle a heavy number of unresolved trades left over from last week's unusually active and volatile trading in precious metals, especially silver.

title: INTERNATIONAL HYDRON reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEGRADING THE PRESS
description: The American economy is losing its productive edge. We are piling up debts that will burden our children. Our highest officials have shown brazen contempt for law in running a terrorist war in Nicaragua.

title: TOWN IN MICHIGAN SEEKS SLOWDOWN
description: At a time when most states are scrambling to raise the speed limit on rural highways, people in this tiny Michigan town are protesting an increase of the speed limit on a state highway that cuts through Leonidas.

title: Karl Davis, 25, Dies; A Designer of Fashions
description: Karl Davis, a fashion designer, died Saturday morning at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 25 years old and lived in Manhattan. His family said the cause of death was pneumonia.

title: AMERIBANC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Weyerhaeuser Predicts Recovery
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, helped by lower costs and the weaker dollar, said it was poised to rebound from a six-year slump that depressed the forest products industry in the Northwest.

title: Questions About the President
description: ''What did the President know and when did he know it?'' The 1973 Watergate hearings were already a month old when Senator Howard Baker, now President Reagan's chief of staff, coined the expression while cross-examining Richard Nixon's prime accuser, John Dean. The question resounded not only because of its ring but also its reach. America was watching.

title: LAMBDA MERCANTILE reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

title: Explosion Kills Worker At Fireworks Concern
description: Black powder exploded in an outdoor work area at a fireworks plant today, killing an employee who was making fuses, the authorities said.

title: International Controls Gets Bid
description: The International Controls Corporation said it had received a buyout offer of $40 a share in cash from Synergy Group Inc. The bid comes as a company owned by the president of International Controls, Arthur Goldberg, and Bear, Stearns & Company is tendering for 960,000 shares of the electronics and aerospace company at $32 each, with a merger at the tender price to follow.

title: Pry-WHAT-ca?
description: The American Can Company has changed its name. ''American Can Company'' didn't fit anymore, said an explanatory ad in The New York Times last week, because the company no longer makes cans.

description: Church's Fried Chicken Inc., the nation's second-largest fast-food chicken operation, received a takeover offer yesterday of $12.25 a share, or about $469 million, from an investor group led by two former executives.

title: 3 WALLACH HOMERS WASTED BY EXPOS
description: Tim Wallach hit three home runs and had six runs batted in for Montreal tonight but it wasn't enough as the Atlanta Braves beat the Expos, 10-7.

description: b-Net income

title: Diplomatic Attire
description: Who was that middle-aged jogger pounding the pavement along Reno Road in Northwest Washington on a recent Sunday afternoon wearing white shorts with a large red Canadian maple leaf emblazoned behind? A motorist, slowing to pass, recognized the face of Thomas M. T. Niles, United States Ambassador to Canada. A call to the State Department established that Mr. Niles had come to town from Ottawa for a conference. It could not be learned whether he jogs in Canada with a U.S. symbol on his shorts.

title: Investor Reduces Rorer Holdings
description: The British investor Alan E. Clore has lowered his stake in Rorer Group Inc. to 12.3 percent, from 15.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Clore gave no reason for the sale of the Rorer shares. When Mr. Clore began to buy Rorer shares in the fall of 1985, he said the purchases were for investment purposes only.

title: Chip Merger to Join 2 Respected Chiefs
description: The merger announced last week between Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and Monolithic Memories Inc. will bring together two of the most respected chief executives in the semiconductor industry - Advanced Micro's showman, W. J. Sanders 3d, and Monolithic's Irwin Federman, a self-described ''green-eyeshade type.''

title: OZONE AGREEMENT IS HAILED AS A FIRST STEP IN COOPERATION
description: While negotiations in Geneva last week ended with only a tentative step toward ridding the atmosphere of the chemicals that are depleting the earth's ozone shield, they displayed a degree of international foresight on the environment that had been no more than an elusive goal in recent decades. The negotiations also represented a dramatic success for a United Nations environmental agency that many experts had all but written off as ineffective.

title: SHOWS BEING PRE-EMPTED FOR IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS
description: Viewers searching for ''Another World,'' ''One Life to Live'' or ''As the World Turns'' this afternoon will search in vain. Instead they will find a television drama of another sort: the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair.

title: Cystic Fibrosis Advance
description: In the current search for specific genetic defects linked to human diseases, none has been sought more avidly than the gene responsible for cystic fibrosis.

title: At Home or Abroad, the C.I.A. Is Watching You
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPEZIO AWARDS GIVEN TO FOUR IN DANCE WORLD
description: Luminaries in the dance world honored fellow luminaries yesterday, gathering at the Juilliard Theater to present the 36th annual Capezio Dance Awards to Fred Astaire, Bob Fosse, Rudolf Nureyev and Jac Venza.

title: FIRST FARWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $50,000 for the latest quarter and $40,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said the latest quarter net is after recognition of a gain of $1,250,000 from the termination of the company's pension plan in 1985.

title: COMPUTER AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $136,000 for the quarter and $204,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After a pretax gain from termination of leases of $2,342,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said the latest quarter and 9-month nets are after a pre-tax gain of $233,000 from termination of leases.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MAY 5, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY American business productivity rose at a 1.8 percent rate in the first three months of the year. The increase, which followed two quarterly declines, was accompanied by a sizable reduction in labor costs as hourly compensation rose by the smallest amount in more than 25 years. Experts noted that productivity figures were volatile, and they warned against drawing premature conclusions, as the debate intensifies about whether the U.S. can increase its productivity to meet world competition. [ Page A1. ] The Supreme Court said Rotary Clubs could not exclude women if the states in which they were based outlawed such discrimination. The unanimous ruling reinforced arguments that the Constitution does not protect sex discrimination by most all-male private clubs, especially those often used for business purposes. [ A1. ] Farmers are openly optimistic about their prospects, as are their suppliers and agricultural economists. Profits are up, debts and costs are down, and the outlook is for more of the same, at least through 1987, they agree. [ A16. ] MARKETS Prices of Government bonds fell sharply on the eve of three days of Treasury note and bond auctions, as dealers cut prices to attract foreign and domestic investors. But trading remained light, and potential buyers were generally silent about their intentions. Information from the financial centers in London and Tokyo was scanty because of holidays. [ D1. ] The Commodity Exchange shortened hours and lifted limits on some price swings as it tried to resolve problems left over from last week's unusually active and volatile trading in precious metals, especially silver. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said it was monitoring the exchange's emergency actions. [ D1. ] Silver again led the advance in precious metals futures, with spot silver up 51.8 cents, to $8.685, its highest level since June 1984. [ D20. ] Stocks had another seesaw session, ending slightly higher on sharply lower volume. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 5.82 points, to 2,286.22, after losing ground much of the day. [ D10. ] The dollar fell to new lows in light trading reduced by holidays in Tokyo and London. In New York, gold rose $5.50, to $462.50. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Church's Fried Chicken received a $469 million takeover offer from an investor group led by two former executives. Church's, the nation's second-largest fast-food chicken operation, said its board would consider the offer, which is valued at $12.25 a share. [ D1. ] First Boston and Allegheny International ended their merger, a $500 million deal, saying they had been unable to obtain two-thirds of Allegheny's preferred stock. [ D5. ] Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field's had 20 percent gains in operating income last year over 1985, and sales rose about 15 percent, according to their parent company, Batus Inc. [ D4. ] The former president of a defunct brokerage was convicted of tax fraud in Federal court in Newark. The jury reached no verdict on securities fraud charges against Gilbert C. Schulman, who headed Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc. until its collapse. [ D17. ] The William Esty agency resigned the Mastercard account, after losing Nissan's $140 million account late last week. The Mastercard assignment, worth about $40 million annually, had been Esty's for 10 years but was under review. [ D25. ] Zapata will give its creditor banks a 30 percent stake to pay off a portion of its debt. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL World Bank lending to developing nations could be imperiled if the dollar continues to fall, according to the president of the huge lending institution, Barber B. Conable Jr. He also announced changes intended to raise efficiency by slashing up to 10 percent from the staff of 6,000 and restructuring top management. [ D1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Taxpayers face a mismatch in disputes with the I.R.S. And some lawmakers are questioning whether the agency has too much power and taxpayers too few protections. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Recoveries for selected hospital management companies are forecast by some analysts. Hospital Corporation of America and Humana are expected to show gains. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: A VICTIM OF AIDS, WED AT ST. PATRICK'S AFTER DISPUTE, DIES
description: David Hefner, the AIDS patient who renewed his wedding vows at St. Patrick's Cathedral after being told he would not be allowed to because of his illness, died Sunday night, one year after his diagnosis. He was 38 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: President Kurt Waldheim said today that he would take legal action over the United States decision to bar him from the country on suspicion that he took part in war crimes in World War II.

description: Perhaps it will all change. Perhaps some little-known figure like Joseph L. Welch or Sam J. Ervin Jr., some homespun philosopher who seems to embody simple justice, will grasp the public imagination.

title: Family Outing
description: As a 39-year-old cross-country runner at Georgia State, Nora Weed is old enough to be the mother of one of her teammates. Next fall she will be. Her 17-year-old daughter, Theresa Bertram, has accepted a Georgia State scholarship and they will become what is believed to be the first mother-daughter duo to run on the same college team.

Gary Hart's Judgment
description: A candidate's private morality may or may not be fair grounds for judging fitness for office, but a candidate's judgment is surely fair game. What is known so far about Gary Hart's actions last weekend suggests a remarkable lack of judgment and insensitivity to appearances of impropriety.

description: State officials said today that the replacement for the bridge that collapsed last month on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway would be built on pilings in the Schoharie Creek and that the creekbed would be widened to reduce the force of water against the bridge.

title: KEY RATES
AGENT FOR MANY TOP WRITERS
description: Helen M. Strauss, who created the literary department at the William Morris agency and became a major influence in the worlds of books, motion pictures and the theater, died of cancer yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. Miss Strauss, 83 years old and a resident of Manhattan, had been ill for almost a year.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SEIZES 120 AT CAMPUS RALLY By
description: South African riot policemen arrested 120 students and fired tear gas at about 50 faculty members at the University of the Witwatersrand here today as the students and teachers protested the whites-only election scheduled for Wednesday.

title: Short on Height, Long on Talent
description: Michael Adams, all 5 feet 7 inches of him, dribbled his way from Boston College of the Big East Conference to the Washington Bullets of the National Basketball Association, overcoming the long odds against a short man playing in the N.B.A.

title: EX-BEVILL PRESIDENT CONVICTED
description: The former president of a defunct securities brokerage was convicted in Federal District Court today of tax fraud. The jury reached no verdict on securities fraud charges against the former executive, Gilbert C. Schulman, who was president of Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc. when it collapsed in April 1985.

title: Market Place; Hospital Stock Gains Forecast
description: HOSPITAL management companies have suffered in recent years from a decline in patients - along with a decline in their stock prices - as a result of cutbacks by Medicare and efforts by private insurers to rein in their medical costs. But some Wall Street analysts now are taking a more positive view of selected companies in this once-thriving growth industry.

title: Merrill Makes Debut At the Premium Show
description: Merrill Lynch, which has been offering retirement financial planning counseling to customers for some time, is going to extend the service to corporations to be used as an employee perk.

description: In a dramatic conflict in their closing statements yesterday, the lawyers for the two men accused of slashing a Manhattan model's face with a razor blade attributed the attack to different people.

In the seven years since he began presenting his dances in New York, Mr. Morris, who is 30 years old, has become one of the leading - and most controversial - modern-dance choreographers of his generation.

description: ''The QE2 is supposed to be the epitome of gentlemanly travel, and it was the pits.'' - Dennis Aaron, passenger on a troubled cruise. [ B8:4. ]

description: As former outposts of the British Empire go, Colombo stands somewhere, geographically and philosophically, between Bombay and Kuala Lumpur.

title: Rescue Depositors, Not the Thrifts
description: Will Uncle Sam protect small depositors when hundreds of savings and loans in the Sun Belt go bankrupt? Deposits up to $100,000 are insured by a Federal agency, and it is virtually certain that Washington would make up losses the insurance fund couldn't cover. But the fund is now broke and Congress is reluctant to assess healthy ''thrift'' institutions for replenishment.

title: DOLLAR'S DROP MAY HURT LENDING BY WORLD BANK
description: The plunge of the dollar could ''imperil the capacity'' of the World Bank to lend to developing countries, by squeezing the value of its capital, Barber B. Conable Jr., president of the huge lending institution, said today.

title: FLYERS WIN OPENER IN OVERTIME BY 4-3
description: Ilkka Sinisalo's second goal of the game 9 minutes 11 seconds into overtime gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 4-3 victory over the defending Stanley Cup champion Montreal Canadiens tonight in the opening game of their semifinal playoff series.

title: ON THE TOE OF ITALY, THE SHOTGUN SETTLES OLD SCORES
description: Shotgun pellets have left their mark on many walls in this village on the Ionian Sea. Even the facade of the small concrete church is peppered with little holes. On the hot and lonely streets, weeds sprout from broken curbstones, and heavily armed policemen keep watch at roadblocks.

title: Garvey Sits Out
description: Larry Bowa, the Padres' first-year manager, has benched the veteran Steve Garvey in a shakeup designed to give younger players more playing time. ''It's obvious we're not going to win the division,'' Bowa said before the Padres went into last night's game against the Pirates with a 6-20 record, the worst mark in the major leagues. ''When you get buried like we're buried right now, I think you've got to make changes.'' The 38-year-old Garvey, who is batting .186, was philosophical about his demotion. ''It's something that I knew was a possibility,'' said the 10-time All-Star who holds the National League record for consecutive games played, 1,207. ''Like I told Larry, anything I can do on or off the field to get us back on track, I'll be glad to do it.'' Garvey will be replaced at first by John Kruk and Carmelo Martinez. . . . The Padres activated Rich Gossage from the 15-day disabled list and optioned Ed Wojna, another pitcher, to their Class AAA affiliate in Las Vegas. Gossage, a 14-year veteran, has not pitched this season. He suffered a muscle pull near his left rib cage March 31 in an exhibition game.

title: HORIZON BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank went public in August 1986. Corrected from Thursday, April 30, editions.

title: ANADARKO PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: JAZZ: WAYNE SHORTER
description: WAYNE SHORTER used to draw Flash Gordon-like comic strips when he was growing up in Newark; he included one on the inner sleeve of his most recent album. The music he's making these days is a lot like science fiction in its enthusiasm for new technologies and oblique strategies. His tenor saxophone sound is more down to earth; he is still the gritty Newark hard-bopper. And it isn't always easy for him to make the funky and fanciful aspects of his work connect for listeners the way they connect in his imagination.

title: BRANDS COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: AMERIANA SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There are no per share earnings because the bank did not become a public company until Feb. 25.

title: Hospital Corp. Told to Divest
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Hospital Corporation of America must divest itself of two hospitals acquired as part of a $700 million deal in 1981 and 1982.

title: DURIRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes changes in accounting which increased net earnings by $442,000 and investment tax credits of $1,493,000.

title: Nynex's Request For PTAT System
description: The Nynex Corporation said it was seeking regulatory approval to buy PTAT System Inc. and provide telecommunications services between the United States and Britain. PTAT is a 50 percent participant with Cable and Wireless P.L.C. in a project to install and operate two underwater fiber-optic cables linking New York and London.

title: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and was restated for the adoption of FASB 87.

title: Korean Plea to Japan
description: Foreign Minister Choi Kwang Soo of South Korea called on Japan today to help close the trade gap between the countries. Mr. Choi asked Foreign Minister Tadashi Kuranari of Japan to help increase imports of South Korean goods and to ease import restrictions on Korean textiles, steel, cement and ships, ministry officials said. They said Japan had asked Seoul to protect Japanese copyrights and fishing rights. Japan's trade surplus with South Korea last year amounted to $5.4 billion.

title: ROYAL PALM SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed the lower earnings in the latest periods to a reduction in non-interest income primarily resulting from profit participations and the sale of loans and investments.

title: Prosecutor Denies Vindictiveness on Deaver
description: The independent counsel prosecuting Michael K. Deaver denied today that he was acting with vindictiveness toward the former White House aide and said that the grand jury in the case was continuing to investigate.

title: HPSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Woman Is Found Slain In Her Brooklyn Home
description: A 45-year-old New Jersey woman who had recently bought and moved into a brownstone in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was found stabbed to death there late Sunday, two days after the house had been burglarized, the police said yesterday.

title: Saks, Field's Report 1986 Income Gains
description: Saks Fifth Avenue and the Marshall Field's department stores each had 20 percent gains in operating income last year over 1985, and sales rose about 15 percent, their parent company, Batus Inc., said yesterday.

title: Greece Plans Oil Takeover
description: The Greek Parliament passed a law today to take over a Canadian, West German and American oil consortium whose plans to drill in the Aegean seabed were linked to a dispute that embroiled Greece and Turkey in a conflict in March.

title: ELECTRONIC ASSOCIATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Car Kills Man on Sidewalk; Driver Accused of Homicide
description: A 36-year-old Bronx man was killed instantly last night when a car driven by a drunken driver mounted the sidewalk and struck him, the police reported.

title: BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes gains of $4.4 million from securities and a gain of $3.4 million from the sale of a unit. The latest first quarter includes a provision for loan losses of $15 million, compared with $7.8 million for year-ago period.

title: The Electronic Record
description: Washington Alert, which is what The Congressional Quarterly calls its high-technology computer information service that provides more or less instant access to Congressional action on pending bills, will soon offer the complete daily Congressional Record.

title: Nobody Wanted Raines
description: Midway through last season, Davey Johnson was sitting in his Shea Stadium office when Frank Cashen stopped by. In their casual conversation, the Mets' manager mentioned to the general manager that Tim Raines of the Montreal Expos might be a free agent when the season ended.

title: Vietnam Stresses Oil
description: Vietnam, which shipped its first oil exports only last month, plans to have its oil industry fuel development of the national economy, the Communist Party leader, Nguyen Van Linh, said today. The Hanoi radio reported that he had told oil workers that production of crude this year should be seven times the 40,500 tons of the second half of 1986.

title: PERIPHERALS
description: TO clear the shelves for its new generation of PS machines, I.B.M. last month cut the prices of its existing XT and AT models. The price cuts were especially steep on the most basic XT models, and might be viewed as a parting shot at low-cost foreign clone producers that made life so miserable for Big Blue over the past year.

title: JURORS WEIGH FATE OF 7 ACCUSED OF PLOT TO STEAL POLICE TESTS
description: A Federal Court jury recessed today in the case of six former and current police officers and a former political aide accused of conspiring to steal and distribute promotional and entrance examinations for several police departments in the Boston area. The panel has been deliberating since last Thursday.

title: Testimony Ends in Case Of Reputed Crime Boss
description: Testimony at the $1 million conspiracy and extortion trial of Nicodemo Scarfo, the reputed boss of an organized-crime group, ended today with the defendant declining to take the witness stand.

title: KEY CENTURION BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter net includes operations of Nicholas County Bank, Union Bancorp of West Virginia Inc., and Wayne Bancorp Inc.

title: AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $8,107 for the latest quarter and $6,226 for the year-earlier period.

title: GENERAL AERO PRODUCTS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $554,192 for the latest year and $5,125 for the earlier year.

title: CPT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Non-Oil Goods Aid Iran
description: Iran has earned $2.35 billion in the last five years from selling agricultural items, carpets and other non-oil exports, a customs report said today. The report, quoted by the national press agency, said exports of hand-woven Persian carpets doubled in the 1986-87 fiscal year, which ended March 20. Agricultural items topped the non-oil export list with 36.7 percent of sales; carpets had 29.3 percent, and caviar 4.16 percent, the agency said.

title: Silver Climbs by Limit In a Shortened Session
description: The silver bulls again led the advance in precious metals futures yesterday during an abbreviated trading session on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $8,344,000 for the latest quarter and $1,359,000 for the year-earlier period. Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in February.

title: Woman, 78, Is Raped And Slain in Brooklyn
description: A 78-year-old woman was found dead in the bedroom of her ransacked apartment in Brooklyn Heights last night, the victim of an intruder who raped and murdered her, the police say.

title: McHale Is Top Choice
description: Kevin McHale of the Boston Celtics, who led forwards in shot blocking this season, was the leading vote-getter on the National Basketball Association's all-defensive team, selected by the league's coaches. Joining McHale on the first team were Michael Cooper, a Los Angeles Lakers forward; Akeem Olajuwon, the Houston center, and Alvin Robertson of San Antonio and Dennis Johnson of the Celtics, both guards.

title: Ketchum Buys More Offices
description: In addition to Hicks & Greist, whose acquisition was announced yesterday, Ketchum Communications of Pittsburgh has also bought two offices of Mandabach & Simms in Chicago and Oakland, Calif., and the Richard Handler Company, a Yellow Pages agency in New York.

title: Lowell Russell Ditzen Dies; Presbyterian Church Official
description: The Rev. Dr. Lowell Russell Ditzen, a clergyman, Presbyterian Church official and author, died Sunday from a stroke at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 74 years old.

title: PRODUCTIVITY GAIN SHOWN BY BUSINESS
description: The productivity of American business, an indicator that has assumed new urgency in the debate over the nation's ability to meet world competition, rose at an annual rate of 1.8 percent in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported today.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: HART'S CAMPAIGN REPORTED IN PERIL OVER TRYST STORY
description: Some Republican and Democratic politicians said today that Gary Hart's Presidential campaign is in peril as a result of a newspaper report that a young woman spent Friday night at his home here. But Hart aides insisted that the article was based on lies and that the former Senator would emerge with his candidacy intact.

title: Kabul Says Ex-Afghan Leader Is in Soviet to See Doctors
description: Babrak Karmal, the former Afghan leader who was reported jailed over the weekend, is in the Soviet Union for medical treatment, the Kabul radio said today.

title: Clues on Fungal Disease
description: Scientists at Cornell University have discovered that a plant fungus possesses a peculiar sense of touch and uses it to feel its way across a leaf to find the pores it invades with infectious disease.

title: STAGE: 'FILM IS EVIL: RADIO IS GOOD'
description: THE title of Richard Foreman's quizzical new comedy, ''Film Is Evil: Radio Is Good,'' almost says it all. This is a cryptographic mystery about the encroachment of visual imagery into the world of sound. The heroic forces of broadcasting are represented by the proprietors of a small, unidentified radio station that suddenly finds itself besieged and undermined by a chorus of threatening cineastes.

title: CASINO ACCUSED OF CRIME LINK IN LABOR TALKS
description: State law-enforcement officials charged today that Harrah's casino permitted organized crime figures to participate in labor negotiations in Atlantic City in 1981 in an effort to avoid a costly strike by the teamsters' union.

title: LACANA MINING CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,979,000. c-Net loss and after a $13,412,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $9,510,000 special charge.

title: U.S. TO PRESENT STRATEGIC ARMS DRAFT
description: With time running short for the Reagan Administration to achieve a strategic arms accord, the United States plans an effort to hasten the process by presenting a draft treaty on reducing long-range nuclear weapons.

title: INCOMNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHESAPEAKE UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HIGH COURT RULES THAT ROTARY CLUBS MUST ADMIT WOMEN
description: Casting doubt on claims by many private clubs that they have constitutional rights to exclude women from membership, the Supreme Court ruled in a 7-to-0 decision today that states may outlaw such discrimination by Rotary Clubs.

title: IEC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Deal for A.M.C. Delayed Again
description: The acquisition of the American Motors Corporation by the Chrysler Corporation has been delayed again, but Chrysler executives say they are still optimistic that an agreement can be reached.

title: Facts on Genetic Tests
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES:

title: A TAKEOVER BID TESTS BURLINGTON'S CHAIRMAN
description: Frank S. Greenberg, who has been chairman and chief executive of Burlington Industries since September, is facing perhaps the biggest challenge of his career as the New York investor Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile Inc. try to take over his company.

title: NOVA AN ALBERTA CORP() reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: NUI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago results are after a $17,636,000 writedown against oil and gas operations. The per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid April 15.

title: MUGAVERO ASSAILS HIGH FEES FOR ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: Illegal aliens applying for amnesty under a new Federal law are being overcharged for assistance with their documentation and exploited in other ways, Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: Chip Agreement
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation and the Lattice Semiconductor Corporation said they had signed a licensing, development and manufacturing agreement for advanced, high-speed electrically programmable logic devices, known as E2PLD's. The agreement gives National rights to produce and market logic devices now available and in development by Lattice, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., and provides for joint development, production and marketing of the next generation of E2PLD's. These chips are the newest technology in the field-programmable logic market, which is considered one of the fastest-growing segments of the semiconductor industry.

title: A Third Chemical Unit For Texas Deal Maker
description: Gordon A. Cain has created two big chemical companies through acquisitions from the petrochemical industry's major players. The 75-year-old businessman from Houston is about to create a third.

title: Dow Edges Up 5.82 as Volume Slows
description: The stock market had another see-saw session yesterday, but managed to end slightly higher on a day that saw trading fall off sharply.

title: UNOCAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $21 million from a reversal of a prior provision for natural-gas price refunds.

title: Jury Convicts Merrill Lynch
description: A Federal District Court jury in Sioux Falls, S.D., found Merrill Lynch & Company guilty of unauthorized trading yesterday, and Judge John Jones awarded the estate of Ethlyn Davis damages of $2.27 million.

title: G.M. Unit Buys Amtec
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the computer services arm of the General Motors Corporation, said today that it had acquired Amtec Information Services, a California electronic publishing firm. E.D.S. acquired Amtec, based in Lakewood, Calif., for an undisclosed amount from Zimmerman Holdings Inc. of San Marino, Calif. The 30-year-old Amtec specializes in the automobile and aviation industries, among others.

title: GOETZ VICTIM ADMITS HIS TESTIMONY VARIES
description: One of the four young men shot by Bernhard H. Goetz admitted yesterday that he had given at least three different versions of where he and the other three youths were standing in the moments before Mr. Goetz shot them on Dec. 22, 1984.

title: Plan to Shrink U.S. Tax Gap
description: A study group headed by two former Commissioners of Internal Revenue proposed to Congress today a program for reducing the $103 billion Federal tax gap without raising taxes on those already paying their fair share.

title: SONICS' LAWYER SEEKS COURT DELAY
description: Last year, four Mets were arrested after a scuffle with off-duty Houston police officers working as security guards at a nightclub here.

title: BRESLIN TO QUIT THE NEWS AND WRITE FOR NEWSDAY
description: Jimmy Breslin, the tough-talking columnist who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1986, will leave The Daily News next year and join Newsday and its New York edition, Newsday executives announced yesterday.

title: QUIET CLAY REVEALED AS VIBRANT AND PRIMAL
description: MICROSCOPICALLY, it comes in sheets, pipes, plates and tendrils. It shimmers with electronic energy. It triggers intricate chemical reactions and sucks poisons from the environment. That much is known for certain.

title: WPIX Will Air Six More Games
description: The Yankees said yesterday that six additional games will be carried on WPIX-TV, Channel 11, in May, July and August, bringing to 46 the number of games that station will broadcast this season.

title: The U.N. Today: May 5, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: FARMERS ARE REAPING OPTIMISM BY THE BUSHEL
description: The weather, the Government and the economy are all on the side of the nation's corn farmers this season as they till the soil and plant their seeds, acting out an annual ritual of hope.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ANTONIO LOPEZ, the illustrator, and Willi Smith, the designer, were both victims of AIDS. But it was their creative vitality, not their recent deaths, that was remembered last week at two tributes - for Antonio at the Fashion Institute of Technology and for Mr. Smith at the Parsons School of Design.

title: CADMUS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Superconductivity: The Spray Paint Approach
description: THE first successes in making use of the fast-breaking advances in superconducting materials are coming through the simple act of spraying them.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Music at Sacred Heart

title: Unocal Income Drops 13.5%
description: The Unocal Corporation said today that it earned $61 million, or 52 cents a share, in the first quarter, down 13.5 percent from $70 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues dropped 9 percent, to $2.06 billion, from $2.28 billion in the 1986 quarter.

title: POLY-TECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $426,000.

title: A FASTER WAY TO PAINT
description: WHEN I began reviewing a new graphics package for the Macintosh last week only to discover that the publisher had sneaked advertisements for other products onto the program disk, I was incensed at the liberties taken with the bits and bytes consumers are expected to pay for.

title: Zapata Will Swap 30% Stake for Debt
description: The Zapata Corporation, a leading offshore oil drilling company, said today that it had reached agreement with its banks to swap a 30 percent stake in the company for a portion of its debt. .

title: Admiral Would Jettison Paper to Speed Navy
description: When one of the Navy's newest frigates leaves port it carries Standard air defense missiles, Harpoon anti-ship missiles, MK-46 torpedoes and lots of paper.

title: DALIDA
description: Dalida, an Egyptian-born singer and actress who first won fame in France for her song ''Bambino'' in 1954, was found dead Sunday from an apparent overdose of barbiturates, according to family members. She was 54 years old.

title: INFORMATION RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NORTH SEA ISLE AND THE DAY IT BLEW UP
description: Before setting off the biggest nonnuclear explosion in history, the British detonated a small one so that the birds of Helgoland Island would be frightened away and not be killed in Operation Big Bang. There had been protests from British bird watchers.

title: TCF BANKING & SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $2,477,000 from the early repayment of a Federal Home Loan Bank advance and a tax credit of $365,000. c-After a charge of $8,626,000 from the early repayment of a Federal Home Loan Bank advance and a tax credit of $1,859,000.

title: FILTERTEK COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOME FAR-REACHING PROPOSALS
description: Many of the innovative proposals put forward to deal with the debt crisis are being viewed as palliatives, not genuine solutions. A number of academics and Government officials, however, have offered some grander, more far-reaching plans.

title: GENICOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, the Business and the Law column in Business Day yesterday, about claims filed against the A. H. Robins Company, ended with an incomplete sentence. The sentence should have read: ''Still, Robins has not yet budged in any meaningful way.''

description: b-Includes a $3.2 million after-tax writedown of oil and gas properties.

Anchor converted to a stock ownership April 1.

title: WYSE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
BIG INCREASE IN DEATH TOLL FEARED
description: The legal speed limit is catching up to the drivers on thousands of miles of the nation's interstate highways. But the move to 65 miles per hour from 55 in rural areas is far from universal, and in some states the higher limit is being accompanied by new measures to mitigate what officials say may be a surge in deaths and serious injuries.

title: EMPIRE DISTRICT ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ATCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: FILES MADE PUBLIC ON THE NIXON ERA
description: The National Archives made public a fraction of the 1.5-million-page Watergate file today in an expurgated release that added no startling new facts to the record of the declining years in office of Richard M. Nixon, the only President to resign.

title: INFORMER ASSERTS MOB CONTROLLED TEAMSTERS' BOSS
description: A key informer testified in a Manhattan trial yesterday that the Mafia ''controlled'' Jackie Presser and helped elect him as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: WALTER GROWS UNDER A NEW PHILOSOPHY
description: Inside the museum of a dressing room on the ground floor of a building on St. Catherine Street in Montreal, the happiest moments are followed closely by reminders of the expectations from the outside.
