SYMBOLICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $348,000 and $2,878,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: MARCOS PAINTINGS SOUGHT FROM SAUDI
description: The Philippine Government said yesterday that it had searched the French apartment of a Saudi arms dealer - to no avail - for valuable Impressionist and Renaissance paintings that had belonged to former President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda.

title: Our Towns; Where Dreams Of Glory Days Are Nurtured
description: As the New Britain Red Sox finished batting practice in the gathering twilight, the Kirschners - Ellen and Bob - arrived at Beehive Field here to start preparing for the night's game with the Vermont Reds.

title: Tax Watch; Fighting I.R.S.: Uneven Match
description: THIS is the time of year when many taxpayers begin to worry that the income tax return they just filed will come under scrutiny and someday bring the Internal Revenue Service knocking at their door. And there is reason to worry: Disputes between the I.R.S. and a taxpayer are not an even match.

title: KILLING OF A JOURNALIST AT HIS OFFICE SHOCKS JAPAN
description: A Japanese newspaper reporter was killed and another was critically wounded by a masked attacker who walked into their office in central Japan on Sunday night and opened fire with a shotgun.

title: Suits Challenge Firestone Move
description: A former president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and a former company accountant filed separate lawsuits today in attempts to stop Firestone from moving its corporate headquarters to Chicago.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MAY 5, 1987
description: News analysis: Hearings begin on the Iran-contra affair with no great sense in Washington of historic drama about to unfold, nothing of the feeling of a national turning point about to be reached. Page A1 The testimony of Richard V. Secord at the Congressional hearings should give the first detailed public accounting of both the secret arms sales to Iran and the covert operation to supply the Nicaraguan rebels, investigators said. A12 South African riot police arrested 120 students and fired tear gas at about 50 faculty members at the University of the Witwatersrand as they protested the whites-only election scheduled for Wednesday. A3 U.S. envoys may have broken rules against unauthorized socializing with foreigners in sensitive posts overseas, a State Department official said. The Department is investigating several cases. A13 A draft arms reduction treaty by the United States will be given to Soviet negotiators. The draft treaty on reducing long-range nuclear weapons ignores the issue of space-based defenses and other unresolved differences. A14 Lebanon's Prime Minister resigned after three years in office. Rashid Karami said his 10-member half Moslem, half Christian Cabinet had failed to resolve any of the country's political and economic problems. A10 Yiddish is flourishing in Moscow, according to the principal spokesman for official Soviet Jewish culture. ''The obstacles that hampered our forward movement have been removed,'' Aron Vergelis said. A15 A musical old-timer at age 10, Stefan Milenkovic gave his 424th violin recital last week in Paris. This summer, Americans will get their first chance to hear him play, at the Newport Music Festival on July 16. C13 Pope ends West German tour

title: 'THE MAKING OF A JUSTICE'
description: WE are an open society; it is commonplace to say that. But consider now how television contributes to the openness. Whatever else ''The Presidency and the Constitution,'' a seven-part series, is about, it's about people who exercise power. What do they do, and by what authority do they do it? The provocative series begins on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: EVEN STRAWBERRY IS CHEERING FOR DAVIS
description: Darryl Strawberry and Eric Davis, friends since their teen-age years, worked out together all winter in Los Angeles and set their sights on this season. ''We're not competing against each other,'' Strawberry explained. ''Our goal is to win most valuable player this year. I wish we both could win it. We have to share it because I'm not counting myself out and he's not counting himself out.''

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain on sale of marketable securities equal to 12 cents a share. c-Net loss

title: Stephenson Must Rest
description: Jan Stephenson, who withdrew from a Florida golf tournament after being injured in an auto accident Saturday, has been advised by doctors to rest for the month. Her caddie said she would not play in the Chrysler-Plymouth Classic, to be held in Middletown, N.J., May 15-17. Stephenson was the co-leader in the S&H Classic in St. Petersburg, later won by Cindy Hill. She suffered a sprained back, dislocated rib and scalp cuts in a three-car collision caused by a motorist who ran a red light in nearby Pinellas Park, the authorities said. ''I feel rotten and have a bad headache,'' Stephenson said Sunday after being treated at a hospital. ''It doesn't look like she'll be able to play in Virginia,'' her caddie, Rick White said, referring to the United Virginia Bank Classic to be held this weekend in Portsmouth. ''But she'll go there, rest a couple days and see if she can try to play. She will not play in New Jersey.'' ''I can't believe this is happening to me when I'm on a roll,'' said Stephenson, who captured the Santa Barbara Open two weeks ago for her first victory in two years.

title: Thrift Unit's Owner Guilty
description: A co-owner of the defunct Old Court Savings and Loan Association was found guilty today of stealing $640,000 from the institution through undeserved commissions and consulting fees.

title: Reagan Trip to Italy in June Downgraded to Private Visit
description: President Reagan has downgraded his planned state visit to Italy next month to a private trip because of Italy's political crisis, White House officials said today.

description: For the network news executives who decide what millions of viewers will see in nightly newscasts, the Gary Hart ''womanizing'' controversy presented some difficult questions: A newspaper article saying that Mr. Hart spent the night with a woman was a compelling story, but was it appropriate, or even accurate?

EUROPEAN FAILURES LEAVE SPACE EFFORT MIRED IN FRUSTRATION
description: LESS rain than usual has fallen during the current rainy season, but clouds far more ominous have settled over this tropical backwater on the shoulder of South America.

title: French Steel Merger Likely
description: France's two giant state-owned steel companies, Usinor and Sacilor, are likely to merge completely this year in an overhaul of the industry following huge losses, the two groups' joint president said today.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $624,000. The company had its initial public offering in June 1986.

title: Bill to Restore Gaslight Gains in a House Vote
description: Homeowners would once again be able to install gaslights on their properties under the terms of legislation passed today by the House.

title: POPE LEAVES AS GERMANS PONDER PAST
description: Pope John Paul II ended a five-day tour of West Germany today by celebrating an ecumenical service with other Christian leaders.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ''IT'' GIRLS. Lucy, Lady Duff Gordon, the Couturiere ''Lucile,'' and Elinor Glyn, Romantic Novelist. By Meredith Etherington-Smith and Jeremy Pilcher. 274 pages. Illustrated.

title: Missing Links
description: How much is the presently woeful Mets pitching staff missing Dwight Gooden and Roger McDowell? Manager Dave Johnson is hoping both will be able to return - Gooden from a 27-day stay at a drug rehabilitation center and McDowell from a hernia - about June 1. title: KEITH CARRADINE STARS IN 'MURDER ORDAINED'
description: REAL life in recent weeks has been giving us the scandals of the television evangelists. Now, in a two-part CBS movie that began Sunday and will conclude tonight at 9, televison entertainment is offering the case of a murderous minister. It is not the best of times, clearly, for those members of the clergy interested in the propagation of images.

description: The Board of Commissioners of the Orleans Levee District, in Louisiana, is tentatively offering $95 million of levee and public improvement refunding bonds with a maximum yield of about 8.56 percent for 8 1/2 percent issues due in 2014 and 2015.

title: CENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a non-cash after-tax writedown of $8.9 million of oil and gas properties.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Hudson Newes Aqueduct Winner: Hudson Newes finished strongly yesterday to win the $73,500 Kingston Stakes by six lengths at Aqueduct. Hudson Newes, ridden by Joe Badamo Jr., covered a mile and one-sixteenth over a soft turf course in 1:55 4/5 to earn $44,100 for Robert B. Cohen. It was his second victory in eight starts this year. Tinchen's Prince finished second in the field of eight New York-breds 3 years old and upward. Rollerball was third, another three-quarters of a length back. Hudson Newes returned $28.40, $9.80 and $8.40 for $2 across the board. Tinchen's Prince paid $5.40 and $4, while Rollerball paid $8.80 to show. Yesterday was the last day of the spring meeting at Aqueduct. Belmont Park opens tomorrow. (AP) TENNIS Hanika Upset by Paulus: Barbara Paulus, a little-known 16-year-old from Austria, upset Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, the No. 9 seeded player, as women's play in the Italina Open returned to the Foro Italico in Rome after a seven-year absence. The women's event, hurt by low attendance and prize money, was last played in Rome in 1979. The event was held in Perugia from 1980-84 and Taranto in 1985. No women's tournament was held last year. The men's event begins May 11. Paulus, ranked No. 171 in the world and playing in only her second major professional tournament, beat Hanika, 7-6, 6-3, on the first day of the clay court event. Two Americans also were eliminated. Petra Huber of Austria routed Kathy Horvath of Largo, Fla., 6-2, 6-1, and Janine Thompson of Australia outlasted Anne White of Los Angeles, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2. (AP)

title: CITY BALLET'S SCHOOL JOINS LINCOLN CENTER
description: The School of American Ballet has become a constituent of Lincoln Center, it was announced yesterday. George Weissman, chairman of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, and Lincoln Kirstein, co-founder and president of the school, made the announcement last night at a dinner for the school at the New York State Theater, at which the first Mae L. Wien Awards were also presented.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. to Make Arms Offer

title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Molitor Injured
description: The Milwaukee Brewers' Paul Molitor, the second-leading hitter in the American League, has been placed on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to April 30, because of a pulled right hamstring. Molitor was batting .395, although he had not played since being hobbled by the hamstring injury when he hit a home run at Oakland Wednesday night. He said he felt a slight pull when he was caught in a rundown the previous night.

title: SHIFTS URGED IN BANK LAWS
description: Robert Heller, a Federal Reserve Board governor, called for broad deregulation of the American banking industry today, saying it would increase American competitiveness in international markets.

title: DE KOONING PAINTING TIES AUCTION RECORD
description: Willem de Kooning's ''Pink Lady'' from 1944 tied the record at auction for a contemporary painting and for a work by a living artist when it was sold last night for $3.63 million at Sotheby's. The large and glowing Abstract Expressionist oil and charcoal on panel in pinks, red, bright green and yellow, was sold to an unidentified buyer who bid over the telephone through Lucy Mitchell-Innes, Sotheby's contemporary-art specialist.

title: LANE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN APPROVES SPECIAL AIDS PANEL
description: The White House announced tonight that President Reagan had approved the formation of a special commission to advise him on the public policy aspects of the AIDS crisis.

description: The company said after deducting preferred share dividends, there were no share earnings in the latest quarter. Results are in Canadian dollars.

US TRUCK LINES INC OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,378,000 from termination of a pension plan.

title: CHILD DEVELOPMENT: LANGUAGE TAKES ON NEW SIGNIFICANCE
description: RESEARCHERS are focusing with new intensity on the earliest stages of children's language acquisition as a key indicator of normal - and abnormal - development.

title: China to Issue Bonds
description: The Bank of China will issue about $135 million in yuan-denominated bonds on Tuesday, the first domestically issued bonds from the Communist Government, the official New China News Agency has reported. The one-year bonds will be issued in denominations of 100 yuan, about $27, and 500 yuan, about $135, and will have an annual interest rate of 9 percent, the agency said. Funds raised from the sale of the bonds will go toward loans for expansion projects, joint ventures with foreign nations, collectively run businesses in urban areas and foreign trade enterprises.

title: ONE VALLEY BANCORP OF W VA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Manville Profit Up In Fiberglass Unit
description: The Manville Corporation, the building supplies company facing the last hurdles of bankruptcy protection, said today that its largest division - fiberglass products - had a 50 percent increase in operating income, to $39.9 million from $26.6 million.

title: FIRST DAY: BLUE SHIRTS, RED TIES, DARK TALES
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 -

title: JUSTICE'S HUSBAND SAID TO KNOW OF G.O.P. GROUP
description: The chairman of Gopac, a Republican political action committee, said Monday that he told the husband of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court about the group's identity when first asking him whether the Justice could give a talk to some of the group's members.

title: Officials Term Cargo 'Just Everyday Trash'
description: The bales of garbage on Long Island's outcast barge are ''just everyday trash,'' officials of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation said today.

title: WOMEN LOBBY ON HEALTH
description: The Older Women's League, known as OWL, is sending Mother's Day cards to lawmakers as part of the group's ''Give 'Em Health'' campaign, urging Congress to vote for expanded medical services and insurance.

title: Spindler Joins GreyCom
description: Paul Spindler, who has had his own public relations firm, the Spindler Company, has joined GreyCom Public Relations, a subsidiary of Grey Advertising, and has brought with him some of his employees and nine clients and office space. Together they will establish GreyCom/West in the former Spindler space in Los Angeles.

title: REED JEWELERS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Navratilova Advances: Martina Navratilova, without a tour victory in 1987, started slow in the Italian Open in Rome and scraped past the unheralded Sabrina Goles of Yugoslavia in two tiebreakers. The second-seeded player, Steffi Graf of West Germany, meanwhile, kept up her hot streak, cruising past Petra Huber of Austria, 6-2, 6-2. Navratilova, ranked No. 1 in the world, struggled to a 7-6, 7-6 second-round victory on the slow red clay of the Foro Italico. In the day's biggest upset, unseeded Judith Polzl of Austria eliminated No. 6 seeded Bettina Bunge of West Germany, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4. Also beaten was the 12th seeded Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union, who retired with a back injury trailing another Soviet player, Natalie Zvereva, 6-2, 3-0. Seeded players advancing were Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, seeded fourth, who beat Marie-Christine Calleja of France, 6-2, 6-0; Raffaella Reggi of Italy, No. 10, who defeated Patricia Tarabini of Argentina, 6-1, 6-4, and Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami, seeded 11th, a 6-2, 6-4 winner from Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia. (AP) TRACK Notre Dame Sets Record: The Notre Dame of Staten Island girls' 3,200-meter relay team posted the fastest time in the country this season by winning the event in 9 minutes 9.2 seconds yesterday at the 17th annual Jersey Relays in Plainfield, N.J. Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn also set a meet mark in the boys' 3,200, clocking 7:44. Running with the same four girls - Kerry Moloughney, Eileen Kavanagh, Rachelle Clinton and Courtney Finn - Notre Dame also won the sprint medley in 4:09.3. Loughlin also took the distance medley in 10:21.9, with Kenny Lewis, Jason Williams and Lance Smith on both winning foursomes.

title: Chrysler Offers Sales Incentives
description: The Chrysler Corporation, the third-largest American car maker, said today that it would offer cut-rate financing on some cars and trucks to spur sales, beginning Wednesday and continuing indefinitely.

description: THE dances that Ellen Webb and Lauri Nagel presented Saturday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center resembled artists' drawings. Just as a drawing may suggest much with only a few lines, so these choreographers tried to reveal much with only a few steps.

title: HOSPITAL FINDS 2 PATIENTS DIED OF INSULIN DOSES
description: Two patients were given fatal overdoses of insulin at North Central Bronx Hospital, investigators from the Bronx District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Sosnoff Petitions Caesars Holders
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, the New York investor, urged shareholders of Caesars World Inc. to support his proposal to remove four of the gaming company's inside directors from its nine-member board. In a letter, Mr. Sosnoff denied that he was interested in having the Caesars management buy out his stake at a premium and said the board's adoption of a recapitalization plan showed ''a total failure to recognize the inherent conflict of interest'' by the four inside directors.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PHILHARMONIC: 'PLANETS'
description: THE English conductor Andrew Davis, who is a guest with the New York Philharmonic for three weeks, continued his attentions to English music on his second subscription program - heard Friday afternoon at its second and final performance in Avery Fisher Hall. The first program included Bax and Michael Tippett; this time there was Holst, in the form of his massive, seven-movement suite ''The Planets.''

Bridge: Choice of Suit Is Crucial In Bidding to Make Slam
description: A major element in slam bidding theory concerns the strength of the suit. When two or three possible trump suits are available, the one with the queen and the jack, or at least one of those cards, should be selected.

title: SECORD SAYS HIGH OFFICIALS HELPED HIM SUPPLY CONTRAS DESPITE BAN ON U.S. ARMS AID
description: Richard V. Secord testified today that Government officials including William J. Casey, then Director of Central Intelligence, helped to supply weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels after Congress had prohibited such aid.

title: TITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $476,000 and $620,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively, and the year-ago period also includes a loss from discontinued operations of $200,000. Year-earlier figures have been restated to include the operations of Pulse Sciences Inc., which merged with Titan in the first quarter of 1987. The merger was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Memories: The Pie Only Mom Could Bake
description: LEAD: It was a big country kitchen with big iron kettles and skillets - bubbling and steaming and sizzling - full of good smells and the most wonderful things to eat, for every season.

title: New York's Good Winter Budget
description: Judged by weather and finances, New York City had a good winter. Mayor Koch's executive budget for the year starting July 1 reflects a big swing since early January, when the budget forecast a deficit. Tax revenues now are virtually certain to produce a $514 million surplus, an ample cushion for the new fiscal year. That reflects a large measure of good luck, as tax revenues have surged. The danger is that overconfidence may replace the deficit as a fiscal problem.

title: PAT CASH STARTING OVER AGAIN
description: His career has sputtered like a poorly tuned car, each step forward offset by an injury, necessitating that he begin over again. Pat Cash's most recent setback occurred after he was the runner-up to Stefan Edberg of Sweden in the Australian Open last January. His next appearance was not at a tournament site but in a hospital to undergo surgery for damaged cartilage in his knee.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MAY 6, 1987
description: International A3-19 2,,q>U.S officials helped supply weapons to the contras after Congress prohibited such aid, Richard V. Secord testified at Congressional hearings. He said the officials included William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence. Page A1 Some Federal workers got proceeds from the Iran arms sales to assist Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North in one operation, General Secord said. It was the first indication that Colonel North hired another agency's employees. A17 The Iran-Contra hearings were not particularly gripping, with most people, even in the Capitol, more interested in talk of Gary Hart's problems than Ronald Reagan's. A17 Transcript of Secord's testimony A16 South African police infiltrated the African National Congress by recruting blacks through torture or threats, the group said. They presented a group of blacks who said the police recruited them. A1 In Afghanistan, Soviet troops ring the key trading center of Herat, providing the Government with a seemingly secure hold on the city, officials said. The city was the scene of fighting with rebel forces. A1 Space-based missile defense tests would violate the traditional view of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, a Senate committee voted. The committee spurned Administration efforts to loosen the interpretation. A9 Soviet police detained an Austrian who works as a nanny for the chief of security at the United States Embassy. The police seized her Saturday for three hours, asserting she had been part of an ''anti-Soviet conspiracy.'' A8 An American's death in Nicaragua was mourned in the village of El Cua. The American volunteer killed by rebel fire, Benjamin Ernest Linder, worked as an engineer. A3 U.S. told to repay Iran

title: Unwanted Guests
description: Things were topsy-turvy in the first two rounds of the Stanley Cup playoffs as far as the supposed home-ice advantage was concerned. Visiting teams, usually underdogs, won 36 of 69 games, breaking the National Hockey League record set last year for most triumphs in the playoffs by visitors - 31 victories against 42 defeats. Following are the records in the first two rounds of the current playoffs for the surviving teams. Home Away W L W L Edmonton 4 1 4 0 Detroit 4 2 4 1 Montreal 4 2 4 1 Philadelphia 4 3 4 2

title: DAVIS PLANS TO BID FOR SPECTRADYNE
description: Marvin Davis, the Denver oil billionaire, said yesterday that he would seek control of Spectradyne Inc., the leading suppler of pay-per-view television systems at hotels and motels.

title: SMOKING RULES: HOT ISSUE
description: Nov. 21, 1986 - The 15-member State Public Health Council tenatively approves regulations that would prohibit smoking in most indoor public areas in the state, including schools, auditoriums, banks, hospitals and movie theaters.

title: PALL OVER THE ROBOTICS SHOW
description: It might be remembered as a haunted trade show. The ghosts that hovered over last week's Robotics Industry Association exhibition were those of absent companies who in years past never dreamed of missing the annual conclave.

title: ALTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
Article 390887 -- No Title
description: A Federal district judge here has ordered the Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority to pay a fine of more than $32 million for failing to repair its sewage treatment system under a 1985 agreement with the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: AMERICAN HOME SHIELD CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $421,000 for the latest quarter and $203,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Data General's Latest Laptop
description: The Data General Corporation, based in Westboro, Mass., has introduced a new version of its Model One laptop personal computer, which features a new screen, a faster microprocessor, a built-in hard disk and internal removable batteries. Prices for the Model One 2T start at $1,695.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Charles Smith, the all-Big East center from Pitt, has now decided to stay in school. He previously said he expected to make himself eligible for the National Basketball Association draft . . . John McEnroe has entered the $495,000 Italian Open, beginning next week, marking the first time he will be playing on the slow red clay courts of Rome's Foro Italico. . . . John Brophy, who brought the Toronto Maple Leafs to within one game of the Stanley Cup semifinal series, has been given a new three-year contract as head coach. . . . Jan Stephenson, who was injured in an auto accident last Saturday, has withdrawn from the United Virginia Bank Classic, to be held in Portsmouth this weekend.

title: Water Bonds Issued in Texas
description: The Coastal Water Authority of Texas is offering $120 million of water revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.20 percent for an issue due in 2006 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Interim Franchises Post Is Filled
description: Mayor Koch's nominee as interim director of the city's Bureau of Franchises, Hadley W. Gold, was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: Israeli Leaders Delay Debate on Peace Talks
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres today postponed a debate on proposals for a Middle East peace conference.

title: 'DIALOGUES OF CARMELITES'
description: THE public-television series ''Live From Lincoln Center'' and ''Live From the Met'' are now so well established that they are in danger of being taken for granted. The technology of transmitting or taping a live performance of music or dance is firmly in place except for periodic refinements that make the broadcast even better. The more prominent TV directors, notably Kirk Browning and Brian Large, can now tackle the formidable logistics of the event with little trepidation. It all seems so easy that, every once in a while, we have to remind ourselves that this is indeed special - at times extraordinary - television.

title: S. Carolina Issue
description: South Carolina is offering $85 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation. Rated Aaa by Moody's, the bonds offer yields ranging from 4.50 percent in 1988 to 5.40 percent in 1992, 6.70 percent in 1997 and 7.35 percent in 2003.

title: Loss Narrows For Pan Am
description: The Pan Am Corporation, parent of Pan American World Airways, said yesterday that it had a loss of $93.6 million in the first quarter, down slightly from a loss of $118.4 million a year ago.

title: MARGO NURSERY FARMS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Margo went public Feb. 9.

title: U.S. TOLD TO RETURN $451 MILLION TO IRAN
description: An American-Iranian tribunal has ordered the United States to return $451.4 million in frozen assets to Iran. In addition, the tribunal said Iran did not consider the return of the money to be connected in any way with the fate of American hostages in Lebanon.

title: U.S. Rejects Offer by Suspect
description: Carlos Lehder Rivas, accused of heading a cartel responsible for supplying 80 percent of the cocaine smuggled into the United States, has offered to cooperate with the authorities, a United States attorney said today.

title: LATE APRIL AUTO SALES STRENGTHEN
description: Automobile sales grew stronger in the final 10 days of April, finishing three-tenths of 1 percent below an unusually strong 1986 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. Sales of domestic light trucks were brisk as well, gaining seven-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An Atlanta dispatch last Saturday. and an accompanying set of lyrics, about the lampooning of television evangelists by country-music radio stations, misstated the authorship of a song titled ''Would Jesus Wear a Rolex?'' The song was written by Chet Atkins and Margaret Archer and not by Ray Stevens, who recorded it.

title: AT DEALERS SOON: 4-WHEEL STEERING
description: NOW that four-wheel drive has become an accepted feature on some passenger cars, auto makers are turning their attention to four-wheel steering.

title: PAUL BUTTERFIELD, WHOSE BAND ADDED CHICAGO BLUES TO ROCK
description: Paul Butterfield, the harmonica player who led the Butterfield Blues Band, was found dead Monday at his apartment in Los Angeles. He was 44 years old.

title: BLOOD TESTS LINK SLAIN MAN AND ATTEMPT ON GOTTI
description: Bloodstains from a man who was abducted near the Queens headquarters of John Gotti match the blood type of a man found slain the next day on Staten Island, police officials said yesterday.

title: Ban Shouting 101
description: The latest release of the Nixon Watergate files includes a 1969 proposal by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, then the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's legal division, that the Government crack down on anti-Nixon campus radicals.

title: Emirates in Squeeze
description: Falling oil revenues shrank the United Arab Emirates economy by more than one-fifth last year, cutting into trade and current account surpluses, but the central bank today predicted an upturn soon. Earnings from oil exports, on which the economy depends heavily, fell 37.5 percent to 25 billion dirhams ($6.8 billion), from 40 billion dirhams ($11 billion) in 1985, the bank said in its 1986 annual report. Gross domestic product fell 21.4 percent, to 80.3 billion dirhams, with oil, industry and construction the worst affected sectors. The country's trade surplus fell to 12.2 billion dirhams, from 30.2 billion in 1985, while the current account surplus slid to 6.8 billion dirhams from 25.5 billion.

title: FITCHBURG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SENATE PANEL VOTES AGAINST TESTING SPACE DEFENSE
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee, spurning Administration efforts to loosen the interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, voted today to prohibit any tests that would violate the traditional view of the treaty.

description: b-After special charges of $29,079,000 for the quarter and year. The company said the special charges in the latest periods are associated with programs to restructure the operations of Peoples Drug Stores and with the closing of Imperial Tobacco's Quebec city plant. Imasco said its results include those of Imasco Enterprises Inc., the unit that incorporates the results of Canada Trustco Mortgage Co., from May 1, 1986. It said its equity in the net earnings of Imasco Enterprises was $25.8 million in the fourth quarter and $88.6 million for fiscal 1987. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: SOUTH SEAS NATION TELLS LIBYANS TO GO HOME By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF
description: Apparently in a move to distance his Government from Libya, the Prime Minister of this South Pacific nation said today that two Libyans who arrived to open an embassy would be sent away.

title: NEW FOCUS IN DAY CARE: CHILDREN WITH SNIFFLES
description: FOR children, coming down with the flu used to mean a day off from school to read comic books, watch reruns of ''My Little Margie'' and be the happy beneficiary of undivided maternal attention. But for some children, all that has changed. Today - when nearly half of the women with children 14 and under are working outside the home - many children with colds are spending the day in places like Chicken Soup, Rainbow Retreat and Grandma's House. These places are set up to take care of mildly ill children. Some are clinics; others are in hospitals, and some are in isolated areas of day-care centers. Most are operated privately for profit.

title: G.M. to Idle 30,000 At Six Facilities
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had scheduled temporary production halts at six of its North American assembly plants for various periods during the next two months. The halts will idle about 30,000 workers. Spokesmen said the latest round of temporary layoffs was a result of slower-than-expected demand for vehicles built at the affected plants.

title: RECITAL: STERN, WITH MCDONALD, AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: IT isn't every violinist who can perform in a concert hall that bears a commemorative plaque extolling his service to his nation's music, but Isaac Stern is able to enjoy that pleasure at Carnegie Hall, where he played a recital last evening. The violinist, who made his New York debut more than half a century ago, looks perfectly at home on the stage of Carnegie, which he helped save when its existence was threatened and whose remodeling he more recently oversaw. More importantly, he sounded at ease in a program that was mostly home territory to him: Beethoven, Schubert, Webern and Brahms.

title: Swede to Visit Reagan
description: Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson of Sweden has accepted an invitation from President Reagan to meet with him at the White House on Sept. 9, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, announced today.

GULF & MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fielding Questions On JWT
description: THERE were not that many questions from the floor at the end of the annual meeting yesterday of the JWT Group, but even the dozen fielded by Don Johnston, the chief executive, were a lot more than he is accustomed to.

title: STANDARD PACIFIC LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $4.8 million from the sale of a parcel of undeveloped land in San Diego County and also includes a provision for income taxes of $3,891,400. There is no provision for 1987 because Standard Pacific is now being operated as a master limited partnership and federal and state income taxes are not payable by the company itself. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 split of units to be distributed May 6.

Solin Wins Account For American Star Line

title: ARTHUR S. LOWELL
description: Arthur S. Lowell, a New York lawyer who was active in New York politics as a member of the City Fusion Party in the 1940's, died last Wednesday in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and was a resident of Tenafly, N.J.

title: KEYSTONE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $657,000 for the quarter and $1,097,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss Both year-ago periods are restated to reflect the adoption of certain pension accounting standards.

title: BERLIN, AT 99, A RECLUSIVE IMMORTAL
description: On Monday, Irving Berlin celebrates his 99th birthday, and he is most likely to do it in the reclusive manner in which he has lived for the last quarter-century, shielded from the public by a circle of family and friends that grows smaller each year simply by virtue of the fact that he has outlasted many of them. This year, Mr. Berlin even outlasted the American copyright on one of his most successful early compositions, depriving him of royalties from ''Alexander's Ragtime Band.''

title: Economic Scene; Costs to U.S. Of Leadership
description: CAN the United States continue to provide the leadership required to keep the world economic and financial system stable and growing? Paul Streeten, professor emeritus at Oxford University, speaking at Harvard University this week, expressed his anxiety that the ''Pax Americana,'' established at the end of World War II, has broken down, just as the century-old ''Pax Britannica'' did after World War I. To maintain stable world order, Mr. Streeten said, the dominant country needs to have four attributes: an export surplus; the ability to supply long-term capital to developing countries; industrial and technological supremacy, and the military strength to secure peace as the precondition for political stability and economic development.

title: Voice of the Poet Is Heard Again in England
description: Britain's leading contemporary poets celebrated the unabashed marketing of their Muse nationwide today as if it were the arrival of spring.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Doyle Alexander, free-agent pitcher, agreed to one-year contract. Ken Griffey, outfielder, was placed on 15-day disabled list and Darryl Motley, outfielder, was recalled from minor leagues. CINCINNATI (NL) - Nick Esasky, infielder, joined Reds' Nashville farm club for a 20-day injury rehabilitation program. DETROIT (AL) - Recalled Kirk Gibson, outfielder, and Willie Hernandez, relief pitcher, from rehabilitation assignment and reinstated them on active roster. Sent Orlando Mercado, catcher, to Albuquerque, a Dodger affiliate, in exchange for Balvino Galvez, minor league pitcher, who was assigned to Glens Falls. Also assigned Bryan Kelly, pitcher, outright to Toledo farm club. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Recalled Charlie O'Brien, catcher, from Denver to replace Paul Molitor, injured third baseman, on roster. Sent Mark Ciardi, pitcher, to Denver and reactivated John Henry Johnson, pitcher, from disabled list. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Placed Jose Uribe, shortstop, on disabled list. Recalled Mark Wasinger, infielder, from Phoenix. Rob Wilfong, infielder, signed Class AAA contract with Giants and was sent to Phoenix farm. COLLEGES CAL POLY-POMONA - Named Dave Bollwinkel men's head basketball coach. DEPAUW - Named Royce Waltman head basketball coach. LOUISIANA STATE - Announced that Armando Vega, men's gymnastics coach, was resigning to start a gymnastics school. Named Steve Carter assistant athletic director. NORTHERN MICHIGAN - Named Rick Comley director of athletics. TOLEDO - Hired Thomas Massimino as assistant basketball coach. FOOTBALL NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Signed nine free agents: Brian Careky and Dennis Gadbois, receivers; Darren Twombly and Tim Cahill, centers; Lonnie Hooker, running back-wide receiver; Rich Atkinson and Ray Williams, defensive backs; Jerry McCabe, linebacker, and Phil Mulcahy, defensive tackle. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Reached agreement with Lee Getz, guard, who will sign as free agent. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Signed Steve Lauter, safety, to free agent contract. SEATTLE (AFC) - Signed five free agents: Bob Maggs, center; Dan Dalrymple, guard; Daryl Smith, tackle; Mike Teifke and Dallas Smith, cornerbacks. SOCCER TACOMA (MISL) - Signed Steve Zungul to new two-year contract.

title: Girl, 13, Dies in Inwood Fire That Injures Her 2 Brothers
description: A 13-year-old girl died and her two brothers were injured when fire swept through their basement apartment at 157 Vermilyea Avenue in the Inwood section of Manhattan last night.

title: HART, CONCEDING ERROR, SAYS HE DID NOTHING IMMORAL
description: Gary Hart, seeking to quell the controversy that has engulfed his bid for the Presidency, declared yesterday that he had done nothing immoral and said, ''My campaign has just begun.''

title: BENJ FRANKLIN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank converted from mutual to stock form in December.

title: STAGE: PLAYS AT LA MAMA
description: STEVE BUSCEMI and Mark Boone Jr., who have performed together for the last four years, represent an intellectual East Village variant of classic male comedy teams. Mr. Buscemi, who had a starring role in the film ''Parting Glances,'' is a gaunt, wide-eyed waif whose thin-skinned, quivering sensitivity recalls the young Don Knotts. Mr. Boone, by contrast, is a stocky, bushy-haired endomorph who responds to the world with a bluff, instinctual aggressiveness.

title: O'BRIEN UNWINDS AND ADMITS TO TIGHTNESS
description: Ken O'Brien dropped his protective emotional bubble today as he conceded that he was ''tight'' in the Jets' staggering finish last season.

title: 1,000 TENANTS TAKE THEIR PROTEST TO CUOMO
description: More than a thousand angry, chanting tenants crowded the stately Capitol hallways outside Governor Cuomo's office today and banged on his carved wooden door until he agreed to meet with them on housing issues.

title: Featherbunking Ferry
description: This is about a ship's engineer and a licensed mate who don't have much to do, aboard an old ferry that now houses prisoners on work release. The Vernon C. Bain, flagship of the New York City jail system, sits in a few feet of water, moored at Rikers Island, permanently facing the Bronx. Her main engine and propellers have been deactivated. The Bain has been pressed into service by a harried Correction Department looking for all the beds it can find in the jail-overcrowding crisis. She will soon be joined by a sister ship.

title: PHONEMATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary item of $50,000 from reduction in taxes resulting from utilization of a tax credit.

title: 6 CHICAGO JUDGES TAKEN OFF BENCH
description: Six Cook County judges have been relieved of their duties for 60 days pending an investigation of trial testimony that implicated them in bribery schemes.

title: WORK BY BACON BRINGS $1.76 MILLION
description: Francis Bacon's ''Study for Portrait II,'' a brooding rendering of a man that was begun as a portrait of the artist's friend David Sylvester in 1953 and became a study of a pope, was sold for $1.76 million last night, a record at auction for the artist.

title: THESE FOOD QUESTIONS SEEM TOO SILLY TO ASK
description: YOU should be thinking about Star Wars, or your work or your mother, but no. You're pouring M & M's into your hand, and as you watch them settle into your sweaty palm you realize that there are more important matters in the world. Such as, how do they get that perfect little M on each M & M?

title: Top Andy Award Goes To Chiat's Pizza Hut
description: The grandest of the grand winners at the 23d annual Andy Awards Presentation last night at the Marriott Marquis Hotel was Chiat/Day, which took not only Best of Show, but also seven Andy's, three by each of its Los Angeles and New York offices and one by its San Francisco shop.

title: My Brother Might Kill Me
description: LEAD: The tragedy in Palm Bay, Fla., where a deranged man killed six people in a shooting spree, is only the latest story about people who run amok - stories that inspire fear in the families of psychotics. The Palm Bay killings are particularly painful, for all the warning signs were there but society did nothing.

title: Market Place; Bargains Seen In Auto Supply
description: SEVERAL recent trends in the auto supply industry should lead to strong investment opportunities despite a rise in competition from Japanese companies, many experts believe.

title: TREANSCRIPT OF HART'S REMARKS TO NEWSPAPER PUBLISHER'S GROUP
description: Following is a transcript of remarks yesterday by former Senator Gary Hart to the American Newspaper Publishers Association in New York City, as recorded by The New York Times, on reports of his association with a young woman in Washington last weekend:

title: THE ISSUE IS NOT MORALITY: IT'S CANDOR
description: By this morning, there won't be too many voters who aren't aware that Gary Hart at least had dinner with an attractive model while his wife was out of town. Frankly, whether the voters consider this important information or not, the story has reached such a level of media saturation that it will affect the outcome of the Presidential race - and perhaps the way politics is reported.

title: Manhattan Lawyer Newspaper Debut
description: A preview issue of Manhattan Lawyer has just been mailed to the island's 35,000 lawyers free. Should they be willing to pay $47.50 for a subscription to the weekly newspaper, then they will be regular subscribers when publication begins in earnest in September.

title: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXCERPTS FROM SECORD'S TESTIMONY AT IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS
description: Following are excerpts from Richard V. Secord's testimony yesterday at the opening session of the Congressional hearings in Washington on the Iran-contra affair, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: INTEREST RATES DROP MODESTLY
description: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday as the Treasury sold $10 billion of three-year notes, the first of three note and bond auctions this week.

title: COMMERCE CLEARING HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEMOCRATS VOICE DOUBT ABOUT HART
description: Democratic politicians said today that Gary Hart's assertion that he had done nothing ''immoral'' last weekend would help keep his candidacy alive but had not resolved doubts that the incident had raised about his judgment.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Willcox & Gibbs Fills Two Major Positions
description: Willcox & Gibbs Inc., a Manhattan-based company that has turned itself around in the last decade, announced yesterday that Sidney B. Becker had resigned as chairman and would be replaced by John K. Ziegler, who had been president and chief executive.

title: 2 of 3 Bond Offerings From Nevada Are Set
description: The State of Nevada received bids yesterday for three bond issues totaling about $163 million and awarded two of the issues.

title: British Reserves Soar
description: Britain's gold and currency reserves rose $2.9 billion in April for the second-largest increase ever, the Treasury said today. The rise, which follows March's $1.8 billion increase, was expected to prompt the Bank of England to lower interest rates, financial analysts said. The rise was higher than the increase of $1.5 billion to $2 billion that had been expected.

title: POSTAL SERVICE PROPOSES INCREASING RATES FOR MAIL
description: The cost of mailing a letter would rise to 25 cents sometime next year, and most other postage rates would also rise, under a new rate structure proposed today by the United States Postal Service.

title: MODEL CALLS OFF NEWS CONFERENCE ON LINK TO HART
description: Donna Rice, the Miami actress and model whose weekend visit to Gary Hart's Washington home has cast a cloud over his Presidential campaign, canceled a news conference today, leaving unanswered many questions raised by her detailed description of her relationship with the former Senator.

title: HOUSE VOTE AUTHORIZES $5 BILLION FOR F.S.L.I.C.
description: The House passed a $5 billion rescue package tonight for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the depleted insurance fund of the savings and loan industry.

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $85,000.

title: BALL IS IN ALBERT'S COURT, NOT JOHNSON'S
description: Perhaps the fundamental difference between reporters and gossip columnists is that reporters generally traffic in facts while gossip columnists are content with rumors. Last Saturday, NBC Sports didn't recognize that difference.

title: LPL INVESTMENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago results include charges related to the acquisition of Times Fiber Communications Inc. on Dec. 31, 1985, and the restructuring of operations.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $1,125,000, and also included property transactions, primarily the sale of 10 hotels to a real estate partnership on April 2, which produced a pretax gain of $16.2 million; year-earlier pretax gains from property sales were $716,000. c-Net loss

title: COMPUTER & COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $59,000. c-Net loss The company said year-ago quarter results include a $14,191,000 writeoff of assets.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TREATMENT & TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a tax credit of $276,000. The company said the 1986 results included a $2,131,000 charge for non- recurring merger-related expenses.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Bring-In Breakfast If you think Mother would appreciate breakfast in bed but you can't be the one who shows up with the tray and flowers, there are services that can help, and it's not too late to place the order.

title: NCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter results includes 1 cent a share from an extraordinary tax benefit. The year-ago first quarter includes a $349,000 gain related to the sale of a non-maxcim business and $535,000 of non-maxcim revenue.

title: FED OFFICIAL CITES FEARS OF INFLATION
description: The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve said today that fears of revived inflation prompted its recent decision to raise interest rates, a move recognized as posing some risk to housing and other rate-sensitive sectors of the economy.

title: APRIL'S MORTGAGE RATES REACHED DOUBLE DIGITS
description: Mortgage rates continued to climb last month, reaching double-digit territory for the first time since last summer. Some analysts called the run-up a short-term phenomenon, while others said rates could move still higher.

title: Morgan Plans Drug Testing
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, one of Wall Street's largest and more prestigious investment banks, will announce today a new policy of mandatory drug testing for all existing as well as incoming employees worldwide, officials at the company said yesterday.

title: White South Africa Votes
description: Today's whites-only election in South Africa is actually a racial plebiscite meant to prove that President P.W. Botha still speaks for the three million Afrikaners who dominate a country of 35 million. If there were any chance that Mr. Botha's National Party might lose, there'd be no election. Small wonder that the vote is scorned as a farce by 24 million disfranchised blacks, some of whom called on whites to boycott.

title: Something to Smile About
description: Kiss tinsel teeth goodbye. A new system of orthodontic braces made of clear industrial sapphire was introduced yesterday. Its developers hope it will replace the stainless steel, plastic or ceramic brackets that are worn by one million new dental patients each year.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: FOR several years after my mother's death, I felt about Mother's Day the way I suppose recently divorced people feel about Valentine's Day. It seemed to be an organized effort by the immediate world to spit in my eye, and I gladly would have set fire to every card in every card rack in every card shop in town. In time, the rage abated, and what remained in its place was an emotionless distance. Mother's Day became much like Passover, a holiday that people like me did not celebrate.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
Investor Caution Helps Dollar to a Small Rise
description: A round of profit taking on foreign currencies and a cautionary move by investors into dollars yesterday pushed the dollar slightly higher in world currency markets. But dealers did not attach much significance to the move because trading activity was extremely light.

title: Measles Strikes Dartmouth Again
description: A second wave of measles has hit Dartmouth College, putting more students in the infirmary, crippling athletic teams and wiping out the school's sports schedule for the rest of the week.

title: New Ranger Candidate
description: There's a new name in the derby for Ranger head coach: Gene Ubriaco. He is the coach of the Baltimore Skipjacks, a minor league affiliate of the Pittsburgh Penguins in the American Hockey League. A source familiar with the situation, said that Ubriaco was in New York yesterday afternoon for talks with the Ranger general manager, Phil Esposito. This was confirmed by a source in the Rangers' organization, who also confirmed that Ubriaco and Gino Gaspiarini, coach of University of North Dakota, had emerged as the top two candidates for the job.

title: Nelson Denies a Knick Offer
description: Insisting that he ''never discussed or was offered'' the Knick coaching job, Don Nelson, the Milwaukee Bucks' coach, indicated today that even if the Knicks wanted him as head coach he did not believe New York and Milwaukee would be able to strike a compensation deal. Nelson has three years remaining on his five-year contract.

title: BLACK HILLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,248,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss on extinguishment of debt of $3,048,000. c-After net from discontinued operation of $2,212,000. The latest first quarter's net from continuing operations is after a gain of $33,099,000, or 85 cents a share, from the sale of Greyhound's bus operations. Revenue represents the combined revenue, which includes the unconsolidated Financial Group of $95,377,000, for the latest first quarter, and $112,045,000, for the year-ago period.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BLACKS GO ON STRIKE ON EVE OF WHITES-ONLY ELECTIONS
description: More than half a million black workers and students stayed home in protest today on the eve of a national election for whites only.

title: KEY RATES
MATTHEWS & WRIGHT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter per share earnings reflect the company's initial public offering of 1.5 million shares in August 1986.

title: OLD REPUBLIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $7,487,023 and $5,576,141 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Dow Rises By 51.85, To 2,338.07
description: The stock market moved sharply higher yesterday as investors gained confidence from a firming dollar and a slight drop in interest rates.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
Some Fruit Fancies
description: LEAD: IN any account of fruits, reference must be made to versatility, nutritional adequacy and general ease of eating. These qualities take on deeper meaning with the weather beginning to right itself and the diminishing need to bake fruits into pies, tarts and other cool-weather fancies.

title: PULLMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $1,221,000 and $2,115,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: COUNTRY WIDE TRANSPORT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MS CARRIERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. HEALTH AGENCY MAKES SMOKING BAN TOTAL IN ALL OFFICES
description: A ban on all smoking was issued today throughout the buildings occupied nationwide by the Department of Health and Human Services, the Federal government's largest agency.

title: PAN AM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOR YOU-KNOW-WHO
description: 1.Pins With a Past Susan Kramer makes nostalgic pins from Victorian illustrations. She lacquers them and then adds decorative touches with multicolored rhinestones. The pin shown here, the face of a pretty young woman under a jeweled hat, costs $22.50. The collection, which might have been designed especially for Mother's Day, also includes pins illustrated with cats, flowers and full-length figures. The jewelry is at Jenny B. Goode, 1194 Lexington Avenue (between 81st and 82d Streets) and 11 East 10th Street. 2.Frame for a Favorite This elegant silver-plated frame will enhance a favorite photograph. It was made in France for Van Cleef & Arpels and costs $25 at Planned Parenthood's gift sale, which begins today. At the Planned Parenthood Thrift Shop, 324 East 59th Street, and the Second Time Around Thrift Shop, 220 East 23d Street. 3.For Dressing Tables Here is a dramatic addition to a dressing table: a brass-plated mirror from Birmingham, England. The mirror is rimmed with a choice of faux lapis, ivory or coral. For $18.50 in cosmetics accessories on the first floor at Bonwit Teller, 4 East 57th Street. 4.First-Class Service Give Mother a royal welcome to her day - breakfast in bed on this pretty basket tray. It comes with tea and all the trappings: a china teapot, marmalade and Welsh cookies. Also included are bath soap, a chintz pillow and a bouquet of dried flowers. The price is $75 at the Ultimate Basket, 140 West 83d Street. For telephone orders, call 212-877-3291. There is an $8.50 delivery fee in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, and a $10 shipping fee elsewhere in the country in time for Mother's Day.

title: EMBASSY WORKER SEIZED IN MOSCOW
description: The Soviet police detained an Austrian babysitter who works for the chief of security at the United States Embassy and held her for three hours Saturday, asserting that she had been part of an ''anti-Soviet conspiracy,'' American officials said today.

title: The Unspoken Law
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW HOUSES DON'T FINISH REBUILDING OF BOMBED NEIGHBORHOOD
description: The presence of purple pansies is not unusual in springtime here. But on this particular stretch of road in West Philadelphia, their appearance, along with muddy orange basketballs and green garden hoses, is not just a harbinger of spring but of a more profound determination to renew.

title:
Books;
A Tortured Fate
description: LEAD: THIS FAR AND NO MORE: A True Story.By Andrew Malcolm. 247 pages. Times

title: Maxicare Foils Embezzlement Try
description: Maxicare Health Plan Inc. said it hads thwarted an attempt to embezzle nearly $7.6 million from the health maintenance organization company. It said that one man had been arrested in San Diego by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the case, and added that the suspect was not a Maxicare employee.

title: Sales Up At Black Companies
description: The nation's top black-owned businesses, particularly automobile dealers, generally enjoyed a strong gain in sales last year, but a number of the companies faced greater competition or reduced their work forces.

title: Libya Signals Acceptance of P.L.O. Reunification
description: Libya allowed the main Palestine Liberation Organization office in Tripoli to reopen today, senior P.L.O. officials here said, four years after Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi closed it down and began backing challengers to Yasir Arafat's leadership.

title: IMMUNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $8,056 and a tax credit of $72,000.

description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $519,000 resulting from the completion of an initial public offering of CCC Franchising offset by the loss from the writedown of the company's investment in CCC Franchising to its market value based on its subsequent sale. c-Net income Year-ago results were reclassified to conform to 1987 presentation. The company said that during the latest fourth quarter, the writedown of its investment in CCC Franchising Corp. resulted in a charge of about $600,000. In addition, various other adjustments, affecting primarily selling, general and administrative expenses were recorded in the quarter, which reduced results by about $90,000.

title: People
description: * Ronald Lawner has been named executive vice president at HBM/ Creamer, Boston.

title: Upton E. Liptrott, 83, Dies; Ex-Chief of American Banker
description: Upton E. Liptrott, retired president and chief executive officer of The American Banker, died Monday in Sarasota, Fla., where he was living in retirement. He was 83 years old.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $181,600 related to a prepayment penalty on a Federal Home Loan Bank advance.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,399,000 for the quarter and $4,050,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $532,000 and $1,028,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: World Bank Offers Environmental Projects
description: The World Bank, long accused by legislators, conservation groups and the Reagan Administration of financing environmentally destructive projects, announced sweeping new measures today to protect the environments of developing countries.

title: AMNESTY PROGRAM GETS OFF TO SLOW START AT CENTER IN HOUSTON
description: Arturo Perez has been carefully saving his pay stubs ever since he waded across the Rio Grande from Mexico to Texas six years ago. Today they helped provide the documentation that could make him a legal resident here for the first time.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,672,000. The company said the latest quarter charge for discontinued operations relates to a discontinued operation of Minet Holdings Plc, in which the company has a 25 percent equity interest. Results for 1986 have been restated for poolings of interests. Share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated for a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 20, 1986.

title: CALIFORNIA MICRO DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $350,000 and $567,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: FOR ALABAMIAN, L.I.'S GARBAGE IS DREAM GONE BAD
description: What Lowell Harrelson wants, everyone has. But now that he owns it, no one will take it.

title: MEDICAL CARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $318,000 for the latest quarter and $165,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Board Excuses Student From Dissecting a Frog
description: A 15-year-old high school sophomore who refused to dissect a frog will not be forced to complete the assignment, but a notation about the controversy will be made in her records, school board officials said Monday.

title: BRINTEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DEMOCRATS REACH ACCORD ON BUDGET
description: Senate Democrats, seeking to gain enough votes to approve a budget for the 1988 fiscal year, agreed today on a compromise designed to force President Reagan to support tax increases in exchange for more military spending.

title: DANAHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,373,000 and $1,567,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: THOMAS L. HAYES, BELEAGUERED JUSTICE OF VERMONT COURT
description: Justice Thomas L. Hayes of the Vermont Supreme Court died today after a long battle with lung cancer. He was 60 years old.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CLC OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Senator Lugar Comes Back From Dejection
description: In the two years that Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana ran the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, his world and his reputation expanded at an exhilarating pace.

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Operas in the Park To Open With 'Tosca'
description: The Metropolitan Opera's 21st season of free concerts will open with a production of Puccini's ''Tosca'' at Central Park's Great Lawn on June 16, featuring Placido Domingo, Marilyn Zschau and Sherrill Milnes. For the first time in its summer series, the Met will offer performances in New Jersey - two in Stanhope, one in Jersey City and one in New Brunswick.

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL PETE reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a charge of $5,556,000 relating to the writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: Dance: African Troupes
description: DANCE AFRICA served up a typically joyous and absorbing feast of African and Afro-American dance and music on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. It was also the 10th anniversary of the festival, founded by the academy. May it live forever.

title: Trade Measure Gains in Senate
description: The Senate's key trade committee today approved major provisions of a bill that will force President Reagan to retaliate when countries violate trade agreements with the United States.

title: Alexander Given Pact
description: Doyle Alexander, the free-agent pitcher, has returned to the Atlanta Braves. General Manager Bobby Cox said that Alexander agreed to a one-year contract and that the Braves have an option to sign him for a second year.

title: CLOWNING AROUND AS A CURRICULUM
description: It's not all applause and cotton candy, you understand. They call it circus boot camp: six days a week, from 8 A.M. to 10 P.M., you work your droopy drawers off, and the curriculum is demanding. You have to learn the pratfalls: not only the banana-peel fall and the seat-drop fall, but such difficult refinements as No. 108, which requires you to flip over and land on your back without permanently crippling yourself.

title: TAX INCOME DROPS IN 10 STATES WHILE OVERALL REVENUE RISES
description: State tax collections plummeted 11 percent in North Dakota last year while nine other states also had declines in tax revenue, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: NEW PEACE EFFORT IN NORTH AFRICA
description: Morocco and Algeria have agreed to start talks to resolve the 11-year-old war in Western Sahara at the personal urging of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia.

title: THEODORE SHABAD, A TIMES EDITOR AND A GEOGRAPHER, IS DEAD AT 65
description: Theodore Shabad, who nurtured a childhood fascination for geography into parallel careers in academia and as a foreign correspondent and editor for The New York Times, died of a heart attack Monday night while riding home from The Times in a taxi. He was 65 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Reel Life

title: THE STRUGGLE TO RECRUIT FOSTER PARENTS
description: Last year, with a crisis emerging in its foster-care system, New York City began a large-scale advertising campaign to attract new foster parents.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,540,000 and $1,360,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively, and the year-ago quarter also includes a loss from discontinued operations.

title: SECORD ASSERTS NORTH USED PROFITS TO PAY DRUG AGENTS
description: The first witness in the Iran-contra hearings, Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, retired, said today that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North had used profits from the Iran arms sales to pay employees of the Drug Enforcement Administration for one of his operations.

title: HADSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the rise in revenue was largely due to growth in its natural gas marketing operations.

title: FARM CREDIT SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Farm Credit System said the latest first quarter losses were after provisions for loan losses of $115 million and $267 million for the year-ago period.

description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $847,000 for the quarter and $2,974,000 for the year. The company converted to the stock from the mutual form of ownership on Jan. 9.

title: Shaller Rubin Has New Shop
description: The old Shaller Rubin agency has been dissolved, and Mel Rubin, its 64-year-old chairman, two other principals and an outsider have joined together to create Rubin Reid Noto & Ehrenthal. It has $24 million in billings from accounts that have also been brought in from the old shop.

title: The U.N. Today: May 6, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ADVANCED LOGIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $500,000. c-Includes tax credits of $348,000 and $392,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: California Bonds Yield Up to 7 7/8%
description: The California Department of Water Resources is offering $100 million of water-system revenue bonds for a Central Valley project with a maximum yield of 7 7/8 percent for an issue due in 2023.

title: RACE QUOTAS VOIDED AT BROOKLYN HOUSING COMPLEX
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that private landlords cannot use quotas to limit the number of tenants from minority groups, even when such a policy is meant to achieve or preserve integration among the tenants.

title: MEESE IS SUBJECT OF NEW INQUIRY AT JUSTICE DEPT.
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, the Justice Department's top official, is being investigated by a unit of the department with regard to the ethics and legality of his links to the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor.

title: 4 SEVERE CRITICS OF THE POLICE APPEAR ON RECRUITING POSTER
description: In a marketing twist that might make Madison Avenue proud, the New York City Police Department has mounted a recruiting drive that uses a picture of some of the department's harshest critics on a poster urging people to join the force.

title: BRONX MERCHANT FACES CHARGES OF CHECK FRAUD
description: A 44-year-old Bronx delicatessen owner has been indicted on charges of embezzling $1.1 million in city checks meant to go to hotels that house homeless families, officials said yesterday.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REMARKS BY PANEL CHAIRMEN
description: Following are excerpts from remarks yesterday by Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, and Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, chairmen of the committees investigating the Iran-contra affair, at the opening session of the hearings in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: Inouye Remarks

title: NOW, AIR DECONTROL IN EUROPE
description: Francoise Cernesson, a secretary at a shipping company, said she never used to even consider going to Nice just for a weekend because the train took so long and air fares were so expensive.

title: ALIENS LEAVE THE SHADOWS AS YEAR OF AMNESTY DAWNS
description: Thousands of illegal aliens stepped out of the shadows yesterday, lining up at Government centers around the country to apply for legal status under the new immigration law.

description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said its board approved spending $215 million to buy all the common and preferred stock of the United States Plywood Corporation. It also approved spending about $265 million on two capital improvement projects.

description: The Phillips Petroleum Company of Bartlesville, Okla., had wanted to distribute through the Washington offices of all members of Congress more than a million copies of a booklet containing the Constitution of the United States and the Declaration of Independence.

title: CARMIKE CINEMAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MAY 6, 1987
description: MARKETS Interest rates fell modestly as the Treasury sold $10 billion of three-year notes, the first of three auctions this week. After the sale, prices of notes and bonds rose modestly. Experts said that trading was affected by attractive yields and rumors of heavy Japanese participation. The firming of the market and the decline in rates prodded stock prices upward. [ Page D1. ] Fears of revived inflation led the Fed to raise rates, the central bank's vice chairman said. The official, Manuel Johnson, said that higher rates posed some risks but that the increases need not last for long. [ D6. ] The Dow Jones industrial average surged 51.85 points, its fourth-best point gain ever, to 2,338.07. Volume was up sharply to 192.3 million shares, with blue chips and technology and pharmaceutical stocks leading the way. [ D1. ] The dollar was slightly higher in world markets, but dealers did not attach much significance to the move because trading activity was extremely light. Gold fell $4.25 an ounce, to $458.25. [ D17. ] Silver futures were volatile again, climbing more than 30 cents an ounce, then falling almost 70 cents before steadying to close down 32 to 38 cents. Gold futures also fell. [ D17. ] THE ECONOMY The House passed a $5 billion F.S.L.I.C. rescue package, after rejecting a $15 billion package backed by the Democratic leadership. The defeat of the larger package was a major lobbying victory for the industry's biggest trade group. [ D1. ] Mortgage rates continued to climb, reaching double-digits last month for the first time since last summer. Some analysts said rates would ease; others said they could move higher. [ D1. ] Auto sales grew stronger in the final 10 days of April, finishing 0.3 percent below an unusually strong 1986 period. Analysts said the effects were fading of the new tax law, which cut deeply into sales early in the year by creating a buying surge late last year. [ D5. ] Senate Democrats agreed on a 1988 budget that would force the President to support tax increases in exchange for more military spending. The White House said it opposed the plan. [ A33. ] COMPANIES Burlington said it might seek control of Dominion Textile, Canada's largest textile producer and a partner with the investor Asher B. Edelman in a takeover offer for Burlington. Burlington, the nation's largest textile manufacturer disclosed its plans in a suit filed in Montreal. [ D1. ] The foreclosure of the Herald Center is sought in a suit filed by a mortgage company, raising the possibility that the lender might seek to acquire the troubled Manhattan shopping mall. [ D2. ] The chairman of E. F. Hutton Group will resign today, officials at the firm said. Robert Fomon has held the post for 16 years. [ D2. ] Citicorp is buying the other half of its Australian brokerage subsidiary, Clarke Vickers. [ D4. ] Marvin Davis, the oilman, wants to buy Spectradyne, the leading supplier of pay-per-view movie systems to hotels and motels. The deal would be worth $353 million at current market value. [ D4. ] Black-owned businesses had strong gains in sales last year, led by auto dealerships. But a number of companies faced greater competition or reduced their work forces. [ D5. ] Morgan Stanley plans mandatory drug tests for all employees, officials at the investment bank said. Current and new employees worldwide would be affected. [ D19. ] TECHNOLOGY A pall is hanging over the robotics industry, and a trade show in Chicago did little to dispel it, as Cincinnati Milacron, Westinghouse, I.B.M. and General Electric stayed away. [ D8. ] Auto makers are turning their attention to four-wheel steering, which would be a boon to parallel parkers. Mazda will offer a model this fall with rear wheels that turn side-to-side. Advances. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Has the ''Pax Americana'' broken down, or is the U.S. still capable of world economic leadership? Two experts on international economics differ. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Good opportunities for makers of auto parts are resulting from the longer road life of cars and increased orders from the Big 3, according to many analysts. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: HERE'S HOW TO FEED THEM
description: THERE cannot be many men in 1987 who call home at 5:30 in the afternoon and say to their wives: ''I'm bringing the boss home for dinner at 6:30.'' Not many wives are at home these days. Men who call their wives - at the office more often than at home - and surprise them with company for dinner, might be told a number of things, some unprintable. Should a wife say, ''Guess who's coming to dinner?'' to her husband, the results would probably be the same.

description: Super/Moto Cross is the latest magazine title being offered by the Petersen Publishing Company, the leisure time specialists of Los Angeles. The magazine, to be published six times a year, joins Motorcyclist and Dirt Rider in the Petersen stable. It will cover the fields of motocross and cross-country racing. The first issue, which is already out, carries 20 pages of advertising that sold for $3,200 for a four-color page and $2,000 for a black and white.

title: Decision Reached on Bakker
description: State leaders of the Assemblies of God have reached a decision on whether to recommend that the national church accept the resignation of the Rev. Jim Bakker, the former leader of the PTL television ministry, and the Rev. Richard Dortch, who replaced him as host of the PTL Club program. But the recommendation will not be made public immediately, a spokesman said today. Mr. Bakker and Mr. Dortch resigned from the Pentecostal denomination March 19, the same day Mr. Bakker stepped down as head of the PTL after admitting an extramarital sexual encounter.
