More Than Scandal: News
description: Gary Hart pleaded guilty yesterday to bad judgment, the only charge growing out of his weekend encounter with Donna Rice that is indisputably a matter of public concern. He also denied any immorality, and while that may interest some people, it is primarily a matter between Mr. Hart and his conscience.

title: Roger McDowell: Looking Better
description: It doesn't happen very often, but Roger McDowell is one of those rare athletes who grow in stature while recuperating from surgery.

title: JACK ROMANN, AIDED PIANISTS AS REPRESENTATIVE OF BALDWIN
description: Jack Romann, director of the concert and artist department of the Baldwin Piano Company, died yesterday morning at Cabrini Hospital. He was 59 years old and had had encephalitis and meningitis.

title: FORECLOSURE SUIT FILED ON HEARLD CENTER MALL
description: A Los Angeles-based mortgage company has filed suit in New York State Supreme Court to obtain foreclosure on Herald Center, raising the possibility that the lender might seek to acquire the troubled Manhattan shopping mall.

title: Article 387487 -- No Title
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed a $22.7 billion executive budget that featured a host of improvements in services for New Yorkers. He called it ''the best budget that I have presented in the 10 years I have been Mayor.''

title: White House Dollars
description: ''It is pretty nasty, you know, to pick up $20,000 for arranging trips into the White House for photo ops,'' Donald Regan, former chief of staff, said the other day. He was referring to David Fischer, a former Presidential aide who was paid that amount monthly by a fund-raising organization just to arrange picture-taking sessions with President Reagan for donors to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: 3D HELEN HAYES AWARDS FOR WASHINGTON DRAMA
description: Out-of-town celebrities joined Washington's greasepaint crowd at the Kennedy Center on Monday night for the third annual Helen Hayes Awards Ceremony honoring artistic achievement in the Washington professional theater.

title: BY A 33-0 VOTE, COUNCIL ADOPTS RAISES FOR ITSELF
description: New York City Council members voted yesterday to raise their own salaries and those of several other elected city officials. But in a replay of a similar vote four years ago, they rejected an annual $30,000 limit on their outside business and professional income.

title: MEMORIES OF HINDENBURG CRASH ARE STILL VIVID 50 YEARS LATER
description: She was three city blocks long, but her final pass over Manhattan was so low that the well-heeled passengers waving from open windows in her vast silver belly came almost face to face with news photographers atop the Empire State Building. To millions of Depression-era Americans she seemed as glamorous as a movie star, and people cried when the Hindenburg blew up that fatal day 50 years ago.

title: Swaggart Column Dropped Over Copying of Story
description: A weekly column by the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, the television evangelist, has been dropped by a Baton Rouge newspaper after it learned that major portions of an Easter Sunday column had been copied from a news service article, the newspaper's editor said yesterday.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: SINCE cancer has changed from a topic nobody talked about to one that everyone talks about, many people have the impression that cancer rates are rising rapidly and that we live in a sea of carcinogens. Hardly a week goes by without a report that the foods we eat, the beverages we drink or the air we breathe contain yet another cancer-causing substance.

title: Kerr-McGee To Sell Unit
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation, the diversified energy concern, said today that it was selling its uranium division. The company's chairman, Frank McPherson, said the company would put more emphasis on its chemical and petroleum divisions. The division includes the

title: OLD AND NEW FOOD WAYS FROM THE SOUTH
description: THE South is justifiably famous for its expansive hospitality. That sense of warmth and welcome is as much a part of several new cookbooks devoted to the Southern table as are recipes for traditional and updated Southern specialties. Smiling hosts with platters of roasted meats, bowls of salads and rice and beans, trays of cookies and pitchers of lemonade seem to beckon from every page. The authors do their best to make mouths water. What are often home-style recipes tend to be uncomplicated, requiring no sophisticated techniques. The difficult part is duplicating the atmosphere of warmth.

title: ACCORD REPORTED TO EASE WAR RISK
description: The State Department said today that American and Soviet negotiators in Geneva had reached agreement on a draft accord to establish risk-reduction centers through which each country could notify the other of missile tests, military exercises and the like.

title: RED WINGS THWART OILERS WITH STEFAN
description: Greg Stefan, making his first appearance in six games after a run-in with Coach Jacques Demers, turned in a strong performance in goal as the Red Wings stunned the Edmonton Oilers, 3-1, tonight in the opener of their playoff series. The second game of the four-of-seven-game Campbell Conference finals will be played here Thursday night.

title: Hutton's Chairman Expected to Resign
description: Robert Fomon, chairman of the E. F. Hutton Group for 16 years, is scheduled to announce today that he is resigning from the position and as a director of the brokerage house, officials at the firm said yesterday.

title: APPEALS COURT DELAYS RULES ON SMOKING
description: After weeks of mounting anxiety among smokers and anticipation among nonsmokers, it turns out that broad new restrictions on smoking in New York State will not go into effect on Thursday, as had been planned.

FOR MANY, ISSUE OF TRUTHFULNESS OUTWEIGHS THAT OF FIDELITY
description: Many voters in the state that holds the first Presidential primary in 1988 seem ready to overlook the possibility that Gary Hart has been unfaithful to his wife, or, if he was, to forgive him for it. They think the more important question is whether he told the public the truth.

description: THE city has signed its first leases for upgraded factory space in the Brooklyn Army Terminal, where $33 million is being spent to provide plants for manufacturers who have been squeezed out of other parts of the city by soaring rents.

description: Two men who died in a trailer fire last Saturday after they shot at law-enforcement officers have been positively identified as escapes inmates of a California prison, officials said today.

title: Four N.C.A.A. Finalists
description: Four men were named yesterday as finalists in the N.C.A.A.'s search for a new executive director. The candidates are John W. Ryan, president of Indiana University; Harvey Schiller, Southeastern Conference commissioner; Richard D. Schultz, Virginia athletic director, and John R. Davis, associate director of athletics at Oregon State and the immediate past N.C.A.A. president. A decision is expected by mid-June on a successor to Walter Byers, who is retiring after 36 years as the only executive director the N.C.A.A. has had.

description: The African National Congress has presented a small group of black South Africans who have asserted that the South African police, through torture, threats or the offer of employment, recruited them to infiltrate the congress.

title: The Wrong Focus
description: Was it bad judgment for Gary Hart, a Presidential candidate already rumored to be ''a womanizer,'' to conduct himself in such a way that he might appear to have spent a night with a woman who was not his wife? Of course it was.

description: James Ramseur, one of four youths shot by Bernhard H. Goetz on a Manhattan subway train two years ago, refused yesterday to be sworn as a witness against Mr. Goetz and was held in contempt.

title: CORRECTIONS

title: IN BRITAIN, FEW WOMEN ACHIEVE LEADERSHIP POSTS
description: Ever since she was 3 years old, Emma Nicholson has wanted to be a Member of Parliament. But though her mother's family has had M.P.'s from the 17th century onward, her quest has not been easy. In 1979, Miss Nicholson, a computer systems designer and longtime Conservative, was chosen by a local party committee to run for a seat in a Labor bastion. As might be expected, she lost.

title: ORIOLE MISSES NO-HITTER IN 9TH

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AMERICANS are quick to accept new foods, from herbs and spices to the latest in olive oils, mustards and vinegars. Not long ago, basil was a novelty in this country and shallots were a rarity outside professional kitchens. Fresh chervil, a staple in French kitchens for generations, is now making its mark here, both as a flavoring agent and as a garnish (it is an incredibly easy herb to grow in a small garden or in a windowsill pot).

description: A full-scale trade war between the United States and Japan would hit Australia's troubled agricultural and mining industries, the Minister for Trade, John S. Dawkins, said today. Mr. Dawkins said in a radio interview that Japan might give way to pressure and buy American coal and beef at higher prices, reducing its traditional imports from Australia. Japan and the United States are Australia's biggest markets for coal and beef.

Reservations: 307-7171.

The light-sensitive photoresists are used in the manufacture of chips and printed circuit boards, making it possible to develop the image of circuitry on silicon much as a photograph is developed on paper.

description: SUCH a shame about the baked potato. Most other vegetables cook spectacularly in a microwave oven, but the baked potato is a bust, if by baked potato you mean something with a crunchy skin and mealy, fluffy insides (but if all you want is a quick starch fix, well then, be my guest).

title: Horner Debut Stylish
description: Bob Horner made his debut in Japanese baseball in fine style yesterday - he hit a two-run homer to help the Yakult Swallows defeat the Hanshin Tigers, 5-3. Playing before a crowd of 52,000 at Jingu Stadium in Tokyo, the 29-year-old former Atlanta Braves infielder walked and beat out an infield hit before hitting his homer.

Richardson Files Suit
description: Micheal Ray Richardson filed a medical malpractice suit yesterday, claiming a doctor gave him improper treatment for drug use, resulting in a relapse that brought about his being banned from the National Basketball Association. The suit was filed in Superior Court in Hackensack, N.J., against Dr. Russell Ferstandig of Ridgewood. It charges that as a result of malpractice, Richardson suffered a relapse, was banned from playing in the league and lost $725,000 in salary. Dr. Ferstandig denied the charges of malpractice, adding that he has not yet seen the court papers. He treated Richardson after the former N.B.A. all-star was discharged from the Van Nuys Clinic in Van Nuys, Calif., on Jan. 15, 1986. The player spent 17 days at the clinic and was to receive couseling or psychological treatment to prevent a recurrence of drug abuse. He was banned from the league on Feb. 25, 1986 after testing positive for cocaine use.

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dole's 'Bicentennial Minutes'
description: In commemoration of both the 100th Congress and the bicentennial of the Constitution, Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, has been reading what he calls a ''Bicentennial Minute'' almost every day since the start of the session. Here are two: Mr. President, this chamber has witnessed many dramatic events in the 128 years that it has served as the Senate's meeting place. The joys and the sorrows that engage our nation invariably make their way to this room. One of the most heart-rending moments in the Senate's entire history occurred here 126 years ago today.

title: Baby M Grandparents Denied In a Plea for Visiting Rights
description: The parents of Mary Beth Whitehead cannot visit Baby M until after the State Supreme Court rules on her appeal in the custody case, the court ruled today.

TRUMP OFFERS TO SELL TRACT TO KEEP NBC IN NEW YORK
description: Donald J. Trump, the developer, has proposed to sell his $95 million tract of land on the Upper West Side to the New York State Urban Development Corporation for $1 as part of a plan to keep the National Broadcasting Company from moving to New Jersey, according to officials familiar with the plan.

title: FOR ASIAN-AMERICANS, ACQUITTAL IN RIGHTS CASE AROUSES OUTRAGE AND FEAR
description: The acquittal of a former automobile worker last Friday in the beating death of a Chinese-American five years ago has outraged Asian-Americans here and elsewhere who viewed the case as emblematic of racial discrimination against Asians in the United States.

title: Sonics' Hearing Put Off to May 18
description: A hearing scheduled for Friday involving two Seattle SuperSonic players arrested in a Houston nightclub last weekend has been rescheduled for May 18, court officials said. The hearing date was changed so the players, Kevin Williams and Dale Ellis, could return to Seattle for Thursday and Saturday playoff games against the Houston Rockets.

title: BUSINESS AS USUAL AT MEXICO BORDER
description: At the busiest illegal crossing points on the United States border with Mexico it was business as usual today, with both the Border Patrol and immigrants playing their accustomed roles in the game of hide and seek that is the routine here.

title: 'GRACELAND' TOUR EXPANDS
description: PAUL SIMON has announced that he and 24 South African musicians will perform nine additional ''Graceland '87'' concerts in eight American cities. The proceeds from the concerts, which begin June 15 in Atlanta and end July 2 at Madison Square Garden, are to be divided equally among three classifications of charities. One third is to go to a fund created by the Rev. Allan Boesak, a South African anti-apartheid leader, to aid detained and imprisoned children in South Africa. Another third is to be donated to the United Negro College Fund. The remaining third is to be awarded to a municipal charity in each concert city, a charity dedicated to aiding hungry, homeless, abused and disadvantaged children. In New York, the money is to provide medically equipped vans to provide free health care to homeless children.

title: PIANO: 5-HOUR WORK
description: WHEN music became restless some three centuries ago, purity of tuning was its principal victim. A new method evolved that ''dirtied'' pure ratios of sound held inviolable since codification by the ancient Greeks. Created in its place was a kind of compositional rapid transit system, a network of roads to adventure whereby composers could spring unencumbered from tonality to tonality. D flat and C sharp, for example, are by nature slightly different sounds, yet ''equal temperament,'' as it is called, squeezed them into the same space on the keyboard. Thus a single black key serves both as terminus for one sound world and a launching place into another. Almost all the music we hear today is calibrated in this way.

RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Sukova Defeats Marsikova: Third-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia edged past her countrywoman, Regina Marsikova, 7-6, 7-5, yesterday in the second round of the Italian Open. Unseeded Judith Polzl was the first player advancing to the quarterfinals, beating a fellow Austrian, Barbara Paulus, 6-2, 6-1. Polzl is the first Austrian woman to make it to the quarterfinals of a major tournament. Sukova was one of four seeded players to advance during the rain-interrupted third day of play at the Foro Italico in Rome. Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, seeded fifth, beat Linda Ferrando of Italy, 6-3, 7-5; Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, seeded eighth, trounced Csilla Bartos-Cserepy of Switzerland, 6-2, 6-1, and Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami, seeded 11th, beat Adriana Villagran of Argentina, 6-2, 6-3. The seventh-seeded player, Catarina Lindquist of Sweden, was knocked out by Isabel Cueto of West Germany, 7-6, 6-4; Raffaella Reggi of Italy, seeded 10th, was upset by Aranxa Sanchez of Spain, 1-6, 6-2, 6-3, and 14th-seeded Catherine Tanvier was beatehn by Nathalie Tauziat, 6-0, 7-6.(AP) Lendl Tops McEnroe: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia won an exhibition tournament by defeating John McEnroe, 6-2, 3-6, 6-2, in a two-hour match yesterday in Barcelona. In anothe match, Mats Wilander of Sweden beat Henri Leconte of France, 3-6, 6-3, 6-3, for third place.

title: Iowa Confirms Pay
description: Two former Iowa football players received payments from the sports agent, Norby Walters, while playing for the Hawkeyes in 1985, a university committee reported yesterday. National Collegiate Athletic Association rules prohibit an athlete from being represented by an agent until his or her eligibility is up. The rule specifically includes agreements that do not take effect until after the athlete's last game. The report from a three-member committee appointed by the university president, James O. Freedman, identified the players only as ''Student A'' and ''Student B.'' But at a news conference to release the report, committee member David Vernon identified ''Student A'' was Ronnie Harmon, the former running back. Freedman organized the committee after published reports said Harmon, a first-round draft choice now with the National Football League's Buffalo Bills, received up to $54,000 from Walters in 1984 and 1985. The committee report said it uncovered money orders from Walters to the two players, with Harmon getting a total of $1,000 in four payments and the other player $575.

STAGE: 'LITTLE MURDERS,' JULES FEIFFER'S 60'S SATIRE
description: JULES FEIFFER'S ''Little Murders'' is the darkest and perhaps the funniest comedy ever written about what it was like to be alive and half-crazed in the urban American jungle of the late 1960's. The play postulates a New York whose daily plagues range from noise and air pollution, power blackouts and obscene phone calls to violent struggles between random snipers and proto-fascist cops. Unfortunately for the prophetic Mr. Feiffer, this work had its Broadway premiere in 1967, a year too early. ''Little Murders'' expired after a single week, only to be ''rediscovered'' two years later by theatergoers (and Hollywood) in a hit Off Broadway revival. While the second staging was superior to the first, the improvement wasn't that marked. What really made the difference between 1967 and 1969 was 1968's new round of nationally televised murders, little and otherwise: assassinations, ghetto conflagrations, the Chicago police in blazing riot.

A .38 Smith & Wesson revolver was found in his hand along with a note, the police said. The wife told the police that Mr. Colon was suffering from AIDS.

title: AT HARLEY PLANT, REAGAN DEFENDS TRADE POLICY
description: President Reagan pursued his campaign against stringent trade legislation in Congress by touring the Harley-Davidson motorcycle plant here today and declaring that ''American workers don't need to hide from anyone.''

title: EHRLICH BOBER FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $354,000 for the quarter and $18,000 for the 9 months.

title: STAGE: ELAINE JACKSON'S 'BIRTH RITES'
description: ''WON'T you make my belly cut/Into something delicate?'' sings Guerra (Arlene Roman), the most loquacious of the five young mothers whose Caesarean deliveries in a city hospital are depicted with an earthy good humor in Elaine Jackson's ''Birth Rites.'' Although Guerra has logged more hospital experience than any of the others, at the end of the play she finds herself the most betrayed by bureaucratic carelessness.

title: Moody's Raises Ford Ratings
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company and its parent, two of the most prominent borrowers in the bond market, with about $25 billion of debt outstanding, regained the double A bond rating they had lost six years ago, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: ASTEC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GALLERY REVIVES ART DECO ELEGANCE
description: Jean Harlow, that seductress of the silver screen, would feel right at home at the Renwick Gallery.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $2,622,000 from an accounting change.

title: 'DRUG WAR: HEROES AND THE HYPE'
description: THE ''hype'' part is unclear; the rest of it is forthright. ''America's Drug War: The

title: THE TENDERLOIN TIMES: A VOICE IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: The Tenderloin Times is very likely the only newspaper in this city to be distributed from a grocery shopping cart by a Laotian refugee.

title: BONDS DIVE AS JAPANESE HOLD BACK
description: Tension mounted in the credit markets yesterday when prices dropped sharply because of weak demand from domestic and Japanese investors for $9.75 billion of new 10-year Treasury notes.

title: SENATE APPROVES A BUDGET FOR '88 WITH $18 BILLION TAX INCREASE...
description: The Democratic-controlled Senate, in a challenge to President Reagan, approved a $1 trillion 1988 budget early today that includes $18.3 billion in tax increases while restraining military spending.

title: A Lesson in Lagniappe
description: All the present tumult about cigarettes, cigars and pipes concerns smoke; why not fire? F. Ashe Lincoln of London raised the question in a Letter to the Editor: ''On a recent visit to the United States, I found an almost fanatical campaign against smoking. Yet in every restaurant and hotel we were presented with matchbooks. What, I ask, are they trying to encourage? Arson?''

title: YANKEES
description: By the time the trip was over, there was far less luster to the Yankees than there had been two weeks ago. Their 10-game winning streak in April was a mere memory, their formidable hitting brought to its knees after a four-city stop that resulted in more defeats than victories. Their greatest problem - a lack of sufficient hitting -had not been solved, but tonight they could forget.

title: Government Report Understates Gains on Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report on Sunday in the New Jersey Guide column of the New Jersey Weekly gave an incorrect date for a lecture by Dr. Benjamin Spock at the Muhlenberg Medical Center in Plainfield. The lecture - now sold out - is on Saturday, not today.

title: UNION ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a $51,169,000 writedown of resource properties and a $11,755,000 loss on investment in Burns Foods. c-Net income and after a $5,784,000 provision for loss on a prepaid gas agreement and a $30,601,000 writedown of investment in Numac Oil and Gas Ltd. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: FED UPHOLDS BANK ORDER
description: The Federal Reserve Board today refused a request by the Securities Industry Association to delay the effective date of an order permitting three big New York banks to engage in limited underwriting of securities.

title: INNOVEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
POLYDEX PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $769,391 from the sale of a business segment. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Article 791987 -- No Title
description: Alleging a ''conspiracy of silence and deceit'' in the building of space shuttle booster rockets, the widow of Michael J. Smith, pilot of the Challenger shuttle, filed a $1.5 billion lawsuit today in connection with the fatal flight.

title: Events: Plant Sales and Wearable Art
description: Botanic Garden Plant Sale, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, at Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn; 718-622-4433.

title: Nationalists in Japan Say They Shot Reporter
description: A far-right nationalist group, saying it had inflicted ''divine punishment,'' took responsibility today for a shotgun attack that killed a Japanese newspaper reporter.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MAY 7, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15, A23 ichard V. Secord testified he had been told that President Reagan was informed that proceeds from arms sales to Iran had been diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels. It was General Secord's second day of Congressional testimony. Page A1 George Bush phoned Oliver L. North and warmly praised his work hours after President Reagan dismissed Colonel North from the National Security Council, Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord testified. A14 Naming North, man admits role A14 The leasing of U.S. radar planes to Pakistan would damage the preparedness of the American military, according to Richard L. Armitage, a top Pentagon official. A3 Pretoria's governing party seemed likely to increase its overwhelming majority in the white chamber of the segregated Parliament. Black workers and students halted work to protest the whites-only vote. A1 ''Election fever'' grips Britain A3 Israeli jets attack Palestinians A5 Open war crimes files favored A7 Chilean sentenced in cover-up A9 Vote aids Filipino gunmaker A10 Sri Lanka-India ties worsen A11 Webster nomination held up A13 NATIONAL A16-31, B13-18 Lee Hart said she loved her husband, Gary, very much and believed in his truthfulness. Hours later, he refused to say whether he had ever committed adultery. A1 Gary Hart's campaign money woes have increased amid the publicity surrounding ties between the Democratic Presidential aspirant and a Miami woman, according to Democratic contributors. B16 Publishers focus on Hart B13 Neighbors recall Harts as real people B16 The Senate approved a budget that would provide $18.3 billion in tax increases while restraining military spending. Only three Republicans joined the Senate's Democrats in support of the plan. A1 Excise taxes have emerged as the only option that Congressional tax writers see to raise $18 billion in new revenue. Smokers, drinkers, motorists and telephone users face the steepest rise in Federal excise taxes ever. A1 Thurgood Marshall criticized framers of the Constitution for perpetuating slavery and the disenfranchicement of women. The Supreme Court Associate Justice said the bicentennial celebration invited complacency. A1 A high alcohol-breast cancer link was cited in new studies. They concluded that women seemed to place themselves at a higher risk of developing breast cancer if they took as few as three alcoholic drinks a week. A1 Two Philadelphia contractors stole $208,000 in city funds while rebuilding 61 homes destroyed by a fire, a grand jury charged, accusing the Goode administration of ''gross mismanagement and incompetence.'' A16 As the largest legalization of illegal aliens ever undertaken by any country gets under way, the program is awash with confusing and often conflicting estimates of the number of people eligible for amnesty. A16 Officials charged 115 drug suspects in a three-year undercover operation in which agents were given $116 millionin illegal profits to launder and deposit in traffickers' accounts. A18 Ex-TV evangelists ousted as ministers A19 Crime chief guilty in extortion plot A20 A24 Warning issued on 2d AIDS virus A26 House panel cool to meatpacker A28 Smoking ban urged for workplace A29 The Tenderloin Times: A voice in San Francisco B17 WASHINGTON TALK B14 Preserving Reagan's legacy The Bible on Capitol Hill REGIONAL A32, B1-12 The police discriminate against female and minority-group applicants in psychological screening tests in New York City, according to a group of black police officers. A32 Governor Cuomo and legislators appeared to move further apart on an ethics code as Mr. Cuomo sharply criticized State Senate Republicans and some lawmakers accused him of trying to undermine the talks. B1 A 2d man shot by Bernhard H. Goetz in a 1984 subway incident took the witness stand at Mr. Goetz's trial and refused to testify. The witness, Barry Allen, asserted his rights against self-incrimination. B3 Gang-controlled contractors have made $3.5 million working on Atlantic City casino projects and more than a dozen public projects in New Jersey since 1979, state criminal investigators said. B9 Two men accused of slashing a the face of a model, Marla Hanson, with a razor blade were convicted of assault in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The defendants are Steven Bowman and Darren Norman. B12 The indictment of an elections clerk could jeopardize the Assembly seat of Roger L. Green, chairman of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said. title: SETTING UP GREEN PLOTS IN THE CITY
description: IF you have never coped with gardening on a balcony or rooftop or in a city yard before, thoughtful planning at this time of year will help you avoid some expensive blunders.

title: HORTICULTURE IS ART, SCIENCE AND SOMETIMES A LOVE AFFAIR
description: WHEN I was very young, about the same time that I was struggling with long division, I started my life as a gardener. One of my elementary-school teachers, a hybridizer of irises named Mrs. Harkey, enlisted me to work in her garden, primarily at weeding her iris patch.

description: b-Includes a $258,000 charge from a litigation settlement with the FDIC and a $222,000 writedown of oil and gas properties. The company changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from Oct. 31. The company said that for the fourth quarter ended Oct. 31, 1985, it had a loss of $671,709, which included a $250,000 writedown of oil and gas properties, on revenue of $330,632. For its 1985 fiscal year, the company had a loss of $1,171,348 on $1,125,350 in revenue.

STAGE: 'SECOND AVENUE,' A COMEDY
description: ''SECOND AVENUE'' is an anecdote in two acts about an inept tailor with a romantic bent, who finds himself in the arms of a star of the Yiddish stage. It's 1908. The 27-year-old Shlomo works in a Lower East Side sweatshop, but, as he keeps writing the editor of The Daily Forward, his dreams are of the Yiddishe Nightingale, Bertha Kalish, star of ''The Lady From Kiev,'' ''Mama Vanya'' and other crowd pleasers.

title: DATACOPY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $16,000. The company said its latest first quarter loss resulted from production and start-up costs associated with the launching of six products in the fourth quarter.

title: CELTICS EDGE BUCKS WITH FREE THROWS
description: The Celtics at times showed some effects tonight of having to play successive playoff games in a 24-hour span. But with four of their five starters scoring 20 or more points, Boston managed to edge the Milwaukee Bucks, 126-124.

title: Operating Officer Quits Post at Sharon Steel
description: Walter Sieckman, the chief operating officer of the Sharon Steel Corporation, has resigned because of differences with Victor Posner, the Florida financier who controls Sharon.

title: Sonics Jeered, but Strut Stuff
description: The presence of two burly plainclothesmen near the Seattle SuperSonics bench Tuesday evening was the most obvious reminder of their players' troubles.

title: The Fastest 500
description: Mike Schmidt of the Phillies is the 14th player in baseball history to hit 500 home runs. But he was the fifth fastest to reach that total, both in games played and times at bat. He did it by averaging one home run every 14.66 times at bat. The 14 players in the 500 club, ranked by the number of times at bat it took them to reach 500:

title: POP: SUZANNE VEGA
description: SUZANNE VEGA, the most talented young star to emerge in many years out of New York City's folk music scene, is a cool, urban realist who exudes little of the Earth Mother mystique that characterized an older generation of acoustic prima donnas.

description: b-After a loss of $937,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CHILEAN SENTENCED FOR COVER-UP ROLE
description: A former Chilean Army major who admitted he lied to further a cover-up of the assassination in 1976 of a retired Chilean diplomat was sentenced today to from 27 months to 84 months in prison.

title: How to Stop White-Collar Crime From Paying
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Net loss Year-ago results are restated to reflect the company's investment in Deltona Corp. on the equity method.

title: KNICKS WOO NEW CANDIDATES
description: The Knicks began a new, vigorous effort yesterday to find a coach and general manager by initiating contacts with at least five candidates, including Coach Dick Motta of the Dallas Mavericks, according to a source familiar with the proceedings.

title: Record Profit Seen at T.W.A.
description: Carl C. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., predicted yesterday that the airline would have record earnings this year, mostly because of strong international traffic.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $145,000 for the quarter and $467,000 for the 9 months.

title: Ex-TV Evangelists Are Ousted as Ministers
description: The Rev. Jim Bakker and the Rev. Richard Dortch, the former leaders of the PTL television ministry, have been dismissed as ministers of the Assemblies of God because of Mr. Bakker's tryst with a church secretary and the subsequent cover-up, officials said today.

title: MACK TRUCKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $2,059,000, or 7 cents a share. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary tax benefit of $926,000.

description: b-Net loss

title: Vuitton-Guerlain
description: Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods group that recently bought the champagne producer Veuve Clicquot, said it would acquire a stake in Guerlain S.A., the family-run perfume concern. Vuitton said Guerlain had agreed to transfer about 15 percent of its ownership, but officials from both companies declined to provide details. Last winter, Vuitton paid 4.6 billion francs, or $760 million, for Clicquot, which also owns Givenchy perfumes.

title: SANTANA IS SITTING BUT NOT STEWING
description: It seemed that Rafael Santana had crossed the line that separates baseball players capable of performing seven days a week from those whose limitations force them to sit and watch. The ring he received last month provides lasting evidence of his role on a World Series champion. The usually reliable defensive skills Santana brings to the shortstop position, if not attention-grabbing acrobatics, have been more than adequate.

title: WILLIAM CASEY, EX-C.I.A. HEAD, IS DEAD AT 74
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence until last February, whose role in the Iran-contra affair is under scrutiny in Congress, died of pneumonia yesterday in Glen Cove Community Hospital on Long Island. He was 74 years old. Mr. Casey died less than 24 hours after the first witness in Congressional hearings on the affair named him as having assisted in providing arms to Nicaraguan rebels after Congress forbade such support.

title: SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 12
description: There were 12 weeks in the second quarter and 24 weeks in the first half this year and last.

title: ABORTION BOMBINGS SUSPECT: A PORTRAIT OF PIETY AND RAGE
description: By the time the bomb squad burst into the Manhattan headquarters of Planned Parenthood last Dec. 14, the carpet was on fire and the air clouded by smoke. In the waiting room for abortion patients, the officers discovered the remains of an exploded incendiary device and a full-scale bomb, capable of being ignited at any moment by the heat. When an officer deftly snipped the wires, the threat was over, and the investigation was about to begin.

title: MINIMUN BIDS REDUCED FOR OFFSHORE OIL LEASES
description: President Reagan, seeking to cut the nation's dependence on foreign oil, today announced a sharp reduction in the minimum bids required for Federal offshore leases and said he favored increasing the rate at which the Strategic Petroleum Reserve was being filled.

title: Controversy May Aid Hart, Cuomo Suggests
description: Allegations that Gary Hart spent a night last week with a young woman might work to his advantage, Governor Cuomo suggested today.

title: HART'S FINANCIAL PROSPECTS ARE GRIM, FUND-RAISERS SAY
description: Gary Hart's campaign financial difficulties have grown severe because of the publicity surrounding his relationship with a Miami woman, Democratic financial contributors said today.

title: HART IS THE CHIEF TOPIC FOR PUBLISHERS
description: While there was the usual grumbling about postal rates and competition for advertising dollars at the annual convention of the nation's newspaper publishers in New York that ended yesterday, the No. 1 topic of conversation this year was different.

title: STAGE: 'CASTING OF KEVIN CHRISTIAN'
description: AS a test of the dramatic range of its principal actor, ''The Casting of Kevin Christian'' is brutal, and, in the performance given by Pete Benson at the American Renaissance Theater, often rewarding. As a test of an audience's understanding and sympathy, it is just brutal.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Thus, in this bicentennial year, we may not all participate in the festivities with flag-waving fervor. Some may more quietly commemorate the suffering, struggle, and sacrifice that has triumphed over much of what was wrong with the original document, and observe the anniversary with hopes not realized and promises not fulfilled.'' - Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, speaking about the Constitution. [ B18:6. ]

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $41,972,000 and $35,407,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: AMTRAK SUSPENDS A MONTREAL TRAIN
description: Amtrak announced today that it had indefinitely suspended Montrealer train service north of Springfield, Mass.

title: A CELEBRATION OF NOBEL PRIZE WINNERS
description: ASTROTURF has never had it so good. Eight hundred of the fanciest feet in New York walked and waltzed across the artificial lawn under big white tents Tuesday night at the Founders Ball at Rockefeller University.

title: Beatrice Planning to Go Public
description: The Beatrice Companies, which became privately owned a year ago in one of the largest leveraged buyouts, will apparently be going public again.

title: CUSTOM MINIATURE FURNITURE
description: AS a little boy, the artist William Whiting made model planes and boats. By the time he was 12 years old, he was building miniature houses. After an eye operation, Mr. Whiting, now 36, constructed his buildings as confidence builders. ''In 1978, I started building a Philadelphia Greek Revival town house to get a grasp of my visual and manual skills,'' he said.

title: JACK HENRY & ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NOVICE PLANTERS HAVE DREAMS OF GLORY
description: ''A GARDEN,'' wrote the long-winded Ralph Waldo Emerson, ''is like those pernicious machineries which catch a man's coat-skirt or his hand, and draw in his arm, his leg, and his whole body to irresistible destruction.'' Ogden Nash, on the other hand (or arm or leg), boasted that ''my garden will never make me famous'' since, he said, he couldn't tell ''a string bean from a soybean, or even a girl bean from a boy bean.''

title: Astros Rally With Pinch-Hit
description: Terry Puhl, a pinch-hitter, singled to score Jose Cruz with the winning run with two outs in the ninth inning tonight to lead the Houston Astros past the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-2.

title: MARSHALL SOUNDS CRITICAL NOTE ON BICENTENNIAL
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court today denounced the ''perpetuation of slavery'' and disenfranchisement of women by the Framers of the Constitution 200 years ago and said the bicentennial celebration ''invites a complacent belief'' in the perfection of their work.

title: DOES THE ASHTRAY HAVE A FUTURE WITHOUT SMOKERS?
description: AT places as diverse as Caesar's Palace and the local Holiday Inn, there is a change afoot that threatens to alter a sliver of life as we know it.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about newspaper columns written by the Rev.

title: Highlighting The Lowlights
description: As a young assistant producer for Major League Baseball Productions, Mark Pokedoff had dreams of video glory last year. When the company handed out assignments for its series of team highlight videos, Pokedoff, a Mets fan since he was a youngster growing up on Long Island, crossed his fingers and hoped for the best, a chance to help memorialize the team's championship season. It was not to be. ''I knew there were a lot of guys ahead of me,'' he said yesterday, recalling that he had not only missed assignment to the Mets' video, but, to make matters worse, had to settle for a team that won only 77 games all season and finished dead last in its division.

title: CONFLICTING FIGURES ON ILLEGAL ALIENS ROBERT REINHOLD
description: As the largest legalization of illegal immigrants ever undertaken by any country gets under way, the program is awash with confusing and often conflicting estimates of the number of aliens eligible for legal status and how many might come forward to claim it. The Immigration and Naturalization Service has said that its 107 legalization centers around the country are prepared to process up to 3.9 million applications, a figure some experts say is far too high and others say is just about right.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income

title: Alcohol an Issue
description: ''In 90 percent of the disturbances at the ball park, alcohol is the main contributing element,'' said Al Rosen, the San Francisco Giants' president and general manager. The Giants announced Tuesday that it would stop sales of the jumbo size 24-ounce beer at Candlestick Park and limit sales to two 14-ounce servings a customer at concession stands.

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
DANCE: TRISLER GROUP IN 'TOBI ROPPO'
description: THE Joyce Trisler Danscompany bounded into the Joyce Theater on Tuesday for a week's engagement. It promises to be a lively week. The company is a fine one, with well-trained and personable dancers who move with a distinctively eager, clear attack. And the program they offered was an interesting and entertaining one.

title: City Council Criticizes Corporate Abatements
description: New York City's granting of property tax abatements to corporations that construct office space here came under heavy criticism yesterday from City Council members. They said the city appeared to have no way to recoup the financial benefits it had granted to companies if they later decided to leave New York.

title: WHAT GROWS WELL IN CITY SUN AND SHADE
description: GARDEN centers and catalogues are like a candy stores: too much temptation. But they're the most convenient way to fill your city garden now. Armed with a drawing of your garden space and notes, you can easily narrow your list to the annual, biennial and perennial species that will thrive.

He has sailed faster this time and was expected to better his record by about 24 days.

Special to The Miami Herald
description: I did not become a newspaperman to hide outside a politician's house trying to find out whether he was in bed with somebody. As a reporter for 20 years, I would have refused to carry out such an assignment. As an editor for 23 more years I would not have given such an assignment or allowed one to be made. I would have considered the very idea in conflict with my own journalistic standards and those of my paper. I still do.

title: RUMORS FLY ON RADIUM SOIL ONE WEEK FROM DEADLINE
description: For almost two years, 5,000 barrels of radium-contaminated soil have sat in the yards of four houses on Franklin Street, covered with tarpaulins. Next week, under a court-ordered deadline, they must finally be moved.

title: ISRAELI JETS STRIKE SOUTHERN LEBANON
description: Israeli jets attacked Palestinian targets in southern Lebanon again today. The police reported that 10 people were killed and 28 were wounded.

title: AFTER SETTLING ESTATE, JOHNSON LAWYERS STILL BATTLING
description: The noisy court battle over the $500 million estate of the late J. Seward Johnson ended last summer, but for the prominent lawyers who fought it, the bickering is far from over.

title: TROUBLESOME MIDDLEMAN
description: At one point in his testimony, General Secord described problems in working with Manucher Ghorbanifar, an Iranian who was a middleman in the arms deals. In this passage, the witness also referred to Amiram Nir, an Israeli official, and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Nir stayed behind in London trying to locate Ghorbanifar. North and I returned home. And Nir did locate Ghorbanifar. And it was normal Ghorbanifar, we found, a normal pattern for him. If he had problems he would be a no-show. I mean, he would disappear, go off the scope, whenever he had problems. So we could tell when he had problems, we just couldn't contact him. Now whenever he thought he had a problem solved, then of course he'd be back up on the loop again and we'd be back in touch with him.

title: The U.N. Today: May 7, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Subcommittee on Small Territories - 10 A.M.

title: LIVING IN HISTORY'S GOLDFISH BOWLS
description: JOHN GREELEY'S home in Charleston, S.C., is not open to the public, but it might as well be. ''You will be sitting at your table having dinner and look up and see a row of heads staring in at you over the blinds,'' said Mr. Greeley, who lives in a former 18th-century kitchen in the historic district, which was visited by 2.3 million tourists last year.

title: Someone Say 'A'?
description: Until recently, David B. Ottaway, a senior reporter at The Washington Post, and his wife, Marina, a sociologist, lived a fairly tranquil life at 327 A Street South East, on Capitol Hill.

title: SPRING TOURS OF HOUSES AND GARDENS
description: FOR those interested in design, the most gratifying way to understand an architectural idea, whether it is a starkly modern loft in a mid-19th century town house or an authentic Japanese teahouse at the end of a driveway, is to walk through the buildings themselves. Design concepts suddenly become real as viewers experience them not just visually, but with other senses.

title: CONQUEST EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Advertising; Expansion Continues At WCRS
description: THE WCRS Group of London, which last year acquired HBM/ Creamer and Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, announced yesterday that it was well on the way toward purchasing Robert A. Becker Inc., a New York-based health-care ad agency, and two companies in Australia.

title: Government Report Understates Gains on Cancer; Outdated Statistics
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMAN ARRESTED IN SPORTS DEATH
description: A woman was arrested today on charges of delivering cocaine in connection with the sudden death of a Texas-El Paso basketball star, Hernell (Jeep) Jackson, authorities said.

title: BALLET THEATER: MCKENZIE AND FERRI IN 'GISELLE'
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER'S ''Giselle'' has acquired new scenery and costumes. The results, richly attractive and superbly atmospheric, went on display at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night.

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes tax credits of $80,000 and $390,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Parking/Park; Blooming Miracle
description: The forget-me-nots in Manhattan's Conservatory Garden at last have their way, helping to erase the decay that blights the northeast corner of Central Park.

title: Black Group Calls Police Job Screening Prejudiced
description: An association of black police officers said yesterday that the New York City Police Department discriminated against female and minority-group applicants.

title: Consumers Power Predicts Dividend
description: The Consumers Power Company, which has struggled to carry on in the wake of an ill-fated nuclear power project, said that if its recovery continues it will resume paying a modest dividend next year to holders of common stock. At the utility's annual meeting, the chairman, William T. McCormick Jr., also said its reorganization into a holding company should bring a ''continued financial improvement, leading eventually to undertaking acquisitions, asset restructuring and other actions to increase the value of shareholder investment.''

description: b-Includes tax credits of $33,000 and $113,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a cumulative charge of about $400,000. The company said the $400,000 charge in the latest year is the cumulative result of: a gain of $16.1 million from the sale of securities in connection with the proposed acquisition of Sanders Associates; a writeoff of $17.8 million of non-recurring costs appliciable to the defense electronics segment, previously deferred in connection with a foreign production program; a gain of $2.3 million on the sale of a plastic packaging subsidiary, and a writedown of $1 million of a minority interest investment.

title: G.M.'S BIG BURDEN IN TOYOTA VENTURE
description: Only two and a half years after cars started rolling off its assembly lines, the small-car plant in Fremont, Calif., that is jointly owned by the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation has run into its first significant troubles. The problems plaguing the venture, which was aimed at teaching G.M. how to build small cars profitably, seem to belong largely to G.M.

title: Post-Game Meal
description: In recognition of their recent triumphs in sports, two Giants football players, a pair of local baseball stars and one sports broadcaster have had their names added to the Stage Delicatessen's menu of celebrity sandwiches, expanding the entries from the sports world to 10 and the total to 28.

title: MOSELEY HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $584,000 for the quarter and $1,090,000 for the year. c-Net loss and includes a non-recurring charge of $12 million related to certain government securities trading activities.

title: HERS
description: WHEN I was 5 years old, I packed my doll's suitcase with some underwear, a stuffed animal and a salami sandwich, and left home. It was dark as I set out, and although my parents tried to persuade me to wait until daybreak, I was determined to leave. I left with one of our dogs, a useless, nearly blind white mongrel named Cupcake, and took the route I usually walked to school.

title: The Iran-Contra Web Widens
description: What a sad epitaph for William Casey. As he lay dying, testimony in the Iran-contra hearings showed he was a leader in the Administration's effort to subvert the law and the will of Congress. His terminal illness already had deprived him of any chance to defend himself. With his death, there is need to guard against making him a scapegoat as well as a participant. As the Iran-contra story unravels over national television, it becomes clearer that responsibility is more widespread than the Administration will yet admit.

title: Preserving Reagan's Legacy
description: Around the White House it is sometimes called Operation Legacy.

title: Mob Profits Reported on Public Projects in Jersey
description: Construction companies controlled by Nicodemo Scarfo, the Philadelphia-based organized crime figure, have made $3.5 million working on Atlantic City casino projects and more than a dozen public projects since 1979, the State Commission of Investigation said today.

title: REAGAN MEETS NIXON OVER ARMS
description: President Reagan met with former President Richard M. Nixon last week and discussed Mr. Nixon's criticism of the Administration's arms-control stance, it was disclosed today.

title: INSIDE
description: Pakistan Deal Criticized A Defense Department official said leasing American radar planes to Pakistan would damage United States preparedness. Page A3. Bias Charged in Police Test A group of black police officers said the New York Police Department had discriminated in psychological screening of applicants. Page B12.

title: A LARGE WEST SIDE LANDMARK DISTRICT PROPOSED
description: From the canyon of West End Avenue to the cliffs of Riverside Drive, some 250 buildings would make up the largest historical district on the Upper West Side under a proposal by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rozelle Hears Jackson
description: ''It's time to break down racial barriers in the front office.'' So said the Rev. Jesse Jackson at an informal news conference yesterday outside the office of Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League. Jackson spoke after meeting with Rozelle to discuss an affirmative action plan. ''Football and baseball are in a dead heat when it comes to managers and head coaches - zero,'' Jackson said. He added that a group of black and Hispanic former athletes would meet in Chicago May 29 to discuss ways to increase minority hiring in the two pro sports.

title: Halliburton Posts Loss
description: The Halliburton Company said today that it had a loss of $8.2 million on sharply lower revenues in the first quarter because of continued weak demand in its energy-related businesses. In the first quarter of 1986, before the dramatic decline in oil prices, Halliburton posted an $11.2 million profit. Revenues for the latest quarter fell 31 percent, to $700.1 million from the comparable period last year. Halliburton's president, Thomas H. Cruikshank, said he expected the company's second-quarter performance to be difficult, but he looked for an improvement in the year's second half.

title: SOMEONE SAY GARBAGE?
description: No one had to mention Gary Hart's name in a House subcommittee hearing yesterday, but the real subject of the repartee between Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Representative Norman F. Lent, both New York Republicans, was evident to all.

title: EQUATORIAL COMMUNICATIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EDITORIAL CARTOONIST FOR NEW YORK POST
description: John Pierotti, who drew editorial and sports cartoons for The New York Post from 1950 to 1977, died yesterday in Delaware County Memorial Hospital in Drexel Hill, Pa. He was 75 years old and lived in West Chester, Pa.

title: Chairman Named At Pillsbury Group
description: J. Jeffrey Campbell, who is now in charge of hamburgers, will soon be responsible for steaks, pizzas, seafood and Chinese food as well. Mr. Campbell, the chairman and chief executive of the Burger King Corporation, was named yesterday by its parent, the Pillsbury Company, as chairman of its restaurant group, effective June 1.

title: Ford Introduces Korean-Made Car
description: The Ford Motor Company said its Festiva subcompact car, a South Korean import, would go on sale Thursday in California and five other Western states at a base price of $5,765. The car, which has a four-cylinder, 1.3-liter engine, was developed by Ford of Japan and its affiliate, the Mazda Motor Corporation. It is manufactured by Kia Motors of Seoul, in which Ford owns a minority interest.

description: THE $560 million debt restructuring finally worked out earlier this week between the Zapata Corporation and its bank lenders could ultimately prove to be an elixir not just for the ailing company but possibly for the offshore energy industry at large.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION MANUAL DEFENDED
description: Leaders of the State Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus today strongly defended state affirmative action materials that depict all whites as racists, saying they disagreed with statements in the materials but felt they were useful in provoking discussion.

title: Levine, Huntley Wins Genesee Beer Contract
description: After a creative shootout, Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver has won the account of the Genesee Brewing Company of Rochester. The budget could be between $8 million and $10 million.

title: METS
description: The Mets held meetings often last year, such as at the mound to congratulate the winning pitcher, or at home to cheer another runner crossing the plate. They met for dinner. They met to catch the team bus. This year's Mets also hold meetings, only they have been getting together before games to talk things out. It has been a weekly event, usually called by the players. But last night, it was Dave Johnson's turn. The manager called his annual ''Pet Peeve'' meeting.

title: CRIME CHIEF GUILTY IN EXTORTION PLOT
description: Nicodemo Scarfo, a reputed chief of organized crime here, was convicted in Federal District Court today of trying to extort $1 million from a Philadelphia developer.

title: Martin, Marshall Gets Olympia Office Account
description: Martin, Marshall, Jaccoma & Mitchell, until recently Martin, Sturtevant, Silverman & Marshall, has become North American agency for Olympia International, the marketer of the German-made office equipment. The budget is more than $5 million.

title: U.S. IS URGED TO BAN SMOKING IN WORKPLACE
description: Two public health groups asked the Government today to order an emergency ban on smoking in virtually all indoor workplaces. They contended that tobacco fumes from co-workers were killing 3,200 nonsmokers a year.

CHARMING 'MONSTERS' OF 'LIAISONS'
description: Like a pair of diabolical chess players, they plot their moves. This convent-cloistered virgin will be deflowered, her betrothed humiliated and disgraced; that respectable married woman will be destroyed, her self-worth shattered and her reputation ruined. A young man will be taken on as a lover and cast off as casually as a discarded article of clothing.

title: MODERATE DRINKING MAY INCREASE RISK OF CANCER IN BREAST
description: Women appear to place themselves at a higher risk of developing breast cancer if they take as few as three alcoholic drinks a week, new studies have concluded.

description: Residents of the Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn yesterday denounced a Federal court decision barring the development's managers from setting quotas to limit the percentage of tenants from minority groups.

title: BRITAIN IS GRIPPED BY 'ELECTION FEVER'
description: With the approach of a long weekend of electoral activity and political calculation, an anticipatory hubbub known as ''election fever'' has already taken hold all over Britain. A state of giddy anticipation has gripped the press and put the members of the House of Commons to acting like schoolchildren.

title: Becker Wins Despite Growing Pains
description: His girlfriend sat in the box, in a place once reserved for Gunther Bosch, Boris Becker's childhood coach and surrogate father on the tennis tour. It was a poorly kept secret the way Becker would occasionally steal a glance or two at Bosch during a pivotal point during a match, the coach discreetly trying to signal instructions to his protege.

description: To the Editor:

title: POTENTIAL AND ERIC DAVIS
description: Of all the words in baseball, the cruelest is potential. Duke Snider, the Boys of Summer center fielder at Ebbets Field, is in the Hall of Fame but some baseball people still wonder if he ever really fulfilled his potential. Darryl Strawberry hit more than 100 homers in his first four seasons, but some people wonder when he'll really fulfill his potential. And now, Eric Davis is leading the National League in just about everything, especially potential. But no matter what the Cincinnati Reds' 24-year-old center fielder accomplishes, can he ever possibly fulfill his potential?

title: Wall Street's Money Junkies
description: How much money is enough? How can people who earn more than $1 million a year need money so badly that they are prepared to break laws to get even more?

description: A local grand jury, accusing Mayor W. Wilson Goode's administration of ''gross mismanagement and incompetence,'' has charged two building contractors with stealing $208,112 in city funds while they were rebuilding 61 homes destroyed by fire in the incident involving the radical group Move in May 1985.

Kodak Chairman Sees Record Profit

Chandler, reiterated that cost management and gains in all of its business units could result in record operating earnings in 1987. Mr. Chandler said he could not explain the movement in Kodak stock. ''I think Kodak is still a very attractive buy,'' he added. ''My guess is that the market is beginning to see that.''

title: SOUTH AFRICA VOTE STRENGTHENS HOLD OF BOTHA'S PARTY

description: An Iranian-American businessman, Albert Hakim, has told Congressional investigators that he managed accounts through which almost $48 million was deposited from the Iran arms sales or on behalf of the contras.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ONCE a luxury but now found in almost every home with a lawn, gasoline-powered mowers are remarkably efficient and durable machines that often run for years with comparatively little maintenance. However, like an automobile, a power mower will last longer, start easier and run better if you maintain it properly and give it a complete tuneup each spring.

description: Thomas V. Barnes, who on Tuesday defeated Richard G. Hatcher, the nation's longest-serving black Mayor of a major city, today promised to cut crime and foster better relations with businesses in this troubled steel mill city.

title: ANOTHER YOUTH GOETZ SHOT DECLINES TO TESTIFY AT TRIAL

title: No Breeze for Gone West in Withers
description: Gone West, who skipped the Kentucky Derby last Saturday to be pointed for the Belmont Stakes, won the Withers Stakes for 3-year-olds on opening day at Belmont Park yesterday but was less than impressive in victory.

title: ON SECORD'S SECOND DAY: MORE ABOUT NORTH, THE CONTRAS AND THE PRESIDENT
description: In his second day of testimony yesterday as the opening witness at the Congressional hearings in Washington, Richard V. Secord continued his account of how the Iran-contra affair unfolded. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony. A MILLION-DOLLAR FUND Q. You testified that you got in November a million dollars, the purpose of which was transportation costs. That I take it would have covered the five shipments which were contemplated at that time and only occurred. Does that mean that you spent substantially less than the full million dollars on transportation? A. Yes. We spent, I think it was $130,000 to the 707 operator and another sum of money for a leased Lear jet. So all together, less than $200,000 was expended in support of that project. Q. So more than $800,000, which had been put in by the Israelis remained in Lake Resources? A. That's correct. Q. What happened to that money? A. Well, I assumed that they would ask for their money back, but they didn't. And I discussed this with North, also. And later, I believe late December, he told me that they were not going to ask for it back and we could use it for whatever purpose we wanted. We actually expended it on the contra project. Q. Did you and North discuss the fact that you had spent it on the contra project? A. Yes. Q. Did he indicate where the idea came from to use it for the contra project? A. I think it was his idea. Q. Did he give any indication that he'd discussed this with the Israelis? A. No. He told me he discussed it with the Israelis, but not as to destination of the funds. So Mr. Schwimmer made a contra-bution. TALKING ABOUT IRAN Q. We'll let that one sink in for a minute. Mr. Secord, I think you said that there came a time in January when you did have some further discussions on the subject of Iran? A. Yes. COVERT ACTION PLAN Q. What was the subject of the meeting? A. I thought the meeting was peculiar because I didn't really know why I was there because they were discussing the finding. I had been told earlier by Admiral Poindexter there was going to be a finding. Of course there would have to be if there was going to be a covert operation. And the finding, the Presidential finding, the order initiating this covert action was the main subject at this meeting. Q. Why were you, a private citizen, invited to a meeting with apparently a number of lawyers who were putting together a Presidential finding? A. They had already put the finding together and they were discussing it. And I thought that they were discussing certain language and later reports indicate that that finding may have already been typed and final at that point. I don't recall because it was kind of an academic discussion as far as I was concerned. MR. GOOD, COL. NORTH Q. By the way, what name were you using and what name was Mr. North using? A. North used the name of Mr. Good and at this meeting I used the name of General Adams. Now the reason why that was necessary was that they wanted me to present - that is North and the agency - wanted me to present part of the intelligence briefing which was to be given at this meeting. It had been agreed that some representative sample of tactical intelligence information would be briefed to the Iranian delegation, and since it involved a lot of military symbology and order of battle jargon, and since I'm pretty familiar with the Iranians, they asked me if I would fill that role. So I did. Q. Who was there from the Iranian side? A. An official from the office of the Prime Minister of Iran and he had with him an aide and two colonels that he introduced as being from their military intelligence organization. We believed, however, that one of the colonels actually was from the office of the Prime Minister. Q. Can you just very briefly describe the meeting? A. Yes, the main meeting, which took place, I was not present. It was a meeting among the representatives from Iran along with Ghorbanifar, Oliver North, the C.I.A. official and, of course, Hakim acting as translator. These meetings were taped surreptitiously. I was briefed later as to what had transpired and my understanding was that North went through his talking points which he had - an officially blessed set of talking points -and they went through the U.S. strategic objectives, the U.S. concerns about the Soviet threat in the region, the U.S.'s concern about the continuing Iran-Iraq war and our desire to see an honorable ending to that. Q. Do you feel certain of that, that there were no hostages expected to be released? A. I didn't expect any to be released. I was not informed that there was any plan for any to be released as a result of this initial deal. Q. In any event, you were not told that any were to be released and none were? A. And none were, and we didn't plan for any to be released. FACE TO FACE IN IRAN Q. What was - if anything, what was agreed on for the future? A. The U.S. delegation was pleased with the meeting. It was agreed in this meeting that there would be a future high-level meeting between the - and in the near future - between high-level officials of the United States and high-ranking members of the Iranian Government. And they were talking in terms of Foreign Minister and State Department high officials. Q. Would it be fair to say, Mr. Secord, that a lot was made at this meeting out of the fact that officials of the two Governments were meeting face to face for the first time in a long time? A. Yes. That was also a big point when the meeting was summed up at the end, that this was the first time that there had been face to face discussions between Iranian and U.S. officials since 1981. It was agreed that this future meeting would take place on Kaish Island, which is a small island south - on the south coast of Iran. MEESE AND NOVEMBER Q. In your opening statement you made a reference to Attorney General Meese's statement on the 25th of November 1986. A. Yes. Right. Q. And I think you had some uncomplimentary things to say about the statement. What was it that you objected to in it? A. When I learned that an internal inquiry was going on, I was fearful that there would be a rush to judgment and I asked my attorney, Mr. Green, to go and lay out the outlines of this operation to the Justice Department, to the No. 2 man in that investigation, Bradford Reynolds.

title: Candidate's Throat Slashed
description: The woman challenging the president of the Los Angeles City Council in an upcoming runoff election was found with her throat slashed today after an apparent burglary attempt at her apartment, the police said. The woman, Ruth Galanter, 45 years old, underwent surgery for a puncture wound, a slashing wound and a blow to her skull, said a hospital spokesman. She was listed in critical condition. Ms. Galanter was sleeping when the intruder entered her Venice apartment through a sliding glass door, the police said.

The latest year net also includes a nonrecurring charge of $80,000 related to a writeoff of unamortized bond discounts for convertible subordinated debt assumed by Prism in its acquisition of Fox-Lorber.

title: KANSAS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect shareholder approval of a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid later this month.

title: ELECTIONS CLERK INDICTED IN RECORD TAMPERING
description: The Manhattan District Attorney announced yesterday the indictment of a Board of Elections clerk in a case that could jeopardize the Assembly seat of Roger L. Green, chairman of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus.

title: RICHARDSON ACCUSES DOCTOR
description: Michael Ray Richardson, the talented but troubled playmaker who was suspended from the National Basketball Association because of repeated cocaine use, charged yesterday that a New Jersey psychiatrist treating him for addiction last year once sent him out to buy cocaine.

title: ATLANTIC CITY ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results were restated to reflect an accounting change, a cost containment agreement regarding the Hope Creek Nuclear generating station, and other previously abandoned plant and investments.

title: REPORT FINDS LACK OF AIR CONTROLLERS
description: Most major airports in the United States are short of experienced air traffic controllers, according to a report today by the investigative arm of Congress.

title: MARCOS AND WIFE LOSE CONTEMPT-ORDER APPEAL
description: Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, today lost an appeal of a contempt order stemming from their refusal to give documents to a grand jury investigating reports of corruption on arms contracts.

title: GAP WIDENING FOR CUOMO AND LEGISLATORS ON ETHICS
description: Governor Cuomo and legislators appeared to move further apart on an ethics code today, with Mr. Cuomo sharply criticizing State Senate Republicans even as some lawmakers were accusing him of trying to undermine the negotiations for his own political gain.

title: SOME FAIL-SAFE FLOWERING PLANTS
description: IF I were just starting a garden, rather than trying to figure out how to find room for two dozen new perennials in the crowded and overgrown one I began 16 years ago, I know where my priorities would lie.

title: In the Mail
description: Recently arrived in the dead letter department: from the Jack Kemp 1988 Club, an invitation to Walt Riker to join and make a contribution.

title: CONCERT: THE ST. LOUIS
description: JOAN TOWER'S ''Silver Ladders,'' a 20-minute orchestral work composed last year, was brought to Carnegie Hall Saturday evening by its commissioners, Leonard Slatkin and the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra. Its opening pages were promising, even exciting: the first three steps of a C minor scale, boldly proposed by timpani and chimes, then thundered by the full orchestra. The solemn upward steps continued - not quite in regular rhythm, not sticking exactly to C minor, but purposeful of stride. It sounded like a grand introduction to the unfolding of a big symphonic movement. But though the remainder showed every skill in contrasting and combining the orchestral sections, keeping the rhythm lively, moving effectively toward and away from peaks, on first hearing it left disappointingly little impression of substance.

title: Farm Lender Seeking Aid
description: The Farm Credit System, as expected, told Congress today that it would need $6 billion in Federal aid to stave off collapse of the farm lending network.

title: Government Report Understates Gains on Cancer; Unfortunate, Uncritical
description: To the Editor:

title: NAPCO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $147,000.

title: Lawmakers Study the Lawgivers
description: Moses and the Israelites were half way across the Red Sea on their flight from Egypt when the bell pealed long and loud through the Hart Office building, signaling a vote on the Senate floor.

title: TELEPHONE SPECIALISTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AIDS PERIL LINKED TO A SECOND VIRUS
description: New data have confirmed that a human virus found in West Africa that is related to the original AIDS virus can also cause the fatal disease. This second AIDS virus could contribute to the wider spread of the AIDS epidemic, French researchers reported today.

title: Nine Acres for NBC
description: Donald Trump, aware of New York City's eagerness to prevent the departure of NBC, proposes to make the network an anchor tenant for his proposed Television City on the Upper West Side -in exchange for relief from city taxes and zoning review for all of the huge 76-acre site. Taken together, that's too high a price, but a case can be made for giving special treatment to the nine acres to be occupied by NBC.

title: QUESTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes loss from discontinued operations of $419,800.

title: Market Place; Rumors Rife About Texaco
description: LAST week a spate of rumors forecasting major developments in the dispute between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company prompted a surge in trading and pushed up both stocks.

title: Accusation in Postal Scandal
description: An investigation by the Postal Service has implicated a member of the service's own board in a contract scandal that has sent two people to prison, a House committee chairman disclosed today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CAP International Inc., Marshfield, Mass., a market research and consulting company specializing in the information-processing industry, appointed Stephen M. Pytka executive vice president.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ogilvy and Thompson Lose Vicks Business
description: Ogilvy & Mather and J. Walter Thompson both lost a considerable amount of internatonal business because of a decision by Procter & Gamble to change agencies for a large number of the brands of its recently acquired Richardson-Vicks subsidiary.

title: ARIZONA INSTRUMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Yields Rise Strongly
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, money market mutual funds and bank money market accounts were significantly higher in the week ended yesterday.

title: SPECTACULARS THAT ARE ALSO AUSTERE
description: ONE of the most striking aspects of the Frankfurt Opera's new ''Ring des Nibelungen'' is the decor of Axel Manthey. Its fascinating assemblage of visual symbols - curious boxlike stilt-shoes for the gods, clown-face shields, globes and star-maps, life-sized model horses, phallic shafts and red orifices (the bottom of the Rhine Maidens' dresses, the mouths of the caves in Nibelheim) and so forth - were clearly worked out with the director, Ruth Berghaus. Yet the flamboyance of Mr. Manthey's imagery didn't always mesh so neatly with the Brechtian irony of Ms. Berghaus's dramatic conception.

title: RATE DEAL WITH JAPAN CALLED AIM
description: In an effort to stabilize the dollar, the Reagan Administration is trying to negotiate an agreement with Japan and the Federal Reserve Board under which the Fed would raise a benchmark interest rate and Japan would lower its rate, according to Administration officials.

title: U.S. AIDE HESITANT ON PAKISTAN REQUEST
description: The leasing of American radar planes to Pakistan would damage the preparedness of the United States military, a top Defense Department official said today.

title: BATH ACCESSORIES OF ANOTHER ERA
description: ON Jermyn Street in London, a tiny and charming shop called Czech & Speake carries old-fashioned handmade bathroom fittings.

title: Moscow Notebook
description: The 19 other House members who accompanied Mr. Wright to Moscow are still talking about the trip. As a late-night House session drew to a close Tuesday, several representatives took the floor to swap travel anecdotes.

title: NERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Nerco is a 90 percent owned subsidiary of Pacificorp.

title: CALVIN WILLIAMS, 61, CAR SERVICE OPERATOR AND EX-LEGISLATOR
description: Calvin Williams, a major operator of private livery services in New York City and a former New York State Assemblyman, died Saturday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 61 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: 115 CHARGED AFTER UNDERCOVER DRUG INVESTIGATION
description: Federal drug agents today completed their largest undercover investigation ever, charging 115 suspects after a three-year investigation in which agents posed as money launderers.

title: INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS MASERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a provision for income taxes for those subsidiaries of the company that continue to operate as corporations. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $231,000. Share earnings represent units. The company changed from a corporation to a limited partership Dec. 31. The company said because of differing tax treatments accorded a partnership, the company's share earnings of 10 cents a share for the year- ago first quarter are not directly comparable to the latest first quarter's share earnings.

title: TELECONCEPTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,280,000 and a loss on disposition of discontinued operations of $2,418,000. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $647,000 and $1,340,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain from venture capital investment distributions of $1,684,000 and $1,904,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Some time ago a white, hazy stain appeared on my oak-finished table, probably from a water-filled vase that had sat there. I've tried all kinds of furniture polish but the stain is still prominent. Can I remove the stain without stripping the entire table top? A. I agree that the vase probably caused the stain, most likely by condensation on the outside. White stains can often be removed without stripping the finish because the stain is is near the surface in many cases, not all the way into the wood. Rub with a little toothpaste, preferably the kind that has ''extra brighteners.''

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC
description: ''SOUNDS from the Left Bank,'' the Queens Philharmonic's series of new-music chamber concerts, began worthily Sunday afternoon in a small room at P. S. 1 - once a school, now Project Studios 1 - on 21st Street in Long Island City, Queens.
