Five composers were represented; three were present to explain their work, and eight capable instrumentalists were heard to good advantage.

title: CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $37.7 million for the latest quarter and $109.3 million for the year-earlier period. The company said the operating earnings were affected by the addition of $20 million to the reserves of reinsurance and specialty lines subsidiaries for losses on business written in prior years.

title: SIGMA-ALDRICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CRITICAL INGREDIENT IN AMERICAN CHARACTER, SOMETIMES RESISTED, WORKS AGAINST HART
description: There is a streak of morality in the American character that has perplexed foreigners from de Tocqueville on, but seldom has it been as striking as it has been in this remarkable week. Former Senator Gary

title: Auer Piano Recital
description: The pianist Edward Auer will present a recital that includes the 24 Chopin Preludes, Stravinsky's Serenade in A and a Schubert sonata, tomorrow at 8 in Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue (212-996-1100). Admission is $8 to $12.

title: THE BRASH, HYPNOTIC MUSIC OF ADE
description: KING SUNNY ADE, who is returning to New York with his 19-piece Nigerian juju band for a show at the Beacon Theater tonight, seemed bright-eyed and enthusiastic earlier this week, even though it was the morning after a performance in Boston. ''Why should we be tired?'' he asked. ''Here in America, we can only play for two or three hours. In Nigeria, we might go on at 8 P.M. and still be playing at 4 A.M. If I had the chance to do that here, I would. But you can't just come in and change other people's culture overnight. You have to join their culture, and bring your own contribution.''

title: OILERS TOP WINGS TO TIE SERIES AT 1-1
description: Mark Messier scored two goals tonight as the Edmonton Oilers rebounded from a listless first-game performance for a 4-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings that evened their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There was a sense that this just wasn't going to go away today or tomorrow and that there wasn't anything getting accomplished.'' - Joe Trippi, deputy political director of Gary Hart's Presidential campaign. [ B6:3. ]

title: France Offers Stock in Bank
description: The French Government said today that it was soliciting offers from French companies to buy up to 20 percent of the stock in Societe Generale, one of the nation's largest banks, as a first step in taking the state-owned bank private.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a capital gain of $6,106,465 and an extraordinary credit of $315,000 from utilization of loss carryforward. c-After a capital gain of $1,535,923. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split, effective for shareholders of record, April 10, 1987.

title: HENRY W. WENNING
description: Henry W. Wenning, a former executive vice president of the Martin E. Segal Company, employee benefits, compensation and actuarial consultants, died of emphysema Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 76 years old.

title: FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago share earnings was not presented because the capitalization was not comparable to the new capital structure.

title: No Bright Side When Corporations Leave Town
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FILM: A WICKED 'STEPFATHER'
description: JERRY BLAKE (Terry O'Quinn) is first seen in a bathroom, showering, shaving, changing his clothes and significantly altering his appearance. He has just killed his family. When he is finished washing, Blake descends the stairway to the living room, walks past the bodies and strides confidently out into the street on his way out of town. Actually, Jerry Blake is not his name yet. He will become Jerry Blake in his next life, in the next pleasant small-town setting with the next family he plans to murder.

title: Bleak Outlook
description: Chances are not very good that Jens Peter Berndt, the East German swimmer who defected to the United States in 1985 and is now a junior at the University of Alabama, will be granted United States citizenship in time for him to compete in next year's Olympics. A staff aide to the House Judiciary Committee, which rules on all private immigration legislation, said the panel had received several similar bills, but members did not think athletes should get special consideration. Berndt, age 23, is a former world-record holder in the 400-meter individual medley, and if he has to wait the required five years before citizenship can be granted, he would not become eligible for the United States team until 1990.

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
U.S. Drug Inquiry
description: A Federal grand jury in New York investigating a suspected heroin trafficking network has subpoenaed Walter Berry of the San Antonio Spurs and Dwayne Washington of the New Jersey Nets, according to an official of the National Basketball Association. Mark Breland, the welterweight boxer, has also been ordered to appear before the panel, according to Shelly Finkel, Breland's manager. The investigation reportedly centers on James Jackson, one of 16 people indicted on heroin charges last February. An N.B.A. official said the players were to be asked about events that took place while they were still in college, Berry at St. John's and Washington at Syracuse. They just completed their rookie seasons in the N.B.A. Attempts to reach the players at their homes and through their agents were unsuccessful. Finkel said that Breland had been subpoenaed because Federal agents found a picture of him and Jackson. ''Mark has his picture taken with thousands of people,'' Finkel said. ''He doesn't even know the guy.''

title: GWC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SONICS FALL, 102-84, ON 13-POINT QUARTER
description: Akeem Olajuwon scored 22 of his 33 points in leading the Houston Rockets to a 23-point halftime lead on way to a 102-84 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics tonight. That cut the SuperSonics' lead in the second-round playoff series to 2-1.

title: Dining Out Guide; Mother's Day
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMBASSADOR GRILL, #1 United Nations Plaza, First Avenue at 44th Street (355-3400) - *(Oct. 3, 1986) Dark walls, smoky glass panels and starry lighting create a striking modern setting in which to enjoy a special champagne brunch. About half the regular menu is devoted to the foods of Gascony in southwest France, the region of ducks, geese, foie gras, confit and truffles. On Mother's Day you may select from a buffet that includes a half lobster, shrimp and crab claws; terrines of fish and seafood, pates and meats; prime ribs, leg of lamb and fish of the day. If you wish, eggs Benedict and omelets are available; and dessert options include tarts, berries and cream, and cheese plates. Brunch prix fixe $33; dinner prix fixe $24. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M.; Sundays, 11:30 A.M. and 1:45 P.M. seatings and 6 to 10:30 P.M. CHEZ LOUIS, 1016 Second Avenue, near 53d Street (752-1400) -

title: Economic Scene; Reconstructing World System
description: IS the current international economic and security system, the ''Pax Americana,'' still ''robust,'' as the Japanese economist, Masahiro Sakamoto, maintains, despite unstable exchange rates, huge trade imbalances, enormous world debts, sluggish growth and persistent overcapacity and unemployment?

title: Intermedia Works
description: Larry Kucharz, a film maker and composer, is presenting several of his new works at 8 tonight at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation, 224 Centre Street (212-349-1980). Admission is $3.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday BAROQUE MARATHON

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
EXPERTS EXPRESS PESSIMISM ON SAVINGS INDUSTRY'S FUTURE
description: With hundreds of the nation's savings and loan associations insolvent, many experts maintain that Congressional rescue plans are inadequate and that the system cannot survive without tens of billions of dollars of taxpayers' money.

title: U.S. SEEKING IRAN ARMS EMBARGO
description: The United States began an effort today to persuade the United Nations to impose a worldwide arms embargo against Iran in an attempt to end that country's war with Iraq.

title: Miami Herald Editorial Asserts That Hart Lied
description: The Miami Herald, which first reported Gary Hart's relationship with the Miami model Donna Rice, today called the Democratic Presidential candidate a liar in an editorial headlined, ''Now the Cover-Up.''

title: SUSPICIOUS FIRE DAMAGES 4 COMMUTER BUSES SHORTLY BEFORE WALKOUT
description: Four Short Line commuter buses were damaged by fire late Wednesday, shortly before 250 workers struck the company.

title: CDC LIFE SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RED SOX HIDE MOST OF THE SCARS
description: Their armor more spiritual than literal, the Red Sox returned to the scene of the disaster last night, ducking memories rather than pop bottles.

title: PAUL POPHAM, 45, A FOUNDER OF AIDS ORGANIZATION, DIES
description: Paul Graham Popham, a decorated Vietnam veteran and a founder of the Gay Men's Health Crisis, died of complications from AIDS yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 45 years old.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-After a revision in the estimate of future warranty costs which increased the net loss by $1,930,000. The company also revised its estimate of future expenses related to wholesale finance programs. This increased the year earlier fourth quarter loss by $328,000. The company said the fiscal 1987 loss is after a net gain of $1,252,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: A FLURRY OF AUCTIONS OFFERS PAINTINGS, PIANOS AND BRONZE GIACOMETTIS
description: THE May marathon of sales taking place next week at New York's auction houses offers artworks, prints, antiques, books and manuscripts valued at $120 million, a record total for the week. The crowded auction schedule coincides once again with the blockbuster sales of major Impressionist and modern artworks that attract thousands of bidders and spectators. This year these major sales will offer works from the collections of Baron Lambert and Sam Spiegel.

title: DISCOVERY OF AIDS CAME AFTER VICTIM HAD TRANSFUSIONS
description: AIDS was unknown in 1979 when Representative Stewart B. McKinney, the Connecticut Republican who died of an infection brought on by the ailment, received several transfusions during coronary bypass surgery.

title: A $1.25 BILLION BET PLACED BY SALOMON
description: At 12:59 yesterday afternoon, one minute before the Treasury Department was set to sell $9.25 billion in 30-year bonds, activity on much of the vast trading floor at Salomon Brothers came to a standstill.

title: NEW JERSEY ORCHESTRA ON THE RISE
description: While other executive directors of regional orchestras worry about survival, John L. Hyer of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra is contemplating loftier thoughts. ''It is clear now that we can rise to the very top,'' Mr. Hyer proclaimed in an interview the other day.

title: FILM: 'RIVER'S EDGE'
description: THE generation gap, as revealed in Tim Hunter's bitter and disturbing new film, ''River's Edge,'' is the thing that divides Samson (Daniel Roebuck) and Feck (Dennis Hopper). Long ago, Feck murdered his girlfriend - but he lived to regret it, and the killing has made him a crazy, desperate loner, a hermit who keeps an inflatable party doll as his only companion. Samson is younger, calmer, and very different. As the film begins, Samson has just strangled a young woman who said something unpleasant about his mother. He doesn't regret it; in fact, he doesn't feel a thing.

title: Seagram Sets Loan For Liquor Group
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., will lend $12 million to a new liquor industry group to create a self-insurance program for bars, restaurants and package stores. Seagram said the money would provide initial underwriting and pay organizational costs for the new group, the Consortium of Licensed Beverage Retailers Associations.

title: Article 951187 -- No Title
description: A pawnshop that sold a pistol used in the murder of an automobile dealership employee will pay the man's widow $1.9 million under an out-of-court settlement, attorneys said Wednesday. The widow of the victim, Kay Day, said the man convicted in the slaying, Larry Gene Sewell, stood by while a friend purchased the pistol. The pawnshop, Uncle Joe's Pawn Shop No. 2, has stopped selling pistols. Mr. Sewell is serving a life term for the slaying of J. Weldon Day in October 1985.

title: Bond Worries Prevent a Stock Rally
description: The stock market traded actively yesterday, but attempts at a rally were thwarted by nervous distractions from the credit market for the second consecutive day.

title: AUSIMONT COMPO NV reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company converted results from Italian lira to U.S. dollars at the March 31 rate of 1.285 lira equaled U.S.$1.00.

title: MOORE MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in both periods.

title: Wernick Concerto Set For Premiere at College
description: A new concerto by Richard Wernick, who won the Pulitzer Prize for Music in 1977, will be played for the first time tonight at 8, at the Bard College Chapel in Annandale-on-Hudson in Dutchess County, N.Y. The work, entitled Concerto for Viola and Orchestra, will be performed by the Hudson Valley Chamber Orchestra under the direction of Leon Botstein, president of Bard College. Tickets are $8. To get there, take the Taconic State Parkway north, Route 199 west, through the village of Red Hook and Route 9-G north to the college entrance.

title: BROADWAY
description: VERY few real-life living-room scenes get into a Broadway column. But that is where theater begins - in somebody's home, with young hopes and fresh talents and an idea waiting to bloom at last behind the footlights. This week, in a polished living room with a spectacular view 36 floors above Manhattan's East Side, a pair of young, nervous unknowns at a baby grand piano talked and sang and played their way through their own new musical. Among the two dozen people scattered about the room to hear Winnie Holzman, David Evans and two other singers was Arthur Laurents, tiny and dapper, leaning against a wall and grinning with pride. Mr. Laurents, author of ''West Side Story'' and ''Gypsy,'' director of ''La Cage aux Folles,'' among his many Broadway credits, was also the midwife for the witty little musical given a sneak preview the other night. It is scheduled to open Off Broadway in late September.

title: BREAKING ROTARY BARRIER: MATTER OF SURVIVAL FOR CALIFORNIA CLUB
description: On Monday, after the United States Supreme Court, in a landmark decision, validated her acceptance as one of the first three women in America to join a Rotary Club, Mary Lou Elliott went bowling after work and attended her weekly art class.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Springfield, Mo., dispatch by The Associated Press yesterday about television evangelists misidentified the Rev. Jerry Falwell. He is a nondenominational Independent Baptist, not a member of the Southern Baptist denomination.

title: Name Those Buildings
description: Names were picked yesterday for five Federal buildings by the House Subcommittee on Public Buildings and Grounds.

title: QUIZZING OF SECORD IS SEEN AS SEEKING A CONSPIRACY CASE
description: The select Congressional committees pressed Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord today about his conduct in the Iran-contra affair, apparently in an effort to show that he had been part of a conspiracy with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to violate Congressional restrictions on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Irving Berlin on the eve of his 99th birthday misstated the history of his musical ''Mr. President.'' The show did open on Broadway, at the St. James Theater, on Oct. 20, 1962, and ran for 265 performances.

title: Accident Case Dropped Against O'Rourke Son
description: Drunken-driving charges against Andrew P. O'Rourke Jr., the 31-year-old son of the Westchester County Eexecutive, were dismissed here today by Town Justice Robert Troup, who decided there was insufficient evidence.

title: AMOSKEAG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the share earnings results reflect the distribution of Class B common stock on a share-for- share basis to all shareholders of record April 27.

title: District of Columbia Can't Afford Statehood
description: To the Editor:

title: AARON NEVILLE IN A RARE SOLO SHOW
description: AARON NEVILLE bears a tattoo of a dagger on his right arm, and one of a cross on his left. The dagger might well symbolize the musclebound man who grew up in a housing project, worked as a stevedore on the New Orleans docks and served six months in prison for auto theft. The cross, though, must represent Aaron Neville the singer, a balladeer whose voice can fairly be described as angelic.

title: HEIST, C H CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net loss

title: OPERA AND BALLET HOUSE TO MAKE HOUSTON DEBUT
description: Putting on a brave show in the face of tough economic times, Houston is preparing to raise the curtain this weekend in a new opera and ballet house, the first in this country in 16 years.

title: Pemex Case Sentencing
description: Jorge Diaz Serrano, the former head of the Mexican state oil monopoly Pemex, has been sentenced to 10 years in jail on charges of personally enriching himself during his tenure.

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
CLUSTER BUILDER'S NEW ENTICEMENT: ADJACENT WOODS
description: LEAD: With New York's suburbs becoming more crowded, opportunities for living in a truly pastoral setting are shrinking dramatically. In Westchester County and New Jersey communities, where demand for new homes is particularly strong, even the smallest parcels of meadow and woodland are being paved over as builders frantically seek sites for housing.

title: DERBY'S TOP FIVE ARE BOUND FOR PREAKNESS
description: For the first time in a dozen years, the top five finishers in the Kentucky Derby are all scheduled to run in the Preakness Stakes.

title: Why Mexico Fears Our Immigration Law
description: The only certainty anyone can hold about the Simpson-Rodino immigration act, which went into effect this week, is that no one in Mexico or in the United States knows what its results will actually be.

title: Cuomo Again Rules Out Bid
description: Governor Cuomo, who decided in February not to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination, said yesterday that he was not thinking of changing his mind even though Gary Hart is expected to withdraw from the race.

title: Detaining Asylum Seekers Is Illegal Prodigality
description: To the Editor:

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WESTON, GEORGE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds and company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver Stock Exchanges.

title: GOETZ JUDGE PROHIBITS TESTIMONY AS 'HEARSAY'
description: The judge in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz yesterday refused to allow the jury to hear testimony from a woman who said she had spoken to two youths minutes after they had been shot by Mr. Goetz on a subway car in December 1984.

title: IMS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $15,093,000 from disposal of discontinued operations, income of $625,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,115,000 from early repayment of long-term debt. c-Includes a gain of $453,000 from discontinued operations. The results for all periods are restated to reflect acquisition of Clark- O'Neill Inc. in June 1986 as a pooling of interests.

title: 'A GATHERING OF OLD MEN' ON CBS
description: A BLACK man named Charlie is being chased across a cane field by a white man driving a tractor. For years it has been whites ordering around blacks, Charlie is saying, ''but there comes a day, there comes a day.'' Sunday night at 9 on CBS, ''A Gathering of Old Men'' describes that day, turning a local incident and a small victory into a memorable drama.

title: COURT-MARTIAL OF SOLDIER IS URGED FOR SEX AFTER POSITIVE AIDS TEST
description: An Army investigator has recommended a court-martial for a private charged with assault for having sexual relations with three people when he knew that a blood test showed him to be infected with the AIDS virus.

title: New Pact for Francis
description: Emile Francis, who has seen the Hartford Whalers move from last place to fourth place in the overall National Hockey League standing in his four seasons as president and general manager, has signed a five-year contract to continue in those posts. ''We'll continue to do what we're doing and hopefully do it a little harder,'' said Francis, who engineered a series of trades and draft choices that has left just two players from the roster of the team he took over in May 1983. Francis's new contract is worth about $1.2 million to $1.3 million over its five years, according to sources close to the Whalers. He still has one year remaining on his original five-year contract. In his 40 years of hockey, the one thing that has eluded Francis, a 60-year-old former goaltender, is the Stanley Cup. Before coming to Hartford, he had rebuilt the Rangers and the St. Louis Blues, only to fall short with both teams.

title: TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter loss reflects the results of Continental Airlines, Eastern Air lines, and Systemone Corp., all of which are wholly owned subsidiaries of Texas Air. The operations of New York Air, as well as People Express Airlines and Frontier Airlines, which were acquired by Texas Air in late 1986, have been merged into Continental. First quarter of 1986 operating loss of $3,890,000 and net loss of $11,202,000 have been restated to include $4.7 million of Eastern Air Lines losses apportioned in relation to Texas Air's percentage of ownership of Eastern common stock a year ago.

title:
Market Place;
Stock Options' New Charms
description: LEAD: IN 1973, when stock options first began trading on the Chicago Board Options Exchange, they were considered about the raciest game in town.

title: PLAN BACKED FOR CATASTROPHIC MEDICAL EXPENSES
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today approved a bill that would provide comprehensive insurance against catastrophic medical expenses for 31 million elderly and disabled beneficiaries of Medicare.

title: 4 Girls Offer a Compromise In Row Over Prom Tuxedos
description: Four girls who want to wear tuxedos to their high school prom will stay home if their principal insists they wear dresses, one of the girls says.

title: KOCH CALLS OFF PLAN TO APPROVE CABLE TV WORK
description: Mayor Koch yesterday called off plans to grant approval for the installation of cable television in the Bronx and eastern Brooklyn, citing current investigations of people ''involved in the awarding of cable contracts.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WAR MUSIC: An Account of Books 16 to 19 of Homer's ''Iliad.'' By Christopher Logue. 85 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95.

title: REAGAN, THEIR TARGET, FACES HIS CARTOONISTS
description: For President Reagan and the nation's political cartoonists, who tend to be natural adversaries anyway, the day of their annual peace meeting got off to a shaky start.

title: ART: CINDY SHERMAN AT METRO PICTURES
description: IN her newest work at Metro Pictures, 150 Greene Street, Cindy Sherman continues to push at the limits of the setup photograph and at the deconstruction of the feminine mystique. Long the leading actress in her own images, which over the years have presented dozens of female types and characters, Ms. Sherman now makes only limited appearances. She hovers at the outer edges of these new pictures, which are on view through May 30. We may catch a fleeting glimpse of her face or hand or reclining form, but then only after our eyes have become accustomed to the rugged terrain and dark lurid colors.

title: Rookie No-Hitters
description: When Eric Bell of the Baltimore Orioles lost his bid for a no-hit game against the Minnesota Twins in the ninth inning Tuesday night, he missed an opportunity to join a select group of 16 pitchers since 1900 who have thrown no-hit games in their rookie seasons. Their careers, after that early brush with fame, varied from Vida Blue's 209 victories in 17 seasons to Bobo Holloman's 3 in his one and only big-league season. Pitcher, team Yrs. W L '01 Earl Moore, Indians 14 161 153 '07 Nick Maddox, Pirates 4 43 20 '12 Jeff Tesreau, Giants 7 119 72 '22 C. Robertson, W. Sox* 8 49 80 '34 Paul Dean, Cardinals 9 50 34 '35 Vern Kennedy, W. Sox 12 104 132 '47 B. McCahan, Athletics 4 16 14 '53 B. Holloman, Browns 1 3 7 '55 Sam Jones, Cubs 12 102 101 '62 Bo Belinsky, Angels 8 28 51 '67 Don Wilson, Astros 9 104 92 '70 Vida Blue, Athletics 17 209 161 '72 Burt Hooton, Cubs 15 151 136 '73 Jim Bibby, Rangers 12 111 101 '73 Steve Busby, Royals 8 70 54 '83 M. Warren, Athletics 3 9 13 *Perfect game.

title: AFGHANS USE PLANE AS ANTI-U.S. EXHIBIT
description: The Afghan Government brought foreign journalists to this embattled eastern border area today to see the wreckage of a transport plane said to be carrying women, children and other civilians when it was downed by an American-made rocket last February.

title: Iraq Reports Strikes on Iran
description: Iraqi warplanes struck Iranian troop positions on the Persian Gulf war front today and attacked a ship in the northern gulf, Iraqi military spokesmen said. A communique said Iraqi jets and helicopter gunships flew 126 sorties and combat missions against the Iranians. The official Iranian press agency, monitored in London, said Teheran's forces had repulsed an Iraqi counterattack on the northern front.

title: World War II Fate of Jews Still Shames France
description: To the Editor:

title: GASTINEAU PEDALS INTO SHAPE
description: Watch out, America. Mark Gastineau is back, slimmer than ever, perhaps as fast, probably not as strong. And he will be bicycling across the country, Los Angeles to New York, 3,000 miles in 20 days because . . . well, because he's Mark Gastineau of the New York Jets.

title: INDIA AND CHINA CITE EACH OTHER FOR MASSING TROOPS IN HIMALAYAS
description: India and China are accusing each other of massing troops along their Himalayan border in northeastern India, heightening tension between Asia's biggest nations.

title: Forceful Print Work For Absolut Vodka
description: The search for the impactful ad is never ending. Witness the pop-up ad that popped up eyebrows when it ran in Time.

title: QUEBECOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Whirlpool Officer Adds 2 Key Posts
description: David R. Whitwam, vice chairman and chief marketing officer of the Whirlpool Corporation, has been named president and chief executive.

title: Cure the Bus Pension Bloat
description: Overtime abuse at bus depots in the Bronx and Manhattan costs New York about $11 million a year in inflated pension benefits. Ending the abuse should be a goal of coming contract talks.

title: INSIDE
description: Contra Leaders Reorganize

title: Rep. Ford of Tennessee Admitted to a Hospital
description: Representative Harold E. Ford, Democrat of Tennessee, who is under indictment for tax, bank and mail fraud, was taken to a hospital after suffering severe chest pains, his staff said today.

title: Consumer Debt Drops $63 Million
description: Overall consumer borrowing fell in March for the first monthly decline since 1982, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: GENERAL UNDER ATTACK: THE QUESTIONS SHARPEN
description: For two days, Richard V. Secord - United States Military Academy '55, Naval War College '72, a veteran of more than 250 combat missions in Southeast Asia, a retired Air Force major general - rattled off facts and figures about the work he did to support the Reagan Administration's policies in Iran and Nicaragua.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MAY 8, 1987
description: International A3-15

title: The Meaning of South Africa's Vote
description: LEAD: How has the South African election answered the question that Americans so passionately argued last year: To what extent can political pressure and economic sanctions from Western governments influence white opinion in South Africa?

title: MOB INFORMER SAYS HE DIDN'T LIE
description: A Mafia informer denied under cross-examination yesterday that he lied about defendants to satisfy prosecutors in a major racketeering trial in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Judge Orders Man Held on Israeli Charges
description: A United States citizen accused of taking part in a terrorist attack on a passenger bus in the Israeli-occupied West Bank was ordered held without bail yesterday by a Federal magistrate in Brooklyn after his arrest here on Wednesday.

title: WALDHEIM PLANS SLANDER SUIT AGINST JEWISH GROUP'S CHIEF
description: President Kurt Waldheim of Austria announced today that he had authorized the Vienna state prosecutor to file suit against Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, for slander.

title: In Pursuit of a Coach
description: George Shinn, managing general partner in the new Charlotte, N.C., National Basketball Association expansion franchise, said he did not have a timetable for hiring a coach, but he has found enough common ground with the former Phoenix Suns coach, John MacLeod, to continue their discussions for the job. ''Obviously, I wanted to interview John now,'' said Shinn, who has talked only to MacLeod and Lefty Driesell, the former University of Maryland coach. Referring to MacLeod, Shinn said: ''He's probably not going to have to look too hard for work and I wanted to be in early. If you have four expansion teams and there are capable people like John available, I'd like to hire first.'' MacLeod, 49, who was dismissed by the Suns in February, is working as a commentator on cable telecasts of the N.B.A. playoffs. Charlotte is scheduled to enter the league in the 1988-89 season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 8, 1987
description: MARKETS A surge of Japanese orders lifted bond prices and created hopes that the trend toward higher interest rates had been thwarted for now. The buying of 30-year Treasury bonds by Japanese securities firms soothed fears that turmoil in the foreign exchange market and trade disputes between Tokyo and Washington would interrupt the flow of Japanese capital into the American bond market. The fears had been heightened by weak Japanese participation in Wednesday's auction of 10-year notes. The dollar's stability in recent days was credited with paving the way for the increased level of Japanese participation. [ Page D1. ] The dollar rose against most currencies as traders kept a close watch on the Treasury auction. Gold fell to $457.25 an ounce in New York, down $1.50. [ D11. ] Stocks were active but a rally was thwarted, for the second day in a row, by distractions from the credit market. The Dow had another seesaw day before closing at 2,334.66, off 7.53 points. [ D4. ] Wheat futures climbed to their highest levels in a year and soybeans were up more than 10 cents a bushel. [ D11. ] THE ECONOMY The savings and loan industry may need as much as $45 billion in a Federal bailout, some experts maintain, complaining that Congressional rescue plans are inadequate. These experts worry that the F.S.L.I.C. will require enormous Federal assistance to shut or sell the ailing savings and loans. [ A1. ] A ''summit meeting'' on the budget was sought by Bob Dole, the Senate's ranking Republican, who said it was time for President Reagan to begin negotiating with the Congress on the 1988 budget. The White House said it was not interested in such a meeting. [ A22. ] Insurance against catastrophic medical expenses for 31 million elderly and disabled Medicare beneficiaries was approved by the House Ways and Means Committee. Passage by the full House seems certain. [ A21. ] The Senate Finance Committee approved its trade bill, which mandates much less retaliation than the House's bill. The Senate is expected to vote on the bill in June. [ D1. ] Consumer debt dropped $63 million in March in the first monthly decline since July 1982. Americans paid off a half-billion dollars in revolving debt and homeowners continued shifting credit into equity loans. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Western Union will merge with ITT World Communications to create a leading international telex message service in a $370 million venture. Drexel Burnham Lambert said it was confident it could raise $450 million to finance the deal. [ D1. ] Texas Air reported a loss of $100.7 million for the first quarter, compared with a loss of $11.2 million a year ago. But Eastern, its subsidiary, showed marked improvement. NWA, the parent of Northwest, lost $35 million in the first quarter, more than twice what it lost in the first quarter of 1986. [ D3. ] The nation's largest general retailers reported strong sales in April after a mixed performance in March. Sears, the biggest retailer, had the smallest gain last month - 2 percent. [ D3. ] Another executive at J. Walter Thompson has been dismissed. W. Lee Preschel, president for Latin America and the Central Pacific, was rumored to be a supporter of Joseph W. O'Donnell, who was ousted as chairman and chief executive in January. [ D13. ] Resorts International rejected a $220 million takeover offer from a group led by Marvin Davis. Separately, Mr. Davis offered to acquire Spectradyne for $348 million. [ D3. ] Random House will buy a leading British book publisher. It is the first purchase of a major European trade-book publisher by an American company. [ C29. ] Martin A. Siegel, the former investment banker, secretly taped conversations in January with Timothy L. Tabor, who has been indicted on insider trading charges. [ D3. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Reconstructing the world economic system would require new international institutions and some radical innovations, such as an international income tax, according to one economics professor. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Stock options were the raciest game in town when they began trading in 1973. But now they have been largely overshadowed by options on stock indexes. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: CONSOLIDATED PRODUCTS reports earnings for 16wks to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $203,000 and $393,000 for the 16 weeks and the 28 weeks, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a reversal of tax loss carryforward of $35,000 for the 16 weeks, and a gain of $150,000 from early extinguishment of debt for the 28 weeks.

title: ART: ILLUMINTED BOOKS OF BUDDHISTS ON DISPLAY
description: ''THE WORD AND THE IMAGE: Buddhist Book Illuminations'' is significantly different from exhibitions of Christian illuminated manuscripts. Buddhist books do not have the pre-eminence for Buddhists that the Bible has for Christians and the Koran has for Moslems. Compared with Christian manuscripts, Buddhist books, at least those in this show, at the Asia Society (Park Avenue at 70th Street), through June 7, are modest and restrained.

title: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
On the Museum Front
description: The Smithsonian Institution is about to extend a helping hand to a New York City institution, the Museum of the American Indian, which has been beset by threatened lawsuits, dwindling attendance and concern over deteriorating objects in its collection.

title: BIG O TIRES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year results include a charge of $487,300 for the consolidation of Big O Tires' distribution system. The company also said the latest year results don't include operations of the independent distribution centers in Arizona, New Mexico, Oregon and Washington acquired by Big O around the end of 1986.

title: British Offering Oversubscribed
description: The British Government will offer private investors some of the shares of Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the airplane engine maker, originally allotted for institutional investors, because of an oversubscription of the public offering, the Government's adviser said. The Government is offering a total of 801.5 million shares in Rolls-Royce for $:1.36 billion, about $2.3 billion at current exchange rates, or 170 pence - $2.86 - a share. The state-owned company is a separate concern from the luxury auto maker Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd.

title: Collaborationist Vichy
description: To the Editor:

title: GALA NIGHT IN WASHINGTON
description: An exhibition of 61 drawings by Italian masters, art from the British royal collection that is rarely permitted to leave Windsor Castle, opened at the National Gallery of Art with a small but glittering party Wednesday night.

title: Cannes Festival Opens With Salute to Directors
description: The 40th Cannes Film Festival opened today with ceremonies dedicated to film directors and special tributes to Ingmar Bergman of Sweden, Bernardo Bertolucci of Italy and Richard Brooks of the United States.

title: 535 PASS FIRST HURDLE ON FIRST DAY OF THE AMNESTY PROGRAM
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service gave temporary legal status to 535 illegal aliens on the first day of its year-long amnesty program, the service said Wednesday.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $209,000 and $836,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; extraordinary pretax losses of $600,000 for the quarter and $2,100,000 for the 9 months; and the 9 months also includes a $3,407,406 pretax gain on the sale of stock; a $1,394,959 after-tax gain on a debenture exchange offer and an after-tax net from discontinued operations of $58,260. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,505,286 and $3,422,846 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The latest revenue includes Jeneric Industries, acquired Dec. 29. The company said the year-ago third quarter and 9-month results are restated to reflect the discontinuance of the company's piping component business on Dec. 5.

title: TESTING OF GENE-ALTERED BACTERIA TO BE FIRST UNDER CHEMICAL LAW
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has granted a Massachusetts biotechnology company preliminary approval to release gene-altered bacteria in Wisconsin. The decision marks the first time a living organism has been regulated under Federal laws that were intended for controlling toxic chemicals The altered bacteria, Rhizobium meliloti, were developed by BioTechnica International of Cambridge. Under natural conditions, the bacteria live in the roots of alfalfa plants and other legumes and provide nutrition by converting nitrogen in the atmosphere to ammonia. New Program Approved

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: GEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After capital gains of $17,284,650 for the latest first quarter and $15,604,548 for the year-ago period.

title: Political Insiders 'in Shock'
description: The shrewd and jaded political insiders who live inside the Washington beltway and trade gossip at ''in'' restaurants make it a point never to be surprised by anything.

title: 5-Year Notes By Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $100 million of five-year fixed-rate notes with a reverse principal linked to the exchange rate betweeen the dollar and the yen.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bridge: 2 Women Are First Chinese In Major International Event
description: In this decade, bridge has boomed in China, but its players have never taken part in a major international invitational event. That barrier will be broken when Gu Ling and Zhang Yalan of Canton play tomorrow and Sunday in the prestigious Invitational Charity Pairs at the Cavendish Club, at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan.

title: Dukakis Gains Endorsement
description: Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, who is seeking the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, was endorsed today by Gov. Madeleine Kunin of Vermont. A friend and political ally of Mr. Dukakis on such issues as nuclear safety, she called him ''a friend, a colleague and a person of great integrity and substance.''

title: RANDOM HOUSE TO BUY BRITISH GROUP
description: Random House announced yesterday that it would buy one of the leading British book-publishing groups -Chatto, Virago, Bodley Head & Jonathan Cape Ltd. It is the first purchase of a major European trade-book publisher by an American company.

title: WOMEN'S WEAR DAILY AND FEUDS IN FASHION
description: John Burr Fairchild looked troubled during the explosive standing ovation that followed Yves Saint Laurent's fashion show in Paris last month. Mr. Fairchild, chairman and editorial director of Fairchild Publications, which publishes Women's Wear Daily, the fashion trade paper, was standing too, but his arms were folded. It was a sign.

title: Breaking Into the Arts
description: Professionals from the worlds of dance, music, theater, literature and art will take part in a career seminar for young artists from 1:30 to 4:30 P.M. tomorrow in the main building at New York University, 100 Washington Square East, at Waverly Place. Among those on hand to discuss how to break into the arts will be Senta Driver, the dancer; Toby Olson, a poet, and Ross Bleckner, a painter. The seminar, titled ''Arts Survival: Lessons for the Late 80's,'' is sponsored by the National Foundation for Advancement in the Arts. The fee is $5. Information: 719-3500.

title: WESTERN UNION DEAL WITH ITT
description: The financially troubled Western Union Corporation would be merged with ITT World Communications Inc. to create a leading international telex message service, under the terms of a $370 million venture announced yesterday.

title: TRANSCO EXPLORATION PARTERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $247.3 million relating to the reduction of the value of oil and gas properties.

title: Canada's First $1 Coin
description: Canada's first $1 piece, a gold-colored coin with 11 sides, was struck today at the Royal Canadian Mint in Winnipeg. The coin will enter circulation in July and eventually replace the dollar bill.

title: HITK CORP reports earnings for As of Feb 28
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Five Musicians Receive '87 Avery Fisher Grants
description: Five young instrumentalists have been awarded Avery Fisher Career Grants for 1987, the Avery Fisher Artist Program has announced. Each recipient receives $10,000 to be used for career advancement.

title: JURY CONVICTS 6 IN PLOT TO STEAL TESTS FOR POLICE
description: A Federal jury today convicted five police officers or former officers and a former state legislative aide of conspiring to steal and distribute promotional and entrance examinations for several police departments in the Boston area. A seventh defendant was acquitted.

title: Resorts Rejects $220 Million Offer
description: Resorts International Inc., the casino-hotel operator, said today that its board had rejected the $220 million takeover offer from a group led by Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman and investor. Separately, Mr. Davis offered $348 million for Spectradyne Inc., the leading supplier of pay-per-view movie systems to hotels.

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Another Departure At JWT
description: A MONTH before his 30th anniversary with the J. Walter Thompson Company, W. Lee Preschel, president for both Latin America and the Central Pacific and a member of the chief executive's office, has been dismissed, it was learned yesterday.

title: U.S. Issues a Travel Warning For Much of the Philippines
description: The United States Embassy, in its most extensive travel advisory since Corazon Aquino became President, urged Americans today to avoid large areas of the Philippines because of ''relatively high levels of unrest.''

title: 32 JAMES STEWART FILMS AT REGENCY
description: All the great movie directors stressed visuals over dialogue, according to James Stewart. John Ford repeatedly said, ''If you can't tell a story visually, you're not using movies correctly.''

title: UNION VALLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $281,000 from the termination of a pension plan.

title: Agnes de Mille On 'Dance in America'
description: The estimable ''Dance in America'' series takes an unusual and fascinating turn tonight at 9 on Channel 13 with an entire ''Great Performances'' program devoted to autobiographical reminiscences by Agnes de Mille.

title: NEW TRIAL ORDER FOR CITY OFFICER IN 1981 MURDER
description: The State Court of Appeals ordered a new trial for a veteran New York City police officer yesterday, saying that he had been wrongfully convicted of both intentionally and recklessly killing a fellow officer during a St. Patrick's Day drinking spree six years ago.

title: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A HINT OF OCTOBER ON A SPRING NIGHT
description: No one saw Bill Buckner inch closer to the baseline, nor did he bring his legs together when Mookie Wilson came to bat. And he did not, in a stray moment, walk to that section of dirt deep in the corner of the infield and offer a small prayer for the one that got away.

title: FILM: MARTIN KOVE IN 'STEELE JUSTICE'
description: ''STEELE JUSTICE'' isn't designed as a comedy, but it does earn high marks for inadvertent humor. This is thanks in part to the writer and director, Robert Boris, whose ''Oxford Blues'' was no laughing matter but who this time has tried to meld ''Rambo'' with ''Miami Vice,'' throwing in a touch of the Chippendale's calendar. The last is evoked by the presence of Martin Kove, the big, burly, smirking fellow in the title role.

title: TWENTIETH CENTURY FOX FILM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $20,477,000. Twentieth Century is an operating unit of the News Corp. Ltd., which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Norman, Stewart Lead: Greg Norman, a playoff loser in the Masters, sank a short eagle putt at the seventh hole yesterday for a 64 to tie Payne Stewart for the first-round lead in the $600,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic in Irving, Tex. Gary Hallberg, Fred Couples, and Gary Krueger each had five-under 65's over the 6,767-yard course. (AP) TENNIS Navratilova, Graf Win: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova of the United States and Steffi Graf of West Germany, the second-seeded player, easily advanced to the quarterfinals of the $150,000 Italian Open with straight-set victories yesterday in Rome. Navratilova, ranked No. 1 in the world, overpowered Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-2, in a night match. Earlier, Graf downed Annamaria Cecchini of Italy, 6-1, 7-5. Navratilova, who has not won a tournament this year and struggled through two tie-breakers in her first match, eliminated the 16-year-old Czechoslovak in 50 minutes.

title: ADOBE RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $288,000. The company said there were no share earnings in either period because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: P.&G. Filing Asks Product Approval
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said that it had filed a petition with the Food and Drug Administration for the approval of a new calorie-free fat substitute that could be used in everyday cooking. The proposed generic name of the ingredient, which has passed some preliminary steps and will now be fully examined by the Federal drug agency, is olestra. Procter said it was seeking permission to use it in shortenings, oils and salted snacks.

title: FEWER TOURNAMENTS ON CLAY
description: It may not be like playing on the red clay at Roland Garros in Paris, where tennis is a game of endurance as well as skill. But the green-gray Har-Tru courts at Forest Hills pass for a reasonable facsimile of the real thing, a surface that requires a player to have stamina, patience and a bag of tennis tricks.

title: CHILI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the figures for the latest third quarter and 9 months include, on a pooling of interests basis, the results of Sunstate Restaurant Corp., which Chili's acquired in January 1987.

title: WALTON IS SIDELINED WITH BROKEN FOOT
description: Injuries have plagued Bill Walton for much of his National Basketball Association career. Now, after returning to the lineup to help the Boston Celtics in their defense of the N.B.A. title, an injury has struck down the 6-foot-11-inch center again.

title: KEY RATES
ISS INTERNATIONAL SERVICE SYSTEM (DANISH, CO)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the increase in revenue was mainly because of the Dec. 26 acquisition of the service contracts of Macke Building Services Inc., a division of Allegheny Beverage Corp.

title: 47% Name Economy As Top U.S. Problem
description: Americans say economic difficulties are the nation's most important problem, according to the latest Gallup Poll. But the number who cited unemployment, budget deficits, the high cost of living, taxes and trade deficits was slightly lower than in January.

title: MCKINNEY DIES OF ILLNESS TIES TO AIDS
description: Representative Stewart B. McKinney, a nine-term Republican from Connecticut, died today at Washington Hospital Center of an infection brought on by AIDS. He is the first member of Congress known to have succumbed to the disease.

title: No Headline
description: Whenever opera enthusiasts forgather, the talk eventually comes around to famous works that have not held a place in the standard repertory. Dvorak's ''Rusalka,'' which Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York performed in a concert version on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, is one of those fairy-tale works whose melodic charms and folkish symbolism thrive hardily in Central Europe but tend to wither when exported. (Neither of New York's major companies has staged any of Dvorak's 10 operas.) What proponents of such neglected operas always hope for is the one brilliant, revelatory performance that will propel the favored work into public attention and into major opera houses. That has happened with Janacek's ''Cunning Little Vixen,'' so Dvorak lovers have reason to cherish hopes for this 86-year-old work.

title: Another Message From Rumpelstiltskin
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreigners Amused and Baffled
description: The most intense speculation at the Israeli Embassy's Independence Day celebration on Monday night was not about whether the Israeli position on a proposed international peace conference was really changing or about whether reports of a meeting between the Iraqi and Syrian Presidents were true.

title: CARDS PUMMEL PADRES
description: Skeeter Barnes, in his first time at bat this season, hit a three-run home run and Jack Clark hit a bases-empty homer as the St. Louis Cardinals pounded out 17 hits today and defeated the Padres, 17-10. San Diego (7-23) suffered its second straight loss to the Cardinals and its eighth in the last nine games.

title: Gooden Takes Another Step
description: The fastball made the same old popping noise in the catcher's mitt. The curveball more than once left the hitter frozen. And Dwight Gooden's expression was as it used to be, blank and cool. In some ways, nothing had changed.

title: Sony, ABC Set Betacam Pact
description: The Sony Corporation of America said today that it had completed a long-term agreement to supply Capital Cities/ABC Inc. and its owned and operated television stations with Betacam half-inch professional video production equipment.

title: Europe Rejects Japan's Plea
description: The European Court of Justice rejected today an appeal by five Japanese companies against anti-dumping duties imposed by the European Community. The decision came at a time of worsening trade relations between Japan and the 12-nation trade bloc.

title: Breaking the Stalemate With Cancer
description: In the long war against cancer, physicians have developed three main treatments - surgery, chemotherapy and radiation. Now there is the glimmering of a fourth, which depends on spurring the body's immune defenses with extra doses of its natural battle signals. A new kind of treatment is urgently needed because the present methods, despite the National Cancer Institute's exaggerated claims, seem to have barely improved survival rates over the last three decades.

title: Name Change By Refco L.P.
description: Refco Partners L.P., a primary dealer in government securities, has changed its name to Brophy, Gestal, Knight & Company L.P. It is one of 40 firms recognized by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as an active participant in the system's open-market operations.

title: Bemis Makes Changes In Its Top Management
description: The Bemis Company, a 130-year-old packaging concern based in Minneapolis, announced changes in its top lineup yesterday in what it called an orderly management transition.

title: Ex-Guinness Chief Charged
description: The former chief executive of Guinness P.L.C. was accused today of criminally obstructing justice and falsifying and destroying documents.

title: Banks Again Faces Charges
description: A Federal appeals court ruled Wednesday that Dennis Banks, leader of the American Indian Movement, and three others could be prosecuted in Oregon on 1975 charges of transporting guns and dynamite.

title: BERNARD CHAUS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago results are adjusted on a pro-forma basis, where applicable, to eliminate the amount of stockholders-officers compensation paid in excess of the $780,000 aggregate base salaries annually payable under current employment agreements and for provision for income taxes based on pro-forma income as if the company had formerly not been subject to S Corporation tax status, which terminated June 30, 1986. The company went public last June.

title: TAPED CALLS DISCLOSED IN INSIDER-TRADING CASE
description: Martin A. Siegel, the former investment banker who pleaded guilty to insider-trading charges in February, secretly tape-recorded telephone conversations in January, according to transcripts provided yesterday by the United States Attorney's office to defense attorneys in the insider-trading case.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''KID GLOVES,'' which recently completed five days of shooting in New York, has an eclectic background: it is produced by a native Californian, Joe Wizan (''Jeremiah Johnson,'' ''Tough Guys'') and directed by a British director, David Drury (''Defense of the Realm''). The cinematographer, Jacek Laskus, is from Poland, and the screenwriter, David Fallon, originally hails from Pennsylvania. In other words, the group is an appropriate combination for a story set in the world's greatest melting pot.

title: SHOREHAM SUPPORTERS AND FOES CLASH AT U.S. SENATE HEARING
description: In acrimonious debate before a Senate panel today, opponents and backers of the nuclear power plant at Shoreham, L.I., demonstrated that the gulf between them has grown wider than ever.

title: 'Chagall and the Bible'
description: Biblical influences in works by Marc Chagall will be explored in an exhibition opening Sunday at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street. The exhibition, titled ''Chagall and the Bible,'' features more than 100 etchings done in the 1930's and 50's; the pieces depict images of biblical stories interwoven with memories from the artist's childhood and journeys. Also on display will be 18 paintings by the artist. The show will run through Aug. 9. Weekend viewing hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Sunday. Admission is $4 ($2 for students, children and the elderly). Information: 860-1888.

title: DRUG COURIERS EASY TARGETS ON U.S. 40
description: The night was cool, but the driver was sweating when Trooper Joe Campbell stopped him for speeding, and it did not take long to find out why - two kilograms of cocaine were hidden in the car.

title: AMPLICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DR. EDWARD I. SALISBURY
description: Dr. Edward I. Salisbury, a surgeon and specialist in tropical medicine, died of heart failure April 19 at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 93 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: LALONDE WINS BY DECISION
description: Donny Lalonde of Winnipeg, Canada, won a unanimous 12-round decision from the veteran Mustafa Hamsho of Brooklyn to capture the World Boxing Council Continental Americas light heavyweight title last night at the Felt Forum.

title: Bombs in 2 Peru Ministries
description: Leftist guerrillas exploded bombs in the restrooms of two ministries here today, causing damage but no injuries, the police said. The blasts blew out doors and window at the Energy and Mines Ministry and the Economy Ministry. The police said the explosions appeared to be the work of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement.

title: Capital Mayor's Kin Held
description: The mother-in-law of Mayor Marion Barry Jr. of Washington was charged Wednesday with arson in connection with a house fire, Prince George's County fire officials said. Polly Harris, 58 years old, of Temple Hills, was taken into custody after a two-month investigation, said a country spokesman, Tony DeStefano. Mrs. Harris is the mother of the Mayor's wife, Effi Barry.

title: Suzanne O'Keefe Becomes a Bride
description: Suzanne O'Keefe and Douglas Martin were married last night at the Terrace Restaurant in Manhattan by Judge Leon Deutsch of State Family Court.

title: Reagans Going to Funeral
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, will travel to New York on Saturday to attend the funeral of William J. Casey, the White House announced Thursday. Mr. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, who was a close friend of the President, died Wednesday at at Glen Cove Community Hospital on Long Island. The funeral will be at Roslyn Harbor.

title: TWO CLINTON FESTIVALS CELEBRATE THE ONE-ACT
description: OVER the next five weeks, all kinds of characters will inhabit Hell's Kitchen - that far west area of midtown Manhattan known these days by the gentler name of Clinton.

title: COLONIAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BABIES TO HAVE AIDS CENTER IN HARLEM
description: Fifteen abandoned or orphaned babies with AIDS, most of them likely to die before their second birthday, will have a home in September because of a novel collaboration between Hale House and Harlem Hospital.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TOWER PROBLEMS NOTED ON DAY BEFORE COLLAPSE
description: The day before a high-rise apartment building collapsed here, killing 28 construction workers, an inspector reported alignment problems with some of the structure's support columns, according to an inspection report made public today.

title: INTERNATIONAL ALUMINUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
South Africa Treks Backward
description: The rightward swing in South Africa's whites-only election is bad news for all concerned, especially the winners. President P.W. Botha's National Party increased its majority at the expense of the moderate Progressive Federal Party, which lost 7 of 26 seats. That means the biggest opposition party, with 22 seats out of a total of 166 elected, will henceforth be the Conservatives, hard-core fundamentalists who demand more segregation and repression.

title: VIACOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $48.5 million related to certain surviving provisions of a terminated merger agreement with MCV Holdings Inc. c-Net income and includes a gain from minority interest of $866,000.

title: PASQUA PONDERS STRUGGLE AT PLATE
description: Dan Pasqua sat at the end of the dugout in Comiskey Park the other day, a bat resting against his leg and a bag of sunflower seeds cradled in his hands.

title: DUST OFF THE STILETTOS, IT'S EDGAR WEEK
description: It was her first husband, the mystery publisher - not the other one who vanished without a trace - who put Anita Helen Brooks on the cover of ''Death Takes A Redhead.'' It showed her sprawled out, dead and beautiful, a gleaming dagger protruding from her heart.

title: TESTIMONY REVEALS DIFFERING VIEWS OF CURBS ON CONTRA AID
description: Testimony in the Iran-contra hearings this week shows that Administration officials held sharply differing views about what the laws restricting aid to the contras permitted them to do.

title: JEANTOT BREAKS HIS MARK IN BOC CHALLENGE
description: The ability to set a record at sea is an arduous task by any standard. But Philippe Jeantot, the French solo sailor, has proved that he can do it more than once.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday about Gary Hart's fund raising misidentified the home state of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. He is from Massachusetts, not Michigan. The same dispatch misidentified a former Democratic national chairman. He is John C. White.

title: Chevron Sells Danish Interest
description: The Chevron Corporation said that it had sold its 15 percent interest in the Dansk Underground Consortium, which operates oil and gas properties in the North Sea off Denmark.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Mac (Dr. John) Rebennack, Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn Heights (718-834-8794). New Yorkers who just missed the sheer musical bliss of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival can console themselves with this solo performance. Dr. John plays from inside the New Orleans piano tradition, subtly shifting his own colorful persona through the prisms of earlier styles such as Professor Longhair's and Huey (Piano) Smith's. Dr. John plays tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets are $10.

title: Hollings on the Spot
description: When a United States Senator calls another country a ''second-rate nation,'' someone is likely to notice. In this case, the Senator was Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, the target of his scorn was Britain, and the result is a minor uproar in the British press.

title: Distrust of Reagan Shown in Poll
description: As Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair began this week, more of the American public than ever before said President Reagan was lying when he said he did not know that money from the arms sales to Iran went to help the Nicaraguan rebels, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE OF NEW MEXCO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IT'S TO BE GRADUAL CHANGE, BOTHA SAYS
description: President P. W. Botha, after widening his parliamentary majority in whites-only elections Wednesday, said today that he had won a mandate for security measures and gradual change.

title: INTERNATIONAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Both year-ago periods were restated to reflect the acquisitions of PEI Associates Inc. in January 1987 and Delian Corp. in February 1987.

title: JAPANESE PURCHASES LIFT BONDS
description: The financial markets weathered a major Treasury financing in strong fashion yesterday, as a surge of orders from Japanese securities firms lifted bond prices and created hopes that the trend toward higher interest rates has been stymied.

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DONOVAN CASE CALLED AN EFFORT TO GET PUBLICITY
description: A lawyer for former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan concluded his defense yesterday by charging that a Bronx prosecutor had created a false criminal case against Mr. Donovan for publicity purposes.

title: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $15,206,000 for relocation of the company's insurance operations to Orlando, Fla. The latest-quarter loss also includes results of operations of Holt, Rinehart & Winston and W. B. Saunders, which were acquired in December 1986.

title: ONE MORE UPHEAVAL, LOOSED BY THE SAVAGE SKIES
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 7 -

title: NORD RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $380,000 and $170,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: FARMER BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $38,873,000 and $100,752,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $95,736,000 for the quarter and $94,317,000 for the 9 months. The company said both the latest quarter and 9 months include a writedown of $18.2 million relating to the sale of Entex's savings and loan subsidiary, and a charge of $14.1 million from the sale of two subsidiaries.

title: Canadian Composer Wins Glenn Gould Prize
description: The first Glenn Gould Prize, which carries a cash award of $50,000 (Canadian), is to be awarded to R. Murray Schafer, a composer, the Glenn Gould Memorial Foundation has announced.

title: Pen and Ink
description: In a duel of autographing authors, Gary Carter and Lenny Dykstra of the Mets battled with pen-clenching fists yesterday while promoting sales of their books about the 1986 championship team.

title: M.T.A. IS STILL SEEKING AN IDEAL GRIME GRABBER
description: A three-year onslaught on grime and graffiti has left nearly two-thirds of New York City's subway fleet clean but the Transit Authority still searching for the perfect substance to remove the scrawl.

title: Wickes Is Sued Over Carpeting
description: The Wickes Companies said that a customer of its recently acquired Collins & Aikman subsidiary had filed suit over the purchase of carpeting that purportedly failed to meet fire safety standards. The company said it would vigorously contest the suit.

title: Mutual Fund Assets Dip
description: Assets of the nation's 382 money market mutual funds decreased $2.02 billion, to $236.27 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 93 institutional funds were down $285.2 million, to $64.70 billion. Assets of the 200 general purpose funds fell $573.7 million, to $66.70 billion. The 89 broker-dealer funds fell $1.16 billion, to $104.88 billion.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: PATRICIA KLUGE was seated in the flower-decked Grand Ballroom of the Plaza, diamonds sparkling at her ears, neck and fingers, the skirt of her floral-patterned Scaasi ball gown billowing around her. ''It's the first society party for AIDS,'' she said. ''It's a small thing, but we're doing what we can.''

title: The Most Vital Skill in Congress
description: What's the single most important quality or skill in a United States senator or representative? (A) Legal and analytical capacity, like that reflected in the Congressional Iran-contra hearings. (B) Honesty and integrity. (C) Substantive expertise in fields like national defense, taxes or social welfare. (D) Experience in public office. (E) Ability to raise money.

title: Making the Grade In All Tests
description: The term ''thinking man's ballplayer'' might describe a talented young athlete who remembers his team's plays, understands the infield fly rule and is careful to make plans for a career teaching physical education should he fail to land a contract in professional sports.

title: ALPHA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $2 million charge from settlement of claims made by Raytheon Co.

title: 'Salute to Mothers!'
description: ''A Salute to Mothers!'' will be presented by the Dance Theater of Harlem at 3 P.M. Sunday at the Synod Hall of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street. Members of the Dance Theater's workshop ensemble will take part in the show, along with Randy Weston, a jazz pianist, and Uttara Coorlawala, a dancer. Admission is $3; $1.50 for children; free for all mothers accompanied by children. Information: 977-7751 or 690-2800.

title: The U.N. Today: May 8, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: MCI Chairman Recuperating
description: William G. McGowan, chairman of the MCI Communications Corporation, received a heart transplant April 25 and has been making steady progress in his recovery, a spokeswoman for Presbyterian-University Hospital in Pittsburgh said yesterday.

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain on sale of property of $908,717, or 12 cents a share.

title: 2 Festivals Planned On Upper West Side
description: Two festivals on the Upper West Side -along Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues - are planned this weekend.

title: Volvo Lifts Stake In Pharmacia A.B.
description: Volvo A.B., the Swedish automobile maker, raised its interest in the biotechnology industry with a $40 million purchase of shares in Pharmacia A.B., a drug concern. The purchase raised Volvo's stake in Pharmacia to 43 percent of voting rights from 31 percent. Reflecting this, Volvo's chairman, Pehr G. Gyllenhammer, is set to take over as chairman of Pharmacia, Volvo said.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results reflect restatement of the 1986 period to account for the investment in CBS Inc. on the equity method, and such restatement resulted in a decrease in net income of $3,606,000, or 4 cents a share. The latest first quarter revenue includes excise taxes of $69,713,000 paid on sales of manufactured products, compared with $79,453,000 for the year-ago period. The year-ago revenue also includes pre-tax gain on settlement of a pension plan obligation of $22,101,000.

title: Bronfmans Ending Trust
description: The family trust set up by the late Samuel Bronfman, who built the Seagram Company into the world's largest distiller, will be broken up this year to allow his heirs to invest their fortune as they see fit. Seagram's co-chairman and

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net realized gains of $26,559,000 for the latest quarter and $12,402,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Piggott Is Charged
description: Lester Piggott, the retired British champion jockey, is to stand trial in London on tax-evasion charges. Piggott, now a trainer, faces 12 charges that he cheated the Inland Revenue and Value Added Tax collectors by not disclosing income of $5.89 million. Bail was set at $392,000 and no trial date was set.

title: MDC ASSET INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are not available; the company began operations this year.

title: Bonn Coalition Openly Split on Short-Range Arms
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition openly split today during a Parliamentary debate on the elimination of shorter-range nuclear missiles from Europe.

title: DEAVER ACID RAIN TALKS CITED
description: Michael K. Deaver discussed with President Reagan the appointment of a special envoy to Canada on acid rain before he left the White House to become a lobbyist for Canada, according to papers filed in Federal District Court here today.

title: Flyers Add Wing
description: A Swedish left wing, Magnus Roupe, has joined the Philadelphia Flyers for the remainder of the playoffs and will be with the team Friday in Montreal. Roupe, 24, had 11 goals, 6 assists and 58 penalty minutes in 31 games this season with Farjestad of the Swedish Elite Division. He also was a member of the Swedish National Team, which won the World Championships last week in Vienna, Austria.

title: ATOM POWER AIDE IS TAKING A LEAVE
description: Thomas M. Roberts, a member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, announced today that he was taking a leave of absence to prepare explanatory testimony for a Senate subcommittee whose questions about allegations of misconduct he refused to answer Wednesday.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IT'S easy to sail right by the Jane Street Seafood Cafe on lower Eighth Avenue without ever noticing it, as I have done dozens of times. The nine-year-old restaurant's weathered-wood facade clings to the bow of a big brick apartment house, and the lack of a conspicuous sign leaves the impression it is just a neighborhood watering hole with New England pretensions. Inside, however, is a neighborly, sleeves-up fish house that prepares a staggering variety of fish and shellfish.

title: Veterans Charge U.S. Seeks to Harass Them
description: The Federal Government is trying to harass the Vietnam Veterans of America by issuing a subpoena demanding virtually all the organization's communications with Congress, clients and reporters, officials of the group said today.

title: SUBSIDIZING THE RICH
description: To the Editor:

title: MOON TO BE THE STAR OF ASTRONOMY DAY
description: There aren't many shows that allow spectators a free preview. But, clear skies permitting, the star of a celebration tomorrow at the Andrus Planetarium in Yonkers can be seen tonight with a quick glance to the heavens.

title: FILM: 'GARDENS OF STONE' PORTRAYS VIETNAM ERA
description: IN the initial sequence of ''Gardens of Stone,'' Francis Coppola's screen version of Nicholas Proffitt's novel, the camera observes the procedures of a military funeral at Arlington National Cemetery with dispassionate, reportorial efficiency.

title: WASHINGTON POST REPORTS LIAISON BETWEEN HART AND SECOND WOMAN
description: The Washington Post reported today that Gary Hart decided to withdraw from the Presidential campaign hours after the newspaper presented a top campaign official with ''documented evidence of a recent liaison between Hart and a Washington woman.''

title: Anne Frank's Words
description: To The Editor:

title: The Divine Right
description: If there were any wisps of doubt about the Reagan Administration's involvement in arming the Nicaraguan contras, the first few days of Congressional hearings have blown them away. Ambassadors, C.I.A. agents and lawyers, Director William Casey and numerous White House staff members played vital parts in the covert operation.

title: HART WILL REPORTEDLY QUIT RACE FOR PRESIDENCY TODAY IN STORM OVER PRIVATE LIFE
description: Gary Hart will announce his withdrawal from the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination at a news conference in Denver today, his friends and campaign associates said yesterday.

title: THE TESTIMONY SUGGESTS HIGH OFFICIALS REJECTED THE LAWS ON COVERT ACTIONS
description: Out of the welter of details about Swiss bank accounts and arms shipments, one theme has emerged from the Congressional testimony of Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord: Some high Reagan Administration officials fostered a private, clandestine intelligence service for operations that the Government was unable or unwilling to undertake.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
IN MALTA VOTE, A MAIN ISSUE IS ORIENTATION
description: The tiny population of this rocky island fortress will vote Saturday in a bitterly contested election that looks like a turning point in Malta's long and turbulent history.

title: Texas Air, Northwest Cite Losses
description: The Texas Air Corporation yesterday reported a loss of $100.7 million for the first quarter, compared with a loss of $11.2 million in the first quarter last year. The company said the 1987 loss resulted largely from the integration of such acquisitions as People Express into its Continental Airlines.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Al Carmines, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005). During the 20 years that the Rev. Al Carmines served as a minister at the Judson Memorial Church on Washington Square, he wrote a series of provocative and award-winning Off Broadway musicals, including ''Peace,'' ''Promenade,'' ''The Gorilla Queen,'' ''Home Movies'' and ''In Circles,'' which has lyrics by Gertrude Stein. He also wrote an oratorio, ''Christmas Wrappings,'' which was performed annually at the church for a decade, and appeared occasionally in cabarets around town. Mr. Carmines resigned from the Judson Church in 1981. He is now minister of the Rauschenbusch Memorial United Church of Christ, at 407 West 43d Street, in the building housing the Westside Arts Theater. And he is again expanding his activities beyond the church. Tonight he returns to cabaret music with the first of a series of Friday and Saturday performances at the Ballroom, taking over the 6:30 P.M. spot occupied by Blossom Dearie for the past eight months. Mr. Carmines's last appearance at the Ballroom was 10 years ago, at its original location in SoHo. His programs included such expected cabaret material as songs by Cole Porter, Irving Berlin and Noel Coward, such unexpected material as his musical settings for lyrics by Miss Stein, Kay Solomon and Mao Zedong, and possibly songs of one of his favorite singers, Bessie Smith - whom, he has said, he has always wanted to play in the movies. Shows are tonight and tomorrow at 6:30. There is a $15 music charge and a two-drink minimum.

title: Firebomber Attacks Dutch Chief's Home
description: A firebomb was thrown through a window of Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers's home on Wednesday night, but the Prime Minister threw it back into the street, the police said today.

title: Carlton to Start Again
description: Lefty is his nickname and starting has been his game for most of the 325 victories and four Cy Young Awards he has achieved in the major leagues. So Steve Carlton was very happy to hear that he will be back in the starting rotation for the Cleveland Indians next Tuesday night, switching with Scott Bailes, a 25-year-old left-hander who will go back to the bullpen after tonight's start against Kansas City. ''It's what I've done my whole career,'' said the Carlton, 42, who is 2-2 with a 4.91 earned run average and 1 save in nine relief appearances this season. ''I've been spotty in relief. I haven't really been satisfied with myself. I'm used to making my own trouble. I've been in the flow only a couple of times.'' Manager Pat Corrales sees Bailes as filling the Indians' most crucial need - relief pitching, where he did some of his best work as a rookie last season.

title: CHAIRMAN APPOINTS LAWYER TO KEY POST ON CORRUPTION PANEL
description: Thomas J. Schwarz, an expert on campaign financing, has been named special counsel to a commission created by Governor Cuomo to investigate corruption at all levels of government in New York State.

title: Courageous Finland
description: To the Editor:
