title: NEW EFFORT FOR MIDEAST TALKS FACES OLD SNAG
description: An American diplomat has been shuttling back and forth between Jerusalem and this hilly capital for the last several weeks with revision after revision of the details of a proposed international Middle East peace conference.

title: DR. ISABELLE B. WINGATE
description: Dr. Isabelle Barnum Wingate, an authority on textiles and a professor at the New York University School of Retailing for 44 years, died at her home in Manhattan on Saturday. She was 85 years old.

title: The Hatcher Era
description: Richard Hatcher escaped defeat as Mayor of Gary, Ind., four years ago mainly because of the dejection that hangs over his city the way smoke from steel mills used to. This year, enough voters roused themselves to end his 20 years in office. His Democratic primary defeat by Thomas Barnes, once a Hatcher supporter, ends an era.

title: INFERTILITY LINKED TO CONTRACEPTION
description: Sexually active women who use barrier birth-control methods such as condoms or diaphragms with spermicides are safer from a major type of infertility than those using any other contraceptive technique, a study says.

title: 'Salt Peanuts'
description: Dizzy Gillespie, the jazz trumpeter, will celebrate his 70th birthday and 50th anniversary in music with a concert June 6 at the Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts outside Washington. He has invited lots of people he has performed with to play at his party: Benny Carter, Jon Faddis, Slide Hampton, J. J. Johnson, Carmen McCrae, Wynton Marsalis and Sonny Rollins. Yesterday, while visiting the area to work out details, he said he was adding another to his list, Jimmy Carter.

title: STAGE: 'EDUCATING RITA,' WITH LAURIE METCALF
description: ''EDUCATING RITA'' is a Pygmalion play with a slight ''Equus'' twist. A teacher educates - and elevates - a vulgar, waif-like student and, to his dismay, the student sheds her distinctive coloration and eagerly embraces conformity. This is, of course, taking ''Educating Rita'' too seriously. At its heart, the Willy Russell two-hander is a comedy about an odd couple who have nothing in common except for the fact that they are the only characters on stage. This is in direct contrast to Shirley Lauro's one-act version of ''Open Admissions,'' which dealt far more incisively with the problems of urban education.

title: DAMSON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from early extinguishment of debentures of $3,115,000 and $1,137,000 for the latest year and year- earlier period, respectively.

title: FOSTER AGENCIES LOSE A DECISION OVER ABORTIONS
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that all foster-care agencies that do business with New York City, including the Roman Catholic Church, must begin to provide contraception and abortion services in group foster homes on July 1.

title: SPARTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter includes a writeoff of about $500,000 in dryhole costs.

title: DIXON TICONDEROGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $32,544 and $213,945 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $18,056 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $76,732 for the 6 months; the 6-month also includes an extraordinary credit of $205,427.

title: A COMPUTER FULL OF SURPRISES
description: Danny Hillis clearly remembers the moment of inspiration for his Connection Machine. It came as he watched a baby recognize its mother's face.

title: EXPERIMENTAL THEATRICS ABOUND DOWNTOWN
description: ANYONE who still clings to the notion that experimental theater is synonymous with grim, impenetrable abstractions should be happily surprised by the playful spirit and physical vitality emanating from Manhattan's downtown stages throughout this weekend.

title: Our Towns; Seeking a Cure For What Ails The Jersey Shore
description: Roy Mittman spent his boyhood summers on the Jersey Shore, at Belmar. He remembers a brighter and better ocean.

title: MORE FROM SECORD: A DAY OF TOUGH QUESTIONING ON MOTIVES AND THE MONEY
description: In his third day of testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington, Richard V. Secord was repeatedly questioned about his handling of millions of dollars in the Iran-contra affair. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony. Keeping $8 Million ARTHUR L. LIMAN: Where is the $8 million that is being held today under the control of Mr. Hakim?

title: CHARTWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $13,000 from discontinued operations and a tax benefit of $164,000.

title: GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $16,173,000 for the latest quarter and $21,000 for the year-ago period. The latest first quarter's net includes a gain of $38.2 million from the previously disclosed sale of the company's investment in Imperial Continental Gas Association. The quarter also includes dividend income of $4.6 million related to the Imperial shares. Results for the year-ago quarter were restated to reflect a change in accounting for oil and gas operations.

title: NOT AS HARSH AS HOUSE'S
description: The Senate Finance Committee today approved its trade bill, a much less retaliatory measure than that passed by the House last week.

title: The Inscrutable Americans
description: Europeans are having extra tongue exercise clucking at peculiar American habits, especially the way the U.S. treats Presidents and Presidential candidates.

title: Venice Moves to Limit Entrance of Tourists
description: The government of this city so beloved by travelers acted today to limit the influx of tourists who come here to gaze at the canals and palaces.

title: ART: GUIGOU'S DEPICTIONS OF HIS BELOVED PROVENCE
description: THE short-lived Provencal landscape painter Paul Guigou (1834-1871) will never rate high in the history books, but on more than one count he deserves the exhibition of close to 40 of his paintings that can be seen through May 30 at William Beadleston Inc., 60 East 91st Street. Organized in cooperation with the London consortium of art dealers known as the Artemis Group, the show springs from an exceptional and clearly genuine commitment to Guigou on the part of Timothy Bathurst of Artemis. ''Guigoumania'' is his word for it, and we believe him.

title: PERES SAYS ISRAEL FACES BAEST CHANCE FOR MIDEAST PEACE
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said today that Israel was facing its greatest opportunity to make peace with Jordan and the Palestinians by going to an international conference.

title: Bouncing Back
description: Painfully aware of professional soccer's fall from notoriety to obscurity in this country, some local former soccer executives have formed an outdoor regional league that will operate on a limited budget beginning in 1988. With Clive Toye, the former president of the Cosmos, as chairman, and Chuck Blazer, the former executve vice president of the United States Soccer Federation, as commissioner, the American Soccer League has five teams committed to start operations next spring.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IF the food were half as impressive as the setting at the new Painted Desert, this would be an unforgettable evening. In short, it's not, at least at this early stage. The striking six-week-old restaurant, in the landmark American Thread Building on West Broadway south of Canal Street, occupies the space of the former Paradis. It is owned by Robert Farley, who also has Black Rock on Avenue of the Americas, Le Picnic on West 62d Street, and a soon-to-open Southern-style restaurant and jazz club on East 63d Street to be called the Cotton Ground, in partnership with the actress Cicely Tyson.

title: DOLE URGES REAGAN TO NEGOTIATE WITH CONGRESS ON THE 1988 BUDGET
description: The Republican leader in the Senate said today that it was time for President Reagan to begin negotiating with Congress on the 1988 budget.

title: INDEPENDENT INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $771,000 for the latest quarter and $4,618,000 for the year-ago period.

title: RENT RISE IMPERILS WEST SIDE BAKERY
description: Alfonso Velasquez muttered about ''rotten capitalists'' as he wiped Hungarian strudel dough off his hands. An elderly woman in a fur-trimmed coat vowed she would ''call somebody about this terrible thing'' and went back to inspecting four loaves of rye to pick one that was not too seedy or too dark.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS REORGANIZE GAIN
description: After three months of negotiations, rival Nicaraguan rebel leaders have agreed to form a new guerrilla organization that appears to leave the main rebel army intact but may open the way for a new political program and new political leaders.

title: INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1.4 million for the quarter and $2.6 million for the 6 months; the 6 months is also after a loss of $1,502,000 from early extinguishment of debt. c-After tax credits of $700,000 for the quarter and $1.4 million for the 6 months; the 6 months also includes a loss of $424,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: POLL FINDS INFIDELITY A LESSER EVIL THAN OTHERS IN PICKING CANDIDATE
description: The issue that seems to have doomed Gary Hart's quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, that of marital fidelity, appears to be considerably less important to Americans in their voting choices than other lapses of personal conduct, such as cheating on income taxes, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: 2 in U.S. Charged in Plot to Kill Nicaragua Chief
description: Two men described by the authorities as right-wing extremists have been indicted by a Federal grand jury in Oklahoma on charges of plotting to murder President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua.

title: Women's Groups to Press for Parental Leave
description: Major women's organizations rallied today behind legislation that would require employers to grant up to 18 weeks of unpaid leave to workers to take care of newborn or seriously ill children.

description: b-After a tax credit of $566,000. c-Net loss The company acquired Northwest- Northside Rehabilitative Inc. and United Rehabilitation Inc. in February.

title: CITIZENS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE STAGE: YALE REPERTORY OFFERS DARIO FO'S 'ELIZABETH'
description: The removal of the State Department ban against Dario Fo has made it possible for this iconoclastic playwright-performer to travel freely between Italy and the United States. American audiences eager for political satire will clearly benefit from the cultural exchange, as they did last season when Mr. Fo toured his one-man show, ''Mistero Buffo.''

title: ITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring pre-tax charge of $2.2 million.

title: F.D.A. DISPUTES CLAIMS FOR SKIN CREAMS
description: One skin cream now on the market promises to ''prevent, postpone and minimize the effects of the aging process.'' Another asserts it will ''re-create the structure of a young skin.'' And a third says it will ''cause cells to divide and reproduce faster - the key to skin rejuvenation.''

title: GOLDEN POULTRY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Canada, Finding No Crimes, Calls Off Iran Arms Inquiry
description: A police investigation of two Canadian businessmen who had been linked to a Saudi arms dealer, Adnan M. Khashoggi, and the sale of United States weapons to Iran has found no evidence of criminal wrongdoing, Solicitor General James Kelleher said this week.

title: BALLET: BUREYEV JOINS TCHERKASSKY IN 'GISELLE'
description: The title role of ''Giselle'' is a legendary challenge for ballerinas. Yet every Giselle needs an Albrecht, a dancer who can be persuasive in the work's leading male role. If Giselle and Albrecht are well matched, then this ballet about how a nobleman in disguise courts an innocent peasant can be a poignant theatrical experience.

title: TORIES DO WELL, SIGNALING A JUNE VOTE
description: Britain still seemed on course for a June general election today after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party made a solid showing in 12,000 local elections throughout England, Wales and Scotland.

title: CABARET: AMANDA McBROOM
description: New York City's cabaret world is so drenched in Broadway and European traditions that it is refreshing to discover West Coast performers who bring a different perspective to a genre so weighted with history. Amanda McBroom, who returned to the Ballroom (253 West 28th Street) on Tuesday for a two-week engagement, doesn't refer to Judy Garland, Edith Piaf or Mabel Mercer. Ms. McBroom, who is best known as the composer of ''The Rose,'' writes songs with country-flavored melodies and folksy autobiographical lyrics that are strongly Middle American in feel. Her most distinguished songs, like ''The Portrait,'' a heartfelt meditation on mother-daughter relationships, have a weight comparable to Joni Mitchell's and Judy Collins's better art songs.

title: GV MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Schoolboy Slugger
description: Dan Ruff, a pitcher and second baseman for Fairfield Union High School in Lancaster, Ohio, is happy that he finally has broken the national high school career record for home runs. ''I was getting overanxious a lot and swinging at bad pitches,'' said the senior slugger after cracking homer No. 52, his 13th this season, in a 18-6 victory over Bloom-Carroll in which Ruff was also the winning pitcher. ''When I got to first base, it seemed like all the pressure turned off like a water faucet or something.'' Ruff, who has signed a letter-of-intent to attend Michigan, broke the record set last year by Butch Harris of Broken Bow, Okla.

description: JOHN HEGLE first took out a student loan during his freshman year at Southwest Missouri State University in Springfield. Eight loans and seven years later, Mr. Hegle, now armed with a master's degree in public administration, has joined the labor force $20,000 in debt.

description: In articulating the philosophy of the growing women's movement, Ms. touched a chord among young readers when it first came out in 1972. Circulation jumped from a first-issue sellout of 250,000 copies to nearly double that number five years later.

HASIDIM LOSE COURT CASE ON BUS DRIVERS
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that barring women from driving district school buses for Hasidic boys in a New York State community violated the Constitution's separation of church and state.

title: Lloyd's Ex-Head Fined
description: The ruling body of Lloyd's of London has fined a former chairman $:32,500, or about $54,600, for what it called negligence before and during his tenure at the helm of the insurance market. The former chairman, Sir Peter Green, was censured for his involvement in an offshore firm that was used to reinsure policies initially underwritten by his own syndicates at Lloyd's. He was judged to have made a personal profit of $182,160. The council censured and fined Sir Peter for what it called ''seriously negligent acts of omission.''

title: CHAMBERS TRIES TO BAR THE PRESS FROM HEARING
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan, citing possible prejudicial publicity, excluded the news media yesterday from a hearing on whether a videotaped statement by the man accused of killing Jennifer Levin in Central Park last August should be used as evidence.

title: INSIDE
description: F.B.I. Studies Embassy

title: CORPORATE TRANSFERS: HARD CHOICES AND CHEERFUL 'Y' ALLLS'
description: By the time William R. Howell, chairman and chief executive of the J. C.Penney Company, ended persistent rumors and told employees last week that the company was moving its headquarters from Manhattan to Dallas, many were already resigned that more than just their jobs would be changing.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in March 1987. The company said the year-ago loss included a pre-tax charge of $80,000,000 to reflect a writedown in crude oil and refined products inventories.

title: Funk and Blues
description: The harmonica player Sugar Blue will lead his funk-blues band tomorrow at midnight at the Limelight, 660 Avenue of the Americas, at 20th Street (807-7850). Admission is $12.

title: BUCKS BEAT CELTICS IN OVERTIME, 126-121
description: Sidney Moncrief scored 6 points in overtime and Ricky Pierce hit the go-ahead basket with 1 minutes 16 seconds to play tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks beat the Boston Celtics, 126-121, for their first victory in the Eastern Conference semifinal playoffs.

title: Backup Again?
description: For the last two seasons at Miami, Geoff Torretta was the backup quarterback to Vinny Testaverde, the Heisman Trophy winner and No. 1 pick in the National Football League college draft by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Torretta has an opportunity to continue that specialty assignment this season, for the Bucs have signed him as a free agent. ''Geoff was impressive in his workout,'' said Ray Perkins, the Tampa Bay coach. ''He looked good enough that we felt he deserved the opportunity to make our team.''

title: SECORD'S LAST DAY: HARD QUESTIONS AND AN UNUSUAL PROPOSAL
description: Richard V. Secord made his last scheduled appearance yesterday before a Congressional hearing in Washington, testifying on covert operations in the Iran-contra affair. Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser, is scheduled as the next witness when the hearings resume Monday. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from Mr. Secord's testimony. A Casey Memorial

description: When 36 top-ranked pairs begin play this afternoon in the Cavendish Club's annual Invitational Charity Pairs, five pairs of women are to take part. Among them are Gu Ling and Zhang Yalan of China and Li Jing and Gu Xing of Hong Kong.

The appearance, part of his reward, was pianistically impressive in many ways but left an incomplete picture of the young Frenchman as a musician.

title: YANKS RALLY WITH SLAM
description: Maybe the Yankees won't lose at home this season. Well, they know they'll lose a game at Yankee Stadium eventually, but they weren't about to let it happen last night.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: Despite rising bond prices and a firmer dollar, the stock market slid yesterday for the second straight day, although trading was enlivened by special situations, including takeover rumors.

title: Deaver Said to Refuse A 2d Jury Appearance
description: Michael K. Deaver, the former Presidential aide, refused to testify a second time before a Federal grand jury that is investigating his lobbying activities, a special prosecutor disclosed today.

title: MORRIS F. GOLDBERGER
description: Dr. Morris F. Goldberger, an obstetrician and gynecologist who retired from a medical practice in Manhattan in 1965, died Wednesday in St. Anthony's Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla. A resident of New Rochelle, N.Y., who was vacationing in St. Petersburg Beach, Fla., when he became ill, he was 101 years old.

title: OPERA: CLARION CONCERTS IN 17TH-CENTURY 'RIVALI'
description: Newell Jenkins and his Clarion Concerts have performed noble service over the years on behalf of Agostino Steffani, a German-based Italian Baroque composer. But the concert presentation of the fifth Steffani opera the group has offered since 1973, ''Le Rivali Concordi,'' Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, was no great success.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Art of Dance

title: HART IS LEGALLY OBLIGATED TO PAY $1.3 MILLION 1984 DEBT
description: Gary Hart's departure from the 1988 Presidential campaign does not end his legal and financial obligations under Federal election laws.

title: How Right-to-Lifers Promote Abortion
description: In July 1986 the world's population, which didn't top a billion until 1850, passed the five billion mark. The Population Institute, a public-interest group that seeks a better balance between population and world resources, warns that the five billion may be ten billion by 2028. All the more reason to lament the Reagan Administration's abandonment of family planning overseas out of misguided obeisance to the right to life movement.

title: FLYERS WIN BY 4-3 AND LEAD MONTREAL
description: When playoff hockey is properly played, the game comes down to a duel between two goalies, both of whom view it as their task to play flawlessly - or else.

title: CHASE LIFTS C.D. RATES BROADLY
description: In the latest salvo in an emerging marketing war, the Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday announced a broad increase in the rates it pays on consumers' certificates of deposit.

title: HART DROPS RACE FOR WHITE HOUSE IN A DEFIANT MOOD
description: Gary Hart, saying he was ''angry and defiant'' but finally overwhelmed by controversy, withdrew from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today, ending a four-year drive for the White House just five days after a public storm began over his private life.

title: SAMSON ENERGY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a $15,058,000 non-cash writedown of the carrying value of Samson Energy oil and gas properties.

title: At Last, an 'Arms Control' Agreement
description: ''The first arms control agreement of the Reagan Administration,'' Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard Perle calls it. The accord, whose terms were wrapped up by American and Soviet negotiators this week, is unusual in two respects. Its provisions do not deal with arms levels at all. And much of the credit for its achievement belongs to Mr. Perle, no fan of military agreements with Moscow.

description: Friends and political associates of Representative Stewart B. McKinney said today that the Connecticut Republican, who died Thursday of an AIDS-related infection, had had homosexual relationships.

description: When the Caltex Petroleum Corporation decided to move its headquarters from Manhattan to the Dallas suburbs in 1982, Amy C. Tubens, a secretary, was apprehensive about leaving her home in Jackson Heights, Queens, to live here.

Paris Is Dangerous? Check Princeton
description: ''But what about the terrorists?'' people ask my husband and me when we tell them we are moving to Paris from the idyllic college town of Princeton, N.J. Paris used to be known for April flowers and singin' in the rain, for cafes and croissants and head-turning fashion. Funny how a reputation can be ruined just like that.

title: ASTRONAUT'S FAMILY REACHES SETTLEMENT WITH ROCKET MAKER
description: The wife and children of Ronald E. McNair, the astronaut killed in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, agreed Thursday to settle their lawsuit against Morton Thiokol Inc., lawyers said.

Chinese Order a Japanese Reporter to Leave
description: China ordered a Japanese journalist to leave the country within 10 days today, after accusing him of stealing information related to national security.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 9, 1987
description: The Economy Chase Manhattan raised its rates on C.D.'s as a marketing war among New York banks heated up. Chase said it would pay 6.40 percent on a six-month C.D., up from 5.44 percent, and raised rates on other consumer C.D.'s comparably. Chemical Bank raised its rates twice this week, and Citibank raised its rates as well. One factor behind the increases is that the banks have lifted the rates they charge on loans. Another is that they are seeking to attract money into their ''all-in-one accounts.'' [ Page 37. ] The Veterans Administration said it was raising its maximum interest rate for federally backed home mortgages to 10 percent, from 9.5 percent. [ 39. ] Unemployment fell 0.3 percent in April, to 6.2 percent, its lowest level in seven years.

description: b-After a loss on early retirement of debt of $118,000.

description: The American Civil Liberties Union, in what may be the first Federal lawsuit of its kind, asked a judge yesterday to bar the city of Long Branch from helping to create a symbolic Orthodox Jewish religious district.

title: Much To Regret
description: It was never clear that Gary Hart would be elected President or even that he would be the Democratic nominee in 1988. His downfall and political demise is a sad spectacle, nonetheless, and one that must leave many an American uneasy and disheartened.

title: HART'S MOVE MAGNIFIES ROLE OF EARLIEST CONTESTS
description: With Gary Hart out of the Presidential race, Democrats today faced the prospect of a protracted nomination battle among a field of candidates who are largely without national stature.

description: ''The Wonderful Ice Cream Suit'' fits neatly into the Lamb's Theater Company's Little Theater. Ray Bradbury wrote this small tall tale more than a decade ago; it reached Off Off Broadway just in time for a newspaper strike and vanished. The new and spirited production is an argument against newspaper strikes.

The measure grants administrative jurisdiction over the trail, an important trade and settlement route from about 1820 to 1880, to the Secretary of Interior.

The treatment was done with magnetic particles that are heated by induction. The inventor, Dr. Robert T. Gordon, reports that laboratory trials of the method have proved successful.

VEBA's chairman, Rudolf Bennigsen-Foerder, said the VEBA subsidiary Chemische Werke Huls A.G. would buy the chemical and plastics divisions of Dynamit Nobel A.G. and assume its debts in a deal valued at 1.3 billion marks, or $734 million. Dynamit Nobel is part of Feldmuhle Nobel A.G., the public company formed after Friedrich Karl Flick sold his conglomerate in 1985.

title: 9 ARE REPORTED SLAIN IN ULSTER IN BATTLE AT A POLICE STATION
description: Security forces tonight killed eight attackers who rammed a bomb-laden earthmover into a County Armagh police station, the authorities said. They reported a bystander slain and three officers wounded.

THE STORYTELLER IS PART OF THE TALE
description: In Alice McDermott's critically acclaimed new novel, ''That Night,'' the narrator comments that ''even children know you cannot separate the tale from the teller.'' The narrator, because of what is going on in her own life, is obsessed with an event she witnessed one night more than 20 years ago, when she was 10 years old - a teen-age boy, unaware that his girlfriend is pregnant and that she has been sent away to relatives in another state, drives onto the lawn in front of the girl's house in a Long Island suburb in the 1960's, threatens her mother and gets into a fight with the neighbors.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Navratilova and Graf Gain: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova beat West Germany's Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday to reach the semifinals of the $150,000 Italian Open in Rome. The victory set up a match between Navratilova and Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, who outclassed Aranxta Sanchez of Spain, 6-0, 6-0. Second-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany defeated Bettina Fulco of Argentina, 6-4, 6-4, and will meet third-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, who beat Judith Polzl of Austraia, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) Mecir Advances: Second-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia defeated Todd Witsken, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday to advance to the men's singles semifinals in the $200,000 Gunze World Tennis '87 tournament in Kobe, Japan. Mecir will meet Japan's Shuzo Matsuoka, who surprised Tim Wilkison, 6-3, 6-3. In women's singles, Pam Shriver, the second-seeded player, used powerful serves to beat Carling Bassett of Canada, 6-2, 6-1, in 48 minutes and advance to the semifinals.(AP) Golf Crenshaw in 4-Way Tie: Ben Crenshaw's late eagle caused a four-way tie yesterday that included unheralded Bob Lohr after 36 holes of the storm-delayed Byron Nelson Golf Classic in Irving, Tex. Crenshaw, with a 65, was tied with Donnie Hammond, who had a 63; Tom Byrum, who shot 65, and Lohr, with a 62, at nine-under par 131.

title: Susan Mannion Weds James Robert Emmert
description: Susan Joy Mannion, a coordinator of corporate public affairs for the Philip Morris Companies, and James Robert Emmert, an assistant vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers, both in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Paul Curtin, a great-uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in West Hempstead, L.I.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bankers Trust New York Corp. said it might acquire the British investment performance measurement concern World Markets Co., which does business as Wm Co. and provides investment services on more than $250 billion of assets.

title: MODEL, IN SECLUSION, SAYS SHE IS EMOTIONALLY DRAINED BY TURMOIL OVER HART
description: Donna Rice said from seclusion today that she was emotionally drained by the political turmoil that was set in motion a week ago when she traveled to Washington to spend a weekend in the company of Gary Hart.

title:
PATENTS;
Detecting Viruses
description: LEAD: A virus detection method patented this week for Profile Diagnostic Sciences Inc. of Warrington, Pa., can, according to its inventor, report anything a physician wants to know within a few minutes. Patent 4,663,277 was granted to Chia-Gee Wang, chief scientist for the company. A specimen is examined by application of microspheres coated with reagents for specific diseases.

description: Year-ago share figure is restated.

title: NEW BRIDGE FOR THRUWAY TO COME IN '87
description: Two lanes of a highway bridge to replace the one that collapsed into the Schoharie Creek last month is scheduled to open by December, Governor Cuomo announced today, and the new four-lane bridge is expected to be completed by the spring of 1988.

title: FLAMEMASTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JMB REALTY TO BUY CADILLAC FAIRVIEW

McKey in N.B.A. Draft
description: In a reversal caused by his suspension for his senior season, Derrick McKey of Alabama, the Southeastern Conference player of the year last season, decided yesterday to apply for the National Basketball Association draft. The 6-foot-9-inch junior center joined Norris Coleman, a junior at Kansas State, and Vincent Askew, a junior at Memphis State, as the only three players to declare for the June 22 draft. Danny Manning, a junior at Kansas, announced hours before the midnight deadline that he would bypass the draft and remain in school. ''My family wants me to stay and get my degree, and that's important,'' said Manning, whose coach, Larry Brown signed a four-year contract to remain at Kansas. McKey, who averaged 18.6 points and 7.5 rebounds a game last season, had planned to stay at Alabama for his senior season. But he changed his mind after being declared ineligible by the school for purportedly signing a contract with an agent. Steve Sloan, the athletic director at Alabama, would not disclose the agent's name. . . . An attorney for Reggie Rogers, a University of Washington defensive end, filed a lawsuit Thursday in Sacramento, Calif., charging two sports agents - Norby Walters of New York City and G. Patrick Healy of Tacoma, Wash. - with using fraud and duress as means of obtaining contracts with Rogers. The lawsuit seeks to nullify the separate contracts and seeks a total of $2.7 million in damages. Rogers, who is from Sacramento, was chosen seventh in the first round of the draft by the Detroit Lions. A lawyer for Walters, who filed suit against Rogers and his current agent, Stephen W. Zucker, in March for breach of contract, said he was not aware of the lawsuit and would not comment. Healy denied the charges.

title: Under the Moral Microscope
description: The Wince of the Week came Wednesday when a reporter asked Gary Hart, ''Have you ever committed adultery?'' Mr. Hart gave the only right response: ''I do not have to answer that question.'' What if - the thought arose yesterday while watching him withdraw from the 1988 race - what if he had said something just like that from the start? When he found reporters watching his house last week, what if, instead of giving them a 20-minute interview, he had said: ''I will not answer such questions. Some things are private business. Get lost.'' And slammed the door. It's possible that he would have quit the race anyway. Some people think the only reason for his blatant recent behavior was that, at some level, he wanted out. They nodded yesterday when he said: ''I gave serious thought to not running for President. In many ways, I didn't want to.'' But it's also possible, had he not invited scrutiny of his private life, that the reaction would have been far calmer, wounding but not demolishing his candidacy.

title: MUSIC: KALICHSTEIN-LAREDO-ROBINSON TRIO
description: Shostakovich E minor Piano Trio (Op. 67) is a bleak work, written during the Second World War and filled with evocations of suffering and despair. The final movement, the work's most ambitious, is thought to be a statement by the composer about Nazi extermination camps. It weaves Jewish folk themes into what becomes a frightening, macabre dance with an ironic conclusion - the strings playing in the highest, most eerie register while the pianist executes a solemn chorale.

title: TV: NBC POLICE DRAMA, 'HANDS OF A STRANGER'

For television, the playwright Arthur Kopit has burrowed into the interior of that world, latching onto its peculiar personal tensions and never letting go. The four-hour television movie - being broadcast tomorrow and Monday at 9 P.M. on NBC - is gripping from beginning to end.

title: VIOLIN: GALINA GEIFETZ RECITAL

Miss Heifetz played it with conviction. The marchlike stride of the first movement was strongly conveyed, and the violinist's most personal work came in the subdued allegretto grazioso of the third movement.

SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54. 1. At a meeting of editorial cartoonists, President Reagan capped his pen after writing one word, ''the,'' in an empty balloon over a cartoon titled ''The Great Communicator.'' What explanation did he give for not writing more? 2. The former United States Ambassador to Costa Rica, Lewis A. Tambs, gave an interview in Phoenix on an issue that was particularly germane to a subsequent proceeding in Washington. Explain. 3. Justice Thurgood Marshall sounded a negative note on a subject that recently has been lavishly praised by President Reagan, former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, and others. What is it and what were Justice Marshall's criticisms? 4. In the 1930's, Irving Berlin, now 99 years old, managed an unusual (and, his friends believed at the time, foolhardy) feat that has made him, by all accounts, a millionaire many times over. But time has begun to run out. What feat was it and what happened recently? 5. While offering mass in the Bavarian city of Augsburg, a center of Reformation history, Pope John Paul II made an unusual ecumenical statement. What did he say? 6. With the withrawal of Gary Hart from the Democratic Presidential contest, only one active contender in the race enjoys the support of 10 percent of Democrats, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Who is he? 7. In a case involving the Starrett City housing complex, a Federal district judge in Brooklyn drew a distinction between the rental policies permissible for private and public landlords. What was the ruling? 8. Newly disclosed correspondence between Albert Einstein and the woman who would later become his first wife revealed a surprise and a mystery. What was involved? 9. According to White House officials, President Reagan has adopted a new strategy to gain Congressional support for United States military aid to the contras. What is it? 10. Representatives of some private clubs said a Supreme Court decision that Rotary Clubs must admit women as members did not apply to their organizations because the ruling focused on the particular characteristics of Rotary Clubs. To what were they referring? 11. Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said that the future of the coalition Government would be riding on a vote the Cabinet will take on Monday. What vote is it? 12. Governor Cuomo tried to explain why he signed legislation for the largest tax cut in New York State history only five days before he proposed a $1 billion-a-year increase in taxes and fees. What did he say? 13. Tim Raines's batting feat for the Montreal Expos in a game against the Mets - a grand slam home run, a triple and two singles -was extraordinary. Why? 14. The Senate and the House have passed differing versions of a $1 trillion 1988 budget, but both call for about $18.3 billion in tax increases. What kinds of taxes do members of Congress have in mind, and why? 15. The refusal of James Ramseur, one of four youths shot by Bernard H. Goetz on a subway train two years ago, to be sworn in as a witness against Mr. Goetz may be as damaging to the defense as to the prosecution. Why? 16. Defense Department officials suggested that a Canadian plan to acquire nuclear-powered submarines to increase allied naval power in Arctic waters might have another purpose. What is it?

title: RENAISSANCE MUSIC
description: The Sione Nomine Singers, under the direction of Harry Saltzman, will perform music of Orlando di Lasso, the Renaissance composer, at 9 P.M. today at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street (362-8719). Admission is $10.

title: NEW YORK MARINE & GENL INURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a realized investment loss of $118,581. c-After a realized investment loss of $71,101 and after a tax benefit of about $210,000. The share earnings reflect 3-for-1 stock split March 24.

title: Beech-Nut Settles Suit
description: The Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation, accused of selling millions of bottles of sugar water as pure apple juice for babies, has settled a class-action suit against it for $7.5 million, lawyers said today.

title: Rock Times Three
description: The Neats, Soul Asylum and the Meat Puppets will play a rock triple bill tomorrow at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800), beginning at 9 P.M. Tickets are $12.50 in advance, $13.50 tomorrow.

title: SCOTT STOPS EXPOS ON 2-HITTER
description: Mike Scott pitched a two-hitter and struck out 12 batters tonight, tying his season high and leading the Houston Astros to a 3-0 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: METRO DATELINE;
description: A New Jersey jury ordered the E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company yesterday to pay almost $1.4 million in damages to six current or former employees whose illnesses were attributed to asbestos used by the company.

title: LONG ROUTE IN LACROSSE
description: Tim Murphy and Gordon Purdie, two sophomore transfers from the other side of the world, have added zest to Adelphi's lacrosse team this spring.

title: SOVIET ARTICLE DOUBTS ECONOMIC LINE
description: A Soviet magazine published an article this week warning that efforts to introduce elements of a free market into the Soviet Union's planned economy were bound to fail and saying the country would have to chose between complete economic freedom and central control.

title: CAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN CITY BUSINESS JOURALS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect 12 businesses acquired Dec. 31, 1986; as a result of common control of the company and the affiliates, results are restated as though the affiliates had been consolidated since their inception.

title: CUE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said there are no common share earnings in the latest quarter because the preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Coke Investment
description: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company Consolidated said it had agreed in principle to sell 1.6 million shares, or a 20 percent interest, to the Coca-Cola Company for $38.50 a share, or a total of about $62.5 million. The company said the stock would be allocated between common stock and class B common on a basis that would give the Coca-Cola Company a 20 percent voting interest in Coca-Cola Consolidated.

title: HOME INTENSIVE CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONCORD COMPUTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Indonesia's Friends Give Advice Within Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split authorized in December 1986.

title: ENVIROSURE MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST SOURCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
About New York; Mother's Day '87: Choose a Gift From 50 Strollers
description: ''Now I see why it takes two incomes to afford a child today,'' said Randi Eisenberg, gaping at the overwhelming array of hundreds of baby items in the Albee's store on the Upper West Side.

title: On Justice; Sentencing Commission Needs Tenure
description: To the Editor:

title: COGNITIVE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: 2 Dead as Commuter Plane Crashes in Puerto Rico
description: A commuter plane crashed and burned today while attempting to land at Eugenio Maria de Hostos Airport, killing the the pilot and co-pilot and slightly injuring the four passengers.

title: FAIRMONT FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After investment losses of $4,000. c-After investment gains of $35,000 and a tax credit of $392,000.

title: Buckeye Reinstated
description: Less than three weeks after he was suspended indefinitely by Coach Earl Bruce for an unspecified violation of team rules, Cris Carter, a junior wide receiver at Ohio State who was an all-America selection last season, was reinstated yesterday. The return of Carter came six days after spring football ended with the playing of the intrasquad scrimmage.

title: MERCHANTS BANK OF BOSTON reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company recently changed its financial reporting to conform with a calendar year from a fiscl year ended April 30. For the quarter ended April 30, 1986, the company posted a net income of $2,275,000, or 62 cents per share, after a tax credit of $1,546,000. The shares outstanding were 3,655,000.

title: BRADLEY REAL ESTATE TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $704,000 for both the quarter and 6 months from the sale of two properties in December 1986. The company said share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in February 1987.

title: NATIONAL GUARDIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter net was adversely affected by one cent a share as a result of tax reform legislation.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF HART STATEMENT WITHDRAWING HIS CANDIDACY
description: Following is a transcript of Gary Hart's statement in Denver yesterday withdrawing his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: COLONIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AUDIOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $55,000 and $71,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: GULF APPLIED TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $1,750,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $649,000. c-Net loss and after income of $128,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Transfer for McCallum
description: A new, less accommodating attitude by the Navy toward Naval Academy graduates wishing to pursue part-time careers in professional sports appears to have surfaced this week. Napoleon McCallum, the former Navy running back who gained 536 yards last season for the Los Angeles Raiders while stationed at Long Beach, Calif., has been transfered to the Coronado command in San Diego, about 120 miles from the Los Angeles Coliseum, where the Raiders play home games. More threatening to McCallum's football activites than the longer commuting distance, however, was the announcement that officers in the Coranado command generally are reassigned within four months to a Pacific Fleet ship, meaning McCallum might be at sea when the Raiders' season opens in September.

title: Canadian Joblessness Off
description: Canada's April unemployment rate fell to 9.3 percent after holding at 9.6 percent for two months, Statistics Canada said today. The unemployment rate was 9.6 percent in April 1986. The Government agency said the number of employed in April, adjusted for seasonal variations, rose 50,000 from the previous month to 11.85 million.

title: Trouble Spots Listed For Weekend Traffic
description: The New York City Department of Transportation has listed these trouble spots for weekend traffic:

title: Dartmouth Out of Rowing
description: Dartmouth voluntarily withdrew its rowing team yesterday from tomorrow's Eastern Sprint Championships in Worcester, Mass. The move came after the

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL INSURNCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,704,000 for the latest quarter and $48,975,000 for the year-earlier.

title: IN LONDON, HOTEL JUST FOR CHILDREN
description: When their parents planned to go to France for a week of vacation recently, they decided that 3-year-old Flora Ellison and her 2-year-old sister, Maudie, would check in at a London hotel. It's not as big as the Ritz or as grand as the Connaught, but the Little House has more toys for them to play with than any other hotel in town.

title: ANDROS ANALYZERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
Matching Funds for Babbitt
description: Former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona has been certified to receive Federal matching funds in his bid for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, the Federal Election Commission has announced. Mr. Babbitt is the second person to qualify for the matching funds.

title: FROM ASIA, THE JOYS OF FRESH GINGER
description: Thanks to Asian cooks, Americans have finally come to appreciate the considerable versatility of ginger. Fresh ginger root can be found in most supermarkets today and almost as many carry pickled ginger, an indispensable ingredient for sushi and sashimi. Preserved and candied ginger are often stocked also.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT DECLINES TO 6.2%, REACHING LOWEST LEVEL IN 7 YEARS
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell three-tenths of a percentage point in April, to 6.2 percent, its lowest level in seven years.

title: Inquiry on Ambulance Peril
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating 22,000 ambulances built on Ford Motor Company chassis after reports that the vehicles constitute a fire hazard, the agency said Thursday. The ambulances, built on Ford E350 Econoline chassis from 1983 through 1986, tend to expel gasoline from the tank pipe when the cap is removed and in some cases leak fuel while the cap is in place, the agency said. It added, ''Both conditions have been reported to cause fires.''

title: COUNTRYWIDE MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COURTING DANGER: THE FALL OF GARY HART
description: Who killed Gary Hart's candidacy? Was it ''the system,'' as he asserted in his speech today withdrawing from the Presidential contest? Or was it Gary Hart himself?

title: NICARAGUAN TESTIFIES FOR ARABS FACING DEPORTATION
description: A former leader of the Nicaraguan rebels told a Federal immigration judge today that he had worked for years in Miami to plan the bombing of Nicaraguan ports, airports and other key installations without fear of deportation by the United States.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF ALABAMA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank converted to stock ownership Dec. 17.

title: Memotech Stake
description: Bell Canada Enterprises Inc. said it would acquire a one-third interest in Memotech Data Inc. for $196 million. Memotech recently won the bid to acquire Teleglobe Canada Inc., Canada's only provider of overseas telecommunications services. The transaction is expected to close May 15. Memotech said its previously announced proposed issue of additional common shares would be reduced as a result of the investment by Bell Canada. The company said it would use the proceeds of the sale to repay the debt it incurred on the acquisition of Teleglobe Canada.

title: PURCELL AND A PREMIERE
description: The American Chamber Opera Company will present Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas'' and the premiere of Alice Shield's ''Shaman,'' at 8 tonight at Tomi Theater, 23 West 73d Street (781-0857). Admission is $10.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERIHEALTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $201,000 and $122,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively. The company said the latest results include the operations of a hospital and a nursing home acquired in April 1986. The latest share earnings is after preferred dividend requirements of $148,750.

title: BECKER FINDS THE RIGHT MOVES
description: All the right moves are there: the ability to lob, slice his backhand, hit moon balls and even spend some time on the baseline, trading groundstrokes, waiting for an opening.

title: TIMES COMPANY SIGNS LEASE FOR BUILDING IN JERSEY
description: The New York Times Company has signed a lease with Z Edison Limited Partnership for a building and site in Edison, N.J., as part of a major long-term capital expansion program, it was announced yesterday.

title: 2 Sentenced in L.I. Murder
description: Two men were sentenced today to 25 years to life in prison for the contract slaying of a man whose death the authorities said was arranged by his wife. Jose Garcia, 19 years old, and Antonio Rivera, 21, both of New York City, were convicted last month in Nassau County Court of second-degree murder for their part in the shooting death of Daniel Lew, 35, as he left his Valley Stream cigar store last June. Ed Grilli, a spokesman for District Attorney Denis Dillon, said Mr. Lew's wife, Carrie, 33, pleaded not guilty Thursday to a second-degree murder charge and was released today on $500,000 bail.

title: In Spain, They Honor the Lincoln Brigade
description: To the Editor:

title: Garbage Barge Heads North
description: A barge carrying commercial garbage from Long Island was headed back north today after several Southern states and three countries had refused to take the 3,100 tons of trash since it left New York on March 22. ''We're heading up the East Coast and that's the only comment we have,'' said a spokesman for the tug's owners, Harvey Gulf International, after the barge left the waters off Key West, Fla. The Coast Guard, which has been keeping tabs on the barge said that, at its present speed and course, the tug could be back in New York waters by Tuesday.

title: COMRADES IN DEATH: MAO AND A VICTIM
description: Waggling a 10-foot bamboo pole, Huang Renhe shooed his ducks into a newly plowed paddy field, a pebble's toss from the house that stands on the site where Liu Shaoqi was born 88 years ago.

title: JOULE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
FAIRMOUNT CHEMICAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: A Company News report in Business Day yesterday, about Resorts International, incorrectly described an offer made by a group led by Marvin Davis. The $220 million bid that Resorts rejected was only for its Paradise Island operations. The revised plan, like the original one, offered $140 in cash and one share in a recapitalized Resorts for each of Resorts' class B shares, and $15 and three shares for each class A share.

title: GREAT LAKES FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Saxophonist's Quartet
description: Arthur Blythe, an alto saxophonist, will lead a new quartet with Jay Hoggard on vibraphone, Bob Stewart on tuba and Marvin (Smitty) Smith on drums, today at 8 and 10 P.M. at Jazztrack, 27 Barrow Street, off Seventh Avenue South. Tickets are $10.

title: COMMERCIAL NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CUOMO AND ART OF AN AMBIGUOUS NO
description: In his first public appearance after Gary Hart withdrew from the Presidential race today, Governor Cuomo of New York looked like a candidate, sounded like a candidate and reiterated that he definitely would not be a candidate in 1988.

title: HICKAM, DOW B INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $71,000.

title: INVACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ERNEST L. STEBBINS, EXPERT ON PUBLIC HEALTH
description: Dr. Ernest Lyman Stebbins, a former director and dean at the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, died at Roland Park Place in Baltimore on April 30. He was 85 years old.

title: FAR FROM A SURE THING
description: The best thing about the Preakness Stakes next Saturday, other than the Maryland crab cakes, is that no one will be talking about the Dosage System.

title: CONTRA CHIEF SAYS HE GAVE $50,000 IN EFFORT TO FREE U.S. HOSTAGES
description: The leader of the largest organization of Nicaraguan rebels said today that he gave a White House official $50,000 in mid-1985 to finance a private effort to free the American hostages in Lebanon.

title: AMERICAN LAND CRUISERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONCERT: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center opened its latest round of concerts with an utterly haunting novelty, a nocturne for string quintet composed by Dvorak in 1870. It is a rapt, melodious slow movement of great concentration and small contrast; it went through several recyclings as a potential part of multimovement works before the composer decided to let it stand by itself - which, one supposes, is why it is so rarely heard. (The society's director, Charles Wadsworth, asked for a show of hands from anyone who had heard the piece before; three or four people had.) The Emerson String Quartet, joined by Alvin Brehm, gave it a beautifully blended and shaped performance last Monday evening. Criticism of musicians who keep going back to the Romantics to see whether we've missed something is disarmed when they return to a gem like this.

title: Reebok Acquires Frye Boot Concern
description: Reebok International, the successful sneaker maker that also owns the Rockport Company shoe concern, said it had expanded into boots, taking over the John A. Frye Company. Reebok did not disclose the price of the deal. It said the 125-year-old Frye operations would be merged into Rockport, known for a wide range of casual shoes.

title: COLUMBIA FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $600,000 for the quarter and $1,150,000 for the 6 months. The company said the 1986 earnings are restated to reflect an accounting change in annual income payments on permanent income capital certificates.

title: CURTISS-WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $200,000 for the latest quarter and $417,000 for the year-earlier period. Year-ago first quarter includes gains from real estate transactions amounting to $1,120,000, or 23 cents a share.

title: ART DRIVE BLENDS 2 CULTURES
description: The reception was a blend of the West and the East. To honor the Metropolitan Museum of Art's new Japanese gallery, the museum was opened after hours to wealthy patrons, both Japanese and American. As a string quartet played, visitors ate sushi and marveled at the Japanese treasures on display.

title: MNX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $47,000. The year-ago results have been restated for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1987.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company changed to a calendar year from a fiscal year ended Feb. 28.

title: NEW MISSION STARTS FOR TOURIST GROUP
description: WHEN the Hudson River Valley Association celebrated its 20th birthday two years ago, the tourist association was nearly moribund. It was kept alive by erratic financial support from various hotels, restaurants and historic-sites organizations and by the volunteer staffs from the Sleepy Hollow Restorations and Boscobel, a 19th-century historic house in Garrison.

title: U.S. RESIDENTS ABOARD JET
description: The Polish airline LOT made public this list of United States citizens and Polish residents of the United States who were killed in the crash of a Polish jetliner in Warsaw yesterday: U.S. CITIZENS BUKOWSKI, Bertha CLARK, Richard McConnel CWIK, Vincent Joseph CZECHOWSKI, Henry HANSON-ADRIAN, Kazimiera MALIN, Chester Stanley NESGODA, Richard Joseph NESGODA, Robert Leonard OBERBECK, Julianna OLSCHEWSKI, George PASZCUK, Bogdan PATRYLAK, Irene POCELAY, Martha Louise SOSNOWSKI, Adam SOSNOWSKI, Helena WIDERYNSKI, Elizabeth Grace WOJTAS-KOZIOL, Gertrude U.S. RESIDENTS BARSZCZOWSKA JAROSZ, Halina CHMIELNICKA, Jadwiga Elbert CZAPKOWSKA STARCZYK, Wieslawa Krystyna DALSKA STEC, Anna FILUS, Joanna FILUS, Kazimierz GIL LAGANOWSKA, Danuta GOSPODARCZYK SZKLARSKA, Irena KIRSCH, Aniela Wladyslawa KURDYLA DUDZIK, Anna PASZCZUK, Henryk RUTKOWSKA SAWKO, Leonarda RUTKOWSKI, Marian RUTKOWSKI, Wiktor SIGDA PAPA, Katarzyna TOKARZEWSKI, Andrzej TRUBISZ FAMULAN, Cecylia TRUBISZ, Janusz TRUBISZ, Yvette Victoria WOJTAS, Christine WOJTAS, Tadeusz

title: Paul S. Bird Wed To Amy Parsons
description: Amelia O'Brien Parsons, a senior cataloguer in the arcade fine arts department of Sotheby's in New York, and Paul Stanley Bird, who expects to receive a J.D. degree May 24 from the Yale Law School, were married yesterday. The Rev. William E. Foley officiated at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: U.S. IS EXPORTING NONSMOKING TO JAPAN
description: IT has been a long time coming, but the people in Japan who don't smoke are starting to steam. Emboldened by the militancy of their American counterparts, they are insisting on, and winning, the right to smoke-free surroundings - not an easy battle in a male-dominated society where three in five men smoke.

title: Racing the Clock In West Midtown
description: THE fateful day for West Midtown developers looms one year away -on Friday the 13th. A zoning bonus, set to expire on that date next May, has prompted a frenzy of demolition and digging north of Times Square.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Stockbridge, Mass.: From College To Condos
description: LEAD: BERKSHIRE Berkshire Christian College will move out of its 62-acre campus here next month and a Lenox developer will begin converting the property into a residential condominium development.

title: EAST SIDE, WEST SIDE
description: Imagine that the island of Manhattan is divided by a wall running down Fifth Avenue, with Times Square and Lincoln Center in the hands of a pro-Western government linked to a free republic entrenched west of the Mississippi River. A Communist regime, though, dominates the eastern half of the island; it also controls all of the United States east of the Mississippi.

title: I HAD MORE TROUBLE THAN THE GIANTS DID
description: THE football season ended several months ago, but for me it still lingers. Here is why. I am an avid New York Giant football fan. I have been one for many years and have witnessed many losing seasons. Despite their past ineptness, I still loved them.

title: CAN THE STATE PREDICT THE SITE OF ACCIDENTS?
description: In the April 5 Long Island Journal I found what I consider a mind-boggling piece of news.

title: NEW DIRECTOR HIRED AT THE HUDSON RIVER MUSEUM
description: IF January at the Hudson River Museum seemed particularly bleak, and it did, May looks like it will be unusually fine.

title: POLICE
description: The biggest boon for the police in the Mayor's proposed $1.4 billion appropriation for the department next year would be the new manpower. Joseph P. Wuensch, the Deputy Police Commissioner for Management and Budget, said the ''first and most dramatic imperative'' would be to expand the Community Patrol Officer Program, the three-year-old initiative that puts officers back on foot patrol in neighborhoods. (More on the program, page 6.) Besides the additional 1,931 officers, 800 of whom would be hired next January and the others in June 1988, the department will hire about 2,000 other officers - as it does each year - just to keep up with attrition. A total of 4,000 new recruits would keep the applicant screening staff hopping, and if the budget is approved, Mr. Wuensch said, the Police Academy will be running more classes from 8 A.M. to midnight to keep up.

title: Producer Is Wed To Marley Klaus
description: Marley Klaus, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Klaus of Philadelphia, and Kevin Dowling, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Dowling of Gladwyne, Pa., were married yesterday. The Rev. James A. Casciotti performed the ceremony at Old St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: Pope Prays for Crash Dead
description: Pope John Paul II, a native of Poland, was shaken today when he was informed that a Polish jetliner had crashed near Warsaw, killing all aboard, a Vatican official reported. ''The Holy Father immediately retired to his private chapel to pray,'' the official said.

title: SWIMMER PURSUES OLYMPICS
description: LEAD: KARIN ANDREN'S daily schedule is quite different from that of her classmates at Roger Ludlowe High School in Fairfield. She wakes up at 4 A.M., and a half hour later is making the 25-minute drive to the Wilton Y.M.C.A., where she swims for an hour and 45 minutes. She then returns to Fairfield for school, spending free periods in the library doing homework.

title: BOTANICAL ROCK GARDEN, COMPLETED IN 1934, GETS A NEW NAME
description: A THREE-ACRE rock garden at the New York Botanical Garden last Friday was renamed the T. H. Everett Memorial Rock Garden, in honor of Thomas H. Everett, the horticulturist, author, educator, former director of horticulture at the New York Botanical Garden and creator of the rock garden. Mr. Everett, who lived in Mount Vernon, died last year at the age of 83.

title: Helen Wuster Marries
description: At the Central Nyack Congregational Church in Valley Cottage, N.Y., Helen Dorothy Wuster, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert C. Wuster of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Donald Kokinchak, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Kokinchak of Somers, N.Y. The bride's father, a retired Congregational minister, participated in the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. Bryan R. Burrell, pastor of the church.

title: THE HARTS: PARADOXES OF A POLITICAL MARRIAGE
description: Gary Hart's dizzy fall offered a searing look at scenes from a modern political marriage, painstakingly patched together in private only to be pulled apart in public.

title: FERRAGAMO, THE HOUSE THE HEIRS BUILT
description: TWENTY-SEVEN years ago Salvatore Ferragamo, a shoe designer in Florence, died leaving a widow, Wanda, and six children, the youngest 2 years old. Mrs. Ferragamo knew nothing about business. But a year and a half before, Mr. Ferragamo had insisted that their daughter Fiamma, the eldest child, who was then 16, come to work with him.

title: HOME VIDEO: ART
description: LEAD: COWBOY ART A London Weekend television co-production with R. M. Arts. Produced and directed by Alan Benson. Home Vision. 55 minutes. $39.95.

title:
NEW JERSEY;
FARMS GIVING WAY TO OFFICES AS DEVELOPMENT PUSHES WEST
description: LEAD: LONG dominated by farming towns and winding roads, Hunterdon County is a part of northwestern New Jersey that time seemed to have forgotten. Over the last few years, however, as businesses moved from central cities to the suburbs, pushing the office market steadily westward, developers in search of open space began to turn their attention to Hunterdon County.

title: Man Dead and 3 Hurt In Brooklyn Shooting
description: A Brooklyn man was killed and three others were wounded by gunfire in a dispute over drugs in a hallway of a Bedford-Stuyvesant building, the police said yesterday.

title: LAND RIFT RESOLVED, BIOTECH PLAN GAINS
description: LEAD: WITH a dispute over land development resolved, Rutgers University and Cook College, its School of Agriculture, have resumed a drive to build a $30 million biomolecular research center on the Cook campus.

title: BOTHA LANDSLIDE WORRIES FOES
description: IN the aftermath of South Africa's whites-only elections last week the anti-apartheid movement was looking, with some anxiety, for indications of how its struggle might continue, and what the Government's reactions might be.

title: Individual Shelters For the Homeless
description: THE toughest problem many homeless people face is finding ''a place to sleep without being treated like prisoners or dogs,'' said a San Francisco architect, Donald MacDonald.

title: OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

title: STRATEGY AT DONOVAN TRIAL: DISCREDIT THE PROSECUTOR
description: Without calling a single witness, the defense in the criminal trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan is seeking victory mainly by assailing the integrity of the chief prosecutor.

title: THE LITTLE VILLAGE AND THE BIG HOUSE
description: FOR more than 100 years the village of Ossining has sought to close the state prison known as Sing Sing. Most recently, a village waterfront revitalization plan has been calling for the state to release 55 acres of the prison property.

title: Encore, Encore
description: To the Editor:

title: HEEDING LIGHT ON SLEEP DISORDERS
description: LEAD: WHILE driving a car one day several years ago, Virginia Hagarty, 60 years old, of Lindenhurst, suddenly woke up and realized she had stopped at a red light. Mrs. Hagarty, who did not remember braking the car to a halt, was frightened and thought perhaps an epileptic seizure had caused the blackout.

title: BERLIN BY NIGHT
description: West Berlin's all-night night life has kept it Germany's most truly cosmopolitan city.

title: Children's Summer Programs Readied
description: LEAD: DANCE or nature studies, music or sports are all there, and then some, as summer programs get under way in the county for children and young people. In addition to community-sponsored recreation programs and day camps and general-interest camps sponsored by Scouts and local Y's, there is a wide selection of programs in which young people can learn more specialized skills or develop existing ones.

title: MAKING DECISIONS ABOUT HEALTH CARE
description: INCREASINGLY these days, the average citizen is overcome with feelings of powerlessness.

title: A WOULD-BE PRESIDENT FAILS THE TEST OF 'CHARACTER'
description: IN announcing his withdrawal from the 1988 Presidential campaign on Friday, Gary Hart said that elections should be decided on issues.

title: Video Sentences in Hanoi
description: A Hanoi court sentenced one man to prison and gave two men suspended sentences for showing pornographic videos for profit, a Vietnamese radio broadcast said. The verdict last Monday from a Hanoi people's court was ''a warning knell'' to all those with videotapes and recorders that they must follow state regulations, the Hanoi radio said.

title: MUSIC IS SUBTEXT IN 'THROUGH ROSES'
description: CALL it a mini-spoken opera, a music monodrama or just a hybrid. Whatever the designation, ''Through Roses,'' with its cast of one actor (Harold Gould), one conductor (Paul Dunkel) and eight musicians (members of the New Orchestra of Westchester) represents a departure for East Coast Arts at Wildcliff, where it is playing through next Sunday.

title: Margaret Ann Drewes Weds Richard G. Pyle
description: Margaret Ann Drewes was married yesterday to Richard G. Pyle at the Douglaston (Queens) Community Church by the Rev. John Meyer.

title: Books That Self-Destruct
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: 60 Artisans Show And Sell Their Wares

title: OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

title: The Purpose Of Weight Lifting
description: Unlike Leonard Kriegel, I am both ''looking better'' and ''growing particularly stronger,'' since beginning, at age 36, to work out on exercise machines three months ago (''The Purpose of Lifting,'' About Men, April 12). Moreover, I am not ''simply continuing''; I am changing, gradually but steadily. The satisfaction of watching the muscles grow larger is physically analogous to the exhilaration of expanding the mental parameters by reading a good book. Afterward, I am literally a different person, changed and somehow better. This process of taking control of one's own development is aptly described, in another context, by Joyce Carol Oates (''On Boxing'') as ''. . . an act of consummate self-determination - the constant re-establishment of one's being.'' PAUL VAN SOUDER New York City

title: Ms. Salathe Married To Thomas D. Horan
description: The New Orleans Opera Guild Home was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nancy Ellen Salathe and Thomas Denton Horan. Judge Lorain F. Wingerter of the Second City Court of New Orleans officiated.

title: A FAULKNER FLIRTATION
description: LEAD: HAVING RELUCTANT ly reached the point in life at which the memory of things once done and people once known sharpens with unnerving clarity, I find I spend time actually yearning for certain departed friends. Discovering some old letters and photographs during a recent move, I began to think of William Faulkner, who, had he lived, would have been 90 years old next Sept.

title: New Evidence Linking Alcohol To Breast Cancer
description: For the last 10 years, researchers have accumulated data suggesting a possible connection between drinking and breast cancer. Two studies published last week in the New England Journal of Medicine made the association seem especially strong. While past studies have spoken of the possible dangers of consuming more than three drinks a day, the new research indicates that women might be increasing their risk of getting cancer by having only several drinks a week.

title: REBELS ARE NOW A FORCE WITHIN NICARAGUA
description: A LONG a dirt road winding through Nicaragua's northern mountains, a patrol of Sandinista troops suddenly went on combat alert the other day after hearing a report that a rebel squad had just crossed the road less than a mile ahead.

title: PIANO: GERALD ROBBINS
description: IT took only the opening theme of Mendelssohn's ''Variations Serieuses'' to establish that Gerald Robbins's evening of piano music at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday would be an event of substance. The balance of voices, the dignified movement, the kind of definition that subdued the encroaching loudness of this acoustical space - were qualities that carried through the rest of his pieces.

title: 33 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 33 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: CON ED OFFERS LILCO NEW POWER IF NEEDED
description: LEAD: THE Long Island Lighting Company, which is seeking to use 170 megawatts of power from the Shoreham nuclear plant to meet what it expects to be record energy demands this summer, can count on support from a neighboring utility.

title: Robin L. Reeves Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Robin Louise Reeves to Gregory Jannig Zorthian took place yesterday at St. Thomas' Church, Whitemarsh, in Fort Washington, Pa. The Rev. Mary E. Laney performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: MAP MAY BE FROM VIKINGS AFTER ALL
description: A map purporting to show that the Vikings charted North America long before the arrival of Columbus, branded as a fraud in 1974, could turn out to be genuine after all, scientists at the University of California have concluded.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
111 Years of Service
description: LEAD: IN 1875, a band of thieves roved through Hastings-on-Hudson, and a bunch of vigilantes set out to nab them. But worse than robbery were a rash of suspicious fires and, on Christmas Eve of that year, the conflagration that engulfed the Hudson River Steam Sugar Refinery. The crime-fighting group soon turned to firefighting instead.

title: HOME VIDEO: NATURE
description: AFRICAN WILDLIFE A National Geographic production. Vestron Video. 1980. 60 minutes. $29.98.

title: 4 PIANISTS, 1 SAPRANO
description: THOMAS LABE

title:
GARDENING;
THINGS TO DO, RESULTS TO ENJOY
description: LEAD: MAY is a big month for gardeners with all the planting and cultivating to be done, and tending even a small garden can seem like a full-time task.

title: Andrea Zalaznick, A Research Aide, Becomes a Bride
description: Andrea Zalaznick, a research assistant for the Whitcom Investment Company in New York, was married yesterday to Eugene Braigen, research analyst for Veronis, Suhler & Associates, an investment bank specializing in the communications industry. Lois Kellerman, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the National Arts Club in New York.

title: GOMEZ UPSETS BECKER, WILL FACE NOAH IN FINAL
description: The irony, as Boris Becker saw it, was that after all the talk this week about his lack of expertise on clay courts he would lose in the semifinals of the Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions because his serve deserted him. Becker was convinced that he had outplayed Andres Gomez of Ecuador from the baseline yesterday, had more than enough chances to win, but lost simply because his strength became a weakness.

title: New Orleans, La.; A Glossy New Anomaly Rises in an Overloaded Market
description: TO the motorist drving along Interstate 10 west of New Orleans, the new high-rise looks as if it just flew in from Dallas, a mirrored monolith above the flatlands.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: ROME
description: The ''urban cohorts'' of Emperor Augustus probably encountered less trouble in dealing with the crowds in the Forum and with the litter bearers, charioteers and horseback riders all around than do the blue-uniformed men and women of Rome's municipal police in their current battles with the city's more than one million cars.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Spot Among the Warehouses
description: LEAD: THAT American Bistro has recently celebrated its fourth birthday at its unprepossessing location in Mamaroneck's warehouse district says a great deal about the place. Despite poor parking facilities, a well-worn interior and the absurdly crowded alley of tables, the dining room plays to near-capacity crowds every evening.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Week in Review April 26 included an incorrect percentage provided by Wheaton College as part of a survey by the Women's College Coalition. The coalition said that 11 percent of the young women it surveyed (not 3 percent) had said they would consider attending a women's college.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: LEAD: THE APE MAN With Bela Lugosi, Wallace Ford and Eileen Currie. Directed by William Beaudine. 1943. Videoyesteryear. (800) 243-0987. 62 minutes. $29.95.

title: Minister Asks to Talk to Police
description: A prominent minister whose wife was nearly choked to death, and who himself later attempted suicide as the police prepared to question him about the incident, says he does not know who attacked her.

title: FACING DOWN THE GESTAPO
description: ANNE FRANK REMEMBERED The Story of the Woman Who Helped to Hide the Frank Family. By Miep Gies with Alison Leslie Gold. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Howard University
description: More than 2,000 students were awarded degrees by Howard University at commencement ceremonies yesterday at the university's main campus in Washington.

title: The Bail Bond Phantoms of Baxter Street
description: Ida Schenkman no longer writes bail bonds from her storefront office behind the Tombs jail on Baxter Street in Manhattan. Her name has disappeared from the Yellow Pages - along with all the other Baxter Street bondsmen. Their departure, and the failure of judges and defense lawyers to adjust to it, intensifies the jail crowding crisis.

title: A CHILEAN TREKS HOME FROM EXILE
description: After 12 years of enforced exile abroad, Clodomiro Almeyda, who was one of the best-known members of the leftist Government of Salvadore Allende, climbed the eastern slopes of the Andes on a mule and made his way through a snow-covered mountain pass to come home to Chile.

title: EUROPE SEEKS TO DAM A STREAM OF THIRD WORLD REFUGEES
description: THE doors of Western Europe are slamming shut on the poor, the persecuted and the merely adventurous from Africa, Asia and the Arab world.

title: Trish Murphy Is Wed To Gregory S. Hatfield
description: Patricia Marie Murphy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Paul Murphy of South Egremont, Mass., and Gregory Scott Hatfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gross Hatfield of Wilmington, Del., and Stone Harbor, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Patrick O'Neill, president of St. Thomas University in Miami and the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Great Barrington, Mass.

title: Fistfights Reported at Polls As Maltese Pick Government
description: Voters cast ballots today in the most fiercely contested election on this Mediterranean island since independence from Britain in 1964. All 65 seats in Parliament were at stake; results were not expected until Monday.

title: Brooke Conaty Weds Thomas Joyce Farley
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting in New York yesterday for the wedding of Brooke Elizabeth Conaty to Thomas Joyce Farley. The Rev. Thomas J. Joyce performed the ceremony.

title: The Democrats' Trade Folly
description: It is up to Democrats in the Senate to reaffirm their party's long-standing commitment to free trade by voting ''no'' to protectionist legislation. That is the only way they can atone for the irresponsible behavior of their Democratic colleagues in the House, who handed President Reagan an enormous political gift when they passed (with the help of 17 Republicans) the Gephardt amendment to the trade bill.

title: Flight Attendants
description: To the Editor:

title: TOLL BRIDGE TAKEOVER OPPOSED
description: LEAD: THE Atlantic Beach Bridge Authority, after 41 often turbulent years, and under investigation by a Nassau County grand jury, which is expected to wrap up its proceedings in the next few weeks, is asking county government to take over its responsibilities. But opposition to any such move is being mounted by Atlantic

title: A MEMBER OF THE FAMILY
description: Thank you for the article ''Blending Heritage and Change'' [ Long Islanders, April 12 ] . I am grateful for the sensitivity in portraying me personally and the grasp of Hadassah's philosophy and mission.
