title: DOMESTIC AFFAIRS, IN THE ANCIEN REGIME AND AFTER
description: IF YOU CAN'T GET TICKETS FOR ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' with its awesome and unsparing portrait of immediately pre-Revolutionary France, you can fall back for the moment on two new exhibitions in town that will give you fresh insights into France in the 18th century. If, on the other hand, you have already been to see ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' you will have had an unforgettable evening in the theater. You may, however, have emerged chilled and disoriented from your three hours' exposure to an ice-age of the heart that has few parallels.

title: GARDEN CLUB 'SUMMIT' IN SOMERSET
description: LEAD: WEARING spring tweeds and toting six-packs, 500 members of the Garden Club of America will gather at the Somerset Hilton Hotel today for their annual meeting, the first to be held in the Garden State.

title: SHUE'S 'FOREIGNER' IN FAIRFIELD
description: ''THE FOREIGNER'' has made it from survival to success. After it opened off Broadway in 1984, the comedy by Larry Shue was on the verge of closing several times. Then, the proverbial show business ''angel'' materialized - in the guise of a Texas oilman who saved the sinking show with a $60,000 interest-free loan. Still, after running more than a year and a half, the play lost almost its entire $250,000 investment.

title: Susan M. Gough Wed To Lieut. Mark Hicks
description: Susan Michelle Gough, a front office manager for the Hyatt Hotel in Ravinia, Ga., and Lieut. Mark Raymond Hicks, U.S.A., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Enon Baptist Church in East Bend, N.C., with the Rev. Robert Belford, a Baptist minister, and the Rev. Eugene O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest, officiating.

title: How to Improve the Bidding Process on Government Contracts
description: To the Editor:

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
East Hampton Tightens Vise on Groupers
description: LEAD: RISING property values in the Hamptons, and changes in styles of life, have led to increased joint purchases of vacation houses by unrelated individuals. Now the Town of East Hampton, fearful that joint buyers may circumvent residential zoning ordinances by setting up time-sharing or cooperative-style arrangements, has hung out the ''not welcome'' sign.

title: Talking: Sponsors; Conflicts On Master Leases
description: MANY New York City co-ops are able to keep maintenance charges down by using the commercial income derived from leasing out the garage, stores or laundry facilities in the building.

title: THEIR EVENING WITH MAURICE
description: THE MARRIAGE HEARSE By Larry Duberstein. Illustrated by Dorothy Ahle. 154 pp. Sag Harbor, N.Y.: The Permanent Press. $17.95.

title: Nixon Files Yield A Wealth of Detail
description: There were memorandums on how to ''paint . . . black'' such opponents as Edward M. Kennedy, George McGovern and Daniel Ellsberg. There was a proposal from Richard M. Nixon to try to uncover ''some of the real crooks on the highest court and in some of the other Federal courts.'' There were ideas - from William H. Rehnquist, now Chief Justice, for example - on how to crack down on campus radicals.

title: A Lesson in Development
description: A group of academics, most of them professors at Queens College, have joined together in an unlikely real-estate venture that is teaching them a few things that are not readily available in the classroom. The proposed residential development, in the Town of North East, N.Y., just south of Millerton in Dutchess County, has taken them from the heady world of academe into the not-so-romantic realities of zoning ordinances, modular design and marketing.

title: IRVING BERLIN'S AMERICAN LANDSCAPE
description: IN A LETTER TO ALEXANDER Woollcott half a century ago, Jerome Kern offered what may be the last word on the significance of Irving Berlin, who turns 99 tomorrow. ''Irving Berlin has no place in American music,'' wrote Kern. ''He is American music.'' And today that assessment still rings true, in spite of the fact Mr. Berlin has remained professionally silent for 25 years.

title: BISTRO'S BEST
description: ACCORDING TO LEGEND, the Russian troops occupying Paris after the fall of Napoleon were unhappy with the off-handed treatment they received from the local tavern-keepers. As conquerers, they were miffed by the surly behavior of the conquerees. So they rapped their kopecks on the zinc bars to demand better service. Whatever it was they shouted, it sounded to the French like ''Bistro! Bistro!'' - and the name stuck.

title: A CATHEDRAL OF THE SEAS
description: Was there ever a liner that skimmed the Atlantic with more grace than the Normandie? Frank O. Braynard, a historian of passenger shipping, meticulously details the life of the proud French ship that linked Le Havre and New York between 1935 and 1939 in PICTURE HISTORY OF THE NORMANDIE (Dover, Paper, $9.95). She was the first liner longer than 1,000 feet, one of the only three ever to gross more than 80,000 tons, the first of the mammoth breed to sport a clipper-type bow and a rakish hull that encased the apogee of Gallic luxury. The Normandie was not a money maker in her short life, and she came to a sad end. The enemy didn't sink her at sea; she burned and went down ignominiously at her West 48th Street pier in Manhattan in 1942, while incompetents were transforming her into a troop ship. Navy salvage experts learned their trade by raising her, but she was a dowdy hulk, useless for war or peace, and was hauled off to a knacker's yard in New Jersey to be demolished. Mr. Braynard captures the spirit that people invested in this queen of the seas. The Normandie was a nova that brightened the firmament of ships for a moment, only to fade a few years before her proud contemporaries, the Queen Mary and the Queen Elizabeth, also were lost in a storm of travel innovation.

title: TALES FROM THE FABLE FACTORY
description: STORMING THE MAGIC KINGDOM Wall Street, the Raiders, and the Battle for Disney. By John Taylor. Illustrated. 261 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: HEALTH SERVICES
description: Money spent on health accounts for 5 percent of the proposed city budget. According to the Office of Management and Budget, this year's allotment represents a $56.7 million increase over last year's.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cleveland;
A 15th Century Manor for Sale
description: LEAD: SOME say the 15th-century English house now crowning a hill outside Cleveland used to be a country inn before it was dismantled and brought to this country. Others say it was the manor of a wealthy merchant, one of the nouveau riche of the age between Chaucer and Shakespeare.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: FOR MOM Celebrating Mother's Day on Long Island today couldn't be easier; besides the usual ways, there's enough special on tap to satisfy almost every taste. For example, art lovers could meander to Southampton, where the Parrish Art Museum on Job's Lane has just opened an exhibition devoted to ''American Impressionism.

title: Miss Orrick Wed To David Barton
description: Anne Lloyd Orrick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Riggs Orrick of Baltimore, was married yesterday to David Bassett Barton, a son of Amy Veerhoof Barton of Rye, N.Y., and the late Samuel George Barton. The Rev. Ben H. Smith, assisted by the Rev. David F. Gearhart, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Ruxton, Md.

title: THE WHOLE PLACE WAS MADE UP
description: MIAMI City of the Future. By T. D. Allman. 422 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $22.50.

title: LOOKING BEYOND THE CURRENCY QUICK-FIX
description: THE dollar continues to confound and confuse. Has it fallen too much or too little? Must it be stabilized or drop further?

title: A Martyr Of Auschwitz
description: It appears to me that Susanne Batzdorff misunderstands the concept of martyrdom. Martyrdom is not the desire to die. Rather it is the belief that there is something more important even than one's own life, to wit, one's convictions, one's principles or what one perceives to be the truth.

title: 11 WEEKS LATER, CUOMO STILL SAYS HE WON'T RUN FOR PRESIDENT
description: Late at night, flying home from delivering one of his major speeches, Mario M. Cuomo sometimes drops his ''I am the Governor'' tone, loosening his tie, sipping a vodka on the rocks, telling political war stories and doing impressions. (His Daniel Patrick Moynihan is great.) He is at his most vulnerable in moments like these - weary yet chatty as he sits in the dimly lighted cabin of his private 13-seat state plane - and so the questions asked at the news conferences and in the formal interviews are asked once again: Doesn't he really want to be President? Wasn't his Feb. 19 announcement that he would not run for the Democratic nomination just a ploy somehow to run by not running?

title: Cards and Flowers
description: Mother's Day remains the prototypical greeting card holiday, yet the cards have a strained quality. For instance, one card selected at random from the Mother's Day section of a shop on Fifth Avenue bears the photograph of a monarch butterfly landing in a flower garden. Etched on the pink background are the words, ''Mother, You're Especially Dear.'' Inside, an eight-line rhymed verse begins, ''I may not often say so. . . .,'' and ends, ''Have a Wonderful Mother's Day.''

title: POLICE GAINING A COMMUNITY ROLE
description: ONE day a few weeks ago, a large garbage container appeared on Columbus Avenue near 62d Street in Manhattan. The bin, provided for a nearby construction project, blocked the fire hydrant in front of a restaurant. Police Officer Edward Acevedo, who walks past the restaurant nearly every day as part of his duties as a member of the Community Patrol Officer Program in the 20th Precinct, called the Sanitation Department. The container was moved the next morning.

title: Addict May Rejoin Police
description: Police Officer Jerome Landry, who says he became a drug addict while working as an undercover agent, may return to the force despite a Police Department request that he be dismissed, the Police and Fire Commission ruled Thursday. Officer Landry told the commission last month that he became addicted because he had to use cocaine as part of his covert work.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Asharoken $535,000 208 Asharoken Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, 50 feet of waterfront; taxes $4,000. Islip $138,000 76 Smith Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old brick ranch; den, basement, 1-car garage, walk to stores; taxes $3,400. Northport $175,000 311 Waterside Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old Cape Cod; pool, walk to beach; taxes $3,200. Plainview $203,000 30 Knolls Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split level; sunken living room, den, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. Sayville $220,000 203 Candee Avenue 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; fireplace in living room, wraparound porch, 0.75 acre; taxes $4,000. Tanglewood Hills $129,300 61 Wellsley Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 16-year-old ranch; family room, fireplace, central A/C, pool; taxes $2,800. OTHER AREAS Forked River, N.J. $94,000 647 Chelsea Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, sunroom, 1-car attached garage; taxes $870. Guilford, Conn. $249,000 364 North Wood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old Cape Cod; pool, finished basement, 1.5 acres; taxes $2,405. Armonk, N.Y. $355,000 220 Cedar Hill 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old frame co lonial; den, playroom, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $4,566.

title: Ms. Blau and J. M. Klein, Freelance Writers, Wed
description: Justine Hope Blau was married last evening to Jeffrey M. Klein at the Sara Delano Roosevelt Memorial House of Hunter College. Rabbi Clifford Kulwin performed the ceremony.

title: DEPARTING PRESIDENT: William G. Bowen; The Economist Who Taught Princeton Basic Economics
description: BACK in the mid-1950's, when he was racing through his economics Ph.D. in three years at Princeton, the last thing William G. Bowen thought about was eventually running that university. ''I set out to be a teacher and a scholar,'' he said.

title: 5 Jailed in Puerto Rico In Big Cocaine Seizure
description: The Coast Guard seized almost a ton and a half of cocaine aboard a 28-foot fishing boat off the United States Virgin Islands Friday and arrested five Colombians, who were imprisoned here today.

title: Thon Is Ready
description: THE HOUSTON ASTROS have activated Dickie Thon, a shortstop, and sent Bert Pena, another shortstop, to the club's minor league team in Tucson of the Pacific Coast League. Thon had been on a 20-day rehabilitation program at Tucson, where he hit .333 in 11 games. He walked out of the team's spring training camp because of blurred vision. He was hit in the left eye in April 1984 and has been off and on the disabled list since then. He also was hit in the head with a pitch at Tuscon and had to miss five games.

title: GUN MOVIES: BIG BORE AND SMALL CALIBER
description: IT'S TIME TO COME TO THE DEFENSE of the American moviegoing public, too often and too glibly characterized as a collective cretin with the taste of a 12-year-old and the brain of a gnat. In fact, the American moviegoing public is incredibly sophisticated. It's an organism so sensitive that, within a few weeks, it can discern the difference between Sylvester Stallone in ''Rambo,'' stripped to the waist and carrying enough live ammo to refight the Vietnam War, and Sylvester Stallone in ''Over the Top,'' in which the fully dressed star plays an arm wrestler with heart.

title: THEATER ARTS BECOMES MANAGEMENT TOOL
description: A DOZEN adults were running around a conference room at the Ramada Inn in Mystic. Soon some would be ''piloting'' imaginary airplanes across the carpet, and later all would be exchanging memories of giving birth, seeing rainbows, and other experiences.

title: Judith April Karp to Marry Dr. Warren Scott Kurnick
description: Judith April Karp, director of public relations for the Philadelphia Orchestra, and Dr. Warren Scott Kurnick, a physician at the Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia, plan to be married June 27. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Karp of Fairfax, Va., who have announced her engagement to a son of Harry Kurnick of Philadelphia and the late Sheryl Kurnick.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, Ronald Steel's affiliation was misstated in his book review April 26. He is a professor of international relations and journalism at the University of Southern California.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: THE VIEW FROM THE HOSPITAL After an emergency operation in a strange city, a convalescent man looks out at an ugly world that has never seemed so beautiful. This is from a story called ''The City'' in John Updike's new collection, ''Trust Me'' (Knopf).

title: GLITTER AT HANDY & HARMON
description: LEAD: The strength in precious metals has brought sharp run-ups in mining stocks, many of which have doubled since the first of the year. But the shares of the metals refiners have not been quite so buoyant. Handy & Harman, a leading fabricator of gold and silver, has risen only about a third since January, to around $26 a share last week.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE TEA BUSINESS
description: IT WAS the drink back in colonial days. But then the Boston Tea Party made it a symbol of British oppression. After that came expanding coffee imports.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about the Hearst Corporation on April 26 misstated The San Fransico Examiner's record on Pulitzer Prizes. It won its first Pulitzer in 1951, and its second this year.

title: VERMONT EDITOR CHARGES POLICE WITH INTIMIDATION
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has filed suit against this small Vermont town and its police chief on behalf of a local newspaper editor who contends the police are trying to intimidate him into editorial silence.

title: Tenants are in Command As Vacancies Hit Home
description: FACE-TO-FACE with a record volume of empty offices, many of the nation's developers and builders are changing the way they do business. Smaller companies that were in the business just for the tax advantages have either left the field already or sold out at fire-sale prices. The larger, more diversified owners have reached far into their deep pockets and now are willing to cut major deals to finally fill some of their vacant buildings.

title: A DIRECTION FROM FASHION
description: HUNG in Charles Robert Priest's studio is one of his recent creations: a black tuxedo jacket that from the front looks quite ordinary. But on the back there is a large white leather cutout of a woman's face with eyes of blue sequins, hair of gold sequins, and gray tassels with pink sequins that outline her neck and shoulders.

title: CHASING AWAY THE POST-LUNCH BLAHS
description: THREE or four times a week Raeza Raein, a Washington businessman, goes to the Four Seasons Hotel in Georgetown for afternoon tea. ''A couple of times it's for business, a couple of times for pleasure,'' he said as he reclined in a fat armchair there one recent afternoon, a china teapot and a plate of pastries arrayed before him.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
OF FUTURE AUCTIONS, SALES AND HOBBY BOOKS
description: LEAD: THE personal reference collection of Aubrey E. Bebee, one of the nation's best-known coin dealers, will be offered for sale this summer at the annual convention of the American Numismatic Association to be held on Aug. 26-30 at the Georgia World Congress Center in Atlanta. The auction is expected to be the star attraction.

title: YANKEE BATS SILENT IN DEFEAT
description: Dennis Rasmussen of the Yankees did not yield any home runs last night, something he has done frequently this season, especially with no one on base. But his offense let him down as he pitched a complete game at the Stadium.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF WOLFGANG HILDESHEIMER. Translated by Joachim Neugroschel. (Ecco, $17.) ''I listen to [a] vaguely imagined song that sings itself,'' says a guitarist in one of Wolfgang Hildesheimer's collected stories, and that inaudible song suggests the immaterial world that lies beyond the familiar and is the constant concern of this author.

title: Connecticut; Old Gas Stations Are Yielding To Retail Strips and Offices
description: A RECTANGULAR yellow sign nailed to a post at the Gulf gas station on Boston Avenue in Bridgeport alerts motorists that the station itself is for sale. On Main Street in Westport, stores and condominiums are rising on the site of an old Mobil station.

title: AIRLINE CHECK-IN FOR YOUR KAYAK
description: When it took us several days to bully a Latin American airline into freighting our son's acoustic bass to him in Bogota, we thought with envy of those parents whose offspring had fallen in love with the flute or piccolo. The crate sat for days and days in a hangar at Kennedy International Airport, presumably to be sure it was not explosive or illegal.

title: CHAMBERS AND ELLIS LIFT SONICS TO 3-1 ADVANTAGE
description: Tom Chambers scored 38 points and Dale Ellis added 32 today to lead the SuperSonics to a 117-102 victory over Houston and a 3-1 lead in their four-of-seven-game playoff series.

title: Tennis: Planning Over Power
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LIFE ON THE ROUNDS IS NOT JUST A JOB
description: LEAD: IT WAS, she said afterward, a relatively calm day on North 3 Main, a 32-bed medical-surgical unit at Muhlenberg Regional Medical Center here.

title: PATTERNS IN FAMILY VISITS
description: LIFE, after all, is not a one-way street. Living on Long Island had seemed to dictate that everything moved from the city to the suburbs. First we moved to the Island, and hardly looked back to Brooklyn.

title: ELEMENTARY CLASSES GROWING LARGER
description: LEAD: IN 1980, the Tarrytown school district closed an elementary school because of dwindling enrollments and sold the building to a condominium developer. But now after a decade of decline, elementary enrollments are rising and the district is facing a shortage of space.

title: ROCK: SQUEEZE, REUNITED
description: SQUEEZE disbanded in 1982. But the crowd that packed the Ritz on Wednesday for the last of the reunited band's three sold-out shows greeted the barrage of insidiously catchy songs as enthusiastically as if they were the latest pop hits. One had to wonder where all these people were in 1979-80, when ingenious pop-rock confections like ''Another Nail in My Heart'' and ''Pulling Mussels (from the Shell)'' were failing to win Squeeze the American mass audience the critics insisted the band deserved. But one could hardly maintain an ironic attitude in the face of so much melodious good cheer.

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET IN 'HISTOIRE DU SOLDAT'
description: IGOR STRAVINSKY'S ''Histoire du Soldat'' has attracted a number of choreographers. Like Bartok's ''Miraculous Mandarin,'' it is a narrative score that seems to fascinate but elude those challenged. In ''Suite from 'Histoire Du Soldat,' '' performed by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday at the New York State Theater, Peter Martins does away with the narrative element but joins the list of confounded choreographers anyway.

title: Headliners; A Return Trip
description: Mahmoud M. Atta, who was born in the Middle East and became an American citizen in Puerto Rico, was expelled from Venezuela last week and arrested in New York on charges of firebombing a bus in Israel last year.

title: Diane Ruotolo Marries Mark Webber
description: Diane Sweeney Ruotolo, a daughter of Mrs. Joseph William Vollmerhausen of Summit, N.J., and the late Dr. Andrew Keogh Ruotolo, was married yesterday to Mark Freeman Webber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Richard Webber of Westfield, N.J. The Rev. G.David Deppen performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield.

title: A New Japanese Nationalism
description: Yes, there are various fringe, ideological, political and religious movements and superpatriotic cults in Japan, as there are in the United States and other democracies where the freedom to be different is guaranteed (''A New Japanese Nationalism,'' by Ian Buruma, April 12). Yes, these aberrations invite a reporter's attention, especially when they are found in a country that has Japan's reputation for conformity, consensus and the pursuit of harmony. One must also acknowledge that the Japanese people, like an earlier generation of Americans, are feeling their way toward larger global responsibilities, commensurate with their national power and influence. No wonder that ''defining Japaneseness'' has become ''a huge intellectual industry.''

title: TELEVISION'S MESSAGE IS SEX
description: GEORGE ORWELL'S ''Nineteen Eighty-Four,'' published in 1949, portrayed a form of television as ''Big Brother,'' which beamed controlling messages to the public. Orwell may have misread the messages, but he pinpointed the messenger.

title: QUESTIONS OF OLD AGE AND DUTY
description: A WOMAN I know has put her mother into a nursing home in a town some distance away. I asked why she had not chosen a place near by.

title: A Modern Coach
description: WE THREE COACHES are huddled by the side of the baseball field.

title: Janet Smith Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. W. Herbert Smith Jr. of Clover, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janet McArthur Smith to William Edwards Hunt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Hunt of Cambridge, Mass. The wedding is to be June 27.

title: INSURANCE ACCORD HITS SNAG
description: FOR SIX years, Governor Kean has tried to change New Jersey's automobile-insurance law to limit nuisance suits, but just when he appears to have his best chance, the changes he wants seem to have developed a language problem.

title: OFFICER CORPS WARY AS LESS-EXPERIENCED GENERALS TAKE CHARGE OF THE ARMY
description: A new group of generals are taking command of the Army in perhaps the most sweeping change since World War II, and the shift is causing concern throughout the officer corps.

title: COUNSELING OFFERED TO WOMEN IN MARITAL DISTRESS
description: LEAD: THEY come at a low point to learn how to cope with the wrenching emotions of marital discord.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Gaithersburg, Md.: Boom Town's Homebuilder
description: LEAD: WHEN Clarence Kettler brought his home-building operation to this Washington suburb 20 years ago, it was a modest village with a quaint downtown, bumpy two-lane roads and miles of rolling green farmland. But Gaithersburg has since experienced an aggressive development that has more than tripled its population and made it one of the East

title: VORACIOUS SPACE DEMAND MEETS A SURGING SUPPLY
description: TAKE a map of Manhattan, overlay a one-story building as wide and long as Central Park, then extend it eight blocks south to the edge of Rockefeller Center.

title: Broadcast TV
description: This week brings offscreen couples together onscreen in films not often shown. On the schedule are Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy in ''Keeper of the Flame'' (1942); the Joanne Woodward-Paul Newman project, ''Rachel, Rachel'' (1968); and though not in the same league, Don Ameche and Gene Tierney in the original ''Heaven Can Wait'' (1943). And for an inspired romantic teaming in a surprise from way back, try Jean Arthur and Charles Boyer in ''History Is Made at Night'' (1937).

title: MINORITIES SOUGHT FOR SELF-HELP
description: LEAD: THE Westchester Self-Help Clearing House, the umbrella group that serves as a central resource for mutual support and self-help activities in the county, recently announced that it had received a grant from the New York Council on Children and Families to develop self-help groups for minorities in the county.

title: SPOTLIGHT FALLS ON THE SECRET WORLD OF A MASTER OPERATIVE
description: AS the first week of hearings on the Iran-contra affair drew to a close, new questions had been raised about Ronald Reagan's involvement. But the public still had not learned what the President knew and when he knew it.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''If you raise the discount rate, you build confidence in the financial markets that the U.S. authorities will fight inflation and defend the dollar. I think that would bring interest rates down.'' Sam Nakagama, economist with Nakagama & Wallace.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
THE SUPERMARKET BLUES: ONCE A WEEK, SHOP TILL YOU DROP
description: LEAD: HELL hath no fury like me in a supermarket. Like dieting, it brings out the beast in me.

title: Tears of Mrs. Hart
description: Gary Hart said he woke up about 4 A.M., and decided hell, no, he wouldn't just go out quietly but would speak his mind, tell everybody about the dreadful times we are in. He ought to know that those wonderful middle-of-the-night inspirations don't look so good in daylight.

title: Miss Bundschuh And J. B. Coogan Exchange Vows
description: Lauren Elizabeth Bundschuh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Bundschuh Jr. of Rye and Millerton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph Baker Coogan, a son of Dr. Philip S. Coogan and Carol Jean Gerlach, both of Johnson City, Tenn. Auxiliary Bishop Eugene A. Marino of Washington performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye.

title: OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

title: AIDS Illness Kills Congressman
description: When Representative Stewart B. McKinney, a 56-year-old Republican from Connecticut, died last week of an infection brought on by AIDS, his office issued a statement attributing the disease to blood transfusions received during heart bypass surgery in 1979. But some friends and associates of Mr. McKinney, who were concerned that people needing transfusions would be needlessly frightened, later disclosed that he had had homosexual relationships.

title: On the Stand: Patriots or Rogues?
description: The first week of Iran-contra hearings quickly displayed the harsh dilemma facing the Reagan Administration. The testimony of the first witness, a retired Air Force general named Richard Secord, threw the untenable choice into sharpest relief: whether to describe those who participated in the Iran-contra affair as patriots or as rogues.

title:
GARDENING;
CONTAINERS PROVIDE EXTRA SPACE FOR FLORAL DISPLAYS
description: LEAD: GARDENING in containers is a wonderful way to add color. There also are several advantages. The plants are raised above soil level and make a better show. The soil mixture can be tailored to suit the needs of the plants. The floral display can be changed from spring to summer to fall. The same flowers can be repeated from year to year, if you find a particular combination pleasing, or the selection can be changed to suit new ideas.

title: JOURNAL FOR ELDERLY FACES UNCERTAIN FATE
description: FOR the past week, Rita Reutter has been busy writing what she calls a ''very spiffy'' newspaper article to commemorate Older Americans Month. She is also busy writing other articles that involve the elderly, as well as putting out her monthly newspaper column.

title: Pop Music
description: Amanda McBroom, who achieved recognition in 1979 as the composer of the title song for ''The Rose,'' is one of the leading lights of the small but active Los Angeles cabaret scene. Ms. McBroom's music blends three different worlds. Original ballads like ''The Rose,'' ''Ship in a Bottle'' and ''From Where I Stand,'' have a pop-country melodic feel and the lyric precision of theater songs. Her masterpiece, ''The Portrait,'' a wistful meditation on an unresolved mother-daughter relationship, boasts the harmonic richness and poetic depth of a full-blown art song.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, two arts-review headlines were reversed last Sunday on the bottom of page 76 in this section. The headlines that should have been transposed were ''Recital: Norma French Sings Grieg Program,'' and ''The Stage: 'Keeping Up.' ''

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ROAR OF THE CROWD
description: LEAD: THE shine of the stagelights, the glamour of greasepaint, the magic of musical comedy: such is the fabled stuff of the theater, long savored by professionals. But what of those who have not succumbed entirely to the silent goal of the stage, who have opted for a more secure, 9-to-5 existence, whose names are not in lights every night, but who want to be part of it all anyway?

title: A TRW TWIST: SELLING A SERVICE THAT IS OFTEN FREE
description: CREDIT reporting agencies have been keeping tabs on Americans' spending habits for years, selling the information to banks and other lenders. Now TRW Inc., the biggest of these watchdogs, has introduced a unique marketing twist: It wants consumers to pay $35 a year for a package of services centered on their credit reports, some of questionable value, others available for free. ''It's a brilliant marketing strategy to sell something to consumers that they may not need or could get for free,'' said Gary L. Walker, spokesman for the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: BASEBALLS ARE FLYING OUT EVERYWHERE
description: BOB OJEDA, the Mets' best pitcher in 1986, suggested that maybe the moon is aligned with Saturn. Dave Johnson, his manager, speculated that it might have something to do with the work force in Haiti. ''Maybe one shift likes pitchers and another shift doesn't,'' Johnson said. ''Maybe the shift that doesn't like pitchers comes in and winds the ball tighter.'' Bert Blyleven thought it was amusing that he should be asked the question at all considering he gave up a record 50 home runs last season.

title: WHOSE BUSINESS IS TV NEWS?
description: THERE IS A CRISIS IN NETWORK NEWSROOMS, although then again maybe there's not. Congress has wondered what's up. Is a network news division a public trust or, God forbid, a ''profit center,'' and whatever the answer, what are the implications? The discussion has been going on for months, in Washington and on Wall Street, in newspapers and in seminars, and on television itself. The three major networks want to spend less money on news programs, and a great many people are aroused. There are real issues here, along with a large element of gamesmanship. What could be more fun than to beat up on a network?

title: A NEW JAPANESE NATIONALISM
description: It is a historical truism that the dominant civilizations of history prospered, paradoxically, by an open absorption of alien cultures. Witness the character of history's greatest cities: Athens, Florence, Amsterdam, New York and, perhaps soon, Tokyo.

title:
ART;
PUTTING A CAREER TO THE TEST OF TIME
description: LEAD: A ONCE prominent name in the American art world, Byron Browne (1907-1961), warrants re-examination, if only to see whether the passage of time has clarified the fluctuations in his reputation.

title: JAZZ: JIMMY WITHERSPOON SINGS THE BLUES
description: JIMMY WITHERSPOON, a veteran blues singer, is singing the blues with more than theatrical emotion at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas between Ninth and Tenth Streets. He is fighting a throat problem that leaves his voice less rich, less resonant and free than it once was. But the effort gives his performances a sense of involvement that can be unusually strong, even with a restricted voice.

title: 'Turandot', 'Fidelio' AND THE BRAHMS DOUBLE
description: LEAD: PUCCINI'S last opera, ''Turandot,'' will be presented Friday at 8 P.M. and next Sunday at 3 P.M. at Fairleigh Dickinson University here.

title:
Long Island;
Industrial Corridor Is Becoming The Latest Locus of Prime Space
description: LEAD: WITH very little commercially zoned land left for development in Nassau County and in western Suffolk, the construction of high-quality office space is moving eastward. Veterans Memorial Highway, 30 miles outside New York City, is becoming Long Island's newest prestige office address.

title: IN THE ARTS, LIKE MOTHER, LIKE DAUGHTER
description: JULIET SHAW has always loved duo piano, in which two pianists play musical works arranged for two pianos. In her living room in Norwalk stand twin grand pianos, and she is happiest when each is occupied by one of her two daughters, both accomplished pianists.

title: HOME VIDEO: ANTIQUES
description: THE STORY OF ENGLISH FURNITURE Presented by Arthur Negus and Hugh Scully. Produced by Paul Smith and Robin Drake. Home Vision. Part I, 108 minutes; Part II, 107 minutes. $39.95 each.

title: COUNCIL LOOKS FOR BETTER WAYS TO CROSS THE STREET
description: WHEN Borough President David N. Dinkins announced appointment of a Planning for Pedestrians Council in February, he said the council would make recommendations within a year. Last week, at its first public hearing, the council heard what dozens of New Yorkers, many representing community boards or citizens' action groups, think of the state of the sidewalks and intersections and what Julian Menken of Community Board 5 in central Manhattan called ''this bicycle infestation that we have.'' Excerpts from their testimony follow. Mary Frances Dunham Transportation Alternatives

title: USING LIFE INSURANCE AS A TAX SHELTER
description: WHILE the recent Tax Act effectively axed many tax shelters, it hardly touched the tax breaks provided by life insurance. In particular, the single-premium policy has emerged as a popular tax-advantaged investment: You make a single payment up front - usually a minimum of $5,000, but in practice often $50,000 or $100,000 or more - that buys you a chunk of life insurance and an investment fund that appreciates tax-free as long as you keep the policy in force.

title: TOWNS CITE SAFETY CARES AS SKATEBOARDING GAINS
description: LAST month, a 10-year-old boy rode his skateboard out of the family driveway in Vernon and collided with a passing car.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Industrial Development Quietly Reviving
description: LEAD: SINCE the mid-1970's, the state's industrial space has remained relatively static because of rapid commercial and residential expansion in which old and abandoned factories have been converted into office and living space. A shortage of industrial space has evolved over the last three years as a result and developers have responded, spurring a slow, quiet revival in the industrial marketplace.

title: No Party Walls
description: Most of today's clustered condominiums are connected in such a way that barking, hammering and other din can permeate common walls, floating from living room to living room. But a 125-acre residential development planned for the Town of New Castle, N.Y., near Chappaqua, is trying to overcome this by having the condos attached at their garages.

title: Residential Resales

QUEENS Forest Hills $51,750 62-59 108th Street Postwar studio co-op; separate kitchen and dressing area, new windows; maintenance $233, 58% tax-deductible (Broker: Glenjay Realty) Woodside $225,000 52-42 66th Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath brick detached single-family house; new thermal windows, semifinished basement; 24- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $800 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate Inc.) STATEN ISLAND Stapleton Heights $255,000 300 Van Duzer Street 2-family Victorian house; 3 bedrooms, den and loft in upper duplex apartment, 2 bedrooms in secondary unit; 1 bath in each; professional office on ground fl. stained-glass windows, enclosed porch; 40-by 175-ft. lot; taxes $1,246 (Broker:

title: ALIENS PROGRAM OFF TO A TEPID START
description: LEAD: ILLEGAL aliens in the state who are eager for legal status under the new immigration law but wary about identifying themselves to the authorities are turning to go-betweens.

title: BECKER FACES BURDENS BEYOND HIS YEARS
description: HIS right knee was caked with blood and his tennis whites were covered in clay, a souvenir from the stadium court at Forest Hills. For Boris Becker, these were the signs of an honest night's work, the measure he uses to evaluate his performance. He, more than those around him - the hangers-on, news media and fans - appears to know his limitations, to understand that progress does not always result in victory and that inexperience is still his biggest adversary.

title: Air Fares Cut To Scandinavia
description: Some airline fares to Scandinavia have been reduced by about 50 percent, as Northwest Orient, Tower Air and the Government-owned Scandinavian Airlines System have engaged in a fare war.

title:
DINING OUT;
BEIJING CUISINE ON ROUTE 22
description: LEAD: ALICE WANG, the elegant proprietress of Springfield's Cathay 22, which opened in December, has imported six chefs from Beijing to cook in an unlikely location on bustling, capitalistic Route 22.

title: Westchester Ordered to Lower Jail Population
description: A Federal judge, warning that overcrowding at the Westchester County Jail could lead to a riot unless it is relieved, has ordered the county to reduce the number of inmates housed in its jail building.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
GREEN LACEWING
description: LEAD: Chrysopa ornata Size: To five-eighths of an inch.

title: INHERITED FACTOR MAY PLAY A ROLE IN RISK OF AIDS
description: British scientists have found the first evidence that genetic differences make some people more susceptible than others to infection with the virus that causes AIDS.

title: KREMLIN REINTERPRETS AND RE-EMPHASIZES THE LEGCY OF LENIN
description: GENNADI Gerasimov, the Soviet spokesman, appeared at his Tuesday press briefing last week with a smug look and the collected works of Vladimir Ilyich Lenin. President Reagan, in a speech two days earlier to American newspaper publishers, had attributed to Lenin the menacing words that ''the road to America leads through Mexico.'' If anyone in the room could find such a remark in Lenin, Mr. Gerasimov challenged, ''I am ready to eat my hat.''

title: J.T. KRUGER, QUELLED SOWETO RIOT
description: James Thomas Kruger, a hard-line enforcer of apartheid who gained world notoriety for harshness as South Africa's Minister of Justice, died Friday at his home near Pretoria. He was 69 years old and had recently undergone heart surgery.

title: STATE, HOSPITALS AND NURSES ACT TO FORESTALL AN ACUTE SHORTAGE
description: LEAD: HOSPITALS and nurses groups around the state used Nurses Day last week to call attention to the growing nursing shortage in New Jersey and elsewhere. Although officials said that the situation had not yet endangered patients, they warned that it soon could affect health-care delivery at all levels, from the storefront clinic to the coronary-care unit.

title: Cable Service Postponed Again
description: The saga of cable television in New York City might be the stuff of a network series - if it is ever concluded. In the latest cliffhanger, a state official announced last week that agreement with the city on plans for cable installation in the Bronx and Brooklyn was at hand; the next day, Mayor Koch announced tersely that the agreement was postponed.

title: FOR HIS RETURN TO TV JOHN TRAVOLTA TURNS COCKNEY
description: HAROLD PINTER, A MASTER of subtle, evocative, multilayered drama, and John Travolta, who soared to stardom playing inarticulate hunks, might seem an unlikely team. But Mr. Travolta will be seen in a one-hour adaptation of Mr. Pinter's short play ''The Dumbwaiter,'' which is to be shown Tuesday night at 10 on ABC.

title: MIAMI TAKES A LEAP INTO BALLET
description: LEAD: EDWARD VILLELLA HAS been the answer to the Miami City Ballet's dreams. Everyone knows about Miami. The city imports its performing arts: orchestras and dance companies in hit-and-run elusiveness and theatrical road companies offering featherweight comedies and CoolWhipped musicals. Miami doesn't even have its own symphony orchestra.

title: BALLET: 'TCHAIKOVSKY,' 'AGON' AND 'LA SOURCE'
description: AN unexpected debut occurred Friday night at the New York State Theater when Michel Mesnier danced the ''Tema con Variazioni'' sequence of George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3.''

title: DANCE OF LIFE AND GLAROS EQUALLY SUCCESSFUL
description: Dance of Life and Glaros scored similarly impressive victories while posting identical times in divisions of the Fort Marcy Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: BEYOND THE SPECTACLE OF A.B.T.'S 'SLEEPING BEAUTY'
description: ''THE SLEEPING BEAUTY'' OF 1890 was created as a ''ballet-feerie'' for Russia's Imperial Theater in St. Petersburg. Yet, if ''ballet-feerie'' was a term applied to productions in which spectacle was dominant, ''The Sleeping Beauty'' was never conceived as empty spectacle. Meaning was present on every level.

title: LEHMAN SHOWS 'PRODUCTS' OF BRONX ALTERNATIVE SPACES
description: THE number of artists has long exceeded that of galleries willing and able to exhibit them. Still, the imbalance can never have been so dire as it was in the early 1970's, when the present art-education system introduced by American universities after World War II began bearing fruit in earnest - and when alternative spaces came to the rescue.

title:
Boston;
In the Face of Skepticism, a Move To Push Out the City's Perimeter
description: LEAD: CABOT, Cabot & Forbes, an old-line private investment firm turned developer, is making a daring effort to push this city's suburban office development beyond its traditional limits. It is risking millions of its own dollars on the proposition that greater Boston will be bounded by Interstate 495, nearly an hour's drive from downtown.

title: 5,000 NESTS IN EVERY TREE
description: THE DREAMS OF DRAGONS Riddles of Natural History. By Lyall Watson. 178 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: Driving Abroad
description: To the Editor: I have just returned from a four-week European trip that included 12 to 14 border crossings, many in the Bregenz area where Germany, Switzerland and Austria meet. My experience may be of interest to readers of the items (Travel, April 5) about French visas and Swiss superhighway stickers.

title: ATHLETES DRAW FIRE, AND PEOPLE STOKE IT
description: IT happened on a Sunday night after a game in Kearney, Neb., during the summer of 1959. I was a 19-year-old pitcher with the Kearney Yankees of the Class D Nebraska State Rookie League. Four teammates and I had just walked around the corner after leaving a restaurant when we were suddenly confronted, in a menacing way, by eight local tough guys about our age. As best I can remember, they were angry about something that had to do with somebody's girlfriend, and probably with good reason.

title: WHY OUR GREATEST COMPOSER NEEDS SERIOUS ATTENTION
description: THE GREAT DISAPPOINT-ment of this concert season was Leonard Bernstein's withdrawal of Charles Ives's Fourth Symphony from his Philharmonic programs. It is Ives's biggest and most difficult work; Leopold Stokowski gave the premiere with his American Symphony Orchestra in 1965 only after weeks of rehearsals and after failed attempts with other orchestras. It has not yet had a fully satisfying realization in the hands of an American conductor steeped in Ives and the traditions he knew. Mr. Bernstein might be that conductor, and we must hope that this season's cancellation was merely a postponement.

title: U.S. TIES WITH LIBERIA PUT UNDER NEW STRAIN
description: ''PARADE rest,'' barked the United States-trained officer to troops wearing United States Army issue uniforms and drilling in front of barracks built with United States military aid. Every West African nation has a patron, usually the former colonial power - Britain, France or Portugal. Liberia has the United States.

title: OILERS EDGE WINGS WITH GOAL AT )0:36
description: Marty McSorley's goal with 36 seconds to play tonight gave the Edmonton Oilers a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in Game 3 of their semifinal series.

title: The Annual Rent Catharsis
description: Now is the time for tenants and landlords to sign up for the annual hearings that help to determine how much rents will be allowed to rise in some 943,000 rent stabilized apartments, lofts and hotel rooms in New York City.

title: INSIDE
description: 3 I.R.A. Leaders Died in Raid The police in Northern Ireland disclosed that three senior figures in the Irish Republican Army were among eight guerrillas killed Friday in an intercepted raid on the police.

title: Witchcraft and the Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Applaud Meese For Doing His Job?
description: To the Editor:

title: OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

title: QUIET HAVEN IN THE BALEARICS
description: For many people, Minorca is the plain Jane of the Balearic Islands. Less visually spectacular and poorer than Majorca, not as hip or trendy as Ibiza, the island to miss if you can't see them all. All true perhaps, but therein lies its charm, and because it has not been totally swamped by tourism or overrun by foreign boutiques, it retains a naturalness and authenticity that is at once soothing and refreshing.

title: THE WRIGHT SITE
description: To the Editor:

title: FORGING A KINDLY IMAGE FOR DRIVING INSPECTORS
description: AS a result of complaints -and officials say there have been many - the State Department of Motor Vehicles is beginning a statewide ''image-enhancer'' program to teach its gruff and put-upon driving inspectors how to be more sympathetic to people trying to pass their driving tests, the majority of whom are teen-agers.

title: A World Without Nuclear Weapons
description: I thought your symposium entitled ''A World Without Nuclear Weapons?'' (April 5) was an important contribution to this complex debate.

title: CUOMO TO ORDER STUDY OF SALARIES
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he was ordering a review of salaries paid to employees of New York State's largely independent public authorities.

title: FINE CARTRIDGES AT MODEST PRICES
description: THE CONTINUED IMPOR-tance of LP's in the musical lives of serious record collectors has not only prompted the development of new turntables (as reported in last week's column) but also led to several noteworthy new designs of phono cartridges.

title: PATRIOTISM IS A THEME FOR THE NEWEST DESIGN
description: THE United States Postal Service added some excitement to the regular 22-cent flag stamp by introducing a new one showing the flag against a night sky illuminated by fireworks. The stamp was issued in Denver, Colo. in conjunction with the stamp show, Rompex '87. It goes on sale tomorrow at post offices.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Remembering Mother
description: LEAD: Future students and visitors to Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry who enter the Viola D. Hank Mathematics Laboratory may well wonder who Viola D. Hank is and why the room bears her name. They might conjecture that she is a well-known mathematician or a teacher of note, but the answer is ''neither of the above.

title: Drug Charges Are Dropped For 2 Accused by Daughter
description: Charges against the parents of a teen-age girl who turned them in for using drugs were dropped Friday after the couple proved they had successfully completed a counseling program.

title: RUMANIA SEEKS TO KEEP FAVORED TRADE STATUS
description: In recent days, the Rumanian Embassy has brought to Washington a chorus of 40 Jewish boys and girls who sang Yiddish songs and a delegation of 12 religious leaders of various denominations. These were not so much a part of a cultural exchange or to discuss comparative religion as a question of trade policy.

title: 90 FEARED DROWNED AS FERRY CAPSIZES ON YANGTZE
description: More than 90 passengers on a ferryboat were feared to have drowned in the Yangtze River Friday when the ferry collided with a tugboat near the city of Nantong in Jiangsu Province, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Headliners; Voting for Jobs
description: When voters lose jobs, elected officals tend to lose votes. So it was with Mayor Richard G. Hatcher of Gary, Ind., whose bid for a sixth term ended last week when he finished second in the Democratic mayoral primary. Mr. Hatcher, who gained national prominence in 1967 as one of the first blacks elected mayor of a major city, had been losing support in recent years as the steel industry, Gary's main employer, collapsed and his administration was unable to revive the city's economy. Local mills have laid off more than 10,000 workers since the 1970's, pushing the city's unemployment rate to more than 20 percent. Mr. Hatcher's opponent, Thomas V. Barnes, a former Hatcher campaign worker, said unemployment was the main issue in the race. Mr. Barnes, whose primary victory is tantamount to election in the overwhelmingly Democratic city of 145,000, promised better relations with local business.

title: RuthAnn Warnell Becomes a Bride
description: RuthAnn Warnell, who expects to receive a medical degree from the University of Pennsylvania May 18, was married yesterday to David Livingstone Kerr 3d, an associate in the investment banking division of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York. The Rev. John A. Gilmore performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Milford, Del.

title: CLEAN PITTSBURGH AIR SYMBOLIZES ECONOMIC SHIFT
description: The air in Pittsburgh, a city once branded ''hell with the lid off,'' has for some time ceased to be a black joke without a punch line. Now, unlike the air in New York, Baltimore or Chicago, it even meets Federal standards for cleanliness, state officials have announced.

title: OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE MAKING OF A JOURNALIST. By William S. White. (University Press of Kentucky, $22.) William S. White has nearly 50 years of journalism behind him, from his Texas roots in hectic wire-service and ''Front Page''-type scoops to his apotheosis as nationally syndicated columnist and opinion shaper.

title: Julia Kathryn Westerman Is Married To Herbert Bostwick 3d on Long Island
description: Julia Kathryn Westerman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Westerman of St. Petersburg, Fla., and Wantagh, L.I., was married yesterday to Herbert Bostwick 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bostwick Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I.

title: Less Joblessness, Higher Hopes
description: Analysts in and out of Government tore back to their calculators at last week's report of a drop of three-tenths of a percentage point in unemployment in April, to 6.2 percent, the lowest level in seven years.

title: ARTFUL BEASTS OF THE MIDDLE AGES
description: GALLERY EXHIBITIONS of medieval objects -boldly carved stone capitals, dragon-embellished candlesticks, massive iron locks, lavishly illuminated manuscript pages and buckles enameled in jewel colors - have become increasingly rare in New York in recent years. The scarcity of such material in the marketplace makes ''Art Treasures of the Middle Ages,'' at Michael Ward, 9 East 93d Street, through May 30, a welcome event.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SEVENTH SANCTUARY. By Daniel Easterman. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Daniel Easterman, the pseudonym for an English professor of Islamic studies, has crammed this thriller with enough murky mayhem to see Robert Ludlum through his next six epics. ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' seems like ''Radio Days'' in comparison. When he is describing the desert, the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem, forgotten monasteries in Sinai defiles, Mr. Easterman writes well. But his dialogue is studded with lines like: ''There isn't time!'' and ''We've got to get out of here.'' Characters invariably feel fear like a lump of ice in the throat or lead in the stomach. Most of them don't stay around to feel anything for very long. Astonishing numbers of people are killed with revolting brutality within a page or two of their appearance. Only David Rosen, an American-born Jewish archeologist, and his Palestinian girlfriend, Leyla, escape swift extinction. It seems that in defeat the Nazis retreated to a buried city in the Arabian desert, where, in the 1980's, they are schooling a new generation for a comeback. A veritable corps of them has infiltrated the Israeli Army and intelligence service as well as the American military and political establishment (which Mr. Easterman trashes in an offhand way). Only David and Leyla are smart enough to connect the multiple murders to the Nazis' plan to destroy the state of Israel and create an Arab Reich. Archeology buffs and thriller aficionados with strong stomachs will stay with it even when they don't believe a word.

title: Monster Makeup
description: To the Editor:

title: CITIES VIE FOR SITE FOR LITTLE LEAGUE
description: KEVIN KEELEY is well aware of what Little League baseball has done for Williamsport, Pa., putting it on the map as the home of the Little League World Series. Now Mr. Keeley is convinced that Little League baseball can be a key to revitalizing Bridgeport.

title: Ms. Gibson, Chef, Weds C. S. White
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Atonement in Tenafly, N.J., yesterday Ellen Elizabeth Gibson, executive chef of the Silver Palate in Manhattan, and Christopher Silva White, a financial executive for the Bristol-Myers Company in New York, were married by the Rev. John P. Croneberger. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ian W. Gibson of Alpine, N.J., and Amagansett, L.I. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis White of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Sarasota, Fla.

title: THE OTHER SIBERIA
description: YOU LIVE AND LOVE And Other Stories. By Valentin Rasputin. Translated by Alan Myers. Foreword by Richard Lourie. 180 pp. New York: Vanguard Press. $16.95.

title: REWRITNING THE ANNUAL BUDGET DRAMA
description: THE clarion call has come once again from the Treasury Department: Congress must approve an increase in the public debt ceiling so the Government can continue to borrow to pay its bills. By Friday, if the increase is not approved, the Treasury will be in trouble. By May 28, the Treasury says, the Government will be in default.

title: INSIDE EVERY TOURIST, A TRAVELER
description: It has been fashionable for some years now, perhaps since Paul Fussell wrote his splendid book about the history and nature of traveling abroad, to speak of the profoundly deep gulf that separates those of us who are brave enough to do so. (Not all are so brave: ''Never go abroad,'' warned old King Edward VII. ''Abroad's bloody!'') But those who do take the risk are, it is now customary to say, divided: There is that unspeakable breed of humanoid who is known as the ''tourist,'' and there is that semi-mythic, usually heroic character who, in full Banana Republic raiment, is referred to by many - and certainly by himself - as the ''traveler.''

title: DAWSON IS GIVING MICHAEL AND THE CUBS A WINNING TOUCH
description: BEFORE he maneuvered the Chicago Cubs into first place in the National League East last week, Gene Michael hadn't managed a first-place team since June 11, 1981. The players' strike started the next day, insuring - as it turned out - the Yankees' presence in the postseason playoffs. Michael, however, did not make the playoffs. George Steinbrenner dismissed him a month before they began.

title: HOME VIDEO: DOCUMENTARY
description: MARCH OF TIME'S SHOW BUSINESS - THE WAR YEARS Embassy Home Entertainment. 75 minutes. $24.95.

title: Single Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Germans Stand Up Not to Be Counted
description: In the eyes of the authorities, the 30 young people gathered in the smoky back room of a bar called the South Railroad Station were plotting against the state.

title: O'ROURKE ASSAILED OVER HOUSING SITES
description: THE pieces of county-owned land listed last month by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke are either too small, too wet, too rocky or not really available for moderate-priced housing, according to officials in the communities where the land is situated.

title: America's Cup Groups in Dispute
description: A spokesman for the Sail America Foundation, sponsor of the America's Cup-winning yacht Stars & Stripes, said tonight that the group will seek arbitration concerning membership of the site selection committee for the next America's Cup.

title: Lyle Jenee Mayne Marries
description: Lyle Jenee Mayne, the daughter of Mrs. Fred J. Mayne of Saddle River, N.J., and the late Mr. Mayne, was married yesterday to Gregory Scott Owens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Owens of Wayne, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Howard Hansen performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J. Mrs. Owens is an assistant secretary at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York. Mr. Owens is a plant engineer for the U.S. Gypsum Company in Stony Point, N.Y.

title: Conrail Engineer Indicted in Wreck
description: A Federal grand jury last week indicted a Conrail engineer on 16 counts of manslaughter, saying he showed ''wanton or reckless disregard for human life'' in driving through a stop signal and into the path of a speeding Amtrak train. In addition to the 16 passengers who died in the crash, 175 were injured.

title: THE BARBIE FILE
description: THE TRIAL OF KLAUS Barbie is to open tomorrow in the French city of Lyons, and when it does, it will take an act of will to reconcile the frail 74-year-old man in the dock, whom one might imagine stooped over a flower bed in the garden of his retirement home, with the crimes he is accused of committing. What, this kindly looking and rheumy-eyed old widower, whose voice can barely rise above a whisper, was the S.S. captain in Lyons who signed the order sending Jewish children to their deaths at Auschwitz? This senior citizen personally tortured men and women, was responsible for sending thousands of Jews and members of the French Resistance to concentration camps, and earned the sobriquet ''Butcher of Lyons''?

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: NEXT Saturday, North America's best birders will square off against New Jersey's birds in the World Series of Birding. The contest, sponsored by the New Jersey Audubon Society, accomplishes several things:

title: No Headline
description: ALTHOUGH New Jersey may soon have a new law aimed at protecting families with children against discrimination in rental housing, the measure's sponsor, State Senator Wynona M. Lipman, believes that more will be needed.

title: 'De-Powering'
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A World Without Nuclear Weapons
description: In his contribution to the symposium, Zbigniew Brzezinski argues that, as long as the great powers continue to settle disputes through war, it is not possible to abolish nuclear weapons because, in case of war, the antagonists would be tempted to build them again - and possibly use them - and the knowledge of how to make these weapons cannot be erased. I agree. Mr. Brzezinski concludes that, therefore, the abolition of nuclear weapons is a pipe dream. I conclude, with many others, that therefore war itself must be abolished as a human institution, as slavery was abolished, if we want to survive. DIETRICH FISCHER Robbinsville, N.J.

description: It seems appropriate that in the bicentennial year of the Unites States Constitution officials in Washington should demonstrate some of its lesser-used protections. Last week, Thomas M. Roberts, a member of the Nuclear
