description: To the Editor:

title: WILL BOOZE AND PERRIER BE OBSOLETE?
description: LAST September, just before the World Series was to begin, The New York Post asked Mets star Howard Johnson about his biggest worry going into the pennant race.

title: Marla S. Smith Marries Thomas Berkenkamp
description: Marla Susan Smith, a daughter of Martin G. Smith and Jeri B. Smith, both of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Alan Berkenkamp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. Berkenkamp of Kankakee, Ill. The Rev. Raymond Schulze, a Lutheran minister, and Cantor Mayer Becker officiated at the Westbury Hotel in Manhattan.

title: DEFIANCE AND RAGE HONE A DEBUT RAP ALBUM
description: ''UH-OH, CHUCK, THEY OUT TO get us!'' are the first words on the debut album by Public Enemy, ''Yo! Bum Rush the Show'' (Def Jam/Columbia BFC 40658, album and cassette) - the grittiest rap album so far this year and one of rap's fastest sellers. ''Us'' refers to Chuck D (whose last name is Ridenhour) and Flavor-Flav (William Drayton), Public Enemy's songwriters and rappers. While they don't usually get preachy about it, they make it clear that they're also speaking for an embattled black underclass, shown as targets on the album's cover and innersleeve. With Bernhard Goetz currently on trial for shooting four young black men in the subway, and with the Howard Beach racial incident still in the air, Public Enemy can't help being topical.

title: Leslie Plesent Weds Jordan Fox in Massachusetts
description: Leslie Plesent, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Plesent of New York and Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to Jordan Charles Fox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Fox of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Harold Salzman performed the ceremony at the Seven Hills Inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: ROCK: HUEY LEWIS
description: CLEAN-CUT, good-natured, proudly conventional - that's Huey Lewis's kind of rock, and it filled Madison Square Garden on Monday and Tuesday for shows by the six-man Huey Lewis and the News. With the Tower of Power horn section for added punch, the band dispensed a solid, well-crafted amalgam of soul, doo-wop and blues-rock on Tuesday, topped by Mr. Lewis's exuberantly husky voice. For those who like rock without rebellion - rock that proclaims it's ''hip to be square'' - it was an exemplary show.

title: PROPP SILENCING HIS CRITICS
description: Brian Propp, Philadelphia's version of a tight-lipped Jim McMahon, ran a calloused hand over his latest brush cut, removed his opaque wraparound sunglasses, and considered the spectacle of the black-shirted Flyers gliding through a practic session today.

title: KEEPNG SPRING NOISY WITH SONG
description: THIS year marks a quarter of a century since Rachel Carson told her ''fable of tomorrow'' - a tomorrow in which a devastating blight had crept over a once happy, healthy and beautiful town.

title: Beverly Miller Is Married To Peter Busch Orthwein
description: Beverly Miller and Peter Busch Orthwein were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. C.Hugh Hildesley. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Miller of New Vernon, N.J. Mr. Orthwein is a son of Mrs. David D. Metcalfe and Adolphus Busch Orthwein, both of St. Louis, and a great-great-grandson of Adolphus Busch, founder of the Anheuser-Busch Brewing Company.

title: Susan Widdemer Engaged
description: Mr. and Miss John DeWitt Widdemer of Gloversville, N.Y., and Canada Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan DeWitt Widdemer, to Keith Eaton Harrington, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman W. Harrington of Oxford, Md. A July 18 wedding is planned. Miss Widdemer is a production coordinator at Sotheby's in New York. Her fiance is vice president of Village Craftsmen, a printing company in Rosemont, N.J. His marriage ended in divorce.

title: LOCAL MOVES FAIL TO BAR EX-CONVICT
description: An appellate court has ruled that California counties may not prevent the state from paroling prison inmates in their communities, ending the odyssey of a former convict who had been shunted among various hiding places since April 25 like a stateless man.

title: Streetscapes: The Third Avenue 'Cottages'; A Cool Low-Rise Oasis In Hot Development Area
description: The ''cottages,'' as they are called locally, comprise a little low-rise oasis on Third Avenue between East 77th and East 78th Streets. Built in 1937, they occupy a prime potential development site, a full blockfront on the bustling avenue just outside the Upper East Side Historic District. Only two stories high, with a large garden, they are 50 years old this year. But it is hard to believe that they can long survive the superheated Manhattan real-estate market.

title: NEW TESTS URGED ON MISSILE SHIELD
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has sent President Reagan a report proposing four new tests that would violate the traditional interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Administration officials said today.

title:
ART;
OBSERVER AND OBSERVED
description: LEAD: ''SELF-PORTRAITS: The Message, The Material,'' the current exhibition at Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery in Hempstead, is the latest in a series of recent shows that have explored the artist's function as both observer and observed. The duality of this role is especially timely in that contemporary trends have brought the artist more and more, so to speak, out from behind the shadow of the easel and into the limelight of public scrutiny.

title: LIFE WITHOUT ONE'S BEST FRIEND...
description: ''ALL my life Mom never let me down. Whenever I needed her, she was always right there. It's so hard to believe she's really gone.''

title: Bonni Lyn Levine Weds Peter Curran
description: Bonni Lyn Levine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Levine of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Peter Gamble Curran, the son of Catherine Gamble Curran of New York and Jean Alonzo Curran of Rowayton, Conn. Justice Leonard E. Yoswein of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was just above me and I could see the faces in the windows. There was some sputtering from the two engines on the right side. Then the plane disappeared into the trees and there was a big explosion with fire and smoke. The ground shuddered.'' - Czeslaw Buchalksi, after183 died in the crash of a Polish airliner. [ 1:1. ]

title: Goetz Trial Examines the Nature of Threat
description: Testimony last week in the increasingly fractious trial of Bernhard H. Goetz revolved around perceptions of threat.

title: REAGAN'S BAND OF TRUE BELIEVERS
description: SOON WE WILL know more about the Iran-contra affair. Witnesses before the special prosecutor's grand jury, and before the Congressional committees that began hearings last week, will expose the operations in much greater detail. They will delve into the un-derworld of arms dealers and financial brokers into which Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and his fellow National Security Council staff members descended. They will tell of Manucher Ghorbanifar, the main intermediary with the Iranians and the Scheherazade of polygraphs. They will enumerate the secret arms deals and try to account for the millions of dollars gone astray on their way to the contras. In the end, we may discover what the President and his Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, knew and what they did. But the Tower Commission report has already made the style of the operations quite clear - and it has given us important clues to the central question of how such a thing could have occurred.

title: JOHN SCHIFF, A PHILANTHROPIST AND INVESTMENT BANKER, DIES
description: John M. Schiff, investment banker, philanthropist and last of the senior partners of Kuhn, Loeb & Company, with which his family had been associated for more than a century, died yesterday at his home in Oyster Bay, L.I. He was 82 years old and also had an apartment in Manhattan and a home on the island of Jamaica.

title: Verbatim; Dissenting
description: ' I do not believe that the meaning of the Constitution was forever ''fixed'' at the Philadelphia Convention. Nor do I find the wisdom, foresight and sense of justice exhibited by the Framers particularly profound. To the contrary, the government they devised was defective from the start, requiring several amendments, a civil war and momentous social transformation to attain the system of constitutional government, and its respect for the individual freedoms and human rights, we hold as fundamental today. ' Justice Thurgood Marshall addressing a lawyers' convention.

title: The Modifiers of Mother
description: MY COLLEAGUES at U.S. News & World Report and such learned journals as The New York Times,'' writes David E. Pollard, ''keep referring to Mary Beth Whitehead as the surrogate mother of Baby M. I hold that she isn't a surrogate anything. I say she is the mother. As in real, actual, honest-to-God mother. For hire, maybe. But mother, nonetheless.

title: 1988: A New Chapter
description: Politics more or less as usual resumed after Gary Hart quit the Presidential race. Four Democrats took their case to Iowa: Bruce Babbitt, Michael S. Dukakis, Richard A. Gephardt and Paul Simon.

title: A Slow Modernization of India's Ancient Cart
description: For centuries, the bullock cart has symbolized the face of traditional India and its ancient, village-based civilization to the outside world.

title: 17 Killed in a Crash in Haiti
description: A water truck crashed into a crowd of pedestrians and street vendors here Friday night, killing at least 17 people and injuring five others, witnesses said. The accident occurred in the densely populated Post Marchand slum neighborhood.

title: Whistle-Blowing In a U.S. Prison
description: AN inmate's complaint of ''bad air'' in the Federal prison office where he worked ignited a dispute that pitted the Federal Department of Labor against the Justice Department and its Bureau of Prisons.

title: Photography
description: Victor Schrager has never been interested in appealing to the crowd. Until recently, his photographs consisted of skeletal webs of images appropriated from various webs of images appropriated from various sources, both artistic and commonplace. Their complex network of meanings, and the daunting air of intelligence that accompanied them, tended to override what decorative appeal the pictures possessed. His was an art for the mind more than for the eye, and many eyes disdained it. Only in retrospect do Schrager's early combinations of paintings, maps, magazine illustrations and other photographs seem prescient, so perfectly do they match the current concerns of a younger generation of artists.

title: WHEN HOSPITAL'S DISASTER PLANS BECOME REALITY
description: ALL hospitals in the state are required to have disaster plans. A building collapse and a radioactive alert forced hospitals in two cities to put their plans into practice.

title: FILIPINOS DRAW BATTLE LINES FOR ELECTIONS
description: With a prayer and a shower of fireworks, campaigning ended today for legislative elections Monday that will restore a complete Government structure in the Philippines.

title: ON LAWNSMANSHIP AND SPRINGTIME CHORES
description: THE grass is growing; it may be necessary to mow more than once a week. Be sure mower blades are sharp and remember to set them to cut high, at least two inches or more since high cut encourages deep grass roots and makes the turf more drought resistant. Groom daffodils and tulips by snapping off faded flowers to prevent wasteful seed pods. Check pea vines daily as crop is starting to ripen; flavor is best when pods are young and succulent. Thin thickly sown rows of beets, chard and leaf lettuce; young plants should be at least one thumb width apart. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS PETUNIAS

title: PRINCES OF THE MENTAL STATES
description: THE CULTURE OF CRITICISM AND THE CRITICISM OF CULTURE By Giles Gunn. 216 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: The Air Force's SR-71 shows an eye for detail
description: MOST OF THE TIME IT IS INVISIBLE from earth, hurtling along at speeds over 2,000 miles an hour at altitudes up to 100,000 feet. The United States Air Force SR-71 is the world's fastest, technically most advanced spy plane, capable of seeing more from a greater distance than any other aircraft. And recent developments - the escalation of espionage between East and West, the curtailment of NASA's Space Shuttle program and the loss of several spy satellites through technical failures - have made this extraordinary plane more vital than ever. From its home at Beale Air Force Base in northern California, the SR-71 serves as America's eye on the globe. THE AIR FORCE, WHICH HAS BEEN using the SR-71 since 1966, has nicknamed the plane Blackbird, although viewed in flight it more resembles a spacecraft from ''Star Wars.'' According to the author and aviation expert William E. Burrows, 15 to 19 Blackbirds exist; the exact number is classified. Operated by a two-man crew, a pilot and a reconnaissance systems officer (R.S.O.), the craft's espionage capabilities are unparalleled: an SR-71 can survey 100,000 square miles from 15 miles up in only one hour. Difficult to detect by radar, it can also track SAM missiles at a distance of up to 100 miles. The Blackbird can reach speeds of up to Mach 4, or 2,600 miles per hour; no country has ever succeeded in shooting one down. EACH PLANE IS FITTED WITH A PAIR of cameras that automatically produce 1,800 overlapping photos of up to 1,600 miles of terrain; and a camera that can produce pictures with a ground resolution of 12 inches. The Blackbird's view of San Francisco from 80,000 feet (below), showing the pyramid-shaped Transamerica building in the upper left and the Oakland Bay Bridge, has the clarity of a photo shot at 1,000 feet. The picture's quality may have to do with the emulsion on the extremely fine-grain film used - about which the Air Force will say nothing.

title: CONTRA CONTROVERSY RAISED AT CASEY FUNERAL
description: The funeral of William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence who died Wednesday, was marked today by the controversy that continues to swirl around President Reagan's policy of aiding the rebels fighting the Government of Nicaragua.

title: WAR ON POVERTY
description: To the Editor:

title: Erin Marie Casey to Wed John Leo Walsh 3d Aug. 1
description: Gov. and Mrs. Robert P. Casey of Harrisburg, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Erin Marie Casey to John Leo Walsh 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsh Jr. of Scranton, Pa. The couple plan to marry Aug. 1.

title: Patricia Anne Woods Weds R. E. Andersen
description: Patricia Anne Woods was married yesterday to Richard Esten Andersen at the Fourth Universalist Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Joyce Smith performed the ceremony.

title: Inquiry Pu?sued On Meese's Links To Contractor
description: The Justice Department has started a internal investigation into the legality and propriety of connections between Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the Wedtech Corporation, and Congress is asking that it work quickly.

title: Criminal Obsession
description: Mystery fiction is to its fans what bottles are to babies: something for which they perpetually hunger. So they haunt bookstores with names like Foul Play and Scene of the Crime. They pause for a tour of airport paperbacks even while the flight attendant announces boarding. And they live in fear of the day when their favorite scribbler joins Agatha and Ngaio, Dashiell and Dorothy at that great writers' convention in the sky.

title: Anne Phillips Has Wedding
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston was the setting for the wedding yesterday of Anne Crocker Phillips to Henry McFarlan Ogilby. The Rev. Spencer Morgan Rice, the rector, performed the ceremony.

title: FOR THE PANEL, SECORD STIRS ANGER AND QUESTIONS
description: After listening to Richard V. Secord's detailed testimony in the first week of Congressional hearings into the Iran-contra affair, many committee members say they are outraged and amazed by how much the Reagan Administration delegated foreign policy to a small group of covert private operators.

title: HAS TRIPLE CROWN LOST STATURE? IF SO, WHY?
description: No, the Triple Crown has not lost stature; present day million-dollar bonuses have only distorted what has always been the true picture. Thoroughbred breeders and owners recognize that the 11 winners of the Triple Crown are the apex of the breed: superbly athletic, resilient to stress and of strong will and great heart.

title: SHIPWRECKS IN MYSTIC
description: Shipwrecks, long the inspiration of fear and fascination, are the focus of an exhibit, ''Shipwrecks and Disasters at Sea'' at the Mystic Seaport Museum in Connecticut.

title: TEMPLE CREW WINS
description: Temple won the featured race of the 49th annual Dad Vail Regatta today, capturing the Tom Conville Cup for varsity eights for the fifth straight year, tying the record for successive victories established by the Coast Guard Academy in the mid-70's.

title: Bonnie Tilkin Is Bride Of Robert S. Alexander
description: Bonnie Tilkin was married last evening to Robert Saphir Alexander at the home of Albert Ross, the bride's uncle, in Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Sheldon Harr performed the ceremony.

title: NEW YORK CITY CHILDREN LEARN TO RECYCLE REFUSE
description: A squadron of pupils from a Greenwich Village elementary school has enlisted in New York's war against waste, shouting their battle cry -''recycle'' - in their classrooms, playgrounds, neighborhoods and homes.

title: Where There's a World There's a Way
description: AFTER the gray skies of winter break and patches of blue burst out more frequently from whitening clouds then, in the first glorious sun-filled days of spring, the human spirit rises to greet the coming season of rebirth. The warmth and promise, so different from the chill before and the dulling heat to come, provide the most delicious time of the year.

title: ONTARIO'S FRENCH RIVER FOR SALACE OF THE WILDS
description: Canoeing around Ontario's near north one day in 1615, the French adventurer Samuel de Champlain found what he had long been searching for, a river that French fur traders could ply to paddle their pelts out from as far west as present-day Sault Ste. Marie. Some 300 years later well-heeled Pittsburghers - this time in search of nothing more esoteric than a patch of fresh air -discovered the same French River. Instead of canoeing straight through, they built fishing cottages on islands in the upper river, and those structures survive almost intact today.

title: JAMES AND US-25 YEARS AND THE BOND SURVIVES
description: JAMES BOND, THE INDEFECTIBLY-tailored British secret agent with a license to kill, celebrates his 25th anniversary as an international film star this year, and the observances will begin Wednesday at 9 P.M., when ABC broadcasts a television special called ''Happy Anniversary 007.'' (A Museum of Modern Art retrospective of Bond films and the newest James Bond film, ''The Living Daylights,'' will follow later this year.) As a literary figure, Bond came into the public eye in the first Ian Fleming account of his exploits, ''Casino Royale,'' in 1953. He had worked his way up to the rank of commander in the Royal Navy before going into the Civil Service, so he would have been about 36 in 1953, making him a spry 70 today. We should only do as well.

title: Betsy B. Phillips Weds E. S. Mandel in Capital
description: Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Betsy Bowman Phillips, a daughter of Melvin Burdette Phillips of Liberty, Ky., and the late Mrs. Phillips, to Edward Safford Mandel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Frank Mandel of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Lawrence J. Madden performed the ceremony.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; NEW CANAAN
description: TWO hundred years ago, Canaan Parish's population of less than a hundred people was decimated. With the Revolutionary War ended, the Loyalists had fled, and many other families had moved to New York or Vermont in search of better farmland.

title: SACRAMENTO JAZZES IT UP
description: Beginning May 22, much of Sacramento, Calif., will be taken over for four days by an invading force of trumpet and tuba players, drummers and banjo strummers, piano players and Red Hot Mamas from around the world. What began 13 years ago as a weekend jam session by local musicians has blossomed into the Sacramento Dixieland Jubilee, which residents say is one of the largest jazz festivals anywhere.

title: ...AND LEARNING TO BE A MODERN MOM
description: ONCE upon a time, motherhood was a sacred institution based on the combined arts and sciences of baking, laundering, polishing and mending, in addition to listening, advising, healing and nurturing. But as my musical hero Bob Dylan so aptly put it, ''The times, they are a-changing.''

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: A Mother's Desire To Be Rediscovered
description: I DON'T remember exactly when I stopped thinking of my mother as just my mother and began to look at her as a real person - a person like other people, like my friends' mothers who talked and laughed and carried on in the regular world.

title: DU BOIS STILL A GREAT HERO TO GHANAIANS
description: Elders blew cow horns, an Ashanti chorus sang praises, and a chief priest splashed libations over the coffin of the man from Great Barrington, Mass.

title: 'THE TEMPEST' STAGED IN STRATFORD
description: WITH the ''potent art'' of a magician transforming monsters and melting spirits ''into air, into thin air'' - all on an enchanted island -''The Tempest'' is a magical play, through and through. In its modest way, the Theater for a New Audience, a Manhattan-based troupe, is making theatrical magic during the Stratford American Shakespeare Theater's three-week student season, which offers two performances this Saturday for general audiences.

title: Data Update
description: BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing units)

title: The Danger of Giving and Taking Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: SKIDMORE COLLEGE
description: At Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., 518 students were awarded degrees yesterday. Honorary doctorates in humane letters were conferred upon Richard Wilbur, recently named the country's poet laureate, and Lena Spencer, owner of a local coffeehouse, for her contribution in furthering the careers of folk musicians.

title: CABARET: K.D. LANG, COUNTRY
description: K. D. LANG comes on strong. She started her set Monday at the Bottom Line with a torchy ballad, leaning over the electric piano and emoting in throbbing, overwrought crescendoes that most country singers would save for peaks. Not Ms. Lang: she built from there.

title: Next Week; Should Athletes Be Role Models?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: China Says Cyanide in River Killed Over 50 Tons of Fish
description: More than 50 tons of fish were killed when cyanide discharged from a textile factory polluted 25 miles of the Meijiang, a river in southern Guangdong Province, the official China Daily reported today.

title: Motta to Decide
description: SAYING he would tell the Knicks tomorrow night whether he was interested in the team's coaching job. Coach Dick Motta of the Dallas Mavericks said he was definitely not interested in being hired as the team's general manager. ''I tried that once,'' Motta said, referring to a stint as coach and general manager in Chicago. ''I don't want to ever do that. I'm not interested in being a general manager at all.''

title: Death Row
description: LEAD: In October 1983, four days before he was scheduled to be executed in the electric chair at the Florida state prison at Starke, something took place that enraged Shabaka Sundiata Waglini more than any single event during his nearly 10 years on death row. They came into his cell and measured him for his burial suit.

title: Europe Moves to Block Refugees Seeking Asylum
description: Ramin, a 20-year-old Iranian seeking political asylum in Belgium, rolled up a sleeve of his sweater and pointed to a fresh scar on his left wrist. The jagged wound was inflicted in a suicide attempt last month, he said.

title: CLEAN AIR-CONDITIONERS FOR THE COMING COOLING SEASON
description: ALTHOUGH modern room air-conditioners require little maintenance, there are a few steps that every homeowner can take to prolong the life of the machine, as well as to improve efficiency and lower costs.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: CARMEN Opera by Bizet. With Maria Ewing, Barry McCauley, Marie McLaughlin and David Holloway. The London Philharmonic Orchestra and Glyndebourne Chorus, conducted by Bernard Haitink. Directed by Peter Hall. Home Vision. 175 minutes (two cassettes). $59.95.

title: Disappointing Dividends
description: With those corporate rites of spring - annual meetings - drawing to an end, shareholders may have been left with great expectations. Annual meetings, like annual reports, are meant to put the company's best foot forward. But shareholders who expect higher dividends may be disappointed.

title: At TV Ministry, Bugs, Dismissals and Dissent
description: Officials of the PTL television ministry have reported finding a listening device in the executive offices of the organization, racked by turmoil and financial troubles since a sex scandal forced its leader from office.

title: Stereotype and Stigma
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCK: FILM, ELECTRONICS AND SOME MUSIC IN MIXED BILL AT RITZ
description: ''THAT'S what we're all here for, baby, the lowest common denominator,'' Lydia Lunch warbled enthusiastically in her role as master of ceremonies at the Ritz last Sunday. Was she talking about the singer in Big Stick, the first band on the bill? He wore what looked like a black plastic trash bag and a black mask with something like a black dustmop for a crest, and he sang about his mask at some length. Then he tore apart posters of various rock and sports figures while growling rather self-consciously.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: G.I.: The American Soldier in World War II. By Lee Kennett. (Scribners, $20.95.) They came from the mountains and the prairies and all points between, culled from families, jobs and schools by the Selective Service System. At their peak, they were 8.3 million strong. Long on griping, short on patriotic rhetoric, they went to fight and sometimes die for ''freedom and democracy'' -seldom apostrophized in those clear-cut days - on beaches, in jungles and forests.

title: FOUR FROM 77TH PRECINCT TESTIFY
description: Four former colleagues of a New York City police officer accused of corruption testified last week that they had never seen him steal money or drugs from drug dealers.

title: IN PRAISE OF ALIENATION
description: AFTER THE REVOLUTION Studies in the Contemporary Jewish American Imagination. By Mark Shechner. 261 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $29.95.

title: Comings and Goings
description: FOR his first competition since last summer, Edwin Moses, the world record-holder in the 400-meter hurdles, will participate in the Adidas-Princeton International track and field meet next Saturday . . . Rosa Mota, who won the women's division of the Boston Marathon, has entered the L'eggs Mini Marathon in Central Park May 30. . . . Darren Veitch, a Detroit Red Wing defenseman, underwent arthroscopic surgery Friday to repair torn ligaments in his left knee and will miss the rest of the National Hockey League playoffs. He had 3 goals and 4 assists in 12 playoff games,

title: Poll Finds Most Back Role of Nancy Reagan
description: A majority of Americans approve of Nancy Reagan's handling of her role as the wife of the President, the Gallup Poll reports.

title: Don't Blame Single Women if the World's Changing
description: To the Editor:

title: HOMAGE TO THE ONCE AND FUTURE SPIRIT OF CATALONIA
description: ''BARCELONA - NOW MORE than ever,'' say the bumper stickers all over this Catalan city, and if the tone smacks of boosterism, the reality in Barcelona is much more substantial. There is a sense of ever-mounting cultural energy in this city, as it looks toward the 1992 Olympics, and it is neatly balanced between a respect for Barcelona's extraordinary architectural and artistic heritage and a commitment to creating significant new works that enhance the city's image of itself.

title: For Designers, State of Art Means Computers
description: FIVE years ago, when Melanie Snyder, an interior designer, went into business for herself, her New York apartment doubled as her office. Miss Snyder now has an office in White Plains, where she employs nine people, including her parents. She expects to reach $1 million in sales this year.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: HOLIDAYS. By Lisa Ruffolo. (New Rivers/Talman, Paper, $7.95.) As the title suggests, the predominant theme of Lisa Ruffolo's first collection of short stories is holidays - those rare, special occasions that reunite family and friends in a pungent atmosphere of celebration and strain. Birthday cakes and Thanksgiving dinners go uneaten as Ms.

title: GLENN LOURY: ADMINISTRATING SELF-HELP
description: GLENN C. Loury, a conservative black political economist who teaches at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, is expected to be appointed Under Secretary of Education. Professor Loury's views that educators should stress morals and values and that the Federal Government should take a less prominent role in education agree with those of Education Secretary William J. Bennett. Professor Loury, who is 38 years old, has said that most efforts to help poor blacks rely too heavily on Government intervention and that leadership must come from the black community itself.

title: FOR BANKS, MUCH IN A NAME
description: DON'T be surprised if the next time you drive by your neighborhood bank, someone is out front changing the sign.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A NOT ENTIRELY BENIGN PROCEDURE: Four Years as a Medical Student. By Perri Klass. (Putnam, $18.95.) At some point during medical school each student crosses the line dividing ''civilization'' - nondoctor - from the world of medicine. ''A Not Entirely Benign Procedure'' is Perri Klass's fascinating account, made up largely of articles that she has published in various national newspapers and magazines, of her four years at Harvard Medical School.

title: WHEN A MOTHER GIVES UP A CHILD
description: WHEN a woman gives birth, something happens that bonds her forever to that child. There is a primal, instinctive drive that makes mothers do crazy things to keep the children they bear - Mary Beth Whitehead is a good example of that. No matter what the courts decide, a woman who gives up her infant is affected for life by it.

title: Legacy Of a Mother's Murder
description: Peter Maas's distressing story of the victimization of Teresa Taylor, her young son and, ultimately, her entire family by a violent husband is, tragically, not an anomaly in our society (''Legacy of a Mother's Murder,'' April 12). The latest Federal Bureau of Investigation statistics indicate that 30 percent of the women murdered in this country are killed by their husbands, former husbands or boyfriends (usually after having suffered years of physical and emotional abuse).

title: WHERE KOCH WOULD PUT NEW YORK'S NEW MONEY
description: CALLING it the best budget of the 10 he has prepared, an ebullient Mayor Koch last week proposed a $22.7 billion municipal spending plan -$1.2 billion higher than this year's - for the fiscal year that begins in July.

title:
DANCE;
AILEY DANCERS INSPIRE STUDENTS
description: LEAD: BRIDGEWATER

title: PSYCHOBIOGRAPHY OF A MAESTRO
description: BERNSTEIN A Biography. By Joan Peyser. Illustrated. 481 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/ William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: STATE IDENTIFIES PRINCETON CORRIDOR KEYS
description: LEAD: PUBLIC transportation and private-sector money are two key components in a new state study that suggests ways to solve the traffic-congestion problem along the Princeton Corridor - Route 1 between Trenton and New Brunswick.

The tale of a British secret agent and his father, a flamboyant con man. 2 2 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter becomes a consuming passion. 3 10 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.95.) title: 2 DEMOCRATS SUE O'ROURKE OVER ISSUE OF CONSULTING
description: A GROWING dispute between the Board of Legislators and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke reached the courts last week when two Democratic legislators sued Mr. O'Rourke for allegedly violating the County Charter by ignoring a Board resolution.

title: Susan E. Rehm Becomes Bride of Joseph D. Gatto
description: At the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights yesterday Susan Elizabeth Rehm, a vice president for corporate finance of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Manhattan, was married to Joseph Daniel Gatto, an investment banker for Goldman, Sachs & Company in Manhattan. The Rev. Frank A. Goodwin performed the Congregational ceremony.

title: HISPANIC BOSTONIANS MARK A REBIRTH
description: Twenty years ago the residences in the Hispanic section of the South End lay dilapidated and ruined, and the city was preparing to raze them in an urban renewal project. But about 200 Puerto Rican immigrants who had settled in the area refused to move.

title: Prague
description: To the Editor: Your articles on Prague (Travel, Jan. 25) mentioned only one hotel - the Prague Inter-Continental - which by the author's own admission is ''quite charmless.'' Let me point to more palatable alternatives.

title: BLUES: JIMMY WITHERSPOON
description: ANDREW DAVIS has moved from England to Russia in his choice of repertory for his third New York Philharmonic subscription concert, heard in Avery Fisher Hall Friday afternoon and scheduled to be repeated there Tuesday evening.

title: 'What Do I Owe This Frail Woman?'
description: MY mother has come again for an extended stay. She comes now with a home health aide to care for her and tend to her needs, a hospital bed and other assorted paraphernalia of the aged and infirm. Most of the time she knows she is at my house but she does not always remember why, and there are times when she speaks of her visit as if she were in a hotel.

title: OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

title: THE LAW WEIGHS THE WAYS OF CLUBS
description: LEAD: In a striking demonstration that exclusive men's clubs may be becoming things of the past, a well-known feminist lawyer is likely to become the first regular woman member of the prestigious Friars Club in Beverly Hills later this month. Her application was supported by the club's president, Milton Berle, and another comedian, Dick Shawn, signed as her sponsor the night before his death last month.

title: Westchester; A New Look, Use and Address Keep an Old Building Current
description: A MODERN mirrored-glass building known as Ryebrook Plaza used to be an industrial building faced with white brick and with a Port Chester address.

title: Perspectives: Rent Stabilization Code; The New Rules Affect 943,000 Apartments
description: AFTER almost two years and three revisions, the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal has published its final version of the administrative code for rent-stabilized housing in New York City. The code, which took effect May 1, governs 943,000 apartments.

title: MUSIC MUST BE MORE THAN RITUAL
description: THE WORLD SEEMS DIVIDED BETWEEN PEO-ple for whom music is interesting mainly as accompaniment to some sacred or secular ritual and those for whom music itself is an experience needing little or no outside justification. However, it should be evident that ritual pervades every aspect of music and probably always has. Music was employed to induce religious trances and other primal ecstasies for some time before it reached the point where its complications could serve as analytical fodder for graduate seminars. Today, as in the distant past, the composer composing, the musician performing, the listener listening - all must be transported outside themselves, as celebrants in a communal ceremony.

title: Legacy Of a Mother's Murder
description: My gratitude to you for publishing Peter Maas's article. To me, the callous attitude of officials was even more shocking than the murder. LUCILLE PURDY Westport, Conn.

title: JOY BECOMES GRIEF FOR KIN AWAITING CRASH VICTIMS
description: About 50 stunned, sobbing relatives and friends of the passengers on a New York-bound Polish jetliner that crashed near Warsaw gathered at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, only to learn that there was no hope for anyone aboard the ill-fated flight.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Seattle; New High-Tech Corridor Challenges Downtown
description: ABOUT 15 miles north of here, within viewing range of the great peaks of the North Cascades, a series of sleek, suburban office parks are rising among tall cedars and moisture-rotted homesteads. Virtually overnight, this 2,300-acre stretch of low-rise offices has posed a significant challenge to tenant-needy developers throughout the West.

title: HAITANS FIND HOPE IN SPECIAL STATUS
description: When there was a knock on the door of his apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the former Haitian farmer would be gripped by fear, afraid it was the immigration agents.

title: HOW TO GROVEL
description: LEAD: THE WIDE, WIDE WORLD By Susan Warner. Illustrated. 608 pp. New York: The Feminist Press. Cloth, $25.95. Paper, $11.95.

title: ECONOMIC BOOM OUT WEST IS MOSTLY INSIDE CITY LIMITS
description: MORE people moved out of Utah last year than moved into it. The same was true in Colorado, Idaho, Montana, North Dakota, Oregon and Wyoming. The reason: Not enough jobs.

title: HOTLY CONTESTED PRIMARIES LIKELY IN BOTH PARTIES IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: It was appropriate, somehow, that so much of the drama of former Senator Gary Hart's decision to withdraw from the 1988 Presidential campaign unfolded in New Hampshire, which has for so many years played a special role in the quadrennial American political pageant.

title: OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

title: No Headline
description: QUESTIONABLE SUBLEASE Question: I have been offered a sublease for $800 a month on a rent-stabilized apartment for which the tenant pays only $400 a month. The tenant says she has bought an apartment elsewhere in Manhattan and plans to move there.

title: HAPPY ANNIVERSARY, DENNIS LEVINE
description: THE puncturing of a social myth is not a lovely thing. When Dennis Levine was arrested a year ago this week, and then others and still others, and then Ivan Boesky - suddenly the whole idea that risk arbitrage could be practiced without inside information lay in doubt. And with it, the Reagan era myth that greed was good.

title: RAY DANDRIDGE, THE HALL OF FAME AND 'FENCES'
description: LIKE many other fathers, Ray Dandridge liked to bring his children to his place of work. His place of work was third base for the Newark Eagles.

title: IN ROWAYTONCASUAL COMPETENCE
description: IN this era of two-income families, going out to dinner is often a nonevent, a mere excuse to avoid cooking at the end of a working day; it is no longer always a special occasion. A clutch of pleasant restaurants have opened to meet our new need, establishments that are fun and informal with light-hearted atmospheres.

title: IN COLLAPSE'S WAKE, SCRUTINY FOR BUILDING LAWS
description: THE collapse April 23 of an apartment complex under construction in Bridgeport in which 28 workers died is likely to cause tremors throughout the state's construction industry as regulators and professional organizations turn to some of the problems exposed by the disaster.

title: No Headline
description: A listing accompanying an article Jan. 18 on Istanbul misstated the location of Hidiv Kasri, the summer palace of the last Khedive of Egypt. It is at Cubuklu, on the Asian side of the Bosporus.

title: Theater
description: The theater season, once again, is more notable for its revivals than for its originals. To name but two, Eliza Doolittle is being transformed on Broadway by haughty Henry Higgins from a squashed cabbage to something resembling a duchess, while down around Sheridan Square, the relationship of a pair of male lovers is transformed by AIDS.

title: HOSPITALS PITCH HARDER FOR PATIENTS
description: IT worked for Tupperware. So now hospitals are using the same idea: getting a group of women to gather in a home for games, prizes, refreshments and a sales pitch. But at the BodyCues women's home health care parties sponsored by the St. Elizabeth Medical Center in Dayton, Ohio, the pitch comes from doctors and nurses - and what is being sold is nothing less than the hospital itself.

title:
FOCUS: ATLANTA;
A Suburb Welcomes Slowdown
description: LEAD: LILLIAN WEBB, the chairwoman of the Gwinnett County Commission, sees a certain gallows humor in the fact that because no other space could be found, her temporary office is the former trauma room of a hospital. ''They've certainly got the right place,'' she says with a laugh.

title: A SPRINGTIME DINNER, A TO Z
description: A SPRINGTIME dinner, one that takes advantage of the season's fresh treasures, can be a pleasure to prepare and serve. After a winter of tired parsley, distressed zucchini and lettuces struggling to survive, it is a delight to shop for produce once again. The verdant selection beckons. Spring means freshness. The appetite is not whetted by long-simmered stews, hearty root vegetables and thick soups. Furthermore, this dinner, which depends on light flavors and takes its cue from the season, does not chain the cook to the stove for hours.

title: With Tax Shelters Gone, Losers Can't Be Winners
description: INVESTORS in a Knoxsville, Tenn., office building recently saw their promised 17.5 percent return shrivel to 6 percent when the deal was restructured to reflect the soft office market and the new tax laws, according to James D. Ewart, a tax partner with Coopers & Lybrand.

title: Jonathan Billings And Lili Gillespie Married in Capital
description: At the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington yesterday Elizabeth Posey Gillespie was married to Jonathan Lee Billings. The Rev. Kenneth Roeltgen, assisted by the Rev. Anthony I. McHale, performed the ceremony.

title: DISMAL DAY FOR METS AND OJEDA
description: In the year after, their infielders make errors, their hitters do not always come up with the necessary hit, and worst of all for the Mets, they cannot elude the big injury.

title: TAFFETA GOWNS BLOSSOM AT FESTIVE SPRING BALLS
description: SWIRLING onto the New York social scene like so many taffeta tornadoes are this spring's ball gowns, which seem to be setting a new standard for opulence. Few, and not far enough between, are the chairs that can accommodate these splendiferous garments, whose skirts drape or balloon over the edge of chairs like parachutes floating to rest. On the dance floor - several were on view last week at the Embassy Ball at the Plaza and at Lincoln Center galas - the dresses need extra space to avoid collisions. So stand back and give them ample room. They deserve it.

title: Tarver Hebner Wed
description: Anne Tarver Hebner and Michael David Harris were married yesterday at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield, Conn., by the Rev. Edward J. Scull. The bride, who is known as Tarver, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hebner 3d of Southport, Conn. She is a graphics designer for the Carter Printing Company in Richmond. The bridegroom, a son of Carolyn R. Harris and Arthur J. Harris, both of Millville, N.J., is a sales manager for Pitney Bowes in Richmond.

title: Rebuttals Filed In Deaver Case
description: The rhetoric heated up last week in the case against Michael K. Deaver, the former deputy White House chief of staff who is accused of lying to Congress and a Federal grand jury about his lobbying activities.

title: Whitney Baldwin And Miss Keane Are Wed in Rye
description: Mary Elizabeth Keane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Keane Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Whitney Hayes Baldwin, a son of Geraldine W. Baldwin of Morristown, N.J., and Robert H. B. Baldwin of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I. Msgr. Donald J. Pryor performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: Trading Letters
description: Dear Prime Minister Nakasone:

title: RIDING CHINA'S CAPITALIST ROAD
description: IN 1979, with an economy staggering from a decade of chaos during the Cultural Revolution, the leader of China, Deng Xiaoping, set an ambitious course of economic reform. His idea: to wrench China's stagnant economy from orthodox socialist central planning and management by embracing some economic ideas of the capitalist West.

title: Gayle Masri, a Medical Student, to Wed
description: The engagement of Gayle Debra Masri to Dr. Barry E. Fridling, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Fridling of Silver Spring, Md., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dorothy Cohn of Eastchester, N.Y., and Norman Masri of Weehawken, N.J.

title: HOME VIDEO: NATURE
description: LEAD: THE SHARKS A National Geographic special produced by the National Geographic Society and WQED/Pittsburgh. Narrated by Alexander Scourby. Vestron Video. 60 minutes. $29.98.

title: 2 Men Convicted Of Slashing Model
description: Two men were convicted last week of assaulting Marla Hanson, the model whose face became familiar to New Yorkers when it appeared in the newspapers with disfiguring razor slashes.

title: SUBWAY PASSENGERS DIFFERING IN TESTIMONY AT GOETZ TRIAL
description: It was the last Saturday before Christmas in 1984 and the 20 or so passengers who were riding in subway car No. 7657 were wrapped up in private thoughts and conversations.

title:
Cincinnati;
Downtown Dowager Is Revived In a Bid for the Business Traveler
description: LEAD: JAY LENO, the comedian, who once stayed there, called the old Cincinnatian Hotel a $3-a-night dump for old men who told stories of the sea and rolled dice in the lobby. So the management of the newly redeveloped Cincinnatian, where rooms now go for $125 a night, recently invited him on a tour to see the change.

title: Design Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: Doing Battle With the Scourge of Graffiti
description: IT may not be Star Wars weaponry, but a company in Stamford, Conn., has developed a chemical and a technique to remove vandals' scrawls from buildings and keep them off.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: JAZZ: Myth and Religion. By Neil Leonard. (Oxford University, $16.95.) In this unusual approach to the world of American jazz, Neil Leonard tries to show that belief and not reason is the proper key for interpreting the history and artistic development of the music. Building upon a close reading of many biographical and anecdotal accounts, Mr.

title: SABERHAGEN GOES TO 6-0 ON 2-HITTER
description: Bret Saberhagen pitched a two-hitter today and faced only 28 batters - one over the minimum -as the Kansas City Royals scored their sixth consecutive victory, 4-0, over the Cleveland Indians.

title: FOSTER CARE
description: The additional $103 million for foster care would permit some innovations, including a computer to track vacancies in foster homes and a new unit to review adoptions. The largest chunk - $66 million - would be used to provide foster-family standing for relatives who take in children. There are 3,000 such families now, caring for 6,600 children who are related to them.

title: Police Hold Stabbing Suspect In Los Angeles Council Attack
description: A man sought in the nearly fatal stabbing of a candidate for City Council president last week turned himself in this afternoon.

title: M'FARLANE TO SAY REAGAN ORDERED HELP FOR CONTRAS
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, intends to tell Congress on Monday that President Reagan ordered the national security staff to arrange support for the Nicaraguan rebels after Congress restricted aid in 1984, according to officials and associates of Mr. McFarlane.

title: Recent Sales
description: East Brunswick $198,500 5 Dorothy Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old contem porary; dining room, wall-to-wall carpeting, fireplace in family room; taxes $3,150. Forked River $94,000 647 Chelsea Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, sunroom, 1-car attached garage; taxes $870. Hawthorne $175,000 97 Passaic Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 47-year-old Cape Cod; enclosed porch, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $1,980. Maplewood $155,000 24 Meadowbrook Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial, living room with fireplace, screened porch, newly remodeled kitchen; taxes $3,700. Middletown $115,500 2 Cherry Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old ranch; pool, dining room, full basement; taxes $1,619. South Orange $442,000 496 Long View Road 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; central A/C, patio, fireplace, 2-car attached garage; taxes $6,881. OTHER AREAS Islip, L.I. $138,000 76 Smith Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old brick ranch; den, basement, 1-car garage, walk to stores; taxes $3,400. Guilford, Conn. $249,000 364 North Wood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old Cape Cod; pool, finished basement, 1.5 acres; taxes $2,405. Armonk, N.Y. $355,000 220 Cedar Hill 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old frame co lonial; den, playroom, 2 acres; taxes $4,566.

title: 3 SENIOR I.R.A. MEN ARE AMONG THE DEAD IN ULSTER SHOOTOUT
description: The police said today that three senior figures in the Irish Republican Army were among the eight guerrillas killed when policemen and soldiers intercepted a raid on a police station Friay night.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A users' guide to New York City parks on April 26 in The World of New York, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misstated the size of several city swimming pools. Only Hamilton Fish Pool in Manhattan and Astoria Pool in Queens now meet Olympic specifications. Also in that magazine, on the map of development projects in the city, site 14 was misidentified. It is Columbus Center.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE garbage that gathered uncollected in Hunterdon, Sussex and Warren Counties last month may be a hint of things to come for the rest of northern New Jersey later this year. However, the state's Department of Environmental Protection has taken several steps to contain the crisis.

title: Biased Sampling
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW SYNAGOGUE BEGUN BY 3 WOMEN
description: LEAD: THIRTY-TWO families, united by a desire for a place to worship and a form of Judaism that adheres to old rituals while adapting to modern times in America, hope to celebrate Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur this fall in what will become the first synagogue in Monroe and the first Reconstructionist synagogue in the state.

title: McKinney Memorial Service
description: Memorial services will be held Thursday for Representative Stewart B. McKinney, a Republican and nine-term Congressman from Connecticut who died of an AIDS-related infection. The service will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport at 2 P.M. The McKinney family has also announced the formation of the S.B. McKinney Memorial AIDS Research Fund, and said donations could also be given to the Westport-Weston chapter of the American Red Cross. Mr. McKinney, 56 years old, died Thursday in a Washington hospital.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Wells, Me.: Condo-Hotel Wins Approval
description: LEAD: A NEWLY built 99-unit condominium hotel in this coastal resort town in York County is moving into the renting season with a cloud removed. It received its final state environmental approval in March - two years after construction started, and long after occupancy began.

title: BERLIN 1937, BERLIN 1987
description: Berlin is about to begin celebrating its 750th anniversary, and on both sides of the wall there will be a great outpouring of art, theater, music and so on, enough to keep things humming for the rest of the year. As usual, culture and politics will be cunningly intermingled in ways not always visible, for in this remarkable city you cannot play a sonata or exhibit a painting without touching a political chord.

title: PLAN FOR A 12-MONTH SCHOOL YEAR LEADS TO A TUG-OF-WAR
description: LEAD: IF voters in the Sag Harbor School District vote Wednesday for an innovative ''Extend-Ed'' plan, educators say the district will be the first in the country to offer 12-month education to both elementary and high school students.

title: The Pope Looks at The Reformation
description: In other centuries, and even in this one, the Roman Church referred to Protestant groups as ''heretical conventicles,'' so unyielding was the schism over Rome's authority. A few decades of ecumenicism have cast it in a softer light. Last week the Pope himself visited a center of the Reformation, and he said the movement had brought spiritual renewal to the Roman Catholic Church.

title:
GARDENING;
THINGS TO DO, RESULTS TO ENJOY
description: LEAD: MAY is a big month for gardeners with all the planting and cultivating to be done, and tending even a small garden can seem like a full-time task.

title: SECRETS OF THE TITANIC
description: A National Geographic production narrated by Martin Sheen. Written and produced by Nicolas Noxon. Vestron Video. 1986. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: EROTIC SALVATION
description: WALKING DISTANCE By Marian Thurm. 279 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: PETITION TO CLOSE SCHOOL SPLITS VILLAGE
description: LEAD: A NUMBER of students at Bridgehampton High School staged a walkout recently but, unlike most such demonstrations, it was to show support for the district's administration and school board.

title: ESCAPE FROM A MEN'S CLUB
description: MEMOIRS OF AN INVISIBLE MAN By H. F. Saint. 396 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: 2 Utah Convicts Held In Assassination Plot
description: A convict on parole from the Utah State Prison was held today for questioning in connection with what the authorities said was a plot to assassinate 10 prison officials.

title:
GARDENING;
THINGS TO DO, RESULTS TO ENJOY
description: LEAD: MAY is a big month for gardeners with all the planting and cultivating to be done, and tending even a small garden can seem like a full-time task.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Condos That Are All Work and No Play
description: THE main topic at the next meeting of a condominium board in Mamaroneck will be whether to buy a new pot for the 12-foot ficus tree in the atrium.

title: EATING DISORDERS GO BEYOND FOOD
description: LEAD: THE typical woman who has an eating disorder is not the good student from a perfect home as most studies have found, according to recent findings. Behind the facade of privilege are often traumas such as alcoholism, divorce and learning disabilities, according to Dr. Diane Mickley, an internist who founded the Wilkins Center for Eating Disorders in

title: Big Brother?
description: To the Editor:

title: Patrick Walker Weds Theresa Levins
description: Theresa Mary Levins was married yesterday to Patrick Dunne Walker at St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Edward Flannery.

title: ANDRETTI CAPTURES INDY POLE
description: Mario Andretti won the pole for the 71st Indianapolis 500, beating his chief rival, Bobby Rahal, today but falling short of the track record at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

title: Reluctant to Relate
description: To the Editor:

title: HIS LAST AUTOBIOGRAPHY
description: WITH ALL MY MIGHT An Autobiography. By Erskine Caldwell. Illustrated. 332 pp. Atlanta: Peachtree Publishers. $19.95.

title: A LA CARTE
description: WHEN Main Streets, not shopping malls, were the centers of Long Island, luncheonettes were the places to meet friends and have freshly squeezed lemonade. There are still a few luncheonettes left on Long Island. Their decor is not 1987 but 1947, and so is the food.

title: NEW FIGURES SHOW A DECLINE IN VOTERS
description: LEAD: FOR the second year in a row, overall voter enrollment in Westchester has declined.

title: BUSH, ON THE TRAIL, SPEAKS ON ETHICS
description: Vice President Bush today began outlining his major policy positions for the 1988 Presidential campaign with a strong statement on public ethics, saying democratic institutions required ''a high degree of trust.''

title: HOUSING CRISIS NEEDS COOPERATION
description: WE have reached a stage on Long Island where the average Long Islander can no longer afford to buy the average-price house in Nassau or Suffolk.

title: RICE UNIVERSITY
description: Rice University presented degrees to 650 undergraduates and 320 graduate students in commencement exercises today.

title: Gwenne Haggerty a Bride
description: The wedding of Gwenne Marie Haggerty and James J. Dawson took place yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. John P. Moore performed the ceremony. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Haggerty of Summit and Sea Girt, N.J., graduated from Hollins College. She is a sales analyst in the international division of the Westvaco Corporation in Manhattan. Mr. Dawson, a son of Mrs. James L. Dawson of the Bronx and the late Mr. Dawson, is a graduate of Pace University and a sales manager in Westvaco's international division.

title: TROPICAL ECHOES
description: Since summer is nearly here, the sun and the swimming season cannot be far behind. For those women who haven't already found an attractive suit, there are many new ones to choose from. Sleek in fit, daring in shape and hot in shade, they will certainly light up any beach. One requisite, though, will be a superb figure.

title: PRIEST-MAESTRO FORMS CHARITY ORCHESTRA
description: THE Rev. Alphonse Stephenson, a diocesan priest who used to conduct the ''A Chorus Line'' orchestra on Broadway, has formed what is believed to be the first professional symphony orchestra in the nation specifically to raise funds for churches and nonprofit groups.

title: PHILADELPHIA'S PRIDE
description: CELEBRATED ART LOVERS FROM ALL OVER the world habitually flocked to 1914 Rittenhouse Square in Philadelphia, for 35 years the home of the late Henry P. McIlhenny, former chairman of the board of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, world-renowned collector and host. His drawing room was filled with a stunning collection of paintings and Charles X furniture, the dining room overlooked a garden shaded by magnolia trees, and the grand ballroom was festooned with classical columns -all providing a rich setting for countless salons, luncheons, teas and dances. While he was regarded by many as the last great host of Philadelphia, McIlhenny's generous spirit and flair were felt on both sides of the Atlantic. For many summers he presided over Glenveagh, a 19th-century castle set on 30,000 acres in County Donegal, Ireland.

title: FRESH AIR HOSTS LOOK FORWARD TO NEW GENERATION
description: Dorothy Kachmar, a mother of five from Punxsutawney, Pa., arrived in New York City recently with her daughter to visit Michael Hall and his 5-year-old girl.

title: Youth Hostels
description: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann's mention of youth hostels in Europe in his A to Z listings (''The Instant Seasoned Traveler,'' March 1) neglected to point out that many of them are open to those of all ages, umpteen-agers as well as teen-agers with some hostels being real show places, i.e., the Swiss youth hostel in St. Moritz. To encourage Americans with the deflated dollar, the hostel in Basel continues to offer bed and breakfast for $10 a night not only in their establishment conveniently located in the historic part of town but also in the nearby Jura Mountains (French-speaking Switzerland), which can be easily reached by train from Basel: Delemont, Bemont and la Chaux-de-Fonds where I had delicious dinners (good French cuisine) for about $5. For bargain meals elsewhere I discovered the Migros supermarkets, which also run cafeterias in many Swiss towns: delicious food for half of what you pay elsewhere. The Swiss rail card - unlimited travel on trains, buses and some steamers -costs $140 for 8 days, $165 for 15 days. A $10 check sent to the Basel Hostel, Post Office Box 204, Basel, 4006 Switzerland, guaranteed me bed and breakfast for the first night. LLOYD MCCUNE Orlando, Fla.

title: CONVERSION DUE AT OCEANSIDE CLUB
description: LEAD: THE Oceanside Country Club, a four-acre swim club and caterer, will not have its lease renewed, and the leaseholders say that the property, owned by the parent company of the Mays Department Stores, will be developed for condominiums.

title: THE AVANT-GARDE ADVANCES, EARNING APPLAUSE AND RUFFLING FEATHERS
description: THE BIG NEWS IN VIENNA this season - culturally speaking, that is - has been the takeover of the ancient and honorable Burgtheater by a bunch of West German avant-gardists. Traditionalists are shaking their heads in dismay, but the theaters - the Burgtheater itself and the separate Akademietheater, under the same company's auspices - are full, and the press response has been enthusiastic.

title: Israeli Leaders Split Over Press Conference
description: Israel's Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, who is also head of the Labor Party, threatened last week to try to break up the country's 31-month-old goverment over the issue of a proposed international peace conference on the Middle East. Mr. Peres, a former Prime Minister, favors the talks, whose participants would include Israel, Jordan, a Palestinian delegation, the United States and the Soviet Union. But the conference was opposed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, the leader of the Likud bloc.

title: Study Shows Reported Crimes Rose 6% in '86
description: Crimes reported to the police rose 6 percent in 1986, the biggest increase in seven years, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

title:
RECORDINGS;
PERFUMED RESTRAINT AND CHISELED CLARITY
description: LEAD: FRENCH MUSIC HAS LONG POS-sessed certain attributes that set it apart from the music of neighboring Germany. Never interested in abstract structure, disinclined toward contrapuntal density or thematic development, the French have preferred less dogmatic means of expression, which favor clarity and balance.

title: 183 DEAD IN CRASH OF POLISH JETLINER GOING TO NEW YORK
description: A Polish airliner bound for New York crashed and burned here today after the pilot unsuccessfully tried to bring his faltering jet back to the airport less than an hour after takeoff. All 183 people aboard were killed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MAY 10, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17 The President ordered the N.S.C. to arrange support for the contras after Congress restricted aid in 1984, Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, will tell Congress tomorrow, according to people familiar with Mr. McFarlane's planned testimony. Page 1 The testimony of Richard V. Secord at the Congressional hearings into the Iran-contra affair outraged many committee members. They said they were amazed the Administration delegated foreign policy to covert private operators. 14 A Polish airliner crashed in Warsaw after the pilot tried and failed to bring his faltering jet back to the airport less than an hour after takeoff. All 183 people aboard the airliner bound for New York were killed. 1 Crash stuns family and friends 16 A proposal for anti-missile tests was sent to the President from Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. Officials said the tests would violate the traditional interpretation of the Anti ballistic Missile Treaty. 1 Most detainees in South African jails are suffering physical and mental abuse, with insufficient legal safeguards, a South African association's study says. The report is based on studies of 131 former detainees. 6 Campaign closes in Philippines 3 Europe seeks to block asylum 8 90 lost on Yangtze ferry 13 NATIONAL 18-24, 34-38 A hereditary link to AIDS was found by a team of British scientists. A form of an inherited protein they identified may reduce vulnerability to the virus and slow development of the disease. 1 Tough primaries in New Hampshire are expected for both political parties. In nine months, once the state has voted, few candidates are expected to survive from the original field, strategists say. 1 George Bush focused on public ethics in a commencement speech, saying democratic institutions require ''a high degree of public trust.'' The speech was the first in a series outlining Mr. Bush's policy positions. 23 Mario Cuomo still will not run for President, he says. At the same time, strategists say they believe the Governor is strengthening his position as a candidate. ''Why won't people simply believe me?,'' he said. 22 The funeral of William J. Casey on Long Island was marked by the controversy surrounding President Reagan's policy of aiding the Nicaraguan rebels, a policy that Mr. Casey, former Director of Central Intelligence, espoused. 1 The President threatened to veto legislation that restricts flexibility in arms control talks or provides what he considers to be inadequate levels of military spending. He made the comments in his weekly radio broadcast. 18 In the U.S. Army, young generals are taking command in perhaps the most sweeping change since World War II, causing concern throughout the officer corps. By end of June, five of the Army's 12 full generals will be new to their rank. 18 Reported crimes rose 6% in 1986 20 Support for Nancy Reagan 21 Paradoxes of a political marriage 22 REGIONAL 27-32, 40-42 Witnesses to the Goetz shooting, which took place almost two and a half years ago, have been assembled again through a combination of detective work and luck. They will testify in Bernhard H. Goetz's trial. 28 Prison overcrowding in Westchester could cause riots at the county jail unless it is relieved, a Federal judge said. He ordered the county to reduce the number of inmates housed in its jail building. 27 An effort to build a playground at General Sherman Park in Manhattan has attracted young and old, rich and poor, skilled and unskilled. The new playground is scheduled to open tonight. 28 Two support bars of a bridge fell into the East River, prompting a city inspection of the structure. The problem with the Williamsburg Bridge was discovered by the police Friday. 28 Minority students should be trained to become teachers, the president of the city teachers' union said. The program should be adopted by the Board of Education in place of seeking minority teachers in foreign countries, she said. 28 Attacking Donovan's prosecutor 29 Ex-colleagues testify for officer 31 Principal stabbed to death 32

title: RESTLESS ICONOCLAST OF THE VIOLIN
description: STANDING IN HIS PITEOUSLY FURNISHED Manhattan apartment not long ago, Gidon Kremer said he had changed his mind. The man Herbert von Karajan called ''the greatest violinist in the world'' was exhausted from his concert 13 hours before and still jet-lagged from a trans-Atlantic flight four days earlier. There were 10 days ahead in which he planned to rest before beginning a new round of concerts, but on the spur of the moment he was flying back to Europe that afternoon ''to be with friends.''

title: Miss Hately Wed To Clayton Prugh
description: At St. John's Episcopal Chapel, Del Monte, in Monterey, Calif., yesterday, Eleanor Martin Hyde Hately, a partner in Blodgett/Hately Design, an interior decorating firm in New York, was married to Clayton Alexander Prugh, an associate in the New York law firm Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives. The Rev. Jerome Politzer performed the ceremony.

title: HE SHOULD HAVE STAYED IN CHARLOTTESVILLE
description: FIVE HUNDRED SCORPIONS By Shelby Hearon. 306 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: Elizabeth Zeltner Weds L. B. Sorrel
description: Elizabeth Zeltner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Zeltner of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married last evening to Lawrence Brian Sorrel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Sorrel of Scarsdale, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover officiated at the Pierre.

title: Harassment
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE DOCTOR OF DESIRE. By Allen Wheelis. (Norton, $14.95.) Allen Wheelis's latest fictional work is an engrossing epic journey through the thoughts and yearnings of a modern-day Faust. He is Henry Melville, a 53-year-old psychiatrist, the narrator of the novel, who believes: ''Sex is our tie to the world, the source of meaning.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: EDITOR TO AUTHOR: The Letters of Maxwell E. Perkins, edited by John Hall Wheelock. (Scribners, $10.95.) At Charles Scribner's Sons, the editor Maxwell E. Perkins shepherded into print the works of Wolfe, Fitzgerald, Hemingway and others. In reviewing this selection from his letters, Alfred A. Knopf said in The Book Review in 1950 that all the authors ''were devoted to Perkins and none ever wandered from his or her allegiance. The letters over and over again tell why. . . . [ They ] will be of enormous and enduring interest to writers, editors and publishers everywhere.'' KATE VAIDEN, by Reynolds Price. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Kate Vaiden tells her life story in retrospect as she sets out, at the age of 57, to find the baby son she abandoned 40 years earlier. Most of the novel is set in the early-1940's North Carolina of her youth, and it is ''a forgiving, immensely readable story . . . almost light in feeling,'' Rosellen Brown said in these pages last year. ''The voice of Mr. Price's heroine blows like fresh air across the page. . . . [ He ] has found a narrator of great charm whose sad story, from which she sets herself free, sounds (as Kate might say) new as morning.'' EIGHT MEN OUT: The Black Sox and the 1919 World Series, by Eliot Asinof. (Owl/Holt, $8.95.) Eliot Asinof reconstructs the blackest event in baseball history - the Chicago Black Sox scandal of 1919, when eight players were accused of throwing the World Series. In 1963 one reviewer called the book ''comprehensive'' and ''superb'' and said the author ''thoroughly airs the conditions that made the players' venality possible.'' GIRLS FOREVER BRAVE AND TRUE, by Caryl Rivers. (Pocket, $3.95.) A decade after high school, two best friends reunite in the Washington of the 1960's, where one becomes a Capitol Hill gossip columnist and the other is a prize-winning journalist. In The Book Review in 1986, Kiki Olson said, ''In the seemingly endless parade of best-selling heroines who are unrealistically beautiful, wealthy and humorless about having it all -what a pleasure to run into funny, warm, often confused Peg Morrison and Constance Masters.'' A PIECE OF MY HEART: The Stories of 26 American Women Who Served in Vietnam, by Keith Walker. (Ballantine, $4.95.) This oral history records the experiences of 26 American women - Red Cross workers, U.S.O. entertainers, Army nurses - in Vietnam. ''The stories of memories and conflicts tend to run together,'' Marcia Froelke Coburn said here last year, ''but the emotional current never falters.'' BORDERLINE, by Janette Turner Hospital. (Bantam, $4.50.) The narrator of this suspense novel is a piano tuner whose stepmother has disappeared after trying to aid an injured South American alien at a United States-Canada border crossing. The tale is ''complex and disturbing,'' Cheri Fein said here in 1985, ''a compelling attempt to go beyond the safe borderlines within which much current fiction resides.'' PORTRAIT OF AN ARTIST: A Biography of Georgia O'Keeffe, by Laurie Lisle. (Washington Square/Pocket, $5.95.) This life of Georgia O'Keeffe has been revised and updated with new material since her death in 1986. In these pages in 1980, Janet Hobhouse described O'Keeffe as ''the matron saint variously of modernism, regionalism, abstract art and realism, of ecology, women's liberation, old-fashioned virtue and free love. . . . Invited to do what she could without her subject's cooperation, Laurie Lisle has amassed the clues to convey a semblance of the life, curiously unconnected with anything we know of the artist from her work.'' HARD LAUGHTER, by Anne Lamott. (North Point, $8.95.) Anne Lamott's first novel is about a Northern California family's struggle to cope when the father is stricken with a brain tumor. The book's appeal, Anne Tyler said here in 1980, is ''that it has much to say about how a good family works - any good family - in times both hard and easy. . . . It's a moving and strangely joyful book, a kind of celebration.'' ON PERSEPHONE'S ISLAND: A Sicilian Journal, by Mary Taylor Simeti. (North Point, $11.95.) Mary Taylor Simeti, who visited Sicily in the 1960's and ended up marrying a Sicilian agronomist, offers a month-by-month journal of her 21st year (1982-83) as an American living there. ''She has constructed an intricate mosaic of Sicily past and present, historical and personal,'' Ann Cornelisen said here in 1986, and by year's end ''has told us so much that is fascinating.'' BHOWANI JUNCTION, by John Masters. (Carroll & Graf, $4.50.) John Masters' tale of India in the late 1940's, on the verge of emancipation and partition, is set in a railway outpost and centers on a woman who is half-English and the three men who love her - a railway official who is also half-English, a British officer and an Indian political leader. In 1954 our reviewer, John Barkham, praised the book's ''magic of atmosphere, subtlety of character, vigor of narrative and overtones of meaning.'' KEROUAC: A Biography, by Ann Charters. (St. Martin's, $10.95.) This life of Jack Kerouac (1922-69) by Ann Charters, who was a friend of the Beat Generation writer, evokes a lively period in American letters and ''is a pleasure,'' John Deck said here in 1973. ''It is about men and ideas that changed everything.'' PICTURE PALACE, by Paul Theroux. (Washington Square/Pocket, $4.95.) At 70, Maude Coffin Pratt, a famous photographer, relives her life and work as she prepares for a retrospective. Paul Theroux's eighth novel is ''vibrant and compelling,'' Anne Tyler said here in 1978 - largely thanks to ''strong . . . slangy, tough, blunt, single-minded'' Maude.

title: ON WEST SIDE, AN URBAN BARN-RAISING
description: Robert Lee, 6 years old, sanded. Kim Kemmer, 9 3/4, moved 2-by-12's into what he called the good piles and the bad piles. Zelda Josephs, a real-estate consultant, pounded nails and told her companion George, who was not that confident with a hammer, to watch out for his fingers. John Stark, a West Sider who said he was wealthy and had the extra time, drove bolts.

title: Legacy Of a Mother's Murder
description: Grandparents' rights notwithstanding, I am appalled by an omission in the Baby Taylor custody case.

description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 8 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Navy aviators at war. 15 3 ANYWHERE BUT HERE, by Mona Simpson. (Knopf, $18.95.) Love, hate, fear, need and loyalty lock mother and daughter in 20 years of combat. 16 * 16 2 WINTER HAWK, by Craig Thomas. (Morrow, $18.95.) Thwarting a Russian plot to launch a ''Star Wars'' weapon on the eve of the signing of a disarmament treaty. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 2 11 COMMUNION, by Whitley Strieber. (Beech Tree/ Morrow, $17.95.) A professional writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his home. 2 * 5 5 HOLD ON, MR. PRESIDENT! by Sam Donaldson. (Random House, $17.95.) A White House television correspondent comments on his assignment and the ways of the news media. 3 9 5 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating serious illness. 4 1 19 A SEASON ON THE BRINK, by John Feinstein. (Macmillan, $16.95.) A chronicle of one season spent with the Indiana University basketball team. 5 3 23 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists. 6 4 4 THIS 'N THAT, by Bette Davis with Michael Herskowitz. (Putnam, $17.95.)
