Boone Pickens Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) The autobiography of an oilman and corporation-takeover entrepreneur. 9 * 8 12 THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) From the Boston slums of Irish immigrants to the White House: three generations of a family. 10 11 2 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education and American undergraduates during the past 25 years. 11 10 10 INTIMATE PARTNERS, by Maggie Scarf. (Random House, $18.95.) Changing patterns in love and marriage. 12 1 GLORY DAYS, by Dave Marsh. (Pantheon, $18.95.) Bruce Springsteen in the 1980's; an account written with the rock star's cooperation. 13 13 13 ECHOES IN THE DARKNESS, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Perigord/Morrow, $18.95.) A case involving the murder of a Pennsylvania high school teacher and the disappearance of her two children. 14 14 61 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 15 15 179 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 31 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $16.95.) How to cope with overbearing men. 2 3 87 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 3 2 28 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. 4 5 2 SUPERIMMUNITY, by Paul Pearsall. (McGraw- Hill, $17.95.) How to control your emotions in order to improve your health. 5 * 6 HOW TO BE YOUR OWN NUTRITIONIST, by Stuart M. Berger. (Morrow, $16.95.) Ways to create a diet regimen for health and energy. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) A SPORT OF NATURE, by Nadine Gordimer. (Knopf, $18.95.) Postcolonial Africa, its past, its promise, as seen through this fiercely intelligent writer's heroine, Hillela, a mythic figure in a powerful, grand-scale novel of awakening, emergence and, in so far as fiction can make it possible, a call for a new order. FAST LANES, by Jayne Anne Phillips. (Seymour Lawrence/ Dutton, $15.95.) The overall image in this heterogeneous story collection is of the gifted Ms. Phillips developing a sense of voice and subject while seeming to evolve into a regional writer and family chronicler, kin to Eudora Welty and Reynolds Price. NOBODY BETTER, BETTER THAN NOBODY, by Ian Frazier. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $14.95.) Wonderfully dry and droll reporting in five comic essays that teach us what we most likely won't learn elsewhere while we enjoy ourselves immensely. ARE WE TO BE A NATION? The Making of the Constitution, by Richard B. Bernstein with Kym S. Rice. (Harvard University, Cloth, $35; Paper, $14.95.) This readable, reliable survey of what led to and came out of the Philadelphia convention accompanies an exhibition at the New York Public Library through Sept. 19. AEGYPT, by John Crowley. (Bantam, $17.95.) Mr. Crowley's gateway to a deeply strange world of transformations and a new myth of the universe is the first volume in a quartet that is attempting to turn fantasy and the conventional novel into a single element through the alchemy of words. TRUST ME, by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) Twenty-two stories by a master of private vernacular experience, the best of them full of the humor and compassion demanded by even the saddest tales about us frail humans in a mysterious world. NIXON: The Education of a Politician 1913-1962, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) This detached, objective and thick (752 pages) biography by a professional historian shows Mr. Nixon as both more accomplished and complicated than either his friends or his enemies usually suppose.

title: SLEEK DECOR WITH FOOD TO MATCH
description: RESTAURANTS make statements about themselves. The West End Cafe says SoHo, not Carle Place. The ceilings are high enough to accommodate the full-size tree growing there. The decor is clean and modern: black and white tile floors, glass brick walls, neon signs, Art Deco light fixtures, brass railings and high-tech exposed water pipes.

title: THE HIGHER TRUTH OF PYHSICS
description: RABI Scientist and Citizen. By John S. Rigden. Illustrated. 302 pp. New York: Basic Books. $21.95.

title: Compassion From Connecticut
description: The stir over the cause of Representative Stewart McKinney's death ought not distract from his achievements as a public servant. Mr. McKinney, who died last week at age 56, was a man of compassion. His constituency for 17 years was Connecticut's ''Gold Coast'' Fairfield County, and he was well to do himself. But he was distinguished by his concern for the poor and powerless, from Bridgeport to Saigon.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DESERT FABULOSO. By Lisa Lovenheim. (Plume/ NAL, Paper, $7.95.) ''Desert Fabuloso'' would be a typical coming-of-age novel about the early development and spiritual education of Bradley Roberson 3d, but for the fact that the poor little rich boy is already a man. The task before Bradley is remedial: mastering and changing the unhappy, often nasty child that dominates him from within. Petulant, narcissistic and homosexual, Bradley - in his late 20's - blithely caroms through people's lives until he is rejected by a lover who won't tolerate his immaturity. Realizing he is destructive and childish, Bradley withdraws into introspective self-isolation behind the adobe walls of his new Santa Fe, N.M., home for some major self-reconstruction. This arid but beautiful man - this desert fabuloso -sets out to restore a neglected house, and there is no way to miss that the house, especially its interiors, represents his own condition: the walls of the building were cracked because it was abandoned and unloved. Not without its complexities and subtleties, this first novel unfortunately hardly becomes more than an exotic and exaggerated case history. With characters acting like straw figures in the predictable symmetries of a plot outline, the psychodrama has little credible drama. The awkward symbolism, plot manipulation and relentless stereotyping vitiates almost all characters, events and places. Bradley wears white safari shorts, Paco Rabanne pour homme, a pale yellow Calvin Klein undershirt, and drives a BMW with a sunroof. Santa Fe itself hardly escapes Lisa Lovenheim's uncharitable gaze. There is, in her view, no human condition in the Santa Fe condition, only gentrification, chic and a croissant culture.

title: 'I'M FROM THE GUTTER. AND DON'T FORGET IT'
description: THE ORTON DIARIES Edited by John Lahr. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title:
INVESTING;
TOO MANY CHOICES? ONE FUND BUYS ALL
description: LEAD: CONSUMERS in an affluent society face an abundance of choices, sometimes too many.

title: 'TEACHERS' SCHOOL PROPOSED BY UNION
description: Instead of seeking minority and bilingual teachers in foreign countries, the New York City Board of Education should establish a high school to prepare students to become teachers, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, Sandra Feldman, said yesterday.

title: Career Choice
description: WHILE many of his fellow graduates will start the summer continuing their search for suitable employment, Brian Bosworth, who picked up a degree in management information from the University of Oklahoma yesterday, should have a simpler time securing a job worthy of his college-honed talents. The outspoken Sooner star is expected to announce tomorrow that he will try his hand in the National Football League, and given his record on the football field and in the classroom, he should have no problem finding a slot in a linebacker-training program. Bosworth, who won the Butkus Award as the nation's top collegiate linebacker for two years in a row and was named an academic all-America student-athlete last season, won't even have the bother of deciding on one of the 28 N.F.L. teams. Under league rules, a lottery, weighted to favor the teams with the worst 1986 records, will be held to determine which gets a crack at him in a supplemental draft.

title: Circa 1885
description: Meile Rockefeller, the 31-year-old great-granddaughter of the man who built Rockefeller Center, is herself altering the cityscape. Her current project, however, in TriBeCa's ''dairy district,'' is far less grandiose than that of the late philanthropist, John D. Rockefeller Jr. Now nearing completion is the conversion of a former egg-packing and cheese-making plant, at 168 Duane Street near Hudson Street, into loft condominiums. John T. Fifield Associates of Manhattan is the architect.

title: TWO STEEL SUPPORT BARS FALL FROM WILLIAMSBURG BRIDGE
description: Two 30-pound steel bars that help support a section of the outer roadway of the Williamsburg Bridge fell into the East River Friday, and city investigators have found three other sections of the roadway with similar structural problems.

title: YANKS' '88 CABLE BUYOUT
description: JUST when some people in the Bronx and eastern Brooklyn thought their homes were about to be cableized for Yankee and Met games, Mayor Koch called time. After consulting with ''various Federal and state prosecutors,'' the Mayor declined to grant approval Thursday, as had been expected, for the installation of cable television in those areas of New York City.

description: Andorra

title: LOVINGLY NURTURED FREAKS OF NATURE
description: AT this time of year, when home landscapers are busy seeking out and planting the best small evergreens for their needs, the work of one man has special significance.

title: No Place For This Wave
description: To the Sport Editor:

title: BOND TRADERS ADD JAPAN TO THEIR WORRIES
description: Bond prices bobbed and weaved on uncertainty over interest rates, trade relations with Japan and the dollar. Prices of Treasury securities plummeted as Japanese investors stayed out of the auction of 10-year notes, apparently fearful that the fall of the dollar against the yen would make the investments less attractive. But prices recovered some as the Japanese participated in an auction of 30-year bonds. Investors had feared a slowdown in Japanese investment in American securities, which would have forced interest rates higher. Still, bond prices are way down from their recent high levels.

title: JEWELRY, GEMS AND JADE OF SEOUL
description: South Korea has been a treasure-trove of purple amethyst, smoky topaz and white jade for centuries.

title: HUGE PROJECTS THAT SHAPE THE LANDSCAPE OF THE CITY
description: THE term ''mega,'' deriving from the Greek word for large or great, surely seems the appropriate prefix to use for some New York City development projects.

title: BISTRO'S NEW SIMPLICITY
description: THE RETURN - SOME MIGHT even say the debut - of bistro-style cooking in the United States has restaurantgoers astir. But the puzzlement of the moment seems to be exactly how to define what it is.

title: M. Tati And M. Hulot
description: PLAYTIME Starring Jacques Tati Embassy Home Entertainment 108 minutes. $29.95.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS BILL FOR HOMOSEXUALS MOVES FORWARD IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: For 14 years homosexual and lesbian advocates in Massachusetts have been promoting, without success, the passage of a rights bill that would assure equal access to housing, employment and credit, regardless of sexual preference.

title: QUEST FOR A FABLED ANCIENT LIBRARY
description: IN 1979 THE WORLD REMEMBERED - WITH EX-hibitions, congresses, publications - the Great Eruption of Mount Vesuvius that, in 79 A.D., buried the Roman towns of Herculaneum, Pompeii and Stabiae, on the Gulf of Naples, under volcanic ash, mud and lava. Next year will mark the 250th anniversary of the inauguration, at Herculaneum, of systematic excavation of those Vesuvian cities - a development of immense consequence not only for our knowledge of the ancient world but for the influence exerted over archeology, art and science, and over civilized consciousness, by the Vesuvian revelations. Scholars urging that 1988 be commemorated at Herculaneum with specific new excavations may take heart from the fact that the most dramatic of these is already under way - at the Villa dei Papiri, an unseen and almost legendary structure whose influence has been felt around the world.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: THE on-again, off-again controversy over whether to save the old Loew's Theater in Journal Square, Jersey City, is on again, but a final decision is said to be just weeks away.

title: 'Chucking' Edmund Wilson

description: LEAD: COUNTRY LIVES ON THE ISLAND Even though the first American cowboy roped his first American cow on Long Island - 1747 in Montauk for you history buffs - Long Island hasn't been considered the hotbed of country and western life. But don't tell that to the 250 country music lovers who danced the night away at the American Legion Hall in

Last Resort For Developers
