GARDENING;
THINGS TO DO, RESULTS TO ENJOY
description: LEAD: MAY is a big month for gardeners with all the planting and cultivating to be done, and tending even a small garden can seem like a full-time task.

title: ARE LIBRARIES DOOMED TO DRY UP AND BLOW AWAY?
description: MY MOTHER tied a ribbon in my hair the day she took me to the public library for my first card. I wore my best dress and I was nervous.

title: ADDING A PETAL, OR MAYBE A SPICE
description: ABOUT seven years ago, Thomas J. Lipton Inc., the nation's largest tea producer, decided to branch out. After nearly a century of sticking to blends of black tea, it added Orange & Spice, Blackberry Brandy and other flavored teas to its product roster.

title: Ms. Schuon Wed To Photographer
description: Jonalyn S. Schuon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Schuon of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to J.Ross Baughman, a son of Patricia Hill Baughman of Bradenton, Fla., and Charles T. Baughman of Savannah, Ga., and Dearborn, Mich. Mayor Clair Wolf of Ephrata, Pa., performed the ceremony at the Ephrata Cloister.

title: A FINE DEBUT ILLUMINATES 'CAT'
description: ONE of the many nice things about the Arena Players Repertory Theater is that aside from offering lightweight comedies and mysteries during its season, it also makes a point of presenting great American classic drama. It is currently offering Tennessee Williams's Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece, ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.''

title: TALE OF TWO STRING QUARTETS: ONE RISES, ONE DISBANDS
description: TWO string quartets performing Friday evening provide a contrast between an up-and-coming group and a 15-year veteran that is disbanding.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JAZZ IN NEWARK Eddie Daniels, the virtuoso jazz clarinetist who came to his instrument via the alto and tenor saxophones, will be featured Friday evening in the Terrace Room at Newark Symphony Hall.

title: 'HIGH SPIRITS' AT FORUM THEATRE
description: ANYONE who saw ''High Spirits'' on Broadway in 1964 got two shows for the price of one: a perfectly agreeable musical and an evening with Beatrice Lillie.

title: THE WRIGHT SITE
description: To the Editor:

title: RIGHTEOUS AND RESILIENT
description: EVANGELICALISM The Coming Generation. By James Davison Hunter. 302 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

title: IN U.S., IMMIGRANTS LINE UP FOR AMNESTY
description: AFTER eight years of looking nervously over her shoulder, Krystyna Swiatek walked into the immigration legalization center here Tuesday and sighed with relief. ''I feel at home now,'' said Ms. Swiatek, a 36-year-old native of Warsaw. Ms. Swiatek visited Chicago as a tourist in 1979 and decided not to return to her home in Poland after martial law was imposed.

title: Krista A. Willett Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald K. Willett of Ridgefield, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Krista Anne Willett, to William Bennett Hildebrand, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Fredric L. Hildebrand of Neenah, Wis. The couple plan to marry next month.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Stockbridge, Mass.;
From College To Condos
description: LEAD: BERKSHIRE Christian College will move out of its 62-acre campus here next month and a Lenox developer will begin converting the property into a residential condominium.

title: Study Details Abuses of Detainees in South Africa
description: Most detainees in South African jails are suffering physical and mental abuse, with insufficient legal safeguards, according to a recent study by the National Medical and Dental Association in South Africa.

title: Page Merrill to Wed Anthony N. Brady
description: Page Boughton Merrill and Anthony Nicholas Brady plan to marry Sept. 12, Miss Merrill's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Barrant V. Merrill of Sun Valley, Idaho, and New York have announced. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Frederick Brady of Far Hills, N.J.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: EMILY: The Diary of a Hard-Worked Woman. By Emily French. Edited by Janet Lecompte. (University of Nebraska, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $7.95.) Emily French failed to write in the little book she called ''the holder of my poor thoughts and actions'' on only three days in 1890. Some entries were brief - ''Oh Dear, so hard, washed all day,'' was all she managed on Sept.

title: HOLLYWOOD FASHIONS SMALL TOWN INTO SMALL TOWN
description: There is an air of unreality in this small town in northern Vermont. Brightly colored autumn leaves cover lawns where daffodils are blooming. On Main Street, a three-sided shell of a building poses as a barber shop. Children in Halloween costumes roam the streets. A grocery store employee, asked for directions to the Post Office, responds: ''The real one or the fake one?'' Hollywood has come to town. Life in Hyde Park has been a trifle off kilter since February, when the production company for a Tri-Star movie, ''Sweet Hearts Dance,'' arrived, bringing with it a retinue of movie technicians and the stars, Don Johnson, Susan Sarandon and Jeff Daniels.

title: EMULATING KASPAROV TAKES NERVES OF STEEL
description: THE most closely watched player in the world is the world champion, Gary Kasparov.

title: THERE WAS AN OLD LADY FROM SPAIN...
description: ITS ORIGINS ARE SHROUDED in mystery, possibly even antiquity, but the anecdote in verse known as a limerick has long pleased those who delight in rhymes, both proper and bawdy, which can bring on a leer or maybe a grin and even have been deliciously naughty.

title: WHY THE DOLLAR MUST FALL ANOTHER 30%
description: DESPITE having fallen nearly 40 percent since February 1985, the dollar continues to be overvalued. In fact, it will have to decline as much as 30 percent to eliminate the remaining trade deficit, create the conditions for cutting the Federal budget deficit and force Europe and Japan into more reasonable macroeconomic policies.

title: SAVING THE WORLD, ONE BOOK AT A TIME
description: I HAVE no shame. Every Thursday morning, as I walk to the L.I.R.R., I scan the piles of trash for possible buried treasure: books.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: STAGED READINGS Christopher Durang is the first celebrity to participate in a series of staged readings of theater works at the Westport Arts Center. The playwright will act in and direct his new satire, ''For Whom the Belle Tolls,'' at 8 P.M. Friday. The piece is billed as a sendup of the Tennessee Williams genre.

title: MY SUMMER JOB WITH SINCLAIR LEWIS
description: ONE morning in May 1937, back from a year's study at Clare College, Cambridge, I sat reading ''Gone With the Wind'' in the New York apartment of my former Yale roommate Chester Kerr, wondering what to try next in the job line. A hoped-for spot on Time magazine had fallen through. The phone rang, and the call was for me - from another Yale classmate, Henry McKnight, who was working at The Herald Tribune. He said he had heard from Dorothy Thompson, then a columnist for the paper, that her husband, Sinclair Lewis, was looking for a secretary. Why not take a shot at that? He gave me Lewis's phone number.

title: Home From the Sea
description: THE YACHTSMAN from Jamestown, R.I., who built his own sailboat for a race around the world won the Class II prize yesterday in the BOC Challenge competition. Mike Plant crossed the finish line in Newport, R.I., at 2:10 P.M., completing his 27,000-mile solo voyage in 157 days 11 hours 44 minutes 44 seconds. His boat, Airco Distributor, is a 50-foot sloop designed by Rodger Martin. For winning Class II (for boats 40 to 50 feet), Plant will receive $15,000 and a gold-and-silver globe trophy. The winner in Class I (for boats 50 to 60 feet), was Philippe Jeantot, a 35-year-old Frenchman who finished Thursday in a record-breaking 134 days.

title: A Blast Kills a Lebanese Man As Gemayel Has Talks Nearby
description: A bomb exploded today in the Syrian-controlled north Lebanon resort of Zgharta during a visit by President Amin Gemayel, killing one man and wounding 34 people, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: A NEW SLR MAKES ITS DEBUT
description: NIKON is a camera company best known as a supplier of professional equipment, including rugged camera bodies, crisp lenses and fuss-free accessories. My earliest image of what a ''real'' camera looked like was a bruised and battered Nikon F, slung over the shoulder of a news photographer. Its black pentaprism was badly dented, and bits of brass showed through on the edges where the paint had worn off.

title: OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

title: Boston Under The Weather
description: ''IT'S more, more, more,'' C. T. Roosevelt of Cambridge said of the almost uninterrupted rain and clouds that have dampened spirits in Boston since spring ostensibly arrived. ''I keep wishing I were a duck so I would think it's a beautiful day.''

title: Barbara Burke Weds J. L. Valk
description: The marriage of Barbara Burke, director of blood services for the Norwalk-Wilton chapter of the American Red Cross, and J.Lansing Valk, an investment broker for A. G. Edwards in Wilton, Conn., took place yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the United Church of Christ in Rowayton, Conn., by the Rev. John Livingston of the United Church of Christ and the Rev. Charles Smith, a Congregational minister.

title: DRESSING UP ROUTINE PAPERWORK
description: WITH its new PS/2 series of computers, I.B.M. is beaming its spotlight on large corporations. Indeed, the new line would seem to be the opening act in a drama whose logical finale is a business environment in which everything is hooked up to, or at least able to communicate with, I.B.M.'s big mainframe computers.

title: TURNING A PROFIT
description: St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church here is where the idea for the Orchestra of St. Peter by the Sea began to evolve just over a year ago, when its first concert sold out weeks beforehand to a standing-room-only audience of 400.

title: TWO VISIONS OF THE SPOILS OF CRUELTY
description: AS THE CREATOR OF THE THEATER OF Cruelty, Antonin Artaud declared that cruelty was not exclusively a matter of ''bodily laceration.'' From the point of view of the mind, he said, it ''signifies rigor, implacable intention and decision, irreversible and absolute determination.'' That definition aptly applies to the essence of Christopher Hampton's brilliant adaptation of Choderlos de Laclos's novel, ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses.'' For years, Artaud's radical theories achieved their greatest theatrical realization in Peter Brook's production of Peter Weiss's ''Persecution and Assassination of Marat by the Inmates of the Asylum of Charenton under the Direction of the Marquis de Sade.'' That claim can now be shared by Mr. Hampton's deeply mordant play.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: WATER SKY By Jean Craighead George. Illustrated by the author. 212 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.95. (Ages 11 and up)

title: WOMEN AT WAR
description: GONE TO SOLDIERS By Marge Piercy. 703 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: TINY PINK SCALLOPS FROM PUGET SOUND
description: Seattle's array of seafood, which already boasts remarkable variety, has been graced with a new arrival recently. Tiny pink and spiny scallops from Puget Sound have appeared in fish markets and on restaurant menus. Because the entire animal is consumed right out of the shell, scallop lovers enjoy the full, sweet richness of their meat, and they must be served absolutely fresh, within 48 hours of being taken from the water, for there is no middle ground between that and spoilage.

title: Popular Jersey Principal Is Stabbed to Death
description: The principal of this town's high school was stabbed to death early today by a former boyfriend of one of his daughters, according to the Middlesex County Prosecutor.

title: Schools as Developers: Putting a Surplus to Use
description: A FIVE-YEAR boom in the development of office parks by colleges and universities may be ending just as dozens of schools have decided that their surplus real estate could help solve long-term financial problems. And while American universities are struggling to get their projects off the ground, Japan's municipal and regional governments have launched a crash program to create 26 ''technopolis'' centers before the turn of the century.

title: RESTAURANTEUR BRINGS IN 6 CHEFS FROM BEIJING
description: THINGS are a bit different these days for Wang Yijung, and Union County is quite different from Beijing, but the master chef is starting to enjoy himself and to see that this part of America will be his universe for two years.

title: THE WRIGHT SITE
description: To the Editor:

title: NOW, WOMEN HAVE TO TAKE THE BLAME
description: IT HAS been easy and valid during the past decade to blame women's inability to reach senior management on corporate America's caste system - men at the top and women at the bottom or, more recently, at the middle management level. The reasons for women's failure to rise through the ranks more quickly are myriad and have been dissected ad nauseum - lack of drive, family considerations, lack of sponsors, the old-boy network. The list goes on and on.

title: MUSTANG STILL SPORTS THAT OLD APPEAL
description: I HAVE lusted, oft as not, over objects made of fiberglass and steel, with a bit of leather thrown in here and there. It is hard to say how some of them have escaped me, but the list is long, a whole litany of automobiles I have coveted but not possessed.

title: Diane L. Jensen Is Married to Capt. Dean C. Berry
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va., yesterday Diane Lyn Jensen was married to Capt. Dean Clement Berry, U.S.A. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Mark S. Anschutz, the rector, who was assisted by the Rev. James D. Ford, the chaplain of the House of Representatives and a Lutheran minister.

title: ORGANIZING AN EVENT FOR THE RECORD BOOKS
description: IN another week it seems likely that bridge will hold the world record, and so earn a place in the Guinness Book of Records, for the greatest number of participants in a single competitive event. The Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest, which attracted 66,000 players when it was initiated almost a year ago, is expected to reach a six-figure participation.

title: HIGHT-POWERED FISHING DERBIES CAN DISTORT THE SPORT
description: NEARLY 50 years ago, I encountered my first fishing tournament and in the interim nothing has altered my original perception of them as a poor substitute for hoeing potatoes or other equally pleasurable pursuits.

title: Judge Accused Of Morals Charge
description: JUDGE JAMES D. SLOAN of Alabama was in Providence, R.I., last July to attend the 49th annual meeting of the National Council of Juvenile and Family Court Judges when he was arrested at a hotel.

title: Commercial Property: Sidewalk Newsstands; Retailers Resent Their Bargain-Rent Competition
description: ON street corners of Manhattan, pedestrians dodge, squeeze and shove their way past sidewalk emporiums offering T-shirts, sunglasses, snack foods, cigarettes, jewelry, lipstick, even cotton candy. Nominally known as newsstands, the establishments pay pennies a day for rent.

title: Miss Casale Weds Thomas Maisano
description: Laura Anne Casale and Thomas Paul Maisano were married yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Henry Boyle. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Casale of Plandome, L.I., and Manchester, Vt., is a 1984 graduate of the Pratt Institute School of Architecture. She is a designer with the firm Swanke-Hayden & Connel Architects Ltd. in Manhattan and will keep her name professionally. Her father owns Aftermarket Sales Inc., automotive manufacturers' representatives in Roslyn Heights, L.I. Her mother, Barbara Casale, is an interior designer in Plandome.

title: MOTHER'S DAY IN AN EMPTY NEST
description: TODAY will be another in the line of firsts. In fact, it may be the most daunting of all.

title: NOW, AN ADD-ON TO UPDATE YOUR CHERISHED OLD CONSOLE
description: GIVEN THE HEFTY PRICE of television sets, repair is often preferable to replacement. This is especially true of sets housed in elaborate consoles. Such sets, over the years, become familiar furniture whose loss would be tantamount to a domestic upheaval.

title: No Racial Quotas For Starrett City
description: Even in the interests of integration, a Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled last week, a private landlord may not set quotas to limit the number of apartments to be rented to minority group members .

title:
ART;
A COMPREHENSIVE LOOK AT COSMIC UNITY IN WOOD
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Jane Teller is not very well known in the art world at large, she is practically an institution in New Jersey - which takes diligent care of its best mature artists - and her sculpture has been shown up and down the state.

title: OPERA: IN NEW JERSEY, AN UNSTAGED 'FIDELIO'
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 8 - Hugh Wolff is being widely credited for reviving the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, and tonight, in the first of five concert performances of Beethoven's ''Fidelio,'' he proved he is worth all the credit he's receiving. This was a passionately played and conducted, stalwartly sung and altogether convincing performance of one of the greatest operas in the repertory.

title: NUMBER TO CALL FOR PASSENGER DATA
description: People who believe their relatives might have been aboard the Polish airliner that crashed today can call (212) 944-8116 for information, a State Department spokeswoman announced.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Bird's-Eye View
description: LEAD: For those of you already worrying about what to get mother next year at this time, the county's Planning Department may just have the answer: an aerial photograph of her own little portion of Westchester.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: INNOCENCE. By Penelope Fitzgerald. (Holt, $16.95.) Where E. M. Forster saw Florence as a place to soak up sun and beauty while relaxing British constraint, Penelope Fitzgerald, the British biographer and Booker Prize-winning novelist, inverts the premise. It is her convivial, inept Italians, the Florentine Ridolfi family, long on lineage (they descend from Renaissance midgets) but short on cash, who need a bit of shaking up.

title: TEAPOT -- TEST OF A POTTER'S INVENTIVENESS
description: HOW FAR can you push a teapot? It would seem, from a group of works by Mayer Shacter, a California artist, at the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery here, that a teapot can be pushed to the point of disassembling the components. Of course, that implies that a sculptural form has been based on the concept of a teapot.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: JUMPING CLASSIC

title: CO-DIRECTING: THE PITFALLS OF A COMMON PURSUIT
description: LEAD: IN THESE EXCERPTS FROM ''The American 'Common Pursuit' Diary,'' by Simon Gray, which Mr. Gray has recently completed, he discusses his relationship with his co-director, Michael McGuire. ''The Common Pursuit,'' Mr. Gray's look at 20 years in the lives of a group of Cambridge University classmates, was first staged in London, and then, in revised versions, at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, the Matrix in Los Angeles and the Promenade Theater in New York, where it is still playing.

title: Ellen B. Tobie Married To Lawrence F. Gilberti
description: Ellen Bidwell Tobie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan F. Tobie of Lancaster, Pa., was married at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday to Lawrence Francis Gilberti, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael V. Gilberti of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Elizabeth Tobie Irvine, a sister of the bride.

title: OF 'POOR' WALL STREETERS, AND RICH FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: From time to time, an article receives a particularly strong response. Whenever possible, we will print a large number of the letters it elicits.

title: NOT DROWNING BUT WAVING
description: STEVIE A Biography of Stevie Smith. By Jack Barbera and William McBrien. Illustrated. 378 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: PRESIDENT THREATENS TO VETO BILLS LIMITING HIM ON ARMS
description: President Reagan moved toward a major collision with Congress today when he threatened to veto any legislation that restricted his flexibility in arms control talks or provided what he considers to be inadequate levels of military spending.

title: Peeping Into Biographies
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Used Cocaine
description: PHIL FORD, a former University of North Carolina star and National Basketball Association player, has told a Charlotte, N.C., newspaper that he used cocaine while playing in the N.B.A. ''I did use the drug, but it's something that's behind me,'' Ford told The Charlotte Observer Friday. ''I haven't drunk anything or used any drugs in almost a year and a half.'' Ford, 31 years old, played for Kansas City, New Jersey, Milwaukee and Houston. His last season was 1984-85. ''Mostly my drug of choice was alcohol,'' he said.

title: SHE FOUNDED A SHOPPING SERVICE -- FOR MORTGAGES
description: ''I THOUGHT there was a need,'' said Jane Greenstein of Roslyn Heights. ''Sometimes that's the key to an idea - recognizing a need and going for it.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE MAN WHO FELL FROM THE SKY. By William Norris. (Viking, $17.95.) Here's a nice, true-life premise for a murder mystery: Alfred Loewenstein, a financier who's spent the 1920's kiting and bluffing his way into fortunes, tumbles from his Fokker monoplane into the English Channel. The six people on board say they didn't see a thing, that Loewenstein must have mistakenly walked out of the plane through the exit door in the lavatory.

title: A Martyr Of Auschwitz
description: All the current hullabaloo about whether Edith Stein was killed because she was a Jew or because she was a Roman Catholic is irreligious and irrelevant (''A Martyr of Auschwitz,'' by Susanne M. Batzdorff, April 12). Of course, she died because of the Nazis' odium fidei! Jewish faith and Catholic faith are at their esoteric core the same faith: the faith of our common father, Abraham. To turn Edith Stein's death into a turf battle is the kind of arrant perversion of faith upon which the Nazis of every generation have fed. Banality breeds tyranny. JACQUES POISSON Wakefield, R.I.

title: War on Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: SINGULAR ARTISTS WHO WORK IN THE FIRST PERSON PLURAL
description: IN ONE OF THE GALLERIES OF THE current Whitney biennial, the work of the photographers Mike and Doug Starn, better known as the Starn Twins, and the collaborative painters David McDermott and Peter McGough face each other from opposite walls. With this juxtaposition, - perhaps the most provocative and appropriate in the entire exhibition - the biennial's curators signal that the artists have a lot in common, and to some extent they are right. First of all, in both cases the art is made not by an individual but by two artists working together, and as such is part of a growing phenomenon of collaborations in the art world today. Second, both these teams are very much involved with bygone eras, styles and attitudes. In ways that are quite different and may be diametrically opposed, their work deliberately embraces a period look that often seems Victorian or Edwardian in flavor.

title:
ART;
CREATIVITY TO ENLIVEN THE KITCHEN
description: LEAD: THE kitchen is the arena of life for which one carries around the clearest archetypes. One holds in one's head an ideal fork, an ideal cup and an ideal serving platter and recognizes individual objects as manifestations of these ideals. It is an enjoyable art experience when the ideal is seen in fresh ways.

title: EDUCATION
description: For too long, say Board of Education officials, the city schools received too little from the city budget. But the picture began to brighten two years ago and looks brighter still this year. ''We've had a succession of good years and this was another in that succession,'' said Richard Riley, the spokesman for Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones.

title: 4,000-SEAT AMPHITHEATER TO REOPEN
description: LEAD: ''The open-air theater presented a scene of idyllic beauty. It was one of those mellow days when the lilacs sent their faint perfume by the breezes which rippled the blue lagoon. On the topmost terrace, the large silk flags of the Allies made their mute appeal to the kindly sky. Old Glory floated protectingly above them while to their left were flung multicolored banners of the world of long ago.

title: THE APPOINTMENT OF A SUPERVISOR
description: The April 12 issue carried a letter to the editor from the new Islip Supervisor, Frank Jones, in which he sharply crticized a recent ''Politics'' column that reported that Mr. Jones was appointed supervisor as a ''protege'' of the Islip Republican leader, Tony Pace.

title: LAW INTERNS FOCUS ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: Sixty law students at Columbia University will soon begin jobs as summer interns in an unusual human rights program.

title: Market Place; The Turnabout In Steel Stocks
description: WHEN the LTV Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, filed a bankruptcy petition last July, shock waves were sent through an industry already facing intense price competition and sluggish demand. The move raised fears that LTV could emerge as the industry's low-cost producer.

title: Secord's Companies
description: The Presidential Records Act obviously does not apply to Richard V. Secord, the retired Air Force officer who testified before the select Congressional committees last week. Mr. Secord told of how he controlled a network of 10 secret foreign companies in the Iran-contra affair without ever having his signature appear on a single piece of paper.

title: North Carolina
description: Peter V. Ueberroth, the commissioner of baseball, addressed more than 5,000 graduates at commencement exercises at the University of North Carolina today.

title: EXPLICIT AIDS ADS EXPECTED TO SPARK DEBATE IN NEW YORK
description: In an effort to slow the burgeoning AIDS epidemic, New York City officials are turning to an unusally explicit advertising campaign that is likely to generate controversy in certain religious and political quarters.

title: Oil Barge Explodes in Alaska; Two Die and Another Is Hurt
description: An empty petroleum barge exploded in the harbor here today, killing two people and critically injuring a third, officials said.

title: FILIPINOS, REBUILDING DEMOCRATIC RULE, CAST VOTES FOR A LEGISLATURE
description: Filipinos were voting today for a new legislature that will restore the country's democratic institutions and limit the powers of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: ANATOMY OF A STAGGERING LOSS
description: When Merrill Lynch & Company suffered a stunning $275 million loss from mortgage-securities dealings last month, it was quick to blame an unauthorized series of transactions and an adverse market.

title: Adelphi and Army In Lacrosse Event
description: Army and Adelphi were among 12 teams chosen yesterday for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's lacrosse tournament, and will meet in a first-round game Wednesday at West Point.

title: AMERICAN SALES GROW IN IVORY COAST
description: The setting was Africa and the language was French, but the corporate logotypes were American: Eveready, Lockheed, I.B.M., Dow Chemical, Xerox, Texaco and Citibank.

title: CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT IS SOUGHT TO LIMIT CAMPAIGN SPENDING
description: Congressional sponsors of a constitutional amendment to limit spending in political campaigns contend that any effort to control the influence of money is doomed as long as an 11-year-old Supreme Court decision remains on the books.

title: MUSIC: B.J. WARD, SINGER
description: THE song that best defines B. J. Ward, a Los Angeles-based pop singer making her New York club debut at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street, is called ''Voice-Over.'' A novelty written by Billy Barnes, the song offers an amusing account of the tasks a professional vocal chameleon is required to perform in jingles, on cartoon shows and in theme parks. Peforming the song, Ms. Ward, who has done more than 2,000 such voice-overs, impersonates sounds that range from talking cats and spiders to a Valley girl and a Southern belle.

title: DANCE: BOSTON BALLET IN 'TALES OF ANDERSON'
description: Hans Christian Andersen, the 19th-century Danish writer of fairy tales, admired ballet and often attended performances by the Royal Danish Ballet. Choreographers have always loved Andersen's stories and over the years have turned many of them into ballets.

title: CHOICE IN TEXAS: TO DRING OR DRIVE?
description: Another Texas tradition has fallen. Starting Sept. 1, Texas drivers will no longer be able to hurtle down the road in their pickup trucks guzzling beer, though their passengers will.

title: ONE MAN'S CONSTITUTION: IF IT ISN'T BROKE, DON'T...
description: As the Constitution approaches its 200th anniversary, Prof. Forrest McDonald, a leading constitutional scholar, wonders why anyone would want to tinker with it, either now or any time soon.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 10, 1987: TUESDAY FPL Group Inc Minnesota Mng & Mfg Greyhound Corp Questar Corp Lockheed Corp WEDNESDAY Arkansas Best Corp Household Intl Bandag Inc Meredith Corp CBS Inc USAir Corp Fireman's Fund USG Corp Fleet Fin'l Group USG Corp Gerber Products USLife Income Fund THURSDAY Carpenter Technology Int'l Flavors & Fragrances Champion Intl MAPCO Inc. Eldon Indus Sears Roebuck FRIDAY Barnes Group Learonal Inc Chelsea Industries Reynolds Metals Hannaford Bros Texas Utilities Holly Sugar Waste Management

title: WARRIORS WIN ON FLOYD'S 51
description: Eric (Sleepy) Floyd scored 51 points - 29 in the final period for a playoff record - as the Golden State Warriors defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 129-121, today after losing the first three games of their series.

title: WHAT COULD BE SO RARE AS A 90-DEGREE MAY DAY?
description: Forget about spring.

title: UPDATING 50 SUBWAY STATIONS: COSTLY AND LATE
description: Five years after the Transit Authority set out to modernize 50 subway stations, the program is years behind schedule and more than $100 million over its original budget.

title: Advertising; Lois Pitts Sets Hotels' TV Debut
description: LOIS PITTS GERSHON PON/ GGK won the Inter-Continental Hotels account in November and now finally is ready to run some advertising that will include the first TV campaign in the chain's history.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Seven Added to Indy Field: The accidents continued yesterday at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway as a rookie, Ludwig Heimrath Jr., led seven more qualifiers into the field for the 71st Indianapolis 500. Eighteen of the 33 positions in the tentative starting field have been set, with more time trials scheduled next weekend. Both Tom Sneva, the 1983 Indy winner, and George Snider escaped injury in crashes, which brought the number of such incidents to 13 since practice for the May 24 race opened on May 2. Meanwhile, the second of four days of time trials went on at a slow pace, with Heimrath and Rich Vogler qualifying at the start of the six-hour session and five other drivers joining them in the tentative field during the final 90 minutes.(AP) Road Racing Kristiansen Takes London: Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway won the women's division of the London Marathon for the third time yesterday, but a leg injury thwarted her bid to break the 2-hour-20-minute barrier. For half the race, the 31-year-old runner was on schedule, powering the first 13.1 miles in 1:07:51. But as the miles dragged on, she slowed to six minutes per mile and finished in 2:22:48. Afterward, she said she had suffered a recurrence of a muscle injury in her right leg that her doctor had discovered Friday during a routine examination. Hiromi Taniguchi of Japan won the men's race in 2:09:50, a personal best.(AP) Tennis Graf Keeps Rolling Along: Steffi Graf of West Germany extended her winning streak to 27 matches and won her fifth consecutive tournament title, beating Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, 7-5, 4-6, 6-0, in the Italian Open in Rome. The 17-year-old Graf fell behind by 0-4 in the first set, losing 11 consecutive points during one stretch as she struggled to keep her powerful forehand in the court. The 16-year-old Sabatini served for the set at 5-2, but squandered 4 set points.

title: THE STAGE: 'MISS JULIE,' AT SAMUEL BECKETT THEATER
description: ALTHOUGH he wrote some satire, August Strindberg has not come down to us as a humorist, so when you find yourself chuckling at a production of one of his ''naturalistic'' plays, chances are it is either an unorthodox approach or something has gone awry. The chuckles elicited by the version of ''Miss Julie'' now at the Samuel Beckett Theater do not appear to be intended.

title: OJEDA'S ELBOW HURTS THE METS
description: Bob Ojeda flew back to New York this morning and the Mets were set to absorb yet another blow to their pitching staff and to consider their next move.

title: INSIDE
description: Filling the Void In Iowa, it was ''the first day of the new campaign,'' an aide to one would-be Presidential candidate said, as Democrats studied those who want to replace Gary Hart. Page B6. The Last Picture Show The Thalia, a longtime haven on the Upper West Side for repertory and offbeat films, has closed. Page B3.

title: Al Mamoon First In John Henry
description: Al Mamoon, ridden by Patrick Valenzuela, led all the way today to win the $159,200 John Henry Handicap on the turf course at Hollywood Park.

title: WITH BARE CHURCHES, IT'S BARELY ENGLAND'S CHURCH
description: As usual, the Church of England's attendance this bright spring Sunday morning was somewhere below 3 percent of the population, anemically, alarmingly low in the view of the Bishop of Durham, who presided from the pulpit of St. Luke's Church.

title: PHOTO OF CAR MAY SUPPORT PART OF HART'S ACCOUNT
description: A photograph taken by a member of the The Miami Herald's team that staked out Gary Hart's town house last weekend appears to support a portion of Mr. Hart's account of his activities.

title: FILM: 'HOT PURSUIT,' STARRING JOHN CUSACK
description: ''HOT PURSUIT'' begins with the tragedy of a failed chemistry test, which keeps a prep school senior, Dan Bartlett, from joining his girlfriend and her family on a Caribbean cruise. Danny is a level-headed scholarship student, and his romance with Lori is an attraction of opposites. She is a rich girl distinguished by her ability to talk and smile at the same time and her tendency to practice cheerleader splits at any moment. Unexpectedly, the chemistry teacher shows up in Dan's room and lets the lovelorn A student out of the makeup test so he can go on the trip; the teacher has a 16-year-old daughter of his own and, he says, pretty girls don't like to be let down. (These adults aren't understanding about their kids' love lives; they're saintly.) As Dan scrambles to catch up with Lori's family, he is always a step behind in a series of shamefully predictable near misses: after flying to the Caribbean, he is waylaid by drugged-out islanders, done in by a bottle of rum and caught in a suspenseless storm at sea. In the final, silliest plot twist, he challenges the murderous pirates who try to take over the family's charter boat.

title: WHO'S ON FIRST? GIANTS DON'T CARE
description: PART of Roger Craig's success with the San Francisco Giants has come from his unflagging refusal to see the glass half-empty. In transforming this team from chronic and willing losers to National League West challengers in little more than a full season, he has used the split-finger fastball and Norman Vincent Peale in equal measures. Nothing about his team's success this year surprises him.

title: 15 Killed in Punjab Violence
description: Fifteen people have been killed in Punjab in the last 24 hours, the worst violence this year in the northern Indian state, the Press Trust of India reported today. Seven of those deaths occurred when a gang of about 20 men on motor scooters swept through two villages near Amritsar, firing at everyone they saw, the news agency said. The police blamed Sikh extremists for the killings.

title: Alice Henkin Married To John Gary Nicolich
description: Alice Phoebe Henkin, a partner in Moser & Henkin, and John Gary Nicolich, an associate at Shea & Gould, both New York law firms, were married yesterday at the Picnic House in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. Rabbi Eugene Sack officiated.

title: JOBS AND CHILD CARE STUDIED
description: Child care costs Americans billions of dollars each year, and such problems as the inability to find a baby sitter disrupt the jobs of 450,000 parents each month, according to a Government study.

title: 2 SCIENTISTS SHARE A $150,000 AWARD
description: A botanist who has catalogued some 2,000 plants used in the tropics as medicines, narcotics and poisons, and a geographer who championed finding ways to live with recurring floods and hurricanes rather than fight them, are sharing this year's $150,000 Tyler Prize, awarded for outstanding research in environmental science.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Retail Sales...April Thursday Inventory-Sales RatioMarch Merchandise Trade BalanceMarch Friday Producer Prices...April Industrial Production...April

title: Santa Fe Trail Designation
description: President Reagan signed a bill on Friday designating the Santa Fe Trail, stretching 950 miles from Missouri to New Mexico, as the Santa Fe National Historic Trail. The measure grants administrative jurisdiction over the trail.

title: Kathleen Battle to Open 1987 Caramoor Season
description: A performance by the soprano Kathleen Battle on June 27 at 8:30 P.M. is to open the 42d season of music at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y. Miss Battle, who will be making her Caramoor debut, will sing arias and songs by Gabrieli, Handel, Respighi and Zwilich, with the Orchestra of St. Luke's conducted by John Nelson.

title: Syracuse University
description: Syracuse University awarded 4,945 undergraduate and graduate degrees yesterday at its 133d commencement.

title: Solid Increases For Retail Sales
description: April retail sales in the New York area had the largest year-to-year gain in many months, averaging 17.8 percent ahead of the year-earlier total in both New York City and the metropolitan area, according to a spot check of several leading stores.

title: Black Vietnam Hero Honored
description: A Marine sergeant killed in Vietnam when he threw himself on a grenade to save members of his platoon was honored Saturday as the Navy commissioned its first ship named after a black recipient of the Medal of Honor. About 1,300 people gathered at the naval station here for the ceremony for the 453-foot guided missile frigate Rodney M. Davis. Sergeant Davis was killed Sept. 6, 1967, while serving with the First Marine Division in Quang Nam Province.

title: PREAKNESS FAVORITE IS STILL A TOSSUP
description: Alysheba was so much the best in winning the Kentucky Derby nine days ago that it at first would seem difficult to beat him in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Saturday. Still, at least seven other 3-year-olds will try, and their handlers share the same hope: Alysheba may be as likely to revert to his old form as to repeat his Derby.

title: PRESIDENT URGES BLACKS TO ATTAIN SKILLS IN SCIENCE
description: President Reagan said today that if black Americans were to progress socially and economically, they must become part of the scientific and technological revolution.

title: CHIP BATTLE GROWS IN EUROPE
description: The decision by the Thomson Group of France and STET, the Italian state telecommunications enterprise, to form Western Europe's second-largest manufacturer of semiconductors demonstrates how the Europeans are trying to increase their share of a highly competitive market.

title: WITH HART'S WITHDRAWAL, IOWA BECOMES A LAND OF OPPORTUNITY
description: With Gary Hart's withdrawal from the Presidential campaign, ticket sales doubled for the Polk County Democratic Steak Fry, held here on the State Fair Grounds Saturday night.

title: Duke University
description: Duke University conferred degrees on more than 2,000 students in a midmorning ceremony today.

title: Indiana University
description: A total of 7,262 degrees were awarded today at Indiana University's commencement exercises.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MAY 11, 1987
description: Companies

title: Bridge: Favorites and Foreigners Struggle in Cavendish Event
description: Favorites and foreigners had a hard time on the first day of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs event. At the end of Saturday's play at the Cavendish Club's headquarters, at 105 East 73d Street, the lead was held by two young Manhattan experts, Drew Casen and Jim Krekorian. Only 2 of the 16 players from other countries, and none of the 15 Americans who have won world titles, were in a good position.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Which major leaguer hit the most extra-inning home runs in his career?

title: Boating; Racing Success Runs in the Family
description: A father-and-son team from Greenwich, Conn., has hit the offshore powerboat racing season full-throttle this year as favorites for world championships in their respective classes. But with their successes also comes concern for safety in the sport.

title: Koch Defends Hasidim to Blacks
description: Speaking yesterday at a crowded and sometimes angry black church gathering in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, Mayor Koch strongly defended a local Hasidic Jewish sect that has complained that it is the victim of crimes committed by blacks.

title: NUMBER OF INMATES IN U.S. PRISONS REACHED RECORD HIGH LAST YEAR
description: The number of inmates in Federal and state prisons reached a record high last year, an agency of the Justice Department reported today.

title: THE THALIA, OFFBEAT HOME OF CLASSIC MOVIES, IS CLOSED
description: The Thalia, a tiny Upper West Side theater that has been venerated by generations of college students, movie buffs and other aficionados of Hollywood revivals, classics and foreign films, closed down over the weekend, apparently for the last time.

title: Leonard Lampman Sr. Dies; Chief of the Abenaki Nation
description: The Abenaki Tribal Nation will hold elections later this year to name a successor to Leonard Lampman Sr., chief of the nation for seven years. Mr. Lampman, who was 65 years old, died Wednesday after a long illness.

title: RECITAL: EUGENE ISTOMIN
description: BETWEEN beautiful simplicity and workaday plainness in musical execution there is sometimes a fine line, and even careful listening can leave one unsure whether player or hearer is responsible for the apparent shift between the ordinary and the exquisite. Some portion of Eugene Istomin's piano recital at Carnegie Hall Saturday night clearly fell into the realm of the exquisite: the beautifully balanced sonorities and fluent, unhurried unfoldings of Debussy's ''Images'' (Book I) above all.

title: CHRYSLER REDEFINING PARTS UNIT
description: The Chrysler Corporation is expected to announce Monday that it will restructure its $2.8 billion a year parts-making operation as a wholly owned subsidiary - an action that could prove to be preliminary to a public stock offering.

title: Tobacco Exports Criticized
description: The Government should stop promoting the export of tobacco products to developing nations, according to a resolution unanimously adopted by the American Lung Association at its 82d annual meeting. The association said in a statement that smoking causes 2.5 million deaths each year worldwide.

title: BUYOUTS WITH RUDE SURPRISES
description: A corporate marriage, like any other, can be less than blissful. But what happens when the new spouse reveals a deep, dark secret only after taking the vows?

title: 'QUEENIE,' BASED ON KORDA NOVEL
description: TAKE a girl of mixed blood, make her determined to climb out of desperate poverty, send her on the way to becoming an international film star and, lo and behold, you have ''Queenie,'' the latest television extravaganza in the absurd but good-for-a-giggle tradition of Judith Krantz and Sidney Sheldon. The first two hours of this sumptuous five-hour Tinker Toy were broadcast on ABC last night. The rest can be seen this evening, beginning at 8.

title: Today's Auction Cut to $12.8 Billion
description: Treasury financing this week is limited to the bill market, where the regular Monday auction of three- and six-month issues will be followed Tuesday by a sale of one-year bills.

title: ROSLYN LINDHEIM
description: Roslyn Lindheim, a professor of architecture at the University of California at Berkeley who was known for her work in hospital design, died of cancer Tuesday at her home in Berkeley. She was 65 years old.

title: BRAZIL'S STREET CHILDREN: NEW ATTEMPT AT RESCUE
description: For two months earlier this year, Brazil's fantasy world of television soap operas and slick advertising was briefly interrupted each evening by cheaply made public service messages in which nervous black teen-agers from a Government welfare agency asked viewers to give them a chance to work.

title: SO WHY ARE PANDAS SO CUTE?
description: They are reclusive, even hostile. They are so romantically disinclined that their very survival is threatened. Their primary activity is sleep, and they spend most of their waking hours scrounging for food.

title: It's Better to Have Citizens Screening Judges Than the Politicians
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TOUGH QUESTION FOR THE HERALD IS IN SPANISH
description: Controversy over The Miami Herald's coverage of Gary Hart hit this city over the last week with the fury of a tropical storm. The host of one radio call-in show urged listeners to cancel their subscriptions, and Herald-bashing, a favorite Miami pastime, was in full flower.

title: IN MALTA, TIES TO WEST AT ISSUE AGAIN
description: A bitterly contested general election that will decide this island nation's relations with the West for the next five years appeared to be headed for a photo finish today.

title: Site for Cup Is in Dispute
description: Dennis Conner and his Sail America syndicate may have won the America's Cup, but they may be losing a battle with the San Diego Yacht Club on where the next defense will be sailed.

title: HUDSON (5-0) AND WARD OVERPOWER TWINS, 6-1
description: A year ago, they were playing for different teams in different cities, both of them unwanted and apparently unappreciated. But Charles Hudson and Gary Ward, whose respective paths took them from Philadelphia and Texas to New York, may have found places of permanence in the Bronx.

title: Stop Keyhole Journalism
description: ''Have you ever committed adultery?'' was the stone some sin-free questioner lobbed at Gary Hart last week. His answer was a temperate ''I do not have to answer that question.'' Mine would have been ''Go to hell.''

title: L. T.'s Other Life
description: EVERY so often last season in the Giants' ascent to the Super Bowl XXI championship, Phil Simms would be trotting onto the field when the offensive unit took over. But above the rumble of the crowd, the quarterback could hear Lawrence Taylor's voice.

title: Say It With Music
description: Oh, how Irving Berlin hates to get up in the morning (1918). Well, even if it's a lovely day today (1950), he's allowed to sleep in. It's his birthday. The remarkable man who asked that God bless America (1939) with a singable national anthem has done 99 years.

title: Time for Europe to Cheer
description: European delay in answering Mikhail Gorbachev's latest proposals for getting rid of all medium- and shorter-range missiles on the continent betrays a paralysis of will. Nothing is going to be learned or better understood by prolonging the debate.

title: Aides to the President and Vice President are Braced for Bombshells: 'Resignation' on Reagan Staff
description: The Republican political strategist allowed himself a full-throated laugh. ''I don't mind sharing the headlines with Gary Hart for the next week or so,'' he said, bellowing.

title: Douglas Names Leader For MD-80 Jet Program
description: The Douglas Aircraft division of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation has named Richard A. Bibee to head its MD-80 program after a six-year absence from the company. Maurice A. O'Connor, who has served as the manager for the twin-engine jet program since 1981, has been appointed to a new engineering position as director of product design.

title: Black Separatism Is an Old Soviet Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. May Cut Charges In Moscow Spying Case
description: Cpl. Arnold Bracy, one of the Marine embassy guards charged with espionage in Moscow, was interviewed again by investigators this weekend and continued to insist that his initial incriminatory statements had been coerced, according to a lawyer in the case.

title: American Brands Losing Its President
description: Virginius B. Lougee 3d, president of American Brands Inc., has announced plans to retire at the end of the year.

title: Presidential Records
description: If the White House had paid more attention to a little-noticed 1978 law, there might be fewer unanswered questions in the Iran-contra affair.

title: LOUGANIS COMPLETES TRIPLE
description: Less than a month ago, the disturbing questions arose again - about his skills, his age and the possibility that time, finally, had caught up with him.

title: Phillies Sting Reds and Power
description: Juan Samuel and Lance Parrish belted homers, and Shane Rawley pitched seven scoreless innings for Philadelphia today as the Phillies defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3.

title: Tortured Reasoning on Starrett City
description: Starrett City, a national metaphor for carefully nurtured housing integration, rises from a tract of southern Brooklyn not far from Kennedy Airport. By controlling the intake of minority group tenants, the project's management has sought to prevent racial ''tipping'' - admission of so many minority families that whites desert en masse. So far it has succeeded, but only by openly discriminating against would-be minority tenants.

title: Succession Is Settled At Ayer, Los Angeles
description: Bartine A. Stoner, 61 and chairman of N. W. Ayer, Los Angeles, is retiring in July to be replaced by John E. Littlewood, 49 and president and chief executive of what is now being called Ayer Pacific.

title: Carpet Treatment
description: It will hardly cheer baseball purists, but those concerned about the nation's trade deficit with Japan should be heartened by the news that American-made Astroturf has cracked the Japanese baseball market.

title: EXPERTS ON AIDS URGE MORE TESTING ON OPTIONAL BASIS
description: Federal health officials, in a confidential new report, have recommended a major increase in voluntary testing for infection with the AIDS virus. They opposed wider mandatory testing and called for new laws to keep test results secret and to protect the civil rights of people infected.

title: MUSIC: TWO GUITAR STYLISTS
description: NOTES were sliding all over the place at the Village Vanguard, where Jim Hall and a second guitarist, Bill Frisell, led a quartet through yesterday. Mr. Hall's crystalline, introspective style - single-note lines that wink into view, skeletal but revealing chords - is well known to jazz fans, while Mr. Frisell's utterly distinctive playing makes him one of the most important young guitarists around. Together, they played whisper-quiet sets full of oblique lyricism.

title: Outdoors; Fishing for Memories
description: THE Delaware River's shad were our quarry, but although Roger Kitchen of Stroudsburg, Pa., and I dutifully cast flies and lures at them, we were fishing other waters also.

title: Winning Style
description: During a game, he is a perpetual motion machine, alternately sitting, kneeling and standing while keeping up a constant bellow of instructions and exhortations to his University of New Haven players. To see him in action, it is obvious that Frank Vieira is a born basketball coach, one cast in the same frenetic mold as Bob Knight, Jim Valvano and Lou Carnesecca.

title: Metro Matters; City in A.D. 2000: Quality of Life Depends on Koch
description: Mayor Koch will see the future this month. Whether it works may depend on how much his defensiveness about the present clouds his vision of things to come.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FAST FORWARD. Hollywood, the Japanese, and the Onslaught of the VCR. By James Lardner. 344 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: Dentsu Gets No. 1 Spot In Rankings by Ad Age
description: Advertising Age will report today that Dentsu, the Japanese giant, has returned to the No. 1 spot in terms of billings among the world's ad agencies, nudging out Young & Rubicam, which had briefly replaced it.

title: BEIRUT AIRPORT OPENS, WITH HIGHER FARES
description: Beirut International Airport reopened today after being closed for 98 days, but higher insurance premiums that add $200 to the cost of a ticket may prohibit many Lebanese from using the airport.

title: SWINDELL FANS 15 ROYALS
description: Greg Swindell struck out a season-high 15 batters and Rick Dempsey had a key two-run double as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Kansas City Royals, 4-2, today.

title: FATES (AND FINANCES) CREATE A CRUEL TWIST FOR THE BARD
description: ''What's in a name?'' William Shakespeare asks. ''Everything,'' says Domenico Manchisi, owner of Jerry's Shakespeare Pizza.

title: First Chicago Cites Inquiry
description: The First Chicago Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, said that two former officers were being investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. It said the inquiry involves ''the propriety of the expenditures of some portion of the $400,000 in consulting and outside services fees which we reported to Federal authorities.''

title: THE STAGE AS ELEMENT OF DANCE
description: A dance by Lucinda Childs tends to send its performers hurtling serenely along like celestial atoms. The SoHo loft where she lives and works is as open, spacious and clear as her dances. But for all that simplicity, Ms. Childs is a choreographer with a strong interest in stage design and the way a dance interacts with the environment in which it unfolds.

title: NEW RITUALS EASE GRIEF AS AIDS TOLL INCREASES
description: By monitoring the sky above a certain courtyard on West 11th Street in Greenwich Village, you can tell when another member of the People With AIDS Coalition has died.

title: Babbit & Reiman Gets Days Inns Account
description: Babbit & Reiman Advertising, a year-old agency in Atlanta, has landed the account of Days Inns of America, with billings of $4 million.

title: A RUBBER REVIVAL FOR LIBERIA
description: Wielding a sharp knife, Henry Koluboi deftly made a spiral cut in a rubber tree. Soon small white drops of latex appeared in the cut and dripped into a cup.

title: Tough Law Hasn't Reduced Drug Use or Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORD-IT-YOURSELF MUSIC ON CASSETTE
description: Recorded music is thriving outside the record business.

title: Head of Emporium Unit Leaving Carter Hawley
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said today that David Folkman will step down as president and chief executive officer of Emporium Capwell, its northern California chain of 22 department stores, effective June 1. He will join U.S. Venture Partners, a venture capital firm based in Menlo Park, Calif., that specializes in technology and retail startup companies.

title: Myers to Buy Buckhorn
description: Myers Industries, a tire distribution company based in Akron, Ohio, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Buckhorn Inc., a maker of plastic containers, for $21.8 million. A spokesman for both companies said that Myers would soon begin a tender offer that would pay $4.375 for each common share and $8.125 for each series A preferred share of Buckhorn. Among other conditions, the offer is subject to Myers's gaining a majority of voting power in the company and its obtaining sufficient financing.

title: 5 Jailed in Puerto Rico In Big Cocaine Seizure
description: The Coast Guard seized almost a ton and a half of cocaine aboard a 28-foot fishing boat off the United States Virgin Islands Friday and arrested five Colombians, who were imprisoned here Saturday.

title: JWT Reconstitutes Chief Executive Office
description: The five-man office of the chief executive at the J. Walter Thompson Company, which lost two of its members, has been reconstituted. The chairman is still Don Johnston, who is also chairman and chief executive of the parent JWT Group.

title: CONCERT: CANADIAN BRASS
description: THE Canadian Brass is an ensemble that has not really decided whether to be a serious purveyor of music or a show-business act. Judging from its evening at Avery Fisher Hall Friday night, it sees no reason why the choice must be made.

title: BOSTON BIOLOGISTS TRY TO SAVE THE WHALES FROM THEMSELVES
description: Three baby pilot whales, nursed back to health after they beached themselves in December, will be returned to the sea within the next few weeks in what experts say is a unique attempt to save the animals from their own suicidal instincts.

title: The Price of More Aid: Less U.S. Control
description: The Reagan Administration is undermining two international agencies that, between them, provide almost one-quarter of the multilateral aid for third world countries. It doesn't want the Inter-American Development Bank and the Asian Development Bank to expand their lending activities unless they do it Washington's way. But at a time when Latin America's debt burden threatens a world crisis and Asia's poor ache for help, what is the Administration trying to prove?

title: COMPROMISE PLAN PROPOSED ON HOUSING HOMELESS
description: A new plan for housing homeless families, designed as a compromise between the competing proposals of Mayor Koch and Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins, was announced yesterday by the Partnership for the Homeless, a network of more than 300 New York churches and synagogues providing emergency food and shelter.

title: Chapter 11 Companies Pauperize the Retired
description: To the Editor:

title: Tuning In
description: Don't rush for the dial just yet, but come July 1, New York sports fans won't have to sit through those tedious national and international radio news reports, not to mention all that distracting music and chit-chat in between, before getting the scores.

title: COLLEGE STUDENTS, FULL OF PARADOXES, DEMONSTRATE A QUIET COMMITMENT
description: Springtime on college campuses is hardly what it used to be.

title: PILOT IN JET CRASH PRAISED IN POLAND
description: ''This is the end. Farewell,'' Capt. Zygmunt Pawlaczyk radioed seconds before his Ilyushin 62M jet slammed into a piney grove, killing him and the 182 other people it was to have carried to New York on Saturday.

title: FOUR-STAR BLACK PIONEER
description: Gen. Daniel (Chappie) James Jr., whom President Reagan honored yesterday at the dedication of an aerospace and science center at Tuskegee University, was the first black four-star General of the Air Force.

title: OPEA NEWS EDITOR AND CRITIC
description: Robert M. Jacobson, the editor of Opera News magazine, died Saturday night at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THOMAS KEEPS PROMISE TO MOM
description: IN April 1981, Isiah Thomas, with some trepidation, told his mother that he planned to leave college. Mary Thomas, who raised nine children alone in a Chicago ghetto, protested. Isiah knew it was her dream that he, her youngest child, should earn a college degree, and become the first of her boys to do so.

title: TARIFF CUT ON PARTS DRAWS FIRE
description: A new trade dispute is beginning to stir emotions in Congress.

title: Sybao B. Cheng Wed To William Wilson 3d
description: The Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Sybao B. Cheng and William W. Wilson 3d. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony.

title: CELTICS EDGE BUCKS IN SECOND OVERTIME
description: Don Nelson, the Milwaukee Bucks' coach, described today's 3-hour-7-minute double overtime game against the Celtics as ''a big one for the stars and the average players.''

title: Young Students, Old Truths
description: In 1953, I was a student at Harvard College, determined to get decent grades even though my fellow students and I were spending much of our time in front of a TV set, riveted by the Army-McCarthy hearings. Those of us who shared the searing experience of McCarthyism are sensitized today to the strain of sharing civil liberties with those with whom we deeply disagree. But have we failed to communicate that lesson to today's students?

title: Man Fatally Shot on S.I.
description: A 37-year-old man was found shot in his Staten Island apartment yesterday and died later at Staten Island Hospital, the police said. The victim, Edward Camera, had been shot twice in the head with a small-caliber gun. Mr. Camera was unconscious when he was discovered slumped on the floor of his second-floor apartment at 208 Atlantic Avenue in the Grant City section, the police said. Several guns and a pipe bomb were found in the apartment and the police said the shooting might be drug related.

title: SETON HALL IS A POWERFUL TOURNEY CHOICE
description: LEAD: LAST week, when Seton Hall defeated Brooklyn College, 21-0, it marked the 500th career victory for Mike Sheppard (the most ever by a metropolitan area coach). There were gifts of champagne and flowers, congratulatory messages from Vice President Bush and Governor Kean - and even a respite from the midweek rain to go with the team's thunderstorm of runs.

title: O.E.C.D. TOPICS: GROWTH AND DOLLAR
description: When the economic and finance ministers of 24 industrial nations gather here this week, they will have three pressing matters on their minds: the slowdown in economic growth, the plummeting dollar and growing strains on world trade.

title: 2 EXPERIMENTAL CANCER THERAPIES APPROVED
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved expanded use of two experimental therapies for patients with advanced kidney and skin cancers.

title: JEWS' FATE UNMARKED IN SOVIET-RULED REGION
description: Until the German Army came in World War II, this city, Lvov and Uzhgorod were important centers in the belt of Jewish settlement that grew in the late Middle Ages in the plains and foothills on both flanks of the Carpathian Mountains.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the first day of the new campaign.'' - William Daley, political director for Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. [ B6:1. ]

title: SCRUTINIZING THE LEGACY OF ROBERT MOSES
description: It is a measure of the force of Robert Moses that he left such an expansive legacy to be judged. It is a measure of his methods that the judgment is not settled, that partisans' blood can still be brought to boil two decades after the master builder stopped building.

title: Marriott's Sales Goals
description: J .W. Marriott Jr., chairman of the Marriott Corporation, which operates hotels and restaurants, said Friday that he expected this year's sales to climb to $6 billion, from last year's $5.3 billion. He also told shareholders at the annual meeting that the Bethesda, Md., company's stated goal, to increase its profits at a 20 percent annual rate for the next five years, was realistic. The company last year earned $191.7 million. ''We believe 1987 will be a good year for the company over all, and will benefit increasingly from recent acquisitions, internal expansion, strong domestic travel and more foreign visitors to America,'' he said.

title: Zulu Leader Warns Of White Junta Rule
description: The Zulu leader, Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, suggested today that South Africa might be headed for rule by a white military junta, which he said would result in more repression and more black anger.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MAY 11, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 The trial of Klaus Barbie in France is due to begin. The trial, taking place more than 40 years after his alleged crimes as a Gestapo lieutenant, has absorbed the French like few other recent events. Page A1 Israeli efforts for a peace conference in the Middle East have caused a split in the country between demonstrators demanding Government attendance and hard-liners who oppose the conference. A1 Soviet diplomacy in the Middle East could restore Moscow's influence in the region. The Soviet Union has launched a series of diplomatic moves to reach out to moderate Arab countries and to Israel. A1 Beirut's central airport reopened after being closed for 98 days, but higher insurance premiums that are adding $200 to the cost of a ticket may stop many Lebanese from using the international airport. A3 Possible lying in the contra affair is being checked in a review of Congressional testimony of some Government officials. It is being made by Lawrence E. Walsh, the special prosecutor. A1 In the Philippines, voting began for a new legislature that will restore the country's democratic institutions and limit presidential powers. Delays were expected as voters faced write-in ballots with 25 blank spaces. A3 Low attendance in English churches has become common. It has fallen to among the lowest in avowedly Christian countries. ''The Church of England is largely in the position of an historical hangover,'' one Bishop said. A4 Polish officials hailed the pilot of the airliner that crashed Saturday as a hero for veering the troubled aircraft into an uninhabited wood, avoiding a populated area. The investigation of the accident's cause continued. A5 A musicians' underground is taping and releasing music on cassettes, selling them in a network that extends across several countries. The freedom and low cost have encouraged thousands to do recordings themselves. C13 Ties to west at issue in Malta A3 Brazil's street children: New attempt at rescue A6 Jews' fate unmarked in land lost to Soviet A10 NATIONAL

title: Dr. Pamela Grich Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Dr. Pamela Louise Grich, a resident in internal medicine at the Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia, to Dr. Louis Israel Fink, a fellow in cardiology at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, took place yesterday at the Wharton Sinkler Estate in Philadelphia. The Rev. William McGown, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Mayer Selekman performed the ceremony.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: By C. Gerald Fraser

title: AS THE TRIAL OF BARBIE BEGINS, FRANCE ALSO IS BEING JUDGED
description: The Rue Sainte-Catherine in Lyons is one of those European locations that exist in infamy.

title: WITH GLITTER AND GLAMOUR, HOUSTON HAILS OPERA HOUSE
description: If Houston is now enduring troubled economic times, there was little evidence of it Saturday night. Nearly all of the city's elite was out in force in their Rolls-Royces and limousines, the women in designer gowns, the men in black tie.

title: Freedom Summer
description: To the Editor:

title: A Double Whammy of Volatility
description: ''We sometimes lose sight of the potential risks in our haste to create new products,'' one investment banker said last week. ''What happened to Merrill is a warning signal.''

title: Vintage French Films By Renoir and Godard
description: Two vintage films by Jean Renoir and one by Jean-Luc Godard are being shown through May 28 at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: SOVIET ACTS ON SEVERAL FRONTS TO REBUILD MIDEAST INFLUENCE
description: The Soviet Union has begun a series of diplomatic moves in the Middle East that appear aimed at restoring its influence in the region, which has suffered since President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt expelled Soviet military advisers 15 years ago.

title: Accounts
description: * The New York Mercantile Exchange to McCann Direct.

title: Freedom Behind Bars
description: The Angolite, a bimonthly magazine published at the state penitentiary at Angola, La., has long spoken with special authority on crime and punishment in America. One reason for its strength has been the unusual talents of its editors, Wilbert Rideau and Billy Sinclair, both serving long terms for murder.

title: IN DIVORCE, VITAL ROLE OF PARENTS
description: WHEN older parents watch an adult child struggling through the anguish and upheaval of a divorce, they want to help. ''But too often those parents do nothing at all or end up doing the wrong thing because they don't understand what is needed,'' said Dr. Elena K. Lesser, an assistant professor of psychiatry.

title: Porpoises, Permits and Japan
description: Each year Japan sends a fleet to U.S. waters to fish for salmon. In the process, porpoises become entangled and die in nylon nets that are invisible to their sonar. A permit that allows this ''incidental'' catch is up for renewal. The Commerce Department should allow the Japanese some leeway despite the objections of conservationists. The porpoises are in no danger of extinction, and denying the permit would run against other U.S. interests.

title: ERROR-PRONE METS SWEPT BY BRAVES
description: After all their shoddy play in the recent days and weeks, the Mets finally came upon a game that could have been an inspiration.

title: FLYERS LEAD BY 3-1 OVER CANADIANS
description: Methodical as ever, the Flyers commenced their dissection of the Canadiens tonight by plaguing the goaltender, Patrick Roy, and providing their own goalie, Ron Hextall, with the type of coverage that has helped him play unblemished hockey.

title: SUPERCONDUCTORS CROSS BIG BARRIER
description: Scientists have found a way to send enormous electric currents through newly discovered superconducting materials, overcoming the most important remaining technical barrier to applications ranging from high-speed computers to high-power magnets.

title: COUPLES TAKES NELSON ON 3D EXTRA HOLE
description: Fred Couples, who hadn't won in three years, parred the third hole of a sudden-death playoff today to beat Mark Calcavecchia and capture the $600,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: SEIDMAN MOVE WIDENS FINANCIAL ADVISER ROLE
description: The recent establishment by Seidman & Seidman/BDO of a separate organization for financial planning could mark a breakthrough of accountants into the proliferating planning business.

title: FOCUS IN CREDIT MARKETS SHIFTS TO ECONOMIC DATA
description: Attention in the credit markets this week will shift to economic data, which economists hope will provide some clues to the future performance of the dollar and interest rates.

title: Chief Obafemi Awolowo Dies; A Nigeria Nationalist Leader
description: Chief Obafemi Awolowo, a founding father of Nigerian nationalism, died Saturday in his hometown of Ikenne in Ogun state. He was 78 years old.

title: The U.N. Today: May 11, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Aristech Chemical Corp., Pittsburgh, appointed Charles W. Hamilton Jr. senior vice president-planning and business development.

title: Patenting the Worm at Our Civilization's Heart Expedited Breeding
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridgeport
description: At the graduation ceremony at the University of Bridgeport in Connecticut yesterday, 1,356 students received bachelor's degrees.

title: GOMEZ TOPS NOAH IN FINAL, 6-4, 7-6, 7-6
description: If points were given for style, Yannick Noah and Andres Gomez might still be on the stadium court at Forest Hills, trying to determine the winner of the Shearson Lehman Brothers Tournament of Champions.

title: BEHIND THE SCENES AT THE GOETZ TRIAL: A FIERCE LEGAL BATTLE OVER A WITNESS
description: Behind the scenes and unknown to the jury, a furious and far-reaching legal debate is being waged as the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz enters its third week.

title: Helping Guatemala and Others
description: When the elected civilian President of Guatemala, Vinicio Cerezo, visits the White House later this week, President Reagan is likely to take the occasion to comment on the great advances of democratic government in Latin America. Yet it should also be the occasion for attention to the weakness of most of the new democracies in dealing with their own armed forces.

title: Nancy Liebermann Marries Fellow Lawyer, J. A. Godles
description: Nancy Helen Liebermann, an associate at Linowes & Blocher, and Joseph Alexander Godles, a partner in Goldberg & Spector, both Washington law firms, were married yesterday in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: QUEST FOR A MIDEAST PEACE PARLEY BRINGS DISQUIET TO A DIVIDED ISRAEL
description: Israel got a small taste tonight of the domestic price of an international peace conference.

title: Business and the Law; Copyrights On Software
description: ByFLECTING the growing uncertainty about the boundaries of copyright law, the chief lawyer for the Copyright Office has asked the agency to re-examine its rules protecting certain computer technology.

title: Energy Ministers to Gather
description: Western energy ministers meet here Monday to review their preparedness for an energy crisis amid signs of a long-term tightening in the world oil market.

title: SHOP-AT-HOME PROGRAM FAILS TO SHOW AND TELL
description: It seemed an irresistible idea: a television show combining the fevered allure of the home-shopping craze with the proven appeal of the traditional talk-show format. If it caught on, the thinking went, it could be the most profitable use of the public airwaves ever contrived.

title: WALSH SAID TO STUDY OFFICIALS' TESTIMONY ON HELP FOR CONTRAS
description: Lawrence E. Walsh, the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, is studying Congressional testimony by current and former Reagan Administration officials to see if they lied about aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, according to Federal investigators.

title: Sadamichi Hirasawa Is Dead; Was on Death Row 32 Years
description: Sadamichi Hirasawa, believed to have been on death row longer than any other prisoner in the world, died today of pneumonia in a medical detention center in suburban Hachioji, a hospital official said. Mr. Hirasawa was 95 years old.

title: John M. Leavens, 80, New York Budget Critic
description: John M. Leavens, a former executive director of the Citizens Budget Commission, one of New York City's longstanding municipal watchdog groups, died of congestive heart failure while being taken to a hospital in Naples, Fla., last Tuesday. He was 80 years old and lived in Naples.

title: EXPERTS WATCH SURROGACY LAW DEBATE
description: Attempts by the New York State Legislature to regulate surrogate motherhood are being watched by legal experts and adoption officials across the country as a likely indication of how such efforts will fare nationwide.

title: Iowa Votes Higher Speed
description: The Iowa Legislature approved a bill Saturday raising the speed limit to 65 miles an hour on most Interstate highways. Gov. Terry E. Branstad has said he would sign the measure.

title: BROWN HEAVYWEIGHTS WIN SPRINT TITLE
description: Brown University won the featured varsity heavyweight race in the 42d annual Eastern Sprint Championships, capturing the Worcester Bowl in a wide-open final.

title: PIANO: EDWARD AUER RECITAL
description: Listening to Edward Auer play the piano at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night, one felt - for better and for worse - in the presence of a gentleman. Mr. Auer is a musician, in other words, who uses his considerable powers with discretion. The Stravinsky Serenade in A had a certain neutrality, an almost ''senza espressione'' feeling that suited the music's tart but gracious quality quite well.

title: OLAJIDE IS WINNER BUT IT'S NO TUNEUP
description: Troy Darrell was supposed to be a mere tuneup for Michael Olajide, who is scheduled to fight for the International Boxing Federation middleweight crown this summer.

title: Patenting the Worm at Our Civilization's Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: SPAIN IS HOLDING U.S. PHOTOGRAPHER
description: Nine months after he graduated cum laude from Syracuse University and two months before he was to report as a second lieutenant in the United States Army, Conan David Owen found himself in a Spanish jail, accused of being part of an international drug ring.

title: GCA CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''This election is about saving our country from industrial decline, social division and the destruction of community services.'' - Neil Kinnock, the Labor leader. [ A1:2. ]

title: TO PROTEST APARTHEID, SMITHSONIAN WILL SELL STOCKS
description: The Smithsonian Institution decided today to sell its $27 million in holdings in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: RUSTY PELICAN RESTAURANT reports earnings for Qtr to April 12
description: b-Net loss and the yer-ago 9 months includes an accounting change loss of $176,000.

title: AIDS: QUESTIONS OF VIRULENCE
description: A BRITISH report that variations in an inherited protein may influence individual susceptibility to the AIDS virus has put the spotlight on one of the puzzles of the epidemic - why the virus behaves so differently in different people. Scientists suspect that further research on genetic factors will provide rich insights.

title: Nations Trim I.M.F. Debt
description: Poor countries are paying back more to the International Monetary Fund than they are getting in new loans, and the difference rose sharply to about $1.69 billion in the first quarter. In the first quarter of last year the net payback was about $226 million.

title: MACROCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company had no revenue for the year-ago periods.

title: CLASS OF '87: A SUMMING UP
description: WITHIN the next four weeks, almost one million young men and women will graduate from college and cease being students. About 400,000 will get master's, professional and Ph.D. degrees to become doctors, lawyers, business executives, college teachers or researchers.

title: CAROLINA MOUNTAIN HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: WHITE HOUSE OFFERS ITS VIEW OF REAGAN ROLE ON CONTRAS
description: The White House moved today to explain what President Reagan knew of efforts to secure private aid for the Nicaraguan rebels and insisted that the President had not engaged in illegal activities.

REGENCY CRUISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Bonds of 1896 Vex Burlington
description: Bonds issued in 1896 for the Northern Pacific Railway are still a contentious subject for executives at Burlington Northern Inc.
