description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Nuclear Agency Takes Safety Seriously
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCTORS GAIN RIGHTS IN MEDICARE EVALUATIONS
description: The Reagan Administration has agreed to give doctors substantially more procedural protections before suspending them from the Medicare program for violations of professional health-care standards, Federal officials said today.

title: MICHAEL ANTHONY JEWELERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ADVERTISINGBurger King Plans A Review
description: BURGER KING, the giant hamburger chain that has used J. Walter Thompson as its agency since 1974, announced yesterday that it planned to open up a competition for its account.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MAY 12, 1987
description: COMPANIES Burlington Industries will pay $80 a share for up to eight million shares of its common stock and explore a restructuring to benefit the remaining shares. It was Burlington's latest initiative to frustrate the hostile $67-a-share tender offer by a group that includes Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile. [ D1. ] Thomas A. Cooper resigned as BankAmerica's president. The resignation, which was not a surprise, apparently stems from conflicts with the company's chairman, A. W. Clausen. According to BankAmerica executives, Mr. Cooper found it difficult to exercise his authority and saw his responsibilities being eroded. [ D1. ] Baxter Travenol will acquire Caremark for about $528 million in a stock swap. The purchase of the California company will enable Baxter, the nation's leading hospital supply company, to expand into the fast-growing area of home-care treatment. [ D1. ] Chrysler is changing its parts manufacturing division into a subsidiary called Acustar Inc., which will emphasize sales to companies outside the Chrysler organization. The unit made a pretax profit of $250 million last year, Chrysler disclosed. [ D5. ] Lomas & Nettleton will acquire Equitable Life Leasing from a subsidiary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. The price, which may be adjusted, is $1 million in cash and $288.1 million in Lomas common and convertible preferred stock. [ D5. ] Shares of Texaco and Pennzoil surged again as speculation grew that the two companies are close to settling their protracted legal dispute or that some corporate raiders are trying to maneuver one or both of the companies into a takeover situation. [ D5. ] The A. H. Robins Company revised its $1.75 billion proposal for compensating women who say they were injured by the company's Dalkon Shield contraceptive device. [ D8 ] . Burger King plans to hold a competition for its advertising. The incumbent agency, J. Walter Thompson, said it would compete to retain the account, which has a budget of about $190 million. [ D24. ] MARKETS Futures prices for wheat, corn and soybeans soared, fueled by poor spring planting weather and rising sales of wheat to the Soviet Union. The sharp rises unleashed fears of higher inflation, and prices of virtually every food and industrial raw material rose. The 2.7 percent gain in the Commodity Research Bureau index of futures prices was the largest one-day rise since Aug. 13, 1974. [ D1. ] Bond prices slumped as market participants were discouraged by the rise in commodity prices. Early in the day, Treasury bond prices had risen modestly, but the growing fear of higher inflation soon dominated credit market trends. [ D23. ] The Dow Jones industrial average retreated 15, to 2,307.30, after a gain of almost 45 points was wiped out. One analyst blamed bad news from the bond market for the ''bloodbath'' and said the decline had been accelerated by computer program selling. [ D12. ] The dollar inched upward before retreating in Tokyo. Gold rose $1.25 an ounce in the U.S., to $455.50, after weakening abroad. [ D26. ] THE ECONOMY Hundreds of U.S. companies could face retaliation overseas, the Administration warned, if U.S. ''dumping'' penalties are increased. The chemical industry could be especially vulnerable. [ D5. ] The White House urged an increase in the national debt ceiling before Friday, although legislative strategists say they do not have the votes to assure passage of such a measure. [ D15. ] INTERNATIONAL Egypt announced a reform of its currency exchange rate in the hope of satisfying I.M.F. requirements for assistance in repaying its $38.6 billion foreign debt. [ D11. ] The Smithsonian Institution decided to sell about $27 million worth of stock in companies that do business in South Africa. [ A6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A new blood test for cancers is being marketed by a Boston University School of Medicine biochemistry professor who developed it. Business and Health. [ D2. ] The London Stock Exchange has reached a record high, which experts say reflects an endorsement of Prime Minister Thatcher's policies and high hopes for her re-election. Market Place. [ D12. ]

title: RAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $8,390. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $146,711 and $190,263 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Bosworth Enters N.F.L. Draft
description: Brian Bosworth, the all-American linebacker who likes to do the unexpected, yesterday did the expected by saying he would enter the National Football League's supplemental draft.

title: THE HART LEGACY: HE BROKE DEMOCRATS' LINK WITH POLITICS OF NEW DEAL
description: Gary Hart's departure from the Presidential race has broken a link between the politics of the 1960's and the politics of the late 1980's.

title: TOFUTTI BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
Ford Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had increased the cash allowance alternative on its cars and extended its buyer-incentive program until June 8, from May 9. It said buyers of all 1986 and 1987 models of the Taurus and Sable now had a choice of a $500 cash allowance or a 3.9 percent to 9.9 percent annual percentage rate financing. As part of the program, which took effect Sunday, a choice of a $600 cash allowance or the low-rate financing terms has been added for the 1987 Merkur XR4TI.

title: FOR COMPULSIVE GAMBLERS, INSIDER HELP
description: When a compulsive gambler from out of state sits shivering in his car all night in Atlantic City, broke, hungry and - because he is out of gasoline -cold, chances are he will soon be talking to Arnie Wexler.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing With a Twist Wins: With a Twist got up in the stretch drive and posted a half-length victory in the $45,000 Mom's Command purse for fillies and mares at least 3 years old yesterday at Belmont Park. Mrs. Beeton was the runner-up, two lengths ahead of Cherokee Chill. The victory was the first in eight starts this year for With a Twist, the 4-year-old daughter of Fappiano-Flashy Twist, who earned $24,000 for the Centennial Farm. She covered the mile and a sixteenth under Jerry Belmonte in 1:45, and returned $11.20, $3.60 and $3 for $2 across the board. Mrs. Beeton paid $2.60 and $2.40, and Cherokee Chill was $4.60 to show. Water Polo United States Beats Spain: James Bergeson scored with 45 seconds remaining to give the United States an 8-7 victory over Spain yesterday at the men's water polo World Cup tournament in Salonica, Greece. Italy, which was undefeated, took sole possession of first place in the eight-team, round-robin tournament at the Poseidonion swimming pool by beating Cuba, 10-9. West Germany, the defending World Cup champion, tied Yugoslavia, the world champion, 12-12, while the Soviet Union routed Greece, 11-4. The United States team, which finished fourth at last year's world championships in Madrid, registered its first victory at the tournament on a pair of last-second goals - one by Mike Evans, whose score gave the Americans a 7-6 lead, and the other by Bergeson.(AP)

title: SUPRADUR COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed its increase in sales primarily to the September 1986 acquisition of Twin City Tool Co.

title: STAGE: LINNEY'S 'HEATHEN VALLEY' IN PHILADELPHIA
description: The interrelationship of God, man and the land is at the heart of many of Romulus Linney's plays. Drawn with a specific regard for geography and character, they are often tales of elemental passion. Mr. Linney's characters are shaped - and entrapped - by their environment and by an atavistic attachment to the rituals of their past, as in ''Heathen Valley,'' the playwright's compelling dramatization of his first novel. The play, directed by the author, is the third work in the spring series at the Philadelphia Festival Theater for New Plays.

title: Hodel Blunders as He Squanders
description: If James G. Watt were still Secretary of the Interior, he couldn't have done much worse than Secretary Donald P. Hodel has done in recent weeks. Except for differences in decibel level, the two have faithfully followed the identical policy of squandering the nation's natural resources for presumed short-term gains.

The equity accounting pre-tax losses for the latest 6 months totaled $3,247,000, compared with $1,546,000 for the year-ago period.

title: FRANCE OPENS BARBIE'S TRIAL ON ROLE IN NAZI CRIMES
description: Klaus Barbie, the wartime Gestapo chief of Lyons, went on trial here today for crimes against humanity as Jews and others here commemorated victims of Nazi genocide.

description: b-Includes a $42.5 million writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: NOW, TAX REVISION IN SWEDEN
description: The global push for cutting tax rates, spanning ideological boundaries, has come even to Sweden, home of the world's highest taxes.

title: 'USEFUL' MODES OF THINKING CONTRIBUTE TO THE POWER OF PREJUDICE
description: IN SEEKING to understand the tenacity of prejudice, researchers are turning away from an earlier focus on such extreme racism as that exhibited by members of the Ku Klux Klan to examine the pernicious stereotypes among people who do not consider themselves prejudiced.

Harriette Ann Gray, Dancer and Educator
description: Harriette Ann Gray, a dance educator, choreographer and dancer, died in Columbia, Mo., on April 20. She was 73 years old.

description: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation, the country's biggest independent mortgage banking institution, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Equitable Life Leasing Corporation from a subsidiary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

description: FINANCIAL planning for middle managers is ''the hottest area going'' in the field of employee benefits, according to George Barbee. This planning, he said, might be described as ''a timely action to cut the stress of staff reductions.''

title: 2 MORE CHARGED IN QUEENS ARSON AT FOSTER HOME
description: A leader of the effort to keep New York City from opening an infants' foster home in an unoccupied house in Queens was charged yesterday with being part of a group of residents who set fire to the house last month.

title: Lost on Campus: Minority Momentum
description: After growing for 20 years, the number of black college students has stagnated in the last four years; in many schools, the proportion is dropping. These are disturbing declines that call for university administrators to renew their commitment to diversity and for black leaders to reemphasize the importance of education.

title: DDB Needham Change In Operating Procedure
description: DDB Needham New York, like most ad agencies, has run its business with the traditional account group system under which account executives of various grades served as liaison with the clients.

title: A BEAM OF PROTONS ILLUMINATES GUTENBERG'S GENIUS
description: THE birth of modern printing four centuries ago is cloaked in obscurity, but with the help of the cyclotron used to develop the atomic bomb, scientists are wresting long-forgotten secrets from Gutenberg Bibles and other antique documents to reconstruct the technology of the Renaissance. In cooperation with scholars at New York City's Pierpont Morgan Library and elsewhere, a group of researchers at the Davis campus of the University of California has learned that Johann Gutenberg of Mainz, Germany, was an even greater inventor and innovator than historians had known.

title: DOROTHEA OPPENHEIMER
description: Dorothea Oppenheimer, a New York literary agent, died of cancer Thursday at New York Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Emory University
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, told Emory University graduates today that the United States should not blame Japan and other countries for its trade deficit.

title: Hart's Book
description: Gary Hart's Presidential campaign may be over, but his unofficial campaign book, ''One Man's Luck: A Brief Glimpse at the Life and the Ideas of Gary Hart,'' is still scheduled for publication this fall by William Morrow & Company. The book is part personal reminiscence and part excerpts from speeches. Odetta Davis, a Morrow spokesman, said the original publication date, Sept. 16, stands.

title: Puritan Fashions Regains President
description: Andrew Rosen was president of the Puritan Fashions Corporation when he was 26 years old, but when the company was taken over in 1983 by Calvin Klein Industries, Mr. Rosen lost the post and was made head of a Puritan unit. Now he has come full circle, and at the age of 30, has bounced back as president of Puritan.

title: MOTTA IS NOT READY TO JUMP AT AN OFFER
description: Dick Motta, the latest entry on the Knicks' ever-growing list of coaching candidates, said he has as many questions for Richard Evans, as the Knick president will undoubtedly have for him when the two men get together this week.

description: Grain and soybean prices soared yesterday, fueled by a potent combination of poor spring planting weather and rising sales of wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: SMITHSONIAN ACTS TO ACQUIRE INDIAN MUSEUM IN NEW YORK
description: The Smithsonian Institution today took a major step toward acquiring the collection of the Museum of the American Indian in Manhattan and moving it to the Mall here.

title: Giants Sign 18
description: The Giants have signed 18 free agents, including Wayne Haddix of Liberty Baptist, a cornerback who was impressive in two postseason bowl games. The 6-foot, 200-pound Haddix played in the Senior Bowl and the Blue-Gray games. The Giants also signed Lewis Bennett of Florida A&M and Shelton Boyer of Clemson, wide receivers; Jeff Smith of Tennessee-Knoxville and Charles Coleman of Alcorn State, tight ends; Robert DiRico of Kutztown State, Adrian Wright of Virginia Union and Darren Goode of Elon, running backs; Curtis Struyk of East Carolina, guard; Jim Crociccha of Penn,quarterback, and Dana Moore of Southern Mississippi, who once played with several United States Football League teams, punter. On defense, the Giants signed Dwight Bingham of Mississippi and William Colley of Virginia Union, defensive ends; Toney Catchings of Cincinnati, Leonard Jackson and Warren Thompson, both of Oklahoma State, as linebackers, and Chris Servais of North Dakota State and Doug Smith of Ohio State as defensive backs.

title: AFTER 17 YEARS, CICADAS PREPARE FOR THEIR ROARING RETURN
description: THROUGHOUT the East, from Georgia to Long Island and westward to Illinois, the Rip van Winkles of the insect world are about to emerge from the subterranean bedrooms they have continuously occupied for the last 17 years.

title: Candidate Seen For S.E.C. Post
description: William von Raab, the head of the United States Customs Service, is being considered for the post of chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, an aide of Mr. von Raab confirmed today.

title: ANECO REINSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized gains of $72,640 and $641,958 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively; and the year-earlier period also includes a gain of $1,971,537 from transactions involving the sale of loss reserves.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Candy Maldonado, who hit five home runs and batted .419 for the San Francisco Giants for the period ending Sunday, was named National League player of the week. Maldonado also knocked in 10 runs, scored 11 runs and had four doubles during the week. He hit safely in all seven of the Giants' games and had a .455 on-base percentage. . . . Kevin McHale, the Boston forward who sprained his right ankle on the last play of the Celtics' N.B.A. playoff victory Sunday over the Milwaukee Bucks, said yesterday that he expected to play in the next game. ''I'm going to play Wednesday night,'' he said after practice, ''unless something happens between now and Wednesday.''

title: North and South California Rattled by Mild Earthquakes
description: A mild earthquake struck near Big Bear Lake in the San Bernardino Mountains today, setting off security alarms but causing no damage, just hours after a different quake rattled Oakland in northern California.

title: SPIRITUAL GO-BETWEENS: NEW CHANNEL FOR ADVICE
description: In California these days, consumers can consult a reincarnated ''spirit'' for as little as $10 or as much as $1,500 an hour. Hundreds, possibly thousands, do so each week.

title: TUITIONS HIT NEW PEAK, IGNITING A BITTER DEBATE
description: With tuition continuing to rise twice as fast as inflation, a national debate is intensifying over whether a college education costs too much.

title: THATCHER CALLS JUNE 11 ELECTIONS, BUOYED BY A BIG LEAD IN THE POLLS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today called a general election for June 11, a year ahead of schedule, and thus tied her political fortunes to an improving economy and her rising position in public-opinion polls.

title: Correction
description: A music review on Thursday of ''Sounds From the Left Bank,'' a concert of new music at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, misstated the program's sponsorship. The sponsor was the Queens Symphony, not the Queens Philharmonic.

title: DANCE: MARK MORRIS
description: ROLAND BARTHES explores the mythic underpinnings of everyday rituals in ''Mythologies,'' finding signs and symbols in the most ordinary of experiences. Three of his essays served as inspiration for Mark Morris's ''Mythologies,'' an evening of recent dances presented by the Mark Morris Dance Group on Friday at the Manhattan Center's Grand Ballroom. But Mr. Morris, though a master of the kind of telling exaggeration about which the French semiologist writes, reverses the process of Barthes's exploration. In collaboration with his impressive dancers and Herschel Garfein, a composer, he constructs a world of inseparable spectacle and symbol.

title: LOTTERY MAY BRING NOTHING FOR KNICKS
description: The National Basketball Association will stage its third lottery Sunday among the seven teams that failed to make the playoffs to decide the first seven picks in the draft. The Knicks will be a participant for the third time, but they may not get one of the top seven players.

description: Church's Fried Chicken Inc. said it had rejected a takeover overture valued at almost $470 million from an investment group that includes a former Church's executive.

Lincoln Hometown Voting Today on Black Rights
description: Here in the hometown of Abraham Lincoln, a city which everywhere boasts the name of the Great Emancipator, no black has ever won a city office. Indeed, the form of government here has virtually insured against it.

title: 2 MUSICALS LEAD TONY NOMINATIONS
description: Two musicals, both British imports, led the nominations for this year's Tony Awards, which were announced yesterday. ''Me and My Girl'' received 13 nominations and ''Les Miserables'' received 12.

title: Allied Division Loses Its Chief
description: Frank W. Harvey has retired as chairman and chief executive of Maas/Jordan Marsh, the Allied Stores Corporation's division based in Florida. He has been succeeded by Donald F. Dunn, Allied's senior vice president for profit development.

title: 'We're Becoming A Bland Society'
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., a former Senator from Tennessee who recently abandoned a plan to run for President so as to become President Reagan's chief of staff, was in a reflective mood here the other day. Sitting in his quiet corner looking out on the flowering White House lawn, he talked about the current turmoil in the capital. Following are some excerpts from the conversation: Q. Tell me what you see of America these days. Let's begin with character. Is it worse than before, or are we reporting it in a different way? A. I've been around Washington a long time. I was a volunteer lawyer for Ray Jenkins, reviewing documents and the like, on the McCarthy Committee. My father was in Congress (1951-63), so I've had a long view of this city.

description: Ting-Yung Hang, a former editor in chief and publisher of The China Tribune in New York, died of cancer Saturday at Parsons Hospital in Queens. He was 79 years old and lived in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Broadhurst's House
description: Mr. Broadhurst uses his Capitol Hill town house, where he and Mr. Hart had dinner with the two Miami women, to entertain extensively and often makes it available to members of Congress and business clients for receptions. Tomorrow the house will be the scene of a $500-a-head reception for Sammy Nunez, president of the Lousiana State Senate, who was an unsuccessful Democratic candidate in 1986 for the United States Senate. The fund-raising event, with the state's two Senators, J. Bennett Johnston and John B. Breaux, as hosts, is to help Mr. Nunez retire his campaign debt.

The 2,183 box seats were sold out at $4 each on Friday, and by late yesterday afternoon, more than 3,800 grandstand seats were sold for the 7 P.M. International League game against the Richmond Braves. The Tides usually average about 2,500 fans per game in the 6,100-seat Metropolitan Memorial Park, said Dave Rosenfield, the Tides' general manager. The 1985 National League Cy Young winner voluntarily took a drug test during spring training and it proved positive.

Neutron capture therapy, which requires the use of a nuclear research reactor, holds the first promise of prolonged survival for victims of the cancer, called high-grade astrocytoma, according to scientists working on the project. These patients now rarely survive more than a few years.

title: YOUNG DESIGNER PLEASES WITH EASY, SEXY CLOTHES
description: Twenty years ago, Barry Schwartz invested $10,000 in Calvin Klein's business and his friend Mr. Klein was on his way. Last spring, John Axelrod decided to back Carmelo Pomodoro in a sportswear concern. The investment was close to $2 million, but it is aleady beginning to pay off. The company, which shipped its first styles in August, expects to book $9 million its first year, and Mr. Pomodoro is already developing a following.

title: SURFACE IS STILL A W.C.T. ISSUE

But Forest Hills also has problems that have plagued the tournament for 10 years and eventually must be resolved to guarantee its future as part of the grand prix tour.

title: Subway Station Stagnation
description: Most of New York City's 463 subway stations need fixing badly; that was clear a decade ago. Funds are available to modernize 41 stations. But little has been accomplished and passengers must daily make their way through obstacle courses and filth. The missing ingredient is leadership, and that can only be supplied by David Gunn, president of the New York City Transit Authority.

title: Johncock Returns
description: Gordon Johncock, a two-time Indianapolis 500 winner, drove an Indy-car yesterday for the first time since retiring from auto racing two years ago. ''We're going to take it as it comes,'' he said after taking about a dozen laps in the Buick-powered March he hopes to place in the starting field for the May 24 Indy race. ''We've got all week to make changes as we need them. There's no rush,'' he said. Practice will continue on the two-and-a-half-mile oval through Friday, with the final two rounds of qualifications Saturday and Sunday. Fifteen of the 33 starting positions remain unfilled following last weekend's qualifying. Johncock received approval from race stewards to begin practice without taking a refresher test usually given to drivers who have been away from the speedway for several years. Johncock, the 50-year-old veteran of 254 Indy-car races, who won at Indianapolis in 1973 and 1982, is replacing Jim Crawford of Scotland in the American Racing Series entry. Crawford is recovering from severe leg injuries suffered when he crashed another Buick-March.

title: BURST OF GROWTH IN CHICAGO'S ART WORLD
description: For art lovers in Chicago, it's been a banner season. Last weekend they flocked to Navy Pier for the eighth annual Chicago International Art Exposition, one of the art world's best fairs. On Sunday, they got a look at the dazzlingly refurbished galleries of European art at the Art Institute of Chicago, the first stage of a more than $30 million building and renovation project. And several weeks ago, they toasted the opening of the Terra Museum of American Art, a promising new resource that gives downtown Chicago its third major art institution.

But on Wall Street, a late and stunning drop in blue-chip share prices turned a gain of almost 45 points in the Dow Jones industrial average into a 15-point loss, and it closed at 2,307.30.

title: Q&Q
description: Q. What are vitamins and how are they made? A. Vitamins are complex organic compounds that regulate the metabolism and functions of the body. They are found in minute quantities in food or synthesized in the body. Vitamins function as catalysts in many of the body's chemical reactions producing energy, hormones or chemical regulators. They are also needed to remove toxic substances, synthesize tissue and break down waste products and toxins. Scientists have divided vitamins into a fat-soluble group consisting of vitamins A, D, E and K, and a water soluble group with the various B vitamins, including thiamine and riboflavin. Most vitamins can be extracted from plants and animals, where they are concentrated in tissues that are most active metabolically. For example, vitamin A is heavily concentrated in the liver and viscera of most animals or is derived from carotene, a yellow plant pigment. A lack of this vitamin can result in night blindness, susceptibility to infections and degeneration of tissue. Scientists have learned to synthesize vitamins in the laboratory. Several microorganisms including yeasts can synthesize vitamins, especially those of the B complex. Commercial vitamin tablets contain small amounts of vitamins that have been added to a base.

title: Business and Health; A New Test For Cancers
description: IMAGINE a patient who has some symptoms of cancer, but whose physical examination and laboratory tests produce inconclusive results. Does the doctor order treatment or tell the patient to go home and try not to worry?

title: A LABORITE FRUSTRATED IN THE NORTH
description: There is a political machine here as well tempered as any product of the proud steel industry that has been suffering such an agonizing retreat across the eight years of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's incumbency.

title: ABC'S 'DUMB WAITER'
description: THE obvious question: What is a play like this doing in a place like commercial television? Tonight at 10 o'clock, ABC is presenting ''The Dumb Waiter,'' a one-acter by Harold Pinter. Of all contemporary playwrights, surely, Mr. Pinter is the one whose work is least likely to survive commercial interruptions. His plays are subtle, fragile, almost claustrophobic. Intrusions to sell cars or headache potions can only be disastrous. ABC - specifically, Gary Pudney, vice president in charge of specials - deserves applause for making the effort, decidedly daring in the context of network scheduling. But why not go all the way and simply cluster the commercials at the beginning and end of the hour?

title: Maryland Fills Post
description: Lew Perkins, the former athletic director at Wichita State, was named athletic director of the University of Maryland. Perkins, 42, while praising Maryland and its athletes, admitted that the Terps' image has taken a beating since the cocaine-induced death of Len Bias last June. ''It's something we're going to have to address and something we're going to have to deal with,'' Perkins said at a news conference.

title: Gunman Gets Life Sentence In Quebec Legislature Attack
description: A former army corporal who sprayed machine-gun fire into the Quebec legislature in 1984, killing three people and wounding 13, was sentenced today to life imprisonment after pleading guilty to reduced charges of second degree murder.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE POEMS OF LINCOLN KIRSTEIN. 320 pages. Atheneum. $25.

title: ILL EFFECTS OF STEROIDS
description: Ill Effects of Steroids The use of anabolic steroid drugs in muscle building is a widespread practice among athletes and a subject of much controversy among health professionals. Important ill effects on health have been reported including damage to the liver, testes and other organs.

title: ULTIMATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Frontier Airlines Settlement Cleared
description: The Texas Air Corporation said that a bankruptcy court had approved a settlement proposed by its Continental Airlines subsidiary and the Allegis Corporation in the Frontier Airlines Inc. bankruptcy case. Frontier was acquired last year by People Express Inc., which in turn was acquired by Texas Air and merged into Continental. Allegis is the parent of United Airlines.

title: ACME STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Altschiller Gets Bowery
description: Altschiller Reitzfeld has become agency for the Bowery Savings Bank, which says it has a $4 million advertising budget. The previous agency, Ogilvy & Mather, resigned the account in March after 15 years. Remember Joe DiMaggio, the spokesman?

description: The Scott Paper Company, a leading American paper producer, is considering an investment in a tree plantation in the remote Irian Jaya province, Indonesia's Investment Coordinating Board said today.

description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., which has been making a big push to lure top talent to Prudential-Bache Capital Funding, its investment banking arm, said yesterday that it had hired Ralph O. Hellmold, a managing director and corporate restructuring specialist at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Home Loan Issues
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks will announce interest rates today for three new bond issues totaling $2.862 billion. About $1.092 billion of bonds will mature May 25, 1988, with $1.045 billion due May 25, 1990, and $725 million due May 26, 1992.

title: THE 99-WORD STATUTE THAT MAY TRIP OFFICIALS
description: Buried in the hundreds of pages of the Federal Criminal Code is a 99-word conspiracy statute that law enforcement officials say may become the principal legal instrument in unraveling the Iran-contra affair.

title: Peugeot Profits Rise
description: The French car group Peugeot S.A. increased its profits more than sixfold last year, helped by improved productivity and higher European sales. But the group nevertheless remained heavily in debt, its president, Jacques Calvet, said today. He told reporters that consolidated net profits soared to 3.59 billion francs ($600 million),from 543 million francs ($90 million) in 1985.

title: Northwest Job Cut
description: Northwest Airlines Inc. said it would eliminate 646 positions, about 1.9 percent of its work force, through attrition and layoffs beginning this week. The company said it hoped to rehire many of these employees later. Northwest said the job cuts were intended to help control costs in the face of pricing competition created by low-cost, nonunion airlines. The staff cuts will involve all management and non-management employees except pilots and flight attendants. After the cuts, Northwest will employ 33,781 people worldwide.

title: ONE PROMISING APPROACH
description: ONE of the most promising methods of breaking down prejudices in grade-school children, who are at an age when stereotypes are malleable, has built on the discovery that prejudices decline among students in interracial sports teams, bands or clubs. Such activities allow for the kinds of personal contacts that belie and change negative stereotypes.

title: MAKING THE DISC 'GROW
description: THERE are rows of chockablock file cabinets in the oversized room below my study where incoming hardware and software, among other things, are stowed until they make their way upstairs. Some of the file drawers haven't been opened in years. In their dark recesses can be found short stories, novels and travel pieces written ages ago. Still, someday I might need their contents, I tell myself, and so they remain.

title: CHARGES DISMISSED AGAINST PALESTINIAN SUPPORTERS
description: An immigration judge today dismissed charges by the Reagan Administration against eight immigrants it is seeking to deport on charges that they fostered Palestinian terrorism. The Government said afterward it had refiled identical charges.

title: Man Sentenced for Killing 6
description: A Browns Mill, N.J., man was sentenced to life in prison today for killing six people by running a red light with a stolen state police cruiser. Stephen G. Bolling, 26 years old, stole the cruiser, which a trooper had left running, and led troopers on a 11-mile chase that ended in Moorestown, witnesses testified. Mr. Bolling then ran a red light and rammed the cruiser into the victims' car. Killed were the driver, Janice E. Carmody of Levittown, Pa., and her sister, Frances E. Baldwin. Stephen M. Harriman, 35; his wife, Hope, 36; their 6-year-old son and 3-year-old daughter also died in the crash.

title: Maj. Gen. H.C. Parks Of U.N. Armistice Unit
description: Maj. Gen. Harlan C. Parks, retired, a former senior member of the United Nations Command for the Military Armistice Commission in Korea, died on May 4 of cancer in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old and lived in Juneau Beach, Fla.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Dear Pravda
description: In Russian, ''pravda'' means truth and ''izvestia'' means news, and the old joke about the Soviet press was that there's no truth in Pravda and no news in Izvestia. Now that truth and news are uncharacteristically cropping up in the Soviet media, the Russians are snatching up newspapers and magazines and eagerly watching television news that used to glaze their eyes.

The buyer of Revere, which is based in Wallingford, Conn., is Dobson Park Industries of Lancashire, England. Allied-Signal did not disclose the price.

title: Pressing On
description: Ralph Pollio and Rita Napolitano are not yet familiar names in the expanding world of college basketball, but the couple from West Hempstead, L.I., have pulled off a feat most devoted hoop fans only dream of: for more than a decade, they have written, edited and published their own regional basketball magazine. What began as a labor of small-team devotion has bloomed into a profitable, full-time enterprise. Eastern Basketball boasts more than 15,000 monthly subscribers and ads from such national sponsors as Nike, adidas, Alberto Culver and Miller Beer. ''It started in 1976,'' said Napolitano, who first considered starting the magazine after she lost her job on a television game show. ''In those days, all you saw in sports pages were stories about teams like U.C.L.A. and Notre Dame. No one wrote about teams that we followed: Manhattan, Fordham, Iona and St. John's.''

title: FUTURES LISTINGS EXPANDED

JAMES ANGLETON, COUNTERINTELLIGENCE FIGURE, DIES
description: James Angleton, the erudite Central Intelligence Agency officer whose search for Soviet agents inside the Government stirred an uproar in the murky worlds of intelligence for a generation, died here this morning of lung cancer. He was 69 years old, Mr. Angleton, who joined the C.I.A. at its inception in 1947, served for more than 20 years as head of its counterintelligence office. He was forced to resign his post in 1974 by William E. Colby, then Director of Central Intelligence, who had become convinced that Mr. Angleton's efforts were harming the agency.

title: Deliveryman Is Slain Outside L.I. Market
description: A newspaper deliveryman was shot and killed yesterday morning outside a supermarket, and the Nassau County police said the motive appeared to have been robbery.

title: Olivetti Head in Talks
description: The Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti is negotiating with a Spanish bank with a view to creating a joint investment concern to buy stakes in fast-growing Spanish companies, banking sources said today. Mr. de Benedetti is chairman of Italy's Olivetti group and head of his own independent finance group, Cofide. A spokesman for Banco Zaragozano, one of Spain's leading medium-sized banks, said talks between its chairman, Jose Ramon Alvarez Rendueles, a former governor of the Bank of Spain, and Mr. de Benedetti had been going on for more than a month.

The bonds are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by S.& P. Because of the sharp rise in interest rates in the last two months, yields were sharply higher than on Feb. 11 when the state offered $1.1 billion of bonds to refund outstanding debt. At that time, bonds backed only by the state's credit were offered with a maximum yield of 7.1 percent for bonds due in 2002.

description: A picture caption on the Washington Talk page May 4, with an article about Congressional hearings as a vehicle to prominence for little-known legislators, misidentified Charles P. Clark. He was a counsel to the committee investigating the National Defense Program, not a senator.

title: DANCE: 'LECONS DE TENEBRES' IN PARIS
description: Whether Paris is challenging New York as the dance capital of the world is a point worth pondering, given the current French dance explosion and the number of foreign companies that perform here regularly.

title: AFGHAN RULERS' DIVISIONS SAID TO PERSIST AND GROW
description: After nine years in power, the Soviet-backed Afghan Government reportedly remains torn by internal divisions that diplomats say have been aggravated by the stalemate in the war against the insurgents.

title: FARADYNE ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DURHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,962,000 and $1,057,000 for the latest quarter and year-ago period, respectively.

title: ABEL JUST
description: Abel Just, a New York lawyer, died Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Port Washington, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Sands Point, L.I.

title: Malta's New Leader: Tough and a Planner
description: Sixteen years of Socialist rule ended here today when Eddie Fenech Adami kissed a crucifix in the former Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Malta to become Prime Minister of this tiny Mediterranean island.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: KRISCH AMERICA INNS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company was incorporated May 1986 and went public October 1986.

title: OFFSHORE OIL PLAN DRAWS CRITICISM
description: Dixy Lee Ray, the marine biologist who was Governor of Washington from 1977 to 1981, is one of the few prominent people who supports a Federal plan to begin oil and gas exploration on the outer continental shelf in Northern California, Oregon, Washington and Alaska.

title: MINISTER WHOSE WIFE WAS BEATEN ENTERS DALLAS PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITAL
description: The Rev. Dr. Walker L. Railey, senior pastor of the First United Methodist Church in Dallas, has admitted himself to a psychiatric hospital in Dallas, a church spokesman said today.

title: Roadblocks to Start For Drunken Drivers
description: Bergen County officials said yesterday that they will use money confiscated during drug raids to pay for new roadblocks aimed at catching intoxicated drivers.

title: OFFICER SAID HE GAVE STOLEN DRUG MONEY TO CHARITY, TWO TESTIFY
description: A suspended New York City police officer told two psychiatrists that he gave to charity most of the $4,000 he is charged with stealing from drug dealers, the psychiatrists testified at his trial yesterday.

title: ESSEX COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in December 1986.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JAMES BOND PAID TRIBUTE ON ABC
description: THE fantastic James Bond is being paid rather ordinary tribute in ''Happy Anniversary 007,'' the hourlong compilation of film clips on ABC tonight at 9 o'clock. Being celebrated is what the subtitle refers to as ''25 Years of James Bond.'' More precisely, it's 25 years of the movie versions of the character who was created in a series of books by Ian Fleming. The first Bond movie, ''Dr. No,'' starring Sean Connery, was released in 1962, triggering a steady flow of sequels that have added up to over $1 billion in box office receipts. And in the beginning, remember, a movie ticket cost only about 50 cents.

title: EDGY WISTFULNESS FROM FLEETWOOD MAC
description: FLEETWOOD MAC'S exquisitely produced new album, ''Tango in the Night'' (Warner Brothers) is filled with ghostly voices and delicate folk-rock instrumentation all interwoven into the pop musical equivalent of a moody Gothic romance. ''Looking out for love In the night so still Oh I'll build you a kingdom In that house on the hill Thus begins Lindsey Buckingham's song, ''Big Love.'' The album's opening cut and first single (currently No. 7 on Billboard's Hot 100), ''Big Love'' establishes a mood of edgy, sophisticated wistfulness that runs through all 12 of the album's cuts.

title: TRIO-TECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the third quarter loss was caused principally by lower sales levels and extraordinary charges related to settlement of a lawsuit and the move to a new facility.

title: Metro-North Engineer Suspended for Drug Use
description: A Metro-North Commuter Railroad engineer involved in a train accident in the Bronx in February - but not the engineer who was said to have caused it - was suspended yesterday after drug tests indicated he had been using marijuana, said a railroad spokesman, Tito Davila.

title: Teamsters Trustee Is Selected by Judge
description: A Federal judge yesterday replaced the trustee he had named last June to run a Teamsters local in Union City, the first union convicted of violating Federal anti-racketeering laws.

title: 2 Infant Brothers Die in Brooklyn Fire
description: A 4-month-old boy and his 18-month-old brother were killed yesterday by a fire that started in the kitchen and swept through their Brooklyn home, the police said.

title: AON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: b-Includes securities gains of $719,000 in the latest quarter and $29,941,000 in the year-earlier period.

title: CONFEREES CONFIDENT OF COMPROMISE ON '88 BUDGET
description: Saying they did not expect their job to be difficult, House and Senate negotiators today began to work on a compromise budget for 1988.

title: WAVETECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PENTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shea Parachutist Draws Prison Term
description: It was a flight that captured the fancy of baseball fans last fall, but it landed Michael Sergio a six-month prison term and a $18,000 fine yesterday.

title: Lindsay Elected
description: It has been a while since anyone has written, ''John V. Lindsay was elected . . .'' But Mr. Lindsay was recently elected to a one-term term as president of the United States Association of Former Members of Congress.

title: Boutique Owner Says Hart Tryst Ruined Her
description: Lynn Armandt, the boutique owner who toured Washington and sailed to the Bahamas with Donna Rice, Gary Hart and his friend and political associate, William C. Broadhurst, says the past week ''has ruined my life.''

title: CROWN BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $144,000 and a charge of $1,100 from a share in the loss of an affiliate. Year-ago first quarter results do not include the results of Rokeach, which was acquired in July 1986. The company went public in February.

title: Bet Twice's Jockey Is Still High on Colt
description: Craig Perret had a unique view of the Kentucky Derby 10 days ago, because he spent the race crouched over Bet Twice's withers. To hear the jockey talk, though, it sounds as if he was in a different race from the one that the rest of the world was watching.

title: Clorox Bleach to End Spot TV Ads in Florida
description: The Clorox Company of Oakland, Calif., announced yesterday that, as the result of Florida's new tax law, which will include a tax on all national advertising coming into the state, it will cancel all spot TV advertising for its liquid bleach brands in Florida as of July 1.

title: THINGS TO AMUSE OR USE
description: 1. Playful Puppets Puppet fanciers will find an unusual and playful selection at the Children's Museum of Manhattan. The one shown here is an orange lobster with juicy-looking red claws for $12.95. Many other puppets are also available in the museum shop at 314 West 54th Street. 2. Bows for the Beach Adrienne Arundel's pretty denim bows promise that your hair will be chic at the beach in the summer. The bows come in all sorts of styles - on headbands or ponytail barrettes, in solids or stripes, with or without rhinestones. The ponytail bow shown here, in soft pale denim with rhinestones, is $35. At La Coupe, 694 Madison Avenue, between 62d and 63d Streets. Bows can also be made to order. 3. Opera-Shop Chic Where can a man find a stylish cotton sweater for $15? At Repeat Performance, the thrift shop that benefits the New York City Opera. The sweater shown here, with a Chaps-Ralph Lauren label, is part of a large collection of new sweaters ($15 each) and polo shirts ($8 each) acquired from a Fifth Avenue store. Repeat Performance is at 220 East 23d Street. 4. Burst of Color This ceramic vase from Loudwear is bursting with color: blue, orange, yellow, red, green, gray and slices of black, all on a white background. The vase, which costs $165, is handmade in Great Britain. In Chelsea Passage at Barneys New York, Seventh Avenue and 17th Street.

title: GOODEN PASSES A MINOR TEST
description: The starting pitcher emerged from the tunnel behind home plate 30 minutes before game time tonight, dressed in pinstripes, wearing the familiar No. 16, but with Tides instead of Mets written in script across the front of his uniform shirt.

title: CAPITOL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN OF DENER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Panel Proposes Ending A Small-Business Tax
description: About 29,000 small businesses would no longer pay New York City's unincorporated business tax and the general corporate income tax rate would be reduced to 8.85 percent from 9 percent under a proposal made yesterday by a city tax advisory panel.

title: GUATEMALAN ARMY YIELDS LITTLE POWER TO LEADER
description: After 16 months in office, President Vinicio Cerezo, who left for a four-day visit to Washington today, has not managed to wrest significant power from the army, in the view of diplomats and Guatemalan officials.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF BROOKSILLE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Toshiba-Motorola Joint Venture
description: The Toshiba Corporation and Motorola Inc. said their previously announced joint venture, the Tohuku Semiconductor Corporation, would invest 35 billion yen, or about $250 million, in a plant in northern Japan to make one megabit dynamic random access memory chips and eight- and 16-bit microprocessors. It will later expand to make four-megabit D-RAM's and 32-bit microprocessors.

title: NICOLET INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 17
description: b-Includes a gain of $36,000 from discontinued operations and a gain from the disposal of discontinued operations of $9,392,000. c-Net loss and includes a gain of $433,000 from discontinued operations. d-Includes a gain of $1,898,000 from discontinued operations.

title: LIFECORE BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations, net of income taxes, of $26,212,000 and $37,878,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. c-Net income

title: ZYGO CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSH'S JOB PROVES BLESSING AND CURSE
description: Eyeing the red carpet, the police escort, the long motorcade, the marching band and the curiosity seekers at a recent appearance by Vice President Bush in Mountain Grove, Mo., his campaign manager, Lee Atwater, said, ''This is why we're going to win.''

title: KEY RATES
Advertising; Saatchi Director Joins Vitt
description: STEPHEN R. FAJEN, director of corporate communications and former media director of Saatchi & Saatchi, Compton, has joined the lengthening list of agency media executives who have defected to a media buying service. His service of choice is Vitt Media International, which with an 18-year history is one of the oldest in the business.

title: JURY GETS CASE AGAINST 3 IN DRUG INFORMER'S KILLING
description: The case of three Colombian nationals charged with murdering Adler (Barry) Seal, a key government witness against a reputed leader of a Colombia-based cocaine cartel, went to a state jury tonight.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes loss from discontinued operations of $1,105.

title: JUDGE MAY HALT RECONSTRUCTION OF FOSTER HOME
description: A judge indicated yesterday that the Koch administration might be violating her order limiting repairs on an arson-damaged house in Queens that the city wants to use as a foster home for babies.

title: NATIONAL BUSINESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $5,300,000 for a writeoff of part of consolidation programs in the U.S. and abroad. c-Includes tax credits of $217,000 and $419,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CUTCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GENERAL PHYSICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WILD WEDNESDAY: THE MATINEE CRUSH
description: The red neon clock on Broadway read 1:36. Not even 25 minutes remained before curtain time and Helen Scaroulis tapped her foot at the corner of 47th Street and waited for her friend, Olga Brett, to arrive. They were going to a show.

title: WHAT'S IN THE FORECAST? EVERYONE WANTS TO KNOW
description: LEAD: FOR many people, it has become the first thing to tune in to in the morning and the last before going to bed. It pervades television and radio news. And every hour, on average, 6,000 New Yorkers telephone for information about it.

title: College Notebook; HOBART IS AIMING AT THE IMCOMPARABLE
description: When it tries for the Division III national lacrosse championship Saturday, the Hobart team will have precedent and the home field as advantages and a defeat to remember.

title: CRS SIRRINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $43 million writeoff of tangible and intangible assets for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: Only Conformists Need Apply
description: Chinese students protested last year over the pace and nature of reform. University students are a privileged group in China; so openly to differ with authority was a dramatic challenge.

title: CIRCLE EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $141,000 and an after-tax gain of $252,000 on the sale of a warehouse. The 1986 share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid on May 16, 1986.

title: BLENDING OLD AND NEW IN SAVANNAH
description: THE cooking of the South - embracing as it does such foods as corn pone, turnip greens, hush puppies, spoon bread, country ham, grits and red-eye gravy -lends itself to caricature and stereotype and all the cliches of the marketplace. To speak of the present state of the art as ''nouvelle Southern'' strikes some as ridiculously highfalutin and a contradiction in terms.

title: Giant Group Has 6.3% Clark Stake
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (Reuters) -

title: HODEL DEFENDS CONSTITUTION
description: The Secretary of the Interior, responding to a Supreme Court Justice's criticism of the authors of the Constitution, praised the document's ''essential greatness'' today and urged Americans to celebrate its 200th anniversary this year.

title: MARITAL RAPE: DRIVE FOR TOUGHER LAWS IS PRESSED
description: A month after Rosanna Hawkins filed for divorce in Michigan in 1981, her estranged husband broke into the house where she was staying and in more than an hour of what she said was total terror, raped her. Her husband, Eugene, who had been armed with a six-inch knife, was convicted in Oceana County Circuit Court in 1982 and sentenced to 27 years to 92 years in prison.

title: Ogilvy Board Adds 2
description: At its 21st annual meeting yesterday, the Ogilvy Group elected two new members of the board: Ian Hunt, chief executive of Britain's Research International, recently acquired by Ogilvy, and Hugh Parker, a retired director of McKinsey & Company. That brings the board to 18 members, four of whom are outsiders. William E. Phillips, chairman of the Ogilvy Group, said the company was striving to increase the outside membership.

title: SANDS REGENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ROCKETS TOP SONICS TO CUT DEFICIT TO 3-2
description: The Houston Rockets, the defending Western Conference champions, did not handle the pressure of the playoffs well tonight, but they managed to survive with a a 112-107 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics. It took inspired performances from Akeem Olajuwon (26 points, 7 blocked shots) and Rodney McCray (24 points, 11 assists, 10 rebounds), who helped them recover after they lost a 21-point first-half lead.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Water Polo U.S. Upsets Italy, 7-3: Greg Boyer and Terry Schroeder scored three goals each as the United States posted a 7-3 victory over favored Italy at the men's World Cup competition yesterday at Salonica, Greece. The victory was the second straight for Coach Bill Barnett's all-California team and left the Americans tied for third in the eight-team round-robin tournament with a 2-1 record and 4 points. In other games, the Soviet Union edged Cuba, 11-10; Yugoslavia beat Spain, 11-8, and West Germany routed Greece, 10-4.(AP)

title: INSTITUTE OF CLINICAL PHARACOLOGY PLC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The dollar amounts were converted from Irish pounds at March 31, 1987, at the rate of $1.4800 equals Irish pound 1.00. The equivalent rate at March 31, 1986, was $1.2920 equals Irish pound 1.00.

title: FORUM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FORTUNE TELLER. By Marsha Norman. 387 pages. Random House. $18.95.

title: Arrest in Los Angeles Attack
description: Mark Allen Olds, a 27-year-old neighbor described by the authorities as a drug addict, was charged today with attempted murder and burglary in the stabbing attack last week on Ruth Galanter, a candidate for the City Council. Mrs. Galanter is in fair condition at U.C.L.A. Medical Center recovering from surgery for two stab wounds to the neck.

title: NEW YORK SCHOOL BUILDINGS SCARRED BY YEARS OF NEGLECT
description: At the 125-year-old red brick Pacific High School, across the street from the Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn, students attend classes in rooms with boarded-up windows, the lone science laboratory is inoperable and one of just four toilets is usually not functioning.

title: ENDEVCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid August 1985.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MAY 13, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Aquino candidates were leading and appeared bound for victory in the Philippine elections. Some opposition leaders charged that irregularities took place, but most people called the election the calmest and most honest in years. Page A1 The President denied seeking money for the contras in meetings with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia in 1985. White House officials denied any link between the aid and an accord to sell weapons to the Saudis. A1 A $10 million mistake resulted in that amount being sent to a Swiss shipping magnate's bank account instead of to a fund to help the contras. The recipient withdrew the money and bought a certificate of deposit in another bank, investigators said. A1 Tempers flared in Israel as Yitzhak Shamir attacked Shimon Peres's proposed international Middle East peace conference. Mr. Shamir called it ''perverse and criminal.'' A1 More forces were sent to the Punjab as Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi took command of a campaign to curb terrorist attacks by Sikh extremists in the northern Indian state. A1 The Afghan Government is torn by internal divisions that diplomats say have been worsened by the stalemate in the war between the Soviet-backed regime, now nine years old, and insurgents. A8 News analysis: Margaret Thatcher, in seeking re-election next month, is really running for a place on the short list of Prime Ministers who have sig-nificantly altered change-resistant Britain. A3 Klaus Barbie denied responsiblity for atrocities that took place in Lyons during the German occupation. It was his first statement at the trial. A5 A record auction price for sculpture was paid for Alberto Giacometti's ''Large Female Standing II'' at Christie's in New York. A buyer said to be an American paid $3.63 million for the work. C24 U.S. arms proposal criticized A3 Ghana embraces change A4 Letter adds to political fray A7 Army yields little power to leader A10 NATIONAL A16-25, B10, B13-14, D31 'Star Wars' spending would be cut by half a billion dollars next year under a provision approved by the House. The measure would reverse past rapid growth of spending for the space-based missile defense program. A1 Budget conferees voiced optimism about early agreement on a compromise plan for 1988 that would provide for $18 billion in tax increases. The House and Senate negotiators began negotiations. B14 A man's heart was transplanted into another man from a live donor, doctors said. The surgery was part of a complex series of operations involving three people at two hospitals in Baltimore. A1 United Airlines, seeking protection from a possible hostile takeover, announced a $2.1 billion deal with the Boeing Company. The move puts a considerable ''chunk of stock in friendly hands,'' one analyst said. D1 News analysis: Commodity prices are expected to be volatile but big rises are called unlikely by experts despite this week's sharp jump and higher inflation. D1 Laws barring husbands from trial for sexually assaulting their wives or setting severe limits for pursuit of such prosecution are opposed by women's organizations who say they subject some wives to humiliation, pain and injury. A16 Opposition to oil exploration proposed by the Federal Government on 750 million acres in the Pacific is almost uniform among state officials, environmentalists and private citizens. A25 Bringing back the trumpeter swan to Michigan, a biologist flew in three swan eggs swathed in styrofoam, kept warm with a hot-water bottle and ventilated with a tiny, battery-operated fan. A16 In a culinary generation gap, members of an old guard of American chefs, producing classic French cuisine, vie for customers with members of a new guard of chefs producing an often idiosyncratic cuisine. C1 Air Force blamed for rocket's loss A22 Students faulted on global issues B10 Bush's job: Blessing and curse B14 Haig asserts position in race B14 Hodel in defense of Constitution D31 WASHINGTON TALK 12 A military bill like no other Trade interpretations REGIONAL B1-9, B36, D31 School officials seem overwhelmed by efforts to provide minimally decent buildings in the New York City public system in the face of scarce funds and a clogged bureaucracy, according to interviews. A1 Reduced political contributions by individuals to New York City candidates would be enforced under a bill introduced in both houses of the State Legislature. B1 The Metropolitan's new chairman is Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive officer of The New York Times Company. He was elected by unanimous vote of the art museum's board of trustees. C19 Joseph L. Galiber's chief lawyer urged a jury to acquit the State Senator of charges of plotting with former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and others to steal $7.4 million on a New York City subway project. B3 A suspended police officer, Robert Rathbun, told psychiatrists he gave to charity virtually all of $4,000 he is charged with stealing from drug dealers, according to court testimony. B4 Attorney General Meese's adviser, W. Franklyn Chinn, plotted to defraud the Wedtech Corporation of more than $1 million while he was a member of the Wedtech board, the company charged in a civil suit. B1 Path cleared for trash return B1 Wednesday's matinee crush B1 Subway visit sought for Goetz jury B2 U.S. acts on Nazi collaborator B3 Judge may halt repairs on home B9 Museum plan under attack B36

title: China Asserts Reporter Paid for Secret Report
description: China accused a Japanese reporter today of paying for classified information, including a ''confidential document'' from the Communist Party Central Committee.

title: YOUNG REBUFFED ON BID TO DELAY QUESTIONS ON COCAINE IN ATLANTA
description: A judge today refused a request by Mayor Andrew Young and a key aide to delay their appearance before a Federal grand jury investigating allegations of drug use among prominent Atlanta political figures, including former State Senator Julian Bond and Mr. Young himself.

title: Gunman Kills 7 in Belgium
description: A gunman killed seven people, including a child and five members of one family, before being found dead in his car today. The police said the man, found near the southern town of Mons, apparently shot himself. They gave no further details. The man shot dead five members of a family and wounded a sixth person at a farm in Pepingen. He then followed and killed a witness and her 3-year-old son before fleeing by car. The identity of the gunman and the reason for the killings was unknown.

title: IN MONTREAL, BAGELS LIKE NONE OTHER
description: Philadelphia is known for its cheese steaks, New York its cheesecakes. Chicago has its deep-dish pizza, San Francisco its sourdough. And nowhere but here can you get Montreal bagels.

title: NOAH UPSET, 7-5, 6-1, AT THE ITALIAN OPEN
description: In a match that began after midnight, fourth-seeded Yannick Noah was upset by Eduardo Bengoechea of Argentina today in the first round of the Italian Open tennis championships.

title: JAPAN CHEERS FOR STAR WITH STAYING POWER
description: On June 6 in Hiroshima - assuming rainouts, injuries or other imponderables do not interfere - a Japanese baseball player named Sachio Kinugasa will step unto the field and into the record book.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BALDWIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in January 1987.

title: OLYMPIC BROADCASTING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE season of maximum thirst is approaching, and the latest data on what Americans most like to drink suggest that far too many nutritionally questionable beverages are sliding down our throats at the expense of drinks that may improve health as well as mental and physical performance.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Scouting column of Sports Pages last Wednesday misstated the history of women in the Iditarod Sled Dog Race. Susan Butcher, who won in 1986 and 1987, was not the first woman to do so; Libby Riddle won in 1985.

title: DATAKEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $32,000. c-Net loss

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF AUSTIN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a provision for loan losses of $22.5 million and a gain of $4.4 million from the sale of loan servicing. c-Net income

title: Chrysler Insurance
description: The Chrysler Corporation said that it would expand its insurance programs for its 4,000 dealers to cover such matters as garage liability, theft and workers' compensation. The company said the expanded services would cause employment at its Chrysler Insurance subsidiary to triple to 150 over the next two years. The subsidiary, a part of the Chrysler Financial Corporation, insures against damage to vehicles that dealers hold in inventory.

title: CHURCH'S CHIEF FIGHTS FORMER COLLEAGUE'S BID
description: J. David Bamberger left Ohio for the Southwest in the 1950's to seek his fortune. He found it, first in vacuum cleaners, then in fried chicken.

title: HAIG ASSERTS HE'S NOT AN ASTERISK IN REPUBLICAN PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that he had ''moved from an asterisk in January to a solid third position in this country'' in the 1988 Republican Presidential race.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $176,000 for the latest quarter and $344,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: Loan Demand Expected to Rise
description: Loan demand will rise sharply in the second half of the year, increasing profits at the nation's commercial banks, according to a survey of 850 chief financial officers by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Paine Webber Names Official
description: A. Edward Allinson has joined Paine Webber Group Inc. as president of Mitchell Hutchins Asset Management, the company said yesterday.

title: US SHELTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LAWRENCE INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ting-Yung Hang Dies at 79; An Ex-Journalist and Scholar
description: Ting-Yung Hang, a former editor in chief and publisher of The China Tribune in New York, died of cancer Saturday at Parsons Hospital in Queens. He was 79 years old and lived in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Step by Step, the Court Helps Affirmative Action
description: This year's United States Supreme Court rulings on affirmative action have been greeted with the thunder of a grand finale - with both applause and boos. Now that the reviews are in, more mundane responses will be required of the major actors.

title: Politics in a No-Party System
description: The sudden departure of Gary Hart from the campaign has, strangely enough, probably not altered the Democratic nomination or the Presidential outcome. Before his exit, Mr. Hart was clearly his party's front runner, just as Vice President Bush has had a handy lead in the Republican sweepstakes. In both cases, the polls have placed them around the 50 percent mark and found their competitors struggling to get into the double digits. Only Senator Bob Dole in the G.O.P. seemed to be close enough to being a serious contender.

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: HOUSE CUTS FUNDS FOR 'STAR WARS' IN TACTICAL MOVE
description: The House of Representatives voted today to reduce spending for research into missile defenses next year to $3.1 billion, half a billion dollars less than the amount being spent this year.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO FAVOR REQUEST FOR INCREASE IN AID TO GUATEMALA
description: A senior Administration official said today that the United States would respond positively if President Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala asks the United States for military aid during his first official visit this week.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nation Is Demeaned by Press Prying on Hart
description: To the Editor:

title: NEBRASKA INDEPENDENTS TO VOTE IN PRIMARIES
description: Nebraska's Attorney General said today that a ruling last December by the United States Supreme Court means that independent voters in Nebraska cannot be denied participation in the Republican and Democratic primary elections for members of Congress.

title: IN 3-WAY TRANSPLANT, LIVING PATIENT DONATES HEART
description: In what is believed to be a medical first, a healthy human heart was taken from a living person and transplanted into another human, doctors in Baltimore said yesterday.

title: Senator Hollings's Tanker Ploy
description: Faced with such a big budget deficit, Congress might be expected to embrace owners of oil tankers who have, voluntarily, repaid $142 million in Federal subsidies. In fact, many members of Congress are demanding that the Transportation Department return the money. Leading the fight is Senator Ernest Hollings, who as co-author of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law ought to be doubly embarrassed by the naked defense of special interests.

title: CAREERCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Witnesses Admit Theft Of $80 From 2 Jurors
description: Two women who were Government witnesses in a criminal trial have admitted stealing $80 from the pocketbooks of two of the jurors.

title: JAPAN'S RECORD INDUSTRY WORRIED
description: The digital audio tape recorder is off to a slow start in its home market. While the product has not sparked the same level of opposition in Japan as it has in Europe and the United States, the record industry here has also registered protests.

title: READING & BATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,985,000 on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: THE RECORDING INDUSTRY HOPES TO BAR TAPING FROM COMPACT DISKS
description: Weighing the lure of a new technology against the political power of the nation's recording industry, Congress will soon decide whether to allow into the country - and under what conditions - a new kind of Japanese high-fidelity tape recorder that may make the Walkman even smaller and the tape deck disappear.

title: A Polish Airlines Jet Makes Emergency Warsaw Landing
description: A Polish airliner bound for Baghdad with 110 people aboard safely made an emergency landing in Warsaw after the pilot found a malfunction in the plane's equipment, an air-traffic controller said today.

title: Chemical Bank
description: The Chemical Bank said it would raise the rates it pays on six-month and one-year certificates of deposit, beginning today. The move was apparently in response to a similar increase by Citibank. Chemical said its new rate on the six-month account was 6.85 percent, up from 6.77 percent. The one-year certificate would carry a rate of 7.30 percent, up from 7.25 percent. Because of compounding of interest, the actual yield to maturity on both savings accounts would be slightly higher.

title: Losing Winter
description: ''Freedom's just another word for nothing left to lose,'' according to one of the more haunting 60's song lyrics. It's also a fine description of what it is to walk out on a warm spring day - unburdened, for the first time in months, of things that are fated to be forgotten.

title: MOSCOW CRITICIZES U.S. ARMS PROPOSAL
description: The Soviet Union said today that it had serious reservations about an American draft treaty to reduce long-range nuclear weapons.

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'OLLIE IS GETTING A BUM RAP'
description: At one point, Mr. McFarlane described the character and background of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North:

title: CALPROP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Results of the Lincoln-Douglas Debates
description: To the Editor:

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $136,000 and a gain from the sale of discontinued operations of $491,000.

title: People
description: * Michael P. Burns, Sheffield J. Halsey Jr. and Katalin M. Kovago have been named senior vice presidents, management supervisors at DFS Dorland/New York.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I AM upstairs watching television on an old black-and-white set with unreliable horizontal hold. Downstairs the good television is in use; the kids are watching ''Dumbo'' on the VCR. I am watching the Congress of the United States engaged in righteous indignation. My sons are watching an elephant fly. They believe what they are seeing. I do not. On the way to the store I run into a friend, a contemporary. ''I've been watching the hearings on the Iran-contra thing,'' I say. ''Why?'' she asks evenly.

title: GOETZ'S LAWYER SEEKS ORDER TO TAKE JURY TO SUBWAY CAR
description: The lawyer for Bernhard H. Goetz said yesterday that he wants the jury in Mr. Goetz's trial to be taken to a subway car to see firsthand the conditions in which Mr. Goetz found himself when he pulled an unlicensed revolver and shot four teen-agers in December 1984.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $89,963. c-Includes tax benefits of $932 for the quarter and $5,029 for the year. d-Net loss

title: PRESIDENTIAL LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $5,254,000 and $2,220,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Oil Output Splits OPEC
description: OPEC's leading member nations are publicly bickering over whether the group should increase its oil production at a time when world oil prices are holding steady. The United Arab Emirates' oil minister, Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, today reiterated the desire of his nation to lift its individual production quota to satisfy increasing demand. Sheik Otaiba also said all 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would consider an increase in overall production at their next meeting on June 25. But OPEC's largest producer, Saudi Arabia, and Kuwait urged the group's members to adhere to the output quotas devised at the last meeting of OPEC ministers in December.

title: Forecast on Oranges
description: The nation's orange harvest for the 1986-87 season is estimated at 189.9 million boxes, down fractionally from the April forecast but still 8 percent more than last season, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: CONE COMES TO METS' RESCUE
description: Even though he had struggled in recent weeks, the reputation of David Cone somehow grew. His catcher called his breaking ball one of the best he had ever seen. His manager promised that one day he would be an important part of the starting rotation. But no one predicted that Cone would come to the Mets' rescue just now, just when panic could appear around the next turn.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''With all the anger and bitterness we have in our hearts against this perverse and criminal idea, we must keep calm and repel it by using the ways and means that are available to us.'' - Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel on proposal for an international Middle East peace conference. ''Such assaults? Such a style of speaking? What happened? He wants to delegitimize half the people of Israel? Half of the government? At least half the people support this idea.'' - Foreign Minister Shimon Peres. [ A8:2. ]

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section on March 25 about endive misstated its price. It is sold by the pound, not the piece. Long Island endive was $2 to $2.25 a pound at the time, and Belgian endive $2.50 a pound.

title: TRANS LEASING INTERNAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AIR FORCE BLAMED FOR ROCKET'S LOSS
description: An investigating board of the space agency has blamed Air Force weather forecasters for allowing a $78 million Atlas-Centaur rocket and its $83 million cargo to be launched March 26, when they were destroyed by lightning.

title: Koch Assails Judge on Remarks
description: Mayor Koch expressed outrage yesterday at a judge's criticism of Marla Hanson, the fashion model whose face was slashed at the behest of her landlord.

title: Sematech Gets $250 Million Budget
description: The organizers of Sematech, the consortium of semiconductor companies acting to improve chip manufacturing technologies, said yesterday that a $250 million-a-year budget for the effort had been approved.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
TEAS FOR SUMMER
description: LEAD: TAKING a trip down the coffee and tea aisle at the supermarket is likely to dazzle and confuse any shopper these days. It used to be a matter of just choosing between bags and instant powder, or maybe the lemon-flavored tea hiding behind the regular stuff. Instant powdered tea is relatively Instant powdered tea is relatively old as processed foods go; John Mariani in his ''Dictionary of American Food and Drink'' (Ticknor & Fields, 1983) dates it to the 1930's.

title: O.E.C.D. Study Critical Of Farm Program Costs
description: A report on the cost of Government farm programs that was released today at a meeting of ministers of 24 industrial democracies was described as even more critical of existing programs than had been expected.

title: Combustion Issue
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. is offering $150 million of 9.70 percent notes due in 1997 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The notes are rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by S.&P., and they yield about 1.15 percentage points more than 10-year Treasury notes. The issue is not callable for seven years.

title: Pepsico's Bottled Water
description: Pepsico Inc., the huge soft drink, snack food and restaurant concern, said today that it will introduce a bottled water in several New England markets starting June 1. The product, called Ice Mountain Maine Spring Water, will be test-marketed by a new Pepsico subsidiary, Great Spring Waters of America, in Boston, Providence, R.I., Hartford and New Haven.

title: U.S. LAWS OFFER LESS PROTECTION THAN THOSE OF MAJOR TRADING PARTNERS
description: Officials of the Corning Glass Works were outraged when they discovered that Sumitomo Electric Industries of Japan was using, without permission, their patented manufacturing process to make optical fiber, the thin glass wires widely used in telecommunications.

title: Perle's Pen
description: Richard N. Perle, whose resignation as Assistant Secretary of Defense for International and Security Policy became official last week, will write a monthly column for U.S. News & World Report. His first effort, dealing with proposals to remove intermediate-range missiles from Europe, will appear in the news magazine next Monday, 10 days after his departure from the Pentagon.

title: ACROSS PACIFIC, DIGITALLY
description: Seiji Ozawa is to raise his baton tomorrow to conduct the New Japan Philharmonic's 150th performance, and the sound the orchestra produces will travel for the first time across the Pacific into American homes on a digital signal path.

title: Fighting Words
description: It is spring in Japan, which means the Yakult Swallows are proceeding to ''Hop and Hop,'' the Nankai Hawks are vowing to ''Win or Lose With Youth'' and the Hankyu Braves are advancing ''Step by Step.''

title: BIOSPHERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Military Bill Like None Other
