title: Don't Delay
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Continue the Search
description: Richard Evans, the president of the Knicks, said yesterday that his search for a new general mananger and a new coach was ''probably ahead of schedule'' because of the number of candidates he has been able to interview.

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for 13wks to May 2
Settlement Reached In U.S. Pension Suit
description: A Federal judge has given tentative approval to a plan to pay an estimated 16,000 retirees up to $35 million to settle a class-action suit against the Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation.

title: VIETNAM TELLS OF WIDE MALNUTRITION
description: Malnutrition in Vietnam has become serious and widespread, and beriberi, a diet-related nervous disorder, is occurring in the army in epidemic proportions, according to the head of a military medical institute in Hanoi.

title: SYNERGEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $34,800 and $135,400 for the latest and year- ago quarters, respectively.

title: THE SPOTLIGHT SHIFTS FROM DOMENICI
description: Senator Pete V. Domenici still finds himself answering to the title ''Mr. Chairman.''

title: CONCERT: STUTTGART ORCHESTRA
description: MUCH can be said for sheer sonic effect. Toward the end of the Sibelius First Symphony, the slow theme dominating the last movement returns for a grandiose climax. In its performance Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, the Stuttgart Philharmonic offered as plush and rhapsodic an account of that passage as one is likely to hear, its richly colored sound filling the large hall.

title: FERROFLUIDICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes losses of $13,000 and $238,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from equity in an affiliate.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A television review on Tuesday about coverage of the Iran-contra hearings in Congress misidentified the program on which Representative Dick Cheney, Republican of Wyoming, appeared as a guest on Sunday.

title: EUROPEAN PRESS SEES U.S. FLAWS IN HART'S FALL
description: The European press has depicted the collapse of Gary Hart's Presidential campaign as the result of his personal failings and of fundamental flaws in the Presidential selection process.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $401,000 and $483,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively; the year-earlier period also includes a loss from discontinued operations of $927,668.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have no intention of appearing before this tribunal and I demand that you have me taken back to St. Joseph Prison.'' - Klaus Barbie. [ A8:2. ]

title: SUN DISTRIBUTORS LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $7.7 million one-time charge due to the sale of inventory and a $1.4 million charge for acquisition fees. The loss also includes a $1.3 million non-cash charge for increased depreciation and amortization of property, plant equipment and intangib assets, as well as a $1 million non- cash amortization of non-recurring financing fees. c-Net income Year-ago results are pro-forma. The company went public in February 1987, and prior to that time was a part of Sun Co. The company said the 1986 net income resulted in no payment for Class B partnership interests.

title: Hart Will Seek Federal Funds
description: Gary Hart has returned to his law practice in Denver and plans to apply for more than $1 million in Federal money to help pay off campaign debts, according to his spokesman.

title: SUNSHINE-JR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A DASH THROUGH FLAMES TO PUT THEM OUT
description: As firefighters sprayed water on him, a worker dashed through rivers of flaming diesel fuel at a storage depot today to shut off valves under a 30,000-gallon tank of propane gas, which was feeding the flames.

title: ELECTROSPACE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
Sudan Rebels Report Downing Troop Plane
description: Rebels in the southern Sudan said today that they had shot down a Government plane filled with troops.

title: M'FARLANE STATES HE BRIEFED REAGAN ON CONTRAS OFTEN
description: Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser, testified today that he had briefed Mr. Reagan ''frequently'' on what his staff was doing to help the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: Stocks End Mixed; Dow Gains 7.08
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday for the second day, as rises by blue-chip issues were offset by declines in the broader market. Investors appeared cautious, content to wait on the sidelines until the releases by the Government today of trade figures and tomorrow of producer price statistics.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jackson Retiring From Seahawks
description: The Seattle Seahawks' linebacker, Michael Jackson, announced today that he is retiring from the National Football League to enter business.

title: CITY HALL PARLEY SEEKS TO KEEP NBC FROM LEAVING
description: Donald J. Trump and Deputy Mayor Alair A. Townsend met for nearly two hours yesterday to discuss how the Koch administration could help prevent the National Broadcasting Company from moving to New Jersey.

title: PENTAGON ASKING EMPLOYEES ABOUT SEX PRACTICES
description: The Defense Department has introduced sweeping new regulations on drug and alcohol abuse and sexual misconduct affecting nearly three million military and civilian employees and defense contractors who hold security clearances.

title: NOBEL INSURANCE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $251,000 and $304,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: Eurotunnel Gets $1.66 Billion Loan
description: Eurotunnel, the British-French consortium formed to build a tunnel linking Britain to the European mainland, has secured a loan of $:1 billion, or $1.66 billion at current exchange rates, from the development fund of the European Community. A statement from the Eurotunnel co-chairmen, Andre Bernard and Alastair Morton, said the loan from the European Investment Bank represented a major part of the consortium's $:5 billion, or $8.3 billion, overall bank financing package. The twin-tube undersea tunnel is due to be built by 1993.

title: Talking Deals; Dome Lenders Unappeased
description: COMPLETING a corporate takeover is difficult enough when only the directors and shareholders of the target have to approve the deal. But as the Amoco Corporaton is discovering in its multibillion offer for financially crippled Dome Petroleum Ltd., the chances of success are more remote when the buyout needs the approval of creditors who are being asked to take the short end of the stick.

title: CORRUPTION-TRIAL JURY IS TOLD BROOKLYN OFFICER IS A 'VICTIM'
description: A New York City police officer accused of corruption was described by his lawyer yesterday as a ''a good cop who was victimized by a bad cop'' trying to avoid a jail sentence for his own misdeeds.

title: OILERS SCRAMBLE BUT GAIN CUP FINAL
description: Mark Messier sparked a five-goal Edmonton rally with two goals, including the game-winner with 15 minutes 12 seconds to play tonight, as the Edmonton Oilers advanced to the Stanley Cup finals for the fourth time in the last five years with a 6-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: WOOLWORTH CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
LANDS' END reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CHARTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $353,000. c-Net loss and after a gain from discontinued operations of $1,134,000.

title: Gephardt to Offer Bill Curbing Film Coloring
description: Representative Richard Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, said today he would introduce legislation aimed at ending the unsanctioned coloring of black-and-white motion picture classics.

title: ELECTRONICS PUSHING BOOKS AND CURIOS OFF THE SHELF
description: IN the late 70's, people were still asking about where to put books,'' said Donald Mark, a sales manager for Mobilia, a manufacturer of wall storage units. ''Now the interest is in where you put your VCR, where you stack your stereo. To a great extent, electronics have even displaced the liquor cabinet.''

title: The Worm and the Apple: Less Justice, and More
description: Three Times a Victim Marla Hanson was victimized first by the attackers who slashed her face with a razor, leaving her scarred for life. The second time, at their trial, was by a defense lawyer who implied she was a racist, a liar and a slut. Now she has been abused a third time - by the judge. For Acting Supreme Court Justice Jeffrey Atlas to criticize her harshly for speaking out deserves a worm. More, it raises serious doubt about his fitness for reappointment.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary losses from antitrust litigation of $664,000 and $1,414,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; ASTRONOMICAL ODDS DON'T SCARE TRAINER
description: In 113 Kentucky Derbies, 138 starters have finished 15th or worse. Only 19 of them had handlers with the faith, or gall, to try them back in the Preakness Stakes. None of them won, and the only one to hit the board was General Thatcher in 1923, who went from 16th in Louisville to second in Baltimore None of them was trained by Happy Alter, an aptly named beam of optimism who will try to break the streak here Saturday. Alter will run No More Flowers, who finished 15th at Churchill Downs 11 days ago, back in the Preakness.

title: BARBIE QUITS HIS TRIAL, CHARGING HE IS HOSTAGE
description: Klaus Barbie, asserting that he is a ''hostage, not a prisoner,'' declared today that he would no longer take part in his trial for crimes against humanity.

title: Monoclonal, Biogen Losses
description: Two troubled biotechnology companies -Monoclonal Antibodies Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., and Biogen N.V., of Cambridge, Mass. - reported losses today for the quarter ended March 31.

title: CAMPSITES, CANOEING TRIPS AND EXHIBITS
description: Sixteen of the 50 public campgrounds operated by the Department of Environmental Conservation in New York State are open for business and the remaining 34 will begin operating tomorrow.

title: IS SEEN AS TOO LENIENT
description: A Federal judge replaced the man he named to oversee a crime-ridden New Jersey teamsters local because he was perceived as too lenient with some union leaders, officials familiar with the court's action said yesterday.

title: Yankee to Sell Gas Subsidiary
description: The Yankee Companies, a diversified energy and financial-services concern, said its board had accepted a revised offer from the management of its Yankee Gas Company subsidiary to buy the unit.

title: Bipartisan Arms Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Yields Rise Broadly
description: As competition for the saver's dollar intensified among banks, yields on bank money-market accounts, certificates of deposit and money-market mutual funds continued to climb in the week ended yesterday.

title: NORTH EUROPEAN OIL ROYALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings are in units.

title: CHINN HO, 83, A MAJOR FIGURE IN SUCCESS OF HAWAII'S ASIANS
description: Chinn Ho, a major figure in the rise of Asians to prominence in Hawaii, died of heart failure Tuesday night at Straub Hospital in Honolulu where he had been under kidney dialysis for two weeks. He was 83 years old.

title: Arms Reaction - and Reactionaries
description: Newton's third law of motion finds a parallel in modern arms control: For every prospective reduction in one class of armaments there are inevitably increases in others.

title: CONCERT: CANTORIAL MUSIC
description: APPROACHING Jewish vocal music from the outside is presumably to miss many of its resonances. Yet the surfaces of this distinctive style, as presented at the 92d Street Y Sunday afternoon, did offer their own strong characteristics, even to the uninitiated.

title: South African Rebel Impresses Church Parley
description: The young South African black stood up before about 300 church leaders to ask the president of the African National Congress, Oliver Tambo, a question.

title: Free-Agent Hearing To Resume
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth and George Steinbrenner, owner of the Yankees, are scheduled to testify next week when baseball's free-agent conspiracy hearing resumes. They could be the last witnesses in the hearing that began last June.

title: G.O.P. BRINGS SENATE TO A HALT TO DELAY VOTE ON MILITARY BILL
description: Republican Senators today used delaying tactics that have not been seen in 25 years to forestall consideration of a military spending bill that would limit space tests for President Reagan's proposed missile defense system.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIELD IN CALIFORNIA GETS A SECOND DOSE OF ALTERED BACTERIA
description: Genetically altered bacteria sprayed on a strawberry patch here last month have not been found outside the test site, researchers said.

title: Parent Is Selling Helena Chemical
description: Bayer A.G. has agreed to sell its American subsidiary, the Helena Chemical Company, to an international trading company. The sale is conditional on the approval of American authorities and the companies' boards. Hermann Strenger, Bayer's chairman of the managing board, gave no further details of the buyer or the selling price.

title: THEATER: MARATHON OF ONE-ACT PLAYS
description: EARLIER this season in ''The Maderati,'' Richard Greenberg spoofed the pretensions of the publishing world, and revealed himself as a deft social satirist. In his new literary comedy, ''The Author's Voice,'' the high point of Evening A in the Ensemble Studio Theater's annual marathon of one-act plays, he scores an ace: game, set and match to Mr. Greenberg.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In our attached brownstone, the odor of fuel oil permeates the ground floor so strongly that I am afraid it might be a health hazard. There was a leak in our neighbor's oil delivery line, and oil seeped through the stone wall we share in the basement. The leak was fixed, but the smell remains. Is there a chemical for treating the stone or a sealant that would get rid of it? A. I doubt that the odor, objectionable as it is, is a health hazard. The oil has saturated the masonry, and the smell can last years. You might minimize it by scrubbing the wall with a strong detergent, then rinsing with lots of water.

title: 10-DAY AUTO SALES TUMBLE BY 28.5%
description: Sales of new American-made cars dropped 28.5 percent in early May from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. Sales of light trucks dropped 12.4 percent, the first decline in three months.

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $43,000 and $176,000 for the the quarter and 9 months, respectively; tax credits of $97,000 for the quarter and $612,000 for the 9 months. The company said its reported results for the latest 9 months are consolidated, including revenue and earnings of Craig and Stater Bros.

title: BOSTON SCHOOLS OFFER COURSES FOR AMATEUR PRESERVATIONISTS
description: Some unusual courses are being offered here for those who want to take an active part in preserving historical arts, artifacts and buildings.

title: The Barbie Trial: Not Just Vengeance
description: It's not obvious to everyone that prosecuting Klaus Barbie, the ''Butcher of Lyons,'' is such a relentlessly good idea. Many in France resent the Barbie trial, just under way, for reopening the bitter issue of French collaboration with the Nazis. Others fear an anti-Semitic backlash. And some Jews oppose it in the belief that linking Mr. Barbie's crimes against Resistance fighters and his crimes against Jews trivializes the Holocaust.

title: TEACHING SUCCESS AT 2-YEAR COLLEGES
description: Community colleges should make placement tests mandatory for new students and test students as they leave, if they want to send more graduates to four-year colleges, a group of urban community colleges said Tuesday.

title: A STOLEN STRADIVARIUS, A 51-YEAR OLD SECRET
description: By his widow's account, Julian Altman was something of a scoundrel - a womanizer and gambler who made a living playing the violin at restaurants and society functions.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHRED BREEDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
380 MILES FROM LYONS, A QUIETER TRIAL
description: Three hundred and eighty miles away in Lyons, Klaus Barbie, the city's erstwhile Gestapo chief, finds himself at the center of the world's attention.

title: Signed by the President
description: In a detailed financial statement that he had printed in yesterday's Congressional Record, Senator Paul Simon listed a ''Presidential autograph collection'' among his assets.

title: New Wine Company Chooses 2 Agencies
description: After a whirlwind agency search, the newborn Vintners Internatonal Company, which acquired most of Seagram's wine brands, has chosen SSC&B to promote Paul Masson and Great Western Champagne, and Avrett, Free & Ginsberg to promote Taylor California Cellars and Taylor New York Champagne.

title: It Gets Easier to Fall Asleep at the Switch
description: To the Editor:

title: JURY WATCHES AN ANGRY GOETZ ON TAPE
description: In a two-hour videotape played in court yesterday, Bernhard H. Goetz - appearing angry, sarcastic and full of rage - told New York City police detectives that he was a murderer in his heart.

title: Teachers College
description: Four distinguished service medals were presented to educators by the president of Teachers College at Columbia University, P. Michael Timpane, in the college's commencement convocation yesterday.

title: QUEENS COOKS, AND WASHINGTON NOSHES
description: The band, consisting of an accordion, a clarinet and drums - a little heavy on the brushes - played ''I'll Take Manhattan'' and other songs with a New York theme. The corned beef was piled high as an elephant's eye, and the seltzer flowed like water. There were kishka and kasha and kreplach and a noodle pudding as ponderous as the Congressional Record.

title: RETAIL SALES BARELY UP LAST MONTH
description: Declines in real income and record levels of debt prompted American consumers to cut discretionary spending last month for big-ticket items like cars and furniture, and economists say they expect the pattern to continue.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Less Justice, and More; Supremely Welcome
description: In past years New York City court officials, prosecutors and defense lawyers have taken to the hills and beaches for long summer vacations.

title: CELTICS' 33-GAME STREAK ENDS
description: The Boston Celtics' 33-game home winning streak ended tonight when the Milwaukee Bucks scored a 129-124 victory in Boston Garden to stay alive in the playoffs.

title: A Spy's Banned Memoir To Be Published in U.S.
description: Viking Penguin will publish ''Spycatcher,'' the controversial memoir by Peter Wright, a former high official of Britain's Secret Service. The British government has blocked publication of the book in England for almost two years, on grounds that it would compromise national security, and Viking Penguin officials said yesterday that they expected the Thatcher Government to try to prevent its publication in this country.

title: People
description: * Joseph V. Karle Jr. has been promoted to executive vice president at Campbell-Ewald and will head the New York office.

title: Bank Failures Seen Peaking
description: Although the number of banks on the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's problem list has risen slowly in recent weeks, the number of bank failures appears to be peaking, the F.D.I.C.'s chairman, L. William Seidman, told a thrift industry group today.

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $19,000 and loss on disposal of $42,000.

title: FEW SPIES, FEWER CAMELS AND THE FEZ IS OLD HAT
description: On the streets of this city below a skyline stitched with minarets, a visitor might buy silk rugs and gold baubles; or, at lower price, the wisdom of a hawker's bathroom scales laid out with some pride on the sidewalk, or a glass of water and a wash of the hands, or a vendor's cooked mussels and sliced lemon, or even the dance of a gypsy's trained bear.

title: THEATER: 'ONE TOUCH OF VENUS' IN CONNECTICUT
description: In rejecting the title role in ''One Touch of Venus,''

title: Lower Earnings Seen at 7-Eleven
description: The Southland Corporation expects its 7-Eleven convenience stores to have lower earnings in the first half of this year, Jere W. Thompson, Southland's president, said.

title: A RAINBOW OF TEXTURES
description: SHYAM AHUJA, right, was born to the textile business in Bombay, India, and at age 19 started working in his father's company, which exported raw wool to the United States and Europe. At 30, Mr. Ahuja had his own company. Shortly after he started designing and making carpets, Mr. Ahuja expanded his line to include yardage for drapes, coverlets, napkins, place mats, pillows, towels and bathrobes. Now 54, Mr. Ahuja has 16 shops in department stores like Liberty of London and Macy's in San Francisco. Today, he is to open the first store of his own, at 201 East 56th Street. Mr. Ahuja is shown with a wool rug that is 4 by 6 feet and has a stylized floral pattern in pink, peach and green on a cream background. It is $400. Behind him are embroidered silk panels, which are 48 inches wide and $120 a yard. The red and black geometric wool rug above is 4 by 6 feet and costs $400. Pure cotton napkins, above center, are 18 inches square and $3 each. Square pillows, above right, are 16 inches across and are covered in handwoven cotton and piped in contrasting colors. They come in aquamarine edged in pink, white edged in blue, peach edged in pink and other colors. They are $20 each.

title: Estonian Deported by U.S. To Soviet Is Seeking Pardon
description: Karl Linnas, the Estonian deported from the United States last month and facing a death sentence passed by a Soviet court 25 years ago for war crimes, has asked the Estonian Supreme Court to pardon him, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

title: MAGIC FADING AT FISHERMAN'S WHARF
description: On a hot, cloudless afternoon this week, Fred Miller, a vacationing Chicago salesman, looked around him and commented: ''The first time I was at Fisherman's Wharf was 20 years ago, when I got out of the Navy. It was really a fisherman's wharf; now, it's almost like Coney Island.''

title: RESTORING AMERICA'S PAST: BED AND BREAKFAST INNS
description: For years bed-and-breakfast inns have offered the coziness of down-home accommodations amid antiques and handcrafted furnishings -and at rates that many travelers find more affordable than hotels. Now, B & B's are playing an increasingly important role in saving old American houses. From New Jersey to California, in urban areas, mid-sized towns and out-of-the-way villages, an enthusiastic battalion of B & B proprietors is refurbishing and refurnishing dilapidated mansions and once-opulent townhouses.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes restructuring costs of $6,161,000 and nonrecurring charges of $1,679,000 for the latest quarter, and for the year-ago period includes after- tax restructuring costs of $1,582,000.

title: 2 CARTOONS, 'BLONDIE' AND 'CATHY'
description: WHEN a network pre- empts its regular programming for cartoons, there is always the embarrassing prospect that nobody will notice the difference. But CBS is plunging ahead tomorrow evening anyway, with two half-hour animation specials based on popular comic strips: ''Blondie and Dagwood'' at 8, and ''Cathy'' at 8:30.

title: CONSECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $236,000 for the latest quarter and $267,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said the latest quarter results include Bankers National Life Insurance Co. and Lincoln Income Life Insurance Co., which were acquired in 1986.

title: MAKING FLOOR TILES THAT LAST CENTURIES
description: IN an aging row house here Linda Ellet is reviving some of the complex and delicate techniques used to make encaustic tiles. In the process she uses, which dates from the monastery workshops of medieval Europe, clays of different colors are placed in molds to form geometric patterns, and then are fired without glazing.

title: The Replay Button
description: It was a real Cuomo stemwinder of a speech, full of passion, humor, good sense and appeals to emotion and public service. It was made before a small audience, a couple of hundred people from the cosmetic and fashion industries at a benefit lunch for the New York Foundling Hospital, and did not get any press at all.

title: JAPAN'S U.S. TRADE SURPLUS A RECORD
description: Japan said today that its surplus in trade with the United States jumped to $5.15 billion in April, a record in dollar terms, but American economists said the volume of Japanese exports had actually begun to shrink.

title: IT'S U.S.S.R. VS. THE BRONX
description: Tonight's the night. The Soviet basketball machine, future Olympians all, not a man among them under 6 feet 3 inches, is coming to the South Bronx to play ball.

title: No Security, No Bonus?
description: The lapses in security at the old and new United States Embassies in Moscow continue to rankle members of Congress, who are finding a variety of ways to express their displeasure.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $14,000 and $310,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes an extraordinary loss of $321,000.

title: REPAIR
description: MANY amateurs do not realize that using a chemical paint and varnish remover to strip the finish on wood furniture will not remove dark discolorations, ugly streaks or stains - nor will it lighten wood that is naturally dark. For instance, stripping the finish won't make mahogany look like pecan or another light wood. Usually a remover will not even take out the color of a regular wood stain: stains soak into the pores, so the color is not removed by ordinary stripping. To lighten wood or remove dark blemishes and other stains, bleach is required.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alcan Aluminum Ltd., Montreal, said it would proceed with the construction of the Laterriere aluminium smelter in Chicoutimi, Quebec, estimated to cost between $175 million and $225 million.

title: ARGENTINE SEEKS TO LIMIT ABUSE CHARGES
description: President Raul Alfonsin asked the Argentine Congress today to adopt legislation that could free from prosecution most of the military officers still on active duty who face charges for killing or abusing political detainees in the mid-1970's.

title: WOMEN EXCEL IN FIRST COED CLASS
description: At Columbia College, the last Ivy League school to become coeducational, the impact of the first group of women to graduate yesterday was keenly felt.

title: STAGE: 'MUCH ADO' IN CUBA
description: ''MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING'' set in Cuba in the 1930's?

title: The Talk of Cannes; MOVIES AND STARS FOR EVERY TASTE
description: ''It's like being on a two-week cruise to nowhere with Fellini as the entertainment director,'' is the way one American journalist described this 40th anniversary Cannes Film Festival. It's often crazy and sometimes sublime but, always, there is the feeling of isolation. The Iran-contra hearings are never mentioned. Gary Hart is last week's news. Only at the end of the day is someone likely to remember the real world, including the Klaus Barbie trial just getting under way in Lyons. It's a cruise, all right, but no one can be sure whether he's on a rocket to the moon or the Titanic.

title: EECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income Share earnings and shares outstanding for 1986 are adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split in August 1986. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: DANCE TROUPES TO HOLD AIDS BENEFIT
description: Thirteen New York-based dance companies will perform in ''Dancing for Life'' on Oct. 5 at the New York State Theater, a benefit to raise money for organizations involved in research, public education and patient care related to acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The benefit was announced yesterday by Robert Yesselman, president of the benefit's board of directors and executive director of the Paul Taylor Dance Company. The event will be coordinated by Jerome Robbins.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co. promoted Debra Isenberg to senior vice president, business development and data base management, of its direct marketing group.

title: EX-FRANCHISE CHIEF TAKES THE 5TH AND ASKS IMMEDIATE CITY PENSION
description: Morris Tarshis, the former New York City franchise director who resigned this month, refused to answer questions from the city's Department of Investigation this week and invoked the Fifth Amendment against the possibility of self-incrimination, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart on May 4 on potential witnesses in the Iran-contra hearings incorrectly summarized what is known about the role of Theodore G. Shackley, a former official of the Central Intelligence Agency. He testified before the Tower Commission that at a meeting with Manucher Ghorbanifar, an Iranian middleman, he discussed a possible exchange of cash or humanitarian aid - not arms - for the release of American hostages in Lebanon.

title: Britons To Acquire Ammirati
description: NOW it is Ammirati & Puris, one of the most talked about medium-size agencies, that is being acquired by a publicly held British ad agency holding company, the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership.

title: EMINENT JAMES JOYCE SCHOLAR
description: Richard Ellmann, whose 1959 biography of James Joyce became the definitive work on the Irish novelist, died yesterday in Oxford, England. He was 69 years old.

title: Volkswagen Recalling Cars
description: Volkswagen United States is recalling 275,000 1985-1987 cars for replacement of the fuel pump, which could stop working properly in hot weather and cause the engine to stall, the automobile maker said Tuesday. Owners of 1985-87 Jettas, Sciroccos and Cabriolets and about 40,000 1986 Golfs are being notified to bring their cars to dealers for free replacement of the pump.

title: YORKVILLE TOUR OFFERS HISTORICAL FLAVOR
description: OLD-TIMERS call it Yorkville. Young urbanites call it the

title: MAIL-ORDER SALES TAX STUDIED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: In an effort to help state governments extend their taxable reach to the growing direct-marketing industry, a Congressional panel today began considering legislation to require mail-order retailers like L.L. Bean Inc. to collect sales taxes on out-of-state purchases.

title: 'LOST' $10 MILLION REGAINED BY SWISS
description: A $10 million donation from the Sultan of Brunei to the Nicaraguan rebels that was sent to the wrong Swiss bank account last August has been recovered by Swiss authorities, a spokesman for the bank said today.

title: Reprimands at Texas
description: David McWilliams, the University of Texas football coach, and three other athletic staff members have been reprimanded by the school for violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, according to a published report. The Austin American-Statesman, quoting unnnamed sources, said that along with McWilliams the following officials had been reprimanded: Kenn Dabbs, athletic director; Paul Trickett, team physician, and John Mize, assistant coach.

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a pre-tax charge of $11.8 million related to certain plant closings. All prior year figures are adjusted for the 5-for-4 stock split in July 1986, and adjusted to include recent acquisitions on a pooling-of-interests basis. Lancaster said the figures are not truly comparable due to its restructuring.

title: Pennsylvania Conducts Postponed Bond Sale
description: The Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, which delayed a proposed debt financing on April 21 because of unfavorable market conditions, sold about $154 million of bonds yesterday through the First Boston Corporation.

title: IRAQ CHEMICAL WAR CITED IN U.N.
description: Iraq has stepped up its use of chemical weapons against Iran to include attacks on civilian targets, a United Nations inspection team reported today.

title: Lessons in the Wake of the Islip Garbage Barge
description: To the Editor:

title: SHONEY'S SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Ninth Life For the Met's Cat
description: LEAD: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's Egyptian cat stands accused of being ''in all probability a modern forgery.''

title: Students Invest In Celtic Pride
description: As a token of affection for the private school that his son, Bobby, attends in Burlington, Vt., Robert Brent decided to give each of the 25 students a novel gift: a share in the Boston Celtics.

title: SYM-TEX SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: SENATOR TO DELAY C.I.A. APPOINTMENT
description: Senator John Melcher, Democrat of Montana, said today that he would delay the confirmation of William H. Webster to be Director of Central Intelligence because he was not satisfied with the Federal Bureau of Investigation's handling of crime on Indian reservations.

title: YONKERS IS NEAR FISCAL STABILITY, MANAGER SAYS
description: The Yonkers City Manager proposed a $303 million budget for 1987-88 today that would give this city, which has faced several fiscal crises in the past decade, its third consecutive balanced budget.

title: British Aerospace Selects Chairman
description: Roland Smith, a director of British Aerospace P.L.C., will succeed Sir Austin Pearce, who is retiring, as chairman of Britain's largest aircraft, missile and spacecraft manufacturer, effective Sept. 1.

title: THE ART OF ARCHITECTURAL MODEL MAKING
description: LEAD: A NEW section of midtown Manhattan skyline that recently sprang up took just three weeks to erect. To see it, though, you must look down, not up.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday, with an article about Merrill Lynch's losses from mortgage-securities trading, described the status of Jerome P. Kenney incorrectly. He remains the chief executive of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. He has been relieved of responsibility for the firm's securities trading pending an internal inquiry into the causes of a $275 million loss.

title: AGENCY URGES STEPS TO HALT DECLINE IN AIR TRAVEL SAFETY
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, saying there had been an apparent ''erosion of safety'' that could worsen with summer travel, yesterday urged immediate steps to prohibit any increase in the amount of air traffic in peak hours through critical sectors of airspace.

title: TINSLEY LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: 2 Transplant Survivors Reported Doing Well
description: A man with cystic fibrosis who underwent a heart-lung transplant after apparently becoming the first living person to donate his own heart was taken off a respirator today, doctors said.

title: Plane Lands in Liberty Park When Engine Fails
description: A small airplane made an emergency landing in Liberty State Park in Jersey City last night after its engine failed, officials said.

title: U.S. SEEKING TO USE STATEMENT BY BIAGGI'S LAWYER
description: Prosecutors plan to use a television interview with Mario Biaggi's attorney as evidence against Mr. Biaggi and Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, when they go on trial on bribery and other charges, a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: PETROLEUM HEAT & POWER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HAMPTONS GARDENING
description: The Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, L.I., is starting its second annual landscape exhibition with a series of lectures and garden tours.

title: FOR U2, A REDISCOVERY OF AMERICAN ORIGINALS
description: WHEN the members of the Irish rock band U2 aren't playing to capacity crowds at New Jersey's Brendan Byrne Arena this week, they are likely to be listening to American music and reading fiction by American writers. The band has sold millions of records and is in the middle of one of the year's major rock tours. It's one of the enduring ironies of rock-and-roll that many of the musicians that bands like U2 listen to and the writers they read are artists their American fans have never heard or read.

title: CITY BALLET: 'VARIATIONS'
description: NEW York City Ballet presented George Balanchine's ''Variations Pour une Porte et un Soupir'' on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater and, as usual, there were almost as many unhappy groans from the audience as there were on the taped score. Balanchine carefully set this trio for a man, a woman and her stage-covering, capelike black skirt to the measure of Pierre Henry's score for deep-voiced sighs and the higher-pitched creaks and groans of a door. Though the ballet has had its defenders, at its 1974 premiere it was greeted with somewhat derisive Freudian interpretations and shrugging dismissal as a calculated attempt at sheer novelty.

title: ASIDE FROM FARM SHIFT, IDEAS AT TALKS SEEM FEW
description: Teams of ministers from 24 industrial countries tried for two days here, as many of them have tried in other settings, to dig their way out of the damage to the world economy that they readily allow they brought on themselves.

title: Bujones to Boston Ballet
description: Fernando Bujones will join the Boston Ballet as principal guest dancer, Bruce Marks, artistic director of the company, announced yesterday. He also said that Carla Stallings, a soloist with American Ballet Theater, would be joining the Boston company as a principal dancer. Mr. Bujones, currently associate director of the ballet company of the Teatro Municipal in Rio de Janeiro, will perform with the Boston Ballet in its 1987-88 season, dancing lead roles in ''Giselle,'' ''Miss Julie,'' ''The Nutcracker'' and other ballets to be announced.

title: ADAM F. McQUILLAN
description: Adam F. McQuillan, a former warden at several New York City jails and a former president of the Correctional Association of New York, died of a heart attack Monday at the Massapequa (L.I.) General Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Levittown, L.I.

title: A FRIEND, INDEED, HELPS OUT A FORMER LEAMMATE, IN NEED
description: Gerry Hart, like Brian (Spinner) Spencer, is from a small place in Canada. ''Tough northern country towns,'' Spencer remembers. ''The kind of towns where the roads were impassable in the winter.''

title: DEPICTING REAGAN: IN TOUCH OR OUT?
description: The Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair have elicited disclosures that suggest President Reagan was far more deeply involved in aiding the contras than he and his aides have been saying.

title: 5 Senators Offer Legislation To Shut P.L.O. Offices in U.S.
description: Bob Dole and four other Senators proposed legislation today to close the two Palestine Liberation Organization offices in the United States.

title: CONCERT: THE PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA
description: The all-Berloi program per-formed by the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening focused on two contrasting aspects of the French psyche. A Gallic fascination with exploring the soul's mysterious interior was illustrated by the psychologically subtle song cycle ''Les Nuits d'Ete,'' in which Jessye Norman was the soprano soloist. At the other extreme, no less characteristic of both the composer and his nation were the flamboyance of the ''Corsaire'' Overture and the pomposity of the rarely performed ''Grande Symphonie Funebre et Triomphale.''

title: JUDGES URGED TO HELP CURB CRISIS IN JAILS
description: Anticipating an increase during the summer in prisoners at New York City's already overcrowded jails, the state's Chief Judge yesterday called on all city judges to defer their vacations so they could reduce a backlog and avoid long delays before disposing of defendants' cases.

title: MONOCLONAL ANTIBODIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes charges of $3,255,000 for the quarter and $4,306,000 for the year, both to increase the reserve for costs associated with the ovutime withdrawal. c-Net income

title: Khalilullah Khalili Dies at 79; Afghan Poet and Ex-Official
description: Khalilullah Khalili, an Afghan poet and diplomat who had been living in exile since 1979, died on May 4 in Islamabad, Pakistan. He was 79 years old.

title: FILM ON CHICAGO 8 INCLUDES ORIGINALS
description: Re-creations of historical events have been a television staple at least since the ''You Are There'' series of the 1950's. But ''Conspiracy: The Trial of the Chicago Eight,'' a film that has its premiere on Home Box Office on Saturday, is something of a television novelty. The Chicago Eight, who were tried in 1969 on charges of conspiring to incite a riot at the Democratic National Convention the year before, appear in the film with the actors who portray them, commenting on the action from today's perspective. ''Here was an opportunity to take the real people and have them integrate with the actors who are playing them,'' said Jeremy Kagan, the writer and director of the film. ''How many times can that happen? Most times when you're doing biographical films, the subjects are no longer with us.''

title: DELMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,322,000 and after a provision of $3,408,000 for the estimated loss to be incurred on the disposal of the company's El Salvador subsidiary. c-Net loss

title: Suit Challenges School Book Ban
description: Students, teachers and parents have gone to court to challenge a school board policy banning classroom use of four plays by Shakespeare, Ernest Hemingway's ''The Old Man and the Sea'' and dozens of other classics.

title: THERMAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cutting the Deficit
description: This week in all four National Basketball Association conference semifinals and both Stanley Cup conference finals, six teams faced 3-1 deficits in the four-of-seven-game competitions. In major professional postseason competition, only 15 teams in such situations have rallied to win. Year Team Opponent STANLEY CUP 1942 Maple Leafs* Red Wings 1975 Islanders* Penguins 1987 Islanders Capitals 1987 Red Wings Maple Leafs N.B.A. PLAYOFFS 1968 Celtics 76ers 1970 Lakers Suns 1979 Capitals Spurs 1981 Celtics 76ers WORLD SERIES 1925 Pirates Senators 1958 Yankees Braves 1968 Tigers Cardinals 1979 Pirates Orioles 1985 Royals Cardinals A.L. PLAYOFFS 1985 Royals Blue Jays 1986 Red Sox Angels *Trailed by 3-0

title: Financial Corporation's Talks
description: HF Holdings, whose founders include Preston Martin, former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is interested in buying the troubled Financial Corporation of America and the two companies have held talks, a Financial spokeswoman said today.

title: HERS
description: YEARS ago I journeyed to Europe and took with me excess baggage. Among my material excesses were assorted electrical appliances I'd never use, high heels that made no sense on cobblestone streets, dozens of pleated skirts and sweaters of high school vintage, weighty guidebooks I abandoned in trains, jackets for all weathers, and all those innumerable items called accessories, as if they were accomplices in crime. Along with heavy bags I carried a heavy heart. My inner baggage - a desire to be taken care of, an endless search for love and excessive needs - weighed me down. I spent much of my journey standing in train stations and bus terminals waiting for a porter or some other man to come to my aid.

title: HOW TUITION COSTS ARE SET: AN EDUCATION IN ITSELF
description: Although Education Secretary William J. Bennett and others contend that colleges could reduce tuitions through greater efficiency, many educators and economists say his arguments are wrong and irrelevant. They say education is an ''industry'' in which the normal rules of competition, productivity and price-setting don't apply.

title: MUSIC: RUBBING GLASS
description: FOR nearly a thousand years, Europeans have experimented with musical instruments that rely on rubbed glass as their basic sound source; they seem to have gotten the idea from the Persians, who may have received their inspiration from still farther East. In the late 18th century, Benjamin Franklin elaborated the concept into his ''glass harmonica,'' for which Mozart wrote some charming music. More recently, Francois and Bernard Baschet have created a range of glass instruments, and in 1965 the Museum of Modern Art mounted an exhibition of their sound sculptures.

title: 20% of Banks In Red in '86
description: Some 20 percent of the nation's banks lost money in 1986 and many of the others suffered declining profits, a Federal Reserve study has indicated. In most cases the losses and lower profits were tied to bad loans in the energy and agriculture sectors, the study said.

title: Utah Utility Bonds
description: The Utah Power and Light Company is offering $95 million of 9 7/8 percent bonds due in 2017 at a price of 99 5/8 to yield 9.913 percent. The underwriters, led by Bear, Stearns & Company, won the issue with a bid of 99.059. The issue, rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.&P., yields 1.19 points more than Treasury bonds.

title: 'FOREIGN ALLIANCES AND MISALLIANCES'
description: THERE is an undercurrent to ''Foreign Alliances and Misalliances.'' The panelists on the program, part of the fine series ''The Presidency and the Constitution,'' appear to be thinking about something else. Presumably, it is the Iran-contra affair, which was unfolding when the program was taped. The panelists discuss the mythical country of Alistan, but their minds seem to be on Teheran and Managua.

title: GIULIANI SEEN HURT BY MOVE
description: The Government's move to drop its insider-trading indictments was widely seen yesterday as a major embarrassment for Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney.

title: 4 WIN GENERAL MOTORS CANCER RESEARCH PRIZES
description: Four scientists who have made important contributions to the understanding, treatment and prevention of cancer were named winners of the three 1987 General Motors Cancer Research Foundation prizes yesterday.

title: THE DOCTOR OVERSEEING DR. K
description: Occasionally, Dr. Alan Lans will wear a warm-up suit and take part in calisthenics with the minor leaguers he meets while traveling in the Mets' farm system as a counselor.

title: Law Enacted On Takeovers
description: State legislators today enacted into law a measure enabling shareholders in North Carolina companies, as well as companies that do most of their business in the state, to thwart hostile takeovers.

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
RIGHTS CONFERENCE STIRS WARSAW IRE
description: A three-day meeting of foreign and Polish peace and human-rights activists, held last week in the catacomb-like basement of an unfinished church here, would not have been unusual in London, Stockholm or an American college town. But here, the very fact of its occurrence evoked wonder from the participants and outraged condemnation from the Government.

title: COMSTOCK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $2,531,000.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $6,136,000 for the latest quarter and $5,103,000 for the year-ago period. c-Includes a tax credit of $613,000. Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the deconsolidation of Guaranty National Corp.'s financial statements since the company's investment in Guaranty National is now reflected in the company's consolidated financial statements using the equity method of accounting.

title: INSIDE
description: Economics and Education

title: Comings and Goings
description: Cotton Fitzsimmons, former coach of the Phoenix Suns, rejoined the team in the newly created position of director of player personnel. In another move, the Suns named Herb Brown as an assistant to John Wetzel, who took over last month as the head coach. . . . Robert E. Frederick will return next month to Kansas, his alma mater, as athletic director. He will replace Monte Johnson, who resigned last March to return to private business. . . . Marteese Robinson, the junior first baseman for Seton Hall who leads college baseball with a .540 batting average, was named the Big East Conference Player of the Year. . . . Jerry Mays, who led Georgia Tech in rushing last season, will miss the 1987 season because of torn ligaments and cartilage in his left knee that will require surgery.

title: Associates' Notes
description: The Associates Corporation of North America is offering $100 million of 8 3/8 percent senior notes due in 1990 through underwriters led by U.B.S. Securities. The price may vary, the underwriters said, though the notes were offered at 99.923 to yield 8.40 percent. Rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P., they yield about four-tenths of a point more than Treasury issues of similar maturity.

title: For Woody Allen, A New Audience On Capitol Hill
description: Toward the end of the ''The Front,'' the 1976 movie about a group of New York television writers blacklisted during the McCarthy era, a character named Howard Prince appeals to his producer to somehow spare him from testifying before the House Un-American Activities Committee.

title: TOUCHDOWN FOR FATHER TED
description: I don't remember what the football player said to me after the game - it was two years ago and the topic was the intricacies of defense -but I remember he said it so well that I left the locker room and returned to the press box and immediately leafed through the press guide to find out where this guy went to school. The football player is Dave Duerson, now a safety for the Bears. The school is Notre Dame. The press book said he had earned a bachelor's degree in economics.

title: NEW EVIDENCE SEEN FOR ATMOSPHERE ON PLUTO
description: Evidence that Pluto, the small, outermost planet, has a significant atmosphere has been found in data recorded by the Infrared Astronomy Satellite and supplemented with telescopic observations made from the Earth over the last three years.

title: GUATEMALAN IN PLEA OVER U.S. POLICY
description: Guatemala's President said today that the differing signals coming from the Administration and Congress made it difficult for Central American leaders to know who is responsible for policy.

title: Congressman Denies Guilt
description: Representative Harold E. Ford, a Tennessee Democrat, pleaded not guilty today to charges of bank and mail fraud.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
More Insider Cases Are Due
description: The departing chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission told a Senate panel today that more major insider-trading cases are coming this summer.

title: MASSMUTUAL INCOME INVESORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: MUSIC: THE BANG ON A CAN FESTIVAL
description: THE Bang on a Can Festival, Sunday's 12-hour orgy of contemporary music on lower Broadway, invited the musical browser. Beginning at 2 in the afternoon and stretching into the early hours of the morning, this laid-back, supermarket approach to new ideas offered 28 pieces; stylistically, there was every brand and generic name imaginable.

title: S.E.C. Studies Short-Selling
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked for comment today on a proposal that would prohibit investors from covering short sales of over-the-counter stocks with securities bought from the underwriter or any participating firm in an underwriting syndicate.

title: Unser Rejoins Penske
description: Al Unser, three-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, drove in only five Indy-car races last season before the Penske Racing Team cut him loose. Unser decided to wait for a solid ride before committing for this year's Indianapolis 500, and now he is back with Penske in the seat left vacant by Danny Ongais.

title: CASEY SAID TO HAVE OFFERED NORTH $1 MILLION OF HIS OWN FOR CONTRAS
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North reported that William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, once volunteered to give $1 million of his own money to the Nicaraguan rebels, Robert C. McFarlane testified today.

title: Brian and the Jets
description: With his multicolored, layered Mohawk hairdo, Brian Bosworth hardly fits the Jets' stereotype. On the other hand, he is probably better than any other linebacker they have available to start the season, since Lance Mehl is recuperating from knee surgery.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MAY 14, 1987
description: MARKETS Prosecutors asked for dismissal of insider-trading charges against three Wall Street professionals but are expected to seek a new, broader indictment. The move by the U.S. Attorney is likely to lead to an increasingly complex series of legal maneuvers. But it also creates substantial risks for the prosecution because it opens up possible challenges of any future indictment. A ruling on the dismissal motion could be made today. [ Page A1. ] The move to drop the indictments was regarded by many lawyers as a major embarrassment to Rudolph W. Giulani, the U.S. Attorney. [ D4. ] Stock prices again ended mixed, as rises by blue-chip issues were offset by declines in the broader market. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.08 points, to close at 2,329.68, but declines on the New York Stock Exchange led advances. [ D8. ] Interest rates on notes and bonds were little changed as many participants continued to wait for fresh economic statistics. [ D19. ] Yields continued to climb on bank money-market accounts, certificates of deposit and money-market mutual funds as competition for the saver's dollar intensified among banks. [ D13. ] The dollar moved slightly higher against most currencies except the British pound in quiet trading. Gold fell $1.50 an ounce, to $458, in late trading in New York. [ D20. ] Modest gains in precious metals futures became losses after a late burst of selling. [ D20. ] INTERNATIONAL O.E.C.D. ministers called for reduced farm support. Their communique represented the first time there had been a consensus among the U.S., Europe and Japan that farm subsidies need to be reduced. The ministers also disclosed a new willingness by West Germany to stimulate its economy. [ D1. ] Norway is taking steps to reorganize Kongsberg Vapenfabrik and tighten export controls after the company illegally sold sensitive technology to the Soviet Union, which has enabled the Russians to make their submarines more difficult to detect. [ D1. ] Japanese officials asked currency traders to refrain from speculation in a move aimed at halting the yen's rise. Compliance is voluntary, but such ''administrative guidance'' has worked in the past. [ D21. ] Japan's trade surplus with the U.S. leaped to a record $5.15 billion in April, but analysts said the volume of Japanese exports actually began shrinking. [ D21. ] THE ECONOMY Mail-order retailers would be required to collect sales taxes on out-of-state purchases under legislation before a Congressional panel. The bill would also require national magazines and newspapers to collect sales taxes on subscriptions and remit the revenue to the tax authority of the subscriber's home state. [ D1. ] Retail sales in April were up a mere 0.1 percent, to $125.38 billion. Analysts said that declines in real income and record levels of debt had caused consumers to cut spending for big-ticket items and that they expected the pattern to continue. [ D1. ] COMPANIES A.T.&T. provided details of a reduction in long-distance rates, saying it would lower basic domestic rates by an average of 4.8 percent on July 1. The reduction for residential and business service would save consumers more than $590 million a year. [ D1. ] Sales of new U.S.-made cars dropped 28.5 percent in early May from last year, and light trucks dropped 12.4 percent, their first decline in three months. The seasonally adjusted annual rate fell to 6.5 million units, compared with 8.7 million a year ago. [ D6. ] Tiffany reported net income in the first quarter of more than $1 million, in contrast to a loss in the 1986 period. [ D2. ] A Federal judge tentatively approved paying up to $35 million to about 16,000 retirees to settle a class-action suit against the Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Amoco's offer for Dome Petroleum may be in doubt. It seems likely to get the approval of shareholders but the endorsement by creditors is less certain. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Allegis's stock action was ''really weird,'' first diving and then climbing, as traders and analysts tried to assess its deal with Boeing, which provides $700 million in financing. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: B.P. Now Holding 95% of Standard
description: The British Petroleum Company controls about 95 percent of the common stock of the Standard Oil Company following expiration of its $7.9 billion tender offer for the shares it did not already own, British Petroleum said. The tender offer of $71.50 a share was originally to expire Monday, but was extended through Tuesday because B.P. was unable to obtain a 90 percent stake by the deadline.

title: Young Is Expected to Appear Before Jury in Atlanta Today
description: Mayor Andrew Young has been summoned to appear before a Federal grand jury Thursday in an investigation of possible obstruction of justice by city officials following allegations of cocaine use by him, Julian Bond and other prominent Atlantans.

title: Market Place; A 'Weird' Day For Allegis
description: THE stock market sometimes defies logic and, in turbulent trading yesterday, that is apparently what happened to the shares of the Allegis Corporation, the parent of United Airlines.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Kindred Minds

title: BREWERS DROP EIGHTH IN ROW
description: Mike Davis and Mike Gallego hit home runs to highlight a five-run seventh inning today, leading the Oakland Athletics to an 8-2 victory and sending the Milwaukee Brewers to their eighth straight loss.

title: LINING UP ON DIVESTMENT
description: When the regents of the Smithsonian Institution decided earlier this week to sell its stock in companies doing business in South Africa, no announcement was made as to which regents favored the action and which opposed it.

title: Jets Ask Lynn to Retire
description: Johnny Lynn, the veteran of the Jets' secondary at the age of 31, has failed a second physical examination and has again been asked by the club to retire. Lynn, the club's player representative to the union, has said that if he were to fail the examination he would start a grievance procedure.

title: LOUIS RESHIN FRUMER
description: Louis Reshin Frumer, a former editor in chief of Matthew Bender & Company, a publisher of legal books, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old.

description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results both include a one-time charge of $1.2 million, pre- tax, for costs associated with an early retirement program in the quarter ended March 31; the 6-month results also includes a one-time charge to income tax expense of $585,000 due to repeal of investment tax credits by the Tax Reform Act of 1986 in the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1986. The 1986 results are restated for the adoption of FAS No. 87, Employers' Accounting for Pensions and includes the results of Trans La for the period Jan. 1, 1986, through March 31, 1986.

title: METS: THE MISPLAY'S THE THING
description: The Mets returned to the Astrodome this evening for the first time since they won the pennant in one of those magical games of last October. And for nearly the entire night, they and the Astros performed to a playoff pitch. Ron Darling and Mike Scott worked superbly, and there was Jesse Orosco, in the place where he first threw his glove into the air.

title: Clarence H. Adams, 81, Dies; Former S.E.C. Commissioner
description: Clarence H. Adams, a former commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission and a former president and trustee of the Boston Celtics professional basketball team, died Sunday in the Maine Medical Center here. He was 81 years old.

FIRST CITY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: S.I. Group Dissolved In Dispute Over Guns
description: The Richmond County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, which New York State officials said existed solely so its 65 members could legally carry unlicensed firearms, has been dissolved by a court order.

title: On 'Country 2' and Aid to the Contras
description: At one point, Robert C. McFarlane and Senator Daniel K. Inouye discussed the characteristics of Country 2, which has earlier been identified as Saudi Arabia. Here is that exchange.

description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Dallas Tries Real Desegregation
description: When the West Dallas Housing Project was built it was, like most housing in Texas in 1952, unashamedly segregated: 1,500 units for whites, 1,500 for blacks and 500 for Hispanics. After ''desegregation'' it became all black, like the ghetto that surrounded it. Now, under an unusual three-way agreement, most residents are to be integrated into suburban apartment complexes and most of the project is to be torn down.

title: SYMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
McFARLANE'S ACCOUNT: WORKING WITH NORTH AND THE PRESIDENT
description: In his third day of testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington, Robert C. McFarlane told of efforts to help the Nicaraguan rebels and what President Reagan knew about such aid. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony. NORTH AND CONTRAS

title: Bridge: Winners in Cavendish Teams Posted a Remarkable Score
description: Many of the experts who were gathered at the Cavendish Club during the weekend for the annual Invitational Charity Pairs persevered for another two days in the Cavendish Teams.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $619,075 and $868,313 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, and a tax credit of $251,338 and $1,207,146 for the same periods, respectively.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MAY 14, 1987
description: International A3-15

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Lendl and Wilander Advance: Ivan Lendl, seeded first, and Mats Wilander, seeded second, scored straight-set victories to lead a string of seeded players into the third round of the Italian Open men's tournament yesterday. Lendl, of Czechoslovakia, beat a West German, Damir Keretic, 6-0, 6-3, in the opening match on the clay center court at Foro Italico in Rome. Wilander, of Sweden, overwhelmed Luiz Mattar of Brazil, 6-2, 6-1 on an outside court. John McEnroe, seeded sixth, defeated Argentina's Horacio de la Pena by 6-2, 6-4. Henri Leconte of France, seeded fifth, was one set down and tied at 5-5 in a second-set tiebreaker against Sergio Casal of Spain before rallying to win by 4-6, 7-6, 7-5. Andres Gomez of Ecuador, Emilio Sanchez of Spain and Mikael Pernfors of Sweden were other seeded players who advanced. In the day's biggest upset, Paolo Cane of Italy beat Jonas B. Svensson of Sweden, who was seeded 13th, 6-1, 6-4, and Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland scored an impressive victory, eliminating Sweden's Anders Jarryd, 6-2, 6-4. (AP) Meier Upsets Sukova: Sike Meier of West Germany beat second-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 3-6, 6-4, in a first-round match of the West German Open women's tournament yesterday in West Berlin. Steffi Graf of West Germany, the world's No. 2-ranked player and seeded first, advanced with a 6-4, 6-1 second-round victory over Janine Thompson of Australia. Sukova struggled to make her hard-hitting serve-and-volley game count in the difficult windy conditions against Miss Meier, who is ranked 72d in the world. Fifth-seeded Katarina Lindqvist of Sweden and seventh-seeded Helen Kelesi of Canada were also eliminated. In other first-round action, Adriana Villagran of Argentina defeated Wiltrud Probst of West Germany, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, and Patricia Tarabini of Argentina beat Gabrielle Dinu of West Germany, 6-3, 6-1. (AP) WATER POLO United States Loses to Yugoslavia: Yugoslavia, the world champion, edged the United States, 9-8, yesterday in the men's World Cup in Salonica, Greece, on a goal with two seconds remaining. The loss dropped the Americans into a fourth-place tie with Italy in the round-robin tournament with two victories and two losses. In other games, the Soviet Union beat Italy, 12-7; West Germany downed Cuba, 14-9, and Spain held off Greece, 11-8. The Soviet Union and West Germany remained tied for first place with 7 points. Both have 3-1 records. (AP)

title: Barnard College
description: The president of Barnard College, Ellen V. Futter, yesterday urged students to act morally when faced with choices in their private and professional lives.

title: Dan-Air Lease
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation said it had signed a five-aircraft, $103 million leasing deal with the Dan-Air Ltd. unit of Davies & Newman Holding P.L.C. of London. The transaction includes two new Boeing 737-400 aircraft on three-year leases, with options for a two-year extension, and a two-year lease, with options for a third and fourth year, on two Boeing 737-300 jets.

title: N.V. Philips In Stock Offering
description: N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken said today that it was offering 20 million shares around the world. They were offered at 48.60 guilders, or $24.10, each, the Amsterdam-Rotterdam Bank said, raising $482 million.

title: Bryson and Snyder Seek Cenergy
description: The Bryson Oil and Gas Company and the Snyder Oil Company said they had joined forces in their effort to gain control of the Cenergy Corporation in Dallas. Bryson and Snyder, which own 17.5 percent and 19.9 percent, respectively, of Cenergy's 9.7 million shares outstanding, are the largest single stockholders.

title: Air Force and Airman Settle a Recruiting Dispute
description: In an out-of-court settlement the Air Force has agreed to drop efforts to court-martial a color-blind airman who said he was recruited into an officer training program under false pretenses.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER MUSIC FROM MARLBORO
description: MUSIC FROM MARLBORO'S concert Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall brought together eight artists with a shared musical vision. The vision - a buoyant, outgoing approach to the making of music - is something of a Marlboro trademark, an extension of the esthetic developed at the Marlboro Summer Music Festival in Vermont, headed by the pianist Rudolf Serkin. The festival has been responsible for turning out many thoughtful and talented players.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Includes additional costs of about $1 million to complete film applications. c-Net income

title: U.S. SEEKS TO DROP INSIDER INDICTMENT AGAINST 3 TRADERS
description: In a move that stunned a Federal courtroom in Manhattan, Government prosecutors asked yesterday for the dismissal of insider-trading charges against three Wall Street professionals.

title: GLOBAL CUT URGED FOR FARM AID
description: Ministers of 24 industrial nations called on their governments today to reduce expensive farm support programs, and they also disclosed a new willingness by West Germany to stimulate its economy in response to sagging growth.

title: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 7.

title: 9 Enter N.B.A. Draft
description: Derrick McKey, the Southeastern Conference Player of the Year from Alabama, and Olden Polynice, the former Virginia center, were among nine underclassmen to apply to be eligible for the National Basketball Association draft June 22.

title: WIELDING POWER DISCREETLY
description: Presidents may falter, budget deficits may climb, Cabinet members may come and go. But within the Federal Government the executive secretary stays on, part of a permanent, little-noticed network of civil servants, predominantly women, who are privy to much and tell absolutely nothing.

title: MERCURY GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Strong Turnaround Is Reported by Tiffany
description: Tiffany & Company, which a week ago offered stock to the public after more than two years of being a privately held company, yesterday reported a sharp turnaround in performance for its first quarter ended April 30.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $6,917,000.

title: Two-Headed Israel
description: Every five years, Jordan's King Hussein and Israel's Labor Party chief Shimon Peres figure out a way to embroil the U.S. President in a scheme to (a) undermine the authority of the Prime Minister of Israel and (b) force Israel to give up what Arabists call the West Bank.

title: IN A BERIBBONED BALLROOM, 1,000 GLITTER AT HOSPITAL BENEFIT
description: EVERYTHING is easier the second time around, and running a charity ball is no exception. ''This now has a life of its own,'' Stephen A. Schwarzman said of the Crystal Ball for the Mount Sinai Medical Center. Mr. Schwarzman, a co-founder of the Blackstone Group, and his wife, Ellen, were co-chairmen of the party for the second year. ''It was established last year as a fun evening, a purely social evening,'' he added. ''It's become a hot ticket.'' ''It sold out much faster this year,'' Mrs. Schwarzman said. ''Tables went like crazy. And we made $1,250,000 -a quarter of a million more than last year.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on May 1 about an agreement giving ownership of two parks to tenants of Tudor City in Manhattan misidentified Leonard F. Grant, board president of the tenant group that took title. He is an industrial designer, not a structural engineer.

title: Events; Antiques and West Side Walks
description: Nyack Antiques and Crafts Fair, Main Street and South Broadway, Nyack, N.Y; 914-928-9495.

title: WHERE A ROSE ISN'T JUST A ROSE, BUT AN ANTIQUE
description: SEVERAL times each week, a prospective customer approaches Patricia Wiley at her office in a lush valley near here, cautiously extends a prickly stem and asks her, as if she were a jeweler appraising an antique brooch, to identify the rose.

title: Assembly Sends a Bill On Rents to Governor
description: The State Assembly overwhelmingly approved legislation today to extend rent-regulation and cooperative-conversion laws until June 15, 1989. The measure passed, 95 to 36, with no debate.

title: GULF CANADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $1 million loss from disconinued operations. c-After net from discontinued operations of $149 million and a $72 million special charge. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: YANKS HOLD FIRST, BRIEFLY
description: Bobby Valentine conceded that it was indeed better to win than to lose and that it was better to have been in first place for a day than to never have been in first at all.

title: Angry Pittsburgh Chief Quits
description: William (Mugsy) Moore, the city's first black police Chief, resigned today, asserting that his duties and power had been reduced and that he had been made ''a token.''

title: NAVIGATORS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $404,000 and $30,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: Patent Piracy Bill Advances
description: A Senate subcommittee voted today to allow American companies for the first time to seek Federal court relief against foreign pirating of their patented manufacturing processes. The pirating is estimated to cost American industry billions of dollars annually.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,197,000 and $11,228,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: THE DANCE: 3 WORKS BY CHILDS
description: LUCINDA CHILDS makes simplicity complex. At the same time, she makes complexity seem simple. And because the members of the Lucinda Childs Dance Company usually look relaxed, even when they thread their way through intricate choreographic designs, one suspects that Ms. Childs feels at home amid complexity.

title: Manager for Moynihan
description: The undeclared manager for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's undeclared re-election campaign is the New York Democrat's wife.

title: PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS UNEASY ABOUT QUESTIONS ON ADULTERY
description: In the aftermath of Gary Hart's downfall, most of the Presidential aspirants in both parties showed great reluctance to answer questions on whether adultery should be a campaign issue.

title: TWO EX-CUSTOMS AGENTS ARRESTED IN THE MURDER OF CURRENCY COURIER
description: Two former United States Customs officials were arrested today on Federal charges of robbing and killing a currency courier in 1982 shortly after he had declared to airport Customs agents here that he was carrying some $650,000 in cash and checks.

title: Accounts
description: * Jamar S.A., Geneva, to Smith/ Greenland for a direct marketing program to introduce Maniquick, a manicure/pedicure appliance.

title: TOKYO ASKING YEN RESTRAINT
description: In an effort to halt the yen's rise in value, Japanese Government officials today summoned major Japanese participants in the foreign-exchange market and asked them to refrain from speculative currency trading.

title: Documents Disclosed On Hazards at Work
description: Internal documents made public Tuesday by a member of Congress showed that Government scientists had warned that current levels of allowable exposure to toxic materials in the workplace cause widespread injuries to workers.

title: MOTHER IS ACCUSED OF KILLING HER 2-YEAR-OLD RETARDED SON
description: A woman was charged Tuesday with killing her retarded 2-year-old son, whom 300 people once volunteered to help teach such basics of life as crawling.

title: PARIS BUSINESS FORMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $398,000 from a fire-related settlement.

title: MURDER VERDICTS IN DRUG RING CASE
description: A jury today found three Colombians guilty of the first-degree murder of a key government drug witness.

title: DONOVAN JURORS URGED TO IGNORE NAME-CALLING
description: After listening to eight days of attacks on his integrity by defense lawyers, the chief prosecutor in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan asked a Bronx jury yesterday to ignore ''name calling'' and ''throwing mud'' and to concentrate on the evidence.

title: SOUTHERN ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

description: Is today's stock market bouncing around more than it did before?

title: Car-Sale Drop Disputed
description: A private study predicts that American auto sales this year will decline by only half as much as expected by many forecasters, and imports will continue to gain an ever larger share of the market. The study by Wharton Econometrics, a private forecasting concern in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., and Ward's Automotive Reports states that a buying rush to beat tax-law changes in late 1986 - rather than a collapse in consumer demand - was the primary force behind this year's expected sales decline. The study forecast sales of 10.4 million passenger cars this year and sales of 4.4 million light trucks.

title: APPEALS COURT RULES CHAMBERS HEARING IS OPEN TO THE PRESS
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that news reporters could not be excluded from a pretrial hearing for the man accused of killing Jennifer Levin in Central Park last August.

title: H.R.A. RULES SAID TO ADD TO HOMELESS
description: The cutoff of welfare benefits to thousands of families each year for reasons unrelated to financial need is a main cause of homelessness, a new survey of homeless families in New York City has concluded.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The earnings for the prior year include a charge of $4,221,000 for the closing of a plant in Oakland, Calif.

title: House Approves Debt Ceiling Bill to Avoid Crisis
description: The House of Representatives, moving to avoid a Government financial crisis, today approved a two-month extension of the Federal debt ceiling. The vote was 296 to 124, with 77 Republicans voting for it.

title: ADELPHI ADVANCES BY DEFEATING ARMY
description: Adelphi's skill at ball control was the key to a scoreless final period and a 6-5 victory over Army today in a first-round game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I lacrosse tournament.

title: ILLEGAL SALE SPURS OSLO CRACKDOWN
description: Norway's Defense Minister said today that his Government was taking steps to reorganize a major state-owned company and tighten export controls in the wake of disclosures that the company had illegally sold sensitive technology to the Soviet Union.

title: PISTONS TOP HAWKS TO GAIN EAST FINAL
description: It was just a year ago that the Detroit Pistons were crushed, three games to one, in the opening round of the National Basketball Association playoffs. But after a season of changes, the Pistons are suddenly surprising contenders.

title: Quotron's New System
description: Quotron Systems Inc., a subsidiary of Citicorp, said today that it had developed a new global trading system built around existing Quotron products and services. The company said it will start testing the system at customer sites this fall. The product will feature displays of information from various sources intermixed on screens and integrated with Quotron's market information, analytical applications and third-party research data bases.

title: SAVANNAH FOODS & INDUSTRY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Head of Caremark Is a Pioneer in His Field
description: In the late 1970's, James M. Sweeney realized that a considerable number of hospital patients requiring intravenous therapy and nutrition did not really need to be hospitalized. Parenteral, or nondigestive, feeding could be done at home, he reasoned, freeing patients and their insurers from uncomfortable, expensive hospital stays.
