title: CONCERT: MAHLER'S EIGHTH
description: THIS seems to be the season for massive choral events, with singers spilling out from the stage into seats normally used for the audience and electronic organs thundering away in eager imitation of the real thing. Peter Tiboris's MidAmerica productions has presented some stirring concerts of this sort already, and Monday night in Carnegie Hall it was the turn of the Canterbury Choral Society.

They are The Vietnam Experience, Healthy Home Cooking, Great Meals in Minutes and The Good Cook. The billings will be in the undisclosed millions. description: Traces of a barbiturate were found in the engineer of a Conrail train that hit another train and derailed last month in Pittsburgh, the Federal Railroad Administration said today.

title: BIOGEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Platinum Leads Decline In Precious Metal Prices
description: A late burst of selling yesterday converted modest gains in precious metals futures into moderate losses. As usual, the volatile platinum futures posted the largest declines. Brokers attributed the late selloff to the squaring of positions by nervous holders before the release of the March balance of trade figures by the Government this morning.

title: Debentures Issued By Ryder System
description: The Ryder System Inc. is offering $100 million of 9 7/8 percent debentures due in 2017 at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 9.901 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: RIGHTS PANEL ASSAILS HIGH COURT FOR SANCTIONING JOB PREFERENCES
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights has drafted a statement harshly criticizing the Supreme Court for a recent decision upholding job preferences for women and minority-group employees.

title: Don't Bet on Peace In Central America
description: Have the prospects for a negotiated settlement in Central America really improved? At first glance, one might think so. On March 12, for example, the United States Senate voted 97 to 1 to express its strong support for ''the thrust'' of a peace plan put forward by the Costa Rican President, Oscar Arias Sanchez - a plan that is to be discussed by the five Central American presidents at a June meeting in Esquipulas, Guatemala.

title: RATES STEADY IN QUIET SESSION
description: Interest rates on notes and bonds were little changed in generally quiet trading yesterday. Many participants continued to wait on the sidelines for fresh economic statistics.

title: 210 FUGITIVES CAUGHT IN NATIONAL DRUG SWEEP
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced today that 210 people have been arrested over the last two months in the Government's first nationwide crackdown on fugitives wanted on drug trafficking charges.

title: BANISTER CONTINENTAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

U.S. Concerns Defy Pretoria on Integrated Housing
description: Seventy-seven American companies operating in South Africa have settled black, Indian and mixed-race employees in whites-only areas in defiance of the country's residential apartheid laws.

title: KEY RATES
ISRAELIS DEADLOCKED OVER PARLEY
description: The inner Cabinet failed again today to reach a decision on whether Israel should take part in an international peace conference on the Middle East.

title: CANING FOR OLD CHAIRS
description: JOHN BAUSERT'S family has been in the chair-caning business since 1899. His store, Veterans Caning Shop in Manhattan, does both hand caning and machine caning.

title: Reversing Age
description: On three consecutive days this week, the Texas Rangers defeated three starting pitchers with a combined age of 133 years and a combined victory total of 903 major league games.

title: GAP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
NOVO INDUSTRI A/S reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results are translated into U.S. dollars at the March 31 exchange rate for Danish kroner at U.S. $1 equals per 6.8175 Danish kroner. Share earnings are in American Depositary Shares (ADS).

title: OPERA: 'SALVATOR ROSA'
description: ALMOST all of his works have dropped into obscurity, but for a while the Brazilian-born Antonio Carlos Gomes was a leading Italian opera composer. Gomes first came to know the works of Bellini and Donizetti and Verdi as a student in Rio de Janeiro in the 1850's and 1860's. He began composing operas of his own, and the success of his ''Joana de Flandres'' in 1863 won the 27-year-old Gomes a grant, sponsored by the Brazilian Government, to study at the Milan Conservatory. By 1870, he triumphed at La Scala with ''Il Guarany,'' which remains the composer's best-known work.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT DECLINED IN MARCH AS EXPORTS SURGED
description: A surge in exports, to the highest monthly level in six years, helped to narrow the United States trade deficit to $13.6 billion in March, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: JAZZ: KEN PEPLOWSKI A J'S
description: KEN PEPLOWSKI, who plays jazz on both clarinet and tenor saxophone, has developed a clarinet style that avoids the two paths usually taken by most contemporary clarinetists. He is neither as wide-ranging as Eddie Daniels or Richard Stoltzman, who are involved in both classical music and jazz, nor as individually focused as those who follow Benny Goodman's swing style or Buddy de Franco's be-bop approach.

title: A FROLIC-PACKED WEEKEND OF FAIRS, FUNNEL CAKES AND BUCKING BRONCOS
description: FESTIVAL mania has struck New York. Every spring, the city's calendar is filled with street festivals, fairs and parades, but rarely do so many occur on a single weekend. In the next 60 hours or so, it is likely that more people will be marching, eating, singing, dancing, shopping and schmoozing in the city's great outdoors than during any other weekend of the year.

title: THE SENATE VOTES THRIFT AID AGAIN
description: For the second time in two months, the Senate today passed a legislative package that would inject $7.5 billion in new money over the next two years into the insolvent fund that insures $900 billion of deposits at the nation's 3,200 thrift institutions. Today's vote was 93 to 3.

title: ANYTHING'S BETTER THAN TARANTULAS
description: IN a 1981 film debut as brief as it was traumatic, Alfred Molina let tarantulas swarm over him.

title: FLORIDA OFFICIALS YIELD ON BOOK BAN
description: The Bay County School Board has proposed tearing up a list of 64 books the Superintendent wanted banned from high school classes, a day after a lawsuit was filed on constitutional grounds.

title: ROYAL DUTCH-SHELL GROUP OF COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Royal Dutch Petroleum's share of group net amounted to $2.59 a share compared with $2.49 in the year-ago quarter; Shell Transport & Trading Co.'s share of group net was equal to $1.38 a share up from $1.33 in the year- earlier quarter.

title: Tip Who?
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who until last January was the Speaker of the House of Representatives, learned recently how fleeting is fame in the nation's capital.

title: NEW APPROACH FOR L.P.G.A.
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.J., May 14 -

title: Reaction Cool To Amoco Bid
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the debt-ridden Canadian oil company, disclosed terms of a $3.86 billion takeover bid from the Amoco Corporation to its 60 major creditors today, but there were indications the offer could fail.

title: INVENTORIES UP BY 0.4% IN MARCH
description: Business inventories edged upward in March for the third consecutive month, and economists said sales would have to pick up soon to justify the growth in unsold stock.

title: EAGLE BANCSHARES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company went public March 27, 1986.

title: LONG SPELL OF WARM, DRY, WEATHER WORRIES CORN BELT INTERESTS
description: A long spell of warm, dry weather is spreading anxiety across the most productive parts of the Corn Belt as well as in markets where their crops are traded.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Graf Gains: Top-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany routed Claudi Porwik, another West German, 6-0, 6-1, yesterday to gain the quarterfinals of the West German Open in West Berlin. In other matches, sixth-seeded Rafaella Reggi of Italy and 13th-seeded Nathalie Tauziat of France also reached the quarterfinals. But eighth-seeded Jo Durie of Britain was upset by an unseeded 17-year-old Australian, Nicole Provis, 6-1, 4-6, 6-4. Patricia Tarabini of Argentina, another unseeded player, advanced to her first major tournament quarterfinal when Sike Meier of West Germany twisted an ankle and retired with Tarabini ahead, 6-1, 5-0.(AP) College Baseball C. W. Post Wins: Julio Morales scored a run and drove in another to lead C. W. Post (27-11-1) to a 2-1 victory over the University of New Hampshire yesterday in the opening round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I baseball championship at Beehive Stadium in New Britain, Conn. In the second game of the doubleheader, Brad Howland of Fordham hit a two-run homer with one out in the bottom of the ninth to give the Rams an 8-7 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson. Pete Harnish, the Fordham starter, pitched four innings, giving up five runs. Fordham's record is now 28-11; F.D.U. dropped to 16-14. New York Tech beat Utica, 15-5, in another game. Golf Two Birdies Worth Lead: Bill Rogers birdied the last two holes for a 65 and a one-shot lead yesterday in the first round of the $600,000 Colonial National Invitation Tournament in Fort Worth. ''There was a lot of resemblance to the guy who used to shoot some good scores,'' said Rogers, who has been mired in a deep slump since winning the British Open and player-of-the-year honors in 1981. His only victory since then came in New Orleans in 1983. One stroke back at 66, four under par in the chase for a $108,000 first prize, were Clarence Rose, Bill Sander and Chip Beck. Beck had the lead alone until he bogeyed the last two holes.

title: SURVEY ASSAILS INACCURATE 'LEAN' LABELS FOR MEAT
description: Consumers who buy ground beef labeled ''lean'' or ''extra lean'' in New York City supermarkets have no guarantee that the meat is any leaner than regular ground beef, which can cost half as much, according to the City Consumer Affairs Department.

title: Order for Sikorsky
description: The United Technologies Corporation said it had received an Australian Army order worth more than $200 million for an additional 25 S-70A-9 Sikorsky Black Hawk helicopters. The company had previously received orders for 30 of the helicopters from the Australian Army and Navy. It said the first delivery of the 55 helicopters would take place in October 1987.

title: Wrong on Rights, Again
description: References to the current United States Commission on Civil Rights ought to carry a disclaimer: ''Despite its name, this body no longer can be relied upon to stand up for the rights of those who have legitimately felt unfairly treated, now or in the past.'' That would help the public make sense of documents like the one on which the commission plans to vote today. It condemns the Supreme Court's recent decision upholding affirmative action hiring preferences for women and minorities.

title: Piano and Bass Duo
description: The duo of John Hicks on piano and Buster Williams on bass will perform tonight and tomrrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music starts at 9:45 P.M.; there is no cover charge.

title: SEA CONTAINERS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Real Air Safety Scandal
description: Who's right? The National Transportation Safety Board, citing ''an erosion of safety'' in the air traffic control system, calls for immediate reductions in peak-hour flights. The Federal Aviation Administration acknowledges increasing strains on the system, but argues that the margin of safety remains high.

title: 'QUARTERMAINE'S TERMS,' BY SIMON GRAY, ON 13
description: SIMON GRAY, the British playwright, has established himself solidly in this country with a series of plays going back to ''Butley'' in the early 1970's and continuing to the current production of ''The Common Pursuit.'' Approximately in the middle, in 1981, he wrote what is perhaps his most representative and most skillful work thus far: ''Quartermaine's Terms.'' That play has now been produced wonderfully well by Louis Marks for the BBC and can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13 as a ''Great Performances'' presentation.

title: El Paso Is Puzzled By Player's Death
description: A medical examiner's finding today provided few answers for the people of El Paso as they continued to search for the reason behind the death of one of the local university's most personable and well-known basketball players.

title: FALWELL SAYS PTL NEEDS CASH
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell says the PTL ministries have to raise $20 million to $25 million in 90 days and cut expenses by $1 million a month to survive.

title: FIJI COLONEL NAMES GOVERNMENT, BUT CONTROL OF ISLANDS IS IN DOUBT
description: The army colonel who led a bloodless coup here named a new government today, but the Governor General, an influential chief, said he had assumed executive power.

title: MR GASKET CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Of 'Steelhammer' and 'TC'
description: In his testimony, Robert W. Owen described a world of code names on mysterious documents. Here are excerpts from the questioning.

title: CONTINUING A DYNASTY
description: DEAD babies and a crypt full of rats, insects crawling out of a corpse's mouth and a writhing pile of leeches served up on a silver platter, flying goblins that attack her throat with sharp talons and the sight of her beloved in the arms of another man -such horrors are only a few of many endured by the character of Mary Godwin during the long, trying night brought to the screen in Ken Russell's new movie, ''Gothic.''

title: FARM EXPORT WEAPON VOTED BY SENATE PANEL
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee today approved a huge export-subsidy program for American farmers that would take effect in 1990 if other food-exporting nations failed to reduce or eliminate their agricultural subsidies.

title: More Tokyo Stock Seats
description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange plans to upgrade its computers and renovate its building to provide more seats for foreign brokerage firms by next May, it said today. Of the six that now hold seats on the Tokyo exchange, three are American - Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and Goldman, Sachs.

title: BUSH ASKS BACKING OF NEW YORK G.O.P.
description: Vice President Bush began a push for New York Republican support last night with a speech at the largest political event in the state - the annual Nassau County Republican fund-raising dinner.

title: INSIDE
description: Shake-Up at Wall St. Firm Kidder, Peabody's chief executive is stepping down as part of a reorganization announced by the firm's parent, General Electric. Page D1. Police Officer Convicted A jury in Brooklyn, after deliberating three hours, convicted an officer accused in the 77th Precinct corruption scandal. Page B1.

title: DR. MILLA ALIHAN
description: Dr. Milla Alihan, a psychologist and former management consultant, died of a stroke yesterday at New York Hospital. She lived in Manhattan and was in her 80's.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest periods included results of operations of Trim Trends Inc., acquired in February 1986, and of Kingston-Warren Corp. and Hayes-Albion Corp., acquired at the end of December 1986.

title: Abuse of Candidates Is an American Tradition; Poor Judgment
description: To the Editor:

title: BROADWAY
description: ANOTHER play is coming over here from over there - but save the sighs. This one, which closed recently after a successful run in London's West End, is not only set in America (Cleveland, 1934), but was written by Ken Ludwig, an American, and was seen originally at the American Stage Festival in New Hampshire.

title: BIDEN, OFFERING VISION OF PRESIDENCY, SEES AMERICAN DREAM ON THE WANE
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., laying out the broad themes of his Democratic Presidential candidacy, today declared that ''the American economic dream has begun to evaporate'' and that solutions lay ''beyond the reach of government.''

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Presidency; Espousing 'High Morality,' Living With Scandal
description: Moral values have always been a key element of President Reagan's appeal. In a recent interview, when asked to describe the legacy he will leave after eight years in office, Mr. Reagan answered, ''I hope that the imprint would be . . . one of high morality.'' He went on to denounce ''value-free education'' and to urge schools and parents to impart ''the right and wrong of things'' to young people.

title: Dow Chemical Shifts Top-Level Executives
description: Frank P. Popoff, an executive vice president who runs the Dow Chemical Company's international business, has been named the company's president and chief operating officer - one of several management changes that Dow announced yesterday.

title: HOTEL FACING FINE OF $527,400 IN SAN JUAN FIRE
description: Puerto Rico's job safety agency proposed today that San Juan's Dupont Plaza Hotel be fined $527,400 for violations that contributed to the New Year's Eve fire that killed 97 people.

title: LEE DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $152,000 from discontinued operations. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,139,000 for the quarter and $2,589,000 for the year. d-Net loss

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A Benefit Jazz Concert for Carol Britto, St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street (Information: 362-6580). A benefit concert this Sunday evening for Carol Britto, a pianist who is recovering from an illness, promises to be a summit of mainstream jazz talent. Ms. Britto, a student of Oscar Peterson, plays with a hard-swinging, expressive romanticism that has earned comparisons to Erroll Garner and Thelonious Monk as well as to her teacher. She will perform, as well as some fellow keyboardists: Dave McKenna, Marian McPartland, Mike Renzi, Lance Hayward and Frank Kimbrough. Other guests include Tal Farlow, Peter Leitch and Wayne Wright on guitar; Al Grey and Wayne Andre on trombone; Marvin Stamm and Ed Polcer on trumpet; Clarence Hutchenrider, clarinet; Major Holley, Paul West and Dave Shapiro on bass; Bobby Rosengarten, Jackie Williams and Tootsie Bean on drums; Percy France and Loren Schoenberg on saxopone; the Ernie Lumer Sextet, and the singers Jackie and Roy, Joya Sherrill and Joan Foley. Suggested donation is $12.50. Tickets are available at the door. Show time is 8:15 P.M.

title: ENRILE LEADS 10,000 IN MANILA ELECTION PROTEST
description: Juan Ponce Enrile, described by an opponent as ''a wounded tiger,'' led thousands of supporters today in a protest over his party's apparent defeat in legislative elections.

title: Pretoria Ousting 2 Reporters for British TV
description: The South African Government today ordered two senior British television correspondents to leave the country.

title: DOME PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 'The Most Cruel'
description: It was a modest Congressional hearing, little noted, in comparison with the Iran-contra hearings. But suddenly, in a few minutes, it illuminated a most important question about the United States Government's proxy war on Nicaragua: what the war has done to us.

title: Person Is Top Rookie
description: Chuck Person, the talented forward who helped the Indiana Pacers to their first playoff berth in six seasons, has been named the 1987 National Basketball Association Rookie of the Year. Person received 68 votes from the nationwide panel of news media members to win the Eddie Gottlieb Trophy.

title: Diablo Canyon Cost Report
description: The California Public Utilities Commission's Public Staff division, a consumer-advocacy unit, recommended today that the Pacific Gas and Electric Company be allowed to recover from rate payers only $1.15 billion of the $5.52 billion cost of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant. The commission can accept all, part or none of the division's recommendation in its final determination, which is not expected for at least one year.

title: 10-Stringed Guitar
description: Yomo Toro, who plays the Puerto Rican cuatro (10-stringed guitar), will perform tonight at 8 at the Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue at 68th Street (249-8950). Tickets are $12. On Sunday, Mr. Toro will lead his band at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue at 13th Street (242-1664), in a benefit for the Public Image Art Gallery, with Peter Cherches, a singer, opening. Shows are at 9:15 and 11:30 P.M.; admission is $15.

title: Move to Raze Embassy In Moscow Is Defeated
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today defeated a measure requiring demolition of the United States Embassy building under construction in Moscow.

title: IDENTICAL TWIN SISTERS MAKE WEST POINT HISTORY
description: Whenever Brig. Gen. Roy R. Flint encounters Cadets Tara or Tracy Miller on the grounds of the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., he plays it safe. They are identical twins, and he is never sure which is which.

title: Ex-Postal Official Indicted in Wedtech Bribe Case
description: A former United States Postal Service official has been charged with accepting bribes from the Wedtech Corporation and an internal investigation is examining the possibility that the Postal Service itself was cheated by the Bronx military contractor, the subject of other state and Federal inquiries.

title: JURORS SEQUESTERED IN DONOVAN TRIAL
description: A Bronx judge sequestered the jury in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan yesterday following a report that Mr. Donovan is being reinvestigated by a special Federal prosecutor.

title: MCA ENDS SALE PLAN
description: MCA Inc. has decided against selling 15 percent of its music-entertaiment gourp to the public, reversing last month's announcement that it might do so.

title: Good Neighbor Dies Helping Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICEMAN IS CONVICTED ON GRAFT
description: After deliberating only three hours, a jury yesterday found a suspended New York City police officer, one of those accused of corruption in the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn, guilty of all 37 counts on which he was tried.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 381 money market mutual funds decreased $683.4 million, to $235.63 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 93 institutional funds were down $522.2 million, to $64.17 billion. Assets of the 199 general-purpose funds were up $299.0 million, to $67.04 billion. The 89 broker-dealer funds fell $460.2 million, to $104.41 billion.

title: Nippon Syndicate For Big Yen Issue
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation has asked four foreign securities houses to be among the 30 members of the underwriting syndicate for its planned 100 billion yen issue of 11-year bonds, a company spokesman said. A public offering is expected today.

title: Britain Plans Airbus Aid
description: The British Government said today that it would lend $:450 million, or about $750 million, to British Aerospace P.L.C. to develop a new generation of aircraft for the Airbus Industrie consortium.

title: Advertising; Expanding Market for Turkey
description: TURKEY consumption, already the fastest-growing among meat products in the United States, would grow even faster if it weren't for a certain mental block among consumers. To them turkey means big bird for big meal, a holiday offering.

title: Nystrom Upsets Lendl
description: Joakim Nystrom of Sweden upset Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3, today in the third round of the Italian Open.

title: AFRICAN DEBT HELP AND LIBERAL TRADE ARE SUMMIT GOALS
description: Agreement on a debt-relief plan for black Africa and steps to speed talks on freer trade will be the most concrete results of next month's economic summit meeting, according to officials preparing the talks.

title: JAMES MADISON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The increase in shares outstanding reflects the public offering of 2.9 million common shares on Oct. 8, 1986.

title: FARMERS IN JAPAN AGREE TO A RICE SUBSIDY CUT
description: With Japan's protectionist agricultural policies under attack at home and abroad, the nation's most powerful farmers' group has agreed to accept a cut in rice subsidies for the first time in 31 years.

title: G.E. TIGHTENS REINS AT KIDDER, PEABODY
description: After 20 years as head of one of Wall Street's most prominent investment banking houses, Ralph D. DeNunzio is stepping down as chief executive of the Kidder, Peabody Group Inc. His resignation is part of a management shake-up announced yesterday as the General Electric Company moved to assert control over the firm it bought last year.

title: STUDENTS ARE ROBBED OF $2,000 AT ACTORS' CENTER IN MANHATTAN
description: Two men, one of them apparently armed with a rifle, burst into an actors' studio in Manhattan Wednesday night and robbed 28 people of cash and jewelry, the police said.

title: DR. THEODORE NORMAN
description: Dr. Theodore Norman, former managing director of the Baron de Hirsch Fund, which assists Jewish farmers, died of cancer Wednesday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE appearance of grilled bear steak on the menu of a new downtown restaurant, the TriBeCa Cafe, presented an irresistible temptation. Was this just a publicity stunt? Or, perhaps, is some atavistic eating trend arising in certain bohemian circles? The grilled bear steak, served with chestnuts and bacon in a red-onion sauce ($17.50), is just one of five game dishes on this wide-ranging regional menu. The all-American fare ranges from roast breast of turkey with all the fixings ($10.50) and grilled venison ($17) to macaroni and cheese ($8.50) and Boston scrod with ginger cream sauce ($10.50).

title: TORIES EXPERIMENT IN AILING SCOTLAND
description: The politics of Scotland resound with grand experiments in Britain's national attic.

title: Suspect in Philadephia Is Insane, Lawyer Says
description: The lawyer for a man accused of murdering two women and kidnapping, raping and torturing four more said today that his client is ''completely and totally insane'' and entered pleas of not guilty to all the charges.

title: Abuse of Candidates Is an American Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: AUCTIONS
description: A REMARKABLE African mask - the eyes heavily lidded, lips parted and skin surface deeply grooved in chevron patterns - is to be auctioned Wednesday at 10:15 A.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. The powerfully carved work, probably completed before the 1920's in the Belgian Congo (now Zaire), was worn by medicine men of the Songe tribe in times of danger or during initiations of tribal members into a secret society.

title: Halley's Who?
description: The heavens tend to be more constant than human beings, the United States Observervatory discovered somewhat belatedly.

title: No Reinstatement
description: The N.B.A. refused to reinstate Micheal Ray Richardson despite Richardson's contention that his former drug counselor caused him to relapse into cocaine use and resulted in his ban from the N.B.A. Gary Bettman, the N.B.A.'s vice president and general counsel, said in a statement that Richardson's dispute with the counselor has nothing to do with the 32-year-old guard's attempt to rejoin the league.

title: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest first quarter.

title: HOLLERING THE CHICAGO BLUES SOUND
description: IF there had been electric guitars back in the 1920's, Joe Willie (Pinetop) Perkins might still be a guitarist, still calling himself Little Willie. But when he'd play the blues at house parties near his hometown of Belzoni, Miss., he said the other day, ''everytime I'd go where somebody was playing the piano, they'd drown me out.'' By the early 30's, he'd decided to switch to piano - a choice that has made blues fans grateful for more than 50 years.

title: Soviet Industry Below Target
description: The Soviet Union's industrial production, a major focus of the effort by the nation's leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to rejuvenate the economy, fell below target in the first four months of this year, with particularly acute problems in the machine-building sector.

title: MATTINGLY BREAKS OUT IN GRAND STYLE AS YANKS ROLL
description: Rickey Henderson, who was to help fuel the Yankees' 9-1 victory over Texas yesterday with his bat, his legs and his glove, had led off the first inning with a home run. Willie Randolph had then walked and worked his way around to third on Ed Correa's wild pitch and errant pickoff throw. Don Mattingly was the next batter, but consistent with his seasonlong slump, he hit a weak bouncer back to the mound.

title: DRAWINGS EXAMINE MODERNISM WITH WIT AND HUMOR
description: ANYONE who takes a little trouble can chart the ups and downs and the ins and outs of modernist predilections as they have evolved since the beginning of our century. Not only can those predilections be charted, but they can be combined and recombined ad infinitum. Dealers, curators, collectors and writers on art find in those recombinings the occupation of a lifetime. Lay people function as observers - marveling, making mock, sometimes a bit out of it but ever ready to try some conjunctions of their own.

title: Market Place; Grain Traders Active Again
description: FOR the better part of three years, business in the grain pits at the Board of Trade here has not been exactly brisk.

title: TIFFANY & CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss Tiffany completed its initial public offering May 5. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: 'Shoot Your Best Shot,' McFarlane Urged, But Imprecise Points Weren't Followed Up
description: In four days of questioning, the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair never pinned down Robert C. McFarlane on what he told President Reagan about the White House staff's activities on behalf of the Nicaraguan rebels. Mr. McFarlane, who was the President's national security adviser from October 1983 through December 1985, is one of only two witnesses who could reasonably be expected in the course of the hearings to testify thoroughly on what the President knew and said about those activities. The other such witness, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, who succeeded Mr. McFarlane as national security adviser, will not testify until next month.

title: Donald Joyce, Organist
description: Donald Joyce, an organist, will present two performances of Bach's ''Art of the Fugue,'' Sunday at 3 P.M. and Monday at 8 P.M., at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, 55th Street and First Avenue. Admission is $5 at the door; information: 675-3652.

title: Alysheba Stirs Worries With Slow Drill Bet Twice on Rail in Field of 9
description: BALTIMORE, May 14 -

title: PANEL SAYS LAW WAS IGNORED WHEN SOVIET SAILOR FLED SHIP
description: A Congressional commission has concluded that State Department and other Federal officials ignored the law in their handling of a Soviet seaman who twice jumped ship near New Orleans in 1985, in what appeared to be a defection attempt.

title: CHAMPION OF MODERN MUSIC
description: Lawrence Morton, a longtime champion of contemporary music in the Los Angeles area and former director of the Monday Evening Concerts and the Ojai Festival there, died, apparently of a heart attack, May 8 at the home of his brother Arthur in Santa Monica. He was 82 years old.

title: Northwest to Buy G.E. Engines
description: Northwest Airlines said it would buy up to 325 airplane engines from a joint venture between the General Electric Company and a French company, the Societe Nationale d'Etude et de Construction de Moteurs d'Aviation, for about $1.25 billion. Northwest, which is based in Minneapolis, said that the General Electric group beat out a consortium involving Pratt & Whitney and Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the airplane engine maker.

title: Comings and Goings
description: World B. Free, a former N.B.A. star, signed a contract with the Miami Tropics of the United States Basketball League. . . . Henri Leconte of France, the World's sixth-ranked player, has said he will tune up for the Wimbledon tennis tournament in the Bank of Scotland Grasscourt Championships in Edinburgh June 6-14. The women's field includes Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and Zina Garrison of the United States. . . . Johnny Parsons, a veteran of 11 Indianapolis 500-mile races and the son of a former winner, fractured his left heel and right ankle in a crash during practice for the May 24 race. Parsons, 42 years old, of Brownsburg, Ind., was taken by helicopter to Methodist Hospital for X-rays, evaluation of his injuries and treatment.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review Tuesday of the television coverage of the Iran-contra Congressional hearings incorrectly paraphrased a statement by Senator Howell Heflin, Democrat of Alabama, about Richard V. Secord. Senator Heflin said he believed that Mr. Secord would be indicted.

title: 2--YEAR-OLD L.I. MAN IS ARRESTED FOR CRASH THAT KILLEDNEWLYWEDS
description: The police today arrested a man they said was driving a speeding car that crashed into a limousine carrying a wedding party in Lido Beach on April 3, killing three people. He faces nine charges, including second-degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide.

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net realized gains of $9,978. c-Net income

title: FILM: HOFFMAN AND BEATTY IN ELAINE MAY'S 'ISHTAR'
description: THERE are parts of ''Ishtar'' that could have been directed by anyone - anyone equal to the demands of a big-name, big-scenery adventure, anyone capable of herding large crowds of extras across the screen. But there are also parts that could have been directed only by Elaine May. One of these finds Chuck Clarke (Dustin Hoffman), a writer of horrible songs, being cradled in the arms of Lyle Rogers (Warren Beatty), a songwriter of equivalent talent who is Chuck's partner in crime. Chuck is in the midst of attempting suicide, but he has become distracted, as usual, by the artistic possibilities inherent in his situation.

title: McCoy Tyner
description: McCoy Tyner, a pianist, is leading a trio tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 P.M. and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.

title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $4,253,000 from discontinued operations. The company said year-ago results are restated and include realized investment gains of $197,000.

title: LET'S SEE, COUNTRY 1 OR 2?
description: As the Iran-contra hearings proceed, witnesses and committee members are confusing their audiences by referring to foreign countries by predesignated numbers instead of by their names.

title: INTERCARE INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Profits Fall at Shell, B.P
description: Two of the world's largest oil companies, Royal Dutch/Shell Group Ltd. and British Petroleum P.L.C., today reported lower first-quarter earnings. Both companies cited a squeeze in refining margins, a problem that has also affected American oil companies this year.

title: POLITICAL DIVISION WIDENING IN SEOUL
description: For the last five weeks, Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's most prominent anti-Government figure, has been held prisoner inside his house in a quiet Seoul neighborhood.

title: CONCERT: GERHARD WORKS BY SPECULUM MUSICAE
description: ROBERTO GERHARD is a composer distantly respected but not often heard in New York, so Speculum Musicae provided a real service by devoting the first half of its concert Tuesday night in Merkin Concert Hall to his music.

title: NEVADA PARDONS 2 IN 1907 MURDER DURING LABOR-COMPANY BATTLE
description: The Nevada Pardons Board has granted posthumous pardons to two members of a radical union whose trial for murder 80 years ago affected the history of the American labor movement.

title: They Lied to Congress
description: The most audacious excuse made for the Reagan Administration's Iran-contra disasters is that it was all Congress's fault. For some apologists, the reason that money for the Nicaraguan rebels had to be raised illegally was the meddlesome action of Congress to ban official military aid.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 15, 1987
description: The Economy

title: STAGE: 'WAVING GOODBYE'
description: BOB MORRIS toys with an old movie device in his play ''Waving Goodbye,'' showing us a suburban Long Island family in smiling or clowning photographs and then bringing the pictures to life to reveal the real emotions behind the images. Flashed on screens in large frames, the photographs taken through three decades of a mother, father and two sons eventually become silent characters in the play, moving in counterpoint to the speaking characters.

title: IN THE SOUTH BRONX, EAST-WEST BASKETBALL DIPLOMACY
description: The Russians went to the South Bronx last night to play basketball, and on the way got a glimpse of opulence, poverty, traffic, iniquity and other features of the real New York. It was just what they had hoped to see.

title: Maryland Drug Plan
description: The University of Maryland, still reeling from the fallout caused by the cocaine-induced death of Len Bias last year, has unveiled a $300,000 anti-drug initiative, including stiffer punishments for drug users, more counseling and education and reduced random testing for athletes.

title: ALLIED SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for 12wks to April 4
description: b-Includes tax credits of $86,000 and $648,000 for the 12 weeks and 40 weeks, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $1,059,000 for the 12 weeks and $3,221,000 for the 40 weeks. The year-ago 12 weeks and 40 weeks include pre-tax gains on sale of Family Drug stores of $290,000 and $1,496,000, respectively.

title: Ford to Study Retooling Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was considering spending more than $900 million to retool a tractor factory near Detroit for the production of a new line of engines.

title: Former United Way Official Sentenced in $15,000 Theft
description: A former campaign chairman of the United Way was given a conditional discharge today for taking almost $15,000 in United Way funds donated by workers at his company.

title: KOCH TOUR PAUSES IN KANSAS FOR ADDRESS ON URBAN ISSUES
description: Mayor Koch, seeking to create a role for himself in the 1988 Presidential campaign as a spokesman for the cities and for the political center, called today for increased efforts by the Federal Government and individuals to build housing, combat illicit drugs and care for AIDS victims.

title: The U.N. Today: May 15, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Economic Committee - 3 P.M.

title: President Leaving Job at RKO General
description: Shane O'Neil, the president of RKO General since 1983, is leaving the company. RKO is the entertainment division of Gencorp, formerly the General Tire and Rubber Company, which was founded by Mr. O'Neil's grandfather, William, in 1915. Mr. O'Neil was the last family member to hold an operating position in the company.

title: Estonia Was Victim of Hitler and Stalin
description: To the Editor:

title: FLYERS WIN, 4-3, TO GAIN FINAL
description: There was screaming in the Philadelphia locker room and a deathly quiet in the room where, beneath the gaze of their predecessors, whose portraits are accompanied by a demand for further excellence, the current Canadiens bowed their heads after a 4-3 defeat.

title: Don't Touch That Dial
description: Subscribers to Capitol Connection, a microwave television broadcast service provided by George Mason University, were surprised yesterday morning to turn on their sets expecting to receive the joint Congressional hearings into the Iran-contra affair and instead see a business meeting of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Mayor and Aide Are Indicted In a Baton Rouge Inquiry
description: Mayor Pat Screen and a former top aide have been indicted on one count each of malfeasance involving millions of dollars in road projects done just before re-election campaigns by the Mayor in 1984.

title: School Bands Compete
description: The McDonald's High School Big Band Competition will present its finals contest and concert Sunday at the Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Street at 122d Street. Bands will compete from noon to 4 P.M.; the winners will perform from 4 P.M. to 5 P.M., with Branford Marsalis as guest saxophonist . Admission is free; information, 749-2802.

title: Tom Paxton
description: Tom Paxton, a singer and songwriter, will perform tonight at 8 at P.S. 41, 116 West 11th Street, in a concert presented by the New York Pinewoods Folk Music Club (594-8833). Admission is $8, or $4 for children and the elderly.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,570,000 from alitiagation award.

title: PERES'S STAFF, IN ISRAELI INFIGHTING, BARS SHAMIR MESSAGE TO EMBASSIES
description: The fighting inside the Israeli Government reached a new level today.

title: Suit Payment For Anheuser
description: Paul Thayer, a former Dallas industrialist, has agreed to pay the Anheuser-Busch Companies nearly $600,000 as part of a settlement of a two-year-old, $250 million damage suit against him and eight other defendants, a lawyer for Anheuser-Busch said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DEBUTANTE: The Story of Brenda Frazier. By Gioia Diliberto. Illustrated. 332 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: REUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized gains of $881,000 for the latest quarter and $3,657,000 for the year-ago period; the latest quarter is also after an extraordinary tax benefit of $390,000.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $675,000 in connection with the adoption of FAS No. 87 relating to employee pensions.

title: JUDGE TAKES BACK CRITICISM OF MODEL SLASHED WITH BLADE
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice apologized yesterday for telling Marla Hanson, a 25-year-old fashion model whose face was slashed in a razor-blade attack last year, that he was ''incensed'' by her criticism of the criminal-justice system.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption Monday with an article about efforts to change the name of the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., incorrectly described the production of ''The Tempest'' currently playing there. It is by the Theater for a New Audience, not by the American Shakespeare Theater.

title: 6,900 U.S. TROOPS STAGE MOCK ASSAULT 100 MILES FROM NICARAGUA
description: In one of the biggest United States military exercises in the region, 6,900 American troops staged a combined air and sea assault this morning near this small town on the northern Honduran coast, about 100 miles from the Nicaraguan border.

title: BARBIE SAID TO TAKE OLD WAYS TO EXILE
description: A former Bolivian official testified today that Klaus Barbie, during his 32-year stay in South America, behaved very much like the Gestapo officer he was in France during World War II.

title: McKINNEY RECALLED AS FIGHTER FOR THE POOR
description: With solemnity and laughter, friends and political associates paid tribute today to the late Representative Stewart B. McKinney for fighting the causes of the forgotten while representing one of the nation's most affluent Congressional districts for almost 17 years.

title: Treatment for Dokes
description: Michael Dokes, a former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, was released from jail on his own recognizance yesterday in Las Vegas, Nev., after promising to enter a treatment center for cocaine addiction. Dokes had been jailed since April 13, when he was arrested on drug and probation violation charges after his car was stopped by Las Vegas police. District Judge Miriam Shearing set a June 21 hearing to check on Dokes's progress in the treatment center and to consider a request by prosecutors for revocation of his probation.

title: BRITAIN ACCEPTS OFFER ON SHORT-RANGE ARMS, BUT WITH CONDITIONS
description: Western nations today moved closer to accepting the Soviet proposal to eliminate short-range missiles from Europe, as Britain officially endorsed the offer under certain conditions.

title: Reveille on 42d Street
description: After a long sleep, Manhattan's 42d Street redevelopment project stirs with life. First, Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch agreed on Carl Weisbrod, a fine choice to head the redevelopment. And now Federal District Judge Thomas Griesa has dismissed the last legal challenge, a suit claiming the project fails to meet air quality standards.

title: Chairman of Harper & Row Resigns
description: Brooks Thomas resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of Harper & Row. No successor was named as chairman, but for what was described as an interim period the office of chief executive will be shared by two top officials of William Collins & Sons, a major British book publisher - Ian Chapman, the chairman, and George Craig, a vice chairman.

title: CHARTER-CRELLIN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was a Scaasi kind of week. Scaasis to the left. Scaasis to the right.

title: HARVEY ABRAMSON
description: Harvey Abramson, a consultant in the biomedical field who helped design life-support systems, died of a brain tumor Sunday night at St. Rose's Home in Manhattan. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: San Miguel Taken Over
description: The Philippine Government took control today of the board of the San Miguel Corporation, the beer and food giant, apparently ending a yearlong struggle by its management to stave off the takeover.

title: The A.C.L.U.'s Myopic Stand on AIDS
description: Remarkably, the American Civil Liberties Union still adheres to a policy statement on AIDS that it issued in April 1986. The organization opposes testing for the AIDS virus unless a person wants it. It opposes reporting of cases of AIDS by doctors, hospitals and laboratories. It opposes tracing those with whom the harborer of the virus has had sexual contact. All in the name of privacy.

title: ART: MIRO REVISITED IN GUGGENHEIM SHOW
description: THE Joan Miro retrospective at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is a curious affair. Miro has long been recognized as a very special and unusually influential artist, and a large show of his work is always welcome. Even though Miro died in 1983 and there had been no Miro retrospective in New York since 1959, however, the art public has felt little or no need to think about him. The first question a Miro retrospective therefore has to answer, certainly in New York, where the artist is so well known, is - why do it? There is no indication that this question was seriously considered.

title: Santa Fe Seeks Merger Review
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation has asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to reconsider the proposed merger of its two subsidiary railroads, saying competitive problems that blocked the deal last year have been resolved. But opponents to the merger, including two other Western railroads and the Justice Department, said the revised proposal changes little and has the same flaws it had in July 1986 when the I.C.C. rejected the merger.

title: LEADER OF DEMOCRATS SAYS BUSH WILL WIN G.O.P. NOMINATION
description: The Democratic national chairman predicted today that Vice President Bush would win the Republican Presidential nomination in 1988. The chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr., also said he would rather have the Democratic nominee run against Mr. Bush than any of the other current Republican contenders.

title: Single Pearl Auctioned For Record at Christie's
description: A single natural pearl was auctioned for $467,123 yesterday by Christie's in Geneva, a record price at auction for a single pearl, to an unidentified American collector.

title: REAGAN IN ACCORD ON DEBT LIMIT BILL
description: In an effort to assure quick approval of an increase in the Government's debt ceiling, President Reagan agreed today to support an attempt to repair the automatic mechanism of the 1985 budget-balancing law.

title: Videotape of a U.S. Hostage Is Issued by Captors
description: Moslem kidnappers today made public a videotape of an American hostage, Alann Steen. He appeared in good health despite earlier assertions by his captors that he was near death.

title: Hasty Handcuffs
description: Wall Street trembled in February when three high-powered executives were arrested on the same day and led away, one in handcuffs, to face sensational insider trading charges. U.S. Attorney Rudolph Giuliani, a crusader against white collar crime, bristled at suggestions that he had staged the roundup in part to encourage the cooperation of other potential defendants. The executives were being treated like any other defendants, he said.

title: Swiss Accept Yamani
description: Saudi Arabia's former oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, has received permission to reside in the village of Chermignon, near the ski resort of Crans-Montana, Swiss officials said today. A spokesman for the Justice Ministry said the authorities in Bern had ''agreed in principle'' to a request for a permit Sheik Yamani made in February. Sheik Yamani, who was dismissed from his post in October, made frequent visits to Geneva for meetings of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. He owns several properties and business in Switzerland.

title: METS STUMBLE ONCE AGAIN
description: The Mets' long week of travails ended tonight at a new low.

title: AIDS VICTIMS' FRANTIC SEARCH FOR CURE
description: Desperate AIDS patients are turning to home remedies, grasping at rumors of new treatments and worrying about how to raise money for the one drug that has proved effective against the deadly disease.

title: MORINO ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings include 2 cents a share in the third quarter and 6 cents a share for the 9 months, representing capitalization of certain software product development costs in accordance with FAS Statement No. 86.

title: FILM: 'MONSTER IN CLOSET'
description: FOR about 20 minutes, ''Monster in the Closet'' seems about to break out as a spoof not only of ''Aliens'' and such, but also of anything else that happened to pop into the head of its writer and director, Bob Dahlin -from health food to insect lib. Most of the characters remind you of somebody. There's a reporter named Clark, who becomes a sexual object when he takes off his glasses; a bespectacled kid, known as ''the professor,'' who's a gadget whiz; a garrulous Nobel laureate whose white hair sprouts like Einstein's, and of course the gurgling, growling, snarling, slurping monster that closets a sexy coed, a seeing-eye dog and an obnoxious movie child before the credits roll. There are informative captions: ''The Building Next Door. Two-Seventeen P.M. The Shower.''

title: MUSIC: KING SUNNY ADE AND BAND, FROM NIGERIA
description: THE glories of Nigerian juju music rang out anew when King Sunny Ade played his first New York concert in three years last Friday at the Beacon Theater. Mr. Ade's 17-man band has new members, including a synthesizer player, and he's willing to warm up a Western crowd with a few pop-length songs; now and then, he uses an English word amid the Yoruba lyrics. He also changes his outfits between encores, like a Western rock star. But he hasn't seriously internationalized, or diluted, his music. His modern juju is still the multilayered, intoxicating marvel that makes him one of the world's great band leaders.

title: Niskanen Sounds Off
description: Another former insider in the Reagan Administration's economic policy making team is about to take the Administration to public task for poor performance in running the economy.

title: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1.4 million or 3 cents a share.

title: Jazz Interactions
description: Jazz Interactions, the nonprofit educational group that runs Jazzline (718-465-7500), will celebrate its 22d birthday Sunday with 12 hours of jazz at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120), beginning at 2 P.M. The more than 100 performers will include Doc Cheatham, a trumpeter, Harold Vick and Bobby Watson, saxophonists, Charli Persip, a drummer, Benny Powell, a trombonist, Carla White, a singer, and many other musicians. Admission is $15 and $12 for Jazz Interactions members.

title: MAN AND GOD IN CUBA: A CASTRO-CHURCH DETENTE?
description: The young Cuban sat in the cool, shaded courtyard of one of the graceful old churches of Havana talking about his mother and religion.

title: BRIDGE: FOUR TEAMS PLAY FOR A SPOT IN 1987 WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP
description: A long battle to determine the United States team to play in the 1987 world championship began here Wednesday night. Two of the teams included players from the New York metropolitan region and they were facing each other in a semifinal playoff tonight.

title: Note and Bond Prices Down
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell modestly yesterday, as news of a smaller American trade deficit in March was not enough to dispel the gloomy mood of many market participants.

title: Tokyo Electric Contract to G.E.
description: The General Electric Company said it had been selected by the Tokyo Electric Power Company to supply the nuclear boiler systems, initial nuclear fuel and turbine-generators for two new nuclear power stations. Tokyo Electric estimated the cost of the stations, which would be built on the Sea of Japan northwest of Tokyo, at 692 billion yen, or nearly $5 billion at current exchange rates. General Electric estimated its share of the project will be more than $1 billion.

title: JAMCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-After a provision for loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $163,000. Jamco Ltd. was formerly Mr. Steak Inc.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: STANLEY KRAMER, the independent producer-director, has accepted an offer by David Puttnam, the president of Columbia Pictures, to develop and direct an indefinite number of films, subject to agreement on each project by both sides. ''Puttnam has the soul of an independent,'' Mr. Kramer said. ''He has a good track record. He's interested in films one can take pride in.'' The arrangement is not exclusive, but gives Columbia the right of first refusal on any project Mr. Kramer suggests.

title: MIKE FEDER TAKES RADIO MONOLOGUES TO THE STAGE
description: ''People say they find a lot of urban angst in my stories,'' Mike Feder reflected last week. ''But I don't see it as angst. I'd rather think of myself as a modern-day Candide walking through Manhattan. I have a kind of adolescent purity that hasn't washed away.''

title: COURIER FOR NORTH TELLS OF CARRYING CASH FOR CONTRAS
description: A former Senate aide who worked as a courier for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified today that he carried cash from Colonel North's White House safe to Nicaraguan rebel leaders in Washington and Central America.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MAY 15, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 A former aide carried cash to rebels in Nicaragua from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's White House safe, Congressional investigators were told. Page A1 News analysis: Investigators never pinned down Robert C. McFarlane in four days of questioning on what he told President Reagan about the White House staff's activities on behalf of the Nicaraguan rebels. A1 The President was not limited by laws barring American aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, White House officials said. The laws never limited his ''constitutional and historical power'' to manage foreign policy. A13 A plan to ease black Africa's debt and accelerate trade-freeing talks will be the most concrete results of next month's annual Western economic summit meeting, officials planning the talks said. A1 The President rejected a plea from El Salvador's President, Jose Napoleon Duarte, to give temporary refuge to Salvadorans living illegally in the United States. A1 Kim Dae Jung has been held in Seoul as a prisoner inside his house for the last five weeks. The confinement of the opposition leader is symbolic of the Government's attempt to intimidate Mr. Kim's party. A1 Afghanistan stresses free-market principles in business and agriculture, women's rights and the fundamentals of Islam in an effort to seek support in the midst of a stubborn war. A1 Israel's infighting continued as Yitzhak Shamir's office asked the Foreign Ministry to tell its embassies that Shimon Peres had no mandate to pursue an international peace conference on the Middle East. A1 Scotland is an electoral battleground for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. In Britain's elections next month, the Tories could lose a third or more of their 21 Parliamentary seats in Scotland. A3 Britain backs arms pact A3 Pretoria to oust 2 journalists A5 Egypt breaks ties with Iran A7 Fiji colonel names cabinet A10 Enrile leads vote protest A10 NATIONAL A14-19, A21, B9-12, D18 The U.S. trade deficit narrowed to $13.6 billion in March, the Commerce Department reported. At the same time, the nation's import bill was the highest ever recorded in a single month. A1 The cause of a rocket's destruction two months ago was detailed by NASA officials. The string of malfunctions and misjudgments are prompting some to wonder what was learned from the space shuttle disaster. A14 Civil rights violations were charged by the Government in a lawsuit against Pennsylvania and Philadelphia's school board for not employing a teacher in public schools who sought to wear religious attire. B12 Warm, dry weather spells anxiety for farmers across the most productive parts of the Corn Belt as well as in markets that trade their crops. A long-range forecast says conditions could last another month. A14 Joseph Biden called for nationalism that ''reflects a shared sense of responsibility.'' Mr. Biden is the first Democratic Presidential candidate to offer his vision of the Presidency since Gary Hart withdrew. A19 A postal official was charged with accepting bribes from the Wedtech Corporation and an inquiry is under way into whether the Postal Service was cheated by the Bronx military contractor. A15 Denver Major fights to hold job A14 Reagan backs budget plan A21 Two unionists pardoned B9 Marines aim at terrorism B9 New drug may help schizophrenics B12 Halt asked in animal patents B12 Falwell says PTL needs cash D18 Florida officials yield on book ban D18 WASHINGTON TALK B10 Of 'high morality' and scandal Whither Volcker? REGIONAL B1-8 AIDS patients are seeking cures in home remedies and grasping at rumors of new treaments. As the death toll mounts, they grow angrier at the health-care establishment and more independent in their treatment decisions. B1 A police officer was found guilty of 37 counts of corruption. The officer, Robert Rathbun, was the first of 11 indicted policemen from 77th Precinct in Brooklyn brought to trial. B1 A Soviet dissident was ordained as a rabbi at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America on Morningside Heights. Leonid Feldman may be the first Soviet dissident to become a rabbi in the United States. B4 Jurors in the Donovan trial were sequestered by a judge following a report that a special Federal prosecutor is reinvestigating former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan. B3 Some judges would delay vacations to help reduce the backlog of cases that confronts the New York City court system each fall, they said. But others suggested canceling weeklong judicial seminars held every summer. B4 Basketball diplomacy arrived in New York City as a Soviet national team met the Gauchos of the South Bronx. The Gauchos came from behind to win the game, 89-86. B1 Urging an urban agenda, Mayor Koch called for increased Federal and individual efforts to build housing, combat illicit drugs and care for AIDS victims in a speech to the Kansas Banking Association. A18 Festival mania has struck New York with 60 hours of marching, eating, dancing and shopping. If all anticipated spectators attend, almost every New Yorker will be outside celebrating this weekend. C1 Inmate drop at Rikers ordered B1 Tributes for Stewart McKinney B1 Judge apologizes to crime victim B2 2 rob acting Students B2 Ground-beef labels criticized B3 Cuomo nominates an aide B6 Drug-related officer arrests rise B8 L.I. driver held in fatal crash B8

title: THE STAGE: 'POSTCARDS'
description: IN ''Three Postcards,'' a new musical play by Craig Lucas and Craig Carnelia, one character is obsessed by a newspaper article about the self-transforming power of subatomic particles. They change shape as scientists watch them. Presumably this is meant to be a metaphor for the show that opened last night at Playwrights Horizons.

title: Abortion Opponents Declare Partial Victory Against Drug
description: The National Right to Life Committee, the largest of the anti-abortion groups, today declared a partial victory in its efforts to get the Upjohn Company to remove an abortion-inducing drug from the market.

title: A Child-Welfare System Waiting for a Dickens to Describe It
description: To the Editor:

title: DRUG COMPANY TO CANCEL MOVE TO NORTH JERSEY
description: Sterling Drug Inc., manufacturer of pharmaceuticals and other consumer products, is to announce today that it has canceled its plan to move its headquarters from Manhattan to New Jersey, according to real-estate consultants to the company.

title: Puerto Rican Bomba
description: Pepe Castillo will lead his group, Bomplene, in a concert of Puerto Rican bomba and plena tonight at 8 at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, 179 Varick Street, below Houston Street (691-9510). Afterward, the dance steps for bomba and plena will be taught, and the band will return to play for dancing. Admission is $5.

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,298,000 and $4,382,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,299,000 and $2,006,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Benjamin Colarossi and Robert J. McKinley have been elected senior vice presidents at McCann-Erickson.

title: FROM SOVIET PRISONER TO NEW RABBI
description: Eleven years ago, Leonid Feldman was sitting in rags on the cold stone floor of a Soviet prison with his hair shaven and belly swollen. His crime was conducting an illegal hunger strike as part of an effort to persuade Soviet authorities to let him leave for Israel.

title: Learjet Crash Kills 2 Pilots
description: A twin-engine Gates Lear 35A jet taking off from Allegheny County Airport while one pilot gave another a federally required proficiency test crashed and burned in heavy woods Tuesday, killing both pilots, the authorities said. Robert Miller, executive vice president of Corporate Jets Inc., said Regis A. Stretavski, was administering the test to Walter Troy when the plane went down.

title: NO RISE IN AIDS INFECTION AMONG MILITARY RECRUITS
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control reported today that the rate of AIDS infection among military recruits remained virtually constant over a period of 15 months. But the Government epidemiologists warned against drawing broad conclusions from the data.

title: VERIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company attributed the decline in results for the third quarter to lower sales volume of consumer electronics merchandise.

title: AIDE CITES REAGAN FOREIGN POLICY POWER
description: The White House contended today that laws passed by Congress barring American aid to the Nicaraguan rebels for two years never limited President Reagan's ''constitutional and historical power'' to manage the nation's foreign policy.

title: Man, 83, Kills His Nurse
description: An 83-year-old man shot his nurse to death in the belief that she was trying to poison him and was killed by the police after he fired three shots at officers, the authorities said today. The police shot Enrique Fuentes Wednesday night after they were summoned to an apartment complex by neighbors who had heard shots. Mr. Fuentes's grandchildren told investigators he had called them to say, '' 'I just shot my nurse.' '' The nurse's name was withheld by the authorities.

title: Canticum Novum
description: Harold Rosenbaum will lead the Canticum Novum Singers and Baroque Orchestra in Handel's oratorio ''Joshua'' tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y. Soloists will be Karen Beardsley, a soprano; Drew Minter, a countertenor; Patrick Romano, a tenor, and Jan Opalach, a bass-baritone. Tickets cost $15, $13 and $11, and are available at the Y box office, 1395 Lexington Avenue, or by calling Y-Charge, 996-1100.

title: BRITISH PETROLEUM CO PLC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The figures represent historical costs results. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR). Each ADR now represents 12 B.P. ordinary shares following the recent 2-for-1 capitalization issue (3-for-1 stock split). Results are in U.S. dollars; translation of the sterling results into U.S. dollars has been made at an average rate for each period as follows: for the latest quarter, $1.54/pound sterling and for the year-ago period, $1.44/ pound sterling.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 25
description: b-Net income

title: GOTTSCHALKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 split paid April 10, 1987.

title: LONDON HOSPITAL TELLS OF EARLIER LIVE DONORS
description: Magdi Yacoub, one of Britain's leading transplant surgeons, performed two operations involving live heart donors before American surgeons in Baltimore carried out a similar procedure this week, hospital officials said today.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE'S TEXAS MOVE
description: First Interstate Bancorp, the Los Angeles-based holding company that is a dominant force in interstate banking, said today that it was involved in negotiations with Allied Bancshares of Houston about a merger.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What we are saying, very simply, is that there seems to be a great deal of confusion about the Boland Amendment, how many amendments there were, what they prohibited, what they authorized, when they were in effect, what they affected. They all related to the power of Congress to control the Federal purse, and prohibited or limited certain expenditures. None contained any language which limited the constitutional and historical power of the President to set andimplement foreign policy.'' - Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. [ A13:6. ]

title: Economic Scene; More Efforts On the Dollar
description: JAPAN'S Finance Ministry exerted ''moral persuasion'' this week on that nation's major commercial banks, securities firms and investment companies, urging them to stop their speculative selling of dollars.

title: RUTH, AND REILLY, LIVE ON
description: Muzzy Field, where the Big East baseball tournament opened today, would probably have been torn down or hopelessly ''improved'' if Bristol were a prosperous town. It is not.

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'DELIGHTS' BY CLARKE PREPARING FOR TAKEOFF
description: SNEERING grotesquely, held aloft by wires, Martha Clarke soared high over the empty seats of the Minetta Lane Theater, prompting laughter and applause from members of her company; it was her first practice flight in some time.

title: THE CONTRA LEADERS REORGANIZE AND PLEDGE TO INTENSIFY THE FIGHT
description: Leaders of a newly reorganized anti-Sandinista movement pledged today that they would intensify their struggle against the Nicaraguan Government, especially on the political front.

title: Abuse of Candidates Is an American Tradition; Sexist Innuendo
description: To the Editor:

title: LEVITT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Knowzone' Studies Efforts To Talk With Animals
description: Can we talk to the animals? No, not really, at least not yet, but it's usually an entertaining question to explore. ''Knowzone,'' on Channel 13 at 7 o'clock tomorrow night, with a repeat Sunday morning at 10:30, focuses on apes, dolphins and whales. Various people, all of them serious, try to speak with the creatures. Some of this is beguiling.

title: Dining Out Guide: Upper West Side
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMSTERDAM'S BAR AND ROTISSERIE, 428 Amsterdam Avenue, near 80th Street (874-1377) - **(Aug. 24, 1984) This casual cafe has white-painted plaster and brick walls, black tin ceiling and red-and-white and blue-and-white homespun tablecloths. The food is as simple and appealing as the decor, and most of it is cooked on the gas-fire rotisserie in the open kitchen. Starters are duck-liver mousse, gravlax with dill-mustard sauce, and smoked trout. Recommended main dishes include the roasted half chicken, shell steak and Norwegian salmon. Dinner entrees $8.50 to $15.25. Fridays through Sundays, noon to 1 A.M. CAFE 79, #206 West 79th Street (769-3377) - *(March 27, 1987) A warm and congenial setting, an inviting bar and a menu of French classics are a few of the pluses going for this Upper West Side bistro. The decor consists of beige walls, mustard banquettes, beveled mirrors and wooden crossbeams overhead. The best appetizers are scallops in cream sauce; warm saucisson with cubes of sauteed potatoes; leeks in vinaigrette, and the onion soup. For a main dish, you might try rack of lamb with baby vegetables; tournedos of beef with truffle sauce; roast duck with fig sauce or the classic sauce of cherries and port, or trout a la meuniere. Entrees $14.50 to $21.50. Fridays and Saturdays, 5 to midnight; Sundays, 5 to 11 P.M. DOCKS OYSTER BAR AND SEAFOOD GRILL, #2427 Broadway, near 90th Street (724-5588) - *(Feb. 6, 1987) A changing assortment of seafood is the attraction at this sparkling black-and-white tiled restaurant on upper Broadway. The long tile bar has a glass-enclosed shellfish display, and you may choose from Belons, Wellfleets, Apalachicolas and bluepoints or clams on the half shell while waiting for a table. Frying is one of the kitchen's strong points, and fried clams and oysters are recommended. Other good options are calamari rings with a cumin-laced hot sauce; steamed giant New Zealand mussels in a saffron cream broth; Norwegian salmon; kingfish over sauteed onions and peppers, and steamed lobster, two pounds and up. Dinner entrees $6.50 to $18. Fridays and Saturdays, 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to 1 A.M.; Sundays, 10:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M. FANDANGO, #305 West End Avenue, at 75th Street (877-1500) - *(Nov. 14, 1986) The multilevel dining room of this capacious California-style grill restaurant has great potential that is largely untapped. The allure here is the food. You might start with wok-charred spicy filet of beef with Napa cabbage and sun-dried tomato vinaigrette, or Belon oyster pancakes with smoked salmon, with a light sesame and sea urchin butter sauce. Pasta options include oversized ravioli filled with sea scallops and julienned artichokes, mache, tomato and jicama with lemongrass and chive butter sauce. Main-course selections are tournedos of Norwegian salmon with steamed ribbon vegetables and mache; whole pan-roasted Maine lobster with a dark oyster sauce and sweet-potato chips; roast sliced boneless rack of lamb wrapped in spinach and herbs with a celery root gratin. Entrees $13 to $25. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 P.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. and 6 to 10:30 P.M. LA MIRABELLE, #333 West 86th Street (496-0458) - *(May 10, 1985) Off the lobby of a residential West Side hotel is this quaint French restaurant with pink and white wall panels and ornate molding and simply appointed tables. Appetizer options include coquilles St. Jacques; sauteed chicken livers with bacon and raspberry vinegar, or soupe au pistou, a melange of fresh spring vegetables. The regular entrees are supplemented by two or three daily specials and you might choose duckling with plums; entrecote with green peppercorn sauce; rack of lamb with garlic-tinged pan juices, or monkfish with tomato, wine and herbs. Entrees $13.50 to $18.25. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 to 10:30 P.M.; closed Sundays. What the stars mean, page C16.

title: 'Stardust' Ending Run
description: ''Stardust'' will close after the Sunday matinee at the Biltmore Theater. The musical, conceived and directed by Albert Harris, moved from Off Broadway and will have run for 118 performances.

title: AMERICAN PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $925,000. The 1987 and 1986 figures represent results of operations of American Pioneer and subsidiaries and does not include operations of Heritage Federal prior to merger on July 31, 1986.

title: STOCKS MIXED AS DOW FALLS 4.19
description: Stock prices ended narrowly mixed again yesterday in trading restrained by worry over a soft dollar and renewed concern about inflation.

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,922,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BIGGS GOES WEST FOR DIRECTION
description: Earlier in his pro career, Tyrell Biggs, a gold medalist at the 1984 Olympics, was viewed as the rival of the future for Mike Tyson.

title: JUDGES SAY THEY WOULD PUT OFF VACATIONS TO CURB JAIL CROWDING
description: Several judges in New York City said yesterday that they were willing to answer the call by the state's Chief Judge that they defer summer vacations to help reduce the backlog of cases that confronts the system each fall.

title: 'Drood' to Close
description: ''Drood,'' the Tony Award-winning musical by Rupert Holmes based on Charles Dickens's unfinished novel, will close after the Saturday evening performance at the Imperial Theater. Directed by Wilford Leach and starring George Rose, Karen Morrow and Howard McGillin, the play will have run for 608 regular performances and 24 previews.

title: SATIRIC 1649 OPERA, 'GIASONE,' AT MANNES
description: ''I consider it the greatest of all 17th-century operas,'' said Paul C. Echols. Mr. Echols, sitting recently amid the chaos of unconstructed stage sets, was describing Francesco Cavalli's 1649 opera ''Giasone,'' which opens tomorrow at the Mannes College of Music. The production, by the Mannes Camerata, is the first fully staged version of the work to be done in this country. Mr. Echols directs and has collaborated with Martin Morell on the English translation.

title: Our Towns; Sluder's Crusade: End Self-Service At the Gas Pump
description: Leroy Sluder, is sitting at his kitchen table, his blue eyes blazing, complaining in a very determined way that service companies no longer provide service.

title: AFGHANS MIX 'SOVIETIZATION' AND FREE MARKET
description: The Soviet-backed Government is seeking support by emphasizing free-market principles, women's rights and the fundamentals of Islam.

title: Egypt Breaks All Diplomatic Ties With Iran
description: Egypt announced today that it was breaking all diplomatic ties with Iran, shutting down Iran's two-member interests section here and recalling Cairo's single diplomat in Teheran.

title: McENROE STILL MIRED IN CLAY
description: John McEnroe defeated Aaron Krickstein today to reach the quarterfinals of the Italian Open, but he did little to dispel doubts about his chances for attaining the most elusive prize of his career: the singles title at the French Open.

title: The Testimony of 3 Men: McFarlane, a State Dept. Official and a Courier
description: As the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair ended their second week yesterday, three witnesses appeared before the joint committee: Robert C. McFarlane, Gaston J. Sigur Jr. and Robert W. Owen. Mr. Owen is to continue his testimony when the hearings resume on Tuesday. Here are excerpts from the testimony yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. McFARLANE TESTIMONY President on the Line

title: DENVER MAYOR OF HIGH PROMISE FIGHTS TO HOLD JOB
description: When he was elected Mayor of Denver in 1983, Federico Pena was hailed as a dynamic young Hispanic leader who would soon become a force in national politics.

title: SIKH PRIEST IS CLEARED IN KNIFE-CARRYING CASE
description: A Queens judge has ruled that a Sikh priest violated New York City's weapons laws when he was seen standing on a subway platform wearing a sheathed knife at his side as a religious symbol.

title: Allegis Deal Blocks Takeover by Boeing
description: The Allegis Corporation, whose United Airlines subsidiary has become a takeover target, disclosed yesterday that its investment agreement with the Boeing Company makes it virtually impossible for the aerospace giant to attempt a hostile bid for Allegis and protects the company from other suitors.

title: 3 Soundtracks For One Ad
description: Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss may have found a good way of keeping down TV production costs on a pool of commercials for 4C Foods, a client that came aboard in December: Make one commercial and use three sound tracks. The pool, for 4C Iced Tea

title: FONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $438,000 and $876,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $690,000 for the quarter and $810,000 for the 9 months.

title: REDS TOP EXPOS ON 5 RUNS IN NINTH, 10-9
description: Lloyd McClendon's two-run pinch-hit single capped a five-run ninth-inning rally tonight that gave the Cincinnati Reds a 10-9 victory over the Expos.

title: A SUFFOLK PROJECT CATERS TO TWO TYPES OF BUYERS
description: What does a developer do when he realizes that two different types of home buyers are likely to be interested in the same community? He tries to satisfy both by building to suit each, thereby broadening his market while lessening his risks.

title: Solarz's Endorsement
description: Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn will endorse Senator Paul Simon of Illinois for the 1988 Democratic nomination for President today, and, as proof of his enthusiasm, will escort the Senator to New York City for a private visit with Mayor Koch.

title: RESTAURANTS
