description: THE eight-year-old Gibbon was one of the first restaurants in New York to apply the esthetics of Japanese cuisine to the canvas of French gastronomy. The result was a visually arresting tableau, one that held appeal to those seeking lighter fare that eschewed butter and cream in favor of an Oriental approach based on soy sauce and fresh herbs. Recent samplings indicate that the formula still yields some delightful meals, although the kitchen's timorous approach to seasoning leaves some otherwise meritable dishes flat.

title: INDEPENDENT BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An article on March 18 about the race discrimination trial involving The Daily News gave an erroneous account of analyses of the newspaper's pay practices made by Dr. Mark R. Killingsworth, an expert witness for the plaintiffs. Dr. Killingsworth testified about two sets of studies, not one. The first showed average pay of black and nonblack News employees - adjusted, at most, for a single characteristic, like age. Under cross-examination, he acknowledged that no one could tell whether the racial pay differences in these studies were necessarily attributable to racial discrimination. Dr. Killingsworth said the second set of studies - adjusted for numerous variables like age, education, prior work experience and seniority - provided ''substantial evidence'' of pay discrimination.

title: BankAmerica Offering Is First in Nearly 3 Years
description: The BankAmerica Corporation returned to the public securities market yesterday with a $100 million issue of subordinated capital notes. Beset with losses and large amounts of bad loans, the company has been absent from the market for nearly three years, securities dealers said.

title: SENATOR ASKS HALT TO ANIMAL PATENTS
description: A Senator asked the United States Patent and Trademark Office today to defer granting patents for genetically engineered forms of animal life until Congress has considered a host of ethical and moral issues.

title: Bush Records Say Aide Met Contra Supporter
description: A review of Vice President Bush's office records turned up a previously undisclosed meeting between a Bush aide and Felix Rodriguez, a one-time C.I.A. operative involved in the private support network for the Nicaraguan rebels, it was announced tonight.

title: 3 Jumpers Start Some Big Strides
description: A women's track-and-field program that began with a turnout of only three freshman jumpers in 1981 will be aiming for its sixth consecutive Eastern College Athletic Conference Division II team championship against 15 other teams today and tomorrow at Mitchel Field in Uniondale, L.I.

title: In the Cards
description: In Dr. James Beckett's ''Price Guide to Baseball Cards,'' he devotes more than 450 pages to listings of current values of all popular baseball cards since the printing of the first post-World War II set, the 1948 Bowman. Also included are the pricings in collections by Topps, Donruss, Fleer, Kelloggs, Hostess and Sportifics.

title: FOR SKINS OF ALL SHADES, NEW COSMETICS
description: In July of last year, Juin Rachele came out with a line of cosmetics for women with skin tones from blond to black.

title: EX-CHICAGO OFFICIALS ARE INDICTED IN BILL-COLLECTION BRIBERY SCANDAL
description: A Grand jury today named nine people, including the powerful clerk of the Circuit Court, a former mayoral adviser and two former aldermen, in a second round of indictments in a Federal investigation of influence peddling in city and county government.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY POLYRHYTHMIC SYMPHONY The music of the American composer Charles Ives (1874-1954) has always been controversial. An amateur musician, Ives wrote complex works using polytonality, polyrhythm and other devices considered radical at the time. Tonight at 8, the Cleveland Orchestra will perform the composer's rarely heard Fourth Symphony at Carnegie Hall. The piece, which was written in 1915 and first performed in 1965, is one of Ives's most difficult works: the score calls for two conductors to help keep the music from running rhythmically amok. Carrying out that task in tonight's concert are Christoph von Dohnanyi, the orchestra's music director, and Jahja Ling, its resident conductor. Joining the musical forces for this performance of the 30-minute symphony is the Cleveland Orchestra Chamber Chorus. For those with more traditional tastes, Brahms's Fourth Symphony will round out the program. Tickets, at the box office, are $14 to $25. Information: 247-7800. ANIMATION FESTIVAL Mention animated film and Walt Disney usually comes to mind. But animation comprises a wide variety of styles and techniques, many of which can be seen tonight at New York University's seventh annual Animation Festival. Fifteen films by students and alumni of the university's Tisch School of the Arts department of film and television will be shown in a 90-minute program beginning at 8 P.M. Among them are two Claymation films, which use hand-crafted clay sculptures, meticulously positioned and shot at 24 frames per second. There is also a political collage-montage; a children's movie titled ''Traveling,'' which illustrates the alphabet, and ''Peer Pier,'' a line drawing depicting a journey through a magical underwater world. Several of the films have won awards at international film festivals. The screenings are at the Eisner Lubin Auditorium of the Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place, off Washington Square. Tickets are $3 (free for N.Y.U. students). The proceeds will go to the school's Leo Dratfield Animation Scholarship. Information: 598-3757. COLLECTORS' NICHE Rare 17th-century Chinese chairs, 18th-century Queen Anne and Chippendale sofas and 20th-century Art Deco tables are a few of the items on view this weekend at the New York Armory Antiques Show. One hundred and twenty exhibitors from the United States, Canada, Austria, Britain and France will fill the vast space of the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street in Manhattan. Now in its 11th year at the armory, the show has grown into one of the largest furniture and antiques exhibits. Along with the many pieces of top-quality furniture will be rugs, folk art, jewelry, toys, paintings, rare books and many other decorative items. A special booth to benefit the Save the Children Federation will feature crafts from 40 of the countries served by the relief organization. The show will be open from 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. today and tomorrow, and 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is $6. Information: 772-2240 or 772-2327. SATURDAY PUCCINI GEM One of the most beloved ballets in the dance repertory is ''Giselle,'' but few people have ever heard ''Le Villi,'' Giacomo Puccini's first opera, which is based on the ballet. Il Piccolo Teatro dell'Opera, a Brooklyn-based group, will present a concert version of the hourlong opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Saturday at 8 P.M. Barbara Elliott, the founder and director of the small three-year-old group, said its purpose was to offer shorter operas, the ''gem masterpieces'' that are rarely heard. Singers for this performance are Eva Baraian, a soprano; Jia Nyi Zhang, a tenor, and Mark Rucker, a baritone. The opera will be sung in Italian with English supertitles, and the actor Tony Randall will narrate. Giampaolo Bracali will conduct the Brooklyn Philharmonic. Tickets, at the box office, are $5 to $20. Information and reservations: (718) 855-4751; or Teletron: 947-5850. HISPANIC THEATER Pregones, the New York-based Touring Puerto Rican Theater group, will end its spring season on Saturday with a performance of the musical ''Migrants! Cantata a los Emigrantes.'' This bilingual play was written by the troupe's director, Rosalba Rolon, who used historical texts, oral history, interviews and poetry to tell the story of Puerto Ricans who migrated to the United States. The performance, which begins at 2 P.M., is at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, at Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard West near Jerome Avenue, in the Bronx. Tickets are $10. Information: 585-1202. SUNDAY QUIVAR IN RECITAL Opera audiences are well acquainted with the mezzo-soprano Florence Quivar, who, in her ninth consecutive season at the Metropolitan Opera, recently appeared in that company's production of Poulenc's ''Dialogues of the Carmelites.'' On Sunday at 7:30 P.M., Ms. Quivar will make her New York recital debut at Alice Tully Hall as part of the Great Performers series at Lincoln Center. A native of Philadelphia, Ms. Quivar has appeared throughout the United States and Europe with some of the world's leading orchestras, opera companies and music festivals, including the New York Philharmonic under Zubin Mehta, the Boston Symphony with Seiji Ozawa and the Cleveland Orchestra under Lorin Maazel. For Sunday's program, Ms. Quivar, with Mikael Eliasen at the piano, will offer songs by Brahms and Mahler, a Mozart concert aria and a selection of spirituals. Tickets are $15, at the Tully Hall box office, 362-1911; or through Centercharge: 874-6770. YIDDISH TALES Isaac Bashevis Singer has been captivating readers with tales of demons, goblins and spirits for a good part of this century. On Sunday at 2 P.M., the 83-year-old Nobel laureate will be honored at the 16th annual Sholem Aleichem Festival, which celebrates Yiddish music, theater and culture. Among those who are to be on hand for the festivities are Tovah Feldshuh, an actress; Zwi Kanar, a mime; Norman Kruger, a Yiddish actor, and Emmanuel Almossino, a klezmer musician. Excerpts from Amram Nowak's 1986 Oscar-nominated documentary, ''Isaac in America,'' will be shown. Mr. Singer and his wife, Alma, will read selections from his stories. The festival, sponsored by Queens College and its English-language journal, Yiddish, is at the college's Colden Center, off the Kissena Boulevard exit of the Long Island Expressway, in Flushing. There is free parking on campus. Tickets are $8 to $12. Information: (718) 793-8080.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring tax benefit of $8,996,000.

title: Westland Job Cuts
description: Westland, the British helicopter company that an American-led consortium saved from bankruptcy last year, will cut 1,155 jobs at its Yeovil factory in the west of England, a company spokesman said. ''We had to make capacity reductions in view of the market situation of helicopter manufacturing capacity,'' he said. Last month, the British Government said it would place an order worth $500 million with Westland. But the company has announced that it will have to cut its operations by up to a third, in spite of the order.

title: Japan Forklift Inquiry Is Set
description: The Department of Commerce agreed today to investigate complaints that Japanese manufacturers of forklift trucks have been dumping their products in the United States. The Hyster Company of Portland, Ore., a major producer of forklifts, and four labor unions made the charges on April 22 against Toyota, Nissan, Komatsu, Toyo Umpanki, Mitsubishi and other companies.

title: EDWIN C. BERRY
description: Edwin C. Berry, a longtime civil rights leader and former president of the Chicago Urban League, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW DRUG IS SAID TO HELP SEVERE SCHIZOPHRENICS
description: Nearly one-third of the severe schizophrenics who were given a new drug improved significantly, but the drug requires weekly blood tests because of a potentially fatal side effect, researchers said today.

title: SPACE EXPERTS DETAIL LAUNCHING FAILURE
description: Space agency officials today provided new details about a string of malfunctions, bad data and misjudgments - some remarkably similar to those preceding the loss of the space shuttle Challenger - that led to the destruction of an Atlas-Centaur rocket and its satellite payload two months ago.

title: WANDERING TRASH BARGE TO RETURN TO NEW YORK
description: Saying that the outcast garbage barge of Islip cannot remain at sea indefinitely, the owners of the trash and barge today said they had agreed to return it to New York.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $3,255,000 for the latest quarter and $46,832,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: GRAHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $450,000 for the latest first quarter and $766,000 for the year- ago period.

title: ART: 'VIEWER AS VOYEUR,' AT A WHITNEY BRANCH
description: INSTALLED at its Philip Morris branch, the Whitney Museum's ''Viewer as Voyeur'' could be an exercise in cultural anthropology, a lecture on sociology, a political grievance session - almost anything but an exhibition of art. Art is present, of course - 26 items, more than half of them photographs, the remainder a mix of constructions, paintings and one etching. The contributors are 16 and can be divided into three groups more or less equal in size: Dead masters; living biggies and semi-biggies, and the emerging and just emerged. The curators are four - Andrea Inselmann, Grant Kester, James Peto and Charles A. Wright Jr. They are Helena Rubinstein Fellows in the museum's Independent Study Program. Apparently, their mission here is to inquire into the circuitry of watching (as opposed to looking or seeing), to distinguish between watcher and watched, and, needless to say, to question old subjective assumptions, replacing them where possible with trendier subjective assumptions.

title: REAGAN REJECTS SALVADORAN PLEA ON ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: President Reagan today turned down a plea from the President of El Salvador to give temporary refuge to thousands of Salvadorans living illegally in this country.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegrpah Co., said it and Shindengen Electric Manufacturing Co. had signed a multimillion-dollar agreement to transfer certain A.T.& T. technology to Shindengen.

title: U.S. SUES PENNSYLVANIA OVER RIGHTS
description: The Justice Department has accused the State of Pennsylvania and the Philadelphia school board of religious discrimination for banning the employment in public schools of people who wear religious attire or emblems.

title: ALBANY'S NEGOTIATOR WITH UNIONS IS CUOMO CHOICE FOR LABOR AGENCY
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that he was nominating Thomas F. Hartnett, director of the Governor's Office of Employee Relations, to be State Labor Commissioner. Mr. Hartnett would replace Lillian Roberts, who resigned from the position in March under pressure from the administration.

title: French Inflation Is Up
description: French inflation increased to an annual rate of 3.4 percent last month, from 3.3 percent in March, as oil prices rose, the National Statistics Institute said today. The increase took the inflation rate back to its February level, well above the 2.1 percent rate at the end of last year.

title: JUDGE ORDERS INMATE DROP AT RIKERS JAIL
description: A Federal judge told New York City yesterday that it must reduce the number of inmates in a section of its overcrowded Rikers Island jail by June 15.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: George Coleman Trio, Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Playing at peak intensity, George Coleman, a tenor saxophonist, hits like a hurricane, flattening anything in his path. He is also capable of considerable subtlety and nuance, and this is the side of his music that has been coming to the fore since he began performing occasionally at Bradley's, accompanied only by piano and bass. Fans with a special fondness for his work on enduring 60's albums like Herbie Hancock's ''Maiden Voyage'' and Miles Davis's ''Seven Steps to Heaven'' won't want to miss the Coleman Trio, which plays three one-hour sets on Sunday beginning at 9:45 P.M. There is a $5 music charge and a $5 minimum.

title: FISHER SCIENTIFIC GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago first quarter results exclude operations of Imed Corp., which was acquired by Henley Group Inc. and was contributed to Fisher in June 1986. The company went public April 6.

title: THE YOUNG PRESIDENT
description: For those of you who have been engrossed in the Gary Hart case and the Iran-contra hearings, New York sports has had its own little imbroglio in recent weeks: Richard Evans went to Italy.

title: Texaco Asks Court To Review Ruling
description: Texaco Inc. has asked the Texas Court of Appeals to reconsider an earlier ruling upholding the original verdict in its dispute with the Pennzoil Company. The dispute involves Texaco's purchase of the Getty Oil Company. Although the appeals court originally ruled against Texaco, it reduced the total damages by $2 billion, to $10.53 billion.

title: MAINE PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an accounting change gain of $830,000.

title: RISE IS REPORTED IN OFFICERS ARRESTED ON DRUG CHARGES
description: The number of New York City police officers arrested on drug-related charges more than doubled last year, rising to 17, from 7 in 1985, according to a Police Department report released yesterday.

title: New Standards Studied
description: A study of the new minimum academic requirements for freshman participation in intercollegiate athletics has found that 684 students who failed to qualify under the new standards, which took effect last fall, enrolled at Division I schools anyway. Of those, the study found, 424 had the required 2.0 grade-point average in their core high school courses but had failed to obtain the minimum score on their college admissions tests. The survey of 250 Division I colleges was conducted by Ursula Walsh, the director of research and sports sciences for the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Abuse of Candidates Is an American Tradition; The Press Will Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Quartet at Carlos 1
description: James Newton, a flutist, will lead a quartet - with Clyde Criner on piano, Anthony Cox on bass and Victor Lewis on drums - tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 P.M. and 11 P.M., with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: FILM: 'PERSONAL SERVICES'
description: CHRISTINE PAINTER, the heroine of ''Personal Services,'' seems to slip into her career in prostitution by accident. When the film begins, Christine (played by Julie Walters, the star of ''Educating Rita'') is working as a waitress and apparently making some extra money by subletting apartments to prostitutes. So she is party to what they do, but somehow thoroughly indignant whenever their clients appear and misunderstand her own role (''What do you think I am?'' she snaps furiously at one polite, elderly man.) One day, though, the rent is due and Christine has no money. She seemingly has no recourse when the landlord suggests he take it out in trade, and after that, the rest is history.

title: KEY RATES
Abuse of Candidates Is an American Tradition; Hamilton's Troubles
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: NEW LEADS IN 'GISELLE'
description: THE two acts of ''Giselle'' are very different in mood and in the kind of challenge they present to dancers. Leslie Browne and Robert Hill, new this season in the ballet's lead roles, offered charming first-act portrayals of Giselle and Albrecht in a performance by American Ballet Theater on Monday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House. But it was in the second act, when the dead Giselle and the mourning Albrecht meet in the vengeful spirit world of the Wilis, that Ms. Browne and Mr. Hill soared, both literally and figuratively.

title: Dismissal Sought
description: A judge in Phoenix has been asked to dismiss drug-conspiracy charges against James Edwards, a Phoenix Suns center, on the ground of vagueness and to send the indictment back to the grand jury. The request by a defense lawyer for Edwards was made Wednesday to Judge Michael Ryan of Maricopa County Superior Court. Edwards was among 12 defendants named an the indictment by a county grand jury. They were accused on a variety of cocaine, marijuana and conspiracy charges. Those indicted included two other current Suns players - Grant Gondrezick and Jay Humphries - and two former Suns, Garfield Heard and Mike Bratz.

title: The Guilt Of Doing Nothing
description: The special courtroom arranged in the grand foyer of Lyons's Palace of Justice for the trial of Klaus Barbie makes clear that this is no routine affair. The French say it will probably be the last big war-criminal trial in the West, and many hope it will serve as a gripping history lesson for those too young to remember, those who have forgotten and those who never wanted to know.

title: INSIDER DECISION POSTPONED
description: A Federal judge's decision on the effort by the Government to dismiss insider-trading charges against three Wall Street professionals was postponed yesterday after lawyers for the three defendants said they would oppose the move.

title: Vitamin Programs Said to Cut Child Deaths in Third World
description: Vitamin A supplements, long known to prevent blindness in malnourished children, may also reduce susceptibility to diseases often fatal to children in developing nations, according to testimony today before a House committee.

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a gain on the sale of West Los Angeles real estate of $8,485,000, or $1.05 a share.

title: Millstone 3 Shuts Down
description: The Millstone 3 nuclear power plant was accidentally knocked out of service today during routine maintenance, a spokesman for the plant's owner, Northeast Utilities, reported. The spokesman, Tony Castagno, said workers were testing circuit breakers and apparently caused the turbine to stop and the reactor to shut down automatically. He said the 1,150-megawatt plant, Connecticut's largest, should be back in operation ''in a day or two.''

title: Whither Volcker?
description: With sensitive details of the Iran-contra affair and Gary Hart's love life the subject of everyday conversation these days, Washington might seem to have no mysteries left, perhaps not even any secrets.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch on May 7 from Oakland, Calif., about commercial blimp flights starting in that area, misstated their place in recent history. For many years before 1982 the

title: THE WITNESS FILE
description: Name: Robert W. Owen Age: 32 Position: Staff director at the Institute on Terrorism and Sub-National Conflicts. Formerly a staff aide to

title: MARINE GUNSLINGERS AIM AT TERRORISM
description: Like marshals in the Old West, the two Marine sergeants stood balanced with feet apart, right hands caressing black leather holsters secured with thongs about their legs, eyes on silhouette targets seven yards away.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $100,000 from land condemnation award. c-Net loss

title: Aquino Must Address Filipinos' Poverty
description: Three decades ago, the United States launched one of its first counterinsurgency wars, in the Philippines. The ''enemy'' was the Huks, an army of peasants with legitimate grievances and a Communist ideology. This covert campaign, a combination of paramilitary operations and political reforms, was probably America's most successful counterinsurgency war.

title: Judge Bars Bid to Stop Times Sq. Renovation
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan has rejected the last pending legal challenge to the $2 billion Times Square redevelopment project, ruling that the local residents and business executives who brought the suit failed to show the project would violate Federal clean air rules.

title: 3 Hurt as Movie 'Ice' Burns
description: Fake ice for a scene in the movie ''Poltergeist III'' caught fire and exploded in an underground parking garage Wednesday, causing three minor injuries and $250,000 in damage. Plastic had been poured into six cars so the vehicles looked frozen. According to Fire Chief Anton Barton of Oakbrook Terrace, an explosion set off for a scene in the horror movie ignited the plastic ice.

title: AN INDUSTRIALIST GOES TO WALL ST.
description: After considering a list of candidates to head the Kidder, Peabody Group Inc., the General Electric Company, its parent, made a seemingly strange choice by selecting Silas S. Cathcart, a 61-year-old Illinois industrialist who has never worked on Wall Street.

title: 'Nunsense' AIDS Benefit
description: To benefit the AIDS Resource Center, a special performance of ''Nunsense,'' an Off Broadway musical comedy, has been scheduled for Sunday at 7 P.M. at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42d Street. Tickets for the benefit are $50 and include a reception with the cast of the show following the performance in the theater's garden. Information and reservations: 239-4321.

title: MARATHON OFFICE SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

PATENTS;
U.S. Shift on Treaty
description: LEAD: A notice by President Reagan that the United States will adhere to Chapter II of the Patent Cooperation Treaty was published in this week's Patent Office Official Gazette, a weekly summary of new patents. Chapter II will allow the Patent Office to make a preliminary examination of a patent application filed with it under the treaty.

title: COMET ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $15,260. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,928,657 and $2,164,435 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: BRAE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,282,000 from discontinued operations. The company said the latest quarter results include pretax income of $1,175,000 related to an expired option to purchase the company's railcar leasing and management.

title: M-A-R-C INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an investment tax credit of $215,000, or 7 cents a share.

title: TV: Filmed in Africa, Simon's 'Graceland'
description: We already have ''Graceland'' the recording and ''Graceland'' the touring concert, which recently completed several sold-out performances at Radio City Music Hall. Now, on pay-cable's Showtime service, there is ''Graceland: The African Concert,'' a towering and memorable achievement in the cluttered land of music specials. It can be seen by subscribers tonight at 10. Additional play dates include May 20, 24 and 29, June 2, 6 and 11.

title: ACCELERATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $410,000 and $507,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively; the latest quarter also includes an extraordinary gain of $325,000 on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Message From the Sponsor
description: The White House asked a Nashville radio station today to refrain from using a tape of President Reagan saying he listens to ''WSM, the 50,000-watt blowtorch of the South.''

title: Spectradyne Bid Withdrawn
description: Marvin Davis, the Denver oil executive, said yesterday that he was withdrawing his bid for Spectradyne Inc. because another offer has been made.

title: MARINES DROP MOST SEVERE CHARGE AGAINST MOSCOW EMBASSY GUARD
description: The Marine Corps announced today that it was dropping the most serious charge against a former Marine guard at the United States Embassy in Moscow -that he had allowed Soviet agents to roam through the compound.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $819,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,537,000.

title: RECITAL: BEVERLY MORGAN
description: Beverly Morgan's song recital at the 92d Street Y Thursday night was a model of substance and imagination. Her program was unusual not only for its quality but also for the fact that so much of it was sung in English. This included three songs from Haydn's London period, Robert Helps's ''Running Sun'' and the five settings by Benjamin Britten of Auden's ''On This Island.''

title: INDUSTRIAL TRAINING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Third U.S. Reporter Is Told to Leave South Africa
description: South Africa told a United States journalist today to leave the country within two weeks.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC
description: The first two of the guest conductor Giuseppe Sinopoli's three subscription programs this spring with the New York Philharmonic both contain tone poems of Richard Strauss, and one reason is that Deutsche Grammophon will record them this week. If the performances on record are as lively and dramatic as that accorded ''Also Sprach Zarathustra'' Thursday night, it should be a record worth buying.

title: BELVEDERE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $496,000 for the latest quarter and $707,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said results were adversely affected by start-up costs and non-recurring interest expenses of about $225,000 after taxes, or 4 cents a share.

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: KOHL URGES BROADENING OF ANY SHORT-RANGE MISSILE ACCORD
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl asserted today that any Soviet-American agreement to eliminate short-range nuclear missiles - those with ranges of 300 to 600 miles - must be accompanied by a ban on battlefield nuclear arms of even shorter range.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As a matter of fact, I was very definitely involved in the decisions about support to the freedom fighters. It was my idea to begin with.'' - President Reagan, on private aid to Nicaraguan rebels. [ 1:1. ]

TO-FITNESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Soldier Killed in Leap to Flee Blaze on Airborne Helicopter
description: A soldier was killed today when he leaped from a burning military helicopter before it went down in dense woods, the authorities said. Three solders were injured in the incident.

title: IN CANNES LIMELIGHT: GISH AND DAVIS
description: For a brief moment tonight, some of the true glory of the cinema was demonstrated (instead of being exploited) at the 40th Cannes International Film Festival with the showing of Lindsay Anderson's ''Whales of August,'' starring Lillian Gish and Bette Davis.

title: THE STAGE: IN REVIVAL, 'WISH YOU WERE HERE'
description: When the Harold Rome musical, ''Wish You Were Here,'' was first mounted on Broadway in 1952, the original production boasted what then seemed a sensational novelty. The show, which is set at Camp Karefree, a summer mating ground for young singles in the heart of the Catskills, featured a $15,000 swimming pool built into the center of the stage. The gimmick gave the director Joshua Logan a perfect excuse for serving up a titillating parade of poolside pulchritude.

title: White House Planning To Sell F-15's to Saudis
description: The White House will notify Congress next week that it intends to sell a half-billion dollars' worth of F-15 fighter planes to Saudi Arabia, Reagan Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: ACTIVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring litigation charges of $2,400,000 for the latest year and $1,200,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: Candelaria Sidelined
description: The California Angels pitcher, John Candelaria, arrested for the second time in a month for investigation of driving while intoxicated, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday.

title: FRIENDS FOR LIFE
description: LOVE UNKNOWN. By A.N. Wilson. 202 pages. Viking. $16.95.

title: STOCKS PLUMMET
description: More evidence of stepped-up inflation emerged today as the Government reported that one of its main price indexes climbed in April by seven-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest increase in 18 months.

title: ASAMERA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,065,000. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $8,227,000. Results are in Canadian dollars. Year-ago results are restated.

Article 397587 -- No Title
description: The International Monetary Fund today agreed to lend Egypt $327 million over the next 18 months as part of a multilateral effort to shore up its weakened economy.

title: Richardson Scores 28
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, banned by the National Basketball Association because of repeated drug use, made an impressive debut in another league tonight.

title: A TENACIOUS SLOTNICK FACES BIGGEST TEST
description: Barry I. Slotnick, an unabashed self-promoter, views himself as the best criminal lawyer in America. Others, including some of his friends, would not go so far, but they do acknowledge that he is very good at what he does.

title: IVERSON TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BURLINGTON HOSTILE BID IS RAISED
description: An investor group led by Asher B. Edelman yesterday raised its hostile offer for Burlington Industries to $72 a share, from $67.

title: ALYSHEBA BATTLING THE ODDS
description: Alysheba's competition in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Saturday consists of five colts he beat in the Kentucky Derby 13 days ago and three newcomers with skimpy credentials. The bettors will understandably make him a heavy favorite - but the odds are that he will lose.

title: MIAMI CORRUPTION INQUIRY IS GROWING
description: New reports of criminal activities by members of the Miami Police Department represent a ''significant development in our investigation of corruption'' in that department, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said here today.

title: Gunman Wounds 3 Students In Dormitory at Stony Brook
description: Three students were wounded yesterday in a shooting at the State University Center, the third campus shooting in two weeks, the authorities said.

title: Fatless Fat
description: In the futurist comedy ''Sleeper,'' two scientists share a laugh about Woody Allen's request for wheat germ and honey. Woody, it seems, went into hibernation in 1973, before the health-preserving properties of steak, cream pies and hot fudge were discovered. Now life is about to imitate parody. Steak may never be neutralized, but if Procter & Gamble has its way, cream pies, hot fudge and many fat food treats will be transformed into health food.

title: GEORGIA MAN EXECUTED AFTER APPEAL TO HIGH COURT
description: Joseph Mulligan, who was convicted of killing a witness to a murder he committed for the insurance money, died this evening in Georgia's electric chair.

title: Judge Refuses to Force Barbie to Attend Trial
description: A judge today refused to force Klaus Barbie to attend his trial despite pleas from lawyers representing some of the people the former Gestapo officer is accused of killing.

title: SPROUSE-REITZ CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CERAMIC FUNERARY ART FROM CHINA ON DISPLAY
description: It was the practice of the very earliest Chinese emperors, such as those of the Shang Dynasty from around 1,500 to 1,000 B.C., to have a group of slaves slaughtered at the time of their own deaths, so that the souls of the slaves could continue to serve the emperor's soul in the afterlife.

title: MAJORITY OF ISRAELIS BACK PARLEY, BUT NOT A COST OF CABINET'S FALL
description: A majority of Israelis favor participation in an international peace conference on the Middle East but are not willing to bring down the Government to pursue the idea, according to a newspaper survey published today.

title: FAIRFIELD-NOBLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOR JIM AND TAMMY BAKKER, EXCESS WIPED OUT A RAPID CLIMB TO SUCCESS
description: As a teen-ager growing up in Muskegon, Mich., Jim Bakker was forbidden from dancing by his strict fundamentalist religion. Instead, he became the disk jockey at school sock hops, chattering into his microphone as he spun the hits of the 1950's.

title: SUPERTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes an inventory writeoff of about $440,000.

title: Flyers, Canadiens Pay Price for Brawl
description: Ed Hospodar of the Philadelphia Flyers was suspended today by the National Hockey League for the Stanley Cup championship series, and the Flyers and the Canadiens were fined a total of $24,500 for the 15-minute fracas that preceded Game 6 of the semifinal series here Thursday night.

title: TECH DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Medicaid for All Poor New York Families
description: On a recent afternoon in Albany, N.Y., we listened to the stories of a number of New Yorkers who are among the 37 million Americans - a number that grows by about one million a year - who do not have health insurance for themselves or their families. In Albany, as in other places around the nation, we heard of the terrible dilemmas faced when illness or accident strikes a family that is not protected by health coverage.

title: FINANCIAL SECURITY SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FRONTIER INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $88,000 and $1,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: PHILADELPHIANS TOAST A FRIEND, A MAN OF ART
description: At least there was something that both the New Yorkers and the Philadelphians could agree on: the sense that, in some inexplicable way, Henry was there, though, of course, he couldn't possibly be.

title: FIRST HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company converted to stock from mutual form in August 1986.

title: TOKYO PUNISHES 2 COMPANIES IN SALE
description: In a rare punitive action against Japanese industry, the Government today imposed a limited export ban on two corporations for illegally selling technology to the Soviet Union that enables it to make submarines harder to detect.

title: Tennis Umpire Rehired
description: After being dismissed a month ago as a full-time umpire by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, Jeremy Shales has been approved to handle matches without restrictions at the Wimbledon tournament this year. The approval came from the management committee of the All England Lawn Tennis Club after listening to a recommendation from the British Tennis Umpires Association.

title: INFLATION FEARS HURT BOND PRICES
description: Interest rates soared and prices of fixed-income securities plunged yesterday amid strong new evidence that the pace of inflation was quickening.

title: New York City's Value for Business
description: LEAD: Is it good for corporations to leave New York City?

title: BUCKS STOP RALLY, TIE SERIES
description: A seventh game Sunday afternoon at the Boston Garden will decide whether the Milwaukee Bucks or the Celtics advance to the Eastern Conference final against the Detroit Pistons.

title: CONCURRENT COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: A WESTCHESTER FAMILY GIVES UP A WAY OF LIFE
description: In 1907 DeWitt Clinton Haight came to this town in the northeast corner of Westchester County and bought 70 acres of land.

title: AIR BAGS, FATS AND RECALLS
description: The head of an agency that does research for consumer groups, most of whom support the installation of air bags in automobiles, is alive today thanks to an air bag in her car, she said.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INCM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,908,027 for the quarter and $1,975,000 for the 9 months; the 9-month also includes a tax credit of $1,510,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $121,864 and $93,173 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Fiscal 1987 sales and earnings reflect the consolidation of Rexnord Inc., acquired March 2, 1987.

title: 1873 COLT REVOLVER BRINGS RECORD PRICE FOR A FIREARM
description: An 1873 single-action .45-caliber Colt revolver - the first six-shooter of the type known as the ''Peacemaker'' to be produced - was sold for $242,000, a record at auction for a firearm, at Christie's East on Thursday.

title: Congress of Opposites
description: Joel Forrester, pianist and composer, will lead his group Congress of Opposites - including Bobby Watson on alto saxophone and Dennis Charles on drums - tonight and tomorrow at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set tomorrow. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: PRIME RATE UP 1/4 POINT, TO 8.25%
description: Banks increased their prime rate again yesterday, this time to 8.25 percent from 8 percent, and economists said that further increases were in prospect.

title: IDC SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A Miami dispatch yesterday about reorganization of the Nicaraguan rebel movement described the voting for the movement's new directors incorrectly. The director whose election was most contentious was Alfonso Robelo, not Adolfo Calero.

title: Municipals And Fine Print
description: FAILURE to read the fine print in a municipal bond offering - the equivalent of a stock prospectus - can be a costly mistake for investors.

title: Student Plans to File Lawsuit In a Dispute Over Dissection
description: A high school sophomore who refused to dissect a frog in her biology class will fail her laboratory section and the failure will be noted on her transcript, school officials said Thursday.

title: 6 Performers to Receive George London Awards
description: Three opera singers and three performers of musical theater are the recipients of this year's George London Awards, sponsored by the National Institute for Music Theater. The six - Mark Doss, Ruth Golden and Michael Sylvester for opera; Suzzanne Douglas, Brenda Pressley and Abra Bigham for musical theater -received $10,000 each at a benefit gala Thursday at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chris McCarron's 'Horrible Wreck'
description: In that split second when Alysheba stumbled in the Kentucky Derby two weeks ago, Chris McCarron didn't have the time to think of what nearly happened. Or even to think of what had happened in a five-horse spill last Oct. 17 when the jockey's left leg was fractured in four places.

title: Death And Disparity
description: There is only one crime on the record of Edward Earl Johnson, a 26-year-old black man of Walnut Grove, Miss., and there are substantial doubts that he committed even that one.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $976,000.

title: CONSTRUCTION DATE IS SET AT STALLED BRIDGEMARKET
description: After a decade of delays, construction of Bridgemarket, a vast food and restaurant center planned for the cavernous recesses beneath the Manhattan side of the Queensboro Bridge, is scheduled to begin May 31.

title: CYNTHIA AUERBACH, DIRECTOR
description: Cynthia Auerbach, an opera director who was associated with the New York City Opera for 15 years, died Thursday night at Mt. Sinai Hospital. She was 44 years old and had been suffering from lung cancer.

title: TOP DEMOCRATS FAIL TO BREAK FILIBUSTER OVER MISSILE SHIELD
description: The Senate Democratic leadership failed today to break a Republican filibuster that has kept this year's major military programs bill from coming to the Senate floor.

description: b-After a $348,750 tax credit. c-Net loss

Immanuel Velikovsky 40 Years Later: Not to Be Taken Seriously
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Incentives
description: The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation has extended sales incentives to a new line of light trucks. The new incentive program runs through June 12, and the existing incentives for cars have been extended to the same date. Buyers have the choice of 3.9 percent financing for two-year loans or a $500 cash rebate. Loans with longer periods would get less interest-rate support.

title: TURNER BROADCASTING SYSEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed the wider loss in the latest quarter to interest and amortization costs related to its acquisition of the MGM film library on March 25, 1986. Those costs applied to only six days of the year-ago quarter, compared with the full 1987 quarter. The company also said interests costs were $51,119,000 in the latest quarter, compared with $16,230,000 for year-ago period. Amortization charges were $28,858,000 for the latest quarter, compared with $6,728,000 for the year-ago period.

title: MOVE BY LINCOLN CENTER PROVOKES BRIEF SQUABBLE
description: A controversy erupted yesterday between Lincoln Center, which operates the Guggenheim Bandshell in Damrosch Park south of the Metropolitan Opera House, and various performing groups that use the facility. But by late in the day, the dispute appeared to have been resolved.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Synergy Group Raises Buyout Bid
description: The International Controls Corporation said Synergy Group Inc. had raised its offer for the company to $45 a share, from $40. International Controls, an electronics and aerospace company, has 3.7 million shares outstanding. The company's board determined Thursday that a rival $42.50-a-share offer from a buyout group, the ICC Acquisition Corporation, was within the range of fairness for shareholders. That bid had been raised from $32 a share.

title: Texaco Bill Fails in Texas
description: Sponsors of a bill to help Texaco Inc. in its court battle with the Pennzoil Company said today that they were giving up their efforts to win passage of the bill in the Texas Legislature because of lack of time and the threat of Senate filibusters.

title: TELEBYTE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dome's Creditors Oppose Amoco Bid
description: The Amoco Corporation's proposed takeover of Canada's Dome Petroleum Ltd., which was outlined in detail Thursday, is unacceptable to creditors who must approve the deal, but bank sources said that they are hoping for a compromise. ''It was a nice try, a first shot,'' said a banker involved in assessing the deal, worth $5.2 billion Canadian, or $3.9 billion United States. ''It doesn't work and we do need to come to some sort of a compromise agreement.''

title: FLORIDA ROCK & TANK LINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for 1986 are pro forma.

title: Senator Says Moscow Will Let Stolars Leave
description: Abe Stolar, a 75-year-old Chicago native who has been trying to leave the Soviet Union since 1974, will be permitted to depart along with four members of his family, Senator Paul Simon said today.

title: CLASSIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: OMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $1,861,000 from refinancing of long-term debt. c-Includes a $27 million after-tax writedown to estimated recoverable value of one foreign-flag crude carrier and to net realizable value of three foreign-flag car-bulk carriers (one of which was 50 percent owned by OMI Corp), and one foreign-flag geared bulk carrier.

title: TOLLESON'S HOMER HELPS HUDSON TO 6TH
description: The power that lifted the Yankees to their sixth victory in seven games came from an unlikely source tonight.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, MAY 16, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-7,32 The President knew of private aid to the Nicaraguan rebels and was ''definitely involved'' in decisions for the financing effort, he said. ''It was my idea to begin with,'' he said. Page 1 A marine facing spying charges will not face the death penalty, the Marine Corps said. But Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree will be court-martialed on other charges stemming from a spy scandal at the United States Embassy in Moscow. 1 New arms pacts should eliminate all Soviet and American medium-range missiles and not allow each side to retain 100 warheads outside Europe, Western defense ministers said. 1 Broadening of agreements to limit nuclear arms was urged by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. A superpower agreement limited to short-range weapons ''would ignore precisely those weapons that threaten above all our country,'' he said. 4 Agents arrested a Sikh suspected of masterminding the assassination of an Indian general. Sukhminder Singh, described as one of India's most wanted men, was captured at a New Jersey gas station. 7 A railroad construction scandal in Brazil threatens what Brazil's President Jose Sarney had planned as the main public-works effort of his administration. 3 A Japanese drive to buy American is succeeding only in part. Despite a drop in the dollar of more than 40 percent against the yen, imports from Europe and Taiwan have recorded far more substantial percentage gains. 37 Most Israelis favor participation in an international conference on the Middle East but are not willing to bring down the Government to pursue the idea, according to a newspaper survey. 3 Sakharov in doubt on releases 3 Fiji troops shut 2 newspapers 4 Segregation in South Pacific 4 Kenya upholds tribal burial 7 Turks frame vote on democracy 32 NATIONAL 8-9, 54 Producer prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Government reported. ''I know Satan's against us,'' the Rev. Jerry Falwell told followers of the ministry. 1 Jim and Tammy Bakker are exiles. The couple climbed beyond their working-class circumstances to dizzying heights of fame and wealth only to be brought down, in the end, by their own excesses. 8 A statement critical of a court ruling was rejected by the United States Commission on Civil Rights. The statement criticized the Supreme Court's decision upholding job preferences for women and minorities. 1 A board for teacher certification tests was announced by the Carnegie Forum on Education and the Economy. The voluntary tests would be developed by the teacher-dominated board. 9 AIDS testing for all immigrants seeking permanent resident status was recommended by the Public Health Service. Aliens found to be infected with the virus would be prevented from gaining permanent status. 1 A hunting and fishing rights dispute between residents of a small Wisconsin town and Indians from a nearby reservation has caused frictions even in the local softball league. 8 An investigation of corruption among Miami police officers is being aided by disclosures from two former officers who pleaded guilty to charges this week. 54 Sale of painkiller suspended 8 Man executed in Georgia 9 Senate filibuster continues 54 REGIONAL 33-36 High revenue may defer tax rises, the Cuomo administration said. More transactions made by taxpayers in 1986 to benefit from tax breaks being phased out under the new Federal tax code created an unexpected revenue increase. 1 Bernhard H. Goetz's lawyer is in the midst of what may be his most difficult legal test. But Barry I. Slotnick is an unabashed self-promoter who views himself as the best criminal lawyer in America. 33 A youth shot by Bernhard Goetz reversed an earlier decision not to testify in Mr. Goetz's trial, rather than face penalties for contempt. The witness, James Ramseur, was one of four teen-agers shot on a Manhattan subway train. 36 A teachers' manual was denounced by the chairman of a legislative panel on human rights because it contains passages that characterize all whites as racist. 33 Bus company records subpoenaed for an inquiry into an automobile purchase by Morris Tarshis, the former New York City franchise director. The Queens Transit Corporation, regulated by Mr. Tarshis's office, had owned the car. 35 Bridgemarket construction begins May 31, after delays from community opposition and financing problems, its promoters say. The food and restaurant center is to be built beneath the Queensboro Bridge. 35 Bicyclists still draw complaints in midtown, although the police say they are issuing more summonses for traffic violations by cyclists and accidents have declined. Critics say existing laws and their enforcement are not strict enough. 33 Smokers would be segregated in Westport, Conn., restaurants under terms of a proposed ordinance. If approved, the ordinance would be among the nation's most restrictive smoking laws. 34 New York City bars barge 33 Farmer gives up a way of life 33 Jersey officer killed by teen 34 Homosexuals to help police with recruiting 35

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Governor Cuomo's nomination of Thomas F. Hartnett to be State Labor Commissioner misidentified Elizabeth D. Moore. title: MUSIC: IVES AND BRAHAMS BY CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA
description: The most interesting composers are not always those who put technical sophistication above all other qualities. In Charles Ives, for instance, we find a bewildering but exhilarating mixture of musical sophistication, philosophical seriousness and naivete, the whole lump leavened by a kind of undergraduate wildness. His Symphony No. 4, which the Cleveland Orchestra performed last evening, is a distillation of those elements in Ives's artistic makeup, with the wildness under somewhat firmer control than in his other, more immediately accessible pieces.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 16, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY Producer prices rose a sharp 0.7 percent in April. The increase, the largest in 18 months, jolted the financial markets by creating new anxiety that the general inflation rate could move well above 4 percent or so in coming months. Higher prices for meat, energy and motor vehicles led the advance, but a wide array of other goods also posted gains. The Producer Price Index measures changes at the wholesale level and is considered a harbinger of inflation at the retail level. The index has averaged a gain of 0.4 percent a month so far this year. On an annual basis, April's rise would produce an annual inflation rate of 5.1 percent. [ Page 1. ] Industrial production fell for the second consecutive month in April, registering a 0.4 percent drop that was the sharpest decline in more than a year. [ 38. ]

title: Sri Lanka Loan Talks
description: Sri Lanka will begin tough negotiations for crucial loans of $240 million in talks with the International Monetary Fund next week, Government officials said today. They said an I.M.F. team would be in Colombo for two weeks, starting Monday, as part of the fund's annual consultation with member countries. Sri Lanka, troubled by a bloody rebellion by its Tamil ethnic minority, has requested the money to support its balance of payments and to offset losses in commodity exports, the officials said. They said that Sri Lanka agreed with the I.M.F. on the need for economic revision but that the agency had its own ideas for reform.

title: Schenley Industries

Schenley, which is based in Dallas, is one of Rapid-American's most profitable divisions. Its products include Dewar's scotch and Gordon's gin. Industry sources said that Mr. Riklis may have approached Guinness P.L.C. or the Seagram Company Ltd. Harold Divine, vice chairman of Rapid-American, did not return phone calls seeking comment.

title: America as Sanctuary
description: In times of turmoil in their homelands, foreign visitors need temporary sanctuary; to send them away would be cruel. Many countries have formal procedures for granting temporary refuge. But visitors to the United States who need a port in a sudden storm are left to the discretion of the Attorney General, whose humanitarian impulses may be constrained by politics. It's time for Congress to formalize safe haven status by law.

The appointment of the 52-year-old Casciola to run the day-to-day operations of the National Basketball Association team was announced by Alan L. Aufzien, the chairman of the board, who called Casciola a ''unique blend of business and sports.''

title: TURKS TO VOTE ON EASING POLITICAL-ACTION CURB
description: After weeks of wrangling, Turkish politicians have agreed on terms for a referendum later this year that is supposed to advance the nation's return to full democracy.

title: BOARD NAMED TO SET TEACHER STANDARDS
description: The Carnegie Foundation announced yesterday that it had created a board to set the first national standards for the professional certification of teachers.

title: SHIFTS IN ABC FALL SCHEDULE ANGER THE NEWS DIVISION
description: ABC, pressed hard by its affiliates for ratings improvement after a dismal prime-time season, announced a new fall schedule yesterday that prompted angry protests from ABC's news division over the cancellation of one news program and the rescheduling of another.

title: HOMOSEXUALS TO HELP POLICE RECRUIT OFFICERS
description: For the first time, the New York City Police Department has requested the help of an organization of homosexual police officers and criminal-justice workers in a recruiting drive.

title: SUSPECTS IN ASSASSINATIONS IN INDIA ARE HELD IN JERSEY
description: An eight-month international search for the man accused of having masterminded the assassination of India's most decorated soldier ended at a gasoline station in New Jersey on Thursday night when Federal agents arrested a Sikh who was being sought by the Indian Government as a suspected terrorist.

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $481,000 and $5,257,000 in the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: IN A REVERSAL, YOUTH SHOT BY GOETZ AGREES TO TESTIFY FOR PROSECUTION
description: Ten days after refusing to be sworn in as a prosecution witness, a young man shot by Bernhard H. Goetz agreed yesterday to testify in the case rather than face penalties for contempt.

title: PRIVATE AID IDEA FOR REBELS IS HIS, PRESIDENT ASSERTS
description: President Reagan said today that he was deeply involved in private American efforts to aid the rebels in Nicaragua, even during a two-year period when Government aid to the rebels was barred by Congress. He indicated that he was proud of it.

title: 2 EXCITING SEMIFINALS MARK INTERNATIONAL TEAM PLAYOFFS
description: Two sensational finishes marked the semifinal of the International Team playoffs here tonight, and the start of the final was delayed.

title: TOWN TRIES NEW NOISES IN THE WAR ON GEESE
description: FRED WALTERS can hardly wait for his six-shooter to arrive so that he can start blasting away at the hundreds of Canada geese expected at Byram Beach in Greenwich this summer. Not to kill them, mind you -just to scare them away.

title: STEINITZ LIVES IN GAMBIT GANTLETS
description: THERE are times when what is needed is the argumentative, stubborn antigambit attitude made famous by Wilhelm Steinitz, who dominated the game from 1866 to 1894.

title: The Most Interesting Recipe I've Clipped: Julia Child
description: ALTHOUGH CHICKEN POACHED in wine with a julienne of vegetables sounds like nouvelle cuisine, it's an age-old method, and one I have been rethinking, transforming and enjoying for more than 35 years.

title: 2 PIANISTS, SAXOPHONIST AND CELLIST IN RECITALS
description: GARY LOUIE

title: SEEING GOLD IN THE GRAY: ACCEPTING SIGNS OF AGE
description: I AM growing gray, or rather platinum, before my time. Still straddling the middle of my 30's, I think of myself as permanently ''pre-middle age,'' save for those telltale signs that crown my head.

title: IN PARIS, A FACE LIFT IN GRAND STYLE
description: WHEN THE ENGLISH QUIBBLE about plans for new public buildings in London, the arguments are esthetic. But when the French do battle over proposals to add something new to Paris, it sometimes seems as if the entire Government may tumble.

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS BEGAN
description: LEAD: I HAVE been thinking lately about the monsters - or fantasies or whatever - that frightened me as a child, and that probably frightened me into being an artist. I can only come up with a few. My parents, of course. The vacuum cleaner, which still frightens me. My sister. A very few ordinary horrors from movies, books, the radio.

title: AFFORDABLE HOUSING: ANOTHER VIEW
description: Herbert Mandel is missing the mark when he blames advocates of low-density housing on Long Island for the area's lack of affordable housing [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, April 19 ] .

title: MCHALE, A MAN OF MANY APPETITES, HAS INSATIABLE ONE FOR HARD WORK
description: A bellhop, with enough food on the tray to feed someone 6 feet 10 inches tall and weighing 235 pounds, knocks on the door of Kevin McHale's hotel room almost every Wednesday morning when the Boston Celtics are playing on the road.

title: Susan Daly Weds A. J. Grymes 4th
description: Susan Daly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Daly of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Arthur Johnson Grymes 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Grymes 3d of John's Island, Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. Richard Lund performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Southampton, L.I.

title: Playing the Best
description: When Julian Altman acquired a stolen Stradivarius violin in 1936, he put it right to work. In fact, he played it for a living in restaurants and at parties for nearly half a century. Not until he was on his deathbed in 1985 did Mr. Altman reveal his secret to his wife, Marcelle Hall. Ms. Hall said he told her he bought the violin from a friend for $100 shortly after it was stolen from a Carnegie Hall dressing room. After his death, she sought out the violin's rightful owner. That turned out to be Lloyds of London, which paid off on a $30,000 policy after the instrument, now valued at about $1 million, was stolen. ''The whole reward to me is to bring this beautiful instrument back to the world,'' Ms. Hall said last week after the Stradivarius was safely on its way to England.

title: Amy S. Kaminow To Marry Aug. 30
description: The engagement of Amy Susan Kaminow to Howard Roy Friedner has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. George Kaminow of Hewlett, L.I. The wedding is to be Aug. 30.

title: Laurie Goodwin Cherbonnier Marries John Christopher Nielsen in Hartford
description: At the chapel of Trinity College in Hartford yesterday, Laurie Goodwin Cherbonnier, the daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Edmond LaBeaume Cherbonnier of West Hartford, Conn., and London, was married to John Christopher Nielsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Nielsen Jr. of Winnetka, Ill. The Very Rev. Alan Jones, dean of Grace Episcopal Cathedral in San Francisco, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Alan Tull.

title: BRINGING THE TERRORS BACK HOME
description: INDIAN COUNTRY By Philip Caputo. 419 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $18.95.

title: TODAY'S MORALITY PLAY: THE SITCOM
description: IN THE CONTROVERSY OVER TV evangelism, no one seems to have noticed that the most influential preacher in America is not Jim Bakker or Jerry Falwell or John Cardinal O'Connor. Rather it is Bill Cosby. Every week his program and some others - ''Family Ties,'' ''Growing Pains,'' ''Mr. Belvedere'' and ''My Sister Sam'' - present vivid and appealing paradigms of love to vast audiences. This love is disclosed by the resolution of family tensions in the lives of characters who have become as real as your next-door neighbors - the Huxtable family of ''The Cosby Show'': Heathcliff, Claire, Sondra, Denise, Vanessa, Theo and Rudi; ''Family Ties' '' Alex, Andy, Jennifer and Mallory and their ''parents,'' Steven and Elyse.

title: A Dog And His Man
description: I am getting fed up with stories such as this, in which the author uses any excuse (in this case, his dog) to publicize his accomplishments in life, how well off he is and what a fine and charming wife he has. I mean, who really cares? MIRIAM N. ALLARD New York City

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SNYDER'S WALK. By Thomas B. Morgan. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $17.95.) Ezra Pound described literature as news that stays news. Thomas B. Morgan's second novel is literature about how hard it is for news to stay news. Jacob C. Snyder, a magazine writer, sees reporting as an almost Arthurian quest for the truth. He has a code of conduct as elaborate as that of any knight out of Chretien de Troyes, with canons against such evils as getting too involved personally or being manipulated. But at the age of 42, when only the ''irrational, incompetent, or unlucky'' are still in journalism, Snyder is faced with a story he can't keep at arm's length - a trek across America in 1966 by a ragtag group of antiwar protesters. He starts out with every intention of maintaining a reporter's distance from the news. Though the walkers see him as a superman who can ennoble their cause by writing favorably about them, he jokes that ''Clark Kent without a phone booth is only Clark Kent.'' But as the weeks pass he sympathizes with them and finds it hard to ignore their complaints that he won't let them ''get closer than your notebook.'' When the walkers dwindle to 11, he sees them as Apostles and himself as a Judas for remaining neutral. In the end, he emerges from his ''journalist's cocoon'' to help, but his betrayal of his own code has unexpectedly tragic consequences. Mr. Morgan, a former editor of The Village Voice, writes adeptly, though he gets carried away at times with awkward similes. And he lets the book's pace, like that of the walk, drag now and then. Nevertheless, he shows us that fiction can provide a surprisingly good medium for raising important questions about the search for facts.

title: LOGRANDE, HALPIN IRK CONSERVATIVES
description: ALTHOUGH the Conservative Party has often been the balance of power in Suffolk County elections, the likely Democratic candidate for Suffolk County Executive has rebuffed the party, while the expected Republican candidate is at odds with Conservative Party leaders.

title: ILLEGAL ALIENS LEARN 'CAVEAT EMPTOR'
description: Lawyers, real-estate agents, notaries public, travel agents and even some driving instructors have put up signs in recent weeks offering to help illegal aliens sort their way through the complexities of the new immigration law.

title: BRING THE TAKEOUT IN
description: TAKEOUT IS A 1987 WAY OF LIFE FOR many people too busy to cook for themselves. It can also be an inventive and spontaneous way of entertaining. These days takeout shops are making more sophisticated dishes and creating more varieties of ethnic and homespun American foods than ever before, and with such a wide array, elegant meals can be assembled almost in the time it takes to arrange the food on party plates.

description: LEAD: ALL'S FAIRS

description: LEAD: THE State Planning Commission is expected to release to county and municipal planning boards on July 2 a preliminary plan for harnessing New Jersey's galloping economic growth.

title: AIDS: SHOULD INSURERS BE ABLE TO TEST?
description: INSURANCE companies want to be free to require individual applicants to undergo laboratory tests designed to detect infection with the AIDS virus. But several states, responding to complaints of discrimination against homosexuals and concern that some people who have antibodies to AIDS may never develop the disease, have restricted the use of such tests by insurers.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: THE tragic end of a civilization that peopled New Jersey as early as 10,000 B.C. is recounted in ''The Lenape: Archaeology, History, and Ethnography,'' by Herbert C. Kraft (New Jersey Historical Society, 230 Broadway, Newark, N.J., $26.70 postpaid).

title: REWARDS OF THE FRESH AIR COUNSELOR
description: Evan Inlaw, a junior majoring in psychology at Fordham University, found that working as a counselor at the Fresh Air Fund's Camp Hidden Valley meant putting to use all of what he has learned. ''You have to use a lot of psychology,'' he said.

title: CAPITALISM KEEPS A TOEHOLD IN CHINA
description: HE BIN rarely leaves home without his Great Wall credit card. One of this city's most successful entrepreneurs, Mr. He uses China's latest status symbol with a casual confidence that belies the long hours and political uncertainties he faces.

title: The Anti-Hitler Conspirators
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
BLONDES
description: LEAD: IF it's true blondes have more fun, Town and Village Hair Stylists should have been a hotbed of good cheer one recent afternoon. The place was packed to almost overflowing with blondes. There were blondes with hair the color of a sandy beach in the morning glare, blondes whose flaxen tresses were pale, blondes with the burnished gloss of gold.

title: TAKE THE GUESTS OUT
description: THE CITY IS HOT, WITHERING HOT, loiter-in-air-conditioned-office-lobbies hot.

title: PAST AND FUTURE VIE AT INDIAN HILL
description: LEAD: THIS is the good time of year on Yorktown's Indian Hill, the time when trees, heavy with leaves, hide any trace of shoppers at the Jefferson Valley Mall and muffle the sounds of cars on busy Route 6, allowing people who hike the 600-foot-high elevation to lose themselves in their thoughts.

title: Officials Pledge Fight On Move of Museum
description: A group of elected officials vowed yesterday to fight a plan to relocate the Museum of the American Indian from Manhattan to Washington.

title:
MUSIC;
CHICAGO'S STANDARD-BEARER OF THE STANDARD REPERTORY
description: LEAD: THE CHICAGO SYMPHONY comes to Carnegie Hall and the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University this week with Mahler, Bruckner and Strauss, the great Middle European repertory for which it is famous. German-born musicians founded and shaped the Chicago Symphony; the Hungarian-born Sir Georg Solti, its music director for 18 years, has continued their tradition.

title: CANDIDATES AIMING AT BABY BOOMERS, SEEN BY MANY AS KEY TO '88 VICTORY
description: Who will decide America's political future? Thomas E. Donilon, an adviser to Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., has a ready answer: ''A 36-year-old accountant from the suburbs of Atlanta.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE HUMAN SEASON. By Sarah Rossiter. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) Prep school novels about a boy's coming of age are familiar and usually written by men, but this first novel by Sarah Rossiter updates the genre while retaining the stock characters. Dunster, a New England boys' boarding school, seems to be a place time forgot, replete with tie-and-jacket code, compulsory chapel and bully-boy students who sir and madam everyone. Whether such a school can or ever could teach morality is the theme underlying this novel of duplicity, adultery and homosexuality. Peter Spaulding, its introspective 18-year-old hero, is the connecting link in an intricate love chain: Peter loves Cate, the waiflike 20-year-old wife of his English teacher, Manning, a bisexual who loves mostly himself but who once loved Peter. Manning also had an affair and fathered a child with Melissa, who is married to the school coach. Melissa and Cate love each other. This dizzying round of sexual variations is given an added spin by Cate's suicide (or was it murder?): she was pregnant with Peter's child. Elements of Gothic mystery are added by an almost mute, mentally incompetent kichen worker who sits in the dark school basement, rocking; an incriminating letter intercepted by the wrong person; and Cate's frenzied jottings (in an examination blue book), which Peter casts into the stream where Cate drowned. (Lest we miss the point, Peter's senior thesis is on Shakespearean tragedy.) The staggering weight of this involuted, somewhat teasing plot would sink most novels, but Ms. Rossiter's restrained, tightly controlled writing keeps it afloat. She writes in a clean, staccato style and has captured preppy male speech quite nicely. But do prep schools still put saltpeter in the mashed potatoes?

title: MUSIC: PETER SCHICKELE IN AN ALTERNATE MODE
description: It was curious to sit in Washington Square United Methodist Church Wednesday night, along with 30 or 40 other devoted listeners, and hear the music of a man who routinely fills Avery Fisher Hall and Carnegie Hall. Even more curious to remember how utterly charming he can be in either circumstance, and to wonder bemusedly about the inherent schizophrenia of having a public and private persona.

title: Mansell Gets Pole
description: Nigel Mansell of Britain and Nelson Piquet of Brazil, Williams-Honda teammates, gained top positions today on the starting grid for the Belgian Grand Prix, which Mansell won last year.

title: Philanthropy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sequel to Tragedy On Mount Hood
description: AFTER seven of its teen-age students and two teachers were killed in the worst climbing accident in the history of Mount Hood, the Oregon Episcopal School in Portland suspended its wilderness education program to take stock.

title: A House In the Country
description: I read your article about a house in the country, and my husband would agree with you. He loves taking long walks in the woods to the river with our dog and he loves puttering around outside. And what am I doing? I am cleaning the house or shopping for food or discovering some form of wildlife in the kitchen, sometimes alive, sometimes not. And as the weekend draws to a close, again, packing up the food, packing up the dog, turning off the water. There are also the fun times when I have to go a day early to wait for the fix-it person.

title: 4,500 GALLONS OF WINE THAT CAN'T BE SOLD
description: EARLY each morning, Randy E. Percy goes to the fields.

title: PLAN TO FIGHT LYME DISEASE GOES TO BOARD
description: LEAD: SANDRA R. GALEF of Ossining, the Democratic minority leader of the County Board of Legislators, says she knows what she will be doing during Lyme Disease Awareness Week, which begins today: studying the County Executive's $240,000 program to combat the tick-borne malady that since 1983 has afflicted 1,400 people in

title: VERMONT PICKS BEST STUDENT WRITERS
description: It seemed like a typical school event: 20 students, dressed casually in jeans and T-shirts, or loose skirts and blouses, sat in a littered classroom, hunkered over blue examination books as two teachers in tweed jackets watched the clock tick toward the time limit.

title: LACK OF DOCTORS CALLED PERIL TO ALIEN AMNESTY
description: A shortage of physicians certified to perform required examinations on illegal aliens under the amnesty program ''is the single biggest problem threatening'' the program's success, according to a report submitted to immigration officials by a New York member of Congress.

title: LAKERS HOLD OFF SONICS
description: James Worthy scored 27 points and Michael Cooper sank three free throws in the final 1 minute 42 seconds today as the Los Angeles Lakers held off the Seattle SuperSonics, 92-87, in Game 1 of the Western Conference finals.

title: LEGISLATIVE WOMEN MAY ADMIT MEN TO CLUB
description: LEAD: THE Connecticut Order of Women Legislators may open its membership to male lawmakers, five of whom have already applied.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: KITE COMPETITIONS A kaleidoscope of kites will take to the skies above Wildwood next weekend. The event, the East Coast Stunt Kite Flying Championship, is attracting about 100 entries from around the country, including Hawaii, where experts abound.

title: Player's Son Dies
description: THE 15-month-old son of Marques Johnson, the Los Angeles Clippers forward, died yesterday after having fallen into the family swimming pool, club officials said. The child, Marques Kevin Johnson Jr., died of cardiac arrest. The youngster was admitted to U.C.L.A. Medical Center Friday night.

title: A RECORD PRISON CENSUS
description: The number of inmates in Federal and state prisons reached a record high last year, the Justice Department reported last week. Since 1980 the prison population has increased 66 percent to a total last year of 546,659.

title: A NEW LIFE FOR GARDEN STATUS
description: BETWEEN THE CIVIL War and World War II, sculptors decorated the gardens of Europe and America with grandiose urns, fanciful fountains, heroic statuary and a wealth of weighty furniture. Nobody knows how many of these figures and furnishings have survived the elements, wartime scrap drives and property subdivisions of the 1950's. But we may soon find out, now that these works are reappearing on lawns and in living rooms.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: UNHEARD VOICES: Labor and Economic Policy in a Competitive World. By Ray Marshall. (Basic Books, $19.95.) ''What is good for General Motors may not necessarily be good for the country,'' writes Ray Marshall, ''but what is good for American workers and their families is almost certainly good for the country.

title: In Death, as in Life, Casey Stirs Strong Feelings
description: To the Editor:

title: Rhett Cahill Has Wedding
description: Sarah Rhett Cahill, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George F. Cahill Jr. of Stoddard, N.H., was married yesterday to Kenneth Alan Zuckerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Zuckerman of New York. The Rev. Katrina R. Finley, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Boston.

title: Italy Sets 1990 Cup Dates
description: The 1990 World Soccer Cup competition will take place in 12 Italian cities from June 9 to July 8, with the final at the Olympic Stadium in Rome, the organizers announced today. The dates will have to be officially ratified by the Federation Internationale de Football Association, but this was considered a formality. The cup will follow the same formula as the 1986 championship in Mexico. The countries wishing to compete have to enter their teams by September of this year. The draw for the qualification groups will be held in Zurich Dec. 12.

description: Massachusetts has become the first state in the nation to outlaw alachlor, the nation's most widely used agricultural herbicide, which is suspected of causing cancer.

description: CONTRARY to the claims of several Japanese companies in New Jersey, the recently proposed United States trade sanctions against Japan ''actually may have some positive effects on our efforts to sell New Jersey products overseas,'' according to Ming Hsu, director of the state's Division of International Trade.

description: IT won't be long now before I move my house plants to their summer locations.

Zinsser of New York and Old Black Point at Niantic, Conn., and Robert Ferreira, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Anthony Ferreira of Seekonk, Mass., and Jamestown, R.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. David Good performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

NUMISMATICS;
FRANCE CONTINUES ITS ANNUAL SERIES
