description: ''WE'RE not missionaries running the Constitution up for everybody to salute and give honor to it,'' said Richard Petrow of Manhattan and Southampton. ''We're looking at it as a very real document drafted by politicians in Philadelphia. And it's not perfect; yet it's been around for 200 years, and it certainly contributes something important.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: NEWTON, MASS.;
Project Brings 'Class Struggle'
description: LEAD: THE view beyond the boarded-up classroom buildings of St. Sebastian's Country Day School here is of a distant golf course and the towers of the Boston skyline.

title: Julia Schieren Penick, a Law Student, Is Married to Timothy Howard Garry
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Julia Schieren Penick, a daughter of Mrs. Sydnor Barksdale Penick 3d of Princeton and the late Dr. Penick, was married to Timothy Howard Garry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Garry of Cincinnati. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Daphne Hawkes, assisted by the Rev. Dennis Corrado, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Miss Greenberg Weds Jeffrey Lehman on L.I.
description: Mallory Greenberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Greenberg of Sands Point, L.I., and Jeffrey H. Lehman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lehman of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., were married last evening. Rabbi Stephen Folberg performed the ceremony at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

title: Rosemary Cosentino Weds
description: Rosemary E. Cosentino and Walter J. Winnitzki were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary in Manhasset, L.I., by the Rev. Lawrence D. Costello. The couple's parents are Angelina Cosentino of Brooklyn and the late Michael J. Cosentino, and Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Winnitzki of Forest Hills, Queens. The bride, who will retain her name, is director of financial planning and budgeting for the Manhattan Shirt Company in Glen Rock, N.J. Mr. Winnitzki is a vice president of the investment banking firm L. F. Rothschild & Company.

description: Lucie Francesca Maslow, a clinical social worker at the Helen Ross McNabb Mental Health Center, and William Roland Hartley-Urquhart, director of international finance at ConAgra, a food and agriculture conglomerate, both in Knoxville, Tenn., were married yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: WETLANDS ISSUE: STATE INTERVENES

They have charged that because of a lack of inspections and enforcement of environmental protection laws, many parcels have been developed that should not have been.

description: Steaming With Vanessa Redgrave. Directed by Joseph Losey. 1986. New World Video. 102 minutes. $69.95.

title: Kathryn S. Lewis To Become Bride Of Douglas Heidt
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Lewis of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathryn Suzanne Lewis to Douglas Carl Heidt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Heidt of West Simsbury, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: A Guide to Italian Cooking with Giuliano Bugialli. Producer/director: Lee Kraft. Videocraft. 100 minutes. $49.95.

title: Q and A
description: Passports Question:Is there any way you can obtain a passport without spending time at a passport office? - R. S., Hicksville, L.I. Answer:There are agencies that specialize in obtaining United States passports, visas and other documents. They use messengers to stand on line at passport offices and consulates and their fees depend on how quick a service is needed. Usually an applicant needs to make a brief visit to the agency's office, taking birth certificate and oher documents, but for renewing a passport it is sometimes not even necessary to do that. If certain criteria can be met, applicants just have to deliver documents to the office. (The agencies can also supply birth certificates for people who have lost them.) Among services in New York is Passport Plus (677 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022; 212-759-5540 and, from out of state, 800-367-1818). A citizen obtaining a passport for the first time pays Passport Plus $50 for one-week service, $65 to get a passport in 48 hours. The office will make the required photographs for another $5.95. For passport renewal, fees are: one week, $35; 48 hours, $50.

title: REAGAN SAYS HIS EFFORT TO PROMOTE THE REBELS WAS RIGHT - AND LEGAL
description: THE disclosures came in bits and pieces last week, buried in the impassive, often disjointed testimony of Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser. But they added up to a new picture of the President's role in the Iran-contra affair, a picture very different from that drawn by the Tower Commission last February.

title: Fiji Army Says It Will Limit the Rights of Indians
description: Two days after seizing power in a coup, the army said today that it would restore democracy under a new constitution limiting the rights of ethnic Indians.

title: Amy Gewirtz to Wed Michael F. McGahan
description: Amy Ellen Gewirtz and Michael Francis McGahan, both lawyers, plan to marry June 28, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gewirtz of Southport, Conn., and New York have announced. Mr. McGahan is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis McGahan of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: TOURISTS, IN A WAY
description: IT has been a few years since I last wandered around downtown Great Neck, a place I have never lived in but have often, if sporadically, visited, mostly to see friends whose children have now grown up and gone west - that is, to new apartment households in the city whence they came.

title: In Today's Issue
description: Special Today: Entertaining/Magazine Part 2 * Strategies for easy summer get-togethers for busy people. * Take the Guests Out. It can be done with style. * Bring the Takeout In: A quick and effortless party. * Let the Guests Do the Cooking - it lightens the load. * A Feast for 20 Under $100. * Picnics built around your favorite sport, even balloning. * How to choose wine for every taste and budget.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Fanny and Alexander Directed and written by Ingmar Bergman. Starring Pernilla Allwin, Bertil Guve, Ewa Froling, Erland Josephson, Jan Malmsjo, Gunn Wallgren. 1983. Embassy Home Entertainment. 197 minutes. $39.95.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: LEAD: A Fine Mess Written and directed by Blake Edwards. With Ted Danson, Howie Mandel, Richard Mulligan, Stuart Margolin and Maria Conchita Alonso. 1986. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 100 minutes. $79.95.

title: BRAVING THE WILDS OF FASHIONABLE HAIR
description: I HAD WORN my hair in a conservative pageboy for years, but now in the springtime, this middle-aged woman's fancy turned to thoughts of a new hair style. For the last seven years or so, I've looked the part of the college instructor that I am - classic in coiffeur and dress, correct. Then, in a moment of madness, I walked into the beauty salon for my first ''perm'' since high school. In two hours, I emerged, my hair a mass of frizzy waves, each strand springing from my head with a life of its own. Luckily, this hair style is ''in.'' If it were not, strangers would suspect I'd had an unfortunate encounter with a light socket.

title: Alysheba Goes for $5 Million
description: INSTEAD of improving the breed, it's as if horse racing were trying to improve the greed. When the Belmont Stakes is run on June 6, the Triple Crown Challenge bonus will be worth either $5 million or $1 million, depending on Alysheba, now the winner of both the Preakness and the Kentucky Derby.

title: CONCERT: PERCUSSION AND PIANO DUO, AT WEILL HALL
description: WEDNESDAY'S evening of percussion and piano music at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall eloquently reminded us of the polyglot world around us. Daniel Druckman -tapping, beating, stroking a wild variety of instruments - and Alan Feinberg at the keyboard together called to mind a pair of frantically busy interpreters at a United Nations parley, racing from one party to another trying to create coherent messages from confusion.

title: Maltese Policy
description: After years of drifting politically toward Libya, the Mediterranean island nation of Malta is preparing to move closer to Europe, according to its new Prime Minister, Eddie Fenech Adami. Mr. Fenech Adami, who took office last week after his conservative Nationalist Party ended 16 years of Socialist rule by defeating the governing Labor Party, said he planned to renegotiate a treaty with Libya to elminate clauses on defense cooperation. ''Malta and Libya will no longer give the impression that their policy is identical,'' he said. Instead, he favors closer ties with Western Europe and eventual membership in the European Community. However, Mr. Fenech Adami said Malta would remain neutral, denying harbor access to both NATO and Warsaw Pact nations.

title: Data Update
description: VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS (Residential in millions of dollars)

title: FINDING A NEED, FILLING A NICHE
description: LEAD: FOR The Globe Pequot Press in Chester, born of humble beginnings, this year marks a coming of age as it celebrates three events - its 40th anniversary, publication of the 10th edition of its best-selling book ''Guide to the Recommended Country Inns of New England'' and the purchase of the East Woods Press of Charlotte, N

title: ALYSHEBA, 2-1, WINS THE PREAKNESS
description: The Kentucky Derby was rerun today at Pimlico Race Course under the name of the Preakness Stakes, and Alysheba beat Bet Twice again. Alysheba's half-length victory made the son of Alydar eligible to become thoroughbred racing's first Triple Crown winner since Affirmed in 1978.

title: IT'S MATING SEASON AT THE THEATER
description: I DON'T KNOW THAT LOVE IS SWEEPING THE country, but sex is surely taking the town. On stage, that is. Some of the sex is dramatically useful, some of it is just plain nutty fun, and some of it is deliberately distasteful. I guess that's a gamut, though the plays all seem to end up with their principal characters deeply troubled, momentarily deprived, or flat out dead. Strange bedfellows.

title: CONNECTION TO A CALMER WORLD
description: WE were standing - my husband and I - in a lot at the Cape Cod Fence Company, trying to choose a fence for a dog pen when I saw the wooden glider on the other side of the lot.

title: THE HIGH-TECH AUCTION IS A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: LEAD: THE scene was more reminiscent of a professional seminar than a sale. Men in pin-striped suits took turns at the podium and pointed to slides that flashed by on a screen. But the 1,600 people packed into the conference room at the Dedham, Mass., Holiday Inn recently were bargain hunting in cast-off computers.

title: Miss Maloney Weds James Patrick Dowd
description: Elizabeth Ann Maloney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Maloney of Easton, Conn., and James Patrick Dowd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mathew J. Dowd of West Brighton, S.I., were married yesterday at Notre Dame of Easton Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Robert J. Hyl performed the ceremony. Mary Ellen Maloney was her sister's maid of honor. Matthew Dowd was his brother's best man.

title: BRONX ELDERLY FIND NEW USES FOR TV
description: Unless the Bronx becomes wired for cable or a major network syndicates the show, only a fraction of the Friday morning television audience will ever see ''Zeit Gezunt! It's Friday.''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: OPPONENTS of the dumping of sewage sludge in the Atlantic are backing a bill introduced by State Senator Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of the 11th District (part of Monmouth County), that would bar New Jersey treatment plants from using the ocean unless it met the toxic-contamination standards for land-based disposal.

title: PROFESSIONAL GROUPS FIGHT DRUG ABUSE
description: LEAD: A GROWING number of professional organizations, concerned about substance abuse among their members, are stepping up their effort to identify and offer assistance to those with problems.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Little Shark Face Mothers' love has evolved like everything else, as we can see in ''Bluegill,'' a story in which a young woman strikes an unusual maternal note in talking to her unborn child. This is from ''Fast Lanes'' (Dutton/Seymour Lawrence), by Jayne Anne Phillips.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Check Phone Rates Before Dialing

title: Housing the Homeless: Workshop
description: Government officials and private citizens have been seeking ways of easing the plight of the homeless for many years. Yet solutions still elude the seekers and the number of homeless people seems to grow with each passing year.

title: NEW YORK BATTLES CAR LICENSE FRAUD
description: For the last five months, tax investigators have searched streets by night and subpoenaed garages' customer lists seeking to track down New York residents who violate the law by registering their cars outside the state.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: Expand Academy of Sciences to Embrace Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
description: LAST fall, as I was in the middle of a study of 19th-century school readers, I learned that Christian fundamentalist parents in Tennessee had won a victory in Federal court in their challenge of the reading textbooks used in the public schools. The parents claimed that the school district in Greeneville violated their First Amendment rights by requiring their children to read textbooks that taught feminism, pacifism, humanism and other tenets offensive to their religious convictions. The judge ruled that their children should be excused from reading the district's textbooks whenever something offended their religious values.

title: IS WALL STREET READY FOR BAD TIMES?
description: AFTER five years of booming markets and unparalleled expansion, Wall Street's major securities firms have been transformed into sprawling global behemoths. But suddenly they are trying to reverse course out of a fear that leaner times lie ahead. That raises an unsettling question: Are Wall Street managers, already straining to control their bloated ranks, prepared to cope with a squeeze?

title: TELEVISION NEWS AND THE CONGRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALY'S SOCIALISTS SUDDENLY FALTER
description: When Bettino Craxi resigned as Prime Minister on March 3, he was considered one of the most popular politicians in Italy, and his Socialist Party seemed poised to achieve substantial election gains.

title: CARDINALS EDGE REDS, 6-5
description: Jack Clark drove in three runs with a homer and a double, and Curt Ford also had a home run, leading the Cardinals to a 6-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Carving Out a Community for the Retired
description: LEAD: AT a time when most Long Island communities oppose new construction, a 49-acre project centered around a retirement community in the heart of the village of Stony Brook is finding a welcome.

title: Doctors' Offices: Rx for Rental Squeeze
description: Doctors do not have an easy time finding offices on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. One reason is the number of medical institutions there. Clustered in the 60's and 70's are Lenox Hill Hospital; Manhattan Eye, Ear, Nose and Throat; New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, the Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, and, farther uptown on Fifth Avenue, the Mount Sinai Medical Center.

title: IN THE NEW YORK CITY AREA
description: A sampling of some of the firms offering sports opportunities in the vicinity of New York City - upstate New York, Long Island, New Jersey, Connecticut and eastern Pennsylvania - follows. All are within about two and one-half hours of Manhattan. BALLOONING

title: AQUEDUCT WORKSHOP
description: Twelve Westchester communities along the Hudson River share another waterway: the Old Croton Aqueduct, which begins in Cortlandt and runs 26.1 miles south to the Bronx border. An aqueduct workshop on the weekend of May 29 will provide an opportunity to explore this historic treasure, which was completed in 1842 to carry water to New York City and is now a state park.

title: Students Clash With Police For 6th Day in South Korea
description: Thousands of students battled policemen today in the sixth day of demonstrations demanding the ouster of President Chun Doo Hwan, witnesses said.

title: THEY HAD REASON TO BE HUMBLE
description: THE LAUNCHING OF MODERN AMERICAN SCIENCE 1846-1876 By Robert V. Bruce. Illustrated. 446 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: AUSTRIANS SEEM TO CUT SUPPORT FOR WALDHEIM
description: Chancellor Franz Vranitzky will make a symbolically important visit to Washington this week amid signs that political support for President Kurt Waldheim has eroded in Austria since the Justice Department listed Mr. Waldheim as being barred from entering the United States.

title: WORK STARTS ON WASTE CENTER
description: LEAD: ACADEMIC, industry and government officials got together here last week to move the first shovelful of earth at the site of a new building for the Center for Hazardous and Toxic Substances Management.

title: A 'NEW CENTRISM' QUIETLY CREEPS INTO CAMPAIGN
description: A quiet change under way in American political life - the creation of a new center - may be more momentous in the long run than such attention-seizing matters as Gary Hart's evening with Donna Rice or President Reagan's Iran-contra problems.

title: 20% DROP IS PREDICTED IN STATE PEACH HARVEST
description: NEW JERSEY'S peach trees, which last year yielded the third highest crop in the nation, were severely damaged in southern counties this winter, and state agriculture officials say that the coming summer's harvest will be down 20 percent.

title: Barbara Thistle Marries
description: At Faith Lutheran Church in Andover, Mass., yesterday Barbara A. Thistle and John R. Tormondsen were married by the Rev. Dennis P. Kohl, assisted by the Rev. Richard O'Leary, a Roman Catholic priest. The couple's parents are William H. Thistle of Malden, Mass., and the late Mrs. Thistle, and Mr. and Mrs. Roald Tormondsen of Duluth, Minn. The bride graduated from Dartmouth College, from which she and her husband both received M.B.A. degrees. Mr. Tormondsen, a bond trader at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, graduated from Middlebury College.

title: DOWN-TO-EARTH DOWN EASTERS
description: LEAD: This winter I found in Maine what I have sorely missed in five years of living in California. A friend of mine - British, like me - put it this way: she said that if only California had peasants, she would travel to it for all her holidays.

title: '42d STREET STAGED IN EAST WINDSOR
description: SHOWMANSHIP, glitter and a distinctive directorial imprint don't just embellish the quintessential backstage fairy tale, ''42d Street,'' they define it. The 1933 film is identified by its splashy Busby Berkeley production numbers, the stage version turned out to be a testament to the effervescent style - and spectacular career - of its director and choreographer, Gower Champion, who died the day the show opened on Broadway almost seven years ago.

title: ITALIAN DRAWINGS WITH A NOBLE PAST
description: WALKING ROUND THE Italian Old Master drawings from the British royal collection that can be seen at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, through July 26, this visitor did not think all the time of the kings and queens of England, fascinating as many of them were. He thought of the private enthusiasts who had been given a chance of getting hold of fine drawings in large numbers and made haste to gobble them up. It is to them, in the end, as much as to any royal fiat, that the present richness and diversity of the collection are owed.

title: NEW POSTAL CARDS MARK HISTORIC EVENTS
description: TWO postal cards are scheduled for release in the next eight days. The first, to be released Friday, commemorates the 150th anniversary of the self-scouring steel plow. The second, to be released May 25, will mark the 200th anniversary of the Constitutional Convention.

title: NEW YORK CITY OFFICIALS CITE 30 FOOD OUTLETS FOR VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 30 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: PLAINFIELD INVITES THE UNWELCOME
description: THE state is beginning to look for sites to build three major medium-security prisons, and while most municipalities are trying to keep them out, a small town in the eastern part of Connecticut is courting corrections officials.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: OUR WAR AND HOW WE WON IT by E. J. Cullen. Viking. 238 Pages. $17.95.

title:
GARDENING;
IN PRAISE OF THE MANY SPLENDORED ROSE
description: LEAD: AS you may know, the rose was recently declared our national flower. This was not a spur of the moment decision: the debate began back in the 1950's when Senator Everett Dirksen of Illinois, supported by David Burpee of the W.Atlee Burpee Seed Company, proposed the marigold for that honor. One might say that Mr.

title: Breeze McMennamin to Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. G. Barry McMennamin of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marilynn Breeze McMennamin to Gustavus Warfield Hobbs 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hobbs 3d of Manasota Key, Fla., and Stonington, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: Stephanie Jane Mairs Weds Dr. Nitin Damle
description: Stephanie Jane Mairs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Conway Jr. of Warwick, R.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Nitin S. Damle, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Shridhar Damle of New York. The Rev. Frank Gillespie, assisted by the Rev. Alfred Burns, performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Greenwich, R.I.

title: To My Dearest Enemy. . .
description: Dear President Reagan:

title: Elizabeth Malone Wed To Kenneth Diamond
description: Elizabeth Sahlin Malone, an associate in the Washington law firm Hughes, Hubbard & Reed, was married yesterday to Kenneth Joel Diamond, a law clerk to Judge J.Frederick Motz of the Federal District Court in Maryland. Judge Motz officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gifford D. Malone, in McLean, Va. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward J. Diamond Jr. of Pittsburgh.

title: LESSON PLANS FOR LIVING WITH THE UNTHINKABLE
description: ATTEMPTS to teach schoolchildren about the dangers of nuclear war have been criticized by conservative organizations and educators, including Secretary of Education William J. Bennett, as indoctrination in the ideals of the nuclear freeze movement.

title: THE HUMAN DRAMA BEHIND A HOT AD
description: IT WAS ONE of those painful moments that people in the advertising business remember forever. The top talents of this city's hottest agency, Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc., were crowded into the 39th floor conference room late on a December afternoon. There, too, was Kenneth A. Olisa, the new marketing chief of Wang Laboratories, for years the agency's most important client. He was making it plain that he was waiting for magic to happen. And everybody in the room knew it wasn't happening.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Protectionism is the ally of isolationism, and isolationism is the Dracula of American foreign policy.'' - William G. Hyland, former national security adviser. [ 34:5. ]

title: DANCE: PAINTERLY STROKES FOR PARIS THEATER PIECES
description: One never can tell what will happen at the Paris Opera these days. The premiere of a mixed-media event involving dancers and two painters well-known in New York - Paul Jenkins and Karel Appel - is typical of the winds of change, for better or for worse, that are blowing outside influences into the Opera House productions.

title: Orbach's Restoration: Revival on 34th
description: The turn-of-the-century structure that once housed two of America's great retailing institutions - J.P. McCreery's and, more recently, the flagship store of Ohrbach's - is destined for renovation and conversion into 430,000 square feet of offices and stores.

title: A House In the Country
description: At a time that millions of Americans cannot afford homes of their own, in a world in which land is a limited resource, it is appalling that owners of second homes may still deduct mortgage interest from their taxable incomes.

title: No Fracture for Davis
description: HE was still feeling the pain, but Eric Davis, the Cincinnati Reds' star outfielder who hurt his left shoulder making a diving catch against the Cardinals in St. Louis Friday night, had some good news yesterday morning. According to a Reds spokesman, a second round of X-rays confirmed that there had been no fracture to the shoulder, indicating that Davis should be able to return to the lineup within a few days. Jim Ferguson, the Reds' spokesman, said the injury had been diagnosed as a jammed shoulder with injury to the soft tissue.

title: FRIENDS DESERTING SARNEY AS BRAZIL'S ECONOMY WORSENS
description: ONLY six months ago, Brazil's majority party seemed proud to count President Jose Sarney among its members, using the popularity of his economic policies to score a stunning victory in crucial gubernatorial and Assembly elections.

title: Birdsong Ruling
description: THE official announcement isn't due until tomorrow, but according to a report in The Daily News, an arbitrator has decided that the Nets have to pay Otis Birdsong his full $500,000 salary next season but don't have to fork over some $280,000 the team had withheld from his salary for this past season. The Nets, claiming that Birdsong had fraudently failed to tell the team about a pre-existing stress fracture that kept him out of the lineup for most of the season, had sought to void his entire three-year contract, which includes an option year, at a $500,000 salary, for the 1988-89 season. Birdsong started only six games this season, scoring only 44 points.

title: FARMERS' INCOME RISE 35% IN NEW YORK STATE
description: New York State's farm economy improved last year, with farmers' net income up 35 percent, according to agricultural officials. But farmers still made less than in the early 1980's.

title: Move to Aid Salmon Pays Off
description: MEETING in Manhattan recently, directors of the Canadian-American Atlantic Salmon Federation heard two of their officers report that after nearly 20 years of battling for the species' survival, there was cause for rejoicing.

title: Yugoslav Named to Top Post
description: Lazar Mojsov became head of the collective presidency, Yugoslavia's highest Government body, the official Tanyug press agency reported Friday. Mr. Mojsov, a former Foreign Minister, replaced Sinan Hasani, who served for the last year under a rotation system. Mr. Mojsov is the ninth head of the collective presidency since the death of Tito in May 1980.

title: On Giving Wolves A Second Chance
description: ONE problem with trying to reintroduce wolves, an endangered species, to national parks in the United States is that the wolf has always had bad press.

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: Five Lionni Classics The Animal Fables of Leo Lionni Random House 30 minutes. $14.95.

title: A Fine Mess
description: In New York City, it can be difficult to get a landlord to make repairs. Witness the case of J. Leonard Spodek, a Long Island resident who has been charged with failing to make court-ordered improvements in 29 of his 70 Manhattan and Brooklyn apartment buildings. Last year, Mr. Spodek served 45 days in jail on criminal and civil charges involving uncorrected building code violations.

title: French and Russians Still at Odds on Arms
description: Three days of reportedly sharp talks between Soviet leaders and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France did not bridge the gap between the two countries on disarmament issues, a Soviet spokesman said today.

title: IT'S 'EMBARRASSING' TIME FOR PADRES
description: PERHAPS a pivotal run that the Pittsburgh Pirates scored against San Diego one night last week epitomized the kind of season it has been for the pathetic Padres.

title: STATE POLICE AID LOCAL FORCES
description: LEAD: AN OUNCE of crime prevention, says Col. Clinton L. Pagano, Superintendent of the State Police, is worth ''half a ton of cure,'' and a key to the state's current effort, he contends, will be widespread use of the Crime Prevention Resource Center.

title: Constitution Race Has Shaky Start
description: The Constitution Race, a trans-Atlantic regatta marking the 30th anniversary of the European Economic Community and the 200th anniversary of the signing of the United States Constitution, got off to a shaky start today.

title: Anne Whiteman to Wed
description: Anne Margaret Whiteman and Andrew Clark Brummer, both 1985 graduates of Colgate University, plan to be married in July. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Whiteman of Shaker Heights, Ohio, who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Gordon Brummer of Manhasset, L.I.

title: GARBAGE ACCORD FAILS TO END DISPUTE
description: LEAD: OFFICIALS from the State Department of Environmental Conservation and Islip are applauding the agreement last week giving the town additional landfill capacity to accommodate its solid waste through 1990.

title: Japanese Make Roads, and Inroads, in Africa
description: Asaji Kurosawa, the son of a Japanese rice farmer, decided last year to see a bit of the world. Today, he builds low-income housing in this West African village.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: LEAD: The Canadian Brass Live! Gurtman & Murtha and Brassworks Music Inc. 50 minutes. $19.95

title: TEA KETTLE WITH DESIGNER CACHET
description: WATER kettles designed by architects may be to the 1980's what sheets created by designers were to the 1970's. The latest status object in which to boil water is Aldo Rossi's Il Conico.

title: Polly K. Hahn Weds Matthew Ernst
description: Polly King Hahn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Hahn Jr. of Washington, and Matthew Abbott Ernst, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Calvin Bradley Ernst of Ann Arbor, Mich., were married yesterday. Judge John Lewis Smith of the District Court of the District of Columbia performed the ceremony in the garden at the Hahn home.

title: Article's Source Taken to Task
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CHINA OPPOSITION THRIVES IN QUEENS
description: Sitting at a card table in the back room of an apartment in Flushing, Queens, Wang Bingzhang does not seem a likely figure to be plotting the introduction of democracy to China.

title:
ART;
'PEOPLE AND PLACES' AT THE KORNBLUTH
description: LEAD: THEMES for art exhibitions are growing increasingly complex these days, and the complexity is being reflected in titles with ingenious punctuation or rafts of subordinate clauses.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: INDECENT EXPOSURE. By Tom Sharpe. (Alantic Monthly Press, Paper, $6.95.) ''Indecent Exposure,'' originally published in Britain in 1973, purports to be a satire on South Africa and apartheid. Its first appearance here has been awaited eagerly in view of the author's success in this country with a previous novel, ''Riotous Assembly'' (now also available in paperback from the same publisher).

title: JERSEY CHURCH HELPS REGION'S ALIENS
description: For the last few weeks, scores of undocumented aliens have come through the doors of the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd here seeking information on the amnesty program that will permit many of them to legalize their status in this country.

title: No Pinstripes? No Problem
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A House In the Country
description: I continue to be surprised that New Yorkers have never heard of the eastern part of Connecticut. We, too, have nice old houses yearning to be restored, and we have, at least at the moment, brooks with cowslips and forget-me-nots and orchards with bluebirds and lovely views. I persist in believing the climate is much nicer than on the other side of the river. But no couturiers or writers or artists in search of peaceful weekends come here. Now most of the large farms are selling out to builders of masses of small houses, and the peace and the beauty are threatened. Where, oh, where are the zillionaires who love peaceful weekends? LOIS ORSWELL Pomfret Center, Conn.

title: 'A MOUTH TO FEED'
description: ISAAC CAMPION By Janni Howker. 85 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $10.25. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: Science, Technology And AIDS
description: Dr. Gould's muddy thoughts do little more than add to the general alarm. He fears the coming pandemic explosion yet rejects technology as our main ally. He sees its mechanism yet hints the answer is nontechnological.

title: 'In the Country of Last Things'
description: One prepares, when picking up a novel that promises to be postapocalyptic, to change his critical kit bag. One prepares to find moral guidance and instructions for living in novels of the next world, in a way we've learned it is sophisticated not to find them in novels of this world. The assumption is that whatever horror is contained in the next world may, if we buy the prophecy and the route from here to there, serve to change our current imprudent behavior and steer this unhappy world away from the unhappier one the novelist warns us is ahead.

title: USE A MICROWAVE
description: THE ARRIVAL OF WARM WEATHER and weekend guests is an ideal time to take advantage of a microwave oven. This handy appliance does not heat up your kitchen, cooks rapidly and lets you make festive dishes quickly after a late return from tennis or the beach. And although microwave ovens are not appropriate for every recipe, many foods cook as well as, or better than, they would in a conventional oven, and in a fraction of the time.

title: FLIER CHAMPIONS BREAKFAST
description: THE Westchester County Office for the Aging has produced a nationally cited booklet that reinforces an old message. For years, parents have told their children about the importance of starting the day with a good breakfast. Now this six-page booklet, entitled ''The Forgotten Meal,'' is trying to deliver the same message to the elderly.

title: VIOLINS YIELD THEIR SECRETS TO EXPERT
description: TO DARIO D'ATTILI, although ''no two fiddles are or sound alike,'' there is ''not much of a difference'' between one fine violin and another.

title: CHOOSING THE SPORT
description: A SENSE OF SHARED ADVENTURE IS the goal when you are organizing a day of sports activity for friends. Among the summer outings that you can host for a small group are ballooning, river rafting, canoeing, sailing, board sailing, horseback riding and deep-sea fishing. The question is, which one is best for you and your companions?

title: Misquoting 'Texasville'
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeffry B. Seidel Married To Leslie Carol Fielden
description: The marriage of Leslie Carol Fielden, an associate in the New York law firm Solinger Grosz & Goldwasser, and Jeffry Bruce Seidel, a manager in the tax department at the Touche Ross Financial Services Center in New York, took place last evening at Federal Hall in Manhattan. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony.

title: WEINBERGER COMMENT ON MISSLES SAID TO UPSET WHITE HOUSE AIDES
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's open questioning of an understanding on medium-range missiles that was reached at the Iceland summit meeting has displeased senior White House and State Department officials, Administration officials said today.

title: CHANNEL 21 DROPPED BY CABLE SYSTEMS
description: LEAD: A MANHATTAN cable system has dropped WLIW/Channel 21 from its programming, and Long Island public broadcasting officials are worried that the move may foreshadow more desertions.

title: THE INSIDER SCANDALS TAKE A STUNNING TURN
description: The Government asked to dismiss insider trading charges against three Wall Street professionals, but the defendants' lawyers are fighting the request. The strange twist in the insider trading scandals came when a Federal judge denied a request by the Government for a two-month delay in the trial of Timothy L. Tabor, Robert M. Freeman and Richard B. Wigton. The Government said it needed more time to develop its case, and, when it could not get the delay, asked for a dismissal of the indictments so it could seek new, broader indictments. The defense lawyers are expected to ask the judge to either order an immediate trial or dismiss the indictments ''with prejudice,'' preventing the Government from bringing the same charges again. The development was seen as the first major setback in the Wall Street investigation for Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan. For its part, the Government claims that it has so much information that it needs time to develop a wider and more comprehensive case against the three men. * * *

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: MAY 17, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $4.95.) The tale of a British secret agent and his father, a flamboyant con man. 2 3 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter becomes a consuming passion. 3 11 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.95.) A plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 4 3 WISCONSIN! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $4.50.) Toby Holt of the ''Wagons West'' series fights to preserve his lumber enterprise. 5 * 2 THE SONGS OF DISTANT EARTH, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) Mankind's first encounter with life on a paradisaical world. 6 6 THE GREAT ALONE, by Janet Dailey. (Pocket, $4.95.) Women's role in seven generations of Alaskan history. 7 8 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 8 1 GOD GAME, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Tom Doherty/Tor, $4.50.) A couple's marriage is seriously strained when they strike it rich in journalism. 12 7 MAGIC KINGDOM FOR SALE - SOLD! by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.50.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 5 28 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's experiences flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 6 2 ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Seventy-six days alone at sea on an inflatable raft. 7 2 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by Harold Kushner. (Pocket, $4.50.) (Jove, $3.95.) The story of a former C.I.A. agent who supplied the Libyans with illegal weapons and bombs. 11 * 3 ARCTIC DREAMS, by Barry Lopez. (Bantam, $4.95.) A rhapsodic report on human life and wildlife north of the Arctic Circle. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction: Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 4 HOUND OF THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $5.95.) A collection of syndicated ''Far Side'' cartoons. 2 50 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 3 2 THE ROTATION DIET, by Martin Katahn. (Bantam, $4.50.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 4 5 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $6.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 5 16 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $4.95.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: RAISING BUCKS FOR BUSH
description: LAWRENCE E. BATHGATE 2D, LAW-yer, land investor, multimillionaire, inveterate schmoozer, and fund-raiser for Vice President Bush, is on the phone, dealing in the currency of politics.

title: Elizabeth Ann Monaco Bride of Neil McCarthy
description: At St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Marblehead, Mass., yesterday Elizabeth Ann Monaco, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Vincent Monaco of Marblehead, was married to Neil Michael McCarthy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. McCarthy of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. George A. Westerberg, rector of the church, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Hugh Cleary, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Valerie Campbell Is the Bride of Eric Abrahamson
description: Valerie Gayle Campbell, who is to join the New York law firm Brown & Wood as an associate in September, was married yesterday to Eric Abrahamson, a teaching fellow and a doctoral candidate in management at the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration. The Rev. Richard Edens, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Fearrington House in Pittsboro, N.C.

title: IT'S A MATTER OF HONOR FOR OLDERS IN THE FINAL
description: In what is perhaps the proper conclusion to the seemingly endless hockey season, the two teams that painstakingly compiled the best records over the 80-game regular season will duel for the Stanley Cup. The Edmonton Oilers, with the best record, and Philadelphia, second best, meet Sunday night at Northlands Colieum to comence the four-of-seven-game series that will anoint a new champion.

title: A RELATIONSHIP LIKE NO OTHER
description: WALTZING WITH A DICTATOR The Marcoses and the Making of American Policy. By Raymond Bonner. Illustrated. 533 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.

title: Jordan's Quest for a Peace Parley
description: LEAD: Jordanian authorities want an internationally based Middle East peace conference, and want it soon. They are, in general, very realistic about Israel. They recognize that Israel has become a fact of life in the region and that it is not about to disappear. They very much want to reach some sort of accommodation and appreciate the limits within which Israeli politicians have to operate.

title: ROSENCRANTZ AND GUILDENSTERN ARE BACK
description: IT ALL BEGAN ON A BAD DAY BACK in 1963. Tom Stoppard - sometime journalist, occasional drama critic and aspiring playwright - had gone to the BBC in search of a commission for a drama series, only to be turned down. He was driving dolefully away from the television studios when his agent, who had accompanied him, came up with an idea designed to revitalize his creative morale. Why not a play portraying what Shakespeare's ''Hamlet'' had left tantalizingly incomplete? Why not a comedy, farce, burlesque, or something about the arrival in England of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, complete with the letter demanding their instant execution?

title: 11 SMALLER COMPANIES NAMED 'WINNERS'
description: THEY are growing faster than any other companies in the country. They employ more than half the work force and create about 40 million new jobs a year - nearly all the new employment. And they are responsible for half of the nation's sales.

title: Lisa Sherman Is Wed To Robert M. Cohen
description: Lisa B. Sherman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Burton S. Sherman of Valley Stream, L.I., was married last evening to Robert M. Cohen, the son of Faye Cohen of North Miami Beach, Fla., and Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Samuel Cohen. Rabbi Morris Pickholz performed the ceremony at the North Woodmere (L.I.) Jewish Center.

title: ISRAELI CONNECTIONS
description: THE LOBBY Jewish Political Power and American Foreign Policy. By Edward Tivnan. 304 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: A NEW-FASHIONED PLAYGROUND RAISING
description: LEAD: IT WAS a motley work crew: A Princeton University physics professor in white-oxford shirtsleeves sawed wood and dug holes, a Lutheran minister dispensed tools from a trailer, teachers in skirts heaved lumber onto dirt mounds and a dozen small children sanded boards and washed tires.

title: CANCER WORKERS BALK AT PLAN TO MOVE
description: A tentative decision by executives of the American Cancer Society last month to move the 74-year-old agency from New York has stirred dissatisfaction at the society's headquarters in Manhattan and touched its officials around the country.

title: TARIFFS SEMINAR
description: The World Trade Club of Westchester is sponsor ing a seminar on a new system of international tariffs that will become effective Jan. 1 and change duty rates on world markets.

title: DRIVER'S SHARP TURN LEADS INTO DESERT
description: Two years ago, Roger Mears was a driver in the Indy 500. But next weekend he won't be at Indianapolis, where his younger brother, Rick, starts the 500 from the outside of the front row.

title: Patient Gives His Heart in Exchange For Another
description: Before long, Clinton House may have the unusual pleasure of meeting the man to whom (quite literally) he gave his heart.

title: Planting Proceeds
description: JUST about everything can be planted in the garden this week except in northern cool regions where there still could be danger of late frost. Before planting out seedlings, started indoors, adjust them to the outside for the day, but take them in at night; put them outdoors overnight the day before they are transplanted to the garden. Tender vegetables such as tomatoes and eggplants may be set out, too, but if there is frost warning for the evening, be sure plants are protected overnight with a light covering such as sheeting or tents made of newspaper. Keep up with lawn mowing and set machines to cut high, two inches, to promote root growth for the long hot summer. Cut back early-flowering shrubs to keep them in shape for their spaces. Seed rows of corn, beans, beets, carrots and melons. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS LATE TULIPS

title: GIVING ISLAND'S HOMELESS A FACE IN FILM
description: LEAD: AFTER discovering that 16-year-old Linda was pregnant, her parents disowned her and when she could not afford an apartment, she resorted to living out of a car for several days. Eventually, she discovered a shelter for the homeless in Suffolk County.

title: Packing Too Much
description: THE way the Green Bay Packers' coach, Forrest Gregg, figures it, Donnie Humphrey's ideal playing weight would be 270 pounds, or about 25 pounds under the defensive lineman's listed weight last season. To help Humphrey trim down, the Packers sent him to a hospital nutrition program, but the 26-year-old player didn't cooperate, Gregg said, citing some weighty evidence. When Humphrey reported to an off-season workout program and stepped on the scales, Gregg said, the reading was ''somewhere around 335 pounds,'' or 40 pounds over his 1986 weight and 65 over the ideal. As a result of Humphrey's failure to shape up, Gregg cut him from the squad. Humphrey, a former Auburn player, started 16 games for the Packers as a rookie in 1984, then developed his weight problem the next year after spending a month in a cocaine rehabilitation program.

title: Nixon Denies He Backed Marcos's '72 Takeover
description: Richard M. Nixon has denied charges in a new book that he approved the decision by Ferdinand E. Marcos to impose martial law on the Philippines in 1972.

title: RESTORATION IS CALLED KEY TO PROTECTING LAND
description: ONE year ago this month, Sleepy Hollow Restorations, the Tarrytown-based historic site organization that owns four Westchester locations, named its first new president in 35 years, purchased Montgomery Place, a 443-acre estate on the Hudson River in Dutchess County for $3 million; and announced plans to play a more active role in the future of the entire Hudson Valley region.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Emerson $235,500 146 Lozier Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old contemporary; patio, family room, central A/C; taxes $2,881. Fair Lawn $185,000 13-39 Edwards Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34 year old Cape Cod; basement, 1-car garage, solarium; taxes $1,831. Lambertville $139,900 20 Lincoln Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 68-year-old ranch; family room with cathedral ceiling, deck, newly remodeled; taxes $1,479. Livingston $320,000 97 Laurel Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 26-year-old split-level; fireplace, den, wall-to-wall carpeting, 2-car garage; taxes $4,180. Millburn $243,000 76 Chestnut Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; fireplace, deck, den; taxes $2,926. Red Bank $129,900 47 Peters Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old town house; eat-in kitchen, front porch; taxes $1,609. OTHER AREAS Patchogue, L.I. $113,000 199 West Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 75-year-old Cape Cod; basement, wood stove, balcony, 2-car garage; taxes $1,600. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $385,000 38 Aspinwall Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, den, alarm system; taxes $5,535. Rocky Hill, Conn. $158,000 41 Pheasant Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 14-year-old split-level; walk to school, bar in rec room, 0.75 acre; taxes $2,077.

title:
GARDENING;
IN PRAISE OF THE MANY SPLENDORED ROSE
description: LEAD: AS you may know, the rose was recently declared our national flower. This was not a spur of the moment decision: the debate began back in the 1950's when Senator Everett Dirksen of Illinois, supported by David Burpee of the W.Atlee Burpee Seed Company, proposed the marigold for that honor. One might say that Mr.

title: Washington University
description: William G. Hyland, who served as national security adviser to Presidents Nixon, Ford and Carter, told graduates at his alma mater Friday that the Reagan Administration should not permit its foreign policy to reflect a trend toward isolationism and protectionism. ''Protectionism is the ally of isolationism, and isolationism is the Dracula of American foreign policy,'' Mr. Hyland, the editor of Foreign Affairs magazine, told 2,000 graduates of Washington University. He said President Reagan had been successful in restoring nationalism and public pride after the Iran hostage affair and should protect against a move away from aggressive foreign policy, despite suggestions that the public supports a more isolationist stance.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
THE CONSEQUENCE
description: LEAD: ''The truth?'' Dr. Joseph N. Hankin, president of Westchester Community College, said the other day. ''I told them to save it for someone else - it's more important for someone else. I've been saying that for years, but this year, they got me in a weak moment.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
MOCK TRIAL
description: LEAD: AFTER defeating 450 other teen-agers to win the state championship earlier this month, members of the Ossining High School Mock Trial Team will be participating in a national competition this week in Washington.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: AMERICAN HUMOR. Edited by Arthur Power Dudden. (Oxford University, $18.95.) There are many funny things in it, but ''American Humor'' is not a funny book. It is intermittently thought-provoking, and frequently frustrating, in part because the question it purports to ask - is there an American humor?

title: Perspectives: Offices in Queens; British Airways Lands in Jackson Heights
description: THE name Bulova has a secure place in the affections of northern Queens. The watch company built itself a home with Art Deco touches in Jackson Heights 35 years ago and manufactured fine watches there for years.

title: NEW FERRY AT CAMDEN IS STUDIED
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of new waterfront projects - including a $42 million aquarium here, planning for which is expected to begin this summer - a ferry may again ply the Delaware River between this city and Philadephia, carrying tourists, commuters and sightseers.

title: China Reports It Has Halted One Side of Huge Forest Fire
description: Firefighters have halted the eastward spread of a huge forest fire that has burned in northeastern China for 10 days and has killed 160 people, the official New Chine News Agency reported today.

title: Jazz
description: Eddie Daniels is coming into the Village Vanguard with a quartet on Tuesday in an unusual glow of encomiums. He was the No. 1 clarinetist in Down Beat's readers' poll last year, and he also gained a Grammy nomination as the best jazz instrumental soloist. His reviews have called him ''the most gifted and intensely beautiful clarinetist now recording'' and declare that he is ''bringing [ the clarinet ] to a new stage in its evolution.''

title: CAUGHT IN THE UNDERTOW
description: BEST INTENTIONS The Education and Killing of Edmund Perry. By Robert Sam Anson. 221 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Science, Technology And AIDS
description: Granted, the ''power and lability of human sexuality'' is great, but so is the very real fear of death. If AIDS is to have an impact on future generations, it will be seen in a change in sexual behavior rather than in a massive death toll. STEPHEN J. LOMPERIS New York City

title: INDY TRIALS: A FRIGHTENING TURN
description: THEY have been crashing into walls, and spinning, and fighting a steering wheel that refuses to turn to the left.

title: WHEN CATERERS GO ON VACATION
description: LIKE MANY PROFES-sional caterers, Chip Fisher doesn't stop entertaining during his weekends off. ''We usually have between six and a dozen people over for lunch or dinner at least once each weekend,'' said Mr. Fisher of his summer holidays at the house he and his wife rent near the beach in East Hampton, Long Island. ''And once a season, we pull out all the stops and have a big production, with 50 to 100 guests.''

title: Panel May Save A Boston Church
description: THE Boston Landmarks Commission has unanimously recommended landmark status for the interior of a 126-year-old church that was partly demolished in a renovation effort by the Jesuits who own it.

title: FREEZE AHEAD
description: OUT ON THE EASTERN TIP OF Long Island, where I live, this time of year brings a tidal wave of fruits and vegetables. It starts in May, with the first sweet peas and tender asparagus, rising to a swell in midsummer with string beans, spinach and multicolored peppers. By August, the countryside has been inundated with zucchini, tomatoes, corn and yellow summer squash.

title: LAST STRAW FOR ISRAEL'S ODD COUPLE
description: THE last vestiges of unity were squeezed out of Israel's national unity Government last week during a bitter Cabinet debate over whether or not to attend an international Middle East peace conference.

title: ALL IN A DAY'S CHORES
description: I will do spring cleaning by cleaning out closets and maybe throwing out junk. I have nine closets. I wonder which has the most memorabilia.

title: PREPARING FOR A WINNING CROSS-RUFF
description: A week ago, at 105 East 73rd Street, Manhattan was home to the world's most unusual bridge event: The Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs. It is the only annual international event, at a permanent location, which assembles players from both sides of the Atlantic and on this occasion four from the Far East.

title: DOOMED COWS GET FOREIGN HOMES
description: EIGHTY young cows from Connecticut are being sent abroad, rather than to an abattoir, as a gift from two Connecticut farmers to Heifer Project International.

title: DISPUTE ON TAXES IN TEXAS SEETHES
description: It looks like another long hot summer for Texas lawmakers who admit there is little chance they will be able to deal with the state's budget crisis before finishing their legislative session at the end of the month.

title: Miss Zukaukas Marries Lawyer
description: St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Long Branch, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Andrea Jo Zukaukas, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Laurence Zukaukas of Long Branch, to Mark Richmond Aikens, a son of Ellen K. Aikens of West Long Branch, N.J., and the late Judge Louis R. Aikins. Msgr. Paul F. Bradley performed the ceremony.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; How Norwalk Deals With Affordability
description: LAST January, Norwalk adopted a sweeping new zoning ordinance requiring developers to sell a percentage of all new condominium units at no more than $125,000. So far, six applications for such projects have been received at City Hall, while four lawsuits oppose the ordinance.

title: IN BRONX, EVERYONE KNOWS HOW TO SPEND THE CITY'S MONEY
description: The testimony had not even begun. City Councilman Michael DeMarco was explaining the rules for the public hearing in the Bronx on New York City's proposed $22.7 billion budget: The speaking time would be five minutes for elected officials and heads of agencies, two minutes for everyone else.

title: BUSH URGES HIGHER SPENDING TO FINANCE COLLEGE EDUCATION
description: Vice President Bush, while insisting that he was not breaking with President Reagan, said today that one of the ''highest priorities'' in the next decade should be helping families finance a college education.

title: PANTS SUITS: TAILORED AND ELEGANT STANDBYS
description: THE pants suit has been with us for a while, and shows little sign of going away. Why should it? While much attention is riveted on the ups and downs of skirts, the pants suit, either carefully tailored or in soft dressmaker styling, continues to provide a casual, down-to-earth elegance appropriate for a range of activities. This spring, a number of alluring combinations have shown up; one is a shell-pink jacket worn over bone-colored trousers, another is plaid pants and a solid-color jacket. Then, of course, there's the navy-blue suit, still tried and still true.

title: LET THE GUESTS DO THE COOKING
description: FOR PEOPLE WHO OFTEN WORK SIX days and 60 hours a week, entertaining can be more of a burden than a joy. Deborah Sussman and her husband, Paul Prejza, solved that problem by inviting eight of their friends to do the cooking for a spring Sunday lunch.

title: MIGHTEST ROCKET IN SOVIET SENT UP ON ITS FIRST TEST
description: The Soviet Union today announced the successful test launching of its most powerful rocket, one capable of putting a 100-ton space shuttle into orbit.

title: Panel Split Over Job Rights Ruling
description: For the first time in more than three years, conservatives lost their tight control of the United States Commission on Civil Rights last week. By a vote of 5 to 3, the panel decided not to issue a draft statement charging that the Supreme Court was ''wrong'' to uphold a California affirmative action plan.

title: JACKSON GETS NEW RESPECT IN OLD SOUTH
description: The night air was humid and heavy and the politics were rich. A butler served iced tea as reporters gathered on the white-columned veranda of the Louisiana Governor's Mansion, swatting bugs and awaiting the emergence of the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Gov. Edwin W. Edwards.

title: EUROPEANS SWITCH TRAINS
description: One era in European railroading is about to come to an end, and a new one is beginning. For 30 years the Continent has been crisscrossed by some of the best trains in the world, the T.E.E.'s. The initials stand for Trans Europ Express, and the lack of a final ''e'' on Europe was deliberate. That was the spelling used for the group of first-class, air-conditioned, extra-fare trains that connected the major cities of Western Europe.

title: JACKSON TOPS POLL (NOT COUNTING CUOMO)
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson now has more support than any other Democrat seeking his party's 1988 Presidential nomination, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. But when asked to rank a larger group of Democrats, including some who say they will not be candidates, Democratic primary voters said Governor Cuomo of New York was their top choice.

title: A PLEA FOR THE CHIMPS
description: LEAD: THE CHIMPANZEE IS MORE like us, genetically, than any other animal. It is because of similarities in physiology, in biochemistry, in the immune system, that medical science makes use of the living bodies of chimpanzees in its search for cures and vaccines for a variety of human diseases.

title: Ethnic Flavors
description: New York offers art, dance, danger, dirt, music, traffic and wildlife. It also offers falafel, calamari, sushi, cannoli, quiche, cheesecake, tempura, sausage, scungilli, yogurt on a stick, popcorn in a bucket, meatballs on a roll and all manner of things delicate and indelicate. To eat on the streets of New York this weekend is to understand better than ever how much New York remains a remarkable assemblage of ethnicities.

title: TRASH BARGE ENTERS NEW YORK HARBOR, HEADS FOR BROOKLYN
description: The garbage barge that nobody wants was towed into New York Harbor last night but was turned quickly around and anchored in Gravesend Bay off Brooklyn.

title: Miss Green Weds Franklin Everett, An Ad Executive
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday, Colleen Deborah Green, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Edward Green of Amston, Conn., and New York, was married to Franklin Charles Everett, a son of Charlotte Sonja Everett of Arosa, Switzerland, and San Diego, and the late William Greenough Everett. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Ward Williams and the Rev. Edward A. Rebmann. Alisa Schaeffer Reese was the matron of honor. Russell Hood Everett was best man for his brother.

title: PUPILS PIECE TOGETHER PAST AT LYNDHURST
description: LEAD: THE Dobbs Ferry school system and the Lyndhurst National Historic Site have become partners in developing an innovative museum education program for children.

title: Budapest Officially Dedicates A Mounument to Wallenberg
description: A monument to Raoul Wallenberg was officially dedicated Friday, nearly 40 years after an earlier statue was mysteriously removed on the eve of its dedication.

title: A PARK LACED WITH WATER RICH IN TROUT
description: Peruse the old-time photos of Adirondack sporting life and inevitably you come across this classic shot: the grizzled guide, his smooth-faced tweedy young client, and on the grass between them enough gaping speckled trout to keep a sushi chef busy for a month.

title: Residential Resales

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; PARK SLOPE
description: JAN HODENFIELD remembers six years ago when a town house in Park Slope could be bought for less than $200,000 and Seventh Avenue was mostly bodegas, cobblers and neighborhood bars. Today, brownstones cost $750,000 and a Benetton clothing store opened on the avenue in October.

title: IN A CATASTROPHE, WOULD WE BE READY?
description: CONNECTICUT has not experienced a catastrophe in recent memory. We've had terrible floods, blizzards, hurricanes and tornadoes. As tragic as the collapses of L'Ambiance Plaza apartment complex in Bridgeport and the Mianus River bridge in Greenwich were, they were not catastrophes as defined by widespread devastation and great loss of life.

title: HAYDN'S KEYBOARD MUSIC BLOOMS ANEW
description: MOZART AND BEETHOVEN found the piano a major merchandising tool in their struggle for audience recognition. For Haydn it was more a faithful companion - a trusted appliance for the daily business of making music. Haydn's last sonatas, and a few of the earlier ones, do seek a public forum, but for him, the instrument was principally his private conduit for ideas. Neatly dressed, he sat punctually at the keyboard every morning and improvised - hoping for inspiration and praying to God on his knees when it eluded him.

title: PUBLISHERS ADD FREE WEEKLIES
description: LEAD: SEVENTEEN years ago, Stan Henry and David Willmott were partners in a hand-delivery service for circulars and advertising material; recently the two, both of whom are now newspaper publishers, have become competitors.

title:
ART;
PHOTOGRAPHY, A NEWCOMER TO SHOW, TAKES PRIZES
description: LEAD: Although this is the first year that photography has been included in the Council for the Arts on the North Shore's annual juried exhibition at the Wunsch Arts Center in Glen Cove, that category has attracted some outstanding entries. In fact, three of the show's four top prizes, including the best-in-show award, were taken by photographs.

title: TRYING TO MAKE MONEY MAKING 'TEST-TUBE' BABIES
description: AMERICANS still spend more to prevent pregnancy than to pursue it, but that could soon change.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Minneapolis Loafing Costs Mayor $1,130
description: Mayor Don Fraser has fined himself a week's pay, taking responsibility for loafing by city sewer workers.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE COMPETITION WILL MOVE HERE;
WHY THE DOLLAR WON'T BAIL OUT INDUSTRY
description: LEAD: IN future years, we may look back on the current sharp fall in the dollar as a watershed event for American manufacturing companies. For the lower dollar, while providing some immediate relief for our manufacturers, will not end our competitiveness problems - as many economists now promise - but merely shift them to another field of battle.

title: CANDIDATES ARE WOOING HART BACKERS
description: New York supporters of Gary Hart are being wooed by other Presidential contenders but for the most part, they are staying on the sidelines at least for now.

title: FOR SISTERS, WRITING IS A TEAM EFFORT
description: LEAD: TEN years ago, Eve Potts, a medical writer who lives in Westport, was trying to help a friend who had lung cancer. ''I had a houseful of material written for the medical profession, but there was nothing available to tell the patient what was going on,'' Mrs. Potts recalled.

title: Reagan Rejects Duarte's Request
description: Approximately 10 percent of El Salvador's 5 million people are believed to be living illegally in the United States. The country's president, Jose Napoleon Duarte, wanted them to stay for a while.

title: Aquino Allies Win Senate Seats
description: In another reflection of her wide popularity, President Corazon C. Aquino did very well last week in voting for the Philippine Senate.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: LIGHTNING illuminated the Western sky, revealing, for the span of a warbler's heartbeat, the approaching line of clouds. Overhead, beyond the limits of any bird's wings or the ingenuity of man, the galaxies of the universe vied for space. Several thousand feet below, in aspiring replication, lay the cities and towns of New

title: THE HARD LIFE OF A TARANTULA
description: THE SPIDER By John Crompton. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: Nick Lyons Books. Paper, $8.95. THE SNAKE By John Crompton. Illustrated. 150 pp. New York: Nick Lyons Books. Paper, $8.95.

title: THE LUXURY OF CALLING A CAR TO THE DOOR
description: AFTER undergoing knee surgery this winter, Peter Baida, a hospital fund-raiser, hired a car service to take him to work for the month of February, rather than chance the icy Manhattan sidewalks. Taxis are not easily found during rush hour in Mr. Baida's neighborhood, but for a fee of $8, a sedan pulled up to his apartment building promptly each morning and deposited him several minutes later at his office entrance.

title: HUMANITY IS WASHED UP - TRUE OR FALSE?
description: EINSTEIN'S MONSTERS By Martin Amis. 149 pp. New York: Harmony Books. $12.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
ALONG THE NAVESINK IN SEA BRIGHT
description: LEAD: MANY shore restaurants are predictable. They are usually casual, and often have a nautical theme and a very limited menu. They are perfect for vacation dining, particularly when children are included.

title: ON THE APPALACHIAN TRAIL
description: A hiker can follow the Appalachian Trail for 2,000 miles, between Georgia and Maine, and the route is well known for its ''through hikers,'' the several hundred people who hike its full length each year. But as it passes through the heart of New England, the trail takes in 300 sometimes bucolic, sometimes breathtaking miles of Vermont and New Hampshire that can be appreciated by all levels of outdoor enthusiasts.

title: In Congress, Tactical Ploys Over 'Star Wars'
description: When the technological uncertainties of President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative were combined with the complexities of the budget process in Congress last week, it was hard to tell what was being shot down by whom.

title: Student Gets $27,000 For Help With Reading
description: School officials here agreed Friday to pay $27,000 for special schooling and legal expenses for a former dyslexic student who graduated from high school with honors, even though she could not read.

title: ONE MAN'S MOUSETRAPS
description: HIS FRIEND WAS SO SHORT THAT when she was seated at Washington's Kennedy Center her feet barely reached the floor. Could he, she asked, devise some sort of stool on which to rest her feet? One day while driving to work it came to him. You can't walk into a theater with a stool under your arm. But what about a book? What if an ordinary hard-back book, not much larger than a theater program, opened up to let two hinged metal flaps swing out and, suitably restrained, form the legs of a stool?

title: YANKEES SLIP, 10-8
description: In the Kingdome, these kinds of games are not unusual. There were five home runs, two lead changes and 25 hits, but it became the sort of evening the Yankees would sooner wipe from their memories. Their pitching failed in the seventh inning tonight, and Ken Phelps hit two home runs that led the Seattle Mariners to a 10-8 victory.

title: Alex Simons Married To John Edward Lange
description: The marriage of Alexandra Hope Simons, an associate at Sonnenblick-Goldman, a real-estate investment bank in Manhattan, and John Edward Lange, a legal consultant to the Manhattan law firm Rogers & Wells, took place yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Stephan E. Klingelhofer performed the ceremony. Jennifer S. Porter was her sister's matron of honor and Robert and Mark Lange were their brother's best men.

title: THE POIGNANCY OF 'FALLING AWAY'
description: My husband and I both look forward, with particular pleasure, to the Long Island section. We always save the Long Island Opinion Page and its facing page for last, savoring each wonderful article.

title: MAGUY MARIN'S VISIONS OF LOST CHILDHOOD
description: AMID THE THEATER PIECES recently created in the dance-theater genre, ''Cendrillon,'' by the French choreographer Maguy Marin, stands out for its richness of detail. When the Lyons Opera Ballet presented the American premiere of this magical doll's-eye view of ''Cinderella'' in January, its originality and psychological rightness came from this accumulated dramatic detail.

title: IT WAS A LOVELY YEAR FOR A BOOKSTORE
description: TO open a bookshop is one of the archetypal romances or escapes, like sailing around the world or living off the land. The peculiar appeal of a bookshop is that you don't have to know anything about books - your customers will educate you.

title: REVIVAL OF COPLAND'S 'PROMISED LAND' IN NEW HAVEN
description: THE Long Wharf Theater is using a revision by Aaron Copland of his sole full-length opera, ''The Promised Land.'' In addition to the revision, made after the original New York City Opera run in 1954, the New Haven production boasts a new orchestration for chamber ensemble, undertaken with the composer's blessing by the conductor Murry Sidlin.

title: Ms. Frisch to Wed John J. Monaghan
description: The engagement of Judith Ellen Frisch to John J. Monaghan has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Alan J. Frisch of New York, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Monaghan Jr. of Cumberland, R.I. An August wedding is planned. Ms. Frisch, an associate in the Boston office of the law firm LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae, graduated cum laude from Barnard College and the Boston University School of Law. Her father is a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst in private practice in New York. Her mother, known professionally as Dr. Brigette Gutman, is a clinical psychologist.

title: NEW BUSINESS BRINGS OLD CLASSMATES TOGETHER
description: LEAD: DAVE FIORE attended 15 high school reunions in one year, but none was his own.

title: NEW PROGRAM AIDS HOMELESS
description: LEAD: AN ambitious program to monitor Nassau County's services for the homeless, to establish an information network about private services and to try to find out the major causes of homelessness is now under way in the county.

title: SUGAR, MUGGSY AND LADY MAGIC IN THE BOONDOCKS
description: THIS is nobody's dream, summer basketball so deep in the woods that Daniel Boone could be the commissioner. At best it is a shelter in the storm for wanderers like Sugar and Lady Magic, and a hopeful young man named Muggsy.

title: COST? UNDER $100
description: WHEN THE COOK WANTS TO provide a bountiful table at minimal expense, expertise goes a long way. For those who find the idea of a dinner party for 20 daunting at any time, doing it on a shoestring becomes an even greater challenge. The trick is to shop carefully, taking advantage of seasonal foods, set the table stylishly and be prepared to spend more time than money.

title: Beirut Newspaper Says Gemayel Will Resign
description: A leading Beirut newspaper reported today that President Amin Gemayel, under pressure from his own Christian camp and with his Government threatened by the resignation of the Prime Minister, is expected to resign soon.

title: Diana Van Benschoten Wed to C. T. Locke 3d
description: The marriage of Diana Joy Van Benschoten, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Van Benschoten of New Canaan, Conn., to Charles T. Locke 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Locke Jr. of New Hartford, N.Y., took place yesterday in New Canaan. The Rev. Roland Jones performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Liam Whelan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MAY 17, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21 A proposed Middle East conference will be pursued by American officials even though they regard prospects as poor in view of the Israeli political deadlock over whether to support the idea. 1

title: RECRUITING NURSES IS DIFFICULT
description: LEAD: AT WARREN HAVEN, the county-run nursing home in the Warren County community of Oxford, 45 beds are empty and 45 people are waiting for them, but their admissions have been held up for more than a year. Until the home can fill eight nursing vacancies, it must operate below capacity to meet state staffing requirements.

title: Lynne Queenan Is Wed in Washington To Philip Henry Michael Beauregard
description: Carrie Lynne Queenan, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Thomas Queenan of Washington and of Jeffersonville, Vt., was married yesterday to Philip Henry Michael Beauregard, a son of Mrs. Dillon-Smyth Crocker of Washington and the late Henry George Beauregard. The Rev. James Maier officiated at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: ED BERGER had a 50th birthday not long ago, and he rearranged his priorities or, as he put it, had a ''mental reorganization and liberation.''

title: BAR GROUP OPPOSES COURT AMENDMENT
description: THE Suffolk County Bar Association has decided to oppose the constitutional amendment for court merger in New York State, one of the most significant changes in the judicial system since its inception and one endorsed by Governor Cuomo and most other bar associations, which see it as the means to simplify the court system and make it more efficient.

title: The Seclusions of Men-Only Clubs and Purdah
description: To the Editor:

title: On Videotape, Goetz Describes The Shootings
description: Prosecutors in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz last week presented what they said would be the most damaging evidence against him -Mr. Goetz's own videotaped statement about how and why he shot four youths in a Manhattan subway car on Dec. 22, 1984.

title: FOR MURRAY SCHISGAL, THE PLOTS THICKEN
description: ''I HAVE NO INTENTION OF EVER writing a play again,'' Murray Schisgal wrote in the introduction to his 1983 anthology, '' 'Luv' and Other Plays.'' But this Thursday, ''Road Show,'' Mr. Schisgal's newest play, opens at the Circle Repertory Company, and this fall more of his work will be seen in New York when his three new one-act plays premiere.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review of the New York City Ballet last Sunday misidentified the ballerina in ''Variations pour une porte et un soupir.'' She was Maria Calegari, not Darci Kistler.

title: MUSIC: HARMONIE ENSEMBLE
description: ON Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall, The Harmonie Ensemble offered an original-instrument performance of - believe it or not -Gershwin. Several of the composer's pieces have gone through a process not unlike what happened to certain Baroque works. ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' for instance, was written for piano and a small jazz orchestra, then expanded into the full-blown symphonic version known widely today; ''An American in Paris,'' went through a similar process. In the originals, the brass becomes more prominent, the strings more coloristic, and the result is jauntier and less suave.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
SHE DIDN'T TELL ON NORMAN
description: LEAD: RABBLE STARKEY By Lois Lowry. 192 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: HOW TOKYO RECOVERED THE FUMBLE
description: FAST FORWARD Hollywood, the Japanese, and the Onslaught of the VCR. By James Lardner. 344 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Fresno, Calif.;
L-a-k-e-f-r-o-n-t Spells Relief
description: LEAD: A PLANNED residential community built around a manmade lake is proving to be a hit in this hot, central California agricultural city.

title: SUSTAINING WILLIWEAR'S SPIRIT
description: One month ago today, Willi Smith, 39, who designed inventive low-priced sports clothes that became street classics, died of AIDS at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: JAZZ: WIDESPREAD BAND
description: PLAYING a one-night engagement last Monday at the Blue Note, the Widespread Jazz Orchestra showed that it has finally become the band it has been promising to be for the last decade.

title: A Dog And His Man
description: In his article ''Life With Trixie'' (About Men, April 19), Ben J. Stein has articulated what those of us who love our dogs have always known. The best therapists have four legs, wet noses and eyes that see nothing but us! BARBARA P. HOWELL Family Counselor Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

title: DANCE: GREGORY'S BEAUTY'
description: THERE are actors' actors and dancers' dancers. There ought, perhaps, to be a category of performances about performing. Cynthia Gregory offered a radiant, skillfully danced interpretation of the title role in ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' presented by American Ballet Theater on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. But it was Miss Gregory's rapport with the audience that made this the interesting evening that it was.

title: TAKING THE PERSONAL OUT OF PC
description: THE word ''personal'' is still very much a part of I.B.M.'s promotional campaign for its new line of microcomputers. But in a very real sense the machines are not personal computers at all, and this may well be the crux of their impact on the future of small computers.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GUNNAR MYRDAL AND BLACK-WHITE RELATIONS: The Use and Abuse of ''An American Dilemma,'' 1944-1969. By David W. Southern. (Louisiana State University, $35.) This is a revealing analysis of the political, intellectual and personal aspects of Gunnar Myrdal's influential 1944 study, ''An American Dilemma.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: UNDER THE DOG STAR. By Joseph Caldwell. (Viking, $16.95.) What should a 37-year-old woman living in a small upstate New York town do after her very respectable husband (a newspaperman) gets himself killed robbing a gas station?
