Grady Durant, former singing teacher and mother of three, packs up and heads for the old dairy farmhouse where she was raised by her grandparents.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Conshohocken, Pa.
description: HARD-HIT in the 1970's by the closing of steel mills and rubber factories, this blue-collar borough about 10 miles west of Philadelphia has suddenly found itself in the midst of a building boom traced to the development of interstate highways.

title:
GARDENING;
IN PRAISE OF THE MANY SPLENDORED ROSE
description: LEAD: AS you may know, the rose was recently declared our national flower. This was not a spur of the moment decision: the debate began back in the 1950's when Senator Everett Dirksen of Illinois, supported by David Burpee of the W.Atlee Burpee Seed Company, proposed the marigold for that honor. One might say that Mr.

title: KEEPING OUTDOOR FURNITURE IN SHAPE
description: OUTDOOR furniture of good quality is designed to withstand exposure to all kinds of weather, but pieces will last longer and look better if they are given regular preventive maintenance.

title: SERGEI AND THE WOLVES
description: SERGEI PROKOFIEV A Biography. By Harlow Robinson. Illustrated. 573 pp. New York: Viking. $29.95.

title: KNOTTY DONOVAN TRIAL WINDS DOWN
description: In a Bronx courthouse accustomed to violent-crime cases it is a rare event: an intricate fraud trial in which two key defendants, former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and State Senator Joseph L. Galiber, charge they are victims of political persecution.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
YELLOW-BILLED CUCKOO
description: LEAD: Coccyzus americanus Size: 11 to 13 inches.

title: Connecticut Weighs 15 Percent Rise in Spending
description: With a steadily rising surplus in state funds, Connecticut's General Assembly began approval this week of a $5.64 billion budget that will increase spending by a record 15 percent.

title: A FAST-FOOD CLOSING SADDENS BENSONHURST
description: It was just another fast-food store in a neighborhood with at least a dozen others.

title: Garden City
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOULD WE CARE WHO WROTE IT?
description: DOES IT MATTER THAT STRAVINSKY WAS A Russian? If that question strikes you as too obvious to deserve serious consideration, you probably haven't kept up with the hot debate being waged in scholarly circles over two seemingly irreconcilable methods of appraising music. The argument originally was joined over the narrow musicological question of whether ''The Rite of Spring'' is essentially a tonal or a nontonal work, but has taken on the fervor of a dialectical struggle between Greek philosophers over the nature of the Sublime. The dispute does, in fact, resurrect an ancient esthetic dilemma: whether a work of art is more profitably considered in the ideal, virtually as an anonymous phenomenon, or as a product inextricably intertwined with human experience and the social process.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: BLOOMS AND TROPHIES The New York Botanical Garden's annual orchid show has been extended from three to five days but it is still the shortest show on the schedule, running this year from Thursday through next Monday under the glass dome of the Conservatory. It is the only show in which the plants are supplied by hobbyists, commercial growers and orchid societies worldwide. More than 40 exhibitors have made the journey, carrying their delicate cargos of flowers. ''The purpose of the show is the competition,'' said Pares Mallis, publicist for the Botanical Garden. Judging is done the day before the opening.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MOST LIKELY TO SUCCEED: Six Women From Harvard and What Became of Them. By Fran Schumer. (Random House, $17.95.) In the first half of ''Most Likely to Succeed'' Fran, the smart and sassy narrator, tries to re-create the turmoil, frustrations and fierce expectations that she and five other 'Cliffies endured in the early 1970's at Harvard University, in a male-dominated environment that simply intensified their ambivalence about their desires and goals; later in the book we find out what happened to them. As Fran sails through her classes, she grapples with a severe eating disorder, falls in and out of love with David and primes her journalistic skills on the Harvard Crimson. Through her we learn about Daisy, an insecure but compulsive student from the Midwest who becomes a successful photographer, disillusioned by her failures with men; Paige, an aloof and unhappy attorney who never finds what she wants or finishes what she starts; Eleanor, a brilliant physician who turns down a Harvard-affiliated hospital for a practice in Kansas; Tess, a successful doctor in conflict about her roles as professional, wife and mother; and Felicity, a tennis star and superwoman who is finally done in by her own aspirations. The material and the premise are ripe for provocative commentary, but the book has limited sociological value because the characters are composites and there is little documentation. More important, the writing is often heavy-handed - Ms. Schumer, the co-author with Mary Cunningham of the best-selling ''Powerplay,'' says that at Harvard she was a better reporter than a writer. On this evidence, she hasn't changed much.

title: Kristie K. Bryant Married to Richard Kornhauser
description: Kristie Karen Bryant, an account executive with Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey Inc., a New York advertising agency, and Richard Wayne Kornhauser, a vice president of Ted Bates Advertising in New York, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Hattiesburg, Miss. The Rev. Joseph Rowland performed the ceremony.

title: SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVALS THROUGHOUT THE LAND
description: ALASKA BASICALLY BACH FESTIVAL Anchorage, June 9-19. Serge Luca is among the guest artists in a five-concert series that is part of an educational project. Michael Palme is music director. FAIRBANKS SUMMER ARTS FESTIVAL July 26-Aug. 8. This farthest north arts festival in North America has workshops as well as concerts on the University of Alaska-Fairbanks campus. Fred Buda and Myron Romanul are artistic directors of a greatly varied program. Among those present will be John Barcellona, Linda Rosenthal, Boston Jazz Pops Ensemble and Terry Gibbs. SITKA SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL June 5-26. Chamber-music concerts with Jerome Rosenthal, Doris Stevenson, Christiaan Bor, Edward Auer, Milton Thomas, Nathaniel Rosen, Jeffrey Solow, Nancy Allen and others. Paul Rosenthal is music director of a festival now 16 years old. ARIZONA FLAGSTAFF FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS July 11-Aug. 2. Orchestra and chamber-music concerts Thursday through Sunday evenings at Northern Arizona University. Irwin Hoffman conducts. Guest artists are Alex and Mark Peskanov, Toby and Gary Hoffman. GRAND CANYON CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL Sept. 4-19. A post-season event. Concerts with such artists as Abba Bogin, Michael Newman, Ani Kavafian, Toby Appel, Julius Levine and Kenneth Cooper. Robert Bonfiglio is festival director. New works by Arnold Black and Theodore W. Libbey Jr. Extra concerts for the Navajo and Hopi nations. SEDONA CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL June 20-28. Six concerts in various locations with the Blair Quartet, Pennsylvania Quintet, Janet Lynch, Edgar Meyer and Ian Ginsburg. Judith Ginsburg, a participating pianist, is artistic director. CALIFORNIA BEETHOVEN FESTIVAL San Francisco, June 19-July 2. The San Francisco Symphony will perform under the direction of Kurt Masur. Alfred Brendel will be heard in the five Beethoven piano concertos, and the Beaux Arts Trio will appear. CABRILLO FESTIVAL Santa Cruz, July 16-26. The festival, celebrating its 25th anniversary, stresses contemporary music. Concerts are in a tent in a hilltop meadow at the UC Santa Cruz. Dennis Russell Davies is music director. The composers-in-residence will be Isang Yun and Heinz Holliger. There will be a retrospective of Schumann's music, including his Mass (Op. 147). Among the participants will be Kaspar de Roo, New World String Quartet, Ursula Holliger and Akiko Tatsumi. CARMEL BACH FESTIVAL July 13-Aug. 2. Sandor Salgo conducts this substantial festival, observing its 50th year. Performances of the Mass in B minor, the Christmas Oratorio and Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' are scheduled. Also a program called ''Leipzig Revisited'' at the Carmel Mission Basilica. Among the performers: Peter Rejko, Beverly Morgan, Janina Fialkowska, Janice Taylor, Christiane Edinger and Patricia Schuman. CHAMBER MUSIC WEST San Francisco, June 1-18. The San Francisco Conservatory will give 9 concerts in a variety of settings, featuring leading musicians from the Bay Area, plus Felix Galimir, Jan DeGaetani, Gilbert Kalish and the Sequoia, Francisco and Sierra String Quartets. ''French Impressions'' is the theme. CONCORD PAVILION May-September. An outdoor amphitheater in the foothills of Mt. Diabolo. Concord hosts an ongoing series of concerts by jazz, pop, choral and country groups and such other visitors as the Vienna Philharmonic under Leonard Bernstein. HOLLYWOOD BOWL Los Angeles, July 7-Sept. 15. The Los Angeles Philharmonic will be conducted at its summer home by Andre Previn, its music director, plus Edo de Waart, Lukas Foss, Daniel Lewis, Andrew Litton, Henry Mancini, David Alan Miller, Hugh Wolff, Ivan Fischer, Gunther Herbig, Lawrence Foster, Leonard Slatkin, David Zinman, John Williams and Erich Kunzel. The large roster of famous visitors includes the Montreal Symphony under Charles Dutoit and Vienna Philharmonic under Leonard Bernstein. The range of 61 events extends to several programs with fireworks and a joint program by the Philharmonic and the Los Angeles Philharmonic Institute Orchestra. MIDSUMMER MOZART FESTIVAL San Francisco, July 8-Aug. 2. Orchestra concerts under the direction of George Cleve in San Francisco and environs. Alicia de Larrocha, Jeremy Menuhin and Jean-Philippe Collard are among the soloists. MONTEREY JAZZ FESTIVAL Sept. 18-20. This notable and oldest continuous jazz festival, now in its 30th year, takes place at the county fairgrounds. MUSIC ACADEMY OF THE WEST Santa Barbara, July 7-Aug. 22. Lawrence Leighton Smith is artistic director of the school, celebrating its 40th anniversary. It will observe this with a special concert featuring Marilyn Horne. The school has a distinguished list of faculty-performers: Jerome Lowenthal, Stephen Kates, Zvi Zeitlin, Stuart Canin, to name a few. ''La Boheme'' will be staged by Bodo Igesz. MUSIC FROM BEAR VALLEY Alpine County, July 25-Aug. 9. Orchestra concerts led by Carter Nice, a staging of ''Rigoletto'' and other events will be given in the festival tent. ''A Soldier's Tale'' is in the repertory, and the performers include Mason Williams, Charles Treger and Lloyd Bridges. OJAI FESTIVAL May 29-31. Lukas Foss is music director this year for this small but innovative festival. The composers involved besides Mr. Foss are Charles Wuorinen, Rand Steiger, David Del Tredici, Joan La Barbara, John Biggs and Daniel Kessner. The performers include Mr. Foss, Carol Wincenc, Ms. La Barbara and the Pacific Singers. PAUL MASSON SUMMER SERIES '87 Saratoga, June 4-Sept. 20. Classical music, jazz and Shakespeare utilize the services of Alicia de Larrocha, Cambridge Buskers, Paris Boys Choir, Mel Torme, Ramsey Lewis, Roberta Flack and others in an outdoor series at the winery. Sandor Salgo is music director, and the series is in its 30th season. REDLANDS BOWL SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL July 1-Aug. 2. Free concerts in a 64-year-old series. ''Anything Goes,'' opera, ballet and assorted events will be staged. SAN FRANCISCO OPERA June 24-July 5. This company will present the Houston Opera's production of ''Porgy and Bess'' as its summer offering. SAN LUIS OBISPO MOZART FESTIVAL Aug. 3-9. Concert sites vary in the county. Two programs include more than Mozart and feature such artists as Arnold and Victor Steinhardt, Paul O'Dette and the Classical Quartet. Philip Willy is the composer-in-residence. A week-long series of lectures and recitals will precede the festival. STERN GROVE FESTIVAL San Francisco, June 14-Aug. 23. Free Sunday afternoon concerts, with symphony orchestra, ballet, jazz, operatic, chamber and ethnic groups. The festival is in its 50th year. COLORADO ASPEN FESTIVAL June 26-Aug. 23. One or more concerts take place each day in this historic mining town in the Rockies. The orchestras and chamber groups mix seasoned and young professionals from the Aspen Music School. Soloists, some of them faculty members, are among the best. The conductors include Murry Sidlin, James DePreist, Lawrence Foster, Kenneth Jean, Christopher Keene, Stephen Mosko, John Nelson, Claudio Scimone, Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, Yoav Talmi and Paul Vermel, besides Jorge Mester, the music director. There will be nine composers-in-residence and seven visiting composers, the customary Fromm Week of New Music (Aug. 2-7), and a number of premieres. In the more than 130 performances the accent will be on Scandinavian music. Opera productions will include Copland's ''Tender Land'' in its new chamber-ensemble transcription; ''The Rake's Progress'' and ''La Cenerentola.'' CENTRAL CITY OPERA July 11-Aug. 11. ''Madama Butterfly,'' ''Don Pasquale'' and ''The Vagabond King,'' all in English, form the repertory for this veteran company's season. There are sidelights such as Henry Mollicone's cabaret opera ''The Face on the Barroom Floor'' staged in the Williams Stables. COLORADO MUSIC FESTIVAL Boulder, June 18-July 31. Concerts by the Festival and Chamber Orchestras and smaller ensembles are given in Chautauqua Park Auditorium. Giora Bernstein is music director. Among the guests will be Joseph Swensen, David Lively, Sidney Harth and the Dale Warland Singers. Robert Craft and Sixten Ehrling will be guest conductors. A special series will be devoted to ''Stravinsky - The Late Works.'' NATIONAL REPERTORY ORCHESTRA Keystone, June 14-Aug. 20. Formerly known as the Colorado Philharmonic, these young instrumentalists will give numerous concerts at the Keystone Resort, 68 miles west of Denver, either with its full complement of 85 or with smaller ensembles. MUSIC IN OURAY June 13-27. A historic community between Durango and Grand Junction is the site for concerts with Daniel Epstein and Elaine Comparone as artistic co-directors. Bert Lucarelli, Frank Bowen and the Raphael Trio will also be on hand. MUSIC IN THE MOUNTAINS Estes Park, June 28-Aug. 23. Concerts by the Rocky Ridge Music Center at the foot of Long's Peak by chamber, symphonic and choral ensembles, resident and visiting artists. CONNECTICUT MUSIC FROM ASTON MAGNA Hartford, July 12-26. The Massachusetts festival's concerts of 17th- and 18th-century music played on period instruments will be repeated at the Wadsworth Atheneum. CONNECTICUT EARLY MUSIC FESTIVAL Mystic, Noank and New London, June 12-28. John Solum and Igor Kipnis present nine concerts with the assistance of some of the finest practitioners of early music around: the organizers themselves, Julianne Baird, Marilyn Costello, William Parker among them. ''La Serva Padrona'' will be sung. CHARLES IVES CENTER FOR THE ARTS Danbury, July 4-Aug. 23. This outdoor center is on the Westside campus of Western Connecticut State University. The events embrace symphonic music, ballet, jazz, operetta and country music. Kenneth Fricker is artistic director. Guest conductors are Bruce Ferden, Jesse Levine and Marin Alsop. CONNECTICUT FESTIVAL OF AMERICAN MUSIC THEATER/87 Stamford, June 28-Aug. 2. Five free concerts by the National Chorale under Martin Josman. LEVITT PAVILION Westport, June 28-Aug. 22. Classical concerts with the Fairfield Chamber Orchestra, jazz, pop, etc. MUSIC MOUNTAIN Falls Village, June 13-Sept. 13. This nation's oldest chamber-music festival (58 years) is given by several string quartets, the Manhattan String Quartet being in residence, with major assisting artists. NORFOLK CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL June 26-Aug. 8. Associated with the Yale Summer School of Music, the festival offers in concert the Tokyo String Quartet, Fine Arts Quartet, New York Wind Quintet, New York Brass Quintet and Norfolk Chamber Orchestra. Concerts are given in the Ellen Battell Stoeckel Estate music shed. The historic Litchfield County Choral Union will sing Mendelssohn's ''Elijah.'' DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA KENNEDY CENTER June 24-27. Four concerts from the Mostly Mozart Festival in New York. On July 6 Mstislav Rostropovich will conduct the National Symphony in a concert version of ''Boris Godunov,'' with Ruggero Raimondi, Galina Vishnevskaya and Nicolai Gedda. CAPITOL WEST LAWN CONCERTS May 24, July 4 and Sept. 6. The National Symphony will play three concerts on the west lawn of the Capitol. LIBRARY OF CONGRESS SUMMER CHAMBER FESTIVAL June 9-23. Free concerts in the Coolidge Auditorium of the Library with artists from various countries playing distinctive programs. Additional performances at Candlelight Concerts, Columbia, Md., and Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. FLORIDA LONDON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA AND CHORUS Daytona Beach, Aug. 3-9. Concerts in Peabody Auditorium and Ocean Center with Yuri Aronovitch, Michael Tilson Thomas, John Dankworth and Richard Hickox, conductors. Soloists include Stephen Hough, Maurice Murphy, Cleo Laine and Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg. MUSIC FESTIVAL OF FLORIDA Sarasota, May 31-June 21. Chamber and symphony concerts involving members of an outstanding faculty. IDAHO ELKHORN MUSIC FESTIVAL AT SUN VALLEY Aug. 4-23. Fourteen free Sunset Concerts on the village mall by a 20-piece festival orchestra conducted by the festival's founder, Carl Eberl. Charles Bressler, Eric Stokes, the Boise Opera and American Festival Ballet are scheduled. FESTIVAL AT SANDPOINT July 19-Aug. 9. Gunther Schuller is artistic director of the festival, which is largely for training musicians but also offering 15 concerts on the shores of Lake Pend Oreille. The Spokane Symphony will be in residence. ILLINOIS GRANT PARK CONCERTS Chicago, June 27-Aug. 30. Several free concerts each week by the Grant Park Symphony in the James C. Petrillo Music Shell east of the Art Institute. The principal conductor will be Zdenek Macal. Others will be Frans Brueggen, James DePreist, Andrew Parrott, James Paul, Trevor Pinnock, Robert Shaw and Gerhardt Zimmermann. Soloists will include Barry Douglas, David Golub, Richard Goode, Lorin Hollander, Lee Luvisi, Joseph Swensen, Nathaniel Rosen, Richard Stoltzman, Sylvia McNair, Barbara Pearson, Benita Valente, Janice Taylor, David Kuebler, Glenn Siebert, Kurt Link and many others. The program highlights will be Beethoven's Ninth Symphony and the local premieres of works by Ellen Taafe Zwilich, Michael Torke, David Amram, Duke Ellington, Douglas Lilburn, Ronald LoPresti and Martinu. RAVINIA FESTIVAL Highland Park, June 26-Sept. 13. The Chicago Symphony moves to a Chicago suburb for the summer, with James Levine as the festival's music director, for one of the country's major summer series. Concert performances of ''Cosi fan tutte'' and ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' will have stellar casts as will the orchestra programs, along with eminent guest conductors. Schoenberg's ''Gurrelieder'' and Mahler's Eighth Symphony are sedededed. erere wi b bvivitsts bthe Academy of St. Martin in the Fields under Sir Neville Marriner, Boston Pops under John Williams, Ensemble of Period Instruments under Christopher Hogwood and London Symphony under Michael Tilson Thomas. INDIANA FIREFLY FESTIVAL South Bend, June 20-July 25. Concerts in the natural amphitheater of St. Patrick's County Park. Jazz, bluegrass, folk, Pops and classical music. Lionel Hampton and Newton Wayland will be among those present. IOWA DES MOINES METRO FESTIVAL OF OPERA Indianola, June 19-July 12. The 15th season will offer three new productions: ''La Boheme,'' ''The Flying Dutchman'' and Britten's ''Turn of the Screw.'' All in English, at the Blank Performing Arts Center. Among the singers are Kay Griffel, Stephen Oosting, David Cumberland, Susan Hinshaw, William Walker and David Rudat. MAINE ARCADY MUSIC FESTIVAL July 27-Sept. 3. Over 35 chamber orchestra concerts in Bangor, Mt. Desert Island and Dover-Foxcroft. Masanobu Ikemiya is artistic director. Performers include Anthony Newman, Pilar Vidal, Kenneth Cooper, Erick Friedman, Roberta Cooper, William Blossom, Eugenia Zukerman, Robert Dick, Robert Routch, Nancy Allen. BAR HARBOR FESTIVAL Acadia National Park, July 17-Aug. 16. Chamber-music concerts at the Bar Harbor Congregational Church, Maine Sea Coast Mission and Bar Harbor Club. Violinist Francis Fortier is the artistic director and conductor. String orchestra concerts, including one in the Blackwoods Campground Amphitheater. Composers-in- residence are James Park and Fred Tompkins. BAY CHAMBER CONCERTS Rockport, July 2-Aug. 27. Concerts in the local opera house on nine Thursday and five Friday nights. Appearing will be the resident Vermeer Quartet with various guests. BLUE HILL FESTIVAL July 5-Aug. 16. Chamber music on Sunday afternoons and Wednesday evenings by faculty members at Kneisel Hall, home of the well-known summer school. BOWDOIN COLLEGEBrunswick, June 27-Aug. 8. Lewis Kaplan is director of the summer music activities here, which includes a school. Chamber music by faculty and guest artists, including Szymon Goldberg, Nathaniel Rosen, Paul Neubauer, Ransom Wilson and Kurt Ollmann. Ellen Faull will produce ''Cosi fan tutte,'' with Glen Cortese as conductor. The annual Charles E. Gamper Festival of Contemporary Music will have as composers-in-residence George Crumb, Mr. Cortese, Robert Rodriguez and Elliott Schwartz. MT. DESERT FESTIVAL OF CHAMBER MUSIC Northeast Harbor, July 14-Aug. 11. Concerts at the Neighborhood House by the resident Composers String Quartet and guests, including Evelyne Crochet, Sahan Arzruni, Elizbeth Rich, Trudy Kane and Todd Crow. Matthew Raimondi is music director, and the festival is in its 24th season. PIERRE MONTEUX SCHOOL FOR CONDUCTORS AND ORCHESTRA PLAYERS Hancock, June 21-July 26. Sunday concerts under the direction of Charles Bruck plus chamber music on Wednesday evenings. SACO RIVER FESTIVAL Cornish, July 15-Aug. 18. Chamber music and recitals with the Atlanta Virtuosi, New England Piano Quartette, Frank Glazer, David Glazer, Cavani String Quartet and others. MARYLAND BALTIMORE SYMPHONY July 9-25. Music by Mozart and Beethoven will be played in six concerts at Joseph Meyerhoff Symphony Hall, conducted by its music director, David Zinman. They are accompanied by a Viennese ''Summerfest'' outside the hall. UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND PIANO FESTIVAL AND WILLIAM KAPELL COMPETITION College Park, July 9-18. Eugene Istomin is artistic director of this annual event, now in its 17th year. As usual there will be recitals by well-known pianists, Paul Badura-Skoda, John Browning, Shura Cherkassky, Youri Egorov, Nikita Magaloff and Ivan Moravec. The Buswell-Parnas-Luvisi Piano Trio will also perform. The competition finals on the 18th will be at Kennedy Center in Washington with the National Symphony under Stanislaw Skrowaczewski. Master classes. MASSACHUSETTS AMHERST FESTIVAL July 12-25. Faculty of the Dorothy Taubman School of Piano and guest artists give a series of evening recitals in the 11th season of this series. ASTON MAGNA Great Barrington, July 11-25. The festival's 15th anniversary season features three concerts at St. James' Church, devoted to 17th- and 18th-century music played on period instruments. The concerts are also given at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, Conn. (see listings). John Hsu is director of this notable series. BERKSHIRE CHORAL INSTITUTE Sheffield, July 11-Aug. 8. Rehearsals end in five public performances of major works: the Vivaldi Gloria and Mozart Requiem under Richard Westenburg, Brahms Requiem under John Oliver, Holst's ''Hymn of Jesus,'' Poulenc Gloria and Stravinsky Symphony of Psalms under Charles Dodsley Walker, two Handel Coronation Anthems and the Schubert Mass in E flat under Joseph Flummerfelt, and Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Iolanthe'' under Mr. Walker. BERKSHIRE FESTIVAL AT TANGLEWOOD Lenox, July 2-Aug. 30. The most famous of American summer music festivals is given by the Boston Symphony, Seiji Ozawa, music director, and this year the orchestra celebrates its 50th year there. The guest conductors will be Charles Dutoit, Edo de Waart, Gennady Rozhdestvensky, Hiroshi Wakasugi, Carl St. Clair, Andrew Davis, Leonard Slatkin, Leonard Bernstein and Michael Tilson Thomas. Sir Neville Marriner will lead his Academy of St. Martin in the Fields in one concert. Stellar soloists, of course. The Verdi Requiem will be sung, and Jessye Norman will be heard in Strauss songs and the final scene from ''Salome.'' Also offered are chamber-music concerts, recitals, pre-concert ''Preludes,'' a Boston Pops program (July 7) and the annual Festival of Contemporary Music (July 30-Aug. 6). BOSTON EARLY MUSIC FESTIVAL June 8-14. The American premiere of a late version of Haydn's ''The Seasons'' will be one feature of a distinguished series. Roger Norrington will conduct. Other performers include the Hilliard Ensemble, Amsterdam Loeki Stardust Quartet, John Gibbons, New York Baroque Dance Company and Ensemble Project Ars Nova. Concert locations are varied. CAPE & ISLANDS CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL Aug. 4-22. Concerts and open rehearsals in Hyannis, Wellfleet, Woods Hole and Falmouth. Samuel Sanders is artistic director. He will be joined in performance by the Colorado String Quartet, and by Yehuda Hanani, James Campbell, D'Anna Fortunato and Andres Diaz. Tison Street is composer-in-residence. CASTLE HILL FESTIVAL Ipswich, July 4-Aug. 9. A variety of indoor and outdoor weekend events on the grounds of a 165-acre estate. Of special interest will be a staging of ''La Vie Parisienne,'' a two-day folk festival, a Jazz Ball, and an Independence Day celebration with the Bourbon Street Jazz Band and Northern Lights. Chamber music and piano recitals. CHILMARK CHAMBER CONCERTS Martha's Vineyard, July 14-Aug. 18. Performers include the Zennor Trio from Vienna, a string ensemble with Eric Grossman as concertmaster, Delores Steven and Caroline Worthington (co-directors) and Glenn Dicterow. Four programs are given in Chilmark Community Center; two are repeated in Oak Bluffs Union Chapel. COMPOSERS CONFERENCE, CHAMBER MUSIC CENTER AND SINGERS WORKSHOP Wellesley, Aug. 2-16. Concerts by faculty members at Jewett Arts Center, Wellesley College. Andrew Imbrie and Martin Boykan are guest composers. GREAT WOODS CENTER FOR THE PERFORMING ARTS Mansfield, July 17-Aug. 9. An amphitheater seating 7,000 inside and 8,000 on the lawn outside, new last year, has become the summer home of the Pittsburgh Symphony. Michael Tilson Thomas is music advisor and principal conductor, and the series is billed as the US Trust Festival. Guest soloists include Andre Watts, Marilyn Horne, Cho-Liang Lin, Jean-Pierre Rampal, Emanuel Ax, Richard Stoltzman, Alicia de Larrocha, Itzhak Perlman and Lynn Harrell. ''La Boheme'' will be given a concert performance. May 22-Sept. 7 will bring a procession of popular entertainers. JACOB'S PILLOW Lee, July 7-Aug. 23. This dance center will present a free music series, July 7-11, with BoSho, Danny Mydleck, Sussan Deihim with Richard Horowitz and the Manhattan Marimba Quartet. The Kronos Quartet will play on Aug. 2, and a jazz series will last from July 5 to Aug. 23. MARBLEHEAD SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL July 19-Aug. 16. Five Sunday evening concerts will be given by the Cambridge Chamber Players and guest artists under the direction of Robert Stallman at the Unitarian Church. MOHAWK TRAIL CONCERTS Charlemont, July 17-Oct. 11. Friday night concerts, repeated on Saturday night, at the Federated Church. (Exception: final program is on Saturday and Sunday nights.) Artists include Masako Yanagita, Abba Bogin, William Bolcom, Joan Morris, Laszlo Varga, Meyer Kupferman, Henry Schuman, Eugene Drucker, Joanna Simon and Arnold Black, founder and artistic director. MONOMOY CHAMBER ENSEMBLE Aug. 26-29. Concerts at the Monomoy Theater in Chatham and First Congregational Church in Wellfleet. The ensemble includes Nancy Allen, Stanley Babin, Mimi Dye, Erick Friedman, Eleanor Lawrence (artistic director) and Eugene Moye. MUSIC THEATER GROUP Stockbridge, July 8-Aug. 23. The avant-garde Lenox Arts Center presents ''Poppie Nongena,'' based on the novel by Elsa Joubert and directed by Hilary Blecher, a story told through dance, song, words and ritual movement, and ''Small Town/Big Dreams,'' conceived and directed by Anne Bogart, written by Milcha Sanchez-Scott, with music directed and arranged by Jeff Halpern. The music is drawn from Massenet's ''Cendrillon.'' A one-night performance (Aug. 1) will be given of ''Beginnings: Native American Creation Stories,'' with Barbara Ensrud. NORTH SHORE MUSIC THEATER Beverly, June 21-Sept. 20. A long list of pop artists will appear, beginning with Roy Clark and Mel Tillis and ending with Rita Coolidge. PROVINCETOWN PLAYHOUSE MUSE SERIES Aug. 5-30. Seven concerts with the Boston Chamber Music Society, Tom Paxton, Odetta, the Brass Ring and others. At the Universalist Meeting House. ROCKPORT CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL June 4-28. Concerts at the Rockport Art Association by the Manhattan String Quartet, An die Musik, Jubal Trio, Trio dell' Arte, Bach Chamber Soloists, Annapolis Brass Quintet and others. David Alpher is composer-in-residence. Listed as a world premiere is Granados's Serenata for two violins and piano. SEVENARS FESTIVAL Worthington, July 12-Aug. 9. Founded and directed by the Schrade family pianists, the festival celebrates its 20th season. Concerts are performed in a historic landmark Academy. Guest artists include William Wolfram, Philip Thomson, Kathleen Bride, Miriam Shames and the Trio dell'Arte. SOUTH MOUNTAIN CONCERTS Pittsfield, Aug.-Oct. 4. Chamber music on weekend afternoons with the Ridge and Guarneri String Quartets, New York Chamber Soloists, Beaux Arts Trio and Lydia Artymiw. A 69-year-old venture. VINEYARD CONCERTS Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, July 23-Aug. 20. Events at the Old Whaling Church will feature Boston Chamber Music Society members and others. MICHIGAN ANN ARBOR SUMMER FESTIVAL June 20-July 18. On the University of Michigan campus the festival provides a little bit of everything: dance companies, mime, music, theater, art, with Marcel Marceau as resident artist. Performers are of international stature. INTERLOCHEN ARTS FESTIVAL Interlochen, June 21-Aug. 17. A variety of events by talented students at the National Music Camp, the oldest of its kind and observing its 60th year. Visiting professionals include Canadian Brass, Emerson and Mendelssohn String Quartets, Alexander Toradze, Marcel Marceau and Lorin Maazel. MATRIX:MIDLAND FESTIVAL Midland, May 26-June 13. A mixture of performance, educational and humanitarian events, including concerts by the Detroit Symphony with Ruth Laredo as soloist, Colorado Quartet, Marvin Hamlisch, Ben Vereen and others. MEADOW BROOK FESTIVAL Rochester, June 16-Sept. 15. The campus of Oakland University is the summer home of the Detroit Symphony. Conductors include Gunther Herbig, its music director, Jerzy Semkow, Leonard Slatkin, Jiri Belohlavek, Paavo Berglund and Stephen Stein. Major concert artists are the soloists. The London Symphony under Michael Tilson Thomas and the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields under Sir Neville Marriner will appear. MINNESOTA SOMMERFEST '87 Minneapolis, July 15-Aug. 8. The orchestra's eighth annual summer series will focus on ''Vienna and the Romantic Tradition.'' Leonard Slatkin, the festival's founder and artistic director, will lead most of the concerts, the guest conductors being Gerard Schwarz, Tsung Yeh, Jere Lantz and Jeffrey Siegel. Mr. Siegel will also be a soloist, along with Emanuel Ax, Elmar Oliveira and others. A concert version of ''Otello'' will end the series, with James McCracken, Justino Diaz and Elizabeth Holleque in leading roles. MISSOURI OPERA THEATER OF ST. LOUIS May 23-June 21. Now a major and enterprising company in its 12th year, it will present the American premiere of Stephen Oliver's ''Beauty and the Beast'' plus ''Carmen,'' Handel's ''Alcina'' and Rossini's ''Cinderella.'' The first will be accompanied by an octet, the rest by members of the St. Louis Symphony. All are sung in English. Emily Golden, Peter Puzzo, Juliana Gondek, Stella Zambalis, Victoria Livengood and John Brandstetter are a few of the singers. The operas are performed in the Loretto-Hilton Theater of Webster College. John Nelson, the music director, Joseph Rescigno, Hal France and Richard Buckley are the conductors. CITICORP SUMMERFEST '87 St. Louis, May 29-June 30. The St. Louis Symphony, playing in Powell Hall, will feature the music of the Bach family in eight programs under the artistic direction of conductor Raymond Leppard. One concert each will be led by Jere Lantz and Tsung Yeh. The large number of concertos listed will have as soloists members of the orchestra, Daniel Heifetz, Ransom Wilson, Layton James and others. New Hampshire HOPKINS CENTER Hanover,June 17-Aug. 26. This center at Dartmouth College will house assorted concerts, ranging from the Preservation Hall Jazz Band to the Carnegie Chamber Players, with recitals along the way by Andres Diaz and Pamela Gore. The New England Summer Organ Festival will be held on the campus Aug. 2-5. MONADNOCK MUSIC Jaffrey and adjacent towns, July 12-Aug. 29. The churches and meeting houses in the Monadnock area host many concerts, some of them free, under the general direction of James Bolle. There will be chamber music in the Jaffrey Center Meeting House and two orchestral concerts and two concert operas in the Peterborough Town House. NEW HAMPSHIRE MUSIC FESTIVAL Center Harbor, July 9-Aug. 15. A 35th anniversary for these orchestra and chamber concerts in Gilford, Lincoln, Plymouth and neighboring towns. Thomas Nee, music director; Cecil Lytle, soloist in the world premiere of William Rice's Piano Concerto; Kathleen Arecchi, soprano, and Jere Lantz, guest conductor, have been announced. The Second Annual NHMF Composers Conference (Aug. 4-7) will be host to Steve Reich, Mr. Rice, Elliott Schwartz, Marga Richter and Gerald Gabel. NORTH COUNTRY CHAMBER PLAYERS Franconia, July 10-Aug. 1. The ensemble is made up of 13 first-chair musicians from various orchestras. Concerts are on Friday evenings in Sugar Hill Meeting House and Saturday evenings at the Governor Adams Lodge, Loon Mountain in Lincoln. WATERVILLE VALLEY FESTIVAL OF THE ARTS July 11-27. At this ski resort the concerts range from jazz and blue grass to classical music, involving among many others the Paul Winter Consort, Tom Rush, Chet Atkins. NEW JERSEY GARDEN STATE ARTS CENTER Telegraph Hill Park on the Garden State Parkway, June-September. All kinds of events go on at this outdoor amphitheater, including ethnic festivals and appearances by the New York Philharmonic, Boston Pops Orchestra and New Jersey Symphony. In one of the latter's concerts Beethoven's Triple Concerto will have Itzhak Perlman, Yo-Yo Ma and Dudley Moore as soloists; in another it will be joined by the Westminster Choir in the Verdi Requiem, Robert Shaw conducting. JUNE OPERA FESTIVAL Lawrenceville, June 19-27. Michael J. Pratt, music director, conducts Strauss's ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' and Rossini's ''Cinderella'' in English translations in Lawrenceville School's intimate Kirby Arts Center. An extra concert will include Babbitt's ''Philomel,'' Maxwell Davies's ''Eight Songs for a Mad King'' and Haydn's ''Arianna a Naxos.'' Members of the New Jersey Symphony are in the pit. NEW JERSEY SYMPHONY May 21-Aug. 23. On Thursday, the orchestra will take part in the Hollybush Festival at Glassboro State College with a program that includes the world premiere of Eleanor Cory's ''Tapestry'' and Alexander Tchaikovsky's Ballet Suite ''The Battleship Potemkin'' and a solo appearance by Ilya Grubert, winner of the 1978 Tchaikovsky Competition, in Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto. Hugh Wolff, music director of the orchestra, will conduct. The orchestra will also be heard at Garden State, with the June Opera and in Pops concerts around the state. For these last it has its own mobile soundstage. RUTGERS SUMMERFEST New Brunswick, June 16-Aug. 9. A new venture, directed by Ilana Vered and sponsored by the Mason Gross School of the Arts, it will offer 58 performances in 55 days. Cooperating with Miss Vered are John Bettenbender, dean of the school, and James Scott, music chairman. On the musical side there will be visits by the Aston Magna Festival, Metropolitan Opera, Jupiter Symphony, Orchestra of St. Luke's, Tokyo String Quartet, other major chamber ensembles and recitalists. A Piano Institute will be held July 13-31. Three plays will be presented by the Levin Theater Company and dance performances by the Princeton Ballet and Don Redlich Company. WATERLOO VILLAGE FESTIVAL June 19-July 26. A varied series of performances and exhibitions are presented in this restored Revolution-era village now a National Landmark. Gerard Schwarz, spelled twice by Jahja Ling and Yoav Talmi, conducts the festival orchestra on Saturday nights. Soloists include Dylana Jenson, Janos Starker, Leonard Pennario, Ilya Grubert, Claudio Arrau and Bella Davidovich. A pair of these concerts will be repeated at Richardson Hall, Princeton University, where there will be chamber-music concerts on Friday nights by faculty artists from the Waterloo School of Music. Sunday afternoons at the Village will be occupied by band, young people's and sampler concerts, for some of which Sol Greitzer is the conductor. Samuel Lipman is artistic director. NEW MEXICO MUSIC FROM ANGEL FIRE Aug. 12-Sept. 1. Ida Kavafian is music/artistic director of this concert series, which ranges through several cities and towns. It boasts a distinguished list of chamber musicians: David Jolley, David Shifrin, Warren Lash, Fred Sherry, Walter Trampler, Andre-Michel Schub, Joseph Villa, Toby Appel, etc. A jazz quartet, Free Flight, is in residence. SANTA FE CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL July 12-Aug. 24. Pianist Alicia Schachter is artistic director of this thriving festival, now in its 15th season. Tobias Picker will be composer-in-residence and the many performers include Carter Brey, James Buswell, Ani Kavafian, Jeffrey Swann, Young Uck Kim, Ursula Oppens, Nathaniel Rosen, Joseph Swensen, the Mendelssohn String Quartet and Astor Piazzolla and his New Tango quintet. The programs will spotlight works by Beethoven and French composers. Concerts are in the historic St. Francis Auditorium at the Museum of Fine Arts. SANTA FE DESERT CHORALE June 19-Aug. 11. A professional chorus under the direction of Lawrence Bandfield, it is now in its fifth season. It will sing four different programs in a series of 20 concerts in Santa Fe and Albuquerque. SANTA FE OPERA July 1-Aug. 29. This summertime mecca for opera lovers will offer five works: new productions of ''Madama Butterfly,'' Handel's ''Ariodante,'' Strauss's ''Die schweigsame Frau'' and Shostakovich's ''The Nose,'' sung in English, and a revival of ''Le Nozze di Figaro.'' The singers will include Maria Spacagna, Roberta Alexander, Kathryn Gamberoni, Marcel Vanaud, Tatiana Troyanos, Benita Valente, Alan Titus, Erie Mills and Marius Rintzler. John Crosby, founder and general director, will conduct, as will George Manahan, Edo de Waart and Nicholas McGegan. TAOS MUSIC FESTIVAL June 19-July 25. Chilton Anderson directs the Taos School of Music, of which the festival is a part. Concerts are by resident artists Robert McDonald and the American String Quartet, with guest artists Michael Tree and Kay Griffel. NEW YORK ADIRONDACK FESTIVAL OF AMERICAN MUSIC Saranac Lake, June 28-Aug. 1. Gregg Smith is artistic director of a concert series featuring Mr. Smith's professional chorus, the Adirondack Chamber Orchestra, Ensemble Josquin Des prez from France and other artists. Besides a full range of American music, the French-American connection will be emphasized. ADIRONDACK LAKES CENTER FOR THE ARTS Blue Mountain Lake, June 6-Sept. 4. All kinds of music, from classical to bluegrass, jazz and folk. ARTPARK Lewiston, June 23-Sept. 13. ''Siegfried,'' the third opera in Wagner's ''Ring,'' will be staged in an ongoing project devoted to the cycle (it will be done in its entirety in 1989). Also staged will be ''Die Fledermaus,'' ''La Fanciulla del West,'' ''Annie Get Your Gun'' and ''My Fair Lady.'' Also performances by the Paul Taylor Dance Company, National Ballet of Canada, Pilobolus and American Ballroom Theater's Sheer Romance. There will be a marathon concert of music by Aaron Copland, a salute to Count Basie's music and appearances by Ella Fitzgerald, Mel Torme, Arlo Guthrie, Roberta Flack, Robert Klein and many others. Christopher Keene is president and music director. ASTON MAGNA AT BARD COLLEGE Annandale-on-Hudson, July 10-24. Performances of 17th- and 18th-century music on period instruments, repeating the Aston Magna Festival programs at Great Barrington, Mass. BACH ARIA FESTIVAL AND INSTITUTE Stony Brook, June 13-28. The Bach Aria Group with assisting singers and instrumentalists will perform choral music, concertos, solo and chamber works at the Fine Arts Center. Additional concerts at the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts, Roslyn. Open master classes, daily rehearsals. Samuel Baron is the music director. BARGE MUSIC Brooklyn, all summer long. Chamber music on a barge Thursday nights and Sunday afternoons. BAROQUE 25 Greenfield Center, July 9-Aug. 2. Usually known as the Festival of Baroque Music, it celebrates its 25th anniversary with a name change. Robert Conant, harpsichordist, is founder and music director of the series, which also is heard in Saratoga Springs. BRIDGEHAMPTON CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL Aug. 8-16. A four-year-old series, which will feature weekend concerts in the Presbyterian Church, with Ani and Ida Kavafian, Marya Martin, Fred Sherry, Kenneth Cooper and others. BUSCH BLUE GRASS FESTIVAL Malone, June 27. Six hours of music at the Ballard Mill Center for the Arts on a site overlooking the Salmon River. CARAMOOR MUSIC FESTIVAL Katonah, June 27-Aug. 23. The Spanish Court and outdoor Venetian Theater on a former private estate form splendid settings for the exceptional programs of this 42-year-old festival. John Nelson, music director, Michael Feldman, Julius Rudel and Raymond Leppard will lead concerts by the festival orchestra, and there will be a number of eminent chamber-music ensembles and soloists taking part in these and other programs. The members of the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble form the Caramoor artists-in-residence. Tours of the house and grounds, and picnicking facilities are offered. CELEBRATE BROOKLYN July 3-Sept. 6. An extensive free performing-arts festival featuring dance, music and theater at the Prospect Park Bandshell. Jazz groups will open the series, with the Brooklyn Philharmonic taking over on July 10. Dance programs begin on July 17. CHAUTAUQUA INSTITUTION June 27-Aug. 30. Orchestra concerts with Joseph Silverstein as the major conductor and soloists John Browning, Aaron Rosand, Grant Johannesen, Claude Frank, Jaime Laredo and Lorin Hollander. The operas and one musical comedy to be staged are based on Shakespeare: Gounod's ''Romeo and Juliet''; Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream''; ''Kiss Me Kate,'' and ''Falstaff.'' Also theater, dance, lectures and a siege of chamber music (July 1-6) by the Audubon String Quartet will take place at this long-standing and highly active institution. CLEARWATER HUDSON RIVER REVIVAL Croton-on-Hudson, June 20-21. Over 100 performers are promised, including Richie Havens, New York Choral Society, Georgia Sea Island Singers, Bonnie Raitt and the Harlem Blues & Jazz Band. GLIMMERGLASS OPERA THEATER Cooperstown, June 28-Sept. 1. Moving into its new home, the specially designed $5-million Busch Opera Theater, the company will present ''Eugene Onegin,'' ''The Pirates of Penzance'' and Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream.'' There will be a gala opening concert on June 27 featuring Frederica von Stade, Alan Titus and some singers who have performed with the company in the past. GOLDMAN MEMORIAL BAND New York, June 25-Aug. 2. These concerts, now in their 70th season, are a great New York tradition. They are given free on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Sunday nights in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center, and on Saturday nights at Brooklyn's Seaside Park. Ainslee Cox is the conductor. HUDSON VALLEY CHAMBER MUSIC CIRCLE Annandale-on-Hudson, June 6-27. Four Saturday night concerts at the Chapel of the Holy Innocents, Bard College, with Todd Crow, Gary Schocker, the Emerson String Quartet, Ida Kavafian, Steven Tenenbom, Andre-Michel Schub and Peter Wilsey. JULIUS GROSSMAN ORCHESTRA New York, July 6-31. Free concerts in various boroughs. JVC JAZZ FESTIVAL New York, June 19-28.This continuation of the old Newport Jazz Festival operates under the direction of its founder, George Wein, in a number of the city's major auditoriums as well as on the Hudson River Dayline excursion boat and various out-of-town sites. The performers make up a veritable who's who in jazz. LAKE GEORGE OPERA FESTIVAL Glens Falls, July 10-Aug. 17. The veteran company is giving ''Rigoletto,'' ''The Mikado,'' ''The Elixir of Love'' and the world premiere of ''Hazel Kirke.'' This last has music by Mark Houston and is based on Francis Cullinan's adaptation of an 1879 melodrama by Steele MacKaye. All operas are sung in English at the Queensbury Festival Auditorium. There will be opera programs aboard Lake George cruise ships, and special programs by its apprentice artists. LAKE PLACID CENTER FOR THE ARTS July 10-Aug. 23. Concerts by a variety of ensembles, jazz, ballet, Baroque, etc., in addition to those by the Sinfonietta. LAKE PLACID SINFONIETTA July 4-Aug. 16. Performances at the Center for the Arts on six Sunday nights and a number of free park concerts and special events. David Gilbert is the conductor. LIGHT OPERA OF MANHATTAN New York, June 10 and all summer. The company will open with Cohan's ''Give My Regards to Broadway'' at Playhouse 91 and then go on to other works. LINCOLN CENTER OUT OF DOORS New York, Aug. 4-30. Free performances on the plaza by all kinds of groups. LONG ISLAND MOZART FESTIVAL Oyster Bay, May 23-25. The Sea Cliff Chamber Players continue a series begun last year at the Planting Fields Arboretum Hay Barn. Soloists include Carol Wincenc, Charles Neidich, Paul Coletti, Karin Beardsley and Julie Holtzman. Herbert Sucoff is music director. MAPLEWOOD MUSIC FESTIVAL Elizabethtown, Lake Placid, and adjacent towns, July 12-Aug. 30. Eleven concerts of Baroque and Classical chamber music performed on period instruments. Jorie Garrigue is director. MAVERICK SUNDAY CONCERTS Woodstock, July 5-Sept. 6. Sunday afternoon concerts in an unusual woodland structure, perfect for chamber music. The series, now in its 72d year, will include the Colorado, Chester, Composers, Alexander and Tokyo String Quartets, the Dorian Wind Quintet, George Walker, Jaime Laredo, Sharon Robinson and others. METROPOLITAN OPERA IN THE PARKS June 16-July 3. Concert versions of ''Tosca'' and ''La Boheme'' will be given free in parks in the Metropolitan area and in three New Jersey sites: Waterloo, Liberty State Park in Jersey City and Rutgers University in New Brunswick. MILLER GENUINE DRAFT CONCERTS AT JONES BEACH Jones Beach State Park, Wantagh, June 13-Sept. 7. Among the performers will be Diana Ross, Whitney Houston, Tina Turner, Chicago, the Kinks and Anita Baker. MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL New York, July 7-Aug. 22. Concerts in Avery Fisher Hall, ranging from recitals and chamber music to choral works and orchestral programs. Gerard Schwarz is music director and principal conductor of the festival orchestra. Some highlights: concert versions of Mozart's ''Il Re Pastore'' and Handel's ''Acis and Galatea,'' Bach's B minor Mass led by Helmuth Rilling, a visit by the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields led by Sir Neville Marriner, an all-Bach harpsichord-concerto program including the one for four harpsichords and a gala opening program presented twice with stellar soloists. The festival is one of the adornments of New York's summer season. MUSIC IN THE MOUNTAINS New Paltz, May 16-Sept. 26. Concerts that stress American music, primarily contemporary plus a tribute (Aug. 15) to the composer Vittorio Rieti. Gundaris Pone is the music director and conductor of the Festival Orchestra. Appearances will be made by Steven Mayer, Richie Havens and the Hudson Valley Wind Quintet. Concerts are held in McKenna Theater on the SUNY campus. NATIONAL CHORALE SUMMER FESTIVAL/87 New York, June 27-Aug. 1.Martin Josman will lead his group in 15 free programs devoted to American theater music, from Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center to Kensico Plaza Park in Valhalla and other sites in the metropolitan area. NAUMBURG ORCHESTRA New York, July 4 and Aug. 1. Free outdoor concerts conducted by Jens Nygaard in Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center, with Dickran Atamian, Lisa Lancaster and David Kim as soloists. NEW YORK CITY OPERA Beginning July 7. The company's successful extension into the summer months will open with a week devoted to ''The Student Prince,'' followed by a mixed opera repertory in which new productions of the double bill of ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci'' and ''The Magic Flute'' will be premiered. A new production of ''The Desert Song'' will begin a two-week run on Aug. 26. Before the end of the season on Nov. 15 there will be one more new staging, a double bill of Mozart's ''L'Oca del Cairo'' and Knussen's ''Where the Wild Things Are.'' NEW YORK GRAND OPERA New York, July 9, 16, 23, 30. Vincent La Selva's company will stage five operas at the band shell on the Central Park Mall in this order: a double bill of ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci,'' ''La Boheme,'' ''Madama Butterfly'' and Verdi's ''Il Corsaro'' in its New York stage premiere. NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC June 4-July 20. The orchestra will present three Gershwin-Ellington programs, June 4, 5, 6, led by James dePreist, with Dexter Gordon and Leon Bates as soloists, and a Carter-Bruckner program, June 9, led by Zubin Mehta during the annual American Symphony Orchestra League conference and open to the public. The annual free park concerts in the metropolitan area will last from June 30 to July 20. The conductors will be Raymond Leppard, John Nelson and Mr. Mehta. The soloists will be three first-desk men: Philip Myers, horn; Glenn Dicterow, violin, and Paul Neubauer, viola. OLD FORGE MUSIC FESTIVAL July 8-Aug. 24.Assorted concerts will be part of this almost daily series, which includes films, lectures. exhibitions, etc. PEPSICO SUMMERFARE '86 Purchase, July 10-Aug. 2. This adventurous festival on the grounds of the State University, under the artistic leadership of Christopher Hunt, will give over 80 performances, many of them dealing with the legend of Don Juan. The director-conductor team of Peter Sellars and Craig Smith will stage ''Don Giovanni,'' with Kurt Ollmann in the title role, and their version of ''Cosi fan tutte'' will be revived. A musical from Catalonia, ''El Tango de Don Juan'' by Quim Monzo and Jerome Savary, will be imported, as will a Mozart parody, ''Donna Giovanni'' with the Companias Divas of Mexico City. The Kronos Quartet will present a program and a new theatrical presentation, and there will be a collaborative work about Don Juan by performance-artist Matthew Maguire and Creation Productions, In addition members of Sweden's Royal Dramatic Theater will be directed by Yuri Lyubimov in''A Feast in the Plague-Time,'' his adaptation of Pushkin stories. ''Mori el Merma,'' a collaboration of Joan Miro and the Catalan street-theater company La Claca, will be presented. Plays from France, Italy and America are scheduled. Several dance companies, including the Frankfurt Ballet and Joffrey Ballet, are also promised. QUARTET PROGRAM Troy, June 27-Aug. 15. Educational and chamber-music programs are given at the Emma Willard School in this 18-year-old series under the direction of Charles Castleman. RIVERSIDE PARK SUMMER MUSIC SERIES New York, July 12-Aug. 16. Mark Morganelli, executive director of Jazz Forum Arts, announces the third season of free Sunday afternoon concerts of jazz and ethnic music at the Rotunda at 79th Street in Riverside Park. ROXBURY CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVALJuly 6-Aug. 9. Six musicians plus guest guitarist David Burgess are in residence and will perform in various historic sites in Delaware County under the sponsorship of the Roxbury Area Group. SARATOGA PERFORMING ARTS CENTER Saratoga Springs, June 17-Sept. 5. The New York City Opera will present ''Tosca'' and ''La Boheme'' at the beginning of the season, June 17-21. The New York City Ballet will be in residence, as usual, July 7-25, to be followed, also as usual, by the Philadelphia Orchestra, July 29-Aug. 15. Dennis Russell Davies is principal conductor and program director of classical music for the orchestra's series, which will also be led by the Philadelphians' music director, Riccardo Muti, Robert Irving, William Smith and Victor Borge. Several works by William Bolcom, composer-in-residence, will be featured. Soloists include Alicia de Larrocha, Itzhak Perlman, Alec Chien, Elma Oliveira, Yo-Yo Ma, Andre Watts, Alexander Toradze and Emanuel Ax. Also chamber music, other events including dance programs at the Little Theater and throughout the season concerts by leading pop artists and groups. SCHROON LAKE FESTIVALJuly 12-Aug. 23. Four varied concerts in the Boathouse Theater. SIXTH ANNUAL SUMMER CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVALBrookville, July 27-Aug. 14. The Pierrot Consort faculty ensemble-in-residence at C.W.Post offers concerts by its members and participants in their educational project at this Long Island University campus. A chamber orchestra is under guest conductor Charles Barker. SPENCERTOWN CHAMBER MUSIC CONCERTS May 30-Sept. 5. Concerts are held in Spencertown Academy, a historic Greek Revival structure. Pianist Christian Steiner is artistic director. Performers include Nathaniel Rosen, McDermott Piano Trio, Ruth Laredo and others. SUMMER AT SNUG HARBORStaten Island, June 20-Aug. 15. A mix of musical events at a landmark site. SUMMER EVENINGS AT SARAH LAWRENCE Bronxville, June 11-28. Eight concerts in Reisinger Hall by such musicians as the Laurentian and Emerson String Quartets, Borodin Trio, Sarah Lawrence Wind Quintet, Jean Wentworth, New York Consort of Viols Courante, Stanley Lock, Michjael Lewin, Paul Doktor and a Festival Orchestra conducted by Kenneth Wentworth. SUMMER OF MUSIC ON THE HUDSONTarrytown, July 4-Aug. 8. At Lyndhurst, a National Historic Trust Property, Saturday night concerts feature the Festival Symphony Orchestra under Stephen Simon's direction. SUMMERPOCanandaigua, June 27-Aug. 1. A new name for the Finger Lakes Music Festival featuring the Rochester Philharmonic. It will begin with two days of Newport Jazz, followed by 10 concerts of a Pop nature, with conductors such as Mitch Miller and Erich Kunzel, and then four more seriously oriented programs. Mark Elder, the orchestra's music director-designate, will open the last series. SUMMERSTAGENew York, June 19-Sept. 13. At the Central Park Bandshell the Central Park Conservancy will present 41 events, of which 28 are music. The New York Grand Opera productions are listed elsewhere. Other kinds of concerts are ethnic, jazz, folk and avant-garde. TICONDEROGA FESTIVALJuly 12-Aug. 9. A mixed bag of entertainment in a tent on the village green. The Metropolitan Brass Quintet, Vermont Jazz Ensemble and Green Grass Cloggers are sample groups. WASHINGTON SQUARE FESTIVALNew York, July 14-Aug. 18. Six free Tuesday concerts in Washington Square Park. Henry Schuman, Tania Leon and Abba Bogin are the conductors. WESTBURY MUSIC FAIRMay-September. A continuous flow of entertainers, as themselves or in former Broadway musicals, come to this popular center. NORTH CAROLINA AN APPALACHIAN SUMMERBoone, June 16-Aug. 29. John Houseman's Acting Company, the Broyhill Chamber Ensemble, North Carolina Symphony and Miami City Ballet are a few offerings of this all-inclusive festival, in which the Appalachian State University is joined by the Smithsonian Institution. BREVARD MUSIC FESTIVALJune 24-Aug. 9. Henry Janiec is artistic director. The festival observes its 51st year with the customary numerous events by symphony orchestras, symphonic band, wind ensemble, chamber groups. Productions of ''Cosi fan tutte,'' ''La Boheme,'' ''Rigoletto'' and other stage works. Outstanding soloists. EASTERN MUSIC FESTIVALGreensboro, June 26-Aug. 8. A summer school on the Guilford College campus provides a steady series of concerts, many with guest artists, among them David Bar-Ilan, Josef Gingold, Nobuko Imai, William Vacchiano, Ransom Wilson and Miklos Szenthelyi. Sheldon Morgenstern is music director. HIGHLANDS CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL July 12-Aug. 4. Sunday afternoon and Tuesday evening concerts at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, featuring the Alexander String Quartet. OHIO BLOSSOM MUSIC CENTERCuyahoga Falls, June 27-Aug. 30. The summer home of the Cleveland Orchestra, whose music director, Christoph von Dohnanyi, will conduct on two weekends, with Andras Schiff, Cyprien Katsaris, Midori, Pamela Coburn and Wieslaw Ochman as soloists. Guest conductors will be Franz Allers, Andrew Davis, Gunther Herbig, Erich Kunzel, Yoel Levi, Jahja Ling, Jesus Lopez-Cobos, Robert Page, Michael Stern, Yoshimi Takeda and David Zinman. Additional soloists of international stature. The Boston Pops Orchestra, Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields and Baryshnikov and Company are scheduled. CINCINNATI MAY FESTIVALMay 22-30. James Conlon is the music director of this 115-year-old major choral festival. He will conduct a concert version of ''Otello,'' with Susan Dunn, James McCracken and Cornell MacNeil; Handel's ''Messiah'' and Durufle's Requiem. Andrew Davis well lead Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' and other choral works. Additional soloists are Benita Valente, Vinson Cole, Benjamin Luxon, Alfreda Hodgson and Jon Garrison. CINCINNATI OPERAJune 25-July 11. A mainstay of summer opera, the company's repertory includes Leoncavallo's ''Zaza,'' ''Madama Butterfly'' and ''The Barber of Seville.'' Patricia Craig, Charles Long, Barbara Daniels, Michael Sylvester, Ruth Welting and Brian Schexnayder are among the singers. Anton Coppola and Byron Dean Ryan are the conductors. CINCINNATI SYMPHONYRiverbend Music Center, June 19-Aug. 1. Conductors include Jesus Lopez-Cobos, music director, and Erich Kunzel, Pops conductor, for concerts in a specially designed pavilion on the banks of the Ohio. Soloists include Andre Watts, Nathaniel Rosen, Edith Peinemann, Joseph Swenson and Kazuhiro Koizumi, as well as Mel Torme and Woody Herman. OHIO LIGHT OPERA FESTIVALWooster, June 10-Aug. 9. Seven full-length productions at Wooster College by a company very successful in the operetta repertory. This summer it presents ''The Vagabond King,'' ''Wiener Blut,'' ''The Beggar Student,'' ''H.M.S. Pinafore,'' ''Iolanthe,'' ''Utopia Ltd,'' and Offenbach's ''Bluebeard.'' James Stuart is artistic director. PERFORMING ARTS AT OBERLIN-SUMMER 1987June 7-Aug. 1. Over 20 public programs, some repeated, arising out of summer workshops at Oberlin College. Most programs are devoted to music, ballet and drama. OKLAHOMA OK MOZART INTERNATIONAL FESTIVAL Bartlesville, June 12-20. Concerts are given in the Bartlesville Community Center, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. Ransom Wilson is artistic director and will conduct the resident Solisti New York Chamber Orchestra. OREGON BRITT MUSIC FESTIVALSJacksonville, June 24-Sept. 1. This 25-year-old festival has John Trudeau as music director and conductor of the symphony concerts. JoAnn Falletta is guest conductor, and Lorin Hollander, Christiane Edinger and Leon Bates are soloists. Also recitals, jazz, dance, musical theater and blue grass. CHAMBER MUSIC NORTHWESTPortland, June 22-July 25. The festival's 17th season will present 25 concerts at Reed College and Catlin Gabel School. Clarinetist David Shifrin is music director, and the 26 other performers include Andre-Michel Schub, Ida Kavafian, Paul Neubauer, Walter Trampler and David Jolley. World premieres by William Albright, William Kraft and David Schiff are highlights. OREGON BACH FESTIVALEugene, June 28-July 12. Hellmuth Rilling is music director for this University of Oregon event. There are 30 concerts, with expected stress on the music of Bach, including the St. Matthew Passion. Works by Schubert, Handel and Brahms will also be performed. Vocal soloists include Sylvia McNair, Sarah Walker, Rodney Gilfry, David Gordon and William Parker. OREGON COAST MUSIC FESTIVALCoos Bay/ North Bend, July 11-25. Festival Orchestra under the direction of Gary McLaughlin. Artists and ensembles appearing will include Robin McCabe, Yuval Yaron, Elaine Comparone, Kristi Bjarnason, the Radost Folk Ensemble and the Heather and the Rose dance group. PENNSYLVANIA BEDFORD SPRINGS FESTIVALBedford, June 27-Aug. 2. This takes place on the grounds of the historic Bedford Springs Hotel. Orchestra concerts, chamber music and performances by the Pittsburgh Ballet Theater are listed. Among the soloists are Ruth Laredo, Louise Wohlafka, Mark Kaplan, Theodore Lettvin and Judith Burganger. Jacques Brourman is music and artistic director, and Henry Mazer will be a guest conductor. MANN MUSIC CENTER SUMMER FESTIVAL Philadelphia, June 9-July 24. A distinguished series of free concerts by the Philadelphia Orchestra. Among the guest conductors are Zubin Mehta, Charles Dutoit, Rafael Fruhbeck de Burgos, Leonard Slatkin, Maxim Shostakovich, Henry Mancini, Lorin Maazel and Stanislaw Skrowaczewski. The soloists will be Isaac Stern, Yo-Yo Ma, Alexander Toradze, Itzhak Perlman, Jorge Bolet, Shirley Verrett, Roberta Peters, Jeffrey Siegel, Mark Peskanov, Jerome Lowenthal, Shura Cherkassky, Raphael Oleg and Eugene Istomin. MELLON JAZZ FESTIVAL Philadelphia, June 19-28. Concerts are spread over a variety of sites for a series produced by George Wein. MUSIC AT GRETNAMt. Gretna, June 12-Sept. 6. Chamber music and jazz at the 84-year-old Chautauqua Playhouse. The Audubon Quartet and Leonard Trio are in residence. Also performing will be James Campbell, the Annapolis Brass Quintet, Ruth Laredo and Christopher O'Riley. WILDFLOWER FESTIVAL White Mills, June 27-Aug. 15. Seven weekend concerts at the Dorflinger-Suydam Wildlife Sanctuary, with the Northeastern Pennsylvania Philharmonic Chamber Players under Hugh Keelan, the Birch Hill Consort, Annapolis Brass Quintet, Veronica Tyler and others. PUERTO RICO FESTIVAL CASALSSan Juan, June 6-20. This festival, founded by the late great cellist, will have as conductors Rafael Frubeck de Burgos, Mstislav Rostropovich, Werner Torkanowsky and Odon Alonso, who is also music director this year. Participating will be Margarita Castro, the National Choir of Spain, Bruno Leonardo Gelber, Nicanor Zabaleta, Nigel Rogers, Jean-Yves Thibaudet, the National Symphony of Washington, D.C., and the Puerto Rico Symphony. RHODE ISLAND NEWPORT FESTIVALJuly 7-20. The fabulous mansions at this famous resort are the sites of concerts of old music that is often forgotten as well as great standard works. There are usually three programs daily, performed by some of the finer artists around. As is customary, a number of heralded artists will be presented in their American debuts: Stefan Milenkovic, 10-year-old violin prodigy from Yugoslavia; Raphael Oleg, French violinist; Michel Dalbarto, French pianist, and Peter Roesel, East German pianist. Among other performers will be Thomas Hrynkyw, Bert Lucarelli, Mimi Lerner, Juliana Gondek, Glenn Siebert, Beverly Hoch, Charles Pailthorp, Boris Pergamenschikow, Shura Cherkassky and the San Francisco Chamber Singers. Virgil Thomson will be present for the performance of some of his works. SOUTH CAROLINA SPOLETO FESTIVAL U.S.A. Charleston, May 22-June 7. Gian Carlo Menotti is founder and artistic director of this festival, but it has a new music director in Spiros Argiris. The host of events in historic Charleston has as highlights Strauss's ''Salome,'' led by Mr. Argiris; the professional United States premiere of Rameau's ''Platee''; the Orchestra of St. Luke's with pianist Paolo Bordoni in his United States debut; Athol Fugard's ''The Road to Mecca,'' directed by and starring the author; the United States debut of the Colla Family Marionettes from Milan; Pennsylvania Ballet and Merce Cunningham Dance Company. In addition concerts of chamber, orchestral and choral music and jazz. TENNESSEE SEWANEE SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL June 20-July 26. Orchestral and chamber-music concerts by student and faculty members at the University of the South. Guest conductors are James Paul, Tsung Yeh, Dale Clevenger, Amerigo Marino and Sidney Harth. TEXAS FESTIVAL-INSTITUTE AT ROUND TOP June 1-July 19. Founded by the pianist James Dick, the festival includes chamber, orchestra and solo programs. Among the faculty artists and performers are Mr. Dick, Elisabeth Braden, the Colorado String Quartet, Dorian Wind Quintet, Jeannette Haien, Peter Rejto, James Van Demark and Patricia Zander. The Texas Festival Chamber Orchestra will be led by Heiichiro Ohyama. HOUSTON GRAND OPERA SPRING FESTIVAL May 19-30. Free performances at the Miller Outdoor Theater in Hermann Park of ''La Boheme.'' SAN ANTONIO FESTIVAL June 12-21. The roster of evens includes productions of ''Tosca,'' with Valerie Popova in the title role and Julius Rudel conducting, and of Haydn's ''L'infedelta delusa''; the Fort Worth Ballet with guest stars Valentina Kaslova and Cornell Crabtree; a gala with Frederika von Stade; a performance of Gounod's St. Cecilia Mass; recitals, etc. VERMONT CHAMBER MUSIC CONFERENCE AND COMPOSERS' FORUM OF THE EASTBennington, July 26-Aug. 23. Informal music-making in the evenings when faculty and participants perform together in Greenwall Auditorium at Bennington College. Free and open to the public. Premieres by resident composers in events in the Carriage Barn. Jacob Glick is music director. CRAFTSBURY CHAMBER PLAYERSJuly 16-Aug. 21. Concerts at the Twon House, Hardwick, and St. Paul's Cathedral, Burlington. DISCOVER JAZZBurlington, June 11-14. The city will be overrun with jazz, in the streets and parks, in restaurants and clubs, on buses and ferries for this event. MANCHESTER MUSIC FESTIVALJuly 12-Aug. 8. Concerts at the Southern Vermont Art Center. Taking part will be Michael Rudiakov, director, David Glazer, Ronald Levy, Eudice Shapiro, Henry Schuman, Robert Sherman and others. MARLBORO FESTIVALJuly 18-Aug. 16. Rudolf Serkin's distinguished gathering of young and experienced artists results in worthwhile music-making on Saturday nights and Sunday afternoons plus a couple of Fridays. Also a traditional Bach choral concert by the Brattleboro Music Center led by Blanche Honegger Moyse. SUMMER MUSIC FROM GREENSBOROJuly 21-Aug. 4. Three concerts and an evening of theater presented by Vincent Ricento and Thomas Zajkowski, founders and directors. VERMONT MOZART FESTIVALBurlington, July 19-Aug. 8. Indoor and outdoor concerts at a number of striking locations distinguish this festival. Featured artists are the New York Chamber Soloists, Festival Winds, the New Orchestra of Westchester led by Paul Dunkel, Helen Kwalwasser, Sharon Moe, Andre Laplante and Andreas Bach among others. Melvin Kaplan is artistic director. YELLOW BARN MUSIC FESTIVALPutney, June 28-Aug. 1. Twenty concerts with David Wells, cello, and Janet Wells, piano, artistic directors; Eric Rosenblith, resident violinist, and others. Gunther Schuller will be a guest composer/conductor. VIRGINIA GARTH NEWEL CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVAL Hot Springs, July 5-Aug. 30. Now in its 15th season, the festival is under the direction of Luca and Arlene Di Cecco. Performers include the Garth Newel Chamber Players and Garth Newel Piano Trio. HAMPDEN-SYDNEY MUSIC FESTIVALJune 8-21. Chamber-music programs by Sidney Harth, Ethan Sloane, Patricia Lust, Yehuda Hanani, James Kidd, Edward Auer and others at Hampden-Sydney College. WOLF TRAPVienna, June 11-September. Among the multitude of participants and events scheduled are the New York City Opera in ''La Traviata,'' ''Tosca'' and ''The Student Prince''; Wolf Trap Opera in Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream''; National Symphony; Boston Pops; Houston Ballet; San Francisco Ballet and ''South Pacific'' with Robert Goulet. Sir Yehudi Menuhin will conduct one symphony concert with himself, Elmar Oliveira, Ruggiero Ricci and Joseph Silverstein as violin soloists. Hugh Wolff will conduct Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. WASHINGTON OLYMPIC MUSIC FESTIVAL-CONCERTS IN THE BARNQuilcene, June 20-Aug. 9. Concerts by the Philadelphia String Quartet and guest artists: Paul Hersh, Linda Rosenthal, John Davis, Thalia Moore among others. The site is a 40-acre farm. PACIFIC NORTHWEST FESTIVALSeattle, Aug. 2-15. The Seattle Opera, directed by Speight Jenkins, will repeat its production of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle (newly completed last year). The two cycles will be sung in German, with English surtitles. Singers will include Leonie Rysanek as Sieglinde, Roger Roloff, Alexandra Hughes and Linda Kelm. SEATTLE CHAMBER MUSIC FESTIVALJune 29-July 24. Twelve concerts with pre-concert recitals at Lakeside School. Toby Saks is founder and artistic director. Thirty-three additional faculty artists will be involved, such as Cho-Liang Lin, Mark Peskanov, Ronald Thomas, Marcus Thompson, Lucy Shelton, Stephanie Brown, Edward Auer, Paul Rosenthal and Hamao Fujiwara. WISCONSIN INTERNATIONAL FESTIVAL OF ART SONG Milwaukee, June 22-27. Three public recitals with Kurt Ollmann, Udo Reinemann and Elly Ameling, guest artist/teachers, with James Tocco and Jeffry Peterson, pianists. PENINSULA FESTIVALFish Creek, Aug. 5-22. A 45-member orchestra in nine concerts with soloists. The festival, founded by the late Thor Johnson, is now in its 35th year. Claude Frank will appear, and a commissioned work by Alan Stout will be played. SUMMER EVENINGS OF MUSICMilwaukee, June 8-29. Four Monday evening concerts with the Fine Arts Quartet, presented by the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee at the Pabst Theater. Guest artists include Lukas Foss and Menahem Pressler. WYOMING GRAND TETON FESTIVALTeton Village, July 8-Aug. 23. Ling Tung, music director, conducts a 100-member orchestra in several concerts, with such soloists as Steven deGroote, Gregory Fulkerson, Sharon Isbin, Jon Deak, Lionel Party, Susan Starr, Hidetaro Suzuki, Cyprien Katsaris and Joseph Robinson. Robert Shaw will be guest conductor for Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' with the Mormon Tabernacle Choir. CANADA BANFF FESTIVAL OF THE ARTSJune 6-Aug. 30. A showcase for the Banff Center School of Fine Arts with more than 130 events. Highlights include productions of Cavalli's ''Ormindo'' and Argento's ''Postcard from Morocco,'' the premieres of Brian Macdonald's ballet ''Breaks'' and one by David Earle, a staging of Ibsen's ''Ghosts'' and concerts by the Orford String Quartet, Karen Tuttle, Janos Starker and Gyorgy Sebok. FESTIVAL ORFORDJuly 4-Aug. 23. Some of the many artists appearing at the Orford Center for the Arts will be Anton Kuerti, Paul Cocker, I Musici de Montreal, Karl Engel, Rodney Friend, Sonny Rollins Quintet, Cambrian Brass Quintet and Ifor James. VICTORIA INTERNATIONAL FESTIVALJuly 16-Aug. 25. Concerts by the faculty of the Johannesen International School of the Arts. Among those present will be Harvey Shapiro, Gary Carr, Ruth Laredo, Bela Siki, Ronald Turini, Quartet Canada, Festival Contemporary Ensemble, Daniel Heifetz and New ZuRICH STRING QUARTET.

title: 'The True Detective'
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: GLOWSTONE. By MacDonald Harris. (Morrow, $17.95.) Take a woman scientist, Paris during the Belle Epoque and a mysterious substance that gives off powerful rays. MacDonald Harris, a seasoned storyteller, transmutes these elements into a thoroughly engaging work of imagination. In 1906, after the death of her husband, Paul, an eminent physicist, Claire Savarin-Decker vows to carry on the research they shared ever since Paul's discovery of an unknown metal that glows in the dark, reduces tumors and may ''prove to be the greatest boon to mankind since the invention of fire.

title: ALBANY DUCKS A RENT CONTROL CONFRONTATION
description: IT promised to be a dramatic showdown over one of New York's most bitterly contested issues. With only days remaining before the May 15 expiration of the state's rent regulation statutes, legislators were besieged by lobbyists. Tenant and landlord groups took turns busing thousands of angry, placard-waving supporters to Albany to press competing demands.

title: No Headline
description: Tenant Rights in a Sale Question: I am the leaseholder on a town house in a rent-stabilized complex that includes five apartments and three town houses. Access to the units is from an interior courtyard connected to the street by an enclosed passageway. All units are served by a common heating hot-water system. I believe that the entire complex is registered as a single lot for tax purposes.

title: CONDOM ADS ON BUSES FIRST IN AIDS SERIES
description: LEAD: THE bus advertisements approved last week in New Haven to promote condoms in preventing AIDS are the first in a series planned by groups in New Haven and Hartford.

title: GETTING A TASTE OF BREAD LINE BLUES
description: THERE were 27 people in line ahead of me. Men in work boots with strong hands. A widowed grandmother. A Wall Streeter in pinstripes reading a business section. It was a spring morning in the unemployment line.

title: Fanny Butcher Dead; Literary Critic Was 99
description: Fanny Butcher, the literary editor of The Chicago Tribune for 40 years, has died at the age of 99.

title: GOING AFTER THE INDISCRIMINATE SPENDER
description: AS POPULAR as exotic fruits have become, they are still small potatoes at many supermarket cash registers. Mr. Kemp of Super Valu, for example, says they account for just 1 percent of total fruit sales at his stores.

title: WALDER OVERTAKES OKAMOTO TO LEAD BY 2
description: Just as Ayako Okamoto of Japan was struggling uphill to a double bogey on the 15th hole at Navesink Country Club today, Colleen Walker of Bradenton, Fla., was playing downhill to a birdie 2 at the 17th.

title: When to Test for AIDS
description: Why not compel everyone to be tested for AIDS as the basis for halting further spread of the virus? That's a natural first thought to anyone who ponders the deadly epidemic. But it's only a first thought. That some senior Administration officials argue for mandatory AIDS testing shows how late in the day they have arrived at step one.

title: FORMER MEMBERS TELL ABOUT 'CIRCLE OF FRIENDS'
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the Circle of Friends has denied that it coerces members or uses deception to further its goals, several people who left it in the last few years tell a different story.

title: Dance
description: This is a good week to explore modern dance at some of the city's vital smaller dance houses. Lisa Kraus and Dancers moves into Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue at Ninth Street, for five performances, Friday through next Sunday at 9 P.M. Ms. Kraus's dance tends to be yeasty, and she will present a wide-ranging program that includes new and recent works ranging from ''dancing to grand-scale classical music without the protection of tongue-in-cheek irony,'' as the choreographer puts it, to ''narrative dancing that relies primarily on the expressiveness of movement.'' Maria Cutrona, a veteran of the Dana Reitz, Susan Rethorst and Sally Silvers companies, performs new work that alludes to our contemporary sports culture.

title: BUY ME SOME SOFTWARE AND CRACKER JACK
description: JUST after Jim Ray Hart, the third baseman for San Francisco, grounded out to end the seventh inning in the last game of the 1965 season, the phone rang in the press box at Candlestick Park. It was Herman Franks, the manager of the Giants and a man of few words, calling from the dugout. ''And?'' he rasped.

title: CONGRESSMEN UNITE IN FIGHT FOR SOUND
description: RECOGNIZING the need for regional political cooperation in the drive to make the nation's waterways safe for swimming and fishing, Congressmen from New York, Connecticut and Rhode Island have formed a Congressional Long Island Sound Caucus.

title: PORTABLE CD PLAYERS ADVANCE
description: IN 1935, THE BRITISH NOVEL-ist and critic J. B. Priestley traveled to what was then still a relatively exotic region: Arizona.

title: NOTED SCHOLAR OF SEISMOLOGY
description: The Rev. J. Joseph Lynch, a Jesuit priest and longtime scholar of seismology, died of heart failure Thursday at the Murray-Weigel Infirmary at Fordham University. He was 92 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: TRACK AND FIELD
description: Edwin Moses had one of his closer calls this sunny afternoon at Princeton University's Palmer Stadium in the Adidas/Princeton Invitational track meet.

title: Bees Released in Truck Crash
description: A truck carrying 800 boxes of honey bees overturned on a highway Thursday night and released about 40 million bees. The unidentified truck driver was treated at a hospital and released, said Fire Chief Guy Jones of Crisp County. Several officers were stung by bees but there were no serious injuries, he added. The truck was taking the bees from Florida to the Dakotas, where they were to be used to aid pollination of clover and wheat fields, when it overturned on Interstate 75.

title: LAWYER FOR BARBIE TRIES TO INDICT ALL OF FRANCE
description: IT did not take very long for the trial of Klaus Barbie to become as much a contest among lawyers as a lesson in history. Mr. Barbie, whose trial opened here last week, was the wartime chief of the Gestapo in this region of France. As the trial's main exhibit, he did offer a kind of presence here for the first two days - the gray, pallid, strangely smiling and apparently unrepentant presence of an old Nazi. But then he walked out of the trial in the middle of its third day, which very likely means he will never be seen publicly again. Remaining were two groups of lawyers symbolizing two opposing points of view in a judicial event full of symbolism.

title: 'Me Nuh Chose None'
description: To the Editor:

title: A PLACE IN THE SUN
description: FOR THE MANY WOMEN RAISED ON baby oil and cocoa butter, it's tough to come to grips with the dangers of tanning. Basking in the sun makes them look and feel good - it's tied up with sports and fitness, with vacations and rest. Sunning is an addiction, and some women aren't quite ready to kick the habit.

title: AUSTRALIAN, 2 OTHERS TIED FOR LEAD AT COLONIAL
description: Steve Elkington took advantage of near-perfect conditions to shoot a seven-under-par 63 that lifted him into a tie for the second-round lead today in the $600,000 Colonial National Invitation Tournament.

title:
DINING OUT;
AN OASIS IN ELMSFORD
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH it has faults, The Evergreen should not be dismissed lightly; the separate bar seems to have a charisma that keeps it jolly and full every afternoon of the week, management is anxious to please and the kitchen shows promise. In sum, this restaurant has merits that make it worthy of review.

title: Trudeau Emerges as Quiet Foe of Canadian Pact
description: Three years after he retired as Canada's Prime Minister, Pierre Elliott Trudeau has emerged as an important behind-the-scenes opponent of a new constitutional accord.

title: LEIBRANDT PITCHES ONE-HITTER
