description: Charlie Leibrandt yielded only one hit, a bunt single in the sixth inning that broke up his bid for a perfect game, as Kansas City routed Milwaukee, 13-0, tonight. It was the Brewers' 10th consecutive loss.

title: STATES REDUCING TAXES OF LOW-INCOME PEOPLE
description: Following the lead of the Federal Government, many states are moving this year to reduce tax burdens for people with low incomes.

title: Classical Music
description: Bach's ''Art of the Fugue'' is one of the great works from the Baroque, a summation of Bach's thinking on contrapuntal writing and a heroic piece of music. Extant manuscripts give no indication what instrument or instruments were intended to perform the work, and so, over the years, harpsichordists, chamber groups and full-blown symphony orchestras have been among those to tackle the piece. The organ is especially well suited to it. Sunday afteroon at 3 P.M., Donald Joyce, a much-admired organist, will be presenting Bach's work at the Church of St. John the Evangelist (348 East 55th Street, at First Avenue), which is said to possess one of New York's best-sounding organs. Mr. Joyce will repeat his performance on Monday at 8 P.M.

title: WILANDER ROUTS MCENROE IN ROME
description: Second-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, playing nearly flawless baseline tennis, crushed John McEnroe, 6-1, 6-3, today to advance to the final of the Italian Open.

title: RESTAURANTS OFFER AMERICAN CHOICES
description: THE wide selection of American wines at three relatively new area restaurants give patrons an excellent opportunity to become acquainted with a variety of domestic products.

title: When Winning Is Another Way of Losing
description: To the Editor:

title: Catholic University
description: The Catholic University of America presented degrees to 614 undergraduates and 709 graduate students in commencement ceremonies at the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in Washington yesterday. Edouard Saouma, the Director General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, addressed the graduating class and was awarded an honorary Doctor of Science degree. Honorary degrees were also awarded to John T. Dunlop, the former Secretary of Labor, and to Floretta Dukes McKenzie, the Superintendent of the District of Columbia Public Schools.

title: GENUINE FANATICS
description: ''THEM'' Stalin's Polish Puppets. By Teresa Toranska. Translated by Agnieszka Kolakowska. 384 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95.

title: MUSIC: RYO NODA IN DEBUT
description: RYO NODA'S music revolves around carefully shaped tones and phrases that hang in the air. The saxophonist-composer, who has studied in Japan, the United States and France, made his New York debut Thursday at Merkin Concert Hall. His program sought to unite the detail and note-by-note drama of Japanese traditional music with the pinpoint, chromatic gestures of Western contemporary music.

title: Elizabeth McBratney and Franklin Wallin Marry
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Montclair, N.J., yesterday, Elizabeth Carroll McBratney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R.Bruce McBratney of Montclair, was married to Franklin Bogue Wallin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin W. Wallin Jr. of Asheville, N.C. The Rev. Walter Sobol performed the ceremony. The bride's sister, Sara D'Alessandro, was matron of honor, and Thomas E. Wallin was his brother's best man.

title: THE MYTH OF A POST-INDUSTRIAL ECONOMY
description: IN THE 1960's, when Americans still looked to the future with unbounded optimism, analysts such as Daniel Bell and, later on, popularizers such as Alvin Toffler, confidently predicted an imminent and historic transition from a dirty and dank industrial era to a lean, clean information age - the post-industrial economy. Today, that vision has become the accepted wisdom that guides policy. But it is guiding policy the wrong way.

title: Mark Edwin Mouton Wed to Brooke Slater
description: At the New Orleans Botanical Garden yesterday Brooke Dorothy Slater was married to Mark Edwin Mouton in a ceremony performed by Rabbi David Goldstein.

title: WHO DECIDES THE COLOR OF MUSIC?
description: WHEN THE NA-tional Association for the Advancement of Colored People examined racial discrimination in the music business recently, its report concentrated on offstage employment opportunities. For all the visibility and profitability of black performers, the report said, blacks are ''grossly underrepresented'' in the business itself: in record companies, concert promotion, management. As in major-league baseball, there are far more blacks playing than running the front offices.

title: ORANGES, LEMONS AND CARAMBOLAS
description: MARC and Kiki Ellenby have seen the future and it is filled with carambolas, millions of pounds of them.

title: U.S. Inspector Is Dubious About Quality of Meat
description: As the Agriculture Department told Congress it was looking for better ways to protect consumers from food poisoning, one of its processing plant inspectors declared that Government labels on beef, pork and poultry products should read: ''Eat at Your Own Risk.''

title: A House In the Country
description: At best, Erica Abeel's article ''Magnificent Obsession - A House in the Country'' (April 19) is a subtle treatment of the story, which needs to be told. That story tells that responsibility for the deteriorating quality of life in the city must be placed on the individuals who are presently obsessed with the great escape from New York. The jammed appointment book, power breakfasts and outrageously long work days are ''in style,'' and it is because we have made them so.

title: Flying Pains
description: To the Editor:

title: FERRY EXPANSION DEBATED
description: LEAD: CITING increased demand by both commercial interests and tourists, two Connecticut-based ferry companies want to add as many as five new routes to the service across Long Island Sound to the Hamptons and the North Shore. But opponents in East Hampton and Port Jefferson say they already have enough traffic.

title: The Latest Twist On Insider Trading
description: In the year since the insider trading scandal broke, no case has outraged Wall Street more than the one the Federal Government sought to dismiss last week.

title: ALL IN A MORNING'S WORK
description: SOMETHING I cannot forgo is having time in the morning, in bed. I accomplish it, but with difficulty. Without this small pleasure, my nerves become jangled by late afternoon and my spirits sag.

title: Film on State Hospital Provocative After 20 Years
description: A documentary film about brutality at a state hospital for the mentally ill, made 20 years ago and promptly banned, has proved that its power to provoke debate has not diminished.

title: CASINO OFFICIAL AND MAYOR AT ODDS
description: LEAD: THE mayor's office and representatives of the hotel-casino industry here are at odds over a number of issues, including the handling of city government and charges of racism.

title: Flying Pains
description: To the Editor:

title: SURVEY FINDS MAJOR GAPS IN COLLEGE SALARIES
description: The presidents of the nation's major private research universities were paid an average of $153,400 in 1986, nearly $50,000 more than their counterparts running the largest public universities, an administrators' group says.

title: Susan L. Green Marries
description: Susan Louise Green, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alanson Wood Green Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married at Christ Episcopal Church there yesterday to Edward Dean Willett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Edward Willett of Mount Sinai, L.I. The Rev. John Bishop officiated.

title: Gooden Pitches Scoreless 4 Innings
description: Dwight Gooden took another step last night, pitching four scoreless innings against a team of minor leaguers in the second live workout of his comeback.

title: JAZZ: JAMES NEWTON REPRISES THE SPECTRUM
description: ''TONIGHT we're going to go through the whole spectrum of the music and then some,'' James Newton promised his audience at Carlos 1 on Tuesday. Was he boasting? Maybe, but in the course of the evening's first set the flutist-composer forged elements of the blues, gospel, early Duke Ellington, and work by Ornette Coleman and Eric Dolphy into a consistently inventive and personal performance. Is it boasting if you deliver what you promise, ''and then some?''

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Building Up the 'Under-Retailed' Route 1
description: LEAD: THE Route 1 corridor, covering 20 miles from New Brunswick to Trenton, has been the scene of rapid economic expansion that in the last decade has replaced old sod farms with a legion of contemporary office and housing complexes.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
A Case of Bigamy
description: LEAD: I'M A MARRIED MAN. NOTH-ing unusual about that, lots of us out there. I just happen to be married to two people. My situation is common knowledge to all our friends, acquaintances and associates. In fact, both my spouses know each other and like each other. During the week, I kiss Brooks goodbye in the mornings and head for the office, where I begin my other life with John, my other ''significant other.

title: Asbestos in Roads Pits the U.S. Against California
description: Federal and state agencies are at odds over the health hazards posed by thousands of miles of gravel roads made from asbestos-bearing serpentine rock.

title: MEDICAL STAFF PUNISHED IN JERSEY PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITAL DEATHS
description: New Jersey's Commissioner of Human Services suspended a physician and announced measures to improve medical services at the state's psychiatric hospitals after charges of negligence in the deaths of three patients last year.

title: Boston
description: Spring is the season when Boston, which is still a pedestrian's city, slips gratefully from galoshes to running shoes. It is the time to enjoy the texture of the 18th and 19th centuries, and even savor the finer parts of the 20th, a period through which the city has exported, by turns, revolution, culture and high technology.

title: Indian Museum Hitting the Trail?
description: For more than a decade New York State and city officials have been debating how to rescue the Museum of the American Indian and its more than one million artifacts from the too-small and poorly attended quarters at 155th Street and Broadway it has occupied since 1922.

title: CALLING A GUPPY A GUPPY
description: HOW TO THINK LIKE A SCIENTIST Answering Questions by the Scientific Method. By Stephen P. Kramer. Illustrated by Felicia Bond. 44 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $11.50. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: No Headline
description: Earlier this month, on the hard and mountainous terrain at Semdinli, a Turkish Army patrol walked into an ambush by Kurdish rebels and lost 13 men in half an hour of rifle fire.

title: GRAND ALLUSIONS
description: SUMMER'S MOST INNOVATIVE TABLE accessories are not what they seem. Tumblers look as if they are sculpted from stone, paper plates appear as marble, and ceramic dishes boast a quarry-like array of mineral patterns. Even when objects are clearly for the table, they often allude to architecture more than dining.

title: Call for Amnesty In Argentina
description: Less than a month after a brief uprising by several army units, President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina last week submitted legislation to absolve virtually all middle- and lower-ranking military officers for their role in the country's ''dirty war'' of the late 1970's.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Elmont $149,900 128 Heathcote Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 70-year-old Tudor; attic, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes, $1,700. Farmingdale $165,000 17 Baldwin Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; 2 kitchens, finished basement, 1-car attached garage; taxes $3,000. Greenlawn $475,000 9 Grace Court 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; wide pine floors, walk-in fireplace, cedar exterior, 2 acres; taxes $7,000. Patchogue $113,000 199 West Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 75-year-old Cape Cod; basement, wood stove, balcony; taxes $1,600. Port Jefferson Station $158,500 11 Barbara Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old high ranch; 2-car garage, pool; taxes $3,100. Shirley $99,900 48 Breston Drive East 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 15-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, studio apartment, patio; taxes $1,400. OTHER AREAS Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $385,000 38 Aspinwall Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, den, alarm system; taxes $5,535. Rocky Hill, Conn. $158,000 41 Pheasant Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 14-year-old split-level; bar in rec room, 0.75 acre; taxes $2,077. Emerson, N.J. $235,500 146 Lozier Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old contemporary; patio, family room, central A/C; taxes $2,881.

title: MR. MEESE'S ETHICS ARE ONCE AGAIN SCRUTINIZED
description: IN 1984, days after asking for a special investigation of his personal financial dealings, Edwin Meese 3d said there was little he would do differently, given the opportunity to change the past. Mr. Meese, then the nominee for Attorney General, said in an interview, ''The trouble is not created by me'' but by other people ''distorting'' his activities. Months later, the special prosecutor said he had found no basis for prosecution regarding any of 11 allegations, including whether Mr. Meese had arranged Federal jobs for people who had helped him financially. The prosecutor, Jacob A. Stein, said his jurisdiction did not permit him to judge Mr. Meese on ethics.

title: Philanthropy?
description: To the Editor:

title: A TRULY BAD RABBIT
description: THE TALES OF UNCLE REMUS The Adventures of Brer Rabbit. By Julius Lester. Illustrated by Jerry Pinkney. 151 pp. New York: Dial Books. $15. (Ages 5 and up)

title: Science, Technology And AIDS
description: Stephen Jay Gould is correct to stress that we humans are a part of nature, subject to its unrestricted, amoral patterns. Sadly, the AIDS tragedy reminds us of that humble reality. But let's not confuse our much-maligned love affair with technology with the power of medical science. The latter has provided our species with some control of our destiny.

title: PAS DE DEUX WITH DR. TACET
description: PRIVATE DOMAIN By Paul Taylor. Illustrated. 371 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title: THE PARROT DOES BOGART
description: HARRY'S MAD By Dick King-Smith. Illustrated by Jill Bennet. 123 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $9.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: REAGAN'S DEFENDERS ARGUING HE CAN DEFY CONGRESS'S BAN
description: As evidence accumulates that President Reagan was active in getting aid for the Nicaraguan rebels from foreign nations and private donors, his defenders began arguing this week that Mr. Reagan has sweeping power to disregard legislation barring such Government aid.

title: TV WOMEN HAVE COME A LONG WAY, BABY-SORT OF
description: THIS THURSDAY EVENING at 9:30, NBC will introduce a new half-hour television series, ''The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd,'' about a 34-year-old divorced woman (with no children) who lives and works in New York City. There are ready-made seeds of drama planted within these statistics, and, given the large number of viewers who fit Molly's description, there is likely to be an audience out there who will want to watch these seeds grow.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SELLING HITLER, by Robert Harris. (Penguin, $4.95.) This account of the splashiest hoax of the 1980's - the ''discovery'' of 60 volumes of bogus Hitler diaries, later shown to be crude forgeries - is ''thorough and mordantly funny,'' James M. Markham said in The Book Review in 1986. But there are serious lessons amid the humor, he said. ''One lesson is not to believe handwriting experts. Another is that checkbook journalism - paying for news - is a very bad idea.'' THE GOLDEN GATE, by Vikram Seth. (Vintage, $5.95.) A cluster of Californians, most of them in various stages of romantic attachment, populate this novel in verse form -John, a young Silicon Valley executive; Janet, his former girlfriend; Liz, his current love interest; Ed, Liz's brother; Phil, John's friend (who fancies Ed); and Charlemagne, Liz's cat.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
MYSTERY IN THE DESERT
description: LEAD: The Nazca lines are the Stonehenge of South America. Colossal triangles and rectangles, a spider web of lines radiating for miles in the desert, enormous silhouettes of plants and fantastic animals dug into the sand - this mysterious network, best seen from the air, extends over 120 square miles of Peruvian pampa.

title: Promises, Promises
description: THE AMERICAN FAMILY: THE POSTWAR YEARS 1946-1948 Part of the series ''The March of Time: American Lifestyles 1939-1950.'' Executive producer Louis de Rochemont. Narrated by Westbrook van Voorhis. Embassy Home Entertainment. 90 minutes. $24.95.

title: WHERE ARE THE BLACK FANS?
description: FROM THE GRAND-stands, they saw bleacher bums sprawling in the sun beyond the outfield, neighbors watching from nearby rooftops, and, beyond these sights, the boundless Midwestern sky.

title: Edward Swayduck, 75; Headed Lithographers
description: Edward Swayduck, the former head of the lithographers union in New York City, died Thursday at the Hollywood (Fla.) Medical Center of complications from Parkinson's disease. He was 75 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: Joann E. Sikorski Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York yesterday Joann Elizabeth Sikorski, a daughter of Mrs. Edward Joseph Sikorski of Northport, L.I., and the late Mr. Sikorski, was married to Kerry Batchelor Watterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Watterson of Bay Village, Ohio. The Rev. Frederick Hoesli performed the ceremony. Irene Armenia was the bride's matron of honor, and Mr. Watterson was his son's best man.

title: The Golden Land
description: One night, creeping through the bushes along the Texas side of the border, I began to laugh. I laughed until I had to stop and sit on the ground to control the sense of wild comedy that suddenly seized me.

title: AN UNEVEN FILM ABOUT JOE ORTON THAT COULD HAVE USED HIS LEFT HAND
description: THE BEST PLACE TO meet a writer, it has been said, is on the page (or on the stage, or wherever else his work appears). I don't think the British playwright Joe Orton would have dissented. At all events, he once told an interviewer that, unlike Oscar Wilde, he thought that a writer should put his genius into his work, not into his life.

title: 40 YEARS OF CANNES: GHOSTS AND DREAMS
description: LOOKING RATHER LIKE AN OVER-sized reproduction of Christopher Columbus's flagship, the vessel built for the filming of Roman Polanski's ''Pirates'' is now moored alongside a quay off the old port of Cannes. From time to time, it's open to the public. It can be rented for private parties. Right now, in the middle of the celebratory, 40th annual Cannes International Film Festival, the ship is not receiving visitors, but it dominates the view from the Croisette.

title: HERE'S TO SEXUAL PHILANTHROPHY
description: CHARLES FOURIER The Visionary and His World. By Jonathan Beecher. Illustrated. 601 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $49.50.

title: Two Visions Vie In the East Village
description: AS the spirit of the East Village creeps eastward into the region that runs from Avenues A to D, between Houston and 14th Streets, two distinct yet overlapping identities are emerging. One is Loisaida, indigenous and struggling; the other is Alphabet City, arty and affluent.

title: CENTER STEPS IN WHEN CUSTODY IS AT ISSUE
description: LEAD: A 5-YEAR-OLD boy, upset by his divorcing parents' custody battle, told a New Haven psychiatrist about a dream he had had.

title: Brooke Bayard Baldridge Marries Daniel G. Pelizza
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday Brooke Bayard Baldridge, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dickson Bouton Baldridge of Wilmington, N.C., was married to Daniel Gregory Pelizza, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Pelizza of Wallingford, Conn. The Rev. M.Jennings Matheson performed the ceremony, assisted by Kempton Dunn Baldridge, a seminarian at the Berkeley Divinity School of Yale University and brother of the bride.

title: Water Problems And Development
description: It appears quite admirable of Roger Tilles to stress the seriousness of one of the issues confronting us on Long Island [ ''Arbitrary, Unilateral Caps on Water Use Will Hurt,'' Opinion Page, April 19 ] . However, one has to wonder where, as a developer who has constructed and proposes additional development in Nassau County, he and other builders have been while these issues were intensifying.

title: BATTLE RAGES TO PRESERVE COLLEGE IN NEW ORLEANS
description: The sedate social clubs of upper-class New Orleans are abuzz this spring with an unusual issue for the time and the place: The rights of women, specifically Newcomb College women. The issue has caught on as the proposed Federal equal rights amendment never did.

title: A ZIMBABWE ISSUE: KILLING OF BABIES
description: Eriya Jokasi was 38 years old, unemployed and a widow with seven children when she secretly gave birth to a baby in a cornfield and, using a heavy rock, killed it.

title: THE SEVEN AGES OF DOG
description: GOODBYE, MAX Written and illustrated by Holly Keller. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75. (Ages 4 to 8) ROSALIE By Joan Hewett. Illustrated by Donald Carrick. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $11.75. (Ages 5 to 8) OMA AND BOBO Written and illustrated by Amy Schwartz. Unpaged. New York: Bradbury Press. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 7)

title: JOHNCOCK, UNSER TOP TRIALS
description: A quartet of former winners, led by Gordon Johncock and Al Unser Sr., who did not have a ride until this week, easily qualified today for the Indianapolis 500.

title: Guatemalan Refugees in No Hurry to Return
description: The return of more than 40,000 Guatemalan Indians who fled to Mexico to escape military repression is proceeding slowly, according to Government officials and human-rights advocates.

title: MUSIC: STRING QUARTET FROM MILAN'S LA SCALA
description: ABOUT 130 people gathered - or, by the look of it, scattered - in Alice Tully Hall Thursday evening for one of the most enjoyable string quartet concerts this listener can recall from recent seasons. The occasion was a visit by the Quartetto della Scala (four principal string players from the orchestra of La Scala, Milan), brought over by the Banco Popolare di Milano. As it was all but a private affair (unadvertised, nearly unannounced), it might better have been held in an elegant room somewhere; the only justification for moving chamber music out of the chamber is that of letting more people hear it.

title: 'THE END IS ONLY IMAGINARY'
description: IN THE COUNTRY OF LAST THINGS By Paul Auster. 188 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: 'LA MANCHA' IN A WOEFUL UPDATING
description: IF Don Giovanni can be transported to modern-day Harlem, why can't Miguel de Cervantes be incarcerated in contemporary Latin America?

title: DEVELOPER TOLD TO CUT A BIT OFF FOUR HOUSES
description: LEAD: EVER since a six-story office building went up on Sunrise Highway where some people were sure only a four-story structure was supposed to go, Valley Stream residents and officials have been sensitive to developers who say one thing and build something else.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN EXOTIC FRUIT
description: For exotic fruits, these are the glory days. Increasingly, shoppers who were once content with bananas and oranges are now purchasing fruits they can barely pronounce and never heard of until recently - exotics like the star-shaped carambola, the prickly lychee and the grapefruit-like pummelo.

title: U.S. IN CROSSFIRE OF BORDER WAR
description: ''THIS is the heart of Asia,'' said a poet reciting Pushtoon verse at a recent mammoth celebration of the Soviet-backed government here. ''When Afghanistan trembles, all of Asia moves.''

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
WAITING FOR OPERATION MOSES
description: LEAD: THE RETURN By Sonia Levitin. 213 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: KEY IRAN WITNESS IS GIVEN IMMUNITY
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra case has granted immunity to a key figure in the case, Robert C. Dutton, and has questioned him before a grand jury, according to a Federal investigator and others with knowledge of the inquiry.

title: SHOULD ATHLETES BE ROLE MODELS?
description: Athletes should not be role models; fathers and mothers should be role models. E. P. HUMPHREY Jr. Wynnewood, Pa.

title: The Latest Crop Of B&B Guides
description: The shelf for researching bed and breakfast accommodations grows crowded.

title: IT'S TIME FOR A SPRING CHECKUP
description: LAST week the leaves finally unfurled on the trees surrounding my country retreat north of the city. This event triggered a seasonal urge to get my view camera out of storage. But before venturing outside, I realized, an annual camera checkup was in order.

title: SIMILAR FEELINGS, DIFFERENT VOICES
description: STEREOTYPING the sexes can be useful in understanding people if you are wise enough to remember that exceptions are to be expected.

title: Cynthia A. Carey To Marry July 18
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dennis J. Carey Jr. of Sands Point, L.I., and North Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ann Carey, to Charles Bernard LaLone, a son of Marie T. LaLone of Locust Valley, L.I., and Bernard H. LaLone Jr. of Locust Valley and Palm Beach, Fla. The wedding is to be July 18.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music review headline in this section last Sunday appeared in similar versions on two adjoining articles.

title: In Divided Fiji, Army Ousts the New Government
description: Racial hostilities led to the overthrow last week of the newly elected Government of Fiji.

title: Streetscapes: Audubon Terrace; Attrition Taking Its Toll At a Cultural Complex
description: IF it were in, say, Toledo or Phoenix, it would be a major cultural attraction to which residents would make frequent visits. But Audubon Terrace - a magnificent assemblage at 155th Street and Broadway of a church and other structures that once housed five museums - is unknown to most New Yorkers, and now the second of its founding institutions is about to pull up stakes for another location.

title: THE PERILS OF A SOCIAL LIFE
description: PEOPLE WHO CLAIM THEY HAVE NEVER had a disaster while entertaining either have maids and butlers or serve sliced white bread and salmon out of a can. Otherwise, it can only be assumed that they are flirting dangerously with falsehood.

title: Bridge Playoff Finalists Make Close Escapes
description: The final playoff to determine the United States entry in the 1987 world bridge team championships continued here quietly today after an extraordinary day of excitement and legal argument in the semifinal stage Friday.

title: Tough Love and Glass Slippers
description: To the Editor:

title: RICHARDSON'S STRUGGLE: ASSESSING WHAT WENT WRONG
description: He is the man who will not go away.

title: Talking: Co-ops; Tracking Resale Prices
description: BECAUSE cooperatives are exempt from the public recording requirements that apply to condominiums and houses, co-op resale prices have been, until recently, well kept secrets.

title: A TRADITION THRIVES IN RIDGEFIELD
description: THE restaurant mortality rate being what it is, the 30-year-old Inn at Ridgefield is unusual. Even more remarkable is that its high performance remains as consistent as ever - even when it changes hands.

title: Monroe Belongs In Hall of Fame
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE PITFALLS OF A SECOND MORTGAGE
description: WHEN the Chase Manhattan Bank mailed hundreds of thousands of letters to homeowners in the New York area a few weeks ago, offering them bargain rates on home-equity loans, or what used to be known as second mortgages, the bank was joining in an increasingly popular promotion.

title: Miss French Wed To an Executive
description: Mary Tyler French, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seth Barton French Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley to Stuart Hall Hartmeyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Hartmeyer of Glen Head, L.I., and Trappe, Md. The Rev. Charles Newberry, assisted by the Rev. Alan C. French, the bride's brother, performed the ceremony.

title: JAZZ: NANA VASCONCELOS
description: NANA VASCONCELOS has brought the spark of Brazilian percussion to all sorts of cross-cultural music in the last few years. Now, he's put together his own band, Bush Dance, and on Wednesday at S.O.B.'s it turned rhythms into melodies and tunes into grooves - heady, exhilarating, unpredictable music.

title: CITIES IN THE SKY, SKYSCRAPERS BY THE ACRE
description: AT a time when most American cities are trying to figure out what to do with hundreds of thousands of square feet of office space no one seems to need, New Yorkers are facing a generation of skyscraper parks laid out not by the square foot but by the block. Never before have so many gigantic projects been planned simultaneously, underscoring the unrelenting expansion of the city's financial services industry, which seems to devour almost every inch of space that comes on the market.

title: NO-NONSENSE NEOPOLITAN FARE
description: CONSISTENCY is the hallmark of a good restaurant, but it's not the word to describe Mamma Lombardi's in Holbrook.

title: THE RISKS OF DEBT DEPEND ON THE YARKSTICK
description: THE drop in inflation that started in the early 1980's removed one of the main incentives to borrow. But Americans have continued their rapid pile-up of debt. Though the Federal Reserve reported that consumer borrowing fell in March for the first time since 1982, by one-tenth of 1 percent, analysts pointed out that the figure does not include home-equity loans, the fastest growing credit instruments.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: From Booties to Hats, Clothing for Children Les Petites Passions, which opened in Scarsdale last August as a children's clothing boutique, specializes in handmade clothing in sizes infant to 6X. The store also takes custom orders for clothing for christenings, weddings and bas mitzvahs. A few soft-soled shoes and sandal styles are in now - more will be added in the summer - and the shop also has tights, opaque and sheer stockings, socks and straw or felt brimmed hats, depending on the season.

title: IGNORING ISSUES IN ELECTION REFORM
description: The Mayor of Norwalk, William A. Collins, writes in favor of reforming our nominating procedures [ ''The Struggle to Control Nominations,'' March 29 ] . He suggests that a direct primary will cure two ills of the current system: patronage and issueless contests for nomination.

title: Making It Easy For Yourself
description: EASY IS A LOVELY WORD. AMONG ITS DICTIONARY DEFINI-tions one finds even nicer words: ''free from constraint,'' ''comfortable,'' ''carefree,'' ''unhurried.'' All evocative of what a summer should be. And how a host or hostess should feel about summer entertaining. But the reality is that most of us look on a summer party as a chore - the beach beckons, the hammock lures, the dolce far niente of warm months takes over and sociability goes on hold until fall. Nevertheless, with good planning and the spice of invention, summer get-togethers can be all that the word easy implies. Takeout foods make a fast and elegant meal after a busy workday. Giving your dinner party in a restaurant may cost a touch more - but it's a lot less work. Inviting your guests to show off their culinary talents in your kitchen is another idea (remember, however, that guests seldom do the cleanup). Or you can take a group off for a day's outing and a classic picnic. This issue is packed with ideas for summer gatherings. Choose one that suits you, do it well and you'll have a festive and successful party. Do it very well and you'll find there's even time for a good read in the hammock.

title: A SEAFARING PAST PRESERVED
description: One kind of museum more than any other reflects New England's heritage: museums connected with the sea.

title: Gorbachev Outpolls Reagan in West Germany
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, is more popular and credible in West Germany than President Reagan, according to a flurry of recent opinion polls.

title: AS PRO-AQUINO VOTE RISES, FOES ARE 'STUNNED'
description: Legislative candidates backed by President Corazon C. Aquino consolidated their lead today, and their opponents appeared uncertain on how to press a threatened protest.

title: A BLEND OF DRAMATIST AND PROPHET
description: ''YOU can be either a prophet or a rabbi - but not both.'' Melvin Cooperman of East

title: LAUGHING ALL THE WAY TO THE PIGGY BANK
description: THE ANGEL AND THE SOLDIER BOY Written and illustrated by Peter Collington. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $9.95. (All ages)

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LOVE IS COLDER THAN DEATH: The Life and Times of Rainer Werner Fassbinder. By Robert Katz. (Random House, $19.95.) Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the wunderkind German film director and a heavy cocaine user, died of a stroke in 1982, at the age of 37. Encouraged by a Fassbinder intimate (''You should write a book.

title: Baseball Marks Fall
description: IT was just a routine single that made little difference in Oklahoma State's 18-14 victory over Oklahoma Friday night, but it made a big difference to Robin Ventura, the Cowboy sophomore who rapped out the hit in the sixth inning. It marked the 48th straight game in which he had hit safely, breaking a collegiate record set by Phil Stephenson with Wichita State in 1981.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Treading water is not making the shoreline.'' Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the Speaker of the House, on the slight decline in the trade gap.

title: No Welcome for Prodigal Barge
description: If there is a world record for distance traveled to take out the garbage, Lowell Harrelson has probably broken it.

title: Betty Symington Becomes a Bride
description: At the Old Southeast Church in Brewster, N.Y., Betty Welsh Symington and Michael Jacob Sonnenfeld were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert L. Tate, rector of Christ Episcopal Church on Capitol Hill in Washington.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lake Forest, Ill.;
The Mystery Of the Manor
description: LEAD: AFTER being vacant for 46 years, one of suburban Chicago's most mysterious properties has been sold to a local businessman who intends to restore the house and grounds and make it his principal residence.

title: AFTER 112 YEARS, A VILLAGE DEBATES ITS NAME
description: LEAD: ''I'M really not in favor of changing the name - it's been North Tarrytown as far back as I can remember,'' Marilyn Bregman said as she finished ringing up a sale at Ross Hardware, a store on Beekman Avenue in North Tarrytown.

title: IRAN CONTRA AFFAIR: THE UNFOLDING STORY
description: Testimony by Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, dominated not only last week's Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair, but also the attention of White House strategists. Highlights of the week's developments follow. * Mr. McFarlane said he had briefed the President ''dozens'' of times on the Administration's secret efforts to funnel private aid to Nicaraguan rebels. Mr. Reagan, who had previously implied lack of knowledge about details of the program, acknowledged that he was ''very definitely involved'' in it. But he insisted he did not know that profits from the sale of arms to Iran had been diverted to the contras. * Mr. McFarlane said Mr. Reagan personally approved a secret plan, ultimately unsuccessful, to pay $2 million in ransom for American hostages in Lebanon. Mr. Reagan said he did not recall any ransom plan but might have approved hiring rescuers. * Mr. McFarlane said he believed William J. Casey, the late Director of Central Intelligence, regularly gave instructions to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. And he conceded that he had not given a ''full account'' of the affair to Congress last year. * The President acknowledged that he and King Fahd discussed Saudi Arabia's secret aid to the contras when the King visited Washington in 1985. But Mr. Reagan said that it was the King who brought up the subject. * The White House said Mr. Reagan had a Constitutional right to conduct the nation's foreign policy, including provision of aid to the contras, despite the laws in place from 1983 to 1985 that restricted such aid. * Robert Owen said that, as a courier between Colonel North and contra leaders, he carried envelopes full of cash from a White House safe, C.I.A. maps and Colonel North's tactical advice about military strikes. * An hour after Mr. Owen asserted that Johnathan S. Miller, a mid-level White House aide, had helped him make payments to contra leaders, Mr. Miller resigned from his job. * Senate investigators said they had located $10 million that was donated to the contras by the Sultan of Brunei and was reported to have been mislaid. Colonel North had transposed two numbers in making the electronic transfer of funds, and a Swiss businessman had found an unexpected $10 million in his account. He returned the money.

And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE EXILE, by William Kotzwinkle. (Seymour Lawrence/Dutton, $17.95.) In this novel of bitter laughter and plain fun, Mr. Kotzwinkle, incarnated here as a Hollywood satirist, uses stylish shadings of black humor to draw a fantasy of wartime Nazi Germany and Jungian speculation on themes of the double. STORMING THE MAGIC KINGDOM: Wall Street, the Raiders, and the Battle for Disney, by John Taylor. (Knopf, $18.95.) The feud between the Disney brothers, Roy and Walt, led to a corporate house divided. Roy Jr.'s successful fight to repair the split and clean out Mickey and Goofy's home on Dopey Drive in Burbank, Calif., is a tale of raw corporate power. FIVE HUNDRED SCORPIONS, by Shelby Hearon. (Atheneum, $18.95.) A bittersweet marital comedy, witty, fast-paced and benign, in which the struggle between the demonic and the domestic denies neither and intensifies both. ANNE FRANK REMEMBERED: The Story of the Woman Who Helped to Hide the Frank Family, by Miep Gies with Alison Leslie Gold. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Miep Gies, in a book of immaculate witness, insists that under the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands she and those like her were ordinary. WALKING DISTANCE, by Marian Thurm. (Random House, $16.95.) A willful warding off of adulthood is elevated to a somewhat dubious state of grace in this first novel about a deliriously tortured relationship. THE ORTON DIARIES, edited by John Lahr. (Harper & Row, $19.95.) The extinction of Joe Orton's scoffing, anarchic talent had a terrible inevitability, and the diary proves it. TAKING AMERICA: How We Got From the First Hostile Takeover to Megamergers, Corporate Raiding, and Scandal, by Jeff Madrick. (Bantam, $19.95.) An adroit tracing of the merger movement and its impact on the way big business is controlled and operated, while all the time the pots at the end of the rainbow are increasing exponentially.

title: Julie Freundlich Becomes a Bride
description: Julie Beth Freundlich, a partner in the New York graphics design firm Dekker Freundlich Babian, and Julius Francis Lang Jr., an associate in the New York law firm Shearman & Sterling, were married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations in Manhattan. Rabbi Burt Siegel and the Rev. George Kuhn, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: A Dog And His Man
description: What a lovely, deeply affecting piece of writing, and what a lovely man. How fortunate that fate brought Ben Stein and Trixie together at the animal orphanage.

title: MY MOTHER'S MYSTERY
description: WHEN MY MOTHER DIED, shortly before her 74th birthday, the only possession of hers that I carried back from California was a Memory Book I found in her closet which she had begun assembling in 1928 while still in high school in Oswego, Kan. I was surprised to recognize her familiar script under photos of a skinny girl in laced shoes, shapeless frocks and oversized hair bows, and I took the album on a whim to show my children a more sympathetic side of the grandmother they had known only as a rather stern dowager with silver hair.

title: Commercial Property: Transforming the West 100's; Chic Begins to Blossom on Broadway North of 96th
description: ANY day now, a plywood construction shell around the first floor of a Broadway apartment building at 105th Street will be torn down, revealing a new mahogany-and-marble restaurant.

title: GANDHI, ATTACKING THE U.S., SAYS WEST UNDERMINES INDIA
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, in some of his toughest criticism of the United States and Western nations, charged today that recent attacks on his political leadership were a part of a campaign by ''foreign forces'' to undermine India's democracy.

title: ROCK: CHRIS ISAAK SINGS
description: SOME rock singers try everything; some specialize. Chris Isaak, the singer who came to the Bottom Line Tuesday, has narrowed his specialty to a subsection of a subgenre - rockabilly-tinged, minor-key songs about deceitful lovers. It's a surprise when he breaks into a major key; it's a shock when he straps on an accordion to sing the Louis Jordan hit ''Caledonia Boogie.'' But for the most part, he stays true to his specialty, and with his four-piece band, Silvertone, he makes his subgenre sound like a full-blown style.

title: AUTO INSURANCE TAKES ON A NEW POLITICAL LIFE
description: THE State Senate guaranteed last week that automobile insurance would be a major issue in the fall elections. It amended legislation that would have limited an injured motorist's right to sue in return for some savings in premiums.

title: New Repair Yard Is Opened
description: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company opened its $13.7 million repair yard today to trains on the Harlem line. The 63,000-square-foot center in Putnam County, 52 miles north of Grand Central Terminal in New York City, was built on the site of a smaller diesel repair shop made obsolete with the introduction of electric trains on the Upper Harlem line in June 1984. The new shop was part of the $82 million project to install the electric trains.

title: MOUNTAIN CRAFTS OF THEW ADIRONDACKS
description: Some of the most intriguing trails in the Adirondack Mountains lead to the many crafts studios and shops nestled among the peaks and valleys. They range from rustic workshops hidden down dirt roads to the spacious new Adirondack North Country Crafts Center in Lake Placid. Besides the predictable woodcarvers and guideboat builders, you can find paper makers, clothing designers, silversmiths and potters among the artisans. Mirroring the mountains' qualities, their crafts are lovely but strong. The creators are independent people who often are as colorful as their work.

title: IN DEATH, AS IN LIFE, CASEY STIRS STRONG FEELINGS
description: To the Editor:
