title: SKIDDING METS FALL TO GIANTS, 5-4
description: Any way you look at it, these are bad times for the Mets. And they worsened last night before 48,128 fans, the largest Shea Stadium crowd of the season.

title: Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: OSSINING DIRECTOR IN HIS FINALE
description: FOR nearly half of the 50 years that the Ossining Choral Society has performed in the county, the man at the podium has been the pianist and conductor Vladimir Havsky. So there is a special feeling attached to his final concert as music director at 3:30 P.M. today in the Ossining High School auditorium.

title: IN CHARLESTON, A 20TH-CENTURY PRESERVATION BATTLE
description: In this city renowned for its well-tended colonial history and rows of carefully restored antebellum mansions, the battle over historical preservation has moved for the first time into the 20th century.

title: TOUCHING THE 19th-CENTURY ADIRONDACKS
description: ''The Sunday Rock was the rock everybody passed on their way into the park, on their way into the Adirondack wilderness back in the old days. Once they passed that rock, Sunday could be Wednesday, Tuesday could be Saturday. You lost account of time. It didn't matter, because once you were in the woods, you were on a different time, in a different frame of mind, everything. That rock became known as the Sunday Rock, because when you went in, it was always Sunday, and when you came out, it was always Sunday.''

title:
GARDENING;
IN PRAISE OF THE MANY SPLENDORED ROSE
description: LEAD: AS you may know, the rose was recently declared our national flower. This was not a spur of the moment decision: the debate began back in the 1950's when Senator Everett Dirksen of Illinois, supported by David Burpee of the W.Atlee Burpee Seed Company, proposed the marigold for that honor. One might say that Mr.

title: Midblock Oasis: Gift of Sunlight
description: In 1971, a vest-pocket retreat known as Greenacre Park was carved out of the East 51st Street block between Second and Third Avenues. It has trees, a waterfall and a sculptured fountain, and it has become a neighborhood delight. But in recent years, high-rise development in the area has threatened to throw shadows over this midblock oasis.

title: Survey Planned on How Churches Use Money
description: Seven cents of every dime that Americans donate to charity goes to religious groups and their schools, hospitals and institutions. Now the Independent Sector, the country's largest philanthropic coalition, is trying to find out how this money is used.

title: 'JOURNEY TO HINDOOSTAN' AT UCONN'S BENTON
description: FEADING Edmund Wilson on the subject of Rudyard Kipling, George Orwell was amazed to find how much of the Anglo-Indian mystique, ''so boringly familiar'' to the British, was ''barely intelligible to an American.''

title: DYSLEXIC STUDENT SEEKING NEW GRADE
description: LEAD: CHRISTOPHER BROWN of Massapequa is a 24-year-old biology major at Nassau Community College who has a hidden handicap. He has dyslexia, a learning disability that typically causes sufferers to transpose letters and words.

title: MORE PATIENTS ARE STOCKING BLOOD FOR THEIR OWN USE
description: LEAD: SURGICAL patients worried they might receive AIDS-contaminated blood are, in increasing numbers, having their own blood drawn for use in surgery, say officials at the American Red Cross in Connecticut and at the blood banks of hospitals in the state.

title: THATCHER PLEDGING MORE OF THE SAME STERN STUFF
description: WHEN she called a general election for June 11, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher made it clear she was not thinking of serving a few more years and retiring to her garden. ''This is only the third term we are asking for. There is quite a long way to go,'' she said, hinting that the year 2000 might be a nice time to step down.

title: THE NEED FOR GIVING TO COLLEGES HAS GROWN
description: The article ''On Campus, a Boom in Giving'' [ April 26 ] accurately recognized that donations have been increasing as alumni and individuals become aware of needs and the fund-raisers become more sophisticated. There are two other areas of note. First, it is important to understand the role of corporations and foundations. Fairfield University, for example, raised a school record $3.3 million in 1985-86 and has already surpassed that figure this academic year.

title: PAYING FOR COLLEGE
description: 'There was a time when families would make major sacrifices to pay for children's college...The available evidence shows that the ability to pay for college is more or less the same. It's not clear that people are as willing to do so.' - Terry W. Hartle chief education adviser, Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources

title: LEGISLATOR'S STAND ON DISCLOSURE
description: The article ''Officials Criticize Disclosure Proposal'' on April 12 contains false and misleading statements that I feel compelled to address.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
FALLING IN LOVE WITH A GHOST
description: LEAD: THE TRICKSTERS By Margaret Mahy. 266 pp. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. $12.95. (Ages 14 and up)

title: GIVING THE SERVICE ECONOMY A BUM RAP
description: IN the last 10 years or so, the service economy has earned such a bad name that its apologists have resorted to a series of synonyms to describe it, including ''information'' economy, ''knowledge'' economy, and most recently, ''new'' economy.

title: GROSSE POINTE TREMBLES AS MANSION IS STRIPPED
description: There were tremors along the elm-lined lawns of this courtly Detroit suburb this week as collectors, builders and ordinary homeowners dismantled one of the town's stateliest mansions, even stripping its oak floors and bronze door knockers.

title: EARTH DAY'S VISION: A LONG WAY TO GO
description: THE first Earth Day in New Jersey - April 22, 1970 -served notice to government and industry that the environmental cause had, indeed, become a mass movement. All over the Garden State, campus organizations and citizens' groups launched cleanup campaigns, recycling projects, educational forums and public rallies.

title: BOSTON HOSPITALS BATTLE STATE'S MOVE TO TAKE OVER THE POLICING OF DOCTORS
description: Eight Boston-area hospitals have filed suit to block new regulations that empower a state medical licensing agency to evaluate the performance of doctors.

title: GRADUATION CEREMONY SAVED
description: FOR months, members of the Newington High School Class of '87 had looked forward to graduating at the Hartford Civic Center on June 18. Then came the bad news: because of ''snow days'' - days on which schools were closed because of snow - that had to be made up, the seniors would not complete the state-mandated 180 school days until June 19 and, thus, could not graduate until that day.

title: Not Chun or Chunism, but Democracy
description: The decision by South Korea's President Chun Doo Hwan to end negotiations with the opposition on a new system of government, and to proceed with a presidential election on the basis of the existing Constitution, could jeopardize South Korea's future and impair vital American interests in Asia.

title: THE BARGAINS IN A BAD MORTAGE MARKET
description: THE April leap in mortgage interest rates did more than raisemonthly paments for new borrowers; it also damaged a pulic confidence in affordable rates that had been building since the autumn of 1984, when rates began their 30-month decline - from 14.5 to 9.25 percent. Uncertainty has re-entered the mortgage marketplace and that hurts both home buyers and sellers.

title: INSIDE
description: Key Witness Gets Immunity The prosecutor in the Iran-contra case has granted immunity to Robert C. Dutton, a retired Air Force colonel who helped supply private aid for the Nicaraguan rebels and who reportedly knows many details. Page 15. Inquiry on Atlanta Mayor

title: BOOKED FOR THE SUMMER
description: FORGET the gold that was discovered in Cobalt last year; the hottest commodity in Connecticut this summer is waterfront rentals. They are almost impossible to find and more costly than ever.

title: TELEVISION NEWS AND THE CONGRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Strawberry Brunet
description: ''Womanizer'' achieved more fame, but another word apparently vital to the spirit of Gary Hart's weekend with Donna Rice was ''blonde.''

title: Next Week; Has Auto Racing Become Too Dangerous?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
REACH IS TARGETING THE WRONG PEOPLE
description: LEAD: THE REACH plan of Drew Altman, Commissioner of the state's Department of Human Services, which expands employment and educational opportunities for welfare recipients (''On Changing the Welfare System,'' Opinion Page, March 8), aims to help people get off the welfare rolls. (REACH stands for Realizing Economic Achievment.) Dr.

title: Drug Testing For Police Force
description: ''I THINK all police officers should be drug tested,'' Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said. It was, he said in June 1986, ''absolutely'' a priority of the force in New York City.

title: Susan Cauffman Becomes a Bride In Pennsylvania
description: Susan Vinson Cauffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Cauffman of Berwyn, Pa., was married yesterday to David Gardner Butterworth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Butterworth of Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Stephen K. Jacobson, assisted by the Revs. Lewis and Joy Mills, performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne.

title: Developers Confront The Past
description: ON the wide-open spaces of Albuquerque's west side of the Rio Grande, developers are facing a challenge from the past: Public awareness of the city's rich archeology is raising preservation issue sthat could interfere with growth.

title: Philanthropy?
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: CONSHOHOCKEN, PA.;
The Fast Lane To Boom Town
description: LEAD: HARD-HIT in the 1970's by the closing of steel mills and rubber factories, this blue-collar borough about 10 miles west of Philadelphia has suddenly found itself in the midst of a building boom traced to the development of interstate highways.

title: L.I. SOUND BACKED IN CONGRESS
description: RECOGNIZING the need for regional political cooperation in the drive to make the nation's waterways safe for swimming and fishing, members of Congress from Connecticut, New York and Rhode Island have formed a Congressional Long Island Sound Caucus.

title:
MUSIC;
JUNE OPERA FESTIVAL WIDENS PROGRAM
description: LEAD: THE summer season of the June Opera Festival of New Jersey will include four performances of ''The Barber of Seville,'' three of ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' and a concert of ''Dramatic Scenes for Solo Voice.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: LITHOGRAPHS OF THE 1800's

title: L. Edwin Sproul 3d Wed To Jodi Dana Goldstein
description: Jodi Dana Goldstein and L.Edwin Sproul 3d, 1982 graduates of Ithaca College, were married last evening at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains by Rabbi Douglas Krantz.

title: THE NEW IRON RAGE
description: CAST-IRON FURNITURE RE-splendent with intricate patterns of ferns, grape vines, morning glories or ivy epitomized the 19th-century Iron Age, when burgeoning industrialization made ornate, mass-produced furniture plentiful and well-priced for the growing middle class. Those interested in buying outdoor furniture and ornaments today are again gravitating toward these decorative designs. ''As gardening has become increasingly popular, old-fashioned garden furniture as well as architectural ornaments are finding their way into country or suburban backyards, city gardens, terraces and even interiors,'' says Cynthia Beneduce, co-owner of Beneduce & Lozell, the Manhattan antiques store. Gil Shapiro, co-owner of a shop named Urban Archaeology, agrees: ''Years ago, we couldn't give cast-iron furniture away; now, we can't keep it in stock.''

title: TV FILMS GROW UP AT LAST
description: SCORNED AND RIDICULED FOR TWO decades, the made-for-TV movie now gives every indication of being ready to confound the smirkers.

title: A Dog And His Man
description: I realize that men have become more ''sensitive,'' but Ben Stein's article ''Life With Trixie'' gives sensitivity a bizarre name. We're all familiar with the adage about dog being man's best friend, but whoever heard of dog becoming man's preferred companion? It's embarrassing to hear Mr. Stein describe ''what it feels like to hold Trixie.'' BRADLEY B. BRIGHAM Colrain, Mass.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: Bobby Short at the Cafe Carlyle View Video. 75 minutes. $29.95.

title: Toxics in L.I. Sound Traced to Sewage Plants
description: Large amounts of toxic metals in the waters of Long Island Sound can be traced to discharges from sewage treatment plants, a Federal study has found.

title: U.S. PRESSES VOUCHER PLAN AS A RENT AID
description: COMMUNITIES in the county are being urged by the Federal Government to use a new rent-subsidy system that could make more housing available to homeless and low-income people but that would require them to pay more than the 30 percent of their income they are paying now in rent.

title: THE CHALLENGE OF CHILDREN'S HISTORY MAKING IT VIVID, GETTING IT RIGHT
description: REVIEWING 10 current books on the American Revolution and the Constitution was, for this professor, too often like grading mediocre student exams.

title: PIANO: JOHN KAMITSUKA
description: AS winner of the Mary Mulligan Award, given by the Abby Whiteside Foundation, John Kamitsuka, a pianist, appeared in recital at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday evening. He walked out on crutches, the result of a torn Achilles' tendon. The injury seemed not to bother the pianist, but did prevent him from using the soft pedal. That, no doubt, added to the impression of him as an artist for whom color and subtlety of shading are not of primary concern.

title: NEW YORK STATE REJECTS PLAN TO GIVE DRUG USERS NEEDLES
description: State health authorities have refused to let New York City officials give needles and syringes to drug users as part of a test project to stem the spread of AIDS.

title: HAIR IN THE SUN
description: THE SUN DRIES AND BLEACHES THE HAIR and leaves permanently waved, colored or chemically straightened hair weak and brassy, but these are superficial concerns compared with the health hazards that the sun poses to skin.

title: NEAR COLLISIONS OF AIRCRAFT AMONG SIGNS OF SAFETY CRISIS, MANY EXPERTS SAY
description: A safety crisis is brewing in the American airline industry, many aviation experts say, citing warning signs that flight disasters could be imminent.

title: RICHARD M. CLARK
description: Richard McConnell Clark, chairman of the Department of Theatre Arts at Ithaca College in Ithaca, N.Y., was among the 183 people killed in the crash of a LOT Polish airlines plane near Warsaw on May 9 while en route to New York, the college reported Thursday. He was 51 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: THE SWEDISH QUANDRY: ARMS DEALS OR PACIFISM?
description: For years, the Swedish Government has been a vocal champion of peace and disarmament, a stand that is a source of national pride. But today Sweden finds itself embroiled in an arms-trading scandal that raises questions about its adherence to its stated principles and underlines the ''Swedish paradox'' of a pacifist country with a thriving weapons industry dependent on exports.

title: PROBLEMS OF HOMELESS ARE FELT BY MANY
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY has a serious homeless problem -and it is not just the homeless who are feeling the impact. From the homeowner facing higher county taxes to meet the budget demands created by the emergency needs of the homeless - to the residents living in the local communities that have become sites of homeless shelters and motels - virtually every Westchester resident is affected.

title: HOME VIDEO: CHILDREN
description: The Littlest Outlaw Starring Pedro Armendariz, Andres Velasques, Joseph Calleia, Rodolfo Acosta. Produced by Larry Lansburgh. 1954. Walt Disney Home Video. 73 minutes. $69.95.

title: A GUEST'S GUIDE TO BRINGING WINE
description: WHEN SUMMER WEEKENDS come around, the people who own vacation homes give invitations. The rest of us accept them, put down the phone and say to each other, ''We'd better bring them something.''

title: DANCE: A NEW WORK FROM SUSAN RETHWORST
description: SUSAN RETHORST works with the kind of small, slippery phrases that identify the dance of Trisha Brown. In ''What She Knew,'' a new piece by Ms. Rethorst presented on Thursday at the Kitchen, those phrases are as discrete as words in conversation. And the ''words'' build up to a murmured conversation through which ideas, history and evocative imagery dart like quick, colorful little fish. There is more than a touch, too, of Virginia Woolf in this elusive summoning-up of the home,women's friendships and familial bonds.

title: DR. SIDNEY COHEN, 76, DEAD: STUDIED MOOD-ALTERING DRUGS
description: Dr. Sidney Cohen, a leading authority on marijuana, LSD and other mood altering drugs, died of heart failure at his Los Angeles home on May 8. He was 76 years old.

title: New Delhi Takes Control in Punjab
description: The Government of India removed the moderate Sikh leadership of the Punjab last week and assumed direct command of the campaign to curb terrorist attacks by Sikh extremists in the northern state.

title: ANGUISHED YOUTHS GET REASSURING HUG
description: LEAD: A BROWN-HAIRED girl in skintight Levis and Reeboks speaks haltingly of how she came close to suicide after the death of her best friend. Nobody understood how she felt, she said.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: VERMONT CRAFTS FESTIVAL

title: Cindy A. Sikorski Engaged to Marry E. E. F. Stebbins
description: A June 27 wedding is planned by Cindy Ann Sikorski and Edwin Ellis Flood Stebbins. The future bride is the daughter of Mrs. Joseph Charles Sikorski of Delray Beach, Fla., and Silvermine, Conn., who has announced her engagement, and the late Mr. Sikorski. Her fiance is a son of James F. Stebbins of Muttontown, L.I., and Mrs. Andrew M. Blum of New York.

title: THE SEASON FOR SETTING OUT PLANTS HAS COME
description: WHAT a glorious spring. The lawn has never been greener. Tree blossoms are clouds of pink with the flowers of crabapples, flowering cherries and dogwoods. Lilacs are in bloom. Tulips are showing off their regal petals in shades of yellow, orange, red and almost blue. Even the last daffodils shimmer.

title: Science, Technology And AIDS
description: As always, Stephen Jay Gould casts biological issues in a stimulating perspective (''The Terrifying Normalcy of AIDS,'' April 19). However, I believe anyone writing about AIDS should explain that geometric progression works both ways. That is, any interruption or short circuit in this exponential expansion in the numbers of future AIDS victims will create an exponential shrinkage.

title: COLLEGES, BIG AND SMALL, BID FAREWELL TO CLASS OF '87
description: LEAD: THE comedian Bill Cosby; John B. Anderson, the 1980 Presidential candidate, and the conservative columnist William F. Buckley Jr. are among the speakers who are addressing college and university graduates in the state over the next month.

title: MAN'S RELATIONSHIP WITH NEW CARS IS MORE THAN SKIN DEEP
description: THERE are certain dreads that must be universal among men: the dread of turning and running from the first danger on the battlefield, the dread that a desirable woman will look you straight in the eye and whisper, ''Not so long as you shall live,'' and the dread of the first scratch on your brand-new automobile.

title: Subversive Fun
description: BLONDE VENUS Starring Marlene Dietrich (in photo), with Herbert Marshall, Cary Grant, Dickie Moore. Directed by Josef von Sternberg, based on his story. 1932. MCA Home Video. 89 minutes. $29.95.

title: LOVE THAT DARE
description: YOU HAVE BEEN grievously misinformed about the love that dare not speak its name.

title: Robinson Top Prize
description: For the second time in three years, the ultimate prize in the National Basketball Association's draft lottery will be well worth the season of ineptitude endured by each team that qualified for the drawing.

title: CULT LEADERS ACCUSED OF LOAN FRAUD
description: LEAD: A THREE-YEAR investigation by the State Attorney General culminated last week in the unsealing of indictments charging the leader and two members of a cult with running a student-loan fraud.

title: Cable TV
description: Cable's worthy film fare this week is topped by two premieres of 1986 films - Eugene Corr's ''Desert Bloom'' and Federico Fellini's ''Ginger and Fred.'' There's also a Fellini bonus of ''Variety Lights,'' ''The White Sheik'' and ''La Strada.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Soccer Title to Coventry City: Tottenham Hotspur's Gary Mabbutt put the ball into his own net six minutes into overtime to give Coventry City a 3-2 victory yesterday in the Football Association Cup final. It was the first F.A. Cup title won by Coventry in its 104-year history and the first-ever loss in a final for Tottenham, which shares the record of seven cup victories with Aston Villa. A capacity crowd of 100,000 fans saw Mabbutt, an England national team defender who had a part in one of Tottenham's goals, turn a center from Coventry's Lloyd McGrath into his own net after six minutes of overtime.(AP) St. Mirren Takes Scottish Cup: St. Mirren upset Dundee United, 1-0, after extra time yesterday to win the Scottish Cup at Hampden Park in Glasgow. Ian Ferguson scored in the 111th minute as St. Mirren won the trophy for only the third time in its history. St. Mirren, a Scottish Premier Division team, captured its first major trophy since 1959.(AP) College Baseball Seton Hall Wins Title: Seton Hall rallied with five runs in the eighth inning to capture the Big East Conference tournament yesterday with a 10-9 victory over Villanova in Bristol, Conn. The Pirates (44-8) rallied from a 7-5 deficit to tie the score on run-scoring singles by Maurice Vaughn and Marteese Robinson. After loading the bases, Jeff Riggs singled in a run to break the tie. Seton Hall gained an automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. World Series. Villanova (35-19) completed its best season in history. Villanova, earlier in the day, eliminated St. John's, 12-2.(AP) Fordham Gains: Fordham (30-11) advanced to the championship round of the E.C.A.C. Division I tournament by defeating top-seeded C. W. Post, 8-4, yesterday in New Britain, Conn., as Art McCormick picked up his eighth victory of the season. By winning their third straight game of the double-elimination tournament, the second-seeded Rams earned the right to meet New York Tech, a 10-5 winner last night over C. W. Post (27-13-1) in the championship game. Both games will be today, with the champion advancing to the first round of the N.C.A.A regionals.(AP) Boxing Lacair Takes Title: Santos Laciar of Argentina stopped the defending champion, Gilberto Roman of Mexico, on cuts in the 11th round yesterday in Reims, France, to win the World Boxing Council superflyweight title. Roman, defending the title for the seventh time, was cut below the left eye in the fourth round. In the 11th round, Laciar stung Roman with a right and a left. Referee Angelo Poletti stopped the fight and the ringside doctor did not allow the champion to continue. (AP) Duran Wins on Decision: Roberto Duran, making another comeback attempt, won a unanimous decision over Victor Claudio of Puerto Rico tonight in a 10-round fight in Miami Beach. The 36-year-old Duran, whose record is 80-7, was fighting for the first time since losing a split decision to Robbie Sims on June 23, 1986. Duran had lost six of his previous 13 bouts. But he opened a cut over Claudio's left eye in the third round. Duran had to reduce to 164 pounds for the fight.(AP) Knockout for Shavers: Earnie Shavers ducked frequently and punched sparingly for a second-round knockout last night in what he hoped was the start of a comeback toward a heavyweight title bout. The 42-year-old Shavers floored unheralded Larry Simms, 36, with a body blow and an uppercut at 1:30 of the second round. Shavers improved his record to 68-15-1 with his 65th career knockont. Shavers reportedly weighed in at 223 pounds. A roll of flesh hung over the waistband of his purple and gold trunks. (AP) Dogs Wire Fox Terrier Is Best: Ch. Galsul Excellence, the Irish-bred wire fox terrier handled by Peter Green for Joyce and William MacKay and Ruth Cooper, was named best of 1,442 dogs yesterday at the 81st all-breed show of the Ladies Kennel Association of America at Hofstra. It was the 83d top award for Paddy, and the third time he was named best in a week, having scored at Chester Valley and Lancaster last weekend.(AP) Water Polo U.S. Tops Cuba: The United States held off a second-half challenge to defeat Cuba, 8-7, and moved into a tie for third place with West Germany yesterday in the World Cup tournament in Salonica, Greece. Kevin Robertson and Craig Klass scored two goals apiece for the Americans, and James Bergeson, Greg Boyer, Terry Schroeder and Mike Evans added one each. In other games, the unbeaten Soviet Union rallied to defeat Spain, 11-9, and tie Yugoslavia for first place; Italy edged previously unbeaten West Germany, 8-7, and Yugoslavia routed Greece, 12-4, in the eight-team, round-robin competition, which ends Sunday.(AP) Track and Field Lindgren Returns: Gerry Lindgren, who had been living under an assumed name, made his first competitive appearance under his real name in seven years last night at the Oregon Twilight track and field meet. The 41-year-old Lindgren finished 11th in the Legends' Mile, an event for runners over 40. Web Loudatwon in 4:20.89. Lindgren disappeared seven years ago, when he left his wife, three children and a bankrupt athletic footwear business. He was discovered running under the name of Gale Young in Honolulu last October.(AP) Decker-Slaney Delays Return: Jackie Joyner-Kersee won two events and Greg Foster took the high hurdles at yesterday's Pepsi Invitational meet in Los Angeles, but Mary Decker-Slaney's heralded return was delayed. Scheduled for her first major competition since taking a year and a half off for the birth of her first child, Decker-Slaney withdrew just before the mile. She said she felt soreness in her right Achilles' tendon, the one on which she had surgery last November. Joyner-Kersee scored her double in the long jump, with a leap of 22-7, and the 100-meter hurdles, with a hand-timed 12.6-second clocking. Foster won the 110-meter hurdles in 13.1, also hand-timed, as officials had intermittent problems with the electronic timing system.(AP)

title: 2 NEWSPAPERS BATTLING FOR 6,200 DOWN-EASTERS
description: In this coastal village of 6,200 people in the poorest county in New England, two weekly newspapers are in fierce competition, pitting longtime colleagues against one another.

title: Texas, 2 Cheers For Temperance
description: Texas, cowboy-and-pickup-truck division, continues to undergo deflation: As of Sept. 1, drinking at the wheel will no longer be permitted. The Legislature made the decision by voice vote, without opposition.

title: Pamela Mack Becomes Bride of John W. Mauer
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Hopewell, N.J., yesterday Pamela Etter Mack, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Duncan Mack of Ringoes, N.J., and Chatham, Mass., was married to John Walker Mauer, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Alton Mauer of Pasadena, Tex. The Rev. Catherine Snyder performed the ceremony.

title: ANDREW YOUNG SAID TO BE 'TARGET' OF U.S. GRAND JURY
description: Mayor Andrew Young is the target of a Federal grand jury here studying whether local officials sought to hinder an investigation into drug use involving former state Senator Julian Bond and other prominent Atlanta political figures, sources familiar with the inquiry say.

title: BARBECUING: A MANLY ART
description: WE WANT BURGERS AND WE want them now. We want them in all their cholesterolic glory, incinerated over an outdoor charcoal fire that gives them a nice dusting of ashes and a coating of benzopyrene, before we drown them in maroon barbecue sauce.

title:
ANTIQUES;
TRANSFORMING A PLAINFIELD CLERIC'S HOME
description: LEAD: KILIM upholstery? Model trains running on a lacquered track around the ceiling molding? A faux-bois floor in the servants' wing? An upholstered bathroom so completely dressed that the only porcelain left exposed is the rim and interior of a 1914 tub?

title: ALL ABOARD FOR A RIDE BACK TO THE 1920's
description: LEAD: Framed in the windows of the Valley Railroad's heavyweight Pullman parlor car are rolling hills, meadows, woodlands, tidal marshes and, finally, the broad reaches of the lower Connecticut River. Here and there is a white clapboard dwelling of New England styling. Marinas and boatyards, apparently the region's main industry, are everywhere.

title: Sid Fernandez Status Unclear
description: The Mets were told by their doctors last night that Sid Fernandez did not suffer cartilage damage in his left knee while pitching Friday night.

title: Stapley Wonham Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Stapley Wonham and David Merton Emberling took place yesterday at the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., with the Rev. Dr. Warren E. Ost, a Presbyterian minister, officiating. Diane Molleson was maid of honor, and James Warinsky was best man.

title: COAL MINERS' DAUGHTERS
description: IN COAL COUNTRY By Judith Hendershot. Illustrated by Thomas B. Allen. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 10) TROUBLE AT THE MINES By Doreen Rappaport. Illustrated by Joan Sandin. 85 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $11.50. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: PUTTING A KIWI IN EVERY LUNCH BOX
description: WHAT drives the marketers is the dream of finding the next kiwi, the Horatio Alger of exotic fruit.

title:
INVESTING;
THE RISKS OF SPECULATING ON DREAMS
description: LEAD: THEIR fans call them the companies of tomorrow - the next Syntex or Xerox. Detractors call them puff stocks - companies with billowing market valuations, but minimal sales, earnings or equity. What these companies have, usually, is a story about a marvelous product that promises to bring an explosion in earnings.

title: A GENERAL AND THE CONTRAS: MULES, AIR DROPS AND CASH
description: When the White House enlisted Richard V. Secord in 1985 to organize an airlift for the rebels fighting inside Nicaragua, he recalled, they were relying on mule trains to deliver their food, weapons and medicine.

title: Albany Discovers A Tax Windfall
description: Governor Cuomo announced Friday that an extra $850 million had turned up in checks attached to 1986 income-tax returns. As a result, administration officials said, the array of new taxes and fees proposed only two weeks earlier to raise $1 billion a year to rebuild roads and bridges could be deferred for at least a year.

title: Benefits Around the City
description: PARTY AT SARDI'S

title: Gotham's Groundhog
description: To the Editor:

title: HOBART SETS RECORD
description: Hobart defeated Ohio Wesleyan, 9-5, at Boswell Field today in a Division III lacrosse game that set a record for National Collegiate Athletic Association championships.

title: 'ALASKA! NEBRASKA! WHO ASKED YA?'
description: THE SHADOWMAKER By Ron Hansen. Illustrated by Margot Tomes. 66 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $10.95. (Ages 7 to 11)

title: NEWEST CASINO GETS OFF TO A FAST START WITH SLOTS
description: IN ITS first full month of operation last month, the Showboat Hotel-Casino led all of its Atlantic City competitors in slot-machine revenue and trailed only Caesars in total revenue.

title: THE POIGNANCY OF 'FALLING AWAY'
description: I would like to commend you on publishing Julia Aldrich's ''Falling Away, Here at Home'' [ Opinion Page, April 26 ] . The subject, a theme that makes most flinch and recoil, is one that is stark, sensitive reality - it moved me to tears.

title: An Outsider Riles the Locals
description: RIVAL builders say that a major Pennsylvania developer who broke ground last December for two housing developments in this hill country west of Wilmington not only paid too much for farmland, but is also trying to lure away employees with wages that they cannot afford to pay.

title: The Sporting Picnic
description: SUMMER IS A SEASON FOR RELAX-ation and excitement - lazy picnics and high-style adventure. The two can be combined in a sports outing for half- a-dozen people or so. There's a sense of exhilaration in being on a raft trip or aloft in a hot-air balloon. Or in just paddling your way to a leisurely picnic on a river bank.

title: A Capacity for Inflation
description: Inflation fears are growing despite the nation's industrial overcapacity, which has traditionally been seen as a form of insurance against price surges.

title: RAW OR BLANCHED VEGETABLES, COCKTAILS FOR 70
description: WHAT to serve at a large cocktail party? Spring vegetables are the answer at this time of year. Crudites - raw or blanched vegetables - are hardly new, but they are always popular, especially with the host or hostess who does not have to worry about taking sizzling trays out of the oven during the evening, or spending hours beforehand making complicated little things with puff pastry. Recently I served a heaping selection of asparagus spears (blanched), red and yellow pepper strips, cauliflower and broccoli florets, carrot sticks, cherry tomatoes, radishes and fennel, which was cut in thin slices. Baby vegetables such as zucchini (wonderful with their flowers intact, if you can find them) and other squash are also good, lightly blanched and served whole. Red cabbage or raddichio leaves and curly leaves of cabbage or kale make an attractive base for the display.

title: GIACOMETTI IN THE CONTEXT OF FAMILY AND VILLAGE
description: IN THE 20TH CENTURY THE ARTISTIC family has become almost obsolete. The notable exceptions are the Duchamps -Marcel, Jacques Villon, Raymond Duchamp-Villon and Suzanne Crotti - and the Giacomettis - the father, Giovanni; his second cousin, Augusto, and his three sons, Alberto, Diego and Bruno. Both families were raised in provincial settings: the Duchamps in Normandy, the Giacomettis in Italian Switzerland. Indeed it is probably only in a provincial setting, where values and traditions can be passed down and closely shared, that a family of artists is still possible.

title: PRESSING FORWARD, GETTING NOWHERE
description: LEAD: MORTAL SPLENDOR The American Empire in Transition. By Walter Russell Mead. 381 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

title: DRINKS WITH A PAST
description: IRVIN S. COBB ONCE SAID OF HIS FRIEND AND fellow writer H. L. Mencken, who liked a good drink, ''Any guy who'd put rye in a mint julep and crush the leaves would put scorpions in a baby's bed.''

title: SALVORS 'MULTILATED' SHIP, EXPERT SAYS
description: The salvaging of the 18th-century British warship deBraak effectively ''mutilated'' the hull and has denied archeologists valuable data on life aboard the legendary ship, a leading preservationist has charged.

title: NEIGHBORS SEEK TO BUY CLAM ISLAND
description: LEAD: NEIGHBORS, environmentalists and local officials have mounted an effort to purchase an ecologically sensitive parcel of land that for two years has been the focus of a protracted antidevelopment struggle.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THAT EYE, THE SKY. By Tim Winton. (Atheneum, $14.95.) If you don't know Australian slang you might stop reading this novel after coming upon words like ''ute'' (pickup truck or van), ''crook'' (sick or broken), ''bowser'' (gasoline pump), ''plonk'' (red wine) and ''dag'' (sloppy or slovenly person). That would be a shame because ''That Eye, the Sky'' is a thoroughly engaging story of childhood, tragedy and faith. The narrator, 12-year-old Morton Flack (''Ort for short''), lives in an isolated community of western Australia with his father, Sam; his mother, Alice; Sam's senile mother, Grammar; and his moody 16-year-old sister, Tegwyn. One summer morning, Sam Flack is nearly killed in an automobile accident. When he comes home brain-damaged and paralyzed, Ort and his mother must care for him without help from anyone. A sensitive boy, Ort becomes a beguiling figure as he attempts to make sense of the tragedy and of the unexpected appearance of a stranger, Henry Warburton. This onetime poet and drifter helps to nurse Sam and shares his version of the story of Jesus, which Ort recounts as follows: ''He can do crazy things like walk on water and then make it into plonk, make crook people better and dead people alive. People didn't like him because he was so good to them. They killed him by sticking him on a tree. They put him in a hole but he got up afterwards and went up into the sky with God.'' Tim Winton, a young Australian novelist whose previous work has won acclaim in his country, depicts without condescension the emotional crosscurrents of the Flack household. Toward the end of the novel Ort prays for a miracle: ''Funny when you talk to God. He's like the sky. . . . Never says anything. But you know he listens.'' Though God hasn't answered Ort yet, Mr. Winton convinces us he might.

title: 10 U.S. Students Win Churchill Scholarships
description: Ten American students have been awarded the 1987 Winston Churchill scholarships for graduate work in engineering, mathematics and the sciences at Cambridge University in England.

title: A Trade: Cable TV, Baseball

title: Comings and Goings
description: AFTER spending 14 acclaimed years as athletic director at North Dakota State, A. L. (Abe) Sponberg probably deserved a rest. What he got was a new job as athletic director at the University of Wisconsin. Sponberg, who replaces Elroy Hirsch, called the Wisconsin post ''the ultimate challenge.'' . . . Marques Kevin Johnson Jr., the 15-month-old son of the Los Angeles Clippers' star, Marques Johnson, was listed in very critical condition at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center yesterday after falling into a swimming pool at the Johnson home in Bel Air on Friday. A hospital spokesman said the child had arrived at the hospital in respiratory and cardiac arrest and was being treated in the pediatric intensive care unit. . . . The Chicago Cubs have acquired Mike Mason from the Texas Rangers for a player to be named, and the left-hander will join the team in Houston today. Mason has an 0-2 record and a 5.59 earned run average this season. . . . Paul Householder, a switch-hitting outfielder who was batting .274 at Tucson, has been brought up by the Astros.

title: ROCK: THE CAMEO BAND
description: CAMEO delivered a hyperkinetic hour of music Sunday at Radio City Music Hall - strutting, conga-lining, hip-swiveling, rapping and singing over a pile-driver funk beat. Larry Blackmon has led Cameo through 10 years and 12 albums, gradually dropping band members so the current group is simply three male singers - himself, Tomi Jenkins and Nathan Leftenant. But Cameo's current album, ''Word Up,'' is a multimillion-selling hit, and in Cameo's two shows Sunday the group was a 13-man band.

title: TOP BASSISTS ARE THE BOTTOM LINE IN JAZZ ENSEMBLES
description: PLAYING THE BASS IN YOUR own improvising ensemble can put you in the driver's seat, just as a certain rent-a-car agency claims to do. Of course, not every bassist wants to drive or is capable of handling a careering vehicle. Not every band wants to be driven, by the bassist or by anyone else. But the bass has special capabilities, and its role in the jazz ensemble has developed in a special manner. Bass provides the bottom, and the pulse. In freer musical situations, the bass probes and prods, working in tandem with the drummer's rhythmic embroidery while feeding harmonic and melodic material to the players of chordal and melody instruments. Only the bass fulfills this triple-threat, rhythmic-melodic-harmonic function. A bassist, especially one who is a composer and bandleader as well, can simultaneously ground and guide a performance of improvisational music as it unfolds.

title: THE OLD HOUSE: A LOT HAS CHANGED, BUT IT'S STILL THE SAME

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In their long, hostile and transcontinental rivalry, which team holds the edge, the Giants or the Dodgers? It's still the Giants, by a 30-game margin, even though the Dodgers have lowered the difference by 14 games since both clubs abandoned New York for California 30 years ago. Counting the 4-3 edge in victories for Los Angeles this season, the teams have played nearly 1,800 games to a decision since 1900, and the scoreboard reads: Giants 914, Dodgers 884. On the East Coast, New York was the leader over Brooklyn, 650 to 606. On the West Coast, Los Angeles leads San Francisco, 278 to 264. On both coasts, the Dodgers have won 17 pennants, the Giants 15, and each team has been a World Series winner five times. In this century, no team has beaten the Giants more than the Dodgers have, and no team has beaten the Dodgers more than the Giants have. QUESTION: Why do coaches in the National Basketball Association wear jackets and ties during games? It's a league rule, part of the N.B.A. dress code, for all head coaches and their assistants to wear sport coats or suit coats. Ties are not required, though, and this no-tie loophole not only spares open-collared coaches such as Doug Moe of the Denver Nuggets from being penalized, but also symbolizes the league's policy to play every game to a decision. That's right, no ties. QUESTION: A held ball is called in a basketball game between the Pistons and the Lakers after Isiah Thomas of Detroit ties up Kareem Abdul-Jabbar of the Lakers near midcourt in the closing seconds of a tie game. The resulting jump-ball situation is a mismatch, with Abdul-Jabbar more than a foot taller than Thomas. If Thomas is certain that the Laker center will win the tap and try to direct the ball to a teammate for a possible fast-break game-winning basket, can the Piston guard concede the tap to Abdul-Jabbar, fake it as if he were going to jump against him, and instead slip toward one of the Lakers' intended receivers in an attempt to intercept the anticipated tapped ball and prevent a fast break? He'd probably have nothing to lose doing it, since the mismatch is so pronounced, but he'd wind up losing anyway, since the rules on jump balls restrict the two jumpers from leaving the jumping circle before the ball is tapped. Once the violation is called, the Lakers would get the ball out of bounds at midcourt, and that might not be as much of a disadvantage for the Pistons. Now they could guard the Lakers man to man on the throw-in pass as well as have a player guarding the passer on the sideline without a height mismatch. QUESTION: Has an N.B.A. player ever made the all-league team every season he has played? Only Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics has ever achieved this, although Bob Pettit, the former St. Louis Hawks' star, came mighty close. In his rookie season of 1979-80, Bird was selected at forward to the five-man first team in the voting of basketball writers and broadcasters in league cities, and he has not missed since. If he's chosen again, as expected, when the team is announced next week, that will make it a string of eight straight seasons for Bird.

QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
YANKS STEAM ON; METS 6, GIANTS 4
description: It was too early to call it a revival, or even a comeback. Maybe a stirring, a rustling, a hint of something better. Whatever it was, the Mets revived at least their spirits yesterday when they beat the San Francisco Giants, 6-4, and won for the second time in three games.

title: Variety of Offerings Set This Week
description: Treasury financings this week consist of today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills, followed by the regular monthly sale of two-year notes on Wednesday.

title: DANCE: LINES COMPANY FROM SAN FRANCISCO
description: THE LINES DANCE COMPANY offered some good dancing and a conundrum on Saturday night in a New York debut season at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Founded in 1982 by Alonzo King, a ballet and modern dance performer, teacher and choreographer with wide-ranging credits, this San Francisco-based company is sleek and likable, and it arrived in New York with two winning guest artists from the San Francisco Ballet. But Mr. King's choreography can be a puzzle.

title: TELECALC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $54,000. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $4,000.

title: PROST TIES RECORD WITH 27TH VICTORY
description: Alain Prost of France tied Jackie Stewart's record of 27 Formula One victories, and regained the lead in the world championship standings today by capturing the Belgian Grand Prix.

title: Boston University
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court urged graduates of Boston University today to value their spare time. Justice Rehnquist ignored a sprinkling of protesters when he urged the graduates to place as much value on spare time as they do on work time.

title: Reinterpretation Cuts Both Ways
description: The Reagan Administration flirts with a reinterpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. The State Department has now issued a detailed legal argument favoring a controversial, more permissive reading. The way Reagan officials justify the reinterpretation may come back to haunt them -when and if they complete a treaty of their own on medium-range missiles.

title: THE CARTERS MAKE THE MOST OF A NEW LIFE
description: To hear Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter tell it, life could hardly have been worse in November 1980.

title: U.S. SAID TO LINK LATIN AID TO SUPPORT FOR CONTRAS
description: The Reagan Administration has used a variety of tactics, including pressure by American economic and military aid, to push Central American countries into supporting the Nicaraguan rebels, according to interviews with Central American officials and present and former American officials.

title: MAURY FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank went public in September.

title: NASA PLANS NEW USE OF DISPOSABLE ROCKETS
description: The space agency is moving to end its dependence on the shuttle and has developed plans for sending satellites into space on throwaway rockets in 1990 and 1991, according to its Administrator, James C. Fletcher.

title: NUMAC OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: BREAKWATER RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter earnings were determined after deducting $1,632,250 for depreciation and depletion of the company's investment in the Cannon Mine Joint Venture and $903,000 for deferred income taxes. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF LAW: BRENNAN ASKS THE WEALTHY TO SACRIFICE FOR THE NEEDY
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court, at a commencement address today, called for legal changes, higher taxes and sacrifice by ''the establishment'' to help the poor and ''achieve real equality.''

title: SHIFT OF '20/20' STIRS ANGER AT ABC
description: As the new managers of ABC have grappled with problems of declining revenues and shrinking audiences in the last 18 months, Roone Arledge and his news division have been valuable allies. ABC News has provided the network with low-cost programming and has quietly undergone cutbacks without the public discord that has attended cost-control efforts at NBC and CBS.

title: COUNCIL ELECTION SETUP ON BALLOT IN PITTSBURGH
description: Voters in the Tuesday primary will be asked to decide whether to change the way Pittsburgh City Council members are elected.

title: St. John's University
description: St. John's University awarded 969 undergraduate degrees yesterday at its commencement in Queens. The ceremonies began with a baccalaureate mass.

title: BALLET: SECONDARY PLAYERS
description: A BALLETIC treasure house, ''The Sleeping Beauty'' offers choreographic rewards for stars, soloists and corps de ballet members alike. Therefore it was interesting to watch interpreters of secondary roles in recent performances of the work by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Fernandez's Knee Is Sound
description: Not a bad afternoon for the Mets' riddled pitching staff. In the main event, David Cone lasted eight innings against the San Francisco Giants. And, in a crucial preliminary, Giants. And, in a crucial preliminary, Sid Fernandez did one knee bend in Cone drew cheers from the crowd of 46,744 in Shea Stadium for his performance. But Fernandez drew a smile and a high sign from Dr. Fiske Warren for his performance, which in the long run may prove just as important for the revival of the Mets' pitching.

title: Inflation Up in Canada
description: Price increases for a broad range of products and services pushed Canada's annual inflation rate to 4.5 percent in April, from 4.2 percent in March, Statistics Canada reported Friday. The Government agency said six of the seven main components of the index were higher, led by tobacco and alcohol, housing and gasoline. But food prices were unchanged, helping to temper the overall price advances. On a month-to-month basis, the Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent from March to April.

title: CAUTIOUS FED STANCE PREDICTED
description: The uneasiness in the long-term bond markets, where yields have increased 1 1/2 percentage points since late March, is sure to be discussed at tomorrow's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.

title: Pretoria Blocks a Visit by U.S. Foe of Apartheid
description: The South African Government has told the Rev. Leon Sullivan of Philadelphia, author of the Sullivan Code of conduct for American companies operating here, that he must cancel a planned visit to the country on May 24.

title: OPTO MECHANIK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Make Offers For H.M.O.
description: Two companies have offered to buy the nation's largest Medicare-certified health maintenance organization after a court declaration of insolvency, Bill Gunter, the Florida insurance commissioner, said Friday.

title: Challengers Upset By Lack of Cup Site
description: Potential challengers for the America's Cup are angry over what they perceive as foot-dragging by the San Diego Yacht Club and Dennis Conner's Sail America team in deciding where the next America's Cup campaign will be sailed.

title: LINEUP FOR INDY 500 UNEXPECTEDLY SLOW
description: A last-minute rush today filled the 33-car field for the Indianapolis 500, leaving a lineup slower than expected but loaded with the experience of a record nine former winners.

title: QMAX TECHNOLOGY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: PRAXIS BIOLOGICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TURNER REPORTS LOSS OF $39.7 MILLION FOR QUARTER
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. has reported a net loss of $39.7 million for the quarter ended March 31. That compares with a loss of $6.7 million, or 38 cents a share, for the comparable period last year. Revenues for the quarter rose to $137.9 million, from $86.6 million in the year-ago quarter.

title: AMERICAN MUSEUM OF HISTORIAL DOCUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: ACHING CELTICS GET BY BUCKS
description: The Boston Celtics, old, tired and aching, survived one of their more grueling tests today with a 119-113 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks in the deciding game of the Eastern Conference semifinal. Two points separated the teams in the seven-game series that included an overtime and a double-overtime game.

title: WHERE THE HIGH YEN HURTS
description: In the early 1980's, many American manufacturers, reeling under competitive pressures, cut back their production in the United States and began importing components, even entire products, from Japan.

title: THE STARS CELEBRATE HOLLYWOOD
description: THROWN together under the heading ''any excuse for a party,'' tonight's star-filled ''Happy Birthday Hollywood'' takes over, beginning at 8, all three hours of ABC's prime time. In the grand tradition of so many television spectaculars, this one is pointless, witless and almost touchingly absurd.

title: GUNNAR MYRDAL, ANALYST OF RACE CRISIS, DIES
description: Gunnar Myrdal, the Swedish economist and sociologist whose 1944 book, ''An American Dilemma,'' helped to destroy the ''separate but equal'' racial policy in the United States, died yesterday in a hospital in Sweden. He was 88 years old.

title: YANKS STEAM ON; YANKS 8, MARINERS 3
description: By the time Willie Randolph slapped a double into the right-field corner today, the game was already moving steadily toward its expected conclusion. Dan Pasqua had delivered a three-run homer in the fifth inning, Joe Niekro had tamed the Seattle Mariners after a shaky start, and the Yankees were moments away from extending their lead in the American League East to two games. Then came the fateful double. It bounced into the corner, and it seemed to give Claudell Washington, who was on first base, enough time to score. But he pulled a muscle in the left side of his groin rounding third base, collided with the catcher, Dave Valle, at the plate, and had to be helped into the clubhouse for treatment.

title: DREAM CATCHES UP TO FORMER CHAMPION
description: AS he tells his tale, his big, brown eyes radiate excitement. Sometimes, trying to find the exact English word slows him down, but not for long. Usually he figures it out, and the result leaves him almost breathless for the re-telling.

title: TRANSPLANTED HUDSON BLOOMS AT LAST
description: IN his mind's eye, Charles Hudson can still see vividly the moments of growth in his life. He is sitting in a dugout at this moment, but he is looking fondly into the distance: to idle summer days beneath a shady tree in Texas, to formative college years when he learned his craft, to the beginning of a pro career as a baseball pitcher. He smiles when he considers the ground he has traveled, the lessons he has learned.

title: ROOKIE TIES RECORD IN COLONIAL VICTORY
description: Keith Clearwater shot two rounds of 64 for a total of 12-under-par 128 in today's 36-hole wind-up, and won the Colonial National Invitation Tournament as he beat Davis Love 3d by three strokes.

title: FIJI TENSIONS GROW IN WAKE OF COUP
description: As hundreds gathered under the palm trees to protest the coup d'etat and kidnapping of the Prime Minister last week, a university student, S. N. Reddy, lamented: ''Democracy has died and this is its funeral.''

title: RE CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a reserve of $240,000 to cover the company's potential liability for the self-insured portion of its life insurance obligation to its chief financial officer who is seriously ill. c-Includes income of $123,412 from discontinued operations.

title: WOMEN'S HEALTH CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHILD'S JOB AS VIEWED BY PARENTS
description: TO hear their parents tell it, Jerry Martin leads a rather glamorous life as chairman of an advertising company and Andrea Grover vacations in Italy several times a year.

title: NEW YORK REPORTS JAIL SPACE CRISIS
description: The Cuomo administration said this weekend that the state's prison system was in ''crisis'' and that within a year it would have 4,700 more inmates than cells to hold them.

title: SPECTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: AUSTRALIA'S RICHEST STRATEGIST
description: Even in his school days in South Africa, Robert Holmes a Court had a genius for making money.

title: WHAT THE CITY DOES TO KEEP COMPANIES
description: With teams of industry economic specialists and fancy advertising campaigns, New York City makes a considerable effort to persuade businesses to relocate here.

title: Smith College
description: Garry Trudeau, the Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist, praised the value of impertinent questions today in his address to the 109th graduating class of Smith College.

title: Hofstra University
description: Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., awarded 1,498 undergraduate and graduate degrees yesterday at three ceremonies. Among those who received honorary degrees were Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who was honored at the School of Business, and Jihan Sadat, wife of Anwar el-Sadat, the assassinated President of Egypt. Mrs. Sadat received her degree at the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences. Dr. William L. Smith, former United States Commissioner of Education spoke at the School of Education commencement.

title: Arnell Bickford Getting Credit Line on TV, Too
description: The leadership of the Arnell Bickford agency believes it deserves a credit line for the advertising it produces, and the agency has gotten it, going back to the first advertising for Bergdorf Goodman in 1983.

title: P&F INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $281,000 and $245,000 for the latest and year- ago quarters, respectively. Latest quarter includes dividend payments of $112,500 paid on preferred stock issued in December 1986.

title: Chinese Business Is Westernizing
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PERSIAN GULF: A DEADLY CORRIDOR
description: The Persian Gulf has become the most dangerous body of water in the world for shipping. Seven years of fighting between Iran and Iraq, which face each other at the head of the Gulf, have turned the strategic oil-shipping corridor into a shooting gallery.

title: Diplomatic Approach
description: There's nothing like a catchy title to help get a new venture off the ground, but as the organizers of a program designed to promote peace through baseball have discovered, when it comes to raising money for international tours, a little alliteration can go a long way toward alienating potential sponsors. As a result, Bats Not Bombs, a group formed last year to sponsor a series of friendship games between the Nicaraguan national squad and college teams in California, has reemerged this year with a new mission and a new name - Baseball Diplomacy.

title: MOSCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest first quarter net is reported without provision for income taxes because of a tax loss carryforward.

title: CSX's Troubleshooter Is Given Sea-Land Task
description: In his career at the CSX Corporation, one of the tasks of Robert L. Hintz, an executive vice president, has been troubleshooting for the company's varied units. And in each case he has been able to turn the operation around within a few years, he recalled in an interview.

title: Susan L. Sorrell Weds Steven Brand Schwab
description: The marriage of Susan Lynn Sorrell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winfred A. Sorrell of Clayton, N.C., to Steven Brand Schwab, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Schwab of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday in Raleigh, N.C. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk performed the ceremony at Meredith College.

title: PHILADELPHIA TRIES NEW APPROACHES AS MENTAL HEALTH SYSTEM IS REVAMPED
description: With mobile teams to handle psychiatric crises and case managers to insure continuity in patient care, Philadelphia is changing the way it cares for the chronically mentally ill.

title: A Fearful Dole Bill
description: Legislation introduced by Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, would close two American offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The purpose, Mr. Dole says, is ''to strengthen the defenses of this country against the real, physical threat that the P.L.O. represents.''

title: What! Lose to the Japanese Again?
description: The U.S. may be losing another technology race with Japan. In fact, some experts argue that America's dwindling share of the world market for computer memory chips augurs the decline of the whole semiconductor industry. They've already persuaded President Reagan to protect chip makers against Japanese competitors. Now the industry is lobbying the Government to subsidize Sematech, an industrywide venture that hopes to raise $250 million a year for research and development.

title: Israeli Inflation Rate
description: Israel said Friday that inflation rose 2.2 percent in April, the highest monthly increase for 1987. But economists said that the figure was expected, that it resulted largely from seasonal factors and that it was not likely to change predictions of an annual rate of about 20 percent.

title: MERIDIAN DIAGNOSTICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Wrong Debate on Education - and the Right One
description: LEAD: The problem with Secretary of Education William J. Bennett is not only that he is often wrong about higher education, which he is, but that he is often right. However, he has so needlessly angered and confused so many that few listen anymore.

title: GARBAGE BARGE RETURNS IN SEARCH OF A DUMP
description: After more than eight weeks of wandering in the Caribbean and up and down the East Coast in a futile search for a final resting place, Long Island's outcast garbage was anchored off Brooklyn yesterday, awaiting the outcome of another round of legal and political wrangles.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Aid as a Lure

title: HOT PUTTER WINS FOR OKAMOTO
description: Ayako Okamoto, currently the hottest pro golfer on any tour, posted her second Ladies Professional Golf Association victory in five weeks today by winning the $33,750 top prize in the 12th annual Chrysler-Plymouth Classic.

title: Thai Exchange Cites Illegal Act
description: The Securities Exchange of Thailand announced Friday that it had discovered illegal manipulation in this month's sharp rise in the stock price of a finance company. In reaction, prices fell on the Thai stock market.

title: Bridge: Team of World Champions Wins in International Trials
description: A team of reigning world champions coasted to victory here this afternoon in the final of the international team trials.

title: William & Mary
description: Twelve hundred graduates participated yesterday in the commencement at the College of William & Mary in Williamsburg, Va. Roger Mudd, the television news correspondent, was the principal speaker. Arthur J. Goldberg, a former Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, spoke at the baccalaureate service Saturday. Among those receiving honorary degrees were Dr. Denton Cooley, founder of the Texas Heart Institute, and the author John Hersey.

title: IRAQI MISSILE HITS U.S. NAVY FRIGATE IN PERSIAN GULF
description: A United States Navy frigate in the Persian Gulf was struck Sunday by a missile fired from an Iraqi warplane, causing serious damage and many casualties, the Reagan Administration said.

title: LESSONS LEARNED SEASON THE STYLE OF SONICS' COACH
description: Among his other duties, an assistant coach studies the techniques of the head coach with whom he works, hoping to fuse his boss's strengths with his own philosophy when he coaches a team of his own.

title: Lanie Jones Wed To L. C. Peterson
description: Lanie Lippincott Jones, a staff writer for The Los Angeles Times, and Larry C. Peterson, a political writer for The Orange County Register in Santa Ana, Calif., were married yesterday in an outdoor ceremony at Crescent Bay Point in Laguna Beach, Calif. The Rev. Susan Webster Klein of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Irvine, Calif., performed the ceremony.

title: Baptiste Married To Edward S. Morrison Jr.
description: Elizabeth Jean Baptiste and Edward Stephen Morrison Jr., both professional photographers in New York, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Stockbridge, Mass., by the Rev. Theodore H. Evans.

title: GET READY, GET SET, GET WEIRD
description: By the time the last runner crossed the starting line today at the Bay to Breakers foot race here, Arturo Barrios was almost to the finish line.

title: GOVERNING: 200 YEARS OF TENSION
description: Independence Hall shines splendidly. Old Philadelphia's greenery has burst forth in full foliage. Fifes, drums, fireworks, bands and speechmakers are ready. So are the voting machines.

title: Franklin & Marshall
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, president of the National Baseball League, spoke on the place of education in a democracy yesterday as he gave the commencement speech at Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster, Pa. The ceremony for 500 graduates was the college's bicentennial commencement. Mr. Giamatti, a former president of Yale, was awarded an honorary degree.

title: A South Africa Choice: See Husband, or Son
description: Albertina Sisulu, 69 years old, one of apartheid's most prominent foes, was in a quandary.

title: MUSIC: FROM FINLAND, THE TAMPERE PHILHARMONIC
description: TAMPERE is a Finnish city about a hundred miles northwest of Helsinki. Its metropolitan area of about a quarter of a million people is served musically by the Tampere Philharmonic, an orchestra of 78 members conducted by Paavo Rautio. Together, they brought a little bit of Finland to Town Hall on Friday night.

MONITOR TECHNOLOGIES inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: To the Editor:

description: For the suburban lawns, backyard swimming pools and five-minute car washes of Nassau County, the days of free-flowing faucets and unrestrained sprinklers are numbered.

description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $52,000. c-Net income

title: STAGE: TOM STOPPARD'S 'ROSENCRANTZ'
description: TOM STOPPARD'S virtuosity was immediately apparent in his debut as a playwright with ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead,'' something that can be passingly perceived in a 20th-anniversary revival of the play opening last night at the Roundabout Theater Company. The inspiration for the play begins with the idea of turning ''Hamlet'' inside out. To Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, as ultimate outsiders, supporting players in the lives of others, the plot of Shakespeare's play is indecipherable.

title: MID-AMERICA INDUSTRIES inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''When I was a kid I saw 'The Blob' and couldn't sleep for a week. What the kids now rent over the counter at a mom-and-pop video store every week would give me the screaming meemies.'' - David Weiner, editor of Video Source Book. [ B9:1. ]

title: Susan D. Brown Wed To Elliott S. Hollander
description: At Rutherford House in Stuyvesant Square in Manhattan yesterday, Susan Deborah Brown was married to Elliott Sidney Hollander by Rabbi Dr. Manfred Fulda.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MAY 18, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The Fed is expected to move cautiously on raising interest rates amid continuing uneasiness in the bond markets and signs of weakness in the domestic economy. [ Page D1. ] Importing Japanese parts and products has become costly as the dollar's plunge has forced suppliers to raise prices. Some U.S. companies have chosen not to renew contracts with Japan. [ D1. ] Night futures trading is off to a good start, according to officials at the Chicago Board of Trade. Volume is expected to increase sharply in the next few months, especially as the Japanese begin to trade in foreign futures and options contracts. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Kidder, Peabody faces a troubling period. Morale at the investment bank has fallen in the wake of disclosures involving insider trading and a shake-up of top management. [ D1. ] Earnings at major corporations exceeded predictions in the first quarter. Although analysts had raised their earnings projections, profits surpassed the estimates by an average of 4 percent at 426 companies. [ D1. ] Businesses oppose an accounting board plan that would require consolidated earnings statements by companies with subsidiaries in businesses different from the parent's. Executives say the change would present a distorted picture of liabilities. [ D5. ] Turner Broadcasting had a loss of $39.7 million in the quarter ended March 31. The company cited interest costs and amortization related to its acquisition of MGM's film library. [ D8. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Egypt will seek to reschedule $10 billion of its foreign debt, after receiving $325 million in standby economic credits from the International Monetary Fund. [ D7. ] Australia's richest man, Robert Holmes a Court, has earned a reputation as a brilliant strategist and financier. [ D10. ] Tijuana has a strong industrial and commercial base because of its ties to Southern California and the proliferation of foreign-owned plants that assemble components for export. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Investors are taking notice of packaged-food companies, which have made handsome profits since the start of the bull market. In addition, talk of acquisitions in the business has raised the stock price of such companies as General Mills. [ D8. ] Two courts have dealt setbacks to ''set-aside'' programs intended to assist businesses owned by women and members of minority groups. Business and the Law. [ D2. ]

title: Zambian Bank Firings
description: Zambia's central bank dismissed 10 senior executives Friday after the discovery of what President Kenneth Kaunda called ''devastating and terrifying irregularities.'' Mr. Kaunda initiated the shake-up at the Bank of Zambia on Wednesday by firing the deputy governor and general manager. He gave no details about the irregularities, but banking officials said they included embezzlement of bank funds, irregular allocations of foreign exchange and shady deals involving cobalt, a strategic metal.

title: Fumes in Philadelphia Force 300 From Homes
description: Chlorine fumes from leaking chemical tanks spread over southwest Philadelphia today, sending at least 42 people to hospitals and forcing 300 to leave their homes for several hours, the authorities said.

title: CITY TO OFFER EXTRA AID TO FAMILIES
description: In an experimental effort to stem the rising number of homeless families in New York City, certain welfare recipients will be offered extra benefits ranging from furniture allowances to baby sitters.

title: Symbiosis in the Sky: Coach and Discount
description: To the Editor:

MILLS-JENNINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
The Bureaucracy, and Others, at Bat
description: Some are called the Monopodes, some the Noise Boys. Some are the Penetrators, others Shoot the Wounded. Rock groups? No, they are some of the teams of softball players who cover the Mall and other clearings each late afternoon and evening like so many colonies of honeybees.

title: C. W. Post Campus
description: The C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University held its 30th commencement in Brookville, L.I., yesterday, and 2,400 graduates received degrees.

title: GOETZ'S LAWYER PRAISES THE RIGHT TO BEAR ARMS
description: The lawyer for Bernhard H. Goetz preached yesterday about the ordinary citizen's right to keep and bear arms during a gathering of gun enthusiasts in Brooklyn.

title: CANDELA LASER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BONN CENTRIST PARTY GAINS ON ARMS ISSUE
description: The small Free Democratic Party, which has pressed for the acceptance of Soviet arms control proposals, carried off significant successes today in two bellwether state parliamentary elections. The breakthroughs put new pressure on Chancellor Helmut Kohl to soften his own disarmament positions.

title: No Chlorofluorocarbons
description: Environmentalism begins at home, and in the Senate it begins in the cafeteria. Fast food sold to lawmakers and their aides will no longer come in foam packages that include chlorofluorocarbons, thanks to an effort by Senator Robert T. Stafford of Vermont, who is the ranking Republican on the Environment and Public Works Committee.

title: Merger Forcing Agency To Drop Hiram Walker
description: Last month it was announced that Saatchi & Saatchi was merging its Rumrill-Hoyt into its McCaffrey & McCall.

title: OILERS DEFEAT FLYERS IN FIRST CUP GAME
description: There was Wayne Gretzky, storming into the circles, careering round the net behind Ron Hextall, and generally preening his offensive talents to the detriment of the Philadelphia Flyers and to the delight of his teammates.

title: Video Rivalry
description: Would the Allies have published the plans for Operation Overlord in a German comic book before the Normandy invasion? Would Macy's have ever told Gimbels anything, let alone revealed its entire marketing strategy to the whole world in a Saturday morning kiddie cartoon?

title: 60'S PROTESTERS HOLD BITTERSWEET REUNION IN PARK
description: They came to Central Park, many with gray hair, some pushing baby carriages or trailing teen-age children, and gathered in Central Park's Sheep Meadow, where the aroma of coconut tanning lotion drifted on the breeze instead of the headier scent of marijuana and the din of the antiwar protests of their youth.

description: In several cases with profound implications for the privacy rights of government employees, Federal appeals court judges have upheld the constitutionality of rules subjecting public employees to random drug tests.

description: For the two months ended March 31, 1986, the company reported a loss of $720,000 on sales of $20,778,000. The company changed its fiscal year-end from Jan. 31 to Dec. 31, effective Dec. 31, 1986.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $145,000. The company said in the year-ago 9-month extraordinary credits cancelled out extraordinary losses.

title: QUAKERS GET $10,000 TO FIX A LANDMARK
description: So plain that it came to be beautiful, so beautiful that it came to be a landmark, the Quaker meeting house on Stuyvesant Square needs a lot of work after 127 years. Private preservationists stepped in to help yesterday with a $10,000 check.

title: Strategist at Pru-Bache Staying as a Consultant
description: ''Greg Smith likes the investment process. He dislikes administrative routine. Greg enjoys money management. He dreads organizational labyrinths. Greg wants to go into a real estate venture. He does not want to leave Pru-Bache.''

description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, retiring after 35 years as president of the University of Notre Dame, today bade farewell in a commencement ceremony with the words of Dostoyevsky: ''Let us agree that we shall never forget one another.''

title: Amy B. Wallace Weds S. J. Sklar
description: Amy Beth Wallace, a daughter of Jean Wallace of Syracuse and the late Milton Wallace, was married in Syracuse yesterday to Steven Jon Sklar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Sklar of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbis Charles Sherman and Fabian Schoenfeld officiated at Temple Adath Yeshurun.

CHANGING ERA FOR NEW YORK'S ECONOMY
description: New York City's economic engine, after humming smoothly for nearly a decade, backfired twice last month with the announcements that two of the city's oldest and largest corporate citizens, the Mobil Corporation and the J. C. Penney Company, were moving out of town.

title: Some Mud in the Mail
description: Anyone who believes that 1988 will be free of negative campaigning isn't on the right Washington mailing lists. The New Hampshire primary is still eight months away, but political reporters in the capital received an anonymous mailing last week that was postmarked Denver and addressed in pencil and clearly designed to do Vice President Bush no good.

title: Lesley Fisher Married

Rabbis Elazar Teitz and Pinchas Teitz officiated at the Meadowlands Hilton in Secaucus, N.J.

title: 'ADAM SMITH'S MONEY WORLD' ON THE PACIFIC RIM
description: ASIAN economies now compete with the American economy; we know that already.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS >Wilander Wins Final: Mats Wilander of Sweden, showing why he is considered the world's top clay court player, trounced Martin Jaite of Argentina, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday and won the Italian Open men's tennis championship at the Foro Italico in Rome. Wilander, the second-seeded player, did not drop a set during the weeklong tourney and dominated the 11th-seeded Jaite with a virtually errorless baseline game and emerged as a favorite for the French Open, beginning in a week. Wilander, ranked No. 4 in the world, controlled the match with high, looping topspin groundstrokes that drove Jaite deep beyond the baseline. (AP) Graf Streak at 32: Steffi Graf of West Germany stretched her winning streak to 32 matches and captured her sixth straight title, beating Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, 6-2, 6-3, in the final of the German Open women's tennis tournament in West Berlin. The 17-year-old Graf dominated with her powerful forehand, winning eight straight games from 2-2 in the first set and moving within two games of victory. (AP) BASEBALL Fordham Takes E.C.A.C. Title: Peter Harnisch struck out 13 and allowed just five hits yesterday as Fordham scored a 5-1 victory over New York Tech in the championship game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I tournament in New Britain, Conn. Fordham (31-11) earned an automatic berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association regional tournament. (AP) BIATHLON Mailman Sets Course Mark: Russ Jones, a 32-year-old mailman from Collingswood, N.J., won the his second straight event in the Goldome New York Biathlon Series, winning the Queens event in a course record time. Jones ran two three-mile races in Alley Pond Park sandwiched around a 20-mile bike race up and down the Cross Island Parkway in 1 hour 19 minutes 14 seconds, erasing the 1:20:13 mark set last year by Rainer Boettcher. Doris Trueman, 33, from Australia, was the first woman finisher in 1:25:53, also a course record. DOG SHOW Collie Is Best in Show: Champion Ha'Penny Moon Shadow, the top winning bearded collie in the history of the breed in this country, was chosen as Best in Show at the 85th all-breed fixture of the Long Island Kennel Club at Hofstra. It was the 16th top award for the 6-year-old dog, owned by Robert Greitzer and Richard Schneider.

title: ART VENTURES INCREASE BETWEEN U.S. AND SOVIET
description: The painting depicts a room decorated with a portrait, perhaps of Vladimir Ilich Lenin. The figure appears to be stern and bearded, in Lenin's traditional stoic pose, but his exact features are obscured by a ray of sunlight. And the portrait hangs not in a government office or a schoolroom, but in a seedy hotel room, with the Lenin-like figure gazing with revolutionary fervor upon a dingy wall and an empty bed.

title: University of Vriginia
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole addressed graduates of the University of Virginia in Charlottesville yesterday, as nearly 4,000 students received degrees. Almost two-thirds of the recipients received bachelor's degrees. The rest were graduate and professional degrees.

Deterrence Without Nukes
description: LEAD: The truth is out. After more than 40 years of life under the nuclear umbrella, we are addicted to the bomb. For many on both sides of the Atlantic, the breakdown of disarmament talks at the Reykjavik summit meeting was good news, while the prospect that missiles in Europe may be reduced to zero now causes considerable distress.
