description: An obituary of Maxine Sullivan on April 9 misidentified her as a winner of a Tony Award in 1979. Miss Sullivan was among the nominees that year, but did not win an award.

title: SPIRITS HAUNTING A BELATED COURTROOM RECKONING
description: There are unseen spirits in the courtroom where Klaus Barbie, the wartime chief of the Gestapo in Lyons, is on trial for crimes against humanity. There are half-buried memories and distant events obscured by the passage of time. There is the dryness of a courtroom procedure and, from time to time, the contrasting moisture of grief.

description: In the ''Horror'' section of a video store here recently, a boy scanned the titles of dozens of videocassetes displayed on wall racks.

The company also said accordingly, the 1986 net income reflects an increase in the provision for income taxes as if all operations were taxable during that period.

title: Comart Bought By KLP Group
description: Comart Associates, a New York-based sales promotion company, has been acquired by Britain's KLP Group, which now claims to be the largest such company in the world.

title: MUSIC: FLAMENCO GUITARIST
description: THE austere style of the noted flamenco guitarist Paco Pena offers a musical rejoinder to the commonplace notion of flamenco as a colorful, sensual ''gypsy'' music. Mr. Pena, who gave a solo performance at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday evening, is a meticulous classicist who brings a scholarly approach to a style that evolved in southern Spain's region of Andalusia. The fact that the area absorbed Romans, Jews and Moors, as well as a large influx of gypsies in the late 15th century, helps to account for the strong Middle Eastern modality that haunts much flamenco music.

title: Japan Speeding Economic Plan
description: Responding to American pressure, Japan decided Friday to speed up work on an economic package intended to give a stimulus to its flagging economy, officials said. Prime Minister Yasuhiro

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MAY 18, 1987
description: International A3-12

title: SHULTZ ENDORSES A PEACE PARLEY FOR THE MIDEAST
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz tonight gave the strongest American endorsement to date for an international peace conference for the Middle East.

title: CONCERT: 2 BY GERSHWIN
description: George Gershwin, like most great craftsmen of American theater music in their formative years, was something of an artistic chameleon. Just how skillfully the youthful Gershwin could adapt his musical thinking to suit an occasion was illustrated on Friday evening at Coolidge Auditorium at the Library of Congress. There, under the auspices of the Gertrude Clarke Whittall Foundation and the Ira and Leonore Gershwin Charitable Foundation, John McGlinn, who has played a crucial role in resurrecting vintage American theater scores, led a hefty ensemble in sparkling concert performances of the shows ''Primrose'' (1924) and ''Pardon My English'' (1933).

title: We Are Five Billion Now
description: Perhaps while you are reading this newspaper, perhaps next week but soon, the five billionth living inhabitant of this earth will be born. Before the end of the century, there will be six billion. Population is growing by 150 a minute.

title: Tufts University
description: Gloria Steinem, the feminist and editor of Ms. magazine, urged Tufts University graduates today to follow their hearts rather than bow to societal pressures or traditions.

title: Market Place; Now Popular, Food Stocks
description: SHARES of General Mills Inc., whose products range from Gorton's frozen seafood to Betty Crocker desserts, climbed to record highs last week in the wake of unconfirmed takeover rumors. The flurry of excitement gave analysts an opportunity to assess prospects for companies in the packaged-food industry.

title: Guard at L.I. School for Deaf Is Found Dead After Beating
description: A security guard at the Cleary School for the Deaf was apparently beaten to death while on the job, the police said today.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

EGYPT SEEKS RESCHEDULING OF $10 BILLION OF DEBT
description: Buoyed by an emergency loan from the International Monetary Fund, Egypt will seek rescheduling this week of $10 billion of its foreign debt from the Paris Club of Western creditor nations.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis United States Tops Spain: John McEnroe, playing for the United States for the first time in two years, defeated Spain's No. 1 player, Emilio Sanchez, yesterday in the $750,000 Peugeot World Team Cup tennis tournament in Dusseldorf, West Germany. McEnroe downed Sanchez, 7-5, 3-6, 7-5. Earlier, Brad Gilbert of the United States beat Spain's Sergio Casals, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3. A doubles match, put off yesterday because of darkness, will be played today.

title: UNWANTED LAMPREYS MAKE COMEBACK
description: Sea lampreys, the blood-sucking ''vampires of the deep'' that all but wiped out game fish in the Great Lakes in the 1940's and 1950's, are staging a comeback that is worrying officials responsible for carefully rebuilt stocks of salmon and trout.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alpha Solarco Inc., Cincinnati, said it had signed two $175 million contracts with the Pawnee and Otoe-Missouria Indian tribes to build two 70,000-kilowatt electric-generating stations on tribal lands in Oklahoma.

title: CAPACITY USE DOWN TO 78.9%
description: The nation's industrial operating rate was just 78.9 percent of capacity in April, the poorest showing in more than three years, the Government reported today.

title: Rig Count Down to 744
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States totaled 744 this week, down 23 from last week, Baker Hughes Inc. officials said today. The count totaled 757 one year ago. Its peak was 4,500 in December 1981, and its low was 663 last July.

title: 'All My Sons' Closes
description: ''All My Sons,'' a revival of Arthur Miller's 1947 drama, closed after the matinee on Sunday at the John Golden Theater. The play, directed by Arvin Brown, ran for 29 performances and six previews.

title: MULTIMILLION FUND TO DEVELOP JEWISH LEADERS
description: To Leslie H. Wexner, who built a small family clothing shop in Ohio into the world's largest retail apparel chain, the key to success was finding the best leaders.

title: American Goes To a Tee Party
description: All caddies at The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, Scotland, will line the sides of the first fairway from tee to Swilkin Burn on Sept. 17 when William C. Campbell of Huntington, W. Va., ''drives in'' as Captain of the R. & A. and becomes the head of the most presitigious golf club in the world. The caddie who retrieves the drive will receive a gold sovereign from Campbell, who will thus begin a year's tenure as only the third American to head the St. Andrews, the birthplace of golf.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the latest third quarter and 9-month results include an extraordinary pre-tax charge of $5,307,000 from the company's proposed recapitalization program.

title: Brain Food
description: Supporting the theory that a good meal is the kind of special occasion that stands out from the haze of ordinary memories, scientists have found mice are better able to learn to run a maze when they are fed immediately after training.

title: Unilever Lifts Earnings 48%
description: Unilever P.L.C., the British-Dutch consumer products conglomerate, said today that its first-quarter profit jumped 48 percent, reflecting strong growth by all its lines.

title: GUARDIANS OF WORLD'S HEALTH FIND IT HARD TO QUIT SMOKING
description: When Dr. Halfdan Mahler, the Director General of the World Health Organization, publicly smashed a glass ashtray in front of a crowd of his agency's employees and officials here recently, his symbolic gesture evoked a mixed response.

title: HARD TIMES GET WORSE AS PADRES HOLD OFF METS
description: You know you're going bad when the San Diego Padres come to town with 30 defeats in 39 games and a staff earned-run average of 5.39 and still beat you, 7-5. But that's what happened to the Mets last night in Shea Stadium as their hard times grew worse.

title: COMPUTER USERS FALL VICTIM TO A NEW BREED OF VANDALS
description: A new breed of vandals, working within a vast network of computer ''bulletin boards,'' are devising sophisticated software programs that erase and scramble the computer files of unsuspecting users.

title: Massachusetts Faulted On Its Law on Disabled
description: The percentage of disabled students who are segregated from the general school population has gone up despite a 13-year-old state law requiring them to be in regular classrooms when possible, according to a study released today.

description: W. Ann Reynolds, chancellor of California State University, has survived an initial attempt at ousting her from her position as the head of the nation's largest four-year university system, but she faces another review before the Board of Trustees.

title: Donovan Graduates
description: Billy Donovan, whose long-range shooting helped Providence get to the Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, received his diploma yesterday and then hurried to the College of Staten Island gym to join the Staten Island Stallions for their game last night against the Long Island Knights. The 5-foot-11-inch Donovan, who attended St. Agnes High School in Rockville Centre, L.I., was originally a territorial draft pick of the United States Basketball League's Rhode Island Gulls, but indicated he would like to play closer to home. Donovan scored five points and had five assists in 23 minutes as the Stallions lost, 120-110.

title: HOBART COACH HAILS PLAYERS IN MILESTONE
description: Although Hobart set a record for consecutive national championships when its lacrosse team beat Ohio Wesleyan Saturday for the Division III title, Dave Urick remains unimpressed.

title: Lendl Seeded No. 1

Lendl, who took last year's title by defeating Mikael Pernfors of Sweden in three sets, has won only one tournament this year. Boris Becker is second seeded despite his inability to win a clay court tournament. John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors are seeded seventh and eighth, respectively.

description: Brazil's President, Jose Sarney, said tonight that he was willing to leave office a year early, in an apparent effort to smother growing demands for elections even earlier.

title: Injury at Site of Safety Film
description: A man was critically injured Sunday when the race car he was driving careened out of control during the filming of a student movie about the dangers of drag racing, the authorities said. The driver, Anthony Galati, 25 years old, was not wearing a seatbelt when he lost control of his car, said Patrick Russell, a campus police officer at Los Angeles Valley College.

description: South Korea's gross national product rose 15.6 percent in the first quarter from a year earlier, provisional Bank of Korea figures showed today. The quarterly growth rate was the highest in eight years.

title: 'THE MORMONS,' ON 13
description: 'The Mormons' is bril-liantly done; it is also etched in acid. The heirs of Joseph Smith and Brigham Young all look as if they're auditioning for ''The Stepford Wives.'' Are the Mormons really that good looking? Don't they ever have a hair out of place? Male or female, these people don't even seem to perspire. They are made to look a little spooky, and spookiness is the real subject of the documentary. It can be seen on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why does February have only 28 days? Why wasn't a day taken from January and another from March to even all three months out to 30 days? A. The calender that we use is arbitrary, according to Dr. J. T. Fraser, president of the International Society for the Study of Time. Dr. Fraser said that our calender is based on the Julian year, 365.25 days long. Initially, the 12 months of the Julian year each contained either 31 or 30 days, alternating one after the other, and adding up to a 366 day year. The month of February was reduced from 30 to 29 days three out of every four years. July, which was named after Julius Caesar, had 31 days but August, named after Augustus Caesar, had only 30 days. Dr. Fraser said it is believed that Augustus did not like having fewer days in his month and prevailed upon the calendar makers to give August another day. The day was taken from February. Q. What does ''water softening'' mean? A. Water softening is a treatment process that removes the calcium and magnesium salts that make water ''hard.'' Hard water makes washing difficult and causes unpleasant scums and stains in households and laundries. The salts in hard water are also harmful to food processing and chemical processing because they produce unwanted byproducts and can damage boilers. Municipalities that have natural water with a hardness of more than 150 parts per million soften the water by treating it with lime and soda ash that turn the salts into precipitates that can be filtered out. The water is then passed through an exchanger that substitutes sodium ions for calcium and magnesium in the water.

description: WRITTEN, produced and directed by Jeremy Kagan for Inter Planetary Productions, ''Conspiracy: The Trial of the Chicago Eight'' - on pay cable's Home Box Office tonight at 8 - describes an event that took place only 18 years ago and already looks as if it could be in another century. Mr. Kagan, who wrote the script in 1979, sees the trial posing basic questions: Does justice in America actually work? Can the country deal with people who do not accept the political system operating at the time? Those who found the Yippies and other protesters an affront to authority, not to mention courtesy and decency, are unlikely to have their minds changed by this two-hour docudrama. Supporters, however, established and potential, will be delighted.

title: The Attack on the Stark
description: Iraq's blundering attack on the frigate Stark should not change America's aims or means in the Persian Gulf. A military presence is needed to reassure the Gulf states against encroachment by Iran, and warships play a necessary role. But the death of 28 sailors and the crippling of their vessel by a single Exocet missile weighs heavily. All the more so, since the Navy still hasn't explained why the Stark failed to defend itself, even though it was aware it was under attack.

title: Above the Law in the White House
description: As investigators peel away the layers of lies, the White House piles on new layers of legal defense. Did President Reagan agree to give arms for hostages to raise funds illicitly for the Nicaraguan rebels? No, he insisted at first. Then, as facts accumulated, he said he didn't remember; he'd wait for boards and Congressional committees to tell him what he knew. Now, as the Senate-House investigation increasingly shows his involvement, his story is changing again.

title: MUSIC: HANDEL'S 'JOSHUA'
description: ''JOSHUA,'' one of the lesser known Handel oratorios, was performed most ably by the Canticum Novum Singers and Baroque Orchestra at the 92d Street Y on Saturday evening. Harold Rosenbaum, the conductor, managed to keep in line his occasionally unruly band of instrumentalists, and he drew wonderful sounds from his chorus -energetic, expressive, clear and sunny are the adjectives that come most quickly to mind. When the text read ''the nations tremble at the dreadful sound,'' their voices trembled and sounded full of dread, and when it read ''Heav'n thunders, tempests roar, and groans the ground,'' there was a nice bit of groaning.

title: In Brazil: Military or Mandate?
description: Not yet fully democratic, Brazil already stumbles on the road to stable civilian rule. Jose Sarney, a president who came to power through insider dealing rather than free elections, is renewing old ties with the military as he becomes increasingly embattled. A return to military rule is no longer inconceivable. However messy, early presidential elections commend themselves as the best way to restore legitimacy and reestablish a mandate to deal with runaway politics and inflation.

description: To the Editor:

title: BOND PRICES INCH UP WITH THE DOLLAR
description: Note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday in sympathy with a slight rise in the dollar and decline in commodity prices.

title: Four in Arts and Letters To Receive Bobst Award
description: The Elmer Holmes Bobst Awards in Arts and Letters, established by New York University, will be presented tonight to John Updike for fiction, Louis Simpson for poetry and Flora Lewis, a foreign affairs columnist for The New York Times, for nonfiction. The special award for lifelong contribution to arts and letters will be given to Sir Harold Acton.

title: MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Carter to Retire
description: The Denver Broncos' Rubin Carter, who has played more games at the nose tackle position than any other N.F.L. player, retired yesterday to become an assistant defensive line coach for the team. Carter, 34 years old, has played 152 games as nose tackle since being drafted by the Broncos in 1975 from the University of Miami. He suffered a knee injury last year which required arthroscopic surgery and spent the final 11 weeks of last season on the injured reserve list.

title: How to Isolate America
description: They capture peasants and cut off their ears. They burn clinics.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MAY 19, 1987
description: Companies

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of oil and gas properties of $3,450,000.

title: ASSOCIATED COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter includes a pretax gain of $763,335 from non-recurring sales of properties.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago third quarter and 9 months include a $1.7 million non-recurring charge related to company's purchase of a partnership interest in its battery business.

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated.

title: SERVICE RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $71,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $167,000.

title: MUSIC: SOLTI, THE CHICAGO AND MAHLER
description: AS a reminder of what an orchestra concert can be, last night's breathtaking performance of Mahler's Symphony No. 9 by the Chicago Symphony will certainly do. Sir Georg Solti played like an angler with the tempo of the tragic finale, letting out the line to the point - but not past the point -of snapping.

title: FREDERICK A. POTTLE, SCHOLAR AND EDITOR OF BOSWELL PAPERS
description: Frederick A. Pottle, Sterling Professor Emeritus of English at Yale University and for more than half a century the principal intellectual force behind an ongoing study of the life and work of the 18th-century biographer James Boswell, died Saturday at the New Haven Convalescent Home, after a long illness. Mr. Pottle, who lived in New Haven, was 89 years old.

title: 5.3% Heck's Stake
description: Two investors told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had acquired 469,900 shares of Heck's Inc., or 5.3 percent of the outstanding common stock. Monroe Milstein, president of Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse in Burlington, N.J., and Andrew Milstein, a White Plains lawyer, said they had bought the stake for $2.1 million for investment purposes. They said they have no plans to seek control of the company, which operates discount stores.

title: Rise in Inflation, Growth Seen
description: The economy will have significantly higher inflation this year, but economic growth will strengthen at the same time, pushing the next recession further into the future, the nation's business economists have predicted in response to a survey.

title: IMAGE MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in May 1986.

title: COLOROCS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Turner Officer Joins Tishman
description: Robert D. Kupfer, co-president of the Turner Corporation, a diversified construction company based in New York, is leaving the post to initiate an expansion into Asia by Tishman Speyer Properties.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ASTRADYNE COMPUTER INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: REAGAN'S CONTRA-AID LINE: NEW SHIFT
description: President Reagan's new assertion that he was ''very definitely involved'' in the covert program to aid the Nicaraguan rebels is only the latest in a string of White House reversals on the question.

title: ORIENT-EXPRESS HOTELS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $7,770,000 on the sale of leisure assets. c-Net loss

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alcoa, Pittsburgh, named as a director John P. Mulroney, president and chief operating officer of Rohm & Haas Co., Philadelphia.

title: DEROSE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BERKEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $601,000 from discontinued operations.

title: AT 38, GARVEY BECOMES MR. IN-BETWEEN
description: Lately, the questions for Steve Garvey have been growing more complex. He has never been one to place a lot of space between himself and his constituents, the people who cast all-star ballots at ball parks across the country. He has understood that while the circular stadiums in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh and Cincinnati and St. Louis may look the same, the places are different.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid May 23.

title: MASSACHUSETTS' CLAIM TO PIRATE SHIP IS DENIED
description: Massachusetts has no rights to the wreck of a pirate ship found by a private salvager off Cape Cod, and thus cannot claim 25 percent of the treasure or limit the locations searched, a Superior Court judge has ruled.

title: University Offer
description: A $53 million financing for the University of Pittsburgh was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company. Yields on the tax-exempt issue range from 6.20 percent for bonds due in 1991 to 7.40 percent in 1997, 8 percent in 2002 and 8.25 percent in 2005. The bonds are a general obligation of the university and are rated A by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: MOBILE COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Arrest in Beirut Bombings
description: The mastermind of more than 100 minor bomb blasts in West Beirut since Syrian soldiers were deployed there three months ago was arrested today, Brig. Ghazi Kanaan, the chief of Syrian military intelligence in Lebanon, said today. The bombs, mostly sticks of dynamite thrown into pavement rubbish heaps, have caused few casualties but were a clear challenge to the Syrian drive to impose order on West Beirut, the Moslem sector of the capital. Officials say at least 35 people have been arrested on suspicion of involvement with the blasts.

title: What Else Is Wrong With Alaska Oil Proposal; Proud Bayonne
description: To the Editor:

title: McHale Fined $3,000
description: Kevin McHale was fined $3,000 yesterday for entering the stands and accosting a fan in Milwaukee during the third game of the Celtics' Eastern Conference semifinal series against the Bucks.

title: WAREHOUSE CLUB reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $3,000 and $211,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: UNIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPANY IS FOCUS OF POSTAL INQUIRY
description: A 14-month-old investigation of corruption in the Postal Service, which has led to the imprisonment of two business executives, is now focusing on a Texas company that is said to have proposed a contract-sharing deal with a competitor.

title: KOCH NOMINATES 6 FOR LANDMARKS PANEL
description: The makeup of a broadly reconstituted Landmarks Preservation Commission was revealed yesterday as Mayor Koch announced his choices for 6 of the 11 seats - including an Episcopal rector, a magazine editor and a landscape architect who has fought the landmarks panel in the past.

title: Pact Would Cut Phone Bills
description: State officials yesterday announced an agreement with the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation that would save customers a total of $54.5 million and avoid rate increases through 1988. The agreement, which requires approval by the State Department of Public Utility Control, would mean bill reductions of at least $14.20 for each customer and long-distance rate reductions of $31.5 million in the 18-month period. The settlement is the result of negotiations and court action that began in October.

title: WINFIELD'S 2 BLASTS GIVE JOHN THE EDGE
description: If the specter of a returning Ron Guidry hovered over Tommy John like a dark cloud tonight, he did not show it. John pitched six scoreless innings, and Dave Winfield cracked two home runs to keep the Yankees two games in front in the American League East with a 2-1 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

title: College Athletes Under Scrutiny
description: A Federal grand jury in Chicago will consider whether to indict student athletes, as well as sports agents, on charges of defrauding colleges by signing contracts before college eligibility had expired, The Atlanta Constitution reported today.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the 1987 results were translated at 20.3908 Philippine pesos to $1.00; the 1986 results were translated at 19.8711 to $1.00. The company also said the results for the first quarter of 1986 have been restated to reflect adjustments made at the end of 1986 which related mainly to the adjustment of the depreciation charges based on the revised estimated service lives of property and equipment of the Masbate Gold operations; these adjustments resulted in a decrease in net loss by U.S. $437 for the quarter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MAY 19, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16, A32-33 The Pentagon said 28 sailors died after an Iraqi missile attack Sunday on a United States Navy frigate in the Persian Gulf. President Reagan put American military vessels in the region on a heightened state of alert. Page A1 The reason the frigate did not fire against the warplane to defend herself is unknown to senior military officers. The ship's officers had detected the firing on radar and had tried to communicate with the attacker. A1 The mission of the stricken warship and the fleet it belonged to has been only vaguely defined. The fleet holds its military muscle in check. Officials said the ship could have fired if the captain had felt threatened. A10 Gulf war spurs China arms sales A9 At Stark's base, the families wait A10 News analysis: President Reagan's new assertion that he was ''very definitely involved'' in the covert program to aid the Nicaraguan rebels is only the latest in a string of White House reversals on the question. A3 Shimon Peres met with Yuri Dubinin and asked whether Moscow would be willing to play limited role in a Middle East peace conference, officials said. The Israeli Prime Minister's meeting with the Soviet Ambassador was not announced beforehand. A8 In West Germany, Helmut Kohl has stumbled into one of his most politically painful passages as Chancellor as he tries to fashion a response to Soviet proposals for the abolition of some missiles in Europe. A3 Some immigrants with green cards work on the United States side of the border but choose to live in Mexico. ''It is a way to take advantage of the best of what both sides have to offer,'' one such commuter said. A4 A political campaign in Portugal is slowly taking shape two months before national elections. In July, the Portuguese will vote for their 17th government in 13 years, prompting some to compare their politics to Italy's. A33 Fiji coup may be coming apart A5 Barbie papers called authentic A6 Arabs and Jews rally in Israel A8 U.S.-India relations worsen A14 African population still surging A33 NATIONAL

title: United Phone Mortgage Bond
description: The United Telephone Company of Florida is offering $65 million of 9 7/8 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2017 at a price of 97.562, to yield 10 1/8 percent through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Wespercorp Is Charged
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Wespercorp, a maker of minicomputer accessories, and three former officers with overstating the company's revenues and filing false and misleading reports about its financial condition.

title: GARTNER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $107,000 and an extraordinary gain of $118,000.

title: NOSHING AWAY THE WASHDAY BLUES
description: JoJo Hughes set out to get a cup of coffee yesterday morning and ended up with freshly laundered sheets in the bargain.

title: AW COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHURCH'S DECIDES IT IS NOT FOR SALE
description: Church's Fried Chicken Inc. said today that its directors had voted to remain independent, saying that the ''best way to maximize shareholder value'' would be to turn the company's finances around.

title: Pyramid Mystery Is Solved
description: American archeologists digging in Egypt have found an inscribed stone slab enabling them to identify the builder of a 4,600-year-old pyramid as the Pharaoh Sneferu, the first king of the Fourth Dynasty, whose son, Cheops, built the Great Pyramid at Giza.

title: WHY DIDN'T STARK DEFEND HERSELF? U.S. AWAITS THE CAPTAIN'S REPORT
description: Senior military officers said today that they did not know why an American ship, set afire by a missile launched from an Iraqi warplane in the Persian Gulf Sunday night, did not defend herself although the missile firing had been detected on radar. The ship had also twice tried to communicate with the attacker.

title: Pennsylvania
description: Riccardo Muti, the music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra told graduates of the University of Pennsylvania today to open their lives to art to help combat the problems of the world.

title: HENLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter loss reflects a charge to expense for the $65 million payment to Allied-Signal in connection with certain modifications of a Henley agreement with Allied-Signal, as well as charges of $24 million for the amortization of goodwill, step-up depreciation and other acquisition effects; the loss also reflects a $4 million increase in the net loss of Equilease Corp. The company also said in the year- ago first quarter it had $26 million of charges from the amortization of goodwill, step-up depreciation and other acquisition effects. The increase in the latest revenue is primarily attributable to its Wheelabrator Technologies Group, and the inclusion of Fisher Group's Imed Corp., which was acquired in the second quarter of 1986.

title: The Editorial Notebook; United's Pioneering Pilots
description: The plot is familiar: A corporate raider makes a surprise offer for a big company, claiming that management has lost its competitive drive. Scenting blood, Wall Street arbitrageurs bid up the share price by 20 percent. Management dismisses the offer as inadequate - and prepares for the worst by enlisting the aid of a ''white knight'' and voting ''golden parachutes'' for executives.

title: War in Gulf Spurs China's Arms-Export Role
description: China has become the fourth largest arms exporter to the third world, partly on the strength of its sales to Iran and Iraq, according to a new report by the Congressional Research Service.

title: ATKINSON, GUY F CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter results are restated to reflect a pension accounting change.

title: NEW YORK STUDY OF POLICE FINDS NO WIDE MISUSE OF DEADLY FORCE
description: A commission appointed by Governor Cuomo to investigate police brutality in New York State has found ''neither systemic nor pervasive misuse'' of deadly physical force.

title: Dow Off 13.86 as Stocks Fall Broadly
description: Stocks prices fell broadly again yesterday as existing fears of inflation were compounded by the Iraqi attack on a United States Navy ship in the Persian Gulf, a rise in spot crude oil prices and early weakness in the bond market.

title: Helping Hands
description: Bert Blyleven of the Minnesota Twins, who set a major league record by giving up 50 home runs last season, is serving up gopher balls at an even higher rate this season. In 1986 he averaged one homer every 5.44 innings but now is giving up one every 4.51 innings. The dozen pitchers who have contributed most to the upward surge in home run hitting:

title: Motions Snag Cable TV Trials
description: A flurry of legal motions threatens to delay the trials of two men from Queens charged with crimes related to cable-television franchising.

title: AMERICAN SHARED HOSPITAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TPI ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes loss from discontinued operations of $13,403,000 and $9,591,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $750,000 and $497,000 for the same periods, respectively. Year-ago results are restated.

title: PAPERS ON BARBIE CALLED AUTHENTIC
description: A senior official in the West German Justice Ministry testified today that documents used by the prosecution in the trial of Klaus Barbie, the wartime Gestapo chief of Lyons, are authentic.

title: BUSH TURNS FROM HISTORY TO VISION
description: Vice President Bush, whose first Presidential bid in 1980 sought to highlight his experience, has seized upon a less specific theme in the 1988 Presidential campaign.

title: Chief Auto Designer Is Promoted by Ford
description: When John J. Telnack bought his house on Grosse Ile, an island in the Detroit River, he thought its small windows afforded too narrow a view of the water. So he built an annex with a wall of glass. ''I subscribe to the philosophy of Mies van der Rohe that form follows function,'' he said.

title: SEX, POWER, FAILURE: PATTERNS EMERGE
description: THE drives that lead powerful men to self-destructive sexual encounters have little to do with sex, according to psychiatrists and other mental health experts.

title: SHIP DID NOT FIRE IN DEFENSE; U.S. ORDERS A HIGHER ALERT
description: The Pentagon said today that 28 sailors were killed in the Iraqi missile attack Sunday night on a United States Navy frigate in the Persian Gulf.

title: Chess: Korchnoi, at 56, Carries Out A Youthful Sacrificial Attack
description: The Beersheba International Tournament in Israel was won jointly by the grandmasters Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland and Jonathan Speelman of Britain. Each scored 8 1/2-2 1/2 in the 12-player, round-robin, invitational event.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''THESE are my customers,'' said Kai-Yin Lo, the Hong Kong jewelry designer, waving a bejeweled arm around Le Cirque. But, she continued, ''it's the small people,'' not the restaurant's lunchtime feminine eminences, who brought her to New York last week. Those small people, out-of-town buyers, were here for what Ms. Lo termed ''the most important accessories week of the year.''

title: COMPUTER IDENTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOC OPTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST PROVIDENT GROUP reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A TASTE OF HISTORY From its starting point at Lake Henderson in upstate New York and south for 100 miles, the Hudson River is picturesque and clear. For the next 215 miles, from Corinth, N.Y., to the Battery, it is picturesque and polluted. And the river valley also has a place in the nation's political and literary history.

title: DIAGNOSTIC VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WILFRED AMERICAN EDUCAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Firm on the Move
description: Richard Pollock Associates Inc., a small public relations firm whose leader got his start with Ralph Nader and has continued to represent public advocacy organizations, has been taken over by APCO Associates, a subsidiary of the powerful Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: INSIDE
description: Takeover Bid for Harcourt Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, offered $1.7 billion to acquire Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, which firmly rejected the bid. Page D1. I.R.S. Shows New Forms The Internal Revenue Service introduced the tax forms to be used under the new tax law. They are no shorter than the old forms. Page D1. Reversals on the Contras President Reagan's assertion that he was involved in the program to aid the contras is only the latest reversal on the issue. News analysis, page A3.

title: Della Femina to Handle Bausch & Lomb Work
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, which won two Andy Awards a few weeks ago, has also won its first assignment from Bausch & Lomb. It is from the company's personal-products division. Very little more information is available except that the agency will handle the national introduction of whatever it is. Could it be for the hypo-allergenic eye cosmetic that Business Week recently reported Bausch & Lomb at work on?

title: Cato Institute Marks 10 Years
description: When Edward H. Crane was working on a political campaign in Washington a dozen years ago, he was impressed by public policy research groups like the Brookings Institution and the American Enterprise Institute. They seemed to have a remarkable impact on government, he now recalls thinking, considering how much smaller and poorer they were.

title: Carter Latest to Be Hurt
description: To Gary Carter, the decline of the Mets is ''crazy and weird,'' and built on a series of improbable events. And the point was brought home to him yesterday when he suffered a stiff neck while tossing a softball to his 8-year-old daughter in his backyard in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: DANCE: 2 NEW WORKS BY A BELGIAN IN PARIS
description: Anne-Teresa de Keersmaeker, a 26-year-old Belgian experimental choreographer who was the sensation of the 1986 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has proved unusually controversial in Paris with two new works.

title: 'GERRY COONEY - IT'S ABOUT TIME'
description: His manager and his sparring partners were wearing red-white-and-blue T-shirts that displayed an American flag and the words: ''Gerry Cooney - It's About Time.''

title: Test Shows Bridge Operator In Fatal Accident Was Drunk
description: A report made public today showed that the operator of a drawbridge was legally drunk when his span crushed a taxicab, killing the driver.

title: Fiji's Army to Free Cabinet as Coup Unravels
description: The South Pacific's first coup d'etat appeared to be unraveling today as Fiji's new military rulers agreed to release Government ministers they had kidnapped five days ago.

title: End Party Fiction in New York City Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Takeover-Law Losses Seen
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that shareholders of Ohio-based companies lost more than $1.4 billion in the value of their stockholdings in the wake of a new state law passed last fall to discourage hostile takeovers.

title: THE BEAUMONT SO FAR: VARIETY, VITALITY
description: ''The Comedy of Errors,'' which is now in previews at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, is the final offering in the first full season of Lincoln Center Theater under Gregory Mosher, the director, and Bernard Gersten, the executive producer. If it is difficult to characterize what has happened in the northwest quadrant of Lincoln Center - other than to say it has done well since Mr. Mosher and Mr. Gersten took over in July 1985 - that is fine with them.

title: Magazine Is Planned For the Handicapped
description: Equal Opportunity Publications of Greenlawn, L.I., publisher of six special-market career publications, is bringing out a seventh in September called Independent Living, a life-style magazine for the handicapped.

title: SFM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tax Watch; I.R.S.'s Dispute With Charities
description: OVER the last several weeks, the Internal Revenue Service has been caught in the middle of a controversy over how far nonprofit groups can tread into the political sphere before jeopardizing their right to solicit tax-deductible contributions from the public.

title: DIVERSIFIED HUMAN REOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ENIGMA. The Life of Knut Hamsun. By Robert Ferguson. 453 pages. Illustrated. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

title: NATIONWIDE CELLULAR reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1987 results include the operations of Nova Cellular Co., which was acquired Dec. 31.

title: INDIAN FINDS RICHES IN BRITAIN
description: For Arunbhai J. Patel, Britain has been a land of opportunity, yielding prosperity in return for his hard work, enterprise and grit. In just a few years, Mr. Patel has moved from the ranks of shopkeeper to one of the country's most successful entrepreneurs.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MEDAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
E&B MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses of $3,127,000 and $2,858,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the latest quarter also includes an extraordinary charge of $1,495,000; both periods include a $5.5 million pretax provision for loss related to the sale of its four remaining non-core businesses. c-Net income and includes income of $432,000 and $1,083,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, repectively; also includes extraordinary credits of $1,039,000 and $2,237,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Bridge: Team Trial Winners Qualify For World Champion Play
description: The International Team Trials, which proceeded with a bang here for three days, ended with a whimper Sunday night when a team of reigning world champions won the final by 82 international match points.

title: Seton Hall University
description: Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J., awarded 1,400 undergraduate and graduate degrees yesterday at commencement ceremonies in the Brendan T. Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Shearson Adds To Office Space
description: In a sign of continuing expansion of the financial services industry, Shearson Lehman Brothers has leased 215,000 square feet of office space in a new 14-story building at 75 Park Place to house some of its data processing and commercial paper operations, the company said yesterday. Shearson plans to vacate 100,000 square feet at nearby sites.

title: What Else Is Wrong With Alaska Oil Proposal; Very Few Scars
description: To the Editor:

title: Clay Felker Is Named Editor of Manhattan, Inc.
description: Clay Felker was named editor of Manhattan, Inc. yesterday, replacing Jane Amsterdam, who resigned following a dispute over editorial control with the magazine's owner, D. Herbert Lipson.

title: Son of a Mob Figure Is Found Shot to Death
description: The son of a man linked to the $5.8 million Lufthansa robbery of 1978 was found shot to death on a Brooklyn street yesterday, the authorities said.

title: Market Place; Belated Lure Of Platinum
description: PLATINUM may be much rarer than gold and may have far more important industrial uses than silver, but the dull gray metal is only now starting to attract sizable numbers of investors in this country. One major reason is that platinum is now readily available to investors in one-ounce bullion coins, which have become the most popular form of owning precious metals among investors.

title: INTERMEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results reflect the acquisition of two formerly independent distributors in a pooling of interest transaction.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DANCE: KIROV BALLET OPENS NORTH AMERICAN TOUR
description: The recent news that the Kirov Ballet from Leningrad would open its North American tour with two previously unscheduled performances here at Glassboro State College was received with special excitement by New York-area balletomanes. This would be the only East Coast stop on the tour, produced by Great World Artists Ltd. of Ottawa and the Pagurian Corporation, which includes performances in Chicago late this month and in five Canadian cities through June 13.

title: Ranger Has Arthritis
description: Don Jackson, the defenseman obtained by the Rangers from the Oilers last season, is reported to have arthritis. Edmonton says that Phil Esposito, the Rangers' general manager, is seeking additional compensation for Jackson. Edmonton obtained the rights to Reijo Ruotsalainen from the Rangers in exchange for Jackson and Stu Kulak, a forward. ''I'm not God,'' Glen Sather, the Oiler general manager and coach, said of Jackson's problem. ''I can't get into a player's body to see how it is. When Don Jackson left here, he was fine.''

title: Brett to Miss 4 Weeks
description: The Kansas City Royals said yesterday that George Brett was expected to miss four weeks of the season because of an injured right knee, but will not need surgery. . . . . Lonnie Smith, the free-agent outfielder who played for the Royals last season, has signed a contract with Kansas City's Class AAA team in Omaha.

title: NEW CHEMICAL 'HOLE' FOUND OVER ANTARCTICA
description: Radio observations in Antarctica have revealed another ''hole'' in a chemical of the stratosphere, deepening the mystery of what happens there in the spring.

title: HEMOTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CANCER VIRUS FOUND IN DRUG ABUSERS
description: SCIENTISTS of the National Cancer Institute have found a surprisingly high prevalence of a rare cancer-causing virus, HTLV-1, in drug abusers tested in New Orleans and six New Jersey cities.

title: U.S. FLEET IN GULF: MISSION INSCRUTABLE
description: The American warship attacked by Iraq in the Persian Gulf was on a mission whose purpose has been only vaguely defined, and carried out by a fleet with military muscle held in check by peacetime rules of engagement.

title: BORG-WARNER SALE
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said that it intends to sell its trucking operations and is seeking a buyer that would continue to provide service to many of Borg-Warner's operations.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After a loss of $300,000 from discontinued operations. The share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid June 5.

title: Chickens Hatch Eagle Eggs
description: Biologists trying to preserve the American bald eagle have found new collaborators: chickens.

title: SOVIET MISSILE PROPOSALS PUT KOHL IN A TOUGH SPOT
description: In trying to fashion a coherent response to Soviet proposals for the abolition of medium- and shorter-range missiles in Europe, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has stumbled into one of the most politically painful passages of his five and a half years in office.

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter net reflects the acquisition of E-Z Service Inc.

title: PRATT HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $72,000.

title: LINDAL CEDAR HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Lindal said Windowvision Inc., acquired Dec. 31, contributed $1.2 million to the quarter's sales.

title: COURT CAMERAS GAIN IN ALBANY
description: A bill allowing news cameras in some of New York State's courtrooms was passed by the Assembly this afternoon, and Senate aides said approval in that house was likely.

title: Mitsui Official Returns To U.S. for Top Post
description: Hisao Kondo has spent two tours of duty in the United States for Mitsui & Company. He has now come back for a third time, to be president of Mitsui U.S.A.

title: REGAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AFRICAN POPULATION STILL SURGING, STUDY SAYS
description: Population growth rates in Africa continue to outstrip that continent's ability to feed itself, dooming the region to widespread hunger and impoverishment until the early 21st century, according to a United Nations report issued today.

title: Samuel R. Gerber Dies; Coroner for 50 Years
description: Dr. Samuel R. Gerber, who served as Cuyahoga County coroner for 50 years until his retirement five months ago, died Saturday. He was 88 years old.

title: Douse the Spreading Iran-Iraq Flames
description: Over the next six months or so, there may be a fragile opportunity to explore nonviolent alternatives to the military and diplomatic stalemate between warring Iraq and Iran.

title: NETWORK CONTROL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $380,000.

title: GIANT YELLOWKNIFE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: AT STARK'S HOME BASE, FAMILIES WAIT IN DREAD
description: Navy chaplains climbed in cars and vans today and headed across the Jacksonville area, and relatives of the crew of the damaged frigate Stark braced themselves for the possibility that they might come calling.

title: TBWA Named Agency For Acura Dealers
description: TBWA Advertising, which has never had an automotive account, has been named agency for the Acura Tri-State Dealers' Association, which is expected to bill $5.5 million.

title: PRISON COUPLE FOUND GUILTY IN TRIAL ON HELICOPTER ESCAPE
description: Two lovers who fled a Federal prison in a stolen helicopter last November were convicted today of charges stemming from their escape.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a one-time pretax charge of $23,351,000 for both periods for a writeoff of pre-opening expenses for the development and construction of the Atlantic City, N.J. Showboat Hotel, Casino and Bowling Center. Both periods also include a loss of $109,000 from a minor interest in a subsidiary and an extraordinary charge of $470,000 from a purchase of subordinated sinking fund debentures. c-Net income.

title: WINTHROP INSURED MORTGAGE INVESTOR reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A.T.& T. SIGNS PACT LIMITING PLAN TO MOVE
description: Mayor Koch and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced a compromise yesterday that modifies the company's plan to relocate much of its staff from its Manhattan headquarters to New Jersey.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Net loss

title: ECONOMIC COMPETITION IS SHIFTING GOVERNMENT ROLE IN LOW-COST HOUSING
description: Fierce competition for economic development is bringing about a new era in housing for low-income people as states and cities around the country forge far ahead of Washington in finding new approaches.

title: Guidry Gains Minor Victory
description: Ron Guidry made his third appearance last night in a minor league game, picked up a victory for the Columbus Clippers and is likely to join the Yankees on their current trip and be activated by the weekend.

title: TPA OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter results do not reflect acquisitions made in the second quarter of 1986.

title: BARBIE IS A SPECTER IN A CABINET RIFT IN FRANCE
description: With Klaus Barbie's trial in its second week, the former Gestapo official's name has been invoked in a dispute within France's governing conservative coalition.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1.9 million.

title: Bridge: Numbers Still Being Counted In Epson Worldwide Contest
description: Whether or not the Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest played Saturday set a participation record for any competitive activity will not be clear for some time to come.

title: Upjohn Appoints A Chief Executive
description: The Upjohn Company yesterday named Dr. Theodore Cooper to succeed Ray T. Parfet Jr., the longtime chairman and chief executive of the big pharmaceutical company.

title: Economic Scene; A Dependence On Foreigners
description: FOREIGNERS now supply more savings to the United States economy than do Americans. In 1986, the inflow of foreign savings to the United States totaled $142 billion, or 3.4 percent of gross national product, while domestic savings totaled only $83 billion, or 2 percent of G.N.P.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: HERE is nothing like a tag sale to force you to confront the hard choices in life. To junk the class notes from Introduction to Psychology and give away the trunk that houses them; to stare with hard, unromantic eyes at the cake plate your husband's great-aunt gave you as a wedding present and tote it out to the car; to look upon a size 8 suit and accept for all time that the body it fits is no longer yours - these things mark milestones, besides providing much-needed closet space.

title: MAN IS EXECUTED IN MISSISSIPPI CASE
description: The State of Mississippi carried out its first execution in nearly four years early today after three Federal courts and Gov. Bill Allain rejected appeals on behalf of the condemned man, Edward Earl Johnson, who was convicted of killing a town marshal.

title: Laxalt Loses Libel Suit Ruling
description: A reporter's information from confidential sources may be introduced as evidence in the trial of former Senator Paul Laxalt's $250 million libel suit against McClatchy Newspapers, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FROM baseball fields and tennis clubs to homes and restaurants, something tall, cold and thirst-quenching could be the most sought-after food during the coming months. But what shall it be? Aside from carbonated soft drinks, there are many choices, with varying merits and demerits when thirst, nutrition and health matters are considered: iced coffee (regular or decaffeinated), iced tea (regular or herbal), fruit juice, fruit drinks, milk, beer, wine coolers, mineral water and bottled or tap water.

title: Proposed New York City Budget Doesn't Do Enough for Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Hempstead Adopts Water Saving Rules
description: The Hempstead town board yesterday approved the most sweeping set of water conservation measures in Nassau County.

title: H. SPENCER MARTIN
description: H. Spencer Martin, a real-estate developer, died of liver disease and heart failure Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

title: AMID THE GRIDLOCK, TRAVEL BY RIVER RETURNS
description: Ferry service on the Hudson River, which began in 1661 and ended in 1967, has begun a comeback that could see hundreds of thousands of commuters heading to work each month aboard dozens of swift boats.

title: WINE TALK
description: IN New York City's theater of wine, visiting vintners occupy leading roles. The visitors present their lines, new and old, playing salesmen in restaurants, wine schools and importers' tasting rooms. Here are four recent scenes: Scene 1: Le Ferrandi, the restaurant of the French Culinary Institute, 462 Broadway, at Grand Street.

title: Louisiana School Chief Is Acquitted of Fraud
description: Louisiana's education superintendent and one of his former aides were acquitted today of what prosecutors said was a scheme in which an employee was paid for work he never performed.

title: Another S.M.U. Ban
description: At Southern Methodist University, where the football program has been suspended for the 1987 season by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for repeated recruiting violations, the sale of T-shirts that poke fun at the school's plight has been banned.

title: 'DIANA ROSS' ON ABC
description: THE pitfalls of having too much artistic control are given a textbook illustration in ''Diana Ross . . . Red Hot Rhythm-and-Blues.'' The hourlong music special - which can be seen on ABC at 9 o'clock tonight - was produced by Ms. Ross for Anaid (spell it backwards) Film Productions. The writer is listed as Lanie Robertson but the final credits note that the writing was ''supervised'' by Ms. Ross. There are ''guest stars'' -Little Richard, Billy Dee Williams, Bernadette Peters and Etta James -but each of them is carefully upstaged by the star. In short, this is a glittering but sad exercise in self-indulgence.

title: PIALAT FILM GETS TOP PRIZE AT CANNES
description: At tonight's awards ceremony marking the end of the 40th Cannes Film Festival, the audience at the Festival Palace loudly jeered the announcement that Maurice Pialat's ''Under Satan's Sun'' had won the Golden Palm, the festival's top prize.

title: New York City Insures Some of Its New Bonds
description: To ease the burden of high interest rates, New York City is making its first use of muncipal bond insurance. The insured bonds, with principal and interest payments guaranteed by two separate firms, are part of a $451.9 million financing announced yesterday. Proceeds of the financing will be used to refund outstanding bonds, producing budget savings of $3.7 million in the current year, $16.2 million next year and $33 million over the life of the new bonds.

title: A Route Out of the Afghanistan Maze
description: LEAD: United States spokesmen have laid down two conditions for acceptance of the projected United Nations agreement on a Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan. They are a short withdrawal timetable and approval of the United Nations agreement by the American-backed resistance alliance based in Pakistan.

title: AIDE TELLS HOW HE AND NORTH ARMED THE CONTRAS
description: Robert W. Owen, a ''foot soldier'' in the secret operation to help the Nicaraguan rebels, detailed today how he and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North used the State Department's humanitarian-aid program to supply weapons to the rebels.

title: DR. MICHAEL WOOD, A FOUNDER OF EAST AFRICA FLYING DOCTORS
description: Dr. Michael Wood, a founder of the Flying Doctors Service of East Africa, died of cancer Friday night at his home in Nairobi, Kenya. He was 68 years old.

title: Schwab Offering
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the discount brokerage based here, said it was considering an initial public offering of common stock. The company said it would not comment on the size, timing or any other aspects of the offering before filing a prospectus with the Securities and Exchange Commission. A group headed by the founder and chairman, Charles R. Schwab, purchased the brokerage from the BankAmerica Corporation in February for $175 million in cash, $55 million in 9 percent junior subordinated debentures and a 15 percent interest in any appreciation, which would take effect at the time of a public offering or after eight years.

title: Article 242487 -- No Title
description: A 10-kilometer walk for AIDS research and services last weekend raised $1.61 million, the organizers of the event said yesterday.

title: Rights Violation Found In Ouster of Counselor
description: The State Human Services Department violated a drug counselor's civil rights by discharging her after she used the hallucinogenic substance peyote in Indian religious ceremonies, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most remarkable changes in American taste I've witnessed within the past few years is a preference for fish that is well done on both sides but slightly undercooked in the center. I recall that during my days as a professional chef, if a piece of fish was not cooked through, it was returned to the kitchen to be thrown back on the grill.

title: Lakers Lead, 2-0
description: James Worthy scored 25 of his 30 points in the first half, and Earvin (Magic) Johnson had 12 of his 20 in the fourth quarter tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 112-104 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics and a 2-0 lead in their Western Conference final series.

title: KINCAID FURNITURE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
ASHTON-TATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
OFFICER KILLS KNIFE-WIELDING MAN IN RAID ON BROOKLYN CRACH HOUSE
description: A police officer raiding a crack house in Brooklyn early yesterday killed a man who confronted him wielding a knife, the police said.

title: A GROUP FAULTS DELAY IN FIXING TRADE SCHOOLS
description: A program announced three years ago to modernize New York City's 17 vocational high schools is so far behind schedule that it is likely to produce out-of-date schools, according to a civic group that monitors the school system.

title: Qawi Retains Standing
description: Dwight Muhammad Qawi will remain the International Boxing Federation's No. 1-ranked cruiserweight, despite a 10-round majority-decision loss in Las Vegas, Nev., last week, I.B.F. President Robert W. Lee said yesterday. Qawi, a former World Boxing Association cruiserweight and World Boxing Council light-heavyweight champion, lost to Ossie Ocasio last Friday when two judges favored Ocasio and one called the fight a draw. Lee, who was at ringside, said, ''This is an unusual course of action for us, but I felt the decision was questionable.'' The No. 1 ranking maintains Qawi's position for a mandatory challenge to Evander Holyfield, who is the I.B.F. and W.B.A. 190-pound class champion.

title: UNITED MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a loss of $76,000 from discontinued operations. The company said an unrealized currency translation loss of $1,226,000 significantly contributed to its latest first quarter loss.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
WORLDS OF WONDER reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A JERSEY FAMILY GRIEVES FOR A HAPPY-GO-LUCKY SON
description: ''They were like sitting ducks,'' Robert DeAngelis said today as he fought back tears over the death of his son Christopher, one of the 37 American seamen killed in an Iraqi missile attack in the Persian Gulf.

title: DANCE: A TRIBUTE TO LINCOLN KIRSTEIN
description: PLANS for a sumptuous New York City Ballet production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' were revealed. Mikhail Baryshnikov danced with a swarm of tiny student-performers. Mayor Koch arrived with a medallion. And the New York State Theater was filled with cheers, standing ovations and cascades of balloons and flowers. The occasion Monday night was a celebration of the 80th birthday of Lincoln Kirstein, the founder, with George Balanchine, of the the New York City Ballet and School of American Ballet. But despite the giddy splendor of the event, Mr. Kirstein was its indisputable star.

title: The Success Of Sweet Smell
description: Cats were worshiped as gods in ancient Egypt, probably because there was so much sand nearby for filling cat boxes. But sand alone could not mask the less than divine odors of the cat's natural byproducts, so various fragrances were added, and thus the cat box filler industry was born.

title: Don't Apply Lieberman
description: Nancy Lieberman, a former all-America with the Old Dominion women's basketball team, has been told by school officials not to apply for a coaching job with the team because she has no college degree. Lieberman said Monday that she notified O.D.U. officials over the weekend of her interest in the job after Marianne Stanley resigned Friday to become the coach at Penn. Lieberman, 28 years old, is nine credits short of a bachelor's degree in health and physical education and hopes to have the degree by December.

title: AUSTRALIA OUSTS LIBYAN DIPLOMATS
description: Prime Minister Bob Hawke today ordered Libya to close its embassy here, asserting that its staff had engaged in unspecified ''clandestine activity'' in Australia and the South Pacific.

title: F.A.A. Lifts Bar on Airport Landing Systems
description: In a move intended to reduce flight delays and increase airport capacity, the Federal Aviation Administration has lifted its five-year-old freeze that prevented airports from installing more electronic guidance systems that allow pilots to land in conditions of low visibility, officials said yesterday.

title: Heirs of Fortunes Are Among Wealthiest in Senate
description: John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia and such other heirs of fortunes as John Heinz of Pennsylvania and John C. Danforth of Missouri emerged again today as some of the wealthiest members of the Senate.

title: FURTHER EXPANSION OF WEDTECH INQUIRY SOUGHT
description: The chairman of a House panel asked a special prosecutor today to expand his investigation to include senior Government officials who might have lied to Congress about the Wedtech Corporation, a military contractor in the Bronx.

title: NAVISTAR INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $21.9 million for the quarter and $28 million for the 6 months; the 6 months also is after an extraordinary loss of $112.8 million related to debt extinguishment. c-After extraordinary gains of $8.7 million for the quarter and $21.9 million for the 6 months. d-Net income

title: Developer to Preserve Queens Clock Towers
description: Two century-old towers - once the hub of a trolley system that sent its spokes throughout New York City -will be preserved and incorporated into a developer's plan for a shopping center in Woodside, Queens, according to an agreement announced yesterday by Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens.

title: FOR THE U.S., A MIDEAST CONTRADICTION
description: At the core of the recent diplomatic flurry over a Middle East peace conference lies a classic American ambivalence about the Soviet Union, an inner contradiction that reads: We need the Russians but don't want them.

title: SWEEPING CHANGES URGED FOR BRITAIN
description: Britain's general election campaign reached battle speed today with the unveiling of party platforms outlining sharply contrasting ideological visions of Britain's future.

title: CELTICS BEAT PISTONS TO LEAD SERIES, 1-0
description: Offensively the Boston Celtics' game plan never changes. It is geared to getting the ball inside to their big and talented front line of Larry Bird, Kevin McHale and Robert Parish.

title: Motta to Give Decision
description: Although Coach Dick Motta has been given until Friday by the Dallas Mavericks' owner to decide whether to accept a coaching offer from the Knicks, he has scheduled a news conference today to declare his intentions. After meeting with Motta for two hours Monday, the Dallas owner, Donald Carter, said there was no question that Motta would return for an eighth season. ''Coach Motta went to New York with my permission,'' Carter said. ''And in the course of that trip, some of the words and actions definitely created some misunderstandings.''

title: The Nazis, and Other People's Guilt
description: Americans too young to remember World War II have recently been offered highly simplified reruns of Good and Evil. The question of Germany's war guilt was revived two years ago by President Reagan's stubbornly insensitive visit to the cemetery in Bitburg. What Kurt Waldheim really did during the war ignited angry argument before and after his election as President of Austria. Now the trial of Klaus Barbie in France inflames old questions about the guilt of French collaborators as well as of Gestapo torturers.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
England Tied, 1-1
description: Mirandinha scored in the 36th minute as Brazil's national team earned a 1-1 tie against England in the Sir Stanley Rous Cup soccer tournament today. The match, played before 92,000 fans, was the first in the three-team tournament named after the former president of the world governing body. Each team will also play Scotland.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Home on the Range

title: No U.S. Radar Planes for Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: HELM RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,280,000 for the latest quarter and $86,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said the latest quarter earnings include an after-tax gain of $1,452,000 from the sale of stock in Bamberger Polymers, a subsidiary, and an after-tax gain of $970,000 from Bamberger's initial public offering.

title: BARBECUE FIT FOR A KING ON PRINCELY GRILLS
description: LEAD: BARBECUE is only as good as the grill that produces it.That's according to Bill

title: GENEVE CAPITAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized gains on investments of $3,471,160 for the latest quarter and $8,416,131 for the year-earlier period.

title: NATIONAL INTERGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $7.5 million. c-After income from discontinued operations of $54,007,000 and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $6,305,000.

title: The Browns Are Back
description: Nostalgia, which usually sells briskly among people who have been deprived or robbed of something pleasurable, is up for sale again in the pages of the Official 1987 Gift Catalog of Major League Baseball.

title: ARGENTINE REBEL CHIEF CONVICTED
description: Mario Firmenich, the best-known leader of the leftist guerrillas who fought the Argentine Government in the early and middle 1970's, was found guilty today in a 1974 kidnapping-murder case and sentenced to life in prison.

title: Flat Surface Adds Fidelity And Contrast
description: THE idea of a perfectly flat-surfaced color picture tube was tested, and reluctantly rejected as being far too complex, in the 1950's when color television was young. Now, using an advanced design that was originally developed for use in military avionics, Zenith has returned to ''flat technology'' with a new color monitor for computers.

title: WHITE HOUSE'S EMPLOYMENT OF 3 IS UNDER INVESTIGATION IN CONGRESS
description: In what a Congressional investigator has concluded may be a violation of Federal law, White House officials have been using three political appointees in positions unrelated to those they were hired to fill or to the agency that pays their salaries.

title: Rising to the Occasion
description: As coaching debuts go, John Fontana's was memorable. The Southington (Conn.) High School baseball team not only won his opener in 1962, but the pitcher, Tom Garry, also threw a no-hitter. ''It was against Cheshire and was one of three Tom pitched that year,'' Fontana recalled the other day.

title: Fiji Premier Is Freed, and He Promises Trials
description: The Prime Minister and his 11 Cabinet ministers were freed unharmed by the army on Tuesday night, five days after soldiers stormed Parliament and took them hostage.

title: ALL IS RIGHT AT WRIGLEY AGAIN
description: For nearly two months, the faithful at Wrigley Field rose for the seventh-inning stretch and turned west to an empty window in the broadcasting booth and sang, ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game.'' At Wrigley Field, the baseball pious often sway to the tune.

title: Walter Slowinski Jr., Lawyer and Tax Expert
description: Walter Aloysius Slowinski Jr., a leading international tax lawyer and law lecturer, died of cardiac arrest Monday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 66 years old.

title: United Airlines, Citing Fuel Costs, to Raise Fares
description: United Airlines, the nation's largest air carrier, said yesterday that it would raise fares across the nation by $15 for one-way first-class flights and by $10 for one-way unrestricted coach flights, effective June 3.

title: Editor's Note
description: An article yesterday about the new immigration law discussed implications for the employment of child-care helpers in American households.

title: CONCERT: JANACEK'S 'GLAGOLITIC'
description: IF Janacek's ''Glagolitic Mass'' had a Latin text rather than the old Slavonic translation of the traditional liturgy, it might join the requiems of Verdi and Brahms as a staple of the great Romantic chorus-and-orchestra repertory. But it would not be itself, since Janacek's involvement in the rhythms of language was a powerful factor in his compositional life. So this stirring, powerful work is heard in the West only from time to time, when a big choir makes the struggle to learn it. Robert DeCormier, who is retiring after this season from the New York Choral Society that he has directed for 17 years, presented it at his farewell concert Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

title: L.S.U. Suspends Star Outfielder
description: Joey Belle, holder of almost every batting record at Louisiana State University, was suspended today fromm the baseball team, just two days before it begins competition in the National Collegiate Athletic Association regional playoffs.

title: Citicorp Rates Up
description: Interest rates rose moderately at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of the 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.144 percent, up from 6.9367 percent last week. Paper due in 182 days sold at an average rate of 7.282 percent, up from 7.1175 percent.

title: U.S. OFFICER SAYS FRIGATE DEFENSES WERE TURNED OFF
description: The commander of the United States Persian Gulf force said tonight that the sophisticated electronic defenses aboard the frigate Stark were not turned on Sunday because the officers did not fear an Iraqi missile attack.

title: IN WINE INDUSTRY, A MERGER AND A MOVE
description: JIM GIFFORD, the wine maker at Domaine Mumm, said Monday that he will return to the Finger Lakes region of New York in July as wine maker and president of Glenora Wine Cellars.

title: Automated Teller Charge
description: The Marine Midland Bank has begun charging its upstate customers a 75-cent fee for using automated teller machines at other banks. Marine Midland is a member of the New York Cash Exchange, and its customers can gain access to their accounts through the automated teller machines of dozens of banks in several states.

title: Victory at Hand, Aquino's Backers Split Up
description: President Corazon C. Aquino's backers, apparently headed for solid control of the Senate and the House of Representatives, have begun to fragment into competing camps in the race for legislative leadership.

title: BOND PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Bond prices fell sharply yesterday afternoon, just a few hours before Citicorp announced plans to increase its provision for loan losses by $3 billion and take an estimated $2.5 billion second-quarter loss.

title: DESEGREGATION PLANS SAID TO IMPROVE RACE BALANCE IN SCHOOLS
description: A new study concludes that desegregation plans have significantly improved the racial balance in public schools, but it says some of this progress has been offset by declines in white enrollment over the same period.

title: POLAR BEARS KILL A CHILD AT PROSPECT PARK ZOO
description: Two polar bears mauled and killed an 11-year-old boy who climbed a fence at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn with two friends last night and then sneaked into the polar bear enclosure.

title: Controls Takes ICC's $44 Offer
description: The International Controls Corporation, a manufacturer of aerospace and electronic devices, said its board had accepted a revised proposal from the ICC Acquisition Corporation to acquire all common outstanding stock not owned by ICC for $44 a share in cash, up from ICC's earlier offer of $42.50.

title: SCHERER, R P CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $760,000 and $1,420,000 for the quarter and the year, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $4.3 million and $12.6 million related to discontinued operations for the quarter and the year, respectively.

title: LOVELY NOTES, STYLISH TOTES
description: 1.Lace Mats

title: STAGE: 2D BILL OF NEW ONE-ACT PLAYS
description: SURPRISES generally await one at the Ensemble Studio Theater's annual festival of new one-act plays. In Evening B, the second of three parts in Marathon '87, the star - and scene-stealer - is a 6-year-old actor named Macaulay Culkin, who plays the pivotal role in a very funny, malevolent domestic comedy by Keith Reddin.

title: Market Place; Limited's Move In Men's Wear
description: AFTER five years of dramatic success in building the nation's largest retail women's apparel chain, The Limited Inc. created some surprise at its annual meeting in Columbus, Ohio, Monday with an announcement that it would enter the men's apparel field. Yesterday, company watchers on Wall Street, with varying degrees of enthusiasm, endorsed the retailer's move to open 15 experimental Express Man stores this summer or fall.

title: U.S. Bancorp To Buy Peoples
description: The U.S. Bancorp of Portland, Ore., said it had agreed to acquire the Peoples Ban Corp of Seattle in a stock transaction valued at about $275 million. Under the terms of the definitive agreement, U.S. Bancorp will issue 2.6 new shares of its common stock for each of Peoples' 3.8 million shares outstanding.

title: Freedom for Skateboarders
description: Three teen-agers who were arrested, frisked, handcuffed and interrogated last month for skateboarding on the sidewalk in this elite seaside community will probably not be prosecuted, according to Robert Foley, the lawyer representing them. No charges have been filed against the boys since their arrests April 10 for violating a town ordinance banning skateboards on public streets and sidewalks, Mr. Foley said.

title: Veal Alternatives
description: To The Living Section:

title: FLYERS 1, HOCKEY 0
description: Turn on the police scanner, Scoop, we're going to the Stanley Cup finals. You never know where violence might break out when the Philadelphia Flyers are involved.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IN March, when daffodils filled florists' windows and the new crop of warm-weather dresses sprouted ruffles, our friend the would-be fashion maven bought a bunch of both. This summer, she thought with relief and a glance at her ruffles, I will be on top of the new styles.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AGENTS RESCUE GIRLS AND FIND 2 BODIES IN CALIFORNIA HOME
description: Federal agents smashed through the door of a mobile home Monday to rescue two terrified adolescent models and arrest a man who the authorities believe kidnapped them and killed their chaperones.

title: Hugo Black's Widow Dies
description: Elizabeth Black, widow of Justice Hugo Black of the Supreme Court, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Sunday at Sibley Hospital here, her son, Fred J. DeMeritte, said Monday. She was 79 years old. She married Justice Black in 1957. His first wife had died in 1951. He died in 1971, just after retiring from the Court.
