Elizabeth Black's memoirs, ''Mr. Justice and Mrs. Black,'' were published last year.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: Revenue represents total net sales and rental revenue.

title: PRE-COLUMBIAN WORKS COULD BE FAKES
description: Some of the most spectacular examples of pre-Columbian art in major art museums and private collections around the world, including a ceramic sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, are being studied as a possible group of forgeries all made by a single artist now living in Mexico.

title: U.S. CALLS HALT TO INVESTIGATION OF A CONTRACTOR
description: The Justice Department said today that it was closing its three-year fraud inquiry into the General Dynamics Corporation because there was insufficient evidence to obtain a successful prosecution.

title: Wilbur Cohen's Frontiers
description: The time was 1961, the place was John Kennedy's Washington and two young New Frontiersmen were leaving Wilbur Cohen's office in the then-Department of Health, Education and Welfare. ''I sure hope,'' one said, ''that someday the wheel comes around again for us - and that when it does, we'll have the same energy and commitment.''

title: Chevron Unit's $1 Billion Filing
description: Chevron Capital USA has filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a sale of up to $1 billion of guaranteed debt securities. No underwriter was named.

title: Comings and Goings
description: ''I intend to keep them and win the American League pennant,'' said Eddie Chiles, the majority owner of the Texas Rangers, in announcing that he would no longer accept offers to buy his team. ''It's a closed chapter.'' Chiles had been considering offers because his Western Company has been foundering from problems in the energy business. . . . Billy Carroll, 28, who played seven years in the National Hockey League and was on four Stanley Cup championship teams - three times with the Islanders - will retire to enter real estate. Injuries limited the Detroit Red Wing center to only 31 games this season. . . . The Seattle Seahawks have acquired quarterback Jeff Kemp in a trade with the San Francisco 49ers. The 49ers will receive an undisclosed future choice in the draft. Kemp, 27, played in 10 games for the 49ers last season, including six starts in place of Joe Montana, who was injured. . . . Everson Walls, the Dallas Cowboys' cornerback, has signed a three-year contract worth $5.05 million, his manager said. The contract will make him the fifth highest-paid player on the team, and the second highest-paid cornerback in the league.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-After a charge of $14,148,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said the latest quarter's sales do not include those of John Wanamaker, which was sold Dec. 31, 1986.

title: RASMUSSEN MAKES A QUICK DEPARTURE
description: One night earlier, the Yankees' offense was limited to two bases-empty homers by Dave Winfield. Tonight, they scored as many runs, but had less success.

title: Fun on the Radio With Bob and Ted
description: It's the Bob and Ted show!

title: BLACK IS HANDED DEED TO OFFICES OF KLAN GROUP
description: The keys to the door and the deed to the headquarters of one of nation's largest Ku Klux Klan organizations now belong to a 67-year-old black woman from Alabama, the mother of a teen-age son whose murder in 1981 was tied to two Klansmen.

title: TWO RAP GROUPS PLAN EXTENSIVE SUMMER TOUR
description: RUN-D.M.C. and the Beastie Boys, the country's two most popular rap music acts, have announced a 40-city summerlong tour tentatively scheduled to begin in Honolulu on June 13 and to culminate at Madison Square Garden on Aug. 17. The ''Together Forever'' tour will be one of the few in pop music history to give top billing to black and white acts of equal stature. Both Run-D.M.C.'s latest album, ''Raising Hell,'' and the Beastie Boys' debut, ''Licensed to Ill,'' have surpassed the three million mark in sales.

title: McHale Gets Support
description: Fans of the Boston Celtics pledged more than enough money yesterday to pay a $3,000 fine the National Basketball Association levied Monday against Kevin McHale, the Celtic forward, for a shoving incident with a fan in Milwaukee on May 8. ''We wondered what would cause Kevin McHale, Mr. Clean Cut, to go after a fan,'' said Andy Moes, a co-host of a morning talk show on WROR-FM radio, which received the pledges. ''The resounding overwhelming tone of the calls was that they had been at sporting events where some guy was being obnoxious. One cop called and said, 'It's about time somebody stepped in and did that.' '' McHale, who said he would appeal the fine, said he appreciated support, but would ask the N.B.A. office whether he could accept the pledges.

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The crew of the Stark did not believe they were in any danger. I do not think that they had any fear that they were under fire.'' -Rear Adm. Harold J. Bernsen. [ A1:6. ]

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of Wilbur J. Cohen yesterday misstated his college background. Mr. Cohen, former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, graduated from the University of Wisconsin, not Michigan.

title: The U.N. Today: May 20, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest second quarter includes the results of Enterprise Paint Cos., acquired Dec. 31.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Convicted Drug Dealer Held In Death of Mob Figure's Son
description: A convicted drug dealer was arrested early yesterday and charged with the murder of a suspected organized-crime figure who was found shot to death on a Brooklyn street Monday, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MAY 20, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY Citicorp will increase its reserves for possible loan losses by $3 billion, a move that will result in a $2.5 billion quarterly loss for the nation's largest banking company. Citicorp also said it would step up its efforts to reduce its debt exposure in the third world. The company's action is likely to cause an upheaval in the banking community and in financial markets. [ Page A1. ] Brazilian officials say interest payments to Western governments may be halted. [ D6. ] Housing construction dropped 2.9 percent in April as apartment building fell to its lowest level in four years. New homes and apartments were built at an annual rate of 1.70 million units. [ D1. ] The Senate Banking Committee passed a bill that would reduce a company's responsibility to police its employees on foreign bribery matters under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. [ D17. ] MARKETS A Federal judge dismissed insider trading charges against three Wall Street professionals, as requested by the prosecution. The move gives the United States Attorney almost unlimited time to seek the new, broader indictment he has promised. [ D1. ] The stock market was battered by the rumors about Citicorp's plan involving its reserves for loan losses. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 37.38, to 2,221.28, while volume inched higher. [ D1. ] Bond prices fell sharply in reaction to Citicorp's plans. Earlier, bond prices had weakened a bit in sympathy with a slight drop in the dollar, but the declines later swelled. [ D17. ] New York City is using municipal bond insurance for the first time, seeking to ease the burden of high interest rates. [ D17. ] The dollar tumbled against most currencies amid market anxiety over higher rates, a weaker economy and accelerating inflation. Gold prices rose $5 an ounce, to $476.50. [ D18. ] Precious metals surged in futures trading. Energy contracts were mixed. [ D18. ] COMPANIES The Government closed its inquiry into General Dynamics because of insufficient evidence for a successful prosecution. The Justice Department's original fraud inquiry into overcharges for submarines by the nation's largest military contractor had begun in 1979. It was reopened after a former executive turned over tapes of conversations he had secretly recorded. [ A1. ] I.B.M. is entering the ''systems integration'' business -installing and running computer systems composed of equipment from many vendors - in an apparent effort to make up for sagging profits. The move marks a significant change of strategy. [ D1. ] Ford will guarantee the resale value of its new Merkur Scorpio by promising that it will not depreciate at a rate faster than the Mercedes-Benz 190's. If it does, Ford will pay the difference. [ D1. ] Harcourt Brace Jovanovich's stock closed at $48, well above the $44 price offered by the publisher Robert Maxwell. Analysts see a number of possible outcomes to the takeover battle. [ D4. ] A.T.&T. will move no more than 778 headquarters employees from its Manhattan headquarters to Basking Ridge, N.J., under a modification of its relocation plan endorsed by Mayor Koch. [ B1. ] Two more Merrill Lynch executives have resigned, in the wake of the firm's $275 million trading losses. [ D4. ] Four investors have made a bid for controlling interest in Resorts International, topping an offer by Donald J. Trump. [ D4. ] TECHNOLOGY American Rocket is using a decades-old rocket motor design as it tries to compete with NASA, the Air Force and large military contractors in the space-launching business. [ D8. ] A perfectly flat color picture tube will soon appear in Zenith products. The idea was rejected in the 1950's as too complex. The new design was developed for military avionics. Advances. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The U.S. has become dependent on foreigners' savings, while its swelling budget deficit has been the leading cause of the drop in the domestic savings rate. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The Limited's move to open 15 experimental stores for men this summer or fall was generally greeted with favor by the company's watchers on Wall Street. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Gore Goes Abroad
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee, a member of the Senate arms control observer group and an active contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination, will step onto the world stage next week.

title: INFECTED BUT NOT ILL, MANY TRY UNPROVED DRUG TO BLOCK AIDS
description: While AIDS patients search in vain for remedies, thousands of other Americans who have not yet developed the deadly illness are traveling to Mexico to buy an experimental drug they hope will prevent its onset.

title: Bring Back TV's Antismoking Ads
description: Who could forget those public service announcements on television between 1967 and 1970 that dramatized the health hazards of smoking?

title: SOVIET FOR WIDER MIDEAST TALKS
description: A Soviet spokesman said today that a Middle East peace conference must be more than an ''umbrella'' for face-to-face negotiations between Israel and Jordan, and that the Palestine Liberation Organization should determine who would represent Palestinian interests at such a meeting.

title: Nicaraguan Coffee
description: To The Living Section:

title: CONNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW YORK CITY TO BUILD FIVE SHELTERS MODELED ON S.R.O. HOTELS
description: The Koch administration has abandoned its plans to erect dormitory-style shelters for homeless individuals and will instead put up five buildings modeled on single-room-occupancy hotels, city officials said yesterday.

title: TEAMSTER SPOKE OF LINK TO MOB, A WITNESS SAYS
description: A major informer has testified in a racketeering trial that Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, told him of having close ties to a Mafia boss.

title: Reagan Ignites a Constitutional Crisis
description: After President's Reagan's former national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, testified that he had briefed the President ''dozens'' of times about the steps that he and various aides were taking to raise funds for the contras' military operations, the White House defense began edging away from the increasingly implausible ''factual'' claim of no Presidential involvement and toward an even more troubling legal claim of Presidential immunity.

title: Adam Smith Understood The Limits of Greed
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTERN HEALTH PLANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 25
Goodbye Moscow, Hello Chill
description: Only a year ago Arthur A. Hartman, the United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, and his wife, Donna, flew back to Washington for a day of praise and honors. The Institute for the Study of Diplomacy at Georgetown University was giving Mr. Hartman an award for ''his unique contribution to excellence in American diplomacy and to the career Foreign Service that nurtures it.''

title: Bell & Howell Sale Of DeVry Stake
description: The Bell & Howell Company, as part of its strategy to focus on its publishing and information-services operations, said it planned to sell its majority stake in DeVry Inc., a technical-school business, for $147.4 million. The sale of 85 percent of the unit to the Keller Graduate School of Management received Wall Street's approval. The company's stock rose $3, to $47.25, today.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for 13wks to May 2
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 common stock split on April 13, 1987.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MAY 20, 1987
description: International A3-15, B10-12

title: 9 SCHOOL INSPECTORS INDICTED IN A SCHEME TO ORGANIZE BRIBES
description: A grand jury has indicted nine building maintenance supervisors and inspectors for the New York City Board of Education on charges that they joined in a bribe-taking conspiracy that was planned 10 years ago.

title: NOT MUCH MARGIN
description: When Bobby Rahal won the Indianapolis 500 last year with a record average speed of 170.72 miles an hour, he beat Kevin Cogan, the runner-up, by only 1.44 seconds. But the narrowest margin of victory was the 16 one hundredths of a second that separated Gordon Johncock and Rick Mears in 1982. The 10 closest finishes in Indianapolis history: Margin Year, Winner Runner-up in seconds 1982, Gordon Johncock Rick Mears 0.16 1986, Bobby Rahal Kevin Cogan 1.44 1937, Wilbur Shaw Ralph Hepburn 2.16 1985, Danny Sullivan Mario Andretti 2.48 1981, Bobby Unser Mario Andretti 5.18 1978, Al Unser Tom Sneva 8.19 1961, A. J. Foyt Eddie Sachs 8.28 1983, Tom Sneva Al Unser 11.17 1962, Rodger Ward Len Sutton 11.52 1960, Jim Rathman Rodger Ward 12.67

title: The Hollywood Touch
description: From the top down, officials of the Reagan Administration seem to think the American people are either such gullible fools, or so trusting of those in power, or both, that they will believe anything - no matter how contradictory or implausible. Call it the Hollywood touch.

title: A Bid for Resorts Tops Trump Deal
description: A New York lawyer said today that that he and three other investors have made a bid for a controlling interest in Resorts International Inc. that tops by $75 a share an offer made by Donald J. Trump, the New York developer.

title: A Trip to the Market to Get Some Money
description: At one point in his testimony, Robert W. Owen provided details of a trip to New York to get money from a market on the Lower West Side.

title: U.S. GAINS TIME IN INSIDE CASE
description: A Federal judge yesterday granted the prosecution's motion to dismiss insider trading charges against three Wall Street professionals. The move gives the United States Attorney almost unlimited time to seek the new, broader indictment he has promised.

title: DOLE DISSENTS ON MOZAMBIQUE POLICY
description: Senate Republicans are mounting an offensive to force the Reagan Administration to abandon its support for the Government of Mozambique and instead back an anti-Communist insurgent group with ties to South Africa.

title: Libya's Moves Incite Fear
description: Libyan overtures to the South Pacific are provoking fears of a new front of Libyan-sponsored terrorism, in a region unaccustomed to anything more violent than a free-falling coconut.

title: YOUTH SHOT IN SUBWAY SAYS HE DIDN'T APPROACH GOETZ
description: One of the four youths who was shot by Bernhard H. Goetz on a Manhattan subway train in December 1984 testified yesterday that he was in his seat minding his own business and looking away when Mr. Goetz pulled a pistol and opened fire.

title: 3 HEART TRANSPLANT PATIENTS: RENEWED AND FULFILLING LIVES
description: AS Alfred Steffen lay on an operating room table in Pittsburgh last year, his body rejected the heart that had just been transplanted. Dr. Bartley P. Griffith of Presbyterian-University Hospital gave Mr. Steffen's wife, Joy, a choice: let her husband die or permit doctors to implant an artificial heart until a second human heart could be found.

title: REAGAN SAYS FILMS AND MUSIC MUST STOP GLORIFYING DRUGS
description: President Reagan suggested today that the movie and music industries should tighten their standards and become less tolerant of productions that glorify and encourage drug abuse.

title: A HUMBLE ROCKET ASPIRES FOR STARS
description: GEORGE A. KOOPMAN likes to think of his nascent commercial space launching business not as a daring, high-technology endeavor but as the outer space version of United Parcel Service.

title: 2 Resign At Merrill
description: Two more executives have left Merrill Lynch & Company in the wake of the staggering trading losses announced last month. The executives supervised Howard A. Rubin, who was recently ousted after his unauthorized trading contributed to a $275 million loss.

title: JERSEY ADVOCATE URGES STATE TAKEOVER OF BEACHES
description: The state's Public Advocate urged today that New Jersey take over all beaches along the coast, charging that oceanfront communities were imposing the highest beach fees in the nation.

title: IN A SETBACK TO REAGAN'S POLICY, HOUSE VOTES TO HALT NUCLEAR TESTS
description: In a setback for the Reagan Administration, the House of Representatives voted today to prohibit all but the smallest nuclear tests.

title: 3 HEALTH WORKERS FOUND INFECTED BY BLOOD OF PATIENTS WITH AIDS
description: Federal health officials said today that they had learned of three cases in which health care workers became infected with the AIDS virus after their skin was briefly exposed to blood from infected patients.

title: U.S. WIDENS NAVY'S ESCORT ROLE IN THE GULF WAR ZONE DESPITE ATTACK ON SHIP
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was moving quickly to provide naval escorts for 11 Kuwaiti oil tankers that operate in the war zone at the north end of the Persian Gulf, expanding the American military role there despite the attack that crippled the frigate Stark and killed 37 crew members.

title: CITICORP ACCEPTS A BIG LOSS LINKED TO FOREIGN LOANS
description: Citing continuing problems in the world economy, Citicorp said yesterday that it would lose $2.5 billion in the second quarter because of an increase in its cushion for possible loan losses.

title: AUTHOR KILLS HERSELF AND AGED HUSBAND IN SUBURB OF CAPITAL
description: A critically acclaimed science fiction author, who wrote under the pen name James Tiptree Jr., killed her husband and herself today after warning her lawyer to call the police, the authorities said.

title: Owen's Work With North: Tales of Jokes, Cash and Secrecy
description: In his second day of testimony yesterday at the Congressional hearings in Washington on the Iran-contra affair, Robert W. Owen discussed his work for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. Here, as recorded by The New York Times, are excerpts from his testimony. JOKING ABOUT ACTIONS

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times yesterday incorrectly described a statement in the American Psychiatric Association's revised diagnostic manual. The manual says it is for use only by mental health professionals.

title: AN AVANT-GARDE SERIES IS SET AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: Lincoln Center announced yesterday a two-week series of avant-garde performance events this summer, its most extensive commitment thus far to new music, dance and performance.

title: U.S. AND IRAQ PLAN A JOINT INQUIRY
description: The United States and Iraq will conduct a joint investigation of the Iraqi missile attack on a United States frigate in the Persian Gulf, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Drexel Financing Study
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert, the Wall Street investment house, said yesterday that a study it conducted of 23,000 United States companies with sales of at least $25 million showed that fewer than 800 qualified for investment-grade bond ratings by Standard & Poor's or Moody's. The rest, it said, would be financed by the high-yielding securities known as ''junk bonds.'' Drexel said it accounted for 46 percent of the capital raised through such securities in the first quarter.

title: Gretzky Voted the Best
description: Wayne Gretzky, the Edmonton center, received two honors at the annual National Hockey League awards ceremony today. For the third straight year, Gretzky was named the N.H.L. Player of the Year.

title: STIFEL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 24
MCDOWELL BRINGS RELIEF AS METS AVERT MISHAP
description: Snakebit, they are. Bewitched, they are. Maybe even bothered and bewildered. Whatever they are, a lot of strange things are haunting the Mets in this season of omens and tricks and haunting scenes.

title: WARNER COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ROYALS WIN, 4-1
description: Bret Saberhagen pitched a six-hitter and became the American League's first seven-game winner tonight, leading Kansas City to a 4-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: KEY RATES
SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $863,000 from a tax credit and payment of a debt in an affiliate. c-Includes a tax credit of $73,000.

title: Robinson Named To Pan Am Club
description: David Robinson of Navy and two players from Indiana, the National Collegiate Athletic Association champions, have been named to the 12-member basketball team that will represent the United States in the Pan American Games in Indianapolis in August.

title: EXPO '87: BRIGADOON OF BOUTIQUES AND SAD STORIES
description: The floatplane banked for its approach into Vancouver harbor, giving passengers a stunning view of cruise boats anchored at the Royal Vancouver Yacht Club, of the towering redwoods in Stanley Park, and of mountains topped with snow in a springtime temperature of 80 degrees.

title: VMS HOTEL INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AT FORD, A RESALE GUARANTEE
description: In an effort to woo buyers of high-priced European cars, the Ford Motor Company is introducing a new marketing tactic with the debut of its Merkur Scorpio model: a guarantee on resale value.

title: Bill on Easing Bribery Curbs Gains
description: The Senate Banking Committee today approved a bill that would significantly ease the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act by reducing a company's responsibility to police its employees on foreign bribery matters and permitting certain ''nominal'' payments to foreign government officials.

title: WESTERN CAPITAL INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,250,000.

title: New Ways to Treat Third World Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Calculation Of Municipal Yield
description: The municipal bond yield shown in the Key Rates table today is calculated on the basis of yield to maturity, rather than yield to the first call date at a price of par.

title: U.S.-Egyptian War Games
description: The United States and Egypt plan to hold joint air, sea and land exercises in August, Egyptian Defense Ministry spokesmen said today. The war games, called Bright Star-87, would include mock attacks, the spokesmen said.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
A SAFER CALZONE
description: LEAD: DOES it surprise you to see a recipe for calzone here? If so, you're probably a victim of the stale notion that Italian food, and its components, are too tasty and therefore inherently unhealthy. There is nothing wrong with eating pasta, as long as you don't consume several plates at a sitting. And tomato sauce is fine, as long as it is made with olive oil rather than salt pork or fatback, which add saturated fats and cholesterol.

title: Ex-Officer of Pepsico Is Cogenic Chairman
description: When Herman A. Schaefer retired two years ago as chief financial officer of Pepsico Inc., he planned to get involved in a few ventures and take life a little easier.

title: COUNCIL PANELISTS SEE HIGHER SURPLUS
description: New York City's budget surplus may be as much as $200 million above the $500 million announced three weeks ago by Mayor Koch, members of the City Council Finance Committee said yesterday.

title: 5 People Get Organs of Slain Man
description: Surgeons here removed organs from a man who was fatally shot during a robbery and transplanted them into five people, hospital officials said today.

title: CHURCH ORDERED TO RETURN $6 MILLION TO GIVER
description: A judge in Federal Bankruptcy Court ruled today that a fundamentalist church, Bible Speaks, had ''abused the trust'' of a chief contributor, and he ordered the return of $6.6 million that the member said she had been duped into donating.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Audrey P. Hawks, 44, Chief Of Caribbean Tourism Group
description: Audrey Palmer Hawks, the director general of the Caribbean Tourism Association and a former senator and minister of state for tourism in Grenada, West Indies, died of cancer May 1 at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. She was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Zenith Ruling
description: Zenith Laboratories Inc. said a civil action against it by the Bristol-Myers Company charging infringement of a patent had been terminated by a consent order by the United States District Court for New Jersey. As previously reported, Bristol-Meyers charged that Zenith had infringed on its patent covering a form of Cefadroxil, an antibiotic. Zenith said the court order requires that it provide Bristol-Myers with a sample of any Cefadroxil product that it intends to market at least 50 days before the beginning of marketing.

title: JETS CUT LYNN OVER PHYSICALS
description: The Jets, already embroiled in a lawsuit with one former player representative, cut another yesterday when they put Johnny Lynn on waivers as ''failed physical.''

title: Brazil Debt Move Hinted
description: Brazilian officials have begun warning privately that the country might suspend interest payments on its debts to Western governments, as it has done with foreign banks, because of the depletion of Brazil's hard-currency reserves.

title: Medicaid Is for Families, Too
description: At a time when virtually everyone agrees the welfare system ought to nudge recipients toward work and self-sufficiency, a key facet of New York's system pushes the opposite way.

title: BOTHA OUTLINES TERMS FOR ANY CHANGES
description: President P. W. Botha, opening the segregated Parliament, asserted today that there would be no further political initiatives until black leaders were prepared to enter talks on power-sharing on the Government's terms.

title: UTAH POWER AND LIGHT CO reports earnings for 12mo April 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $43,741,076 from the Dec. 1986 provision for the coal mining operations refund.

title: Reagan Names 2 Envoys
description: President Reagan will name two career diplomats as Ambassadors to Bangladesh and Congo, the White House said today. Willard De Pree, 58 years old, will be Ambassador to Bangladesh to succeed Howard Schaffer and Alan Shurtleff, 46, will succeed Alan Lukens as Ambassador to Congo, the White House said.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $22,158,000 for the latest quarter and $1,084,000 for the year-ago period.

title: I.B.M. RESHAPING ITS SALES STRATEGY
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it was entering a new facet of the computer business - installing and running computer systems composed of equipment from many vendors -in an apparent effort to make up for sagging profits in its mainstream businesses.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Wet Start for Tournament: The Dodge Open - the season's first event for competition among professionals in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut - had a cold and wet start yesterday in Denville, N.J., with only six players in a field of 64 breaking par for the Rockaway River Country Club. Bobby Heins, the head pro at Old Oaks in Purchase, N.Y., led with a three-under-par 69. Joe Felder of Innis Arden, in Old Greenwich, Conn., followed with a 70. Darryl Kestner of Winged Foot, Carl Lohren of North Shore, Ed Whitman of Knickerbocker, and Mike San Filippo of Ridgeway posted 71's. TENNIS Georgia Takes Title: Georgia capitalized on an injury to U.C.L.A.'s top player, Dan Nahirney, yesterday to win its second National Collegiate Athletic Association men's team championship in three years. Nahirney was leading Philip Johnson, 6-4, 2-1, in Athens, Ga., when he apparently tore ligaments in his right knee and retired. Georgia won five of six singles matches; the three doubles matches were canceled. (AP)

title: Waldheim Sees Errors In His Initial Reaction
description: President Kurt Waldheim acknowledged today that he reacted improperly to accusations that he was involved in Nazi war crimes, but he reiterated that he was innocent of wrongdoing and offered an explanation of what he meant by doing his ''duty'' in Hitler's army.

title: Bonding and Women
description: To The Living Section:

title: 5 Are Killed as Truck Flips Over Onto Car
description: A young couple, their two daughters and a woman were killed yesterday when a garbage truck flipped over onto their car, the police said.

title: Stars' Showing Sparks Oilers
description: After just one victory, a calm seemed to drift over the entire Oiler organization and, as if in celebration, a minor spring blizzard painted the town white today.

title: MAXWELL'S SUCCESS IS UNCERTAIN
description: Wall Street professionals said yesterday that there were numerous possible outcomes to Robert Maxwell's takeover bid for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., a leading publishing company.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OF LOVE AND SHADOWS. By Isabel Allende. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. 274 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: AVX Is Offering Convertible Issue
description: The AVX Corporation, a manufacturer of ceramic capacitors, is offering $75 million of 8 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2012 at par through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: WEBSTER IS CONFIRMED BY SENATE AS HEAD OF CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE
description: William H. Webster, who won bipartisan acclaim for his nine-year leadership of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was confirmed by the Senate tonight as Director of Central Intelligence. The vote was 94 to 1. The 63-year-old former Federal judge will take charge of the Central Intelligence Agency at a particularly difficult moment in its history. The C.I.A. is under intense scrutiny by Congress for its role in the Iran-contra affair. Assailed on Notice Requirements

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Ford Indictment
description: The 23-member Congressional Black Caucus is trying to raise money for the legal defense of Representative Harold E. Ford, a Tennessee Democrat who was indicted last month by a Federal grand jury in Knoxville on charges of bank and mail fraud.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $89,963. c-Net loss and includes a tax benefit of $5,029. Corrected from Wednesday, May 13, editions.

title: Real Estate; An Office Boom in Somerset
description: FOR the last decade, office developers have pushed steadily westward from New York into the farmland of Morris and Somerset Counties in New Jersey in a bid to provide alternatives to the high rents in Manhattan.

title: AN UPSTART CATERER WINS BIG
description: ONLY in textbooks do businesses start because an entrepreneur studiously analyzes a market, discovers a hole, makes a plan for filling it and goes into action. Julie Rose was an aspiring but unemployed producer, a former musician and a sometime caterer when she got a message on her answering machine saying that the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center was looking for a concessionaire to serve its patrons.

title: Ludlam, in Hospital, Explains Postponement
description: Charles Ludlam, who withdrew last week as director of Shakespeare's ''Titus Andronicus,'' scheduled for Central Park this summer, is recovering from double pneumonia, he said yesterday, explaining that the illness was the reason for his withdrawal.

title: 2.9% DROP IN HOME BUILDING
description: Housing construction dropped 2.9 percent in April as apartment building fell to its lowest level in four years, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts warned of further declines brought on by rising mortgage rates.

title: Muddled Coup in Fiji
description: They had a military coup last week in Fiji, the South Pacific paradise whose tourist slogan is ''The Way the World Should Be.'' A Sandhurst-trained officer stormed into Parliament, leading bizarre-looking troops wearing gas masks. Lieut. Col. Sitiveni Rabuka arrested the entire Cabinet of a newly elected Government and claimed he had been sworn in by the island group's Governor General, who is appointed by Queen Elizabeth II. The coup sputtered as the colonel freed the jailed Cabinet and the Governor General promised new elections, while the newly released Prime Minister challenged his authority.

title: TRANSDUCER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BALLET: MARIN'S 'CINDERELLA'
description: MAGUY MARIN'S choreographically magical ''Cendrillon'' (''Cinderella'') returned to the City Center Theater yesterday afternoon. Thanks to technological magic, the production by the Lyon Opera Ballet also returned to France, for the company's reopening in New York was televised by TF1, one of the French networks. It was the 100th performance of the ballet, which was created in 1985.

title: FOR THIS ARTIST, RICH PATTERNS IN LIFE AND YARN
description: Kaffe Fassett entered his yarn-filled workroom carefully balancing a tea tray. Next to the ordinary pot and mugs, all worn and unmatched, stood a vase of tomato-red flowers, a jolt of color that heightened and defined the tones of the tea set. It was the precise effect one would expect from Mr. Fassett, a textile artist whose knitting and needlepoint designs reverberate with luxuriant and often surprising color.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Coca-Cola Bottling Co., Charlotte, N.C., said William H. Dougherty Jr. had resigned as vice chairman and chief financial officer to ''pursue outside business investments.''

title: INSIDE
description: Black Given Klan Property

title: PREWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOW TUMBLES BY 37.38 ON CITICORP RUMORS
description: The stock market was battered yesterday by rumors that Citicorp would restructure its portfolio of loans to developing nations and by fears of higher interest rates.

title: Frequent-Flier Tax Is Like Tax on Decoder Rings
description: To the Editor:

title: AEGON INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. U.S. dollar equivalents are translated at the first quarter average rate of Dfl 2.076 equals $1.00.

title: NEW YORK ENDS A 10-YEAR FIGHT FOR POWER PLANT
description: A 10-year-old controversy about building a million-kilowatt, pumped-storage generating plant at Prattsville in the Catskill Mountains ended today when the New York Power Authority announced it was giving up the project.

title: HARCOURT: A VULNERABLE GIANT
description: William Jovanovich owns only about 1 percent of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., but he has long ruled the diversified publisher as if he owned all of it. Unlike the chairmen and chief executives of most publicly held companies, he has had little use for Wall Street, the press or even his peers in the publishing industry.

title: VMS SHORT TERM INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PENNEY, J C CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-After a provision for relocation of corporate headquarters of $82 million. c-After an extraordinary charge on debt restructuring of $24 million. The share earnings for the latest first quarter reflects a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 1.

title: The Invitation
description: Aides to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger are looking favorably on the Soviet suggestion that top defense officials from the two countries meet to discuss the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.

title: Inside Children's Television
description: CY SCHNEIDER has written a book titled ''Children's Television, the Art, the Business and How it Works.'' And having five children is only one of his credentials.

title: Morton Thiokol Begins Tests For Drug Use at Space Center
description: Morton Thiokol Inc., the failure of whose space shuttle booster rocket was blamed for the Challenger disaster 16 months ago, started screening its Kennedy Space Center workers for drug use Monday.

title: FILM: MURPHY IN 'COP II'
description: IN the interval between ''Beverly Hills Cop'' and ''Beverly Hills Cop II,'' Axel Foley, the brash young police detective from Detroit, has been on at least one fishing trip with Billy Rosewood (Judge Reinhold), John Taggart (John Ashton) and Andrew Bogomil (Ronny Cox), his friends on the Beverly Hills force. Some other things have happened as well. Axel has become, in the mind of the nation if not in his own, the supreme practitioner of inspired back talk, the wise guy against whom all others are measured. To anyone who saw the first film, Eddie Murphy's endlessly resourceful Axel is now no stranger to the ways of Beverly Hills, and no novice at manipulating them to his own comic advantage.

title: 9.9% Tiffany Stake
description: A British pension fund said that it had acquired a 9.9 percent stake in Tiffany & Company, the New York-based jewelry and silversmith company. The fund - the Merchant Navy Officers Pension Fund - said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it bought its entire holding of 829,500 shares of Tiffany common stock between May 5 and May 11 at $21.62 to $23.12 a share, for a total of about $18.6 million. The Tiffany stock was purchased for investment purposes, the fund said. Although it may increase its Tiffany stake, the fund said it had no plans to seek control of the company or try to influence its management. The fund is based in Surrey, England.

title: GIANTS LOOK AT LONG SHOTS
description: Dave Walter said he was not even going to think about his chances of making the team: ''I'm just going to do the best I can day by day.''

title: A Third of Afghans Have Fled
description: Five million Afghans, or one-third of the country's population, have fled from Afghanistan as a result of the civil war in which Soviet forces have been fighting since 1979 on the Government side against Islamic insurgents, an international conference on refugees was told today.

title: About New York; Magazine Chaos: From Hot Tubs To Talking Birds
description: ''Do you have Women?'' Marilyn Imhoff asked the newsstand clerk. ''No,'' replied the clerk, who said he had lots of Womans, but no Women. ''I have Woman, New Woman, Complete Woman, Working Woman, New York Woman - all those Womans.''

title: Steinbrenner Testifies
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, testified for nearly four hours yesterday at a hearing of a players' union grievance that owners conspired to restrict the movement of free agents and hold down salaries. Donald Fehr, the union's executive director, said that Steinbrenner provided no new or substantial information during the closed session. Steinbrenner refused to comment on his testimony to Thomas Roberts, the arbitrator who will decide the case under a collective bargaining procedure.

title: TASTE OF HOME FOR LONESOME NEBRASKANS
description: NEBRASKANS living in New York miss the sweeping prairies, lush sunsets and college linebackers who can hit, and many do not think much of the subways and the skyscrapers and - frankly - the rudeness. But the Nebraskans recently had two tons of food from home to comfort them.

title: ROYALE AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Judge Sets Hearing To Aid in Sentencing
description: A Criminal Court judge decided yesterday to hear psychiatrists and others before sentencing a high school student who hired a classmate to kill her father because, she said, he sexually abused her.

title: SOUTHERN UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $42,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes a loss of $557,000 from discontinued operations and a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $2,216,000.

title: 4 ARRESTED IN TOKYO SPY CASE
description: Four Japanese, including an employee at a United States air base, were arrested Tuesday night and charged with passing technical documents of American military aircraft to a Soviet official.

title: President to Fill Navy Post
description: President Reagan plans to nominate H. Lawrence Garrett 3d, general counsel to the Defense Department, as Under Secretary of the Navy, the White House announced today.

title: FILM: 'GOOD WEATHER,' FRANCE'S MIDDLE CLASS
description: ''GOOD WEATHER, but Stormy Late This Afternoon'' is a sort of tribute to Micheline Presle, a French actress who came to international attention in 1947 when she starred with Gerard Philipe in ''Le Diable au Corps.'' Gerard Frot-Coutaz, who directed and collaborated on the screenplay for ''Good Weather,'' his first feature, loses no chance to display Ms. Presle's still attractive face and offers her plenty of opportunity to show her stuff, from comedically cracked to sadly sexy. The pleasant movie, which opens today at Film Forum 1 (whose modest marquee may not be able to accommodate the windy title), is a slice-of-middle-aged-life that goes from soup to soap.

title: DR. H. FRIEDMAN DIES IN CALIFORNIA
description: Herbert Friedmann, an ornithologist and director emeritus of the Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History, died Thursday at Saddleback Hospital in Laguna Hills, Calif. He was 87 years old.

title: Pays His Own Fare
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY FINDS HARRAH'S ERRED BUT RENEWS CASINO LICENSE
description: The Casino Control Commission voted today to renew the license of Harrah's Marina casino in Atlantic City, despite ''mistakes in judgment'' by some managers involving organized crime.

title: No Toxic Materials Are Found on Barge
description: New York City health inspectors, in their second day of testing garbage aboard the barge, Mobro, said they found no evidence of hazardous or toxic material.

title: HIGH ACIDITY IN A JERSEY AQUIFER IS FOUND TO INCREASE LEAD HAZARD
description: Ground water in much of New Jersey's coastal plain is sufficiently acidic to extract lead from plumbing, producing unacceptably high levels of lead in the tap water of some homes, it was reported here today.

title: Hispanic Adviser Named
description: Mayor Koch has named an educator and administrator, Luis A. Miranda, as his special adviser for Hispanic affairs. The $70,000-a-year position was previously held by John Cinque-Sacarello, who has been named to the Housing Authority. Mr. Miranda, 32 years old, of Manhattan, worked for the Board of Education until 1984, when he became a director of the National Action Council for Minorities in Engineering.

title: MAYOR AND FORMER MAYOR WIN PHILADELPHIA PRIMARIES
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode, assailed long and hard by critics who charged that he had badly mismanaged this city's affairs, revived his political fortunes and his troubled administration today by easily defeating Edward G. Rendell, a former District Attorney, in the Democratic mayoral primary.

title: France Backs Airbus Jets
description: The French Government will help finance the participation of two state aerospace groups in the European Airbus consortium's long-range A340 and medium-range A330 jet projects, the Transport Minister, Jacques Douffiagues, said today.

title: Eight Artists in Show
description: ''One Challenge: Eight Visions,'' an art exhibition sponsored by the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, will open tomorrow at the society, 205 East 42d Street. Eight artists who have the disease are represented in the show, which will be up through August.

title: MINISTRY NETWORK TO CHANGE NAME
description: The PTL television network is trying to bolster its image within the cable television industry by dropping PTL from its formal name and distancing itself from the troubled television ministry, network officials said today.

title: Interpublic Group Discloses Ad Research
description: At the annual meeting of the Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday in the Time-Life Auditorium, Philip H. Geier Jr., chairman and chief executive, disclosed that the holding company and its agencies are in the midst of developing proprietary research that will be used in making advertising.

title: AFTER THE RIVERS REVERSAL, FOX IS PLUGGING AHEAD
description: ''The Late Show'' with Joan Rivers was the first and biggest show in the Fox Broadcasting Company's effort to become television's fourth network. Last week, when low ratings prompted Ms. Rivers's removal as regular host of the show, it became Fox's first and biggest failure.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: At the Greenmarkets

title: MCI Matches A.T.&T.'s Cut
description: The MCI Communications Corporation plans to lower its long-distance telephone rates by 4.8 percent, matching a similar rate reduction by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, an MCI spokesman said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A dispatch on Monday from South Bend, Ind., about commencement exercises at the University of Notre Dame, omitted two recipients of honorary degrees. They were Joan Kroc, philanthropist, and Carlos Chagas, president of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences.

title: Micro Devices Seeks Damages
description: The Advanced Micro Devices Corporation has disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it is seeking an award of $1 billion in monetary damages in its dispute with the Intel Corporation over the right to manufacture important new chips. Advanced Micro's filing said that it would alternately seek $100 million in damages plus the right to make the chips.

title: Brewers Lose 12th Straight
description: Carlton Fisk and Greg Walker hit two-run homers tonight as the Chicago White Sox dealt the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-1, their 12th straight loss. The Brewers' pitcher, Teddy

title: ZENITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CLASSIC GAME FOODS GRACE SUMMER TABLES
description: WITH Memorial Day and summer's barbecues and picnics upon us, serving game seems about as logical as planning a clambake for Christmas dinner. But rabbit, squab, boar and the like, traditionally regarded as cold-weather fare, are now foods for all seasons.

title: ENGINEERED SUPPORT SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. TO ALLOW USE OF TRIAL DRUGS FOR AIDS AND OTHER TERMINAL ILLS >
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they had completed work on a new rule to make experimental drugs more quickly available to patients with AIDS and other ''immediately life-threatening diseases.''

title: HEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a first quarter net gain of $441,000, or 22 cents a share, from the sale of a former manufacturing facility.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch on May 10, about Rumania's efforts to keep its most-favored-nation trade status, misstated the circumstances of a visit by a choir of 40 Jewish children from Rumania. The group appeared at the Rumanian Embassy, but its trip to the United States was organized by Alfred H. Moses, a Washington lawyer, and was sponsored privately by American Jewish organizations as part of observances commemorating the Holocaust.

title: SHORELINE SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter loss was primarily caused by the provision for $6.1 million in additional reserves for real estate owned and non-performing loans.

title: Competitors Listed For Nissan Business
description: O.K., now forget about the rumors. Here's the official lineup for the competition for the $150 million Nissan Motor Corporation account that is leaving the William Esty Company: Ogilvy & Mather, which has Ford business in Britain and has been trying for years to get it here; Tatham-Laird & Kudner of Chicago; Jordan, Manning, Case, Taylor & McGrath, whose James Jordan has Dodge experience and whose Burt Manning supervised Ford; Chiat/ Day, and the Bloom Agency. The search is being conducted for Nissan by the consulting firm of Canter Achenbaum Associates.

title: AMERICANA HOTELS & REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Intelsat Suit Accuses Ex-Chief of Kickbacks
description: Intelsat charged yesterday that its former chief executive received $2.4 million in kickbacks for the construction of a new headquarters for the international satellite consortium. It also accused him of setting up bogus consulting firms that funnelled millions more to his Swiss bank account.

title: CITY PROSECUTORS TAKE EXCEPTION TO KOCH BUDGET
description: The district attorneys of New York City were unanimous yesterday in opposing Mayor Koch's proposed budget, saying the planned 3 percent increase in their funds was far too small to meet caseloads that have increased by 50 percent or more in the last few years.

title: CARDS SINK BRAVES IN 9TH, 5-4
description: Ozzie Smith's tiebreaking single in the ninth inning tonight gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-4 victory despite Ozzie Virgil's eighth home run in eight games for the Braves.

title: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,477,000 from the sale of Imatron stock. c-Includes a gain from the sale of Imatron stock of $1,213,000 for both the quarter and year. Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: STAGE: 'UNCLE VANYA' IN PRINCETON
description: Georgi Tovstonogov's realization of ''Uncle Vanya'' has the scope and luxury of a Wagnerian production at Bayreuth. The director of the Maxim Gorky Academic Bolshoi Drama Theater in Leningrad brings to the lines of the play the kind of care demanded by poetry; his almost musical use of pauses and silences gives the language great resonance. It also lengthens the play; the performance at the McCarter Theater runs well over three hours and there is some laughter when a character in the third act says, ''It is all so boring.'' But in its sweep and attention to detail, this production reveals the dramatic mind of Chekhov in a way far too few do.

title: Transco President Adds Post of Chief
description: George S. Slocum, president of the Transco Energy Company, was elected to the additional post of chief executive, the company said yesterday. Mr. Slocum, who is 46 years old, replaces W.J. Bowen, 65, who will retain the position of chairman.

title: MARINE CORPS TO FREE GUARD IN EMBASSY ESPIONAGE CASE
description: The Marine Corps announced today that Sgt. John Joseph Weirick, one of three Marine embassy guards arrested on suspicion of spying while in the Soviet Union, would be released from confinement because military law does not permit prosecution for an espionage offense that is more than two years old.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MORE DIE OF HEARTBREAK. By Saul Bellow. 335 pages. Morrow. $17.95.

title: LETTER SHOWS HIGH ARMY OFFICIAL TRIED TO AID WEDTECH ON CONTRACT
description: A previously undisclosed Army memorandum and letter show for the first time that a high official in the Army urged its contract officers to give special consideration to the Wedtech Corporation in overseeing a contract won by the company after White House intervention.

title: INSIDE
description: Tax Break for Writers An appeals court ruled that authors, playwrights and others could deduct business expenses in the year they were incurred. Page C28. Mets Lose Ojeda for Season The troubled Mets have lost Bob Ojeda for the season. The team's top-winning pitcher last year will have to undergo elbow surgery. Page D23. Bears' Victim Took a Dare The 11-year-old boy who was killed by polar bears at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn entered the enclosure on a dare, the police said. Page B1.

title: CONVEST ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that during the 1986 first quarter, it received reimbursments of $259,000 for costs incurred in prior years for marketing certain gas production and $228,000 for overhead of the general partner, which was charged to various working interest owners of certain wells operated by the general partner. The company also said the non- recurring reimbursements are included in revenue for the first quarter of 1986.

title: CAPTAIN OF STARK SAYS SHIP FAILED TO DETECT MISSILES
description: The captain of the American frigate Stark said today that his ship's advanced electronic equipment had ''failed to detect'' the launching of Iraqi missiles against the vessel. He also confirmed that the Stark's antimissile defense system had been turned off and said the ship was hit before the system could be activated.

title: CUSTOM-MADE LOOK, FOR LESS
description: EVEN as Susan Turner, above left, and Leslie Madden worked in advertising and publishing, respectively, they always wanted to own a home furnishings shop. In April, the two longtime friends opened Turner & Madden, a 500-square-foot shop that specializes in new furniture covered with the customer's fabric. They also sell painted furniture, new accessories and English antiques. The furniture is upholstered with 75 percent down and 25 percent polyester, and can be delivered within eight weeks of manufacture. Chairs start at $1,100, love seats at $2,500. Prices do not include fabric or shipping.

title: 'STAR WARS' IS 10, AND LUCAS REFLECTS
description: Exactly one decade ago, the Millennium Falcon sailed the skies of the Galactic Empire for the first time - and transformed the motion picture industry.

title: RECITAL: FLORENCE QUIVAR, MEZZO
description: FLORENCE QUIVAR is a mezzo-soprano with a world-class voice and appreciable expressive talents. Her singing sometimes fulfills the high expectations those gifts engender and sometimes seems oddly unfocused, as though the pieces are all there but haven't fallen into place. Her recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening included both kinds of work. At her best she is superbly qualified to take a place among today's first rank of singers.

title: TOUGHER TERMS ARISING ON NEW 3D-WORLD DEBT
description: The decision by Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, to treat $3 billion of its foreign loans as all but uncollectible will probably make the third world debt crisis even more difficult and acrimonious.

title: SCIENTIFIC SYSTEMS SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $194,000 from the sale of a company building, land and certain equipment and also includes a tax credit of $156,000. c-Net loss.

title: Nelson Chats With Knicks
description: Don Nelson, coach of the Milwaukee Bucks, said that he talked with officials of the Knicks and the Los Angeles Clippers today but said there was virtually no chance of him becoming coach of either team.

title: CORDIS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $53,881,000 and $53,997,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,032,000 for the quarter and $1,917,000 for the 9 months.

title: Save the TV Giraffe
description: A long time ago, some government officials and Congressmen had an inspiration. Their goal was to make sure that this burgeoning way of carrying news to the American people, called radio, did not get away from government control, as had that older way, called newspapers.

title: SYNTREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $112,000 and $305,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Gorbachev Provides Peek at Private Life
description: Breaking a long silence about his personal interests, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in an interview published today that his ''weakness'' was being curious about too many things.

title: CONCERT: ASHKENAZY CONDUCTS
description: DESPITE his distinguished career as an instrumentalist, Vladimir Ashkenazy has never really evoked the ''orchestral'' qualities from the piano that many of his colleagues are famous for. Perhaps he has found them in the orchestra itself.

title: ZEUS COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $60,000 from the repurchase of debt. c-Net income

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Tuesday about the new immigration law and its implications for child-care employment, and an accompanying picture caption, misidentified the city where Deborah Davis runs a referral service for nannies. It is Pomona, Calif., not Chicago.

title: MUSIC: LA MONTE YOUNG
description: AS much as one regrets the retrenchment of the Dia Art Foundation's philanthropic largess - the avant-garde financing organization was forced to curtail its activities when oil prices declined - a felicitous side effect has been the re-emergence of La Monte Young into the public eye.

title: JEWS IN ISTANBUL REOPEN SYNAGOGUE
description: Subdued and with some tears, the Jews of Istanbul reopened the synagogue today in which 22 of their number died in a terrorist attack last September.

title: KALVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-After tax credits of $106,000 for the quarter and $414,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $54,000 for the quarter and $143,000 for the year.

title: COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest quarter resulted principally from purchase accounting conventions and financing costs associated with the acquisitions of Group W Cable Inc. and Indianapolis Cablevision Inc.

title: PARKWAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RECITAL: PRESTON, ORGANIST
description: SIMON PRESTON, organist and master of the choristers at Westminster Abbey and widely recorded as both organist and conductor, is the 1987 winner of the International Performer of the Year award from the New York City chapter of the American Guild of Organists, and Tuesday the chapter presented Mr. Preston in a recital on Alice Tully Hall's underutilized Theodore Kuhn organ.

title: SOVIET HINTS ROLE FOR AFGHAN KING
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev hinted in an interview published today that the Soviet Union would accept the former Afghan King, Mohammad Zahir Shah, as part of a coalition government to hold power after the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

title: Scores of Indians Are Injured as Riots Sweep Fiji
description: Mobs of several thousand indigenous Fijians attacked ethnic Indians throughout the capital today, wounding scores in the worst outbreak of ethnic violence this Pacific island group has ever seen.

title: Bridge: 2 Americans Have Chance To Win a Title for Britain
description: There is some possibility that two American players will win a world title this year without bringing honor to the United States.

title: How the Japanese Collect Garbage
description: To the Editor:

title: A.M.C. WILL ACCEPT NEW CHRYSLER OFFER
description: The American Motors Corporation, after two and a half months of negotiations, said today that it would accept the Chrysler Corporation's takeover offer at the sweetened price of $4.50 a share.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for 12mo April 30
ASSOCIATED INNS & RESTAUANTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pots on the Lawn
description: In the past two weeks or so, more than 300 white, urn-like ceramic pots have cropped up on the Capitol's grounds, the first stage of a security plan meant to deter terrorists.

title: Ford Increases Truck Rebates
description: The Ford Motor Company increased its cash rebates on two light-truck lines and extended all of its incentives by one week, to June 15. Rebates of $1,000 are being offered to purchasers of the Bronco II and the Ranger STX, increases of $400 and $500, respectively. Other Rangers carry cash-back offers of $800, up from $300.

title: Advertising; Musically, It's Back To the 60's
description: THE musical sounds of the 60's are back and advertising's got 'em.

title: Broken Hill Tied to Bid For Texaco
description: Robert Holmes a Court's ultimate strategy may be to consolidate his control of Australia's largest company, Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd., and use it as a vehicle to make a bid for Texaco Inc., according to an analyst close to the Australian investor.

title: CALERO AND SINGLAUB TELL PANEL OF THE PRIVATE AID NETWORK FOR THE CONTRAS
description: At the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair yesterday, two witnesses appeared before the joint committee: Adolfo Calero and John K. Singlaub. Here are excerpts from the testimony, as recorded by The New York Times: * * * 'MASTERS OF DECEIT' CALERO. Millions of words have been written, spoken and televised on Nicaragua. Images, many of them false, have been created. Half-truths and outright falsehoods, propelled by the masters of deceit, have found their way to public opinion and official circles the world over. * * * In addition to the sea of troubles brought on Nicaragua by the Sandinistas, we have been unfortunately dragged into an internal inquisition, involving . . . technicalities and fine points of laws or amendments that we do not fully comprehend . . . .

title: BUSH PAC RAISED $9.37 MILLION IN 1985-86, TOPPING ALL OTHERS
description: Vice President Bush's political action committee raised more money than any of the 4,567 other PAC's registered with the Federal Government in 1985-86, according to figures released today.

title: A WAYFARER IS TRUNDLING HOME TO GLORY
description: High in the Cascade Mountains, where the road rises and falls steeply between rushing alpine streams, tourists have been lining up to cheer on a young man propelling himself westward in a wheelchair.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ROLLS SOARS IN INITIAL TRADING
description: Investors gave Rolls-Royce P.L.C. a rousing welcome to the private sector yesterday, sending the stock of the British jet engine maker soaring on its first day of trading on London's stock exchange.

title: FIGHT BUILDS OVER NEW SITE FOR MUSEUM
description: The dispute over the future of the Museum of the American Indian intensified yesterday. The question is whether the Harlem museum - with what many regard as one of the world's finest collections of its kind - will leave New York City.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter includes an increase in pension expense of $240,000 because of the adoption of a change in pension accounting, legal settlements and costs of $178,000 and net interest expense of $443,000 resulting from the spread in interest rates between the company's 13 percent subordinated notes and its short-term investments. The year-ago quarter includes a provision of $375,000 in connection with the resignation of the company's former president and expenses of about $552,000 because of the operating inefficiencies and costs related to the closure of the company's contract packaging division.

title: U.S. Agency Urges Automatic Train Brakes
description: The Transportation Department, acting in the aftermath of a railway accident that killed 16 people last January, proposed today that all railroads operating in the Northeast Corridor be required to equip their locomotives with devices to stop the train automatically if an engineer does not obey signals.

title: BARGE MUST REMAIN OFFSHORE UNTIL JUDGE RECEIVES NEW REPORT
description: The fate of the garbage barge Mobro was put on hold again today, pending results of the state's inspection of the garbage for toxic or hazardous material.

title: MICROBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
YALE PLANS TO INVEST $50 MILLION IN NEW HAVEN
description: Yale University plans to invest $50 million in endowment and other funds in housing, commercial and industrial development here over the next 5 to 10 years, Yale's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., announced today.

title: PROSECUTOR ASSERTS T.W.A. HIRED DEAVER AS ACCESS TO WHITE HOUSE
description: Trans World Airlines hired the lobbyist Michael K. Deaver in a 1985 takeover fight because he provided ''real access'' to the Reagan Administration, the special prosecutor in the perjury case against Mr. Deaver said today.

title: PANEL BACKS PET DOG IN HOUSING DISPUTE
description: This is the story of an 11-year-old boy and his dog and the no-pet clause in the lease on his family's apartment.

title: STAGE: ARTHUR SCHNITZLER'S 'LOVEPLAY'
description: Arthur Schnitzler's ''Liebelei'' or ''Loveplay,'' as it is called in Lawrence Leibowitz's new translation at the South Street Theater, is echt Schnitzler. The popular and prolific Austrian playwright (''Anatol,'' ''La Ronde'') was a master of turn-of-the-century Viennese entertainments -world-wise, world-weary and wistful. That is to say, they are stagewise (''We hate the women we love, and we love only the women who can be our playmates'') with an affectation of weariness (''A farewell always hurts, no matter how long you look forward to it''), yet they can glow with a sophisticate's view of the allure and the limits of romantic love.

title: Warning Europe
description: It was something of a record, the drafters said, a further sign of rising tempers on trade: It took only 90 minutes for more than half the Senate to sign a letter rattling the saber about soybeans.

title: BEN & JERRY'S HOMEMADE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONCERT: EARLY-MUSIC ENSEMBLE
description: IT'S a pity only two dozen people gave up Sunday afternoon's good weather to hear Music for a While, an early-music trio, perform in the Church of St. Ignatius on West 87th Street. The ensemble's program focused on the life and work of Oswald von Wolkenstein, composer and rogue.

title: FMI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Seoul Curbs Goods for U.S.
description: South Korea, alarmed by its fast-growing trade surplus with the United States, said today that it would restrain shipment of video cassette recorders and nine other items to the American market starting July 1.

title: NEW FOSSIL FIND ALTERS NIEW OF MAN'S EVOLUTION
description: A new fossil discovery in Africa suggests that the species believed to be the earliest tool user and a direct ancestor of modern humans was apparently much smaller and more apelike than had been thought, scientists reported yesterday.

title: The Editorial Notebook; When Virgil Was a Warm Friend
description: In my mother's house nothing is ever thrown away so one finds bits and pieces of the past in every drawer or closet. My mother saves letters, photographs, Christmas cards, report cards, birth announcements and wedding invitations; and whenever a member of the family dies, she incorporates that person's collection in hers. That's how she acquired the valedictory speech her Aunt Mame made on the June night in 1891 that she graduated from Warren High in Rhode Island. It is written in a faded, angular hand on several sheets of parchment rolled into a scroll and tied with lavender ribbon. It begins, ''Since our entrance to the high school in September 1887, we have formed some dear attachments.''

title: New Drug Charge
description: Grant Gondrezick, one of three Phoenix Suns players already indicted on cocaine charges, is facing an additional drug charge under a new indictment issued last Thursday by a Maricopa County grand jury. It accuses Gondrezick, a 24-year-old rookie reserve guard, of transferring or offering to transfer a quantity of cocaine to a woman between Dec. 1 and Jan. 15.

title: Cambodia's Unpunished Genocide
description: In December 1948, the United Nations unanimously adopted a convention to prevent and punish genocide, defined as attempting to destroy a national, ethnic, racial or religious group. The fanatic Communists known as the Khmer Rouge seemed to have committed such a crime, killing a million people in Cambodia from 1975 to 1979. So why not invoke the never-before-invoked convention and ask the World Court to determine the truth about the alleged act of genocide? Why not indeed.

title: British Banks React Calmly
description: Britain's largest banks are unlikely to follow Citicorp's move and dramatically increase their reserves to cover possible bad loans to developing nations, banking analysts said today.

title: THE CONSTITUTION'S 'CHANGING STORY'
description: FOR better or worse, but inevitably, our sense of the Constitution has changed. Different centuries, decades and court sessions interpret the document differently, although its principles are supposed to endure. Think of the Constitution as a literary text, with each generation finding new meaning. ''Ronald Dworkin: The Changing Story,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, examines the process.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: INSTALLING one's own extension telephones has become almost essential because it costs so much to have a phone company do the job. The wiring is relatively easy to install and safe for the amateur, because low voltages are involved.

title: AUTHORS' WRITEOFF CURB UPSET BY APPEALS COURT
description: In a decision that affects authors, playwrights, songwriters and other creators of literary property, a Federal appeals court ruled Tuesday in Manhattan that writers could deduct business expenses in the year in which they were incurred.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $76,600. c-Net loss

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $1.2 million for settlement of litigation.

title: 2 Senators to Question Meese Over Appointee
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee wants to know what Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds is going to do in his newly acquired job as counselor to the Attorney General.

title: What Hart's Fall Says About America
description: Reports of Thomas Jefferson's supposed sexual relationship with a slave on his plantation were a staple of the popular press in 1800. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. faced recurrent rumors (subsequently confirmed) of infidelity. Both these leaders survived with their political and historical reputations largely intact. Why was Gary Hart unable to do the same?

title: ZIMMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 18
PATRICK J. CORBETT
description: Patrick J. Corbett, a former president of the New York State Sheriff's Association, died Tuesday. He had suffered a heart attack while playing golf in Syracuse. He was 79 years old and lived in Syracuse.

title: CONCERT: 'QUILL,' FOR HARPSICHORD
description: ''QUILL,'' a new work by Wendy Chambers that was given its premiere Tuesday evening at Symphony Space, raised the pressing question: If a thousand birds are warbling in a concert hall, is it music?

title: BUNDY CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2,842,540 on the sale of property, plant and equipment. The company said the latest quarter and 6 months includes the operating results of Allied Uniking, which was acquired Nov. 30, 1986, and the results of Southeast Broach Co. and Viking Die Cast Corp., which were acquired Dec. 31, 1986.

title: Books of The Times
description: It's easy enough to get caught up by the story that Saul Bellow unfolds in his brilliant and funny but sometimes suffocating new novel, ''More Die of Heartbreak.'' Benn Crader, a brilliant and absent-minded botanist who lives and teaches in a large Midwestern city, decides suddenly to marry and settle down. In the past, he's had trouble knowing what he wants in women, so he opts for conventional beauty and accepts the advances of the spectacularly glamorous Matilda Layamon, the daughter of a successful gynecologist. He hopes to live with her ''bound together in love and kindness.'' <TD WIDTH=2

title: Wynne Gibson Is Dead; Stage and Film Actress
description: Wynne Gibson, known for her wordless role as a suddenly rich lady of the night in the 1930's movie ''If I Had a Million,'' died on May 14 in a nursing home in Laguna Niguel, Calif. She was 81 years old, and had suffered a stroke.

title: TRC COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $119,000. Latest quarter and 9 months include results of the GCA Technology Division, which was acquired in October.

title: Link Luxury to Moderate-Cost Housing
description: New York City's Board of Estimate ought to endorse modest zoning changes that can encourage more moderate-cost rental apartments. A good way to do that is to approve a proposal called inclusionary housing when it comes up today.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Administration to Seek Radar Planes for Pakistan
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to try to find a way to supply Pakistan with advanced American radar aircraft to defend itself against attacks originating from Afghanistan, officials said today.

title: U.S. Tells the Airlines To Act on Complaints
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole, citing a continuing high number of complaints from air travelers, called on airlines today to take new steps and ''reduce the level of passenger dissatisfaction.''

title: NBC Leads Ratings For the Week
description: CBS's ''Dallas'' got its highest Nielsen ranking of the season this past week with an episode that left the fate of Pam Ewing in doubt, but the network finished behind reruns of NBC's ''Family Ties'' and ''The Cosby Show.''

title: Some New Caledonians Fear Clash Over Vote
description: On the country roads outside the capital of this South Pacific island group, ubiquitous graffiti announce that a visitor is entering Kanaky.

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PARTY ABHORS VACUUM HART WITHDRAWL LEFT
description: ''When someone who occupies a lot of space disappears,'' William Schneider, an election expert at the American Enterprise Institute here, said today, ''he leaves a big hole.''
