ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After investment gains of $13,010,000 for the latest quarter and $4,130,000 for the year-ago period; the latest quarter also includes an extraordinary loss of $33,000.

title: Contra Hearings Plan Break in Early June
description: The joint Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair will take a break in early June while President Reagan attends the economic summit conference in Venice.

title: ATHLETES FACE TOUGH INQUIRY
description: A United States Attorney in Chicago is using possible racketeering charges to pressure college athletes into cooperating with an investigation into two New York sports agents, according to a report in The Atlanta Constitution.

title: JURY GETS DONOVAN CASE AFTER SHORT INTERRUPTION
description: The judge in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan sent the case to the jury yesterday after accusing a co-defendant of deliberately delaying the final stage of the trial by checking into a hospital.

title: GRUEN MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NATIONAL INDUSTRIAL BANORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company's initial public offering was completed April 3, 1986.

title: Withrow Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for James R. Withrow Jr., a senior partner in the law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, will be held next Wednesday at 4 P.M. at the City Bar Association, 42 West 44th Street. Mr. Withrow, who died April 23 at the age of 76, specialized in antitrust matters. He practiced law with the firm for more than 50 years.

title: MOTTA CUTS MAVERICK TIES
description: Dick Motta resigned as coach of the Dallas Mavericks today, but he would not say whether he would seek another job in professional basketball.

title: FROM AZTEC TO ZUNI: THE STUFF OF LEGEND
description: The air inside the Plains Indian artifacts vault at the museum warehouse smelled of smoked leather and sweet plains grasses. Adams Taylor, the collections manager of the Museum of the American Indian, touched the beaded charm dangling from a century-old Indian cradle board mounted on a wall, and thoughts of family came to mind.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jefferies Group Stake Reported
description: TBK Partners and its Tweedy, Browne Inc. brokerage unit told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had acquired a 5.5 percent stake in Jefferies Group Inc., the big securities brokerage holding company based in Los Angeles. The Jefferies chairman, Boyd L. Jefferies, recently resigned from his post after settling Government charges of participation in illegal stock dealings with the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky.

title: CARME INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Merrill Sets Shifts at Unit
description: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday announced internally a series of management changes to further shore up its securities trading operations.

title: CIVIL LIBERTY FOR CUBANS: TWO VERSIONS
description: As Fidel Castro tells it, there is hardly anything more unfair than accusations that Cuba violates human rights.

title: Stocks Slide Again; Dow Drops 5.41
description: The stock market continued its nervous slide yesterday, although one sector responsible for that nervousness - money-center banks - did fairly well.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: JAZZ: MICROSCOPIC
description: THE Microscopic Septet throws free-jazz tone clusters, swing-era saxophone riffs, rhythm-and-blues honking and Dixieland and be-bop colorings into a style-pulverizing blender, then adds a leavening of humor. At Sweet Basil on Monday, the band's four saxophonists and three-man rhythm section poked fun at some of the formalities of conventional jazz presentations while expertly navigating their challenging, tricky arrangements.

title: 'MOLLY DODD,' A SITCOM
description: MOLLY DODD, formerly Molly Bickford of Huntington, L.I., is 34 years old, divorced and trying to write soul-wrenching poetry while working for a lecherous real-estate agent in Manhattan.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $4,760 and $71,300 for the quarter and the year, respectively. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $6,200 for both periods. The company said the results for fiscal year 1987 do not give effect to the company's recent acquisition of Macrotest, formerly the test systems division of Eaton Corp., which Technology Marketing acquired on April 1.

title: The Pride Of the Lions
description: There were no fireworks displays on Morningside Heights and not one toy cannon was shot off at Baker Field, but Tuesday was a day for small celebrations among those in the athletic community at Columbia.

title: Dr. Marie Csete and Dr. Joshua Prager Are Wed
description: Dr. Marie Csete, a fellow in critical care at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, and Dr. Joshua Prager, an anesthesiologist, were married yesterday at the DeCordova Museum in Lincoln, Mass. The Rev. Alice Hageman, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the ceremony.

title: Judge Changes Gooden's Tests
description: A judge who met last week with Dwight Gooden has decided to drop court-ordered drug testing of the Mets' pitcher in favor of random tests directed by major league baseball. Hillsborough Circuit Court

title: THE WITNESS FILE
description: Name: Adolfo Calero Portocarrero Age: 55 Position: Installed by the C.I.A. as political leader of the largest contra army, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, in 1983. Educated in the United States, he used to be general manager of the Coca-Cola bottling plant in Managua. Role: Mr. Calero has said that once Congressional aid to the contras was halted in the spring of 1984, he helped set up a complex set of secret bank accounts and dummy corporations to channel aid to the contras.

title: PAN ATLANTIC RE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $1,015,789 and a tax loss carryforward of $542,455.

title: SLAVERY ISSUE ADDS VIGOR TO DEBATE
description: The observance of the bicentennial of the Constitution is being invigorated by an unexpected debate over what meaning black Americans should draw from a document that allowed the continuation of slavery.

title: CONCHEMCO'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
NATIONAL HEALTH CARE SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advo Suing Times Co.
description: Advo-Systems Inc., a direct-mail advertising sales company, said yesterday that it had filed an antitrust suit against The New York Times Company in Federal District Court in Hartford. Advo-Systems, which is based in Windsor, Conn., said in the suit that a Times newspaper executive had encouraged a research company to triple the price of a readership survey that Advo wanted to buy. The suit seeks unspecified damages and punitive damages of at least $1 million. Leonard Harris, a spokesman for the Times Company, said its officials had not seen the suit, and he said the company did not comment on matters in litigation.

title: FOR MET'S ROOF GARDEN, A BORDER OF YEWS
description: IF things go according to plan at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a large sculpture garden will be in place this summer on the 10,000-square-foot roof of the Lila Acheson Wallace Wing.

title: RECITAL: MIMI DYE, VIOLIST
description: MIMI DYE, a violist active in several New York orchestras, gave a recital at Weill Hall Tuesday evening that demonstrated her command of the instrument persuasively and offered a well-chosen assembly of works, enjoyably contrasted and relatively unhackneyed. It was particularly a pleasure to hear Britten's ''Lachrymae'' (based on a song of John Dowland), both because Ms. Dye played it with concentration and skill, and because it is good to see further evidence that the composer's instrumental works are estblishing themselves in the repertory alongside his more frequently performed vocal music.

title: Warrant Issued for Kahane
description: A bench warrant was issued today for the arrest of Rabbi Meir Kahane, a member of Israel's parliament, after he failed to show up for trial in Municipal Court here on a charge of attempted battery. The charge against the founder of the Jewish Defense Leaguestemmed from a fight at a speech Nov. 18. Mr. Kahane and Mousa Shukair, a Palestinian, scuffled after Mr. Shukair interrupted Mr. Kahane's speech.

title: A COUNTRY HOUSE OF SUMMER STYLES
description: GAUZY curtains, a hammock swaying slowly on the veranda, crisp white bed linens, cotton slipcovers and pastel-painted walls are some of the summer design ideas that await visitors to Chieftans, the former estate of Alva and Bernard Gimbel in Greenwich, Conn. The 33-room fieldstone house, on 96 acres, has been spruced up and transformed into a designer show house by 22 interior decorators, muralists and floral designers from the New York region. It will open to the public Sunday, and for decorating buffs, it is an event that should not be missed.

title: FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $110,000. c-Net loss The company changed its fiscal year to end on Dec. 31 beginning with the year 1986; previously the year ended April 30. The company attributed the rise in revenue and its return to profitability to the acquisition of Mid-West Spring Manufacturing Co. in October.

title: BEST BUY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Feb. 23. The company attributed the increase in sales to the inclusion of revenue of 12 new stores, increases in comparable store sales of 26 percent and increases attributed to conversion and relocation of four stores in the Minneapolis-St. Paul Market.

title: ON THE BANKS OF THE DELAWARE
description: The deep, black color of the pool shoaled into amber water as a pod of more than a dozen shad darted under the bow of the canoe. In the stern, Richard Gross's rod bowed sharply as a fish hooked itself on his bucktail-skirted jig.

title: CONVICT IN MISSISSIPPI, PROFESSING INNOCENCE, IS EXECUTED FOR MURDER
description: Professing his innocence and urging prison aides to hurry, Edward Earl Johnson died in the gas chamber early today, the first inmate to be executed in Mississippi in nearly four years.

title: OILERS WIN IN OVERTIME FOR 2-0 MARGIN
description: In the first minute of overtime tonight, Esa Tikkanen chopped at the puck in the slot but could not fool Ron Hextall, who had appeared to hover in his goal all evening.

title: Q&A
description: Q. About six months ago I had a deck built of cedar. It is my understanding that cedar is durable and that I could let it age naturally without waterproofing or painting. The trouble is that some portions have turned green with what seems to be a film of mildew or mold. Can you tell me what I can do about this? A. Moss and mildew generally form where ventilation and sunshine are inadequate and where there is too much dampness. You can remove the mildew or moss by washing with a mildewcide (sold in swimming-pool supply and garden supply outlets) or by using a solution of one part liquid laundry bleach to four parts water.

title: Russians Reopen Embassy
description: The Soviet Union today formally reopened its Monrovia embassy, closed two years ago when Liberia accused diplomats at the mission of engaging in activities incompatible with their status. A five-member Soviet delegation flew here over the weekend and was received at a ceremony today at the Foreign Ministry. Foreign Minister John Bernard Blamo called on Moscow to ''start a new chapter in the relations between the two countries.''

description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $87,988 for quarter and the 9 months includes a loss of $2,050,176 related to the company's bankruptcy reorganization and a tax credit of $2,098. c-Net income d-Includes a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $81,736 for the quarter and a tax credit of $250,440 for the 9 months. title: FOUNDER JOINS BID FOR CRAZY EDDIE
description: In a surprise move, Eddie Antar, the founder and chairman of Crazy Eddie Inc., came out of seclusion yesterday to join the Belzberg family of Canada in a $187 million offer to buy all of the stock of Crazy Eddie and take it private.

title: HUDSON IS THROWN FOR HIS FIRST LOSS
description: Ron Guidry was probably resting comfortably in his hotel room by the time Charles Hudson walked slowly off the mound at the Oakland Coliseum tonight.

title: U.S. Shifts Policy On A.T.& T. Bid
description: The Federal Government said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that would allow regulated telephone carriers to bid on a huge contract to modernize the Government's telephone system.

CANCERS NEAR A REACTOR: A MYSTERY AND A DEBATE By MATTHEW L. WALD
description: Men living in a coastal strip that extends 20 miles north from a nuclear reactor in Plymouth are developing some forms of cancer more than 50 percent more frequently than the statewide rate, according to a study endorsed by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health.

title: People
description: * Douglas K. Schores has been named senior vice president of the Weightman Group, Philadelphia.

title: WITH DEMOCRACY'S DAWN, CRIME TOO HAS ITS DAY
description: In a poor section of Guatemala's capital, Felix Medrano and his wife run a small store where they sell sacks of rice and other grains that relatives send them from the eastern province of Jutiapa. Mr. Medrano says he could expand his business, but prefers instead to do odd jobs in the afternoon and evening to make ends meet.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People see bears as funny eating, tender loving creatures.

title: Hearings End
description: Eleven months after it began, the hearing into charges that major league baseball owners conspired against free-agent players in 1985 ended yesterday in Chicago with testimony from Commissioner Peter Ueberroth.

title: GENE FOR RARE DISEASE TIED TO BREAST CANCER
description: A gene that causes an extremely rare nerve disease may also be responsible for approximately 8 percent of all breast cancer, or perhaps 10,000 cases a year, a study concludes.

title: HAMILTON M. CHASE
description: Hamilton M. Chase, an investment counselor for almost half a century, died yesterday at the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: KEY RATES
JET ROOKIES FOLLOW TWO SIMILAR PATHS
description: Alex Gordon and Onzy Elam thumbed through their defensive manuals today, seemingly oblivious to the rush of activity around them at the Jets' minicamp.

description: He is fourth in career scoring and the only place-kicker to win the league's most valuable player award, but now Mark Moseley will end his playing career after 16 pro seasons.

description: Pat Bradley is conceding nothing in the bid to defend her title in the L.P.G.A. Championship, which begins here Thursday.

title: STAGE: 'COWBOY' LOOKS AT CHARLES RUSSELL'S LIFE
description: ''COWBOY,'' a sprawling, brawling old-fashioned musical comedy about the life and times of the celebrated artist Charles M. Russell, is a show that wants to be a combination of ''Oklahoma!'' ''Big River,'' ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' and any number of seriocomic movie westerns.

description: The simmering battle between Steven J. Ross, chairman of Warner Communications, and Herbert J. Siegel, chairman of Chris-Craft Industries, has grown signficantly more intense, according to legal papers filed in recent days.

description: Federal regulators took control of a large, failing thrift institution, the Independent American Savings Association, and said they might sue the former owners and managers to recover more than $500 million.

title: MUSIC: ARMENIAN FOLD ENSEMBLE
description: ENSEMBLES that have been created to perform polished concert versions of folk or traditional music have a somewhat problematical relationship to their sources. The tendency is to want to ''elevate'' the informal performing standards of village and popular music. But genuine folk music was never intended for the concert hall. It has its own standards, and its own vitality, and attempts to re-create it in a different context often result in a somewhat lifeless hybrid.

title: IN PRIVATE, A DARKER U.S. VIEW
description: While American officials were publicly touting the virtues of the Nicaraguan rebel leaders, Government officials and other participants in the contras' private aid network viewed some leaders of the movement as wasteful, incompetent and possibly corrupt, according to Congressional testimony and documents.

title: OJEDA WILL MISS REST OF SEASON
description: The Mets got another jolt last night, and this time it was worst-scenario news: Bob Ojeda, their best pitcher last season and the hope of a staff already riddled by injuries, must undergo surgery on his left elbow and will be lost for the season.

title: PANEL APPROVES A KEY MEASURE TO BATTLE BIAS
description: A Senate committee gave overwhelming approval today to a measure expanding the Government's power to fight discrimination.

title: BOY ENTERED BEARS' AREA ON A DARE
description: The 11-year-old boy who was killed by two polar bears at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn Tuesday night entered the enclosure on a dare, the police said yesterday.

description: The target date for launching the next space shuttle has been delayed until June 1988, four months later than previously planned, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

title: Look: An Honest Bank
description: Any bank that reports a $2.5 billion loss in a single quarter must be in serious trouble, right? Wrong. Citicorp's dramatic decision to set aside enough cash to cover a fifth of its loans to poor countries simply acknowledges facts that have been known for years. The institution remains a major player in global banking, one that deserves credit for injecting a constructive note of reality to negotiations over third world debt.

title: NEIGHBORS UNCAP THEIR PENS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is to visit Rumania this month, and Hungarian analysts say they believe that his agenda is likely to include the issue of undisguised tension between two members of the Soviet bloc, Hungary and Rumania.

description: The host city for Super Bowl XXV in 1991 will be Tampa, Fla., National Football League owners decided today. The choice was made on the sixth ballot at the owners' annual spring meeting.

title: First Boston Official Is Back
description: The First Boston Corporation announced yesterday that T. Anthony Brooks was returning to the investment banking house as managing director of its equity capital market department after a hiatus of 15 years. In his new role, Mr. Brooks will be managing First Boston's sizable business in new stock issues.

title: Beatrice Sets Public Offering of Spinoff Company
description: The Beatrice Companies announced today that, as expected, it would spin off part of the company in a public offering.

title: Homeless Children Also Need Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Computervision Sets New Systems
description: The Computervision Corporation announced a series of computer systems, based on the Intel Corporation's 80386 microprocessor, that will be available in July at prices from $11,495 to $21,995. The systems are built around a personal computer manufactured for Computervision by Wyse Technology of San Jose, Calif.

title: CAROLCO PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1987 results include revenue from International Video Entertainment, in which it has a controlling interest.

title: Queens Man Guilty of Rape In Break-In on Mansion Row
description: A 29-year-old man was convicted of rape and robbery today in connection with a break-in at a mansion on Millionaire's Row last year that yielded more than $1 million in cash and jewelry.

title: ATTACK ON THE STARK: ANSWERS TO KEY QUESTIONS ARE BEGINNING TO EMERGE
description: In the three days since a United States Navy ship was attacked in the Persian Gulf, killing 37 sailors and gutting the ship, the facts, as they have emerged, have often appeared contradictory.

title: CITICORP'S DEFIANT LEADER: JOHN SHEPARD REED
description: John S. Reed, Citicorp's 48-year-old chairman, has finally made his mark.

title: REPORTING OF SUSPECT DEATHS AT V.A. HOSPITALS IS ASSAILED
description: The Veterans Administration, under fire for the quality of medical care in its hospitals, has not begun collecting data needed to improve conditions, a Congressional report said today.

title: 53 ARCHITECTS DESIGN FOR THE FINE FEATHERED SET
description: IN ''1001 Questions Answered About Birds,'' a sort of Miss Manners for the migratory set, Allan D. Cruickshank discussed the criteria for designing birdhouses. ''The simpler the box the better,'' he wrote, adding, ''Brightly colored, fancy-looking houses with chimneys, steeples, frescoes, porches, balconies and other absurdities should be avoided.''

title: Metro Matters; For Renters Escape Clause Could Be Costly
description: ''No one knew it when we got the lease,'' Irv Gray remembered the other day. ''No tenant was told about the law when they moved in.''

title: Foe Says Botha Is Deviating From Rigid Apartheid
description: There was a hushed silence today as Andries P. Treurnicht rose from his green leather bench in the white chamber of the segregated Parliament.

title: MUSIC: YOUNG ENSEMBLES
description: IN 1974, Claire Rosengarten, a musician and music teacher, founded New Music for Young Ensembles to foster the composition of chamber works for intermediate-level players. Toward that end, the organization each year runs a competition for composers, the winners of which have their works performed at a concert in New York. Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall, the three pieces that shared the 1986 prize were performed on a program that included the premieres of Dick Hyman's Sonata for Violin and Piano and Francis Thorne's ''Rhapsodic Variations No. 3,'' the latter commissioned last year by Ms. Rosengarten's group.

title: Reagan Hails Schools That Educate Poor Children
description: President Reagan today commended schools that have succeeded in educating poor children, saying, ''They don't use poverty as an excuse for failure and they don't wait around for new Federal programs before they start to do their jobs.''

title: DESIGN FOR THE U.S. HOLOCAUST MUSEUM IS READY
description: After eight years of study and planning and two proposals that proved unacceptable, the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, created by an act of Congress in 1980, will present the design for the national Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington at a public hearing of the Federal Commission of Fine Arts tomorrow.

title: SEAPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SECORD, COOPERATING, HOPES TO AVOID CHARGES
description: Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force major general who is a key figure in the Iran-contra affair, is cooperating with the special prosecutor in hopes of averting criminal charges, according to a Federal investigator and others with knowledge of the case.

title: ROCKY MOUNTAIN MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INNOVATIVE DANCE DETAIL IN A GENE KELLY MOVIE
description: ''IT'S ALWAYS FAIR WEATHER'' recently made a welcome return to the Film Forum. An M-G-M movie of 1955 with music by Andre Previn and lyrics by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, it depicts the comic misadventures of three Army buddies who get together 10 years after being discharged from the service. Since the three ex-soldiers are played by Gene Kelly, Dan Dailey and Michael Kidd and the film is directed and choreographed by Mr. Kelly and Stanley Donen, one can easily guess that the reunion will involve lots of dancing.

title: SAHLEN & ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Wendy's Layoffs
description: Wendy's International Inc. said it would eliminate 160 positions, or 20 percent, of its nationwide administrative staff. About half of the cuts will be made at its headquarters here. The company said the action would improve profitability by streamlining its administration and reducing restaurant development expenditures. It said it would open 175 to 200 restaurants this year, down from the 260 originally planned. Of the almost 3,800 Wendy's restaurants worldwide, 1,300 are operated by the company. Sales in 1986 were nearly $2.75 billion.

title: POPE, EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $388,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $1,796,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Assailing Castro
description: Timing is everything, as the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole, demonstrated Tuesday when he introduced a bill designed to ''turn the economic screws'' on Fidel Castro.

title: Japan's Frontier at Venice
description: LEAD: At next month's economic summit conference in Venice, Japan will propose an unusual effort in international scientific research and cooperation. The focus will be on the life sciences, particularly molecular biology and genetic engineering, that are expected to produce the most revolutionary technological breakthroughs of the 21st century.

title: NEW COMPLICATIONS LOOM FOR LATIN BORROWERS
description: Government officials, bankers and diplomats across Latin America said today that Citicorp's decision to add $3 billion to its reserves as protection against weak loans was certain to complicate the process of obtaining the new money that Latin American debtors will soon require.

title: IN JERSEY CITY, 2 SIDES TO A REJUVENATION
description: As the evening rush hour fell on Journal Square, commuters carrying trenchcoats and canvas tote bags spilled out of the PATH train from Manhattan and hurried past the cracked window of the Five Corners Bakery.

title: Sabena and S.A.S. In Merger Talks
description: Sabena, the Belgian state carrier, said it had agreed to discuss a merger of flight operations with Scandinavian Airline Systems, which could create one of Europe's biggest airlines. Aviation industry officials said the merger talks were prompted by increased international competition and a move toward air deregulation in the European Community.

title: WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $450,000 from the sales of marketable securities.

Experimental Video and Film Festival. The program can be seen today at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 3 P.M. Admission is free.

In December, OPEC agreed to an increase in the group's production ceiling.

description: UNDER the patronage of the Gonzaga family, the northern Italian court of Mantua from the 14th through the 17th centuries was home to generations of notable musicians, including Giaches de Wert, Giovanni Battista Guarini, Salamone Rossi and Claudio Monteverdi. On Sunday evening at the 92d Street Y, the Y Chorale, under the direction of Amy Kaiser, and the Levin Baroque Ensemble presented a program of works by those four composers.

description: Bob Johnson resigned as coach of the Calgary Flames to become executive director of the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States. The Flames were 193-155-52 under Johnson and made the playoffs in each of his five seasons.

description: At a Congressional hearing yesterday, Richard L. Osbourn, director of personnel for the Small Business Administration, testified that three employees on his payroll in fact work at the White House in jobs that have nothing to do with his agency.

description: Financial Security Assurance Inc., an insurer of corporate debt, was rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service, the rating agency announced Tuesday.

description: Reports of the demise of American tennis may be exaggerated, said Gordon Jorgensen, the president of the United States Tennis Association, who noted that there are two Americans in the top 10 and 15 among the top 50.

description: To this city of flowers, parks and blossoming trees has come a new four-acre garden that evokes not only the spirt of the Victorian era but also the serenity of the art of Asia and Africa.

title: HOUSE DEFIES REAGAN WITH BILL ON ARMS PROGRAMS
description: Renewing its challenge to the Administration, the House today approved military legislation that includes several arms control provisions strongly opposed by President Reagan.

description: Six years after a farmer offered free land to families with children in the hope of keeping open the elementary school in the tiny town of Antler, the school is closing its doors for good.

Walk Back the Cat
description: When intelligence professionals want to figure out what went wrong, they convene what they call ''the murder board.'' This group of second-guessers reexamines estimates in the light of subsequent events; its review -which can reveal anything from mistaken motivation to moles - is called ''walking back the cat.''

title: C.D.'s Lead Upswing
description: Certificates of deposit led the general rise in yields for the week ended yesterday, followed by smaller increases in bank money-market accounts and money-market mutual funds.

title: MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
Fatal Fire Blamed on Cord
description: A faulty electrical cord on a radio caused the apartment fire Feb. 20 that killed five children, the State Fire Marshal's office said today. The children, all age 2 or younger, had been left alone for about 10 minutes while the woman caring for them borrowed a car jack from a friend, the authorities said.

title: THE GILDER'S TOUCH
description: IN his left hand, a craftsman at D.Matt holds a small pad filled with squares of 23-karat gold leaf. In his right is a three-inch brush, which he touches lightly to his cheek (the oil there lets him pick up the gold). He applies the brush to the gold, then to the delicately molded flowers of a wooden frame.

description: When Mark Breland, the World Boxing Association welterweight champion, won his title last February from Harold Volbrecht, he broke his left hand doing it.

title: 17 MAYORS RESPOND TO KOCH ON PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: More than three weeks after Mayor Koch wrote to 150 mayors around the country, asking them to withhold endorsements of Presidential candidates and to help him formulate an urban agenda, he has had responses from 17 mayors, about half of whom fully endorsed his plan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Heins Increases Lead: Bobby Heins lengthened his lead in the second round of the Dodge Open yesterday, shooting his second consecutive 3-under-par 69. After 36 holes on the soggy Rockaway River Country Club course in Denville, N.J., Heins, a former PGA Tour pro who is head professional at Old Oaks in Westchester, stood at 138. The runner-up in last year's tournament, Rick Vershure of Quaker Ridge, shot a 68 in the afternoon to take second place at 142. The defender, Mike Burke Jr. of Mountain Ridge, posted a 69 for 143. Tennis Jelen Upsets Mecir: West Germany's Eric Jelen upset Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 6-1, at the World Team Cup tournament as the two countries tied at 1-1 in their two-of-three-match series in Dusseldorf, West Germany. In the other group match, Sweden secured its second victory of the tournament by taking an unbeatable 2-0 lead over Australia.(AP) Garrison Upset: Jenny Byrne of Australia upset second-seeded Zina Garrison, 6-4, 4-6, 6-4 in the second round of the Geneva Open. Top-seeded Chris Evert gained by beating Emmanuelle Dely of France, 6-1, 6-4.(AP) Soccer Gothenburg Wins: I.F.K. Gothenburg of Sweden won the U.E.F.A. Soccer Cup, playing to a 1-1 tie with Scotland's Dundee United at Tannadice Park to win the two-game final series, 2-1, on aggregate goals. (AP) Squash Wahlstedt Beats Waite: Top-seeded Anders Wahlstedt of Sweden defeated third-seeded Gary Waite of Canada, 9-0, 8-10, 9-1, 9-3, to advance to the final of the $20,000 Swan Laser-Die United States Pro Softball Squash Racquets Championship at the Park Place Squash Club. Second-seeded Fredrik Johnson of Sweden defeated sixth-seeded Mark Talbott of Wakeville, R.I., 9-5, 9-0, 9-5. The top-seeded woman, Liz Irving of Australia, defeated third-seeded Gail Pimm of Canada, 9-4, 9-5, 9-5, and second-seeded Heather Wallace of Scotland beat fourth-seeded Sue Cogswell of New York, 9-5, 9-3, 9-0.

title: THE TENANTS AREN'T LITTLE PEOPLE IN FEATHERS
description: LEAD: I SUSPECT the first birdhouses in America antedated the arrival of sophisticated architects on our shores by some hundreds of years, when Indians hung up hollow gourds for purple martins. Did they do this as a celebration of life, or simply to eat the fledglings?

title: BONN EXPECTS A PICKUP
description: The West German Government expects it economy, Western Europe's strongest, to pick up a little after a sluggish first quarter, a senior official said today. Gross national product should rise by 1 percent to 1.5 percent in the second quarter and continue at that rate for the rest of the year, according to Otto Schlecht, Secretary of State at the Economics Ministry.

title: LONG LIVE THE BROWNS!
description: It's remembered best as the only major-league franchise that ever had a midget and a one-armed outfielder. But it had a first baseman who still holds the record for the most hits in a season, 257. It had the only pitchers to throw no-hitters on consecutive days. And when its best team didn't win a pennant because a rival was strengthened in a late-season deal, the June 15 trade deadline was imposed.

title: Edict Urged on Alien Families
description: Four lawmakers today urged Alan C. Nelson, Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, to issue a directive preventing the separation of families under the Government's amnesty program for illegal aliens.

XOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HERS
description: I DREAMED my daughter before I had her. I dreamed her on a Yangtze River cruise where the dead bodies of pigs and cattle and humans floated by. I dreamed her in a sweltering heat where the stench of urine rose into our cabin from deck class below. On the river that the Chinese say is the river of life and of death, I imagined my daughter, and there I conceived her.

title: FROM IRAQIS EXPRESSIONS OF SYMPATHY
description: A young Iraqi woman at the Baghdad airport told an American this week that she had lost two brothers in the long war with Iran.

BETTE MIDLER WINS 4 COMEDY AWARDS
description: Bette Midler, finally conceding that ''it's my night,'' collected four American Comedy Awards Tuesday night, while Woody Allen was voted three.

title: American Airlines
description: American Airlines said it would follow United Airlines' example and raise fares effective June 3. The airline said it would increase one-way fares by $10 for unrestricted coach seats and by $15 for first-class travel. The step by American makes it likely that other airlines will follow suit. United had announced its similar increases on Tuesday.

title: YOUNG ARCHITECTS' WINNING DESIGNS
description: EACH year the Architectural League of New York holds a nationwide competition, ''The Young Architects Forum,'' to select projects by architects who are no more than 10 years out of architecture school. This year's winners, chosen from among 125 entries on the basis of architectural excellence, are being exhibited at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street, through May 29.

title: Daryle Feldmeir, 64, Is Dead; Editor of Chicago Daily News
description: Daryle Feldmeir, former editor of The Chicago Daily News, died Tuesday at the Brentwood North Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in suburban Riverwoods, where he had been ill since August. He was 64 years old.

title: CONSUMER LEADER
description: Colston E. Warne, a founder and longtime president of Consumers Union, the group that publishes Consumer Reports magazine, died yesterday at the Carleton Willard Village nursing home in Bedford, Mass., where he lived. He was 86 years old.

title: INQUIRY CAN'T TRACE ALL NORTH'S MONEY
description: Congressional investigators said today that they had been unable to determine how Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North spent tens of thousands of dollars in traveler's checks that he was given by a contra leader, Aldofo Calero.

title: STAGE: 'A NARROW BED'
description: IN the 1960's, Common Green was a thriving experiment in communal living, but, 15 years later, the fictitious utopian farm in upstate New York is facing hard - and changing - times. Almost all of the original members have dispersed, along with the movement itself; the men have become lawyers and stockbrokers. Left behind with their ideals in jeopardy but their memories intact are two women (played by Beth Dixon and Debra Monk). They are held to the commune by commitment as well as by habit - and they are increasingly faced by an economic crisis.

title: TOYS 'R' US CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
AMERICANS CONTRIBUTE TO FRENCH RESTORATION
description: France thanked former President Richard M. Nixon today for one of the benefits this nation, so proud of its architectural heritage, began to receive while his Administration was in office. Starting in 1969, Americans could claim tax deductions for their contributions to charities that, in turn, have brought in a steady stream of dollars to restore the crumbling architectural treasures of France.

title: Missing the Most
description: As a rookie last year, when he set an American League record for most strikeouts in a season with 185, Pete Incaviglia of the Texas Rangers had a strikeout average of .343. Now another rookie, Bo Jackson of the Kansas City Royals, is threatening Incaviglia's mark by fanning at a .392 pace in his first 35 games.
