title: Kidder Still Bars Trader
description: Richard B. Wigton, whose indictment on insider trading charges was dismissed by a Federal District Court on Tuesday, will not be reinstated at this time in his old job at Kidder, Peabody & Company, officials of the firm said yesterday. Mr. Wigton was suspended without pay as head of arbitrage and over-the-counter stock trading at Kidder when he was indicted on April 9. While the indictment has been dismissed, the United States Attorney's office has said that it will file an expanded indictment.

title: U.S. AGENCY SETS EXPLORATION OF SUNKEN CIVIL WAR IRONCLAD
description: Marine scientists and archeologists will explore the wreck of the Union warship Monitor next week to determine whether the Civil War ironclad can be raised, a Government agency said today.

title: REMATCH IN PHILADELPHIA: GOODE VS. RIZZO IN MAYORAL CONTEST
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode's resounding triumph Tuesday in the Democratic mayoral primary election gives his often-troubled administration a chance to start over and strengthens his hand in trying to capitalize on that chance, political analysts said today.

title: Air Atlanta Move
description: Air Atlanta, the black-owned airline that filed for bankruptcy protection last month, may be forced to liquidate its few remaining assets as soon as Friday, when a creditors' meeting is scheduled, according to lawyers involved in the bankruptcy proceedings. The airline had been seeking additional capital and was in talks with the Texas Air Corporation and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, but officials said talks on both fronts had broken off.

title: US MINERALS EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MCCORMICK CAPITAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: McCormick went public in September 1986.

title: F.D.I.C. Sues Auditing Firm
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has sued one of the nation's largest accounting firms for $250 million, charging it was too lax in auditing banks owned by the banker Jake Butcher and his brother, C.H. Butcher Jr. The F.D.I.C. contends in the lawsuit filed Monday that Ernst & Whinney ''departed markedly from professional standards'' in 1981 audits of four banks before the 1983 collapse of the Butcher brothers' financial empire.

title: Prosecutors Withdraw Pizza Shooting Charge
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday withdrew their charges against a man who had been accused of ordering the shooting of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug case.

title: ADVANCED TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the gains reflect the profitable operations of the acquisitions it made during the last year.

title: A Foamboard Lobbyist
description: Sometime today, each of the 533 sitting members of Congress will get a visit from a strange lobbyist: a lifesize cutout of an endangered textile worker.

title: Pincay Gets Santos Mount
description: After sniping at each other for three days, Jose Santos and Flint (Scotty) Schulhofer have parted company, and Santos will be replaced by Laffit Pincay Jr. as the rider of Cryptoclearance for the Belmont Stakes on June 6.

title: INSITUFORM SOUTHEAST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $123,000 for the quarter and $312,000 for the year.

title: Budget Wizard Wanted
description: Congress seems to be taking a long time in its search for a new director for the Congressional Budget Office.

title: Move by U.S.F.&G. Gains AAA Rating
description: The Standard and Poor's Corporation said ratings on about $1 billion of tax-exempt securities were raised to AAA, from AA, following the arrangement of reinsurance and assumption agreements that replace U.S.F.&G. with Capital Guaranty Insurance Company as the primary insurer.

title: Baker Praises Banking Step
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d indicated tonight that he would welcome more decisions by banks to accept losses in building loss reserves against loans to developing countries, as Citicorp is doing.

title: Mixed Day For Shares Of Banks
description: The stock of Citicorp rose swiftly today, a day after the bank's announcement that it would increase its reserves for bad foreign loans. But the market was less kind to some weaker banks, particularly BankAmerica and Manufacturers Hanover, that would be less able to afford to act as Citicorp did.

title: SUN COAST PLASTICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $25,000 and $83,000 for quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $83,000 and $213,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: The U.N. Today: May 21, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Review of Technical Cooperation Among Developing Countries - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M. Economic Committee - 3 P.M. Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DIVERGENT VIEWS OF TV POLICE DRAMAS
description: Police officers and the public in New York City have widely differing views of the accuracy of television police dramas, and nearly half of officers think such programs hurt the image of the force, according to a poll released yesterday by the New York City Police Foundation.

title: Criminals Deserve Not So Much Treatment as More Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: AIDS Definition Approved
description: An association of state health authorities accepted a new definition of AIDS today that could boost the number of cases counted in the United States. The Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists, meeting here, gave its unanimous approval to the definition proposed by the Federal Centers for Disease Control to better monitor the spread of of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The new definition adds two disorders, dementia and emaciation, as diseases that can be used to confirm an AIDS diagnosis.

title: SHOE-TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: b-Includes $43,000 income from discontinued operations.

title: SEQUEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $182,619 and $420,913 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6-month period, repectively.

title: US DESIGN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes charges of $2,129,000 for inventory obsolecense and a reduction in inventory value to market and $351,000 for bad debts related to trade accounts receivable arising in prior years.

title: WITNESS TELLS OF ALMOST KILLING BARBIE
description: A witness in the trial of Klaus Barbie, the wartime Gestapo chief of Lyons, testified today that he almost killed Mr. Barbie in Bolivia a decade ago, abandoning a carefully conceived act of vengeance only at the last minute.

title: YESTERDAY'S HARDWARE MADE FOR TODAY'S CUSTOMER
description: BRASS door knockers and hinges in hard-to-find patterns, chandeliers and sconces, wrought iron mud-scrapers, drawer pulls shaped like wreaths or fans: Renovator's Supply Inc. will sell you almost any hardware, any at all, for your self-consciously old-fashioned house. When finished, even modern rooms can look Victorian, with porcelain hot and cold knobs for the shower.

title: RECORD TAIWAN EXPERTS
description: Export orders for Taiwanese products rose to a record $4.51 billion in April from $4.29 billion in March, an economics ministry official said today. A year earlier, the orders totaled $3.23 billion.

title: ANALYSIS & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DANCE: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER REVIVES 'ETUDES'
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER'S production of ''Etudes'' was a rite of passage for many ballet fans in the 1960's and 1970's. In this simple-minded extravaganza, Harald Lander offered dancers a chance to prove their mettle in an unusually forthright way, taking them from classroom barre exercises through to the kind of demanding allegro combination that ends a typical class. As the dancers progressed through the piece, balletomanes were able to scrutinize their favorites and pet dislikes as keenly as any race track tout.

title: French Edition Of Fortune
description: Time Inc. is seeking a French Fortune.

title: PHOTON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Photon went public in February and the year-ago results are not comparable.

title: RAY OF SUN IN BREWERS' FOG
description: The home crowd of nearly 15,000 was standing and clapping with hope and anticipation today at County Stadium as the pitcher got two strikes on the batter, possibly the last batter of the game.

title: OCEAN BIO-CHEM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRESIDIO OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Preferred stock requirements exceeded net income in the latest periods.

title: SOUTHOLD SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There are no common share earnings because the bank converted from mutual to stock form on April 28, 1987.

title: ACTORS' FUND TRYING TO CUT DEFICITS
description: Grappling with the first major deficits in its 105-year history, the Actors' Fund of America is making new efforts to seek donations.

title: Article 587487 -- No Title
description: Adolfo Calero's turnover of $90,000 in blank travelers' checks to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North - and the use of some of them to buy groceries and snow tires - came up yesterday in a statement by Paul Barbadora, a committee counsel, and in questioning of Mr. Calero by Senator Warren B. Rudman. BARBADORA: Of the $90,000 in blank travelers' checks that Mr. Calero testified he delivered to Colonel North, we have been able to identify approximately $25,000 worth that were cashed by D.E.A. agents or their associates. In addition, we've been able to identify $2,440 worth of travelers' checks that were endorsed and cashed by Colonel North himself. . . .

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CODE ON PESTICIDES URGED FOR NATION
description: The nation's food supply is inadequately protected from cancer-causing pesticides, according to a report issued today by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: CONGRESS AND WHITE HOUSE AT ODDS OVER GROWING PRESENCE IN GULF
description: Congress and the White House are increasingly at odds over Administration plans to expand the American naval presence in the Persian Gulf after an Iraqi missile attack that killed 37 American seamen aboard the frigate Stark.

title: Chrysler-A.M.C. Tie Seen by August
description: The Chrysler Corporation expects to complete its takeover of the American Motors Corporation by Aug. 15, officials of Chrysler said. They also acknowledged that the 50-cents-a-share increase in the offer for the shares of A.M.C. was that company's price for co-operation in the merger. The board of the French auto maker Renault, which is A.M.C.'s principal shareholder, approved the takeover this morning, Chrysler officials said.

title: THEATER: CIRCLE REP'S 'ROAD SHOW'
description: AS a playwright and screenwriter, Murray Schisgal has always had a genuine affection for life's losers and prodigals, colorful individualists such as the suicidal Harry Berlin in ''Luv.'' However, in his new play, ''Road Show,'' which opened last night at the Circle Repertory Company, Mr. Schisgal is dealing with stock characters - the artist who has sold out for success, his ambitious wife and a long lost college sweetheart. These three - and the sweetheart's husband, a druggist - meet on a rainy afternoon in a small Indiana town, helped, one might suggest, by the long foot of coincidence.

title: CRAFTMATIC-CONTOUR INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago second quarter and 6-month results are pro forma to account for the change from S corporation status and other charges.

title: 2 Killed in Navy Jet Crash
description: Two Navy crewmen died when their A-6E Intruder fighter jet crashed Wednesday night in a heavily wooded area at a Navy bombing range. The victims were identified as Lieut. Bruce E. Pommer, 25 years old, of Merritt Island, Fla., and Lieut. James D. Hicks, 25, of Staten Island. The Navy is investigating the reasons for the crash.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MAY 22, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 How ships would defend themselves against attack would have to be reported to Congress by the Administration before the Navy vessels start escorting Kuwaiti tankers, under a bill approved in the Senate by a vote of 91 to 5. Page A1 Ships may be highly vulnerable to unexpected attacks similar to the Iraqi missile assault on an American frigate in the Persian Gulf on Sunday, according to details provided by Navy experts. A10 News analysis: Doubts that policy makers properly analyze American commitments to trouble spots around the globe were revived by the Iraqi missile attack on the frigate Stark in the Persian Gulf. A10 An Israeli has been subpoenaed by the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair to testify before a grand jury, officials said. He is David Kimche, a former director general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry. A1 3 wealthy conservatives testified that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North had influenced them to make large contributions to the Nicaraguan rebels after Congress cut off official United States assistance. A1 Doubts about peace in Afghanistan have settled over negotiators in Geneva, Western diplomats and analysts say. A1 Optimism at the nuclear arms talks is evident in Geneva. After two years, dealings between the American and Soviet negotiators have become frequent, nonpolemical and faintly friendly. A11 A witness at the Klaus Barbie trial testified he had seen the defendant direct a roundup of Jews in Lyons in 1943. A second witness described how he had survived the roundup, while his brother did not. A11 Charles A. Lindbergh's 1927 landing in Paris was recreated with a copy of his Spirit of St. Louis. Onlookers recalled the delirious throng that greeted Lucky Lindy after his 33 1/2-hour trans-Atlantic flight. A11 Gorillas appear secure in East Africa, where they had been protected by Dian Fossey, the zoologist who was murdered 18 months ago. The latest census counted 280 of the endangered primates - up from 250 in 1981. A4 Austrian rebuffed by U.S. on Waldheim A3 South African reacts to blast A5 Lebanon drops P.L.O. accord A7 Fijian accord on elections A8 Blows exchanged in Polish press A10 NATIONAL A14-21, A32, B6 Key research universities oppose accepting funds for scientific facilities directly from Congress when those grants are awarded to projects without competitive reviews of their scientific merits. A1 Alzheimer's disease is hereditary, a new report by scientists suggested. It said the risk of developing Alzheimer's was four to five times as great among close relatives of patients as it was in the general population. A14 National concern about AIDS has prompted a flurry of action in Washington. Bills in Congress would allocate nearly $1 billion to research and education on the lethal disease. A20 The White House should educate the world on the danger of AIDS, Vice President Bush said. The Reagan Administration has been accused of not providing enough funds for research on the disease. B4 Older women with breast cancer tend to get less treatment than younger women, researchers say, citing records of 374 patients showing 96 percent aged 50 through 69 received appropriate treatment while only 83 percent of those over 69 did. A17 Some breast cancer victims can be saved by drugs, but the disease remains fatal for most victims if not discovered early. A16 An education bill that renews and expands programs affecting most elementary and secondary schools was approved in the House by a vote of 401 to 1. The bill includes a $1 million program for excellence in teaching foreign languages. A15 Cuban-American voters wooed A14 Rare sedition charges prepared A14 Alien law changes approved A14 Report on pesticides analyzed A15 Pentagon space station urged A21 Struggle over military force A32 Bid to break filibuster postponed A32 Wedtech inquiry widens B6 Judge won't rule on alien rights B6 WASHINGTON TALK A20 At center of debate, Reagan leans toward AIDS tests Two thinkers named Brie REGIONAL B1-4, B7 The AIDS epidemic will cost more than $1 billion in hospital costs in New York City in 1991, according to state officials. They foresee a medical disaster no matter what vaccines are developed by then. A1 A motorist faces no criminal charges for an accident that killed a black man who was fleeing white youths in Howard Beach, Queens. A grand jury cited insufficient evidence against the driver, Dominick Blum, 25. A1 Traffic will increase by 10 percent in New York City this summer, officials predict. The warm weather surge could lead to some of the worst jams in history, especially along the many roads under repair. B4 New York City is the top choice among companies planning to acquire new office space in the next year, despite low standings on quality of life and government attitude toward business, a survey of leading executive has found. B1 The mother of a boy mauled and killed by two polar bears in Prospect Park Zoo said the family had lived on welfare benefits since her husband died six weeks ago and she could not afford a funeral. B3 News analysis: Goetz defenders have a major objective - to persuade jurors that Mr. Goetz acted in self-defense when he shot four youths in a Manhattan subway car in 1984 to prevent them, he says, from robbing him. B3 A do-it-yourself walking tour of lower Manhattan sites known by the framers of the Constitution is described in a pamphlet available at such landmarks as Battery Park and Castle Clinton. C1 Polo's popularity soars B1 Foster case upsets urban oasis B1 Apartment zoning change voted B1 Nassau curbs on water use sought B2 More security for zoos weighed B3

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HUDSON VALLEY
description: In the Hudson Valley, the contrast provided by adjoining tracts of lushly growing green alfalfa and newly plowed brown corn fields is a visual delight. It is also a reminder that the valley is one of the state's major farm areas. The sight of tractors working in the fields as farmers plant their corn and cut their alfalfa for hay is one of the major attractions of the Hudson Valley this weekend, along with a series of fairs, walks, art exhibitions and musical performances.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''BEVERLY HILLS COP,'' starring Eddie Murphy, received mixed reviews from the critics back in December 1984, but it was a smash hit at the box office. Martin Brest directed the comedy adventure in which the sizzling, fast-talking Mr. Murphy strutted his stuff, helping to make the film the highest-grossing comedy ever made, earning $350 million worldwide. So when Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer, the producers, decided to make ''Beverly Hills Cop II,'' which opened Wednesday, they had a successful formula to follow.

title: POLAND'S SPOKESMAN AND UNIVERSITY CHIEF EXCHANGE BLOWS IN PRESS
description: A Polish Government newspaper today published a three-paragraph condemnation of the Government's chief spokesman by the Warsaw University rector, then appended a 3,000-word reply from the spokesman denying that he had slandered four scholars by saying they had met with an American accused of spying.

title: Britain Refuses License To Export 'Sunflowers'
description: Vincent van Gogh's ''Sunflowers,'' sold here at auction in March for a record $39.9 million to a Japanese insurance company, has been prevented from leaving Britain for six months.

title: KINARD CONTINUES ON THE ROAD BACK
description: Terry Kinard is back and doing fine, if not quite ready to play tomorrow.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Citicorp's announcement that it would add $3 billion to its loan-loss reserves has created enough uncertainty in the credit markets to force some issuers of new debt to re-evaluate their positions. The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it would not proceed with a $200 million offering of 9 7/8 percent subordinated notes due 1999. The offering was priced on May 14 through a group of underwriters headed by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: RECITAL: MORDECAI SHEHORI, PIANIST, AT MERKIN HALL
description: MORDECAI SHEHORI demonstrated in his piano recital Wednesday at Merkin Recital Hall that he is a rarity among performers today - a distinctive player with strong, serious, compelling musical ideas and the physical capacity to realize them on stage. His playing is by no means technically flawless, and at several moments during the concert he pressed fast tempos beyond manageability or played so quietly that notes became inaudible. But Mr. Shehori's mishaps occurred because he tried (too hard) to convey the drama of the music, and that made them excusable.

title: Haitian Rock
description: Ayizan will play Haitian rock tonight at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street (255-5793). Tomorrow, Greg Tate, a writer, will present ''The New Black Culture'' with music by Geri Allen on piano, Steve Coleman and Jemeel Moondoc on saxophones, and others. Concerts begin at 9 P.M.; admission is $7.

title: U.S. BANKS' PROFIT DROP LINKED TO BRAZIL LOANS
description: A top banking regulator told Congress today that losses on loans made to Brazil were the cause of almost all of the current drop in profits at the nation's largest banks.

title: North, K.G.B. and a Secret Plan for the Navy
description: In his testimony, William B. O'Boyle provided details of conversations with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North in which he said they discussed the arrest of a drug dealer, the K.G.B. and what was described as a secret plan to bring the contras to power, with help from the United States Navy. * * *

title: Drugs Offer Hope Against Advanced Breast Cancer
description: New research shows that using drugs as the first line of therapy can save some victims of advanced breast cancer, but the disease remains fatal for most victims if not discovered early.

title: ATTEMPT TO BREAK FILIBUSTER PUT OFF
description: Amid signs of a shift in Republican strategy, the Senate Democratic leaders today postponed further efforts to break a Republican filibuster blocking legislation governing military programs.

title: BILL ON EDUCATION APPROVED IN HOUSE
description: The House today overwhelmingly approved a sweeping education bill that renews and expands programs affecting most of the nation's elementary and secondary school children.

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PESTICIDES: WEAK LINK IN THE NATION'S FOOD CHAIN
description: A report Wednesday by the National Academy of Sciences on pesticides in the nation's food supply shed little new light on the dangers of these chemicals, but it did have a disturbing message. Government efforts to protect the public, it found, are something of a shambles.

title: STEP-SAVER DATA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $33,198

title: Mozartian Instruments
description: The Classical Quartet - Linda Quan and Nancy Wilson, violinists; David Miller, violist; Loretta O'Sullivan, cellist - will present an original-instrument performance of works by Mozart tonight at 8 at St. Michael's Church (225 West 99th Street). Lowell Greer, a horn player, is guest artist. Tickets are $8, or $5 for students and the elderly. Information: 874-4037.

title: CENTRAL JERSEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOUNDED QUEENS SYMPHONY
description: David Katz, who founded the Queens Symphony Orchestra in 1953 and oversaw its growth from an amateur civic group to a fully professional, 80-member ensemble, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 62 years old, and had conducted his last concert with the orchestra on April 26.

title: Indoor-Outdoor Art
description: The human form is the subject of an exhibition that will run through October at the Storm King Art Center, Old Pleasant Hill, Mountainville, N.Y. More than 20 pieces are included in the show, which is mounted indoors and outdoors; three of the works have never been shown. The participating artists are Magdalena Abakanowicz, Jonathan Borofsky, Sandro Chia, Antony Gormley, Tom Otterness, Richard Rosenblum and Joel Shapiro. Viewing hours are noon to 5:30 P.M. today through Sunday. Contribution, $3 ($2 for students and the elderly). Information: (914) 534-3115.

title: TONY LAMA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the boy who was killed by polar bears at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn included an incorrect word in a quotation from Parks Commissioner Henry Stern. He said: ''People see bears as honey-eating, tender loving creatures. But polar bears are carnivorous animals and highly protective of their territory. In romance, we've overlooked the fact that they are highly dangerous animals.''

title: NASSAU COUNTY PLANS LLIMITS ON USE OF WATER
description: Nassau County proposed today to restrict hours for sprinkling lawns and gardens, require commercial car washes to recycle water and mandate large commercial offices to recycle water used in their air-conditioners.

title: SENATE DEMANDS ASSURANCE ON USE OF NAVY IN GULF
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to require the Administration to tell Congress how United States Navy ships escorting Kuwaiti tankers would defend themselves against attack.

title: Austria Convicts Two In '85 Airport Attack
description: A jury found two Palestinians guilty of two counts of murder each today in a terrorist attack on the Vienna airport in 1985. The presiding judge of Vienna's regional court sentenced them to life in prison.

title: KRUG INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to March 31. Krug had in the 9 months ended March 31, 1986, a net of $1,972,000, or 49 cents a share, on revenue of $90,784,000.

title: Norwegian Airline
description: Braathen Safe, the Norwegian Airline, which is part of the Braathens Group, said that it had ordered 31 medium-sized planes under a contract worth about $730 million. The privately owned airline ordered 25 737-500's and six Boeing 737-400's. Boeing is using Braathen as the launching customer for its new 737-500, which is a plane for short hauls and carries 124 passengers.

title: WOOING CUBAN-AMERICANS IN G.O.P.
description: Like eager suitors, prospective Republican Presidential candidates are courting Cuban-American voters in South Florida.

title: ZYTEC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $39,000 and $71,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $86,186 and $175,666 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: FILM: JAPAN'S 'TAMPOPO'
description: ''Tampopo'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 26. The film opens today at Cinema Studio 1, Broadway at 66th Street.

title: Leave Sexually Oriented Art Alone
description: LEAD: The United States Supreme Court recently made a foray into the thicket of obscenity regulation to interpret a constitutional test developed by the Court for determining whether a particular work may be suppressed and its disseminators criminally punished.

title: MAUNA LOA MACADAMIA PARTERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The partnership began operations in June 1986.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NOFZIGER INQUIRY IS BROADENED TO INCLUDE FAIRCHILD INDUSTRIES
description: The special prosecutor investigating links between the Wedtech Corporation and Lyn Nofziger, the former White House aide, has broadened the inquiry to include questions about a relationship between Mr. Nofziger and Fairchild Industries.

title: SCITEX CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $488,000 from Scitex's share in losses of 50 percent- owned companies, compared with similar losses of $446,000 a year ago.

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $201,000 and $345,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a $993,000 gain from the sale of assets.

title: XEBEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: The company said that in the latest second quarter its Information Memories Corp. and Dastek subsidiaries, which are developing and producing thin film media and heads, incurred about $900,000 in losses. It also said that sales to International Business Machines Corp. accounted for about 22 percent of revenue for the latest second quarter.

title: COLUMBIA GRADUATE IS 2 FOR 4 IN DEBUT
description: Gene Larkin became the first former Columbia University athlete to appear in a major-league game since Lou Gehrig in 1939 when he went 2 for 4 with a run batted in tonight as the Minnesota Twins lost to the Cleveland Indians, 6-3.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about opposition by New York City's district attorneys to Mayor Koch's proposed budget quoted a word incorrectly in a comment from District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan. He said, ''I think the nicest thing you can say about the Mayor and the Budget Director is that they've got their heads in the sand.''

title: Our Towns; Jailhouse Clog: A Jersey Plumber Foils the Inmates
description: For some reason that Arthur Blancato cannot understand, jail inmates love to stuff up their toilets. ''I've pulled out shirts, socks, sheets, blankets, TV cable wire'' said Mr. Blancato, a plumber for Ocean County. ''I've pulled out whole fruits. I've got an apple. I've got a banana.''

title: TOTAL ASSETS PROTECTION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $10,364 and $44,518 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Kirshenbaum & Bond Begins With One Client
description: Richard Kirshenbaum, 26 years old, and Jonathan H. Bond, 29, who as freelancers were responsible for the moderately controversal print campaign that has been running for Kenneth Cole shoes, have started Kirshenbaum & Bond, with the shoemaker as their first client.

title: 3 Injured in Attack On Freighter in Gulf
description: A Qatar-owned freighter, Rashidah, was hit by 10 rockets in the northern Persian Gulf early today and three crew members were seriously injured, Lloyds Shipping Intelligence reported.

title: THE GUEST OF HONOR WAS A CONDOMINIUM
description: Each time a guest arrived, eight soldiers from Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn played a fanfare, their gleaming brass instruments not incidentally bearing banners imprinted with the words ''The Horizon.'' And since there were about 1,300 guests, a lot of trumpet fanfares resounded over Murray Hill on Wednesday evening.

title: SUIT OVER 'SICILIAN' FILM
description: A dispute over an unreleased movie, ''The Sicilian,'' erupted into a Federal court case this week when the director, Michael Cimino, sued to keep the producer, David Begelman, from making and distributing his own final cut of the movie.

title: Why That Isn't Capitalism, Soviet-Style
description: To the Editor:

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
First 3 U.S. Lawyers Accredited by Japan
description: Three Americans today became the first foreign lawyers permitted to practice in Japan under a new law that took effect April 1, a Justice Ministry official said.

title: Bridge: Eastern Regionals Begin At the Javits Center Today
description: The oldest and most famous regional tournament in North America, the Easterns, begins today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, at 36th Street and 11th Avenue in Manhattan. The premier events are the Goldman Pairs, dating to 1929, and the Reisinger Knockout Teams, which began a year later.

title: Crooked Street to Stay Open
description: A city supervisor has dropped a proposal to close what is known as ''the crookedest street in the world'' to traffic for safety, but he wants a police officer stationed there to control the flow of automobiles. City officials said a poll showed there was no strong sentiment among residents to close the street, Lombard. The street, which has been featured in films, draws thousands of tourists who steer their cars downhill through its sharp curves. The traffic and speeding by a few motorists led some residents to ask that the street be blocked to all but those who live along the steep block.

title: Nelson Free to Talk
description: After weeks of speculation, the Knicks finally got permission yesterday to speak with Don Nelson about becoming their general manager. ''I've heard that I can talk with anybody,'' Nelson said from his office in Milwaukee. Nelson, the Bucks' coach and general manager, said that although there was little chance he would coach another team because of provisions in his contract, nothing could prevent him from becoming general manager elsewhere. Nelson said he had talked with Dick Evans, the president of the Knicks, on Wednesday and that they had discussed names of coaching candidates - none of whose names he was willing to disclose. He said no formal interview has been scheduled with the Knicks, but he does expect to speak with team officials again. Evans refused to comment on the matter.

title: FORDHAM STRIKES A BLOW FOR THE NORTH
description: The first game had just ended, and Fordham, in its first national collegiate baseball tournament appearance since 1953, had surprised 14th-ranked Georgia, 5-3. In the games that would follow, Dartmouth, which has not appeared in the tournament in 17 years, would beat Michigan, 4-0, behind the four-hit pitching of Mike Remlinger, and Rider College, which had a 21-21 record during the season, would beat Georgia Tech, 8-5.

title: A Plea to Reagan And to Gorbachev
description: The following statement was signed by Raul Alfonsin, President of Argentina; Miguel de la Madrid, President of Mexico; Ingvar Carlsson, Prime Minister of Sweden; Rajiv Gandhi, Prime Minister of India; Julius Nyerere, President of Tanzania, and Andreas Papandreou, Prime Minister of Greece. It was released in their respective capitals today.

title: ART: FRANCIS BACON SHOW CENTERS ON 80'S TRIPTYCHS
description: FRANCIS BACON'S latest exhibition, at the Marlborough Gallery (40 West 57th Street), is an impressive dose of more of the same: writhing figures, often violently truncated, isolated by their own evident anxiety and by fields of solid ''abstract'' color, most often a strong orange-red. This exhibition focuses on the artist's triptychs of the 1980's - in all there are five of the large three-panel works to be seen here, through July 31. Several of them give us three versions of the same individual - one at the center of each panel - which creates the effect of seeing someone at three different points in time or in varying emotional states. The gestures change, as do the blurred expressions; sometimes the figures seem to be replaced by another, more animalistic form, as if the artist had finally penetrated to the true inner soul of his sitter.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 22, 1987 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Economic Committee - 3 P.M. Social Committee - 10:30 A.M and 3 P.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: PETROLEUM INVESTMENTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MOTHER OF MAULING VICTIM CAN'T AFFORD A FUNERAL
description: The mother of the 11-year-old boy killed by polar bears at the Prospect Park Zoo said yesterday that her son's body was still in the county morgue because she cannot afford a funeral.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT Miniscribe Corp. is offering $97.8 million of B-2/B- rated 7 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2012 at 100 through Morgan Stanley. The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $19.20 a share.

title: THE GOETZ DEFENSE: OVERCOME TAPED STATEMENT AND EYEWITNESS TESTIMONY
description: As Bernhard H. Goetz's lawyers opened the defense case yesterday, they had one main objective: to convince the jurors that Mr. Goetz really did act in self-defense.

title: Age Bias Found in Breast Cancer Treatment
description: Older women with breast cancer often get less treatment than they should because of their age, regardless of whether they are otherwise healthy and likely to live a long time, researchers say.

title: ACTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $9,926,000 from a tax loss carryforward and a credit of $7,461,000 from the earned discount of indebtedness. c-Net loss

title: METS' MISSION: TRY TO SURVIVE
description: ''The Mets aren't dead,'' Gary Carter said. ''It won't be a blowout, the way it was last year. But there's time.''

title: PACIFIC INLAND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $48,000.

title: Shue to Coach Clippers
description: Gene Shue, the only coach to have a winning season with the Clippers, has signed a multiyear contract to become coach of the Clippers again after the team's worst season. Terms were not disclosed. Shue, 55 years old, is fourth in victories on the National Basketball Association career coaching list with a 757-768 record. He is returning to the Clippers after having coached them in the 1978-79 and 1979-80 seasons, when they played in San Diego. The club had its only winning record, 43-39, in 1978-79 and was 35-47 the following season. Shue has also been the coach of the Baltimore Bullets, the Philadelphia 76ers and, most recently, the Washington Bullets. The Clippers dismissed Coach Don Chaney April 22 after they had the worst record in the N.B.A. (12-70).

title: SEISMIC ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $137,081

title: HERE, RUSSIANS AND AMERICANS CAN BE COMRADES
description: It is only a two-minute car ride from the Soviet mission at the bottom of the curving Route de Pregny to the American mission at the top - two stone complexes with high walls where, one might argue, the fate of mankind is being negotiated.

title: APPLIED DNA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rating the Changes
description: The Mets and the Boston Red Sox, 1986 pennant winners who met in the World Series last October, have become clubs with losing records in 1987, and their eight-and-a-half game falloffs have been exceeded only by the hapless San Diego Padres. The Cincinnati Reds, whose rocky start in 1986 was the worst in the major leagues, have shown the most improvement in the year beginning and ending on May 21: LARGEST GAINS

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Sun Ra, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). When Wurlitzer marketed the first electric piano and Moog began manufacturing synthesizers, Sun Ra was one of the first customers. A pioneer in the use of African polyrhythms, he mixed avant-garde improvising with theatrical spectacle, and explored the repetitions and permutations of process music years before anyone else in jazz. But forget about the innovations. There's never a dull moment at a Sun Ra performance; his fans keep coming back because they know they're going to have fun. The Cosmos Adventure Outer Dimension Arkestra is playing Sunday at 8 P.M. and 11 P.M.; tickets are $11.

title: LTV Sees Delay In Reorganization
description: LTV Steel Corporation will not likely meet its self-imposed target of emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization by late 1988, but the steelmaker will survive, the company president said today. ''We are reorganizable. There will be an LTV Steel,'' said David H. Hoag, president and chief executive.

title: FOUNTAIN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jazz in Westchester
description: Arrowwood of Westchester, on Anderson Hill Road in Rye Brook, N.Y. (914-939-5500), will present Roy Eldridge singing with a traditional jazz septet tonight at 8:30 in its Atrium restaurant; there is a $10 cover charge with dinner from 8:30 to 10:30, a lighter menu between 10:30 and 12:30.

title: G.M.'S PLAN FOR SATURN: FEW SELLERS, MORE PROFIT
description: The General Motors Corporation is expected to announce next week that it will try a marketing strategy pioneered by Honda, Hyundai and other automobile importers when it begins naming dealers for cars produced by its Saturn Corporation, people familiar with its plans said.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL DIAGNOSTICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring expense of $91,174 resulting from the consolidation of Environmental Diagnostics' Florida facility into its single operating facility in North Carolina. The company said that a significant portion of the increase in revenue is attributable to the acquisition of Granite Technological Enterprises Inc., effective as of June 1, 1986.

title: Powers Elected to 13th Term As Typographical Union Head
description: Bertram A. Powers, the president of New York Typographical Union No. 6 since 1961, has been elected to his 13th term, the union said yesterday.

title: Meridian Adds Delaware Trust
description: Meridian Bancorp Inc., Pennsylvania's fifth-largest bank holding company, said it had agreed to acquire the Delaware Trust Company in a stock transaction valued at $196 million.

title: Farm Credit Banks
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Corporation said yesterday that it planned to announce next Tuesday the interest rates on a proposed $2.46 billion bond offering. Divided into three parts, the offering will consist of a $768 million issue due Sept. 3, 1987; a $1.13 billion issue due Dec. 1, 1987, and $561 million of bonds due June 1, 1988.

title: Youth Symphony
description: The New York Youth Symphony, whose players are 12 to 22 years old, will present the premiere of James Primosch's ''Dappled Things'' at a free concert Sunday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. The program includes Weber's Bassoon Concerto, with Daniel Matsukawa as soloist, and Brahms's Fourth Symphony. Information: 247-7800.

title: Schubert and Shows
description: Frank Patterson, a tenor, will sing pieces by Schubert and Handel and songs from Broadway musicals, tonight at 8 at Carnegie Hall. Tickets are $16 to $25. Information: 247-7800.

title: Alexander Names A Chief Executive
description: Tinsley H. Irvin, president of Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., a leading insurance broker, was elected yesterday to the additional post of chief executive.

title: Late Developers Victims of New Rules
description: Coastal in 1979 and Temperence Hill in 1980 were late-blooming colts who had not shown enough early-season promise to be nominated for the Belmont Stakes. Both had to be supplemented two days before the race at a $5,000 penalty fee, and both won.

title: TRANS-NATIONAL LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 9.

title: The Hesburgh Legend
description: The Rev. Theodore Hesburgh, who just retired after 35 years as president of the University of Notre Dame, was probably best known to the nation for his long service on the United States Commission on Civil Rights. He was a charter member in 1957 and was chairman from 1969 to 1972, when he was sacked for criticizing the Nixon civil rights record.

title: AMERICAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago results were restated to reflect the combination of American Realty Trust and Novus Property Co.

title: DELAWARE OTSEGO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FILM: 'AMAZING GRACE AND CHUCK'
description: IMAGINE what a thrill it is for Chuck Murdock (Joshua Zuehlke), a Montana schoolboy, to find the President of the United States right there in his bedroom. The President is a genial, movie-starrish fellow with a folksy manner - actually, he's Gregory Peck - and he has come to discuss nuclear disarmament. He wants to see if his plans to negotiate a treaty with the Soviet Union meet with 12-year-old Chuck's approval.

title: 'Hollywood Goes to War,' Attitudes in Transition
description: The remarkable thing about ''Hollywood Goes to War'' is how good the old movies look. The program, part of Channel 13's ''Film on Film'' series, examines Hollywood's attitudes toward World War I. The attitudes aren't as interesting, however, as the silent films in which they were expressed; 60 or 70 years later, the films still hold up. The program, at 10 o'clock tomorrow night, is fascinating.

title: NASA URGES SPACE STATION FOR THE PENTAGON
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration suggested today that the Defense Department should consider building its own space station, a move that could ease growing concerns over possible military uses of NASA's proposed space station.

title: Rating for Unisys May Be Upgraded
description: The long-term debt and commercial paper rating of the Unisys Corporation, one of the largest American computer makers, has been placed under review for possible upgrading, Moody's Investors Service announced. About $3.8 billion of debt may be affected.

title: FILM: ANIMATED MUSICAL, 'CHIPMUNK ADVENTURE'
description: WHAT sort of film walks a thinner line than the animated children's musical, catering as it does to two such disparate age groups, each so easily bored? At least ''The Chipmunk Adventure,'' which opens today at Embassy 4 and other theaters, tries to interest both parents and children and does a reasonably good job. For the parents, there are references to high finance, bored jet-setters and Pierre Cardin socks. For the children, there are pleasant, colorful Chipmunks on a round-the-world tour. And for both there is music, including a Chipmunk-style rendition of ''Woolly Bully'' and a nice, sentimental hymn to Mother.

title: FOYT ESCAPES SERIOUS INJURY
description: The great, grouchy A. J. Foyt, preparing for his 30th straight Indianapolis 500, gave the two rookie drivers on his racing team a lecture this morning, ''I told them, don't be racing on Carburetion Day - and then I go and do it.''

title: BGS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Time Inc. Decides to Sell Discover
description: Time Inc., continuing the cutbacks begun in late 1985, announced yesterday that it planned to sell its money-losing science magazine, Discover, to Family Media for $26 million.

title: Spoleto Festival U.S.A. Opens in Charleston
description: More than 100 performances of music, dance and theater will be featured at the 11th Spoleto Festival U.S.A., which opens today in Charleston, S.C. American and international artists will be making appearances during the festival, which is held at various locations in the city; some of the foreign companies will be making their United States debuts.

title: CAETANO VELOSO PERFORMS NEW SOUNDS FROM BRAZIL
description: CAETANO VELOSO, who has been one of Brazil's most influential and durable singer-songwriters since the late 60's, says he was skeptical when associates suggested a solo concert in New York City. ''Alone? With just my guitar? In New York? I didn't feel technically or professionally prepared to do something like that,'' he recalled earlier this week. ''I was planning to bring the percussionists who played on my American album, and when they couldn't come, I decided I was going to stay home.''

title: CONSOLIDATED STORES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WESPERCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included pretax extraordinary charges of $60,000 for the quarter and $660,000 for the 9 months from litigation settlement.

title: Asking Gary Hart the Question He Asked For; His Tragic Flaws
description: To the Editor:

title: ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PARTERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a non-cash property impairment writedown of $41,505,000 that was taken due to the sharp deterioration in oil market prices.

title: BARBIE WITNESSES DESCRIBE ROUNDUP
description: The trial of Klaus Barbie continued today with one witness angrily claiming to have seen him direct a roundup of Jews in Lyons in 1943, and another, a victim of the roundup, describing how he survived it while his brother did not.

title: CRACKER BARREL OLD COUNRY STORE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March.

title: Stocks Recover as Dow Gains 9.90
description: The stock market rebounded yesterday - albeit cautiously - from its recent slide. But volume eased considerably, as investors tried to sift through conflicting economic signals.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: WESTCHESTER COUNTY
description: Memorial Day weekend invariably offers the promise of outdoor adventures, and this year's activities in Westchester, including some special events, are no exception. There will be a circus and a fair, parades and fireworks, tours of historic structures and the chance simply to drive through the rolling, wooded landscapes of the county's northern towns and villages.

title: LONG ISLAND
description: Long Island will begin the Memorial Day weekend with fireworks as it officially reopens its beaches, shears some sheep, takes a nostalgic trip back to the 19th century and enjoys the splendor of spring while listening to the magic of Mozart.

title: Duo at Bradley's
description: The duo of Kirk Lightsey on piano and Santi DeBriano on bass will perform tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Music starts at 9:45 P.M.; there is no cover charge.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: MANHATTAN needs another baffling geographical acronym about as much as it needs a few hundred more T-shirt shops. Try out the latest: SOFI. Stumped? To muddle matters further, SOFI has two meanings: South of Flatiron, and an ambitious new restaurant on Fifth Avenue near 15th Street.

title: Prisons Facing Inquiry In District of Columbia
description: A Federal district judge has named a special officer to examine the District of Columbia's overcrowded Lorton Reformatory.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $110,421. c-Net income

title: AMERICAN HEALTHCARE MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,223,000.

title: STUDY FINDS DOCTORS BACK AIDS PATIENTS IN SCHOOLS
description: A majority of doctors and the American public favor allowing AIDS patients to remain in school or on the job, according to a survey by the American Medical Association.

title: FLYERS GOOD, BUT OILERS (2-0) ARE BETTER
description: Once again, both teams played the caliber of hockey that distinguishes the playoff season from the rest of the schedule. On Wednesday night, the quest for a Stanley Cup made for a thrilling game that could not be resolved within three regulation periods.

title: Exxon Predicts Strong Profit
description: The Exxon Corporation said today that it would post a strong second-quarter profit, citing higher earnings from refining operations, and that it expected a reasonably successful year with the stabilization of oil prices at $18 to $20 a barrel.

title: AMC ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: SIGMA DESIGNS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 10.

title: INTERMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $1,134,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after income of $61,000 for the quarter and $144,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: BOARD VOTES PLAN TO ADD HOUSING FOR LOW INCOMES
description: The Board of Estimate early today approved a change in New York City's zoning resolution that would allow developers to build luxury apartment towers higher than normally allowed if they agreed to build low-income housing nearby.

title: BORED WITH TENNIS,'NEW BREED OF WEALTHY' TURNS TO POLO
description: Life, as usual, is good here at the Greenwich Polo Club. The sun is warm, a soft breeze blows across a plain of rich green grass, leaves rustle in the wooded hills nearby. And a half-dozen rookies on horseback are chasing and, when they are lucky, whacking a small white ball.

title: BROADWAY
description: HOW'S this for starters? The Seventh Regiment Armory will be the theater, the $75 to $125 tickets will include champagne and an elaborate ''intermezzo'' (formerly known as intermission) buffet, and the performers will roam from room to room, some here, some there, taking with them various members of the audience. And if it all sounds complicated, don't fret - even people who have seen ''Tamara'' find it impossible to describe.

title: DELAY IS BACKED IN ALIEN LAW FINES
description: The Senate, in the first attempt to change the new immigration law, tentatively approved legislation today that would delay the enforcement of sanctions against employers who hire illegal aliens.

title: CONCERT: JUPITER SYMPHONY
description: VICTOR HERBERT supported himself as a cellist before ''Babes in Toyland'' and ''Naughty Marietta'' made his fortune, and he wrote a good deal of music for his instrument. No one would be surprised to find in it a wealth of gracious melody; in his E minor Concerto - revived Monday by Joel Krosnick and the Jupiter Symphony in Alice Tully Hall - there is also an arrestingly angular main theme and substantial symphonic development and construction. Reports of the work's strong influence on Dvorak's essay in the same genre are quite credible.

title: 'LONG GONE,' A BASEBALL COMEDY
description: THE made-for-cable movie is taking a hearty stride forward with ''Long Gone,'' having its premiere tomorrow evening at 8 on Home Box Office. The film is about baseball, Class D baseball, the kind that makes classics like ''The Pride of the Yankees'' look like promotional fantasies.

title: Kennedy and Cohen Pressing Pentagon on Reorganization of Forces
description: Two senior Senators have warned the Pentagon they will block all future military appointments requiring Congressional approval until the Defense Department puts into effect a law that reorganizes the military forces for anti-terrorism, commando missions and other special operations.

title: FARAH INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
STEAMY SUMMER FOR TRAFFIC PREDICTED FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: A 10 percent surge in traffic this afternoon, the start of the Memorial Day weekend, will be a prelude to a summer in which some of the worst weekend jams in New York City's history may materialize, officials warn.

title: Lack of Decent Housing Lies Behind Many of New York's Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: PARTY FOR CONSTITUTION Philadelphia is having a four-day party to mark the 200th anniversary of the opening of the Constitutional Convention there. Page B6.

title: ALDEN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to March 28
N.F.L. Preseason Plan
description: A preseason experiment involving a change in the time between plays was approved today by the National Football League owners, in hopes of quickening the pace of games without sacrificing any action. The owners, concluding a two-day meeting, also gave Commissioner Pete Rozelle the authority to return the collegiate draft to a two-day format, which Rozelle said he would implement beginning in 1988, perhaps Sunday and Monday, May 1-2.

title: Ronald Milhous Reagan
description: President Reagan has a new defense to the charge of lawlessness in soliciting money for the contras and sending arms to them. He knew all about the arms shipments, he now says; they were ''my idea to begin with.'' But the law against them did not apply to him. Or if it did, it was unconstitutional.

title: A TAX LAW EXPERT AND NIXON ADVISER
description: John H. Alexander, a longtime law partner of Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon and a specialist in Federal tax law, died of a heart attack Wednesday while at a business lunch. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GRAND JURY CLEARS DRIVER IN DEATH OF A BLACK FLEEING QUEENS YOUTHS
description: A Queens grand jury voted yesterday not to bring criminal charges against the driver of the car that struck and killed a black man who was fleeing a group of white youths in the Howard Beach racial attack last December.

title: WMS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses of $79,000 and $260,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the loss from discontinued operations represents the company's interest in Entertainment Television Co., which was sold last November.

title: Lack of Decent Housing Lies Behind Many of New York's Woes; Prevent Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: PURE SCULPTURE BY JOHN CHAMBERLAIN
description: JOHN CHAMBERLAIN'S 1986 retrospective at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles was that staple of the art scene - the major exhibition that doesn't make it to New York City. Nevertheless, Xavier Fourcade Inc. honored the artist here by staging a show contributed by six of his most illustrious friends.

title: April Surplus a U.S. Record
description: The Government enjoyed a record $38.66 billion budget surplus in April as income-tax receipts swelled Federal coffers, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Chicago Symphony
description: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Sir Georg Solti, will perform works by Strauss and Stravinsky tonight at 8:30 at the Tilles Center, Greenvale, L.I. Tickets are $30 and $35. Information and directions: (516) 922-0061.

title: ATLANTIC RESTAURANT VENURES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company went public on Feb. 10.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are talking about a medical disaster, a catastrophe of major magnitude, no matter what we do now, no matter what vaccines are developed in the next four years.'' - Health Commissioner David Axelrod of New York State, on the outlook for AIDS in the state. [ A1:2. ]

title: GENEX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $898,000 from a land sale.

title: Troop Buildup Raises China-India Border Tension
description: American officials reported increasing concern today about rising tension between India and China as a result of a buildup of Indian and Chinese troops in a disputed, mountainous border region near Bhutan. The State Department has urged both sides to keep the situation calm, officials said.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: Whether it's competition or contemplation, browsing or buying, there is plenty to excite the senses in New Jersey this weekend, from racing cyclists, jumping horses, soaring kites and colorful quilts to classical music concerts.

title: Ex Berkeley, Thinkers Named Brie
description: John Zysman and Steven Cohen, authors of ''Manufacturing Matters,'' the latest book on trade making the rounds in Washington, are the kind of marketing opportunity that book publicists dream about.

title: Bonds Volatile; Gains Small
description: Prices of Treasury coupon issues closed with small gains yesterday after a session that witnessed wild price swings. The volatility nearly halted trading in the corporate and tax-exempt debt issues, which take their bearings from the Treasury market.

title: 40 UNIVERSITIES AGREE TO REJECT DISPUTED GRANTS
description: More than 40 prominent research universities have agreed not to accept direct Congressional grants for scientific facilities if the grants involve projects whose scientific merits have not been proved through competitive review.

title: Slower Europe Growth
description: The European Community today predicted slower economic expansion for its 12 nations this year and only a slight increase in 1988, saying this would not create enough new jobs to reduce unemployment. Growth in the trade bloc's gross domestic product is projected at 2.2 percent this year, after 2.5 percent in 1986. Only 2.3 percent is predicted for next year.

title: S.E.C. Files Insider Charges
description: A Milwaukee executive and a broker with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. were charged today with insider trading that is said to have yielded about $90,000 in illegal profits. In a civil complaint filed in

title: FOSTER BABY CASE UPSETS URBAN OASIS
description: To the cabinetmakers, factory workers, milkmen and waitresses who moved there nearly half a century ago, escaping tenement apartments in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Manhattan, the name of the new neighborhood expressed everything they hoped for - Utopia Estates.

title: THE WITNESS FILE
description: Name: Ellen Garwood Age: 83 Position: Novelist and philanthropist for conservative causes. Role: Mrs. Garwood contributed $2.5 million to the National Endowment for the Preservation of Liberty, a fund-raising organization established to aid the Nicaraguan rebels. She is also the largest single contributor to the United States Council for World Freedom, run by John K. Singlaub. In 1985 she gave money to help purchase and restore a helicopter for the rebels that was subsequently named the Lady Ellen in her honor. Her donations have also included funds for thousands of pairs of boots for the insurgents.

title: 34 Indicted for Steroids
description: A Federal indictment charging 34 people with smuggling and distributing illegal anabolic steroids nationwide was unsealed today. The indicted included Pat Jacobs, the strength and conditioning coach for the University of Miami's football team, and David Jenkins, a former Olympic runner from Britain.

title: BUSH CALLS FOR SPENDING ON AIDS AND EDUCATION
description: Vice President Bush declared yesterday that the White House should be used as ''a bully pulpit'' to educate the world about the danger of AIDS.

title: Ministry's Chiefs Say Its Park Is Not for Sale
description: Officials of the financially troubled PTL ministry have received several offers for its 2,300-acre Christian theme park but are not interested in selling, a spokesman for the ministry's new leadership says.

title: VELCRO INDUSTRIES NV(0) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $4,551,000 for both periods.

title: RUM AND PEACE
description: What does one sailor offer another when anger frays their halyards? Yesterday morning, Senator John W. Warner, a Virginia Republican and former petty officer who was Secretary of the Navy from 1972 to 1974, arrived at a private Senate dining room bearing a bottle of Irish grog for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who was a lieutenant j.g. in World War II.

title: BCI Expects Sale Of U.S. Foods Unit
description: Donald P. Kelly, chairman of BCI Holdings Inc., said it was probable that the company's domestic food businesses would be sold or offered to the public later this year. The announcement comes just one day after BCI, the parent of Beatrice Companies, said that it was spinning off its consumer products and specialty foods businesses to a group led by Mr. Kelly. The new company is to be named E-II Holdings Inc.

title: A Defeat for Veterans, Not a Gain for Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: S.I. BUILDER EMPHASIZES DISTINCTIVE ARCHITECTURE
description: ''The development of Staten Island is atrocious,'' complained Sanford Nalitt, sporting a pair of striped suspenders, in his office earlier this week. ''There's no style, design or open space. You end up with row after row of tract houses.''

title: Lear Petroleum Selects Chairman's Successor
description: The Lear Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that its president and chief executive, Joseph T. Williams, 49, had been named to the additional post of chairman.

title: CLOTHESTIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Fed Nominee Confirmed
description: The Senate has confirmed Edward Kelley as a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, succeeding Emmett Rice, who resigned.

title: Floundering in Questions
description: Questions. Questions. When did he know? Does the National Security Council perform intelligence activities? What does the law really mean? Does it apply to the President, to the people he commands?

title: MEGAPHONE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a credit of $147,000 from a gain on extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss

title: THREE SEEN AS S.E.C. FINALISTS
description: The Reagan Administration, discarding previous lists of candidates for the chairmanship of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has narrowed its search to three. One of these, James M. Tobin, an Ohio securities lawyer, appears to be emerging as the front-runner, according to Washington and Wall Street lawyers with close ties to the White House.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $10,000.

title: TIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $332,000. c-Net loss

title: LIONEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Niemack at Gregory's
description: Judy Niemack, a singer, will lead a trio tonight and tomorrow at Gregory's, 1149 First Avenue, at 63d Street (371-2220). There is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kennth A. Marden, vice president of a Philadelphia advertising agency, has been named president of the American Kennel Club, suceeding William F. Stifel, who will retire next month. Marden is 58 years old and has been a delegate to the organization from the German Short-haired Pointer Club of America since 1974. . . . A California (Pa.) State University athlete collapsed and died yesterday after completing a qualifying heat in the 1,500-meter run at the N.C.A.A. Division II track championships in Cape Girardeau, Mo. He was identified as Paul Bryan, whose home was Jamaica, said Ron Hines, sports publicist of host Southeast Missouri State University. . . . Pat Kennedy, who led Florida State's basketball program to a 19-11 record in his first season at the Metro Conference school after leaving Iona, has been given a new contract calling for five more years at a substantial salary increase. His base salary at F.S.U. will go from $60,000 to $75,000 under the new deal. . . . When John Thompson, the Georgetown coach, was asked if Knick fans had seen the best of Patrick Ewing yet, he replied: ''You wouldn't hear the best of Diana Ross if she didn't have a band behind her.''

title: CELTICS DEFEAT PISTONS AGAIN
description: It's tough enough to beat the Celtics in the Boston Garden with five men. The Detroit Pistons tried to accomplish the feat tonight with a two-man offense of Isiah Thomas and Adrian Dantley, who combined for 60 points, and it failed.

title: ROOKIE WON'T GIVE UP EASILY
description: Walter Briggs straddled a wooden bench in the Jets' training room and discussed his chances of making the team this summer. He spoke with a rookie's enthusiasm and a veteran's matter-of-fact confidence, but the preoccupied look on his face told a different story. The truth was that he had had a lousy practice Wednesday and the blunders were still haunting him.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PARIS EDITION: The Autobiography of Waverley Root 1927-1934. Edited and with an introduction by Samuel Abt. 208 pages. North Point Press. $16.95.

title: Captors Assert That Beirut Hostages Were Spies
description: Moslem kidnappers holding three Americans and an Indian asserted today that their hostages were involved with American and Israeli intelligence services.

title: 3 SENTENCED TO LIFE IN PRISON IN INFORMER'S DEATH
description: While police officers armed with rifles guarded a state courthouse today, three Colombians convicted in the machine-gun slaying of a Federal drug informer were sentenced to life in prison.

title: Kraft Joins Exodus From Florida Spot TV
description: Kraft Inc. announced yesterday that it had joined Procter & Gamble and Clorox in the withdrawal of its spot TV advertising from the state of Florida in protest against the new tax law that goes into effect July 1. Among the services that will get hit with a 5 percent tax is advertising, both that originating at home and that coming in from out of state.

title: CHANGES IN STORE FOR YANKEES
description: There was a distinct sense of emptiness as the Yankees ate their postgame meals in silence and packed their duffels Wednesday night in preparation for the final stop on a trip through the West. Another game was lost, and it seemed to soothe them little that they were still comfortably in first place, still two games ahead in the American League East.

title: 3 CONTRA DONORS CITE NORTH'S ROLE
description: Three wealthy supporters of conservative causes testified today that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, as a member of the White House staff, had influenced them to make large contributions to the Nicaraguan rebels after Congress cut off official United States aid.

title: CROWN ANDERSEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BLACK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART: BY BRYAN HUNT, DRAWINGS AND BRONZES
description: BRYAN HUNT is a stylish and astute sculptor. His elegantly flowing bronzes, true to their material and engaged in the kind of dialogue with tradition that was unthinkable in the 60's and 70's, are hip enough to raise eyebrows and challenge some of the strictest modernist taboos. No matter how clunky and derivative individual pieces may seem, there is something in almost all of them that cannot be dismissed.

title: SURVEY FINDS NEW YORK CITY AREA IS TOP CHOICE FOR NEW OFFICE SPACE
description: A survey of top American business executives has found the New York City area the leading choice of companies planning to acquire new office space in the next year. But the area received low marks on quality of life and on the ''climate'' that ''state and local government creates for business.''

title: STRONG NEW EVIDENCE FOUND OF INHERITED ALZHEIMER RISK
description: A new study has provided strong evidence that Alzheimer's disease, the devastating mental disorder, is hereditary.

description: The defense began its case yesterday in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz with a witness who saw Mr. Goetz being kicked and beaten outside a lower-Manhattan restaurant in January 1981.

title: CABARET: EARTHA KITT SINGS
description: IT'S been a long time since ''New Faces of 1952.'' But Eartha Kitt, who was one of those new faces, has worn remarkably well - especially in view of the fact that her highly mannered style and her type of material have not changed to any great extent.

title: South African Dismisses a Blast as 'Theater'
description: South Africa's Police Commissioner, reacting to a bombing that killed three white policemen, said today that ''he who lasts longest wins'' in South Africa's political struggle. But he conceded that security measures alone would not keep the situation in check.

title: DR. HAROLD WEINERMAN
description: Dr. Harold D. Weinerman, a Manhattan dentist and a founder of the Long Island Committee on Soviet Jewry, died of lung cancer Tuesday at his home in Baldwin, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: Tackling the Global Farm Ripoff
description: A new international report says it plainly: The industrial countries currently waste $100 billion a year on farm subsidies. Three-quarters of the benefits go to a prosperous top quarter of farmers. These numbers won't shock anyone familiar with farm issues. What's surprising is that the Governments of Japan and West Germany, previously unwilling to brook criticism of their farm lobbies, endorse that analysis.

title: Comment on Hearns
description: ''I am not involved in any negotiations regarding Thomas Hearns for the proposed Bobby Czyz fight,'' said Dennis Talbert, a spokesman for Hearns's manager, Emanuel Steward, in denying that Hearns would challenge Czyz for the International Boxing Federation light heavyweight title. Hearns won the World Boxing Council light heavyweight crown from Dennis Andries of Britain in February and hopes to challenge Sugar Ray Leonard as a middleweight at the 160-pound limit in what would be Hearns's bid for a record four titles in separate weight classes. . . . Bill Cayton, a co-manager with Jim Jacobs of Mike Tyson, will not be at ringside for his fighter's next bout, against Pinklon Thomas May 30 in Las Vegas, Nev. Monday night, Cayton was admitted to New Rochelle Hospital with what he said was diagnosed as a recurrence of endocarditis, an infection of the valve of the heart, a condition Cayton suffered in 1979.

title: RIZZO SETS PACE IN L.P.G.A.
description: Patti Rizzo was nervous throughout her round today, which was just what she wanted. A touch of the jitters kept her on her toes as she was deadly with approach and chip shots to register a six-under-par 66 for a one-stroke early lead in the first round of the 33d annual L.P.G.A. Championship.
