description: A House committee voted Wednesday to require uniform poll-closing times in Presidential election years so potential voters on the West Coast would not sit out the election.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 381 money market mutual funds increased by $3.69 billion, to a record $239.31 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 93 institutional funds were up $1.33 billion, to $65.51 billion. The 199 general-purpose funds were up $1.56 billion, to $68.60 billion. And the 89 broker-dealer funds were up $796.6 million, to $105.20 billion.

title: ENERSERV PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY A TOUCH OF THURBER James Thurber once said that ''a touch of eccentricity ran deep in my family,'' and the characters he created in his essays, stories and cartoons certainly reflect that family trait. Some of them will come to life in ''James Thurber Kintypes,'' the latest in the ''Laugh at Lunch'' presentations of the American Humorists' Series. In this one-man show, John Valentine, an actor whose stage and television credits include ''Deathtrap,'' ''The Rivals'' and ''Cagney and Lacey,'' will step into Thurber's shoes, bringing to life Rex the Dog, Great Uncle Zenus and several other of the author's whimsical creations. The 50-minute production can be seen at the American Place Theater, 111 West 46th Street, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 1 P.M., and Wednesdays at noon. Tickets are $5. Bring your own lunch. (Fruit and beverages are available.) Information: 247-0393. JITTERBUGGING CINDERELLA Since the Brothers Grimm first committed it to print in the early 1800's, the fairy tale ''Cinderella'' has appeared in many guises, including movies, plays, operas and ballets. Its latest incarnation is the dance-theater piece ''Cendrillon,'' by the French choreographer Maguy Marin. In this version, which can be seen tonight at 8 in a performance by the Lyons Opera Ballet, Ms. Marin has given the classic a modern look: the fairy godmother has a neon magic wand, and, after arriving at the ball in a pink convertible, Cinderella jumps rope and dances the jitterbug. The dancers, their faces hidden by doll-like masks, move about in a spectacular three-story doll house, and injected into Prokofiev's score are taped sounds of baby talk and gurgles. The production, which critics lauded after its American premiere in January, will be at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street, now through May 31. In addition to tonight's performance, ''Cendrillon'' will be presented tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $17 to $37. Information: 246-8989, or call Teletron: 947-5850. A MABOU MINES WORLD Mabou Mines, the 17-year-old experimental-theater group, is known for its innovative and often provocative works. Its latest production, ''It's a Man's World,'' is no exception. The play, written by and starring Greg Mehrten, a Mabou Mines member since 1981, is a multimedia work using live performance and video to tell the story of Joey Fontina, a former matinee idol whose admitted homosexuality has jeopardized his career. The play moves backward and forward in time, creating a sense of fantasy and memory, while three onstage monitors display fragmented images of the characters. David Schweizer, whose credits include the New York Shakespeare Festival, Playwrights Horizons and the Yale Repertory Theater, directs the seven-member cast. ''It's a Man's World'' will run through June 28. The performance tonight, at 8, is at the Apple Corps Theater, 336 West 20th Street. The work will also be performed Sunday at 3 and 8 P.M. Tickets are $15; $13 for students and the elderly. Information: 869-3981. SATURDAY THE SOUND OF A STRAD No name symbolizes perfection in stringed instruments more than Antonio Stradivari (1644-1737). The Cremona violin maker, who lived during the height of the Baroque era, built hundreds of illustrious instruments of the highest quality, some 650 of which survive today. One of them, a violin made in 1701 for King Philip V of Spain, grandson of the French monarch Louis XIV, can be heard Saturday at 8:30 P.M. in a recital at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall. The concert, sponsored by the International Festival Series, features Thruston Johnson, a violinist formerly with the Chicago Symphony and a founder of the festival series, accompanied by David Garvey, pianist, and Lisa Ghersi, cellist. The program, representing three centuries of Spanish music, includes works of Luigi Boccherini, who, despite his Italian origins, spent most of his adult life working in Spain; Manuel de Falla, and Joaquin Nin, a Cuban composer. This concert is the eighth in the series' Hispanic Festival. Tickets are $15 at the Carnegie Hall box office, 749-7839. AFRICAN DIASPORA WOMEN May marks the first Tribute to African Diaspora Women at the Caribbean Cultural Center, focusing on the the worldwide political, educational and cultural contributions by women of African descent. As part of the monthlong series of lectures, exhibitions and other events, a special concert, ''The Rhythm of Women,'' will take place at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Saturday night at 8. The program features the renowned vocal ensemble Sweet Honey in the Rock, a five-voice unaccompanied group founded in 1973 by one of its current members, Bernice Johnson Reagon. The group will present songs of struggle and protest, as well as spirituals, gospel and other music rooted in the black American tradition. Opening the concert will be 12 women playing percussion - 2 drummers and 10 chekere players, an ethnic instrument made from a dried-out gourd - and a women's chorus performing traditional African chants. Tickets are $20, $25 and $30 ($15 for students and the elderly) and are available at the Caribbean Cultural Center, 408 West 58th Street (307-7420), or at the Town Hall box office, 840-2824. A RARE BRITTEN OPERA Benjamin Britten's rarely staged opera, ''The Rape of Lucretia,'' can be heard this weekend in a production by the Conservatory of Music at Brooklyn College. The dramatic, two-act chamber opera, written in 1946, recounts the story of the Roman Prince Tarquinius, who, when told that Lucretia, the wife of General Collatinus, is the only officer's wife beyond suspicion of infidelity, decides to put her to the test. Although the setting is Rome in the sixth century B.C., a male and female chorus find a Christian moral in the pagan story. Singers in this performance, all students at the Brooklyn College Opera Theater, include Amy Gluck, contralto, in the title role; Robert Termine, bass-baritone, as Collatinus, and Scott Wilde, baritone, as Tarquinius. Edward Berkeley, whose stage credits include Broadway productions of ''Macbeth,'' ''The Tempest'' and ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' is the director, and the Conservatory Opera Orchestra will be conducted by Richard Barrett, artistic director of the Opera Theater. The performance, in English, is Saturday at 2 P.M. at the Gershwin Theater, Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, one block from the intersection of Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues. Tickets are $5 ($3 for students and the elderly). Information: (718) 434-1900. SUNDAY COPLAND IN THE BRONX Aaron Copland's life has spanned much of the 20th century, during which time the composer, perhaps America's best known, has written numerous works already considered classics. Several of them can be heard Sunday at 2 P.M. when the Bronx Arts Ensemble salutes Copland with a free concert devoted entirely to his music. The program will include two favorites, ''Appalachian Spring'' and ''A Lincoln Portrait.'' Jonathan Tunick, composer and arranger, will conduct, and William Warfield, the baritone whose rendition of ''Old Man River'' in the film version of ''Showboat'' immortalized the song, will be the narrator for ''A Lincoln Portrait.'' The outdoor concert, sponsored by the Bronx Council on the Arts, will be at the Jerome Avenue entrance to the Woodlawn Cemetery, at the intersection of Jerome and Bainbridge Avenues in the Bronx. Seating is limited, and the audience is urged to bring blankets or folding chairs. Information: 931-9500 or 920-0500. MONDAY FOR HOMELESS VETERANS Memorial Day is a time to remember those who have died in war, but a rock concert on Monday will also call attention to our living veterans who are homeless. Dan Snyder, a guitarist with the band Range War and an organizer of the benefit, said that since, in the city, ''as many as one-third of the homeless are vets, I knew it was a situation that would inspire the concern of the New York music community.'' Lined up for the 12-hour marathon, which begins at 3 P.M., are Black Rock Coalition, the Surreal McCoys, Bobby Radcliff, Range War, Beat Brigade and many other local rock groups. The concert will be at CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street. Tickets are $8, with proceeds going to BRC Human Services, a nonsectarian agency that provides shelter, counseling and other social services to homeless men and women. Information: 533-5700 or 473-9763.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE bright balloons and paper streamers flying outside the American Museum of Natural History Tuesday night were a tip-off. Inside the Theodore Roosevelt Rotunda, there was no doubt at all. This wasn't a conventional benefit dinner. A popcorn stand was on the left, waiters were offering miniature pizzas and the huge space was ringed with displays of exotica - electric fish, poison dart frogs, the skull of a saber-toothed cat and flesh-eating beetles working on an owl skeleton (not the most popular exhibit).

The students will perform Dvorak's Carnival Overture (Op. 92); Barber's Adagio for Strings (Op. 11); Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6 and Mendelssohn's ''Elijah.'' Tickets are $6. Information: 362-1911.

title: Daniels at Vanguard
description: Eddie Daniels, a clarinetist, is leading a quartet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Zayre Offering In a New Unit
description: One of the nation's top discount store chains, the Zayre Corporation, said today that it would offer a 16 percent interest to the public of a newly formed company for about $200 million.

title: Money Given by the Contras' Wealthy Backers: Donations or Solicitations?
description: At the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair yesterday, four witnesses appeared before the joint committee: Ellen Garwood, William B. O'Boyle, Joseph Coors and John K. Singlaub. Here are excerpts from the testimony, as recorded by The New York Times: Asking for More

title: TIME-DC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Roseboro Joins Dodgers
description: John Roseboro, a four-time All-Star and catcher on three Los Angeles Dodgers world championship teams, has rejoined the organization as a minor league catching instructor. For the last 11 years, he has owned his own public-relations firm in Beverly Hills, Calif., with his wife, Barbara. ''I have never made a secret of the fact that I wished to return in some capacity to professional baseball,'' Roseboro said. ''By returning in this manner, it will allow me to make a 90-day assessment on what my absence ill have on my business.'' . . . Gordie Hershiser, brother of the Dodgers' pitcher, Orel Hershiser, reports Sunday to the Class A team in Vero Beach, Fla., after signing as a free agent. Hershiser was a starting pitcher for the University of Alabama this season.

title: FILM: TEEN-AGE GANG IN 'ENEMY TERRITORY'
description: THE territory at issue in ''Enemy Territory'' is a graffiti-stricken project somewhere in New York City. After dark, it is prey to the Vampires, a hissing teen-age gang whose members can bust down armor-plated, multi-locked-and-bolted doors with a nudge. They have more guns than the Contras and are led by the Count, a creature so vicious that he smashes an old lady's glasses, which doesn't stop that game soul from spraying the street with an automatic weapon when required.

title: EATON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Article 980187 -- No Title
description: Burlington Industries, the nation's No. 1 textile producer, said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to sell the company to a Wall Street investor group headed by Morgan Stanley Group Inc. for $2.74 billion.

title: Lessons of the Stark, Not All Costly
description: Cheap Exocet missiles crippled the frigate Stark this week and devastated the British destroyer Sheffield in the 1982 Falkland war. But these products of 1960's technology are not magic weapons. Despite their ferocity, they are easy to decoy. The question is why the Stark let down her guard and why, once hit, damage and casualties were so heavy. The answers to those questions may contain some heavy lessons for the Navy.

title: NEW YORK '45 AND NOW: A WALK WITH JAN MORRIS
description: Jan Morris could have written a book about New York as it is today. She actually contemplated it, but the place changes swiftly, and she realized it would be out of date by the time it got to the reader. Instead, she wrote ''Manhattan '45,'' a lively social history of the core of the city as it was at the end of World War II and on the brink of a confident, prosperous golden age. Recently, Miss Morris strolled about a sliver of mid-Manhattan and, almost musingly, scouted out the remains of that 40-years-ago place that are still evident in the 1980's.

title: Japan Data on Chips
description: The Japanese Government will present the United States with statistics that show a steady rise in the share of foreign-made computer chips in Japan, a Ministry of International Trade and Industry official said today. Japan will introduce the data at bilateral talks to be held in Washington next weekend, said Hayao Takenaka, a ministry spokesman.

title: TOTAL RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
When Trouble Strikes, the Doubts Multiply About Commitment of U.S. Forces Abroad
description: The Iraqi missile attack on the United States frigate Stark in the Persian Gulf, which cost the lives of 37 American sailors and disabled the warship, has once again raised a question that has bedeviled American foreign policy for a quarter-century: Does Washington think through with sufficient rigor the commitment of American forces and prestige to trouble spots around the globe?

title: BILL OF $1 BILLION FOR TREATING AIDS SEEN IN NEW YORK
description: By 1991, the spreading AIDS epidemic in New York City will cost more than $1 billion a year in hospital expenses alone, up from $400 million last year, Commissioner David Axelrod of the State Department of Health said yesterday.

title: RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DYCOM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
2 Receive Book Awards
description: The winners of this year's Theater Library Association Book Awards are Dr. Mary C. Henderson, the author of ''Theater in America,'' and Ann M. Sperber, the author of ''Murrow: His Life and Times.'' Alexander H. Cohen, a Broadway producer, will present the George Freedley Memorial award to Dr. Henderson; Charles Osgood, a commentator for CBS News, will present Ms. Sperber's award. The awards, which carry a $250 cash stipend, will be given during a reception tonight at the Library of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.

title: Shuttle Award Is Canceled
description: A Naval Reserve award scheduled to be given to Jane Smith, the widow of Michael Smith, one of the seven astronauts who died aboard the space shuttle Challenger, has been withdrawn because she sued the Government in her husband's death, a spokesman for the Naval Reserve Association said. Capt. Robert Beskind, the national deputy executive director of the Naval Reserve Association, said the group chose not to present the award to avoid any appearance that it supported her suit.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings represent series A.

title: Clausen Still Predicts a Profit
description: A. W. Clausen, the chairman and chief executive officer of the BankAmerica Corporation, said today that the troubled bank remains on target for returning to profitability this year. He conceded, however, that the Brazilian debt situation and Citicorp's decision to increase drastically its provision for loan losses could change the picture.

title: Holiday to Sell 8 Hotels to Bass
description: The Holiday Corporation, the world's largest hotel operator, said it had agreed to sell its interests in eight European hotels to Bass P.L.C., a diversified British brewing concern.

title: PENNZOIL INVESTORS OPTIMISTIC
description: The Pennzoil Company's stock moved sharply higher yesterday as investors became optimistic that the company was likely to get a favorable settlement in its multibillion-dollar dispute with Texaco Inc.

title: TAKING TAP OFF THE STREETS AND INTO REPERTORY
description: Tap-dancing used to be pretty much a matter of street-corner workouts or star turns in movie musicals. The concept of tap repertory has now begun to take hold, however, with the tap revival work being done by younger, more academic performers, who see tap as a part of American dance history.

title: FURS: SMALL ON EVERYTHING BUT ELEGANCE
description: Fur designers tend to emphasize the practical aspects of their wares: they talk about the warmth of mink, the lightness of sable and the flattery of golden fox to most skin tones. Inherently, furs are so rich the designers feel no need to call attention to such obvious qualities as luxury and opulence.

title: LEECO DIAGNOSTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST CONNECTICUT SMALL BUSINESS INVESTMENT CO reports earnings for Year at March 31
description: b-Includes losses on investments of $193,960 for the latest year and $114,692 for the year-earlier period. The net income represents net realized income.

title: Dining Out Guide: Upper East Side
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AUNTIE YUAN, #1191A First Avenue, near 65th Street (744-4040) -

title: PARADES, ART SHOWS AND HOLIDAY FESTIVALS IN THREE-STATE REGION
description: THIS is Memorial Day weekend, a time when New Yorkers will parade to Sousa standards. They will loll in the parks, summer on their minds, even if the calendar does not yet acknowledge the season. They will circumnavigate Manhattan on old schooners and modern-day cruise ships. They will scream as Coney Island roller coasters soar and plunge. And they will remember.

title: Direct Marketing Day Sets Attendance Record
description: The 22d annual Direct Marketing Day, which has grown to a day and a half, ended last evening at the New York Hilton, having attracted some 4,800 members of that fast-growing industry to the general sessions, seminars and exhibits.

title: Screamin' Jay Hawkins
description: Screamin' Jay Hawkins will sing Sunday at midnight at the Limelight, 660 Avenue of the Americas, at 20th Street (807-7850). Admission is $12.

title: ACCO WORLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid May 1.

title: FILM: FROM '66 JAPAN, 'THE PORNOGRAPHERS'
description: THE large carp that presides over parts of Shohei Imamura's ''Pornographers'' is only one of many testaments to Mr. Imamura's real and piquant eccentricity. The carp watches over a widow named Haru (Sumiko Sakamoto), and she believes it to be the embodiment of her dead husband. It jumps, or at least she thinks it does, when it disapproves of her behavior. It seems to jump frequently in the presence of Subu (Shoichi Ozawa), Haru's lover. In any case, Mr. Imamura has any number of opportunities to stage shots near the carp, through the carp tank and from the carp's point of view.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 22, 1987
description: COMPANIES Burlington Industries has agreed to a $2.74 billion buyout by an investor group led by Morgan Stanley. The group includes some executives of Burlington, which is the nation's largest textile producer. The $76-a-share deal is intended to thwart a $72-a-share bid made by Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, and Dominion Textile, a Canadian company. If they accept the buyout deal, Mr. Edelman and Dominion would each make a $45 million profit on their Burlington holdings. In heavy trading, Burlington shares rose $2.875, to $75.125. [ Page D1. ] First Interstate agreed to acquire Allied Bancshares of Houston in a deal that would be worth $415 million to $450 million. First Interstate, based in Los Angeles, is the nation's ninth-largest banking company; Allied, the sixth-largest banking company in Texas, has been struggling lately in the faltering Texas economy. [ D1. ] BankAmerica is still predicting a profit for this year. But its chairman, A. W. Clausen, concedes that the Citicorp move to increase loan-loss reserves could change the situation. [ D1. ] Pennzoil's stock price surged as investors became optimistic that the company might get a big settlement from Texaco. The optimism was based on Robert Holmes a Court's acquisition of a 6.4 percent stake in Texaco, which some think will put pressure on that company to settle a multibillion-dollar dispute. [ D4. ] Robert Maxwell's company might issue stock to pay for the acquisition of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich if the $44-a-share proposal is accepted, the British publisher said. [ D18. ] Time Inc. will sell Discover magazine to Family Media for $26 million. Time has a net investment of $30 million in the science magazine, which began in 1980 and has never shown a profit. [ D18. ] Cannon Group reported a loss of $60.4 million for fiscal 1986. The movie production company also made large downward revisions in its results for past quarters. [ D4. ] Hewlett-Packard introduced three new computer systems for technical users. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY The list of candidates to head the S.E.C. is down to three, with an Ohio securities lawyer considered the front-runner, according to officials in Washington. In addition to James M. Tobin of Ohio, the candidates are said to be Edward H. Fleischman, who is currently serving on the S.E.C., and David Ruder, a professor at Northwestern University School of Law. [ D1. ] Concerns about the declining profits of banks were expressed to a Congressional committee. One Federal regulator said bad loans to Brazil were a principal cause of the current slump. [ D5. ] The New York City area is the top choice of companies planning to acquire new office space, a survey has found. [ B1. ] MARKETS Stocks had a cautious rebound that stumbled toward the end of trading. After being ahead by 20 or more points most of the day, the Dow Jones industrial average closed with a gain of 9.90 points, at 2,225.77. A rise in a commodity futures index was believed to have scared already nervous investors. [ D6. ] Uncovered short sales on the Big Board were off 7.1%, to 437 million shares. [ D5. ] A volatile session in the credit markets produced small gains in Treasury securities, but the big price swings nearly halted trading in corporate and tax-exempt issues. [ D12. ] The dollar edged higher in uneventful trading, awaiting the release today of several economic indicators. Gold fell $2.75, to $469.75, in New York. [ D14. ] The Comex will change its procedures for trading precious metals, in response to snags that developed last month. [ D18. ] Soybeans had a sharp rally in the futures markets. [ D14. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Citicorp's action on shaky loans affects other players in the global debt drama. Some banks will find it hard to increase loan loss reserves, as Citicorp did. As for the banks' power in bargaining with debtors, opinions differ. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Mobile home sales are expected to benefit from the rise in interest rates that is making it harder to buy conventional houses. Manufactured Homes Inc., the No. 2 retailer, has done well by avoiding regions with depressed economies. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: CONNECTICUT
description: A hot-air balloon regatta, a lobster festival, sports-car racing, an antiques fair and a frog-jumping contest are among the festive events planned for the holiday weekend in Connecticut.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: The latest periods' results reflect the acquisition of Crown Zellerbach in May 1986 as well as several smaller acquisitions.

title: AUCTIONS
description: LATE 19th-century paintings by James McNeill Whistler, Winslow Homer and Thomas Eakins are among the outstanding works that will be auctioned in Sotheby's American-art sale next week.

title: 'Death of Cleopatra'
description: The New York Philharmonic, conducted by Giuseppe Sinopoli, will perform works by Ravel, Berlioz and Strauss tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall. Rosalind Plowright, a soprano, is guest soloist for Berlioz's ''Mort de Cleopatre.'' Tickets are $27.50. Information: 874-2424.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Tal Farlow, Zinno, 126 West 13th Street (924-5182). Since Tal Farlow returned to regular activity as a guitarist six-and-a-half years ago, after spending most of the previous 25 in the town of Sea Bright, N.J., he has developed several steady venues for his performances both in this country and abroad. One of them is Zinno, where he is now in the midst of a two-week engagement with Gary Mazzaroppi, the bassist with whom he has played all through this period of renewal. Mr. Farlow built his career to a peak in the early 1950's after playing in a brilliant trio led by Red Norvo, a vibraphonist. The third member of the group was Charles Mingus, a bassist who, like Mr. Farlow, was then on the threshold of fame. However, Mr. Farlow, a North Carolina native, was not comfortable making the rounds of nightclubs. He gave it up to relax in Sea Bright, where he jammed in local bars and returned to his early trade of sign painting. Since his re-emergence, he has refined and polished the mixture of soft warmth and crisp sparkle that give his playing a distinctive quality. He plays tonight and tomorrow starting at 8, and there is a $10 minimum at the bar and $15 at tables, but no cover charge.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: IMAGES AND ISSUES
description: MEMORIAL DAY weekend usually is the signal for the art season to begin winding down. In terms of photography, however, the season seems to be just getting going. At galleries and museums across the city, there now are more compelling and challenging exhibitions involving photography than at any time since the year began. Whether we choose to call this spurt of activity a ninth-inning rally or a renaissance, it reminds us that photography's place within the art world is no longer a fad or fancy, but simply established fact.

title: Rutgers University
description: Rutgers, the state university of New Jersey, held its 221st commencement in New Brunswick yesterday, conferring 8,900 degrees. Among those receiving honorary degrees were the author Philip Roth and Stephen Jay Gould, professor of zoology at Harvard University and curator of invertebrate paleontology at Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology. Mr. Gould also addressed the convocation. All academic degrees are conferred at the universitywide event, but most graduating seniors will receive diplomas at separate convocations that began yesterday and will continue through Sunday.

title: AQUANAUTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $30,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $227,801 and $320,151 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
REAGAN, AT SERVICE FOR SAILORS, BACKS PRESENCE IN GULF
description: At an emotional service today for 37 sailors killed in an Iraqi attack, President Reagan defended the United States military presence in the Persian Gulf, saying the sailors had understood ''their obligations'' and the importance of their jobs.

title: Hartmarx Buys Grethel Label
description: The Hartmarx Corporation said it had acquired the Henry Grethel designer label from Manhattan Industries. Terms were not disclosed. Hartmarx, the Chicago-based manufacturer and marketer of men's and women's apparel, said that all Henry Grethel licensing rights and agreements had been assigned to a new subsidiary called Henry Grethel Apparel Inc.

title: Spanish Investors' Montedison Stake
description: Two Spanish investors have built up a 3 percent stake in Montedison S.p.A., the Italian chemicals concern, in what is considered Spain's biggest private-sector investment outside the country, a spokesman for the executives said.

title: LITTLEFIELD, ADAMS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cornell Goalie Gets His Shot at a Title
description: When Syracuse last won the national collegiate lacrosse championship here four years ago, one of its players was John Schimoler from Brookville, L.I. John's younger brother Paul, then 16 years old, tagged along and included himself in the Orange sideline contingent.

title: Unionists' Right to Know
description: A 16,000-member hotel workers' union must provide Spanish translations at its meetings for Hispanic members, a Federal appeals court ruled Thursday. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit upheld a lower court order requiring translations, saying fundamental rights were jeopardized when Hispanic members could not participate in union policy discussions. The decision involved the Hotel and Restaurant Employees Union Local 11. About half of the local's members do not speak English.

title: New Trial Sought
description: A former caterer for the Philadelphia Phillies, Curtis Strong, is seeking a new trial to overturn his conviction in 1985 for distributing cocaine to major league baseball players. Strong has filed a petition in United States District Court in Pittsburgh saying that his legal defense was impaired because his lawyer was using cocaine.

title: For Our Federal Judges, That Raise Is Overdue
description: To the Editor:

title: WARRIORS JOIN LIST INTERESTED IN NELSON
description: It was perhaps inevitable that the Knicks would face yet another deadline in their seemingly unending quest for a coach and general manager. But this might be the most important one.

title: U.S. REPORTS THE DETAILS OF BOTCHED NUCLEAR TESTS
description: A new Government study provides the first official details about an underground nuclear test that went awry last year, resulting in the loss of millions of dollars in equipment.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Were a hostile power ever to dominate this strategic region and its resources, it would become a choke point for freedom - that of our allies and our own. The fallen sailors of the U.S.S. Stark understood their obligations - they knew the importance of their job.'' - President Reagan. [ 1:6. ]

title: MAXWELL MUSES ON BID FOR HARCOURT
description: Asked what changes are in store if he succeeds in buying Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Robert Maxwell considered the question as he gazed at the ceiling. ''There's a saying,'' he replied finally, ''that before you sell the bear skin, you better catch the bear.''

title: BARTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRINTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-Included a writedown of inventory and equipment of $5.1 million for both periods; the quarter also included a tax credit for current domestic losses carried back to prior years. c-Net income The latest year loss includes a pre- tax gain of $4,150,000 from the sale of an option to purchase a building, which was recorded in the first quarter, and tax credits recorded in the third and fourth quarters resulting primarily from domestic losses, which can be carried back to prior years. The 1986 results included a provision for realignment of operations and plant closing of $4,311,000 recorded in the third quarter. It also included the writeoff of goodwill of $6,447,000 in the third quarter.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report yesterday in the Scouting column of Sports Pages misidentified the shortstop who broke the 35-year-old Duke University record for hits in a season. He is Doug Eastman.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: LTV Constructing Aerospace Plant
description: The LTV Corporation, a large diversified energy and electronics company in Dallas, has begun construction of a $150 million aerospace manufacturing facility near Dallas. The plant, which is expected to employ 800 people when completed in the fall of 1989, will produce aircraft parts made of a lightweight fiber-reinforced plastic, the company said.

title: ECI TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Ed Davis, 108, Tribal Leader Of Snoqualmie Indians, Dies
description: Ed Davis, the tribal elder and ''spiritual leader'' of the Snoqualmie Indians, died Wednesday. He was 108 years old.

title: DESIGNCRAFT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year sales include $17,298,000 from Howard H. Sweet & Son. Inc., which was acquired in December 1985.

title: CALIFORNIA ACTS TO PROMOTE SWITCH FROM GASOLINE TO METHANOL FUEL
description: California took a major step today toward replacing gasoline with methanol as a fuel for motor vehicles. State officials predicted the move could help lead to nationwide use of methanol, a form of alcohol that is abundant and less polluting than gasoline.

title: ORGANOGENESIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company did not report revenue in the year-ago period because it was in its start-up phase.

title: IN HIROSHIMA, WIESEL FINDS NEW HORROR
description: Elie Wiesel, chronicler of one of the century's great horrors, today viewed the legacy here of another enduring agony and left speaking grimly of the ''biblical malediction'' he had observed.

title: Defuse New York's Ballot Booby Traps
description: New York State's 275-page election law, which requires that candidates surmount pointless legal obstacles just to get on the ballot, has long been a national embarrassment. Last year it ignited court battles that ended up disqualifying 200 primary election candidates, even though no one disputed that they had obtained sufficient petition signatures to qualify. Now the Legislature has a chance to end the embarrassment.

title: Cyr of Sabres Shot
description: The Buffalo Sabres reported yesterday that Paul Cyr, a 23-year-old left wing who has played five seasons for them, was recovering at a hospital in the Dominican Republic from a gunshot wound suffered Wednesday night in Puerto Plata.

description: b-Net loss

RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

title: CASINO AIDE SEEKS END TO BAN ON POLITICAL TIES
description: A casino executive today challenged the constitutionality of a New Jersey law limiting political activity by casino officials.

title: HARCOURT SUDDENLY CANCELS MEETING
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. yesterday canceled the special shareholders meeting that it had called to consider a proposal to double the number of outstanding shares.

title: G.M. GETS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: The General Motors Corporation today chose Robert C. Stempel, a 53-year-old automotive engineer, as president, succeeding F. James McDonald, who is retiring.

title: G.N.P. RATE UP TO 4.4% IN QUARTER
description: The economy, powered by strong auto production and an improving trade deficit, grew at a 4.4 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year, slightly better than previously thought, the Commerce Department reported today.

ROLE-PLAYING REVIVES HOLOCAUST HORROR
description: For many ninth graders at Millburn Junior High School, the Holocaust was something out of the deep past, something buried in the dry pages of history books. Then they began living it.

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
POLICE DISCOVER CRACK IN TABLET FORM
description: Crack, the highly potent form of cocaine, has been found in tablet form for the first time, and the police say it is evidence of renewed competition among drug dealers.

title: QUEENS PROSECUTOR REMOVED IN TRIAL OF JUDGE
description: An anti-corruption prosecutor was removed yesterday from a perjury case against Francis X. Smith, the state's administrative judge in Queens, because Justice Smith's lawyers said they intended to call the prosecutor as a witness.

AMERICAN NETWORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

PATENTS;
A Reactor Said to Offer Added Safety Features
description: LEAD: A boiling water nuclear reactor that is described as effectively eliminating the possibility of a reactor core meltdown was patented this week for the Energy Department. The design is described as offering greatly enhanced safety features.

title: McGinty Lives
description: Before King Fahd of Saudi Arabia visited President Reagan in 1985 he was contributing $1 million a month to the contra cause in Nicaragua. After the visit he doubled the contribution to $2 million a month.

title: LANDMARK PANEL NOMINEE QUITS OVER REPORT ON PARK CHANGES
description: A landscape architect nominated by Mayor Koch on Monday for the Landmarks Preservation Commission withdrew from consideration yesterday, following a report that she had been involved in the unauthorized alteration of a landmarked park two years ago.

title: TEACHERS' GUIDE ON RACISM IS HALTED
description: A training manual for new teachers that contains passages characterizing all whites as racists was withdrawn yesterday by the New York City Schools Chancellor, Nathan Quinones.

title: SHELTER IS AVAILABLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article by Michael Brison on April 10 misrepresented the relationship between Ariel Sharon, now Israel's Minister of Industry and Trade, and an agency of the Israeli Defense Ministry that handled Jonathan Jay Pollard, an American who was convicted of spying for Israel in the United States. The agency, known as the Bureau of Scientific Affairs, was created many years before Mr. Sharon become Defense Minister.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 23, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY

title: UNITED AND AMERICAN AIRLINES LIMIT RISE IN FARES
description: United Airlines and American Airlines decided yesterday to put their latest fare increases into effect only in markets that are not served by two other airlines, Continental and Eastern.

title: Canadian Completes Tour
description: A 29-year-old paraplegic completed a wheelchair tour of the world today, returning to the Vancouver shopping plaza he left 26 months ago. ''It's an incredible feeling to travel this far for so long and to finish off on a positive note,'' said Rick Hansen, who visited 34 countries and logged 25,000 miles. Pledges in his name, to be donated to research, are expected to exceed $8 million.

title: TORTURE RECOUNTED AT THE BARBIE TRIAL
description: The court trying Klaus Barbie, which often echoes with whispers, was still and silent today as Simone Lagrange recounted how, as a 13-year-old, she was beaten senseless by Mr. Barbie, who was trying to force her to disclose the whereabouts of her brother and sister.

title: CORRECTION
description: A letter from Wolfgang Hirczy about Kurt Waldheim last Saturday mididentified the writer's position at the University of Houston. His is a teaching assistant.

title: School Star Sentenced
description: A District of Columbia high school basketball star was sentenced yesterday to a maximum of three years of supervised probation for attempted distribution of cocaine and assault after a judge told him he hoped he could resume his promising sports career. ''The next time I see you, I want to buy a ticket for it,'' Superior Court Judge Geoffery Alprin told Tyrone Gibson.

title: RECORD PRICE FOR MOZART MANUSCRIPT
description: A 508-page manuscript of nine Mozart symphonies written in his own hand in Salzburg in the 1770's, before the composer's 20th birthday, was auctioned yesterday by Sotheby's in London for $4.34 million. The sale set a record for a musical manuscript sold at auction. The buyer, an unidentified American, subsequently notified the Pierpont Morgan Library that the manuscript would be placed on deposit there as soon as it arrived in the United States.

title: PANEL VOTES TO RECONSIDER HOLOCAUST MEMORIAL DESIGN
description: The Federal Commission of Fine Arts voted today to reconsider the design that was submitted for the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
RYMER COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to April 25
description: b-After tax credits of $144,000 for the quarter and $447,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $387,000 for the quarter and $673,000 for the 6 months. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest periods.

title: UNITED LEISURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BIG LEAP REPORTED IN THE CONDUCTIVITY OF ELECTRIC CURRENT
description: Pushing past the milestones of the last two months, scientists yesterday reported the loss of electrical resistance in new materials at the temperature of ordinary dry ice, far warmer than ever before.

title: Holiday Monday
description: Monday is Memorial Day. Following are holiday schedules: Parade - Starts at West End Avenue at 72d Street at 10 A.M., moving east to Broadway, north to 86th Street, west to Riverside Drive and north to 90th Street. Parking - Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Governmental offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail only. Banks - Closed. Financial markets - Closed. Transportation - Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North and N.J. Transit on Sunday and holiday schedules. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed.

title: CSM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, MAY 23, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5, 28 2,5.1,q>U.S. presence in the Persian Gulf was defended by President Reagan at a memorial service for the sailors killed in an Iraqi attack on the frigate Stark. Page 1 Iraq will permit U.S. investigators to interview the pilot whose warplane attacked the frigate Stark and the military officers who prepared the mission, American officials said. 5 A former Israeli diplomat will leave the United States without testifying before a grand jury about his role in the sale of American weapons to Iran, officials said. But David Kimche agreed to return if ordered by a Federal court. 1 Man in the News: David Kimche is a veteran spy who delights in using military and economic power to influence third-world countries. The United States was not the first country from which he has hastily departed. 4 The contras have been pushed back from a part of northern Nicaragua where they were operating openly, officials said. The Government and the rebels both claimed victory after a large combat operation. 4 NATO may accept an arms accord that is a modified version of a Soviet disarmament offer on medium- and short-range missiles, officials said. The modified accord would exclude some West German missiles. 1 A witness against Klaus Barbie testified how, as a youth, she was beaten senseless by Mr. Barbie, who was the Gestapo chief in Lyons in World War II. 3 In Poland, Senator Edward Kennedy sought to bridge the divisions of Polish society as he and members of his family met with officials, prayed with the parents of a murdered priest and awarded a human-rights medal to Solidarity leaders. 2 Elie Wiesel visited Hiroshima. The chronicler of the Holocaust said, ''What worries me is maybe I have not seen the past, and what I have seen here is the future.'' 3 Shultz assures Mozambique aide 3 Bacolod Journal 4 Kuwait's ships to get U.S. flags 5 Fiji army returns to barracks 28 NATIONAL 6-10, 32 2,,q>The Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April to post its third straight increase, the Government reported. Prices for clothing and gasoline jumped and economists raised their predictions for this year's inflation rate. 1 New superconducting materials that lose resistance to electrical current at the temperature of dry ice have been reported by scientists. The results promise new applications in electricity closer to room temperature. 1 Methanol use will grow in California under a new agreement between the state and Arco. The company will market methanol at 75 of its filling stations in California within the next three years. 1 New data about a stellar explosion that flared into view over the Southern Hemisphere in February have led some scientists to conclude that the supernova may have spawned a mysterious twin. 6 A racial dispute over a rowing event in Boston was settled when the head of a Boston rowing club apologized for asking a New York club to leave its black members at home. The apology came after three days of negotiations. 6 8 reputed mobsters were arrested and seven others charged in a four-year investigation of extortion and drug trafficking that dealt a severe blow to organized crime in Southern California, the authorities said. 10 Jack Kemp derided arms proposals being considered by the Reagan Administration. The Republican Congressman chided the Administration as naive or misguided in its approach to arms control. 8 The fate of monkeys seized by police six years ago in a Maryland research lab is creating debate. The custodians of the disabled monkeys want some of them put to death, while animal rights advocates want to care for them. 8 Tornado in Texas kills at least 25 1 Florida key deer: adapting or dying 6 Missing PTL money found 6 Airlines limit fare increases 6 Houston man wins poker title 8 Heart donor and recipent meet 8 U.S. reports nuclear test details 9 Georgia executes 2d inmate in week 9 REGIONAL 29-32, 50 2,4.6,q>In the Donovan case, a mistrial is being considered after a juror became distraught and was disqualified. The fraud case against former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and seven co-defednants started nine months ago. 1 More women are seeking AIDS tests because of increased concern about AIDS in New York City, the city's Health Commissioner said. The concern is attributed, in part, to public health warnings. 29 An explosion at a Staten Island house killed its occupant, demolished the house and knocked down walls of two neighborhing houses. Fire officials were uncertain of what caused the powerful blast. 29 An all-white neighborhood patrol will be integrated, leaders of black and Hasidic communities said. The announcement ended years of disagreement over the patrol run by a Hasidic sect in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. 31 One youth shot by Bernhard Goetz received the maximum jail sentence for contempt of court after the trial judge said his behavior before the jury had conveyed ''viciousness and selfishness.'' 31 Illegal wildlife seized in New York from tourists and others arriving at Kennedy International Airport has left Federal officials with an ecologist's nightmare of dead and live creatures and products made from them. 29 A landmarks commission nominee withdrew from consideration following a report that she had been involved in the unauthorized alteration of a landmark park. Frances X. Paulo had been nominated by Mayor Koch on Monday. 31 A change in New York city's zoning was adopted by the Board of Estimate that would permit developers to build luxury apartment towers higher than normally allowed if they agreed to build low-income housing nearby. 32 A prosecutor in the perjury case against Francis X. Smith, the state's administrative judge in Queens, was removed because Justice Smith's lawyers said they intended to call the prosecutor as a witness. 32 Learning about the Holocaust 29 Parachutist begins jail term 30 Casino aide fights ban on politics 30 Teachers' racism manual halted 30 Crack found in tablet form for first time 50

title: Sarah Lawrence
description: Sarah Lawrence College awarded 188 undergraduate and 53 graduate degrees yesterday in commencement ceremonies in Yonkers that had a British flavor.

title: GENISCO TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: REPUBLIC IS BACK IN THE MOVIE BUSINESS
description: The eagle has landed on television. For 20 years the Republic Pictures logo -an eagle alighting on a mountain top -adorned hundreds of Westerns and Saturday afternoon serials. Now, after a 30-year hiatus, Republic Pictures is returning to active production with a number of movies and series for television.

title: FIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $7,203,000. The company said the latest quarter loss includes a $1 million loss for an additional reserve established for the wind-down of Fidata's clearing division. The company also said the year-ago quarter includes a gain of $23,940,000 from the sale of businesses consummated during the quarter; as of May 1986, the company had completed the sale of all its operating divisions.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $96,000 and $186,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: SHORT SKIRTS: STALKING THE BEST OF THE NEW LEGGY LOOK
description: A mini revolution is overtaking fashion. Short skirts and dresses are marching back after two lengthy decades in retreat.

title: CENTRAFARM GROUP N.V.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Dutch guilders; the exchange rate at March 31 was 2.039 Dutch guilders per $1.

title: SMUGGLING OF WILDLIFE: BOOTY BUILDS
description: It is a grim collection of endangered-wildlife exotica: rhinoceros horns and ''medicinal'' pills made from them; live macaws and stuffed migratory birds; carved elephant tusks; crocodile, leopard and python skins, and alligator handbags and shoes.

title: ROBERT O. DRIVER
description: Robert O. Driver, retired chairman and chief executive officer of the former Wilbur B. Driver Company of Newark, a manufacturer of metal alloy products, died Thursday in his home in West Orange, N.J. Mr. Driver, who also maintained a residence in Palm Beach, Fla., was 80 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: New Patrols for Brooklyn After years of tension, blacks and Jews will form an integrated security patrol in Brooklyn to replace an all-white patrol run by Hasidim. Page 31.

title: ABS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $54,000 and $73,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and tax credits of $223,000 for the quarter and $412,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $506,000 and $574,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and the 6-month also includes a loss from discontinued operations $303,000.

title: LOUNGE LIZARDS
description: The Lounge Lizards will perform tonight at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $11.

title: IRAN CALLS GULF CONFLICT A WAR OF SUPERPOWERS
description: The Speaker of Iran's Parliament said today that the Persian Gulf war had become a superpower conflict and that the Soviet Union could have ordered Iraqi pilots to attack the United States Navy frigate Stark.

title: SLUMPING PASQUA SHOWS HIS POWER
description: Two nights ago, Lou Piniella already seemed to have made his decision. Concerned over the never-ending slump of Dan Pasqua, whose batting average and lack of clutch hitting had been among the most troubling aspects of the season, the Yankee manager was prepared for changes.

title: CLINI-THERM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Agrees to Talks On Bid to Indict Biaggi
description: Justice Department officials have agreed to meet with lawyers for Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, to discuss his possible indictment on charges of accepting a payoff from the Wedtech Corporation, according to sources familiar with the investigation.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORGANIZATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in U.S. dollars. The company said effective Jan. 1, 1987 the Group has changed its reporting currency from pounds sterling to U.S. dollars. The 1986 comparatives have been translated from pounds sterling into U.S. dollars at the Dec. 31, 1986 closing rate of exchange of US$1.48/1 pound; the pound sterling comparatives are as published last year. There were no earnings applicable to common in the latest quarter after preferred stock dividends.

title: Youth Survives 5-Story Fall
description: A 22-year-old Northeastern University student who fell off a five-story building while sunbathing was in critical but stable condition today at Brigham and Women's Hospital, a hospital official said. The student, Melvin Gambert of West Caldwell, N.J., ''tripped over his own feet and fell backwards off the roof'' Thursday afternoon, according to a police report.

title: NPS TECHNOLOGIES GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Devils Trade Ludvig
description: Jan Ludvig, a 25-year-old right wing who scored 53 goals and was credited with 79 assists in 288 games over four seasons with the Devils, was traded yesterday to the Buffalo Sabres for Jim Korn, a 30-year-old defenseman and left wing who in his one season with Buffalo picked up 4 goals and 10 assists in 51 games. Ludvig, a native of Czechoslovakia who signed with New Jersey as a free agent, had 7 goals and 9 assists in 47 games last season with the Devils.

title: BOARD APPROVES ZONING BONUS FOR LUXURY TOWERS
description: The Board of Estimate early today approved a change in New York City's zoning resolution that would allow developers to build luxury apartment towers higher than normally allowed if they agreed to build low-income housing nearby.

title: FIJI ARMY RETURNS TO BARRACKS IN POLITICAL ACCORD
description: The army agreed today to return to the barracks immediately, but only as part of a formula intended to curtail the political rights of ethnic Indians, the nation's largest ethnic group.

title: City U. Graduate School
description: The Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York awarded 231 doctoral degrees and 35 master of arts degrees yesterday in commencement ceremonies at Town Hall in Manhattan. Honorary degrees were given to Fernando E. Agrait, president of the University of Puerto Rico; Stanley Fink, a former Speaker of the New York State Assembly; Irving Howe, a professor emeritus of English at the City University; Joseph D. Monticciolo, regional administrator of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development; John Rewald, an art historian, and Jules B. LaPidus, president of the Council of Graduate Schools, who delivered the commencement address.

title: CONSOLDIATED HYDRO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REUSCHEL'S HOMER SETS BACK REDS
description: Rick Reuschel pitched five-hit ball for seven innings and hit a tie-breaking, bases-empty home run in the eighth tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates scored a 4-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Dow Rises 17.43 Points; Light Trading Reported
description: The Dow Jones industrial average gained a quiet 17.43 points yesterday, closing at 2,243.20, in light pre-holiday trading.

title: Bio-Book Mania: All About Vanna And Her Afghan
description: St. Martin's Press decided not to publish the biography of a deceased dachshund (perhaps because the owner wouldn't let the dog go on a book publicity tour, although this is conjecture).

title: CORRECTION
description: The daily stock market article in Business Day on Wednesday misidentified the rate that was increased by the Royal Bank of Canada. The lending rate based on the American dollar was raised, to 8 3/4 percent, from 8 1/2 percent. The prime rate remains unchanged.

title: BIO LOGICAL SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. Year-ago results are pro forma, reflecting the amalgamation with the rose group in September.

title: GRAPHIC MEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FLYERS, DOWN BY 3, RALLY TO DEFEAT OILERS
description: The Flyers, already in complex straits, watched the Oilers speed to a 3-0 lead tonight. Then, playing with a focus bordering on fanaticism, the Flyers made the Oilers watch as they took away that lead.

title: Mandela Is Penalized For Her Role in Boycott
description: The police went to Winnie Mandela's home today and shut off the electricity because the anti-apartheid campaigner has joined a rent boycott, her lawyer said.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: In Albany, Part-Time, Ethical Legislators
description: Underlying the controversy over ethics reform in the New York State Legislature is a question that goes to the heart of our system of government: Should we continue to rely on part-time citizen-legislators or move toward a full-time legislature of professional politicians who have little or no outside income?

title: SHULTZ ASSURES MOZAMBIQUE AIDE U.S. WON'T WITHDRAW ITS SUPPORT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told a senior Mozambican official today that President Reagan had no intention of abandoning support for Mozambique's Government in favor of an anti-Communist insurgency.

title: NORMANDY OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $440,813 from the settlement of debt for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Grand Jury Clears Two In Videotaped Arrest
description: A New York grand jury concluded yesterday that the police officers who were videotaped by an onlooker during the arrest of a suspect in March committed no crime.

title: PERILS OF BORROWING ON A HOME
description: DURING the Depression, people often took out second mortgages just to get by. The practice, however, cost many their homes. Since Congress enacted the new tax law, banks have heavily promoted a new version of the second mortgage, called a home equity loan, and it has become the fastest-growing area in consumer finance.

title: No Smoke-Filled Room
description: For the last year or two, audiences everywhere could be startled by the prediction that the Republicans and Democrats would put forward at least 15 Presidential candidates for 1988. That seemed an improbable proliferation, but suddenly the Democrats look as if they may do it by themselves.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: AS VIDEO SOARS, VESTRON SLIPS
description: Austin O. Furst Jr., chairman of Vestron Inc., has seen far better days than the Friday two weeks ago when he laid off or reassigned about 50 of his 400 employees. At the company's Stamford, Conn., headquarters now, ''there are lots of empty offices,'' Mr. Furst conceded.

title: MORE WOMEN ARE SEEKING TEST FOR AIDS
description: Concern about AIDS in New York City has reached such proportions that increasing numbers of women who are presumably at low risk are seeking to be tested, the city's Health Commissioner said yesterday.

title: FRANKLIN CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After unrealized appreciation of investments of $759,416. c-Net loss and after unrealized losses on investments of $1,116,164. The company said the 1986 results are restated to conform with 1987 presentation, which includes the change in unrealized appreciation or depreciation of investments in the results of operations.

title: KIDDIE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MEALS FOR THE CHEF'S DAY OFF
description: A chef's holiday is just like a busman's: both spend their leisure time doing what they are paid to do the rest of the year. Like bus drivers who enjoy driving, cooks like to cook -even if they have to do the dishes. And Memorial Day is a good reason for chefs, as well as the rest of us, to gather family and friends and feast.

title: ENGINEERED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: FILM: 'ERNEST GOES TO CAMP,' A COMEDY
description: How would you like to spend 90 minutes with Crazy Eddie? ''Ernest Goes to Camp'' is a lot easier on the eardrums, but you get the idea: Take a character well known from television commercials, spin him off into a feature film and destroy that fuzzy line between commercials and entertainment.

title: CHALONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed its increased revenue largely to the acquisition of the Acacia winery in August 1986.

title: DIRECTOR SAID TO BE ILL
description: Michael Bennett, the choreographer and director responsible for such Broadway hits as ''A Chorus Line'' and ''Dreamgirls,'' has been treated for ''a life-threatening disease'' since December, according to an affidavit filed Monday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. In a telephone interview Thursday from California, John Breglio, Mr. Bennett's attorney, would not identify the disease.

title: PRIESTS ARE TARGETS AS THEY STAND UP FOR CHANGE
description: Bishop Antonio Y. Fortich was seated in a white T-shirt eating lunch when a young priest walked up to him with a newspaper folded open to the letters column and began to read.

title: Where the A.C.L.U. Stands on AIDS
description: LEAD: The American Civil Liberties Union has been severely criticized for its opposition to compulsory testing for AIDS and to government efforts to identify and trace all sexual contacts of those suspected of harboring the AIDS virus.

title: CIRCUIT RESEARCH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: N.B.A. Issues Fines
description: A Milwaukee Bucks guard, Sidney Moncrief, and a Boston Celtics center, Greg Kite, were fined $1,000 apiece, and six other players were fined $500 each for involvement in a fight during Game 6 of the Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series, the National Basketball Association announced yesterday.

title: GRAHAM-MCCORMICK OIL & GAS PARTNERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Time Goes By

title: A Good Time to Remember Diving Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Do You Smoke, Daddy?'
description: Representative Anthony Beilenson of California quit smoking, he told readers of the Op-Ed page the other day, because of his children. They'd been impressed by some stuff they'd seen on television, like a boy and girl dressing up in their parents' wedding clothes, for instance, while a voice said: ''Children imitate their parents, the good and the bad. Do you smoke, Daddy?'' And a man putting money in a cigarette machine; as the pack dropped, a voice said, ''You lose.''

title:
PATENTS;
A Cancer Treatment
description: LEAD: A method of treating breast cancer is disclosed in a patent granted this week to Dr. Fernand Labrie of Quebec. According to patent 4,666,885, a combined anti-hormonal treatment includes blocking ovarian secretions by surgical or chemical means and adding an anti-androgen such as flutamide. A number of clinical patients have been treated by the process.

title: The Royal Game in Kabul
description: Mikhail Gorbachev hints at interesting things about Afghanistan. The Soviet leader talks of a political solution and suggests an undefined role for the former Afghan King, Mohammad Zahir Shah, in an interim reconciliation coalition. Meanwhile, over in Kabul, Afghan Communists insist they must be the ''vanguard'' or dominant partner in any such coalition, an idea that the King properly rejects. Meanwhile, over in the Afghan rebel camp, many Mujahedeen forswear all compromises.

title: MEDICORE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax loss carryforward of $25,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $113,102 and a tax credit of $113,000. The year-ago figures restated to reflect the discontinuance of the company's immunological operations carried on by its subsidiary, Viragen Inc.

title: 'ORIENT EXPRESS' WINS WORLD HAND IN POKER
description: At the flip of a 9 of hearts this evening, Johnny Chan, a 29-year-old China-born resident of Houston known as ''the Orient Express,'' collected a pot containing upwards of $500,000 in chips and won the 1987 World Championship of Poker, along with its prize of $625,000 and a gold bracelet.

title:
PATENTS;
Instrument Tests Metals and Welds
description: LEAD: Two engineers at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories, in Murray Hill, N.J., were granted a patent this week for an instrument called Microhmeter 100. It allows manufacturers to test the quality of metal welds. It also sorts metals, determines the size of cracks in steel tubes and measures the hardness of heat-treated parts such as axles and gears.

title: FLORIDA KEY DEER: ADAPTING OR DYING
description: Blondie and Skinny Minnie came first, scenting the air at the edge of the asphalt before crossing the street to the shade of Peg Riepe's beloved fig tree. Other buff-colored does follow, moving cautiously along a neighborhood street like house cats out for a stroll.

title: Triglyceride City
description: LEAD: My husband came home from an annual physical and lugubriously broke the news: ''It's bad. I have high triglycerides.'' He flipped through the oversized medical book he consults whenever he thinks he has a heart attack or an ulcer - or both. ''How bad?'' I wanted to know. He looked directly into my eyes.

title: BAYOU RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fordham Wins Again
description: Fordham tonight remained the last unbeaten team of the five squads left in the Northeast region of the national collegiate baseball tournament, after beating Dartmouth, 4-2.

title: 15 ARE CHARED IN CALIFORNIA IN ORGANIZED CRIME INQUIRY
description: Eight men have been arrested and seven others have been charged after a four-year investigation into extortion and drug dealing that has dealt a severe blow to organized crime in Southern California, the authorities said today.

title: HEART DONOR AND TRANSPLANT'S RECIPIENT WILL KEEP IN TOUCH
description: The nation's first living heart donor and his recipient agreed today that they would keep in touch and closely watch each other's progress after their rare transplant.

title: Digital, Cray Plan Linkup
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation and Cray Research Inc. said they would announce early next month a joint marketing and technology agreement, a move analysts said would step up pressure on I.B.M. in the scientific computing market.

title: Soviet Jumper Leaps 29 Feet
description: Robert Yemmiyan of the Soviet Union became the second long jumper in history to leap 29 feet, soaring 29 feet 1 inch today, the Tass news agency reported.

title: KEMP ASSAILS WHITE HOUSE ON ARMS CONTROL PROPOSAL
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, a contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, criticized the Reagan Administration today as being naive or misguided in its approach to arms control.

title: AN URBANE SECRET AGENT
description: David Kimche, the Israeli who put the White House in touch with the Iranians, is a veteran spy with an infectious delight in using military and economic power to influence the internal politics of third-world countries.

title: HOCKEY AS IT OUGHTA BE
description: A lot of people have it wrong. The problem with hockey is not that there's too much fighting and not enough hockey. The problem with hockey is that there's too much hockey and not enough fighting.

title: CAPITOL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an after-tax gain of $800,000 on the sale of Cap Mortgage Company.

title: MORGAN KEEGAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ABRAHAM LINCOLN FEDERAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank converted to stock form on Feb. 2.

title: First Chicago Unit In Bid for Clevite
description: An investor group led by a subsidiary of the First Chicago Corporation said it had offered to take Clevite Industries private in a leveraged buyout valued at about $130 million. Clevite is a manufacturer of hydraulic lifts and auto parts and has its headquarters in Glenview, Ill. Its stock, traded over-the-counter, closed today at $12.50, unchanged.

title: UPROAR OVER ROWING EVENT REOPENS BOSTON'S RACIAL WOUNDS
description: A dispute over an obscure Irish rowing event that has reopened racial wounds here was settled today when the head of a Boston rowing club apologized for asking a New York club to leave its black members at home.

title: NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: b-After a tax benefit of $245,000. c-Net income

title: CERBERONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: MINISTRY OFICIALS FIND MISSING MONEY
description: Officials of the PTL television ministry said today that they had accounted for all but $12 million of $92 million they had declared missing and called on the ministry's former chairman, the Rev. Jim Bakker, to return a bonus he received in the first three months of 1987.

title: FROST TO INTERVIEW ASPIRANTS
description: David Frost, a British journalist and television personality, will conduct a series of interviews with the 1988 Presidential candidates - a series similar to the one he introduced 20 years ago.

title: METS SLUG IT OUT WITH DODGERS
description: The Mets know they have played badly enough to deserve their struggling status, but the Los Angeles Dodgers provided plentiful proof last night of why they have earned the longest losing streak in the National League this season.

title: Fed Backed Tighter Credit in March
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve, at a meeting in late March, endorsed a slight tightening of credit conditions if necessary to defend the dollar from a precipitous drop in foreign exchange markets, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: FATE OF MONKEYS, DEFORMED FOR SCIENCE, CAUSES HUMAN HURT AFTER 6 YEARS
description: Nearly six years ago a national debate over the treatment of animals in medical research was ignited when the police in Silver Spring, Md., charged a laboratory director with cruelty to animals. The disabled monkeys they seized remain housed in small cages, caught in a protracted and emotional tug-of-war between scientists and advocates of animal rights.

title: TS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Ex-Councilman Is Disbarred
description: A former city councilman, Charles Schiano Sr., was disbarred today by the Appellate Division of the state Supreme Court for illegally keeping part of a $50,000 check mistakenly issued by an insurance company. Mr. Schiano, 53 years old, was not available for comment. The court said Mr. Schiano had accepted the check in a 1982 settlement, even though he and his client knew that the insurance company had already issued a check for the same amount as full payment in the case. The client, with whom he shared the second check, was not identified.

title: Foyt Car Repairs Seem on Schedule
description: A. J. Foyt was seething in his garage today, growling into a telephone.

title: McCoy Tyner in Trio
description: McCoy Tyner, a pianist, is leading a trio tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight; a $10 cover and a $6 minimum tomorrow.

title: CAS MEDICAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ROBERT D. MacDOUGALL
description: Dr. Robert D. MacDougall, the dean of Cornell University's Division of Summer Session, Extramural Study and Related Programs, died of cancer May 8 at the Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo. He was 46 years old and lived in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: OIL-DRI CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The latest periods' share earnings adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split-up effected in the form of a stock dividend on July 16, 1986.

title: SOVIET ARMS PLAN IS GAINING IN NATO
description: The Western allies are moving toward accepting, with conditions, a Soviet disarmament offer on medium-range and short-range missiles, according to officials from several NATO countries.

title: Congressman Is Rescued
description: Representative Silvio O. Conte escaped unharmed after being pulled from his burning automobile by a passerby after an accident on his way to Washington. ''God, the Lord is good to me,'' Mr. Conte, a Massachusetts Republican, told the Newhouse News Service. ''My door was jammed. I couldn't get out.'' An aide to Mr. Conte said the 65-year-old Congressman's rescuer asked that his name not be released. The auto hit a concrete wall after Mr. Conte slammed on the brakes.

title: DANCE: PARIS OPERA BALLET STUDENTS
description: Enchanting! No other word can really describe the annual program being performed this year by the Paris Opera Ballet School's young students.

title: Floating Point Reports Loss
description: Floating Point Systems Inc., a manufacturer of supercomputers and add-on processors based in Beaverton, Ore., today reported a $2.1 million loss for its second quarter, which ended April 30.

title: ASBESTEC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $139,253 for the quarter and $196,855 for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $147,700 and $159,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: AT&E CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STELLAR EXPLOSION REPORTED TO SPAWN MYSTERIOUS TWIN
description: The violent stellar explosion that flared into view over the Southern Hemisphere on Feb. 23 has apparently spawned a mysterious twin, scientists at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics report.

title: Ex-Washington Official Admits Cheating the City
description: Former Deputy Mayor Alphonse Hill, largely credited with designing the District of Columbia's financial system, pleaded guilty today to conspiring to defraud the city and tax evasion.

title: KAPLAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

COMPANY NEWS;
Lockheed Unit Gets Wing Subcontract
description: LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has awarded a long-disputed subcontract to manufacture wing components for the C-17 transport to the Lockheed-California Company, a division of the Lockheed Corporation.

title: PEREGRINE ENTERTAINMENT LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bridge; A Record $62,000 Is Raised At a Harmonie Club Event
description: The world's most charitable bridge game set one more record Thursday night at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street in Manhattan. The annual effort, organized by a group headed by Tubby Stayman, raised $62,000 for the U.J.A.-Federation, from a field of 70 tables. In comparison, the American Contract Bridge League collects about half that amount from its charity games, which typically consist of 4,600 tables throughout North America.

title: WEISFIELD'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a first quarter net gain of about $566,000 from the sale of a building. c-Net loss

title: A HECKLED CHAIRMAN DEFENDS HIS PROGRAM
description: Roger B. Smith, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, defended his record and sparred with hecklers at the company's annual shareholders meeting today.

title: OTF EQUITIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The figures reflected results from operations of OTF and its two majority-owned subsidiaries, Comp-U-Check and Reuter Laboratories Inc.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATORS TO TALK TO IRAQI PILOT
description: Iraq will allow a team of American investigators to interview the Iraqi pilot whose warplane attacked the frigate Stark and the Iraqi military officers who ordered the mission, American officials said today.

title: Selling Options On Your Stock
description: AT the suggestion of his broker, Richard A. Scott, a businessman in the Washington, D.C., area, began selling covered call options as part of his investment strategy about three years ago and intends to continue pursuing this approach.

title: MAKING THE UNUSUAL ROUTINE
description: The fluid routine that initially sets Jim Abbott apart from other outstanding major-college pitchers quickly becomes hardly noticeable. The circumstances that have contributed to the national attention he has received during his two seasons as a pitcher at the University of Michigan are far less significant to his teammates than Abbott's role on a championship contender.

title: BLAST AT S.I. HOUSE KILLS OWNER AND INJURES 3
description: An explosion tore through a wood house in a secluded part of Staten Island yesterday, killing its owner, who was blown onto a nearby yard, demolishing the house and knocking down walls of two neighboring houses, fire officials said.

title: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KENNEDY SEES OFFICIALS IN POLAND AND HONORS OPPOSITION LEADERS
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy sought today to bridge the divisions of Polish society as he and 13 members of his family met with Government officials, prayed with the parents of a priest who was murdered by the secret police and awarded a human-rights medal to two formerly imprisoned opposition leaders.

title: ALLIED RESEARCH ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the reason for the latest quarter results is the company's accounting method that does not credit sales until orders are shipped.

title: BUTCHER SENTENCED TO 20 YEARS
description: A Federal district judge today sentenced the bankrupt financier C.H. Butcher Jr. to 20 years in prison for banking practices that prosecutors say bilked thousands of people of their life savings.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Terry Crisp, who had been pursued by several National Hockey League teams, was named coach of the Calgary Flames. Crisp, who coached Calgary's Moncton farm club for the last two seasons, replaces Bob Johnson, who resigned Wednesday to become executive director of the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States. . . . James Lofton, the former Green Bay Packers wide receiver who now plays for the Los Angeles Raiders, was acquitted yesterday of a sexual assault charge stemming from an incident at a Green Bay night club last December.

title: Memorial Day Closings
description: The nation's stock and commodity exchanges will be closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed.

title:
PATENTS;
A Surgical Procedure For the Eye
description: LEAD: A NEW YORK eye surgeon has patented a method of operating on the eye that he hopes will eliminate the need of contact lenses and spectacles.

title: Interest Rates Sharply Lower
