description: Interest rates tumbled yesterday as bond prices soared in an unusual pre-holiday weekend rally touched off by a flow of positive economic news. As usual, the volatile long-term maturities among the Treasury debt issues showed the most pronounced gains.

title: AN ISRAELI TIED TO CONTRA AID CAN GO HOME
description: A former senior Israeli diplomat who negotiated the sale of American weapons to Iran is leaving the United States without testifying before a grand jury but has agreed to return if ordered by a Federal court, Israeli and American officials said today.

title: QUIKSILVER INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago second quarter and 6 months' nets and share earnings, as well as the year-ago 6 months' shares outstanding, are reported on a pro forma basis to reflect the sale and application of net proceeds of 1 million common shares offered by the company as if the sale occurred at the beginning of the year.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Juan Perez, the 11-year-old boy who was killed by polar bears in the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, misstated his family's address. It is 162 East 19th Street in the Flatbush section.

title: Saudi Stake In Boat Maker
description: A Saudi Arabian financier with ties to the Saudi royal family has bought nearly half the stock of the southwest Florida company that makes Chris-Craft pleasure boats.

title: MISTRIAL WEIGHED AFTER BREAKDOWN OF DONOVAN JUROR
description: A judge began considering a mistrial yesterday in the fraud case of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan after a juror became distraught during deliberations and was dragged from a Bronx courtroom shouting, ''The Lord is my shepherd,'' and ''Help me, God, these people are crazy.''

title: Burlington Bid Studied
description: Dominion Textile Inc.'s chairman, Thomas Bell, said today his company and Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, had not yet decided on whether to raise their $72-a-share offer for Burlington Industries, the textile giant, in response to a higher offer by Morgan Stanley & Company. ''We are evaluating all of our options at this time,'' Mr. Bell said. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Burlington rose 12.5 cents, to $75.25.

title: Local Costs Up by 0.7%
description: Spurred by higher costs for gasoline, clothing and groceries, prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose a sharp seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Suzanne Emil Married To Peter B. Pleskunas
description: The marriage of Suzanne Emil to Peter Benjamin Pleskunas took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Emil, father and stepmother of the bride, in Rye, N.Y. Acting Justice Burton S. Sherman of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Securities Safeguards
description: The Government today approved new safeguards for the multibillion-dollar government securities market aimed at preventing dealer failures like those of 1985, the Treasury Department said.

title: COMPUTRAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March.

title: ATTACK SAID TO PUSH CONTRAS FROM AREA OF NICARAGUA WHERE THEY OPERATED OPENLY
description: Insurgents backed by the United States have been pushed from a part of northern Nicaragua where they were openly operating, according to diplomats and military officers.

title: SUPER SKY INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest fourth quarter results include start-up costs of $85,000 from two joint ventures and recognition of $406,000 of capital gains in the fourth quarter of 1986. The share earnings restated to reflect two 25 percent stock dividends paid June 16, 1986, and Dec. 8, 1986, respectively.

title: KUWAIT'S SHIPS TO GET U.S. FLAGS, BUT THE CREWS WON'T BE AMERICAN
description: The Kuwaiti oil tankers that are changing to American registry in order to gain United States naval protection in the Persian Gulf will be primarily manned by foreigners, despite laws meant to insure that American flag vessels carry primarily American crews.

title: Columbia Also Has an Asian Studies Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES E. CHASE
description: James E. Chase, who served as Spokane's first black Mayor, died of cancer Tuesday at Sacred Heart Medical Center. He was 73 years old.

title: FORECASTS ON '87 INFLATION RAISED
description: The Consumer Price Index, the most widely followed inflation gauge, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April to post its third straight increase, the Labor Department reported today.

title: A Garbage Scow as Paul Revere
description: What should be done with that garbage barge? After a fruitless search down and up the Atlantic Coast and across the Gulf of Mexico for a place to unload 3,100 tons of non-toxic waste, the scow has returned, in desperation. New York ought to resolve the immediate problem by promptly finding room for the waste in one of its dumps.

title: Europe Nears Japan Action
description: The European Community said today that it would push for sharply higher tariffs on a range of Japanese electronics imports to compensate for benefits Japan has derived from the admission of Spain and Portugal into the community.

title: NORTHEAST SAVINGS FEDERAL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of about $3.2 million for the quarter and about $13.2 million for the year; credits for forgiveness of income payments to the FSLIC of about $4.2 million for both periods and a charge of about $5.2 million for prepayment of an advance to the Federal Home Loan Bank for the quarter and year.

title: Canada Backs Lumber Pact
description: A lumber agreement with the United States, in which Canada agreed to impose a 15 percent export tax on softwood exports, has been approved by the House of Commons.

title: CODENOLL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HODGSON HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company's operations are now being reported on the basis of accounting for revenue recognition using the percentage-of-completion method as compared to the completed-contract method previously utilized. This accounting change was made in order to reduce the distortion of quarterly financial data.

title: RINKER TAKES LEAD ON BIRDIES
description: Laurie Rinker birdied four of her last nine holes today to come from behind and take the second-round lead in the Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship by a shot over Deb Richard. Rinker is two shots ahead of five other golfers, including Ayako Okamoto of Japan.

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BROOKLYN GROUPS AGREE TO BLACK-HASIDIC PATROL
description: Ending years of disagreement over an all-white neighborhood security patrol run by a Hasidic sect, members of the black and Jewish communities in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn have agreed to start a new integrated patrol, they announced yesterday.

title: Miss Jewett Weds Peter Lowenthal
description: At the Washington Cathedral last evening, Lucy DeWitt Jewett and Peter Stern Lowenthal were married by Bishop John Walker of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington and Rabbi Harold White, a chaplain at Georgetown University. Elizabeth Bromley Jewett was her sister's maid of honor, and Harry S. Lowenthal was best man for his brother.

title: DISC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations funded research and development of $500,316. The company said the year-ago revenue includes $675,000 on a research and development contract from Kodak that was completed in mid-year.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Correction
description: A table on Thursday listing third-world loans of several major banks, with an article analyzing the effect of a Citicorp decision on the debt situation, included several incorrect figures supplied by Bear, Stearns, for Mellon Bank. Mellon's assets were $34,499 million; its loan loss reserve was $494 million; its third world loans as a percentage of capital were 37 percent.

title: THE PARACHUTIST AT WORLD SERIES STARTS JAIL TERM
description: The parachutist who unexpectedly dropped in on the sixth game of the World Series at Shea Stadium last fall began serving a Federal jail term yesterday for contempt of court.

title: MUSIC: CHICAGO PRO MUSICA
description: This week's extended visit of the Chicago Symphony offered a bonus of sorts with a concert by the Chicago Pro Musica chamber ensemble at the 92d Street Y on Thursday night. The eight musicians, all members of the orchestra, played music by Richard Strauss and Hans Werner Henze and ended with the Schubert Octet.

title: Singapore Trade Gain
description: Singapore's trade deficit narrowed in April as exports rose sharply, the Trade Development Board said today. The deficit for the month came to $447 million, down from $641 million in March.

title: Second AIDS Tests Increase Accuracy Dramatically
description: To the Editor:

title: GOULD INVESTORS L P reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results include gains from the disposition of properties, mortgages and investments of $39,000 and $145,000, respectively; the year- ago quarter results include gains of $241,000 and the 6-month results include gains of $311,000. The company was reorganized into Gould Investors L.P. in May 1986; results for 1986 represent the operations of Gould Investors Trust.

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: *Allis-Chalmers Corp., Milwaukee, said it had signed a definitive agreement for the sale of its solids processing equipment and minerals systems to Boliden A.B. of Sweden. The deal is valued at $94.5 million. *Dart Group Corp., Landover, Md., has tendered 1.9 million shares of Supermarkets General Corp. to SMG Acquisition Corp. under the $46.75-a-share offer made by SMG. The leveraged buyout, led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and members of Supermarkets' senior management, amounts to $1.5 billion for 85 percent of the outstanding shares. *International Minerals and Chemical Corp., Northbrook, Ill., said its board had agreed to enter into a multiyear program with Synbiotics Corp. to find commercial applications of Synbiotics' monoclonal antibody technology for International's animal growth and health business. *Siemens Information Systems Inc., Boca Raton, Fla., has signed an agreement with the N.E.C. Corp. enabling it to remain a full-line distributor for N.E.C.'s NEAX 2400 information management system.

title: ORMAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The 1987 results includes a gain on the sale of certain real estate of $443,000, or 27 cents a share.

title: GEORGIA EXECUTION IS SECOND IN WEEK
description: Richard Tucker, who was convicted of murdering a nurse while on parole in another killing, was executed today. He was the second Georgia inmate to be put to death in a week.

title: NOFZIGER INQUIRY BROADENED TO COVER FAIRCHILD INDUSTRIES
description: The special prosecutor investigating links between the Wedtech Corporation and Lyn Nofziger, a former White House aide, has broadened the inquiry to include questions about a relationship between Mr. Nofziger and Fairchild Industries.

title: SMITH & WESSON IS SOLD TO BRITONS
description: Smith & Wesson, the maker of pistols favored by American lawmen for 135 years, is being sold to a British manufacturer of plumbing supplies and lawn mowers.

title: AMERICAN HEALTH SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter loss primarily reflects the clinical research and development expenses associated with the company's trans- cranial electrostimulation therapy project. Of the $723,013 T.C.E.T. expenses in the quarter, about $310,000 of these expenses were attributable to the TCET acquisition and were of a non-recurring nature. The company recently changed its name from NRM Centers Inc.

title: India and China Are More Than Their Economies
description: To the Editor:

title: MODEST PRICE INCREASES EXPECTED FOR GASOLINE
description: Supplies of crude oil and gasoline are plentiful, but retail gasoline prices will probably increase modestly during the Memorial Day weekend and through mid-June, according to oil industry experts and motorists groups.

title: Constitution Supports a Defense Lawyer's Zeal
description: To the Editor:

title: FUNERAL HOME OWNER IS TO PAY BURIAL COSTS OF BOY MAULED BY BEAR
description: The owner of a Brooklyn funeral home has agreed to assume all the expenses for the funeral of Juan Perez, the 11-year-old who was killed Tuesday by two polar bears at the Prospect Park Zoo.

title: DURABLE GOODS ORDERS SHOW GAIN OF ONLY 0.1%
description: Orders for durable goods inched up just one-tenth of 1 percent in April, the weakest performance in three months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MALRITE COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $1,818,000 from the prepayment of debt.

title: JUDGE SENTENCES A GOETZ VICTIM OVER OUTBURSTS
description: One of the four youths shot by Bernhard H. Goetz received the maximum jail sentence yesterday for contempt of court after the trial judge said the young man's behavior before the jury had conveyed ''viciousness and selfishness more eloquently than words could.''

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a net charge of $15,451,000 from the writedown of oil and gas properties and other unusual items of $310,000.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
President of Mattel Resigns
description: The president of Mattel Inc., Thomas J. Kalinske, resigned today, three months after one of his rivals was named chairman and chief executive of the toy maker.

title: KEY RATES
PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DEVOTED CAREER TO SEA TURTLE
description: Archie Fairly Carr Jr., a Florida zoologist whose studies unraveled many mysteries about giant sea turtles and whose writings and conservation efforts have helped to save them from near extinction, died of cancer Thursday at his home on Wewa Pond near Micanopy, Fla. Dr. Carr, who was affiliated with the University of Florida in Gainesville for his entire 55-year career, was 77 years old.

title: MUSIC: BERLIOZ'S 'DEATH OF CLEOPATRA'
description: THE New York Philharmonic's concert on Thursday evening in Avery Fisher Hall had a United Nations look about it. Giuseppe Sinopoli, the Italian guest conductor, divided his program between French and German works, with Rosalind Plowright, a British soprano, as the night's soloist. Need it be added that the orchestra was American?

title: Dance
description: Claire Porter and Lisa Kraus, two choreographers who can make incisive comments on the world around them, are both presenting works this week. Ms. Porter's creations are as deftly constructed as epigrams, and because her small-scale productions can work in large spaces and small, she calls her dances ''Portables.'' She brings a selection to the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, Tuesday night at 8. Combining movement and text, she shows people in seemingly familiar situations, then lets the situations get comically out of hand until everyday life seems totally absurd. ''Dining Out'' depicts a sedate diner growing progressively tipsy. ''Piano'' concerns what happens when a pianist walks out on the stage for a recital only to find that her piano has not arrived. And in ''Fundraiser'' a solicitor for contributions is forced to contend with a truculent audience.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a report in the Northeast Journal column last Sunday omitted several sentences about an Air Force decision to build two communications towers in Maine. The towers were designed for use if a high-altitude nuclear explosion crippled primary communications systems. The Air Force said the two Maine sites would have the ''least environmental impact'' of any of the dozens of sites studied.

title: STRANGE STATE FOR JOHNSON
description: ON a recent evening at Shea Stadium, Dave Johnson sounded like a shell-shocked manager, and well he might be. The man is unaccustomed to the sort of adversity the Mets have encountered this season.

title: ON THE TOP AT LAST, RAHAL IS TRYING TO GO AT AN EASIER PACE
description: THE irony of his racing life is hardly lost on Bobby Rahal, the slender Indianapolis 500 champion who will defend his title today.

title: 'OF PAPTER, PGIMENT AND GLASS' FROM PERSPECTIVE OF AN ARTIST
description: Artists make good curators because, for them, choosing art is not too remote from making it. This is not to disparage the professionals who would instruct the viewer or prove a point with their choices. But it is to say that a show without a curatorial cause can be very bracing. ''Of Paper, Pigment and Glass'' is an example.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There was a community and now it looks like an open field.

title: Comparing Costs: City vs. the Suburbs
description: WHEN all taxes and commuting expenses are figured in, homeownership costs about the same in New York City as it does in the suburbs, according to a new study that tested the common belief that it costs more in the city.

title: THE JOY OF ART, FOUND BY TOUCH
description: LEAD: ALFRED VAN LOEN was worried. Although thousands of people have trekked through the sculptor's meandering Huntington Station studio, this day was different; Mr. Van Loen was expecting a visit from residents of the Helen Keller National Center for Deaf-Blind Youths and Adults.

title: AUTHORITATIVE BOOKS TO READ AND GIVE
description: THIS season, marked by anticipation of a stretch of leisure, seems an appropriate time to call attention to a range of recently published authoritative books on crafts and related subjects.

title: A PAINTER WHO LENDS FIRE TO THE GODS
description: AT THE MARIAN GOODMAN GAL-lery, 24 West 57th Street, there can be seen through June 4 an exhibition, that is not like any other. In the big room, there are exactly two paintings, on the theme of Isis and Osiris. One measures roughly 11 feet by 18 feet. The other is a little larger. They are huge, therefore, and they are also dense and dark and, at first sight, cryptic. They stand at opposite ends of the room, like altarpieces that have mislaid their altars, and we sense at once that they deal with weighty matters that will take some unriddling.

title: Arresting a Plan To 'Steal' Jails
description: For a while it looked as if Albany might attempt to steal two jails right off the city's drawing board, but as of last week, Mayor Koch still had them firmly in custody.

title: When Hamilton Quarreled With Monroe
description: To the Editor:

title: Disgruntled Fan Seeks 'Justice'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Liquidity Of Investment
description: WHEN WAS the last time you bought and drank one of the great names of wine, a Chateau Mouton-Rothschild, say, or a Chateau Latour, or a Romanee-Conti? Newcomers to wine may find it hard to believe, but 20 years ago these were readily accessible to anyone prepared to spend a dollar or two more than usual for a bottle.

title: HOLLYWOOD SPINS A NEW FAIRY TALE
description: HOLLYWOOD, which has conceived so many wonderful stories over the years, is spinning another beauty about the cable television industry. According to the studios, cable is fast becoming an unrestrained monopoly, intent on gouging consumers and, yes, the companies that make films and other programming. It is a fetching tale and quite convincing - until one probes a bit deeper.

title: Soviet Yiddish Theater To Play in U.S.
description: The Soviet Union's only Yiddish musical theater will embark on its first North American tour this month, performing in New York June 6, 7 and 8. The troupe will arrive in New York today and move on directly to the West Coast.

title: ENTERTAINING AN EMPEROR
description: For the space of an evening last summer I sat in an ancient part of a modern city and watched a progression of stilt-fighters, fire-eaters, jugglers, acrobats, fireworks, trumpets, drums, horses and a costumed cast of thousands. The Ommegang takes place in Brussels every year in early July. This year July 2 is the regular night for the pageant, but this time there is an extra performance. To commemorate the 30th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, which established the European Community, the Ommegang is also being presented on June 30. On both nights the event will combine the weight of history with the sparkle of entertainment, as if the Santa Claus Parade had become the subject of a seminar.

title: IRAN-CONTRA AFFAIR: THE UNFOLDING STORY
description: A parade of secondary figures -expediters, contributors and one beneficiary of aid to the Nicaraguan rebels - testified at last week's Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair. Highlights of the week's developments follow.

title:
GARDEING;
SITE ANALYSIS TO PREVENT PLANT FAILURE
description: LEAD: MANY planting failures result from site problems. Some, though nonexistent when the planting was made, may nevertheless have developed during the intervening years. Others may have existed before planting. In either case, replacement plantings have all too frequently been made without first having ascertained the cause of the problem and having taken steps to remedy it.

title: Virginia Wedding For Ms. Swofford
description: Jean Swofford and Marc S. Firestone, associates at the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va., by the Rev. Nicholas T. Cooke 3d.

title: Shaking Up Sloan-Kettering
description: Philip M. Boffey's article ''Dr. Marks' Crusade'' (April 26) describes the shaking up of Sloan-Kettering in terms worthy of turn-around experts such as Lee Iacocca. However, Sloan-Kettering is a nonprofit research organization, not a Fortune 500 corporation. It relies solely on private donations and Government and privately financed grants for its survival. Ironically, the majority of those so-called ''mediocre'' scientists dismissed by Dr. Marks were recipients of such grants, having been judged for their excellence by a tough peer-review system during a period of particularly scarce funds. Although Dr. Marks has erected new buildings and laboratories and offered research money, generous salaries and apartments, in nearly seven years of effort, he has largely failed in enticing eminent molecular biologists to replace those removed. RISE K. CROSS New York City

title: The Marshall Plan
description: If it can put politics aside for a few minutes, Europe will be celebrating the 40th anniversary of the Marshall Plan on June 6, but it's not likely to remember the little band of valiant men who helped put that European recovery program together.

title: AUCTION FEATURES POSTAL HISTORY
description: AN auction of manuscripts and United States postal history will be held on Saturday at the Hilton Hotel in Danbury, Conn. Richard C. Frajola, Inc. will stage the auction which features an outstanding selection of stampless covers, an important collection of Minnesota Territory usages and selected rarities bearing the 1847 and 1851 issues. Hours will be from 12:30 to 6:30 P.M.

title: Mets Urged To Sign Seaver
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rent Guidelines
description: To the Editor:

title: OLD PRINTS AND MAPS CAPTURE ROME'S PAST
description: The past impresses itself on every visitor to Rome, just as the sky-scraping present spellbinds a visitor to Manhattan. Artists have come to Italy in a constant stream to paint and sketch the ancient ruins and monuments of the capital, while engravers have reproduced these images to create fine period prints. Giambattista Piranesi, perhaps Italy's most famous and prolific etcher, believed that he ''executed a work which will descend to posterity, and will last so long as there will be men desirous of knowing all that has survived of the ruins of the most famous city of the universe.'' He was right. A won-derful way to take home a bit of Roman his-tory is to purchase prints of its famous sights, particularly those done by Piranesi in the 1750's.

title: Preserving a Mix Of Rich and Poor
description: It has been called ''inclusionary zoning'' because instead of keeping low-income families out of a neighborhood it makes it easier for them to stay in. Last week the New York City Board of Estimate approved a change in the city's zoning resolution to do just that.

title: Ft. Greene Conversion: Griffin Co-op
description: A griffin - a mythical animal that is half eagle and half lion - still looks down from the facade of the Griffin, an 18-story building in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, as it has since 1931. But inside the Art Deco structure, at 101 Lafayette Avenue near South Oxford Street, kitchens are being remodeled and new tenants are arriving as the result of a co-op conversion that was declared effective this month.

title: CUOMO'S COURT CHOICE CHAGRINS G.O.P.
description: LEAD: A CASUAL observer might have thought that the Westchester County Republican Committee would have been happy when Governor Cuomo, a Democrat, appointed a Republican to the area's judiciary last March.

title: Great Guns!
description: DODGE CITY With Errol Flynn and Olivia de Havilland. Directed by Michael Curtiz. 1939. Playhouse Video. 104 minutes. $19.98.

title: FRENCH AND ORIENTAL COMBINED
description: HOMER LEE is the Woody Allen of Long Island restaurateurs. Never content with past successes and winning formulas, he's always trying to create something new. His latest venture, Maison de Lee, in Woodbury, combines French and Oriental cooking.

title: RULING DUE IN WEST ON FARMER-RESEARCH LINK
description: A Superior Court judge is expected to rule soon on whether the University of California must arrange a way for small-scale farmers to benefit from university research that is supported by public funds.

title: Nelson Cuts Ties
description: DON NELSON, who has been frequently mentioned as a candidate to become the Knicks' general manager or head coach, said he is leaving the Milwaukee Bucks after 11 years as their head coach. He cited differences with Herbert Kohl, the Bucks' owner.

title: RIDER IN N.C.A.A. REGIONAL FINAL
description: Facing the possible end of its baseball season twice within eight hours, Rider College defeated Dartmouth this afternoon and Fordham this evening to move within a game of the Northeast regional championship in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's baseball tournament.

title: 2-YEAR HOSPTIAL BUILDING MORATORIUM LIFTED
description: LEAD: THE state's Department of Health has lifted its two-year moratorium on hospital construction, allowing 11 to proceed with renovations totaling nearly $500 million.

title: 7 Miners Die in South Africa
description: Rescue workers have found the bodies of six miners missing since an underground cave-in 100 miles southwest of here two days ago, the mine's owners said today. The discoveries brought the toll to seven dead and seven injured.

title: HELP FOR A DAY, OR EVEN AN HOUR
description: JUNE LAVELLE has been managing the Fulton-Carroll incubator since the Industrial Council of Northwest Chicago opened it in 1981. At first, the rent included a receptionist/secretary (Ms. Lavelle), meeting rooms and loading docks. Council members volunteered help when tenants had management problems.

title: Joan Carol Hoffman Wed To Christopher Ellis Green
description: Joan Carol Hoffman, a senior graphics designer at Fortune magazine in New York, and Christopher Ellis Green, a photograph editor and researcher at Fortune, were married at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park yesterday. Acting Justice Richard L. Price of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Slow Motion for VCR's The video cassette recorders will be whirring away at this week's annual Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago, but VCR sales may be starting to slow, or even flatten.

title: CONNECTICUT OPINION
description: THE fashion arbiters have decided low-heeled shoes will be in style soon. While I've never been one to follow the seasonal whimsies of these standard-setters, this latest missive is quite exciting. And the best part of it is that I've been in the vanguard of this style for years.

title: Sports of The Times; The Lion Roars A Little
description: LEO DUROCHER and Ron Hunt had not snapped at each other across a diamond in 14 years, but it all came back to them quickly.

title: No Headline
description: THE Arena Players Repertory Company has just opened a twin bill at its Second Stage Theater consisting of Eugene Ionesco's ''Bald Soprano'' and Edward Albee's ''American Dream.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Tinmouth, Vt.: Preserving The Pastures
description: LEAD: EDWIN BAKER, a dairyman here, had more reason than most to be alarmed when a helicopter carrying real-estate developers was seen circling over the old Dunn farm last summer.

title: Two Adults and a Child Die in a House Blaze
description: Two adults and a 6-year-old girl died today when an early morning fire ripped through the first floor of their two-story row house here, officials said.

title: MARCHING WITH PRETORIA
description: BLACK AND GOLD By Anthony Sampson. 280 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

title: In Goetz Trial, The Defense Goes on Offense
description: Lawyers for Bernhard H. Goetz began his defense last week, trying to persuade jurors that he acted in self-defense when he shot four youths with an unregistered gun in a Manhattan subway car in 1984. Before they did, however, one of the men shot by Mr. Goetz was cited for contempt of court and sentenced to six months in jail after he refused to answer some questions posed during two hours of cross-examination.

title: Green Invasion
description: There are some sections of New York in which the only way you can tell the season is by the temperature. Looking out a window provides no clue when you're looking at a rubble-strewn vacant lot. There are fewer dismal vistas these days, thanks to Operation GreenThumb, now entering its 10th year of bringing life and color to blighted neighborhoods.

title: F.B.I. Reports Increase In Terrorist Bombings
description: Bombings by terrorist groups rose from 5 in 1985 to 15 last year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today, while the total number of bombings nationwide was 709, killing 14 people and injuring 185.

title: Julie Ellen Schmerler Weds Mark Harrison
description: The marriage of Julie Ellen Schmerler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Schmerler of Tenafly, N.J., and Mark Goehausen Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Smith Harrison of Wilmington, Del., took place last evening at the Westbury Hotel in New York. Rabbi Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony.

title: Women and Human Separateness
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Ryan Is Bride
description: Elizabeth Mary Ryan and John Tylko Jr. were married yesterday at St. Agatha's Roman Catholic Church in Milton, Mass., by the Rev. Francis Turke. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Ryan of Milton and Mr. and Mrs. Tylko of Binghamton, N.Y.

title: Stenmark Eligible
description: HE failed to meet the amateur eligibility requirements for the 1984 Winter Olympics, but Ingmar Stenmark, the Swedish skier, will be allowed to compete in next year's Games, according to a Swedish member of the International Ski Federation. Stenmark helped his chances by transferring his earnings trust fund to an account maintained by the Swedish Ski Federation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about negotiations on an international conference on Middle East peace misidentified the group whose meeting the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, was planning to attend. It was the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, not the American-Israeli Political Action Committee.

title: AT GOLDEN GATE, A BIRTHDAY PARTY FOR BRIDGE, 50
description: In some circumstances a mile is a long way. In the 1920's, at the entrance to San Francisco Bay, in a channel of savage tidal currents, ocean waves and rushing winds, within 12 miles of a major earthquake fault, a mile seemed unbridgeably long.

title: 1985 IRAQI ATTACK ON U.S. SHIP CITED
description: The Iraqi attack on the frigate Stark last Sunday night was not the first such incident, Navy officers have asserted, describing a similar but less disastrous episode in 1985 when the destroyer John Hancock appeared to have been an Iraqi target in the Persian Gulf.

title: Colston Freeman, A Physician, Wed To Colin McEvoy
description: Dr. Anne Colston Freeman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Clemon Freeman of Richmond, and Colin McEvoy, a son of Mrs. David Hatch Hamilton of Duxbury, Mass., and the late George A. McEvoy, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Richmond. Canon Robert G. Hetherington performed the ceremony.

title: OFFICE DEMAND: SLOW AHEAD
description: FOR more than a decade, Long Island's supply of office space expanded rapidly as developers sought to meet a growing demand for high-quality, relatively low-priced offices close to Manhattan.

title: NEW YORK, FISCALLY SOUND, MAY BE PRESSED BY UNIONS
description: Contracts between a fiscally sound New York City and its municipal unions expire June 30, and, for the first time in a long time, the unions are out for important gains.

title: UNION AIDE DISENTS
description: OF THE 1,583 New Jersey public schoolteachers to receive Governor Kean's teacher-recognition honor this year, more than 1,300 are members of the New Jersey Education Association, a bargaining organization with 124,000 members statewide.

title: A Report on Risks And Pesticides
description: The risks of cancer in the nation's food supply are unknowable by most measures, but the National Academy of Sciences said last week that the Government could reduce them greatly by reorganizing its ''crazy quilt'' of laws and regulations governing pesticides.

title: HOW CONGRESS CREATED A CABLE MONSTER
description: WHEN he was alive and robustly effective as the senior Senator from Oklahoma, Robert Kerr used to rise heavily to his feet in the Senate chamber and declare that ''I am against all monopolies'' - slight pause - ''that I'm not a part of.'' America has never approved or allowed monopolies - except, as with utilities, under the restraint of public agencies. Today, however, we are nourishing for the first time an unsupervised and unrestrained monopoly - your local cable system.

title: Ojeda Surgery A 'Success'
description: Bob Ojeda underwent one hour of surgery on his left elbow yesterday, and his surgeon told the Mets that the operation had been ''a complete success.''

title: Judith Hill Is Wed
description: The marriage of Judith Gregory Hill to Robert Woodman Harris took place yesterday at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Lyle Guttu, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony. The bride, the daughter of John R. Gregory of Greenwich and the late Mrs. Gregory, is an executive vice president of the Seafood Management Corporation, a Greenwich management consulting concern, of which Mr. Harris is president. He is a son of Elizabeth Harris of Venice, Fla., and the late William Harris. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title: 'CEMERTERY' MOURNS THREATENED SPECIES
description: A ''CEMETERY'' sprang up in the middle of a Bedford Hills schoolyard last week in the first of what sponsors hope will be many such schoolyard appearances around the county.

title: HOME VIDEO: ART
description: LEAD: Eduardo Chillida, Basque Sculptor Produced by William Leeson. Directed by Laurence Boulting. Home Vision. 60 minutes. $39.95.

title: Marcy Deane Is Bride Of Christopher Benton
description: Martha Ann Deane and Christopher Forest Benton were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony performed by the Rev. Daniel Whitley at the home of the bride's maternal grandfather, Howell Taylor, in Chester, N.Y. The bride, who is known as Marcy, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Deane of Roslyn, L.I. Her husband is a son of Mary Elizabeth Pierce of Oceanside, Calif., and Clifford Forest Benton of Tiburon, Calif.

title: ZEN AND THE ART OF NOODLE MAKING
description: THE REST OF THE WORLD may see Japan as a nation of workaholics, but not Juzo Itami.

title: Claudia J. Krimsky Is Married to Gregory M. Kee
description: Claudia Jane Krimsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Krimsky of Chappaqua, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., and Gregory Michael Kee, a son of Mrs. Harrison E. Kee Jr. of North Hampton, N.H., and the late Colonel Kee, an Air Force officer, were married yesterday. The Rev. Allan Roche, the bridegroom's cousin, performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Ipswich, Mass.

title: NEW DIRECTIONS FOR REFUSE AS STATE RUNS OUT OF LANDFILLS
description: FOR weeks the world watched a barge of unwelcome New York garbage get shunted about, a dramatic symbol of the garbage crisis facing many communities.

title: New Mexico
description: To the Editor: On April 12 you featured Las Vegas, N.M. The article was packed immediately because we were leaving for Albuquerque, Santa Fe and Taos the next day.

title: Greitzer Assails Rent-Roll Checks
description: City Councilwoman Carol Greitzer of Manhattan has introduced a resolution condemning a state plan to cross-check computerized rent rolls against income-tax returns. The state hopes to find out whether rent regulation allows large numbers of renters to pay substantially less rent than they can afford.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Honolulu;
Japanese Buy An Idyllic Isle
description: LEAD: EARLY this year, the State Senate's President, Richard Wong, and the chairman of its Ways and Means Committee, Mamoru Yamasaki, presented legislation to buy an idyllic island off Oahu for $8 million. But before the lawmakers had a chance to vote on the measure, a Japanese investor bought the property for $8.5 million.

title: RETELLINGS OF TALES BY HANS CHRISTIAN ANDERSON
description: DANCERS HAVE LONG BEEN fond of the fairy tales of Hans Christian Andersen, for many of the 19th-century Danish writer's fantastic plots seem suitable for choreographic treatment. Three were recently brought to theatrical life in Boston, when the Boston Ballet presented ''Tales of Hans Christian Andersen,'' a new full-evening work, collaboratively choreographed by Bruce Marks and Bruce Wells, that retold ''The Ice Maiden,'' ''The Steadfast Tin Soldier'' and ''The Wild Swans.''

title: TRI-STAR ATTRACTS THE BULLS
description: LEAD: Tri-Star Pictures Inc., a movie producer and distributor, has had investors jumping to their feet in recent weeks - and heading for the door. Its share prices sagged last week to about $9.25, less than a point above its 52-week low. But bargain hunters at Bear, Stearns & Company think Tri-Star looks cheap on a cash-flow basis.

title: CUBS TOP BRAVES IN 16 INNINGS
description: Jerry Mumphrey's double into the left-field corner scored Ryne Sandberg from first base in the 16th inning today, giving the Chicago Cubs a 7-6 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'FAMILY OF YEAR'
description: LEAD: ''We wanted to do something special for our benefit dinner,'' said Helene Handelman, president of the Family Service of Westchester. The agency's board members decided that they should honor an outstanding Westchester family, and they selected the George H. C. Lawrence family of Bedford as the first recipients of the agency's ''Family of the

title: PITCH IN, PITCH TENTS
description: THE counselors come from Westchester, several states and 10 foreign countries, all attracted by the challenge of working at New York City's only camp for homeless children. Because many won't arrive in time to help get the camp in Harriman State Park ready for its 300 occupants, the leaders of Camp Homeward Bound have issued a call for Westchester volunteers to fill the temporary gap.

title: A PRIMER: CITICORP'S LOSS RESERVE
description: CITICORP'S decision last week to allocate $3 billion to its loan-loss reserves raised many questions about how banks deal with problem loans and how such problems affect the banks' profits and financial stability. The following addresses some of the key points. Q. What is a loan loss reserve? A. It is money put aside by a bank when it believes that certain loans will not be repaid. The money placed in the reserve is deducted from the bank's income. When actual loan losses arise, they are charged against the reserve and have no direct impact on the bank's earnings.

title: AN ENGLISH RAINBOW
description: In those years of wealth and privilege before World War II, Lionel de Rothschild, of the banking family, spared no expense in creating his masterpiece, a rhododendron garden in Hampshire, some 100 miles southwest of London. He bought the Georgian Exbury House, the ancestral home of the Mitford sisters near Southampton, in 1919. In the tangled pheasant cover and virgin New Forest woodland surrounding the house, over 150 gardeners dug beds and borders, first breaking the soil, then adding peat and bracken, and finally planting, often where ''Mr. Lionel,'' with great deliberation as to color and form, had stuck his walking stick.

title: FOR A NICARAGUAN, THE MIAMI OPTION
description: On a sunny morning last January, Maria Azucena Ferrey was leaning against a jeep waiting for an anti-Sandinista protest march to begin.

title: Tornado Aid Phone Number
description: A toll-free number has been set up for people wishing to donate money or other items to victims of the Saragosa tornado, the American Red Cross said today. The number is (800) 453-9000. People wishing information about the victims can call (512) 928-4271, the Red Cross said.

title: WHY CONTRA HEARINGS AREN'T LIKE WATERGATE
description: ALONG with new details of White House links to a private foreign policy initiative, the Iran-contra hearings so far have provided clear indications of what the proceedings probably will - and probably will not - achieve.

title: Modern-Day Gloom
description: SOAP OPERA USED to lean heavily on hospital miseries. As soon as a promising young pianist entered the plot you knew a doctor would soon be giving him some bad news: ''I'm afraid you have a rare brain disease, Jeff, that completely destroys the patient's ability to carry a tune.''

title: MISTRIAL REJECTED IN DONOVAN CASE DESPITE PROTESTS
description: Disregarding the protests of defense lawyers, a judge in the Bronx refused yesterday to declare a mistrial in the fraud case of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: SYRIA AIDE SAYS LIBYA BOUGHT FRENCH HOSTAGE
description: Islamic fundamentalists holding foreign hostages in Lebanon have sold at least one of their French captives to Libya, a senior Syrian officer was quoted today as having said.

title: SOBOL APPRAISES HIS SCARSDALE YEARS
description: LEAD: DR. Thomas Sobol, the Scarsdale Superintendent of Schools who was recently elected as the State Commissioner of Education, was looking back at his 16 years in Scarsdale. ''Let me quote what someone once said about those years,'' he said. ''I don't mean to be vain, but someone said, 'Excellence with a heart.

title: Submarine Builder Faces No Charges
description: In the mid-1970's, the General Dynamics Corporation and other military shipbuilders claimed hundreds of millions of dollars in cost overruns, setting off Congressional investigations and repeated attempts at procurement reforms. Last week, after a second criminal investigation of whether General Dynamics had tried to defraud the Navy, the Justice Department decided for the second time that it had insufficient evidence to prosecute the company or its officials.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: LEAD: Among Friends The Juilliard String Quartet at Michigan State University. Produced by Robert Albers. Department of Telecommunication, M.S.U. Available from M.S.U. (517) 355-9543. 30 minutes. $29.95, plus $2.05 for handling.

title: VIEWING IT ALL A FEW YEARS LATER
description: I WAS sitting down to breakfast and the newspaper one Sunday morning when the telephone rang. The voice on the line was a voice from the past. My high school girlfriend was up from Pennsylvania, visiting her parents in Rockville Centre, and she wanted to know if I had time to get together.

title: Soft Touch
description: A Federal judge in Massachusetts last week ordered a fundamentalist church to pass back the contents of its collection plate. After a three-week trial in Federal Bankruptcy Court, Judge James F. Queenan Jr. ruled that the church, Bible Speaks, had ''abused the trust'' of its chief contributor, Elizabeth Dayton Dovydenas.

title: DANCE: GRIMM TALE, 'HANDLESS MAIDEN'
description: SOME of the fairy tales the Brothers Grimm collected are very grim. One such tale is ''The Handless Maiden,'' which was presented in a choreographic version Thursday night at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art, 44 Walker Street. The work was collaboratively created and performed by Tamar Kotoske, Maria Lakis and Mary Richter, who are the members of a trio called Kinematic.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 4-DAY TASTE OF GREECE Authentic Greek dishes will be the centerpiece of ''Greek Festival '87, a Taste of Greece,'' Thursday through Sunday at the Community Center of St. George Greek Orthodox Church, 1200 Klockner Road, Trenton.

title: How to Rent Reality
description: Apparently, the idea has been around for some time, but happily I managed to avoid it until the ad appeared in the paper: surrogate staffs for surrogate bosses.

title: Hill Town
description: To the Editor: Just before we took off for our February trip to Italy, my wife spotted the reference in ''Roman Artichokes, Herald of Spring'' (Travel, Feb. 22) to Ristorante Umbria in Todi. We tried the fried artichokes the article praised and if anything, we'd say the writer was too restrained! Delicious.

title: N.H.L. Violence Turns Off Fans
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'DOWN THE THROAT OF NIGHT
description: LEAD: THE HOUSES OF CHILDREN By Coleman Dowell. 199 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.

title: Claire Kerrigan Plans to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. James Davis Robins of Pawcatuck, Conn., and Richard Thomas Kerrigan of New York of the engagement of their daughter Claire Kerrigan to Thornton Jenkins 3d, a son of Mrs. James E. Cummiskey of Greenwich and Guilford, Conn., and Mr. Jenkins 2d of Marblehead, Mass. The wedding is to be in August.

title: A Spurt in Early Human Evolution?
description: In the conventional view of early human development, evolution occurred steadily and gradually over millions of years. But the discovery last summer of a skeleton in the Olduvai Gorge of Tanzania has raised speculation that an abrupt speed-up in human evolution took place about 1.6 million years ago.

title: THEY NEVER WANTED TO BE THEMSELVES
description: YOU CAN'T GET LOST IN CAPE TOWN By Zoe Wicomb. 185 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $10.95; Paper, $6.95.

title: CAPS AND GOWNS AND 3-PIECE SUITS
description: AGRICULTURE has always been a big deal in Arkansas.

title: Yesterday's Hero
description: Lt. Col. Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, who was lionized as the hero of Portugal's 1974 revolution, now faces imprisonment as a terrorist. Colonel Saraiva de Carvalho, a two-time presidential candidate, was convicted last week of leading a left-wing terrorist group linked to dozens of bombings and bank robberies and the deaths of 13 people. A three-judge panel in Lisbon said the prosecution had ''essentially proven'' that a group called Global Project, which the Colonel said he founded and led, was a front for the Popular Forces of April 25, a terrorist group named for the date of the 1974 coup that ended a half-century of right-wing dictatorship. The Colonel, who was widely known as ''Major Otelo'' in the 1970's, got 15 years in prison. His lawyers said they would appeal.

title: DVORAK -COSMOPOLITAN NATIONALIST
description: ANTONIN DVORAK IS CELE-brated at once for being a musical proponent of Czech (or pan-Slavic) nationalism and for his cosmopolitan career. After he achieved fame in his late 30's, his services as composer and professor were much in demand all over Europe, Britain and the United States; indeed, some of his most popular works were conceived in America.

title: New Study Finds More People in the City
description: AS New York City adds people and continues to reverse its population losses of the 60's and 70's, it does so at the expense of overcrowding in rental apartments, according to a study that will be made public this week by the City Planning Commission.

title: Porch-Wrapped: Adapting a Style
description: Sprawling shingle-style houses from the 1870's and 1880's still dot the coast in shore communities of the Northeast. Typically, such a house is ''a generous, expansive, organic building unified under one great roof,'' according to Turner Brooks, an architect from Starksboro, Vt., who has taken certain design elements from the shingle style and used them in a group of single-family homes in Bellport, L.I.

title: A HOTEL WITH A TOUCH OF THE RAJ
description: Before the British founded their favorite summer resort of Darjeeling in the lush green Himalayan foothills in 1835, the region surrounding the town on top of a 7,000-ridge was known as the abode of Indra, the rain god - dorje ling, or the place of thunderbolts.

title: Emigration Overshadows U.S.-Soviet Cities' Talks
description: A three-day meeting of Russian and American municipal officials has been been dominated by protests against Soviet policies on the emigration of Jews.

title: A LESSON IN THE CAIRO HUSTLE
description: My first day in Cairo I was offered 10,000 camels, 2 donkeys, a horse and 20 shekels to marry a rather charming Egyptian named Sharif. Actually, the two women I was traveling with were offered the booty as they were the only ''family'' Sharif could find to bargain with. He read my palm - ''Let me see your hand, no, no, the clean one'' - in an alley cafe, four chipped Formica tables tilted toward the drain. He smoked a water pipe as he told me I would live a long life, have money one day, be married shortly and have four daughters and one son. I stopped believing him at that point. He said he was better with coffee grounds. We'd met him loping along the street, his head moving from side to side as a leopard's might in stalking pigeons. ''You want to change money?'' he said. So we followed him to a perfume shop. We sat and discussed rates; not good enough. We had, after all, been in Cairo for almost a day and weren't complete novices. He apologized for not being able to do business, then herded us to the cafe with the proprietary air of a salesman with clients.

title: 2 MEMBERS AND LEADER OF CULT ARRAIGNED
description: LEAD: THE leader and two members of a cult that left New Jersey in 1983 to escape mounting legal problems and unfavorable publicity returned last week to be arraigned on fraud charges.

title: Nancy Lenahan Weds John Gourley Jr.
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday Nancy Carpenter Lenahan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Patrick Lenahan of Locust Valley, was married to John Britton Gourley Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gourley of East Norriton, Pa. The Rev. William Guido performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Sutherland to Wed Philip Lipman
description: Pamela Kirkpatrick Sutherland and Philip Abram Lipman plan to marry Sept. 19, her mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Timoleon Andreadis of Huntington, L.I., have announced.

title: IN THE KITCHEN, IN THE BEDROOM, IN THE TRENCHES
description: INVENTING THE ABBOTTS And Other Stories. By Sue Miller. 180 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: TREKKING TO PLACES KNOWN TO FEW
description: ROLLING downhill in the battered blue Volvo to Port Jefferson past the harbor. . . For a minute I feel things open up - there's a flash of Monterey, Calif., in the corner of my memory; memories of last summer's vacation, the land opening out over the water. I'm quickly easing my way uphill, and the first specks of pale green spot the open sky at the hill's top - spring!

title: NEW LEAGUE CHIEF OUTLINES HER GOALS
description: LEAD: AS president of the White Plains chapter of the League of Women Voters, Rita Malmud organized a group of volunteers to attend the city's Common Council meetings and note any significant actions.

title: Sara Whittier, a Writer, Weds Harry B. Boadwee
description: At the San Clemente (Calif.) Presbyterian Church yesterday, Sara Leanna Whittier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Whittier of San Clemente, and Harry Burnett Boadwee, the son of Mrs. Cecil B. Boadwee of Jackson, Miss., and the late Mr. Boadwee, were married by the Rev. James Farley. The bride, who will keep her name, and the bridegroom are graduates of Stanford University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She is a freelance writer and editor in New York. Her father is a research and development manager for Endevco, an engineering concern in San Juan Capistrano, Calif. Her mother, Maryanne Whittier, is a professor of art history at Saddleback College in Mission Viejo, Calif.

title: Razzle-Dazzle in Design
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Emily R. Fox Weds Consultant
description: At St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Philadelphia yesterday, Dr. Emily Randall Fox, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Mickle Fox 3d of Bethesda, Md., and Jonathan Brewster Conant, the son of Elizabeth Benson Conant of Natick, Mass., and the late Donald B. Conant of Weston, Mass., were married by the Rev. Ralph W. Pitman. Sherry Lauren Lubbers was maid of honor and Joseph W. Marshall 3d was best man.

title: NEW HOSPITAL RULES PROPOSED
description: LEAD: THE state's Department of Health has proposed new regulations that would make it harder for inefficient under-used hospitals to stay in business but would funnel more money to well-run hospitals that filled their beds.

title: Chewing Gum
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Liaison' Lament
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
79 PORTRAITS IN NEW HAVEN
description: LEAD: MUCH of the attraction of ''Contemporary Portraits From the Northeast,'' a juried show at the Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven, is the stature of its lone juror, Philip Pearlstein. Mr. Pearlstein is renowned for his no-nonsense figurative paintings in which the figures often have portions of their bodies cropped out, so that one focuses on the terrain of their translucent flesh.

title: WHITNEY EXPANSION RAISES PRESERVATION ISSUE
description: Public debate over the Whitney Museum's expansion plans has opened with a focus on whether razing a row of adjoining brownstones would clear the way for piecemeal dismemberment of historic districts in New York City.

title: SOME PROSECUTORS CRITICIZE RELEASE PROGRAM
description: LEAD: ONE of the most vocal critics of the Intensive Supervision Program, Monmouth County Prosecutor John A. Kaye, said it ''should never have been started, and I think it should be abolished.''
