Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 33 MEN WHO HATE WOMEN & THE WOMEN WHO LOVE THEM, by Susan Forward and Joan Torres. (Bantam, $16.95.) How to cope with overbearing men. 2 2 30 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS WITH WINE, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $16.95.) Recipes to be prepared at moderate cost. 3 3 89 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 4 7 BETTY CROCKER'S COOKBOOK. (Golden Press/Western Publishing, $19.95.) New, revised ring-bound edition. 5 4 BETTER HOMES AND GARDENS NEW COOK BOOK. (Meredith, $16.95.) The ring-bound edition. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) WALTZING WITH A DICTATOR: The Marcoses and the Making of American Policy, by Raymond Bonner. (Times Books, $19.95.) This impressive study of five American Presidents and Ferdinand Marcos emphasizes that the United States' relationship with the Philippines is like no other - and that is a major problem. BEST INTENTIONS: The Education and Killing of Edmund Perry, by Robert Sam Anson. (Random House, $17.95.) A 17-year-old black youth, child of Harlem, honors graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, died after being shot by a white policeman who claimed self-defense. The extremes in his short life and the heritage of racism in America are the author's baffling subjects. INDIAN COUNTRY, by Philip Caputo. (Bantam, $18.95.) A Vietnam veteran in Michigan is trapped by his armor of fear, paranoia and mania in this artful and clever psychological novel. PRIVATE DOMAIN, by Paul Taylor. (Knopf, $22.95.) One of the world's great modern dancers and choreographers creates an extraordinarily vivid and revealing duet-with-one autobiography that should rank among the definitive accounts of what it means to be a creative artist in America. IN THE COUNTRY OF LAST THINGS, by Paul Auster. (Viking, $15.95.) If in the beginning was the word, then in this linguistic-game novel of a city (New York?) post-apocalypse, it still will be. ''THEM'': Stalin's Polish Puppets, by Teresa Toranska. (Harper & Row, $22.95.) Old-guard Polish Stalinists explain to their interlocutor, a journalist, why, despite the unrelenting clarity of history and the Solidarity movement, they still believe. The result is a fascinating political and psychological document. CHARLES FOURIER: The Visionary and His World, by Jonathan Beecher. (University of California, $49.50.) A meaty, sympathetic but not uncritical view of the life of a 19th-century French social critic, a solitary who ruminated on the illusion of liberty and the need for Harmony, an ideal society in which wars would be replaced by international cooking contests.

title: TROUBLES IN INDIA ERODE POPULARITY OF GANDHI
description: Two years ago, at the height of his popularity, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi seemed to move effortlessly from triumph to triumph. But even then, skeptics noted that his leadership had yet to be tested by adversity. Today Mr. Gandhi faces such tests from many quarters.

title: HOME VIDEO: ART
description: LEAD: Germany - Dada From the Museum Without Walls series. Produced and directed by Helmut Herbst. Kartes Video Communications. 55 minutes. $14.95.

title: A LITTLE SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE
description: WHEN the city of Chicago and eight equity partners teamed up in March 1986 to open a business incubator called Enterprise Place, the building was filled within a month. Today, with tenants ranging from a gospel music recording company to a distributor of wild mushrooms, the operation is one of the country's oldest mixed incubators. These joint efforts by public institutions and private companies now make up 9 percent of all incubators; 18 months ago, there were only one or two.

title: Senate Approves C.I.A. Director
description: There was a certain amount of carping about how William H. Webster and the Federal Bureau of Investigation should have dealt with the Iran-contra affair, and several Senators sought various promises from him. But in the end the Senate's approval of Mr. Webster as Director of Central Intelligence was, as expected, whole-hearted.

title: THE VISION OF CHESTER BOWLES
description: TOMORROW is the first anniversary of the death of Chester Bowles. He is remembered fondly in Connecticut, in Essex where the family lived and in Hartford where he served briefly as Governor and throughout the state for the achievements of his diplomatic career.

title: NEW YORK TO FACE FISING WATER BILLS
description: Having long enjoyed water rates that were among the lowest for major American cities, New Yorkers are about to see the first in a series of increases that by 1996 will almost triple the typical homeowner's water bill.

title: STEPPING INTO THREE DIMENSIONS
description: Perspective was always a problem for me in art classes. Sometimes I would capture it successfully, but just as often there would be a false, unsatisfying depth to a drawing or a painting that would leave me keenly frustrated. I would shrug my shoulders and mumble something about the Egyptians and Picasso having had the same problem. All the same, that difficulty, combined with equally unsatisfying portraiture skills, eventually turned me from the visual arts to the written word.

title: Bill Plante, Reporter, Weds Robin L. Smith
description: Robin Lynn Smith, a producer for NBC News in Washington, and William Madden Plante, the CBS News senior White House correspondent, known as Bill Plante, were married yesterday at the Woodrow Wilson House in Washington. Judge Kenneth W. Starr of the Federal Court of Appeals in Washington performed the ceremony. Kimberlee Smith was her sister's matron of honor, and Richard Plante was his brother's best man.

title: All Eyes on Her
description: IT BEGAN IN A RESTAURANT in Portofino. She walked in ahead of me, a classically beautiful young woman with a mass of red hair tumbling around her shoulders. The headwaiter, a dead ringer for Marcello Mastroianni, stripped the blue knit dress off her with his eyes as he bowed deeply and took us to a window table overlooking the tiny harbor. The wine steward and two waiters hovered over us, attentive, respectful.

title: SOVIET SAYS IT IS GIVING UP COMMERCIAL WHALING
description: The Soviet Union has announced that it is halting commercial whaling, and its last whaling fleet is heading home from its final season in the Antarctic.

title: A FEMINIST'S VIEW OF RAMAPO COLLEGE
description: THERE is a crisis in the educational process of our nation. This is most evident in the percentage of illiteracy in our population, which is higher than in some Third World nations.

title: THE GIANTS RING IN THEIR '86 INSTANT REPLAYS
description: LIKE little children, the Giants stared at their Super Bowl rings, smiling at the dazzle of the diamonds. In the blue stone, a miniature replica of the Vince Lombardi Trophy sparkled - a three-quarter-carat diamond in the shape of the football atop the trophy, nine other diamonds forming the base of the trophy. But the beauty of that ring is that you can't go into a jewelry store and buy it. You must win it, as the Giants did with their 39-20 victory over the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXI.

title: MASSACHUSETTS MIDWIFE CURB UPHELD
description: In Massachusetts, anyone can help a woman give birth at home - anyone except registered nurses who have been specially trained as midwives.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Johnson Loses Title: Leslie Stewart of Trinidad and Tobago, the hometown favorite, knocked down Marvin Johnson, the defending champion, twice in the first round and went on to win the World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title yesterday. The scheduled 15-round fight, held in Port-of-Spain, Trinidad, was stopped after the eighth round. Stewart used a quicker and more powerful right to beat the 33-year-old Johnson, who, like Stewart, came into the fight at 175 pounds. Johnson's record is 43-6. Stewart is 24-1.(AP) Tennis McEnroe Leads U.S. Into Final: John McEnroe overcame Henri LeConte of France yesterday and enabled the United States to earn a berth in the final of the World Team Cup tournament in Dusseldorf, West Germany. McEnroe's 2-6, 7-5, 6-1 victory gave the United States a 1-0 lead over France and that was enough to place the Americans into the final as winners of their group. Later, Brad Gilbert, the No. 2 United States player, was overwhelmed by Thierry Tulasne of France, 6-1, 6-0. In doubles competition, Gilbert and Robert Seguso beat Leconte and Guy Forget, 6-3, 2-6, 6-4, giving the United States a 2-1 victory. The United States, which has won the World Team Cup three times in the last six years, will face Czechoslovakia for the $300,000 first prize today.(AP) Evert Coasts: Top-seeded Chris Evert posted a 6-0, 6-2 victory over Lori McNeil in 51 minutes and advanced to the final of the $100,000 Geneva Open in Switzerland. Evert's opponent today will be third-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, who won the other semifinal by beating Rafaella Reggi of Italy, the defending champion, 6-4, 2-6, 6-2.(AP) N.C.A.A. Champion: Andrew Burrow of the University of Miami solved a lob approach by Michigan's Dan Goldberg and went on to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association singles championship, 2-6, 6-1, 6-2, in Athens, Ga.(AP) Track and Field Field Day for Iona Prep: Scoring heavily in the field events, Iona Prep captured the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association outdoor title for the first time. The New Rochelle school shared the indoor crown last winter with St. Anthony's. Jan Mitchell's squad had three winners in the field, where it tallied 27 of its 33 points. Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island finished second with 29 points and McClancy of Queens was third with 26. The event was held at St. John's University. Winners of events yesterday, as well as second-place finishers, qualified for the New York State Championships in Baldwinsville, N.Y., June 5-6. Lynch Beats Lynch: Nnenna Lynch defeated her older sister, Shola, by a step yesterday in the 1,500-meter run at the Public Schools Athletic League girls' New York State qualifying meet at Randalls Island. The sisters had the same time of 4 minutes 41.8 seconds. Earlier, Shola, a senior at Hunter College High School, won the 800 meters in 2 minutes 10.5 seconds and Nnenna, a sophomore at Hunter, was first in the 3,000 meters in 10:03.4. Golf On the Verge: Bobby Wadkins, seeking his first victory in 13 years on the PGA Tour, shot a seven-under-par 65 to surge past an ailing Davis Love 3d and claim the third-round lead in the $600,000 Atlanta Classic. Wadkins was at 17-under 199 after three trips over the hilly, 7,007-yard Atlanta Country Club course. He held a one-shot lead over Dave Barr, who shot a 66, and Steve Pate, who had a 67.(AP) Record for Rodriguez: Chi Chi Rodriguez set a PGA Senior Tour record with eight consecutive birdies in Oklahoma City yesterday. He finished the day with a seven-under-par 65 that gave him a four-stroke lead heading into the final round of the $250,000 Silver Pages Classic. The eight birdies broke the Senior Tour record set by Gene Littler in the 1983 Suntree Classic and left Rodriguez with a two-day total of 131, 13-under par. The players were allowed again to lift, clean and place their golf balls due to heavy rains that have soaked the 6,708-yard, par-72 course. Harold Henning shot a 69 that left him in a tie for second with Bruce Crampton at 135.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: RIVER DOGS. By Robert Olmstead. (Vintage Contemporaries/Random House, Paper, $6.95.) Robert Olmstead's first collection of stories is a quirky, rough-hewn lot. They seem constructed by instinct; some are anecdotal, others wander in odd directions, a few are just right. They are about boys and men, often men without women, often for a very good reason.

title: Help for Wedtech Became a Priority
description: It was 1982, and the Welbilt Electronic Die Corporation, with the help of a series of letters, telephone calls and meetings organized by White House aides, had overcome Army opposition and won a $27.7 million contract to make small engines.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Neatly timed to get viewers through the normal summer drought of quality programming, ''The Jewel in the Crown'' is being revived on public television's ''Masterpiece Theater.'' The 14-part series reopens with a special two-hour episode Sunday at 9 on Channels 13 and 49. Based on the Paul Scott novels known collectively as ''The Raj Quartet,'' this British mini-series, made for Granada TV, has been justifiably showered with international awards. Mr. Scott set out to tell the story ''of a rape, of the events that led up to it and followed it and of the place in which it happened.'' That place, of course, is India, still part of the dwindling British Empire. Here are two nations locked in an imperial embrace that transcends the normal boundaries of love and hate. The TV dramatization - written by Ken Taylor and directed by Christopher Morahan and Jim O'Brien - offers an unflinching portrait of the arrogance and inevitable corruption of imperialism, exposing its underbelly of vicious social snobbery and racism. The story begins in 1942 with the first stirrings of a doomed love affair between awkward, galumphing Daphne Manners (Susan Wooldridge) and brooding Hari Kumar (Art Malik). When Daphne is raped, her would-be suitor, the police officer Ronald Merrick (Tim Pigott-Smith) embarks on a campaign of hateful revenge that will reverberate until the very eve of Indian independence in 1947. The superb cast also includes Peggy Ashcroft, Judy Parfitt and Eric Porter. This is landmark television, not to be missed.

title: NEW LIFE FOR FRESH AIR FUND CHILDREN
description: Three mothers came to the settlement house at the public housing project on Madison Street one day last week to register their children for a chance to spend a couple of weeks away from New York City this summer and see that a world exists beyond the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: HOME VIDEO: SCIENCE
description: LEAD: The Incredible Human Machine Produced by the National Geographic Society and Wolper Productions. Narrated by E. G. Marshall. Vestron Video. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: RUSSIAN NATIONALISTS TEST GORBACHEV
description: The 400 demonstrators began their evening recently by milling around in a large square by the Kremlin wall, bearing hand-painted signs reading ''Down with the saboteurs of reconstruction,'' ''We need reconstruction,'' and ''Give status to the patriotic association Pamyat.''

title: Georgetown School Of Medicine
description: Nancy Reagan told the graduating class of the Georgetown University School of Medicine today that there is no excuse for drug abuse in the medical profession. She asked the new physicians to watch for drug problems among their patients and their colleagues.

title: Spinoff Records
description: To the Editor:

title: HAS AUTO RACING BECOME TOO DANGEROUS?
description: As a devoted fan of many forms of auto racing I think that auto racing is a dangerous sport by nature. On occasion, as recent events in Nascar and Cart have shown, it can become too dangerous. What is necessary is to identify the safety problems that exist and take corrective action.

title: A HARLEM SCHOOL STRESSES THE BASICS
description: Bells never ring, teachers are known by first names and tests have been abolished.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE fourth annual World Series of Birding awards brunch last Sunday morning was a festive affair, even though more than half of those in attendance were clinically dead on their feet - the price of 24 hours of hard birding.

title: Do Not Go Gentle
description: It seems to me that Dylan Thomas was advising not so much the manner of one's going as how to be - ungenteel - while going.

title: BOBBY VAN TRADES JAZZ FOR CHOPIN
description: LEAD: IT has been almost 25 years since he last played Chopin in public, but on Saturday the pianist Bobby Van begins the long road back from saloon to salon.

title: Some Advice For the Rangers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FAKE TRAVEL DEALS RISE DRAMATICALLY
description: WITH the arrival of spring has come a torrent of deceptive travel promotions and offers, prompting consumer experts to warn prospective travelers to beware.

title: Let Texas Have ItTo the
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
A ROSE GROWS IN RIDGEWOOD
description: LEAD: IF the name The Sonia Rose rings a bell with restaurant followers, they may recall a charming little dining spot in Madison that enjoyed a brief time in the sun two or three years ago and then closed. Phoenix-like, it arose three months ago in Ridgewood. Gary Thompson, operator and host at the original restaurant, is both chef and co-owner of the reincarnation.

title: ANYONE WE KNOW?
description: THE BELLES LETTRES PAPERS By Charles Simmons. 175 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $12.95.

title: LIFE BEFORE CONCRETE
description: LEAD: Mark Erlich's history of carpenters in Massachusetts from colonial times through the present is framed by the general struggle to organize building trades. Mr. Erlich, a union carpenter who directs the Massachusetts Carpenters History Project, maintains that the values inherent in craft pride and artisanship were the basis for organizational solidarity and cooperation.

title: Ms. Gaderick Wed To J. T. Reynolds
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Joanne Marie Gaderick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Gene Gaderick of Greenwich, and Jeffrey Toll Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell S. Reynolds Jr. of Greenwich, were married by the Rev. R.Sherman Beattie. Michelle Gaderick was her sister's maid of honor and Mr. Reynolds 3d was his brother's best man.

title: HEMLOCK PEST MOVING NORTH FROM COAST
description: HEMLOCK trees are in trouble. The hemlock woolly adelgid, Adelges tsugae is threatening them, and the prognosis is not good.

title: June 28 Wedding For Ms. Goldberg And an Executive
description: Mr. and Mrs. Avram J. Goldberg of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Beth Goldberg, to Michael Winter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Winter of Malden, Mass. The couple plan to be married June 28.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 45 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 45 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: SHADES OF GRAY. By Timothy R. O'Neill. (Viking, $17.95.) Several West Point cadets, plagued by nightmares, report a ghost as fellow resident of their barracks. Based on an academy legend and an actual incident reported by the national press in 1972, this powerful narrative, Timothy O'Neill's first novel, relates how two Army psychologists on the faculty, Sam Bondurant and Liam FitzDonnell, pursue ''the ghost of the Forty-Seventh Division.

title: REUNION TACTICS FOR THE FAMILY
description: If you drew the short straw and are in charge of the family-reunion arrangements, I sure hope it's for the 1988 season. Your leverage for this year is pretty much used up. And depending upon the site you've chosen, you may be barely in time for '88.

title: ELECTION LOSS JOLTS PHILIPPINE LEFTISTS
description: NOBODY in the Philippines expected the leftist candidates to win big in their first attempt at electoral politics this month. But few people thought they would lose as badly as they did.

title: SEEKING OUT UNSPOILED NATURE HIDEAWAYS
description: LEAD: FROM rugged woods to marshy tidal wetlands, the county offers a startling variety of public and privately operated parks, sanctuaries and preserves for exploration. The county parks system consists of 13 parks. In addition, the Nature Conservancy owns 19 such properties, the National Audubon Society holds 13 and private organizations account for several others.

title: A CHEKHOVIAN 'UNCLE VANYA'
description: YELENA, the young, bored wife of a pompous, aging and ailing professor, has a sudden, all-consuming desire to play the piano.

title: PISTONS HAND TROUBLED CELTICS A TROUNCING
description: The Detroit Pistons, trailing the Eastern Conference final series by 2-0, returned to what Isiah Thomas called ''my house'' today and trounced the Boston Celtics, 122-104.

title: WALKOUT HALTS MOST PROJECTS ON CONNECTICUT'S HIGHWAY
description: A strike by heavy-equipment operators and mechanics has halted both new construction and repairs on most highway and bridge projects in Connecticut.

title: Shaking Up Sloan-Kettering
description: No chief executive has ever brought about change for the better without incurring criticism from those who may have been adversely affected by the process. What is vital for a leader is the ability to be flexible, accept suggestions, acknowledge errors and change procedures when necessary to accomplish a goal. Mr. Boffey's article shows that Dr. Marks does possess these qualifications, but it fails to tell the reader how Dr. Marks' background gives him the experience to make such dramatic changes.

title: Multitask P.C.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Nierenberg Wed to Dr. Jon Roberts
description: Lorie Joan Nierenberg, a lawyer for the United States Information Agency in Washington, was married yesterday to Dr. Jon Laurence Roberts, an associate in the Washington law firm of Ginsburg, Feldman & Bress, at the Barns of Wolf Trap Farm Park in Vienna, Va. The ceremony was performed by Philip J. Lesser, a retired administrative law judge of the Labor Department. The couple were attended by the bride's sister, Wendy N. Gibney, and the bridegroom's sister, Marthe Roberts.

title: About Cars; TALES OF A CHECKERED CAREER
description: THE man at the wheel of the pace car in today's race at Indianapolis has had, if you'll excuse the expression, a checkered career.

title: PROGRAM HELPS THE DISABLED TO JOIN THE WORK FORCE
description: LEAD: THERE are 4,100 adults with severe developmental disabilities in activity programs and sheltered workshops in New Jersey, and Eddie C. Moore, director of the state's Division of Developmental Disabilities, believes that traditional employment can help 60 to 70 percent of them to hold jobs in the private sector.

title: Richard F. Kahn, Champion Of National Bridge Contests
description: Richard F. Kahn, one of the country's leading bridge players, died yesterday of complications resulting from Parkinson's disease and heart problems at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN is considering using an increase in the state's corporate income tax as an incentive to reduce the production of hazardous waste, but an environmental research group believes New Jersey can do much more.

title: Forest Fire in China Threatening City of 20,000
description: The worst forest fire in memory in China has turned south and is threatening a city of 20,000 people in Inner Mongolia, official press outlets said today.

title: INSIDER TRADING: THE FIRST SKIRMISH
description: AFTER several rounds of tough sparring in a Federal courtroom in Manhattan, what would have been the first trial in the insider trading scandal was temporarily called off last week, leaving both sides to claim a measure of victory.

title: THE NEED FOR MORE LIFEGUARDS
description: I hope that prospective lifeguards will read the May 3 article ''Lifeguard Shortage Seen'' and come forward and fill the positions.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; For Discount Brokers, a Mixed Review
description: DISCOUNT real-estate brokers, who work on flat fees instead of a percentage of the sale, are beginning to emerge in Westchester County. One office has already opened and two discount chains are negotiating for offices.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: LATERNA MAGICA. By William Heinesen. Translated by Tiina Nunnally. (Fjord Press, Paper, $7.95.) Written in an effortless style, these 10 stories by the noted Scandinavian author William Heinesen - fluently translated from the Danish - turn casual occurrences into kaleidoscopic mosaics and ordinary descriptions into compelling images.

title: Log-Rolling On Capitol Hill
description: TUCKED into a Congressional spending bill last year was a $2.28 million tree contract: a nursery in Oregon would ship up to 2.5 million cuttings of hybrid poplars to the Himalayan kingdom of Nepal, which is plagued by depleted forests.

title: 12 MINUTES OF STALINISM
description: LEAD: THE CORPSE DREAM OF N. PETKOV By Thomas McGonigle. 133 pp. Elmwood Park, Ill.: The Dalkey Archive Press. $20.

title: PROTECTIN 'NEW' SISTINGE CEILING: A DEBATE FLARES
description: More than midway through their 12-year project, the restorers of the Sistine Chapel frescoes seem to have dampened a debate over the use of solvents to strip away old varnish and five centuries' accumulation of soot.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a producer's change in plans, a picture caption on the theater page of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect title and opening date for a new musical at the American Jewish Theater of the 92d Street Y. ''The Bar Mitzvah Boy'' (formerly titled ''Song for a Saturday'') will open on June 10.

title: Classical Music
description: Massed amateur American choruses are not everyone's cup of tea, especially those used to the surer, more solid English choral tradition or, on the rare occasions when they can be encountered in this country, large professional choruses. Still, amateur choruses can make up in fervor what they lack in tonal focus, and when they are well conducted in the right repertory, the results can be pretty exciting.

title: HOSPITAL IS CATERING FOR FUNDS
description: LEAD: THE mention of hospital food has traditionally triggered jokes about mysterious meat, lumpy mashed potatoes and inedible pudding. Soon, however, guests at weddings and other social occasions will be able to eat food catered by the White Plains Hospital Medical Center.

title: COMBINING COMPONENT AUDIO AND VIDEO
description: EVER SINCE VCR'S BE-came capable of high-fidelity sound and television broadcasting offered stereo, the idea of combining video and audio equipment into a unified home entertainment center has been gaining ground. Such systems, known as audio/video systems - or A/V systems for short - are usually sold as complete packages with all components made by the same manufacturer. They are often housed in elaborate cabinets and typically cost thousands of dollars.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: DUBLIN
description: LEAD: With two consecutive damp and drizzly summers behind them, Dublin's residents have great hopes that the months ahead will bring weather well-suited to outdoor pursuits in the Irish capital: feeding the ducks in St. Stephen's Green, wandering among the flower beds in Merrion Square and enjoying a full calendar of sporting events, including the Irish Open golf tournament in early July, would certainly be among them.

title: 'AGGIE' SCHOOLS SEEK HYBRID CURRICULUMS
description: WHEN the University of California surveyed high school students about their interest in agriculture school, it did not like what it heard. The students described agriculture as a blue-collar occupation, tedious and insecure. ''All you hear about are people going broke,'' one commented. ''That's not the kind of future I want.'' Troubles in the nation's farmland have taken their toll on the nation's agriculture schools. Enrollments have declined more than 25 percent since the late 1970's. Research funds, too, have shrunk because of economic problems in farm states.

title: Darcy Chappel Becomes Bride Of Jeffrey Ahl
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., Darcy Lynn Chappel, the daughter of Barry Hyde Chappel of Rowayton, Conn., and Mrs. Davis Stirling Margold of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Sanders Ahl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Watkins Ahl Jr. of Rowayton. The Rev. Jenny Matheson performed the ceremony.

title: An Index on the Philippines
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS FROM THE TIMES
description: ABOUT MEN: Reflections on the Male Experience. Edited and with an introduction by Edward Klein and Don Erickson. Foreword by Russell Baker. (Poseidon Press, $17.95.) What do men want and do they know that they want it? Russell Baker, in his foreword to this collection of About Men columns from The New York Times Magazine, confides: ''It's no picnic being a man.'' These personal essays that began to appear in 1983 cover the familiar (men at work, at war, at play, with and without women) and the not so familiar (men and the baby carriage, aging, the meaning of manhood). The more than 60 contributors include lawyers, novelists, scientists and journalists - Isaac Asimov, William F. Buckley Jr., John Kenneth Galbraith and Paul Theroux among them.

title: 007's Appeal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. STUDY FINDS FRAUD IN TOP RESEARCHER'S WORK ONMENTALLY RETARDED
description: One of the nation's most influential researchers in the field of mental retardation treatment has reported on experiments that were never carried out and published deliberately deceptive scientific papers, according to an investigative report by the Federal Government.

title: 20 Years Later, City Problems Appear Bigger
description: In the summer of 1967, as riots erupted in city after city around the country, a group of national leaders gathered here to find ways to respond to the violence and its causes.

title: NEIGHBORS WHO NEED CARE
description: The article on the proposed Hewlett home for the mentally disabled [ ''Hewlett Home Opposed,'' April 19 ] , struck a responsive chord. Sadly, the reaction of the possible neighbors is all too typical of the selfish and uncaring attitude of most people.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: LOBSTER FESTIVAL IN MYSTIC The fourth annual Lobster Weekend, which opened yesterday at Mystic Seaport in Mystic, Conn., continues today and tomorrow.

title: LIBERTY PARK MARINA OPPOSED
description: LEAD: OFFICIALS and residents of this city got a chance last week - perhaps their last - to express opposition to development plans for Liberty State Park.

title:
INVESTING;
BETTING ON A DIFFERENT VIEW OF INFLATION
description: LEAD: MANY economists believe that higher inflation is just around the bend. A recent survey by Blue Chip Indicators found that economists expect the inflation rate to jump to 4.4 percent this year, from last year's 1.9 percent.

title: A Stand for Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: BATTLES IN THE DESERT & OTHER STORIES. By Jose Emilio Pacheco. Translated by Katherine Silver. (New Directions, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $8.95.) This ably translated collection is a companion volume to the bilingual edition of the Mexican poet Jose Emilio Pacheco's ''Selected Poems,'' also being put out by New Directions.

title: Robert Morris Marries Lisa Shive in Vermont
description: Lisa Ann Shive, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Shive of Bridgewater, N.J., and Bennington, Vt., and Robert Patrick Morris, a son of Margaret Stoyell Morris of Cortland, N.Y., and Phoenix, and the late Clayton James Morris, were married yesterday. The Rev. Joseph Pray performed the ceremony at St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church in Bennington.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: VAGARIES OF THE GOETZ TRIAL
description: ''Those are the pro-Goetz people over there - we're anti-Goetz,'' a man explained to passers-by as he distributed fliers for a lunchtime rally in lower Manhattan last week.

title: MANY REFUGEES FOUNDER IN NEW YORK JOB MARKET
description: In El Salvador, 50-year-old Luis Dominguez directed a government agency of 3,000 employees, but in Westchester County he finds himself behind the steering wheel of a car, ferrying executives to the airport.

title: A WORD ON BLUEBIRDS AND BLACKSNAKES
description: Your advice on setting up bluebird houses [ ''Bluebirds, With Help, Are Returning,'' May 3 ] missed one important point:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Milwaukee;
Will $500,000 Condos Sell?
description: LEAD: WHEN the renovated Cudahy Tower opens for sales in June, it will offer the most-expensive condominiums this blue-collar city has ever seen. And, if the naysayers are right, prices may come down quite a bit by the time the units are sold.

title:
DINING OUT;
A NEW SPOT IN BEDFORD HILLS
description: LEAD: IT has been some time since the Bedford Hills vicinity has had a decent restaurant, thus the recent opening of Riches has created a bit of a stir in the area. Emerging from the sloughed dark, tacky and tattered Rags, this glowing, eight-month-old fledgling fulfills the proverbial metamorphosis. Although rough edges remain - some rickety chairs, small tables - and the kitchen lacks the polish that experience will bring, the new form is promising, indeed, and even now Riches is ready for company.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Madison $475,000 15 Pomeroy Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; 2-zone heating, den; taxes $5,581. Neptune $69,900 1009 1/2 West Lake Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; fenced property, porch, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,811. Pompton Plains $195,000 6 Libby Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split level; patio, 1-car garage, all appliances; taxes $2,774. Springfield $250,000 564 Mountain Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old contemporary; family room, wall-to-wall carpeting, 2-car garage; taxes $3,283. title: Woodson Off Track
description: HE was the favorite to win the 110-meter hurdles at the Big Ten track and field championships, but when the meet began at Iowa yesterday, Purdue's acclaimed athlete, Rod Woodson, was not among the competitors. On Friday, Woodson, a star defensive back who was a first-round draft choice of the Pittsburgh Steelers, was disqualified from the championships by the Big Ten commissioner, Wayne Duke. He was barred because he had violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules by signing a representation agreement with and accepting money from an agent last year.

title: QUANDARY FOR THE JUDGE: TO START ALL OVER OR NOT
description: Justice John P. Collins swept motions aside, grappled with ambiguity in the law and resolved a legal dilemma over the objections of defense lawyers yesterday, all with one apparent overriding objective: moving the fraud trial of Raymond J. Donovan and his co-defendants forward.

title: TRANSIT BRIEFS
description: LEAD: COMMUTERS who want to join car or van pools are being offered free computerized matching services by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the state's Department of Transportation.

title: HARVEY GOLDBERG
description: Harvey Goldberg, a historian and political advocate, died of cancer Wednesday in Madison, Wis. He was 65 years old.

title: MORSE POSTS A 67 FOR ONE-SHOT LEAD
description: Cathy Morse, who has only one victory in nearly a decade on the women's golf tour, birdied the 15th and 17th holes today for a 5-under-par 67 and a one-shot lead over Laurie Rinker after three rounds of the Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship.

title: Streetscapes: The Dakota Stables; A 'Soft-Site' Garage on the Booming West Side
description: THINGS look peaceful on ''stable row,'' a collection of a dozen public and private garages, most of them former stables, on Amsterdam Avenue from 75th to 77th Streets. But to a developer it is really a collection of sites crying out for development: old, low buildings, with no residential tenants, that are not landmarks - and are right in the middle of the fashionable West Side.

title: WHERE WAGONS HEADING WEST LEFT THEIR MARK
description: It is a quiet place, ignored on most maps, home to a few songbirds and a thousand memories. A couple of weathered signs might steer the extremely curious traveler from the middle of Guernsey, a small southeastern Wyoming community, south past the Sunrise School and just across the North Platte River.

title: Perspectives: Nonprofit Institutions; Handling a Project Without a Developer
description: WHEN a nonprofit institution in Manhattan sets out to make use of the full development rights inherent in its land, it normally allies itself at an early stage with a developer.

title: Reviewing Andrea Dworkin
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SEARCH OF THE BIGGEST TREES
description: NATURALISTS are hunting for the biggest trees in the state, and they are asking the public to help.

title: Deborah Quan to Wed Mr. G, TV Weatherman
description: Deborah Lynn Quan, a financial manager in capital and sales planning for CBS, and Irving Joel Gikofsky, a weatherman for WCBS-TV and WCBS-FM, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University. The Rev. H.Scott Matheney, a Presbyterian minister who is a Columbia chaplain, officiated.

title: SUPERVISED RELEASE OF PRISONERS TRIED
description: LEAD: A STATE experiment designed to ease prison overcrowding by releasing selected prisoners is saving taxpayers money and reducing recidivism, according to a study to be released soon by Rutgers University.

title: A Finder Keeps His Pirate Ship
description: The sunken pirate ship Whydah, which left jewels the size of eggs and streaks of gold dust in the sands off Cape Cod, has been, not surprisingly, the subject of a court dispute. The winner is the man who found it.

title: WILL OLD MACHINES KILL NEW IDEAS?
description: THROUGHOUT the scientific establishment, inside the halls of Congress and in corporate suites across America, concern is mounting about the inadequacy of laboratory equipment and facilities in the nation's universities.

title: Einstein Was Wrong
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN AFTERMATH OF CHALLENGER, SCIENTISTS AND ENTREPRENEURS STILL DREAM OF COLONIZING SPACE
description: SINCExh the Challenger exploded in January 1986, killing its crew of seven, the nation's space program has been pervaded with an air of pessimism and gloom. But there are still those who dream of colonizing the Moon and Mars and mining the riches of the asteroids.

title: IN COURT, ANGER, DISBELIEF AND A CRY OF 'J' ACCUSE'
description: The trial of Raymond J. Donovan, the former Secretary of Labor, and seven other men had lumbered along for more than eight months with spectators and defendants appearing to doze in the sultry Bronx courtroom. The jurors even applauded a witness after he finished three weeks on the stand.

title: SHOULD THE FAIRNESS DOCTRINE BE LAW?
description: IMAGINE, IF YOU WILL, ONE Congressman looking over Dan Rather's shoulder, while another snoops about Peter Jennings. Imagine, further, an incumbent on the phone to his local station, complaining that the 6 o'clock news is being too kind to the candidate running against him. Actually, none of this takes a great leap of imagination. Congressmen are talking now about network news practices, and they have been getting in touch with their local stations for years. What makes this time different than all other times, however, is that now the Congressmen want to do something about it. They are prepared to write the Fairness Doctrine into law. This is a dreadful idea.

title: Razzle-Dazzle in Design
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Not Go Gentle
description: William Safire's article ''The PAWs That Refresh'' (On Language, April 26), on allusion catching, does indeed remind us of one of the few delightful pastimes that is low calorie, tax free and harmless to the environment. When he wanders from citation into literary criticism, however, he spoils the fun.

title: GUTTERS BEYOND REPAIR? HERE'S HOW TO REPLACE THEM
description: MOST rain gutters and downspouts can be repaired when they are leaking or sagging, but if there are many leaks, or if the gutters are badly corroded, rotting or split, it is best to replace them.

title: TRAVELIN' MAN
description: HAMMER By Armand Hammer with Neil Lyndon. Illustrated. 544 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.

title: SOMETHING BETWEEN VOODOO AND BULLFIGHTING
description: OPERAS & PLAYS By Gertrude Stein. 400 pp. Barrytown, N.Y.: Station Hill Press. $29.95.

title: THE P.L.O. HAS ITS OWN IDEAS FOR PEACE TALKS
description: THE Palestine Liberation Organization, now reunited under Yasir Arafat, is pressing for an Arab summit meeting to discuss strategy toward a proposed international conference on the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: NANTUCKETERS ADAPTING TO DEVELOPMENT WOES
description: On this tiny, elbow-shaped island, isolated 30 miles out at sea, there are no stop lights, one town, and 340 licensed real estate brokers.

title: Correction
description: The Summer Music listings in Arts and Leisure last Sunday misidentified a group that will perform at the Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence, which will take place June 11-28. It is the Bowdoin Trio.

title: GRECIAN FLIGHT, $25.60, SCORES UPSET IN THE ACORN
description: Grecian Flight, who won the Black-Eyed Susan at Pimlico just nine days ago, continued the dominance of New York-breds in major races for 3-year-old fillies by posting a 1 3/4-length upset victory over Fiesta Gal in the Acorn Stakes yesterday at Belmont.

title: CITICORP SUCCUMBS TO THE INEVITABLE
description: CITICORP'S decision to take a $3 billion reserve against its third world loan portfolio is in every way welcome, as a sign of rationality at our largest bank and as a signal that the private lenders are prepared to make a real contribution to clearing out the channels of the world's trading system, which have been clogged much too long with garbage debts. But the recognition of losses commends itself essentially as an honorable act, good for the soul and the brain; and honor cannot, as Falstaff once pointed out, take away the grief of a wound.

Farmingville $104,000 27 Pinedale Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, 0.25 acre; taxes $900. title: Deliberations in Film Deaths
description: The jury ended its first week of deliberations Friday in the manslaughter trial stemming from Hollywood's worst movie set disaster. On Tuesday the jurors will continue hearing a stenographer read back testimony from eight months ago. John Landis, director of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' and four associates are charged in the 1982 deaths of the actor Vic Morrow and two children when a helicopter crashed on them amid special effects explosions.
