title: MORE GOLFERS TEE OFF ON LESS LAND
description: LEAD: AS another season gets under way, Long Island golfers who play on public courses are sure to face more hazards in their pursuit of the sport even before any balls are shanked off the fairways.

title: Lynne Scheurer Weds Physician
description: Lynne Norma Scheurer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Charles Scheurer of New York, was married last night to Dr. Carlos Meyer Rish, a son of Dr. Lorenzo F. Rish of Mexico City and Helen Rish of New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: KEEPING TRACK
description: LEAD: An electronic bracelet or wristlet that cannot be removed without damage is used to track inmates in the Intensive Supervision Program and check adherence to curfew.

title: Ms. Chin Weds C. E. McKinney
description: Susan Chin, an architect, and Charles Edwin McKinney, the director of Riverside Park for the City Parks Department, were married yesterday at Riverside Church. The Rev. Dr. Eugene E. Laubach, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Zimbabwe Rebels Kill White Farmers
description: Since 1982, rebels in Zimbabwe have been carrying out a campaign of sporadic violence to protest the treatment by Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's Government of Joshua Nkomo, the opposition leader, and actions directed against his Zimbabwe People's Union and the country's Ndebele minority, which largely supports Mr. Nkomo. Zimbabwe's wealthy white farmers have been targets and 40 of them or their family members have been killed. Less than 1 percent of the population of 8.5 million is white in the country that was Rhodesia, ruled by whites until its independence in 1980.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEAD: WITH THE CONTRAS: A Reporter in the Wilds of Nicaragua, by Christopher Dickey. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $6.95.) Christopher Dickey, who covered Central America for The Washington Post in the early 1980's, spent almost six years collecting material for this book from contra insurgents. Our reviewer, Abraham Brumberg, said in 1986 that ''it succeeds better than any account I have seen in capturing the sordid climate of the undeclared war in which thus far nearly 12,000 Nicaraguans have lost their lives, and in tracing its bloody, convoluted history.

title: The Palestinian Campus
description: If these Palestinian students really want to have freedom, they should develop responsible leadership to negotiate with the Israelis in accordance with the Camp David accords. The Palestine Liberation Organization, which seems to control the activities of these students by demagoguery or by arm-twisting, wants to frustrate any chance of rapprochement. Israel, on the other hand, has encouraged higher education among the Palestinian Arabs to promote the ''intelligentsia,'' hoping that they will dare negotiate and live in peace with the Jewish state. HESKEL M. HADDAD, M.D. New York City

title: Take Some of That Beer Out of the Old Ball Game
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAVING HIS MARK ON A MILLION KITCHENS
description: ''TRUMP. Lefrak. Milstein.'' Leonard Thun of Hewlett

title: Alejandro Rey Is Dead; A Film and a TV Actor
description: Alejandro Rey, who played a charitable playboy in the television series ''The Flying Nun'' and an immigration lawyer in the movie ''Moscow on the Hudson,'' died of cancer Thursday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Ron Wise, a spokesman, said Friday. Mr. Rey was 57 years old.

title: IN THE END, FLYERS FIND DETERMINATION UNDOES OILERS' FLASH
description: There is criticism that the Philadelphia Flyers have a robot-like quality about them. They present so impassive a front to their opponents, and produce such colorless descriptions of themselves and their play that the facade seems an attempt to distance themselves from emotional involvement.

title: POINTS OF INTEREST UPCOMING
description: THROUGHOUT most of the regular season, it is the southern half of the county that gets most of the concert business, but in the weeks before summer programs get under way, Tarrytown and points north are often the musical places to be.

title: 007's Appeal
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad Wine, Good Times
description: Several years ago, I informally presided over a dinner party of seven in the San Francisco area (''The Returns Are In,'' by Frank J. Prial, Wine, April 26). I did not know the wine (it had been selected by committee vote), and it was probably not far off (and after a stiff rum punch and a mild case of sunstroke, could I really tell?), but it seemed off enough to force a snap decision: ''I'm sorry, but I must ask to try another bottle of this.''

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
description: A Business Start-Up and Survival Conference will be held Wednesday at Westchester Community College in Valhalla.

title: More Power To the Scorer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Brook Naff Wed to Michael Fulton in Connecticut
description: Elizabeth Brooks Naff, an assistant research analyst in the Boston office of Alex Brown & Sons, the stock brokerage, and Michael Scott Fulton, an account executive for Prudential-Bache Securities, also in Boston, were married yesterday. The Rev. George Coxe Bland Jr. performed the ceremony at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Jennifer Ann Hoadley Is Married in Queens
description: The Community Church of Douglaston, Queens, was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Jennifer Ann Hoadley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philemon Hoadley of Douglaston Manor, Queens, to Philip Shaw, a son of Margaret Shaw of Cincinnati and Stuart Shaw of London. The Rev. John Meyer performed the ceremony.

title: Anne M. Sheerin to Marry Carl Shoup
description: Anne Marshall Sheerin and Carl Sumner Shoup plan to marry Aug. 15, the parents of the bride-to-be, the Rev. and Mrs. Charles W. Sheerin Jr. of Albany, have announced. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Shoup of Charlottesville, Va.

title: BLOOD AND OIL
description: THE two missiles fired by an Iraqi pilot last Sunday spread havoc far beyond the fiery destruction aboard the United States frigate Stark, where 37 crew members were killed. Also severely damaged in the attack were longstanding assumptions about the American Navy's global responsibilities and capabilities and about the Reagan Administration's military plans for the Persian Gulf region.

title: WHAT GOES UP CAN COME DOWN -- AND WITH DISMAYING SPEED
description: I LIVE in a community in northern New Jersey where it is all but impossible to buy a decent house for less than $200,000, and where rentals - when obtainable at all - command minimum prices of $1,000 a month.

title: THE WOMAN WHO NEVER SAID 'NO'
description: THE epitaph on her tombstone read: ''She never said 'no.' '' And it was true.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: POWER SITS AT ANOTHER TABLE: And Other Observations on the Business of Power. By Earl Shorris. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) It is now possible to have a power lunch alone. All one has to do is carry along this sometimes funny and frequently chilling little tome and digest its contents along with the steak tartare, or whatever it is power lunchers eat. How's this: ''In a contest for power, physical strength still plays a major role; there are no neurasthenic titans.'' (Uh, waiter, another helping of steak tartare.) Or this: ''The powerful man kept his options open. He had no use for philosophers, who are immobilized by truth.'' Earl Shorris, author of ''The Oppressed Middle: Scenes From Corporate Life'' and other books, is a man who has viewed power up close and hasn't found it a pretty sight. In this book he has collected 192 of his observations - no need to count them, they're numbered - on the uses and abuses of the big P. Among those that made this reader sit up straight in his chair were No. 12, ''A Mexican proverb: The rich leave the poor like dishes at an inn, scraped clean and face down''; No. 118, ''When a powerful man yawns, he expresses boredom; weariness is for the weak''; and No. 169, ''A metaphor: To maintain power one will eventually be required to kill a friend.'' Then, of course, there's No. 105: ''There is no power in a small room.'' So much for lunch at those little out-of-the-way bistros.

title: AN OFF BROADWAY TEAM VENTURES INTO TV
description: SOMETIMES THE CHEMISTRY between playwright and director is so crucial that it becomes almost impossible to separate the work of one from the other. Graig Lucas and Norman Rene enjoy that kind of collaboration.

title: Dr. Marjorie Eskay Is Wed in Phoenix
description: Dr. Marjorie Lauren Eskay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Eskay of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Dr. Marc Andrew Auerbach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Auerbach of York, Pa., were married yesterday at the Mansion Club in Phoenix. Rabbi Maynard Bell performed the ceremony.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Wilbraham, Mass.: Site Cinches Condo Zoning
description: LEAD: THE first condominium development in this affluent suburb eight miles east of Springfield is on its way to completion, without a hint of distress over environmental concerns.

title: JUDGE AGREES TO A DELAY IN YONKERS
description: A FEDERAL judge agreed last week to a two-month delay in construction of low-income housing in Yonkers if an appeals court affirms his landmark desegregation order, but he has coupled the move with new demands of the city.

title: THREE-RING SHAKESPEARE
description: JUDGING BY ITS FASHION, COLOR and ornament, as William Shakespeare might have put it, the ''Comedy of Errors'' now previewing at the Vivian Beaumont Theater would seem to be quite the merry demolition of the Bard. After all, this is the vaudeville version of ''The Comedy of Errors'' -the production that transforms Shakespeare's town of Ephesus into a circus's winter quarters, where characters polish their acts while performing their lines. There is ensemble juggling, acrobatics, rope-walking, machete-twirling, tap-dancing, a klezmer score and the inevitable appearance of that sacred icon of the music hall, the rubber chicken.

title: A Case of Speedy Justice
description: A 31-year-old Waco man, Edward Lyon Jr., has turned himself in to the police, pleaded guilty to a slaying and been sentenced to life in prison - all in one day. Negotiations with his attorney accounted for the speedy disposition of the case on Thursday, said District Attorney John Miller. Mr. Lyon admitted stabbing William Long of Texarkana to death on April 22.

title: Francoise Catherine Jeanne Jackson Is Bride of John Stanton Williams 3d
description: At St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in West Hartford, Conn., yesterday Francoise Catherine Jeanne Jackson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Wayne Jackson of West Hartford and Madison, Conn., was married to John Stanton Williams 3d, the son of Mrs. Williams Jr. of New York and Walpole, Me., and the late Mr. Williams. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Francis S. O'Neill, assisted by the Rev. Norman J. Belval and the Rev. William Randolph Robbins, an Episcopal priest.

title: Mr. Dole's Hunger Politics
description: One of the Reagan Administration's wiser foreign policies supports the nominally Marxist but increasingly pragmatic Government of Mozambique. Still, some right-wing extremists would prefer backing the Mozambican insurgency financed by South Africa. The nomination of a new U.S. ambassador to Mozambique offers them an opportunity to press their case. Bob Dole, Presidential candidate, joins in, with an especially offensive rationale.

title: Andrea Braverman Married
description: Andrea Braverman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Monte Braverman of Tenafly, N.J., and Snowmass Village, Colo., was married last evening to Lewis Stephen Gross, the son of Mrs. Irwin K. Chapman of Closter, N.J., and Maurice Gross of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbis Maurice Davis and Jack Bemporad, assisted by Cantor Nathaniel Benjamin, performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Mrs. Gross heads her own company, Ande's Baby Clothes, in Edgewater, N.J. Her husband is president of Sports Professional Management in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Razzle-Dazzle in Design
description: To the Editor:

title: PTL Ministry Raises $100,000
description: The financially troubled PTL ministry raised more than $100,000 today by auctioning thousands of items, including an antique car that sold for $27,000 and an air-conditioned dog house from the home of PTL's founder, Jim Bakker.

title: Blocking an Envoy To Mozambique
description: Mozambique calls itself a ''people's republic'' but with civil war and famine threatening the lives of an estimated one-third of the country's 13 million people, the former Portuguese colony has warmed to the West in recent years. Hoping to encourage moderate political tendencies in southern Africa, Britain and the United States have sent economic aid to Mozambique's Government. Last week, however, some Republican Senators called on the Reagan Administration to switch sides and recognize a Mozambique insurgency, the National Resistance Movement, or Renamo. The rebels are quietly supported by Mozambique's neighbor, South Africa.

title: OPERA: CAVALLI'S 'GIASONE,' BY MANNES CAMERATA
description: HOW many 17th-century Italian operas can New Yorkers absorb within a few weeks that treat Jason, Medea and other mythological figures in serio-comic fashion? Just recently the Clarion Music Society offered ''I Rivali Concordi'' of Agostino Steffani in an only partly successful concert performance at Alice Tully Hall. This past week, the Mannes Camerata has presented a staged version of Francesco Cavalli's ''Giasone'' - which Clarion did in 1976 -and at Friday's fifth and final performance it was so delightful that one feels ready for anything else of this sort that our venturesome local impresarios hurl at us.

title: MAYLAND UPSET; CORNELL SURVIVES
description: Maryland, one of two unbeaten teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse tournament, was eliminated today, while the second, Cornell, survived.

title: AN INSTINCT FOR THE DNGEROUS WIFE
description: MORE DIE OF HEARTBREAK By Saul Bellow. 335 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: Agent's View
description: IN announcing Woodson's disqualification, Duke did not name the agent the athlete had dealt with, but his identity was hardly a secret. Woodson is one of at least half a dozen athletes who have been sued by Norby Walters, the New York agent whose business dealings are being looked into by a Federal grand jury in Chicago. About 60 athletes from 28 colleges are expected to testify in the case. Walters, insisting on his innocence, said the investigators were whistling in the dark. ''I am not guilty of these so-called alleged possible charges,'' Walters told The Atlanta Constitution. ''I have broken no laws. I will be proven innocent, and it is ridiculous that I have to go through this.''

title: Multitask P.C.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDEING;
SITE ANALYSIS TO PREVENT PLANT FAILURE
description: LEAD: MANY planting failures result from site problems. Some, though nonexistent when the planting was made, may nevertheless have developed during the intervening years. Others may have existed before planting. In either case, replacement plantings have all too frequently been made without first having ascertained the cause of the problem and having taken steps to remedy it.

title: 3 JAPANESE ARTISTS IN SEARCH OF A WORLD LANGUAGE
description: BY ORGANIZING ''CONTEMPO-rary Japanese Art in America,'' the Japan Society has provided a valuable service. More and more artists from Japan are living and exhibiting in New York, and it is difficult to see them in a context where they make sense. With the quality of someof the Japanese artists currently living in the United States, and with the perspective they can offer, exhibitions like this one are important.

title: KOHL SHIFTS ON SHORT-RANGE MISSILE BAN
description: In a major step toward NATO consensus, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has reluctantly decided to abandon resistance to any United States-Soviet pact that would abolish short-range missiles, according to high Western officials and political figures.

title: THERE IS NO TIME LIKE THE RIGHT TIME
description: THE essence of chess is time, a point Bobby Fischer always used to be fond of emphasizing.

title: WELCH STOPS METS
description: The Mets shook down fond memories of the old Brooklyn Dodgers in Shea Stadium yesterday in their annual reunion and salute to the past. But they had the devil's own time shaking down any fond memories of themselves from last year, which is something they have been struggling to do all season.

title: MORGAN GRENFELL SURVIVES A BRITISH SCANDAL
description: ''IT'S a hell of a good business that happened to have a couple of nasty setbacks recently,'' said John Craven, referring to the Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C., the British merchant bank that hired him as chief executive a few weeks ago.

title: KITTENS: CUTE, CLEAN AND $1,141.50
description: KITTENS. The classifieds were full of advertisements for adorable, cuddly, fluffy, baby cats. As I skimmed past the columns of kittens, looking for good deals on household items, I realized the best deal was staring right at me. My daughter's birthday was just weeks away and we still had not decided on a gift. But here it was - an adorable free kitten.

title: Mideast Conference? Yes, But First ...
description: What should Israel and America do: Seize the opportunity now to move toward peace? Or stonewall virtually every effort to trade peace for territory? Israel's bitter rivals, Prime Minister Shamir and Foreign Minister Peres, put forward these choices. Neither makes sense.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report last Sunday on a consultation service used in child custody cases misstated its name. It is the Family Divorce Consultation Center.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Manors Await the Rich - or the Wrecker
description: LEAD: IN today's luxury-home market, prices of $1 million or more have become commonplace, but $4.5 million is still an unusual price tag, even on the Island.

title: REMEMBRANCE OF THINGS PAST
description: ROCK-AND-ROLL IS MORE than 30 years old, and its roots reach back further than that. It's a tradition now, not just rude teen-aged rebellion. But with its deliberate formal limitations - rock is simple, danceable, hummable music - there is a crisis of originality in rock. What is original may not be rock any more; what is stereotypically rock may seem boring.

title: S.R.O. Moratorium: Exemptions Deadline
description: New York City's moratorium on the demolition or alteration of single-room occupancy buildings is meant to preserve inexpensive housing. Owners of long-vacant large S.R.O.'s can get exemptions, but only if they file applications with the city by Friday.

title: Connecticut College
description: Connecticut College, in New London, held its 69th commencement yesterday, conferring 468 degrees. The commencement speaker, Marion Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, discussed national priorities in providing for children.

title: Empire Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: PARNASSUS, NEW-MUSIC GROUP
description: PARNASSUS is a new-music group that trafficks in serious contemporary composition. Anthony Korf and his first-rate musicians define the ''uptown'' sensibility: They champion intelligently crafted, earnestly complex scores by composers who owe a direct spiritual and, often as not, academic allegiance to older modernist masters.

title: Chicago Convention Annex Facing Problems
description: Chicago would like to be considered the nation's premier center for conventions and trade shows, but old Chicago problems like corrupt politicians and bad management keep getting in the way.

title: LIVING, AND PLAYING, ON THE HIGH WIRE
description: LEAD: IN ADDITION TO THEIR LEGENDARY talents, Judy Garland, Babe Ruth and Maria Callas are remembered for the high-wire suspense they created before the public. It is these idols from another era (along with a rubber Godzilla head) whose outsized photos adorn the walls of the Manhattan apartment where the violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg lives - and she claims artistic kinship with them all.

title: ADVICE AT SPEEDWAY: GENTLEMEN, WATCH OUT
description: It was almost an ominous plea as the 33 drivers for the Indianapolis 500 heard these words from the chief steward this morning:

title: GRADUATES: DIMMER FUTURE?
description: GRADUATION time - the grand finale of the school year. It's a heady time, a strong brew of final exams, proms, plans, and pomp and circumstance.

title: Howard Beach Driver Cleared
description: Dominick Blum has maintained from the beginning that although it was his car that struck and killed a black man fleeing a group of white youths in Howard Beach one night last December, he was only a passing motorist. Last week a Queens grand jury said it had ''failed to find sufficient evidence'' to indict him.

title: BUILDERS GOT TAX BREAKS, BUT WHAT DID CITY RECIEVE?
description: A DECADE ago, when there had been no major commercial building in New York City for four years running, when the city was losing tens of thousands of jobs a year to the suburbs and was tottering on the brink of bankruptcy, New York City, with Albany's approval, decided to launch a series of giveaways to real-estate developers in hopes of spurring them into activity.

title: A DAY OF READING SET IN BRIDGEPORT
description: LEAD: MORE than 300 Bridgeport civic and business leaders have volunteered to read stories to elementary schoolchildren as part of a Read-Aloud Day.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN BUSINESS INCUBATORS
description: CARLOS MORALES says he can hardly keep pace with the demand. To hear him tell it, the National Business Incubation Association, the group he heads, has been so deluged with requests for information that callers complain they cannot get through on the phone lines. Everybody, it seems - from California colleges to Brooklyn bureaucrats -wants to know just how to put together a business incubator.

title: WEATHER REPORT: YUCKY
description: WHAT'S IT LIKE out today?'' ''Yucky.'' You reach for your raincoat and begin a search for your overshoes (which you used to call rubbers before that word became a euphemism for condoms), because you know that yucky means ''inclement'' (a word most often meaning ''stormy,'' based on the opposite of the Latin clemens, ''lenient, mild'').

title: The Marcoses In Exile
description: Shame on your magazine (''The Marcoses' Moonlight Sonata,'' by Seth Mydans, April 19)! Out of 88 pages, you choose to waste precious space on Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos, who should be relegated to a dim and unwanted memory. What good does it serve humanity to perpetuate their lies, their warped philosophies and their lunacy?

title: THE SEASON'S STARS: STRIPES AND STRIPES
description: LOOKING for this spring's newest fashion fad? It's all there in black and white (occasionally blue and white). Stripes of those colors are most definitely in. The proof is on jackets, pants, blouses, sweatshirts, T-shirts, beach tops, socks, hats -garments, indeed, of every stripe.

title: After the Coup, Fijians Cut a Deal
description: After hard bargaining last week, descendants of the early Melanesian inhabitants of Fiji came up with a deal that was intended to send the army of the Pacific island country back to the barracks. However, Lieut. Col. Sitiveni Rabuka, who led a bloodless coup on May 14, retained important authority in an interim Government led by the Governor General and nominal head of state, Ratu Sir Penaia.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Contempt Written and directed by Jean-Luc Godard. With Brigitte Bardot, Michelle Picolli and Jack Palance. 1963. Embassy Home Entertainment. 102 minutes. $29.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE PARADISE OF BOMBS. By Scott Russell Sanders. (University of Georgia, $14.95.) This is a book about natural marvels and human horrors. In ''The Paradise of Bombs,'' Scott Russell Sanders stages a duel between old beauties and modern evil. Courting owls, children's war toys, limestone quarries and the fatiguing drama of a drug trial tease and tug at a reader's allegiances.

title: Casa de Campo
description: To the Editor: Just to make sure that I never go to Casa de Campo (Letters, April 26), could you please let me know where it is? BARBARA WRIGHT Hebron, Conn.

title: Next Week; How Will Fans React To Gooden's Return?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Change on Horizon for a 20's Community
description: LEAD: FOR decades, Radburn has been spared the development pressures that have transformed much of northern New Jersey. Instead, it has remained virtually untouched since the last new construction in 1950, a genteel, residential enclave of Fair Lawn, distinguished by its rowhouses and abundant park land.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AN AMERICAN WOMAN. By Kati Marton. (Norton, $15.95.) Anna Bator was born in Hungary. When she was 6 years old, her parents were arrested as spies. They were allowed to emigrate after their release, and Anna was raised in America. She grew into a cosmopolitan woman, became a successful television correspondent, married and had a child, but was not happy. Her parents had withheld from her any connection to her past - including the fact that her father was Jewish - and she determined to return to Hungary to search for her roots. She found more than she bargained for, her American-bred innocence no match for the complicated labyrinth of Eastern European politics and hostilities. ''An American Woman,'' a first novel by Kati Marton, is at least partly autobiographical. Ms. Marton, who was born in Hungary, was a correspondent in Eastern and Western Europe for ABC News. This book does not leave the reader with a searing insight into the human condition. It does not startle by the beauty of its prose - the style is straightforward. But it is a lively cold war story, told with sensitivity and intelligence. It is enlightening about life in Eastern Europe, rich with the detail that only a keen memory and a sharp eye can garner, and it offers some interesting musings on the differences between East and West that go beyond the trappings of materialism. One of the virtues of this novel is that it probes beneath the surface, insisting on the importance of history. Anna Bator is an otherwise perfectly assimilated American - part of a culture unique in its belief that history can be ignored or overcome. But she must have been less Americanized than she thought, because the central tenet of the book is deeply Eastern European: without a strong sense of history, without a national and cultural past, any present, no matter how glittering, is unsatisfying.

title: NAVY BOMB SITE RATTLES THE VINEYARD
description: From his home in the center of this quiet farm and fishing town on Martha's Vineyard, John S. Alley can hear the Navy dropping bombs.

title: A SCRAPPY TAKEOVER ARTIST RISES TO THE TOP
description: CLASSMATES vividly remember their first glimpse of Paul A. Bilzerian at Harvard Business School's opening session in 1975. ''Everybody was wearing jackets and ties,'' said Mark Filippell, an investment banker and former classmate. ''It was the first day and no one knew what to expect, and this guy sticks his head in five minutes late. He's wearing blue jeans that look like he's been mining coal in them and a Stanford sweatshirt with holes in the elbow. He needs a shave. I thought he was lost or something.''

title: ARTS INSTITUTE INSPRIES YOUTH
description: LEAD: DURING the next few weeks, about 150 talented high school students will be selected to participate from July 5 through Aug. 8 in a summer arts program designed to focus on career direction and creative individuality.

title: BORDER MUSIC'S LONG REACH
description: THERE ARE THOSE WHO argue that the hippest radio station ever to beam music and chatter over the American airwaves operated out of a tiny studio overlooking the Pacific Ocean in this sleepy Mexican resort town, 15 miles south of the United States border.

title: Commercial Property: A Home Away From Home; Weak Dollar Leads Foreigners to Buy Their Offices
description: AFTER almost a decade as just another faceless tenant in a Manhattan office tower, Banco de Bilbao bought its own piece of Manhattan a few months ago.

title: OHIO CITY WATCHES IRAN HEARINGS WITH YAWN
description: ''We watch it on television at home,'' said Melvin Schottenstein, a lawyer active in civic affairs in this Middle Western city, ''but when I come downtown to work, no one mentions it. I guess everyone has already made up his or her mind.''

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
HERE COMES THE BILL, HERE COMES THE BILL, HERE COMES...
description: LEAD: WHAT is so rare as a day in June - or a wedding without aggravation? The preparations for next month's Long Island weddings were begun in January. January of 1982, that is, because whoever said ''A good man is hard to find'' was talking about a caterer.

title: Studds Mails Out U.S. AIDS Reports
description: REPRESENTATIVE Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, is mailing the United States Surgeon General's report on AIDS to each of the 268,000 households in his district and urging other members of Congress to follow suit.

title: CABARET: LEN CARIOU DEBUT
description: LEN CARIOU and Jo Sullivan, two veterans of the Broadway musical theater, make an appealing odd couple in their joint cabaret act, ''Center Stage: From Loesser to Sondheim,'' which is playing at Michael's Pub (211 East 55th Street) through June 6.

title: ART: 'THE HELGA PICTURES,' BY WYETH
description: Andrew Wyeth's ''Helga Pictures,'' which begin their two-and-a-half-year, six-stop national run today at the National Gallery of Art, are not that disturbing in themselves. In this suite of works, which amounts to around 15 to 20 percent of the artist's output during the last 15 years, Mr. Wyeth is what he has always been -a sometimes admirable, sometimes moving, invariably problematical figure whose work reflects the principles and problems of American provincial life.

title: STATE AND CALIFORNIA SHARE PLAN ON TEACHERS
description: LEAD: THE State Education Commissioner, Gerald N. Tirozzi, said ''it makes a lot of sense'' for Connecticut and California to be working together on a project designed to improve teacher quality. Although the states are 3,000 miles apart, ''geography has nothing to do with it,'' he said.

title: WITH TALK OF 'GOODWILL,' PRETORIA CRACKS DOWN
description: PRESIDENT P. W. Botha spoke to Parliament last week about ''broadening democracy'' and ''negotiating in a spirit of goodwill.'' But he made clear to South Africa's black majority that current repressive laws would continue while the Government waits for nonwhite leaders to accept its terms on modifying the country's race-determined political system.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Pardon Mon Affaire Directed by Yves Robert. Starring Jean Rochefort, Claude Brasseur, Guy Bedos, Victor Lanoux. 1977. French with English subtitles. Embassy Home Entertainment. 105 minutes. $29.95.

title: OFFICERS OF C.I.A. NOW SAID TO TELL OF TIE TO CONTRAS
description: Some Central Intelligence Agency officers have recanted previous statements and are telling the agency's investigators about contacts with the contras and their private supporters that may have been improper, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: Ms. >Uscher Weds William P. Barrett
description: Nancy Joyce Uscher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Uscher of White Plains and Stockbridge, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to William Paul Barrett, the son of Robert E. Barrett of Savannah, Ga., and the late Hope Harris Barrett. Cantor Robert Bloch performed the ceremony at the Montauk Club in Brooklyn.

title: HEALTH-CLUB PARTIES OFFERED IN LIEU OF GRADUATION BASH
description: INCREASING numbers of high school students appear to be saying no to alcohol and drugs, at least on graduation night, according to the sponsors of Project Graduation, which provides an alcohol- and drug-free celebration for students.

title: LAKERS JUMP TO A 3-0 LEAD
description: The inspirational character that led the Seattle SuperSonics to this unexpected juncture of the season is still there. The tenacious defense, brilliant individual performances and admirable resiliency have not changed. Only the opponent has, but that has made all the difference.

title: BOGOSIAN'S VOICES
description: ''SID! SID! SID! SID! SID! LISTEN TO ME. . . .''

title: POLISH SALE TO CONTRAS: ONLY WITH A FACADE
description: The relationship between the contras and their arms suppliers in Communist countries was a little bit like that of a couple who overlook each other's indiscretions, provided they are not too obvious.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC: Behind America's Lens on the World. By Howard S. Abramson. (Crown, $17.95.) Howard S. Abramson's unauthorized history exposes the not so very dark side of a venerable institution and its phenomenally successful publishing arm. Among those aspects of the National Geographic Society we may not read about in the authorized version - due out next year, to coincide with the society's centennial - are the magazine's relentlessly sunny attitude, which gave rise to such travesties as a glowing report on Nazi Germany published in 1937, and a 1962 article about South Africa featuring ''happy blacks doing their tribal dances''; past sexist and racist employment practices, including segregated dining rooms for black and white and male and female employees; and a tax-exempt status that continues to encourage the funneling of profits back into luxurious perks, though the magazine no longer maintains a fleet of chauffeured cars for its editors. Otherwise, this isn't a very interesting book. Mr. Abramson, a financial editor for The Washington Post, got his information mostly secondhand, from a 1943 New Yorker series by Geoffrey T. Hellman and a 1970 New York Times Magazine piece by Tom Buckley, and from The Washington Post. The Post is the source of many anecdotes, like the one about the archeologist George Stuart, who, in search of a Mayan tomb, charged on his Visa card the cost of clearing an emergency landing site in an apparently guerrilla-ridden area of Guatemala. Except for a preoccupation with ''all those memorable brown breasts,'' Mr. Abramson's ''National Geographic'' reads like a term paper - earnest, informative and rife with footnotes and cliches.

title: In Venice, Keeping the World Afloat
description: ''The only good thing about this summit is that it's in Venice - and Venice is sinking.'' This gloomy assessment by an official helping to prepare next month's meeting of the leaders of the seven main industrialized democracies is somewhat off the mark. Because of Italy's corrective action, Venice is no longer sinking, but because of the political paralysis of the summit leaders, the world economy is.

title: GREENWICH ESTATE OPENS ITS DOORS TO BENEFIT 3 CHARITIES
description: LEAD: SONGS from the 20's and 30's played last night on a Steinway grand piano in the ballroom of Chieftans, the Greenwich estate of the late Bernard F. and Alva Gimbel, signaling the passing of an era and the opening of a monthlong charity benefit.

title: A 'Liaison' Lament
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSCOW SEEKING TO EXPLOIT U.S. DIFFICULTIES IN MIDDLE EAST
description: A BENCHMARK event emphasized the new realities in the Middle East last Sunday when the Israeli Foreign Minister met secretly with the Soviet Ambassador in Washington to solicit the Kremlin's thinking on the Arab-Israeli peace process.

title: WOULD MARCEL BREUER APPROVE OF THE WHITNEY ADDITION?
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHOREOGRAPHER TEACHES ACTORS TO HIT-AND RUN
description: LEAD: ELLEN SALAND IS ALWAYS starting fights. Always. Right now, at Circle in the Square Professional Workshop, she's urging Cindy Kaplan, a second-year student, to come at her with a saber. ''Make me move. Push me across the room,'' she urges. ''Come for my head. Now attack my legs.'' Kicking, biting, scratching, hair-pulling, eye-gouging, slapping, jabbing, strangling, head bashing, punching, stabbing, raping -these are routine mayhem to Ms.

title: TV SHOW ON ARTS TO AIR
description: LEAD: ''ARTS WEEK,'' a television program highlighting the arts in Connecticut which has been shown on Channel 49 in Fairfield County since September, will make its statewide debut tonight on Connecticut Public Television's network of five stations.

title: INN TO RANCH IN MOUNTAINS OF MONTANA
description: The train's P.A. system crackled to life just after dawn. A sleepy voice mumbled, ''We're going to stop for just a minute up here to drop off someone from the sleeping car who's visiting the Izaak Walton Inn, coming up on your left.''

title: THE FARCE, BEAUTY AND PASSION OF RAMEAU'S 'PLATEE'
description: ''I DON'T THINK BAROQUE opera is about to displace the 19th-century variety in popularity,'' admits Grant Llewellyn, the 27-year-old British conductor who will lead the American premiere of Rameau's ''Platee'' this evening at the Spoleto U.S.A. Festival in Charleston, S.C. ''Nevertheless,'' he adds, ''there are more and more revivals taking place on both sides of the Atlantic. Handel, certainly, remains in the forefront. Yet, Rameau's operas are increasingly being done too. And for good reason. He was the perfect dramatist, a tremendously imaginative composer who seems to have been incapable of writing music that wasn't lovely.''

title: Silver Spring, Md.: 30's Mall Faces Wrecking Ball
description: A PROPOSAL to raze an Art Deco shopping center built in the 1930's has caused a stir in this suburban community outside Washington.

title: WAITING FOR THE BOOK: STORMS BEFORE THE CALM
description: EIGHTEEN months generally elapse nowadays between the time a publisher accepts a manuscript and its appearance in book form - the gestation period of an elephant. During that year and a half of waiting, a writer is visited by every emotion in the funhouse, from rosy anticipation to exultation, megalomania, brooding, dread, cringing humility, avarice, guilt and, finally, stolid acceptance.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, MAY 24, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15 2,3.5,q>Some C.I.A. officers have recanted previous statements and are now acknowledging to the agency's internal investigators possibly improper contacts with the contras and their private supporters, Administration officials said. 1 The Soviet Union will halt whaling as its last fleet heads home from its final hunting season in the Antarctic, Moscow announced. The flagship of the commercial fleet will be converted to a fisheries ship, they said. 1 Restoring Michelangelo's frescoes in the Sistene Chapel is creating new controversy. Earlier disputes over the use of varnish on the works has been a step to the new debate over climate control in the chapel. 8 In India, riots in the capital left at least 63 dead and hundreds hurt or arrested. The rioting between Hindus and Moslems fueled new concerns about growing sectarian tension in the northern part of the country. 3 Helmut Kohl will not resist a Soviet-American pact for the abolition of shorter-range nuclear missiles, senior German officials and political figures said. The Chancellor's decision is a major step toward NATO consensus. 10 A Cambodian rebel leader broke with the coalition opposing the pro-Hanoi Government. Prince Norodom Sihanouk has shaken the delicate balance of diplomacy in Indochina with his surprise one-year resignation. 14 The anti-Sandinista movement remains splintered in Nicaragua. The recent departure of Maria Azucena Ferrey for Miami, where she assumed a post with the contras, reflects those divisions. 3 Egypt wins debt payment accord 4 Polish sale to contras 12 1985 Iraqi attack on U.S. ship cited 13 1,000 arrested in Seoul 15 NATIONAL 16-23, 34-36 2,3.8,q>After a devastating twister in Texas, residents began trickling back to a town that no longer exists. Saragosa, Tex. was struck Friday by the twister that killed at least 30 people and injured about 120 more. 1 Rare conditions may abet tornado 22 Black Roman Catholic leaders met in Washington to let the wider church know, through gospel singing and calls to action, that black traditions must become a more valued part of Catholic worship. 1 The celebration of the Constitution got off to a rousing start, opening the major phase of Philadelphia's and the nation's observance of its 200th anniversary. The festivities began at the Philadelphia Art Museum. 1 A psychologist fabricated research about mental retardation treatment, according to an report released by the Government. The accused researcher, Dr. Stephen E. Breuning, is influential in the field. 16 For 50 years, the Golden Gate Bridge has stood as the project that changed the economic and social life of the San Francisco Bay Area. The great bridge's 50th birthday is being celebrated today. 16 Protest at U.S.-Soviet conference 17 City problems bigger than ever 18 Foreign money in U.S. elections 21 Regional 24-31, 39-42 2,,q>In the Donovan case, a judge refused to declare a mistrial. The judge in the fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and seven others impaneled an alternate to replace a juror who was disqualified. 1 Donovan Judge's Quandary 24 A series of water rate increases will, by 1996, almost triple the typical homeowner's water bill in New York City. Rates will rise almost 20 percent on July 1. But the increases will not stop there. 1 A strike has halted some road work in Connecticut. Though only 2,000 members of the union for heavy-equipment operators and mechanics are involved in the strike, the walkout has idled thousands of others. 28 A plan to bury nuclear waste byproducts near Buffalo will be blocked for at least two years under a settlement between a citizens' group and the Government. The byproducts would come from 600,000 gallons of radioactive waste. 31 Debate about a museum's expansion has opened. The dispute over the Whitney Museum's expansion plans focused on whether razing a row of brownstones would begin a dismemberment of New York City's historic districts. 25 Municipal unions are seeking gains from New York City in upcoming contract talks. The city has said it expected a surplus in tax revenues in the next fiscal year. The unions want what they see as their share. 24 Reporters Notebook: Goetz trial 26 Key Cuomo advisor will resign 27 Cost of PCB clean up rises 30

title: Stern Stuff
description: To hear her critics tell it, W. Ann Reynolds runs the 19 campuses of California State University with an iron fist inside a steel glove. Dr. Reynolds, chancellor of the 335,000-student system since 1982, was accused earlier this year of verbal brutality in her treatment of Richard Butwell, who died of a heart attack two weeks after she suggested he resign as president of the Dominguez Hills campus. That accusation, made by the presidents of two other campuses, was among criticisms that were considered in a recent review by the Board of Trustees. She survived that one, as the trustees adopted an evaluation that characterized her job performance as ''noteworthy.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday on an application by male legislators for membership in the Connecticut Order of Women Legislators misidentified State Representative William L. Wollenberg of Farmington. He is a Republican.

title: Q AND A
description: A C.P.I. LEASE CLAUSE Question: I have a small retail business in Queens. My landlord is prepared to give me a new lease for 10 years at $325 per month with a 5 percent annual increase. However, she also wants to add an inflation clause that would be based on the Consumer Price Index. I would like to renew my lease but before I do I would like to know if a C.P.I. clause is standard for retail leases? . . . L. A., Far Rockaway, Queens Answer: According to Gene Meer, a senior vice president and a retail specialist with Huberth & Peters, a New York brokerage concern, it is a negotiable item.

title: SECTARIAN TENSION IS ON THE RISE IN INDIA
description: New concerns about growing sectarian tension in northern India were fueled this week after at least 63 people were killed and hundreds were injured or arrested in rioting between Hindus and Moslems in the capital and nearby Meerut.

title: Shortline Bus Workers End Two-Week Strike
description: Drivers and mechanics at the Shortline Bus System approved a new contract today by a 2-to-1 ratio, ending a two-week strike that affected 10,000 riders in three states, officials said.

title: T>alking: Mortgages; Making The Last Payment
description: PAYING off a mortgage is truly a cause for celebration. The moment is so special that it has been assigned a ritual in our society - a mortgage-burning party at which the notorious document is finally laid to rest.

title: Patricia Bayer Marries
description: The marriage of Patricia Laurie Bayer, a vice president in the taxable fixed income department at the First Boston Corporation in New York, to Kent George Troup, national sales manager in New York for the Temcor Corporation, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Abba Bayer, parents of the bride, in East Hampton, L.I. Town Justice Sheppard Frood performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Troup of Schenectady, N.Y.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ILLUSTRATING ROCKWELL A former New Rochelle resident -Norman Rockwell, illustrator of the popular Saturday Evening Post magazine covers of the 1940's and 1950's - is the subject of a musical-in-progress to be performed at 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday in Port Chester's Capitol Theater, at 149 Westchester Avenue.

title: Kathryn Frazer Weds Publisher
description: The marriage of Kathryn A. Frazer and B. V. Brooks took place last evening at the Albertson Memorial Spiritualist Church in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Melvin O. Smith performed the ceremony.

title: VERMONT MEASURE ALLOWING STATE TO COMPETE WITH POWER UTILITIES
description: Fearful of losing its allocation of low-cost Federal power, the Vermont Legislature has passed a bill that allows the Vermont Department of Public Service to buy electricity from any source and to sell that power to any customer.

title: A RIOT OF ROSES
description: EIGHTY YEARS AGO, THIS PENNSYLVA-nia rose garden was planted as a laboratory by Edwin Rosenbluth, a Philadelphia chemist who became well-known as a manufacturer of garden spray. It has matured and changed over the years, and the present owners, Dr. Joseph Kassab, a retired surgeon, and his wife, Betty, have been conducting experiments of their own.

title: WITNESS SAID TO REFUSE TO TESTIFY IN MOB SHOOTING
description: Federal prosecutors dropped charges against two men in the shooting of a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug case because a Government informant decided not to testify, people close to the case said yesterday.

title: Kathleen A. Yockey Weds at West Point
description: Kathleen A. Yockey and Capt. Kurt P. Wangenheim, U.S.A., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y. The Rev. Robert T. Drummond performed the ceremony.

title: KIT CARSON SLEPT HERE
description: Six hundred dusty miles out of St. Joseph, Mo., pioneers crossed a low rise on the plains of eastern Wyoming and came across a welcome sight. There in a saucer-shaped valley was a lonely outpost known as Fort Laramie, a cluster of rough-hewn buildings in a vast and forbidding wilderness.

title: TRAVELER'S AID: HELP FOR THE NEEDY
description: LEAD: EVERY morning Bonnie Gallio stations herself in the lobby of New Haven's Human Resources Building and hands out breakfast vouchers. Her 40 to 60 clients, mostly men, are among New Haven's large homeless population. After they pick up their chits, they go to specified restaurants for a meal of eggs, home fries, toast and coffee.

title: 1,000 Arrested in Seoul During Street Protests
description: Policemen arrested more than 1,000 people in Seoul tonight in street protests against police torture and other reported human-rights abuses.

title: THE GIACOMETTIS' DECORATIVE WORKS
description: ALBERTO GIACOMETTI'S lesser known works -lighting fixtures and furnishings, which he produced to earn a living just before and after World War II -were once again at center stage two weeks ago on the day after one of his bronzes brought the record price at auction of $3.63 million for a sculpture.

title: THE RACER'S EDGE: A STRONG PSYCHE
description: TODAY as many as 40 million people from around the world will watch, either in person or on television, a colorful display of expensively engineered metal in an orchestra of high engine notes. They will see the banging of car bodies and scraping of walls as 33 drivers maneuver their cars around the Indianapolis Motor Speedway at speeds of over 200 miles per hour.

title: 427-Unit Development: Golf Just a Chip Shot Away
description: The Beekman Country Club, a 27-hole public golf course in East Fishkill, N.Y., is about to develop a loyal following. Time Equities and Empire State Land Company are in contract to buy the golf course as well as adjoining tracts - 563 acres in all - for a vast residential development.

title: Razzle-Dazzle in Design
description: To the Editor:

title: SELLING FASHIONABLE CASTOFFS
description: WHEN ''The Real Thing'' closed on Broadway, the costumes from the play ended up at a Litchfield consignment shop. Clothing racks that hold robes and trousers that were worn on Broadway is a tip-off that this is no ordinary thrift shop.

title: AND THEN THE PARADE WAS GONE
description: AN empty nest on Memorial Day! With four participating children in our family, we've stood at attention for a lot of village parades.

title: Verbatim: A Memory
description: 'This monster in the guise of a man had a mocking, sarcastic smile that you can never forget. And nobody could ever forget those eyes, those rat's eyes with no mercy in them.' Michel Thomas

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Avon, Conn. $255,000 61 Harris Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old brick colonial; crown moldings, 1.5 acres; taxes $2,335. Bristol, Conn. $82,000 186 Stevens Street 2-bedroom, 1 bath, older ranch; close to shopping, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,098. Glastonbury, Conn. $205,000 160 Shipman Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; wooded lot, workshop, 0.75 acre; taxes $2,151. Chappaqua, N.Y. $449,000 3 Alden Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 48-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, screened porch, playroom; taxes $4,839. Rye, N.Y. $346,250 63 Claremont Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old frame split-level; eat-in kitchen, screened porch; taxes $4,800. White Plains, N.Y. $225,000 73 Livingston Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 67-year-old frame colonial; wraparound porch, parlor, new eat-in kitchen, deck; taxes $1,645. OTHER AREAS Madison, N.J. $475,000 15 Pomeroy Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; 2-zone heating, den; taxes $5,581. Copiague, L.I. $415,000 105 Shore Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath,3-year-old contemporary; family room, deck, bayfront, 2-car garage; taxes $6,000. Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I. $95,000 54 Woodland Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, Florida room, basement; taxes $1,500.

title: LIGHTS UP! LIBRETTOS OPEN! ENJOY!
description: TO UNDERSTAND EVERYTHING, say the French, is to forgive everything. Perhaps that even applies to opera singing. Unfortunately, audiences at staged productions all too rarely have the opportunity to test the validity of that maxim. For good theatrical reasons, they must be kept literally in the dark. Opera in concert form, on the other hand, while it has serious drawbacks, holds one clear advantage over the usual staged kind: everyone in attendance can understand in detail what is going on. Perhaps that is why the unstaged repertory is so much more venturesome than what regularly turns up in our leading houses. People who are only intermittently aware of what is going on may be forgiven for cleaving to a few standard works that they have come to know, more or less. They may also, out of frustration with unintelligible singing, choose to be connoisseurs of scenery and costumes.

title: HOME VIDEO: DANCE
description: LEAD: Cinderella A ballet production of the Berlin Comic Opera. Staged and choreographed by Tom Schilling. View Video. 75 minutes. $39.95.

title: THE SHAPE OF FORD'S SUCCESS
description: WHEN JACK TELNACK was growing up in Dearborn, Mich., he would often go with his friends to the Ford Motor Company test track. They would scramble up the tall, brown masonry wall around the track and watch the cars of several years into the future come roaring past.

title: Dr. Donna Rosen to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harry D. Rosen of Oradell and Deal, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Donna Ellen Rosen to Dr. Jeffrey Alan Sedor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Sedor of Auburn, N.Y. The engaged couple both graduated from the Emory University School of Dentistry; she is a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, and he of Hobart College. A July wedding is planned.

title: YOUTHFUL PRESS CORPS LEARN ROPES IN NEWARK
description: THE journalistic ethics involved in the articles that ended Gary Hart's bid for the Presidency may be debated for years; however, if Chad Peterman had been assigned to the story, Mr. Hart's candidacy might have been salvaged.

title: One Tough Bench
description: THE Sacramento Kings will have a pair of Hall of Famers on their bench next season. Willis Reed, the former all-star player and head coach, will join the Kings Tuesday as an assistant coach to Bill Russell, who last month signed on with Sacramento for seven years. Although he has no guarantee in writing in the three-year contract he signed with the Kings, it is expected that Reed will move up as the Kings' head coach in a year or two when Russell is expected to become the club's president and general manager.

title: On Land and Water
description: HARBOR CRUISE

title: INSIDE
description: A Test for Gorbachev A Russian nationalist organization has emerged in Moscow, putting Mikhail S. Gorbachev's calls for openness to something of a test. Page 10.

title: DAY OF HOOPS, STAVES AND NIDDY NODDIES
description: ON the green in Waterford, youngsters carded freshly sheared wool to get out the clumps, wound yarn on a wood device called a niddy noddy and tackled a variety of other tasks. Sheep waited to be sheared, a young goat frolicked under a tree and visitors came by the busload.

title: Miss Kahn Is Wed To W. A. Jump 3d
description: Elizabeth Hette Kahn, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Armand David Kahn of Atlanta, was married last evening to William Ashby Jump 3d, the son of Mr. Jump Jr. of San Antonio and the late Dorothy Walsh Tenney of Port Washington, L.I. Rabbi Alvin Sugarman, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Jack S. Boozer, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at The Temple in Atlanta.

title: ROCK MUSIC: 'PRETENTIOUS,' BY THE LODGE
description: ''PRETENTIOUS MUSIC,'' the series that ended yesterday at the Kitchen, seemed to be about new relationships of text and music. But the best songs in Thursday's set by John Greaves and Peter Blegvad, who now call themselves the Lodge, came from an obscure album the two songwriters released in 1977, ''Kew. Rhone.'' For that album, the pair derived lyrics in abstruse ways - for instance, describing illustrations on the album cover (shown Thursday as slides), or using only the letters of the title (''we won honor enow/when we knew her/when we were one'') - and wrapped them in lilting, irregular melodies that fused pop, minimalism and Kurt Weill.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are people who say it never happens to them. They are people who flirt with the truth. Or maybe they just have serious memory lapses, or are born under an extraordinarily benign star. Because it isn't possible to believe that there truly are beings, particularly New York beings, who don't have to have a lot of things done twice.

title: STATE HONORS 1,583 TEACHERS
description: LEONARD CONTARDO, a guidance counselor at Yardville Elementary School here and a New Jersey teacher for 30 years, believes that children go to school carrying ''more emotional baggage than ever before.''

title: THE BROTHERS KONCHALOVSKY-MIKHALKOV
description: PERSONALITIES FROM AMER-ica and Western Europe grabbed most of the press and public attention during the second and final week of the 40th Anniversary Cannes International Film Festival, but the Russians supplied more drama, and even more human interest. Elizabeth Taylor and George Hamilton, both displaying the kind of deep tans that give dermatologists nightmares, were here early in the week. Neither had a film in the festival, but Miss Taylor came by anyway, to become a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor.

title: FINDING A PLINTH TO LIVE ON
description: THE 10:40 was clattering into the East River tunnel, and I was snuggling my knees up against the next seat for the serious business of my long day, the crossword puzzle. ''Tickets, all tickets,'' I heard, and I fished my monthly out and held it out in my left hand, my right poised over the Across and Down with my pen in it.

title: Patricia Kelleher Is Wed
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of SS. John and Paul in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday Patricia Anne Kelleher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Breslin Kelleher of Larchmont, was married to James P. Cassidy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Cassidy of Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Martin performed the ceremony. The bride is president of the Catherine Cooke Studio, a photographic service with offices in New York and Sherman, Conn. Mr. Cassidy is a public relations representative at UST Inc., formerly the U.S. Tobacco Company, in Greenwich, Conn.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Blue Velvet Written and directed by David Lynch. With Kyle Maclachlan, Isabella Rossellini, Dennis Hopper, Laura Dern. 1986. Lorimar Home Video. 120 minutes. $79.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Week in Business last week misstated the month in which producer prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent. It was April. If April's figure holds for 12 months, producer prices will rise at an annual compound rate of 8.9 percent.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: HOLIDAY HAPPENINGS What's Memorial Day without a parade? And villages and towns throughout the Island will have low-key observances that pay tribute to the nation's war dead with speeches, ceremonies and marching bands, veterans and schoolchildren.

title: How Some Students Are Groomed for Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGISLATURE BACK, WITH MAJOR ISSUES STILL UNRESOLVED
description: FOR the first time in more than a month, both houses of the Legislature were back at work last week, and as the two-year session heads toward its final six months many major issues targeted for action over the last year and a half are still unresolved.

title: TAX ISSUE ROILS EAST END
description: LEAD: AS the East End braces for the swelling population of visitors and returning part-time residents, its municipalities are under increasing pressure to find ways to pay for services. In some cases, local treasuries are remaining solvent only with dramatic tax increases. This has stirred residents to ask how much longer revenue can keep up with escalating expenses and if the burden is being shared equitably.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
TEA CEREMONY
description: LEAD: IT was the phrase ''cultural exchange'' come to life. Seven Japanese women, four of them in long silk kimonos, were preparing tea in the centuries-old tea ceremony of Japan, an intricate, precise ritual endowed with spiritual significance. The one enacting the role of host whipped fine, green powdered tea into a froth in a lacquered bowl.

title: Pop Music
description: Unvarnished blues, Chicago and bayou style, will rock New York clubs this week. Saturday night at 9:15 and 11:30 at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street, Rockin' Dopsie and the Cajun Twisters will play zydeco - the accordion-and-washboard-powered bayou dance music that's part Cajun, part Caribbean, part blues and part rhythm-and-blues. And Friday and Saturday at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street, at 9:30 and midnight, the Chicago bluesman Eddy Clearwater will appear with his band as part of the club's ongoing Chicago Blues Festival on weekends through mid-July.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: They Race Terriers, Don't They?

title: Shelly Belfer, a Teacher, Plans to Wed Anthony Malkin, a Banker, in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Belfer of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rachelle Lisa Belfer, to Anthony Edward Malkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Malkin of Greenwich, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: Miss Schadt Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Schadt of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Cardy Schadt, to Charles D. Baker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Baker of Boston and Rockport, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: 3 Found Slain in Restaurant
description: Three employees of a Wendy's restaurant were shot to death before the restaurant opened for business this morning and were not found until another employee arrived for the lunch-time shift, the police said. Ott Cefkin, a police spokesman, said it was not known if the fast-food restaurant had been robbed or how the killer or killers had gained entry. The names of the victims were not released, pending notification of their family members.

title: Cade Convicted
description: MOSSY CADE, a defensive back with the Packers, was found guilty in Green Bay yesterday of two charges that he sexually assaulted a 44-year-old woman related to him by marriage. Cade was acquitted on a third count. The woman had accused Cade of assaulting her at his home in November 1985. Cade, who was allowed to remain free on bond, faces a maximum penalty of 10 years in jail on each count when he is sentenced June 29.

title: IMAGINATIVE ITALIAN FARE
description: PASTA NOSTRA in South Norwalk is that rarity among restaurants: The older it is, the better it gets. What began in late 1984 as a very good Italian lunch-con-pasta-takeout store now offers dinner three nights a week, having added a few entrees to its imaginative repertory of dishes. You will find some of the finest Italian food in the entire state as well as most of New England at Pasta Nostra.

title: COUNTRY MUSIC IS ROAMING FAR FROM ITS ROOTS
description: COUNTRY MUSIC LEFT HOME long ago. It took its heritage -Celtic ballads and fiddle tunes, backwoods hymn-singing and square-dancing, Western swing's echoes of jazz and blues, hints of Cajun and Tex-Mex music, the twangs of down-home singers and guitarists - and moved out of the South and West, reaching listeners and performers from Canada to Great Britain to Nigeria. It's no longer a home-grown idiom, made by and for country folks; it's a recognized, exportable musical style. Paradoxically, it seems that the farther country travels, the more resonant it becomes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article May 10 about the Westchester Jewish Community Services Divorce Counseling Program misidentified the district supervisor at the program's Hartsdale office. She is Edythe Kurz.

title: MY MOTHER THE CLAIRVOYANT
description: THE FORTUNE TELLER By Marsha Norman. 387 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; NEW ROCHELLE
description: ''I REMEMBER, when I was 15, in the middle of World War II, I would ride up to New Rochelle on my bike,'' said Cynthia Ozick, who grew up nearby in the northeast Bronx. ''Because of gas rationing there were very few cars. I would ride right down the middle and look at the houses behind the picket fences and smell the flowers and the blossoming trees. I felt as if I owned the road.''

title: HELPING ADULT STUDENTS PAY FOR COLLEGE
description: ALMOST 27 years after graduating from high school, Adrienne James entered college as a part-time student. She financed her education at New York University with an amalgam of loans, grants and scholarships. ''Every way that I could, I got money,'' Ms. James said. The 51-year-old New Yorker, who just received a bachelor's degree in literary studies, estimates that she paid out of pocket only a few hundred dollars of each semester's $2,000 tuition bill.

title: Data Bank: May 24, 1987
The Palestinian Campus
description: In her article ''The Palestinian Campus'' (April 19), Lisa Wolfe comments several times on the ''basic academic freedoms'' that the Israeli Government bestows on Bir Zeit University. An incident on April 13 gives an example of the privileged existence that Bir Zeit students enjoy. Students were marching in protest of the killing of a boy in Ramallah when Israeli soldiers arrived to stop the march. They shot four students and declared that the school would be closed for four months.

title: HOME VIDEO: HOW-TO
description: Decks Home Improvement Series. DIY Video Corporation, 5250 Seventy-Seven Center Drive, Charlotte, N.C. 28217. 30 minutes. $19.95.

title: PRAISED DRAMAS FROM STATE
description: WHILE London may be the source of Broadway's biggest hit musicals, it is Connecticut that has supplied the New York theater season's most acclaimed dramatic offerings - new and old.

title: BOSTON U. MAY END SCHOOL OF NURSING
description: At a time when hospitals in the Boston area urgently need more nurses, Boston University has announced that its School of Nursing is likely to close next fall because of a shortage of students.

title: Q/and A
description: Hong Kong Dining

title: Jazz Archive
description: PIANO LEGENDS Chick Corea, host. Produced, directed and written by Burrill Crohn. Co-producer, David Chertok. Video Artists International. 63 minutes. $39.95.

title: PRESIDENT'S CREDABILITY ON AID TO CONTRAS FALLS TO 24% IN POLL
description: Only one American in four says President Reagan is telling the truth when he denies knowing that money from arms sales to Iran went to help the Nicaraguan rebels, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: BUS SYSTEM GETS A NAME AND A LOGO
description: LEAD: ADDRESSING what its officials concede is ''an identity problem,'' the county's Transportation Department has initiated a campaign designed to heighten public awareness of its bus system and increase ridership. As part of the effort, the system has been given a name, the ''Bee Line,'' and a matching symbol, a smiling bee in flight.

title: WAR STORIES MY FATHER TOLD ME: THE BEE
description: I AM the son of a soldier. I was born and raised on war stories. The best were repeated time and again, until they became so familiar that my brother and I practically had them numbered and categorized, and my mother was able to correct them for certain inaccuracies or exaggerations that slipped in with the passage of time.

title: Fordham University
description: Fordham University awarded 3,000 undergraduate and graduate degrees at yesterday's commencement exercises. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York spoke to the graduates and their families at the ceremony held on the Bronx campus.

title: Correction
description: A map May 10 accompanying an article about Ontario reversed the identifications of Lake Michigan and Lake Superior.

title: JOE PUTS NIEKROS IN RECORD BOOK
description: Joe Niekro won the 216th game of his major league career tonight, and it might have been more special than any of the others: It put the Yankee pitcher and his 48-year-old brother Phil into the baseball record book.

title:
GARDENING;
A SHORT CUT TO WEEDING
description: LEAD: EVERY gardener has problems with weeds. No one relishes the sight of seedlings being strangled, or the task of pulling up unwanted plants week after week.

title: FUNDING FOR ARENA BACKED
description: WHAT was originally proposed as a $14.1 million sports complex at the University of Connecticut apparently will be built for almost twice that amount, to the chagrin of many state lawmakers.

title: SPARKLE ADDED TO L.I. WINE
description: ''WE'RE in the running as a world-class champagne region,'' said William Skolnik, managing director of Pindar Vineyards in Peconic.

title: A LA CARTE
description: IT is unfair to compare restaurant chains with individually owned and operated eating places. But some chain restaurants are worth recommending. Typical is J. B. Winberie in Great Neck (37 Cutter Mill Road, 482-2181).

title: HOW A GENIUS FUSED ADORNMENT AND MODERNITY
description: IT WAS LOUIS SULLIVAN'S SAD FATE not only to have been insufficiently appreciated in his time - he died in 1924, broke and without work - but also to have been misunderstood later on. For even when there was no doubt about his status as one of the greatest architects America has ever produced, Sullivan was too often thought of as having had one crucial flaw: he was a brilliant modern polemicist who filled his buildings with lavish ornament. A generation ago, Sullivan tended to be revered almost in spite of his ornament; though no scholar dared put it so crassly, there was a sense that Sullivan's tall buildings, like the Wainwright in St. Louis or the Guaranty in Buffalo, which were truly the beginning of the mature American skyscraper esthetic, would have been better still had they only been simpler, starker, free of so many curls and swirls.

title: DANCER DELVES INTO PIONEERS
description: LEAD: ANNABELLE GAMSON, a Rye Brook dancer and choreographer who recently received a Guggenheim Fellowship, said the award would give her an opportunity to continue the work she has begun.

title: HOSPITALS DISCUSS FITNESS AND ILLNESS
description: LEAD: GAIL BOMS had a backache, so she went to Danbury Hospital. But Mrs. Boms, a 34-year-old X-ray technician, was not admitted for tests or surgery. Instead, she attended a lecture on back pain by two orthopedic surgeons on the hospital staff.

title: WHT IT'S LIKE TO BE A CHILD
description: A GOOD ENOUGH PARENT A Book on Child-Rearing. By Bruno Bettelheim. 377 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: EGYPT WINS PACT ON DEBT PAYMENT
description: Egypt has received a boost in its struggle to cope with its economic problems, in the form of a long-sought debt rescheduling by the Paris Club of Western creditor nations.

title: COST TO CLEAN UP PCB'S IN HUDSON IS RISING
description: The cost of New York's long-delayed plan to clean up PCB contamination in the Hudson River by dredging its bed has risen to $40 million, up from previous estimates of $27.6 million, the State Department of Environmental Conservation said.

title: FOSTER PARENTS ARE HONORED
description: LEAD: THE issues that foster children bring to family therapy are: Do I really belong? If I really have a problem, will I be sent back? Do I have roots here? Have you invested in me? ''With a birth child, these questions do not come up,'' Barbara Kenyon of Flemington said in an interview. Currently a foster mother, she was once a foster child herself.

title: Another Mideast Conference Is Crucial
description: In his book ''Years of Upheaval,'' Henry A. Kissinger wrote:

title: Hungarian Academy Gives New Party Plan an 'F'
description: The Communist Party leadership suffered a painful setback this week when the Academy of Sciences turned down the draft of a program intended to lead Hungary out of economic crisis toward long-term economic and social development.

title: TURNING KIDS OFF DRUGS
description: PAULA HAS BEEN A PROSTI-tute. She has stood on street corners hawking cocaine just to be able to afford it herself. She has been a vagabond, a truant and a criminal, but in her 15 years she has barely been a child .

title: THE JEWS, THE FRENCH AND THE NAZIS
description: THE BURDEN OF CONSCIENCE French Jewish Leadership During the Holocaust. By Richard I. Cohen. Illustrated. 237 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $27.50.

title: Janet Thompson Married To Rev. Edward H. Heim
description: Janet S. Thompson and the Rev. Edward H. Heim were married yesterday at Advent Lutheran Church in Fort Lee, N.J., by the Rev. Paul A. Hagedorn.

title: New Mexico
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from two months at Fort Union National Monument (I was working for the National Park Service, through their volunteer-in-the-parks program), I was excited to see ''In New Mexico, the Other Las Vegas'' (Travel, April 12). Fort Union is near Las Vegas and, as the article suggests, is well worth a visit.

title: Olwen Weatherhead Weds David Modell
description: The marriage of Olwen Ebright Weatherhead, a lawyer, and David Orrick Modell, director of marketing for the Cleveland Browns football team, took place yesterday in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Martha Shiverick, sister of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Fairmount Presbyterian Church. She was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Henry W. Anderson.

title: SOVIET THEATER GROUP SAMPLES PLAYS AND PIZZA
description: LIKE millions of other tourists, they saw ''A Chorus Line,'' went to the top of the Empire State Building, toured the Metropolitan Museum of Art and ate at culinary meccas that ranged from Chinatown to John's Pizzeria in Greenwich Village.

title: 6 SOVIET JEWS TO STUDY FOR RABBINATE IN U.S.AND THEN RETURN
description: Six young Soviet Jews will be allowed to study for the rabbinate in the United States with the understanding that they will return to lead Soviet synagogues, according to the head of a delegation of Orthodox rabbis who returned last week from the Soviet Union.

title:
GARDEING;
SITE ANALYSIS TO PREVENT PLANT FAILURE
description: LEAD: MANY planting failures result from site problems. Some, though nonexistent when the planting was made, may nevertheless have developed during the intervening years. Others may have existed before planting. In either case, replacement plantings have all too frequently been made without first having ascertained the cause of the problem and having taken steps to remedy it.

title: FORGOTTEN BLACK UNION SOLDIERS REMEMBERED
description: LEAD: THERE will be no formal Memorial Day services tomorrow for the blacks who fought with the Union forces in the Civil War and whose remains rest in what, for more than 170 years, has been known in this historic Cumberland County village as the ''Ambury Hill Colored Burying Ground.''

title: CREW LAUNCHES SOJOURNER TRUTH
description: GERHARD RANDERS-PEHRSON, a 43-year-old nuclear physicist, arrived late at his Irvington laboratory one morning earlier this month - the same morning Bob Walters was late reaching his New Rochelle window business.

title: CAPUTO LOOKING TO PRIMARY
description: MICHAEL A. LoGRANDE, the Acting Suffolk County Executive, won the overwhelming support of the Suffolk Republican organization last week for nomination to a full four-year term as County Executive.

title: Shaking Up Sloan-Kettering
description: Philip Boffey's article brought back memories to me, the first physician on the new Sloan-Kettering payroll, when Dr. Cornelius Packard Rhoads became the institute's director in 1945. ''We're ready for the next quantum jump in terms of being effective against cancer,'' which Dr. Marks is quoted as saying, echoes what Dr. Rhoads announced 42 years ago. Then, it was the new approach of considering cancer a metabolic, systemic disease. Later, there came the utopian promise of cancer chemotherapy. But real progress has been far less spectacular than that hoped for two generations ago.

title: Philadelphia and Denver Winnow Mayoral Aspirants
description: W. Wilson Goode and Frank L. Rizzo will be opposing each other at the polls for the second time this fall, since Philadelphians gave them equally impressive primary victories last week.

title: Citicorp Allots $3 Billion to Cover Third World Debts
description: For the first time, a big American bank has acknowledged what many people thought was obvious: that some developing countries are not going to pay back all the money they owe.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended May 9 MANHATTAN Chelsea $195,000 155 West 15th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. loft co-op in a renovated prewar building; high-ceilings, private outdoor garden, maintenance $366, 68% tax-deductible (Broker: Debra Kameros Co.) Gottesman Company, Inc.) title: Drug Prosecution Of Ferraro's Son
description: FROM the outset, the defense argued that John A. Zaccaro Jr., a 22-year-old senior at Middlebury College in Vermont, was being singled out for prosecution on narcotics charges because of the prominence of his mother, Geraldine A. Ferraro, the 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee.

title: AIDS FEARED AS OCCUPATIONAL HAZARD
description: FEDERAL officials said there was no reason for alarm when the Government last week reported three cases of health care workers infected with the AIDS virus after brief exposure to the blood of infected patients. The cases, they said, underscored the need for strict adherence to infection-control procedures previously issued by the Government.

title: High Cost of Maintaining the Global Status Quo
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATURE WATCH 
BLACK-THROATED BLUE WARBLER
description: LEAD: Dendroica caerulescens Size: 4 1/2 to 5 1/2 inches.

title: NOW, A CAUCUS FOR L.I. SOUND
description: LONG ISLAND SOUND serves many masters who have a hard time working together.

title: DEVICES TO PROTECT CAR STEREOS
description: CAR STEREOS ARE A NO-torious incitement to crime. In many cities, a car parked overnight at the curb is likely to have its radio removed, with incidental damage to doors and dashboard. Even broad daylight offers little protection in some neighborhoods.

title: Paying It Back
description: AT a time when some college athletes have apparently been looking to supplement their athletic scholarships by taking money from agents and college boosters, Tracy Ham, a quarterback who led Georgia Southern to two Division I-AA championships, has decided that his scholarship was more than enough compensation for his four years of playing football. After rejecting a tryout with the Los Angeles Rams and signing with the Edmonton Eskimos of the Canadian Football League, Ham said he planned to use part of his salary to repay the school for his scholarship.

title: NEIGHBORS RISE IN VETERANS' GROUPS
description: THREE residents of Windham are gaining prominence as leaders of the largest veterans' groups in the state.

title: THE BOOM IN POLITICAL CONSULTING
description: SCOTT MILLER proudly displayed his company's new headquarters on 60th Street just off Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, and the contrast with days past could not have been more striking. Where once the Sawyer/Miller Group Inc.'s 30 employees had toiled in cramped, windowless rooms, the new offices - replete with sleek black furniture and fresh maroon carpeting -abound with light, space and air.
