title: IN NEW JERSEY, A GROWING SENTIMENT FOR LIMITING GROWTH
description: THE old roads that wind through the tree-lined villages and small farmsteads of central New Jersey are still marked as scenic routes on some maps, but with the growth of the area in recent years, the principal view seems to consist of the bumper and brake lights of the car in front.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday on advertisments on Connecticut Transit buses to promote condoms in preventing AIDS misattributed remarks describing the bus system's initial objections to the ads.

title: GOOD ECONOMIC NEWS, BUT WILL IT CONTINUE?
description: The economy grew at a 4.4 percent annual rate in the first quarter, better than the previous estimate of 4.3 percent, and far better than the 1.1 percent rate of the fourth quarter of 1986. But most analysts say they expect smaller increases for the rest of the year, with a final growth rate for 1987 of around 4 percent. . . . Consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the same as in February and March. Food and energy costs rose, as did the costs of imports in light of the lower dollar. . . . Durable goods orders rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in April, extending the weakness there. . . . New home construction dropped 2.9 percent in April, mainly because few new apartment buildings are being built. . . . Industry operated at 78.9 percent of capacity in April, down from 79.3 percent. * * *

title: Holly McHale, a Nurse, Weds Jonathan Biggins
description: Holly Jean McHale, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. McHale of Greenwich, Conn., and St. John's Island, Fla., and Jonathan Thomas Biggins, a son of Mrs. Robert A. Biggins of Wayne, Pa., and the late Mr. Biggins, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael in Greenwich by Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan. Amy G. McHale was her sister's maid of honor, and David J. Biggins was his brother's best man.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Tinmouth, Vt.;
Preserving The Pastures
description: LEAD: EDWIN BAKER, a dairyman here, had more reason than most to be alarmed when a helicopter carrying real-estate developers was seen circling over the old Dunn farm last summer.

title: PRESIDENTIAL SCHOLARS NAMED
description: One hundred forty high school seniors have been chosen 1987 Presidential Scholars, Education Secretary William J. Bennett announced this week.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SIMONE DE BEAUVOIR: A Life . . . a Love Story. By Claude Francis and Fernande Gontier. Translated by Lisa Nesselson. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) This is a lucid, appealingly human account of the life of the French feminist and lover of Jean-Paul Sartre. The authors, Claude Francis and Fernande Gontier, who have written critical works on Simone de Beauvoir, Proust and others, found their point of departure in the more than 1,400 pages of love letters from de Beauvoir to the Chicago writer Nelson Algren. The romance of this mismatched pair is one of the narrative highlights of the volume -the usually somber de Beauvoir calls her American friend ''blond husband,'' ''dear Crocodile'' and ''Brute from nowhere.'' Indeed, there is a joie de vivre about this book, fluently translated by Lisa Nesselson, that explains why it might have been a lot of fun to be an existentialist. Even political disputes have a racy air here: when de Beauvoir published Volume One of ''The Second Sex'' in 1949, Francois Mauriac wrote to a staffer at the review Les Temps Modernes, founded by Sartre and de Beauvoir four years earlier, ''I've learned all there is to know about your boss's vagina.'' Everything about de Beauvoir's life was vehement, beginning with an early infatuation with religion that led her to lock herself ''in the bathroom, where she mortified her flesh by . . . whipping herself with a gold necklace until she drew blood.'' Later on, she had to win Sartre's attentions from Simone Jollivet, an aspiring actress who ''liked to receive her admirers in the nude, standing before the fireplace, her long blonde hair cascading onto her shoulders, reading Michelet's 'History of the French Revolution.' '' The present book vividly captures some of the intellectual and emotional hyperactivity of Sartre and de Beauvoir.

title: High Court Gives Civil Rights Law A Broader Scope
description: The Supreme Court held last week that a Reconstruction-era law designed to prevent and redress discrimination against blacks is not limited to them. The two unanimous decisions involved Jewish and Arab-American plaintiffs, but the Court said the law applied to any people subjected to intentional discrimination because of ''their ancestry or ethnic characteristics.''

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Lots of Lively Things At the Museum The Museum Shop at the Neuberger Museum, on the campus of the State University of New York at Purchase, stocks its own and other museums' books and catalogues on the visual arts for visitors and students, plus art periodicals, posters, note cards, jewelry, gifts and children's books, inexpensive and creative toys and art materials.

title: 9 Years Late, Reactor Is Activated Upstate
description: Officials at the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant triggered the plant's first nuclear reaction today. They said the plant, which is nine years behind schedule, will be tested for two months before generating electricity.

title: WAS HEAD OF TESTING SERVICE
description: William W. Turnbull, who was president of the Educational Testing Service in a period of ferment over its role and influence, died of heart failure Thursday during heart bypass surgery at Presbyterian Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 67 years old and was a resident of Princeton, N.J.

title: CURTAIN UP FOR A NEW CAST OF PRODUCERS
description: ''YOU HAVE TO BE PASSION-ate,'' says Rocco Landesman, reflecting on the status of his peers, the younger generation of independent theatrical producers. ''Getting a show on is such an overwhelming task that unless you can't live without doing it, you'll never get it done.'' While today's emerging producers are as determined as any who came before them, they frequently must fight harder and more imaginatively to bring new plays to an often beleaguered commercial stage, where it can be difficult to build the foundation for an enduring career.

title: A Fee, Not a Ban, on Audio Progress
description: Ever heard of digital audio tape recordings? Most people haven't, and never will if the recorded music industry has its way. Music makers acknowledge the spectacular potential of this new technology, but argue that its unconstrained use poses a ''unique threat'' to their industry. They want Congress to require manufacturers to add a computer chip that would prevent owners of digital recorders from copying compact disc recordings.

title: Outdoors; Guide Invaluable On Trip for Trout
description: FIFTEEN rainbows, and only one keeper. Matt Charlevoix thought the fishing had been pretty bad.

title: VACATION-CAR RENTAL RATES CUT
description: To try to capture a larger portion of the leisure market, car rental companies have been reducing weekly rates in some popular vacation destinations.

title: Albany Notes; CUOMO AIDE WILL REGIGN POSITION
description: Martin Steadman, Governor Cuomo's chief spokesman and one of his closest advisers, will leave the administration early in July. Administration officials said his replacement was expected to be Gary Fryer, who is second in command of the press office.

title: A University Must Not Be a Partner in Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDEING;
SITE ANALYSIS TO PREVENT PLANT FAILURE
description: LEAD: MANY planting failures result from site problems. Some, though nonexistent when the planting was made, may nevertheless have developed during the intervening years. Others may have existed before planting. In either case, replacement plantings have all too frequently been made without first having ascertained the cause of the problem and having taken steps to remedy it.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THINGS ARE BUSTLING IN LAMBERTVILLE
description: LEAD: FIVE days a week, except in the summer, this Hunterdon County community along the Delaware River clings to much of the pace of its 19th-century roots.

title: TENANTS RESIST PLAN TO EVICT THEIR DOGS
description: LEAD: MYRNA DELGADO'S dog is half Chihuahua and half poodle, but its bark is so ferocious she is sure no burglar would enter her apartment in the Pinnacle Heights housing project in New Britain.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
TO THE MANY WHO GAVE THEIR LIVES: THANK YOU
description: LEAD: I LOVE a Memorial Day parade as well as the next fellow and I, too, get a catch in my throat at the sound of a brass band and the sight of Old Glory whipping in the breeze.

title: SCIONS AND SORROWS
description: SKINNY ISLAND More Tales of Manhattan. By Louis Auchincloss. 230 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
CANADA'S NEW MINTAGE ENTERS THE DOLLAR FIELD
description: LEAD: THE Royal Canadian Mint has started producing its new, smaller $1 coin. It hopes to have 100 million pieces available by early July. Deliveries to banks are scheduled for next month and first examples should reach circulation about July 1.

title: AFTER A TWISTER: COPING IN TOWN THAT ISN'T THERE
description: Under rainy, funereal skies, dazed residents of this tiny West Texas town trickled back to a community that barely exists after a devastating tornado Friday night.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article May 17 about Yorktown's Indian Hill incorrectly identified the Town Historian, Doris E. Auser, and an inaccurate publication date was given for Robert Bolton Jr.'s ''History of the County of Westchester,'' which was printed in 1848.

title: SQUATTER INVASION DECLINES IN BRAZIL
description: As barbed-wire fences rapidly seal off undeveloped properties throughout this huge city, only a few hundred wooden shacks and concrete-block houses hurriedly built on muddy hillsides still stand as testimony to the largest urban squatter movement in Brazilian history.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE PERFECT WAR: Technowar in Vietnam. By James William Gibson. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.95.) Early in this argumentative book, the author writes: ''If you are setting up an ambush, you must first pick a place where men are likely to walk. . . . You then position your mines and grenades and automatic weapons to achieve overlapping or intersecting 'fields of fire.' '' In a literary sense, that is what James William Gibson, a sociologist at Southern Methodist University, has done. Then he shoots with abandon at liberals and conservatives, hawks and doves, soldiers and scholars alike for their analyses of how America got into Vietnam, the way the war was fought and why the United States lost. Few escape his criticism for practicing ''mechanistic anticommunism'' and ''Technowar,'' which he calls the ''production model of war,'' in that combat is managed like an automobile assembly line. Moreover, Mr. Gibson fears that the ''Vietnam syndrome,'' which curtailed the application of American military power after Vietnam, has really evaporated; thus, he says, the United States is preparing for a war in Central America in which the ''redeployment of Technowar can only result in another massive defeat.'' With all that, the book leaves one unsatisfied. The reader knows what the author is against but not much about what he advocates, beyond a plea that Americans understand how they became ''entrapped'' in Vietnam. ''And with such understanding,'' he concludes, ''changing the war system and mythology, and creating a more complex, humane, vision of the world, become compelling obligations.''

title: MOREL CONQUESTS
description: ''THE INORDINATE APPETITE for mushrooms is considered to be a French disease,'' observed an anonymous author in the 17th century. The same statement could be made about Americans in the 20th century, who recently seem to have developed their own inordinate appetite for all kinds of wild mushrooms, partly because improved modern shipping allows cooks to use such exotic produce within hours of its being picked.

title: More Indictments In School Scandal
description: A decade-old alleged bribery conspiracy among public school maintenance employees was further unraveled last week with the indictment of nine supervisors and inspectors.

title: THE CONSTITUTION'S 200 YEARS HAILED WHERE IT ALL STARTED
description: In a happy, sometimes boisterous celebration of the United States' chancy, uncertain origins and its present-day power and unity, the major phase of the Constitution's bicentennial got off to a rousing start Friday night and today.

title: THE LEGACY OF ALYDAR HEADS FOR BIGGEST TEST
description: IMAGINE Alydar if there had been no Affirmed.

title: NEW WAY TO GAUGE FETAL HEATLH
description: LEAD: SOON after learning she was pregnant, Susan, who is 35 years old, made an appointment for an amniocentesis to check her developing fetus for Down's syndrome and other genetic abnormalities associated with older maternal age.

title: RARE CONDITINS MAY BE FACTOR IN TEXAS TORNADO
description: The tornado that destroyed much of the West Texas town of Saragosa Friday evening developed under classic conditions for breeding tornadoes and may have formed within a rare, longlasting type of thunderstorm, according to Donald Wernly, chief of the Warning and Forecast Branch of the National Weather Service in Maryland.

title: HOPE AND HELP FOR CHILDREN IN PAIN
description: LEAD: On a pleasant tree-shaded street here is the state's only rehabilitation center dedicated solely to helping disabled children from birth through adolescence.

title: RHUBARB CAN BE USED IN DISHES AS THE VEGETABLE IT IS
description: SPRING is the season for rhubarb, a vegetable that is usually used as a fruit. For that reason in Colonial days it was known as pie plant.

title: THE LEGACYOF MISS ALBERTINA BLOOM, TEACHER AND BENEFACTOR
description: ALBERTINA BLOOM, of course, never thought of herself as a little person, although she was not very tall. Nor did the people who knew her, including her students - especially her students. To them she was a giant because of what she gave them - concern, encouragement, inspiration, love.

title: RELIGIONS MERGED IN LOVE
description: WE were married in October and the first ''Happy Hanukkah'' card arrived in mid-December. I can still remember opening the envelope and staring at the card for quite some time. So many thoughts crossed my mind. ''They're trying to convert me,'' I remember thinking. ''They'll never accept me. . . .what the heck is Hanukkah, anyway?'' And so began my silent revolution.

title: IN PRAISE OF BLACK-AND-WHITE PRINTS
description: I suppose I should admit it: I shoot more black-and-white film than I do color. This makes me a bit of a dinosaur, since 95 percent of the pictures now taken in the United States are color pictures. But despite color's universal appeal, there remain a few diehards to whom the tones of black and white are as beautiful as any colors.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DANCING ON CORAL. By Glenda Adams. (Viking, $16.95.) Lark Watter is an unintentionally disagreeable heroine, and that's not good news. A scheming, kvetching twit with an opinion about everything, Lark longs for life away from her native Sydney and gets her wish. After her boyfriend immigrates to the United States, she makes two friends at the university: the wealthy Donna Bird, daughter of a Columbia University art professor, and Tom Brown, a political activist. When Tom returns to Columbia, Lark and Donna (rivals for his affection) hop a United States-bound freighter loaded with the professor's secret booty: smuggled art. En route, Lark abandons Donna on a remote Pacific island, thus clearing the way for her romance with Tom. But Lark's plans are sabotaged by two unforeseen factors: Tom's devotion to the 60's intellectual radical movement around Columbia and Donna's sudden, melodramatic return. Lark maneuvers her way out of the second obstacle but faces a more difficult challenge in accepting Tom's life. In her first novel to be published in this country, the Australian novelist Glenda Adams attempts to impose a satire of 1960's political cliches on the story of Lark's coming of age - and meets with little success. The two simply do not mix, and despite her lampoon of public ''happenings'' and open marriage, ''Dancing on Coral'' seems more like a novel of the 50's than the 60's. It fares best in its Australian setting, where the author demonstrates a firm grasp of provincial life, nicely evoking her homeland and even showing a gift for nuance. But Lark's shrillness is unremitting and builds to a high pitch whenever the United States meets with her disapproval. When she herself has so little regard for the new life she has created, it is hard to expect readers to care.

title: Plan to Bury Nuclear Waste Byproducts Is Blocked
description: A Government plan to bury a nuclear waste byproduct 30 miles southeast of here will be blocked for at least two years under a court settlement between a citizens' group and the Federal Energy Department.

title: Diane A. Oelsner Is Married
description: Diane Alexandra Oelsner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W.James Oelsner of St. Thomas, V.I., Centre Island, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Carter Todd Peyton Jenkins, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Peyton Jenkins of Richmond and Palm Beach. The Rev. Robert Bryan and the Rev. Ralph Warren performed the ceremony at Bethesda by the Sea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach.

title: PROPOSED BOAT-PAINT CURB DEBATED
description: CRITICS of a Congressional proposal to prohibit the use of tin-based paints by pleasure-craft owners, but not the sale of such paints, say the ban would be virtually impossible to monitor.

title: SUMMER ESSENTIALS
description: MEN THINK first about how they look, then they worry about how they feel,'' says Richard Lane, a proprietor of Latham House, the Manhattan and Long Island clothier. Mr. Lane, who makes it his business to know such things, may be right in predicting that, come summer, men will opt increasingly for elegance over comfort, regardless of how high the mercury soars.

title: CHURCH AND STATE TUSSLE OVER THE GUARDIANSHIP OF RELIGIOUS MASTERPIECES
description: TAKING CARE OF ALL the fine art piled up in this country is more than just a practical matter. It is a problem that involves the ways that Italians look at God and country, the rest of the world and themselves.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
ART;
SEVEN WAYS OF DEALING WITH GEOMETRY
description: LEAD: IF there is one factor with the potential to unify today's diverse means of artistic expression, it is geometry, the system that provides the structure for composition in two and three dimensions. It need not be evident in order to serve its purpose, which is to organize form, in whatever style or medium.

title: BROADTAIL REVISITED
description: BROADTAIL is one of the furs, like Persian lamb, enjoying a revival this season. Long considered a ''mature'' fur, it is being transformed into a youthful style by various designers.

title: THE SOVIET MISSILE STRATEGY MAKES THE FRENCH NERVOUS
description: GIVEN France's general coolness toward NATO, it is not usual for a French Prime Minister to suffer diplomatic abuse for something the Atlantic Alliance might do. But that is what happened on Prime Minister Jacques Chirac's visit to Moscow, which ended last weekend. Mr. Chirac was publicly upbraided for being the West's strongest critic of the Kremlin's plan to eliminate Soviet and American short-and medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe, even though France has no such missiles on its own soil and is not part of NATO's integrated military command.

title: Matching Funds for Kemp
description: The Federal Election Commission says Representative Jack F. Kemp, Republican of upstate New York, will receive Federal matching funds for his 1988 Presidential race. Matching funds are disbursed to candidates in the primaries who agree to abide by Federal spending limits for each state and who raise $100,000 in 20 states in contributions of $250 or less. Mr. Kemp, who declared his candidacy for the Republican nomination last month, has not yet had to file a disclosure statement showing his receipts and expenditures.

title: BLACK CATHOLICS SEEK LARGER ROLE
description: Fifteen hundred black Roman Catholic leaders gathered here this weekend to let the wider church know, through gospel singing, hand clapping and calls to action, that black traditions must become a more valued part of Catholic worship.

title: SHORTAGE OF LIFEGUARDS MAY WORSEN
description: THE lifeguard is an endangered species. So say waterfront directors and swimming-pool operators who have been hard-pressed to fill positions in time for this Memorial Day weekend, the official opening of many beaches and pools in the area.

title: Maple Syrup Season Is Worst in 16 Years
description: New England maple trees yielded only 355,000 gallons of syrup this year, making 1987 the worst season in 16 years and driving prices up to an average of $33.15 a gallon.

title: California Gives Boost to Methanol
description: California, which led the country in requiring stringent smog controls for automobiles in the 1960's, has taken another big step toward cleaning up its polluted air. In what environmentalists hope will prove the impetus for a nationwide movement, state officials said last week that they would promote the replacement of gasoline with methanol, a form of alcohol that is abundant and less polluting.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TWAIN'S SOUVENIRS When Mark Twain and his Hartford neighbor, Harriet Beecher Stowe, traveled abroad, they bought the tourist souvenirs now on exhibit in the basement gallery of the Twain House at 77 Forest Avenue. The exhibition is a collection of some 40 items picked up around the world by Twains and his family, the Stowes and their relatives, the Beechers and the Days, all of whom inhabited Nook Farm, as the compound was called, and by Charles Dudley Warner, Twain's collaborator on the writing of ''The Gilded Age.''

title: The Price of Leadership
description: When members of the New York City Council voted recently to increase the salaries of other top New York City officials, they couldn't resist throwing in a hefty raise for themselves. Do they deserve it? The basic salary of a City Council member is now $47,500. But the true pay adds up to thousands more. Of the Council's 35 members, 30 receive extra stipends ranging from $2,500 up to $30,000, based on committee and other leadership duties. The raises, which go into effect July 1, will boost base pay to $55,000, a hefty sum for what is still considered a part-time job. A council that aspired to statesmanship would accompany the raise with a move to limit the extra stipends.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''While we may not be in a recession, the economy is not very buoyant.''

title: SIX STARS CONTRIBUTE TO A VICTORY
description: THE International Team Trials in Memphis a week ago generated much excitement and some deja vu. The scenario closely resembled the 1985 trials in the same location, for victory went to the same team of six stars: Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., Lew Stansby, Castro Valley, Calif., Peter Pender, Forestville, Calif., Hugh Ross, Oakland, Calif., Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman, both of Dallas. They will now represent the United States in Bermuda Bowl competition in Jamaica in October and will be strongly favored to retain the world title they won in Sao Paulo in 1985.

title: 'FALLING AWAY': A MOTHER'S STRENGTH
description: After tearfully reading ''Falling Away, Here at Home'' [ Opinion Page, April 26 ] , I wanted Julia Aldrich to know how her strength, courage and quiet words touched me and, I am sure, many other readers.

title: PRUNE NOW FOR NEXT SPRING'S BLOOM
description: THIS is the time to keep pruning shears out. Shrubs that have been established for some time become too large for their spaces and should be disciplined by cutting them back. Cut back to near ground level and do not leave ugly stubs. This type of rejuvenation done promptly will invigorate shrubs and allow them sufficient time to form flowers for next spring. If this task is delayed, new buds do not form and the gardener may wonder why there are no shrub flowers next spring. If soil temperature has warmed above 60 degrees, then it is safe to set out seedlings of tomatoes, peppers, eggplants and to seed rows of pole, snap and lima beans, melons and summer squash. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS CRABAPPLES

title: DANCE: ALL ABOUT CASTANETS
description: THE history and musical range of the castanet may not sound like the most exciting of subjects. But the Matteo EthnoAmerican Dance Theater's ''Castanets in Concert,'' pre-sented on Thursday at the American Museum of Natural History, offered an informative and highly entertaining look at that ancient instrument.

title:
FOCUS: NASHVILLE;
A Center Revivifies Downtown
description: LEAD: AN excavation popularly known as the ''black hole of Broadway'' during 10 years of citywide arguments over what to build there has become the center of downtown redevelopment.

title: PERMIT FOR HOME ON ISLET RESTUDIED AFTER 'GLITCH'
description: LEAD: FOR now, several ospreys will continue to be the sole inhabitants of Gid's Island in Orient. Pressure from local environmentalists and officials prompted the State Department of Environmental Conservation to reconsider its decision to approve a development permit for the eight-acre island, and the permit, which was issued in February, could be suspended by the end of this month.

title: Data Update
description: MEDIAN HOUSE PRICES

title: U.S. ELECTIONS GOT MORE FOREIGN CASH
description: Political action committees formed by foreign-owned companies contributed $2.3 million to 1986 Congressional campaigns, according to a study by the Congressional Research Service of the Library of Congress.

title: VISTORS JAM THE CITY'S SIDEWALKS - AND CASH REGISTORS
description: THE continued decline of the dollar may be causing shudders on Wall Street, but in the hotels, restaurants and tourist attractions of Midtown Manhattan it is a source of joy. New York City, while seeming to be ever more expensive for its own residents, is becoming something of a bargain for foreign visitors, and they are flocking here in near-record numbers.

title: Evansville Diet: 640 Pounds Off
description: FOLLOWING a regimen described as a diet of ''low calorie hay'' and exercise, Bunny, an elephant at the city zoo in Evansville, Ind., was reported to have lost 640 pounds.

title: BANNISTER HUMBLES RED SOX ON 2-HITTER
description: Floyd Bannister retired the first 17 batters en route to a two-hitter, ending a personal 11-game losing streak against Boston as the Chicago White Sox scored a 9-1 victory over the Red Sox today.

title: Anguilla
description: To the Editor: Each season we read with interest your Caribbean roundup. We would like to take this opportunity to call your attention to the Anguilla section on April 12, and to advise that the Government of Anguilla has established its own Tourist Information Office for the United States and Ontario. The address of the center, on Long Island, is 1208 Washington Drive, Centerport, N.Y. 11721, and the telephone numbers are 212-869-0402 and 516-673-0150.

title: Joan O'Sullivan Becomes a Bride
description: Joan O'Sullivan, a human resources manager at Citibank in New York, and Stacy Norman Coggins 2d, a consultant and training manager for the Advanced Business Institute at the International Business Machines Corporation in Rye Brook, N.Y., were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Thomas Patrick Guinan and the Rev. Mark Andrew Connolly performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church.

title: SIHANOUK QUITS CAMBODIA RESISTANCE FOR YEAR
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, a leader of the anti-Vietnamese Cambodian resistance, has shaken the delicate balance of diplomacy in Indochina with a surprise one-year resignation.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: OEDIPUS ON ICE While some English teachers encourage exceptional students to become writers, others infuriate them into taking up writing as a revenge. Alfred Kazin describes his case in ''An Apple for My Teacher'' (Algonquin), edited by Louis D. Rubin Jr.

title: Bishop Finis Crutchfield, 70; A Methodist, Victim of AIDS
description: Biship Finis Crutchfield, a retired Methodist leader who helped AIDS victims, has died of the disease, his family said.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Wired; Javits Center, Electrified
description: Managers of New York's 13-month-old Javits Convention Center deserve credit for responding swiftly to disclosures of payroll discrepancies involving electricians who work on exhibits at the center.

title: IN FITNESS STAKES, WALKING FORGES AHEAD
description: Walking is making such tremendous strides these days as a fitness activity that just about everyone has been strolling through New York City to publicize America's latest exercise phenomenon.

title: A NEW STAND OVER CONTRAS
description: President Reagan's recent assertions that a Congressional ban on aid to the Nicaragua rebels in 1985 did not apply to his National Security Council or national security adviser directly contradict detailed statements to Congress in 1985 on how the Administration was complying with the law.

title: Kemp: Hidden Success
description: Quite right. Even indisputable, you could say of a line from a recent speech by Representative Jack F. Kemp, the New York Republican who is a contender for the Republican Presidential nomination:

title: Bridge: Play for Goldman Pairs Title Is the Highlight of Regionals
description: The traditional Goldman Pairs Championship was the focus of attention at the Eastern Regionals, played this weekend at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.

title: YANKEES 10, ANGELS 8
description: The manager took another deep sigh of relief as he began to undress. The afternoon had finally reached its conclusion after 10 unnerving innings, but Lou Piniella was still reliving its dramatic moments. ''I feel like I played,'' he said. The Yankees built an 8-2 lead and then watched it dissolve in the hands of four pitchers. The end came when Willie Randolph and Gary Ward delivered run-scoring singles off the California relief pitcher, Donnie Moore, giving the Yankees a 10-8 victory at Anaheim Stadium today.

title: Belgian Heads For U.S. Talks
description: Belgium's Prime Minister, Wilfried Martens, leaves for the United States Monday on a four-day mission centering on trade issues and Soviet nuclear arms proposals. He will meet with President Reagan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: Hamilton College
description: Gov. Michael N. Castle of Delaware was the featured speaker yesterday at commencement exercises at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y.

title: DEMAND FOR HOME LOANS FALLS
description: LEAD: The recent spurt in mortgage rates has thrown a damper on the overall demand for home loans in the past few weeks, leading industry officials to worry that many potential buyers will be squeezed out of the market if rates continue to rise.

title: DODGERS 8, METS 6
description: Instead of letting yesterday's 8-6 loss to Los Angeles plunge them into deeper dejection and despair, the struggling Mets should look at the positive lesson that came with the game: If the Dodgers could overcome their base-running buffoonery and win the game, there is hope for everybody, including the Mets.

title: HERMIONE GINGOLD, ENGLISH ACTRESS, DIES AT 89
description: Hermione Gingold, the irrepressible English-born comedienne whose tart, quick-witted repartee became her trademark, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 89 years old and lived on the East Side.

title: EFFORT TO BAR U.S. LAWYERS MADE IN SUIT AGAINST V.A.
description: Members of a Justice Department legal team who are defending the Veterans Administration in a lawsuit over its handling of claims may now also have to defend themselves against charges of professional misconduct.

title: Carol H. Buttenwieser Weds
description: Carol H. Buttenwieser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Buttenwieser of New York and North Salem, N.Y., and Dr. John R. Sharp, the son of Helen L. Sharp of Brookline, Mass., and Richard H. Rubin of Newton, Mass., were married yesterday. Rabbi Linda Henry Goodman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's paternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, in New York.

title: HOW TO TAKE THE FIRST STEP
description: Those interested in a walking program should try their local Y or walking club, or write to Sanka National Walking Week, 888 Seventh Avenue, Suite 2800, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title:
TENNIS;
GUARD IS CHANGING ON WORLD SCENE
description: LEAD: WHEN the tennis year began, the principal questions were: Will Boris Becker supplant Ivan Lendl? Can Steffi Graf seriously challenge Martina Navratilova? Five months later, there's an ironic answer to the first question and a startling answer to the second.

title: Penelope Stone Is Wed To Steven J. Campbell
description: Penelope Farrington Stone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Boething Stone of New York and Darien, Conn., and Steven Jeffrey Campbell, a son of James Mulford Campbell of Yellow Springs, Ohio, and Mrs. Robin Crane Wing of Readfield, Me., were married yesterday. The Rev. Susan J. Ingham, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the summit of Cadillac Mountain in Acadia National Park on Mount Desert Island in Maine.

title: DANCE: 'DON QUIXOTE'
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov's 1978 staging of ''Don Quixote'' returned to American Ballet Theater this weekend at the Metropolitan Opera House. If the major debuts in the season's first two performances are an indication of how spiritedly the ballet will be performed in the future, then new life has obviously been breathed into a so-called old warhorse.

title: DIM HOPES FOR SUMMIT TALKS
description: The seven-nation industrial summit conference that President Reagan will attend next month in Venice is likely to prove unusually modest in its achievements despite the long agenda of issues, analysts and officials report.

title: Amy M. Grabino Becomes a Bride
description: Amy Maude Grabino, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Grabino of New York and Orange, Conn., and James Kenneth Landau, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Burton Landau of Rydal, Pa., were married yesterday at the Pierre in New York, with Rabbis Balfour Brickner and Robert E. Goldburg and Cantor Ellen S. Math officiating.

title: A FIVE-YEAR PLAN TO ATTACK AIDS IS DRAFTED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: A panel appointed by Mayor Koch has drafted a broad, five-year plan to combat the AIDS epidemic by expanding care for the sick, promoting research and seeking to prevent the spread of the deadly disease.

title: TV: CHANNEL 13 SHOWS 'HOUSE OF BLUE LEAVES'
description: Television has been doing exceptionally well by stage plays recently. There have been first-rate adaptations of Hugh Whitemore's ''Pack of Lies'' and Simon Gray's ''Quartermaine's Terms.'' Now, at 9 o'clock tonight on Channel 13, there is John Guare's ''House of Blue Leaves'' in the Lincoln Center Theater production that won several Tony Awards last year and moved to Broadway. This television version, directed by Kirk Browning, was taped in January at a regular performance in the Plymouth Theater.

title: NEW YORK BUSINESSES PRESSURED BY REQUIRMENTS OF NEW IMMIGRATION LAW
description: The nation's new immigration law is placing added burdens on business people in the New York City region.

title: CHILD WELFARE UNIT PLANS TO URGE A BAN ON SURROGACY PACTS
description: A national organization of family and child welfare agencies plans to recommend the elimination of surrogate parenting contracts and payments to surrogate mothers, according to senior members of the group.

title: EXPELLED ARTIST SEEKS PAINTING HELD BY THE K.G.B.
description: Among the artists with easels out on Fifth Avenue yesterday was one with an unusual sign: ''Hunger Strike: Day 15. K.G.B.: Return my 88 paintings, confiscated in Moscow on 8/5/82.''

title: Books of The Times; A Sailor's Journal
description: RACING THROUGH PARADISE: A Pacific Passage. By William F. Buckley Jr. Photographs by Christopher Little. 344 pages. Random House. $25.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You got to do what's honest and right and what the rules say. I told my team that people forget the scores of basketball games; they don't ever forget what you're made of.'' -Cleveland Stroud, coach at Rockdale County High School in Georgia. [ 1:3. ]

title: MORGAN FREEMAN LOOKS AT ACTING
description: Morgan Freeman just can't seem to be bad.

title: The Police Academy Needs More Space
description: New York City fields the nation's largest police department and ought to have the nation's best police training facility. Yet through recent massive rehiring, it has struggled along with a cramped, outmoded facility in Gramercy Park. Now a sound plan for a new facility is imperiled because Gramercy Park residents press to keep the Police Academy in their neighborhood.

title: LAKERS' WORTHY NOW PLAYING WELL
description: The nuances that make for the success or failure of a team are often rooted in actions that have little to do with conditioning, practice, or even skill. And they do not always occur between the time the athletes report for training camp and the end of their season. Sometimes, a reassuring conversation between two teammates during the off season can make the difference between months of conflict or months of contentment.

title: IN TERMS OF HIS WEALTH, DU PONT IS FRONT-RUNNER
description: Former Gov. Pierre S. du Pont 4th of Delaware is by far the wealthiest of the Presidential contenders, according to financial disclosure documents. He leads the Republican candidates with assets in excess of $6.3 million and probably greater than twice that much.

title: Polly Hoppin Married To Robert Thomas Jr.
description: The marriage of Polly Jacquelin Hoppin, a candidate for a doctorate in environmental and occupational health policy at the Johns Hopkins University School of Public Health, to Robert Mason Thomas Jr., an associate at the law firm of Covington & Burling in Washington, took place yesterday in Sherborn, Mass. The Rev. Christopher Leighton performed the Episcopal ceremony at the First Parish Church.

title: Dismembered Body Found
description: The dismembered body of an unidentified man was found in plastic garbage bags in front of Sandra's Restaurant at 5 St. Marks Place in the East Village yesterday afternoon, the police said. Three bags containing the body were found by the police at 3:15 P.M. after an anonymous call to 911 complained of an odor, said Sgt. Maurice Howard, a police spokesman. The body was removed to the Medical Examiner's Office where it was determined the victim, who was white, had suffered multiple stab wounds, officials said.

title: WEINBERGER URGES BASES IN GULF AREA FOR U.S. AIR PATROL
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf should provide bases and other support for aircraft that would patrol the waterway, protecting oil tankers and their naval escorts.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Since the National Basketball Association began play after World War II, has one city ever had the winners of hockey's Stanley Cup and the pro basketball championship in the same year?

title: Setting Salaries For Politicians: The Ruth Factor
description: Nearly 60 years ago, Babe Ruth was bargaining with the Yankees over the same $80,000 salary that a borough president now makes.

title: CALIFORNIA'S DARING THRIFT UNIT
description: Until it was acquired by Charles H. Keating Jr. early in 1984, the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., was a quiet little institution suffering like many others through a downturn in the traditional business of home lending.

title: Bail Bond Initiative
description: To the Editor:

title: Ousted Premier of Fiji Balks at a Compromise
description: Timoci Bavadra, who was deposed as Prime Minister in a coup 10 days ago, refused today to work with an interim Government backed by the military.

title: Pictures of Dead Young Men
description: It's been many years since old men in threadbare blue uniforms led the march down Main Street. Many years, too, since anyone wept for the soldier in the flag-markered grave, or spoke of the general whose statue broods over the park. To some Americans the flag of the Confederacy is simply something waved at football games; G.A.R. a forgotten abbreviation; the Civil War the stuff of fiction more than fact. Say ''Atlanta . . . Fort Sumter . . . Bull Run'' to many and the response is ''Rhett Butler! Scarlett O'Hara!'' Turn, though, to the photographs taken by Brady's and Gardner's ''operators'' as they trudged through the battlefields with their big cameras and their portable darkrooms - and the romantic legends become a terrible reality.

title: MUSIC: CAETANO VELOSO
description: Caetano Veloso started to shake up Brazilian music in the late 1960's, when he and some Bahian cohorts created the pushy, rock-tinged ''tropicalia'' style. At the time, tropicalia was seen as a rebellion against the cool, jazzy bossa nova. And in previous New York appearances with his band, Mr. Veloso has raised a celebratory ruckus. But lately, with solo albums and concerts like his sold-out performance Friday at Town Hall, Mr. Veloso has reaffirmed the continuity of Brazilian pop - songwriting that is sophisticated yet effortless-sounding, delicate yet deep.

title: CUOMO GIVES DUKAKIS TIP ON RUNNING
description: Governor Cuomo addressed 4,000 graduates of the University of Massachusetts today, and aside from a few choruses of ''Run! Run!'' that went up from one section of the audience, the tenor of the event suggested that he had convinced the public that he was not seeking the Democratic nomination for President.

title: EDDIE MONTECLARO
description: Eddie Monteclaro, editor in chief of The Manila Times, died of a heart attack Saturday, his newspaper reported today. He was 58 years old. Mr. Monteclaro, who was a Nieman Fellow at Harvard University in 1970-71, was president of the National Press Club in 1972 when martial law was declared by President Ferdinand E. Marcos. He challenged many Marcos decrees in the courts here before seeking political asylum in the United States, where he worked as an editor at The Chicago Sun-Times. He returned to the Philippines last year and became executive editor of The Manila Chronicle before taking over at The Manila Times.

title: Indian Sobriety Drive Begun
description: Estelle Fielder wants to reverse what she calls a national tragedy: alcoholism among Indians, who suffer alcohol-related deaths at a rate nearly five times that of other Americans.

title: A Troubled History at the Burned Foster-Care House in Queens
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy L. Stewart Wed to a Surgeon
description: Nancy Louise Stewart, an account executive for Doremus & Company, a New York-based advertising and public-relations agency, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Arthur Riehle Jr., an associate professor of surgery at the Cornell Medical College. The Rev. Frank M. Harron performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Paoli, Pa.

title: AL UNSER, PATIENT AND LUCKY, TAKES A 4TH INDIANAPOLIS 500
description: Al Unser Sr., a man without a car for the Indianapolis 500 until 11 days ago, today became the oldest driver to win America's greatest automobile race.

title: AT WELFARE HOTEL, PEDIATRIC CARE ON THE PREMISES
description: The narrow corridor on the second floor of the Prince George Hotel was crowded with young mothers holding babies in their arms and balancing other children on their laps. Some had appointments, but many others had simply shown up. They were all waiting to take their children into a place that exists in no other New York City welfare hotel: a medical clinic.

title: New York City's Inhuman Dimension
description: In November 1975, my oldest son was bar mitzvah in ''the near perfect symmetry'' of a 19th century architectural landmark. Mark's bar mitzvah took place a month after the renovations that transformed Gramercy Park's Friends Meeting House into the Brotherhood Synagogue were completed.

title: POSTSCRIPT ADDED TO RETIREES' CAREERS
description: For 15 students who graduated yesterday from the College of New Rochelle's lower Manhattan campus, there will be no panicking over job interviews or last-minute writing of resumes.

title: OFFICIALS SEEK MAJOR CHANGE IN TAXI POLICY
description: New York City is in the midst of a drive to regulate gypsy cabs and other nonmedallion vehicles, an effort officials say will enhance the industry's image and could make it easier to find a taxi - although not necessarily a yellow one.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch May 14 from Siegen, West Germany, on the war-crimes trial of Ernst August Konig misidentified the region in which Siegen is situated. It is in the Sauerland, not the Saarland.

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Personal Income April Wednesday Merchandise Trade Balance 1st qtr. Thursday None Friday Leading Indicators April Farm Prices May

title: EXECUTIVES
description: *Ameritrust Co. and its parent, Ameritrust Corp., Cleveland-based banking concerns, named Benjamin H. Paddock vice chairman and a director of both concerns. *Essex Corp., Alexandria, Va., a diversified professional services concern, named as its new president Robert B. Pirie Jr., who will continue as chief operating officer. *W. R. Grace & Co., engaged in chemicals, natural resources and consumer services, elected John P. McMillin president of its paper and mining division and a corporate vice president. He succeeds John Hirsch, who is retiring. *Home Group Inc., a property, casualty and life insurance company, appointed Hiram F. Moody Jr. president and chief executive of Home Capital Services Inc., its subsidiary specializing in asset management. *Manufacturers Hanover Corp. elected Albert R. Gamper Jr. chairman of its CIT Group subsidiary.

title: A 1,000-YEAR-OLD CULTURE WITH FEW TOMORROWS
description: On a chipped sheet of blackboard leaning against the cinnamon-colored dry-mud wall, Tian Rujun chalked the poem ''Seeking a Recluse in Vain,'' by the ninth-century poet Jia Dao: Let's ask the lad beneath the pine tree. He said: My master has gone to gather herbs. He is somewhere on this mountain, But so thick are the clouds, I know not the place.

title: Where Should the Third World Turn?
description: Citicorp's startling decision to write off $3 billion in third world loans has angered competitors with shallower pockets. Comparable write-offs, they argue, would cut sharply into their capital reserves and dash hopes for settlements that might permit additional loans to debtor nations. Yet if they don't follow Citicorp's lead, depositors and stockholders are likely to interpret their inaction as a sign of financial weakness.

title: Trinity College
description: Ceremonies in which 465 bachelor degrees and 30 master's degrees were awarded were held yesterday at Trinity College in Hartford. Chief Justice Ellen Ash Peters of the Connecticut Supreme Court gave the address.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Rodriguez Wins
description: Chi Chi Rodriguez shot a three-under-par 69 and held off a challenge by Bruce Crampton for a three-shot victory today in the $250,000 Silver Pages Classic.

title: How to Turn the Tide in Wetlands Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE'S 'UNION JACK'
description: Created in 1976 in response to this country's Bicentennial, George Balanchine's ''Union Jack'' rather perversely but amusingly celebrated the British Empire with a ballet changing of the guards. And Hershy Kay wove together British traditional tunes to make a colorfully, grandly nationalistic musical score.

title: UPBEAT MOOD AS BOOKSELLERS MEET
description: There is a decidedly 1960's flavor to the four-day 1987 convention of the American Booksellers Association, which by the time it ends on Tuesday evening will have featured book-related appearances by Joan Baez, Judy Collins, Chuck Berry and Peter, Paul and Mary. At a big after-hours event here Saturday night, more than 1,000 booksellers and publishing-industry employees celebrated until the early hours at a party tied to a forthcoming book about Elvis Presley.

title: FOR TOWN AND TEAM, HONOR IS ITS OWN REWARD
description: For Coach Cleveland Stroud and the Bulldogs of Rockdale County High School, it was their championship season: 21 wins and 5 losses on the way to the Georgia boys' basketball tournament last March, then a dramatic come-from-behind victory in the state finals.

title: Susan Sevilla Married to Kinnaird S. McQuade Jr.
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., yesterday Susan Sevilla and Kinnaird S. McQuade Jr. were married by the Rev. Richard Noonan.

title: SOVIET, IN A SHIFT, EXPANDS CONTACT WITH THIRD WORLD
description: The Soviet Union, in what some diplomats view as a major shift in foreign policy, is seeking increased leverage in developing regions by courting influential non-Marxist nations.

title: IN TYSON'S CORNER, SAVVY SUPPORTERS
description: BY now the story of what Cus D'Amato wrought with Mike Tyson is boxing lore.

title: President of Cox Calls Appointment a Surprise
description: James Cox Kennedy has been named president of Cox Enterprises Inc., assuming command of one of the world's largest privately held media companies.

title: Anne S. Kornfeld Wed To Dr. Joshua A. King
description: The marriage of Anne S. Kornfeld, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald S. Kornfeld of Tenafly, N.J., to Dr. Joshua A. King, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. King of Parsippany, N.J., took place yesterday at the Stronghold Mansion in Bernardsville, N.J. Rabbi Stephen Listfield, assisted by Cantor Kurt Silberman, performed the ceremony.

title: Waterloo Festival Plans Concerts at Princeton
description: Works by Bach, Mozart, Brahms, Samuel Barber and Carlos Chavez are to open this year's Waterloo Festival in Waterloo Village, N.J., the weekend of June 19-21. For the first time in its 12 seasons, the festival will offer adjunct concerts at Richardson Hall at Princeton University.

title: OPERA: UPDATED 'SALOME' AT SPOLETO
description: With their ''Salome,'' Moshe Leiser and Patrice Caurier have provided a good argument against the radical restaging of opera. The two young directors, who work principally in France, have brought their new production of the Strauss opera to the 11th Spoleto Festival U.S.A. here. The setting is a greenhouse belonging to Herod, in this incarnation a wealthy, drunken German industrialist from the 1930's. The work opened Friday night at the Gaillard Municipal Auditorium; repeat performances are Monday night, Friday and June 4.

title: LEO CASTELLI TAKES PETER PAN
description: Leo Castelli outlasted Gone West to win the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday, a race that earned the top two finishers a trip to the Belmont Stakes and made Gone West look especially impressive in defeat.

title: CARDINALS SLAM ASTROS, 8-2
description: Jack Clark's second-inning grand slam knocked out Mike Scott and led the St. Louis Cardinals to an 8-2 victory over the Houston Astros today.

title: Webster's Transfer
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has been beset with anxieties that William H. Webster, recently confirmed as Director of Central Intelligence, will be bringing with him hordes of officials from the Federal Bureau of Investigation to run the agency. Mr. Webster was director of the F.B.I., and the two agencies have different cultures and on occasion have had sharp disagreements.

title: WHITE SOX SWEEP RED SOX
description: Ken Williams drove in Tim Hulett with a 10th-inning double to left that was misjudged by Jim Rice, and the White Sox went on to a 4-1 victory today over the Red Sox. Chicago swept the three-game series.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: FOR THE ASHANTI IN U.S., A NEW KING
description: For a few short hours this weekend, Ghana, the West African nation of 13 million people, was re-created in the ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan.

title: A Top Kenyan Lawyer Buried Amid Tribe's Exorcism Rites
description: Thousands of members of the Luo tribe took part early today in traditional ceremonies near here to drive out evil spirits following the burial of one of Kenya's leading trial lawyers, Silvanus Melea Otieno.

title: SUNY-Binghamton
description: Commencement ceremonies were held in two parts yesterday at the State University of New York at Binghamton.

title: Pistons Have Celtics on Run
description: The tired Boston Celtics were solidly trounced today, 145-119, by the younger and quicker Detroit Pistons.

title: REFLECTION AND HIJINKS AT FESTIVAL
description: One arrived late. Another sent a stand-in. Seven, including the men from New York and New Jersey, who pleaded other commitments, were not represented at all.

title: Banks Need Sensitivity In Latin Debt Talks
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OPERA: 'LUCRETIA,' AT BROOKLYN COLLEGE
description: Just as some Handel oratorios fairly burst with concealed operatic tendencies, Benjamin Britten's ''Rape of Lucretia'' resembles an oratorio dressed up for the stage. The Brooklyn College Conservatory of Music offered a student production of the Britten chamber opera at the school on Saturday afternoon - in a performance that, despite the unresolved musical problems, reinforced the work's creative ambivalence.

title: Mount Holyoke
description: Seven honorary degrees were awarded yesterday at the commencement of Mount Holyoke College in South Hadley, Mass. The degrees were awarded after 524 graduates received bachelor's degrees at the school's 150th graduation ceremonies. Among those receiving honorary degrees were: Maya Angelou, the poet, playwright, composer and performer; the commencement speaker, Dolores Hayden, a professor in the urban planning program of the Graduate School of Architecture and Urban Planning at the University of California at Los Angeles, and David Baltimore, the director of the Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research.

title: ELECTION AGENCY ASSAILED AS WEAK
description: The Federal Election Commission, established as a watchdog over the election process after the Watergate scandal of the 1970's, has evolved into an agency widely viewed as ineffectual.

title: DIVIDEND MEETINGS
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 24, 1987: TUESDAY Becton, Dickinson & Co San Diego Gas & El Brush Wellman Tucson Elec Pwr Gap Inc Watkins-Johnson IMPALCO Enterprises Westvaco Corp Merck & Co Zemex Corp WEDNESDAY CIGNA Corp Manhattan Industries Deere & Co New Jersey Resources EG & G Inc Northern States Pwr MN First Virginia Banks Pennsylvania P & Lt Johnson Controls Philip Morris Cos Kansas Gas & Elec Technitrol Inc THURSDAY Arvin Industries KN Energy Bank of Boston Kellwood Co Combustion Engineering Russ Togs Interlake Corp Union Pacific FRIDAY Bairnco Corp. Whittaker Corp. H & R Block

title: DETROIT'S STEAMERS: NOSTALGIA ON DECK
description: Summer began unofficially here Friday evening when sailors raised the gangplanks, passengers clogged the decks holding binoculars and beer and two grand old steamships once again chugged down the Detroit River, honking at nearby tugboats and freighters.

title: Colgate University
description: The former chancellor of the State University of New York accused Secretary of Education William J. Bennett yesterday of a ''cynical'' and ''disingenuous'' approach to public policy affecting American higher education.

title: MENTOR IS MORE THAN A FRIEND
description: ''PLEASE stop calling me ma'am,'' Phyllis Love said in mock annoyance to Phoebe Prewitt. They both laughed. It was a subtle breakthrough in a new relationship that should last at least until 1990. They had talked on the telephone, but in this first face-to-face encounter the conversation had tended toward ''nice to meet you.''

title: GRETZKY TOO MUCH FOR FLYERS
description: Hoping to use their home ice to advantage and tie their Stanley Cup series with Edmonton at two games apiece, the Flyers instead fell prey to the Oilers' exuberant offense and were defeated, 4-1, in a testily played game at the Spectrum tonight.

title: The Sixth Man
description: It was Bob Cousy and such teammates as Joe Mullaney and George Kaftan who received the lion's share of the acclaim when Holy Cross won the college basketball championship in 1947. So much, in fact, that all five starters have been inducted into the Holy Cross College Athletic Hall of Fame, as has the coach, Al (Doggie) Julian, who received an honorary induction last year.

title: Inquiry Panel Members Want to Recall Secord
description: Members of the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair say they want to recall Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force officer who became an arms dealer, to clear up discrepancies between his version of events and those of later witnesses.

title: PATIENT IS KILLED AND 5 ARE HURT IN HOSPITAL FIRE
description: One patient was killed and five others were injured, two critically, in a fire in a geriatric ward at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island last night, officials said.

title: MUSIC: FOUR CONCERTOS
description: Perhaps no span of time before our own was so subject to wild musical mood swings as the 18th century. Gwendolyn Toth - playing the organ, harpsichord and fortepiano - demonstrated this confusion of riches with four keyboard concertos at St. Michael's Church on Wednesday evening. Miss Toth was joined by the Artek Ensemble - six string players playing on period-style instruments.

title: Baby Boomers: Deeper in Debt, Downwardly Mobile
description: To the Editor:

title: In Harm's Way
description: The case for keeping a U.S. naval force in the Persian Gulf is summed up as (1) a superpower must maintain the principle of ''freedom of the seas'' everywhere; (2) we must not allow Iran to cut off the flow of oil to the Western democracies and Japan, and (3) unless we honor our decades-old commitment to protect the gulf, the Soviet Union will eagerly move into the vacuum and take control of the oil shipping lanes and the Arab world.

title: SCHMIDT GUIDES YALE INTO A 'NEW ERA'
description: Confident that the financial and other problems that rocked it in the 1970's and early 1980's have been solved, Yale University's new president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., has begun laying out priorities for what he calls a ''new era in Yale's history.''

title: Dialing Nofziger
description: Suppose you want to talk to Lyn Nofziger, the former White House aide under investigation for allegedly using his influence to obtain Federal contracts for the Wedtech Corporation, a New York manufacturer. Mr. Nofziger, who left the Government's employ in 1982, has an unlisted number. But it was discovered last week that he can still be reached through the White House switchboard, which will take and forward calls for him.

title: INSIDE
description: Regulating Cabs of All Hues New York City officials are striving to regulate gypsy cabs and other nonmedallion vehicles. The effort could make it easier to find a taxi -but not always a yellow one. Page 21. Slump in Mortgages As mortgage rates climb, some home buyers are being squeezed out of the market and fewer homeowners are seeking refinancing. Page 33. Torture in South Africa Repression is increasing in Kwa-Ndebele, a tribal area resisting ''independence'' from South Africa. Page 5. Hermione Gingold Is Dead The deep-voiced English actress, who appeared on the stage, television and in films, died in Manhattan at the age of 89. Page 37.

title: Amoco's Bid for Dome Could Be in Jeopardy
description: The Amoco Corporation's bid to buy financially troubled Dome Petroleum Ltd. appears to be in growing difficulty.

title: Outdoors: Casting Away Doubts
description: YOU will have heard - if you bother to listen - anglers prating about how catching fish is really less important than the quest itself, than feeling the wind in their hair or listening to a lovely stream's sweet song.

title: Miss Shapiro, Editor, Weds Daniel Berman
description: Susan Shapiro, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore Shapiro of Manhattan, and Daniel Berman, a son of Arthur Berman of Haworth, N.J., and the late Mildred Berman, were married last evening at the St. Regis-Sheraton in New York by Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg.

title: AUSTRALIAN SETS NO BID FOR TEXACO
description: The Australian financier Robert Holmes a Court said Saturday that he was not planning or expecting to take control of Texaco Inc. but might increase his holding if the company's shares remain undervalued.

title: AFTER YEARS OF FROTH, AARON SPELLING GETS SERIOUS
description: ABC will present ''Cracked Up,'' a drama about a teen-age track star's addiction to crack, a potent form of cocaine, Tuesday night at 9. One of the most surprising aspects of the film is that it was produced by Aaron Spelling, who is best known as a purveyor of glamorous escapism.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An Associated Press list Wednesday of casualties aboard the frigate Stark incorrectly listed the hometowns of three crew members. Brian Michael Clinefelter was from Barstow, Calif.; Antonio Armando Daniels was from Greeleyville, S.C., and Gregory Lee Tweady was from Paxton, Ill. In addition, the first name of Mr. Clinefelter and the middle name of Mr. Daniels were not spelled correctly.

title: Pole Swims Across Niagara In Quest for Asylum in U.S.
description: A Polish citizen jumped from a Canadian tour boat Saturday into the roiling waters just below Niagara Falls, swam to the United States side of the river and apparently asked for asylum.

title: Vassar College
description: The playwright John Guare and Adele Chatfield-Taylor, director of the design-arts program of the National Endowment for the Arts, who are husband and wife, addressed those attending the 123d commencement of Vassar College yesterday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Some 570 graduates received degrees in a colorful ceremony that included the faculty in full academic regalia and the traditional 150-foot Daisy Chain, a century-old Vassar tradition. The chain consisted of 3,500 marguerites and 250 pounds of mountain laurel and was carried by women from the school's sophomore class. Men from the sophomore class acted as ushers.

title: Ellen Frankfort, 50, Is Dead; Author on Feminist Issues
description: Ellen Frankfort, the feminist author, died early yesterday at Long Island's Southampton Hospital. She was 50 years old and lived in Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: Miss MacDonald Wed To Thomas A. Witkin
description: Michele MacDonald was married yesterday to Thomas A. Witkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Witkin of Harrison, N.Y., at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. MacDonald, in New Milford, Conn. The Rev. A.Russell Ayre, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: The New, and Democratizing, Soviet Middle Class
description: A major realignment of class power is taking place in the Soviet Union.

title: RULER OF KUWAIT SAYS WAR SPILLS OVER FROM GULF AREA
description: The Emir of Kuwait, which is seeking both United States and Soviet protection for its oil tankers, has said the growing Gulf War threat to shipping should be a matter of ''international concern.''

title: 2 QUEENS DOCTORS STRUGGLE TO SERVE NEEDY PATIENTS
description: When he worked in a hospital emergency room, Dr. D. Narendra Kumar would heedlessly tug at the towel dispenser after washing his hands, unconcerned about how many sheets of paper he used.

title: Summer Market Rally: Inevitable or Mythical?
description: Summer is upon us, and post-Memorial Day thoughts are turning to vacations, tennis, the beach, swimming pools and the inevitable stock market rally. The inevitable stock market rally? Laszlo Birinyi, the statistical guru at Salomon Brothers, says that there is always a summer rally. He also says the ''rally'' has the same relevance to real life as current airline schedules.

title: ALL OBSTACLES FALLING FOR SCHOOLBOY PITCHER
description: EVENTS - like his fastball -are moving at a fast pace, sometimes faster than Willie Banks would prefer. The recent past, the times he would spend playing stickball in the neighborhood schoolyard, seems like an eternity ago, among the few carefree moments in a difficult childhood. Then, Banks pretended to be Reggie Jackson, hitting sponge balls over the schoolyard fence that he and his brothers would have to scale in order to get in. He was Goose Gossage, throwing smoke at the wall.

title: MUSIC: MURALIDHAR, MIMIC
description: It isn't everybody who can sing ''We Are the World'' and do a reasonable approximation of all the voices - male, female, country, soul, rock and pop - on the record. But that is one of the skills of Muralidhar, a singer, keyboardist, composer and mimic, who entertains Wednesday through Friday evenings at Terranova, 18 West 38th Street, from 6:15 to 9:15 P.M.

title: Machine Tool Orders Declined 20.9% in April
description: New orders for American-made machine tools fell 20.9 percent in April from their March level, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said in a report to be released today. The association reported that orders declined 32.8 percent from April 1986.

title: Breeding Success
description: When industry supplicants go to Albany to beg for legislative handouts, they generally tell such heart-rending economic sob stories that the lawmakers have to get out their handkerchiefs to wipe away the tears. When a delegation representing the state's thoroughbred breeders made such a trip a few weeks ago, it was the breeders who had to pull out their bandanas - to wipe the smiles off their faces.

title: BARR IS WINNER BY 4 WITH 65 AT ATLANTA
description: Dave Barr birdied four straight holes on the back nine, breaking a tie with the Masters champion, Larry Mize, and finished with a seven-under-par 65 today to win the Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: Suing Lawyers On Malpractice
description: THE malpractice crisis swirling about the legal profession will not soon subside, according to lawyers and insurance experts.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Coming Up Short It's not that Carl Larsen is an especially impatient sort, but as the executive director of the Kentucky Harness Racing Commission, he's come to the conclusion that many of the sport's fans and potential fans are. They would enjoy harness racing more, he figures, and more of them would come to the track, if the races didn't take so darned long - as much as two minutes for the average trotter or pacer to cover a mile, the standardbred distance standard.

title: MOURNERS FIND SYMBOL OF HOPE AFTER TORNADO
description: Hundreds of mourners gathered today beside the remains of a Roman Catholic church to pray for the 29 people killed by a tornado here Friday night.

title: LYONS REACTS QUIETLY, WITH SOME INDIFFERENCE, TO THE TRIAL
description: Under a row of sycamore trees just across the river from the Palace of Justice here, Yves Girerd, 55 years old, tended a market stand where he sells chickens and ducks every day and gave a somewhat ambivalent and skeptical view of the trial of Klaus Barbie, the wartime head of the Gestapo in this city.

title: Woman Awarded $403,000
description: A jury has awarded Beverly Pittman, 44 years old, $403,000 in back pay and damages in a sex discrimination suit against the General Motors Corporation. The jury found Friday that the automaker discriminated against Ms. Pittman when she was laid off from her job as a production supervisor in July 1981. She was idled 22 months and went back as a security guard. She was reinstated to her supervisor's job in 1984. A company spokesman, John Mueller, declined to comment on the case or whether G.M. would appeal.

title: FORDHAM AND RIDER DEFEATED
description: Somehow, the inferiority complex common to Northeastern teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's baseball tournament had seemed to vanish from the Fordham dugout.

title: ATHENS TO CALL VOTE ON U.S. BASES
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said tonight that he would call a referendum on the future of the United States military bases in Greece before his term of office ends in 1989.

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA 'SHOWCASE,' REPORTS OF BRUTALITY AND ARRESTS
description: There is overwhelming evidence that the troubled KwaNdebele homeland, which has already shown strong resistance to Pretoria-style independence, is a hotbed of official repression and torture and is seething with violence.

title: In Search of A Cause
description: The ardor of the wealthy people who gave money for a plane and military supplies to the White House contra cause is a reflection of the broader attempt by hard-liners to take foreign policy out of functioning international relations.

title: Cindy Louis Is Married
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., Cindy Louis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Louis of North Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Ronald A. Freydberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Freydberg of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony. The bride is a graduate of Syracuse University.

title: BEHIND THE SCENES IN 1787: SECRECY IN THE HEAT
description: When the framers of the Constitution convened here on May 25, 1787, to try to keep the American Union from falling to pieces, Philadelphia was the foremost city of America.

title: RECITAL: IRISH TENOR
description: If you don't especially like the sound of an Irish tenor - clear, reedy, sweet, penetrating and somewhat nasal - you surely wouldn't have liked Frank Patterson's recital Friday night in Carnegie Hall, because all the traditional characteristics are quite marked in his singing. If, like this listener, you have an affection for the style and the songs that go with it, a visit to his next local appearance is warmly recommended.

title: IN BRITAIN, BATTLE IS ON FOR COMPASSION VOTES
description: In an effort to fire up his party for the June 11 general election, Neil Kinnock, the Labor leader, recently accused Margaret Thatcher of trying to recreate a Britain with Victorian extremes of wealth and poverty. ''Charles Dickens,'' he said in an impassioned speech in Birmingham on Wednesday, ''thou shouldst be alive at this hour.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MAY 25, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5, 24 Gulf nations should provide bases and other support for aircraft that would patrol the Persian Gulf, protecting oil tankers and their naval escorts Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said. Page 1 Kuwait wants U.S.-Soviet protection for its oil fleet, the Emir of Kuwait said. The growing gulf war ''has come out of its local framework to become an international concern,'' he said. 3 Moscow woos developing nations in an effort to increase the Soviet Union's leverage in those areas. ''It is a pragmatic rather than a dogmatic approach,'' one Asian diplomat said of the effort. 1 News analysis: President Reagan contradicted previous Administration statements by asserting that a ban on aid to the rebels in Nicaragua in 1985 did not apply to his National Security Council or national security adviser. 1 In South Africa, official repression and torture has been reported in the trouble-torn ''homeland'' of KwaNdebele. Recent accounts have come from a journalist from the top circulation Johannesburg daily. 5 Fear of the spread of AIDS in Greece has prompted changes on the resort island of Mykonos, long viewed as the Aegean's prime gathering place for homosexual men and as a place where a mood of hedonism prevailed. 24 The reaction to Klaus Barbie's trial, while mixed, has been been above all quiet in Lyons, producing few if any signs of a reliving of a traumatic past. For some, the trial is all too much of a bother. 2 In Britain, the 'caring vote' is being pursued by each party for the coming general election. The battle parallels the struggle over ''compassion'' and ''fairness'' in the 1984 Presidential election in the United States. 2 In China, the culture of the Miao, a small ethnic nationality unrelated to China's Han majority, is vanishing under the weight of an unstated but clear policy of national homogenization. 4 Iraqis uncomfortable over U.S. reaction 3 Athens to call vote on the future of U.S. bases 4 NATIONAL$ 6-8, 37 Poor supervision of election finances by the Federal Election Commission has been charged by critics who say the agency is sluggish, partly because of the process established by Congress. 1 In Georgia, a high school's honesty about its use of an ineligible player cost its basketball team the state championship. But the town of Conyers has rallied behind its school and the team's coach. 1 Demand for home loans has slowed following the recent spurt in mortgage rates. Industry officials are worried that many potential buyers will be squeezed out of the market if rates continue to rise. 33 A governors' meeting in Philadelphia was part of the celebration of the Constitution's bicentennial. But only five governors of the 13 original states showed up for the conference on the state of the states. 8 Behind the scenes in 1787 8 Pierre du Pont 4th is the wealthiest of the Presidential contenders, according to financial disclosure documents. The former Governor of Delaware leads the Republican candidates with assets in excess of $6.3 million. 7 Survivors of a Texas twister prayed for the 29 people killed when the tornado devastated this tiny farming community. Hundreds of mourners gathered beside the remains of a Roman Catholic church for the service. 6 On the Detroit River, two steamships began their annual cruise season. It has been a rite of the summer season since 1902 when the huge steamer Columbia made its maiden trip to a Canadian island amusement park. 6 Many young parolees were arrested again at least once for serious crimes within six years of being released, according to a government report. The report by the Department of Justice said about 70 percent of the parolees in a study were arrested again. 6 The conduct of Government lawyers defending the Veterans Administration against a lawsuit has been challenged. The lawyers must defend themselves against motions that they be disqualified for professional misconduct. 6 WASHINGTON TALK 20 On the trail of traveler's checks Mothers, fathers, forefathers REGIONAL 21-24 A 5-year plan to combat AIDS has been recommended by a panel of New York City officials. The plan would expand care for the sick, promote research and seek to prevent the spread of the deadly disease. The plan is preliminary, and the details and cost will not be known for months. 1 A drive to regulate gypsy cabs and other nonmedallion vehicles has begun in New York City. Officials say the effort will enhance the industry's reputation and could make it easier to find a taxi although not necessarily a yellow one. 21 The first 'homesteading physicians' in New York City are two doctors who, with support from the Health and Hospitals Corporation, are struggling to serve patients in a medically underserved Queens neighborhood. 21 'A new era in Yale's history' has begun, the university's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., said. A construction program for the science facilities, as well as restoration of the gymnasium and other facilities are planned. 21 A Yiddish-language newspaper is 90 this year. The Forward, which helped hundreds of thousands of Jewish immigrants understand the often baffling life they found in America, remains spry and can still crackle with indignation. 21 For businesses, the immigration law passed last year is causing headaches across the New York metropolitan region. Employers must record and keep on file documents for all new employees. 23 A Soviet dissident's paintings remain in Moscow after he was expelled from the country. Sergei Batovrin, who now lives in New York City, is struggling to get the works, which were seized by K.G.B. agents, returned. 23 Hospital fire kills one 23 Turnover on landmarks panel 23 Ashanti honor new king in U.S. 23

title: GEDDES TOPS KING IN L.P.G.A.
description: Jane Geddes, winner of the 1986 United States Women's Open championship only 40 miles from here at Dayton's NCR Club, gained her second major tournament victory today when she birdied the 16th and 17th holes to win the Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship by a shot over Betsy King.

title: JAMES J. DELANEY, 86, A DEMOCRAT AND FORMER QUEENS CONGRESSMAN
description: James J. Delaney, the former Queens Congressman whose three decades in Washington catapulted him into the chairmanship of the powerful House Rules Committee, died yesterday at his son's home in Tenafly, N.J. He was 86 years old and had been a resident of Key Biscayne, Fla., since his retirement in 1978.

title: University of Texas
description: Speaker of the House Jim Wright urged University of Texas graduates to work for a just society and for an end to the nuclear arms race.

title: University of Rochester
description: In a graduation ceremony in Fauver Stadium yesterday, the University of Rochester awarded bachelor degrees to 1,133 students, master's degrees to 834 and doctorates to 313. Anthony E. Hecht, a former faculty member and 1968 Pulitzer Prize winner for poetry, gave the commencement address.

title: 90 YEARS OLD, THE FORWARD STILL CRACKLES
description: The Forward, which helped hundreds of thousands of Jewish immigrants understand the often baffling life they found in America, is 90 this year. And while it surely is not as robust as it once was, its step is still spry and its Yiddish voice can still crackle with indignation.

title: MICHELIN'S ANNUAL BEST SELLER
description: When thousands of Americans descend on France this summer, many will no doubt be toting the tourist's bible: the Michelin Red Guide to Hotels and Restaurants.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on April 27 about an international literary conference in Washington sponsored by the Wheatland Foundation characterized the Soviet writer Andrei Bitov erroneously. He is not a dissident, and his visit to Washington was not his first outside the Soviet Union.

title: THATCHER'S WEALTHIEST CRITIC
description: David Sainsbury, one of Britain's most respected business executives and one of its wealthiest individuals, is precisely the type of person expected to be applauding Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's free-enterprise vision of the nation's future and supporting her Conservative Government in next month's general election.

title: Principal Praised by Reagan Is Held in Assault on Teacher
description: A high school principal who was lauded by President Reagan for his tough disciplinary policies has been ordered to face an assault charge filed by a teacher.

title: Thefts Trouble Yankees
