description: Lou Piniella, the Yankee manager, held a closed-door meeting with his players before today's game to discuss a possible theft in the clubhouse Saturday and a string of apparent thefts dating to spring training.

title: Syrian Officer Denies Linking Libya to Purchase of Hostage
description: The chief of Syrian military intelligence in Lebanon denied today that he said Moslem kidnappers had sold a French hostage to Libya, Beirut radio stations reported.

title: How the Trail Led To Traveler's Checks
description: Several weeks ago, in preparation for the public hearings on the Iran-contra affair, lawyers for the Congressional committees spent a full day taking a sworn deposition from Adolfo Calero, the contra leader.

title: Linda R. Snow Wed to Barrett Z. Gross
description: Linda Ruth Snow, an account executive for El Diario/La Prensa, a Gannett newspaper in New York, and Barrett Zinn Gross, a merchandising manager for Illuminating Experiences Inc. in Highland Park, N.J., were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Snow, in Darien, Conn. Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Bernard Gross of Plainfield, N.J., and Merle Z. Gross-Ginsburg of New York and New Milford, Conn.

title: AIDS CASTS SHADOW ON A GREEK ISLE
description: This place in the Cyclades has palms and flat-roofed villas painted glaring white and 360 small white churches, some domed in primary colors. It has white windmills by a deep blue sea and a whiteish pelican called Petros as a mascot.

title: Chanting for Iran
description: Every few weeks an Iran-related demonstration takes place in the streets of Washington. Sometimes it is in favor of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, and sometimes it is against. In either case, passers-by usually pay little notice. But ears picked up last week when a pro-Khomeini group marching by the White House sounded the cadences of an American sports cheer familiar to anyone who has attended a high school football game. The marchers shouted: ''East is East and West is West; Islam, Islam is the best.''

title: 70% OF PAROLED YOUNG ARE ARRESTED
description: About 7 in 10 young adults paroled from prison were arrested again at least once for serious crimes within six years, the Department of Justice said today.

title: Ach, Those Dutch Vowels and German Consonants!
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. HANS H. NEUMANN
description: Dr. Hans H. Neumann, a public health physician and writer, died Saturday at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut after suffering a heart attack at his home in Wilton. He was 75 years old.

title: Marlene Sable and Merrick L. Cohen Are Married
description: Marlene Fay Sable, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Sable of West Roxbury, Mass., was married last evening to Merrick Lloyd Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Cohen of Englewood, N.J. Rabbi Marc Cooper performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Natick, Mass.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Wired; A Shrewd Power Play
description: New York City's biggest handicap in attracting or keeping electricity-hungry businesses is the ruinously high cost of power, compared with that above the city line or across state borders. Higher taxes explain some of the discrepancy. New York takes 22 cents of every Con Edison dollar. New Jersey utilities pay only 14 cents. A back-office city enterprise employing 1,200 could cut $800,000 from an annual $2.6 million electricity bill by crossing the Hudson. The city now proposes ways to slash that power premium to a mere $200,000.

title: Saudis Report Big Gold Find
description: Government geologists said today that they had uncovered what might be Saudi Arabia's biggest gold find at ancient workings southwest of Riyadh.

title: Wyman and Beech Get New Leaders
description: James S. Walsh, president and chief executive officer of the Raytheon Company's Beech Aircraft Corporation subsidiary in Wichita, Kan., has been named president and chief executive officer of the Wyman-Gordon Company.

title: Karen Susan Heiko Is Bride Of Dennis Man-Hei Wong
description: Karen Susan Heiko and Dennis Man-Hei Wong were married yesterday at the Colby Chapel of the Andover Newton Theological School in Newton Center, Mass., by Rabbi Albert Ginsburg.

title: The Peace Conference
description: Every diplomatic effort has its logic, and the next logical step in the process of trying to arrange an international peace conference on the Middle East may be taken when American and Soviet officials sit down for a periodic review of Middle East issues.

title: IRAQIS ARE UNEASY OVER U.S. REACTION
description: Iraqis continue to express dismay over the loss of life aboard the American frigate Stark, which was struck by two Iraqi missiles in the Persian Gulf a week ago, and some fear that the United States will now fire on all Iraqi warplanes flying over the gulf.

title: CORNELL COACH RETURNS
description: After a relatively quiet decade, Richie Moran is back at the lectern, commanding attention.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MAY 25, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY

title: The Gooden Sideshow
description: THE Mets open a road trip in San Francisco today, but Dwight Gooden will be working out at Shea Stadium - alone with himself and his future. Tomorrow night and again next Sunday, he is scheduled to pitch for the Tidewater farm team. And a week from Friday night against the Pittsburgh Pirates, the 22-year-old right-hander is expected to stride to the mound at Shea Stadium, accompanied by cheers of encouragement.

title: Ach, Those Dutch Vowels and German Consonants!
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DOWN TO SEA AGAIN

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A movie review of ''Beverly Hills Cop II'' on Wednesday omitted the film's rating. It is R.

title: A Troubled History at the Burned Foster-Care House in Queens; Hard-Working People
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW OUTLOOK IS LIKELY FOR LANDMARKS PANEL
description: With about half of its members destined to be a freshman class, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission is likely to take on a new tone in coming months.

title: Laura Ullman Is Wed To Howard Schwartz
description: At the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I., yesterday Laura Emily Ullman and Howard David Schwartz were married by Rabbi Martin Rozenberg, assisted by Cantor Jacob Yaron.

title: Mothers, Fathers, Forefathers
description: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, sought the other night to deliver a funny response to a glowing introduction, but not many people laughed.

title: FOR CAMERA BUFFS, A FLIGHT OF FANCY
description: It appears that everyone is going a little shutterbuggy these days. And why not, when taking pictures is so easy?

title: MARCEL CHANDELIER
description: Marcel Chandelier, a former head chef at Lutece restaurant in Manhattan and co-founder of Maison Germaine, a catering concern, died Saturday at his home in Long Island City, Queens. He was 53 years old.

title: FLORIDA'S TOP RANKING IN SYPHILIS CASES IS LINKED TO USE OF DRUGS
description: Florida now has more cases of syphilis than any other state, and health officials attribute the disease's swift spread to the practice of exchanging sex for drugs.

title: REFINEMENTS FOR 'E-MAIL'
description: PERSONAL computers are bringing about a subtle change in the way we exchange information.

title: NEW YORK CITY TO ADD 2 SITES FOR AIDS TESTS
description: The New York City Health Department will more than double its capacity to offer voluntary testing of blood for the AIDS virus by opening two new testing sites this summer and by extending testing to some private and municipal teaching hospitals, a key health official said yesterday.

title: SPIRITED RADIO PROGRAM HUNTS FOR AN AUDIENCE
description: ''Mountain Stage,'' a live musical-variety show from West Virginia public radio, is carving its own niche in the down-home airwaves mainly occupied by the famed ''Prairie Home Companion.''

title: METS TRIUMPH; YANKEES 6, ANGELS 3
description: Claudell Washington pulled a small whisk broom from his bagful of belongings and held it up for general inspection.

title: U.S. CHIP MAKERS RECOVERING
description: After $2 billion in losses and 25,000 layoffs, the nation's semiconductor industry - which makes the chips that run everything from computers to spy satellites to dishwashers -appears to have made a long-awaited rebound, industry executives and analysts say.

title: In Business, Big Doesn't Always Mean Bad
description: To the Editor:

title: Belgian Delays Visit to U.S.
description: Prime Minister Wilfried Martens has delayed a visit to the United States because of a Cabinet discussion of Belgium's linguistic problems.

title: JUMBO ROCKET LOOMS LARGE IN U.S. PLANS
description: AEROSPACE engineers around the country, responding to a new challenge, have begun to develop the rocket that some expect to carry the nation into its next phase of space exploration and exploitation.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT

title: Beatrice Executive To Refocus on Food
description: Frederick B. Rentschler, president and chief operating officer of the Beatrice Companies, has always been a hands-on manager, from developing some of the company's food products to cooking with them at barbecues.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart Friday showing locations of attacks on Persian Gulf shipping omitted one source. It is the International Association of Independent Tanker Owners.

title: Tornado Victims' Relatives Gather for Prayer
description: More than 1,000 relatives and friends of the 29 people killed by a tornado last week in the nearby town of Saragosa filled a school gymnasium for a rosary service tonight for the victims.

title: INSIDE
description: Max. Load: 250,000

title: Paterno to Aid Bush
description: Joe Paterno has agreed to lend his name to George Bush's presidential bid, according to aides and supporters of the Vice President's campaign. The Bush campaign expects to announce soon that the Penn State football coach is being named to a steering committee of about 500 people that will help organize the candidate's effort in Pennsylvania, sources said.

title: Prosecutor Tunes Out
description: While television sets in official Washington are tuned in to the Iran-contra hearings, the single set at the office of the special prosecutor investigating the arms scandal is usually turned off.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The indictment should never have been brought.'' - Rosa Milligan, jury forewoman in the Raymond J. Donovan case. [ A1:5. ]

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ''THEM.'' Stalin's Polish Puppets. By Teresa Toranska. Translated from the Polish by Agnieszka Kolakowska. Illustrated. 384 pages. Harper & Row, $22.95.

title: Emily S. Medine Wed in Princeton
description: Emily Sue Medine, the daughter of Mrs. Myer Medine of New York and the late Dr. Medine, was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Michael Howard Schwartz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Schwartz of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Deborah Hirsch, assisted by Cantor Susan Berkson, performed the ceremony at Prospect House on the Princeton University campus.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 15 about the nomination of Thomas F. Hartnett to be New York State Labor Commissioner misidentified the largest union of state employees. It is the Civil Service Employees Association, not the Public Employee Federation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MAY 26, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The U.S. semiconductor industry appears to be rebounding, according to industry executives and analysts. The success of the Reagan Administration's trade sanctions against Japan and a sudden surge in purchases of personal computers have spurred demand and driven up profit margins. Most forecasters now agree that the domestic semiconductor industry will grow between 15 percent and 20 percent this year. But some in the industry fear that the rebound could mask a need for fundamental changes in semiconductor production and design in the United States. [ Page A1. ] The death blow for the ''Baker Plan'' was Citicorp's decision to set aside $3 billion for potential losses on foreign loans, according to political and economic analysts. The decision by Citicorp could mean less commercial bank lending to the countries - not more, as the plan envisaged - and it heightens pressure on industrial-nation taxpayers and multigovernment lenders, primarily the World Bank, to fill the void. [ D1. ] The Japanese are rushing to enter Mexico's duty-free assembly industry as a way to further their penetration of the American market while avoiding trade disputes. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Steel producers said more Government assistance is needed to meet the costs of pension insurance, equipment write-offs and other expenses involved in closing aging and inefficient plants. In meetings last week, leading steel companies also recommended a surcharge on steel imports and urged that voluntary restraint agreements with other steel-producing countries be extended beyond their expiration in 1989. [ D1. ] Ecolab has agreed to sell its dishwasher detergent business to Joh. A. Benckiser of West Germany for $242.5 million. It plans to use the proceeds from the sale to pay down debt stemming from its acquisition of Chemlawn. [ D1. ] The F.D.A. may place restrictions on the use of T.P.A., a new drug for heart attack victims, to be marketed by Genentech under the name Activase. A public hearing on the drug by an F.D.A. committee is scheduled for Friday. Meanwhile, Genentech's stock has fallen steadily for the last eight trading days. [ D1. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Programs to help employees deal with stress have yet to prove they have real value. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Unilever's foreign origins make it seem mysterious, but its record stock prices speak volumes. Market Place. [ D11. ] The bond market may soon shake off its fears of rising inflation, after the rebound from its lows. Credit Markets. [ D15. ]

title: RECITAL: RON LEVY, PIANIST
description: RON LEVY is a young pianist whose instincts and intelligence just slightly outrun his physical abilities at the instrument. In his performance at Weill Recital Hall Saturday afternoon, Mr. Levy played an interesting program with the kind of technique that probably flourishes in the practice room but may lack that final bit of fiber needed to withstand the pressures of performance.

title: Helping Banks and the Third World, Too
description: LEAD: Citicorp's write-down of its Latin American loans by about 25 percent was a sound decision that will pay handsome dividends for its shareholders. The strength of Citicorp stock and the weakness of some other banks' shares in the aftermath of chairman John Reed's announcement made clear the market's reading that

title: Your Taxes at Work: A National Weed Center, an Ad Drive on Fish
description: Supplemental appropriations bills are intended to provide Government financing for emergency situations that were unforeseen when regular appropriations were enacted. But, like others before it, the supplemental bill now moving through Congress has also become a vehicle for an array of projects, this time ranging from a new national weed center to sweeter Government subsidies for 20 beekeepers.

title: BILL, NOTE AUCTIONS HIGHLIGHT WEEK
description: Treasury financings this week consist of today's three-month and six-month bill auctions, followed tomorrow by the sale of notes due in about five years.

title: TOP SEOUL AIDES, INCLUDING PRIME MINISTER, RESIGN
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea replaced his Prime Minister and seven senior Cabinet members today in an attempt to defuse a crisis over scandals involving police torture and corruption charges.

title: Prom Warning Holds: Tuxedo Girls Barred
description: Four girls kept their promise and showed up at their high school prom wearing tuxedo jackets, leotards and tights.

title: Drug Jury Picked
description: A jury of seven men and five women was selected in Upper Marlboro, Md., yesterday in the trial of Brian Lee Tribble, the man accused of providing Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star, with the cocaine that killed him. Prince George's County Circuit Court Judge James M. Rea spent the latter part of the afternoon listening to a series of pre-trial motions. Opening arguments are scheduled to begin tomorrow morning.

title: RADIATION AND VDT'S
description: MANY computer users, concerned about possible health effects of the low-level electromagnetic radiation emitted by video display terminals, have installed antistatic screens over the glass fronts of their computer monitors.

title: Obfuscation of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: CHIRAC, HIS COCLEAGUES SPLIT, ATTACKS RIGHTIST 'DEMAGOGY'
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, with his political allies deeply divided over how to deal with the growing strength of the far right National Front Party, has publicly repudiated what he called ''intolerance and sectarianism'' in France.

title: Donovan Gives Assist To Saint Raymond
description: During jury deliberations, Raymond J. Donovan, the former Labor Secretary, said, ''My mother knew what she was doing'' when she named him after St. Raymond Nonnatus.

title: PARADES, PICNICS AND PARKS ATTRACT MANY ON COOL, BLEAK MEMORIAL DAY
description: Straining for a bit of sun, some New Yorkers watched veterans marching in parades yesterday, some went bicycling in parks, and some shivered in sweatshirt weather that felt more like a prelude to fall than summer.

title: Avies Copy Takes Derby
description: Avies Copy took the lead for good on the first turn and held off a rally on the far outside by Proudest Duke to capture the 43d running of the $500,000 Jersey Derby today at Garden State Park.

title: Justice In the Grass
description: In the mornings I go to the garden.

title: RECITAL: ALAN WEINBERG
description: IT seems a funny thing to say, but what really made Alan Weinberg's piano playing at Weill Recital Hall pleasurable last Friday night was his obvious pleasure in the doing of it. This is a performing space that has witnessed a lot of grim struggle and half-panicked efforts at survival. Mr. Weinberg, on the other hand, could bring to the finale of Beethoven's ''Adieux'' Sonata an unbuttoned exhilaration that made the occasional crudities of tone and gesture seem minor matters.

title: Careers; A Variety Of Jobs In Credit
description: THE financially troubled Pan American World Airways recently made an agreement with New York's Citibank to borrow $75 million, and the bank said it would try to raise $75 million more. As collateral for the loan, the airline will put up some of its equipment and parts, such as engines, rather than its already-mortgaged planes.

title: FLYERS FEISTY UNDER PRESSURE
description: Feeling endangered, the Flyers let their emotions run rampant, focused on their dislike for their opponent instead of the puck, and after another game spent chasing the Oilers, they retreated to their locker room by far the worse for wear.

title: GENE THERAPY FOR HUMANS MOVES NEARER TO REALITY
description: In an encouraging step toward a revolutionary new form of treatment, scientists have transplanted a human gene into monkeys and it successfully directed production of a desired enzyme.

title: Weinberger Says U.S. Seeks NATO Gulf Aid
description: The United States is pressing Western allies to help American, British and French naval forces protect shipping in the Persian Gulf threatened by the Iran-Iraq war, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Field Publications to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston.

title: photo of Gerard Oestreicher (Irving Kaufman); GERARD OESTREICHER, BROADWAY PRODUCER AND DEVELOPER, DIES
description: Gerard L. Oestreicher, a real-estate developer and Broadway producer, died Sunday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Let's Have More Police Officers on the Sidewalks of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chaos in Cap's Store
description: Caspar Weinberger displays an unusual management style for a Secretary of Defense. Instead of pushing the Army, Navy and Air Force toward a unified strategy under strong central management, he has mostly raised money and let them spend as they please. Now, as famine years follow the feast, the absence of a strategy by which to allocate the cuts is proving all the more harmful.

title: Wheaton Trustees Reaffirm Move Toward Coeducation
description: Reaffirming an earlier decision, the trustees of Wheaton College have voted to admit men in the fall of 1988, according to reports published today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MAY 26, 1987
description: International A3-13

title: REPUBLICANS ON IRAN-CONTRA PANEL AT ODDS OVER BEST TACTICS TO USE
description: As evidence has mounted of President Reagan's personal involvement in the Iran-contra affair, a quandary has been presented to some Republican members of the joint Congressional committees.

title: McCann's Taiwan Move
description: McCann-Erickson, the lead ad agency network of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has acquired a 70 percent interest in United Communications of Taiwan, which brings McCann's total to 134 agencies in 63 countries and its billings to $2.85 billion.

title: Where Politics Isn't Topic A
description: A full-page advertisement in the publishers' catalogue calls it the book of ''a new breed of politician.'' But ''One Man's Luck,'' the Gary Hart campaign biography that was set for publication in September, has been canceled by William Morrow & Company.

title: MAN WITH A PLAN (AND SEEDS) FOR A GREENER GHANA
description: Making her way down a row of young cornstalks, Ifua Amoakwa leaned over and gave each stalk something her Fanti ancestors never tried: one white pellet of nitrogen fertilizer.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK Caraher Sets Record: Phil Caraher of North Rockland High School won two events and White Plains posted a meet record of 41.9 seconds in the 400-meter relay at the 31st annual Eastern States Interscholastic Boys Track and Field Championships at St. John's University. Caraher scored victories in the discus throw at 183 feet 7 inches, and the shot-put at 62-7 3/4. GOLF Langer Takes Title: Bernhard Langer of West Germany won the British Professional Golfers Association Championship yesterday at Wentworth, England, by four strokes over Severiano Ballesteros of Spain with a final-round 69 that gave him an 18-under-par total of 270. (AP) CYCLING Pearson Wins Somerville Race: Paul Pearson of Allentown, Pa., pulled away from West Germany's Volker Diehl and the Olympic Festival gold medalist, Jim Copeland, in the last 50 yards yesterday to win the 44th Tour of Somerville 50-mile bicycle race in New Jersey. Pearson, a 32-year-old professional cyclist, crossed the finish line in 1 hour 46 minutes 36 seconds. Hennie Top of Otterloseweg, the Netherlands, won the 20-mile women's race. (AP) BASEBALL Hitting Streak Extended: Robin Ventura extended his hitting streak to 56 games and Pat Hope, who had already thrown two complete games in the tournament, earned a save by getting the final out yesterday as Oklahoma State advanced to the College World Series in Omaha with an 11-9 victory over Texas A&M.

title: Kimberly A. Howard Wed to C. J. O'Donnell
description: At the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Manchester, Mass., yesterday, Kimberly Anne Howard, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Howard of Manchester, was married to Christopher Joseph O'Donnell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence O'Donnell of Ridgewood, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Peter C. O'Donnell, an uncle of the bridegroom, assisted by the Rev. James Purdy, an Episcopal priest.

title: SELLING TEXTBOOKS LIKE TOOTHPASTE
description: ''OLD textbooks never die they just get paraphrased.'' So says Diana B. Paul, associate professor of political science at the University of Massachusetts and a visiting scholar at the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard University.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Las Vegas, Nev., in some copies Saturday on the World Championship of Poker misidentified the site of the tournament. It was Binion's Horseshoe Casino. An accompanying photo caption misidentified the casino's proprietor. He is Jack Binion.

title: CLARK'S NIGHTMARE: 3 ERRORS IN 1 INNING
description: Jack Clark, the St. Louis first baseman, tied a major league record by committing three errors during a five-run second inning, and the Atlanta Braves got 17 hits tonight in a 14-5 victory that ended the Cardinals' five-game winning streak.

title: Boy's Ear Reattached After Dog Swallows It
description: Doctors reattached a 7-year-old boy's ear after it was retrieved from the stomach of a Doberman pinscher that had bitten it off.

title: Shooting for 20-Year Plan
description: Just when it appeared as if Kareem Abdul-Jabbar had finally decided on a retirment plan, it appears as if there might be another change.

title: COVER UP, SOUTHAMPTON TELLS VACATIONERS
description: This village of seaside estates and elegant, brick-cobbled sidewalks is putting summer visitors under wraps.

title: DOES THE AIDS VIRUS WORK ALONE?
description: WHY do some people infected with the AIDS virus fall ill and soon die while other virus carriers remain healthy for years?

title: DONOVAN CLEARED OF FRAUD CHARGES BY JURY IN BRONX
description: Former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and seven other construction executives were acquitted yesterday of state charges of fraud and grand larceny after an eight-month trial in the Bronx.

title: AID ASKED FOR STEEL INDUSTRY
description: The nation's leading steel producers, who have looked to the Federal Government for assistance in the form of import quotas, now contend that more Government initiatives are needed.

title: FOR GROBACHEV, 3 KISSES IN RUMANIA
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here today for a three-day visit on the last stop of his first round of visits to the Soviet Union's European allies since taking power in 1985.

title: CARELESS SMOKING CITED IN BLAZE THAT KILLED WOMAN AT HOSPITAL
description: A careless smoker apparently caused a fire at Goldwater Memorial Hospital on Roosevelt Island Sunday night that killed an 88-year-old, partially paralyzed woman patient and injured five others, two of them critically, the fire authorities said yesterday.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATORS FLY TO IRAQ TO DISCUSS ATTACK ON FRIGATE
description: The American team investigating the missile attack on the American frigate Stark arrived in Baghdad today, planning to ask Iraq to let them interview the pilot who fired on the ship.

title: YEARS OF JAMMING VOICE OF AMERICA HALTED BY SOVIET
description: The Soviet Union has stopped jamming Voice of America radio broadcasts into the country for the first time in seven years, officials of the American radio service announced today.

title: HUNT IS ON FOR SCATTERED BLUEPRINTS OF POWERFUL SATURN MOON ROCKET
description: ROCKET builders eager to tap the proven technology of the giant Saturn 5 moon rocket have been frustrated because long ago blueprints and other documents were scattered - a few even lost - and all the old dies, jigs and tooling were sold as scrap metal for pennies a pound.

title: HOUSTON'S ELEGANT MENIL COLLECTION
description: Dominique de Menil does not really like to be labeled a collector. ''I find it pretentious,'' she protests. Yet the more than 10,000 art objects accumulated over a 40-year period by her and her late husband, John, make the term somewhat hard to avoid. And so the $25 million museum built to house their holdings -opening here on June 7 - has come to be called the Menil Collection, the latest entry in what seems to be a worldwide trend toward museums devoted to the holdings of individuals.

title: Helsinki Pact Offers Hope to Illegal Aliens
description: To the Editor:

title: PAGEANTRY AND THE IDEALS OF 200 YEARS
description: Just outside the windows of the room where the Framers of the Constitution first convened 200 years ago today, that long-ago moment of high anxiety was celebrated this afternoon with pageantry and pride, but also with subdued reflection.

title: MOTORISTS' DEATHS PROMPT AN UPROAR ON GARBAGE TRUCKS AT JERSEY LANDFILL
description: New Jersey's garbage problem has spilled over in anger and grief here after five motorists were crushed by one of the garbage trucks that use the huge Edgeboro Landfill.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECHES BY BUSH, BURGER AND GOODE AT THE BICENTENNIAL
description: Following are excerpts from addresses yesterday by Vice President Bush, former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia at ceremonies in Philadelphia opening the celebration of the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution, as recorded by The New York Times: Vice President Bush

title: Baker's Wife Hospitalized
description: Joy Baker, the wife of the White House chief of staff, was admitted to Georgetown University Hospital today. The White House said she was there for routine tests and was expected to be released soon. Mrs. Baker had an abdominal operation last year, and several years ago underwent surgery for lung cancer.

title: The Beach War: Rising Fees, Rising Tempers
description: Sister Beverly Bligh and Sister Grace Reape rode from Jersey City to the beach on Memorial Day weekend, but they did not actually get on the sand. They looked at it from the Boardwalk. To go on the beach at Belmar costs $8 a person on weekends, too much for them.

title: NUMBER OF WOMEN IN STATE LEGISLATURES RISES STEADILY
description: The number of women in state Legislatures has grown in every election over the past 18 years, according to a recent study by Rutgers University.

title: 'Test-Tube' Kittens
description: Scientists at the Smithsonian Institution's National Zoological Park have succeeded in producing three litters of kittens in domestic cats by in vitro fertilization. The achievement marks the first time ''test-tube'' fertilization has been successful in any type of cat - or any other non-human carnivores - and holds promise for increasing the reproductive capacity and the long-term survival of such endangered felids as Pallas' cats and flat-headed cats.

title: FIJI COUP LEADER IS GIVEN KEY POST
description: The leader of a military coup d'etat was assigned to the most important portfolio in an interim government today, in another sign that the military continues to play a crucial role after nominally returning to the barracks.

title: Differing With Meese
description: The Justice Department announced this month that a special prosecutor was taking over an internal investigation into links between the Wedtech Corporation and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. It said it was Mr. Meese's idea to seek the special prosecutor's review. His lawyer, Nathan Lewin, said his client wanted the matter settled ''as promptly as possible by an inquiry that will be fair and complete.''

title: LAKERS DOMINATE SONICS, SWEEP SERIES
description: It had truly been a struggle: The Los Angeles Lakers needed all of their talent to stave off the upstart Seattle SuperSonics in the first three games of this four-of-seven-game playoff series. But just minutes into the final period at the Coliseum this afternoon, the Lakers' best players were resting on the bench.

title: Garvey Sidelined
description: Steve Garvey, troubled by a shoulder injury, was placed on the 21-day disabled list by the San Diego Padres. The 38-year-old Garvey, who has played in the majors for 17 years, has been bothered by pain in his left shoulder since spring training. The first baseman was benched May 3 after his poor start at the plate. . . . The Montreal Expos activated Hubie Brooks, their shortstop, and Jeff Reed, a catcher, from the disabled list. Brooks had been out of action with a fractured right wrist since April 11. Reed has been on the disabled list since April 20 with a slight separation of the right shoulder.

title: VIRGINIA S. KAMEN
description: Virginia Swanson Kamen, a West Coast pediatric pathologist, died of cancer Wednesday at Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital in California. She was 64 years old and lived in Montecito, Calif.

title: GULCH'S LATE SURGE TAKES METROPOLITAN
description: Gulch, the lone 3-year-old in a field of nine, ran down King's Swan and Broad Brush in the final furlong and then survived a claim of foul to win the $601,500 Metropolitan Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: GERMAN CONCERN TO BUY ECOLAB DETERGENT UNIT
description: Ecolab Inc., embittered by cutthroat competition on the supermarket shelf, has decided to sell its consumer dishwasher detergent business to Joh. A. Benckiser G.m.b.H. of West Germany for $242.5 million.

title: PAROLEE SHIFTED AFTER PROTEST
description: A paroled rapist, Lawrence Singleton, was removed from an apartment in a bullet-proof vest today after 400 residents surrounded the building to protest a decision to place him there permanently.

title: PLANTS IN MEXICO HELP JAPAN SELL TO U.S.
description: Mexico's duty-free assembly industry, originally conceived as a program to link manufacturers in the United States and Mexico, is increasingly being regarded by Japan and other countries as a way to further their penetration of the American market while avoiding trade squabbles.

title: Time-Life Assignments To Wunderman, Ricotta
description: Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, the direct-marketing arm of Young & Rubicam, continued to bask in the pleasure of Time-Life Books this week, as it has for almost a quarter of a century, by getting four new assignments.

title: LENDL IS EXTENDED IN OPENER AT PARIS
description: Ivan Lendl and Steffi Graf won first-round matches in contrasting fashion today as the French Open began on the clay courts at Roland Garros Stadium.

title: A MONUMENT OF GRIEF FOR DEAD MARINES
description: For decades, this small city on the Susquehanna River has celebrated Memorial Day with a seemingly timeless ritual. It would begin with a slightly ragged parade down Main Street and end with solemn speeches before a worn monument bearing the names of fallen servicemen from World War I, World War II and the Korean War.

title: Rebound Heartens Analysts
description: The bond market rebounded from its lows last week, encouraging some analysts to speculate that the appearance of a 9 percent yield on long-term Treasury issues marked the end of the steep price declines of the last two months.

title: A LEADER IN BLOOD RESEARCH
description: Dr. James G. Hirsch, a biological scientist, medical educator and president of the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation, died of cancer yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Santa Fe Head Finds Tasks More Difficult
description: John S. Reed, chairman and chief executive of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, has a load of worries.

title: Apartheid Foe Sentenced
description: A prominent anti-apartheid leader was sentenced to 11 years in prison today by a court in the so-called independent homeland of Ciskei for furthering the aims of the outlawed African National Congress, the main nationalist movement fighting to end white rule. The leader, the Rev. Arnold Stofile, a member of the executive of the United Democratic Front, and three others were convicted Friday of terrorism and illegal possession of weapons.

title: Chess: Avenging an Earlier Defeat, Ljubojevic Overcomes Short
description: The favorite, the world champion Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, had to be content with a tie for first place with the Yugoslav grandmaster Ljubomir Ljubojevic in the SWIFT International Tournament in Brussels. Both players left an elite field in the lurch by scoring 8 1/2-2 1/2.

title: HBO Video Promotes Its Brand to Renters
description: HBO Video is quite willing to sell its movies on cassettes, but what it is really promoting is renting. And the company is doing it on network TV.

title: Donald H. Putnam, 62, Head of Conrac Corp.
description: Donald H. Putnam, chairman of the Conrac Corporation, died of lung cancer Friday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 62 years old.

title: THERE CAN NEVER BE ENOUGH PRISONS
description: Having just spent $657 million in a dramatic expansion of prisons, New York State faces a rising crisis: not enough prison space. The first round of building made sense, but it also left state officials free to neglect sensible steps for managing a growing convict population - measures that now merit urgent study.

title: Knicks 'Intrigue' Nelson
description: Now that ''it's clear'' to Don Nelson that he won't be returning to the Milwaukee Bucks, he would appear to be headed to the Golden State Warriors, a franchise owned by his ''best friend,'' Jim Fitzgerald, once the Bucks' owner.

title: CITY BALLET: 'PETITS RIENS' AND 'TCHAIKOVSKY SUITE'
description: THE New York City Ballet offered some kinetically surprising works at weekend performances at the New York State Theater.

title: Market Place; Complex, But Strong, Unilever
description: THE Unilever Group, with $25 billion in annual revenues, is the world's largest purveyor of consumer packaged goods. In the United States alone, its operations include Lipton, a producer of specialty foods, along with Chesebrough-Pond's in beauty care and Lever Brothers in detergents and personal products.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''I WAS definitely the only man there in an Issey Miyake minidress,'' Billy Boy said. Billy Boy, the American jewelry designer, Barbie doll collector and fashion archivist who is based in Paris, was describing his weekend sojourn in Washington for the annual American Booksellers Association convention. ''But I walked the gentle line of ambiguity,'' he continued. ''I also wore Lobb shoes.'' It might have been the first time a minidress was matched with footwear from the refined British bootmaker.

title: IRANIANS FLEE TO TURKEY AND DREAM OF U.S.
description: On most days, outside American diplomatic missions here and elsewhere in Turkey, small knots of people gather -sometimes whole lines of them -clutching documents, some false, and harboring dreams, some in vain.

title: OPERA: SPOLETO U.S.A. OFFERS RAMEAU'S 'PLATEE'
description: Rameau's ''Platee'' is an incongruous piece of writing: the composer bestowed some of his most endearing music on what may well be the cruelest of operatic plots. To cure his wife, Junon, of jealousy, Jupiter pretends to court the hideous nymph Platee. When Junon sees the object of his affection, she laughs at her own suspicions.

title: BARBIE REPORTED LIKELY TO BE BACK IN COURT TODAY TO FACE ACCUSERS
description: Klaus Barbie, on trial for Nazi war crimes, is likely to be brought before the court Tuesday to confront witnesses who say he tortured them, the assistant prosecutor said today.

title: Dollar Higher Against Yen
description: The dollar was stable in Europe today in a session subdued by holidays in the United States and Britain. In Tokyo, the dollar moved up to its highest closing in a month.

title: VIEWS ON CONSTITUTION: PROMISES KEPT, MILES TO GO
description: Most Americans say the Constitution has accomplished the bulk of its aims, from unifying a nation of separate states to providing defense and domestic tranquility, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows, but a majority say the Constitution has done a poor job of treating all people equally.

title: Richard Loewus Wed To Cynthia Ann Thole
description: The marriage of Cynthia Ann Thole, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Thole of Redlands, Calif., to Richard Loewus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Loewus of New York and Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Fischell, the brother-in-law and sister of the bride, in Fair Haven, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Ward, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: DANCE: BERLIN TROUPE AT ST. MARK'S CHURCH
description: THE powerful impact of Pina Bausch's Dance Theater has often left the impression that modern-dance choreographers in West Germany today are less influenced by movement exploration than by theatrical images.

title: Want the Pesticide Industry in Your Milk?
description: LEAD: As hearings begin this week on proposed reforms of the Federal pesticide law, members of the House Agriculture Committee should finally stand up to the powerful business lobbies that for nine years have prevented passage of a statute that would protect human health and the environment.

title: A SHOWDOWN IN GULF WAR?
description: When President Reagan meets this week to discuss policy in the Persian Gulf with his national security advisers, he will have to make a crucial decision: Is the United States prepared to bomb Iran to protect Kuwait's ships?

title: A TENSE CLIMATE FOR EASTERN
description: Early this month three Airbus A-300's, some of the best planes in Eastern Airlines' fleet, were transferred to Continental Airlines under a lease agreement. Three more will follow next month, reconditioned and painted Continental's colors.

title: Ready to Go to War?
description: The real question for Americans, Gary Hart said, is the Reagan Administration's intentions in the Persian Gulf. What does our Government plan to do if tankers and other oil facilities come under increasing attack?

title: Ingalls, Quinn Wins Ocean Spray Business
description: Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson of Boston beat out Ketchum Advertising of Pittsburgh and Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver of New York for the non-cranberry business of Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc., a farmers cooperative based in Plymouth, Mass. That means Ingalls will handle advertising for grapefruit and guava juices, which have an ad budget of $15 million.

title: Satellite Video Services
description: Tee-Comm Electronics Inc. of Montreal said Sunday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Satellite Video Services of Catskill, N.Y. Terms were not disclosed.

title: HAUNTING ISSUES SURROUND JEWISH NAZI CAMP OVERSEER
description: During the Holocaust memorial ceremony in Brighton Beach last June, each of the neighborhood's synagogues sent forth one of its faithful to light a candle. A stooped old man named Jacob Tannenbaum represented Temple Beth El, and those who attended the service recall that as he lit the wick he began to cry. And so did the friends who knew that Mr. Tannenbaum himself was a survivor, the sole survivor from a family of 12.

title: TV MINISTRY FALLS SHORT OF FUND-RAISING GOAL
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell said today that the PTL television ministry had fallen short of its weekend fund-raising goal of $2 million and would go out of business unless it got at least $3.2 million by Friday.

title: HENRIK BEER, 71, OF THE RED CROSS
description: Henrik Beer, former Secretary General of the League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, died Saturday at his Geneva home, the league announced yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: Bridge: Two New York City Players Are Goldman Pairs Winners
description: Two New York City players, Lapt Chan of Woodside, Queens, and Carleton Lett of Manhattan added their names to a distinguished list Sunday night. Playing at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, they captured the Goldman Pairs, a prestige event that has been won by many of the game's greatest players, starting in 1929 with Oswald Jacoby.

title: STAGE: ATHOL FUGARD'S 'ROAD TO MECCA' AT SPOLETO FESTIVAL
description: In the past, the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. has generally regarded theater as the stepchild of the performing arts. This year, however, it is offering an event of theatrical magnitude - Athol Fugard's probing drama ''The Road to Mecca,'' featuring Yvonne Bryceland and Charlotte Cornwell in their American stage debuts.

title: Save Them From Limbo
description: To the Editor:

title: Murdoch Considered
description: Bob Murdoch, assistant coach of the Calgary Flames, is reportedly about to be named head coach of the Chicago Blackhawks. ''I'm not at liberty to say anything,'' Murdoch said in Calgary. ''It's up to them to make any comment about it one way or the other.''

title: The U.N. Toda: May 26, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: COURT FINDS ISRAEL FRAMED A MOSLEM
description: The Israeli Supreme Court has ruled that a loyal Moslem officer in the Israeli Army was framed by Shin Beth, the domestic intelligence service, and unjustly sentenced to 18 years in prison.

title: JURY CHIEF SAYS NO INDICTMENTS WERE JUSTIFIED
description: One hundred times the bailiff asked for the verdict. And 100 times it came back ''not guilty.''

title: Business and Health; Coping With Stress at Work
description: SEVERAL hundred companies are offering programs to help employees deal with stress, according to a survey to be published soon by the health-promotion office of the Department of Health and Human Services. But the economic and health value of such stress-management programs, aside from subjective feel-good reactions as measured over a few months, has yet to be established.

title: KENTUCKY'S RACE IS THE VERY MODEL OF A MODERN MAJOR POLITICAL PRIMARY
description: When it comes to tail-wagging-the-dog politics, the Democratic primary campaign for Governor of Kentucky displays the state of the art.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Before scientists learned to make synthetic growth hormone, where was it obtained? A. Growth hormone was painstakingly removed in small amounts from the pituitary glands of human corpses. The hormone was in short supply, and there was a long waiting list. Growth hormone was also obtained from monkeys, the only animals whose protein is active in humans. Today, the nation's supply of growth hormone is produced almost exclusvely through genetic engineering techniques. Q.Which are better for reading, halogen bulbs or standard incandescent bulbs? A.Experts disagree about whether standard incandescent lightbulbs with tungsten filaments or bulbs with halogen filaments are best. But most say the best reading conditions are in a well-lit area with a generous focused pool of light. Under standard conditions, a soft white incandescent bulb provides superb lighting for reading, according to experts, because it is covered with a coating of finely powered silicas that diffuses the light, making the filament almost invisible. Soft-white bulbs also produce the softest shadows. Halogen incandescent bulbs work in a similar way but their filaments produce greater heat and whiter light, even though halogen bulbs are about one-tenth the size of standard bulbs. Many experts suggest that halogen bulbs be used in lamps with large shades and a dimmer switches. If not, the tiny bulbs can produce small pools of light and crisp shadows, which are not good for reading.

title: 500 FAVORS DRIVERS OF CERTAIN AGE
description: Tradition - that's why the Indianapolis 500 wasn't official until 8 o'clock this morning.

title: C.I.A. ACCUSED OF MANILA ROLE
description: An American fact-finding mission led by Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, charged today that the Central Intelligence Agency was behind the rise of vigilante groups opposed to the Communist insurgency in the Philippines.

title: The Police Memorial
description: A proposal to dedicate a prime piece of Washington real estate, the Ellipse area behind the White House, as a memorial to slain police officers is running into resistance.

title: Carroll A. Hochwalt, Ex-Monsanto Official
description: Carroll A. Hochwalt, a chemist and former vice president of the Monsanto Chemical Company, died of a heart attack at his home in St. Louis on Saturday. He was 88 years old.

title: THE BLACK RHINO: PRESERVING DIVERSITY
description: THE genes of the black rhinoceros are being analyzed at Columbia University in a project that may be crucial to the survival of that endangered species in Africa.

title: DALLAS DEATH: SHOOTINGS BY POLICE STOKING ANGER
description: David Horton, an 81-year-old crime watch volunteer carrying a loaded rifle, was shot by police officers responding to a call and died near the dumpster in his apartment house parking lot.

title: PUERTO RICO IS HIT BY FIVE EXPLOSIONS
description: Five small bombs exploded at different points across Puerto Rico today, hours before a public appearance by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain.

title: TRACK STAR AND DRUGS IN 'CRACKED UP' ON NBC
description: IT was only a matter of time, needless to say, before a television movie got around to the hot subject of crack, a potent form of cocaine. Tonight at 9, the ''ABC Theater'' series is presenting ''Cracked Up,'' the story of a high-school track star succumbing to the deadly drug's addiction. Unfortunately the film, written and produced by Peter Lefcourt, is structurally flawed and ends up being kind of deadly itself.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Challenger International Ltd., Hamilton, Bermuda, which is involved in petroleum products and crude oil marketing, appointed Jeffrey W. Hobbing president and managing director. Mr. Hobbing, who will also continue as president of Challenger Petroleum U.S.A. Inc., succeeds Anthony P. Towell, who resigned to pursue other interests.

title: F.D.A. TO GET MORE DATA ON KEY GENENTECH DRUG
description: The price of Genentech Inc. stock has been dropping steadily on expectations that the Food and Drug Administration will place restrictions on the use of the drug that is expected to become the company's biggest product. An advisory committee of the F.D.A. is set to hold a public hearing Friday on the drug, known as tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A.

title: Della Femina Picks Up Hasselblad Account
description: The House of Hasselblad, the Swedish camera concern, will be using Della Femina, Travisano & Partners to promote its cameras and projectors in the United States, just as it uses the agency's parent company, the WCRS Group of London, throughout Europe.

title: AUERBACH'S PROTEGE EMERGES
description: Adrian Dantley has worn uniforms of five different teams during his 11 pro basketball seasons but the ritual has remained the same every time he shows up at the Boston Garden. Sometime during the game, he will look toward Loge 1 where Red Auerbach sits, and nod to him.

title: Prisoners Are Recaptured
description: Four prisoners being taken to Florida overpowered their guards early today, took one hostage and stole a prison van before being stopped at a roadblock, officials said. One inmate was found in the van, dead from a bullet wound to his head, and the three others were captured. The authorities have not ruled out suicide in the man's death. The prisoners were being taken to the Florida Receiving and Medical Center at Lake Bulter from prisons in California, Colorado and Texas when one feigned illness, allowing them to overpower the guards.

title: NORWAY SAYS ISRAEL RESISTS A NUCLEAR CHECK
description: Norwegian officials say Israel is resisting a proposal that would allow international inspectors to determine if Israel is using Norwegian ''heavy water'' to produce nuclear weapons.

title: HANDS ACROSS AMERICA: RACH EXCEEDED GRASP
description: One year ago, Hands Across America was billed as the unassailable charity event of the 1980's: a proposed human chain across the United States to raise at least $50 million for the hungry and homeless.

title: The Happy Adoptive Family Is No Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: THINKING: THE TALK OF THE CITY
description: A city so richly diverse as New York is more than the daily dance or jab of its citizens getting through the rush, more than the groan of its buses or the wail of its sirens, more than the clash of its politicians.

title: UGANDA RECEIVES $6 MILLION TO COMBAT AIDS
description: GENEVA, May 25 - Uganda has received more than $6 million in international assistance to begin a five-year plan for combating AIDS, the World Health Organization said today.

title: GOLDEN GATE CROWD MADE BRIDGE BEND
description: So many people jammed onto the Golden Gate Bridge for its 50th anniversary party that worried engineers did rapid calculations to make sure the span could support the weight, officials said today.

title: Esquire Asserts Its Leadership
description: IN THE OFFICES of Esquire, the men's room door is labeled neither ''Men'' nor ''Gentlemen,'' but ''Man at his finest,'' which is the subtitle of the magazine. With spirit like that, how can the 54-year-old publication be denied an industry leadership position?

title: METS TRIUMPH; METS 8, GIANTS 7
description: East Coast, West Coast, the Mets go struggling on.

title: DEATH OF 'BAKER PLAN' ON DEBT SEEN
description: The decision by Citicorp last week to admit to a staggering $3 billion in potential losses on foreign loans spells the end of the Reagan Administration's 20-month-old ''Baker Plan'' to deal with the turmoil over the debts of the developing countries, according to political and economic analysts.

title: 3 DIE AND 7 ARE HURT IN BEDFORD-STUYVESANT FIRE
description: Three people died and and seven others were injured, four critically, when a fire swept through the second- and third floors of a three-story brick building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn early this morning, officials said.

title: FROM LAGERFELD, FURS OF SPECIAL GRACE
description: Karl Lagerfeld, to practically nobody's surprise, has emerged as the hero of the fur showings in New York. After all, in his 20 years as designer for Fendi in Rome, he has built that company into the world's leading pace setter in fur fashions. Now he has added the French-based Revillon company to his repertory.

title: MAO'S HOME PROVINCE PROVES STUBBORN
description: Here in Hunan Province, where Mao Zedong was born, there are few signs of the economic transformations sweeping other areas in China, changes intended to invigorate industry and improve living standards.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Why Not a Black Mayor?: How New York Differs From Other Big Cities
description: On New Year's Day 1985, New York City seemed on the verge of historic change. Stirred by the Rev. Jesse Jackson's 1984 Presidential candidacy, the city's black masses appeared to have awakened politically, raising the hope of electing a black mayor. A citywide committee of black leaders, displaying unusual unity, formed to choose a candidate to oppose Mayor Koch in the Democratic primary.

title: Toward Leaner Meat
description: MALE sheep, pigs, cattle and chickens tend to grow faster and heavier than females and produce the leaner meat that health-conscious consumers prize.

title: IRAN WAVE IS A RIPPLE BACK HOME
description: It was a perfect setting for a bit of old-fashioned politicking, but out among the throng at the annual Strawberry Festival here, Representative Lee H. Hamilton cut a somewhat aloof figure.

title: BIG WALDENBOOKS STORES MIX CLASSICS AND TOYS
description: Just as the planned community that sprang up here in the potato fields of Nassau County set the pattern for the postwar migration to the suburbs, so Levittown may set the pattern for the bookstore of the future. Its name is Waldenbooks and More, a so-called superstore whose owners have ambitious plans for expansion.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Many Views

title: JOHN D. MCPHERSON, FOUNDER OF AN AIR FREIGHT COMPANY
description: John D. McPherson, who founded the Airborne Freight Corporation and headed it for 22 years, died of cancer Saturday at Mills Memorial Hospital in San Mateo, Calif. He was 64 years old and lived in nearby Hillsborough.

title: SHOTGUN'S BLAST MAY CREATE NEW FORMS OF LIFE
description: WORKING with a miniature shotgun that blasts gene fragments into the cells of living organisms, scientists believe they have hit upon a powerful technique for engineering new forms of life.

title: FAR FROM PASSIVE, MANY PLANTS LIVE IN A STATE OF WAR
description: IN fields, forests, city parks and suburban yards throughout the country, plants and trees are gearing up for an annual pitched battle against myriad enemies - predatory insects, pathogenic microbes, foraging animals and even other plants that try to invade their turf.

title: JOHNS HOPKINS EDGES CORNELL FOR TITLE
description: Craig Bubier scored his fourth and final goal with 1 minute 51 seconds remaining today to break a 10-10 tie with Cornell and give Johns Hopkins the national collegiate lacrosse championship.

title: Secretary Dole For F.A.A. Funds
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole is telling Congress that if it does not come up with more money for the Federal Aviation Administration, air safety may be affected.

title: Boat Races Transcend Earlier Racial Dispute
description: Racial discord was cast aside at a rowing competition that had once been marked by a dispute over comments by members of an all-white Boston team who said black rowers on a New York City club would not be welcome.

title: C.F.T.C. Chairman To Resign in July
description: Susan M. Phillips, chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission since November 1983, has informed the White House that she intends to resign on July 24 to take an administrative position at the University of Iowa.

title: China Finally Halts Its Worst Forest Fire
description: Tens of thousands of firefighters, with some help induced by seeding the sky, have finally extinguished the worst forest fire in China's history, the official Xinhua News Agency said today.

title: Doctor Guilty of Falsifying Drug Tests in Accident Cases
description: A doctor responsible for performing drug tests on employees involved in railroad and airplane accidents pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to giving officials false test results on workers in three train accidents.

title: New Computer Series by NCR
description: The NCR Corporation will announce a new series of personal computers today, in one of the first major responses to the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal System/2.

title: Mid-May Car Sales Fell 24.9%
description: Sales of the eight domestic automobile makers declined 24.9 percent in the middle of May, to a daily rate of 24,569, compared with 32,710 in the period last year.

title: GUNMEN WOUND 2 AMERICANS IN EGYPT
description: Two United States Embassy security officers were shot and slightly wounded here today while driving to work. The attackers, who escaped, fired an automatic weapon from another car.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
VARIATIONS ON 3-BEAN THEME
description: LEAD: TIME now for a word-association test. Picnic? Ants. Mai tai? Beach. That's fine.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RECOMMENDATIONS ON BISHOPS
description: Following are excerpts from a report to the Holy See by a commission of three Roman Catholic bishops named to assess the situation in the Archdiocese of Seattle, which is headed by Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen. The report is to be issued today in Washington.

title: Excluding the Public
description: To The Living Section:

title: Home Resales Down in April
description: Sales of existing homes edged down 1.4 percent in April, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.63 million units, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: SALERNO JURY TOLD TO AVOID PUBLICITY ON BAIL DECISION
description: A jury hearing evidence in the trial of Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno in Manhattan was told yesterday to avoid any news stories about the decision by the United States Supreme Court to uphold the detention without bail of defendants said to be dangerous criminals.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MAY 27, 1987
description: Markets

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We have repeatedly held that the Government's regulatory interest in community safety can, in appropriate circumstances, outweigh an individual's liberty interest.'' - Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. [ A21:1. ] ''But at the end of the day the presumption of innocence protects the innocent; the shortcuts we take with those whom we believe to be guilty injure only those wrongfully accused and, ultimately, ourselves.'' - Justice Thurgood Marshall. [ A20:6. ]

title: 12 Die in Guatemala Fighting
description: Two Government soldiers and 10 leftist guerrillas have been killed in two battles in the northern part of the country, the army announced. A statement released Monday night said the fighting occurred Sunday in Peten Province.

title: The Big Hand on the Diamond
description: The original Pulsar watch, with its startling red numerals on a black face, cost $2,100 in 1971. By 1985, Chiquita Bananas was giving away digital watches as favors at Yankee Stadium. Digital displays had become so ubiquitous that teachers worried that schoolchildren might never learn how to read a clock face.

title: 2,500 SUSPECTS HELD AS THREATS UNDER BAIL LAW
description: About 2,500 criminal defendants have been held by the Government without bail under the three-year-old law allowing pretrial detention of suspects considered dangerous to the public.

title: Giuliani's Idea
description: Ever wonder whether any of the policy recommendations by the hordes of witnesses appearing every week before Congress ever find their way into legislation?

title: FLORIDA BANK MERGER
description: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. and Home Federal Bank of Florida said they had signed an agreement calling for the conversion of Home Federal to a state-chartered savings and loan and then to a bank, and for its subsequent merger with the Barnett Bank of Pinellas County, a Barnett Banks subsidiary.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AS the society has become more health, weight and diet conscious, Americans, particularly children, have become fatter. This seeming paradox has its roots in environmental factors, among them easy access to high-calorie foods; the additional time spent watching television, which can lead to the consumption of foods advertised on television, and reductions in school physical education programs.

title: Solti, Ailing, Cancels Final Week of Concerts
description: Two young conductors will substitute for Sir Georg Solti, music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, for the season's final week of concerts, orchestra officials have announced.

title: Robots? Easy. Humans? Well ...
description: Companies like GTE rely on vendors to develop computer-controlled automation machinery capable of being tied into the CIM network. But some vendors are as much a part of the problem as the solution.

title: Edelman Presses for Burlington
description: Asher B. Edelman informed Burlington Industries yesterday that he might be willing to top the $76-a-share offer from the leveraged buyout group of Morgan Stanley Group Inc. and members of the textile company's management.

title: Regulate Medicare's 'Bottomless Pit'
description: Federal health officials are fond of calling the home health care component of Medicare a bottomless financial pit. If it is, that seems reason enough for those same officials to take an intense interest in how well the money dropping into the pit is being spent. That amounts to $2 billion a year so it's strange to say they don't.

title: SAVORING THE DELIGHTS OF SHAD AT FESTIVALS ALONG THE HUDSON
description: LARRY and Connie Weinberg of Montrose, N.Y., peered at Tom Lake, a fisherman proudly displaying a freshly caught silvery fish so large that each end draped far over the platter.

title: 2,000 ATTEND BUDDHIST CREMATION RITE IN VERMONT
description: A Tibetan teacher who made Buddhism accessible to a generation of Americans, including poets, psychologists and investment bankers, was cremated today in an ancient funeral rite before more than 2,000 students and friends.

title: REPUBLICANS SEE MARCH 8 VOTING AS OPPORTUNITY
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, speaking to Georgia Republicans in Savannah last week, took a swipe at Senator Sam Nunn, saying that if the Georgia Democrat wanted to conduct foreign policy, then he should ''suit up'' and run for President.

title: 'INVISIBLE TOUCH' LATEST IN GENESIS' 20-YEAR SPAN
description: WHEN Genesis performs at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., this Saturday and Sunday, the concerts will mark a pinnacle in the career of one of the longest-running English rock groups. Genesis, which was formed more than 20 years ago and released its first album in 1969, has sold over four million copies of its 16th album, ''Invisible Touch.'' The record has yielded five consecutive hit singles: ''Invisible Touch,'' ''Throwing It All Away,'' ''Land of Confusion,'' ''Tonight, Tonight, Tonight,'' and ''In Too Deep'' (currently No. 11 on Billboard's Hot 100 and climbing). It is by far the most tuneful album by a group whose original inspirations - ''art-rock'' groups like King Crimson and Yes -were noted for long-winded set pieces. Genesis has undergone any number of personnel changes through the years. Today the group consists of Tony Banks, Mike Rutherford and Phil Collins, They are joined in concerts by Daryl Stuermer and Chester Thompson.

title: Murdoch Named
description: As expected, Bob Murdoch, who was passed over for the No. 1 job with the Calgary Flames after five years as an assistant, was named head coach of the Chicago Blackhawks yesterday, reportedly with a two-year contract. The 40-year-old former defenseman succeeds Bob Pulford, who returned to his role as the Blackhawks' full-time general manager. Murdoch's 12-year playing career included stints with the Montreal Canadiens; the Los Angeles Kings, where he played for Pulford, and the Flames, where he was a player-assistant coach before serving as full-time coach.

title: Navy Awards Ship Contracts
description: The Navy awarded construction contracts for three new ships, including a $615 million deal with the General Dynamics Corporation for a new Trident missile submarine. The contract, given to General Dynamics's Electric Boat Division, calls for it to complete construction of the Trident by December 1992.

title: Wheaton Board Assailed on Move to Admit Men
description: Organizers of a failed drive to maintain Wheaton College as an all-women's school criticized the college trustees' decision to admit men as students beginning in the fall of 1988.

title: Resignation At Guinness
description: The deposed chairman and chief executive officer of Guinness P.L.C., Ernest Saunders, resigned from the brewer's board today, one day before shareholders were to vote on whether to oust him.

title: MET OPERA NARROWS REPERTORY PLANS
description: The Metropolitan Opera's proudly announced commissions to Jacob Druckman and John Corigliano for operas in celebration of its 1983 centennial are in disarray.

title: Japanese and Germans Must Just Spend More
description: To the Editor:

title: Judges Rule T.W.A. Must Rehire Strikers
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that Trans World Airlines flight attendants who struck the company last year may not be ousted from their jobs by workers who crossed the picket lines or by trainees hired to replace them.

title: TEXAS TOWN BURIES 17 TORNADO VICTIMS
description: Thousands of people joined with the surviving residents of this little town today as they buried 17 of the 29 people killed by the tornado that destroyed Saragosa.

title: BankAmerica In Japan Talks
description: The BankAmerica Corporation's chairman, A. W. Clausen, will meet with Japanese officials and businessmen later this week and next week to discuss possible Japanese purchases of new BankAmerica securities.

title: COURT BACKS LAW LETTING U.S. WIDEN PRETRIAL JAIL
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal courts may jail criminal defendants before trial if they are deemed a threat to public safety.

title: A Gloomy Report
description: A reporter from Washington can hardly make even a brief political tour of Paris and London these days without feeling uneasy about the Western alliance.

title: Drugs in the Bahamas
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Terrorism, Narcotics and International Operations is scheduled to hear testimony today from Gorman Bannister, son of former Foreign Minister Everette Bannister of the Bahamas regarding the reputed involvement of high-level Bahamian officials in drug trafficking.

title: Undeserved Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: MEROLA ROLE ON DONOVAN BRINGS PROTEST
description: The attorney for former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan urged yesterday that New York City or State bar associations investigate possible misconduct by District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx in his prosecution of Mr. Donovan and seven business associates on fraud charges.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Caterpillar Inc. is offering $100 million of 10 1/8 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 99 3/8 to yield 10.19 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: STANDARD ASSETS TO SHEARSON
description: The Standard Oil Company said yesterday that it would sell some of its manufacturing and mining assets, as well as a note held by one of its units, in a complex financial transaction valued at about $1.8 billion.

title: FRANK E. CANAVACIOL
description: Frank E. Canavaciol, an electrical engineer who taught at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn from 1919 to 1966, died Monday at Parkway Hospital in Queens. He was 91 years old and lived in Queens. He is survived by two daughters, Marie Giorgi of Queens and Vita Tauss of Manhasset, L.I.; a brother, John Canavaciol, and four grandchildren.

title: POP: RAGGAE SUNSPLASH
description: SOCIAL commentary - on apartheid, the disease AIDS, drugs, poverty and multinational investments - took a major role in this year's Reggae Sunsplash, the traveling reggae show that came to the Felt Forum on Monday as part of its 26-city North American tour. The show featured winners of Jamaican Music Industry (Jammy) Awards, and in five hours of music it offered a survey of current reggae - from pop with an eye on the international market to toasting (rapping) with a specifically Jamaican flavor.

title: NORWEST IS TAKING LOAN LOSS
description: The Norwest Corporation said yesterday that it would set aside $200 million for losses on its $650 million portfolio of troubled foreign loans. The action by the big Minneapolis-based bank holding company, the nation's 24th largest, will result in a $160 million second-quarter loss, wiping out 12.3 percent of its net worth, and a $30 million loss for the year.

title: FILM: 'THE SECOND VICTORY,' IN 1945
description: ''THE SECOND VICTORY'' is a brisk action movie abounding in colorful characters, picturesque scenery and the homilies of Morris West, who wrote the screenplay based on his novel. The adroitly plotted tale, which opens today at Cinema 1, takes place in 1945. No sooner does Anthony Andrews, as a British major with a conscience as big as the Alps, arrive to head the Occupation forces at a scenic Austrian town than his sergeant is killed. The search for the killer begins what Mr. West has conceived as a morality tale of justice, vengeance and mercy, but don't let that spoil your enjoyment.

title: Museum Mile Festival
description: More than 40 performers will offer a variety of music, from Dixieland jazz to classical, at the Museum Mile Festival on June 9. Museums along Fifth Avenue, from 82d Street to 104th Street, are to open their doors for the festival, which is to be held from 6 to 9 P.M., rain or shine.

title: Unser Is Unlikely At Meadowlands
description: Next month's Meadowlands Indy, as it is now called, and the other 12 races remaining on the Championship Auto Racing Teams schedule will likely have to do without Al Unser Sr., the winner of the Indianapolis 500 last Sunday.

title: European Steel Cutback
description: Steelmakers of the European Community will receive sharply lower production quotas for the third quarter of 1987 because of plummeting demand, the trade bloc said today.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE computer ate something this afternoon. I suppose that is inaccurate, or, as the computer itself might say, ''Error: file not found.'' The truth is that I did something wrong and a whole lot of words disappeared into that great ozone where all our computer mistakes float about in disconnected turns of phrase and truncated quadratic equations. I prefer to think that the computer ate something.

title: Bird Stole The Ball
description: Dennis Rodman did the boogaloo, a snazzy little two-step, with both arms pumping at midcourt. That's how happy he was. Then there was a noise behind him, and he wasn't happy any more. Just as the Detroit Pistons were doing a bit of premature celebrating on the parquet floor of Boston Garden, Larry Bird staged a quick-minded robbery that may rank along with the famous ''Havlicek Stole the Ball'' incident of the 1965 Celtics' championship season.

title: Yankees Are Solid on Defense
description: Somewhere, lost in all the hoopla about pitching and offense and the rise to first place, the defense has been neglected. Perhaps it is the way, Willie Randolph says, that the fielders are quietly performing their tasks. No one notices consistency.

title: Soviet Starts Radio Broadcasts to U.S. From Cuba
description: The Soviet Union began AM radio broadcasts to the United States from Cuba last weekend, about the same time it stopped jamming Voice of America transmissions, the United States Information Agency said today.

title: COURT BACKS ILLEGAL ALIENS IN A DEPORTATION CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that an alien re-entering the country after being deported cannot be convicted if he can show the original deportation order was invalid.

title: Bridge: Reisinger Knockout Event Is Marked by Major Upset
description: First-round play in the prestigious Reisinger Knockout Teams began at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan Monday afternoon and produced a major upset.

title: 2 ISRAELI INQUIRIES CLEAR TOP LEADERS IN POLAND AFFAIR
description: Two Israeli Government investigations into the Israeli espionage operation in Washington cleared all of Israel's political leaders today of any knowledge of or involvement in the Pollard spy affair.

title: Prosecutor Calls Bias 'Middleman'
description: The prosecutor in the trial of Brian Tribble said today that Len Bias, the former Maryland basketball star, acted as ''courtesy middleman'' for Tribble in the distribution of cocaine.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Ascension, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City tomorrow.

title: Kickoff for Apple Games
description: Mayor Koch took a pass from the Knicks' captain, Bernard King, and drove for a basketball hoop outside City Hall yesterday. The layup was perfect, as was the scenario kicking off the 1987 Mobil Big Apple Games.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: The Press Corps; How the Japanese Gain Perspective On Covering America
description: Toyohiro Akiyama, Washington bureau chief of the Tokyo Broadcasting System, bought a Chrevrolet Impala a couple years ago as his personal contribution to easing trade tensions between Tokyo and Washington. ''This is my own way to redress the trade imbalance,'' he said.

title: EXCERPTS FROM OPINIONS IN COURT'S DECISION ON DENIAL OF BAIL
description: Following are excerpts from the opinions in the Supreme Court's decision today in United States v. Salerno, upholding use of a 1984 Federal law to deny bail to a ''lethally dangerous'' Mafia leader and a co-defendant before trial to prevent them from carrying on crime that the Government argued included ''murder and mayhem.'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion, joined by Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun, Lewis F. Powell Jr., Sandra Day O'Conner and Antonin Scalia. Justice Thurgood Marshall dissented, joined by Justice William J. Brennan Jr. Justice John Paul Stevens wrote a separate dissent. FROM THE OPINION By Chief Justice Rehnquist The Bail Reform Act of 1984 allows a Federal court to detain an arrestee pending trial if the Government demonstrates by clear and convincing evidence after an adversary hearing that no release conditions ''will reasonably assure . . . the safety of any other person and the community.'' The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit struck down this provision of the Act as facially unconstitutional, because, in that court's words, this type of pretrial detention violates ''substantive due process.'' We granted certiorari because of a conflict among the Courts of Appeals regarding the validity of the Act. We hold that, as against the facial attack mounted by these respondents, the Act fully comports with constitutional requirements. We therefore reverse.

title: Ciba-Geigy Pursues Spectra-Physics
description: The Ciba-Geigy Corporation today offered to acquire Spectra-Physics Inc., the world's largest laser company, for $32 a share in cash, or about $194.7 million for all the shares it does not already hold. Ciba-Geigy, the Swiss pharmaceuticals giant, currently owns about 1.4 million shares, or 18.8 percent, of Spectra-Physics, which is based in San Jose, Calif.

title: Willkommen, Bienvenu
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 139587 -- No Title
description: In a move to ward off a hostile takeover bid by the British publisher Robert Maxwell, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. announced an elaborate recapitalization plan late yesterday that would saddle it with nearly $3 billion in debt.

title: On the Road With Bush
description: As part of his still unofficial campaign for the White House, Vice President Bush has tried in recent weeks to increase his efforts to re-establish his own political identity without distancing himself from President Reagan. It is a problem for Vice Presidents, political experts say, and one reason why no sitting Vice President has been elected to the Presidency since Martin Van Buren in 1836.

title: DOLLAR REBOUNDS STRONGLY
description: The weak dollar suddenly rebounded yesterday, posting one of its largest gains this year against almost all leading currencies on a wave of buying that began in Japan.

title: Herzog, Heine Names Officers
description: Herzog, Heine, Geduld Inc., a leading market maker in over-the-counter securities, announced yesterday that the board had elected John E. Herzog, 51 years old, as chairman and chief executive and that Emanuel E. Geduld, 44, would replace him as president. Mr. Herzog succeeds Max L. Heine, 76, who has been chairman since 1976, when his firm, Heine, Fishbein, was acquired by Herzog & Company. The board also named Irwin

title: Presidents Are Not Pastors
description: President Reagan's eulogy of the 37 men killed in the Iraqi attack on the frigate Stark and the personal solace he brought to survivors at the Mayport Naval Station in Florida constituted the latest evidence that he has become the nation's chief pastor.

title: The Constitution Is Still a Plan for All Seasons
description: To the Editor:

title: Vandals Uproot Plants Used in Bacteria Test
description: Vandals uprooted three-quarters of the 4,000 potato plants being studied in an outdoor test here of genetically altered bacteria, a leader of the project said today.

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. PRESENCE IN THE PERSIAN GULF WON'T LEAD TO WAR
description: President Reagan said today that the increased American military presence in the Persian Gulf would not lead to United States involvement in the Iran-Iraq war, now in its seventh year.

title: PRINCETON CLUBS TOLD TO LET IN WOMEN
