description: The last remaining all-male eating clubs at Princeton University were ordered by the state today to begin admitting women.

title: Big-Time Goals
description: For a National Collegiate Athletic Association member school with Division II status, Kutztown (Pa.) University has a success rate for gaining its brightest stars tryouts in National Football League training camps that larger and more prominent Division I universities might envy.

title: FIJI SHOPS CLOSE TO PROTEST COUP
description: Shops were closed and buses stopped running today in the western part of Fiji's main island in what was described as the first of a series of economic protests against the military-backed interim Government.

title: Surgery for Garvey
description: Steve Garvey, the San Diego first baseman, will undergo surgery Saturday to repair a ruptured tendon in the left shoulder area, the Padres announced yesterday. The rehabilitation period following surgery will take three to six months, team officials said. . . . Mike Schmidt, the Phils' star third baseman, has been placed on the 15-day disabled list because of a pulled muscle in his lower left rib cage area. Schmidt left the game against the San Diego Padres Monday in the fifth inning. He leads the Phillies with 13 home runs and 36 runs batted in while hitting .285.

title: Azorin Joins Dugan On Melitta Account
description: Azorin & Davis of New York and Dugan, Valva Associates of Fairfield, N.J., will share the responsibility for the Melitta account.

title: METS WIN AMID NEW WOES
description: The Mets suffered the fourth casualty in their five-man pitching rotation tonight when Rick Aguilera felt his right elbow tightening while he was warming up and was scratched as the starter against the San Francisco Giants.

title: Advertising; Atlantic Chief Dons Sales Cap
description: THE latest publisher of The Atlantic - and there have been a number in the last few years -is Robert E. L. Johnson, better known to masthead readers as Robin Johnson. He will be 30 years old on July 31.

title: Greycom Acquires 65% Of British Shop
description: In its first major acquisition Greycom, the public relations arm of Grey Advertising, has bought 65 percent of Sterling Public Relations of London, whose annual fee income last year was more than $2.8 million.

title: ADORNING A WALL OR A WRIST
description: 1. Collecting Street Art Architectural ornaments are the rage as wall decorations. This plaster cherub, for $26, is part of a collection of eye-catching reproductions from Gargoyles Studio in Brooklyn. Farfetched, at 110 Fourth Avenue in Manhattan, between 11th and 12th Streets, carries these street finds. 2. Bracelets, Anyone? Chris Evert's tennis bracelet is made of real diamonds, but this one is affordable. It is studded with cubic zirconia, which sparkles like diamonds. The clasp and the setting are gold tone. The bracelet costs $39 in the jewelry department on the main floor of Abraham & Straus, 422 Fulton Street (Hoyt Street), Brooklyn, and some branch stores. 3. Roses to Wear Here is a scented rosebud sachet necklace to wear on a romantic summer evening. It was made by hand in Vermont with real roses; $12 at Vermont Classics, 284 Columbus Avenue, at 73d Street. 4. Carrying It All Carrying a camera does not have to be an ordeal, not with this blond leather case made in Italy for Outback Red. It is attractive, compact, easy to carry and large enough to hold a camera, film and an extra lens or flash attachment. The price is $58. A matching date book, checkbook holder and key case are also available. At the Limited, 691 Madison Avenue (62d Street), and the South Street Seaport.

title: DR. MONROE M. BROAD
description: Dr. Monroe Maximilian Broad, a general surgeon, died May 19 at Long Island Jewish Hospital after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Queens.

title: Require Airline Truth in Scheduling
description: Airlines could help to ease air traffic congestion and reduce the danger of collisions by telling consumers the truth about expected arrival times of their flights. But since some airlines will not share this information voluntarily, Congress should make it Federal policy to require truth in scheduling. That would reduce the number of flights in highly congested areas at peak periods and ease the burden on air traffic controllers.

title: THEATER: ONE-ACTERS AT INTAR
description: IN spring, the Ensemble Studio Theater holds its annual marathon of one-act plays and, around the corner at Intar Stage 2 on West 53d Street, the Working Theater sponsors a satellite festival. The newer company shares some playwrights - and a point of view - with the more established Ensemble Studio. The idea is that a writer can say more - or at least, as much - in a brief period of stage time, if he limits his scope.

title: HOW $18 MILLION GOT SOVIET WEAPONS TO IRAN
description: About the time of the first disclosures about United States arms shipments to Iran, the Soviet Union quietly delivered more than $18 million in advanced weapons to Iranians, according to records of a French arms dealer.

title: HERBERT JACOBS, 30'S REPORTER WHO RESHAPED ARCHITECTURE
description: Herbert Jacobs, an emeritus lecturer at the University of California School of Journalism who helped change the course of American architecture, died of cancer last Wednesday in Berkeley, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: U.S. Soccer Unit Has Tough Task
description: Way back in 1885, 18 years before the first World Series and 8 years before Lord Stanley unveiled his hockey cup, the United States played its first soccer game against Canada - and lost, 1-0.

title: Johnson Top Choice
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson - who led the Los Angeles Lakers to 65 victories, the best record in the National Basketball Association this season -was the only player unanimously voted to the all-N.B.A. team announced yesterday. The 6-foot-9-inch Johnson, who has made the first team at guard for five straight years, and Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics, who has made it at forward in each of his eight seasons in the league, were the only two first-team repeaters from last season. This season, Johnson averaged a career-high 23.9 points and a league-leading 12.2 assists.

title: Scots Saluted
description: Jack Nicklaus's 12th annual Memorial Tournament at Muirfield Village Golf Club this week honors the memory of Tom Morris Sr. and his son, Tom Morris Jr., the Scots who were the most renowned players of the mid-19th century. They are best known as Old Tom Morris and Young Tom Morris, each of whom won four of the first dozen British Opens.

title: Waiting for Levine
description: On the other side of the Hill, the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, which is headed by Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, is preparing for the appearance of Dennis B. Levine, the former Drexel Burnham takeover specialist accused last year of a $12 million insider trading scheme.

title: Economic Scene; Floating Up To Venice
description: THE dollar rose sharply yesterday, and so did the stock market. Has there really been a turnaround in sentiment toward the dollar and the economy or is this just a temporary spurt sparked by speculation that the Federal Reserve is going to tighten money and raise interest rates, to float the dollar up before the Venice summit conference begins?

title: U.S. POSTPONES FINES FOR A MONTH ON HIRING OF ILLEGAL ALIEN WORKERS
description: Federal officials said today that they would generally not cite employers for hiring illegal aliens in June because the Government had not distributed forms needed to start enforcement of the new immigration law.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: FRIENDS often tell me they are reluctant to use pork chops as a main ingredient because the chops never come from the skillet quite tender enough. I suspect that often has to do with the quality of the meat, and there is no way to determine at a glance whether the meat is likely to be tender after frying.

title: Bodine Fined $15,000
description: Nascar officials have fined Geoff Bodine $15,000 and placed him on probation until Dec. 31 for rough driving during the Winn-Dixie 300 Busch Grand National race at the Charlotte (N.C.) Motor Speedway last Saturday. Three days before the event, Bodine was fined $1,000 and required to post a $4,000 bond for unsportsmanlike conduct in the Winston on May 17 at Charlotte.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CROOKED HEARTS. By Robert Boswell. 340 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Winthrop G. Brown, Ex-State Dept. Official
description: Winthrop G. Brown, a retired State Department official and former Ambassador to Laos and South Korea, died Monday at his home in Washington. He was 79 years old and had suffered from Parkinson's disease for several years.

title: STAGE: POLITICAL COMEDY
description: THE Iran-contra affair, the AIDS epidemic, New York City's corruption scandals and personalities ranging from Edwin Meese 3d to Barry Manilow were among the subjects addressed in an evening devoted to political comedy at Stand-Up NY (236 West 78th Street) on Monday. The show, which featured Robert Altman (also known as Uncle Dirty), Jim Morris, Beverly Mickins, Randy Credico and Scott Blakeman, was the second in an ongoing Monday night series of politically oriented shows presented by the club in association with WBAI-FM.

title: Lakers Are Eager for the Final Round
description: There was no champagne, no whirling series of high-fives in celebration. Moments after the Los Angeles Lakers had returned to the National Basketball Association final after a one-year absence on Monday, there was no feeling of redemption in their locker room. The mood was businesslike, almost solemn.

title: Sri Lanka Army Starts a Drive Against Tamil Rebels in North
description: Government troops started a long-awaited offensive today to try to break the hold that Tamil separatist rebels have on the northern Jaffna Peninsula, the Government reported.

title: Iran-Contra Lingo: From Fools to Dogface
description: The Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair are only three weeks old, but already they have produced some unusual lingo. A mastery of these terms may not be essential to understanding the essence of the inquiry. But it helps. Here are some of them: B.G. - The code name for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. It stood for ''blood and guts.'' Robert W. Owen, Colonel North's courier, was called ''T.C.,'' for ''The Courier,'' and Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord was known as ''Copp.'' General Secord's code name has nothing to do with police officers or plea-bargaining. He chose it, he said, on the spur of the moment because it was the name of the author of a book he was reading.

title: PHILANTHROPIST AND ART PATRON
description: Dr. Arthur M. Sackler, a research psychiatrist, entrepreneur and philanthropist who became one of this country's leading art collectors and patrons, died of a heart attack yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. RULES OUT A SHORT JAIL TERM FOR T.W.A. SUSPECT HELD BY BONN
description: The American Ambassador to Bonn told senior West German officials today that the United States would not accept any deal that resulted in the early release of a Lebanese suspected in the hijacking of an airliner.

title: Market Place; Analysts' View Of 'Baby Bells'
description: SHARES of the seven regional Bell companies have run into a selling squall since late last summer, when the stock market gradually changed gait to favor cyclical companies rather than the longstanding beneficiaries of a disinflationary environment. Last week three of these operating companies - Ameritech, Pacific Telesis and U S West - traded at their 52-week lows.

title: Reds Defeat Cubs On Parker's Homer
description: Dave Parker hit a homer to lead off the ninth inning tonight, giving the Cincinnati Reds a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: About New York; How Do You Get To the Subways? Practice, Practice
description: There is often a man on board the F train who plays the saxophone so atrociously - almost cruelly, really - that riders pay the man (who incidentally says he hails from Mars) to stop.

title: Real Estate; Converting SoHo Lofts Into Offices
description: THE demand for office space in Manhattan's SoHo area is so strong that some developers are pressing on with conversion plans for loft buildings in that neighborhood despite restrictions that limit the use of renovated space there.

title: Conflicting Images
description: To The Living Section:

title: The Constitution Is Still a Plan for All Seasons; Spark to Gunpowder
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: ROBOT CHEF'S NEW DISH: HAMBURGERS
description: AT the University of Wisconsin's fast-food laboratory here, the sesame-seed buns were delayed somewhere in browning. As a result, flame-broiled meat patties were dropping helter-skelter onto bare conveyor belts and a computer-controlled arm was lifting the top buns, flipping them through the air and setting them down where they should not have been.

title: ARSON BLAMED IN FIRE INJURING 13
description: A fire that injured 13 people, including 4 children, in a Brooklyn tenement early yesterday was caused by arson, the authorities said last night.

title: A YARDSTICK OF BEHAVIOR: DEADLY FORCE
description: Somewhere in the dark building lurked a man with a gun and, perhaps, an accomplice wielding a machete or a sawed-off shotgun.

title: 1940 MEMO CRITICIZED U.S. EMBASSY
description: Lawyers for a Marine guard accused of spying in the United States Embassy in Moscow have uncovered a confidential 1940 memo from J. Edgar Hoover that was highly critical of security measures in the embassy and urged that unmarried employees be assigned elsewhere.

title: Confronting the Truth
description: To The Living Section:

title: OIL PRICE RISE PREDICTED
description: World oil prices are likely to strengthen gradually to as much as $24 a barrel by 1990, Indonesia's oil minister, Subroto, said today. In a speech, he estimated would oil consumption at 47 million barrels a day, up from 45.6 million in 1985.

title: New York City Should Have Red-Light Cameras
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: May 27, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WEINBERGER ASKS FOR HELP IN GULF
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, describing Western access to the Persian Gulf as essential, called today for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies to join Washington's military effort to protect the movement of oil tankers in the gulf.

title: BROWN UPSET IN KENTUCKY PRIMARY BID
description: Wallace Wilkinson, a self-made millionaire making his first bid for public office, today won the Democratic nomination for governor of Kentucky after a remarkable rise from political obscurity.

title: JURY DECIDES NOT TO INDICT OFFICERS WHO MISTAKENLY SHOT AT TWO MEN
description: A Brooklyn grand jury has refused to indict three plainclothes police officers who fired a fusillade of bullets at two unarmed men crouched in a car last year in what the Police Department says was a case of mistaken identity.

title: COLUMBIA BEGINS DISCIPLINARY HEARINGS ON PROTEST
description: In an atmosphere that swung between student protest and courtroom trial, Columbia University yesterday began disciplinary hearings against 45 students who participated in a campus demonstration against racism.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Tokyo dispatch in some copies yesterday about a shake-up of the South Korean Cabinet misidentified the body that has replaced the Korean Central Intelligence Agency. It is the National Security Planning Agency, not the Legislative Administration Agency.

title: THE NEW YORK BABY'S GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LEAD: IT was the hushed finale of the second movement of Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony and the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Zubin Mehta, had just sounded the last chord. In that silence, Graceanna Baird, 3 months old, woke from her nap and screamed.

title: Fast, and Hasty, Draw in the Gulf
description: Talk about confusion. Iranian attacks on American vessels in the Persian Gulf could provoke war with the United States, a State Department official said last week. What did the White House think of that? ''We disagree,'' a spokesman said the next day. Months ago, Pentagon officials insisted that American warships in the gulf had the capability and authority to defend themselves. Now, 10 days after the attack on the Stark, White House officials complain that the Joint Chiefs of Staff have just got around to establishing clear rules of engagement for the warships.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MAY 27, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Israeli political leaders were cleared by two Government investigations of any knowledge of or involvement in the Israeli espionage operation in Washington. But the inquiries concluded that they bore technical responsibility. Page A1 Moscow shipped weapons to Iran after the first disclosures of United States arms shipments to that country, according to a French arms dealer's records. The Soviet shipment last December was valued at more than $18 million. A1 In Rumania, Mikhail S. Gorbachev explained his concepts of openness and restructuring to a mass rally of 5,000 party faithful. Of all the Eastern bloc leaders, the Rumanian chief is believed to be the least interested in introducing such policies. A1 Soviet broadcasts to the U.S. began from Cuba about the same time it stopped jamming Voice of America transmissions, officials said. Several stations in the South are assigned to the frequency the Russians used. A15 Klaus Barbie was returned to court in Lyons against his will to confront for the first time some of those who say he tortured them 43 years ago and sent them to Nazi camps. A1 In Cairo, two U.S. embassy guards were shot and slightly wounded by assailants in another car. Responsibility for the attack was claimed by Egypt's Revolution, which is believed to be linked to a faction led by Abu Nidal. A3 Increasing U.S. military presence in the Persian Gulf will not lead to United States involvement in the Iran-Iraq war. ''We're not there to attack anyone, but if fired upon, we will fire back,'' Mr. Reagan said. A14 Weinberger asks for help in gulf A14 William H. Webster was sworn in as Director of Central Intelligence. He pledged that America's agents would carry out their assignments ''with fidelity to the Constitution and to the laws of our beloved country.'' A14 The first economic protest in Fiji against the military-backed interim government began. Shops closed and buses stopped running in part of Fiji's main island in what was described as the beginning of a series of protests. A10 1940 memo on embassies A3 Ankara journal A4 Italian parties seek alliances A8 Hakim testimony delayed by panel A14 NATIONAL A16-21, B7 Federal courts may jail defendants charged with criminal offenses before trial if they threaten public safety, the Supreme Court ruled in a 6-to-3 decision. The ruling, which upheld a provision of a law passed in 1984, was one of the most important criminal law decisions in years. A1 2,500 suspects held as threats A1 Canada refused to honor a subpoena issued to its ambassador to the United States to testify at the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide. Mr. Deaver has been accused of lying under oath to Congress. A1 An archbishop will have his powers restored under a resolution of the controversy over the leadership of Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle. Archbishop Hunthausen will have to work with an assistant archbishop. A1 In the Kentucky gubernatorial race, Wallace Wilkinson won the Democratic nomination. Mr. Wilkinson, a self-made millionaire making his first bid for public office, solidly defeated former Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. A16 Employers who have hired aliens who are in the country illegally will not be cited in June because the Government has not distributed the forms needed to start enforcement of the new immigration law, officials said. A18 Parents' public outings with infants leave many people differing as to what is acceptable. Authorities on etiquette say they are increasingly being asked where to draw the line on taking babies to public events. C1 G.O.P. sees South as key A16 Doctor falsified drug test results A19 Sally Ride to leave NASA B7 Tornado victims buried B7 WASHINGTON TALK B6 How Japanese cover the capital Iran-contra lingo Quoting Bush, on the road REGIONAL B1-5, B7 The prosecutor in the Donovan trial, District Attorney Mario Merola, should be investigated by New York City or State bar associations for possible misconduct, the lawyer for Raymond J. Donovan said. B1 Masselli moves for quick trial B7 A game teaches police recruits about the use and misuse of deadly force. In the sessions on police tactics, the recruits take part in mock confrontations intended to parallel situations they might encounter on patrol. B1 Landlords want to increase the rent for rent-stabilized apartments in New York City by up to 18 percent for leases due for renewal in the 12 months beginning Oct. 1, a landlords' association said. B3 Retail milk prices have fallen in New York City an average of 17 percent since a Federal court allowed a New Jersey distributor into the tightly controlled market in January, a state survey has found. B3 2 Princeton all-male eating clubs were ordered by the State of New Jersey to admit women. The clubs were also ordered to pay $5,000 to the former student who filed the discrimination suit. B2 Operas commissioned by the Met in celebration of its 1983 centennial are in disarray. One commission has been canceled outright and a second will not be performed until the early 1990's, if then. C17 Beach homes are imperiled B1 Chinese theme park planned for New York state B2 Doctors are asked to fight AIDS B3 Officer testifies in Goetz case B3 Hearings begin for Columbia student protestors B3 Arson blamed for Brooklyn fire B3 Garbage barge ruling delayed B5

title: 3 DIE AS PLATFORM GIVES WAY
description: Lunch-hour pedestrians watched in horror as winds ripped a window-washing platform from near the top of a 36-story skyscraper and hurled it to the street today, killing two men aboard it and a woman on the ground.

title: Rates Decline At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly commercial paper auctions declined for the first time in five weeks.

title: ALLIANCES, NOT ISSUES, IN ITALY'S RACE
description: Kicking off the Christian Democrats' campaign in this city last week, the party secretary, Ciriaco De Mita, issued a dramatic warning. ''The alternative is around the corner,'' he said in a loud threatening voice.

title: THE SAN FRANCISCO SCENE: A NEW SIMPLICITY IN DINING
description: IN recent months San Franciscans have been haggling over how to fete their illustrious Golden Gate Bridge on its 50th birthday, but now that the celebration is over they can return to their most impassioned topic of conversation: Restaurants.

title: POLICE AND FIREFIGHTERS CLASH OVER EMERGENCIES
description: An internal debate has broken out between New York City's Police and Fire Departments over who is in charge in certain disasters and emergencies.

title: Matchbox Officer Turns From Dolls to Toy Cars
description: Thomas J. Kalinske, a man who helped to build the Barbie doll into what it is today, will turn his toy salesmanship to the Universal Matchbox Group, best known for its small metal cars.

title: RIDE QUITTING ASTRONAUTS FOR STANFORD
description: Sally K. Ride, the first American woman to fly in space, is leaving the astronaut corps to take a position as a science fellow at Stanford University, her alma mater, the space agency announced yesterday.

title: BARBIE IS FORCED TO FACE ACCUSERS IN COURT
description: Klaus Barbie was returned to court against his will today to confront some of those who say he tortured them in prison here 43 years ago and sent them to Nazi camps.

title: FLYERS' COMEBACK FORCES SIXTH GAME
description: The Flyers, facing elimination from the Stanley Cup final, came into tonight's game at Northlands Coliseum without much reason for optimism and then fell behind by two goals in the second period. But just as they had done in Game 3, Philadelphia staged a comeback, and the Flyers went on to a 4-3 victory over the Oilers.

title: Key Rates
FOOD NOTES
description: Sephardic Cooking Special dishes will be among the attractions at the Sephardic Fair Sunday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Congregation Shearith Israel, Central Park West at 70th Street. Pastries including borekas, baklava and biscotios will be sold, and Gilda Angel, a cookbook author, will autograph copies of her book ''Sephardic Holiday Cooking'' (Decalogue Books, $19.95). There will also be cooking demonstrations. Admission is $2 ($1 for the elderly and children). The fair will also feature crafts, entertainment and tours of the synagogue. Inexpensive Fish

title: GROUP WITH 13% STAKE SEEKS ALLEGIS CONTROL
description: A small New York-based investors' group emerged yesterday as a threat to the independence of the Allegis Corporation.

title: Self-Help Grows in Israel's Arab Villages
description: To the Editor:

title: GEORGIANS' JELLY SUCCESS
description: A thorny tree that thrives in the bogs of southwestern Georgia has become a symbol of success in an economically depressed area.

title: POP: LORRIES
description: CHRIS REED'S deep, sepulchral voice and the precisely modulated machine-shop drone of interlocking guitar harmonics define the Lorries' distinctive, hard-edged sound. Performing at the Ritz on Saturday, the quartet from Leeds, England, hadn't changed much since its first recordings, made in the early 80's.

title: Decline of the Diet
description: Fresh from a tortellini salad with high-cal dressing, a friend who works in midtown strolled through the International Paper Company Plaza on West 45th Street recently and found that she was not the only New Yorker who needed to walk off her lunch.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: ENVOY SUBPOENAED FOR DEAVER TRIAL
description: The Canadian Government said tonight that its Ambassador to Washington had been subpoenaed to testify at the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide, but would refuse to appear.

title: AFTER-TAX INCOMES FELL BY A SHARP 2.4% IN APRIL
description: American after-tax incomes took their sharpest plunge in 12 years last month as individuals dipped into savings to pay tax bills, the Commerce Department reported today. It said that after-tax incomes plummeted 2.4 percent in April while the personal savings rate fell to an all-time low of one-tenth of 1 percent.

title: Hartford National Sets Note Offering
description: The Hartford National Corporation is offering $150 million of 9.85 percent subordinated capital notes due in 1999 at a price of 99 7/8 to yield 9.868 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Pennzoil-Getty Pact Disputed
description: Thirteen former directors of the Getty Oil Company said in a statement that Getty never had a contract to merge with the Pennzoil Company in January 1984.

title: Gesture in the Gulf
description: On March 7, Secretary of Defense Caspar Weinberger, with the approval of President Reagan, notified the Government of Kuwait that the United States Navy would provide escort for 11 Kuwaiti oil tankers in the Persian Gulf.

title: GORBACHEV SPEAKS TO RUMANIANS ON 'OPENNESS' TO COOL RESPONSE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev explained his concepts of openness and restructuring today to a mass rally in the Communist country whose leader is believed to be the least interested in introducing such policies.

title: INSIDE
description: Surge for the Dollar The dollar rebounded on world markets, posting one of its largest gains of the year and lifting stock and bond prices sharply. Page D1. Brown Upset in Kentucky A political newcomer, Wallace Wilkinson, rose from obscurity to win the Democratic nomination for Governor over John Y. Brown Jr. Page A16. Alien Sanctions Put Off Because forms have been delayed, Federal officials will not cite employers for hiring illegal workers until after June. Page A18.

title: LISTLESS McENROE IS UPSET
description: LEAD: The scene was Round One of the French Open; the startled beneficiary, Horacio de la Pena, a young Argentine, who won, 4-6, 6-4, 6-2, 6-2, against a John McEnroe who seemed almost absent from the court.

title: EVANGELIST SAYS HE WAS MISLED IN GIVING UP PTL
description: Jim Bakker said tonight that he made a ''terrible mistake'' in turning over his PTL television ministry to the Rev. Jerry Falwell and accused Mr. Falwell of misleading him by pretending the arrangement would be temporary.

title: BOND PRICES TURN UPWARD
description: Bond prices rose sharply yesterday, erasing all the declines of the previous two weeks and injecting new optimism in a market dominated by despair in recent months.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Floating Happy Hour In the old days, New York's harbor trafficked in human and material cargo in numbers unequaled in the nation. Although the port has now surrendered its primacy, the harbor is playing a major role in leisure-time activities. Joining the sightseeing boats and daytime cruise ships are vessels bouncing gently around Lower Manhattan for a couple of evening hours, catering to people who want to listen to music, dine, dance, and cool off.

title: DESPITE A STATE PLAN FOR ISLIP'S GARBAGE, JUDGE DELAYS RULING
description: New York State officials, trying to end an impasse over how to dispose of 3,100 tons of garbage that have been aboard a barge since March, offered a detailed plan yesterday on how to unload and truck the garbage to Islip, L.I.

title: DANCE: 'DELICATE PREY'
description: FRED HOLLAND trained as a painter before he turned to performing and choreography. His new ''Delicate Prey,'' performed on Saturday night at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, is filled with visual imagery whose muted quality makes it seem to exist beyond some mysterious scrim, though none is there. The three performers have that same quality of soft-edged vividness. We seem to have wandered into someone else's dream, though not always entrancingly.

title: MASSELLI MOVES FOR QUICK TRIAL ON MURDER CHARGES
description: One of the men acquitted in the fraud and larceny trial of Raymond J. Donovan sent his lawyer back to the same Bronx courthouse yesterday to file papers seeking a quick trial on a murder charge that sparked the fraud case.

title: Gooden: 7 Innings, 9 Hits
description: Dwight Gooden, making his fourth start since his cocaine rehabilitation treatment, again struggled and was hit hard tonight in pitching seven innings for Class AAA Tidewater in a 5-4 International League victory over Pawtucket.

title: HAKIM TESTIMONY PUT OFF BY PANEL
description: In a change of plans, the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair have decided to delay taking public testimony from Albert Hakim until next week.

title: WEBSTER SWORN IN AS C.I.A. DIRECTOR
description: William H. Webster was sworn in today as Director of Central Intelligence and pledged that America's intelligence agents would ''carry out their assignments throughout the world with fidelity to the Constitution and to the laws of our beloved country.''

title: Agreement Is Reached On Spectradyne Buyout
description: Spectradyne Inc., the nation's largest operator of pay-per-view hotel movie systems, said today that it had agreed to be acquired for $452 million, or $46 a share, in cash and securities.

title: GETTING MACHINES TO COMMUNICATE
description: DEEP in the vast GTE Corporation telephone switch factory here, portions of a model factory that will be the centerpiece for next month's Advanced Manufacturing Systems Exposition in Chicago are being put through their final tests.

title: LANDLORDS SEEK RENT RISE UP TO 18%
description: The landlords of rent-stabilized apartments in New York City said yesterday that they wanted rent increases of up to 18 percent on apartments whose leases are due for renewal in the 12 months beginning Oct. 1.

title: OFFICER TELLS OF REMARK ON INTENT TO ROB GOETZ
description: The first police officer to reach the four youths shot by Bernhard H. Goetz testified yesterday that one of them, lying on the floor, had said, ''We were gonna rob him, but the white guy shot us first.''

title: Sosnoff May Raise Bid for Caesars
description: Martin T. Sosnoff said he would consider raising his $32-a-share cash tender offer for Caesars World Inc. under certain conditions.

title: Cruise Ships Mix Science And Romance
description: CAPT. JEAN-MARIE GUILLOU, standing on the bridge of the 440-foot-long Wind Song, the longest and most technically advanced sailing ship ever built, gave the order to set sail into New York Harbor. He extended his right index finger, tapped a few buttons on the console in front of him, and nodded approvingly as the computer monitor diagrammed each of the ship's six triangular sails as they began unfurling automatically.

title: MBIA Announces Plan For Initial Public Sale
description: The Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, the largest insurer of tax-exempt bonds, has announced plans for an initial public offering of common stock.

title: WINE TALK
description: LEAD: VENTANA means window.

title: Stocks Rise Broadly; Dow Up 54.74
description: The stock market, buoyed by what equity investors saw as good news from the other financial markets, staged a broad advance yesterday that included the third-best point gain ever in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: A TIME FOR PUBLISHERS TO FOCUS THEIR HOOPLA
description: After a farewell banquet, the curtain will descend tonight on the four days of entertainment and hoopla that have dominated the convention of the American Booksellers Association. The hard part will begin in a few months, when the fall books that have been on display here begin wending their way out of warehouses into the nation's bookstores.

title: Vindication for Mr. Donovan
description: For more than three years Raymond Donovan, the former Secretary of Labor, has had the unhappy distinction of being the first sitting Cabinet officer to be indicted. The Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, accused him and his construction company of stealing $7.4 million from New York City in connection with a huge subway tunnel project. Now, after nine grinding months of trial, Mr. Donovan stands acquitted, entitled to reclaim his reputation.

title: FLOOD INSURANCE CUTBACKS IMPERIL JERSEY BEACH HOMES
description: Old maps show a small waterfront colony at Moore's Beach here on Delaware Bay, but the tides have been rising for years. Now Charles and Marie Holmes are the last year-round residents.

title: TURKS FINALLY ASK, ARE WE EUROPEANS OR WHAT?
description: In a salon usually reserved for artistic debate, a group of 200 people gathered the other day to discuss a question that reflects a national enigma: Are Turks Europeans?

title: Disagreement on Ethics Outlined by Anderson
description: The State Senate's majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, emerged this evening from a three-hour meeting with Senate Republicans and said there were still two main areas of disagreement between them and Governor Cuomo on proposed ethics legislation.

title: MORGAN LIBRARY NAMES SCHOLAR ITS NEW DIRECTOR
description: Charles Eliot Pierce Jr., a scholar of English literature and the chairman of the English department at Vassar College, has been named the new director of the Pierpont Morgan Library, one of the nation's leading museums and centers for scholarship in the field of printed books, illuminated manuscripts and drawings.

title: Deadline Near On W-4 Form
description: It is one of those once-in-a-lifetime offers from the Internal Revenue Service that nobody can refuse. But millions are refusing, and the offer is about to expire.

title: CONCERT: BIG APPLE CHORUS
description: BARBERSHOP harmony singing, the four-part unaccompanied male vocal style that became popular in the late 19th century, still flourishes in this country, thanks largely to groups like the 130-voice Big Apple Chorus. This mighty ensemble, led by its conductor-director, Don Clause, was the headline act in a Saturday evening program at Carnegie Hall that also featured seven self-contained barbership quartets of varying stripes.

title: Ueberroth Speaks
description: Speaking at College Park, Md., Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth urged University of Maryland graduates yesterday to let the accomplishments of Len Bias and Judy Resnik, two ''remarkable people with great, God-given skills,'' serve as inspiration for them. Bias, a Maryland basketball star who was drafted in the first round by the Boston Celtics, died of cocaine intoxication last year. Resnik, who received her doctorate at Maryland, died in the explosion of the Challenger space shuttle.

title: CATHOLICS WORK OUT COMPROMISE IN DISPUTE ON SEATTLE ARCHBISHOP
description: A compromise has been reached in a dispute over Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen's leadership that will largely restore his powers in the divided Seattle Archdiocese but require him to work with an assistant.

title: PRIVATE DOCTORS URGED TO BATTLE SPREAD OF AIDS
description: New York City's Health Commissioner urged the city's 25,000 private physicians yesterday to accept a much larger responsibility in containing the spreading AIDS epidemic.

title: CELTICS, ON STEAL, LEAD SERIES, 3 - 2
description: Larry Bird did not let the Boston Celtics lose tonight.

title: Shortline Resumes Service
description: Bus drivers and mechanics for Shortline Bus System were back at their jobs today for the first time since May 7, when they went on strike, affecting 10,000 riders in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania. The employees of the commuter bus service approved a new contract Saturday by a 2-to-1 margin.

title: Powerful Debuts
description: Mark McGwire, an Oakland rookie, is leading the American League in home runs with 16, and is slugging them at the astounding rate of one every 7.75 times at bat. If he were able to maintain that pace, the 6-foot-5-inch, 220-pound first baseman would need only 303 times at bat to break the rookie home run record of 38, shared by Wally Berger and Frank Robinson. The top 10 home run totals by rookies: Year Player, team AB HR 1930 Wally Berger, Braves 555 38 1956 Frank Robinson, Reds 572 38 1950 Al Rosen, Indians 554 *37 1934 Hal Trosky, Indians 625 35 1937 Rudy York, Tigers 375 35 1983 Ron Kittle, White Sox 520 35 1950 Walt Dropo, Red Sox 559 34 1963 Jimmie Hall, Twins 497 33 1971 Earl Williams, Braves 497 33 1986 Jose Canseco, Athletics 600 33 *Led league.

title: TALENTS INSPIRED BY THE COOKS OF MEXICO
description: SOME children receive a set of encyclopedias or an unabridged dictionary when they graduate from grade school. Not Rick Bayless. His parents, who owned a barbecue restaurant in Oklahoma City, gave him a copy of Julia Child's ''Mastering the Art of French Cooking.'' Every weekend in the ensuing summer, he cooked a complete meal from the book, making his family ''sit down and suffer through'' each of them. The family drew the line when he wanted to dig a pit in the backyard for a luau.

title: Fairview to Sell U.S. Properties
description: The board of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation today voted to approve the sale of its office buildings and business parks in the United States to a group led by Copley Real Estate Advisers and Michael V. Prentiss, president of the company's United States commercial properties division. Copley Real Estate, which is based in Boston, is acting on behalf of a number of investors, including the New England, formerly known as the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company. The sale, which Cadillac

title: 'ELSEWHERE' SEASON FINALE
description: FIVE years ago, in its very first episode, NBC's ''St. Elsewhere'' revealed that kindly Dr. Auschlander (Norman Lloyd) was suffering from a terminal illness. The chances of his making it through a single season looked decidedly slim. But thanks to the miracle of arbitrary plot developments, the good doctor is still among the ongoing characters, bringing a semblance of depth to the St. Eligius capers with an occasional homily on man's flawed nature. In fact, tonight at 10 o'clock he plays a major role in what looks like a determined effort to have the series self-destruct. The episode may have been written by the series producers, John Masius and Tom Fontana, before ''St. Elsewhere'' got word that, against normal odds, it was being renewed for a sixth season.

title: CLAMOR FOR CHANGES IN THE FUTURES PITS
description: In the rough-and-tumble world of the nation's busiest futures pits - where as many as 700 traders shout their orders and elbow for position for hours each day while trying to remain on two feet - it has become increasingly difficult to discern prices and execute orders.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day yesterday misidentified the new president and chief operating officer of Steris Laboratories Inc. He is James C. McGee.

title: STUDY SHOWS 17% DROP IN NEW YORK MILK PRICES
description: Retail milk prices in New York City have fallen an average of 17 percent since a Federal court allowed a New Jersey distributor into the tightly controlled market in January, a new state survey has found.

title: 'FACES OF THE ENEMY,' A DOCUMENTARY
description: THE central thesis of ''Faces of the Enemy'' is stated early by Dr. Sam Keen, who wrote and narrated this earnest documentary based on his book of the same title: ''Before we make war, even before we make weapons, we first create the idea of an enemy whom we can fight.'' Not a complicated thought, nor an original one, but it is made vivid by Bill Jersey, who produced and directed the hour-long program that can be seen on Channels 13, 21 and 31 tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: DEVELOPER SAYS CHINESE AGREE ON THEME PARK
description: A New York developer said today that he had signed a $17 million contract in Beijing last week to build a Chinese theme park 60 miles north of New York City.

title: Japan Moving to Open Markets to Foreigners
description: A senior Japanese official today disclosed that Japan was taking further steps to open its financial markets to American and other foreign institutions.

title: Yields Rise Moderately
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds showed moderate increases for the week ended yesterday.

title: TV PREACHERS AIR MORE ACCUSATIONS
description: The trouble with television evangelists reached new heights today as the Rev. Jerry Falwell and the Rev. Jim Bakker traded heated public accusations.

Lockheed Stock Soars on Rumors
description: The Lockheed Corporation's stock jumped sharply today in heavy trading. Wall Street analysts said there was speculation that the General Electric Company, the Ford Motor Company or the Chrysler Corporation would make a bid to acquire Lockheed, a major military and aerospace contractor. All four companies declined to comment. Lockheed's shares rose $6.375, to $52.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. On Tuesday, the stock rose $2.125 a share.

description: Rothschild Inc., a New York investment firm, said yesterday that it had opened an office in Vancouver, British Columbia, and named Daniel Pekarsky, a Canadian businessman, to be its authorized representative in Canada.

title: City College
description: The City College of New York held its 141st commencement yesterday, conferring 1,700 bachelors' degrees.

description: The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect acquisitions made during fiscal 1987 which are accounted for on a pooling of interest basis.

description: Goldome Federal Savings of Buffalo, which is planning a public offering, will herald the event with $1 million worth of advertising in 30 days.

title: Iran's Fast Missile: What It Can Do
description: The Chinese-built missiles recently obtained by Teheran have a range of 50 miles and a warhead weighing 1,100 pounds.

title: COLONEL RECOUNTS HOW NORTH RAN CONTRA OPERATION >
description: A former Air Force colonel described in detail today how Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North directed the secret aerial supply of munitions for the Nicaraguan rebels at a time when the program was dogged by almost comical problems.

title: New Quotation Service
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C. yesterday introduced the Equities 2000 quotations service, which will, according to the news and information company, eventually be able to supply quotations ''on every significant stock, commodity, options and futures exchange in the world.'' The new system, which Reuters says is far more extensive than anything provided by its rivals, ''will be particularly useful to traders and treasurers of multinational corporations.'' For example, the system allows the user to see, simultaneously, how a stock, bond, option or futures contract is trading in different markets around the globe.

title: NEWARK BEGINS TO DEMOLISH TROUBLED HOUSING PROJECTS
description: There was a series of muffled explosions and then, to cheers and shouts, two 13-story buildings at the Scudder Homes project collapsed into rubble today.

title: Soviet Denies a Report Of Iran Arms Shipment
description: Tass, the official Soviet press agency, denied a report in The New York Times today that the Soviet Union secretly delivered weapons worth more than $18 million to Iran in December.

title: WIENER ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes a sales gain of $6,876,000 from the company's Builderama unit. The latest quarter results include 13 weeks, compared with 14 weeks for the year-ago first period.

title: Varity Cuts Jobs, Takes a Charge
description: Varity Corporation, the manufacturer of farm and industrial machinery formerly named the Massey-Ferguson Corporation, said it would eliminate 1,500 jobs, or about 8 percent of its worldwide employment. As a result, the company said it would take a first-quarter charge of nearly $10 million (United States), an action that would result in a loss in the quarter ended April 30 of $13.8 million.

title: Bridge: Veteran Makes a Comeback In Quarterfinal of Reisinger
description: The Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, a prestigious postscript to the Eastern Regionals, moved to the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan, for the semifinal stage, which began last night.

title: PENTAGON SEEKS CHIP EXPORT CONTROL
description: The Defense Department is seeking key changes in bureaucratic procedures that could lead to curbs on exports of advanced semiconductor products, even as the Reagan Administration steps up efforts to increase exports.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS HE BROKE NO LAWS
description: President Reagan, acknowledging that his credibility had been damaged, said today that he had not been involved in illegal acts in the Iran-contra affair and blamed the Washington press corps for creating a false impression that he had.

title: BLOCK DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding for the year-ago quarter; the latest year and year-ago period are restated for stock dividend declared October 1986.

title: For a U. S. Lottery
description: LEAD: Passing up an opportunity to increase gross receipts would be viewed as bad business for companies with income statements consistently in the red. Yet opponents of a national lottery advocate the equivalent poor-business policy for the Government.

title: RULE CLOSES RAIDERS' LOOPHOLE
description: The Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department today announced a new regulation that effectively closes a legal loophole that has permitted corporate raiders to hide their takeover activities for up to several weeks.

title: Market Place; Allegis: Parts Vs. the Whole
description: ARE the parts of the Allegis Corporation worth substantially more than the whole? That is the key question in the developing battle for control of the company whose single most valuable part is United Airlines. From recent rapid rises in the price of the stock, the answer would appear to be yes.

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid May 1.

title: SEATTLE'S BISHOP RESUMES CONTROL
description: A smiling and confident Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen, in command of his archdiocese for the first time since the Vatican stripped him of much authority more than a year ago, said today that he still did not understand why his ministry came under criticism by the church authorities.

title: The Honduras Ranch
description: A supplemental appropriations bill now on the Senate floor may provide a way out of a festering diplomatic impasse involving a United States citizen's 14,000-acre ranch in a remote area of northern Honduras.

title: JAZZ: MINGUS DYNASTY
description: A California edition of Mingus Dynasty, the group formed to perpetuate the music of Charles Mingus, is at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at Perry Street, through Sunday. The group's four winds -John Handy on alto saxophone, Craig Handy (no relation) on tenor saxophone, Jimmy Knepper on trombone and, joining the group for this engagement, James Newton on flute - all reside on the West Coast, and true to jazz truisms, they have a lighter, smoother approach than most New York players.

title: SARTRE AND FRIENDS IN TWO-PART SERIES
description: SHOULDERS hunched, hands on knees, cigarette at the ready, Jean-Paul Sartre seems about to pounce as he delivers what amounts to a monologue about his youth, his education, his life as writer, philosopher and political activist. It is 1976, four years before his death, and he is in his Montparnasse study surrounded by books, papers, visitors and television gear. Beside him, tossing in an apercu now and then in fast-forward fashion, is Simone de Beauvoir. Such is the setting of ''Sartre by Himself,'' the first 90 minutes of which can be seen on Channel 13 tonight at 11. Sartre takes Sartre up to the German occupation of France during World War II. The second half will be shown next Thursday at the same hour.

title: Ballet Contest to Open June 23 at City Center
description: More than 50 young dancers from 28 countries will take part in the second New York International Ballet Competition, beginning June 23 at 7:30 P.M. at City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTAINER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $148,000 for the quarter and $330,000 for the year. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid last June 24.

title: Channell's Diet
description: Members of the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair may see a leaner witness than they were expecting when Carl R. (Spitz) Channell testifies next month. The conservative fund-raiser was recently overheard telling his neighborhood pharmacist that Richard V. Secord, the retired Air Force general who was the opening witness at the hearings, looked ''pudgy'' on television. Mr. Channell, who pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud the Government and is expected to testify about raising funds on behalf of the Nicaraguan rebels, confided that he himself was feeling a bit pudgy and hoped to appear less so by the time he goes before the television cameras.

title: FAWN HALL FAN: A COLONEL
description: A former Air Force colonel who managed a supply operation for the Nicaraguan rebels, Robert C. Dutton, emerged today as the mysterious man whose message from the jungle included a reference to Fawn Hall, Lieut. Col. Oliver North's secretary.

title: EX-CHAIRMAN SUES GUINNESS IN OUSTER
description: Sir Norman Macfarlane, the new chairman of Guinness P.L.C., said today that the scandal-plagued company's former chairman, Ernest Saunders, was suing Guinness for unfair dismissal.

title: DAY FOR THE FRENCH TO CONQUER PARIS
description: Despite the leaden skies, it was a bright and wholly unexpected day of triumph for French tennis. Two of France's lightly regarded young players defeated the world's third-ranking man and fourth-ranking woman while another young Frenchman buried in the depths of the computer listings beat an American 262 places above him.

title: ALL IN THE SPIRIT OF SPORT
description: ON June 4 the Muriel Karasik gallery is opening an exhibition of sports memorabilia in the form of home furnishings, accessories and jewelry. The 500 pieces, which Tk. Karasik has gathered from England, France, Austria, Czechoslovakia and the United States, include sofas, candlesticks, ashtrays, cigarette lighters, dishes and key chains that represent either an instrument of a sport or people playing a sport. Most of the pieces are from the 30's and 40's. ''The show reveals each country's passion for sports, and that people were just as interested and competitive in sports in 1910 as they are today,'' said Victoria Karasik, daughter of the gallery's owner and co-curator of the show. The least expensive objects, such as ashtrays and key chains, start at $50. The English sterling silver candlesticks in a tennis motif, below left, are $400 the pair. The American chrome and wire skier, below center, is $425. The Italian leather lounger shaped like a boxing glove, below right, is $6,000. The 1940's English teapot made to resemble a golf ball, bottom right, is $250. They will be available at Muriel Karasik, 1094 Madison Avenue, at 82nd Street

title: A WARNING WAS IGNORED WHEN BRIDGE THAT FAILED WAS BUILT
description: The Schoharie Creek was narrowed during construction of the bridge that collapsed last month, despite an engineer's warning that a narrower creekbed could increase the pressure on the bridge and endanger it during floods, state officials said today.

description: In a visit filled with symbolism for Quebec and its new accommodation with the rest of Canada, Francois Mitterrand today became the first French President to visit this city since Charles de Gaulle called for a ''free Quebec'' 20 years ago.

description: Soviet jamming of radio broadcasts has been yet another reason for skepticism about Moscow's new policy of openness. But the Russians quit jamming the BBC some weeks ago and now they have also stopped interfering with Voice of America broadcasts.

title: THE STAGE: 'ENO,' SOLO MIME
description: THE purest moment in Eno Rosenn's one-man mime show at the Cherry Lane Theater comes late in the evening in a skit called ''The Rat Race.'' As the lights go up, we discover the performer tensely running in place, his elbows locked to his sides, struggling to maintain his position in an unseen river of humanity. Suddenly, the runner crumples to the floor. Sound effects and recorded dialogue inform us that he has had a heart attack. As a medical team tries frantically to save his life, Mr. Rosenn slowly rises to his toes and is tugged heavenward. Extending his arms into rippling liquid wings, the 27-year-old mime seems to float blissfully in space, drawn toward a welcoming chorus of angelic hallelujahs.

description: ''Beverly Hills Cop II'' lived up to expectations and proved itself a box-office blockbuster over the holiday weekend, marking up the biggest single-day earnings in film history.

description: Robert Liburd, a highly recruited basketball player who never got a chance to start his collegiate career because of a rare heart problem, died Tuesday in his Temple University dormitory room, a school spokesman said.

title: BARBIE TRIAL HEARS OF THE MORNING 44 CHILDREN WERE SENT OFF TO DIE
description: The trial of Klaus Barbie for crimes against humanity turned today to what is widely seen as the single most horrific charge against him - responsibility for the arrest of 44 Jewish children and their deportation to the gas chambers of Auschwitz.

title: TAKING FARFLUNG POLITICS TO THE OUTER HEBRIDEANS
description: On a day of rare warmth and brilliance for this misty island that makes its living off pen-raised salmon and Harris Tweed, Dr. David Owen tackled yet again the most daunting task in British politics. He was trying to talk people into voting for a third party that offers little hope of an outright victory.

title: CHASE JOINS BANKS TAKING LOAN LOSS
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday became the latest big lender to concede that a lot of its third world loans are uncollectible.

description: There is some feeling that a record score of 18-under-par 270 or better might be achieved at the 12th annual Memorial Tournament, Jack Nicklaus's invitation event that starts Thursday on his magnificent Muirfield Village Golf Club course.

title: Hollinger Takeover
description: Conrad Black, a Canadian businessman who controls London's Daily Telegraph, is acquiring a major French-Canadian newspaper publisher, according to Hollinger Inc., Mr. Black's company. Hollinger said it would form a limited partnership with Montreal-based Unimedia Inc. in order to acquire Unimedia's assets, which include French-language newspapers in Ontario and Quebec. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Harcourt Shares Soar Amid Heavy Trading
description: The stock of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. jumped a little more than $9 in heavy trading yesterday as Wall Street reacted favorably to the company's $3 billion recapitalization plan.

title: Short Sales Outstanding Up by 21.5% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended May 15 rose 42.3 million shares, or 21.5 percent, to 238.7 million shares.

title: WIRE AND PLASTIC 'FABRICS' AT GALLERY
description: TELEPHONE wires, aluminum siding and strips of translucent plastic replaced traditional yarns in the works of five weavers now on display at the Gayle Willson Gallery in Southampton, L.I. These modern materials were adapted to the time-honored methods of fabric making by the artists, who took advantage of their glowing colors, rigidity or flexibility.

title: ACTION AUTO STORES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Triple Threat
description: After graduating last week from Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn., Julia Kirtland is planning an extensive vacation from academic studies and serious physical training. She deserves it.

title: MERGER OF TWO GROUPS SERVING ART MUSEUMS
description: Two little-known powers in the art museum world - the American Federation of Arts and the Art Museum Association of America - announced yesterday that they would merge, forming the single largest museum service organization in the country.

title: PROFESSIONAL CARE SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results are restated.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER SOUND
description: CHAMBER SOUND, a six-year-old group of 11 talented young Juilliard graduates, presented a diverting concert of mostly unpretentious music Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. The playing was fine and earnest and thoughtful and safe.

title: Bid to Curb Animal Research
description: A fund to find alternatives to the use of animals in research has been established in the School of Veterinary Medicine at the University of California, the school announced today. Dr. Bennie Osburn, the school's associate dean for research, said the new fund would be used to generate research techniques and testing protocols that do not require the use of animals. Emphasis will also be placed on developing substitutes for animals in instructional laboratories, he said.

title: BRANCH SHOWROOMS FOR SATURN CARS
description: Dealers selling Saturn cars, the well-publicized line of small automobiles due early in the next decade, will be expected to use branch showrooms in shopping malls and office buildings in a new approach to automobile retailing, executives of the General Motors Corporation subsidiary said today.

title: COMPANIES JOIN IN PLAN FOR MADISON SQ. GARDEN
description: Plans for a vast new office and entertainment center on the West Side of Manhattan - including a new Madison Square Garden - moved a step forward yesterday when Gulf and Western Inc. and the largest real estate developer in New York City agreed to work together on the project.

title: Reappoint Paul Volcker
description: President Reagan faces a critical choice for chairman of the Federal Reserve Board when Paul Volcker's second term expires in August. The smartest move would be to stick with the chairman he's already got - and do it now. Mr. Volcker takes needed stands on unpopular issues, sticks by them and takes the heat that timid politicians fear.

title: Saving Money on Health Services to the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: UPSET IN DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY: KENTUCKY FERVOR FOR A CHANGE
description: Wallace Wilkinson, the politically unknown millionaire who swept to victory Tuesday in Kentucky's Democratic gubernatorial primary, built his campaign on calls for change, youthful energy and action.

title: STEVENS, J P & CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes $64,379,000 and $133,483,000 for the quarter and 6 month period, respectively, from the finished apparel fabrics divisions which were divested during that year.

title: MEROLA DEFENDS HANDLING OF 2 BIG CASES
description: In February there was a verdict of not guilty in the Eleanor Bumpurs case, and on Monday the same verdict in the Raymond J. Donovan trial.

title: THE BILLIARD ROOM IS BACK IN FASHION, AND SO IS THE GAME
description: THE billiard room: the very phrase seems to summon images that are strongly contradictory. A place of graceful skill and leisurely camaraderie, the billiard room is also seen as the chamber of impropriety, the den of foul language and fouler cigar smoke.

title: Worker Dies in Roof Collapse
description: A supermarket roof collapsed Tuesday while it was being renovated, killing a repairman and slightly injuring a woman, officials said. The repairman, Edward Mamasian, was trapped when half the roof of the two-story J. C. Supermarket collapsed after a beam holding two supports gave way without warning, the authorities said. The woman was treated for minor cuts at Misericordia Hospital and released; six other people escaped the building without injury, officials said.

title: BANCTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $194,000 for the quarter and a gain from an accounting change of $513,000 for the year.

title: Household Finance Is Marketing Notes
description: The Household Finance Corporation yesterday offered $150 million of 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.50 to yield 8.86 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Texaco to File Appeal by June 16
description: A lawyer for Texaco Inc. said the company would file an appeal with the Texas Supreme Court by June 16 of the record $10.35 billion judgment won by the Pennzoil Company and expects to learn by October whether the case will be heard.

title: Individual Ethics and The Plague
description: We all know the truth, every one of us. We live in a time of plague such as has never been visited on our nation. We can pretend it does not exist, or exists for those others, and carry on as if we do not know. But we do.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER Portuguese Team Wins Cup: Porto of Portugal won the European Champions' Cup yesterday by upsetting Bayern Munich of West Germany, 2-1, in the final in Vienna. Bayern Munich opened the scoring in the 25th minute when Helmut Kogl picked up a ball deflected by Jaime Magalhaez of Porto and headed it in. But the Portuguese, following a lackluster first half, took the initiative and scored twice within two minutes late in the game to win. (AP) GOLF U.S. Leads in Walker Cup: A five-under-par 30 on the front nine led Bill Andrade to a 7-and-5 singles victory yesterday and helped the United States Walker Cup team to a 9-3 first-day lead over Britain and Ireland. The eight afternoon singles matches - five won by the Americans - followed four morning doubles matches, all won by the Americans over the 6,580-yard, par-70 Old Course at the Sunningdale Golf Club in Sunningdale, England. (AP) Straub and Saraceno Share Lead: Austin Straub, assistant pro at Pine Hollow, and Tony Saraceno, assistant at Woodmere, shot 3-under-par 69s to share the lead yesterday after the first round of the Long Island Open at the 6,643-yard Hempstead Golf and Country Club. Straub, in the morning flight, scored five birdies against two bogeys. Saraceno sank four birdie putts ranging from 5 to 45 feet and three-putted once for a bogey. Straub, Saraceno and Jim Delich of Deepdale, at 70, were the only players among the 182 starters to break par.

title: U.S. Trade Gap Narrows
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit narrowed slightly, to $38.3 billion from January through March, as the weaker dollar increased sales of exports and slowed the growth of imports, the Government reported today.

description: Theirs is a series without any secrets.

TREATING A DOLL'S AILMENTS
description: ''I'M a doctor and I haven't lost a patient yet,'' said Irving Chaise, who practices at an unusual hospital, the New York Doll Hospital, founded by his grandfather in 1900. Up a winding staircase and through a door to the left, you will find dolls' heads and wigs, legs and torsos and the outfits that will clothe them when, unlike Humpty Dumpty, they are put back together again.

title: Brzezinski in Polish
description: The title may not ring a bell but the name of the author probably does: ''Cztery lata w Bialym Domu,'' by Zbigniew Brzezinski, has been published in London by the Polonia Book Fund Ltd. It is a Polish translation of the book by the man who served as President Carter's national security adviser. The Polish-born Mr. Brzezinski did not translate his own book, however; the translator was Zdzislaw Dziekonski. The English title, ''Power and Principle,'' became ''Four Years in the White House'' in Polish.

title: Sugar Ray Retires, Again
description: Sugar Ray Leonard will ''try'' to retire from boxing again. For the fifth time. ''For now'' at least, that's his plan. The words in quotation marks are his, uttered yesterday in sincerity but not with a warranty. As the 31-year-old middleweight champion stood at the microphone under the crystal chandliers of the Westin Hotel ballroom, even he didn't seem willing to believe that he would never box again.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Butch Goring, a former Islander and a former coach of the Boston Bruins, was named head coach of the Spokane Chiefs of the Western Hockey League. Goring was dismissed by Boston last Nov. 7 after the Bruins started the season 5-7-1. . . . Ronnie Harmon, a running back with the Buffalo Bills, has requested immunity in a grand jury's investigation in Chicago of two sports agents, The Atlanta Constitution reported. Harmon's attorney, Martin Rauch, is said to have asked for immunity after the United States attorney's office in Chicago informed him that Harmon is subject to indictment for fraud and tax evasion because of his dealings with the agents, Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, when the player attended the University of Iowa. . . . Rosa Mota of Portugal, winner of the Boston Marathon and the 1984 Olympic bronze medalist, has withdrawn from the L'eggs Mini Marathon scheduled for Saturday in Central Park. Mota said she had a pain in her side after running a 10-kilometer race in Boulder, Colo., last week. . . . Larry Steele, who played nine seasons with the Portland Trail Blazers, was hired as head basketball coach at the University of Portland. . . . Arvidas-Romas Sabonis, the 7-foot-3-inch Soviet basketball star, has an injured Achilles' tendon and will not play in the European Championships scheduled to begin June 3 in Greece, according to Tass, the Soviet news agency.

description: Negotiations are under way to bring members of Leningrad's Kirov Ballet to City Center for three performances, June 16-18. These would be the Soviet troupe's first New York appearances since 1964.

description: Despite their substantial reliance on oil from countries bordering the Persian Gulf, the world's industrial powers would probably not immediately experience serious supply problems if ships were suddenly unable to carry crude oil through the gulf, experts on the energy industry said yesterday.

title: F.A.A. REJECTS A PLAN TO LIMIT PEAK AIR TRAFFIC
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday rejected a proposal by Government safety experts to limit peak-hour air traffic in congested areas this summer to reduce the risk of collisions. The agency said adequate safeguards were already in place.

description: BRIGHT summer sunshine has a way of accentuating the flaws in a home - the tiny cracks in old paint jobs, the refinishing, redecorating and redesigning that are long overdue.

title: ISRAELI CABINET, 14-3, TAKES BLAME FOR POLLARD
description: The Israeli Cabinet today formally accepted a commission's conclusion that the entire Cabinet was collectively responsible for the Pollard spy affair, but not any specific minister.

description: A California judge will issue a decision on Friday in a huge case that could determine which insurance companies will have to pay billions of dollars in injury claims filed by thousands of people injured by exposure to asbestos.

Vietnam Bank Reform
description: Vietnam, which has severe economic problems, says its banking system must be overhauled if the state is to control the economy. The Communist Party newspaper Nhan Dan said the banking system was inadequate for the issuance and management of the nation's money. Vietnam is suffering triple-digit inflation, large unemployment and food shortages.

title: Lessons of the Stark
description: LEAD: While many of the details of the Iraqi air attack on the frigate Stark that killed 37 sailors in the Persian Gulf remain unknown, a few lessons may be drawn.

title: NEW YORK PLANS TO TURN HOSPITAL INTO AIDS CENTER
description: St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan would become New York City's first hospital to treat only AIDS and related illnesses under plans disclosed yesterday by state and Federal health officials.

title: Allegis Board Meets To Discuss Bid Today
description: The directors of the Allegis Corporation are expected to discuss today how to respond to a challenge posed by a small group of investors who want to gain control of the company and perhaps break it up or sell it whole.

title: MOVING: IT REMAINS AN IMPERFECT ART
description: ''IT was like a ballet,'' declared Sharon Freeman who, with her husband, Bill, moved last week from Bedford Village, N.Y., to Montpelier, Vt. ''The movers came Friday to load the boxes and furniture, and on Monday they delivered everything to our new house. Everything flowed perfectly.'' Not everyone who moves is that lucky. Moving is usually expensive, time-consuming, stressful and brimming with potential disasters. Wayne and Beth Hinkle, who survived more than 20 moves during his career in the Air Force before settling in Fort Atkinson, Wis., 17 years ago, remember a dock strike that resulted in mildewed belongings, the accidental discarding of some belongings and the mysterious loss of a chair while its cushions were being delivered.

title: EX-TEAMMATE TELLS OF BIAS DRUG ROLE
description: Terry Long, a former basketball teammate of Len Bias at the University of Maryland, said today that Bias introduced him to cocaine in the fall of 1984.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My two-year-old house is so well sealed that in the winter moisture from appliances, showers and plants cannot escape. As a result, fungus and fuzzy moss grow on the inside windowsills and the plaster walls are damaged. What can I do? A. Moisture is always a problem in a new house because of vapor from the concrete foundation and joint cement on walls and ceilings. After a year or two, this usually lessens. However, I think this not your only problem.

title: AFTER 15 YEARS OF PROBLEMS, NUCLEAR PLANT WARMS UP
description: Here at Nine Mile Point on the shore of Lake Ontario, the first nuclear chain reaction has just been achieved in what may be the world's most expensive nuclear power plant.

title: Metro Matters; If Companies Move to Suburbs, It Still Hurts
description: Nobody doubts that New York loses when Mobil Oil leaves for Virginia or J. C. Penney packs up for Texas. But does the city really suffer when a company merely moves someplace else in the metropolitan region? The answer is yes, but. Yes, the city loses revenue from personal income, business, sales, property and commercial occupancy taxes.

title: PARISH BANNED FOR GAME SIX
description: Robert Parish, the Boston Celtics' center, was fined $7,500 and suspended yesterday for one game for punching Bill Laimbeer of the Detroit Pistons during the Eastern Conference playoff game Tuesday night at Boston Garden.

title: Anybody Listening?
description: An official of the Federal Communications Commission said today that the agency had not received any complaints about radio interference caused by Soviet broadcasts last weekend from Cuba to the United States. The official, Lex Felker, said it appeared few people in the United States were aware of the broadcasts, at 1040 kilohertz on the AM band, because such broadcasts do not travel long distances during the daytime.

title: Aase Is Out Again
description: Don Aase, who had a club-record 34 saves for the Baltimore Orioles last year, was placed on the disabled list last night for the second time this season. Aase, bothered by a recurrence of tendinitis in his right shoulder, was placed on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to May 24.

description: The trustees of Wheaton College, the oldest women's college in New England, announced today that they had made a final decision to admit men to the school next fall despite opposition to coeducation among many Wheaton students and alumnae.

title: The Vietnam Experience and the Congressman of the 1980's
description: John McCain, a former Navy pilot who spent five and a half years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam, is now a Senator. So is Tom Harkin, another Navy pilot from that era who later discovered the infamous ''tiger cages'' in a prison in South Vietnam.

description: The American Motors Corporation has offered its salaried workers severance pay if they lose their jobs after the company merges with the Chrysler Corporation. A spokesman said the salary plan was intended to encourage white-collar workers to stay with the company during the transition.

title: SATELLITE IMAGES MAY SPUR CONFLICT
description: A Congressional study released yesterday predicts a rising conflict between the Federal Government and journalists seeking to use high-resolution pictures taken by satellites to report on military movements, nuclear missile installations and disasters.

title: AVERAGE SALARY FOR TEACHERS RISES TO $26,704
description: The average salary for the nation's 2.2 million public school teachers is now $26,704, and the cost of educating each student in grade and high school is just under $4,000 a year, the National Education Association said today.

title: 4 ARRESTED AFTER QUEENS SHOOTOUT
description: An off-duty New York City police officer, a city jail guard and a school security guard from Long Island were arrested yesterday after a shootout in Queens that the police said may have been sparked by their attempted robbery of a 17-year-old suspected drug dealer.

title: U.S. STUDY LISTS A 12% DECLINE IN FACTORY JOBS
description: Despite its overall economic improvement, New York City has lost more than 51,000 manufacturing jobs - almost 12 percent of its manufacturing base - in the last three years, according to a Federal study released yesterday.

title: NEW YORK CITY LACKS SPACES FOR INCREASE OF THE HOMELESS
description: The number of homeless people in New York City will reach another record this winter, and the Koch administration does not know yet how it will shelter all of them, the head of the Human Resources Administration said yesterday.

title: PIANO: SYLVIA TORAN RECITAL
description: SYLVIA TORAN'S piano recital at Weill Recital Hall Monday began with Mozart of vivid lyric propulsion: the Sonata in F (K. 332), played at brisk tempos with a firm sense of where the music was going and no inhibiting caution about getting there. That kind of uncomplicated vigor characterized the best of her work throughout the program. A problem in Ms. Toran's pianism that eventually became limiting is one shared by many of her contemporaries: She rises too readily and regularly to a dynamic level at which physical effort intrudes on her ability to shape the rise and fall of a phrase, to maintain independence of the fingers and to keep the notes under control.

title: TWO IN JAPAN SEIZED OVER EXPORTS TO SOVIET
description: Two senior executives of a top Japanese machine tool maker were arrested today after being accused of illegally exporting high-technology equipment to the Soviet Union, the police said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in ''About New York'' last Saturday about Vanna White's book ''Vanna Speaks'' misidentified the publisher. It is Warner Books Inc.

title: OFFICER ADMITS HE LIED ABOUT GOETZ CASE ON TV
description: A police officer called to the scene after Bernhard H. Goetz shot four youths on a subway train in December 1984 testified yesterday that he had lied ''somewhat'' in describing the incident to a television crew on the day of the incident.

title: PLANTING RADISHES? HURRY UP
description: GARDENERS who want to plant vegetables should get busy, whether they live in the city or the country. Recent cool weather has given those who have been tardy in planting a bit more time.

description: President Reagan, adding to growing uncertainty and concern in the capital, left unclear today what the United States might do if its ships in the Persian Gulf were attacked by Iran's newest land-based missiles.

MERC WILL CHALLENGE COMEX IN GOLD FUTURES
description: In an attempt to capitalize on problems at New York's Commodity Exchange, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced yesterday that it would reinstitute trading in precious metals futures contracts, reopening a battle for market share that it lost to the Comex in the early 1980's.

title: CRISIS CASTS SHADOW ON FIJI'S FUTURE
description: A period of military rule this month and continuing racial tension appear to have transformed the economic and social prospects of this Pacific island group.

title: Davis Cuts Stake In Spectradyne
description: Marvin Davis, the Denver oil billionaire, has reduced his stake in Spectradyne Inc. to 3.7 percent, from 7.3 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Davis said that he had sold the Spectradyne shares because of the rise in the Dallas film distributor's stock price.

title: FUGARD'S LONG ROAD TO A 'MECCA' REVIVAL
