description: Here in the lush, sensual low country of South Carolina, far from the South African desert that the play uses as both setting and metaphor, Athol Fugard's drama ''The Road to Mecca'' has completed its own pilgrimage.

title: Nelson and Bucks Part
description: The simmering feud between Don Nelson, the coach, and Herb Kohl, the owner of the Milwaukee Bucks, reached the door-slamming stage yesterday when Nelson officially resigned his position.

title: SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INVESTITECH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public in July 1986.

title: Talking Deals; Losses Turned To Advantage
description: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS, the giant semiconductor manufacturer, lost money in 1983 and 1985 and was barely profitable last year. Ordinarily a record like that means a company would have to pay a lot more than would a more robust enterprise to raise money in the capital markets. But with the help of Shearson Lehman Brothers, Texas Instruments found a way to turn its recent losses to advantage and entice money from other corporations at rates far lower than if it had borrowed by conventional methods.

title: CO-OPERATIVE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes income from the distribution of $1,690,000 from the share insurance fund of the Co-operative Central bank. The bank converted from mutual to stock form in December 1985.

title: Bosworth Arrives
description: Brian Bosworth, wearing three gold rings in his left ear, flew in from Dallas yesterday and will be given a physical by the Jets today in Manhattan. Bosworth, the all-America linebacker from the University of Oklahoma who was graduated last week, will be the star of the National Football League's supplemental draft on June 12.

title: Salmon Are Biting In Oswego Waters
description: The silver sides of the salmon were so bright that they gleamed like mirrors each time the fish cartwheeled out of the water.

title: LAKELAND SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The she e earnings for the year-ago period is not shown because the common stock has been outstanding since Dec. 22, 1986.

title: Article 354587 -- No Title
description: Forstmann Little & Company said yesterday that it had raised a record $2.7 billion from private and institutional investors to use in financing the popular takeover deals known as leveraged buyouts.

title: JAZZ: LLOYD MAYERS AND TRIO
description: LLOYD MAYERS'S choice of material at Positano, Park Avenue South, at 20th Street, where he is playing piano with a trio through Saturday, reflects his close association with the music of Duke Ellington. Since Ellington's death in 1974, Mr. Mayers has been the pianist in the Ellington Band, now led by the Duke's son, Mercer, and he was the conductor and arranger for the Ellington musical ''Sophisticated Ladies.''

title: Counting Miles, Not Their Years
description: ''All we're tying to do is prove you don't have to dry up and blow away when you get to be 60,'' said Bob Mason yesterday. ''Getting old happens mostly in people's heads.''

title: DRUG PRAISED AS A WAY TO REDUCE REJECTION OF TRANSPLANTED ORGANS
description: A new drug that reverses the body's rejection of transplanted organs and has minimal severe side effects may be the most significant advance in transplant technology in five years, experts said today.

title: ALLIES TURN DOWN WEINBERGER ON HELPING IN GULF
description: The NATO allies today appeared to rebuff a Pentagon call for military help in protecting oil tankers in the Persian Gulf.

title: PRETRIAL JAILING RAISES BASIC LEGAL QUESTIONS
description: Few if any laws so passionately denounced by civil libertarians have passed Congress with such overwhelming bipartisan support as the 1984 ''preventive detention'' law that the Supreme Court upheld Tuesday.

title: 'Sweet Sue' to Close
description: ''Sweet Sue,'' the comedy by A. R. Gurney Jr. about a woman who falls in love with her son's college roommate, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Royale Theater. Directed by John Tillinger and co-starring Mary Tyler Moore and Lynn Redgrave, the play will have run for 164 regular performances and 15 previews.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MAY 28, 1987
description: COMPANIES Primerica will acquire Smith Barney for $750 million in a purchase that rounds out its transformation from a basic manufacturing company known as American Can into a diverse financial services concern. It will pay $750 million in cash for the 114-year-old, medium-sized brokerage house. The deal will give Smith Barney the capital it needs to try to remain competitive. [ Page D1. ] Chase Manhattan will set aside $1.6 billion for losses on its troubled loans to developing countries, causing a $1.4 billion quarterly loss and a $850 million loss for all of 1987. The action comes on the heels of a similar move by Citicorp last week. [ D1. ] Carson Pirie Scott will sell its airline catering and terminal services business to Greyhound for $390 million in cash. The sale will allow Carson to concentrate on retailing, while giving Greyhound a sizable addition to its airline services business. [ D1. ] Asher B. Edelman and Dominion Textile raised their offer for Burlington to $77 a share, or about $2.5 billion. The bid exceeds by $1 a share the leveraged buyout offer of Morgan Stanley Group. [ D1. ] Harcourt Brace Jovanovich's shares jumped more than $9 as Wall Street endorsed the company's recapitalization plan. [ D21. ] The board of Allegis will meet today, facing a takeover threat from a small investor group. [ D20. ] Forstmann Little has raised a record $2.7 billion from investors to use in financing leveraged buyouts. [ D17. ] Saturn dealers may show cars in malls and office buildings as part of a new approach to automobile retailing. [ D18. ] Guinness is being sued by its former chairman, Ernest Saunders, for unfair dismissal, the company disclosed. [ D4. ] MARKETS The Chicago Mercantile Exchange will reinstitute trading in precious metals futures contracts. The move attempts to capitalize on problems at New York's Commodity Exchange. [ D1. ] Wall Street failed to follow through on Tuesday's rally and closed mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 2.13, to 2,295.81, although volume rose to 171.4 million shares. The session was lethargic, except for takeover rumors. [ D8. ] Uncovered short sales outstanding rose 21.5 percent, to 238.7 million shares, on the over-the-counter market in the month ended May 15. [ D6. ] Bond prices slipped modestly as dealers bid for a new $8 billion issue of five-year Treasury notes. [ D15. ] Yields on C.D.'s and money market instruments rose modestly in the recent week. [ D7. ] The dollar fell in domestic trading after advancing sharply overseas. In New York, gold fell $3.25, to $448.25. [ D16. ] Silver futures prices plunged for the fifth consecutive session. [ D16. ] THE ECONOMY A new Federal regulation will effectively close a loophole that has permitted raiders to hide their takeover activities for weeks. The new regulation affects any partnership controlled by an investor that buys more than $15 million of a company's stock. [ D4. ] Curbs on exports of advanced semiconductor products could result from changes in in bureaucratic procedures sought by the Defense Department. [ D5. ] Two Toshiba executives were arrested for illegally exporting high-tech equipment to the Soviet Union. [ D5. ] Mayor Koch proposed new tax incentives for companies, seeking to make the city more economically competitive with New Jersey and other states. [ A1. ] Plans for a new office and entertainment center on Manhattan's West Side advanced. [ B3. ] INTERNATIONAL Japan plans news steps to open its financial markets to foreign firms, according to a Japanese official. The actions include granting freer access to Japan's bond market, the official said. [ D21. ] Industrial nations would not face immediate difficulty if crude-oil shipments through the Persian Gulf stopped, experts say. [ A13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Texas Instruments turned losses to advantage and attracted money at rates lower than if it had borrowed by conventional methods in a recent sale of preferred shares. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Analysts calculate that the value of Allegis in parts is about $100 a share, considerably more than the company's stock, which closed yesterday at $79.125. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Radioactivity Taints Navajo Relocation Site
description: To the Editor:

title: NOT RENT CONTROL, BUT APARTMENT WAREHOUSING, SHOULD END
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSECUTOR SAYS CANADA BLOCKS DEAVER INQUIRY
description: The special prosecutor in the Michael K. Deaver case accused the Canadian Government today of ''duplicitous behavior'' intended to block the prosecution of the former White House aide on perjury charges related to Canada.

title: RATEX RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest net loss was primarily because of a writedown of the company's investment in oil and gas properties of approximately $8.1 million.

title: BY HEAD OR BY HEART? A MUSIC MAKER'S DILEMMA
description: A YOUNG pianist came out on one of our smaller concert stages not long ago bringing not only himself but his music and a page-turner. You don't see that much any more. Playing from memory has become, if not a badge of accomplishment, at least one of honor.

title: TEXAN PUT TO DEATH FOR THE 1978 MURDER OF 13-YEAR-OLD GIRL
description: A man convicted and condemned in 15 minutes for abducting, raping and bludgeoning to death a 13-year-old girl with a two-by-four board was executed by injection early this morning.

title: BEI HOLDINGS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $962,000 and $1,549,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $247,000 for the quarter and $431,000 for the 6 months.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: I STARTED reading obituaries when I was in my mid-20's. I don't remember why. At first I think I was looking to see what people did with their lives - for posthumous advice, to see that there are many ways to spend a life. It was encouraging, to see so many possibilities.

title: HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $1.3 million for the quarter and $2.5 million for the 6 months.

title: Texas Banks Get Approval to Merge
description: The Republicbank Corporation and the Interfirst Corporation said they had received approval from their shareholders to complete their planned merger. The combination will create a bank holding company that is the largest in Texas and 12th largest in the United States. The two concerns said that the merger would be completed on June 6, and that the combined First Republicbank Corporation would open the following Monday.

title: JULIUS B. RAYNES
description: Julius B. Raynes, a New York realtor and developer for more than 60 years, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: EL POLLO ASADO CO reports earnings for Year to March 31
Cooper Union
description: Yesterday's commencement at Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art included the usual pomp and circumstance - and a little romance.

title: 3 INDICTED IN ATTEMPT TO KILL A DEFENDANT IN 'PIZZA' DRUG TRIAL
description: Three men were indicted by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday on charges of attempting to murder a defendant in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial.

title: DANCE: DEBORAH HAY
description: DEBORAH HAY stepped onto the stage at the start of her performance Monday at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center and talked to the audience about how to look at her dance. She was engaged, she said, in the ''recognition of changing'' and not the kind of strict linear progression one tends to expect in dancing.

title: SANDWICH CO-OPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The bank converted to a stock form of ownership in July 1986.

title: MGM Grand Air To Begin in July
description: MGM Grand Air, a new venture backed by the investor Kirk Kerkorian, said it would begin luxury airline service between Los Angeles and New York in July. The new airline, which will offer all first-class service at rates similar to those for competing carriers' first-class tickets, is scheduled to offer two flights daily, excepting Saturdays. Each of its three 727-100 jets are designed to carry 33 passengers.

title: BLACKS IN CONGRESS JOIN TO HELP INDICTED COLLEAGUE
description: Members of the Congressional Black Caucus, in an unusual display of solidarity with a caucus colleague, have pledged to raise $250,000 to help pay Representative Harold E. Ford's legal expenses.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $895,000 on the sale of land.

title: REDESIGNED SPACE SHUTTLE BOOSTER PASSES FIRST TEST
description: With their cameras, cans of soda and binoculars, the people lined up along Utah Highway 83 here looked like sport fans waiting for a game.

title: NOT RENT CONTROL, BUT APARTMENT WAREHOUSING, SHOULD END
description: To the Editor:

title: QUADREX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
VOLUME CLIMBS
description: A spate of real and rumored takeovers enlivened what might otherwise have been a desultory session on Wall Street yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday, with an article about floor trading of futures, misidentified the exchange shown. It was the Chicago Board Options Exchange.

title: Top Gerber Officer Is Retiring Early
description: William L. McKinley, chairman and chief executive of the Gerber Products Company, announced unexpectedly yesterday that he was taking early retirement.

title: Judge Quits Hunts Case
description: A Federal judge who had rebuffed four defense requests to step down from the complex Hunt brothers bankruptcy case agreed today to turn the matter over to another judge because a bank merger could create a conflict of interest.

title: RETIRED POLICEMAN KILLED IN BROOKLYN IN EXECUTION STYLE
description: A 45-year-old retired police officer was killed in an underground parking garage in Brooklyn late yesterday afternoon by a gunman who fled, the police said.

title: THE SMELTERS' PRICE: A JUNGLE REDUCED TO ASHES
description: The Amazon rain forest, already under siege from roads and dams, mines and cattle, is now about to lose a part of its timber as fuel for industry.

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
OFFICIALS PUZZLED ON REASON DOCTOR FALSIFIED DRUG DATA
description: Federal officials say they remain puzzled over why an Oklahoma City toxicologist routinely falsified drug and alcohol test results on employees involved in railroad accidents.

title: MOUNTAIN MEDICAL EQUIPENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: The company said that a two-week strike by the machinists union cut third-quarter net income by $5.3 million, or 30 cents a share.

title: On Ethnic Tensions; Blunt Talk in Crown Heights
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESSED TRIFA WAR CRIME CASE
description: Dr. Charles H. Kremer, a Rumanian-born dentist who browbeat and cajoled American officials into pursuing a successful Nazi war crimes case against a Michigan cleric, died Tuesday night at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 89 years old and had been hospitalized for two weeks with pneumonia and kidney problems.

title: CELTICS REVIVED BY 'MIRACLE FINISH'
description: Make room for another chapter in the great moments of pro baskeball. Entitle it, ''Larry Bird stole the ball,'' and include it alongside the memories of Wilt Chamberlain's 100-point game, the Los Angeles Lakers' 33-game winning streak, the triple-overtime 128-126 Boston playoff victory over Phoenix and the night of May 8, 1970, when Willis Reed turned the seventh game of the championship series against the Lakers into a night of emotion.

title: JAZZ: SALSA MUSIC SERIES
description: ''SALSA MEETS JAZZ,'' the Monday evening dance-concert series at the Village Gate, has become a New York institution. Each week, two Latin bands alternate sets and there is a ''guest jazz soloist.'' Sometimes adding a jazzman to a ferociously powerful Latin dance band is a bit like throwing a Christian to the lions, and over the years the shows have begun to focus more and more on the Latin ensembles, bringing out the jazz soloist for one tune per set.

title: GUIDRY FALTERS IN STADIUM RETURN
description: Ron Guidry came home last night to cheers that are typically reserved for some kind of returning war hero. In the fifth inning, he emerged from the bullpen in a sports car, rode it to the front of the Yankee dugout, then opened the door and walked slowly to the pitcher's mound.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK (GA) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $414,000.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: FEW projects are possible without a square, a level or a measuring tool. Measuring tapes are one of the most basic of these tools, and for most amateurs, a flexible steel tape that retracts is probably best.

title: HEALTHWAYS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: FROM GERMANY, A BETTER GERANIUM
description: SPRING, for some odd reason, has a great many harbingers in the natural order: crocuses and robins, the sound of peepers in wetlands, the golden tones that weeping willow branches assume before the first leaves appear. Nobody talks, however, about the harbingers of summer, but it has at least one: The geranium.

title: DANCE: BALANCHINE'S 'CHACONNE' AND 2 BY ROBBINS
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Chaconne'' and two works by Jerome Robbins, ''Afternoon of a Faun'' and ''Concertino,'' made their first appearance of the New York City Ballet season at the State Theater on Tuesday night.

title: TRANS WORLD MUSIC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Three Outrages
description: Austrians, Israelis and Americans share causes for shame this week.

title: U.S. Military Academy
description: More than 1,000 United States Military Academy graduates were commissioned second lieutenants today.

title: Orioles Capture 5th Straight
description: Cal Ripken Jr. drove in the tie-breaking run with a two-out single in the sixth inning as the Orioles defeated the Angels, 8-6, tonight for their fifth straight victory. California has lost five in a row.

title: KOCH PLAN SEEKS NEW TAX BREAKS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed new tax incentives for companies that relocate to new or rehabilitated quarters north of 96th Street in Manhattan or to the other four boroughs.

title: ANNA LOIS JONES
description: Anna Lois Jones, a supervisor with the Newark Housing Authority for many years, died of cancer May 20 in the Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Newark.

title: ARTISTS WORK AS CRAFTSMEN TO SUPPORT THEIR MUSE By JOSEPH GIOVANNINI
description: WHAT set the Upper East Side townhouse apart from other, equally wrecked construction sites were the doodles on the wall, deftly drawn and suitable for framing.

title: The U.N. Today: May 28, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: RADICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ROBERT F. GIEGENGACK, COACH OF TRACK AT YALE FOR 29 YEARS
description: Robert F. Giegengack, a former Latin teacher who spent 29 years as the track and field coach at Yale University and led the United States team at the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo, died on Monday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 80 years old and had lived in Bethany, Conn., since his retirement in 1975.

title: GREYHOUND GETS CARSON UNIT
description: Carson Pirie Scott & Company, one of Chicago's largest retailers, said today that it had agreed to sell its airline catering and terminal services businesses to the Greyhound Corporation for $390 million in cash.

title: CATO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
Dangerous Until Proved Innocent
description: Everyone is presumed innocent until proved guilty but not every defendant is entitled to release pending trial. Murder suspects, for instance, are locked up. The law will always find a way to hold a suspect so mad or so murderous that the usual rules must be waived. Still, America's very sense of justice turns on the noble presumption of innocence; the exceptions should be rare.

title: New York City Shaves Cost in Market Re-entry
description: New York City, which delayed a bond sale last week because of unsettled market conditions, returned to the market yesterday.

title: RECITAL: WAYNE CROUSE IN VIOLA PROGRAM
description: THREE of the four pieces in Wayne Crouse's viola program at Weill Recital Hall Tuesday night were not originally intended for that instrument. Nothing could better illustrate the viola's ''between-the-cracks'' placement in the hierarchy of stringed instruments.

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FINDING A FORMULA FOR LATE-NIGHT TV
description: The time between 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. is the Bermuda Triangle of television, a time period in which seemingly seaworthy programs flounder and disappear.

title: HOLMES, D H LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
PINETREE COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on March 25 about personnel changes in classical-music management misstated the roles of Marvin Schofer and Michaela Deren Gold in the Classical Artists International agency. They were, respectively, the agency's president and director of artists and attractions from September 1986 to March 1987.

title: UNIVERSAL SECURITY INSTRUENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Australian Seeks a Mandate
description: Prime Minister Bob Hawke announced today that he would seek a fresh mandate in a snap election July 11 for the House of Representatives and the Senate so his Labor Party Government could complete its economic measures. Mr. Hawke told Parliament that the Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, Queen Elizabeth's representative and head of state, had formally approved elections eight months before Mr. Hawke's term of office was due to end. It was the second time that Mr. Hawke had called a snap poll since coming to power in a landslide in 1983.

title: FINALCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Clausen Hedges on Reserves
description: The chairman and chief executive of the BankAmerica Corporation suggested today that the troubled banking company might have to increase its reserves to cover shaky Latin American loans, an action that could mean a return to the red.

title: RHODEN POSTS 6th VICTORY
description: A crowd gathered quickly round the television set near the middle of the room. The volume was turned up almost loud enough to drown out the voice of the winning pitcher. But Rick Rhoden, still perspiring from an uneasy night at Yankee Stadium, persisted.

title: A RANKING CUBAN DEFECTS TO THE U.S.
description: A man identifying himself as a high-ranking Cuban military official defected to the United States today, flying a small plane to a Florida naval base, Administration officials said.

title: Cyclist Banned For Using Drugs
description: Willi Tackaert, a Belgian professional cyclist, today became the second Milk Race rider to be found positive after a drug test and has been fined $800 and banned from racing for one month.

title: Fugitive Unmasked by Beard and Furtive Manner
description: A waitress's suspicions about an impatient customer with a scraggly beard helped the authorities here capture a fugitive from Missouri today.

title: KOCH REJECTS TAX BREAK FOR TRUMP TV CITY SITE
description: The Koch administration yesterday ruled out special tax and zoning concessions for Donald J. Trump's 100-acre site on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Mr. Trump had sought the concessions to help him entice the National Broadcasting Company to move to his proposed Television City development on the site.

title: The Ambassadorial Clog
description: The Senate's ambassadorial pipeline is filling up.

title: STAGE: ERIC BOGOSIAN'S 'TALK RADIO,' ABOUT A LATE-NIGHT HOST
description: IMAGINE Lenny Bruce at the height of his notoriety becoming a popular talk show host -and you may begin to have an idea of the whiplash intensity and black, hard-edged cynicism of Eric Bogosian's ''Talk Radio.'' With his new play, opening last night at the Public Theater, Mr. Bogosian takes a long leap from performance artist to playwright.

title: Discovering the High Price of Free Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVING ANTIQUE HOUSES IS A TREND IN CONNECTICUT
description: New England houses of the 18th and 19th centuries, like antiques of any kind, are in limited supply. Even fewer remain in choice residential areas. Many are on roads that have become busy thoroughfares or are in neighborhoods that have become industrial. Others are in environments that are totally unsuited for a weekend or vacation retreat.

title: U.S. Note and Bond Prices Up
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday as traders vacillated between pessimism and optimism about the prospects for improved investor demand.

title: VOTE IN THE SENATE ON ALIEN MEASURE
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate reaffirmed an earlier vote to delay the June 1 enforcement date for portions of a new immigration law. FOR THE DELAY - 47 Democrats - 33 Adams, Wash. Baucus, Mont. Bentsen, Tex. Bingaman, N.M. Okla. Breaux, La. Bumpers, Ark. Chiles, Fla. Conrad, N.D. Cranston, Calif. Daschle, S.D. DeConcini, Ariz. Dixon, Ill. Exon, Neb. Harkin, Iowa Heflin, Ala. Inouye, Hawaii Johnston, La. Lautenberg, N.J. Leahy, Vt. Levin, Mich. Melcher, Mont. Mikulski, Md. Mitchell, Me. Pell, R.I. Pryor, Ark. Reid, Nev. Sanford, N.C. Sarbanes, Md. Sasser, Tenn. Shelby, Ala. Stennis, Miss. Wirth, Colo. Republicans - 14 Chafee, R.I. D'Amato, N.Y. Domenici, N.M. Garn, Utah Hatch, Utah Hecht, Nev. Helms, N.C. Karnes, Neb. McCain, Ariz. McClure, Idaho Nickles, Okla. Stevens, Alaska Symms, Idaho Wilson, Calif. AGAINST THE DELAY - 43 Democrats - 16 Bradley, N.J. Burdick, N.D. Byrd, W.Va. Dodd, Conn. Ford, Ky. Fowler, Ga. Graham, Fla. Hollings, S.C. Kerry, Mass. Metzenbaum, Ohio Moynihan, N.Y. Nunn, Ga. Proxmire, Wis. Riegle, Mich. Rockefeller, W.Va. Simon, Ill. Republicans - 27 Armstrong, Colo. Bond, Mo. Boschwitz, Minn. Cochran, Miss. Cohen, Me. Danforth, Mo. Dole, Kan. Durenberger, Minn. Gramm, Tex. Grassley, Iowa Hatfield, Ore. Heinz, Pa. Humphrey, N.H. Kassebaum, Kan. Kasten, Wis. Lugar, Ind. McConnell, Ky. Packwood, Ore. Pressler, S.D. Quayle, Ind. Roth, Del. Rudman, N.H. Simpson, Wyo. Stafford, Vt. Thurmond, S.C. Trible, Va. Weicker, Conn.

title: W.K. HARRISON, 91, ARMY GENERAL, DIES
description: Lieut. Gen. William K. Harrison, who headed the United Nations armistice delegation in the Korean War, died Monday in Bryn Mawr Terrace, a nursing home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 91 years old and lived in Springfield, Pa.

title: 2 Officers Suspended for Lying About Fatal Crash
description: Two New York City police officers were suspended yesterday on charges they falsely told investigators they had stopped chasing a stolen car before it struck another car in Queens last month, the police said. Three people died in the crash.

title: FILM: LORI SINGER IN 'SUMMER HEAT'
description: THE beautiful, slinky Lori Singer moves like a sleepwalker through ''Summer Heat,'' barely shaking her mane of back-lighted hair. As a sheltered young wife and mother in rural North Carolina tobacco country, she is called upon to knead, scrub, mend and otherwise convey the becalmed monotony of her life. ''Summer Heat,'' adapted from Louise Shivers's much more imaginatively titled novel ''Here to Get My Baby Out of Jail,'' is about the forces that overtake this young woman and reshape her life when a handsome stranger comes to town. It may sound torrid, but on the page it was larger than that, strongly evocative of a place, a time (1937) and an entire way of life. On the screen, it's like watching tobacco grow.

title: 'ATHENS, GA.,' ON ROCK BANDS
description: A NUMBER of the musicians seen in ''Athens, Ga. - Inside/Out'' point to Pylon as the best band in town, but Pylon isn't even operational any more. The group, according to one member, ''just decided to quit while we were still having a good time.'' Formerly art students, the band members now hold odd jobs; the lead singer, a dynamo on stage, works in a copying shop. ''But I never planned on being a musician, so it's no big loss in my life,'' she said. Bear in mind that Pylon, having played several shows with U2 and begun to get some big-city bookings, stood on the verge of stardom while throwing in the towel.

title: Back in Style on the Beat
description: Except for their first nine years, when all they wore was a star pinned onto any old thing, the New York City police have been snappy dressers - the spit and polish of their outfits reflecting the discipline of their work. Their first uniforms, for instance, were double-breasted velvet-collared frock coats; and so what if their hats, designed to deter flying objects, had to be leather? They had, as they say in the fashion business, a ''look.''

title: BROADWAY
description: ARTHUR WHITELAW has, he says, two new plays coming up, and a major reason is his experience with ''Sweet Sue'' -which, incidentally, closes Sunday.

title: JACKSON AND CARDINAL BACK UNION BID
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, saying he had come as a friend and not as a politician, joined with John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday to seek higher wages and better training for workers who tend the ailing and the elderly at home.

title: Marriott Seeks Denny's Chain
description: The Marriott Corporation, the big hotel and restaurant operator, said today that it was holding talks to buy Denny's Inc., a 1,200-unit restaurant company, from the investors who took it private two years ago.

title: Pacific Gas Bonds Set to Yield 10.12%
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company is offering $250 million of 10 percent bonds due in 2020 at a price of 98 7/8, to yield 10.12 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: DATA ON AIDS DRUG CALLED MISLEADING
description: A ranking member of Congress charged today that the manufacturer of a highly publicized drug for AIDS had presented misleading and inaccurate information to the Government and to the public.

title: G.E. and Carbide Choose Counsels
description: Two major corporations yesterday announced the selection of general counsels. The Union Carbide Corporation, heavily involved in litigation relating to its plant accident in India, promoted Joseph E. Geoghan from its ranks, and the General Electric Company reached outside for a prominent Washington lawyer, Benjamin W. Heineman Jr. Mr. Geoghan, 50 years old, was named executive vice president and general counsel, to succeed John A. Stichnoth, 63, who is retiring after 32 years.

title: LESSER CHARGE ACCEPTED IN MILITARY SECRETS CASE
description: A former Air Force sergeant originally accused of trying to deliver military secrets to a foreign agent has pleaded guilty to a charge of attempting to communicate secrets to an unauthorized person. He faces up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000.

title: When Should Envoy Read the Law Himself?
description: At one point in his testimony, Lewis A. Tambs was asked if he was responsible for checking whether the orders he received were legal.

title: INSIDE
description: New Inquiry on Bakkers

title: U.S. DEFERS GIVING NAVAL PROTECTION TO KUWAITI SHIPS
description: The Reagan Administration has postponed for several weeks a plan to provide American military protection to Kuwaiti oil tankers in the Persian Gulf, top officials told Congress today.

title: 4-MONTH DELAY IN ALIEN CURBS VOTED IN SENATE
description: The Senate voted today to delay for four months the enforcement of new civil and criminal sanctions against employers who hire illegal aliens.

title: TOP PLAYERS STRUGGLE TO WIN IN PARIS
description: Chris Evert, struggling with her timing and a little-known opponent, battled into the third round of the French Open today as she and other top-seeded players managed to stem upsets.

title: U.S. UNCERTAIN ON OZONE PACT
description: The United States may back away from a tentative international agreement to freeze and ultimately reduce production and consumption of chemicals believed to deplete the earth's protective covering of ozone, Administration officials said today.

title: The Witness File
description: Name: Lewis A. Tambs Age: 59 Position: Professor of history at Arizona State University. Resigned in January as Ambassador to Costa Rica. Previously was Ambassador to Colombia. Role: Ambassador Tambs says Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North asked him to open a ''southern front'' of contras in Costa Rica. As a result he gave logistical help to the contras and to the Americans flying weapons and other supplies to them at the request of officials in Washington. He was also instrumental in persuading the Costa Rican Government to allow contra supply pilots to use a secret airstrip built in Costa Rica by operatives of Colonel North.

title: House Talk Focuses on Excise Tax
description: House tax writers agreed informally today to focus mainly on raising excise taxes on fuels and other items, as well as estate taxes, to meet 1988 budget needs, according to members who attended the closed-door meeting.

title: Corrections
description: A Montreal dispatch yesterday about the Canadian visit of President Francois Mitterrand rendered the final word incorrectly in a comment before Parliament by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. The passage should have read, ''Twenty years after General de Gaulle's visit, you will find, Mr. President, a Canada at peace with itself, aware of its diversity and resolved to recognize it with respect, tolerance and generosity.''

title: Aguilera Sidelined 3 Weeks
description: The young pitching staff that carried the Mets to the championship last year suffered another tremor today: Rick Aguilera has a sprained ligament in the right elbow, and will not pitch for perhaps three weeks.

title: FILM: 'UNFINISHED BUSINESS'
description: VIVECA LINDFORS is the writer, director and star of ''Unfinished Business,'' which looks and sounds like a monodrama, though there are a number of other speaking parts in it. The film, a project of the Directing Workshop for Women, of the American Film Institute, is an intensely self-absorbed, self-referential work about Helena (Miss Lindfors), a great actress attempting to come to terms with herself and her dedication to the theater, thus ''to justify my time on earth.''

title: Iba Goes to Idaho
description: Bret Iba, representing a third generation of basketball coaches, has been hired as the assistant coach at the University of Idaho, according to the head coach, Tim Floyd. The 28-year-old Bret will replace Larry Eustachy, who left last month to become an assistant at the University of Utah. Bret was a part-time assistant at Southwest Missouri State last year. His father, Moe, is head coach at Texas Christian University in Fort Worth, and his grandfather, Hank, coached at Oklahoma State from 1935 to 1970. Also, Bret's cousin, Gene, is head coach at Baylor.

title: Dog Days
description: John Jenkins, the coach of the Bolton (Conn.) High School baseball team, knew early this season that he was in for another bad year when his squad was beaten by two junior varsity teams.

title: Wallowing in Slush
description: Though it's springtime in Albany, New York's Legislature needs to think about slush - as in political party ''housekeeping'' slush funds. These funds are supposedly used to pay for rent, staff and other routine headquarters expenses. Too often, as recent corruption inquiries suggest, they buy much more.

title: Rejection Seen On Vote Plan
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to vote Friday to reject a New York Stock Exchange plan to abolish its one-share, one-vote requirement, according to some Wall Street professionals.

title: Red Cross Inspected One Concentration Camp
description: To the Editor:

title: McCALL'S TO DROP RATE SYSTEM
description: McCall's, which is part of the magazine category most affected by the competition of television, will formally adopt the advertising sales techniques used by broadcasters.

title: LANDMARK NEW YORK DEWLLINGS STILL SPEAK OF BUCOLIC TIMES
description: SUMMER HOME - Harlem Heights: 19 rms Georgian-style mansion, octagonal dining room. On 130 acres, Manhattan's highest pt., superb view all directions. Restored since Revolution. 45 mins. from city. Available for viewing.

title: Cathedral Choristers
description: The Cathedral Choristers will sing Britten's ''Rejoice in the Lamb'' and a medley of works by Duke Ellington, Sunday at 3:30 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th St. The concert is free. Information: 662-2133.

title: Japanese Concern Buying Dillingham
description: The Dillingham Construction Corporation, a privately held company based in Pleasanton, Calif., said that SC-US Inc., a subsidiary of Shimizu Construction Company Ltd. of Tokyo, had agreed to purchase the company from Dillingham Holdings Inc. Terms were not disclosed, but Dillingham said SC-US would make a minority investment with management and employees taking the majority interest in the new company.

title: TENSIONS GROWING IN EASTERN AFRICA
description: Relations between Kenya and Uganda, whose neighborliness has long been shaken by clashes of personality and ideology, are worsening amid a mounting war of words.

title: Our Towns; For 'Lez Fitz,' A Twin Track To Annapolis
description: By now, just about everybody at North Brunswick High is used to losing to the Fitzpatrick twins.

title: Making a Point
description: The Celtics say Robert Parish could have played last night, which makes his one-game suspension all the more appropriate.

title: THE NEW WAY TO HALT RAIDERS
description: Move over, leveraged buyout. The ''leveraged recap'' has arrived.

title: Armed Men in Teheran Abduct a British Envoy
description: Armed men abducted a British diplomat in Iran today after forcing his car to stop on a highway in Teheran, the Foreign Office said.

title: Insider Case Filing Expected
description: The defense lawyer for Robert M. Freeman, the Goldman, Sachs & Company executive who was charged by the Government with insider trading, is expected to file shortly, under seal, a motion charging the United States Attorney with misconduct in the case, according to several legal sources.

title: ALLEGIS ADDING $3 BILLION OF DEBT TO SHIELD ITSELF AGAINST TAKEOVER
description: The Allegis Corporation, which owns United Airlines, the Hertz car rental agency and major hotel chains, took a drastic step yesterday to avoid being taken over or broken up.

title: Lebanese Plane Intercepted
description: Israeli jets intercepted a Lebanese Air Force plane today and forced it to land in northern Israel. The plane and its two pilots were allowed to return home after four hours of investigation. A communique by the Lebanese military command said the plane had been trying to rescue a small boat in the Mediterranean off Sidon.

title: EX-U.S. ENVOY SAYS HE WAS ORDERED TO ASSIST CONTRAS
description: A former United States Ambassador to Costa Rica, who has been accused of improperly helping the rebels in Nicaragua, testified today that he was operating under direct orders from the National Security Council, the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Court Ruling Supports I.B.M.'s Limits on Sales
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had won a Federal court case brought against it by one of its personal computer dealers, in a decision that appears to strengthen I.B.M.'s hand against retailers who sell its products in the ''gray market.''

title: Pole Detained by Police
description: An opponent of the Government, Danuta Czachmanowska, was briefly detained in Cracow today by the police, who warned her against trying to disrupt Pope John Paul II's visit to Poland next month, members of the opposition said.

title: New York City Elections Bill Encourages Big Campaign Spenders
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: May 29, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mitchell Price, a Southern Methodist University defensive back, has transferred to Tulane following suspension of the S.M.U. football program for repeated recruiting violations. . . . John Ayers, who started 69 straight games at left guard for the San Francisco 49ers before he injured his left knee late last season, has not been invited to training camp after ignoring the advice of Coach Bill Walsh to retire.

title: ARTIST DEPICTS HIS INNER, AND ONLY, VISION
description: ''Sometimes I wake up feeling like certain colors,'' said the artist. ''Right now, I'm into happy colors, summer colors -oranges, pinks, reds - in conflict and in contrast with a phosphorescent yellow offset by blacks and brown.''

title: Wheat Contracts Fall As Harvesting Begins
description: Wheat futures prices tumbled today as harvesting started in the Gulf Coast States and traders braced for a plentiful crop.

title: AMID REJOICING, WORK BEGINS ON MOSQUE
description: New York Moslems - after two decades of changing plans, glacial fund raising and bitter disputes - broke ground yesterday for a $25 million mosque and cultural center at 96th Street and Lexington Avenue. United Nations dignitaries and city officials joined the ordinary faithful to mark ''a day of double significance,'' as the Kuwaiti delegate to the United Nations, Mohammad A. Abulhasan, put it.

title: NAKASONE ENLARGES HIS PROGRAM FOR STIMULATING JAPAN'S ECONOMY
description: The Japanese Government today approved a larger-than-expected program of $43 billion to stimulate its economy and ease trade frictions with the United States.

title: Ex-Reagan Aides Tied To Big Medicare Group
description: The nation's largest Medicare-certified health maintenance organization has reportedly paid more than $350,000 to former aides of President Reagan for lobbying and legal fees.

title: THE BARNEYS CO/OP IS BACK
description: The Pressmans, owners of Barneys New York, the men's specialty store at 17th Street and Seventh Avenue, bit off a bit more than they could chew when they opened their $25 million women's store last September. So in January they closed its casual, contemporary fashion annex, the Co/op, for renovation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MAY 29, 1987
description: Companies

title: Alvin C. Eurich Dead; Former State U. Chief
description: Alvin C. Eurich, an educator who was the first president of the State University of New York, died Wednesday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 84 years old.

title: Brazil Investigates Error
description: President Jose Sarney of Brazil ordered an investigation today into what went wrong in calculating last year's trade figures, which understated Brazilian imports by $1.2 billion. Brazil imported $14 billion worth of goods, not the $12.8 billion officially reported. A Finance Ministry spokesman ruled out deliberate fraud.

title: American Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
U.S. and New Zealand Stop Aid to Fiji to Protest Coup
description: The United States and New Zealand have suspended aid to Fiji to protest the coup that ousted an elected Government, officials said today.

title: Two Policemen Commit Suicide With Revolvers
description: Two New York City police officers took their own lives yesterday in separate suicides on Staten Island and in Queens, the police reported.

title: U.S. PLANS BIG REVISION IN LEADING INDICATORS
description: The Government's best-known tool for economic forecasting - the index of leading indicators - will undergo a major revision by the end of the year, a Commerce Department official said yesterday.

title: TUROFF IS GIVEN 4-MONTH TERM IN U.S. PRISON
description: Jay L. Turoff, the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, was sentenced yesterday to four months in Federal prison, almost three years' probation and a $50,000 fine for income tax fraud.

title: AT PROM, STUDENTS PUT ASIDE SADNESS AT CLOSING OF SCHOOL
description: The slow songs, like the tears, were few and far between. Instead, the band pounded out rock 'n' roll, and the students danced and screamed for more all night long.

title: DEPARTURE OF SHALALA IS REPORTED
description: Dr. Donna E. Shalala, president of Hunter College, is expected to be named Chancellor of the University of Wisconsin at Madison today, according to education officials in New York City and Wisconsin.

title: 1180 ON THE AM DIAL AND A THORN IN CASTRO'S SIDE
description: According to a joke making the rounds here these days, Vilma Espin, the highest-ranking woman in the Communist Party and the wife of Fidel Castro's brother Raul, knocks on the door of a family in the capital.

title: A 4-Letter Nominee
description: Herbert E. Alexander, a professor of political science at the University of Southern California, says he already knows who will win the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination. ''My prediction is that the candidate who will win the Republican nomination has four letters in his name,'' said Mr. Alexander, who was in Washington promoting his new book on financing of the 1984 campaign. That should ease the minds of Messrs. Bush, Dole, Kemp and Haig.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Kadri Gopalnath, Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street (206-1050). South Indian ragas on the alto saxophone? Kadri Gopalnath, whose concert here, sponsored by the World Music Institute, is part of his first American tour, has made the instrument acceptable in Indian classical music circles, playing ragas with a creamy sound and delicate, voice-like inflections. He will be performing with T. T. Srinivasan, a young Indian violinist, and T. K. Ramakrishnan on the South Indian double-headed drum. The concert begins at 8 P.M. on Saturday; tickets are $10.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the resignation of Sally K. Ride from the astronaut corps gave her marital status incorrectly. She was recently divorced.

title: BRAZIL'S CHIEF DEEPENS DISPUTE OVER HIS TERM
description: Despite his claim that ''this question has now been decided,'' President Jose Sarney 's announcement last week that he will serve a five-year term in office appears to have heightened the political uncertainty that has gripped Brazil for six months.

title: Maxwell's Harcourt Bid Ends
description: Robert Maxwell, the British publisher who is eager to add an American book company to his worldwide communications empire, yesterday withdrew his $2 billion offer for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., but said that he was ''continuing to review alternatives.''

title: Rangers' McKegney Traded
description: No points in six playoff games and the presence of several left wings were the reasons that led Phil Esposito and the Rangers to trade Tony McKegney to St. Louis yesterday.

title: MUSIC: MAHLER'S THIRD SYMPHONY
description: MAHLER'S rapturously nostalgic Third Symphony, like his more haunted Ninth, ends in an extended Adagio that demands almost inhuman concentration and dedication from the conductor and his orchestra. Despite that, or perhaps because of it, successful performances of both works have not been uncommon, especially in recent years as the Mahler revival turned into something like a stampede. The New York Philharmonic under its current guest, Giuseppe Sinopoli, conquered the final movement's problems last night and thereby capped off a performance of intermittent interest but cumulative power.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Buffy Sainte-Marie and Livingston Taylor, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). One of the most powerful folk commentators of the 1960's, Buffy Sainte-Marie hasn't lost her bite. Her eerie buzzing alto still flays into songs that discuss the plight of American Indians while evoking Indian cowboy ritualism. Ms. Sainte-Marie's finely chiseled protest lyrics have held up beautifully. So have her love lyrics, especially those of her standard, ''Until It's Time for You to Go.'' The deceptively light folk whimsy of Livingston Taylor, who shares the bill, offers an appealing contrast to Ms. Sainte-Marie's directness. Shows are tonight at 8 and 11; seats are $12.

title: South Koreans Arrest 3 High Police Officials
description: Three senior police commanders were arrested today on charges that they covered up information on the torture death of a student, officials said.

title:
MARKET PLACE;
Possible Play In Brokerages
description: LEAD: FOR a variety of reasons - ranging from embarrassing trading losses to costly overseas expansion programs that sap earnings - investment firms have recently been among the poorest stock performers on Wall Street.

title: Knowledge and Power
description: In addition to opening new academic horizons, college also often marks the beginning of political awareness. The City University of New York would combine the two: when students register for classes this fall, they will also be encouraged to register to vote.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Banner Industries, Cleveland, a supplier of aviation products, named as a director Donald Taylor, chairman of Rexnord Inc., a subsidiary acquired by Banner in March.

title: AUCTIONS
description: JEAN ANTOINE HOUDON'S ''Painted Plaster Bust of Thomas Jefferson,'' from 1789 - the oldest surviving version of this, the most famous portrait bust of the statesman - will be auctioned today in the first session of Christie's American art sale, taking place at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M., at its galleries, at Park Avenue, at 59th Street. Jefferson is depicted as half-smiling and thoughtful in this terra-cotta colored plaster that differs from the other chalk-white versions. Probably completed in one of the diplomat's many visits to Houdon's studio, while he served as United States minister to the Court of France, the dignified image was used as the model for Jefferson's profile on today's United States nickel.

title: GOLDIN PROPOSES CITY FUND TO ADD REHEARSAL SPACE
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin announced a proposal yesterday for the establishment of a city-sponsored revolving loan fund to help performing arts groups purchase and renovate rehearsal space.

title: Bley at Sweet Basil
description: Paul Bley, a pianist, leads a quartet tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: TESTIMONY OF YOUTH GOETZ SHOT IS THROWN OUT
description: The judge in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz yesterday threw out all the testimony of a key prosecution witness, one of the four youths Mr. Goetz shot in a subway car in 1984.

title: DEAVER PROSECUTOR ASSAILED BY HIGH CANADIAN OFFICIAL
description: Canada's Minister for External Affairs today accused the special prosecutor in the Michael Deaver case, Whitney North Seymour Jr., of making unfounded and ''irresponsible'' allegations against the Canadian Government.

title: Japan Investing Abroad
description: Japanese investment overseas nearly doubled in the last financial year, to a record $22.32 billion, the Government said today, with 46 percent of the money spent in the United States. Nearly half the total invested abroad was used to buy into foreign companies. A large share was lent to foreign concerns in which Japanese investors already had a stake. The total investment in the fiscal year ending March 31 was up from $12.22 billion the previous year. The figures do not include purchases of foreign property, as companies do not have to report such investments to the Government. Experts in the field say Japanese real estate investment in the United States may have been as high as $5 billion last year.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ELIOT NESS, the strait-laced United States Treasury officer whose group of hand-picked officers finally felled the mighty Al Capone, is more than the stuff of history and legend. Through television, which from 1959 to 1963 projected Ness's stiff incorruptible image into American homes as a symbol of good against evil, he also became a fantasy.

title: Global Search For Stability
description: THE jeremiads of financiers and economists, like those of other prophets or physicians, are usually intended to alarm miscreants enough to bring about actions that will avert the evil.

title: ART: TINY TEMPLES FROM MEXICO AT MET
description: ''HOUSES FOR THE HEREAFTER, Funerary Temples from Guerrero, Mexico'' is not the kind of show to set a publicity machine in motion. Some of these stone objects are barely larger than a thumb; none are more than eight inches tall. All 94 fit nicely into a small gallery in the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. So little is known about where they came from, when they were carved and what they were made for that no one could pretend now to a full scholarly statement.

title: ORGAN TRANSPLANTS INFECT TWO PATENTS DESPITE AIDS TESTS
description: Transplanted organs from a North Carolina accident victim have infected two people with the AIDS virus, the first case of transmission through donated organs that doctors thought they had determined to be safe, Federal health officials said today.

title: Rain Makes Course a Softie
description: Recent heavy rains softened the mighty Muirfield Village Golf Club course so much that there was just no fight left today in the 12-year-old track of 7,104 perfectly manicured yards.

title: Bridge: Teams With Famed Captains Lead in Reisinger Semifinals
description: Semifinal play in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship resumed last night at the Beverly Club, at 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan, with teams led by two world-famous players in the lead.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Todd Shipyards Restructuring
description: The Todd Shipyards Corporation said yesterday that the loss of a $162 million contract would necessitate a restructuring of the troubled shipbuilding company.

title: Colleges Do Something About Cost of Tuition
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MAY 29, 1987
description: International A2-11

title: Johnson Up for Trade?
description: Bobby Johnson, who caught more passes and scored more touchdowns than any other wide receiver in the Giants' Super Bowl year, is up for a trade.

title: Einstein Letters Decision Delayed Their Release
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuts in the Budget Peril Foreign Affairs
description: Our country is the leader of the world. But can we continue to meet the challenges that this leadership poses for us? Can we continue to stimulate the global economic growth so essential to our prosperity? Can we fulfill the commitments to our friends and allies that keep the peace?

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday AFRO-BRAZILIAN FESTIVAL

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 382 money market mutual funds increased $11.4 million, to $239.33 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 94 institutional funds were down $646.2 million, to $64.86 billion. Assets of the 199 general-purpose funds were up $32.7 million, to $68.58 billion. The 89 broker-dealer funds' assets rose $624.9 million, to $105.89 billion.

title: REDISCOVERING THE GLORY DAYS OF BASKETBALL
description: All who played in the legendary kickoff game agree that Beverly Schanzer was the first to be bitten by the basketball bug.

title: Trooper's Killer Is Sentenced To Death by Lethal Injection
description: A convicted murderer, Dominic Schiavo, became the 27th inmate on New Jersey's death row today when he was sentenced to death by lethal injection for the 1985 shotgun slaying of a state police detective.

title: Cubs Get Their Fan
description: Ronnie (Woo-Woo!) Wickers said tonight that he is just like his beloved Chicago Cubs: alive and well.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's unseemly for us to be chasing a Canadian ambassador around, wrestling with security people to attain service.'' - Whitney North Seymour Jr., the special prosecutor, on subpoenas in the investigation of Michael K. Deaver. [ A12:1. ]

title: Pillsbury Cancels Spinoff of Units
description: The Pillsbury Company, facing a slowing of the fast-food business, abandoned a plan to spin off some of its Burger King restaurants because it appears unlikely to get the minimum $73 million it had expected. Pillsbury, a Minneapolis-based concern that also produces consumer food products, said in a statement it was withdrawing the offer because the increase in interest rates and the uncertain market for new equity issues could hurt the price.

title: FLYERS RALLY ONCE MORE, PUSH CUP FINAL TO LIMIT
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have pronounced themselves incapable of panic, and adept at playing themselves out of deficits, and those credos have become precious in this Stanley Cup series against the Edmonton Oilers.

title: ELECTION IS SNUFFED OUT AT INSTITUTE IN MOSCOW
description: The 2,000 employees of the Transport Construction Research Institute here tried to conduct an election for a new director this spring, inspired by Mikhail S. Gorbachev's calls for increased democracy.

title: LOBBYING FOR A MUFFIN: STATE MAY FAVOR APPLE
description: There are bills that advance slowly through the State Legislature, assisted by arm-twisting and deal-making, and there are those that simply sail through on the strength of a little home cooking. To the latter category clearly belong Assembly bill 3508 and its Senate companion 5107; the bill would declare the apple muffin the official muffin of New York State.

title: POLICIES ON ECONOMY AND BUDGET BACKED BY ANGRY PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan assailed critics of his economic and budget proposals today in a wide-ranging speech, vowing to resist any attempts in Congress to raise taxes.

title: FILM: 'DEVIL IN THE FLESH,' IN A NEW VERSION
description: WHEN Raymond Radiguet was 14 years old, he asked Guillaume Apollinaire to read some of his poetry. Apollinaire didn't much like it, but cushioned his criticism. ''Don't despair, sir,'' he said. ''Remember Arthur Rimbaud didn't write his masterpiece until he was 17.''

title: THOMAS PUTS THE PAST ASIDE
description: The fighter with the troubled past is not exactly a radical figure in boxing. Still, the story of Pinklon Thomas Jr., 29 years old, of Pontiac, Mich., has enough twists to give it distinction.

title: TRIBUTE TO STANWYCK MAKES A SPECIAL
description: ''WHATSA matta, you look upset,'' says the big lug. ''I was born upset,'' snaps Barbara Stanwyck. It is a characteristic bit of movie dialogue for the woman who was born in Brooklyn in 1907, named Ruby Stevens, and wound up a Hollywood star, the genuine article. In April, Miss Stanwyck became the 15th recipient of the American Film Institute's annual Life Achievement Award. The black-tie ceremony, jammed with celebrities, has been condensed into an hourlong television special that can be seen tonight at 9 on ABC.

title: TRANSPORTATION AIDE IN JOHNSON'S TENURE
description: Paul L. Sitton, the first Administrator of the Urban Mass Transportation Administration and a senior official at the National Academy of Sciences, died Wednesday of a liver ailment. He was 60 years old.

title: Turner Set to Delay Stock Dividend
description: Officials of Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said they would delay a preferred stock dividend scheduled for Monday to gain time to close a deal that would provide Turner with a cash infusion of $557 million.

title: The Patriotism Defense: Sometimes It Works, Sometimes It Doesn't
description: When Government officials in Washington are accused of a crime, history shows that they often wrap themselves tightly in the American flag. Often with good reason.

title: JUDGE LIFTS BAN IN GARBAGE CASE BUT CITY DOESN'T
description: Declaring the contents of the infamous garbage barge Mobro to be nonhazardous, a state judge today lifted a restraining order that had kept the scow moored off Brooklyn for 13 days.

title: PRETORIA SAYS TUTU FACES EVICTION AT SOWETO HOME
description: The authorities have warned Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu that he could face eviction from his home in the sprawling black township of Soweto unless he paid charges for rent and utilities.

title: Yeshiva University
description: A yearlong celebration of Yeshiva University's 100th anniversary culminated yesterday when the university awarded more than 1,500 degrees in ceremonies at its Washington Heights campus.

title: Tri-Star Planning Loews Expansion
description: Tri-Star Pictures Inc. said it plans to double the size of its 300-screen Loews Theaters chain over the next year and a half through acquisitions and the building of new theaters. Victor A. Kaufman, Tri-Star's chairman and chief executive, said at the company's annual meeting on Tuesday that the company hopes to expand the Loews chain to 1,000 screens within three years without making a major acquisition.

title: 3 Latin American Leaders Issue Appeal on Debt
description: The Presidents of Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay have appealed to the industrial powers to seek a way to lower interest rates on the foreign debts of developing countries during the meeting of major non-Communist industrial countries in Venice.

title: Extradition of Fugitive Is Approved by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo agreed to an extradition request from Mississippi yesterday to return a 25-year-old fugitive in a murder case who has been living in New York City since 1982.

title: 9 NATIONS CONFER ON TERROR DEFENSE
description: Top law enforcement officials of the major democracies met here today in what a senior American official described as an ''important first step'' in higher-level cooperation against terrorism.

title: Trial Run
description: Although next year's Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, will be televised in this country from Sept. 17 to Oct. 2 by NBC, ABC announced yesterday that it had acquired the television rights to the trials that will determine the United States team. ABC did not disclose how much it had paid the United States Olympic Committee for the rights to the trials. NBC will pay $300 million for rights to the Games.

title: New Jersey Symphony
description: The New Jersey Symphony, conducted by Hugh Wolff, will perform works for chamber orchestra by Ravel, Tchaikovsky and Stravinsky tonight at 8:30 in Princeton University's Richardson Auditorium, near Nassau Street behind the Nassau Presbyterian Church on the campus. The concert, with guest soloists Carter Brey, cellist; Constance Beavon, soprano; Frank Kelley, tenor, and John Ostendorf, bass, will be repeated tomorrow night at 8:30 at Rutgers University's Nicholas MusicCenter, on George Street at the Douglass College Campus in New Brunswick, N.J. Tickets are $5 to $15. Information: (201) 624-8203.

title: Nureyev's 'Cinderella'
description: The American premiere of Rudolf Nureyev's ''Cinderella'' is to be danced by the Paris Opera Ballet on June 16 at 7 P.M. at the Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center. The ballet is set in 1930's Hollywood, with an aspiring actress and a movie star as the leading characters. The staging is by Petrika Ionesco, and the costumes are by Hanae Mori. The company will perform the work through June 20. Opening night tickets are $11 to $200; for other performances, they range from $9 to $47. Information: 362-6000.

title: Clark Clouts 2 as Cards Win
description: Jack Clark continued his May hitting rampage with two home runs, leading an 18-hit St. Louis attack today as the Cardinals scored an 11-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied Research Associates Inc., Severna Park, Md., said it had acquired Barnes & Reinecke Inc. for $4 million, with $3.3 million in cash and the balance in Allied Research common stock.

title: Pistons Run Series to Game 7
description: Isiah Thomas waited for the ''go'' signal tonight. It came at the start of the fourth quarter, and with the ball his to command, the Detroit Pistons turned out their young, fast legs and defeated the Boston Celtics, 113-105.

title: Bias Is Called Drug Supplier
description: A teammate who was with Len Bias on the morning he died testified today that the University of Maryland basketball player provided him with cocaine on three occasions.

title: S.E.C. Charge on Talley Bid
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged an investor with violating the anti-fraud provisions of Federal securities law by falsely telling Talley Industries that he had the necessary financing to complete a $233 million takeover.

title: NO SNICKERS IN THE COURT, AND NO HERSHEY'S EITHER
description: Striking a blow for courtroom decorum, a Federal judge in the trial of a reputed Mafia captain and nine other defendants has laid down the law: there will be no eating candy or chewing gum in the courtroom.

title: SCIENCE BEGINS A SEA SEARCH FOR PIECES OF WORLD'S FIRST ARMORED BATTLESHIP
description: An effort to preserve the remains of one of the most celebrated warships in history began today when a deep-sea robot descended to the murky Atlantic grave where the U.S.S. Monitor has lain for 125 years.

title: J. F. Kidde, Ex-Head Of Diversified Concern
description: John F. Kidde, a former president and chairman of Kidde Inc., which is known for lighting and home products, died Saturday at the Clara Maass Medical Center in Belleville, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J., and Gulf Stream, Fla.

title: Key Agriculture Official Leaving Reagan Ranks
description: Daniel G. Amstutz, who played a pivotal role in shaping the Reagan Administration's farm program and in efforts to reduce global agricultural trade friction, is resigning as Under Secretary of Agriculture for international affairs and commodity programs.

title: Out of 'Contra-Diction'
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica is touring European capitals with his plan to stop the war in Nicaragua. There will probably be a strong endorsement from the European Community in the next week or so, and the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, intends to bring it up at the seven-nation Venice summit meeting.

title: NIXON DATA SHOW A WATERGATE HINT
description: Newly released papers of President Nixon showed today that the seed of the Watergate scandals may have been a memorandum dated Jan. 14, 1971, from Mr. Nixon to his White House chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman.

title: Guard Arraigned in Shootout
description: A New York City jail guard who traded gunfire with a suspected drug dealer on a Queens street early Wednesday was arraigned yesterday on a charge of reckless endangerment, the authorities said.

title: Limits of Personality
description: Neil Kinnock is a charmer. In its 45-year-old leader the Labor Party has the most attractive personality to take it into an election in decades. He can talk wonderfully. He comes across as quick, sympathetic, engaging.

title: Debt Ratings Reduced At Middle South Units
description: Senior debt ratings for subsidiaries of Middle South Utilities were reduced to speculative grade, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

title: No-Savings & All-Loans
description: Say, you got any shopping centers that are still unleased, or bankrupt housing developments that need another mortgage? We could do business, if you're willing to pay a fee up front. Let's talk, over a bottle of Dom Perignon.

title: They Might Be Giants
description: They Might Be Giants performs Sunday at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, at 13th Street (242-1664), with Life in a Blender opening. Shows are scheduled for 9:15 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $8.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SIFTING BAKKER FINANCES
description: The Justice Department has opened a preliminary inquiry into reports that the Rev. Jim Bakker and his wife, Tammy Faye, were involved in financial wrongdoing at the PTL television ministry, according to Federal law-enforcement officials.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT'S a long way from France to Tahiti. And so, to relieve the solitude of life at sea while en route from the shipyard to her exotic home port, the Wind Song, a new four-masted cruise ship, put into New York this week. The gleaming white 440-foot vessel - one of the largest under sail in the world - dominated not only the harbor, but the local social scene as well.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FIRST LINES. Poems Written in Youth, From Herbert to Heaney. Edited and introduced by Jon Stallworthy. 119 pages. Carcanet. $16.95.

title: WEEKLY NEW YORK PAPER PLANNED FOR AUTUMN
description: The principal owner of The Nation, Arthur L. Carter, said yesterday that he was planning to begin a weekly newspaper in New York City next fall.

title: SAFETY AIDE WARNS PANEL ON HEAVY AIRLINE TRAFFIC
description: The chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board told a Senate panel today that he believed the danger of midair collisions had reached a ''critical'' level in some areas and that the safety margin for the summer travel season was inadequate.

title: AN OFFICIAL'S ROLE IN AN UNOFFICIAL WAR: A FORMER AMBASSADOR'S ACCOUNT
description: At the Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair yesterday, Lewis A. Tambs appeared before the joint committee to discuss his role in Central America while he was United States Ambassador to Costa Rica. Here are excerpts from his testimony:

title: Approaching The Unreachable
description: Bob Beamon says that not a day goes by in which he does not think of the long jump he made in the 1968 Summer Olympics at Mexico City, one that lifted him past the existing world record by 21 3/4 inches. His extraordinary leap to the end of the landing pit covered 29 feet 2 1/2 inches and has never been equaled.

title: Bonuses for Bureaucrats? Why Not?
description: Although the Reagan Administration has made some radical economic proposals in the past six years - tax overhaul and privatization among them - the prize for sheer daring might well belong to the Office of Management and Budget for introducing what it calls, somewhat blandly, ''shared savings.''

title: Ford to Recall Some Vans
description: The Ford Motor Company has announced that it will recall 290 heavy-duty Econoline vans and 2,300 chassis for buses and medium-duty trucks, both for the 1987 model year. The F and L series truck chassis and B series bus chassis are being recalled for replacement of an accelerator part that may come apart. The Econoline vans are being recalled to replace gas tank filler pipes that may allow use of leaded fuel.

title: Swat Teams
description: In keeping with the substantial increase in home runs in both major leagues this season, the Baltimore Orioles have been belting homers at a rate that, if maintained through 162 games, would break the team record of 240 set in 1961 by the Yankees, who had Roger Maris slugging 61 and Mickey Mantle hitting 54. With 70 homers in their first 45 games, the Orioles are on a pace that would result in 253 by the season's end. Here are the 10 highest team home-run totals in major league history.

title: Gilbert B. Phillips Dies at 77; Headed New York Auto Club
description: Gilbert B. Phillips, a former president of the Automobile Club of New York, died of cancer Tuesday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 77 years old and lived in Rockville Centre.

title: Kraft Is Acquiring A Quaker Division
description: Kraft Inc., said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Anderson, Clayton food division of the Quaker Oats Company for $235 million in cash.

title: A 'MUST' DIG IN PARIS, RACING TIME, UNEARTHS A TREASURE TROVE OF RELICS
description: When a few practical-minded bureaucrats decided that the Ile de la Cite - the island that is Paris's geographical, historical and spiritual heart - needed a five-story underground parking garage, they never dreamed that the project would turn into an archeological bonanza.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: FOR nine years, long before French bistros became the rage in Manhattan, La Gauloise was quietly and competently serving up such homespun fare as mussels mariniere, pepper steak and French fries, roasted rabbit, roast chicken and creme brulee. This handsome and genial spot on the northern rim of Greenwich Village is still doing so today and at prices that make it worth a detour for those seeking a civilized business lunch or a pre-theater dinner.

title: CLUE FOUND IN 'ELEPHANT MAN' DISEASE
description: Two research teams have found important clues to the gene defect responsible for a widespread disease that can disfigure, cripple and sometimes kill.

title: AUTHORITIES FOIL ATTEMPT TO STEAL $1.2 BILLION IN STOCK CERTIFICATES
description: Federal agents and New York City police detectives said yesterday that they had foiled an attempt to steal more than $1.2 billion in stock certificates from an armored car in lower Manhattan.

title: A. H. Robins Fund
description: The A. H. Robins Company can establish a $15 million emergency fund to pay for medical care that might help women injured by the company's Dalkon Shield achieve pregnancy, a judge has ruled. Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. signed the order last week creating the fund, requested by Robins and other parties in the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy case. The order was released late Tuesday. The program will be administered by Francis McGovern, a University of Alabama law professor who is supervising the Dalkon Shield claims process.

title: Goldome Shift Wins Approval
description: State banking regulators today approved Goldome's proposal to change from a Federal to a New York bank charter, clearing the way for the bank, the nation's largest mutual savings institution, to convert to public ownership.

title: Late Rally Gives Dow a Gain of 14.87
description: The stock market staged a last-minute rally yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average - which had been more than 20 points in the hole at one point - finishing with a 14.87-point gain to close at 2,310.68.

title: On Detention
description: The United States Supreme Court's preventive-detention decision offers mixed messages to those worried about the future of bail.

title: CHARLES LUDLAM, 44, AVANT-GARDE ARTIST OF THEATER, IS DEAD
description: Charles Ludlam, one of the most prolific and flamboyant artists in the theater avant-garde, who seemed to be on the verge of breaking into the mainstream of American culture, died of pneumonia early yesterday. He was 44 years old and had been suffering from AIDS.

title: Olympic Hopes
description: Even though she will be 35 years old when the Games are held in Seoul, South Korea, next summer, Francie Larrieu-Smith hopes to become an Olympian for the fourth time by qualifying for the United States team in the 10,000 meters, an event that will be run by women for the first time, and in the marathon.

title: JACKSON TO WEIGH VICE PRESIDENT BID
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that he would seriously consider accepting the Democratic nomination for Vice President.

title: Steinbrenner Meets
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, met for more than an hour yesterday with a black coalition group, although he made no promises to hire more blacks in top management positions.

title: The City With Dirty Schools
description: In 19th-century England, orphaned and deserted children were often sent to large, shabby barracks-like institutions called ''poor law schools.'' In 20th-century New York City, a million public school students are sent, like orphans, to buildings with crumbling plaster, broken windows, leaky roofs and littered hallways.

title: Dining Out Guide; With Views
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. RIVER CAFE, #1 Water Street, Brooklyn (718-522-5200) - ***(July 25, 1986) Spectacular views of Manhattan and the East River can be enjoyed along with some of the city's most provocative food in this romantic dining room on a barge docked on the Brooklyn shore. The chef's style, which is a fusion of American and French, is clean and bold and never contrived. Appetizer choices include composed salad of smoked fresh cod and three-caviar cream; sauteed with artichoke relish, and lamb's Kent Island oysters on melted endive salad with spicy cheddar corn bread. For a main course you might select whole roasted Maine lobster with citrus fruit and cayenne pasta; grilled yellowfin tuna with confiture of tomato and virgin olive oil, or grilled squab with smokehouse bacon and shoestring sweet potatoes. Dinner prix fixe $48. Fridays through Sundays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 7 to 11 P.M. THE TERRACE, #400 West 119th Street, at Morningside Drive (666-9490) -

title: LITTLE SCHOOL ACHIEVES BIG DISTINCTION IN MISSOURI
description: Like the storied engine of kindergarten books, Missouri City Elementary is the little school that could. And now, after a 10-year struggle, it has the credentials to prove it.

title: ART: JOHN ARMLEDER, FURNITURE SCULPTURES
description: THE rage for furniture-as-sculpture continues apace in New York and the work of John Armleder, a Swiss artist who is one of the phenomenon's early proponents, confirms that it is not a purely American one. Mr. Armleder is known for combining old styles of abstraction with old styles of furniture, conjuring up effects that, in addition to being rather beautiful, are peculiarly neutral and tinged in equal amounts with a dandyish irony and a respect for the past.

title: DEREK HARDWICK
description: Derek Hardwick, president of the International Tennis Federation from 1975 to 1977 and an early advocate of open tennis, died at his home Wednesday night after a short illness. He was 66 years old. Along with Herman David, then chairman of the All England Club, Mr. Hardwick was determined to introduce open tennis, involving both amateurs and professionals, at the Wimbledon championships even if other nations were against it. When others decided to follow, the first open tournament - the British Hard Court Championships -was played at Mr. Hardwick's home club, the West Hampshire Club in Bournemouth, in 1968.

title: REAGAN ADDS FUROR TO RACE IN BRITAIN
description: President Reagan stirred front-page campaign controversy in Britain today with open criticism of the nuclear disarmament policy of Neil Kinnock, the Labor Party challenger to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: Manila to Face Top Turf Foes
description: The Belmont Stakes on June 6 is the racing event of the year, because Alysheba is bidding for the Triple Crown, but the Red Smith Handicap at Belmont Park tomorrow could be the best horse race of the season.
