The Triple Crown races were missing some leading 3-year-olds who were sidelined by injury or illness, but the Red Smith has drawn the three best grass horses in the country.

title: Academic Productivity
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS MAKING RWANDA ANXIOUS AND SECRETIVE
description: Down a narrow alley here, past a tethered goat and off a courtyard for cooking fires, is a one-room clinic with a hand-lettered sign reading, ''Afrikan Medisina Herbs.''

title: Whither Hart?
description: Ever since Gary Hart withdrew from the 1988 Presidential contest three weeks ago, friends and supporters have wondered what lies ahead for the former Democratic Senator.

title: NATICA NAST WARBURG
description: Natica Nast Warburg, widow of Gerald Felix Warburg, the cellist, died last Friday at New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Brookville, L.I.

title: KILLER-RAPIST IS EXECUTED IN TEXAS AFTER SUPREME COURT REFUSES STAY
description: Anthony Charles Williams jumped on a gurney with a smile before being executed by injection today for abducting a teen-age girl and then bludgeoning her to death and raping her.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Americans Win: Bob Lewis of Warren, Ohio, won his fourth match in two days yesterday, leading the United States Walker Cup amateur golf team to a 16 1/2-to-7 1/2 victory over Britain and Ireland in Sunningdale, England. The triumph was the United States' 28th against two losses and a tie in the biennial match-play tournament, which began in 1921. The result was the biggest winning margin since the competition changed to its present 24-point format in 1961.

title: ART: COLNAGHI SHOWS OLD MASTER DRAWINGS
description: THOUGH not immune to the mighty whirlwind of ever higher prices that has been blowing from the auction rooms, the Old Master drawing is still a domain in which the tyranny of the big name is far from absolute. Quite often, in fact, an unattributed drawing, or one from a relatively unfamiliar hand, can be as compelling as one that is signed and dated and in all the books. Such a drawing, when found, is likely to be a bargain.

title: FILM: 'MY LIFE,' TRIBUTE TO ZARAH LEANDER
description: A FEMALE impersonator named Armand does a nightclub impression of Zarah Leander in Christian Blackwood's new film, a study of the German film star and the most ardent of her fans. But he cannot begin to match the freakishness of Miss Leander's own presence, which is captured in a variety of film clips here. The legendary ''dark'' voice that made Miss Leander famous was uncannily deep, and her posturing could be correspondingly muscular. Even at her comeliest, in Douglas Sirk's 1937 films ''To New Shores'' and ''La Habanera,'' Zarah Leander looked and sounded very much like a man.

title: Father and Son Aim for Title
description: ''There was a man on second, and the ball was hit up the middle. It bounced funny off the mound, and by the time Dean fielded it, there's no play at first,'' Ed Tatarian explained. ''So I say to the guy next to me 'watch third.' Boom, Dean spins and nails the guy at third, who'd taken too big a turn.

title: Diner's Journal
description: CHANTAL CAFE is a sunny little sliver of a French restaurant on the fringe of the Broadway theater district that is worth seeking out for its bright bistro fare at bargain prices - lunch runs between $15 and $20, dinner is prix fixe at $16.95 (with several supplements).

title: FRAGILE TRADITIONS OF MUSIC SURVIVE FOR CITY LISTENERS
description: ON the surface, New York may seem like no place for musical traditions to make themselves heard. The rate of change is high; overnight, the corner bookstore turns into a boutique, or a dependable radio station switches to a new format. But New Yorkers, buffeted by trendiness, are happy to take refuge in music that looks back decades or centuries. Carried forward by an aural tradition, musical traditions are fragile; even recordings or, lately, film and video can't quite capture the way performers and audiences interact. But traditions do survive, and in New York this weekend, listeners can sample a half-dozen traditions, imported and homegrown.

title: THAIS AND VIETNAMESE IN BITTER BATLE
description: In a largely hidden conflict in a mountainous border region, Thai and Vietnamese forces are locked in what appears to be their most intense engagement since Vietnam invaded Cambodia more than eight years ago.

title: ANOTHER EXAM FOR TYSON
description: Growing up on Bed-Stuy's mean streets in Brooklyn, he never finished grammar school. But as a boxer, Mike Tyson has progressed to what his trainer, Kevin Rooney, described as ''his first year of college,'' with an exam tonight against Pinklon Thomas.

title: Alvin D. Chandler, 84, Ex-President of College
description: Alvin D. Chandler, former president of the College of William and Mary, died of a heart ailment Tuesday at the Virginia Beach General Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: ROCK: CANADA'S NYLONS
description: The popularity of the Nylons, the Toronto-based vocal quartet that gave a sold-out concert at Carnegie Hall Tuesday evening, has confounded the record industry's thinking about the role of harmony groups. Formed eight years ago by three actors - Marc Connors, Paul Cooper and Claude Morrison - and a former member of the Platters, Arnold Robinson, the Nylons sing the sort of doo-wop rock-and-roll that seems synonymous with nostalgia rather than 1980's commercialism.

title: GOETZ CASE JURY TAKES SHORT TRIP ON THE SUBWAY
description: The jury in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz yesterday filed into a graffiti-smeared subway car for what one of Mr. Goetz's lawyers called ''a class field trip.''

title: DANIEL STERN SCHWARTZ
description: Daniel Stern Schwartz, a real-estate investor who was active in New York charities, died of pnuemonia Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nelson to Become Owner
description: Strike another name from the Knicks' list of potential candidates for general manager and coach. Don Nelson, who recently resigned as coach and general manager of the Milwaukee Bucks, said yesterday that he would soon become part-owner of the Golden State Warriors.

title: New Wrinkles In Unit Trusts
description: THE combination of higher interest rates and a wider choice of portfolios has drawn new business to unit investment trusts.

title: Wellesley College
description: Secretary of Transportation Elizabeth Hanford Dole addressed the graduating students of Wellesley College yesterday at the 109th commencement of the liberal arts college in Wellesely, Mass. She urged the students and their families to pay tribute to the Constitution in its bicentennial year. At the ceremony, 508 undergraduate degrees were conferred.

title: BRIDGE
description: The final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship began last night at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street, with an Old Guard team led by Sam Stayman of Manhattan opposing a group of rising young stars led by Maurice Wong of Larchmont, N.Y. The match ends today. In the Flight B final Thursday night, Alfred Lewis, David Robinson and Robert Christman, all of Manhattan, and Charles Greeley of Larchmont, N.Y., won by 19 international match points against Jeffrey Allen of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and his team.

title: JUST ANOTHER RALLY FOR FLYERS
description: The Philadelphia Flyers, after trailing on the ice and in the standings for the entire Stanley Cup final, are at last even with the Edmonton Oilers.

title: WILTING CELTICS NEED THE GARDEN'S EDGE
description: Seventeen games ago, on April 19, which now seems like years ago to the Boston Celtics, they ended their regular season by defeating the Atlanta Hawks. The victory assured the Celtics of playing the final game of any Eastern Conference playoff series at home, where they have been virtually unbeatable.

title: LOS PLENEROS DE LA 21
description: Los Plenetros de la 21 will play Puerto Rican bombas and plenas tonight at 8 and 10 at Teatro's Terraza, 360 East 10th Street near Avenu B (982-0627) with Sonido Costeno opening. Tickets are $5.

title: JAPAN DEFENSE CHIEF VISITING CHINA IN FENCE-MENDING EFFORT
description: With relations at perhaps their lowest point since the two countries restored normal ties in 1972, Japan's defense chief went to China today on a fence-mending mission given only a limited chance for success.

title: DILEMMA FOR DEMOCRATS IN JACKSON'S STATEMENT ON VICE PRESIDENCY
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's disclosure that he would seriously consider the Vice-Presidential nomination underscored the dilemma his candidacy and his strong black support presents for the Democratic party.

title: Trouble Spots Listed For Weekend Traffic
description: The New York City Department of Transportation has listed the following trouble spots for weekend traffic:

title: South Africa Blamed For Mozambique Raid
description: South African commandos killed three Mozambicans today in pre-dawn rocket attacks aimed at African National Congress targets in Maputo, Mozambican officials said.

title: BRAZIL'S CRIPPLING INFLATION
description: Amid mounting expressions of despair over the explosive inflation that is ravaging Brazilian business today, there is a strong dose of nostalgia for the good old days of annual price increases of ''only'' 220 percent.

title: Don't Torpedo Our Domestic, Unsubsidized Tankers
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: JUBILATE CHORUS
description: The Jubilate chorus of Helsinki was established 20 years ago, when all its members were children. Astrid Riska, still the group's director, reasoned that a good children's choir would keep her church supplied with excellent choristers later on, and she wound up creating an ensemble of considerable distinction and a modest but appreciable international record of acclaim.

title: In '88, a New Era. With Old Assumptions?
description: Archibald L. Gillies is president of the World Policy Institute, a public-policy organization.

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about the possible effect of a disruption in oil supplies from the Persian Gulf misstated the volume of crude oil shipped through the Strait of Hormuz. According to the Department of Energy, an average of 7.4 million barrels a day has been shipped during the last three months.

title: GERALD A. ROBBIE
description: Gerald A. Robbie, a trial lawyer who specialized in aviation negligence cases, died Wednesday at his doctor's office in Manhattan. He had a heart attack two weeks ago. He was 55 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: B.H. HAGGIN, CRITIC, ESSAYIST AND AUTHOR OF BOOKS ON MUSIC
description: B. H. Haggin, an American music critic noted for his passionate convictions and clean, cutting prose style, died yesterday after a short illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TIGERS TURN ON POWER AGAINST TWINS
description: Tom Brookens hit a grand slam, Matt Nokes hit a three-run homer and Pat Sheridan and Alan Trammell also hit homers tonight, powering the Detroit Tigers over the Minnesota Twins, 15-7, for their fifth straight victory.

title: EX-C.I.A. OFFICER TELLS OF ORDERS TO ASSIST CONTRAS
description: A former Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Costa Rica testified today that he acted to help the Nicaraguan rebels under orders from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the American Ambassador and perhaps others in Washington, according to members of the joint Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair.

title: REAGAN STATEMENT ON U.S. ROLE IN THE GULF
description: Following is a transcript of a statement on the Persian Gulf by President Reagan yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Cable News Network:

title: FED CLEARS CHEMICAL BANK MOVE
description: The Federal Reserve Board gave permission to the Chemical New York Corporation today to operate a limited-service bank in Florida that will make consumer loans and take deposits but not make business loans.

title: 2 UNDERDOGS DEBATE ISSUES IN '88 PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: The Democrat running for President stared aross the stage at the Republican running for President.

title: 2 Are Killed in Quake in Iran
description: Two people were killed and 50 were injured today in Iran in an earthquake centered 220 miles southwest of Teheran, the Teheran radio reported.

title: GORBACHEV AND BLOC LEADERS END PARLEY WITHOUT ARMS INITIATIVE BUT WITH PLAN TO PUBLISH DOCTRINE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev and leaders of the six other members of the Soviet military bloc ended a two-day meeting here today without a substantive new arms initiative.

title: INSIDE
description: 5 Acquitted in Film Deaths The director John Landis and four associates were found not guilty in the deaths of three actors during filming of a movie. Page 8.

title: Health-Related Strike Ends
description: Workers at Uretek Inc. here unanimously approved a contract with wage, health and safety improvements, ending a three-month strike, a union official said. About 60 workers struck the company, a fabric-coating plant, Feb. 20 because 10 of them had developed non-infectious hepatitis linked to a solvent used at the plant and 20 more had evidence of liver abnormalities. The official of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, Daniel Perez, said the three-year contract calls for medical testing of workers and the sampling of air in the plant. It also raises wages by $1.90 an hour.

title: PANGLOSS FOR THE MAJORITY
description: It's been an unexciting spring in the Supreme Court. There was some mild interest, of course, when the Court ruled there was nothing terribly unconstitutional about confining the death penalty pretty much to black people.

title: Round of U.S.-Vietnam Talks About Missing G.I.'s Is Over
description: A team of United States officials ended a round of talks in Hanoi on the issue of missing American servicemen but failed to reach agreement on a visit to Vietnam by a Presidential envoy, the State Department said Friday.

title: BOSWORTH'S STYLE: BEHIND THE FACADE
description: She screeched, making heads turn at the South Street Seaport.

title: Calvin's Swissness
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE BROADENS LIABILITY OF ASBESTOS INSURERS
description: A California judge ruled today that the largest possible number of insurance companies should be responsible for paying the claims of victims of asbestos-related diseases.

title: Kevin Schulberg Marries Claire Patry in France
description: Claire Colette Marie Patry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Charles Albert Patry of Genainville, France, was married yesterday to Kevin Carter Schulberg of New York, a son of Barbara Goodrich Schulberg of New York and the late Stuart H. Schulberg. The Rev. Jean-Pierre Walthy performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Eglise St.-Pierre in Cagnes-sur-Mer, France.

title: S.E.C. DELAYS MOVE ON UNEQUAL STOCK
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today postponed a decision on whether to permit the nation's stock exchanges to list multiple classes of securities with unequal voting rights.

title: A MINISTRY OF LOOT
description: As a survivor of the tent-revival circuit in my long-ago youth in the South, I still remember the smell of the sawdust on a hot August night, the awful solitude of a small boy on the mourners' bench, the earnest voices of a pickup choir singing, ''Almost persuaded, doom comes at last.''

title: Israel Judges Itself
description: Holding secret services accountable to law is difficult in the stablest democracies; witness Britain's refusal even to allow publication of a book alleging a secret service plot to overthrow a Labor Prime Minister in the mid-1970's. By the world's measure, Israelis can take solace in a remarkable judicial decision exposing lawlessness by Shin Beth, their domestic intelligence service.

title: North Korea Hardens Olympic Stand
description: North Korea has hardened its stand in a dispute over the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, International Olympic Committee sources reported today.

title: JAPAN PUSHES STIMULUS PLAN
description: In announcing its latest measures to stimulate the economy and promote imports, the Japanese Government appealed to its trading partners today to trust that this time its program would produce results.

title: After Vietnam
description: INDIAN COUNTRY. By Philip Caputo. 419 pages. Bantam Books. $18.95.

title: LEADING INDICATORS FELL 0.6% IN APRIL
description: The Government index designed to forecast the economy fell six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest decline in two years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Henry Street Jazz
description: The Henry Street Settlement Playhouse, 466 Grand Street, at Henry Street (598-0400), begins its Jazz at the Center season this weekend. Tonight Paquito D'Rivera, an alto saxophonist, is to lead his Latin-jazz quintet. Tomorrow, Cassandra Wilson sings with her jazz quartet. Concerts begin at 7 P.M.; tickets are $8, $4 for students and the elderly.

title: FORMER COURT CLERK ADMITS GIVING INFORMATION TO MOB
description: A 67-year-old former court clerk pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that she had passed confidential information about organized-crime cases to members of the Gambino crime family while she was working in the United States Court House in Manhattan.

title: Yankees Routed By A's 16 Hits
description: This was the way the Yankees' pitchers had been expected to pitch this season. If they do it too many more times, the Yankees won't be in first place for long.

title: U.S. AND IRAQ ACT TO PREVENT RAIDS
description: The American team investigating the Iraqi missile attack on the United States Navy frigate Stark said today that Iraq and the United States had agreed on steps to prevent further Iraqi attacks on American naval vessels operating in the Persian Gulf.

title: FLIGHTS RESCHEDULED AT 5 AIRPORTS TO CURB DELAYS
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole announced today that 18 airlines had agreed to adjust schedules at five airports to reduce flight delays this summer.

title: TWO ARE WOUNDED IN CHINATOWN
description: cally wounded a brother and sister at their small takeout restaurant in Chinatown yesterday, in what the police said was a failed holdup attempt.

title: TV: ROYAL DANISH BALLET AND A DANCE ABOUT CHILE
description: Being an art of the body, dance can depict states of emotion with extraordinary vividness. Yet, being an art without words, it cannot easily debate moral or social issues. Nevertheless, choreographers have convictions and so may be drawn to political subject matter. One sort of ballet that can result is Christopher Bruce's ''Silence Is the End of Our Song.'' The work, danced by the Royal Danish Ballet, will be shown tonight at 10 o'clock on the Bravo Network in a production directed by Thomas Grimm.

title: TRUMP SAYS KOCH REJECTED PROFIT SHARING
description: Donald J. Trump said yesterday that he had offered to share 25 percent of the profits on his proposed Television City development with New York City for 40 years, in return for a 20-year tax abatement on the multimillion-dollar complex.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Social Events column last Sunday gave an incorrect telephone number for tickets to the Iris Ball on Tuesday to benefit Helen Keller Services for the Blind. The correct number is (718) 522-2122, extension 227.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: AID SOUGHT FOR HOMELESS VETERANS
description: Mayor Koch has written to President Reagan and the Veterans Administration urging them to shelter homeless veterans in vacant beds at the agency's three hospitals in New York City.

title: Medical Negligence Needs a U. S. Study
description: Every year hundreds of thousands of Americans die or are maimed because of the incompetence or negligence of members of the medical profession -more than were killed or wounded in any year of the Vietnam War. That makes medical negligence one of the nation's worst public health menaces.

title: It's Too Hot for Manila
description: Manila, the nation's champion grass horse last year, has been scratched from the Red Smith Handicap at Belmont Park today, a race in which he would have been heavily favored.

title: U.N. RIGHTS INQUIRY IN IRAN TO GO ON
description: Over strong Iranian objections, the Economic and Social Council voted, 22 to 7, today to continue its two-year-old investigation of human-rights violations by Iran.

title: The Longest-Serving Mayor
description: Schools let out early and municipal offices were closed today in this northern New Jersey community so residents could celebrate with Mayor Frank E. Rodgers as he became the nation's longest-serving mayor. As of today, the 77-year-old Democrat had been at the helm of Harrison's government for 40 years, four months and 29 days, one day longer than the previous record set by Erastus Corning of Albany, N.Y., who died in office in 1983.

title: Jazz at St. Ann's Church
description: Musicians of Brooklyn Initiative will present a night of jazz at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, at Clinton Street, in Brooklyn Heights (718-802-9557). Tonight Vincent Chancey, a French hornist, and Jeff Hoyer, a trombonist, will each lead a quartet. concert begins at 8 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: BUCKWHEAT ZYDECO: BRINGING IT TO AMERICA
description: The scene: a small, nondescript building in a bland suburb of New Orleans.

title: Castle & Cooke Studies Spinoff
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said that it is considering turning its Flexi-Van Leasing subsidiary into a separate, publicly traded company by selling the transportation equipment leasing unit to holders of its common and convertible preferred shares. David H. Murdock, Castle & Cook's chairman and chief executive, said at the company's annual meeting in Hawaii that Castle & Cook's financial position had improved steadily since it merged with Flexi-Van in 1985 and that it no longer needed the unit's financial support.

title: JACK A. PARTINGTON Jr.
description: Jack A. Partington Jr., a former house photographer for the old Roxy Theater in Manhattan, died Tuesday at his Manhattan apartment after a short illness. He was 73 years old and was also a resident of Southampton, L.I.

title: FURS AND CASHMERE
description: The opening scene was a smash as models in white cashmere coats reversing to lynx twirled down the runway, their long coats opening on short white knitted cashmere dresses. They wore brown stockings and matching suede pumps, representing casual elegance at its finest. Carolina Herrera's fur collection for Revillon was off to a strong start.

title: Sentenced to Prison, Condemned to AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: LONE WEST GERMAN FLIED UNHINDERED TO THE KREMLIN
description: A 19-year-old West German pilot flew a light plane from Helsinki to Moscow on Thursday, traversing more than 400 miles of Soviet territory from the heavily defended Baltic Sea border. He landed, unimpeded, next to the Kremlin Wall at the foot of Red Square.

title: METS TOP PADRES WITH 4 HOMERS
description: It may seem a little like tidying up the deck of the Titanic. But the Mets, desperately shopping for pitchers because four starters are disabled, made a trade with the Pittsburgh Pirates today for Bill Almon, a 34-year-old utility man who plays every position except pitcher.

title: Panel Approves Medicare Plan
description: The Senate Finance Committee today unanimously approved a Medicare benefit plan to cover the costs of catastrophic illness. The plan would cover all hospital costs and most physicians' fees for the elderly after a $1,700 annual deductible was met.

title: Rise in Inflation Seen
description: The senior economist at the Conference Board, a business information service, said today that he expects the inflation rate to increase this year and in 1988. The gross national product deflator - a widely used measure of inflation - will be between 4 percent and 5 percent for each remaining quarter of 1987 and climb to between 5 percent and 7 percent next year, according to Vincent Massaro, Conference Board senior economist. The G.N.P. price deflator in the first quarter of 1987 was 4.2 percent. Mr. Massaro attributed his forecast to expectations of continued economic growth and further declines in the dollar.

title: Fight Protectionism Now
description: Poisonous protectionism is spreading in Congress. Practically speaking, the foreign trade bill that the Senate Finance Committee has concocted is hardly distinguishable from the House version. Both ought to provoke urgent opposition. The longer this false flower lives, the more it threatens to intoxicate politicians and public.

title: JERSEY BEACHES TO OPEN AFTER REMOVAL OF SLUDGE
description: A long ribbon of sewage sludge washed ashore along 25 miles of New Jersey's best beaches this week, but officials said today that water quality had not been affected and that the beaches would be open this weekend.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Suit Seeks to Ban a Defoliant
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Natural Resources Defense Council today asked a Federal appeals court to immediately stop fruit and vegetable growers in the Northwest from using a popular defoliant that Federal scientists consider a threat to human health.

title: Deposed Fiji Prime Minister Sues New Regime as Illegal
description: The Prime Minister deposed in the May 14 coup in Fiji filed a lawsuit today seeking a return to power.

title: SHUTTLE STUDY TO WEIGH A SWITCH TO LIQUID FUEL
description: Space agency officials said yesterday that they would begin a multimillion-dollar study of whether to replace the space shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets, which touched off the Challenger disaster, with the kind of liquid-fueled rockets they rejected when the shuttle was designed.

title: Unocal-Goldman Truce Set on Suit
description: The Unocal Corporation has decided to suspend temporarily its $2.5 billion lawsuit against Goldman, Sachs & Company, which it has accused of leaking sensitive information during a 1985 takeover fight with T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman.

title: Joseph Martinis, 81, A Former City Judge
description: Joseph A. Martinis, a retired New York City Criminal Court judge, died Thursday in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx, an institution that cares for cancer patients. A resident of Manhattan, he was 81 years old.

title: TYSON IN A BREEZE, AS THE ODDS SEE IT
description: The question these days about Pinklon Thomas is whether he is anything more than a shadow of what he once was.

title: JAZZ: GEORGIE AULD GROUP AT THE BLUE NOTE
description: Georgie Auld was a child of the big band era, groomed in its styles. He was playing his tenor saxophone in Bunny Berigan's band when he was 17 years old and, at 21, he had taken over the leadership of Artie Shaw's band at the peak of its first success, after Mr. Shaw walked off the bandstand of the Hotel Pennyslvania one night and disappeared into Mexico. A few years later he became one of Benny Goodman's major stars.

title: Israel in Colombia Deal
description: Israel has contracted to buy 2.1 million tons of coal from Colombia by 1990 in a move to diversify its suppliers and distance itself for political reasons from South Africa, a major supplier, Israeli trade officials said today, The contract is worth between $63 and $116 million, depending on fluctuations in the world price, diplomats said. Israel is also discussing coal deals with Poland and China.

title: New Directions Festival
description: New Directions '87, a festival of new music, will take place today from 2:30 to 11 P.M. at the Village Hall, 478 Piermont Avenue in Piermont, N.Y., 16 miles north of the George Washington Bridge (914-358-6372). The composer-performers will include David First, Jules Baptiste, Paul Hoskin and Zeena Parkins, George Cartwright and Sally Silvers, and the bands Rat at Rat R, Rik Little and the Loose and Borbetomagus. Admission is $8.

title: Jefferson Bust Brings $2.86 Million, a Record
description: Jean Antoine Houdon's ''Painted Plaster Bust of Thomas Jefferson,'' the oldest surviving version of the most famous portrait bust of the statesman, was sold yesterday at Christie's for $2.86 million, an auction record for pre-20th-century sculpture and the highest price ever paid for a work by the artist. The buyer was not identified. The under bidder was Lawrence A. Fleischman of Kennedy Gallery, who was bidding for the National Gallery of Art and for Monticello, Jefferson's home in Virginia.

title:
PATENTS;
Special Patent Covers To Mark Constitution
description: LEAD: Beginning next week, each patent granted during 1987 will be decorated with a special cover commemorating the bicentennial of the United States Constitution. The covers are to be printed in blue and black with a shadow reproduction of the Constitution document, decorated with a red ribbon and a gold seal.

title: THE DANCE: 'COPPELIA,' AT DARVASH WORKSHOP
description: ''Coppelia'' is the lively and entertaining production staged this year by Garbriela Darvash, one of New York's best ballet teachers, for the annual workshop performance of the Darvash Studio.

title: Public Invited to Sing Beethoven's 'Ode to Joy'
description: If you've ever dreamed of being onstage in a chorus, singing out the great ''Ode to Joy'' from Beethoven's Ninth Symphony with a full orchestra backing you, then tomorrow is your big chance.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 30, 1987
description: COMPANIES

title: Argyros Switches
description: George Argyros, the Southern California businessman who announced two months ago that he would sell his Seattle Mariners of the American League and purchase the San Diego Padres of the National League, said yesterday that he has changed his mind. Argyros said in Seattle that he would retain control of the Mariners and abandon his plans to buy the Padres.

title: Fraud and Grants at Private Trade Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN DISCUSSES PERSIAN GULF AIMS, BUT NOT NAVY ROLE
description: President Reagan today stated once more the goals of American policy in the Persian Gulf. But he did not say how or when the Navy would begin to escort merchant tankers through the gulf war zone, apparently because those details have yet to be worked out.

title: Disaster at Sea
description: TITANIC: Triumph and Tragedy. By John P. Eaton and Charles A. Haas. 319 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $39.95.

title: AIDS Panel Controversy
description: Refusing to appoint an acknowledged homosexual to a White House commission to study AIDS is the equivalent of having a ''Holocaust memorial without a Jew on it,'' the only avowed homosexual in Congress said today. The lawmaker, Representative Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, said of reports that President Reagan will not appoint a homosexual to the panel, ''The most charitable characterization of it would be insensitivity.''

title: Kirkpatrick Shuns Invitation
description: Dr. Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former ambassador to the United Nations, withdrew today as commencement speaker at Lafayette University here after faculty members protested plans to award her an honorary degree.

title: Drug Setback For Genentech
description: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee recommended today that the agency not approve a drug that proponents say can save the lives of heart attack victims by dissolving clots in their blood.

title: KIROV BALLET CANCELS PLAN TO PERFORM AT CITY CENTER
description: The performances at City Center by members of the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad that had been planned for June 16-18 have been canceled. Mel Howard, who was to have presented the Soviet troupe in New York, said that news of the decision not to perform here reached him yesterday morning.

title: Workfare Means New Mass Peonage
description: In a rare burst of unanimity, policy makers from across the political spectrum are embracing workfare as a bold new approach to welfare reform. Forty states already have work programs for welfare mothers, and at least four different workfare bills will soon be vying for the attention of Congress. But workfare is neither a new idea - it dates back to the first work relief programs, 400 years ago in England -nor a manifestly good one.

title: Harold Hoffman, Executive Of Entertainment Unions
description: Harold M. Hoffman, an executive for New York entertainment unions for 40 years, died Thursday at Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center in Los Angeles after suffering a heart attack a day earlier. He was 79 years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: RIGHTS GROUP URGES BLACKS TO TAKE A LARGER ROLE ON AIDS
description: The Southern Christian Leadership Conference, saying that blacks have been silent too long on the topic of AIDS, today urged blacks to accept a much larger responsibility in containing the deadly disease.

title: Sears to Acquire Eye Care Chain
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said it planned to acquire Eye Care Centers of America Inc. for $52.4 million. Eye Care, based in San Antonio, said that Sears had agreed to pay $2.50 a share for the company's common stock. Edward A. Brennan, chairman of Sears, said the acquisition was part of a plan to expand Sears's presence in specialty retailing.

title: Where Race Means More Than Color
description: Nearly all Americans belong to a national or ethnic group once considered a ''minority'' that suffered - and may still suffer - discrimination. Happily, the Supreme Court has now recognized that this discrimination won't be surgically excised; in a significant ruling it recently gave broad protection against bigotry under a century-old civil rights law.

title: U.S. STEP IN DEAVER CASE ANGERS CANADA
description: The attempt by the special prosecutor in the Michael K. Deaver case to compel Canada's Ambassador to the United States and his wife to testify in Mr. Deaver's trial has angered the Canadian Government, which had hoped that the diplomatic and political ramifications of its involvement with Mr. Deaver were at an end.

title: Editors' Note
description: A Washington dispatch last Saturday, quoting Representative Helen Delich Bentley about Kuwaiti oil tankers now flying the American flag, incorrectly described crews of American-registered tankers carrying natural gas between Indonesia and Japan. Representative Bentley says she was misinformed. The crews of the natural gas tankers consist entirely of Americans, not of foreigners with American captains.

title: Sylvia Townsend Marries C. E. Cowens in California
description: Sylvia Linner Townsend, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Charles E. Townsend of Princeton, N.J., was married in Berkeley, Calif., yesterday to Charles Edward Cowens, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Cowens of San Antonio. The Rev. Rose Braz of the Universal Life Church performed the ceremony at the Brazil Room in Tilden Park.

title: EX-CHANCELLOR OF DUKE IS CHOSEN AS PRESIDENT OF TROUBLED S.M.U.
description: A. Kenneth Pye, a law school professor and former chancellor at Duke University, today was named president of the troubled Southern Methodist University here.

title: Nine Suffer Heat Exhaustion Aboard a Bus Stuck in Traffic
description: A busload of pupils from Massachusetts, visiting Manhattan on the hottest day so far this year, got stuck in traffic yesterday and nine of them were sent to the hospital with heat exhaustion after their air-conditioning failed.

title: DANCE: 'DON QUIXOTE' BY BALLET THEATER
description: Don't be misled by the title's allusion to the classic Cervantes novel. Marius Petipa's ''Don Quixote'' is 19th-century comic tomfoolery. The ballet is messy in form, frivolous in content. Yet the roles of its two young lovers, Kitri and Basil, provide dancers with splendid opportunities to show off, as was demonstrated when American Ballet Theater offered two performances of Mikhail Baryshnikov's staging of the work at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: THE WITNESS FILE
description: Name: Joe Fernandez Age: Not available Position: Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Costa Rica. Pseudonym is Tomas

title: Dollar Stability Raises Hopes
description: Note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday as credit market participants were encouraged by prospects that stability in the dollar might continue.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Rise 3.2%
description: The prices received by farmers for raw products jumped an average of 3.2 percent in May from the April index and were above the level a year earlier for the third consecutive month, the Agriculture Department said today.

title:
PATENTS;
Portable Computer
description: LEAD: A portable personal computer was patented this week for the Zenith Electronics Corporation of Glenview, Ill. Patent 4,669,053 was awarded to Horst M. Krenz, a development engineer for the company. A cabinet encloses the computer and has a detachable outer keyboard and a cathode ray tube display device.

title: Yeutter Wary on Talks
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that markets should not get their hopes up for new economic programs coming out of next month's economic summit talks in Venice.

title: CIGARETTE LIGHTERS AND SAFETY
description: Steps to make disposable cigarette lighters safer, especially when they get into the hands of children, are being studied by the Consumer Product Safety Commission and the head of a Congressional subcommittee.

title: Pennsylvania Fund Will Sell Stocks Tied to South Africa
description: The board of the Pennsylvania Public School Employees' Retirement System voted unanimously today to sell within three years all of its holdings in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bill Madlock, the Los Angeles Dodgers third baseman who has been vocal about his frustration over being benched, was released yesterday. He appeared in 21 games this season, batting .180 with 3 home runs and 7 runs batted in. . . . Roger Maltbie, the 1985 winner of the Westchester Classic, has entered this year's tournament, which will be played next month at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Cardinal Krol Quits Hospital
description: John Cardinal Krol, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Philadelphia, was discharged today from St. Agnes Medical Center where he underwent a seven-hour operation May 19 to stop internal bleeding, a hospital spokesman said. ''He went home to recuperate,'' the spokesman, Bob Gallagher, said of the 76-year-old Cardinal. ''He was in good spirits.''

title: JAZZ: PAUL BLEY
description: In a whimsical place of early 1960's performance art, apianist attempted to persuade his instrument to eat from a bale of hay and drink from a bucket of water Wednesday night at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street). Paul Bley, who is at Sweet Basil with his quartet through Sunday, seems to want his piano to sing. The rate of ''success'' for the bale-and-bucket piece may not have been very high, but Mr. Bley's piano does sing. His attention to nuances of touch and attack, to hitting every note of even the most Byzantine phrases squarely on the head, pays off in a lyricism as subtly shaded as that of a master vocalist.

title: YEARLY COST OF AIDS WILL SURPASS $10 BILLION BY 1991, EXPERTS SAY
description: Federal officials and health economists say the AIDS epidemic will cost the nation at least $10 billion to $15 billion a year by 1991, and they warn that it may require major changes in the financing of health care.

title: INDIA'S FIFTH PRIME MINISTER
description: Charan Singh, a peasant organizer and leader of the independence movement who in 1979 became India's fifth Prime Minister, died today of complications from a stroke. He was 85 years old.

title: CONGRESS GETS BILL TO EXTEND INDOCHINESE RESETTLEMENT PLAN IN U.S.
description: With the Thai Government threatening to dismantle its refugee asylum program by the end of June, legislation has been introduced in Congress to insure that the United States extends its resettlement program for Indochinese refugees by at least three years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He was always crazy about flying. When he was a little boy, he would insist on visiting the tower if we were on holiday near an airfield.'' - Monika Rust, mother of the pilot who landed near the Kremlin. [ 1:5. ]

title: Jackson Holds Sessions
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that major league baseball has one month to work out a comprehensive plan to bring members of minority groups into front offices or face pickets, boycotts and other economic tactics. Jackson said professional football and basketball could expect similar treatment.

title: FOR 007, A SURPRISING BOMBE
description: Vodka martinis (shaken, not stirred), Champagne, Jack Daniel's - that is the stuff of 007. So it was a fascinating thought that a meal could be built around food from Ian Fleming's novels about James Bond. Fascinating enough to lure a food writer out to lunch, especially since it was an opportunity to see the newly redecorated ''21'' Club.

title: Acquittal in Racial Killing Shames the Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: MILAN COMMUNISTS RUN A CAPITALIST
description: Guido Rossi is a graduate of Harvard Law School, a former head of Consob, Italy's equivalent of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and a business consultant who earned more than $2 million last year.

title: FUZZBOX AT THE RITZ
description: We've Got a Fuzzbox and We're Gonna Use It, a British rock band, will perform today at 11 P.M. at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Tickets are $12.50 in advance, $13.50 tomorrow.

title: Squealing and Shouting Over NBC
description: Donald Trump, the real estate entrepreneur, angrily demanded New York Mayor Koch's resignation. The Mayor, relishing the challenge, declared that ''If Donald Trump is squealing like a stuck pig, I must have done something right.'' Behind the raised voices lies the tense, high-stakes negotiation over the National Broadcasting Company's need for a new home. Thoughtful New Yorkers will side with Mr. Koch.

title: A Concert to Benefit The Sloop Clearwater
description: Since it was launched in 1969, the Clearwater, a replica of the 18th- and 19th-century sloops that plied the Hudson River, has done much to dramatize the effects of industrial pollution on the river.

title: General Dynamics Pays Penalty to U.S.
description: The General Dynamics Corporation has paid the Government $1.8 million in penalties to settle a dispute over improper charges levied by the company on a contract with the Federal space agency.

title: CUBA DEFECTOR 'SIGNIFICANT'
description: A State Department official said today that a high-ranking Cuban military officer who defected to the United States on Thursday is ''in command of significant military and political information.''

title: DANCE: STREB'S 'AIRWORK'
description: Elizabeth Streb's ''Airwork,'' a program presented on Wednesday at the Kitchen, is dance for this ''Starlight Express'' era. Ms. Streb deals with bodies working against the limitations or with the challenges posed by physical impediments. Primary colors mark the stage picture in dances of intense distillation. But in ''Airwork,'' a suite of new dances, Ms. Streb does move closer into a world of technological bravura.

title: TOP 2 TALK UP THE CHALLENGERS
description: Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway and Francie Larrieu-Smith of the United States tried hard the other day to convince listeners that the L'eggs Mini Marathon in Central Park this morning will be an open race.

title: GEORGIA EXECUTES MAN AFTER DELAYS
description: William Boyd Tucker, whose death sentence for killing a pregnant newlywed was postponed twice this week, was executed today in Georgia's electric chair.

title: AFTER KEY LOSS, BYRD TEACHES TRUANT DEMOCRATS A LESSON
description: Under any circumstances, it is difficult to run the United States Senate. On Fridays, when members are hankering to escape for the weekend, it's even tougher. And with Presidential aspirants pursuing their ambitions out of town, it's well nigh impossible.

title: Dow Falls by 19.11 in Mixed Trading
description: Trading on Wall Street was mixed yesterday, as the majority of issues moved higher even though many of the blue-chip stocks were being hit hard. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 19.11 points, closing at 2,291.57, but advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange led decliners by 943 to 637.

title: COMEX VOTES TO REMOVE PRICE LIMITS ON METALS
description: The board of the Commodity Exchange voted yesterday to remove limits on how much the price of its gold, silver, copper and aluminum contracts can fluctuate in any single day, which had been a basic feature of trading in metal futures for years.

title: KEY RATES
Elizabeth Ballantyne Weds R. L. Elliott 3d
description: Elizabeth Cox Ballantyne, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Merrill Ballantyne of Ithaca, N.Y., and Richard Louis Elliott 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Jr. of Towson, Md., were married yesterday at the temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Washington. The bride's grandfather Wilbur Wallace Cox, former president of the Mormon temple in Manti, Utah, officiated.

title: JUDGE BARS YOUTH'S STATEMENT FROM THE HOWARD BEACH CASE
description: The judge in the Howard Beach racial assault case ruled yesterday that the prosecution could not use some incriminating statements that a youth charged with murder reportedly made to the police.

title: Debate Widens Over Expanding Use And Growing Cost of Medical Tests
description: Janet Towe saw her obstetrician in North Dallas the other day. Then she went next door to leave samples of blood for routine prenatal testing at OB-GYN Physicians' Laboratory Inc., a facility owned by her doctor and 29 other physicians.

title: ST. CLARE'S IS IN TURMOIL OVER STATE'S AIDS PLAN
description: The medical staff of St. Clare's Hospital was in turmoil yesterday and preparing for an emergency meeting to consider a highly controversial state plan that would turn St. Clare's into the first hospital in New York City to treat only AIDS and related illnesses.

title: GOETZ PROSECUTOR: INTENSITY AND TALENT
description: With his simple attache case and a little orange backpack over one shoulder, the slightly built young man in the dark suit could be just another of the curious who show up each day for the trial of People of the State of New York v. Bernhard H. Goetz.

title: Rising Political Careers in S.I. Family
description: A Staten Island father and daughter who both hold major elective office are assuming increasingly important roles in New York politics.

title: ALLEGIS FACES CUT IN RATINGS
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday that they were considering cutting their bond ratings for the Allegis Corporation and its United Airlines and Hertz rental car subsidiaries because of the company's proposed recapitalization plan.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: J.C. Penney Sets Moving Schedule
description: The J. C. Penney Company expects its much publicized corporate move from New York City to Dallas to be completed next year, William R. Howell, its chairman, said. Penney announced its plans to move last month, saying it no longer needed to be in New York and that it wanted to be closer to its large Midwestern and Southern operations.

title: Toyota, Acura Lift Price
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. and the Acura division of the American Honda Motor Company said today that they plan to raise their prices in the United States because of the continued strength of the Japanese yen against the dollar. Honda said it will raise prices for its Acura division automobiles by an average 1.4 percent, or $232 a vehicle, effective June 1. Toyota announced plans to raise retail prices on 1987 model cars by an average 1.8 percent, or $214, effective immediately.

title: A SOVIET FILM MAKER AT CHERNOBYL IN '86 IS DEAD OF RADIATION
description: A Soviet filmmaker who worked at the Chernobyl power plant within days of the nuclear accident there last year has died of radiation sickness, the weekly Nedelya reported today.

title: EX-SS MAN QUITS U.S. FOR AUSTRIA
description: A 60-year-old Rumanian native who hid his past as a Nazi SS guard at a death camp left the country before being stripped of his United States citizenship, the Justice Department announced today.

title: ARGENTINE SENATE MOVES TO LIMIT HUMAN-RIGHTS TRIALS OF OFFICERS
description: The Argentine Senate passed legislation today that would substantially reduce the number of military officers facing trials on human-rights grounds.

title: IN KASHMIR, ROSES, LAKES AND FEAR
description: The boatmen of Dal Lake are busy this year, ferrying visitors past lotus pads, duck weed and floating vegetable gardens. Trout are biting in nearby mountain streams, and hikers and campers are looking out for black bear in the forest preserves.

title: Harcourt Claims 40% of Share Vote
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., which fought off a $2 billion takeover bid from Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, said that more than 40 percent of its shares would be in friendly hands as a result of the stock repurchases it made this week.

title: BUS DRIVER AND CELLIST, MAN IS HARVARD BOUND
description: Stephen James, a 34-year-old Bronx bus driver and high school dropout, will graduate summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa next week from Lehman College with either a 3.99 or a perfect 4.0 average (depending on final marks).

title: Janet Borden Is Married
description: Janet Borden, a private dealer in New York specializing in fine-art photography, and Christopher Shipley, a New York photographer, were married yesterday by Justice Harold Baer Jr. of State Supreme Court in his chambers in Manhattan. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter K. Borden of Cincinnati, graduated from Smith College and received a Master of Fine Arts degree from the Rochester Institute of Technology. The bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Shipley of Rochester, graduated from the State University College at Purchase, N.Y.

title:
PATENTS;
A Gravity Method For Taking Drugs
description: LEAD: A Long Island physician was granted a patent this week for a gravity method of administering drugs to patients such as those with heart problems. Dr. Michael B. Israel of East Hampton, who received patent 4,668,219, says that lidocaine, which is used to stabilize cardiac rhythms after a heart attack, can be administered by the method.

title: Judge in Marla Hanson Case Is Unjustly Blamed for Trial's Course
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
A Vehicle To Combat Terrorists
description: LEAD: AN antiterrorist patrol vehicle, nicknamed the Viking, was patented this week for its manufacturer, the Tetradyne Corporation, in Dallas. The company's biggest customer is the Federal Government, which has acquired about three dozen of the vehicles.

title: Pilot Called Experienced
description: The Iraqi pilot who fired two missiles into the Stark appears to have been an accomplished aviator with 1,300 hours of flying time and 15 successful missile attacks on tankers in the Persian Gulf, Pentagon officials said today.

title: MANY-FACETED EDUCATOR
description: Not long after she became president of Hunter College in 1980, Dr. Donna E. Shalala told a gathering of college administrators that women tended to stay in their jobs too long. They do so, she said, ''because they're happy in them.''

title: REPORT RECOMMENDS INCREASE IN SECURITY AT BROOKLYN ZOO
description: A report to the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation yesterday recommended that security be increased at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, where an 11-year-old boy was killed last week by two polar bears.

title: ALL 5 ACQUITTED IN 3 DEATHS ON FILM SET
description: The movie director John Landis and four associates were acquitted today of involuntary manslaugher in connection with the deaths of three actors in the filming of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie.''

title: PIANO RECITAL: HARCOURT WALLER
description: LEAD: The simple, unmannered way Harcourt Waller 3d presented the first theme of the largo from Chopin's B minor Sonata suggests that the pianist has in him the makings of an artistic sensibility.

title:
PATENTS;
A System to Improve Long-Distance Calls
description: LEAD: A system of routing telephone calls to a domestic long-distance network was patented this week for AT&T; Bell Laboratories of Murray Hill, N.J. It is designed to insure that virtually all calls will be connected on the first attempt.

title: Gold Contracts Falter As Inflation Fears Ease
description: Gold futures prices came under renewed pressure today as traders, taking into account the dollar's recent gains, squared their positions before the weekend.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about an archeological expedition to the Monitor, the sunken Civil War ship, misstated the date of the ship's battle with the Virginia. It was March 9, 1862.

title: HARRUMPH: SOCIAL ABANDON IN GREENWICH
description: Not long ago a new couple in town threw a party that gave some people pause. It seems the couple, Helmsley by name, sent out invitations to board members of the Round Hill Club and others not necessarily known to them. Next came press releases about Harry, the piano-playing host, and his good wife, Leona.

title: EVICTION FOR ERICK HAWKINS
description: Erick Hawkins moved to his studio on Fifth Avenue near 14th Street in 1965. He laid out an airy, spacious studio with a resilient dance floor. He partitioned off a small office, reception area and dressing rooms in the 2,500-square-foot space. He taught his distinctive modern dance style to students and professional dancers. And he choreographed signature dances - among them ''Lords of Persia,'' ''Black Lake,'' ''Classic Kite Tails,'' ''Agathlon'' and ''Plains Day Break'' - that have helped establish him as one of the major choreographers in American modern dance in a 50-year career. But Mr. Hawkins and his dancers have to leave the studio, though Mr. Hawkins won a stay of eviction through the end of the year, because of elevator problems, according to the landlord. And Mr. Hawkins has not found another studio.

title: Accord on New AIDS Drug
description: Federal officials said today that they had signed an agreement with Hoffman-La Roche Inc. to evaluate a new AIDS drug. The Government's patent licensing arm, the National Technical Information Service, said the agreement gave the company an exclusive license to develop the drug, known as dideoxycytidine or DDC. The agreement was necessary because the patent for DDC is owned by the Government.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 6.

title: VOTE IN THE SENATE ON SPENDING LIMIT
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate fell five votes short of the 60 needed to waive the spending limit in the budget balancing act for the fiscal 1987 supplemental appropriation bill. Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, assailed some of his Democratic colleagues who were out of town when the vote was taken. FOR WAIVING THE LIMIT - 55 Democrats - 37 Adams, Wash. Bentsen, Tex. Boren, Okla. Breaux, La. Bumpers, Ark. Burdick, N.D. Byrd, W.Va. Chiles, Fla. Conrad, N.D. Cranston, Calif. Daschle, S.D. Exon, Neb. Ford, Ky. Fowler, Ga. Graham, Fla. Harkin, Iowa Heflin, Ala. Inouye, Hawaii Kerry, Mass. Lautenberg, N.J. Leahy, Vt. Matsunaga, Hawaii Melcher, Mont. Mikulski, Md. Mitchell, Me. Moynihan, N.Y. Nunn, Ga. Pell, R.I. Pryor, Ark. Reid, Nev. Riegle, Mich. Rockefeller, W. Va. Sanford, N.C. Sarbanes, Md. Sasser, Tenn. Shelby, Ala. Stennis, Miss. Republicans - 18 Chafee, R.I. Cochran, Miss. D'Amato, N.Y. Dole, Kan. Durenberger, Minn. Garn, Utah Grassley, Iowa Hatfield, Ore. Heinz, Pa. Karnes, Neb. Lugar, Ind. McClure, Idaho Packwood, Ore. Pressler, S.D. Specter, Pa. Stafford, Vt. Stevens, Alaska Weicker, Conn. AGAINST WAIVING THE LIMIT - 34 Democrats - 10 Baucus, Mont. Bingaman, N.M. Dixon, Ill. Dodd, Conn. Hollings, S.C. Johnston, La. Levin, Mich. Metzenbaum, Ohio Proxmire, Wis. Wirth, Colo. Republicans - 24 Armstrong, Colo. Bond, Mo. Boschwitz, Minn. Cohen, Me. Danforth, Mo. Domenici, N.M. Gramm, Tex. Hatch, Utah Hecht, Nev. Helms, N.C. Humphrey, N.H. Kassebaum, Kan. Kasten, Wis. McCain, Ariz. McConnell, Ky. Nickles, Okla. Quayle, Ind. Roth, Del. Rudman, N.H. Simpson, Wyo. Symms, Idaho Trible, Va. Wallop, Wyo Wilson, Calif. NOT VOTING - 11 Democrats - 7 Biden, Del. Bradley, N.J. DeConcini, Ariz. Glenn, Ohio Gore, Tenn. Kennedy, Mass. Simon, Ill. Republicans - 4 Evans, Wash. Murkowski, Alaska Thurmond, S.C. Warner, Va.

title: JUMP IN DOLLAR-BUYING BY FED
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that its purchases of dollars during the three months ended April 30 were the largest in nearly a decade.

title: Rights Law on Clubs Signed
description: Racial and sexual discrimination practiced by the city's prestigious private men's clubs will be prohibited under an ordinance passed by the City Council and signed today by Mayor Tom Bradley. ''This is a historic day in the city of Los Angeles,'' Mr. Bradley said of the new law which takes effect in 30 days. The ordinance is aimed primarily at the California Club and Jonathan Club whose members include oil company executives, bank presidents and other influential men.

title: Spiritual Chic: Gaining Success With Channeling
description: Channeling, a metaphysical phenomenon born on the West Coast, has arrived in New York. But, like just about everything else, it is turning out to be a bit different here.

title: Candidates Interviewed
description: Harvey Schiller and Jack Davis prepared yesterday to spend all day answering questions from four groups of interviewers screening finalists for the position of executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: BY AIR AND LAND, THEY GOT TO THE FORBESES'
description: The most important person at the epic party Malcolm Forbes threw for the 70th anniversary of his magazine Thursday evening was not Elizabeth Taylor, Howard Baker, William H. Webster, Henry Kissinger, Jean MacArthur, Donald Trump, Barbara Walters, Ann Landers, Tom Brokaw, Senator Bill Bradley, Governor Kean, Douglas Dillon, Happy Rockefeller, David Rockefeller, Cyrus Vance or Willard C. Butcher. The most important person was Martin Fesselle, the freelance air traffic controller who, for the Forbes version of park and ride, was hired to monitor the 33 helicopters that descended onto the freshly mowed grounds of Mr. Forbes's estate here for the event.

title: HOCH LEADS BY 4 SHOTS
description: Still soft in the steamy second round of the 12th annual Memorial Tournament, the 7,104-yard Muirfield Village Golf Club course surrendered two more record-tying scores of eight-under-par 64 today to Scott Hoch and Hal Sutton and a record low for 36 holes of 13-under 131. Hoch had the lead by four shots over Curt Byrum, who shot a 64 yesterday.

title: 13 Hurt in 2-Alarm Fire Inside a Welfare Hotel
description: Thirteen people were hurt, none of them seriously, when a two-alarm fire broke out late yesterday afternoon in a ninth-floor apartment at the Holland Hotel, a welfare hotel on West 42d Street.

title: Dr. Barbara-Ann Kissel-Hoyler Is Wed
description: Dr. Barbara-Ann Kissel-Hoyler, senior psychologist of Community Life Services, a public agency in Philadelphia, was married last evening to Judge Morton I. Greenberg of the Appellate Division of the Superior Court of New Jersey. The Rev. Cynthia J. Ward, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Sheila M. Mara Is Wed To Ryan John Durkin
description: Sheila Marie Mara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wellington T. Mara of Rye, N.Y., and Ryan John Durkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Durkin of Tiverton, R.I., were married last evening at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye by the Rev. Kenneth B. Moore, a chaplain of the New York Giants football team. Susan McDonnell and Kathy Mara were matron and maid of honor for their sister. Mark Weber was the best man.

title: Rivals Sued By Edelman
description: New York financier Asher B. Edelman's investor group, which includes Canada's Dominion Textile Inc., yesterday filed suit in Federal District Court to challenge Morgan Stanley & Company's proposal to take Burlington Industries private.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: First Time Up

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, MAY 30, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-7 2,,q>A West German pilot flew to Moscow from Helsinki, crossing the heavily defended Soviet-Finnish border and landing his Cessna unimpeded next to the Kremlin wall.Page 1 Matthias Rust, the pilot of the plane, was described by his mother as ''a quiet young man of wonderful character with a passion for flying.'' She discounted any political motive for his flight. 1 The U.S. and Iraq agreed on steps to prevent further Iraqi attacks on American naval vessels operating in the Persian Gulf, the American team investigating the missile attack on the United States Navy frigate Stark said. 1 The U.S. will protect oil shipping and the freedom of navigation in the Persian Gulf, President Reagan said. But Mr. Reagan left unclear how and when the Navy will escort Kuwaiti tankers through the gulf. 1 Thailand and Vietnam are fighting where the borders of Thailand, Cambodia and Laos intersect. The battles have reportedly been going on since January and are described as the most intense in eight years. 4 Japan's defense chief went to China on a fence-mending mission, but analysts said he had only a limited chance for success. Japan's decision to raise military spending has been criticized by Chinese leaders. 4 Japan asked its trading partners to trust that its measures to stimulatethe economy and promote imports would produce results. ''I have completely put my promises to foreign countries into action,'' the Prime Minister said. 39 former C.I.A. officer testified that he was ordered to help the contras by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the American Ambassador to Costa Rica and perhaps others in Washington, officials said. The testimony was given in closed session. 7 Trials of Argentine military officers on human-rights grounds will be cut back following the passage of legislation by the Argentine Senate. The vote took place in an atmosphere of growing tension and assertiveness within the armed forces. 2 Cuban defector ''significant'' 2 Ex-SS man quits U.S. for Austria 2 Milan is political trendsetter 3 Deaver case angers Canadians 3 Srinagar journal 4 Bill to increase Indochinese resettlement in U.S. 4 Communist leaders end talks 6 National 8-11, 32, 49 2,4.5,q>AIDS will cost at least $10 billion to $15 billion a year by 1991, Federal officials and health economists say. They warn that it may require major changes in the financing of health care. 1 An appeal for blacks about AIDS was issued by the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. The group urged prominent blacks and blacks in general to accept a larger responsibility in containing the deadly disease. 49 Some airlines will adjust schedules at five airports to reduce flight delays this summer, the Transportation Secretary announced. The adjusted schedules of the 18 airlines will be effective beginning Monday. 1 Insurance companies are liable for paying the claims of victims of asbestos-related diseases, a California judge ruled. The decision could increase the amount of money available for such victims. 1 The first Presidential debate between two of the Republican and Democratic Presidential candidates of the 1988 campaign was held in Iowa. Former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona debated former Gov. Pierre S. du Pont 4th of Delaware. 11 John Landis was acquitted along with four associates of all charges in connection with the deaths of three actors in the filming of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie.'' It took the jury nine days to reach a decision. 8 A Government economic index fell six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest decline in two years, the Commerce Department reported. Most of the fall in the leading-indicators index was related to a holiday-shortened workweek. 37 A study of shuttle rockets will seek to determine whether to switch from solid-fuel boosters to liquid-fuel ones in light of the Challenger disaster. The move rekindles an old debate within the space agency. 10 By cutting down trees, an actor has created an uproar in a Chicago suburb. Mr. T, the gruff television actor, reportedly suffering from allergies, cut down more than a hundred of the ancient oak trees on his estate. 8 New S.M.U. president named 8 A lesson for truant Democrats 8 Jackson statement underscores Democrats' dilemma 11 Suit seeks to ban defoliant 32 Chemical Bank gets Fed clearance 37 Debate over use of medical tests 49 Regional 33-36, 49, 54 2,,q>Donald Trump offered to share 25 percent of his profits with the New York City government for 40 years in return for a 20-year tax abatement on his proposed multimillion-dollar Television City complex in Manhattan, Mr. Trump said. 33 The prosecutor in the Goetz trial is arguably the best trial lawyer on the Manhattan District Attorney's staff. Gregory L. Waples is known as an excellent investigator and a master at explaining complicated facts. 33 The jury in the Goetz trial rode a specially assembled subway train. The defense requested the trip as a way to make vivid the situation in which Bernhard H. Goetz found himself when he shot four youths. 35 St. Clare's medical staff prepared an emergency meeting to consider a state plan to make it the first hospital in New York City that would treat only AIDS and related illnesses. 49 Woman in the News: Donna Shalala, the president of Hunter College who will be Chancellor of the University of Wisconsin, was praised as a ''dynamic, vigorous educational leader'' by the university president. 33 Sewage washed onto some beaches along 25 miles of the New Jersey shoreline this week. But officials said that water quality had not been affected and that the beaches would be open this weekend. 34 Social barriers in Greenwich, Conn., are falling. As the owners of 45 rarefied properties prepare to give benefit dinners for guests who may be perfect strangers, the mood in select enclaves is one of social abandon. 33 A former court clerk pleaded guilty to charges that she had passed confidential information about organized-crime cases to members of the Gambino crime family while working in the United States Court House in Manhattan. 35 Bus driver to go to Harvard 34 Report on Brooklyn zoo security 35 Family thrives in politics 35 Two wounded in Chinatown 36

title: GENTEEL CHICAGO SUBURB RAGES OVER MR. T'S TREE MASSACRE
description: In this wealthy old community, a bastion of gentility and reserve, the leading citizens would hardly be expected to greet Mohawk hair styles.

title: THATCHER'S CAPITALIST REVOLUTION
description: ON THE DAY AFTER PRIME MIN-ister Margaret Thatcher called a general election for June 11, she appeared in the House of Commons wearing a black dress and the icy expression of contempt she reserves for gazing upon Socialists. The ''right honorable gentlemen'' of the Labor opposition were howling like a football mob. ''Frit, Frit, Frit,'' they chanted at one point, taunting the 61-year-old Prime Minister with a colloquialism for ''afraid.''

title: HOME VIDEO:ART
description: LEAD: Norman Rockwell and The Saturday Evening Post Produced and directed by Lew Sayre Schwartz. Art direction by William Logan. Video Arts. 60 minutes. $39.95.

title: GAUGING REASONABILITY IN GOETZ CASE
description: WHEN the jurors in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz descended into a dirty, old, graffiti-splattered subway car last week to view the type of setting in which he shot four youths, they were being asked, in dramatic fashion, to put themselves in Mr. Goetz's place.

title: THIRD WORLD NATIONS FINALLY EMBRACING POPULATION CONTROL
description: LEAD: SOMETIMErrxh soon, the world's five billionth inhabitant will be born, and by the turn of the century Number six billion will arrive.

title: UPSET IN KENTUCKY
description: IN rrwhat one political consultant called a ''festival of consultants,'' Wallace Wilkinson, a millionaire businessman, defeated former Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. in Kentucky's Democratic gubernatorial primary.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THROWAWAY PRODUCTS;
TODAY THE PHONE, TOMORROW THE HOUSE
description: LEAD: THE list of once-durable products that are now categorized as throwaways seems to grow longer each day. The General Electric Company and the GTE Corporation are offering throwaway fluorescent lamps that sell for under $25 and are designed to be discarded when the bulbs burn out. Black & Decker is marketing a throwaway travel iron.

title: Fan Loyalty Vital for Rangers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Exposed to Meningitis, Children Are Treated
description: About 80 children exposed to meningitis in an unlicensed East Harlem foster care center have begun a course of treatment to protect them from the contagious disease, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: William Randon Marries Ms. Madden
description: At St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford Village, N.Y., yesterday Pamela Christine Madden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Madden Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married to William Randon, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Rene Frendo-Randon of St. Julian's, Malta. The Rev. John Kauta performed the ceremony.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; CARNEGIE HILL
description: WHENEVER Dr. David C. Bladerston glances out the window of his apartment at Park Avenue and 96th Street, one of the most unwelcome sights in his neighborhood of Carnegie Hill looms before him: a red-brick tower with balconies protruding like concrete tongues.

title: SURPRISE: ELITE BACK MESSINGER (FOR POST OUTSIDE NEW YORK
description: It seems City Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger can't go anywhere these days without being told by some member of the city's political and governmental elite that they had just voted for her.

title: AFFIRMED AND ALYDAR RAN INTO OUR HEARTS
description: AS Alysheba tries for the crown that eluded his father, horseplayers fondly push the memory button labeled ''Affirmed vs. Alydar.'' And once again, thoroughbred racing's most persistent adversaries come charging through the stretch.

title: BERLIN, AT 750, GETS A CULTURAL BIRTHDAY SALUTE
description: WHEN IT COMES TO THE exact date of their birth, neither a beautiful woman nor a great city is on oath. In the one case, it's none of our business. In the other, we don't care. If it suits the Mayor of West Berlin to say that Berlin was founded exactly 750 years ago, who are we to spoil the sport?

title: Elizabeth A. Levy Weds R. B. Ward
description: Elizabeth Ann Levy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald D. Levy of New York and Wilton, Conn., and Richard Bruce Ward, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C.Bruce Ward of Portland, Ore., were married yesterday at the Levy home in Wilton. Justice of the Peace Edward S. Rimer Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: PRIMARIES: MORRIS RACE IN SPOTLIGHT
description: DEMOCRATS and Republicans will go to the polls Tuesday to elect the candidates who will represent their parties in the coming fall legislative elections, when all 120 seats in the Senate and Assembly will be contested.

title: 'The Italians and the Holocaust'
description: To the Editor:

title: Money And Freedom
description: Yes, money can mean freedom. And so much more. Although I read Marshall Glickman's article with respect and, perhaps, a little awe, my feelings were tempered with a bit of sadness. A philosopher - a student of life -might know that money can also mean power. And with power comes responsibility. MICHAEL YAM New York City

title: Confusing Prose On Violence
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: John A. Bass Married To Amy Susan Chefitz
description: Amy Susan Chefitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold N. Chefitz of Livingston, N.J., and John A. Bass, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Lee W. Bass of Pittsburgh, were married last evening at the Headquarters Plaza Hotel in Morristown, N.J., by Rabbi Peter Kasden.

title: The Credit Card Wars
description: The prime rate's three-month climb - to 8.25 percent from 7.50 percent - is dragging most consumer loan rates with it. But interest rates on bank credit cards have continued to fall, and will probably drop even further.

title: Perspectives: Housing the Homeless; City Builds Big Apartments for Families
description: A SLIM woman of about 20 approached Bill Ravenal on West Farms Road in the Bronx a week ago and asked him if he could rent her an apartment.

title: JIMINY CRICKET SINGS AGAIN
description: SEVENTEEN YEARS ago, the nation's campuses were erupting with demonstrations against the war in Vietnam, the best-selling novel was Erich Segal's ''Love Story,'' the most popular film was ''Patton'' and the top song was Simon and Garfunkel's ''Bridge Over Troubled Water,'' and throughout the Eastern United States you could hardly hear yourself think because of the chirping of the male cicadas.

title: 'HELLO. CAN YOU BE A TALK-SHOW GUEST?'
description: LEAD: HERE IS A BRIEF LIST OF WHAT people have done in an attempt to be booked on NBC's venerable ''Tonight Show'': Sent flowers, T-shirts, handmade Johnny Carson dolls and money (it was returned).

title: PUBLIC OF 2 MINDS ON GENETIC SHIFTS
description: Most Americans believe the potential benefits of new genetic technologies to alter biological functions outweigh the risks, according to a poll published by Congress.

title: Mail 'Dilemma' For Congress
description: A CHERISHED Congressional privilege known as the frank -sending mail to constituents at taxpayer expense - came under fire last year.

title: A Guide To Health Insurance
description: Morton Hunt writes: ''Coverage starting after a $25,000 deductible and paying up to $1,000,000 costs about $70 a year for a 35-year-old man. . . . Unfortunately, few young people buy such cheap protection.''

title: Cuban Air Hero Flies to Florida
description: During the 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion, Rafael del Pino Diaz was a hero among the Cuban pilots who helped defeat the United States-supported, anti-Castro invaders. Later, as a general, he is believed to have fought with Cuban forces in support of the Marxist Government in Angola.

title: NOTES ON A BRIEF CAMPAIGN
description: GARY HART AND I HAD FEW things in common besides being occasional novelists of a political sort and believing that he might make a good President of the United States.

title: A Beirut Shiite Leader Urges That All Hostages Be Freed
description: One of Lebanon's top Shiite Moslem leaders, Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, called today for the release of ''all innocent hostages'' being held in the country.

title: LED RHODE ISLAND IN LATE 60'S
description: Former Gov. Frank Licht, who pushed through a state income tax to end Rhode Island's fiscal crises of the 1960's, died today at Roger Williams Hospital. He was 71 years old and had suffered from cancer.

title: ELECTRONIC MUSIC TAKES A ROMANTIC TURN
description: ELECTRONIC MUSIC, ONCE feared and misunderstood, is all around us these days - in film scores, commercial jingles, New Age dabblings and certain varieties of rock and jazz. For the composers working in these fields, the latest generation of sophisticated digital synthesizers provides everything from simple percussion accompaniments to almost-convincing orchestral timbres and outlandish effects. Yet, serious electronic composition - the stuff for which electronic musical devices were originally designed - has had a frustratingly uneven history.

title: WHEN A MEMBER OF THE FAMILY IS MURDERED IN THE STREET
description: MORE than a year has passed since that chilling night Red was shot to death by a group of teen-agers. He was attempting to stop them from robbing three other youths of their leather bomber jackets.

title: Laurette Angsten Wed To Kit Kittle, an Author
description: At St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Wilmette, Ill., yesterday Laurette Irene Angsten, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Angsten of Winnetka, Ill., was married to Ralph Wade Kittle Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kittle of Keswick, Va. The Rev. Edward Harnett performed the ceremony.

title: Soviet Guards Off Guard
description: At least 100 Soviet border guards were picked up for drunken behavior in Gorky Park in Moscow on Thursday, their national holiday, the daily Moskovskaya Pravda reported today. It was on Thursday that a 19-year-old West German, Matthias Rust, crossed the Soviet border and flew 400 miles unchallenged before landing beside the Kremlin Wall.

title: TELL ME A STORY, SAM
description: A GAUDY SPREE The Literary Life of Hollywood in the 1930s When the West Was Fun. By Samuel Marx. 217 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $17.95.

title: CANADA'S WEST FEELING NEGLECTED
description: WILLIAM VANDER ZALM, the Dutch-born Premier of British Columbia, exudes the bonhomie of one who knows that he and his fellow citizens have something to celebrate. ''Welcome to British Columbia, God's chosen place in North America,'' he said one day recently, guiding a visitor to a seat in his office in Victoria, the provincial capital. With its mountains, its fertile inland valleys and the spectacular metropolis of Vancouver, British Columbia would rank high on any list of the world's most-favored places.

title: Claire McCrea, Editor, Is Wed To Peter Moore
description: Claire Isabelle McCrea, editor of Discovery, a national quarterly travel magazine in Chicago, and Peter Stewart Moore, associate articles editor of Playboy magazine in Chicago, were married yesterday at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Edward C. Curnen Jr., stepfather and mother of the bride, in Bethany, Conn. The Rev. Daniel D. Hotchkiss of the Unitarian Society of New Haven performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: When the Arkansas Legislature convenes in special session here next week, there is more on the line than Gov. Bill Clinton's plea that lawmakers find some extra money for the state's ailing welfare and prison systems.

title: Search Begins for a New Director for Unesco
description: The search has begun for a successor to Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow as Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: A Guide To Health Insurance
description: Morton Hunt says in his article that a catastrophic-illness policy for people over 65 is available.

title: TO END BASEMENT DAMPNESS, ADD A PROPER DRAINAGE SYSTEM
description: IN most cases, dampness in a basement is due to poor drainage of surface water around the outside of the house, or to excess accumulation of ground water in the soil around the outside of the foundation. To make sure that surface water runs off rapidly when it rains, or when accumulations of snow start to melt, it is essential that the ground be properly graded so that it slopes away from the house in all directions.

title: Dr. Lori Brand Weds Dr. Paul Isaac Abend
description: Dr. Lori Michele Brand, who will begin an internship at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., in July, and Dr. Paul Isaac Abend, who will begin an internship at Union (N.J.)
