Hospital, also in July, were married last evening. Rabbi Rueben R. Levine and Cantor Allen Green performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brand of Bayonne, N.J., and Dr. and Mrs. Morton Abend of Mountainside, N.J.

title: SO IS FOOD
description: Shortly after Mikhail S. Gorbachev left here last Wednesday, the food lines began to form again at stores in the center of the city and in quarters that the Soviet leader's motorcade traversed during his three-day visit.

title: WHEN ARTISTS SEEK ROYALTIES ON THEIR RESALES
description: A LITTLE BIT OF HISTORY WAS made earlier this month - and a little bit was resurrected, too -when ''On Social Grease,'' a 1975 work by the Conceptual artist Hans Haacke, was sold for $90,000. It was the first time that a work by Mr. Haacke had ever come up at auction, and the transaction, part of the sale of the Gilman Paper Company collection of Minimal and Conceptual art, set a price record for the artist. Consisting of six magnesium wall panels reminiscent of corporate plaques, each quoting some prominent business or political leader on the usefulness of the arts to business, ''On Social Grease'' went for more than double the Christie's estimate of $30,000 to $40,000 or, for that matter, any previous price paid for Mr. Haacke's work.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, the method of selecting winners was incorrect in an article last week about teachers' receiving awards. The teachers were nominated by colleagues and then selected by nine-member panels representing each school, with school boards and teachers' unions each appointing three panelists. In an accompanying article about the New Jersey Education Association, the date of the budget reduction opposed by the association was incorrect because of a typographical error. The reducation is in the proposed 1988 budget.

title: USEFUL ITEMS, WRAPPED IN WHIMSY
description: THEY are just the right size to tuck into a suitcase as house gifts - especially if the recipients of the colorful tin boxes are either fans of diner food or owners of new cars. Made in England, the illustrated boxes are filled with items that can be especially handy. Shaped like an old-fashioned diner, and illustrated with vintage cars parked outside, the 11-inch long Deluxe Diner Open All Night box includes a Rand McNally map of the United States, three Band-Aids, one moist towelette, four Alka-Seltzer tablets, two Anacin tablets, a package of tissues, a packet of Rolaids antacid tablets and a box of 250 round toothpicks.

title: SOFT-SHELL CRABS: WHAT TO LOOK FOR, WHAT TO DO WITH THEM
description: SOFT-SHELL crabs are at their peak now. These are not, as some people think, a separate species, but are blue crabs that have molted their hard shells. They are at their best at this time of year, when the water is warm. They settle in the marshes, where they are held in ''floats'' until they molt. Then they are collected and shipped to market before their carapaces have had time to harden.

title: EASY-CARE HAIR
description: THERE ARE SOME WOMEN WHO, at the faintest whiff of a change in fashion, chop off their hair, bleach it white, spray it straight up or slick it straight back. Others stubbornly hold on to their blunt, shoulder-length haircuts regardless of the current trends. And then there are the adapters, those who make minor adjustments to bring them up-to-date.

title: More Rides for Unser
description: AL UNSER Sr., the Indianapolis 500 winner, will have a ride for at least three more races this season according to an announcement yesterday by Roger Penske, president of Penske Racing. He said Unser would have a ride in a third Penske car at both of the remaining 500-mile races this season, as well as the Marlboro Challenge, a special $730,000 invitation race during the final weekend of the season in Miami.

title: Rapist Put on Grounds Of Prison in California
description: A paroled rapist forced out of town after town by public protests has been placed on the grounds of San Quentin Prison under 24-hour supervision of parole agents, Gov. George Deukmejian said today.

title: Streetscapes: Grand Central Post Office; A New Tower Belatedly 'Completes' Terminal City
description: THE seven-story Grand Central Post Office, at 45th and Lexington, is one of those older, grimy midtown buildings lost among taller structures. But it is also among the last remaining buildings of the original ''terminal city'' complex around Grand Central Station. Although the details are not yet definite, a development group expects to begin work this year on a 25- to 30-story addition on top of the postal building. The developers plan to use the old building as the base, keeping its facade and remodeling its interior.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNALART TO SCALE
description: LEAD: A WESTCHESTER resident, Jerry Pinkney of Croton-on-Hudson, is the designer of a United States Postal Service commemorative stamp honoring the United Way's 100 years of community service and the efforts of America's volunteers.

title:
DINING OUT;
SURROUNDINGS THAT SPEAK OF LUXE
description: LEAD: LA RESERVE HOTEL has one of the most luxurious restaurants around. From Corniche's hushed, plush entry through the hotel's suave lobby, past the piano bar to the alert approach of the maitre d'hotel and the gracious and comfortable chairs, the fleet of waiting staff, the lighting, flowers and artistic arrangement of food - there is a sense of luxe, a promise that guests will be ''taken care of.

title: PROMISED LAND IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: On May 1, 1914, a recently widowed woman wrote a letter to the Secretary of Agriculture of the United States. The heading of the stationery on which the woman wrote, ''Biltmore North Carolina,'' was almost regally simple. The letter began: ''Sir:

title: DARLING BECOMES ENIGMA FOR METS
description: The only regular starting pitcher on the Mets who has been healthy while the rest of the staff was collapsing is Ron Darling. And he hasn't won a game in five weeks.

title: WILL SUCCESS SPOIL DIGITAL AUDIO TAPE?
description: THIS WEEK, AT THE annual Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago, thousands of Americans are getting their first earful of DAT - Digital Audio Tape. What they are hearing is by far the best home recording method ever devised - a system greatly superior to the familiar audio cassettes, which it may eventually replace. DAT, which brings cassette recording up to the sonic level of a CD, is already on the market in Japan, but whether it may be legally sold in the United States -at least in its present form - is still uncertain.

title: CHILDREN SEEK ARCHITECTURAL TREASURES
description: THEY were sharp-eyed sleuths who would let nothing escape them - not a bracket, not a pilaster, not a single fancy shingle.

title: Drew Knowlton Becomes a Bride
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Middletown, Conn., yesterday Jane Andrews Knowlton and William Langer Schaeffer were married by the Rev. John P. Miller. The bride, known as Drew, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlisle Knowlton of Haddam, Conn. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. J.Peter Schaeffer of New York and the late Mr. Schaeffer.

title: ROSA LUXEMBURG: MORE THAN A REVOLUTIONARY
description: ALMOST 70 YEARS AFTER THE death of Rosa Luxemburg, her name still conjures up images of revolution - and a good deal of controversy. She was, after all, a major political figure and one of the founders of the German Communist Party. What many people don't know is that she was also an ardent pacifist who spent most of World War I in prison. It was partly to ''rehabilitate Rosa Luxemburg,'' according to the actress Barbara Sukowa, that she and the director Margarethe von Trotta embarked on a film of her life.

title: Newspaper Issues Condoms
description: The Boston Phoenix, an alternative weekly newspaper, distributed a ''safer sex'' guide and condom in each copy of its paper today. Stephen M. Mindich, publisher of the 125,000-circulation newspaper, said the move was intended to help fight acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The eight-page guide was prepared with help from Boston's AIDS Action Committee. The condoms were donated by Trojan, the condom manufacturer, the newspaper said. The Harvard Perspective, a student-run monthly newspaper, distributed condoms in 5,000 copies of its March issue.

title: Bard College
description: The author Joan Didion delivered the commencement address at Bard College yesterday, where 163 Bachelor of Arts and 12 Master of Fine Arts degrees were conferred. Ceremonies were held on the main campus lawn in Annandale-on-the-Hudson, N.Y.

title: SOMERS SLOWING DOWN DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS
description: WHEN International Business Machines and Pepsico announced in the early 1980's that they would build giant new office buildings in Somers, many residents predicted gloomily that the town would lose its rural atmosphere.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: OILS AT HOPPER HOUSE Ann Poor, an artist who grew up in Haverstraw, became a member of the American Academy and Institute May 20. An exhibition of her oils and watercolors opens at 1 P.M. today in the Hopper House Art Center, the former boyhood home of the painter Edward Hopper at 82 North Broadway in Nyack.

title: Lynne Kolber, an Actress, Plans to Wed B. H. Barry
description: Senator and Mrs. E.Leo Kolber of Montreal have announced that their daughter, Marna Lynne Kolber, and Barry William Halliday, the son of Doris Halliday of London, are to be married June 7.

title: SITCOMS SEEN AS HOMILIES
description: To the Editor:

title: In Praise of the Asphalt Campus and the Leaders It's Producing
description: To the Editor:

title: Wisconsin's Gain
description: It's on to Wisconsin for Donna E. Shalala, president of Hunter College. The outspoken educator was named last week as the next Chancellor of the University of Wisconsin at Madison, whose enrollment of 44,000 is more than twice that of Hunter. Wisconsin, a major research institution, attracted $208 million in research grants in 1985, dwarfing Hunter's $11.5 million a year in research financing. Dr. Shalala, who has headed Hunter since 1980, said it would be ''painful'' to leave the New York City college. But there was clearly no pain in Madison, where the Wisconsin Board of Regents unanimously approved her appointment on the recommendation of the university president, Kenneth Shaw. ''Dr. Shalala is a dynamic, energetic leader,'' Mr. Shaw said. ''Her high energy level will stand her in good stead.''

title: Wiping Out Foxes On Aleutian Island
description: AS the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service saw it, if the Aleutian Canada goose, an endangered species, was to thrive again on the Aleutian island of Kiska, it was necessary to turn back the ecological clock. And that meant killing all the arctic foxes there - some 700.

title: MUSIC: FOLK SONGS FROM VIETNAM
description: PHONG NGUYEN, the Vietnamese ethnomusicologist, instrumentalist and singer, noted during the World Music Institute's concert of Vietnamese music on Friday that he had collected 42 different folk songs titled ''Song of The Black Horse.'' He was sorry, he added with a smile, that he could not play them all. The one he did play had a broad, arching melody, which he sang with a wealth of delicately quavering microtonal variations, accompanying himself on a two-stringed lute that delicately shadowed his vocal lines.

title: SWIMSUITS: FOLLOW INSTRUCTIONS CAREFULLY
description: IT'S time someone revealed the harsh truth about new swimsuits. I adore every tiny ritual of spring except buying a new swimsuit. There is, of course, the usual disgruntled acceptance of winter's contributions to one's figure. Like others, I, too, stand in the dressing room and resolve to diet. I then rush home for a soothing bowl of ice cream to prop up my damaged ego.

title: FOR NEW DOCTOR, 44, 'IT'S NEVER TOO LATE'
description: LEAD: WHEN 199 fourth-year medical students graduate from New York Medical College in Valhalla tomorrow, Kay Cowan, a 44-year-old mother of three, will be among them. Seated in the audience beside her husband, children and mother will be her father, who according to Mrs. Cowan is ''the happiest 76-year-old man you ever saw.

title: Herlinde Koelbl
description: To the Editor: As your headline says, Linz, Austria, does ''Cast a Spell'' (Travel, April 5). An interesting industrial-historic city, it and its suburbs straddle the Danube with economic and tourist bustle. Approaching it, as my husband and I did in 1981, by traversing the length of Austria from west to east, we were infused by visions of Alpine farms, breathtaking mountain scenery and some of the finest hiking and skiing centers in the world. Our little red rental car had taken us to pastry shops, outdoor markets and to stays at all kinds of ''Zimmer frei'' houses (the Austrian equivalent of bed and breakfast).

title: 'Les Miserables' Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTER UP! AT L.I. RANGES
description: LEAD: LIKE surfers searching for the perfect wave, more and more Long Island ballplayers are stepping up to the plate in search of the perfect swing at the region's batting ranges.

title: Pamela Pinto Marries William G. Millman Jr.
description: Pamela A. Pinto, an associate in the Hartford law firm of Cohn & Birnbaum, was married yesterday to William G. Millman Jr., an associate in the New Haven law firm of Wiggin & Dana. The Rev. Philip A. Davignon performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: IN RIO SLUMS, SOME CHEERS FOR DEATH SQUADS
description: Such is the tradition of summary justice in the poor, overcrowded shantytowns of this city that a surge of cold-blooded murders during the first months of this year was immediately understood by residents. It meant the ''death squads'' were back.

title: WESTCHESTER'S SELF-INSURANCE GAINS SUPPORT OVER FIRST YEAR
description: LEAD: WITH summer almost here, many Westchester residents have turned their fancies to swimming pools, golf courses and amusement park rides. Kathleen M. Tooher is also thinking about those things -and about how they might affect the county's liability insurance.

title: RAIN HALTS MEMORIAL AS HOCH HOLDS LEAD
description: Golfers had Jack Nicklaus's Muirfield Village Golf Club course at their mercy this week, and they weren't letting up. Their attack continued today as several records were equaled or broken on the soaking-wet course, before play in the Memorial Tournament was suspended for the day by a severe thunderstorm.

title: HOLLYWOOD BATTLES KILLER BUDGETS
description: THE UNION representing Hollywood's extras has agreed to studio demands for sharp cutbacks in wages and benefits for new members. MCA/Universal has discharged 200 employees and is about to order executives traveling to New York to use only those hotels that offer special corporate rates. 20th Century-Fox has bolted five of the six gates leading into its movie lot to save on maintenance and security.

title: Brooklyn Projects Get E.P.A. Go-Ahead
description: THE Environmental Protection Agency has given its blessing to three huge development projects in downtown Brooklyn even though they are likely to worsen air pollution at a time when it already exceeds Federal standards.

title: FRESH AIR WEEKEND IS CRASH COURSE IN COUNTRY LIVING FOR YOUTHS
description: Blackberry brambles and poison ivy flourish in the creases of sun-covered hills here. A small brook chatters, and fluffy clouds float in a cerulean sky.

title: Met's Slogan
description: To the Editor:

title: No-Hitter for 11Y
description: FOR someone who had seen a no-hitter slip from his grasp in the late innings of a game against Chattanooga the previous night, Bob Milacki, a 22-year-old pitcher for Charlotte, the Baltimore entry in the Class AA Southern League, was remarkably cheerful on Friday about the single that marred his performance. ''I thought it was about time they got one,'' said Milacki, referring to the line drive by Greg Briley that spoiled the no-hitter. ''I wasn't disappointed at all. I thought it was kind of funny that it went on that long.''

title: A Guide To Health Insurance
description: When shopping for a supplement to Medicare, you have to be careful of what type of surgical coverage is provided. Most plans will cover only the remaining 20 percent of the Medicare schedule. A good supplement to Medicare will cover the full balance of the surgical fee over the Medicare allowance, subject to a reasonable-and-customary provision. RICHARD P. DUFFY The Equitable Financial Services East White Plains, N.Y.

title: WHEN THE BRIDE SAYS 'I DO'
description: TODAY being the eve of the June mating season, a few words about wedding photography are in order. If you ever have been seen so much as holding a camera, chances are you'll be asked by someone to take pictures at his or her nuptials. You can be a nice person and give it a try, or you can follow my advice: Say no.

title: COMMENTS FROM ARCHITECTS, PLANNERS AND BUILDERS
description: John Ellis is chairman of the Housing and Zoning Task Force of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

title: MARIGOLDS: AMERICA'S BEAUTIFUL NATIVE By CARL TOTEMEIER
description: AFTER years of competition between the marigold and the rose for the distinction of being named the official American flower, the rose won. However, the marigold people are not taking their defeat lying down. Instead, they have managed to get the National Garden Bureau, the educational arm of the seed industry, to designate 1987 as the Year of the Marigold.

title: Turks Are Said to Send Many Iranians Home
description: Amnesty International says hundreds of Iranian refugees in Turkey have been sent back to Iran, where they face the threat of torture and execution as enemies of the Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: STUDENTS AND TEACHERS OF THE ARTS HONORED
description: IN AN experimental arts program at Madison High School this semester, 16-year-old Erik Morsink, a junior, wrote his first play, ''Tides.''

title: Cindy Sernau Is Married
description: The marriage of Cindy Sernau and Bruce Gilburne, graduates of the University of Hartford, took place last night at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Sernau of White Plains and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gilburne of Short Hills, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Housing Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BOLD SOPRANO
description: BEVERLY An Autobiography. By Beverly Sills and Lawrence Linderman. Illustrated. 356 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.

title: Gail Gallagher Marries
description: Gail Tara Gallagher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rayworth Gallagher of Scarborough, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James Michael Reilly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Joseph Reilly of Greenlawn, L.I. The Rev. Trevor Thomas performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Francis E. Oliverio, a Roman Catholic priest. Robin J. Gallagher was her sister's maid of honor, and Edward M. Fogarty Jr. was best man.

title: IN LAW-ABIDING WEST GERMANY, DELIGHT
description: A nation where people customarily wait for a green light before proceeding, even at 2 A.M. at a deserted intersection, appeared bemused and delighted today that a young German had disregarded every rule of flight traffic to penetrate more than 400 miles of Soviet territory and land a small plane Thursday evening at the foot of Red Square.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended May 16 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $1.35 million 294 West 4th Street 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 4-story single-family town house; double-parlor, dining room, patio-garden, original Italianate ceiling moldings, marble mantels, 20- by 60-ft lot; taxes $4,608 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Upper East Side $435,000 300 East 74th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, postwar co-op: 24-hr. doorman, concierge, terrace, attended garage; maintenance $899, 50% tax-deductible (Broker:

title: Through Rose-Colored Sunglasses
description: Industrial chemicals are eating away at the high ozone layer that shields life from the sun's harmful ultra-violet rays. To most people the solution is obvious: Cut production of those chemicals and find alternatives. Not to Donald Hodel, the Secretary of the Interior, and William Graham, the President's science adviser. They object to the State Department's efforts to negotiate an international production freeze. If ultra-violet radiation increases, says Mr. Hodel, people could wear more sunglasses, hats and suntan lotion.

title: Barbie Briefly Faces Accusers
description: Ever since May 13, when Klaus Barbie walked out on his trial in Lyons, France, for crimes against humanity during World War II, his accusers have demanded the chance to confront the onetime Gestapo official in court. Last week, four veterans of the wartime French Resistance got their wish.

title: SUMMER PEOPLE, CHILLY SEASON
description: THERE are no two ways about it: Year-rounders are year-rounders. Summer people are summer people. And never the twain shall meet.

title: THE NEW LOOK: BUTTONED BUT UNBOWED
description: THE last time a do-it-yourself street fashion captured the youthful imagination was during the famous Ripped Sweatshirt era several years ago. Now we seem to be heading into the Great Button period. Imagine, if you will, legions of young folk, needle and thread in hand, sewing buttons onto almost everything: jackets, vests, shirts, collars, skirts, hats, even the soles of boots. This fad recalls the turn of the century, when the cockney king and queen of London's East End used buttons as a signature.

title:
ART;
'ALLERGIC REACTION' TO U.S. SCENES
description: LEAD: CATALONIA'S contribution to modern art has been exceptionally strong. Picasso, Miro, Dali and Tapies are some of the names readily associated with that province on Spain's eastern coast.

title: Home Runs
description: PITCHING FOR KIDS, BY MEL STOTTLEMYRE HITTING FOR KIDS, BY BILL ROBINSON FIELDING FOR KIDS, BY BUD HARRELSON Baseball the Right Way series. Hirschberg Productions. Rainbow Home Video 30 minutes each. $14.95 each.

title: National Auto Registry
description: To the Editor:

title: WATERLOO VILLAGE ROAD DEDICATED
description: LEAD: IN A ceremony attended by political, artistic and corporate leaders, Governor Kean cut a ribbon here last week to officially open Continental Drive, a long-awaited road providing direct access from Interstate 80 to Waterloo Village.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: A BENEFIT IN RAMSEY

title: 'A SKINNY KID WHO SANG BOLEROS'
description: WHO KILLED PALOMINO MOLERO? By Mario Vargas Llosa. Translated by Alfred Mac Adam. 151 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: A RICH SCHEDULE OF CONCERTS PUTS THE EMPHASIS ON THE YOUNG
description: SUMMER vacations are coming, but before they get here, a number of exceptionally gifted students are getting their chances in the spotlight.

title: Another View Of Bristol
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Ocean City, Md.;
Building Up The Beach
description: LEAD: AN $80 million plan for beach restoration at this Atlantic Coast resort has been stalled by difficulties in obtaining easements from property owners.

title: REAGAN IS PREPARING TO SAIL IN UNCHARTED WATERS
description: LATE last Thursday afternoon, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger briefed Congressional leaders on what amounted to a postponement of the plan to put American flags on Kuwaiti oil tankers in the Persian Gulf. At the same time, however, a White House spokesman, Dan Howard, was insisting to a reporter that the ''reflagging'' would go ahead as scheduled this week. And the same evening, just after the Weinberger briefings on the delay, Secretary of State George P. Shultz told newsmen, ''I don't know of any decision to delay.''

title: 'QUEEN' OF CRACK ARRESTED IN RAID
description: A woman whom the police call the ''crack queen of Washington Square'' was arrested late Friday in a raid on her Greenwich Village apartment that culminated a three-month undercover investigation.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: LITERALLY and figuratively, Joel Silberman was at the top of his form. His six-foot frame perched atop a teetery chair in a bare-walled studio deep within the bowels of Lincoln Center, Mr. Silberman was in rehearsal for tomorrow night's ''Show Business Salutes Lincoln Center,'' the annual star-studded benefit of which he is producer and musical director.

title: Lisa Romita Marries
description: Lisa Michele Romita, a daughter of Louis Romita of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Anne Romita of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert James Bischoff, the son of Robert A. Bischoff of Cary, N.C., and the late Kathleen Bischoff. Justice Dominic R. Massaro of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion in New York. The bride is a graduate student in art history at Columbia University, from which the bridegroom received a Master of Architecture degree this month.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
ROW, ROW, ROW
description: LEAD: Dr. Lawrence J. Klecatsky is the first to concede it: at 45 years old, he is going through a midlife crisis. The problem, he explains, has nothing to do with his professional accomplishments - he is director of the department of emergency medicine at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center and is the vice president of the hospital's medical board - but rather, revolves around his avocation: competitive rowing.

title: SOUTHAMPTON: A SEASON OF CHANGE
description: LEAD: THE end of May in the Hamptons is the calm before the swarm - of tourists and summer renters. They bring gardeners, repairmen, painters, house guests, traffic congestion - and money. It's the annual invasion that residents of all resort communities love to hate.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Art Getting Into the Development Picture
description: LEAD: ''HENRY MOORE?'' responded a passer-by at the Nassau West Corporate Center II in Mitchel Field to a visitor's query. ''If he's in this building, he'll be listed in the tenants' directory.''

title: Heir Fare?
description: How much does it cost to fly from New York City to Detroit on a weekday and back the next day? It costs about $100 more than flying back and forth twice between New York and Detroit, provided the round trip tickets commit the traveler to stay over a Saturday night.

title: Classical Music
description: George Gershwin died 50 years ago, leaving behind a legacy that tried to bridge the gap between art music and jazz. Crossover efforts have continued, but rarely do they make their way onto the programs of the standard symphony orchestras. This week, the New York Philharmonic is presenting works by Gershwin and Duke Ellington and the premiere of a work by David Baker titled ''Ellingtones: A Fantasy for Saxophone and Orchestra.'' Dexter Gordon, the saxophonist who starred in ''Round Midnight,'' the recent movie, is the soloist. Leon Bates, a pianist, will play Gershwin's Concerto in F major. James DePreist will conduct. The program will be given Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 8 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: WHY A LOW SAVINGS RATE ISN'T ALL BAD
description: PERSONAL saving is the part of your paycheck that is left over after taxes and all the bills are paid. For most Americans struggling to make ends meet, it will come as little surprise that saving amounts to a small share of income. But the 2.5 percent of after-tax income it represented in 1986 was well below the average of 6.6 percent for the last five years and the lowest level in the postwar era.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: PHILADELPHIA HOUSE TOUR

title: Roberta Schanz Wed To Robert K. Packard
description: The marriage of Roberta Sonia Schanz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Schanz of New York, to Robert Kevin Packard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Packard of Los Altos Hills, Calif., took place yesterday at the Union Club in New York. Acting Justice James Benson of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: TEXT OF SOVIET STATEMENT
description: Following is the official text of the Politburo statement on the dismissal of Aleksandr I. Koldunov as commander of the Soviet antiaircraft forces, as translated and distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency. A separate Government statement on the dismissal of the Defense Minister, Marshal Sergei L. Sokolov, and the selection of Gen. Dmitri T. Yazov as his successor did not mention the incident involving the West German airplane that landed near Red Square.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: NO APPLE FOR TEACHER When Mark Shechner gave a college course in the contemporary Jewish-American novel several years ago, his students treated him to a rude surprise. This is from ''After the Revolution: Studies in the Contemporary Jewish American Imagination'' (Indiana University).

title: HASTINGH MADRIGAL CHOIR BRINGS HOME GOLD MEDAL
description: ''LET us celebrate, let us celebrate our happy, happy loves,'' Henry Purcell, the late Renaissance composer, wrote in a spirited madrigal as the 17th century waned.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Tampa, Fla.;
A Community Made to Order
description: LEAD: EVER since construction began a year ago on an immense, residential community here called Tampa Palms, sales have outpaced construction.

title: HOME VIDEO: FOOD
description: The Food Processor Video Cookbook with Jane Freiman Produced and directed by Lee Kraft. Videocraft Classic. 1790 Broadway, New York 10019 (212) 246-9849. 86 minutes. $39.95.

title: Karin D. Morgenstern Wed to Michael Papp
description: Karin Dewing Morgenstern, a teacher at the Creative Pre-School in Las Vegas, Nev., and Michael Louis Papp, a soil scientist, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in West Stockbridge, Mass., by the Rev. Leonard J.M. Perreault. The bride is the daughter of Dorothy Morgenstern Thomas of Princeton, N.J., and Lenox, Mass., and the late Oskar Morgenstern, a professor of economics at Princeton and New York Universities. She is a graduate of the Princeton Day School and Simon's Rock of Bard College. She has done graduate work at the Philadelphia College of Art and at the University of Maine at Orono, of which her husband is a graduate.

title: Tokyo Defense Aide, in China, Promises No Military Threat
description: Japan's defense chief said today that he had assured Chinese officials there was ''no possibility'' of Japan's again becoming a military threat in Asia, despite efforts to strengthen its military.

title: CONSUMERS CRITICIZE MORTGAGE BILL
description: LEAD: THE 87-year-old Consumers League of New Jersey, the oldest organization of its kind in continuous existence in the country, has pitted itself against the financial-services industry in recent years, fighting what it terms the erosion of consumer safeguards.

title: HOSPITAL INCINERATORS STIR CONCERN
description: LEAD: AN INCREASING number of Long Island hospitals are installing their own small incinerators to burn their medical waste because of the skyrocketing cost of disposing of such trash.

title: AN AMERICAN IN PARIS EXPLORES ENVIRONS AND SELF
description: BEFORE the morning mists have cleared, when the light falling around Paris is still soft and diffused, an American woman can often be found strolling the shrub-studded paths of Versailles. Map in hand, cameras over her shoulder, she pauses at a statue turned a certain way, or at a particular juncture of foliage and sky, and she takes a picture.

title: THE LESSONS LEARNED IN SCRUBBING
description: AT the parents' meetings of my children's cooperative day-care centers, the No. 1 perennial complaint usually centers on cleaning. ''Why can't we send our maid''; ''I never clean my own house - my time is too valuable''; ''Why don't we just raise the tuition and hire someone'' are the oft-heard comments.

title: BLACKS AND CONSTITUTION ARE THE FOCUS OF A PANEL
description: As the nation celebrates the creation of its Constitution, many American blacks are uneasily questioning the extent to which they should honor the Founding Fathers, a number of whom were slaveowners.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF L.I.'S BOUNTY
description: THE accent is on local wine at Ross's North Fork Restaurant in Southold. The wine list boasts seven Long Island vineyards and 21 local wines.

title: THE DANCE: MAKAROVA'S 'BAYADERE'
description: ''LA BAYADERE'' as staged by Natalia Makarova for American Ballet Theater, is exactly the kind of full-evening grandiose 19th-century ballet American audiences seem to crave.

title: On Tour With Rock Hudson
description: It's distressing to think that so many Americans are uncomfortable with the idea that homosexuals might be so masculine as to be unrecognizable. When will they realize that gays might be their doctors, lawyers, sports heroes, garage mechanics or brothers? One woman was quoted as saying that Rock Hudson couldn't be gay because he was so masculine and enjoyed watching football, an infallible measure of heterosexuality, to be sure! CHARLES PETER PIAZZA New York City

title: RISE SEEN IN 'BOARDER BABIES,' BUT MORE ARE FINDING HOMES
description: The number of abused and abandoned babies who are living in New York City's hospitals continues to increase, but officials say they are finding homes for the infants more quickly.

title: INCREASINGLY, SUPREME COURT TAKES THE PROSECUTION'S SIDE
description: THE Supreme Court's landmark decision last week upholding ''preventive detention'' of allegedly dangerous defendants was more a milestone than a surprise. It capped a 15-year trend in which the Court has sided more and more with prosecutors against criminal defendants.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
KEYS TO SURVIVAL, 200 YEARS LATER
description: LEAD: IT is such a great honor for all of us to be a part of history. Last summer we celebrated the 100th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty, and we are now about to celebrate our 200th birthday as a nation - the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution.

title: Fond Memories: Estate in Transition
description: Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., the yachtsman and diplomat, has warm memories of his family's home in White Plains where he lived first as a boy and then as a husband and father. ''It was quite a wrench to leave it,'' said Mr. Mosbacher, who now lives in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Ms. Weatherford Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Donna Frances Weatherford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James William Weatherford Jr. of Richmond, Tex., to James Edward Rickenbacker took place yesterday at St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Houston. The Rev. John Mullins performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of William Frost Rickenbacker of Francestown, N.H., and Alexandra Leys Rickenbacker of South Egremont, Mass., and a grandson of the late Edward V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, the World War I flying ace and former chairman of Eastern Air Lines.

title: SHOPPING FOR A NEW FAMILY
description: ELLEN FOSTER By Kaye Gibbons. 146 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $11.95.

title: Why the U. S. Should Bolster Iraq
description: LEAD: Both combatants in the Persian Gulf war have now had a chance to slam the United States.

title: WESTCHESTER OPINION D>GARDENS, NEIGHBORS, BRIEF HOURS
description: ''I WON'T have them in my garden,'' our neighbor Mabel declared with sudden vehemence.

title: A THINLY-VEILED PUSH FOR PROTECTIONISM
description: CONGRESS is considering legislation that would restrict trade with countries that do not respect certain ''internationally recognized workers' rights,'' such as the right to bargain collectively, a minimum wage, occupational safety and health standards and others. In this misguided approach, countries that do not live up to the standards we set for them could face tariffs, quotas or the loss of special trading privileges.

title: PROSECUTORIAL PITFALL MARK BRONX TRIAL
description: IT began with a fatal bullet fired on a summer night five years ago. From a murder investigation, the case spun off into a larceny and fraud indictment that drove Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan from his cabinet post. Last week the tangled drama ended with vindication for Mr. Donovan, who accused the Bronx District Attorney, Mario M. Merola, of political persecution.

title: Eve Horowitz Is to Marry David Leibowitz in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Horowitz of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Eve Horowitz to David Leibowitz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton Leibowitz, also of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''When things look bad is when you should open your eyes and run toward them, not run away.''

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
On the Waterfront, a Tide of New Homes
description: LEAD: ONCE a rustic fishing preserve, then an enclave of tiny summer cottages, Lacey Township in Ocean County has always had a strong bond with its waterfront. It stretches 11 miles from Barnegat Bay to the Forked River and Cedar Creek.

title: Page Stevens Has Wedding
description: Page Van Brunt Stevens, a second vice president in the New York City real estate division of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and John Dixon Knox, a portfolio manager for Morgan Stanley Asset Management Inc. in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Keith A. Brown performed the ceremony at the Ardmore (Pa.) Presbyterian Church. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stevens of Bethlehem, Pa. Her husband is a son of Dr. and Mrs. W.Graham Knox of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Money And Freedom
description: Isn't Marshall Glickman the quintessential yuppie (''Money and Freedom,'' About Men, April 26)? He believes in freedom and Eastern thought (meditation), while being consumed by the desire to make millions. BRIAN SALZBERG Block Island, R.I.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
AN UNUSUAL MEDAL IS DESIGNED FOR COLLECTORS
description: LEAD: THE latest semiannual issue of Society of Medalists bears a whimsical design by Robert A. Weinman based upon the theme ''Cat and Mouse.'' For those who are accustomed to traditional round medals, Mr. Weinman's work may seem radical. Its shape is irregular and conforms to the contours of the design: a cat stalking a mouse around the side of a chunk of ceese.

title: Grace B. Bingham Weds Michael Ott
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Grace Bradlee Bingham and Michael Thomas Ott were married by the Rev. Harold Elliott Barrett, an uncle of the bride.

title: HOME VIDEO: DOCUMENTARY
description: Gorilla A National Geographic video produced by the National Geographic Society and WQED/Pittsburgh. Narrated by E. G. Marshall. Vestron Video. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: A Winning Crew
description: On May 2, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology men's second frosh heavyweight boat raced against Dartmouth. On the way to Hanover, our coach passed out copies of Devin-adair Mahony's article to the rowers and to me, the coxswain. He called it the best article about crew that he'd read, and felt it showed the intensity and commitment you need to win. A couple of the rowers told me they liked the way Devin spoke to team members by name during the race. I listened, and, during the race, remembered to yell, ''Jay, lengthen it out!''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Keene, N.H.: 'A Logical Place to Be'
description: LEAD: FOR years, Aubrey W. Barrett grew corn for his dairy herd on the 75 acres he and his brother own at the junction of Routes 9 and 12 here. Mr. Barrett says his nephew will probably grow corn there this summer.

title: Verbatim; A More Perfect Union
description: ' I stand here today as the great-grandson of a slave presiding over the fifth-largest city in this country. It points out how far we have come in this country and how far our Constitution has indeed evolved. ' Mayor W. Wilson Goode at Philadelphia's party for the 200th anniversary of the Constitutional Convention.

title: Alice R. Ruvane to Marry Thomas Michael Stanton
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Austin Ruvane of Chatham Township, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Regan Ruvane, to Thomas Michael Stanton, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William M. Stanton of Chatham, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title:
SUMMER READING;
YES TO FAMILY, NO TO MONOGAMY
description: LEAD: IN EVERY WOMAN'S LIFE . . . By Alix Kates Shulman. 308 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Correction
description: A brief article on the theater page in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today about the acting teacher Sanford Meisner omits a name from the list of surviving members of the Group Theater of the 1930's who are still active as teachers. The list should include Stella Adler.

title: URUGUAYANS SEEK VOTE ON HUMAN RIGHTS ISSUE
description: Opponents of an amnesty for military officers accused of human-rights abuses say they are close to their goal of gathering enough signatures on petitions to call a referendum on the issue.

title: PUNGENT HAMS OF SMITHFIELD
description: It's no secret that the tiny southeast Virginia town of Smithfield produces a particularly lusty ham, for the pungent, smoky evidence smacks your nose as soon as you cross the town line. The reputation of this most distinctive of country hams has kept it in demand by both outsiders and locals for centuries, from Colonial days when settlers discovered that salt curing and prolonged aging would keep pork almost indefinitely. The origin of the long-practiced methods - now, in part, a matter of law -remains, however, elusive and debated.

title: FOR BURUNDI, LIBYAN CHECK IS STILL IN MAIL
description: Under the heading ''tourist sights,'' a city map here lists ''Qaddafi Mosque.''

title: IN FRANCE, THE FESTIVAL IS CONSTANT
description: WHEN A MOVIE BUFF DIES, he doesn't go to heaven - he comes to Paris. Whether he wanted to see

title: MONEY-CENTER BANKS - A BAD BET?
description: Citicorp's recent move to add $3 billion to its loan-loss reserves because of its troubled foreign loans has firmed the previously soft prices of money-center bank stocks. Citi's stock jumped more than 7 points after the announcement on May 18.

title: CONVERTS ND CONCUBINES
description: SEGU By Maryse Conde. Translated by Barbara Bray. 499 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: EXPLORING THE KINGDOM OF AIDS
description: I SPENT A MONTH recently in the imaginary kingdom of AIDS, tracking what experts say is the designated future of the disease: its coming assault upon the heterosexual community. What I was looking at was the behavior of heterosexuals surrounded by the same storm warnings yet acting in a wide variety of ways.

title: EVANGELICALS FIGHT OVER BOTH BODY AND SOUL
description: Whether the Rev. Jerry Falwell is trying to steal the PTL ministry, as Jim Bakker says, or to save it, there is more at stake here for the American evangelical movement than an air-conditioned doghouse or gold-plated bathroom fixtures.

title: CELTICS EARN ANOTHER TRIP TO FINAL
description: The Boston Garden worked its charm for the Celtics again today.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: MAY 31, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $4.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter becomes a consuming passion. 3 2 BARRIER ISLAND, by John D. MacDonald. (Fawcett, $4.50.) title: HOW WILL FANS REACT TO GOODEN'S RETURN?
description: Putting aside Dwight Gooden's baseball statistics that have made him a superstar; putting aside his brushes with the law; putting aside his connections with drugs, guns and women, Dwight Gooden will be greeted with the most thunderous applause yet to be heard in Shea Stadium as he strides to the mound for his first game since being suspended.

title: GROUP WIDENS SALUTES TO EISENHOWER
description: Since 1969, the Dwight D. Eisenhower Society has been quietly working to keep the memory of the late five-star general and two-term President vivid by awarding student scholarships and celebrating his birthday every Oct. 14 at Gettysburg College near his beloved farm in Gettysburg, Pa.

title: A DELAWARE BEACH WITH A DOUBLE ALLURE
description: Along a 30-mile strand of sand on Delaware's Atlantic Coast is Rehoboth Beach. If you've never been in this neck of the woods, the first thing you should know is that the woods in question is a pine forest, one that, in the northern residential areas, extends to the very edge of the broad, white sand beach. This makes for an unusual split personality that is especially appealing to summer visitors for whom a little baking in the sun goes a long way.

title: OF TIME AND THE TRAIN
description: ''When does your flight leave?'' my young acquaintance inquired as our Philadelphia convention drew toward a close. For a split second I considered an evasive answer, then decided to brave it out: ''I rode the train.'' My friend's fleeting grimace probably mirrored her inner conclusion: any American in the 1980's who deliberately wastes 48 hours on a train trip to and from a professional meeting must ipso facto be phobic, indigent or verging on senility. Possibly all of the above.

title: CATHOLICS REACH ACCORD IN SEATTLE CASE
description: WHEN a panel of three American bishops announced an arrangement last week allowing Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen to resume control of the Archdiocese of Seattle, the commission appeared to be affirming the right of Catholic institutions in the United States to go about their business in the open, democratic manner to which they have grown accustomed.

title: Constitution Wasn't About Justice, but Order
description: To the Editor:

title: Jane Kamensky Weds D. J. Scannell Jr.
description: At the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Chapel at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J., yesterday, Jane Kamensky and Dennis J. Scannell Jr. were married by the Rev. Thomas P. Lipnick. Ann Kamensky was her sister's maid of honor, and Michael G. Scannell was his brother's best man.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: 'MUSIC-GO-ROUND' Having gone round nine times before this year with concerts and workshops for children, ''Music-Go-Round'' ends its season today in Massapequa Park with the Kaleidoscope Dancers. The four-member modern dance company, backed by piano, choreographs and performs exclusively for young audiences - even inviting the youngsters to dance along to the wide variety of music produced by live instruments, voice chant and recordings.

title: A PROGRAM THAT TRIES TO TALK BACK
description: THE screen greeted me with the title ''Thoughtline Computer Intelligence for Business Communications,'' followed by ''Hi - I'm Thoughtline, the intelligent writers companion.'' There was no apostrophe to be seen. ''I assume you are about to put your thoughts in writing,'' the screen continued. ''You can converse with me in free text by typing in normal English sentences. When you have finished typing your reply, hit 'Enter' (the big arrow key). What is your name.'' No question mark.

title: Representative Frank Discloses He Is Homosexual
description: Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said Friday that he is homosexual, becoming only the second member of Congress to openly discuss his homosexuality.

title: Park Ride Accident Studied
description: A minor design flaw may have caused an accident on a raft ride at Hersheypark in which six people were injured last weekend, according to an article in The Harrisburg Evening News. Richard Coulter, an amusement park safety specialist from Delaware, Ohio, said the flaw in the Canyon River Rapids could be quickly corrected, The Evening News reported Thursday. He is to review his findings with officials of the ride's manufacturer, Intamin A.G. of Berkeley, Calif., and no further details will be released until afterward, said Richard Roberts, a spokesman for Hersheypark.

title: SERVED 3 TERMS AS SENATOR FROM KANSAS
description: Frank Carlson, a former Governor, Senator and United States Representative from Kansas, but above all a farmer, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Concordia, Kan. He was 94 years old.

title: Can the Big Seven Learn to Waltz?
description: SIX somberly suited men and one, the Italian, who invariably arrives in open sports coats, convene every three months or so in the opulent gilded chambers of the Louvre Palace, in the clubby rooms of No. 11 Downing Street or beneath the swooping brass chandeliers of the American Treasury's third-floor conference room. All ministers of finance, they call each other by first names - Jim, Kiichi, Gerhard, Edouard, Nigel, Michael, Giovanni. All come armed with briefing books, kept at their fingertips, and with the weight of their economies on their backs. Each also brings his deputy and his central banker, and three bring interpreters. The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, is also there, to try to keep the others honest.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT doesn't require any particular brilliance to know why thousands of dogs are named Rover, or why carloads of cuddly white cats answer to the name of Snowball. But why would a miniature poodle who looks like a powder puff be called Max, or a cat who, according to his owner, ''just lives for love,'' be named Moe? Especially when the names have nothing to do with family.

title: GAME 7: IT COULD HINGE PENALTIES
description: The Oilers played beautifully and opened a 3-games-to-1 advantage in their quest for a third Stanley Cup, but the Flyers played rough and fought back to tie the series and force a seventh game.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago; Landmark Gets A New Luster
description: THE landmark neo-classical Peoples Gas Building, designed by the turn-of-the-century architect and urban planner Daniel Burnham, is emerging from a $16 million restoration as a general-purpose office building.

title: Prince's New Album
description: To the Editor:

title: On Tour With Rock Hudson
description: It may be the writer's job ''. . . to seek out the truth,'' but who wants to know? Leave some heroes untarnished for us to foolishly admire. ROBERT F. SCHULTZ Johnstown, N.Y.

title: Q/AND A
description: CATALINA ISLAND

title: '84 Political Spending Is Put at $1.8 Billion
description: A private study estimates that spending on national, state and local political campaigns reached a new high of $1.8 billion in the last Presidential election year.

title:
SUMMER READING;
I CAME, I SAW, I GOT RICH
description: LEAD: THE MIDAS TOUCH The Strategies That Have Made Warren Buffett America's Pre-eminent Investor. By John Train. Tables. 207 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Local Asian Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: Collectible Adolescence
description: I'M ENTERING THAT AGE WHEN songs from the hit parades of my adolescence bring tears of nostalgia. I'm a sucker for memorabilia of the 1950's.

title: Eight Steps For Life
description: The Administration in Washington is opposed to making sure that a representative of the homosexual community is named to a panel to study the AIDS plague and what it might mean for the whole country. It shows vividly the people who run the Government simply have not faced reality.

title: Old vs. New Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: Davis Homer Sets 2 Records
description: Eric Davis hit a grand slam in the third inning tonight, breaking two league records and leading the Cincinnati Reds past the Pirates, 6-2.

title: Raiders Reported Stadium Shopping
description: The Los Angeles Raiders, who are involved in a dispute with their home stadium, have approached Pasadena officials about possibly playing in the Rose Bowl, according to a published report.

title: Maine's Caribous Giving Birth
description: THE caribou that were trucked into Maine from Newfoundland last winter have started bearing a new generation that biologists hope will one day return the once common species to the wilds of Maine.

title: LASIX BAN IN BELMONT WILL PUT ALYSHEBA'S ABILITY TO THE TEST
description: When Alysheba steps onto the track for the Belmont Stakes Saturday, he will be lacking one ingredient in the formula that has brought him to the threshold of becoming racing's 12th Triple Cown winner: his usual dose of furosemide.
