The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) MORE DIE OF HEARTBREAK, by Saul Bellow. (Morrow, $17.95.) This brilliant novel of the relationship between a 35-year-old man and his uncle - with its widening ripples of betrayal, deceit and self-deceit, of conspiracy, of sex confused with love, and of a bruising confidence game - demonstrates how you can love someone without at all loving what he did to you. A GOOD ENOUGH PARENT: A Book on Child-Rearing, by Bruno Bettelheim. (Knopf, $18.95.) A leisurely, humanistic approach to children for their elders, in which both sides are awarded gold stars by an eminent teacher who counsels understanding above all, closely followed by forbearance. WALTZING WITH A DICTATOR: The Marcoses and the Making of American Policy, by Raymond Bonner. (Times Books, $19.95.) This impressive study of five American Presidents and Ferdinand Marcos emphasizes that the United States' relationship with the Philippines is like no other - and that is a major problem. BEST INTENTIONS: The Education and Killing of Edmund Perry, by Robert Sam Anson. (Random House, $17.95.) A 17-year-old black youth, child of Harlem, honors graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, died after being shot by a white policeman who claimed self-defense. The extremes in his short life and the heritage of racism in America are the author's baffling subjects. INDIAN COUNTRY, by Philip Caputo. (Bantam, $18.95.) A Vietnam veteran in Michigan is trapped by his armor of fear, paranoia and mania in this artful and clever psychological novel. PRIVATE DOMAIN, by Paul Taylor. (Knopf, $22.95.) One of the world's great modern dancers and choreographers creates an extraordinarily vivid and revealing duet-with-one autobiography that should rank among the definitive accounts of what it means to be a creative artist in America. IN THE COUNTRY OF LAST THINGS, by Paul Auster. (Viking, $15.95.) If in the beginning was the word, then in this linguistic-game novel of a city (New York?) post-apocalypse, it still will be.

title: Customs to Head Drug Effort
description: President Reagan announced a plan today to ''add new vigor and a more comprehensive approach'' to the Government's anti-drug efforts.

title: Ditka Leads Entries Into Hall of Fame
description: Eleven former college football players, seven deceased college players, a retired coach and two deceased coaches were enshrined in ceremonies Friday night at the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame. The Hall conducted no enshrinement program last year, so Friday night's program was intended to cover the last two incoming classes of former college stars.

title: Joy Jacobson Weds Gerald Warburg 2d
description: Joy Jacobson, finance director of the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee, was married in Middleburg, Va., yesterday to Gerald Felix Warburg 2d, foreign policy and defense adviser to Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California. The Rev. John Thomas of St. Albans Episcopal Church in Annandale, Va., performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Frederick M. Warburg, widow of the bridegroom's great-uncle, the sportsman, financier and philanthropist.

title: Alison L. Hart and Peter J. Schlosser Are Married
description: Alison Leigh Hart and Peter Jay Schlosser, architects in San Francisco, were married last evening at Temple B'nai Jeshuran in Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi David J. Seligson, rabbi emeritus of the Central Synagogue in New York, performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor David Summers.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Ocean City, Md.: Building Up The Beach
description: LEAD: AN $80 million plan for beach restoration at this Atlantic Coast resort has been stalled by difficulties in obtaining easements from property owners.

title: IN THE DUNES
description: SOME HOUSES BE-come legends because of where they are; others, because of the personalities who have lived in them. The house shown on these pages is special for both reasons. For 30 years, the late actress Katharine Cornell summered on this 18-acre peninsula in Martha's Vineyard. Named Chip Chop to conform with East Chop and West Chop, two other points on the island, the property consists of a shingled main house, two adjoining guest cottages, a pool and a cabana. The house and cottages, designed by the architect Eric Gugler, took eight years to build. Construction began in 1937, but because World War II intervened, the house was not finished until 1945.

title: WASN'T IT ROMANTIC?
description: NEW YORK 1930 Architecture and Urbanism Between the Two World Wars. By Robert A. M. Stern, Gregory Gilmartin and Thomas Mellins. Assisted by David Fishman and Raymond W. Gastil. Illustrated. 847 pp. New York: Rizzoli. $75.

title: CLASSICAL LESSONS, TAUGHT ANEW BY STUDENTS
description: THE DELIGHTFUL PERFORM-ances of Serge Lifar's ''Suite en Blanc'' and Albert Aveline's version of ''Les Deux Pigeons'' given in Paris this month by the Paris Opera Ballet School serve as vibrant reminders that France's classical ballet tradition is not only alive and well but worthy of deeper appreciation.

title: AN OCEAN OF FLOOZY FISH
description: BLUES By John Hersey. Illustrated by James Baker. 205 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: By FRANK LYNN
description: TWO leading Suffolk Democrats announced their candidacies last week for the County Executive and Islip Supervisor's elections, which will very likely be the most heated contests in the county this November and mirror images of each other.

title: DETAILING 'THE D.E.A. CAPER': BUNGLED BID TO BUY HOSTAGES
description: It was early 1985 and the Reagan Administration had failed to rescue -or even find - William Buckley, the kidnapped Beirut station chief of the Central Intelligence Agency. Almost as an afterthought, the White House asked the Drug Enforcement Agency to search its worldwide network of informants for clues about Mr. Buckley and other American hostages.

title: A Red Hot Poker
description: DOUBLE INDEMNITY Starring Fred MacMurray, Barbara Stanwyck, Edward G. Robinson. Directed by Billy Wilder. Screenplay by Billy Wilder and Raymond Chandler from a novel by James M. Cain. 1944. MCA Home Video. 107 minutes. $29.95.

title: NO TELLING WHAT FORTUNE MAY BRING
description: OUR community center scheduled a fund-raiser, and guess who volunteered to think of a booth. Yes, you guessed it - I did.

title: PEEKSKILL FLEA MARKET, DAWN TO DUSK
description: LEAD: IT is very early on a Sunday morning, and the flea-market people are coming to Peekskill.

title: HOW WILL FANS REACT TO GOODEN'S RETURN?
description: Unfortunately, Gooden will receive a standing ovation upon his return. MICK FALTON Smithtown, L.I.

title: TRACKING THE STATE'S VANISHING SPECIES
description: LEAD: LES MEHRHOFF'S job takes him into some uncomfortable places. Mr. Mehrhoff, an environmental analyst for the State Department of Environmental Protection, spent part of March crawling into caves and abandoned mine shafts in the western part of the state in search of rare bats. He was especially interested in sighting an Indiana bat, a United States endangered species not seen in the state since 1943.

title: Casey Fund Makes Deaths His Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK WILL START GIVING OUT CONDOMS IN BARS AND MOVIES
description: Beginning this summer, a team from the New York City Department of Health will give out free condoms at singles bars, pornographic-movie theaters, massage parlors and sex clubs throughout the city to warn of the dangers of casual sex.

title: A Guide To Health Insurance
description: In addition to H.M.O.'s and P.P.O.'s, there is another ingredient in the alphabet soup - I.P.A. H.M.O.'s, an Individual Practice Association H.M.O. Unlike the staff-model H.M.O.'s discussed in the article, I.P.A. H.M.O. members can continue to use community physicians who participate in the plan.

title: 'I Spy' on 73d: Blockwatchers Stop Alteration
description: A rough concrete-block and brick addition is rising behind and atop a graceful five-story limestone town house at 126 East 73d Street between Lexington and Park Avenues - a common occurrence in Manhattan, where building owners try to benefit from every square foot of their properties.

title: COOKBOOKS
description: Some people relaxing in a hammock or beach chair would rather read of the rise of the perfect souffle than turn 600 pages of fleshy romance. For them there are ample choices this summer - new food books, cookbooks and wine books - that offer armchair contentment and might eventually inspire a trip into the kitchen, or at least over to light the grill.

title: AIDS' GLOBAL PERIL IS HIGH ON AGENDA AT SUMMIT MEETING
description: The spreading epidemic of AIDS, which threatens to have a destabilizing effect on world economics and politics, is expected to be high among the issues addressed by the leaders of the seven-nation industrial summit conference in Venice next week.

title: Worse Trouble Awaits U.S. in Persian Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: Kirkpatrick Refuses University's Invitation
description: Dr. Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, a former chief United States delegate to the United Nations, withdrew Friday as the commencement speaker at Lafayette University here after faculty members protested plans to award her an honorary degree.

title: 'SWISSGOLD,' AND CUOMO AS HAMLET
description: IT IS TIME ONCE AGAIN TO CLEAN OUT THE MIS-cellaneous folder, in which the thrifty critic squirrels away provocative letters, offbeat news clippings, particularly remarkable press releases and other ephemera for possible consideration as future column material. Sad to say, most such nutmeats seem to lose pertinence when stored in this way and resist expansion to serious lengths. The following items, therefore, will be of interest chiefly to readers with short attention spans, a tiny minority of the population but an influential one.

title: RACE IS ON FOR 1988'S BRIGHTEST AND BRASHEST CONSULTANTS
description: WHEN Thomas E. Donilon was in high school, he read Hunter Thompson's ''Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail'' and fell in love with the drama of Presidential politics.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THROWAWAY PRODUCTS
description: LEAD: THIS spring, Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. introduced a palm-sized, disposable camera that comes loaded with a roll of color film and is designed to be discarded after the roll is shot. The Eastman Kodak Company will soon follow with its version.

title: EDUCATOR PURSUES DREAM OF BOXING GLORY
description: ''IF you find something you're good at and work hard at it, there's no reason why you can't do it,'' said Edwin I. Gersh of Huntington. ''There's absolutely nothing in this world that you cannot achieve if you try hard enough to achieve it.''

title: BAKKER'S WIFE DELAYED IN ERROR AT U.S. BORDER
description: Tammy Bakker, wife of the former PTL evangelist Jim Bakker, was detained at the Mexican border for an hour and a half Friday while the authorities checked a report that the car she was in had been stolen, the California Highway Patrol said today.

title: AT 'LES LIAISONS,' A VIEWER MUSES ON THE DIFFERENCES BETWEEN NOVEL AND ADAPTATION
description: TURNING A NOVEL INTO A play can be a difficult operation - a good deal more difficult than those who perform it often seem to realize. But it is hardly something you can object to in principle. If you did, you would have to draw the line at ''Othello,'' which is based on a story by the 16th-century Italian novelist Giraldi Cinthio, to say nothing of ''Measure for Measure'' (also based on Cinthio), or ''The Winter's Tale,'' which has a plot lifted from a prose romance by Robert Greene, or ''As You Like It,'' which is adapted from a story by Thomas Lodge - and the list could readily be extended.

title:
SUMMER READING;
COURTING MUMMY
description: LEAD: BLACK KNIGHT, WHITE KNIGHT By Gloria Vanderbilt. Illustrated. 299 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: JAPANESE MANEUVERING FOR SUCCESSION
description: Although Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's term does not end for five months, a struggle to succeed him is already under way, and it may alter power lineups within Japan's ruling party.

title: BUSH DEFENDS THE PRESIDENT PERSIAN GULF POLICIES
description: Vice President Bush vigorously defended President Reagan's policy in the Persian Gulf today and warned against ''faint-hearted voices'' who would have the United States weaken its military commitment in the region.

title: ORIOLES SIZZLING AS RED SOX STAY COLD
description: WHEN last season ended, the Boston Red Sox and the Baltimore Orioles were separated by 22 1/2 games, the distance from first to last. They are closer to each other this season, but they have traveled in opposite directions. The Red Sox, defending champions of the American League East, have been in sixth place for two weeks, and the Orioles, who finished a dismal seventh last year, have climbed explosively to third place with a four-week record that is even better than the Yankees' pace.

title: Penn South Birthday: A Silver Jubilee
description: On May 19, 1962, President John F. Kennedy, at a dedication speech in sweltering heat, urged the founders of the Penn South Cooperative - a middle-income housing complex in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan - to ''keep the faith and fight to preserve this desperately needed type of housing for generations to come.''

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''From the Land of the Etruscans,'' by Margherita Marchione (Villa Walsh Bookstore, Morristown, N.J. 07960, $20), the chain of events leading to Villa Walsh, one of Morristown's most picturesque estates, begins in the 17th century with the story of St. Lucy Filippini.

title: One for the Books
description: Charles Eliot Pierce Jr. has no experience in museum management, but, as a lifelong scholar, he figures he can learn. Mr. Pierce, the chairman of the English department at Vassar College, has been named the new director of the Pierpont Morgan Library, a leading New York City museum and center for the study of printed books, illuminated manuscripts and drawings. Mr. Pierce received his Ph.D. in English at Harvard University in 1970 and began his teaching career at Vassar the same year.

title:
SUMMER READING;
ALEX ON TODAY'S TOUTH: CREECHING GOLOSSES AND FILTHEY TOOFLES!
description: LEAD: THIS month W. W. Norton & Company published a new edition of ''A Clockwork Orange,'' including the 21st chapter, which had appeared in the British edition in 1962 but was dropped from the first American version. In that chapter, the teen-age thug Alex, who is the narrator, tires of violence and resolves to turn to a new way of life.

title: The Things School Doesn't Teach
description: I was greatly disappointed when I read an answer [ Letters to the Long Island Editor, May 3 ] to a recent article on the ''Olympics of the Mind'' competition. Ronnie Cohen of Rego Park seems to feel that there is no need to expand students' minds. Students should just stick to the book and be either right or wrong.

title: THE AVANT-GARDE'S HORIZONS WIDEN
description: OFTEN ASSAILED FOR BEING hermetic, for stressing style at the expense of substance, the theatrical avant-garde is increasingly expanding its vision and displaying a heightened awareness of science, history and politics. At the same time, conceptual directors are, to a greater degree, employing - and commenting on - other arts in their theater work: painting, sculpture, puppetry, modern dance and music, film and video. The technology can be harnessed to a text, as performance art invites the playwright to be a creative partner (''Cold Harbor,'' the Bill Raymond-Dale Worsley study of the life and myth of Ulysses S. Grant is one admirable example).

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
5 TO 9
description: LEAD: ''YOU'VE heard of the 9-to-5 group?'' Alan Leopold was saying the other evening.

title: Scott's Largesse
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice in Israel: 2 Delicate Cases
description: There were two cases last week of how justice works in Israel.

title: RIDING TO BIOTECHNOLGY ROLLERCOASTER
description: FEW industry groups have displayed more erratic stock market behavior than the biotechnology companies. After last year's swing from favor to neglect, the shares of most companies in the industry sprang back strongly in the first few months of 1987. The upswing, in large part, can be attributed to the growing visibility of new products - many of them getting human clinical trials - with potential markets that analysts put in the hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Ann Ashley Conrad, an Artist, Weds Thayer Stewart, a Financial Analyst
description: Ann Ashley Conrad, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison W. Conrad Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married at St. Luke's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Seth Thayer Stewart, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander C. Stewart of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Anne Kimball of St. Luke's and the Rev. T.Guthrie Speers Jr., minister of the Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, performed the ceremony.

title: THERE'S A RESURGENCE IN PRICE COMPETITION
description: THE philatelic market is enjoying a resurgence reminiscent of the mid-1970's. Buyers are flocking to stamp auctions and competition for scarce stamps and covers is heating up. Prices are encouraging dealers to predict further increases.

title: Headliners; NASA's Loss
description: After nine years as an astronaut, Sally K. Ride has decided to undertake more earthly pursuits. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced last week that Dr. Ride, the first American woman to go into orbit, would leave the space agency in August to take a Stanford University fellowship on arms control and national security policy. Dr. Ride declined to comment on her reasons for leaving NASA, but colleagues speculated that the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger last year may have contributed to her decision. ''Since the accident, many folks have begun thinking about where they are in their careers,'' said Steve Nesbitt, a NASA spokesman. Dr. Ride said only that NASA had provided her with some ''unique challenges'' and that she looked forward to the Stanford position ''in the same spirit of challenge.''

title: Thief to Be in 'Talent' Show
description: An unemployed oil drilling engineer who stole $340,000 from a dozen automatic teller machines was ordered Friday to show how he did it. Judge Ted Poe of State Court ordered the thief, Travis Loofbourrow, to give a demonstration for the authorities. Mr. Loofbourrow, sentenced to 10 years in prison, had explained how he breached the security of the machines but bank officials said they needed a demonstration to prevent anyone else from doing it.

title: Astaire Awards to Be Given
description: Hanya Holm, the choreographer of ''My Fair Lady,'' ''Camelot'' and other musicals, will receive a special award for her contributions to modern dance during the sixth annual Astaire Awards presentations, tomorrow at the Racquet and Tennis Club, 370 Park Avenue, at 54th Street. Robert Lindsay, the star of ''Me and My Girl,'' will be honored as best male dancer on Broadway. Named in honor of Fred and Adele Astaire, the awards are given by the Anglo-American Contemporary Dance Foundation. Tickets to the ceremony are $50. Information: 764-0899.

title: ROBERTSON TO SPURN FEDERAL CAMPAIGN FUNDS
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson plans to pass up Federal matching funds for his Republican Presidential bid, freeing his campaign from spending limits in the primary elections, according to his aides.

title: Carol Dannis Miklos Wed to Richard Eyre
description: Carol Dannis Miklos, a daughter of Mrs. Jules J. Miklos of Longboat Key, Fla., and the late Mr. Miklos, was married in Burlington, Vt., yesterday to Richard Hood Eyre, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Eyre of New York and Sharon, Conn. L.Randolph Amis, a lawyer functioning as Town Judge, performed the ceremony in the Ira Allen Chapel at the University of Vermont, from which the bride and bridegroom graduated.

title: WASTE THE MONEY AND RUN
description: FILM FLAM Essays on Hollywood. By Larry McMurtry. 159 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Jazz
description: The annual spring concerts of the Duke Ellington Society have traditionally been a yearly renewal of the joys of Duke Ellington's music, both the familiar and the unfamiliar, frequently spiced with arcane tidbits. This year's concert, the 26th in the series, will be played by Loren Schoenberg's 17-piece orchestra with the cornetist Ruby Braff, the pianist Dick Katz and the trombonist Britt Woodman, a veteran of the Ellington band, as guests. The show, titled ''Downtown Uproar,'' will be held Sunday at 2:30 P.M. in the Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University.

title: BREWERS WIN, HALT SLIDE
description: B. J. Surhoff singled home Cecil Cooper in the 10th inning today as the Milwaukee Brewers broke a six-game losing streak with a 6-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: HOW WILL FANS REACT TO GOODEN'S RETURN?
description: Dr. K's return to the Mets will generate more electricity than Lilco and Con Edison combined. ERROL D. ALEXANDER Jr. New Brunswick, N.J.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: LEAD: ENGLISH PLANTAIN Plantago lanceolata Size: To 18 inches tall. Color: Dark green stemless leaves, 2 to 12 inches long, from basal rosette. Short brownish flower clusters atop slender stalk. Where found: Lawns, meadows, roadsides and pastures. Reproduction: Seed dispersal and pollination mostly by wind, occasionally by insects.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Political Bureau pointed out that the antiaircraft defense forces command had shown intolerable unconcern and indecision about cutting short the flight of the violator plane without resorting to combat means.'' - Politburo statement on the West German plane that landed near the Kremlin. [ 14:2. ]

title: Commercial Property: Storing Worlds of Paper; New York Area Concerns Feed Giant File Cabinets
description: FLOOR after floor, row after row, thousands of cardboard boxes full of business memorabilia sit in the old Paragon Oil building two subway stops away from Manhattan in Long Island City, Queens.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, MAY 31, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17 2,3.9,q>The Soviet defense chief was ousted and the military was rebuked by the Politburo after an aircraft crossed Soviet airspace and landed beside the Kremlin. The replacement of Marshal Sergei L. Sokolov was announced by Tass. Page 1 The new Soviet Defense Minister, Gen. Dmitri T. Yazov, is a man believed to be a protege of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Diplomats said the appointment was a signal that the military would be held accountable to the political leadership. 1 Ex-defense chief was losing status 14 AIDS is high on the economic agenda for the leaders of the seven-nation industrial summit conference in Venice. The leaders are expected to declare the disease a major world health problem. 1 U.S. hopes low for Venice parley 11 Drug agency officers bungled a yearlong succession of secret operations to free American hostages in Beirut. The officers were assigned to work directly for Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. 1 Sri Lanka's army pressed an offensive against Tamil insurgent strongholds in the north amid reports that hundreds of people had died in fighting in the last five days. 3 Seoul warns protesters 4 Search for Unesco director 8 Uruguayans seek amnesty vote 12 NATIONAL 18-30, 38-42 2,2.7,q>The ripple effect of the PTL scandal has been pronounced on television evangelists, and the fate of PTL has become bound with the evangelical movement's efforts to enter the political, religious and social mainstream. 1 Pat Robertson plans not to accept Federal matching funds for his Republican Presidential bid, freeing his campaign from spending limits in the primary elections, according to aides to the television evangelist. 26 Two G.O.P. Presidential candidates defended President Reagan's policy in the Persian Gulf. Vice President Bush and Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole made their comments at a meeting of Midwestern Republican leaders. 28 Before a Presidential bid, Bill Clinton must decide if, as the Governor of Arkansas, he can afford to turn his back on the state's fiscal problems long enough to join the field of candidates for the Democratic nomination. 28 Students who are illegal aliens are having trouble qualifying for amnesty under the new immigration law. Many of the best-educated aliens stand a poor chance of staying in the country as a result, immigration lawyers say. 18 Day care for the elderly 18 Gold rush reviving the West 18 $25,000 for Hart picture 24 Tribe protests monument plan 25 Russell Means seeks Presidency 27 Kennedy notes to be auctioned 29 REGIONAL 31-34, 44 2,,q>Shorter hours for student doctors in New York hospitals would be required under proposed state hospital regulations. The grueling hours of these interns and residents have resulted in patients' deaths, health officials and a grand jury have said. 1 A woman who ran a crack ring for the last two years was arrested Friday in a raid on her Greenwich Village apartment that culminated a three-month undercover investigation, the police said. 31 Some real-estate ads discriminate against potential buyers from minority groups by using white models only, fair-housing advocates contend. New York State human-rights officials are investigating that assertion. 34 More abandoned babies are being dealt with in New York City's hospitals. Officials say they are finding homes for infants more quickly, but that more needs to be done to prevent the problem. 32 Block and community associations held a conference in Manhattan. The organizers of the groups discussed better ways of organizing and congratulated each other for the work they had done to improve their communities. 34 The roots of the Wedtech scandal lie in a combination of idealism and greed that led the South Bronx company to play the Washington game. Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is among those under investigation by a special prosecutor in the case. 20 Record temperatures for May 30 32 Elite back Messinger 33 Crash course for country living 44 Film set on Jewish farmers 44

title: CURTAIN SET TO RISE ON SUMMER SEASON
description: A CAVALCADE of musicals, spanning five decades, from vintage rarities by George Gershwin (1924) and Kurt Weill (1943) at East Haddam's Goodspeed Opera House to standard 1950's and 60's favorites by Rodgers and Hammerstein, Frank Loesser and Jule Styne at New Fairfield's Candlewood Playhouse, dominate the state's summer theater season.

title: TV EVANGELISM IS SATIRIZED IN 'SALVATION!'
description: IN the late 1970's Beth B and Scott B began making Super-8, home-movie spectacles for the entertainment of their friends in the downtown music and art scenes. Five years ago they went all-out for their 16-millimeter send-up of Big Business, ''Vortex,'' which was shown at the New York Film Festival.

title: Four on the Block: Gaveling a Sale Without a Broker
description: Sanford Sirulnick, the owner of more than 50 buildings with some 5,000 units in New York City, likes to recount the incident last fall that led him to consider the merits of selling buildings at auction.

title: PROGRAM TO SHELTER PREGNANT YOUTHS
description: NINE families in the Meriden-Wallingford area are taking part in a program to give homeless pregnant teen-agers a place to stay before and after they give birth.

title: Cops for All. Taxes for Some?
description: On Tuesday, a large section of inner-city Los Angeles will vote on a proposal to raise property taxes to pay for more city police. That's noteworthy because the rest of the city is not doing the same. This special referendum raises troubling questions about majority will, minority rights and the relationship of a city's parts to the whole.

title: Lisa Gerbasi and Paul R. Goring, Buyers, Are Wed
description: Lisa Marie Gerbasi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Gerbasi of New Hyde Park and Scott's Beach, L.I., and Paul Roger Goring were married yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Louise K. Goring of Sarasota, Fla., and Roger C. Goring of White Plains. The Rev. Lawrence Chadwick performed the ceremony at Notre Dame Roman Catholic Church in New Hyde Park.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Coe Leads by a Stroke: Dawn Coe of Canada shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Kathryn Young after three rounds of the $275,000 Corning Classic on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour at Corning, N.Y.. Coe, a four-year tour veteran, carded four birdies on the back nine and finished at 203 after 54 holes. Young, the leader after the first round and co-leader after two rounds, recovered from a slow start on the front nine to shoot a 69. Jane Geddes, the tour's top money-winner this year, and Laurie Rinker, the defending champion, were two strokes behind Coe. Betsy King made a hole-in-one on the 125-yard 15th hole.(AP) San Jose State Wins: San Jose State, with Anne Jones sinking a crucial 15-foot putt on the final hole, captured the national collegiate women's golf championship yesterday at Albuquerque.. Caroline Keggi, a New Mexico senior, won the individual title in a sudden-death playoff with Jones after the two finished the 72-hole tournament tied at 289. It was Jones's putt on the final hole to save bogey that gave the Spartans the team title and forced the individual playoff with Keggi.(AP) Baseball Montclair State Rolls: John Deutsch drove in three runs, including two during Montclair State's six-run sixth inning yesterday as the Indians overwhelmed Wisconsin-Oshkosh, 13-4, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III World Series at Marietta, Ohio. Bill Coyle put Montclair ahead for good, 4-2, with a two-run double in the fourth inning. Jim Fasano had three hits for the Indians, who improved to 35-14-1 over all and 3-0 in the double-elimination tournament. Jeff Vanderoef went the distance for Montclair, allowing four runs on six hits. Earlier, Eastern Connecticut was eliminated when Garry Ormsby stole home with two out in the bottom of the ninth inning yesterday to give North Carolina Wesleyan a 4-3 victory.(AP) Texas Advances: Brian Johnson's two-run double and Lenny Bell's two-run triple powered No. 1-ranked Texas to a 13-6 victory over No. 4 Arkansas in the first round of the N.C.A.A. College World Series yesterday in Omaha, Neb.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THROWAWAY PRODUCTS;
HOW DO YOU DISPOSE OF DISPOSABLES?
description: LEAD: THERE is a dark side to the throwaway boom that has little to do with production techniques or repair costs.

title: The Demolition Of a Dream
description: Sophocles said, ''Though a man be wise, it is no shame for him to live and learn.'' It is no shame for us to learn from this experience.

title: MINNESOTA WOMAN FOUND GUILTY OF KILLING ADOPTED SON IN 1965
description: A woman has been convicted of killing her 3-year-old adopted son 22 years ago in a case reopened at the urging of the boy's natural mother.

title: Storm Heads for Bahamas
description: A tropical weather disturbance brought 35-mile-an-hour winds toward the outer islands of the Bahamas today, and the Government there issued a storm warning.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: The Killer Inside Me Starring Stacy Keach, Susan Tyrell, Keenan Wynn, Tisha Sterling, Royal Dano, John Carradine. Directed by Burt Kennedy. 1976. Warner Home Video. 99 minutes. $59.95.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Brookhaven $191,000 6 Hearth Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; dining room, den with fireplace, basement, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $2,300. Center Moriches $124,990 27 Surrey Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old split-level; den, patio, finished basement, deeded beach and mooring rights; taxes $2,400. East Patchogue $189,000 299 Dunton Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, new contemporary; sunken living room, oak floors, water view, 2-car garage; estimated taxes $2,000. Elmont $137,500 190 Claridge Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes $1,250. Hampton Bays $242,000 29 Newtown Road 6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old Cape Cod; legal 2-family with 2 3-bedroom apartments, each with dining room and eat-in kitchen, deck, loft; taxes $2,400. Stony Brook $465,000 26 Woodfield Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 25-year-old colonial; dining room, den, basement, 1.8 waterfront acres; taxes $5,700. OTHER AREAS Hartford, Conn. $168,000 17 North Beacon Street 5-bedroom, 3-bath, Victorian; 2 fireplaces, 0.25 acre; taxes $3,082. Katonah, N.Y. $265,000 22 Nightingale Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old frame colonial; solarium, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,209. Maplewood, N.J. $325,000 36 Sagamore Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 42-year-old Tudor; fireplace, porch; taxes $5,070.

title: SUMMER VOTE KEY IN 4th DISTRICT RACE
description: LEAD: AS the field of contenders for the vacant Fourth Congressional District seat grew last week, the summer schedule of the race was being seen as a key factor.

title: THE UNFOLDING STORY
description: Testimony at last week's Congressional hearings on the Iran-contra affair cast a different light from the statements of General Richard V. Secord, the coordinator of several covert operations, and illustrated the bickering that surrounded the secret programs. Highlights of the week's developments follow.

title: THE CITY'S BIRTHRIGHT SOLD FOR AIR RIGHTS
description: ONCE, THERE WAS A TIME WHEN THE CITY of New York saw its responsibility for physical planning as a simple mandate: to limit growth. The idea was not to restrict it unreasonably, or to meddle excessively with the forces of capitalism, but to guarantee that those qualities of urban living that are of public benefit, such as light, air, sunshine and a sense of comfortable scale, did not disappear. It was implicitly understood that the private sector, acting on its own, had little incentive to preserve these things, and that it was the responsibility of the city to do so instead.

title:
DANCE;
PRINCETON BALLET BROADENS ITS CONTEMPORARY REPERTOIRE
description: LEAD: THE Princeton Ballet's annual ''Dance at the Playhouse,''

title: A Winning Crew
description: Devin-adair Mahony's graphic article ''Coxing Her Way to Victory'' (April 26) quickened my pulse. It accurately portrayed what I have experienced as a Brown oarsman: a highly structured activity in which one pushes oneself beyond one's limitations while striving for excellence. This is a paradigm of the best of American society. CHRISTOPHER PAPAJOHN New York City

title: GORBACHEV IS MAKING BOTH GERMANYS EDGY
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV is making the Germans nervous - East Germans and West Germans alike.

title: BALL TO RAISE FUNDS FOR HARMS CENTER
description: LEAD: THE Griffin Ball, which will be held Saturday to raise funds for the John Harms Center for the Arts, is part of the center's efforts to broaden its audience and, eventually, expand its facilities.

title: Comrade Tyrant Mr. Ceaucescu
description: Rumania refused to join the rest of the Soviet bloc in shunning Israel or boycotting the Olympics; such an independent foreign policy appeals to Washington. But if Americans could see the Rumanian tyrant Nicolae Ceaucescu at home, they'd like him less.

title: Patricia Wachtell, Bank Executive, Is Married to Ridgway B. Knight 3d
description: The marriage of Patricia Ann Wachtell and Ridgway Brewster Knight 3d, who graduated from Trinity College in Hartford with the classes of 1982 and '81, respectively, took place yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. Paul Dinter performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title:
SUMMER READING;
TOUGH ACT TO FOLLOW
description: LEAD: EVERYTHING TO GAIN Making the Most of the Rest of Your Life. By Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter. 198 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: IT'S PLANTING, PRUNNING AND HARVEST TIME
description: SINCE daffodil foliage does not ripen until late summer, bunch the leaves in an upright position and tie them together with their own foliage to make room for setting in annual plants. If the tulips have not bloomed well in recent years, dig up bulbs and discard; order new ones for planting in fall; finish pruning spring-flowering shrubs; cold soil has persisted and given tardy gardeners time to sow grass seed or set in sod; continue asparagus harvests from three-year-old plants or older; snap off spears at ground level just before cooking. Check pea vines for pods and pick crop while succulent. Keep up with recommended schedule of sprays to control pests and diseases on fruit trees. THE ROBIN

title: Jennifer A. Porter Wed to a Banker
description: Jennifer Alexanderson Porter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Porter Jr. of Washington, was married at St. Columba's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Vincent John Dowling Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dowling of West Hartford, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Tully, rector of the church, and the Rev. Douglas Morrison, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: CONFLICT DRIES UP AND SO DOES WATER
description: FOR a brief respite, it appeared that Ocean Beach, which has seen more than its share of controversy over its public-nuisance laws, might finally become just another blase resort community. In this Friday's village election, every candidate, including the recently appointed Mayor, Edward E. Krepela, is running unopposed.

title: The Wedtech Case Widens
description: The name of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d emerged again last week in the widening investigation of the Wedtech Corporation.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LIKE AMERICA'S CUP, A LITTLE Protest! The sailboat skippers waited anxiously as the yacht club's protest committee conferred over Dick's charge that Dave had committed an infraction of the international racing rules. ''We rule in favor of Dick,'' announced the commodore of the club, Jack Patton of Lloyd Neck.

title: Milk Prices Down - For Now
description: A little competition has been a big help in bringing down milk prices in New York City, Attorney General Robert Abrams said last week. But he warned that unless Albany widens the hole in the fence made by a New Jersey dairy earlier this year, prices could soon go up again.

title: BOOKS FOR VACATION READING
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1986. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. The quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography & Biography

title: VAST CITY CENTER COMPLEX IN WORKS IN PROVIDENCE
description: Five years after the last downtown department store in this city closed, three developers have announced plans for a $300 million retail, office and hotel complex in the city's center.

title: THE LOST AND FOUND DEPARTMENT
description: A FEW weeks ago we received a notice from Town Hall announcing that Spring Cleanup/Collection would begin the weekend of May 15. This is the time when villagers can throw out anything that is too big to fit into the daily garbage cans. It is also a period of high excitement for local esthetes. The roads are filled with townspeople in their station wagons scouring the streets for collectible trash. They usually travel in pairs. Some furniture needs two people to lift and carry. This affluent community is a trash hound's paradise.

title: ART
description: THE CAVE OF LASCAUX: The Final Photographs. By Mario Ruspoli. Illustrated. 208 pp. (Abrams, $45.) One of the more remarkable incidents in the history of perambulation occurred in September 1940, when a very young garage hand from the village of Montignac in southwestern France went out in the country to take the air. Hearing his dog barking from inside a hole in the ground, he went in to see what had happened and thereby stumbled - almost literally - upon the 17,000-year-old cave paintings of Lascaux. Within three days, the local tourist bureau had put up a sign that read ''Lascaux Caves, 3 kilometers,'' and anyone who wanted to do so, and could overcome the difficulties of a France in catastrophic defeat by the Germans, was free to go down and look around.

title: The Crippled Genius
description: The paradox of Europe these days is that it invented science and is spending twice as much on research and development as Japan, but it is still lagging behind in the high technology race to the future.

title: 'I Gave It All I Had'
description: A WEEK after he lost his World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title, Marvin Johnson said he did not expect to fight again. The 33-year-old Johnson, who failed to answer the bell for the ninth round of his bout against Leslie Stewart in Trinidad on May 23, stopped short of announcing his retirement, but made clear that it was unlikely he would return to the ring. ''There's always a possibility of fighting again, but it's very slim.''

title: FILM SET ON JEWISH FARMERS IN JERSEY
description: The chicken coops have been converted to storage sheds, the farms have gone to grass or weed and the farmers, too, are doing other things.

title: HOME VIDEO: DOCUMENTARY
description: LEAD: American Fashion and Leisure, 1945-50 Part of ''The March of Time'' series. Embassy Home Entertainmt.t. 105 minutes. $24.95.

title: MAKING ASSUMPTIONS TO DEFEAT A GAME
description: WHEN Henry Jones, known as ''Cavendish,'' accidentally invented duplicate 130 years ago in a effort to compare the skill of whist players, he had no idea where it would lead. What it led to earlier this month was more than 75,000 players competing at one time around the world.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
TORA! TORA! TORA!
description: LEAD: The date will be June, not Dec. 7, and the place White Plains not Hawaii, but Japanese warplanes will again fly overhead, guns blazing. This time, however, plenty of advance notice is being given in hopes of attracting thousands of onlookers.

title: Outdoors; Pond Management Is Increasing Fast
description: BILL PHILLIPS says he has ''absolutely no doubt'' that a world-record largemouth bass will be caught within a few years from a small farm pond. But he argues that it will be a pond that is professionally managed by trained biologists.

title: MEDICAL ETHICS: A SURPRISING CONSENSUS
description: LEAD: MIDWAY through its two-year, statewide project to assess public opinion on the dilemmas posed by modern medicine, the Summit-based Citizens Committee on Biomedical Ethics has issued its first report. And, on issues ranging from living wills to patient confidentiality, a consensus is emerging that could guide New Jersey policymakers.

title: 'WHAT CAN YOU BUY WITH A NICKEL?'
description: RECENTLY I was walking on a country lane with a young neighbor and we saw in the road, soiled by sand and melting snow, five shining pennies. I expected the youth to pick them up, a nickel for free. He looked at me with as much scorn as he dared muster and said, ''What can you buy with a nickel?''

title: SOVIET OUSTS MILITARY CHIEF AND HEAD OF ITS AIR DEFENSE FOR KREMLIN PLAN INCIDENT INTRUDER WAS SEEN
description: Defense Minister Sergei L. Sokolov was relieved of his duties today, and the Soviet military was rebuked by the Politburo after a small civilian plane penetrated Soviet airspace Thursday and flew unimpeded 400 miles to Moscow to land beside the Kremlin.

title: HOW WILL FANS REACT TO GOODEN'S RETURN?
description: Dwight Gooden's bout with cocaine is but another of the dozen stories we read about in the newspapers every day. Urban New Yorkers (and perhaps the rest of the country) have become so accepting of drugs as part of daily life that we consider drug addiction no worse an offense than missing curfew. Perhaps some of us remember that Keith Hernandez spent time in court for his involvement in a cocaine scandal. Keith was completely absolved thanks to his brilliant performance and contribution in bringing the world championship flag to New York. If Gooden can win a few games and help get the Mets back on the track to another pennant, he will not only be absolved but will become our hero and our savior. STEPHEN OSTROW New York

title: Pamela J. Pirnie Is Married to Dr. Henry Grayson
description: In the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday Pamela Jane Pirnie, the daughter of Malcolm Pirnie Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Holderness, N.H., and the late Jane Purse Pirnie, was married to Dr. Henry Tate Grayson, the son of the Rev. H. T. Grayson of Panama City, Fla., and the late Ethel Sageser Grayson. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: And the Bride Wore Paper
description: YET another disposable product -the paper wedding gown - was introduced a little over a year ago at a dress shop in the Los Angeles area.

title: On Tour With Rock Hudson
description: I want to thank you for printing Sara Davidson's article ''On Tour With Rock Hudson'' (May 3). It is one of the most vivid illustrations that I have read of the bigotry and prejudice that exists in our American society. STEVEN KASHUB Forest Hills, Queens

title: BUILDERS GET LUXURY BONUS IN RETURN FOR LOW-INCOME UNITS: LIMITS ON LOCATION UNFAIR TO BUSINESS
description: THErr concept of ''inclusionary zoning,'' which is aimed at enabling low-income families to live in high-income neighborhoods, was recently incorporated into New York City's zoning regulations. In certain areas, developers will be allowed to build luxury apartment towers as much as 20 percent higher than would otherwise be allowed. In return, they must build or renovate low-income housing - generally nearby the higher-income project. Like most such plans, the inclusionary zoning measure approved by the Board of Estimate represented a compromise and completely satisfied no one. It did not, as some such measures do in other cities, make it mandatory for builders of luxury housing to construct some lower-income housing. Nor did it give builders the option, as some wanted, of constructing the bonus low-income housing anywhere in the city. Alan Finder, a New York Times reporter assigned to City Hall, interviewed representatives of three points of view on the issue - City Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan; Sylvia Deutsch, Chairwoman of the City Planning Commission; and Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. Excerpts follow.

title: Murray Hill
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BOAT RACES A series of eight races organized by the Norwalk Islands Sailing Fleet, an informal group of sailing enthusiasts, begins at 11 A.M. Saturday off Cockenoe Island. Any performance-handicap-rated boat may enter at a fee of $25 for the series. ''We go all around the islands - 10 to 17 miles - and we have one all-night race to City Island in New York and back, starting at 7 P.M.,'' said Michael Brown, chairman of the fleet. Approximately 30 boats are entered in each race.

title: STUDENTS GET BUSINESS SKILLS FIRST-HAND
description: STUDENTS simulating the actions of young business executives form corporations, sell stock, elect officers, market products and, ideally, post a profit. Within 15 weeks, they then liquidate. These ''young executives'' attend Lincoln High School in Yonkers, one of a growing number of area schools teaching business skills by having students organize enterprises and operate them like real companies. Twenty-eight students are in the Lincoln High School program.

title: Laura Presto Is Wed
description: At St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Plainview, L.I., Laura Jennyfer Presto, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Presto of Woodbury, L.I., was married yesterday to James Phillip Milhaven, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Milhaven of Port Washington, L.I. The Rev. Daniel Sheridan performed the ceremony. The bride is a career counselor at Suffolk County Community College. Mr. Milhaven is a sales representative in Nassau County for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

title: Laura Myers Is Wed
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, Laura Susan Myers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Earle Myers of Long Valley, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven Hammond Poppe, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred C. Poppe of West Islip, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony. Mrs. Poppe is supervisor of telemarketing at the Direct Marketing Association in New York. The bridegroom is an account supervisor at Poppe Tyson Inc., an advertising agency in New York from which his father retired as chairman.

title: Euphemism Loses a Round: 'Sex Education' Is Mentioned
description: If you mean sex education, come out and say so, the state Board of Education has directed department bureaucrats.

title: OFFICIAL FORCING CONTRITE ACTS BY WASTE DUMPERS
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, under pressure from the Los Angeles District Attorney, has agreed to establish a $450,000 college scholarship fund in environmental studies after pleading no contest to charges of illegal waste disposal.

title: Jenny Gault Is Married To Gary Alan Bimblick
description: In the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York yesterday, Mary Virginia Gault, an actress known as Jenny Gault, and Gary Alan Bimblick, an advertising executive, were married by the Rev. T.Jeffrey Gill. Katharine Wendy Young was matron of honor, and Warren M. Bimblick was his brother's best man.

title: SAN FRANCISCO CENTERS REJUVENATING ELDERLY
description: Each slow step was labored, but Ernestine Wellons smiled as she worked her way across the room unassisted, murmuring, ''I'm getting better and better.''

title: Anne Dobson Married To James Glazebrook
description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Anne Marie Dobson, head of the Lower School of the Hewitt School, was married to James Grinstead Glazebrook, a lawyer. The Rev. Thomas Dix Bowers, the rector, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Philip E. Dobson, a Roman Catholic priest who is the bride's uncle.

title: A COLORFUL CORNER OF PENNSYLVANIA
description: Only in the latter half of the eighteenth century did settlers from Connecticut begin clearing the land in the wooded northern hills of Wayne County, Pa. Dyberry Forks, which was to become the county seat, was then just a swampy wilderness at the point where the Dyberry River joins the Lackawaxen on its way to the Delaware. By the mid-19th century Dyberry Forks had become Honesdale, a bustling waterfront town and hub of one of the largest coal transfer markets in the world. Yet today Wayne County, despite its location less than three hours from New York City, remains relatively ''undiscovered.''

title: 'PEOPLE DON'T SEE A NEED TO VOTE'
description: INrrxh 1963, a Presidential panel charged with devising ways to encourage Americans to vote recommended abolishing poll taxes and literacy tests and lowering the voting age to 18.

title:
ART;
HEMP, PEBBLES, SAND AND PSYCHOLOGICAL IMPLICATIONS
description: LEAD: INCREASINGLY, in our technologically oriented age, we have come to view the landscape as a backdrop for human activity, a habitat if you will, rather than as a vast and timeless environment in which we are but humble dwellers. There seems to be no place so remote or hostile that we cannot insinuate ourselves into it, nowhere so perfect that we hesitate to improve it, no sanctuary immune to our violation.

title: Sara Geddes Has Wedding
description: Sara Turnbull Geddes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E.Maxwell Geddes Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to Thomas Joseph Testa, a son of Michele F. Testa Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Bar Harbor, Me., and the late Eleanor Moran Testa. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: For Victims of Larceny, a Sexual Disparity
description: To the Editor:

title: SCULPTURE FUNHOUSE
description: LEAD: SMACK IN THE MIDDLE OF THE PORT AU-thority Bus Terminal's north building, in Manhattan, encased in clear plastic, is a noisy machine, a work of art, sort of. In it, plates are spinning, levers flipping, and billiard balls are rolling down helical ramps and around loop-the-loops, now and then striking bells, xylophone keys or pieces of metal.

title: OUSTED CHIEF SEEN AS ALREADY STALLED
description: Analysts in Washington said today that the ousted Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Sergei L. Sokolov, had been declining in both political status and physical health in the last year. They said he seemed destined for removal from office even before the embarrassing episode involving the light plane that landed near Red Square on Thursday.

title: LIVING TOGETHER AS A WAY OF LIFE
description: LOVER. Significant Other. Steady companion or domestic partner. The search for a comfortable way to describe a mate who is not your spouse goes on, as increasing numbers of couples choose to live together without benefit of marriage.

title: BUILDERS GET LUXURY BONUS IN RETURN FOR LOW-INCOME UNITS: HAVING ECONOMIC MIX IS THE GOAL
description: THErr concept of ''inclusionary zoning,'' which is aimed at enabling low-income families to live in high-income neighborhoods, was recently incorporated into New York City's zoning regulations. In certain areas, developers will be allowed to build luxury apartment towers as much as 20 percent higher than would otherwise be allowed. In return, they must build or renovate low-income housing - generally nearby the higher-income project. Like most such plans, the inclusionary zoning measure approved by the Board of Estimate represented a compromise and completely satisfied no one. It did not, as some such measures do in other cities, make it mandatory for builders of luxury housing to construct some lower-income housing. Nor did it give builders the option, as some wanted, of constructing the bonus low-income housing anywhere in the city. Alan Finder, a New York Times reporter assigned to City Hall, interviewed representatives of three points of view on the issue - City Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan; Sylvia Deutsch, Chairwoman of the City Planning Commission; and Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. Excerpts follow. Question. What is your view of inclusionary zoning? A. Developers have been permitted in high-density districts to get a 20 percent increase in the floor area if they provide certain benefits, which we call amenities. These amenities can be plazas, they can be subway improvements. There has been a feeling that these amenities are really not as substantial as they could be.

title: CREATING A NEW VIBRANCY FOR CITY NEIGHBORHOODS
description: In the many neighborhoods of New York City, there are ''blockwatchers'' and ''graffiti busters,'' people fighting - some inside the system, some outside it - to maintain decent housing and drive away drug dealers, to beautify streets begging for greenery and make the city just a little more livable.

title: 500 PUPILS TOUR HISTORY SITES
description: FOURTH-grade students in New Rochelle were learning more about local history this month, thanks to a bus tour arranged by the city's school district and the Huguenot-Thomas Paine Historical Association.

title: BARRELL AT LITTLE SILVER'S GALLERY JUPITER
description: THIS Monmouth County community may be little, as its name indicates, but it has two post offices, one of them an ''antique'' converted into a museum. It also has Gallery Jupiter Inc., which took up residence last fall at 25 Church Street.

title: NIXON'S NOTE TELL OF AN EARLY DISTRUST OF THE PRESS
description: Richard M. Nixon regarded most reporters as enemies long before the Watergate scandal engulfed his Presidency and ordered his aides to treat them with contempt.

title: VIRGINIA'S FRESH CROP OF VINEYARDS
description: LEAD: In the spring of 1787, when he had just turned 44, Thomas Jefferson undertook a three-month tour of the winegrowing regions of France and Italy. ''I am never satiated with rambling through the fields and farms, examining the culture and cultivators, with a degree of curiosity which makes some take me to be a fool, and others to be much wiser than I am,'' he wrote to

title: Developing New Housing Standards
description: MORE than two years after they were first proposed, a set of amendments to the city's zoning ordinance - sweeping changes that would dictate the shape of multifamily housing in parts of all five boroughs - is going through its final revisions, and could be voted on by the City Planning Commission before the end of June.

title: BIBLICAL 'JOSEPH' STEPS FORTH IN 1960's
description: ''Joseph and His Amazing Technicolor Dream Coat,'' the pop/rock musical by Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber, is a clever stage adaptation of the Old Testament tale about Joseph, son of Jacob. Joseph, for those of you who might not remember, is the one who correctly interpreted Pharoah's dreams and thereby saved Egypt from famine.

title: 'IT'S LIKE L.I. IN THE 1960's -- IN FLORIDA
description: LEAD: IN 1959, Chris Poryles's parents headed east from Westbury to the open spaces of Suffolk County, seeking a new life for their family. In the small town atmosphere of Northport, they found what they wanted: a quiet, friendly place with lots of children for their daughters to play with, good schools and inexpensive living.

title: LAND TRUST WORRIES OF GETTING TOO MUCH
description: WHEN 56 people formed Joshua's Tract Conservation and Historic Trust in 1966, the immediate aim was to preserve a historic stone grist mill in Mansfield.

title: Sidney Hook's Anti-Communism
description: To the Editor:

title: DUNDEE'S TRICK FAILS THIS TIME
description: IN his corner before the sixth round began, Pinklon Thomas suddenly had what was described by the ring announcer as a ''torn'' left glove. And Referee Carlos Padilla called time, delaying the start of the sixth round for about two minutes while Thomas's trainer, Angelo Dundee, fitted him with a new left glove and Mike Tyson waited impatiently across the ring.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark is expected to break ground in the fall for a $22 million information technologies building.

title: Demonstrators Greet Ship
description: The nuclear-powered guided missile cruiser Texas arrived at its new home port Friday on San Francisco Bay as environmentalists staged a symbolic blockade. Six swimmers from the Greenpeace organization accompanied a pair of rubber rafts, three kayaks and a sailboat in the channel at the entrance to the Alameda Naval Air Station.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE carefully lettered signs were posted all through the neighborhood, on telephone poles, in shop windows and on bulletin boards, photo-copied expressions of loss and grief:

title: GARDENING
description: GARDENING AND BEYOND. By Florence Bellis. Illustrated by Valerie Willson. 178 pp. (Timber Press, $19.95.) Florence Bellis's place in the international world of horticulture is assured, thanks to her achievement in originating - over many decades of careful and imaginative hybridization - the many strains of primroses collectively named after her Oregon home, Barnhaven. These remarkable and extremely hardy plants come in a palette of wonderful colors: glowing scarlets and crimsons, golds and yellows, pristine whites, deep blues, as well as blends and combinations of several colors. Her main subject in ''Gardening and Beyond'' (the first volume in the series ''Nature and Artifice: Two Sides of the Gardening Coin'' edited by Richard L. Critz) is her breeding of primroses, but to tell this story she ranges very far indeed, touching on soil chemistry, the long evolution of plants and animals, agriculture and the Industrial Revolution, exploration for plants in the 19th century, and the joys and frustrations that alternate in every true gardener's life. Mrs. Bellis moves so effortlessly from one topic to another and writes with such personal authority that both novice gardeners and longtime practitioners of the art will learn many surprising things from her, including a technique for driving moles away by putting spoiled liver in their tunnels. The Barnhaven primroses enrich our springtime gardens; ''Gardening and Beyond'' enriches the gardener's library. * * * LANDSCAPING WITH PERENNIALS. By Emily Brown. Illustrated by Leslie J. Haning and Rachel Gage. 304 pp. (Timber Press, $34.95.) The foremost trend in gardening in the United States in the last decade has been an increasing interest in ornamental perennials. This interest has raised the profits of American garden centers and mail-order nurseries. It has also attracted the attention of a great many of our major publishing houses, which have imported books on the subject from Great Britain despite the fact that plants readily available there may be almost impossible to find here - and the further fact that practical advice suitable for the climates and soils of England may be recipes for failure on our own side of the Atlantic. Two years ago, HP Books published Pamela Harper and Frederick McGourty's handsomely illustrated paperback, ''Perennials: How to Select, Grow & Enjoy.'' Widely sold in garden centers as well as bookstores, it remains the best introduction yet to the culture of perennials. Now comes Emily Brown's far more complete and exhaustive ''Landscaping With Perennials,'' a reference book that can lay claim to being the standard work on its topic for years to come. Generously illustrated with line drawings and color photographs, it is one of the truly indispensable books for the serious gardener, since it draws together an enormous amount of practical and scientific material on perennials. It is flawed, however, by a poorly executed index that sometimes will send readers scurrying to the wrong page. * * * A PRACTICAL GUIDE TO EDIBLE & USEFUL PLANTS: Including Recipes, Harmful Plants, Natural Dyes & Textile Fibers. By Delena Tull. Illustrated. 518 pp. (Texas Monthly Press, $23.95.) In the tradition established By Euell Gibbons's ''Stalking the Wild Asparagus,'' this fascinating handbook explores such miscellaneous matters as recipes for prickly pear gumbo and farkleberry jelly, the high vitamin C content of rose hips and the use of nasturtium leaves as a yellow dye for fabric. It covers not only ''edible and useful plants,'' but also some very nasty ones that may make us itch, sneeze, contract violent gastrointestinal pains and even drop dead if we confuse an innocent plant with a noxious look-alike. This guide restricts itself to the flora of Texas, both native and introduced, but because many plants that grow in Texas also grow elsewhere, including the Northeast, it should be widely appreciated outside the Lone Star State. Its combination of chatty prose and precise botanical information makes it highly readable, especially for browsers, but it may also prove to be a lifesaver for someone whose child has just nibbled on chinaberries or seeds of the common wild sweet pea, both potentially lethal without swift medical attention. * * * A BOUQUET OF GARDEN WRITING: Selected From Five Grand Masters. Edited by Ursula Buchan. Illustrated. 191 pp. (Godine, $25.) This British import is a curious one, for Ursula Buchan refers to it in her introduction as an anthology and claims on the title page only an editor's role, not a writer's. Indeed, a good bit of the text is quoted from works by her ''grand masters,'' a quintet of influential British horticultural writers composed of William Robinson, Gertrude Jekyll, Vita Sackville-West, E. A. Bowles and Reginald Farrer, all of whom have been much in vogue in recent years on both sides of the Atlantic. But this bouquet was picked by Ms. Buchan herself, with notable taste and intelligence. Much of the text is hers, including biographical chapters on all five grand masters. Her undeniable admiration for them is by no means slavish. She knows that most gardeners don't live at Sissinghurst Castle and cannot thus garden on the same scale as Vita Sackville-West, even if they may learn many a thing from her. Of the flood of British books on horticulture to American shores over the last decade, I would place Ursula Buchan's at the top of my list of favorites. * * * LEAVES FROM THE GARDEN: Two Centuries of Garden Writing. Edited by Clare Best and Caroline Boisset. Illustrated. 415 pp. (Norton, $22.50.) Unlike ''A Bouquet of Garden Writing,'' ''Leaves From the Garden'' is an unalloyed anthology of British garden writers from Humphry Repton in the 18th century to the present. Much of the material is of scant interest or relevance for contemporary American readers, unless they have a special interest in horticultural history. * * * GARDENS BY DESIGN: Step-by-Step Plans for 12 Imaginative Gardens. By Peter Loewer. Illustrated by the author. 224 pp. (Rodale Press, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $12.95.) Readers of Peter Loewer's eight previous books know what to expect of him: graceful, lapidary prose; an affection for miscellaneous horticultural information; charm and a touch of whimsy; and his own illustrations, which always combine botanical accuracy with a highly personal eye and style. ''Gardens by Design'' is a welcome addition to the now-substantial Loewer canon. * * * GARDENING WITH THE NEW SMALL PLANTS: The Complete Guide to Growing Dwarf and Miniature Shrubs, Flowers, Trees and Vegetables. By Oliver E. Allen. Illustrated. 196 pp. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) There's a fine irony in a book advising gardeners to think small when its subtitle is such a mouthful, reminiscent of 19th-century horticultural tomes. But the subtitle is an accurate description of this practical guide to diminutive plants for gardens where a grand scale is impossible to achieve. A valuable appendix lists nurseries offering the plants Mr. Allen discusses. * * * LANNING ROPER: And His Gardens. By Jane Brown. Illustrated. 224 pages. (Rizzoli, $35.) Lanning Roper managed a feat that few observers of the world of horticulture in Great Britain could have predicted or even thought possible. An American, born in New Jersey in 1912, he came to England as a naval officer during World War II, remained there at the war's end, and eventually became noted both as a garden writer for such periodicals as The Sunday Times of London and Country Life and as a garden designer for such prominent clients as Lord Snowdon and the Aga Khan. In this handsome and winning biography, Jane Brown reveals Lanning Roper, who died in 1983, as a knowing and tasteful gardener, an engaging human being and a graceful writer.

title: IT WAS NO BREEZE
description: COMEBACK My Race for the America's Cup. By Dennis Conner with Bruce Stannard. Paul C. Larsen consulting editor. Foreword by Walter Cronkite. Illustrated. 239 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $19.95. THE AMERICA'S CUP 1987 The Official Record. By Bob Fisher and Bob Ross. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $35.

title: SCALLOPERS AT ODDS OVER CATCH RULES
description: Members of Congress have stepped in to head off potential violence in the East Coast's lucrative sea scallop industry.

title: WHO CREATED WHOM? CHARACTERS THAT TALK BACK
description: Fictional characters have been known to haunt, amuse, teach and infuriate their creators. Family ties are strong, even when some of the relatives are made up. The Book Review asked a number of fiction writers and playwrights: Which of the characters you have created has had the greatest effect on your own life? Margaret Atwood Author of ''The Handmaid's Tale.''

description: THE American economy has now been expanding without interruption for four and one-half years, and is rapidly closing in, the President's chief economic adviser boasted last week, on a significant longevity record.

description: For the second year in a row, May left off like a sultry prophecy of August in the metropolitan region this weekend, with temperature records tumbling and crowds seeking relief on the beaches.

title: COCAINE, INC.
description: PALE KINGS AND PRINCES A Spenser Novel. By Robert B. Parker. 256 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $15.95.

title: BUILDERS GET LUXURY BONUS IN RETURN FOR LOW-INCOME UNITS: CITY PLAN DOES NOT GO FAR ENOUGH
description: THErr concept of ''inclusionary zoning,'' which is aimed at enabling low-income families to live in high-income neighborhoods, was recently incorporated into New York City's zoning regulations. In certain areas, developers will be allowed to build luxury apartment towers as much as 20 percent higher than would otherwise be allowed. In return, they must build or renovate low-income housing - generally nearby the higher-income project. Like most such plans, the inclusionary zoning measure approved by the Board of Estimate represented a compromise and completely satisfied no one. It did not, as some such measures do in other cities, make it mandatory for builders of luxury housing to construct some lower-income housing. Nor did it give builders the option, as some wanted, of constructing the bonus low-income housing anywhere in the city. Alan Finder, a New York Times reporter assigned to City Hall, interviewed representatives of three points of view on the issue - City Councilwoman Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan; Sylvia Deutsch, Chairwoman of the City Planning Commission; and Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. Excerpts follow.

title: LYDIA LUNCH LOOKS BACK IN ANARCHY
description: ''MONOLOGUES, RANTS, tirades, complaints'' are Lydia Lunch's stock in trade these days. She is, officially, a performance artist, appearing at Soho's Performing Garage Thursday through Sunday through June 7. Ten years ago, armed with an electric guitar which she did not so much play as strangle, Miss Lunch was the assassin of rock-and-roll, leading a succession of bands that seemed to deal in sheer anarchy. Even the bands' names sounded dangerous: Teen-Age Jesus and the Jerks, Beirut Slump, Eight-Eyed Spy.

title: DANCERS: THE AGONY AND THE ECSTASY
description: A BLOODIED TOE INSIDE HER FIRST PAIR OF toe shoes is a welcome symbol of initiation for a young ballerina, just as it is considered a sign of good luck for a professional. It is the initial stage in the development of the corns and calluses that are a prerequisite for a career in toe shoes. Herein lies one of the many choices dancers must make through the years about whether or not this is a career they want. If the soreness of muscles and toes does not seem insignificant beside the rewards of dancing, the aspirant will not continue. The profession is not regulated as much by audition or the whim of directors as by this form of natural selection.

title: U.S. EXPECTING TO SEND LARGE CRUISERS TO GULF
description: Despite advice from naval commanders in the Persian Gulf that relatively small frigates are ideal for escorting merchant vessels, the Pentagon is likely to send larger, more sophisticated cruisers there, according to Government officials familiar with planning for the operation.

title: LAKERS TINKER WITH WINNING FORMULA
description: ''THERE is no such thing as perfection, not even with us or Boston,'' Pat Riley said one afternoon late last week while sitting and waiting in what may be the most meticulously organized office in the National Basketball Association.

title: Keep U. S. Flags Off Kuwaiti Tankers
description: Had Congress known in advance that the Administration planned to sell arms to Iran in exchange for American hostages in Lebanon, Congress would have stopped the disastrous scheme - to the enormous benefit of our foreign policy.

description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article April 19 about good buys in Australia incorrectly suggested that all boots sold at R. M. Williams were made of cowhide. The store does sell one boot that is made of kangaroo and is so labeled.

title: Sophisticated Sailer
description: The time has come, in the wink of a computer screen, to redefine the romance of sail. For centuries, sailing meant following unpredictable winds to little-known places. In his 1926 book, ''The Romance of Navigation,'' Master Mariner W. B. Whall relived an era ''when the seaman from stormy Europe could find fairylands, where soft breezes blew the year round, where the harsh teeth of winter were never felt, where strange races were found, with gold, spices and pearls.''

description: MISERY By Stephen King. 310 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Preserving the Best Of a Heritage The National Trust for Historic Preservation was chartered by Congress in 1949 as a nationwide, nonprofit educational organization that ''encourages Americans to participate in preserving the best of their heritage.'' Lyndhurst in Tarrytown is one of the 17 house museums it owns nationwide and one of nine it opens to the public with the help of private financing; an additional eight historic sites are administered by cooperating local nonprofit organizations and all celebrate National Preservation Week each second full week in

title: ECHOES OF LEE AND JACKSON
description: In Lexington, Va., on the trim campus of Washington and Lee University crowned with its classic white colonnade, students still go by the gentleman's code of honor. At the nearby Gothic barracks of Virginia Military Institute, cadets still bow to rigid regulations and cut an impeccable figure in the ritual dress parades.

NBC bought the screenplay rights for a miniseries based on a forthcoming book about the Marshall murder case. (Robert O. Marshall, a former insurance salesman, was sentenced to death in March 1986 after having been convicted of conspiring to murder his wife. In September 1984, she was found shot twice in the head in the family car at a Garden State Parkway picnic area.) According to a local newspaper, a vice president for the network's miniseries said:

description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 31 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jonathan B. Coffey, assisted by the Rev. James A. Schillinger, a Roman Catholic priest.

DINING OUT;
ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE DELAWARE
description: LEAD: THERE is a road that winds along the Pennsylvania side of the Delaware River. In lower Bucks County, it is marked as Route 32, but it changes to Route 611 when it reaches upper Bucks County.

description: When Michael B. Mehrtens flew to Montana last year to announce the opening of a new gold mine south of Helena, he was greeted by several grateful state officials, including Gov. Ted Schwinden.

title: MYTHS AND MEMORIES FROM THE SILENT DAYS
description: GLORIA SWANSON, BEING interviewed in the 1970's, recalls how more than 50 years earlier she insisted that the director Cecil B. De Mille let her enter a lion's cage for a scene in the silent movie ''Male and Female.'' Later at a preview, Swanson overheard a fan ask, after watching the star under the menacing paw of the animal: ''I wonder which one is stuffed.''

title: FIVE MILLENNIUMS OF BAUBLES
description: TWO PERIOD JEWELRY collections formed more than 50 years apart by two quite different men -Henry Walters, a turn-of-the-century Baltimore financier and railroad magnate, and Benjamin Zucker, a New York gem dealer -are being presented together here at the Walters Art Gallery in one of the largest and most comprehensive exhibitions of historical baubles and bangles seen in this country in recent years.

title: Q And A
description: Reduction in Service Question: I have an apartment in a building that was recently converted to a co-op but I elected to continue as a rent-controlled tenant. For as long as I have lived in the building - more than 30 years - garbage has been collected dailyfrom the stairwells on each floor. Recently, both tenants and shareholders were advised that the porters would no longer be picking up garbage and that occupants would be responsible for taking their own to the basement. I feel this represents a reduction in service. Am I entitled to a reduction in my rent to compensate for this lost service? . . . V. C., Mount Vernon, N.Y. Answer: Rent reductions for significant reductions in services may be ordered by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the agency that supervises rent-regulated units. Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the agency, said that, lacking details, he cannot tell if your case merits such a reduction. To apply for a rent reduction, complete a Reduction in Service Complaint form and return it to the division at 92-31 Unon Hall Street, Jamaica, Queens 11433. The forms are available at the district rent offices in each borough. ADDING A SKYLIGHT Question: I live on the top floor of a co-op apartment building that has an unused dumbwaiter shaft. I would like to install a skylight where the shaft's rooftop lid now exists. How must I build the skylight and the floor over the shaft's hole to comply with the building code regulations? M. M., Manhattan Answer: According to Vahe Tiryakian, a spokesman for the city's Department of Buildings, you will need a construction permit before starting. To obtain the permit you must have a registered architect or certified engineer file plans with the Buildings Department.

title: Expletives Not Deleted
description: To the Editor:

title: 'I'VE NEVER SEEN A DAZZLING ROSE': THE BOSSY APPROACH TO GARDEN WRITING

There are more than 26 million in print - everything from ''The Flower Expert'' with a million copies to ''The Lawn Expert'' with 2,500,000 to ''The House Plant Expert'' with 7,449,000. Less than a year ago, a British survey of gardening book sales revealed that the top seven were by Mr. Hessayon.

description: Every spring when the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus comes through Baltimore, ''the Greatest Show on Earth'' brings the elephants down to the Lexington Market for lunch, celebrating what the 205-year-old landmark is all about - eating.

description: WHEN Howard H. Baker Jr. became the White House chief of staff in February, President Reagan's conservative supporters in Congress worried that someone with so well-known a penchant for compromise would dilute the Administration's ideological drive.

description: TELEPHONE calls and electricity would cost less under rate agreements reached with the state's two largest utilities that are expected to be ratified by regulators in sessions beginning this week.

title: Irish Pottery
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed ''Pottery From Ireland'' in the April 12 Travel section. Based on our experience, I would have also included the advice caveat emptor. I am still trying to get delivery of over $200 worth of items from a pottery in Kinsale we visited in June 1986. MAURICE L. KELLEY JR. Sewickley, Pa.
