description: SPRING on the East End always brings a game of restaurant roulette for diners.

title: EXOCET ATTACK IN GULF PROMPTS HARD LOOK AT FLEET STRATEGY
description: AFTERrrxh six years of strenuous military buildup, the Reagan Administration is within sight of its goal of a 600-ship Navy. More than 550 vessels are on hand, with the rest to be delivered in the next year or so. John F. Lehman Jr., who retired last month as Navy Secretary, summed up the maritime strategy used by the Administration to justify the expense in building such a fleet with the old slogan dispatching the Navy to ''go in harm's way.'' In a major war, the strategy calls for attacking Soviet bastions with carrier-based aircraft early; in peacetime, it calls for a naval presence ready to perform at a moment's notice in far-flung trouble spots.

title: 'DID YOU FIND A JOB YET?' DON'T ASK
description: THERE'S only one thing worse than not having a job. It's your son's not having one.

title: Discography Lament
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL
description: In much the same way as the top executives at Levi Strauss are reputed to wake in a cold sweat each morning wondering whether anyone is going to want their products anymore, booksellers must wonder whether the apparently insatiable demand for travel books will suddenly come to an end, leaving them with enough stock to build a chain of covers from Kansas to Katmandu. Unlikely. Travel is one of the principal activities of the human race. ''Where you're at is your habitat. Everywhere else you're a foreigner.'' So many travelers (many of them lunatics), so many reasons for traveling: commercial travelers selling Coca-Cola to the Chinese, Protestant Bibles to the Catholics and wondering why they end up getting fired or tottering up the back stairs of provincial stores with armfuls of large-size stock; travelers who were (and are) savants, prospectors, pilgrims, soldiers or people hounded from society for no longer nameless crimes, transported for life, or escaping their creditors, or winter in Boston; travelers without return tickets, such as the Israelites and those who were later to populate what would become the United States, or just travelers, traveling for the sake of it.

title: OLD-FASHIONED MOVIEGOING
description: LEAD: IT'S Tuesday night at the neighborhood movie house, and Irene Terrazano, who is in her 70's, sits inside a sidewalk ticket booth. She slides a ticket beneath a cracked pane of glass to a patron giving her a $1 bill.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Truro, Mass.: Builders Barred On Cape Bluff
description: LEAD: A 22-ACRE property with spectacular views of Cape Cod Bay and Provincetown Harbor has been preserved by a combination of innovative financing and the efforts of local residents, state and county officials and two conservation organizations.

title: Holly M. Horning Marries Scott Cameron in Virginia
description: At the Mount Vernon Unitarian Church in Alexandria, Va., yesterday Holly M. Horning and Scott J. Cameron were married by the Rev. Kenneth Hurto. The bride, a daughter of Virginia Horning of Oakton, Va., graduated from Smith College. The bridegroom is the son of John D. Cameron of New York, who retired as New York public affairs manager for the Ford Motor Company, and Nina Cameron Gewald, also of New York, a special counsel for the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: A PRISONER OF THE THOUGHT POLICE
description: LIFE AND DEATH IN SHANGHAI By Nien Cheng. 547 pp. New York: Grove Press. $19.95.

title: Japan Spends to Ease U.S. Deficit
description: Japan promised last week to divert $43 billion to stimulate its domestic economy and pare runaway trade surpluses with the United States. For skeptics who recalled unfulfilled promises of yesteryear, Kunio Miyamoto, a senior Japanese economic official, offered assurances.

title: FRESH AIR FUND: A PLACE IN THE SUN
description: WHENEVER 13-year-old Mario Clayton of Brooklyn visits Douglas and Helen Opalski and their family in the Middlesex County community of Plainsboro, he learns something new.

title: AS THE WEDTECH CASE UNFOLDS, THE FOCUS SHIFTS TO WASHINGTON
description: In September 1985, when Ursula Meese, the wife of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, was honored at a Washington charity ball, the executives of the Wedtech Corporation, a little-known South Bronx military contractor, bought a $1,500 table.

title: GUIDING A LOW-PROFILE AGENCY THROUGH A HIGH-TECH STORM
description: WHILE its archives are filled with the names of visionary inventors like Edison and Bell, the United States Patent and Trademark Office is itself a paper-shuffling bureaucracy - one that ought to be the safest place imaginable for a Government functionary.

title: Katherine M. Galicich Weds William C. Jaris
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York yesterday, Katherine Marie Galicich, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Galicich of Alpine, N.J., was married to William Charles Jaris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Jaris of Manhattan. The Rev. Richard J. Dillon performed the ceremony.

title: EDUCATED ILLEGAL ALIENS BLOCKED FROM AMNESTY
description: The way the new immigration law is interpreted by its enforcers is making it hard for foreign students who are illegal aliens to gain amnesty. A result, according to lawyers who specialize in immigration cases, is that many of the best-educated aliens stand a poor chance of staying in this country.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THROWAWAY PRODUCTS;
KEEP THE PICTURE, BUT TOSS THE CAMERA
description: LEAD: ''IN the past the camera was one of our most important icons, as significant as the picture itself. Now it's convenience and the picture that counts.''

title: Princeton to Receive Money For Computer Science Unit
description: Princeton University has received a $5 million pledge for the construction of a new computer science building, the school has announced. The pledge came from an alumnus who was not identified.

title: COMPUTERS CAN BE CHALLENGING OPPONENTS
description: ONE of four players registered by the United States Chess Federation refuses to play against a computer when they are paired in a tournament.

title: Broadcast TV
description: June 8, 1944, was the longest on Normandy Beach for the Allied Army invasion and the Nazi holdout, and for the waiting world. The stirring movie version of this historic event tops a worthy batch of war-theme offerings on cable this week.

title: IN DANBURY, SHOW HOUSE FOR A CAUSE
description: HANDS on hips, Tim Ward thoughtfully surveyed the Danbury mansion's half-papered foyer. Painters, movers and frenetic interior designers darted about. Wrapping paper crackled in the drawing room off the foyer, followed by the whoosh of plastic as an antique French sofa, newly reupholstered in a turquoise-and-off-white 18th-century documentary toile de Jouy, was carefully unwrapped by Carole Winer, a designer and the owner of Country Loft Antiques in Woodbury.

title: Talking: Home Loans; Coping With Rate Volatility
description: WITH interest rates rising, many home buyers are concerned that by the time they close on the mortgage loans they have applied for, the rates may be so steep that they will no longer qualify.

title:
ART;
'WILDERNESS' AT THE NEUBERGER
description: LEAD: BOTH within and without, the video installation ''Wilderness'' by Mary Lucier at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, examines the notion of the past coming up against the present. Ms. Lucier was canny in choosing the American wilderness as her subject, because every viewer innately feels he has a share in this bounty.

title: Short Is Chic
description: In the grand scheme of things, skirt lengths are not important (''Why Short Is Chic,'' by Carrie Donovan, Fashion View, April 26). Short may be chic for those women who have nothing better to do than lunch at Le Cirque. (Although I, for one, find scrawny middle-aged women in mid-thigh creations pitiful.) However, in the business world, the length of a woman's skirt is important.

title: Stock Tips
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial Court Merger 'Long Overdue'
description: There was something stale and deceptive in ''Bar Group Opposes Court Amendment'' [ May 17 ] . What was stale was the Suffolk County Bar Association's announcement of its opposition to the merger of our state's trial courts; that position was announced two months ago (see New York Law Journal, March 18). It was deceptive to imply that because the amendment failed to create a fifth intermediate appellate court, it ignored the need for an appropriate adjustment in the appellate structure.

title: The Iowa Caucuses Have No Clothes
description: ''Get thee to Iowa,'' political soothsayers advised Democratic candidates in the aftermath of the funny thing that happened to Gary Hart on his way to the White House. I have a better suggestion: Stay away.

title: Sunday Observer; Addicted to Nicaragua
description: DEAR DIARY: I ONLY thought of Nicaragua 63 times today. That's pretty good, considering that just last week I was thinking of Nicaragua 100 times a day. Doc was right about my Nicaragua habit. ''If Nicaragua was a cigarette,'' he said, ''you'd have a five-pack-a-day habit.''

title: RECORD ESCAPES JOE NIEKRO AS YANKS FALL TO ATHLEITCS
description: Joe and Phil Niekro have to stop meeting like this.

title: Man Seized in Pennsylvania After Lethal Shooting Spree
description: An armed man was arrested today after a nine-hour manhunt that followed a shooting rampage here in which a firefighter was killed and two other men were critically wounded.

title: Koch, Trump Slug It Out
description: In a collapse of negotiations heard round the city, Mayor Koch last week told Donald J. Trump he could not have the tax and zoning concessions he wanted for his proposed Television City on the Upper West Side - not even in return for a share of the profits.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: PHILADELPHIA
description: In this summer of the Constitution's bicentennial, Independence Hall may become the single most prominent tourist attraction in the country. Before the year is out, countless imaginations will soar at the sight and feel of the crowded but airy 18th-century room, with its simple furnishings and green baize tablecloths and austere candlesticks and quill pens, where, 200 years ago this very day, the Constitution's framers were literally sweating out the nation's basic charter.

title: Marxist Theory?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'OUR OCCUPIERS HAVE BEEN MANY BUT THEY ALL LEFT'
description: ONE day last month, a petrol bomb was thrown through the window of a car carrying Jewish settlers near Qalqilya village on the Israeli-occupied West Bank, killing a woman and injuring her husband and four young children. After the attack, there was a chorus of indignation from within Israeli society that produced two demands: that more Jewish settlers be moved into the West Bank, and that the orange trees that line some of the roads be cut down, to make the roads more secure for Jewish settlers. How intriguing, I thought to myself, and how simple: Just cut down all the trees, and there won't be any place for a Palestinian to hide, and to use as a shelter from which to hurl petrol bombs at Israelis who have taken his land.

title: POP: LIZA MINNELLI OPENS 3-WEEK CARNEGIE DATE
description: MIDWAY in Thursday's opening-night performance of her three-week Carnegie Hall engagement, Liza Minnelli struck an uncharacteristically formal pose. Arriving onstage in a sumptuous burgundy-colored gown by Halston, the singer positioned herself between a string quartet and a harpist. Ignoring the 47-piece orchestra behind her, she proceeded to offer an amusing ''highbrow'' chamber interpretation of the Al Jolson favorite, ''Toot Toot Tootsie.''

title: ROCKIN' CHAIR COUNTRY
description: A drive through the mountain town of Hendersonville, N.C., can be deceiving. In some wooded neighborhoods, amid two-story antebellum homes and leveled yards, it's hard to believe you're close to the summits of the southern Appalachian mountains. Not a peak breaks the soft, hilly landscape to remind you. Outside town the countryside can flatten even more, the roads stretching through low-lying fields and spanning basins full of what looks like a low-country marsh. It is almost a surprise when the Blue Ridge Mountains emerge. They are old, weathered mountains, hairy with trees. Sometimes, over a hill, they jump up, almost on top of you. Other times, around a bend, the leathery ridges rise at a greater distance, though still suddenly. On a first visit to Hendersonville the effect can be startling; it is always beautiful.

title: PRIMERICA SHARPENS ITS FINANCIAL FOCUS
description: Primerica is to buy Smith Barney for $750 million, making a services business the mainstay of the company that used to be American Can and had been concentrated in industry. Gerald Tsai Jr., Primerica's chief executive, was a top Wall Street executive for many years, thus returns to the investment business. The move also gives Smith Barney new capital to bolster itself in an increasingly competitive market. Analysts said the move made sense for both companies, although some questioned whether the move was opportune now, when many predict a downturn in the securities industry. But Mr. Tsai says he can improve what he called ''a second-tier'' company. * * *

title: Crash of a Movie Helicopter Kills Four in the Philippines
description: A Philippine Air Force helicopter on loan to an American movie crew crashed into Manila Bay today, killing four Filipinos and injuring five Filipinos and a West German.

title: MAINE TOWN, TOPPLED BY TAX LOAD, HANDS OVER BURDEN BUT NOT IDENTIFY
description: This tiny settlement was carved from the north Maine woods more than 150 years ago by men who would make a living from the land, first from the potato fields and then from the woods. It is a place where people feel a sense of the past.

title: A Physician Wed To Floriane Wu
description: Floriane Chiady Wu, a third-year medical student at the State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn, and Dr. Paul Tornetta 3d, who received an M.D. degree this month from the center, were married yesterday at the Post Chapel of the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Sluberski, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Art
description: The sculpture of Tom Bills has the formal simplicity and referential richness that has defined some of the best American sculpture of the last 25 years. Almost all the steel and lead pieces in his show at the Anne Plumb Gallery (81 Greene Street, through Saturday) are two to three feet tall. All are frontal and symmetrical. All avoid curved lines. All are abstract, but with unexpected architectural and figurative associations. All seem planted where they are, yet in the process of trying to stretch and sing.

title: Mid-Atlantic Wild Food, Sea Cruises
description: The North Carolina Maritime Museum in Beaufort is offering weeklong courses for school-age children this summer. Families vacationing in the area can send their children to the museum for three hours a day for the programs, ranging from fishing trips to stalking wild foods to underwater biology classes. A new program this year teaches high school students how to set up and stock a saltwater aquarium. The courses are $20, $15 for children in first and second grades.

title: HOUSING GROUPS ATTACK ADS USING ONLY WHITES
description: The dominant use of white models in real-estate advertisments is increasingly coming under attack by open-housing groups and public-interest lawyers in New York and elsewhere.

title: AT AGE 20, SGT. PEPPER MARCHES ON
description: TOMORROW, IT BEGINS. THE RELEASE OF the Beatles' ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' as a compact disk (Capitol CDP 7 46442 2), exactly 20 years after the album appeared, will usher in the anniversary of the ''Summer of Love,'' when the hippie spirit seized Western culture. There'll be reminiscences, chin-pulling and milestone-mongering as the calendar turns for such 1967 events as the Monterey Pop Festival and the founding of Rolling Stone magazine. The thunder of pronunciamentos - ''Sgt. Pepper's'' new liner notes call it ''nothing less than the most important and revealing compact disk release there can ever be'' - threatens to drown out the winsome pleasures of ''Sgt. Pepper'' itself.

title: Mathilda M. Cox Weds Executive
description: The marriage of Mathilda Margaret Cox, a daughter of Michael Charles Cox of Naul, County Dublin, Ireland, and the late Ellen T. Cox, to Christopher Reutershan, a son of Nanci Reutershan of East Hampton, L.I., and the late Robert Gordon Reutershan, took place yesterday in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Sean Quigley, assisted by the Rev. Edward J. Dougherty, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Princeton Roman Catholic Chapel.

title: Oil's Hidden Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: SITCOMS SEEN AS HOMILIES
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY LIFE FOR ERRANT YOUNGSTERS
description: LEAD: SOME have been physically or sexually abused; others have parents who abuse drugs or alcohol or have psychiatric problems. For many, conflict at home and their own inner turmoil have simply boiled over.

title: SOVIET DEFENDERS STRESS LOW FLIGHT
description: The Soviet air defense system, which failed to intercept the single-engine Cessna that flew from Helsinki to Red Square on Thursday, is enormously extensive, with forests of missiles, thousands of warplanes and more than 1,500,000 men and women either deployed or on call.

title: NEW HEADS AT 9 AGENCIES FIRM UP PLANS
description: LEAD: THE first thing Leslie Carothers plans to do as State Environmental Protection Commissioner is attend the annual department shad bake Friday.

title: Miss Eckardt Wed To George Ledes
description: Allison Meder Eckardt, a daughter of Mrs. Harold J. Eckardt of Somers, N.Y., and the late Mr. Eckardt, was married yesterday to George Macgill Ledes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John George Ledes of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Stephen M. Bolle performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Katonah.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: Cab Calloway and His Orchestra, 1935-1950 With Jonah Jones, Shad Collins, Milt Hinton. Jazz Classics, P.O. Box 86, Rahway, N.J. 07065. 30 minutes. $19.95.

title: POLO PICNIC
description: MANY TRADITIONAL AMERICAN pastimes are excuses to eat outdoors. Open-air concerts mean raiding the gourmet takeout shop. Fireworks on the beach require grilled hamburgers. And there are even those avid baseball fans who admit, when pressed, that they go to the ballpark as much for the hot dogs and beer as for the game.

title: RACING TO CATCH UP WITH THE PRESENT
description: A COMPUTER breakdown at the state's Division of Motor Vehicles some 20 months ago crippled its operations, which, in turn, caused serious inconvenience for thousands of New Jersey motorists.

title: FERNANDEZ SPARKS METS
description: With their pitching in tatters, the Mets got exactly what they needed tonight: a big performance.

title: ATHLETE, 18, EXCELS IN ALL BUT FAME
description: WHO is the best athlete in Connecticut? Is it Gary Cobb of Stamford and the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League? Or could it be Bud Schultz, the tennis professional from Meriden, or Ken Green, the touring golf pro from Danbury? Or perhaps it is Michael Adams of Hartford, John Bagley or Wes Matthews of Bridgeport, Harold Pressley of Montville or Mark Gminski of Monroe, all of whom play in the National Basketball Association.

title: Rocket Launching in July
description: An Atlas Centaur rocket and Navy communications satellite identical with those that were destroyed in March after being struck by lightning will be launched on July 24, the National Aeonautics and Space Administraton announced Friday. On March 26, technicians had to destroy a rocket carrying a satellite when it veered off course.

title: London
description: To the Editor: My wife and I (ages 67 and 63) would like to comment on ''London on a Pedestal'' (Travel, April 19). The lowest price accommodation mentioned - even those without bath - were well over a $100 a night.

title: THE ROVER BOYS AT SEA
description: RACING THROUGH PARADISE A Pacific Passage. By William F. Buckley Jr. Photographs by Christopher Little. 344 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: Sailor Is Challenging Coast Guard Over Boardings
description: A Great Lakes sailor is challenging the United States Coast Guard's right to board vessels without warrants or the suspicion of illegal activity on board.

title: Russell Means Runs for President as Libertarian
description: Russell Means, who once led an American Indian group in armed rebellion at Wounded Knee, S.D., is now campaigning for the Libertarian Party's Presidential nomination.

title: A Guide To Health Insurance
description: Morton Hunt's useful article ''A Common-Sense Guide to Health Insurance'' (May 3) needs to be considered in this larger context: Why does the world's wealthiest nation indulge in a health system so chaotic, expensive and inefficient that such guides are necessary? Moreover, nearly one in four Americans has either no insurance or such poor coverage that a major illness may bankrupt them.

title: Meg Marion Weds John Lobkowicz
description: Margaret Wood Marion, a daughter of Mrs. Haig Costikyan of Rye, N.Y., and the late B.Pope Marion, was married yesterday to John Brooks Lobkowicz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin M. George Lobkowicz of Dover, Mass. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the ceremony at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye.

title: NEW YORK CLUB SEEKING IDENTITY WITHOUT THE CUP
description: The New York Yacht Club is searching for a new identity. Now that its hopes are dashed for restoring the club's 132-year domination of the America's Cup, members fear that the yacht club may turn into little more than a city luncheon club.

title: MUSIC: HANDEL'S 'SAUL,' BY THE DESSOFF CHOIRS
description: HANDEL'S oratorio ''Saul'' contains some of the composer's most vivid writing, set to a theatrical libretto by Charles Jennens. Characters are sharply, realistically drawn. Handel added to his orchestra trombones, organ and carillon to produce sounds that match the work's subject in color and breadth.

title: GROUP FOR CHILDREN AIMS TO BREAK CYCLE OF ABUSE
description: While much attention has been paid to the problems of battered women who have taken refuge in shelters across Massachusetts, about two-thirds of the residents of those shelters are children. For them, the services are few. Of the 30 shelters in the state, which are supported by state and Federal funds, only about 10 have even one staff member expressly for children, according to Gayle A. Marino of the Massachusetts Coalition of Battered Women's Service Groups. Such child advocates typically attend to the children's needs, conduct individual therapy involving games and playing, field hot line calls for help and assist mothers in finding other services.

title: Catherine Tulis Marries
description: At the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., Catherine W. Tulis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Mott Walbridge of Short Hills and Stowe, Vt., was married yesterday to Chandler F. Stimmel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Stimmel of Slingerlands, N.Y. The Rev. Kenyon Wildrick performed the ceremony. The bride is a graduate of Colgate University. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Stimmel, an investment officer for the Glens Falls (N.Y.) National Bank and Trust Company, graduated from Hamilton College.

title: PUTTING HUMAN RIGHTS INTO TRADE POLICY
description: TRAPPED by locked doors and barred windows, 19 persons died in a fire that swept a small factory in a Bangkok suburb one night last year. The victims, part of a work force of 30 producing leather goods, had bedded down for the night on three floors of their factory. Their normal work day was from 8 A.M. to 11 P.M. On that fatal night they had worked till 1 A.M.

title: Film Tip
description: To the Editor: As a photojournalist, I travel a great deal and always have my camera and films checked at airport security gates. To save time and to avoid possible damage by radiation, I carry opened and unopened film in a clear plastic food storage bag and I ask the guard to hand the film bag and camera over to the other side. No one has ever refused anywhere. This saves time and worry. PHYLLIS H. WOLLMAN New York

title: Humor Paired With Sensitivity
description: I have always enjoyed reading The Times on Sunday, and especially look forward to reading the Long Island Weekly section now because of Barbara Klaus's articles. Her humor and sensitivity to family issues and feelings is both exciting and moving.

title: PATIENTS WHO CHEAT THEIR DOCTORS
description: ''PATIENTS are adversaries today,'' said one of the elder practicing physicians at the hospital. ''Take those senior citizens who were lobbying the Capitol in Hartford trying to convince the legislature to compel physicians to accept the Medicare assignment. As they picketed, some were chanting, 'Doctors are crooks. They steal from old people.' ''

title: NEW YORK MOVES TO CUT SHARPLY INTERNS' LONG AND GRUELING HOURS
description: The long, often grueling hours of interns and residents trained in New York hospitals, which health officials and a grand jury said have resulted in patients' deaths, would be drastically reduced under proposed new state hospital regulations.

title: For St. Kitts-Nevis, It Pays to Be Independent
description: Nearly four years after severing its colonial ties with Britain, the little two-island Caribbean nation of St. Kitts-Nevis has discovered that independence is good business.

title: Electric Boat Is Fined $5,850 Over Safety Rule Violations
description: The Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation has been fined $5,850 after Federal inspectors reported they had found nearly 200 violations of safety rules at a plant that makes hulls for Trident submarines.

title: Toscanini's Achievement
description: To the Editor:

title: Teen-Ager's Flight To Kremlin Wall Jolts Politburo
description: To the amazement of all and the consternation of Soviet authorities, a 19-year-old amateur pilot from West Germany flew a tiny single-engine plane across more than 400 miles of heavily guarded Soviet territory last week and landed next to the Kremlin wall at the foot of Red Square.

title: SO LONG CARS, HELLO PEOPLE
description: BUD CLARK, the tavern owner who became Mayor of this Oregon city in 1984, pedals his bicycle to City Hall most days, but he seldom draws so much as a second glance from pasers-by. That is because Portland has restricted cars and turned its downtown over toe pedestrians. The result of that and several other zoning decisions has been a dramatic revitalization.

title: PIPELINE SHIFT: LOGIC OF LITCHFIELD?
description: A BIG new customer was the reason for shifting part of the preferred route of a proposed natural-gas pipeline that is to go through upstate New York and Connecticut to Long Island, according to the consortium behind the proposal. Some of the pipeline's opponents say the reason for the shift was the wealth and influence of the pipeline's enemies in Litchfield County.

title: CRIME
description: If you're one of those who respond to the Byzantine kind of espionage story, A CONSPIRACY OF ANGELS by Frank Ross (Atheneum, $18.95) is made for you. It is one of those wheels-within-wheels clockwork pieces of work. It has a lot of action but absolutely no hysterics or heroics. It also happens to be exceedingly well written, full of sharply defined, believable characterizations and a kind of 1960's Weltschmerz because of the central character.

title: Mme. Yourcenar Approves
description: To the Editor:

title:
SUMMER READING: PAPERBACKS;
A Noteworthy Collection
description: LEAD: This selection of paperbacks is from the New & Noteworthy column since the 1986 Christmas issue. THE HOUSE IN PARIS, by Elizabeth Bowen. (Penguin, $6.95.) A forbidden love affair has long-lasting consequences in this mesmerizing novel. THE TRIUMPH OF POLITICS: The Inside Story of the Reagan Revolution, by David A.

title: Next Week; Do You Like All the Home Runs This Year?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: SRI LANKA PRESSES BATTLE AGAINST TAMILS
description: Sri Lankan armed forces pressed a major offensive against Tamil insurgent strongholds in the north today, amid reports that hundreds of people had died in fighting and bombardment in the last five days.

title: MURDER HITS HOME
description: DURING THE YEARS when I lived many miles from my hometown of Highland Park, N.J., I generally visited once around Thanksgiving and once during the summer, when the most wonderful listlessness settled over the place.

title: SEOUL APOLOGIZES FOR STUDENT'S KILLING BUT WARNS PROTESTERS
description: Prime Minister Lee Han Key apologized to the nation today for the police torture killing of a dissident student in January, but he warned opposition groups that the Government would not tolerate any attempt to embarrass it further.

title: Original Idea?
description: To the Editor:

title: Montie Mills Wed To Mark S. Perry
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Montie Marion Mills, a daughter of Frieda Smith Odom of Myrtle Beach, S.C., and the late Capt. Robert S. Mills, U.S.A., of Marion, S.C., was married to Mark Sherman Perry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Perry of Avon, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Ross Wright performed the ceremony.

title: CLEARING THE AIR ALOFT OR ABED
description: The air is filled with fret about ordinances on smoking in public places and court appeals on such rules.

title: Jefferson Bust Brings $2.86 Million, a Record
description: Jean Antoine Houdon's ''Painted Plaster Bust of Thomas Jefferson,'' the oldest surviving version of the most famous portrait bust of the statesman, was sold yesterday at Christie's for $2.86 million, an auction record for pre-20th-century sculpture and the highest price ever paid for a work by the artist. The buyer was not identified. The under bidder was Lawrence A. Fleischman of Kennedy Gallery, who was bidding for the National Gallery of Art and for Monticello, Jefferson's home in Virginia.

title: EXPECTATIONS LOW FOR VENICE PARLEY By GERALD M. BOYD
description: President Reagan will be heading to the economic summit meeting in Venice next week amid expectations that have been lowered by his own domestic difficulties and by economic and political uncertainties in the six other industrialized democracies that will take part, Administration officials say.

title: MONROE FAMILY ENJOY FRESH AIR FUND VISITS
description: ONE of the first advertisements Janet Haringa said she saw for the Fresh Air Fund said the children who leave the city for the country each summer ''come out little men and women and go back children.''

title: TRADING IDEAS: PROGRAM PROMOTES SELF-SUFFICIENCY
description: FOR decades, many third-world countries have been suspicious of Western offers to help curb their exploding populations. Family-planning programs sponsored by government agencies and private foundations have often been seen less as altruistic enterprises than as attempts by the industrial nations to preserve their economic dominance by controlling the growth of emerging black countries. Other critics have objected that family planning is an ineffective antidote to their economic ills.

title: Koch Offers New Tax Breaks as Factory Jobs Fall
description: Mayor Koch announced last week that in an effort to attract employers to northern Manhattan and New York's other boroughs, the city would offer new tax breaks aimed at providing businesses with all the comforts of New Jersey.

title: Deborah A. Rice Becomes Bride Of R. C. Noble
description: Deborah Ann Rice, a research associate in Islamic and Arabic commercial law in London, and R.Christopher Noble, a vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company there, were married yesterday in Melrose, Mass. Msgr. Russell R. Novello performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Incarnation.

title: SITCOMS SEEN AS HOMILIES
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTLE OVER PTL ESCALATES
description: BECAUSE of the loss of his PTL ministry, the Rev. Jim Bakker feels he should receive severance pay. According to the organization's new leader, the Rev. Jerry Falwell, the Bakkers have asked for lifetime salaries of $300,000 a year for the deposed television evangelist and $100,000 for his wife, Tammy Faye. Last year, the Bakkers received about five times that much, not counting bonuses and other benefits. In addition, Mr. Falwell said last week, the Bakkers want hospitalization insurance, rights to their books and records, lawyers' fees and telephone service, a maid and a secretary for a year. They also asked to keep the lakefront home in South Carolina that was provided by PTL.

title: ACTING CLASS, DAY ONE, WITH A MASTER TEACHER
description: LEAD: SANFORD MEISNER, A MEMBER of the Group Theater in the 1930's, has taught acting for many years in New York and is considered one of the finest in his profession. What follows is a narrative description of the first day of a first course in acting, excerpted from ''Sanford Meisner on Acting,'' by Sanford Meisner and Dennis Longwell, which will be published by Vintage/Random House in

title: A GUIDE TO SUMMER FESTIVALS OF DANCE
description: The following is a selective list of summer dance festivals and events. It is national in scope but concentrates on the Northeast. New York City

title: THE HAVES - AND HAVE NOTS - IN PUBLIC RELATIONS
description: ITEM: Jack O'Dwyer's Newsletter, the bible of the public relations profession, lists huge increases in billings at P.R. agencies this year.

title: TYSON RETAINS TITLE ON KNOCKOUT IN SIXTH
description: Mike Tyson retained his World Boxing Council-World Boxing Association heavyweight title tonight, knocking out Pinklon Thomas at 2 minutes of the sixth round of their scheduled 12-round fight in the Las Vegas Hilton Outdoor Stadium.

title: Lucrative Contracts
description: THE Arizona Board of Regents has offered lucrative multiyear contracts to several coaches at the University of Arizona and Arizona State. John Cooper, the Arizona State football coach, was the big winner with an offer of a five-year pact worth $96,600 a year, while the school's basketball coach, Steve Patterson, was offered $79,000 a year for three years. At the University of Arizona, the basketball coach, Lute Olson, was offered a five-year deal at $89,500; the football coach, Dick Tomey, got a four-year pact worth $85,000 a year, and Jerry Kindall, the baseball coach, was offered $55,000 a year for five years.

title: Canada Protests Prosecution Move In Deaver Trial
description: A special prosecutor's attempt to serve subpoenas in the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver, the former Reagan aide who left the White House to start a multimillion dollar lobbying business, stirred up a diplomatic tempest last week.

title: IN STAMFORD, STYLE WITH AUTHORITY
description: RESTAURANT openings in Stamford have come so fast and furiously in the last three years, it's enough to make a resident blase.

title: A Vote to Delay Alien Sanctions
description: Beginning tomorrow, employers who hire illegal aliens are subject to fines and possibly even imprisonment. That's what it says on paper anyway.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Hartford Homesteaders Building Equity
description: ANNIE MATHIS, a machine operator for United Technologies, has become a woman of property. A 20-year resident of Hartford and a grandmother, she was selected from among three dozen applicants to purchase for $1 an 80-year-old house being restored on Bellevue Street by the Hartford Urban Homesteading program.

title: Jacqueline Coyle Wed to John Keeshan
description: Jacqueline Johnson Coyle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Coyle of Greenwich, Conn., and John Byrnes Keeshan, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John W. Keeshan of Greenwich, were married yesterday at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Josephine Noble, a Congregational minister and a cousin of the bride. Marcia Coyle was her sister's maid of honor, and Henry McCreery Keeshan was his brother's best man.

title:
GARDENING;
A NEW CHAPTER ON INFORMATION FOR PERENNIALS
description: LEAD: THE perennial borders of England are the envy, but often the despair of American gardeners. Many English hybrids do not perform well because the plants cannot tolerate our hot, muggy summers or bitter winters. Sorting successes from failures has always been an expensive, discouraging process.

title: COMING AND GOING: 2 SOVIET MILITARY LEADERS
description: The two men who figured in the shakeup at the top of the Soviet Defense Ministry yesterday were professional soldiers who had moved steadily through the ranks of the military to attain the post of Defense Minister.

title: GRAF LIFTS STREAK TO 36; BECKER GAINS
description: PARIS, May 30 (AP) - Steffi Graf of West Germany, seeded No. 2, survived a scare from Helen Kelesi of Canada and stretched her winning streak to 36 matches to move into the quarterfinals of the French Open with a 7-6, 6-2 victory today.

title:
ANTIQUES;
HOMAGE TO VICTORIAN GARDENERS
description: LEAD: VICTORIANS apparently made good use of their leisure time, from sewing chores that kept a family clothed and warm to planting vegetables that kept it fed.

title: NEW BEDFORD TOOL PLANT IN NEW BATTLE OVER JOBS
description: The greasy antique machines that were used until two months ago to make drills at a huge brick factory here are now the subject of an intense legal battle, along with the rest of the factory's contents.

title: Nancy E. Cohen, Lawyer, Marries Mitchell A. Golub
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., last evening, Nancy E. Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Cohen of Woodmere, L.I., was married to Mitchell A. Golub, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Golub of Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Joel Zion, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony.

title: MAJOR SYMPOTHY ORCHESTRAS ARE NARROWING THEIR FOCUS
description: JUST OVER A WEEK AGO, THE New York Philharmonic gave the last in the series of subscription concerts featuring works by Giovanni Gabrieli and William Byrd. To many listeners, they probably seemed the least significant events on a program that included Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra'' and the Schumann Violin Concerto, yet they were, in one sense, the most notable items on the menu: these were among the very few pieces from the Baroque or earlier played this past season by one of the country's major symphony orchestras.

title: Miss Hicks Weds Stephen Quazzo
description: Deborah Tyler Hicks, an associate in corporate finance at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, and Stephen Renato Quazzo, an associate in the investment banking division of Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Barnum C. McCarty performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: KENNEDY NOTES FROM '60 CAMPAIGN TO BE SOLD
description: A collection of notes scrawled by John F. Kennedy when his voice gave out in the 1960 Presidential campaign is being offered for sale by a handwriting expert on behalf of a former Kennedy assistant who had salvaged them from wastebaskets.

title: Dr. Maria DeVita Weds
description: Dr. Maria Virginia DeVita, a resident in internal medicine at Lenox Hill Hospital, was married yesterday to Keith Patrick Meyers, assistant director of athletics at Seton Hall University. The Rev. John Camus performed the ceremony at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in New York. The bride is the daughter of Dr. Marie N. DeVita, a family physician in Paramus, N.J., and Dr. Michael R. DeVita, a gynecologist in Westwood, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Patricia Meyers of Orlando, Fla., and the late Charles R. Meyers Jr.

title: INSIDE
description: The Wedtech Drama's Cast The Wedtech scandal has touched a host of people, from Bronx businessmen to two men with links to the White House. An article with a guide to the role of 21 key figures, page 20.

title: Mutual Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: SHELTER FOR WOMEN TO APPEAL RULING
description: LEAD: THE directors of a shelter for battered women in Pleasantville said last week that they were considering appealing a recent court decision that blocked a proposed expansion of the facility.

title: MARTIN BEATS HEAT, 8,355 OTHERS
description: The heat and humidity might have been unbearable for the average New Yorker yesterday, but it didn't seem to discourage the 8,356 women who participated in the 16th L'eggs Mini Marathon in Central Park.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bernardsville $229,900 2 Ambar Place 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 76-year-old English cottage; stone fireplace, full basement, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $2,370. Franklin Township $196,500 13 Domino Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; patio, central A/C, 2-car attached garage; taxes $2,451. title: COUNTY PREPARES FOR 911 SYSTEM
description: THE 911 emergency telephone system long used by New York City residents is coming to Westchester, according to county leaders, and in an improved mode that will let police and civilian dispatchers identify the calling number and address immediately.

title: PILLS - AND PEAS - AT THE PHARMACY
description: RESES PHARMACY stands on a tree-shaded block of clapboard houses down from the Wawa Food Market in the center of Pleasantville, a drowsy town of about 8,000 on the outskirts of Atlantic City. The store maintains a dim, cool atmosphere, perfumed with a slight medicinal scent. When you walk in, you're beset by a great many things: catnip, Spanish olives, toothpaste, corn remedies, beach chairs, curling irons, alcohol prep swabs and garden hoses, not to mention the obligatory racks of greeting cards. If you have a prescription, you thread your way to the back counter.

title: BALLET: 'BRAHMS/HANDEL' AND 'WALPURGISNACHT'
description: TWO of the oddest works in the New York City Ballet returned to the repertory Friday night at the State Theater.

title: HOW WILL FANS REACT TO GOODEN'S RETURN?
description: Mets fans will doubtless bestow a rousing hero's welcome to Dwight Gooden upon his return to the baseball diamond. And that will be a sad development. Not the rousing part, mind you, the hero part.

title: A NO-NONSENSE 'LIVING TREASURE'
description: LEAD: CROUCHING in the attic of her home in this Hunterdon County community, Toshiko Takaezu sorts through a clutch of clay dumplings and gives me one that is glazed a deep blue.
